title: Rudeness Takes a Ride
description: A lot of people have been getting a good laugh out of the notion of courtesy cards for cops. Me, I'm thinking of trying it myself -- in my cab.

title: Forum on Youth Violence Is Set
description: Pleading with parents and students to open a discussion about the causes of youthful rage, President Clinton said today that he would convene a White House meeting on youth violence.

title: SUIZA FOODS SET TO SELL 57% OF PACKAGING UNIT
description: Moving to shed debt, the Suiza Foods Corporation agreed yesterday to sell 57 percent of its domestic packaging operations to a joint venture led by Vestar Capital Partners for $367 million. It will also assume debt of $135 million. Vestar, an investment firm based in New York, will own 51 percent of Suiza's plastics operations, which will become part of a venture called the Consolidated Container Company. Consolidated Container is expected to have annual sales of more than $700 million. Vestar will contribute $61 million in cash to Consolidated Container. The sale will allow the Dallas-based Suiza to pay down some of its $900 million debt load and possibly acquire more small dairy concerns. shares of Suiza climbed $2 each yesterday, to $38.

title: Long-Distance Ties That Bind; Kosovar Albanians in U.S. Ready to Welcome Relatives
description: Sadik Shala is not a wealthy man. An American-in-the-making from Kosovo, he is gleaning English at the pizza shop where he works, and he shares a four-bedroom apartment in a low-rent neighborhood in the South Bronx with friends.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHIFF, JACK
description: SCHIFF-Jack. 89. Of New Rochelle, NY, died on April 30, 1999. He had been a managing editor for DC Comics, including Superman and Batman. Mr. Schiff dedicated his life to promoting peace, justice, and equality and was a social activist in his community. Mr. Schiff is predeceased by his son Paul, who died in 1996. He is survived by his devoted wife of 62 years, Mimi; loving daughter, Laurie (Schiff) Hahn; three grandchildren; and sister Rose Gerard of the Bronx. A memorial gathering will be held on Thursday, May 6, at 11 AM at George T. Davis Funeral Home, New Rochelle. All are invited to share their memories.

title: Bombs Pound Heart and Homes of Serbia's Capital
description: When NATO bombed residential areas of Belgrade for the first time early this morning, two errant missiles, meant for military office buildings, hit houses instead.

title: About New York; Out of View, Young Lives Under Assault
description: THE yearbook pictures from Littleton, Colo., have become familiar to everyone by now. A dozen smiling faces, full of promise and youthful optimism, forever frozen after two classmates opened fire, killing 12 students, a teacher and themselves. Though these young victims lived and died hundreds of miles away, the public has heard as much about them as if they lived next door.

title: Did Police Do Enough?
description: To the Editor:

title: Little Was Done On Complaints In Littleton File
description: The sheriff's department here acknowledged today that it had done little to follow up a complaint a neighbor made last year that one of the teen-age killers at Columbine High School last week ''talks often of making pipe bombs and using them to kill numerous people.''

title: A Defiant N.R.A. Gathers in Denver
description: Gathering here for their annual convention just a day after Littleton finished burying its slain children, officials of the National Rifle Association today rejected any suggestion that the gun lobby was responsible for the shooting rampage that left 15 people dead, and insisted that they would stand fast against any new gun control.

title: Stoic Piazza Can Afford To Show More Emotion
description: Mike Piazza scurried across the mostly empty clubhouse yesterday like a man who was late for an important flight. He stopped briefly to look at some mail, disappeared for a few seconds into the trainer's room and then returned to his locker and flipped through the mail again. If another Met had blinked twice, he might have missed Piazza.

title: Teodoro Garcia, 110; Fought Villa on the Government Side
description: Teodoro Garcia, a reluctant Mexican lieutenant who battled the rebel Pancho Villa in the Mexican Revolution and is believed to be the last soldier in the army of the dictator Porfirio Diaz, died last Saturday in a retirement home in Texas City, Tex. He was 110.

title: NATO Says New Bombing Is the Strongest Effort Yet
description: NATO tonight unleashed what officials described as the most aggressive bombing in the five-week air war, hitting Serbian tanks and armored vehicles in Kosovo and bridges in Serbia.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on April 19 about the appointment of a Washington bureau chief for Knight Ridder's news division misstated her given name. She is Kathleen Carroll, not Katherine.

title: Upholding Union Head's Ouster, Unit Cites $1 Million in Spending
description: Citing evidence of widespread misspending, a union judicial panel yesterday upheld the union's decision to oust Albert A. Diop, president of a 23,000-member local representing New York City clerical workers and to place his local into trusteeship.

title: Risk Takers' Safety Net
description: About two years ago, Matt Hazard and three of his buddies got together to form a new, hard-rock band in Minneapolis. At a loss for what to call themselves, they settled on Moral Hazard.

title: U.S. Investigating Big Wall St. Investment Firms
description: The Federal Government has started an investigation into the way some of Wall Street's largest investment firms set the fees they charge companies to sell their stock to the public in initial offerings.

title: Taking Chances to Help Students
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOHNSON, ESTHER UNDERWOOD
description: JOHNSON - Esther Underwood. Died at her home in Oldwick, New Jersey, at the age of 92 on Wednesday, April 28, 1999. She was married to the late J. Seward Johnson, Vice President of Johnson & Johnson. She was a philanthropic supporter of the NAACP Legal Defense Fund, Planned Parenthood and World Peace through World Law and various wildlife organizations. Esther Underwood Johnson was born in Belmont, Massachusetts, and lived every summer on Cape Cod in Chatham, where she supported the Massachusetts Audubon Society for forty years. The Esther U. Johnson Environmental Center in Wellfleet, Massachusetts, was established in her honor. Esther Underwood Johnson served on local and community groups of Hunterdon County, New Jersey, such as the PTA of Tewksbury Township and the Hunterdon Mental Health Association. She also served on the Far Hills Country Day School Board of Trustees and the Purnell School Board of Trustees. Esther Underwood Johnson is survived by her son, James Loring Johnson, and her daughter, Jennifer Johnson Duke, eight grandchildren and eight great-grandchildren. Services will be held May 1, 1999, at the New Germantown Cemetery, on Joliet Street in Oldwick, New Jersey, at 12 noon. Donations may be made to the New Jersey Chapter of The Nature Conservancy, 200 Pottersville Road, Chester, New Jersey 07930-2432.

title: The Pro Tour Goes Outdoors: In Sunny Bryant Park, Strikes and Stares
description: More than anything else, Mark Gerberich, the commissioner of the Professional Bowlers Association, has been hoping for sunshine at the tour's first outdoor championship today in Manhattan's Bryant Park.

title: When the Mild Go Wild: A Milquetoast's Slow Burn
description: Wednesday at Irving Plaza, a musician led hundreds of young people in a celebration of malice and rage. It wasn't Marilyn Manson; it was Ben Folds, the zany pianist who leads the trio jokingly named Ben Folds Five.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Hope it's all over soon. Mom, Dad, sorry I put you through so much pain and agony.''

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Dow Industrial Average Increased 10.2% in April

title: Taking Chances to Help Students
description: To the Editor:

title: World Trade Organization Deadlocked on Choice of Leader
description: The World Trade Organization became leaderless today, after efforts to appoint a New Zealander as the new Director General were blocked by supporters of his Thai rival.

title: The Knicks' Playoff Push: Winning, Hoping, Hurting
description: The Knicks were all smiles Thursday night after a rousing, come-from-behind victory over the Philadelphia 76ers put them firmly in control of the race for the eighth and final playoff berth in the Eastern Conference. But they were hardly comfortable. In an all-too-literal rendering of the Knicks' position in the driver's seat, Chris Childs stood gingerly in a corner of the locker room and explained how he had to lift his aching right leg up by hand just to get behind the wheel of his car to get to the arena.

title: Taking Chances to Help Students
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBSON, HARRY
description: JACOBSON-Harry. Temple Israel of New Rochelle records with sorrow the death of its cherished member and extends its heartfelt sympathy to the family. Amiel Wohl, Rabbi

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAMBERGER, BERTHA
description: LAMBERGER-Bertha. On April 29, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Stephen Lamberger, cherished aunt of Barbara Fishman, Lawrence Winkler and Joel Grill. Dear friend and adored relative to many others. Services Sunday 11AM at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue

title: 3 CAPTIVE SOLDIERS TELL OF ISOLATION IN YUGOSLAV CELLS
description: The three American servicemen held by Yugoslavia today described their days as lonely and monotonous, interrupted only by perfunctory daily visits from a Yugoslav Army officer and solitary exercise in their cells.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOYT, MURIEL CHRISTIE
description: HOYT-Muriel Christie. The Department of Ophthalmology at New York-Cornell has been greatly saddened by her passing. We will miss her gracious presence and warm smile. The Hoyt family have for many years been thoughtful and generous benefactors to this department and Medical Center. We extend our deepest condolences to the entire family. D. Jackson Coleman, M.D., Chairman

title: McCartney Opens Show Of 73 of His Paintings
description: This is a pretty little town in the hills of North Rhine-Westphalia, but even the most loyal burgers say it's not a place where much happens and it certainly isn't a cultural center.

title: Combining Jazz and Judaism
description: The Jewish Alternative Movement imprint of the Knitting Factory record label brings together a number of downtown New York jazz-based composers who have been wrestling with the question of cultural identity. The label, also known as Jam, had a showcase night at the Knitting Factory on Monday; some of the music answered the question academically, some with the vernacular and some in between.

title: After Seeing Milosevic, Russian Hints at Progress
description: A Russian envoy said tonight that he had made some progress toward a peace settlement after another six hours of talks with President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia, but NATO officials were dismissive.

title: An Albanian Tells How Serbs Chose Her, 'the Most Beautiful,' for Rape
description: Her tormentor told her she was chosen for her beauty. But it is her determination that sets her apart.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LACOVARA, PETER J., M.D.
description: LACOVARA-Peter J., M.D. Remembered with pride, love and gratitude always. Your Famil

title: Tennessee Talks of Paring Plan for 'Uninsurables'
description: In one bold stroke, Tennessee converted its Medicaid health benefits to managed care five years ago and used the savings to cover hundreds of thousands of people who could not afford health insurance of their own or were too sick to qualify. With three million people enrolled, the program, called Tenncare, became the most ambitious and generous government health plan in the nation.

title: Two May Aid Comcast Bid For Mediaone
description: Disturbed by the AT&T Corporation's cable television ambitions, America Online Inc. and the Microsoft Corporation may back the Comcast Corporation in its fight against AT&T to acquire Mediaone Group Inc., the big cable television carrier.

title: Nafta vs. Mexico's Trees
description: To the Editor:

title: Atlanta's Olympic Bid Draws Scrutiny
description: The first batch of documents made public today regarding the 1996 Summer Olympics revealed that Atlanta bid officials behaved in the same fawning manner that Salt Lake City officials did in trying to lure the votes of members of the International Olympic Committee.

title: Helping Whistle-Blowers Survive
description: Jennifer Long, the Internal Revenue Service agent who nearly lost her job two weeks ago after publicly blowing the whistle on abuses at the agency, was rescued at the last minute by the intervention of an influential United States Senator. But the fact that her employers had no inhibitions about harassing her is clear evidence that the laws protecting whistle-blowers need to be strengthened. As they stand, these laws merely invite the kind of retaliation that Mrs. Long endured.

title: GENERAL BINDING WILL CUT JOBS AND END SOME OPERATIONS
description: The General Binding Corporation, a maker of paper shredders and marker boards, will cut 435 jobs, or 8 percent of its work force, and close some European and United States operations as first-quarter earnings plummeted. General Binding's shares fell $7.1875, or 26 percent, to $20. The company, based in Northbrook, Ill., would not disclose the number or site of the distribution centers and plants to be closed. General Binding has 5,332 workers in 22 plants worldwide. It also said first-quarter net income fell 82 percent, to $1.3 million, or 8 cents a share, from $7.1 million, or 45 cents, a year earlier. Revenue rose to $221 million.

title: Did Police Do Enough?
description: To the Editor:

title: Counsel Will Decide Whether to Prosecute Boys in Bomb Plot
description: After interviewing five boys charged with conspiracy to blow up their Brooklyn school, officials yesterday referred the case to the Family Court Division of the city's Corporation Counsel, which is expected to decide by the end of next week whether to prosecute the boys.

title: Man Is Guilty of Forging Kennedy Papers in a $7 Million Scheme
description: A former paralegal at a New York law firm was convicted yesterday of bilking investors of $7 million in an audacious forgery scheme involving the sale of more than 200 bogus documents said to be in the handwriting of John F. Kennedy.

title: Devils Hold Off Penguins; 2d Round Is in Sight
description: The Devils and the Pittsburgh Penguins finally put together a spirited match that was fast, tense and entertaining. In the best game thus far in their mostly tepid series, the Devils won, 4-3, tonight at Continental Arena to take a three-games-to-two lead in the four-of-seven, first-round series.

title: When Bullies Ruled the Hallways
description: One day, 30 years ago, I was in my high school's lunchroom and mentioned to some classmates that I had cut my hand on a loose wire on my spiral notebook. This was in the Deep South, and we sat at assigned tables. The football player near me said: ''Where? Let me see.''

title: Military Satellite Stranded in a Lopsided Orbit
description: A giant rocket failed to carry a communications satellite into its intended orbit after launching from Florida today, dealing the Air Force a third straight setback in a space mission that cost well over $1 billion.

title: Challenging Everyone's Conceptions About Blacks
description: At times Orlando Patterson seems to be mouthing the arguments of racial neoconservatives. An African-American who teaches sociology at Harvard University, Mr. Patterson asserts that problems in many black neighborhoods stem less from white racism than from the breakdown of the black family and the behavior of black men who impregnate too many black women and marry too few.

title: Crew Offers More Schools For Queens
description: Seeking to address complaints that his $11 billion, five-year school construction plan did not do enough to reduce severe overcrowding in Queens, Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew has proposed the addition of 10,650 seats for the borough over the number he called for in his November plan.

title: Torre Not Yet Ready To Manage Yanks; Zimmer to Stay On
description: His doctor warned Joe Torre that his rate of recovery from prostate cancer would be unpredictable, that he could feel strong and vigorous one day and weary the next. Whereas Torre once thought he might assume his role of manager on the Yankees' current road trip, he said today that he was not ready and used two weeks as a time frame for his return.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DURRSE, JACOB G.
description: DURRSE-Jacob G. Of Greenwich, CT. On April 29. Mr. Durrse was the President of the Linen Trade Association in New York City. For information regarding his funeral please phone the Leo P. Gallagher & Son Funeral Home at 203869-1513.

title: Four Officers in Diallo Case Return to Work
description: The four New York City police officers charged with murdering Amadou Diallo returned to work with pay yesterday after attending a morning court session in the Bronx in which a Jan. 3 trial date was set.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LINDBERG, CHARLES MARTIN
description: LINDBERG-Charles Martin. Suddenly on April 28, 1999. Recently retired from the LIRR and the NYC Board of Education. Beloved husband of the late Shirley (nee Eisgrau). Devoted father of Diane Lindberg Curtis and Craig Lindberg. Loving father-in-law of Tom Curtis and special friend of Katsumi. Fond brother of George Lindberg and brother-in-law of Dena, Rhoda and Joyce. Visiting at Leo F. Kearns Funeral Home, 103-33 Lefferts Boulevard, Richmond Hill, NY, Saturday and Sunday 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Religious Service Monday, 10 AM. Interment Forest Lawn Cemetery, Woodbridge, NJ.

title: Minnesota Mining Says Profit Declined
description: The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company, the maker of more than 50,000 industrial and consumer products, said today that its first-quarter profit fell 4 percent despite a rebound in sales in Asia.

title: G.E. Unit to Buy Big Retail Chain
description: The General Electric Company's finance arm will acquire all of the Montgomery Ward Holding Company, the seventh-largest United States department store company, as part of the retailer's bankruptcy reorganization plan, court papers show.

title: An Andromeda Still Hoping, Perhaps Without Cause
description: It is hard to tell whether Polly Walker is intended as a figure of sympathy or contempt in Edward Napier's ''English Teachers.'' As played by Alma Cuervo, Polly is the town kook in Ceredo-Kenova, W. Va., a locality with little regard for Polly's pretensions, which include lounging in yellow silk pajamas, talking in a fraudulent upper-class English accent and making declarations like ''Don't think that this Andromeda has given up the hope that her Perseus will come.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROTSKY, JERRY
description: GROTSKY-Jerry. Died in San Mateo, California on April 28, 1999. Funeral Services will be held Monday May 3, 1999 at 12 Noon at the Ferncliff Cemetery, 280 Secor Rd., Hartsdale, New York.

title: KOSOVO UPDATE
description: PRISONERS

title: Bomb Kills 2 in London Gay Bar; Extremists Tied to Three Attacks
description: A nail bomb ripped through a gay bar in Soho tonight, killing at least 2 people and wounding 73, and leaving the city on edge after two other bombings this month, in minority neighborhoods. The police said they believed that all three attacks were linked to extreme right-wing groups.

title: Knoblauch Upset at Being Hit
description: Seeds of bad blood between the Yankees and the Kansas City Royals were planted with two outs in the ninth inning tonight, when Kansas City reliever Jeff Montgomery hit Chuck Knoblauch on the elbow with a fastball.

title: Five Horses Make Up the Field of Dreamers
description: Three of them bring horses and intriguing tales to their first Kentucky Derby. Two others have been here before. One wears a black cowboy hat and needed a judge's ruling to get his horse into the starting gate. Another survived the destruction of her Tokyo home during World War II, taught Asian studies at the University of Kentucky and didn't begin training horses until 1993.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-10

title: With New Inflation Fear, Happy April Ends on Sad Note
description: Signs that a bustling economy might finally produce a long-feared bout of inflation sent stock and bond prices tumbling yesterday. But the spring revival of cyclical stocks was still strong enough to push the Dow Jones industrial average to a gain of 10.2 percent in April, the biggest monthly gain in more than a decade.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Hoping Bear Will Awaken; Some Foreign Companies Stay the Course in Russia
description: Caterpillar had just cleared away a patch of spindly trees in this town outside St. Petersburg and begun building a new $50 million factory when, one day last August, the Russian financial system collapsed.

title: Xerox Adding Danka Unit
description: The Xerox Corporation said today that it had agreed to acquire the Danka Office Imaging Company's Xerox service business. The value of the purchase was not disclosed. Danka Office Imaging has been servicing Xerox copiers and printers since 1995, primarily high-volume Xerox Docutech and 5090 models of copier-printers. Danka Office Imaging is a unit of Danka Business Systems P.L.C., a London-based seller and servicer of photocopiers and other office-imaging systems.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAYER, HENRY
description: MAYER-Henry. On April 30, 1999. President of Ney Smelting, Brooklyn, NY. Devoted husband of Ruth, father of Ronald, father-in-law of Sydelle, loving grandfather of Michelle, brother of Lis Oppenheimer, uncle of Alice Weisz. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to The Blue Card, NYC. Funeral services will be held Sunday, May 2nd at Schwartz's Funeral Home, Forest Hills, 9:30AM

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEIGENBAUM, ARTHUR
description: FEIGENBAUM-Arthur. On April 30, 1999. Beloved husband of the late Ethel. Devoted father of Ruth Wimpfheimer and Michael Feigenbaum. Loving grandfather of Robert, Lori, Debra, Susan, Amy, Daniel, Nachum and his precious great-granddaughter, Yakira. Services Sunday 1PM Schwartz Brothers, 114-03 Queens Blvd., Forest Hills, NY.

title: Will Serbs Ever Give Up Kosovo?
description: To the Editor:

title: Pataki Backs Mayoral Control of Schools
description: Seeking to influence the debate over who controls public education, Gov. George E. Pataki plans to introduce legislation that would give Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and the mayors of the other four largest cities in New York the authority to run their local school systems.

title: Verniero Auditing Some Spending by Essex Prosecutor
description: The State Attorney General is auditing spending by the office of the Essex County Prosecutor, Patricia A. Hurt, in response to accusations that she spent extravagantly on furnishings, vehicles and equipment.

title: Marbury Gets 36 But Orlando Wins
description: At the Orlando Arena last night, Stephon Marbury did what every outstanding player does when his team is worn thin by injuries: He strapped his club on his back like a knapsack and attempted to carry it to heights thought unreachable.

title: One to Go: Baffert on a Roll Entering the Derby
description: On the eve of the Kentucky Derby, this was the easy part of Bob Baffert's weekend: Silverbulletday winning her seventh straight race and her 10th in 11 starts, dominating the Kentucky Oaks at Churchill Downs before a record crowd of 101,034.

title: Feeling Used, Hartford Residents Sing the Blues Over News
description: Even the good time rock-and-roll that Bob Tomassone was playing for the Friday-night crowd at Coach's Sports Bar & Grille on Allyn Street seemed to refer to how Hartford had lost the Patriots. It was a song by Rod Stewart, something about a girl named Maggie, who had played with the heart of a young man and left him feeling used.

title: Alf Ramsey, 79, Manager Of England's Soccer Team
description: Sir Alf Ramsey, who in 1966 coached England to its only World Cup soccer championship, died Wednesday in a nursing home near his home in Ipswich.

title: Taking Chances to Help Students
description: To the Editor:

title: For Those Who Dress Differently, an Increase in Being Viewed as Abnormal
description: It has always been hard to be the one called a freak, geek, dweeb, weirdo.

title: At Home Abroad; People Of The Law?
description: One of Israel's notable achievements, in the 50 years since the state was reborn, has been the development of a respected legal system. The Israeli Supreme Court is known for protecting the civil liberties of citizens. Its judges are esteemed around the world.

title: Judge Closes Two Clubs, Citing Drug Activity
description: Citing a pattern of illegal drug activity, a Manhattan judge ordered two popular nightclubs temporarily closed yesterday, including the Tunnel, which is owned by the embattled nightlife impressario Peter Gatien.

title: Warnings From a Student Turned Killer
description: The printout of material from Eric Harris's Web site released yesterday was a hodgepodge of rantings about Denver (''I would love to kill almost all of its residents'') and things he loved and hated (school was in the first category, schoolwork in the second).

title: Citing Possible Conflicts, D'Amato Quits Law Firm
description: A week after he took a job with a major law firm, former United States Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato abruptly resigned yesterday, saying he had realized that it would be too cumbersome to resolve conflicts of interest between his legal work and his separate consulting business.

title: Did Police Do Enough?
description: To the Editor:

title: Will Serbs Ever Give Up Kosovo?; Debate on War Powers
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABRAMS, ARTHUR L.
description: ABRAMS-Arthur L., 86, of Scranton, PA, on April 27, 1999. Beloved husband of Ruth Friedman. Cherished father of Judy Steinhardt, Ellen Abrams, Ann Lutz. Loved by his grandchildren, David and Daniel Steinhardt and Sara Berman, Lauren and Max Stossel, Emily and Ben Kaplan. Adoring greatgrandfather of Jacob Berman. Devoted brother of Mildred Golden and Natalie Gossels. Shiva Sunday, May 2, 3-8 p.m., 211 Central Park West, Apt. 15K, and Monday, May 3, 12-9 p.m., 1158 Fifth Avenue, Apt. 16A.

title: History Returns to the Scene of Its Crime
description: Not long ago I received a letter from Israel from the parents of a boy they had named Babi Yar. Through their son's name the parents wanted people to remember what happened at that ravine near the city of Kiev in 1941. But today, from the photograph of their son, two dark eyes stared out at me like the smoking coals on television from Kosovo and Belgrade. Like Raskolnikov, history returns to the scene of its crime -- to the Balkans, where World War I began with a shot fired at Archduke Ferdinand. Today, it seems to me that this Israeli boy has either an Albanian or a Serbian face. Selective solidarity -- Western or Russian -- is blind.

title: United Companies Committee to Join Talks
description: A group of shareholders in the United Companies Financial Corporation who used the Internet to form an alliance to fight for a role in their company's reorganization in bankruptcy court in Wilmington, Del., has been given an official seat at the negotiating table.

title: Mark Weiser, a Leading Computer Visionary, Dies at 46
description: Mark D. Weiser, a computer scientist and the chief technology officer of the Xerox Corporation's legendary Palo Alto Research Center, died on Tuesday at his home in Palo Alto, Calif. He was 46.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Taking Chances to Help Students
description: To the Editor:

title: WNBC Broadcasts a Frank Video on Breast Self-Exams
description: In what media experts called an unprecedented depiction of the human body during an evening broadcast, NBC's New York City television station, Channel 4, devoted eight and a half minutes of its 11 P.M. newscast Thursday to an instructional video on breast self-examination to detect signs of cancer.

title: Unwelcome Addition to a Legacy
description: The agreement between New Jersey and the Justice Department to reach an out-of-court settlement over racial profiling by the state police may have ended Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's worries about an embarrassing Federal lawsuit, but the political problems over the issue may be just beginning.

title: Getting the Word Out
description: Charlie Ward kept dialing the hotel operator Tuesday afternoon, asking that she connect him to the rooms of several of his teammates at the Atlanta Ritz-Carlton. But after a few rings, he invariably ended up leaving voice-mail messages.

title: Isles Turn to Goring to Bring Back Glory
description: Reeling from their fifth straight season without making the National Hockey League playoffs, the Islanders named Butch Goring as their new head coach today and dismissed Bill Stewart.

title: Gian-Carlo Rota, 66, Professor Of Mathematics and Philosophy
description: Gian-Carlo Rota, a professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology whose work bridged the upper realms of mathematics and philosophy, died on April 19 at his home in Cambridge, Mass. He was 66.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the fatal shooting of a teen-ager in Flatbush, Brooklyn, misstated the victim's given name in some copies. He was Wade Nurse, not Wayne.

title: U.S. Is Investigating Public-Offerings Fees
description: The Justice Department antitrust division has started investigating the way some investment firms set fees they charge companies to sell stock in initial public offerings, focusing on the possibility of anticompetitive practices. The typical charge is about 7 percent for offerings up to $80 million, less for larger ones.

title: I.B.M. May Testify for U.S. Against Microsoft in Trial
description: In its antitrust suit against the Microsoft Corporation, the Government has portrayed personal computer makers as little more than indentured servants of the software powerhouse. Again and again, Government lawyers asserted, Microsoft used the monopoly power of its Windows operating system to bend PC companies to its will, reducing competition and consumer choice.

title: Right Plant, Wrong Place
description: The US Generating Company has asked New York State for permission to build a gas-fired power plant near the western shore of the Hudson River in Green County, an area of breathtaking natural beauty 120 miles north of New York City. From an engineering standpoint, it is a good place to put a power plant. From any other perspective -- esthetic, environmental, historical -- it is the wrong place. Gov. George Pataki should deny the application. Failure to do so would set a poor precedent and tarnish his reputation for environmental stewardship.

title: China Takes Steps to Avoid Further Protests
description: Fearing that members of the Buddhist Law movement might demonstrate again in coming days, China's leaders issued a warning this morning to all Government officials and employees of state-run institutions not to take part in any such protests.

title: A Son's Diagnosis
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: MASCO CORP., Taylor, Mich., a maker of kitchen cabinets and bathroom fixtures, bought the closely held Avocet Hardware P.L.C., Brighton, England, a supplier of locks and other builders' hardware products with annual sales of more than $100 million, for an undisclosed amount of cash.

title: City Raising Standards For Provider Of Jail Care
description: The Giuliani administration plans to tighten its standards for measuring the performance of the hospital that provides medical care in the city's jails, a top city official said yesterday.

title: COMING ON SUNDAY: THE END OF AFFIRMATIVE ACTION
description: How diversity on campus survived Proposition 209 in California. A report by James Traub, in The Times Magazine.

title: Reporter's Notebook; Israel's Prime Time Polemics Heat Up
description: The Interior Ministry is a gray institution, a well-worn, humdrum place of civil servants, paper piles and rubber stamps. But this week it grabbed the Israeli public by the lapels in a way that nothing has thus far in a personality-based campaign for the election on May 17.

title: Talk of Selling the Fabled Balducci's Reopens Family Wounds
description: A Maryland supermarket chain has apparently offered to buy Balducci's, the upscale food store in Greenwich Village, reopening old family wounds and casting uncertainty over the store, which began as an Italian produce stand and became a gastronomic landmark.

title: When Fun Isn't Funny: Evolution Of Pop Gore
description: ''I think I'll give it to yuh in the belly! Yuh get more time to enjoy it!''

title: David Duke, Republican
description: To the Editor:

title: FIRST AVIATION WEIGHS SALE OF ITS TURBINE REPAIR UNIT
description: First Aviation Services Inc. said yesterday that it might sell its National Airmotive Corporation gas turbine engine repair unit to improve its stock price. National Airmotive, of Oakland, Calif., one of the leaders in the repair and overhaul of gas turbine engines, is expected to report sales of about $110 million for the current fiscal year. First Aviation, based in Westport, Conn., provides services for engines in military and general aircraft, including corporate jets. First Aviation's other unit, Aircraft Parts International Inc., is a major distributor of aircraft parts in North America.

title: INSIDE
description: Pollution Rules Toughened

title: Hoffa the Son Hopes To Put House in Order
description: In one of his first acts as teamsters president, James Phillip Hoffa hung a beloved oil painting of his father, a colossus posing above a convoy of trucks while looking up toward Mount Rushmore as if he belonged there.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LYDEN, DORIS MACINTYRE
description: LYDEN-Doris MacIntyre. On April 30, 1999. Beloved wife of Jack. Devoted mother to William, Margaret, Hunter and Reynolds. Dear Stepmother to Basil and David. Adoring grandmother to 12 grandchildren. Visiting Sunday 2-4 and 7-9pm at the John J. Fox Funeral Home, Inc., 2080 Boston Post Road, Larchmont, NY 10538. Service Monday 10am at The Larchmont Avenue Presbyterian Church in Larchmont.

title: Army Reportedly Seizes Indian Ocean Nation
description: The Comoran military announced today that it overthrew the Government of the Comoro islands on Thursday night. The streets there were quiet today after the apparently bloodless coup, a local journalist said.

title: Bomb Scare Upsets Student
description: Jovan Martin's high school was closed by a bomb scare on Thursday, and today she got to tell Gov. Christine Todd Whitman how it felt.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MALAMUT, MARGUERITE
description: MALAMUT - Marguerite. The Board of Trustees of Parker Jewish Institute extend heartfelt sympathies to the Malamut family and to fellow Trustee Abraham on the passing of his wife Marguerite. May your memories of her offer comfort to you at this time. David Taub, Chairman of the Board David Glaser, President

title: Hostile Offer Sends Shares Of 2 Oil Companies Higher
description: Shares of Repsol and YPF surged today after Spain's largest oil company expressed confidence that its unsolicited $13.4 billion takeover offer for the Argentine rival would succeed.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Spare Times listing of Weekend yesterday about a spring fair from 9 A.M. to 5 P.M. today at St. Clement's Episcopal Church in Manhattan misstated the address. It is 423 West 46th Street, not 26th Street.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: With Eye on TV Revenue, N.F.L. Keeps Foot in Big Market
description: By terminating a $374 million stadium deal in Hartford yesterday, the New England Patriots played directly into the National Football League's renewed dedication to shoring up its lagging presence in the largest television markets.

title: Subway Platform Perils
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE EURO CONTINUES TO FALL. The dollar rose against the euro after a report that the nation's economy grew at a robust 4.5 percent rate in the first quarter. The euro fell to $1.0582, from $1.0591 on Thursday.

title: Lex Service and RAC In $707.2 Million Deal
description: Lex Service P.L.C. agreed yesterday to acquire another British auto-repair company, RAC Holdings Ltd. Lex said it would pay $:437 million, or $707.2 million, for the member-owned business, which runs Britain's second-largest roadside assistance service and a driving school.

title: Will Serbs Ever Give Up Kosovo?; The Pentagon's Fortune
description: To the Editor:

title: Jagr Is Running Out of Time and Games
description: As the Devils grabbed a 3-2 lead in games in their opening-round Stanley Cup playoff series against the Pittsburgh Penguins, the mystery of Jaromir Jagr's pulled groin muscle continued.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: WHEAT RISES. Larger-than-expected deliveries of wheat and news that the Government made a large purchase for donation to needy countries sent prices up. The July contract rose 4.5 cents, to $2.68 a bushel.

title: Russia Says Creditors May Defer Repayments
description: Fresh from concluding a vital debt refinancing agreement with the International Monetary Fund, top Russian ministers said today that foreign creditors were close to agreeing on deferred repayment of the country's Soviet-era loans.

title: A Most Unbiblical Noah Rocks the Ark
description: Who knew that the story of Noah and the ark included orgies, pirates, action-movie fistfights, an Opheliaesque mad scene and a large helping of Borscht belt humor? ''I didn't know what happiness was till I married you,'' Lot (F. Murray Abraham) tells his wife (Carol Kane). ''Now it's too late.''

title: Plant Lover Up a Tree Is Pruned By Police
description: In one of the more curious protests against Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's plan to auction off 112 community gardens, a man dressed like a sunflower shinned up a ginkgo tree in City Hall Park yesterday morning and vowed not to descend until the Mayor had listened to his concerns.

title: Father Returns to Help Son Avoid Death Penalty
description: Thomas Koskovich, the 20-year-old convicted killer of two pizza deliverymen, saw his father for the first time since 1991 yesterday, but only for a few minutes in a courtroom campaign to save the young man from a death sentence.

title: Apaches Will Face High Risk Over Kosovo; Final Approval Yet to Come
description: One night, maybe soon, the first American Apache helicopters are supposed to take off from a makeshift base in Albania, pause to refuel in the rugged northern Albanian hills and then, with rockets raining ahead of them, fly into Kosovo to try to do what NATO's high-flying jets have not done: eviscerate Yugoslavia's armored forces.

title: Watson Gets a Warmer Homecoming
description: Christ the King High School, where Allen Watson starred 11 years ago, is just a few miles from Shea Stadium, and his family home in Middle Village is close enough that dozens of his friends and family members sat behind home plate last night.

title: Banca Commerciale Says 2d Bid May Be in Offing
description: Banca Commerciale Italiana S.p.A. said yesterday that it was discussing a merger with Banca Intesa S.p.A. in a move that could result in a better offer for Banca Commerciale shareholders than a $15.3 billion offer by Unicredito Italiano S.p.A. last month. Either transaction would create Italy's biggest bank.

title: MILOSEVIC DEFIANT BUT OFFERS A PACT
description: President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia insisted in an interview released here today that Yugoslavs were ''willing to die'' to defend what he called their right to Kosovo, but at the same time outlined what he described as a six-point plan for settlement of the war.

title: SMITH & NEPHEW, BRITISH MEDICAL CONCERN, SELLS UNIT
description: The British medical-equipment company Smith & Nephew P.L.C. said yesterday that it had sold its bracing and support systems business for $:124 million, or $200 million, to Chase Capital Partners, a private investment fund owned by the Chase Manhattan Corporation. The sale is part of Smith & Nephew's strategy to focus on three businesses with strong global prospects: orthopedics, endoscopy and wound management. The California-based Bracing and Support Systems business, which includes the Donjoy knee bracing and Procare soft tissue support products, is predominantly a United States business. Smith & Nephew said it would show a pretax gain of $103 million from the sale.

title: State Dept. Drops Iran as Terrorist Leader
description: In what American officials described as a move they hoped would ease relations with Iran, the State Department today dropped its designation of the Teheran Government as the world's leading state sponsor of terrorism.

title: New Jersey Town Is Tense After E-Mail Threat Against School
description: It may have been a perfect spring day, but 6-year-old Cynthia Ditunnariello and her friends weren't going anywhere near the candy-cane-colored jungle gym that beckoned from across the street.

title: BALTIMORE GAS AND ELECTRIC TO SELL 15 NURSING HOMES
description: The Baltimore Gas and Electric Company plans to sell 15 nursing homes valued at $93.5 million by the end of the year as the utility sharpens its focus on competing in deregulating power markets. The Baltimore-based company has had talks with potential buyers, said Christian Poindexter, the company's chairman and chief executive. He declined to name them. The homes are in Maryland, Virginia, North Carolina and Rhode Island. Baltimore Gas, which sells electricity and power to 1.1 million customers in Maryland, has also created a holding company that will allow it to expand its operations with less regulatory oversight. The company will trade under the name Constellation Energy Group on the Big Board starting Monday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEVRIES, LION
description: deVRIES-Lion. Hofstra University is profoundly saddened by the death on April 29th, 1999 of honorary alumnus and loyal friend Lion deVries. Mr. deVries and his wife, Tilly, helped to build strong ties between The Netherlands and Hofstra's academic community. Through the assistance of Mr. and Mrs. deVries, Hofstra University and the Dutch have formed a strong, supportive relationship that has benefitted both students and faculty. Mr. deVries helped with the creation of Hofstra's annual Dutch Festival, now in its 16th year. The Dutch Festival has brought hundreds of thousands of visitors to the University's campus and become a much anticipated tradition on Long Island. He also helped to establish a Dutch Studies Institute at Hofstra. Through this program, Hofstra students and faculty travel to the Roosevelt Study Center in Middleburg in The Netherlands every summer. Mr. deVries had been instrumental in arranging loans of Dutch art to the Hofstra Museum and in creating a hybrid tulip named for the University. He also played a major role in planning the historic visit of HRH Princess Margriet and her husband, Mr. Pieter van Vollenhoven, to the Hofstra campus in 1991. Lion and Tilly deVries have been honored for their outstanding efforts in promoting good relations between The Netherlands and the United States. Queen Beatrix of The Netherlands bestowed upon them the prestigious award of Knighthood in the Order of Orange Nassau, one of the highest forms of recognition given by the Dutch government. In addition to his tireless efforts at Hofstra, Mr. deVries was an active member of the Corporate Development Committee, The Netherlands America Foundation and The Netherlands Club. Lion deVries is survived by his wife, Tilly; daughters, Cristina and Eveline; and grandchildren, Bridge and Michael. James M. Shuart President Helene Fortunoff Chairperson, Board of Trustees

title: Sports of The Times; Pin Patter: Broncos' Star Goes Bowling
description: TERRELL DAVIS showed up at Bryant Park in Manhattan on cue yesterday afternoon. About 100 children, and a number of noontime diners, cheered as Davis, the Denver Broncos' All-Pro running back, hopped up on the elevated bowling lanes that had been constructed for a clinic as part of the Professional Bowlers Association's first outdoor championship today.

title: PENTAIR, SEEKING TO EXPAND WATER BUSINESS, ADDS ESSEF
description: Pentair Inc., a maker of pumps and electrical equipment, agreed yesterday to buy the Essef Corporation to expand its business of making water tanks, filters and other water equipment. Pentair will pay Essef shareholders $19.09 in cash a share, for a total of $312 million. Pentair will also assume $100 million in debt. The St. Paul-based Pentair, which makes Myers and Aurora pumps, said the purchase would increase revenue from its water and fluid group to about $1 billion next year. Essef, based in Chardon, Ohio, is expected to generate revenue of $350 million this year, excluding results from its Anthony & Sylvan poll construction unit. Essef will spin off this unit to shareholders.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAKLEY, DELPHINE M.
description: SHAKLEY-Delphine M. On April 28, 1999. Beloved wife of Mark, mother of Alexander, Jonathan, Oliver, Jennifer, and Jacob. Daughter of Jane and the late James McCosker, sister of Maureen, Timothy and Muriel. Funeral mass at St Ignatius Loyola Church, Park Ave at 84 St, Saturday, 12 Noon. Interment private. Contributions in her memory may be made to the National Brain Tumor Foundation, 785 Market St, Suite 1600, San Francisco, Ca. 94103

title: As Deadline Closes In, Patriots Reject Lucrative Hartford Offer
description: Five months after the New England Patriots announced a startling plan to move to Connecticut, the football team said today it was walking away from the most lucrative stadium deal in professional sports now that Massachusetts is willing to pay to keep the team.

title: Outgoing U.N. Development Chief Berates U.S.
description: With American debt to the United Nations soaring and contributions to development aid plunging, the outgoing chief of the United Nations Development Program, the highest-ranking American in the United Nations system, has accused the United States of ''tragic shortsightedness'' in failing to support the world body.

title: Beliefs; On generosity to the poor: three sociologists find some surprising results in a religious survey.
description: ''Pie in the sky bye-and-bye'' was the mocking refrain of political revolutionaries who accused religion of pacifying the poor with heavenly hopes instead of helping them with earthly goods. Yet compassion toward the poor, with here-and-now almsgiving as part of it, has been part of every major religious tradition. So it is not surprising that three sociologists recently set out to answer these questions:

title: World Briefing
description: THE AMERICAS

title: Mercantile Bancorporation, Long a Buyer, Will Be Bought
description: The Mercantile Bancorporation, a St. Louis bank that has been cutting jobs and expenses after a three-year acquisition binge, has agreed to be acquired itself by the Firstar Corporation, a Milwaukee bank, which announced the deal late yesterday.

title: Crackdown On Pollution By Vehicles
description: President Clinton has approved strict Federal rules to control pollution from the tailpipes of automobiles and end the special treatment for sport utility vehicles for the first time since Federal emissions standards were drafted in the early 1970's.

title: AEGIS GROUP IN PACT TO PURCHASE MARKET FACTS
description: Aegis Group P.L.C. agreed yesterday to acquire Market Facts Inc., a Chicago-based research company, for $31 a share in cash, or $297 million, as the company, the world's No. 1 independent buyer of ad time, pushes its expansion into the United States, the world's biggest ad market. Aegis, whose Carat Group unit sells media research, media planning and ad-buying services for clients, said last month that acquisitions would remain an important company strategy. Aegis moved into the United States in 1996, where acquisitions have helped turn it into one of the 10 biggest ad-buying companies.

title: Fraud-Fighting Plan Arouses Wall Street Ire
description: In an attempt to combat securities fraud among small over-the-counter stocks, the Securities and Exchange Commission has proposed that brokerage firms do more of the policing.

title: Florida's School Voucher Scheme
description: This week the Florida Legislature approved the first statewide school voucher plan in the nation, allowing some students to attend private and parochial schools at public expense. Gov. Jeb Bush made vouchers a centerpiece of his political agenda. But the Florida plan, though likely to become a template for other Republican-controlled legislatures, has the same profound weaknesses of voucher schemes operating in places like Milwaukee.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEWMYER, ARTHUR G., JR.
description: NEWMYER-Arthur G., Jr. On April 30, at Suburban Hospital in Maryland, beloved father of Barbara N. Johnson and A. G. Newmyer III, and brother of James M. Newmyer; devoted grandfather. A funeral service will be held at The Washington Hebrew Congregation cemetery in Washington, DC, at 1 p.m. on Sunday, May 2. The family will receive friends at 4 p.m. on May 2 at the home of Mr. and Mrs. James Newmyer, 3003 Audubon Terrace, N.W. Contributions in Mr. Newmyer's memory may be made to the National Conference for Community and Justice at Suite 1050, 1815 H Street, N.W., Washington, DC 20006; the Alzheimer's Association at 1003 K Street, N.W., Washington, DC 20001; or The Fair Care Foundation, at Suite 350, 3201 New Mexico Avenue, Washington, DC 20016.

title: The Stage as Playground For a Jack of All Arts
description: Antonio Nobrega was born into a middle-class family in northeastern Brazil and while still a teen-ager had begun a journey that has made him a popular figure today in the Brazilian performing arts. Mr. Nobrega trained in and learned to perform a synthesis of Brazilian folk forms, classical music and violin, mime and circus arts. In ''Figural,'' which he presented on Wednesday night at the Terrace Theater at the Kennedy Center in a now-ended American debut season, Mr. Nobrega performed as a surprisingly believable street mime.

title: Economy's Growth Keeps to Fast Pace, Up 4.5% in Quarter
description: America's economic boom -- already the second longest on record -- shows no signs of flagging.

title: From Milosevic, 6 Steps Toward Ending the War on the Serbs
description: Following are excerpts from an interview today with President Slobodan Milosevic:

title: At Pro-Am Event, Am's Shift Gives a Pro Entry Problems
description: There is no generally agreed collective word for a group of bridge experts. Are they a herd? A flock? A gaggle?

title: A Classical Debt: What Europe Owes to American Music
description: NEW WORLD SYMPHONIES

title: Police Seek Man in Series Of Attacks In Subway
description: A man with a sharp object has jabbed at least five women on subway trains or in stations during the last two months, the police said last night.

title: Lynne Dichter, David Overbeck
description: Lynne Alexandra Dichter and David Holt Overbeck are to be married today by the Rev. Deborah J. Pope-Lance, a Unitarian-Universalist minister, at Ridge Hill Reservation in Needham, Mass.

title: Dena Polston and Kevin Lehy
description: ONCE you hear Dena L. Polston speak, her voice is hard to forget. She has the gravelly sound of a country singer, with a Midwestern twang and high volume. It is the vocal equivalent of a beautiful movie star -- it turns heads.

description: To Tony Bennett and his son Danny, it seemed just an offhand comment. At a star-studded Christmas Eve dinner party in 1997 at the home of Tommy Mottola, then the president of Sony Music Entertainment, Robert DeNiro turned to the crooner, who was 70 at the time, and said, ''Hey, Tony -- there's a film I want you in.''

description: A new resort south of Verona, midway between Venice and Milan, adds golfing in luxury to the pleasures of the Lake Garda region.

title: Last Lap for Bridgehampton Race Circuit
description: THE grandstands are deserted, the starter's tower is empty and the only thing racing down the track is an occasional deer. The Bridgehampton Race Circuit, which for more than four decades has been host to some of the world's most legendary automobile racers, is at the end of its road.

title: Boat Romantics Gather With Handmade Best
description: In the upper left-hand corner of the country, up where Puget Sound is littered with low, rocky islands, about 65 handbuilt boats lined the beach of a quiet, fog-filled bay last weekend.

title: A Composer Freed by Opera To Be Tonal And Tuneful
description: IT was a signal moment in the rebirth of tonality. When the curtain rose on Tobias Picker's first opera, ''Emmeline,'' in 1996, the orchestra conjured an atmosphere of grim foreboding, circling endlessly around a single, brooding chord. As if to emphasize his immersion in the dark realm of B flat minor, Mr. Picker prefaced the score with a device long scorned by modernists: a key signature.

title: Blini and Borscht in English
description: This spring, civic and business leaders in Brighton Beach, long the center of Russian New York, have begun a push to bring tourists to the neighborhood. The first step will make immediate sense to any travelers who have scratched their heads in a foreign store: convince shopkeepers to put up signs in English.

title: Well Beyond The Rotary-Dial Phone
description: If you've ever stood and fumed while the person who got to the airport pay phone ahead of you seemed to tie it up endlessly, you won't like what AT&T has done with 20 pay phones in Terminal 4 at John F. Kennedy International Airport.

title: Welcome to 'Stealth University'; SUNY at Farmingdale Remakes Itself and Hopes Someone Will Notice
description: HAZEM TAWFIK nodded sorrowfully as he stood in the spacious white industrial laboratory he directs at the State University of New York campus at Farmingdale.

title: Radiance, Rebellion and Trust
description: CONSIDER a distressing question facing the habitual theatergoer. Does a deadening production of a great living play deserve to be called valiant, or even ambitious, just because it's there?

title: Federal Limits on Fishing Will Affect Jersey Coast
description: The National Marine Fisheries Service last week announced fishing restrictions intended to protect swordfish, shark and tuna, including a monthlong ban on one type of fishing off New Jersey.

description: To the Editor:

description: A big fat dose of spring was reported to have arrived in earnest throughout New York City yesterday. And just about everywhere you looked, the evidence was rather compelling.

description: The insider-versus-outsider thesis presented by Paul Berman (April 11) opens the door to some questions.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a news analysis article yesterday about Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey misstated the position held by a scholar commenting on her political future. Cliff Zukin is the director of The Star-Ledger / Eagleton Poll and chairman of the public policy department at the Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers University. He is not chairman of the Eagleton Institute of Politics at Rutgers.

title: How the Knicks' Big Swoon Is Now Becoming a Souffle
description: Their season was on the verge of being torn apart by dysfunction when several Knicks gathered in a room to vent their frustrations two weeks ago. It was time to open the floor to a solution during a losing streak that threatened to doom their playoff chances.

title: The Class of Prop. 209
description: The campus of the university of california at berkeley in springtime is about as close to Shangri-La as most mortals are likely to get. When I paid a visit last month, the dogwoods and the cherry trees were in splendid bloom, and the broad, sunny plaza in front of the Mario Savio Steps at Sproul Hall was jammed with students. I had arrived during campaign season, and kids were milling around the plaza holding placards and bedsheets promising better, wiser, bolder student government. Berkeley must be one of the few universities with standing political parties, and several of the parties had set up booths. One of the loneliest of them, never staffed by more than a student or two, belonged to the Defend Affirmative Action Party.

title: Bookend; Let's Go to the Videotape
description: A group called Writers' Corps has just formed a national league for poetry slam. . . . Their events will feature Olympic-style judging and national playoffs. -- National Public Radio, ''All Things Considered''

title: The View From/Waterbury; War in the Balkans Is No Distant Thunder
description: ALBANIAN-AMERICANS, whether from Albania or Macedonia, Montenegro or Kosovo, stay close to each other in the United States and close to the people they have left behind. They raise money, lobby Congress for ground troops and support for the Kosovo Liberation Army, and they hold rallies.

title: Heinz L. Fraenkel-Conrat, 88; Dissected Virus
description: Dr. Heinz L. Fraenkel-Conrat, whose research in biochemistry allowed scientists to peer into the innermost workings of viruses, died on April 10 at Kaiser Permanente Medical Center in Oakland, Calif. He was 88 and lived in Berkeley.

title: Democracy: Round and Round We Go
description: PITY poor May Day, the holiday that no longer has a constituency. May 1 used to be a day to celebrate the glories of socialism and Communism, but ever since it became apparent that socialism and Communism have no glories, it's been just another date.

title: A Humanizing Tale of Noah In a Sea of Poetic License
description: And thus spake the executive producer to his screenwriter:

title: Gershwin Sells but at What Cost?
description: I AM finding special joy in discovering the depths to be plumbed in the simplest lyric of Ira or the tiniest harmonic sparkle of one of George's melodies.''

title: April 25-May 1; Indian Parliament Dissolved
description: India is heading toward its third general election in three years following the collapse of the Hindu nationalist-led government that had ruled the nation for the past year. The fractious ruling coalition narrowly lost a vote of confidence two weeks ago, and when President K. R. Narayanan concluded that the equally fractious opposition parties had failed to muster a new majority, he dissolved the Parliament to make way for fresh elections, which must be held within six months. CELIA W. DUGGER

title: Private Places
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Herbs, Grown and Plucked for Flavor and Folklore
description: IN Port Murray, Warren County, Cyrus Hyde hunches over a small potting table in one of his three greenhouses. The focus of his attention is a batch of seeds that a friend sent him from Morocco. Delighted, he drops the seeds one by one into plastic containers of rich soil: parsley, coriander and black cumin. If it weren't for the radio blasting Dr. Laura's advice, the scene would seem to be lifted from a medieval painting: a master herbalist at work.

title: Beyond Charm in Charleston
description: EATING breakfast in the shade of a palm tree on a sun-drenched Easter morning in Charleston, surrounded by the sound of church bells pealing from every direction and azaleas in full bloom, I surrendered to pure pleasure. A first-time visitor is overpowered by the city's exquisite 18th- and 19th-century architecture, sensuous foliage, near-Mediterranean interplay of light and water and, last but not least, unimaginably good food.

title: McRae Slam Lets Franco Enjoy Day
description: The Mets seemed to have been grinding and churning toward John Franco on his day, overcoming all manner of potential disappointment, setting up what would have been a poetic conclusion to an afternoon of honor for their reliever.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, JEFFREY L.
description: GOLDSTEIN-Jeffrey L. On April 30, 1999. Beloved husband of Carol. Devoted father of Michael and Jaclyn. Adored son of Matthew and Adele. Loving brother of Elaine Perlmutter and Steven. He will be missed by all and remembered forever. Services Monday, 10 AM, at ''Gutterman's, Inc.,'' 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, LI. Interment Beth Moses Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THURSTON, BENJAMIN EASTON, COLONEL
description: THURSTON - Benjamin Easton, Colonel. September 13, 1903-April 14, 1999, Seattle, WA. Col. Thurston was born in Minneapolis, the only son and first born of James Siddall and Mary Winston Thurston. His mother crusaded for child labor laws and was an opium addict, and the children raised themselves. Ben won an appointment to the U.S. Military Academy at West Point, NY, class of 1926, for which he was class historian until his death. Following remote postings of the small peace-time Army of the 1930's, he instructed in English, history, mathematics and chess at West Point. He was stationed at Schofield Barracks at the time of the Japanese attack in December 1941. From 1942-44 he and his family lived in numerous Army bases training newly recruited troops. In 1944 he was appointed battalion commander of the 376th regiment of the 94th division. His battalion was in the European campaign in Patton's army and fought through the Brittany peninsula. They were near Dijon, where the two allied forces joined-those fighting toward the east from Normandy, and those of the FrenchAmerican forces fighting up the Rhone river. They were heavily involved in the Battle of the Bulge, fought through the Alsace campaign, and were among the earliest units of forced crossings of the Saar and Rhine rivers. He was wounded in combat three times. He received three Purple Hearts, three Bronze Stars, the Silver Star, and French Legion of Honor. In 1947 he joined the army of occupation in Europe, serving 4 years in Hoechst, Frankfurt, Berlin and Heidelberg. His duties included organizing defenses for Berlin during the airlift. Col. Thurston, fluent in French, was appointed senior American military advisor during the development of NATO in 194950, working with General Jean de Lattre de Tassigny, who was then and during the war the Commander in Chief of the French Army. In 1955, after the development of mutually adversarial relations between him and the Army, Col. Thurston retired. In the 1970's he wrote his wartime experiences from a notebook he secretly kept during WWII, describing techniques used by this frontline midlevel commander to meet the needs of combat situations, such as preventing frozen feet and counting personnel after a messy night time skirmish, Ugly Duckling, 3rd Battalion, 376th Infantry Regiment, WWII, Europe. Ben married Elizabeth Gay Baxter, also of Minneapolis, in 1933. The marriage was happy and they jointly endured the rigors of military life. However, long separations, the trauma of wartime life, and frequent relocation had their effects and in 1959 the marriage was dissolved-surely also a casualty of the war. Following retirement, Ben participated in numerous endeavors, including grade school and high school teaching and uranium prospecting. Traumatic stress disorder, controlled but always present since the war, was a problem which he faced courageously. Chess was a life-long pursuit at which he achieved national rank and was Arizona Grand Champion. Following his divorce, Ben showed typical resolve in recovering his marital status. A considerable number of shortlived marriages were contracted, found unsuitable, and annulled. In 1963 he married Hazel Turman and made a truly loving life with her until her death. His loving children are Dr. Laura Thurston Gutman, Benjamin Easton Thurston, Robb Olmstead Thurston, Eleanor Turman Williams, Ralph Turman and, recently deceased, Jerry Turman. Grandchildren are Paula Gutman, Catherine Gutman, Laura Thurston Newberry, Stephen Thurston, Michael Thurston, Cindy Williams Knotts, Chris Turman, Linda Turman and (deceased) Susan Turman. A spirit of humility and service informed all aspects of his life and in every situation he sought to think of those least able to assert themselves. An example: his will stipulated that the gravediggers should have a fine meal and drink following his burial. He was an avid scholar, collecting wonderful quotations in English, French and Latin, and used them with great wit and skill. Truly he was a great man.

title: The Way We Live Now: 5-2-99: On Language; Edgy
description: 'Everyone in this room,'' wrote Mark Leyner in The New York Times, quoting a composite TV network executive, ''is committed to developing adventurous, edgy material.''

title: NATO Says G.I. Releases Won't Alter The Air War
description: Administration and Pentagon officials said today that the release of the three American prisoners would not alter the aims or methods of NATO's air war against Yugoslavia, which continued with an unrelenting intensity made possible by clearer skies over the Balkans.

title: Why a Priest
description: As someone sitting in the pew, I'd rather see the seminarians spending their time in soup kitchens, becoming as generous in every act they do as they expect the rest of us to be.

title: W. S. Salant, 87, Economist From the Keynesian School
description: Walter S. Salant, who as a graduate student in the 1930's and later as a Government and private economist helped infuse the revolutionary teachings of John Maynard Keynes into Washington policy deliberations, died on Friday at a hospice near his home in Washington. He was 87.

title: INSIDE
description: Scandal to Be Aired Again

title: After 29 Years, Still Counting Down the Hits
description: ON Cahuenga Boulevard, near Universal Studios, there is a landmark of sorts: a medium-size office building whose upper stories, mirrored in the fashion of the 1980's, angle outward. The structure adjoins the busy Hollywood Freeway; passing motorists get a swift, startling glance of themselves as they speed past.

title: A Haus, Not a Prison
description: To the Editor:

title: Serbs Say Allied Missile Killed 34 On a Bus
description: Under the light of a bright moon tonight, the wreckage of a bus that had been sliced in two, apparently by a NATO missile, still smoldered. At least four bodies and many body parts lay scattered around. The Serbs tonight said 34 bodies had been recovered, and 15 children were believed to be among the dead.

title: Beyond Sequels: It's On to the Hollywood Hybrid
description: THE days of the sequel are numbered. Or rather, Roman numeraled. ''Lethal Weapon,'' the Mel Gibson vehicle that went from zero to IV in 11 years, will have no '99 model. Rocky Balboa's five-bout film career ended in 1990, after a savage critical beating that left him, and moviegoers, with collateral brain damage. Arnold Schwarzenegger, whose most famous film line is, ''I'll be back,'' won't be: The Terminator's term limit was two.

title: Pipe Dream of the Day
description: ''Imagine us goin' off like we really meant to git married, when we ain't even picked out a farm yet! . . . He says Joisey's de best place, and I says Long Island because we'll be near Coney.''

title: Israeli Scientist Reports Discovery of Advance in Code Breaking
description: An Israeli computer scientist is expected to shake up the world of cryptography this week when he introduces a design for a device that could quickly unscramble computer-generated codes that until now have been considered secure enough for financial and government communications.

title: Who Cares if Vouchers Violate the Constitution?
description: To the Editor:

title: Life on the Edge; How High a Fence Is the City Line?
description: CHERRYL MITCHELL is a native New Yorker, born and raised in Brooklyn. But she's quick to tell you she doesn't think much of life in the city, or the ''concrete forest,'' as she calls it.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Thursday about a flutist for the New York City Ballet Orchestra misspelled his surname and misstated his residence. He was Andrew J. Lolya, not Loyla, and lived in Manhattan, not Ossining, N.Y.

title: Monument Will Commemorate Those Buried Beneath NJPAC
description: The memory of 350 people buried in a 19th-century church in Newark where the New Jersey Performing Arts Center now stands will be preserved in a monument to be unveiled June 19. Below the existing arch in Theater Square, opposite the center, the names of those buried at Trinity Episcopal Church between 1809 and 1899, including slaves and free blacks, will be etched on two clear glass pillars about five feet high, flanking a low black granite marker, said Gail Thompson, the arts center's vice president for design and construction. STEVE STRUNSKY

title: POSTINGS: New Jewish Community Center at 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue; From Swimming to Study
description: The Jewish Community Center on the Upper West Side started in 1990 in one room on West 89th Street. Now it occupies 10,000 square feet in the Jewish Guild for the Blind building on West 65th Street. But by January 2001, it plans to move into its own new 137,000-square-foot building on the southwest corner of Amsterdam Avenue and 76th Street.

title: Turf Wars
description: To the Editor:

title: April 25-May 1; U.S. Birth Rate at New Low
description: For the last six years, Federal officials have announced a steady decline in the teen-age birth rate. Now officials say the rate has dipped so sharply that it has helped push the nation's overall birth rate to the lowest point since the Government began keeping records in 1909.

title: Wrong Policy on Sale Of Kings Park Site
description: The Empire State Development Corporation is advocating the wrong policy regarding the sale of the 582-acre Kings Park Psychiatric Center property [''For Psychiatric Center, Park or Development?'' April 11]. Their proposed land-use strategy flies in the face of an integrated plan advanced by local planners, environmentalists, business groups, residents and legislators that achieves the same financial goals set by the state while preserving more open space desired by the community.

title: Laura Kaplan and Joshua Avigad
description: Dr. Laura Miriam Kaplan, the daughter of Carol Kaplan-Lyss and Lawrence P. Kaplan, both of St. Louis, was married last evening to Joshua Michael Avigad, a son of Rosalyn and Nathaniel Avigad of Yonkers. Rabbi James Goodman officiated at the St. Louis Club in Clayton, Mo. Rabbi Samuel Press, the bridegroom's uncle, took part in the ceremony.

title: Drivers Enjoying Life as Brat Pack
description: For a small band of Champ Car drivers, life doesn't necessarily slow down once they have climbed out of the cockpit. Win or lose, the good times for these twenty-something bachelors start after the race is finished.

title: Giving Americans an International Outlook
description: A New York taxi driver who picked up Daljit Dhaliwal near the United Nations not long ago refused, with star-struck finality, to take her money for a trip across town. ''He said, 'You're the news reader from ITN,' '' she recalled a couple of days later.

title: The Nets Catch Glimpse Of a Possible Future
description: Kerry Kittles waited a long time to have his best game of the season, but it led the Nets to victory.

title: A Swell Party for Will, Williams and Company
description: THE quotation that sums up the New Jersey Shakespeare Festival's 1999 season is not ''All the world's a stage,'' or ''Play on,'' or ''A hit, a very palpable hit,'' or ''The play's the thing,'' or ''Such stuff as dreams are made on.''

title: The Way We Live Now: 5-2-99; What They Were Thinking
description: Salve Bernabe, with her daughter Martha

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KASSOF, ELAINE, NEE FREEDMAN
description: KASSOF-Elaine, nee Freedman, formerly Hempling. April 30, in Pompano Beach, FL, after a valiant fight against cancer. She will be dearly missed by her children, Linda Candib and Richard Markx, and their spouses, Richie and Nadjia. She was loved by her grandchildren, Isaac, Jamel, Leyla and Jallel; and her niece and nephew, Carole and Jules Freedman. Her memory will continue on with her friends, and especially her companion, Bill Epstein. Memorial reception to be held at Aaron Funeral Home, 5899 West Oakland Park Blvd, Lauderhill, FL, 800-940-4272, 11 AM to 1 PM, Friday, May 7.

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from the most recent listing to contract.

title: The Nation: No Benefits, But No Jobs; Welfare's Missing-in-Action
description: They seem, at this point, to be the disappeared, the missing, the lost in action of the new welfare era.

title: Hagerstown Journal; Churchgoers' Discount Creates Rift at Ballpark
description: Out here in western Maryland, more than an hour's drive from any big city, diversions are where you find them. For decades, area residents have enjoyed a fair share of them watching minor league baseball in Municipal Stadium, a tidy little ballpark of 4,600 seats on the edge of town.

title: Making What's Public Private, and Private Public
description: NEARLY 10 years after his death, the work of the sculptor Scott Burton continues to give esthetic pleasure as well as perform a useful function on the streets of Manhattan. In the plazas alongside the PaineWebber building on Sixth Avenue at 51st Street, Burton created two ''room settings'' with his archetypal conceptions of furniture in dark green granite: massive settees in the ''salon'' on the north side and conical cafe tables and seats for the ''dining room'' on the south. He would say of these objects, ''What office workers do in their lunch hour is more important than my pushing the limits of my self-expression.''

title: HERBERT D. KELLEHER
description: In 1990, when Southwest Airlines was completing its new headquarters at Love Field in Dallas, the chief executive, Herbert D. Kelleher, looked at plans for the board room and decided they were too grandiose for an airline that started in the 1970's with flight attendants in hot pants. In scaling back, a closet was created between the board room and Mr. Kelleher's windowless office. The closet, neatly lined with shelves, has since become Mr. Kelleher's sanctum sanctorum and a shrine to the irreverent yet highly successful culture he has built at Southwest.

title: Mothers and Daughters Raise Funds for Charity
description: WHEN Carolyn Glickstein walks down the street in Edgemont where she was raised, she sees the trees planted as saplings by her mother grown big and shading the block. For Mrs. Glickstein, the trees are a symbol of the roots her late mother put down in the community and of her efforts to give something back to the place where she brought up her family.

title: Strange Fits of Passion
description: THE HIDDEN WORDSWORTH Poet, Lover, Rebel, Spy. By Kenneth R. Johnston. Illustrated. 965 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $45.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: The Green

title: Charles Gordon, 93, I.N.S. Counsel
description: Charles Gordon, a son of immigrants who became the general counsel of the Immigration and Naturalization Service and the founding author of the 20-volume treatise Immigration Law and Procedure, died on Wednesday at Bay Medical Center in Panama City, Fla. He was 93 and lived in Potomac, Md., and Panama City.

title: Reading the Future in Readings of 'Rusalka'
description: IN the first Czechoslovak elections after the 1989 Velvet Revolution, the victorious Civic Forum party campaigned on the slogan ''Back Into Europe.'' This attempt to fuse political and geographical reality (as Czechs are fond of pointing out, Prague is significantly west of Vienna) has only partially been realized in the decade since. While the Czech Republic appears to be in no hurry to join the European Union, it has joined NATO, and gaudy advertisements and pizzerias are now firmly entrenched in Czech life. This ambivalence about internationalization is also visible in Czech cultural life. The recent vicissitudes of Antonin Dvorak's opera ''Rusalka'' provide an interesting example.

title: Discovering the Allure of a European Summer
description: THE wedding lasted from late one August afternoon through daybreak. At a long table beneath the shady trees in Normandy, three generations toasted the newlyweds with homemade Calvados and unlabeled champagne from the in-laws' vineyards. The table was artfully strewn with fruit and flowers. Chickens plucked the meadow grass; children feasted on peaches nearly burst with sweetness. I danced with a queue of expectant boy cousins under the 3 A.M. stars.

title: Light in Body and in Alcohol
description: The old-fashioned cord trussing the cork stopper in Mionetto's nonvintage Prosecco di Valdobbiadene hints at the homey charm of the frizzante -- semisparkling -- dry, pale-straw-colored wine that has long quickened Venetians' urbane appetites.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Streetscapes /West End Collegiate Church; Restoring a Distinctive Dutch-Style Building's Roof
description: THE picturesque terra cotta and tile peaks of West End Collegiate Church, at 77th Street and West End Avenue, marked the center of a growing collection of Dutch-style buildings on the avenue in the 1890's.

title: Antley Loses Weight and Wins Race
description: Eight months ago, Chris Antley was a broken-down jockey. His weight had ballooned to 147 pounds, or at least that was the number he saw when he had the guts to look at the scale. He had returned home to Columbia, S.C., to live with his folks. He was lost, and his father, Les, tried to buck him up.

title: DataBank: April 26-30; An Off-Key Finale for a Spectacular April
description: The Dow Jones industrial average ended the last day of April with a whimper, suffering its biggest loss of the month on concerns the economy was growing too fast, threatening to hasten inflation and cause interest rates to rise.

title: A Season Is Hanging In Balance
description: Jeff Van Gundy has peeked at the scoreboard, spun the dial on the satellite dish and even sat at the breakfast table with his wife, Kim, and figured out the playoff possibilities. And while it is still possible for the Knicks to finish anywhere from the fifth spot in the Eastern Conference all the way down to the 10th spot, the math has boiled down to a seemingly simple equation: if the Knicks can win two games, they will be assured of a playoff berth.

title: Food; Say Cheese
description: The swath of time between spring and summer is like a patch of freshly mowed grass. Nothing very bad can happen during this season. And if it does, so what? The grass will grow back within a week.

title: The Lucky Label That Saved Soul
description: IN the 1960's, soul music came into its own, a volatile mixture of the raw, confessional emotion of black gospel and the enduring lyrical themes of the blues.
