Divided into the poppy Northern sound of Motown and the ''deep soul'' of Memphis and other Southern centers, it provided a soundtrack for emerging black pride, a touchstone for many white rock bands and some of the most transcendent popular music.

title: Why a Priest
description: I hope that the seminarians featured in Jennifer Egan's article (April 4) are not indicative of all those preparing for ordained ministry. The new millennium needs priests who are preoccupied with serving at the feet of the poor rather than with control and patriarchy.

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: ADAPTATIONS from a Pulitzer Prize-winning novel, a Shakespearan comedy and aDaphne du Maurier story dominate the week's film menu on television, which also includes a melodrama with a ''Thank'' - like climax.

title: White Flight and Its Urban Aftermath
description: THE impact of two decades of white flight from American cities and the impact of new arrivals in Manhattan and Brooklyn will be discussion topics in ''My, How You've Changed! The New Urban Landscape,'' starting at 7 P.M. tomorrow at the Central Library in Brooklyn.

title: Dividing Perennial Borders
description: PERENNIAL borders have made a big comeback in the last few years. There are many reasons, including aggressive promotion efforts by the nursery industry.

title: For Newark Council Members, African Trip Draws Criticism
description: In a publicly financed show of sibling amity, members of the Newark City Council are planning a two-week trip to the Republic of Ghana later this month.

title: Ideas & Trends: The Fat Get Fatter; Overweight Was Bad Enough
description: BETTYE TRAVIS is 5 feet 5 and weighs 300 pounds. So when the National Institutes of Health broadened its definition of overweight last year using a gauge called body mass index, Ms. Travis, 47, the proprietor of a cake- and candy-making supply store in San Francisco, didn't bother to calculate hers. She said she didn't need the Government to tell her she weighs too much.

title: A 31-1 Long Shot Captures the Derby
description: Charismatic, ridden by Chris Antley, right, was one of the lightly regarded horses in this year's jam-packed Kentucky Derby, but he beat everyone to the finish line yesterday to capture the 125th Run for the Roses and send the trainer D. Wayne Lukas to the winner's circle for the fourth time.

title: Style; Zen and the Art of Fashion
description: Lee, a young man with good cheekbones from a poor family, grew up where there was no Banana Republic. He was not schooled in the subtle ways of J. Crew, either. He simply wore what was cheap and easy -- T-shirts, fleece, sneakers and sweats that did not ring of chic or knowingness. When he moved to Manhattan for college and settled into a stimulating new life of study and play, Lee remained badly dressed and adamantly unstylish.

title: Defining 'Disability'
description: To the Editor:

title: Catamaran Sailor Plotting The Revenge of the Tomato
description: For Hans Meijer, a multihull sailor from Virginia Beach, Va., a tomato is anything but a piece of fruit. It has got him into trouble twice now in ocean racing, and both times, he has had to head for the beach. Not a good place for tomatoes.

title: La Comradessa
description: Shadows, Fire, Snow

title: BENEFITS
description: Back to Vaudeville

title: Princeton Perfect In Regular Season
description: Princeton's men's heavyweight varsity crew remained undefeated, capping its regular season yesterday with a Content Cup victory over Brown on the Lake Carnegie course in Princeton, N.J. Brown, ranked No. 4 in eastern rowing coming into yesterday's race, made No. 1-ranked Princeton work for its victory.

title: Littleton Takes The Blame
description: Name a cause, and someone will find support for it. Shootings occur when you put guns in people's hands or violent movies in their VCR's, claims one group of Americans. On the contrary, argues another, kids go on rampages when you take God out of their schools and discipline out of their families.

title: Mariana Barzun, Jonathan Mensch
description: Mariana Lowell Barzun, a daughter of Serita Winthrop Alexander of New York and Roger M. Barzun of Concord, Mass., was married yesterday to Jonathan Lee Mensch. He is a son of Prof. Elizabeth B. Mensch of Buffalo and Steven H. Mensch of Rhinebeck, N.Y., at whose house the ceremony was performed by the Rev. Toni Smith, a United Church of Christ minister.

title: Stadium Lost: How Rowland's Biggest Coup Became His Worst Defeat
description: When the owner of the New England Patriots flew to Hartford to visit his sweetheart deal for the last time on Thursday, he did what he had always done, according to Connecticut officials: He asked for something more.

title: The Doctor Is In Trouble
description: Yeow! Or should I say meow? Did Randy Cohen really compare a living, breathing cat to a recreational device? Pets are not toys. The owner of the sick Manx should pay for its medical care because the cat needs treatment, not because the owner needs some fun.

title: Harassment Claim Wins Inmate $100,000
description: An inmate who claimed that he had been harassed and discriminated against because he complained about corruption at Sing Sing state prison has been awarded $100,000 in damages by a Federal jury.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Best Bet

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAUER, SYLVIA (GREENBERG)
description: BAUER-Sylvia (Greenberg), 91 years, of Brooklyn, New York, and Haskell, N.J. Passed away on April 24, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Arthur J. Bauer, survived by daughter Merle Kessler (Karkur, Israel), grandson Dennis Bauer Kessler (Nara, Japan), granddaughter Jeanne Kessler and great-granddaughter Zoe Kessler Beriss (New Orleans, LA).

title: Never Say Die at Intel
description: At age 62, Andrew S. Grove sees a big difference between today's Internet entrepreneurs and the founding team of Intel three decades ago: himself, Gordon Moore and Robert Noyce. ''At Intel, we never discussed an exit strategy,'' he said during a recent stop in New York. Squadrons of Silicon Valley start-ups, he added, think that if they position themselves to intersect with the ambitions of, say, Cisco Systems or Microsoft, they will probably be bought out in 18 months. ''At Intel in the early days,'' he said, ''we had this naive notion that we were building the next I.B.M. or something.'' STEVE LOHR

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BUDOW, SUNNY (SPRINTZIE)
description: BUDOW-Sunny (Sprintzie). Hello, love-15 years without you. You are always in our hearts. Saul, Fern, Stephen and Family

title: Q and A
description: Touring National Parks

title: In Search of 4-Star, 4-Paw Lodging
description: NO vacation for us this year. We've checked out all the available accommodations and half are already booked, while the rest are small, poorly decorated, hot, noisy and smelly. Room service offers only a few choices at restricted hours, and there is absolutely no entertainment.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: THE ROOTS OF ROMANTICISM

title: Marnie Naiburg and Jeffrey Smith
description: Marnie Blake Naiburg, a daughter of June and Eric Naiburg of Dix Hills, N.Y., was married last evening to Jeffrey Chad Smith, a son of Carol and Steven Smith of Great Neck, N.Y. Rabbi Joseph Potasnick performed the ceremony at Temple Beth Torah in Melville, N.Y.

title: Habitats /195 Hudson Street; Raw Space in TriBeCa
description: THERE is a huge puddle in the middle of the loft that has just been sold for $577,000 to David and Julienne Dweck. The real estate people don't particularly want it to be photographed, but the Dwecks don't mind. When they first saw the place, it had exposed pipes, and no windows. ''You had to have some imagination,'' said Mr. Dweck. So a puddle in their future living room bothers them not at all.

title: Protest Greets N.R.A. Meeting in Denver
description: As more than 7,000 protesters demonstrated outside, the National Rifle Association held its annual meeting in a hotel ballroom here today, rallying defiantly against calls for restricting guns after the school shootings in nearby Littleton.

title: Gloria Barragan, Joseph Tooma
description: Gloria Juliette Barragan, the daughter of Gloria and Alvaro Barragan of Westbury, N.Y., was married there on Friday to Joseph Tooma, the son of Juliette and Saleeba Tooma of Brooklyn. The Rev. Martin Klein performed the ceremony at St. Brigid's Roman Catholic Church.

title: Depictions of Lincoln Shown in Indiana
description: Fort Wayne, Ind., is off the usual tourist track, but history buffs and political junkies may just want to put it on their itineraries this year. ''Lincoln From Life: As the Artists Saw Him,'' at the Lincoln Museum there through Oct. 17, brings together 46 paintings, sculptures, photographs and sketches that Lincoln posed for between 1860, when he was elected President, until his assassination in 1865. Several works, which come from more than a dozen public and private collections as well as the Lincoln Museum, have never been lent before.

title: Wenke Thoman, William S. Sterns 3d
description: Wenke Helene Thoman and William S. Sterns 3d were married last evening by the Rev. Charles Amstein, a Presbyterian minister, at the Knickerbocker Club in New York.

title: Cheerleading Changes as Boys Join Sidelines; Stereotypes Slip Away, Attitudes Shift And a Sport Calls for More Acrobatics
description: Standing 6 feet 2 and weighing 205 pounds, Michael DellaPenna, 17, is the captain of both the football and track teams at Eastchester High School here. Given his physical stature, athletic prowess, rugged good looks and popularity among his peers, neither accomplishment is very surprising.

title: Artists' Debt To the Past More Than Passing
description: THE classical world, especially ancient Greece, continues to be meaningful and relevant.

title: SCHOOLS; Campus Tours: The Video and the Reality
description: In the mid-1980's, Sami Kramon, a college-adviser-for hire in Bergen County, asked her husband, Cliff, to videotape tours of campuses near the places he visited for his clothing manufacturing business. The tapes helped the parents she worked with save money and time visiting schools. Her clients continue to use the tapes, but the Kramons also sell them to others.

title: Government Is Behind Decline in Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Up-to-Date Ideas From Emerging Talents
New Alliance Highlights Ebb of Russian Clout
description: In the shadow of NATO's extravagant 50th anniversary celebrations last weekend, representatives of five former Soviet republics gathered at the Washington embassy of Uzbekistan to signal their growing distance from Moscow, another rebuke for the world's largest ex-superpower.

title: Lives; The Interpreter
description: I can still visualize the dimly lighted corridors of the labyrinthine ''Palace of Justice,'' and especially Room No. 167, where the interrogation took place, furnished with a polished table, a wooden bench and two shoddy chairs. I'll never forget the sensation I felt when he entered the room, an icy chill that turned my breath into frost.

title: A Migration That's Becoming Less Seasonal Every Year
description: ONE sure sign of spring: Jack Williams is heading north.

title: It's the Extras That Count
description: VIRTUALLY every manufacturer has minivan ergonomics down pat. After all, functionality, comfort and convenience are the reasons people drive these mobile dens. So other factors now count: Four doors have become essential for convenience (and for children's safety on one-way streets). Power-operated sliding doors win extra credit. I also appreciate extra horsepower and nimble, car-like handling. Clever ideas, like well-placed storage nets and power outlets, are a big plus.

title: Tales Out of Italy
description: ADULTERY And Other Diversions. By Tim Parks. 184 pp. New York: Arcade Publishing. $23.95.

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH: Chris Eigeman; Last Exit for Whining
description: WILL it fit in the Subaru?''

title: The Quiet American
description: A DANGEROUS FRIEND

title: F.Y.I.
description: Rockettes' Trajectory

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: WHITE OLEANDER

title: Devils' Victory Could Ease Their Past Disappointments
description: Jaromir Jagr's status is still uncertain, but the Devils have health concerns of their own with the injured center Sergei Nemchinov as they hurtle toward Game 6 against the Penguins here Sunday with a long-time-no-see objective: to put a playoff opponent away.

title: POSTINGS: Converting Old New York Post Building; From Offices To Apartments
description: With its $20-million conversion from an office to an apartment building nearly complete, leasing will begin today for the 192 rentals at 75 West Street in Manhattan's financial district.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Three Shows at Neuberger

title: The Real Divide
description: Missing from Berman's essay on the cultural war between insiders and outsiders was the real war: class war. Clinton's consistently high poll numbers during the Lewinsky fiasco were based not on some cosmic dominance of the hippie heathens over the Christians, but on the fact that the have-nots simply did not care. Could Clinton's impeachment help retrain formerly well-paid factory workers about to be dumped into the service industry? It meant absolutely nothing to so many people, and the indifference was so widespread that many in the G.O.P. mistook it for moral decay instead of distracted desperation.

title: Sherlock Holmes's Maker
description: TELLER OF TALES

title: More Melancholy Danes
description: BREATH AND SHADOWS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JONES, REES
description: JONES-Rees. Died peacefully on April 27, 1999, at Beth Israel Hospital. Survived by his wife Betty, family members and many friends. He enjoyed life fully with his love of music, travel, lawn bowling, and the company of friends and family. Memorial service will be held at First Presbyterian Church, 12th St, and Fifth Ave., Manhattan. Sunday, May 16th, 1999, at 2:30pm. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions to First Presbyterian Church Music Fund, 12 W. 12 St., NY, NY 10011, would be appreciated.

title: The Way We Live Now: 5-2-99: The Ethicist; Departure Delays
description: Just as I was about to leave my girlfriend, she learned that her father had a severe illness. Figuring it would be unnecessarily cruel to saddle her with a breakup, I kept my feelings to myself. The problem is, her dad remains ill, and I can't figure out when it would be right for me to leave. I have enough affection for her that I want to be honest -- but what is my ethical obligation here? - T. C., Los Angeles

title: Donny and Marie the Latest To Crown Miss America
description: Since Bert Parks, the Miss America's Pageant's legendary host, was fired in 1980 by the Atlantic City-based pageant organization, his numerous replacements have had short shelf lives.

title: The Poet and the Half-Scalped Woman
description: WHO -- Penelope Scambly Schott, 56, of Rocky Hill, a poet and faculty consultant at Thomas Edison State College in Trenton. Mrs. Schott's most recent work, ''Penelope: The Story of the Half-Scalped Woman,'' is a narrative poem based on a true story from early New Jersey history.

title: April 25-May 1; Justices to Rule on Tobacco
description: It was far from a victory in the tobacco wars, but it was the best the Clinton Administration could hope for from the Supreme Court. The Justices agreed to decide whether the Food and Drug Administration has the authority to regulate tobacco products as a drug. While a ruling is perhaps a year off, the Court thus kept alive the prospect of Federal regulation of smoking, which appeared dead last summer when a Federal appeals court ruled that Congress had never given the F.D.A. jurisdiction over cigarettes. LINDA GREENHOUSE

title: Fire and Ice In the Guise of Jewelry
description: Jewelry inspired by water in various forms -- melting, freezing or sloshing -- is the focus of Chortip Boonto's month-old East Village store, which bears her name.

title: A Few Words in Defense of Swag
description: SITTING on a shelf in my office are two snow-globe paperweights, each depicting a scene from the 1996 Coen Brothers film ''Fargo.'' In one of them, a teeny Marge Gunderson is squatting by an overturned vehicle and a bloody dead body; in the other, she is pointing a gun at the equally teeny figure of villain Gaear Grimsrud as he stuffs what's left of Steve Buscemi's character into the wood-chipper. The snowflakes in the latter globe are both white and red. It's really cool.

title: Honesty's Threat
description: To the Editor:

title: Saving a Little for Next Year
description: Flowers of early bulbs have faded and it is time to start deadheading so that energy from photosynthesis is not spent producing seed, but is stored for next year's display. Except for appearance, it is not necessary to deadhead narcissus. Do not disturb the foliage of any spring flowering bulbs until it dies back naturally (at least six weeks after bloom).

title: Out of Asia: The Move Toward Global Regulation
description: THE Asian crisis is subsiding. Even Russia is reviving a bit. But for all the relief that brings, the global financial meltdown remains a haunting memory -- not as searing as the Depression for a generation of Americans, but scary enough. And just as the Depression brought regulation to America's financial markets, the Asian and Russian crises are forcing rules on the global market.

title: The Way We Live Now: 5-2-99: Word & Image; Our Humanity Vs. Their Sovereignty
description: Perhaps Bill Clinton really believed that he was going to war to crush the seeds of World War III in the Balkan morass. Or maybe he decided that NATO needed a new cause to refresh itself. Or he became convinced that saving Western Europe from a flood of Albanian refugees was a vital American interest. Maybe he was just furious at that man, Slobodan Milosevic, for refusing to let Kosovo move toward independence like the rest of the former Yugoslav federation.

title: Obsessed With a Vision Of Existential Despair
description: IF Albert Camus had made dances instead of writing fiction, they might have looked like the work of the choreographer John Jasperse. The final image of Mr. Jasperse's ''Waving to You From Here,'' which was performed at Dance Theater Workshop in Manhattan two years ago, still haunts with its depiction of despair. A false ceiling, which had slowly lowered over the dancers' heads during the hourlong concert, finally collapsed on them. A metaphor, in part, for the shrinking dance world, devastated by AIDS and a declining audience, it was also a literal image of the experimental artist being crushed by the world he has created.

title: Congress Weighs Bill to Expand the Cartel Letting Northeast Dairy Farmers Set Prices
description: In a fight pitting farmers' incomes against consumers' pocketbooks, Congress has begun a fierce debate over legislation that would allow dairy farmers in New York, New Jersey and other states to charge more for milk.

title: When She Talks, Stocks Move
description: ACCORDING to its advertising, Dean Witter measures its success ''one investor at a time.'' But it might also say that behind each of its 11,450 brokers is one Leah Modigliani.

title: Firefighters' Concerns
description: A new coalition representing union firefighters from seven Westchester municipalities is calling for professional fire departments in every city, town and village in the county.

title: Lost Kidney Is Found
description: As a transplant patient waited for surgery at Westchester Medical Center in Valhalla on April 20, his new kidney was mistakenly tossed into the garbage by a worker cleaning up between surgeries, the hospital said.

title: Ms. Franklin, Mr. Clephane-Hagar
description: Cynthia Aldrich Franklin and Anthony R. Clephane-Hagar were married last evening by the Rev. Dr. Eugene S. Callender, a Presbyterian minister, in St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University in New York.

title: A Housing Phenomenon: Birds Using Light Posts
description: To the Editor:

title: After the Violence
description: To the Editor:

title: The Way We Live Now: 5-2-99; The Western Front
description: Stuck in traffic, in Missoula, waiting for a light, I was startled when a fight broke out. Some young men, they looked like athletic college students, must have given the fellows in the pickup truck behind them some rudeness, maybe some gestures. Whatever, it was a very bad idea.

title: The World; War Protesters Keep Their Powder Dry
description: IN the debate over NATO's bombing of Serbia, the voice of the American antiwar movement has not been heard to any great degree. Once it was so loud that it helped end the Vietnam War.

title: A Perpetual Winner
description: Anyone annoyed by people who can do several things well, without sweating, should avoid Pamela Thomas-Graham. The first black woman partner at McKinsey & Company, Ms. Thomas-Graham is a Phi Beta Kappa graduate of Harvard College and Harvard Law School. Harvard Business School, too.

title: Sir, Yes, Sir! A Workout With Attitude
description: THE Marines have boot camp at Parris Island, Westport's weekend warriors have Sherwood Island.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: Respect An Exploration. By Sara Lawrence-Lightfoot. Merloyd Lawrence/Perseus, $23.

title: Ms. Gaffin, Mr. Russell
description: Jennifer Marissa Gaffin, a clinical social worker, and Christopher Lee Russell, a restaurateur, are to be married in New York this evening by Rabbi Steven Carr Reuben at Parkview at the Boathouse in Central Park.

title: Music for Driving on a Dark Highway
description: GODSPEED YOU BLACK EMPEROR: 'SLOW RIOT FOR NEW ZERO KANADA'

title: In Chicago, Layers of History but Uncertain Future
description: A TUMULTUOUS strike more than a century ago settled the question of whether the model town of Pullman -- built practically in a single stroke by George M. Pullman to house thousands of workers of the Pullman Palace Car Company -- was a new American utopia.

title: Q&A/Carlton Thomas Kissner; A White Leader for an N.A.A.C.P. Chapter
description: IT is a job he did not want because he thinks he is unqualified by virtue of his race. Carlton Thomas (Tom) Kissner, who is white, was recently elected president of the Port Chester-Rye Chapter of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, a post he said he strongly feels should be held by a black person.

title: Bus Death Suit Settled
description: The parents of a 14-year-old Irvington High School student who was dragged to her death by a school bus three years ago have settled out of court a multimillion-dollar lawsuit against the bus driver and Advance Transit, a Yonkers bus company, said Donald N. Silverman, a lawyer for Worby Borowick Groner in White Plains.

title: Fire in a Crowded Home of Immigrants Kills 3 and Injures 16 on L.I.
description: A roaring fire that may have been touched off by gas fumes engulfed a one-family house crowded with 33 Salvadoran immigrants in Huntington Station, N.Y., early yesterday, killing 3 people, including a mother and daughter, and leaving 16 injured and 30 survivors homeless, Suffolk County officials said.

title: Orchard St. Plan Provokes Doubts
description: In 1994, more than 50 red, green and yellow street signs announcing the Orchard Street Bargain District appeared in the historic 17-block area near the Williamsburg Bridge. Ever since, merchants have used private, city and state money to try and restore the district's past vibrancy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SELTZER, HARRY M.
description: SELTZER-Harry M. On April 29, 1999. Beloved husband of Marilyn (nee Bonacio). Father of Merrill (Laurence Kotok), Matthew (Cindy Parnes) and Diana (Yossi BenDavid). Adored grandfather of David and Rachel Kotok, Samantha and Molly Seltzer, and Daniel BenDavid. Dear brother of Sophie Rose and Oscar Seltzer. Services Sunday, 2:30 p.m. at ''Gutterman's'' 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, Long Island.

title: Parties Under the Stars? Liquor Officials Say No
description: It seems that the owners of a catering hall called Tribeca Rooftop may have been a bit hasty in the choice of a name for their business, which is on the top floor of a 12-story building at 480 Canal Street, near Desbrosses Street.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BERLER, ANDREW
description: BERLER - Andrew. 1949 - 1994. Mom, Dad and Ellen and all your friends will always remember all the wonderful attributes you possessed. We miss you so much.

title: Our Towns; Under Siege By Stray Cats And Strangers
description: ROBERT FELDMAN, a New Paltz village trustee, conceded that the Village Board had tried this ruse before: floating a provocative proposal to force residents to confront a difficult problem. It's just that none of the proposals had ever involved killing stray cats.

title: Christian Stone, Kimberly Blaivas
description: Kimberly Blaivas, a daughter of Susan Blaivas and Dr. Jerry Blaivas of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., was married last evening to Christian Benjamin Stone, the son of Elizabeth and Gregory Stone of Mystic, Conn. Rabbi Gerald I. Weider officiated at Tappan Hill in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: Jennifer Ozer, Michael Korten
description: Jennifer Dale Ozer and Michael Scott Korten were married last evening by Cantor Henry Weintraub at the Inter-Continental Hotel in New York.

title: Some Top Relievers Can't Close the Deal
description: It's the last three outs that determine if a manager will whisper those three little words to his closer. Not that the relief pitcher is looking for his manager's love, but he does want his respect, as well as that of his teammates and his team's opponents. The best way to get all of that is to get the last three outs. But it's easier said than done.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLAN, AARON
description: KAPLAN-Aaron. On April 30, 1999. Dearest husband of Marion (Mitzi). Loving father of Emily, Nathan and Bennett. Cherished Grampsy of Sarah and Eva. Poet, wordsmith, author of couplets. He will be profoundly missed. Service Sunday, 12:15 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Lord of the Drosophilae
description: TIME, LOVE, MEMORY

title: Pittsburgh
description: It may be no surprise that Pittsburgh has direct flights to London, Paris and Frankfurt, but consider this: many of the tourists here have come from Europe to the capital of culture in the Alleghenies.

title: Add Egg Yolks And Voila! Art!
description: 'MAKING MASTERPIECES'

title: Federal Grants Will Finance Police Officers in Schools
description: The Federal Department of Justice announced last week that 24 New Jersey municipalities will receive a total of $7.7 million to hire police officers to be assigned to schools. The grants are part of $70 million being distributed to 330 communities nationwide. The timing, after the killings at a high school in Littleton, Colo., was a coincidence; the grants are part of the COPS in Schools community-policing program announced by President Clinton in October. In most instances, municipalities receive $125,000 for each police officer's first three years of salary and benefits. KAREN DeMASTERS

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FRIEDMAN, BELLA KANDELL
description: FRIEDMAN-Bella Kandell. 16th of Iyar, 1949. A day has not gone by when you have not been in my thoughts. You left too soon. I've missed you. Bina

title: Why Are We In Kosovo?
description: The other day a friend from home, New York, called me in Bari -- where I am living for a couple of months -- to ask whether I am all right and inquired in passing whether I can hear sounds of the bombing. I reassured her that not only could I not hear the bombs dropping on Belgrade and Novi Sad and Pristina from downtown Bari, but even the planes taking off from the nearby NATO base of Gioia del Colle are quite inaudible. Though it is easy to mock my geographyless American friend's vision of European countries being only slightly larger than postage stamps, her Tiny Europe seems a nice complement to the widely held vision of Helpless Europe being dragged into a bellicose folly by Big Bad America.

title: The Guns Were Hidden, Not the Writers
description: THE SETTING -- Writers hobnobbing at Elaine's is nothing new, but on Thursday evening the place was crawling with cops, or, more accurately, cops who would be writers, and writers who would be cops.

title: On the Run From Taormina To Torcello
description: IN May, Italian students go ''in giro.'' In other words, they take their school field trips. We encountered our first group in Reggio di Calabria on the southwestern tip of Italy, where we had stopped to see the Riace bronzes, a pair of Greek statues discovered in 1972 off a nearby coast by a scuba diver on holiday. The Riace bronzes are in the basement of the town's sleepy museum.

title: April 25-May 1; Arkansas Lawmakers Indicted
description: The 1997 session of the Arkansas General Assembly was widely derided around Little Rock because of the large number of legislators who found legal ways to profit personally from state contracts. Though ethics laws were later tightened, Arkansans didn't learn until now how bad things might have been.

title: Pity the Children
description: To the Editor:

title: Nassau to Appeal Jury Awards in Beatings
description: Nassau County officials are expected to appeal two separate Federal jury awards last week totaling $2.5 million to two men who were awaiting trial at the Nassau County Jail in East Meadow when they were beaten by fellow prisoners.

title: April 25-May 1; Another Link With Mars
description: There was a whiff of planetary mortality in the latest evidence that Mars, though barren now, once had it all: water, shifting tectonic plates, even stirrings of life -- the makings, in short, of Earth today.

title: A British Bad Boy Finds His Way Back Into the Light
description: IF life were fair, Constant Lambert would be known as the English Leonard Bernstein. A staggeringly assured composer-conductor who became famous in his early 20's, he was irresistibly drawn to the ballet throughout his brief but brilliant career, collaborating as closely with Frederick Ashton as Bernstein did with Jerome Robbins. A fan of jazz, Sousa marches and the Marx Brothers, he led a rackety private life -- his extramarital affair with the adolescent Margot Fonteyn was the talk of London -- and penned a notorious sequence of pornographic limericks. (It was Lambert who immortalized in verse the Bishop of Central Japan, and what he did with his fan.) On top of all this, he tossed off in his spare time one of the shrewdest books ever written about modern music, ''Music Ho!: A Study of Music in Decline.''

title: Tootsies
description: GIRLFRIEND

title: The Nation: Alma Maters; Two Words Behind the Massacre
description: IF much about the murderous assault by two students in Littleton, Colo., seemed so alien and bizarre as to be almost ungraspable, there was at least one part of the story that seemed as familiar as Big Macs and oldies radio.

title: In the Region /Connecticut; A $9-Million Expansion for Norwalk's Aquarium
description: A $9-MILLION expansion of the $30-million Maritime Aquarium now under way in South Norwalk is the most dramatic of a number of changes in progress or planned in a formerly rundown area that has sought a new identity in recent years.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SPINA, PHILIP
description: SPINA-Philip. Died April 30, 1989. Then, now and forever is our love for you. Jo, Gerard, Phyllis and Dian

title: The Logic of Kosovo
description: Slobodan Milosevic's promise yesterday to release three captive American soldiers suggests that he may now be looking to end the war in Yugoslavia. But unless a diplomatic settlement materializes quickly, the war could well extend through the spring, if not beyond. As the American people brace for a sustained military campaign, they deserve a clearer account of America's goals from President Clinton and of how the national interest would be served by achieving them. Anyone who doubts the demand for a compelling rationale for the war need look no further than the House of Representatives, which last week stunned Washington by refusing on a tie vote to support the NATO air offensive.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARRIS, FLORENCE
description: HARRIS-Florence. On April 30, 1999. Dear sister of the late Lewis Harris. Beloved aunt of Mark and David Harris of New York City. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. Graveside services Sunday, 1 PM, New Montefiore Cemetery.

title: Should R-Rated Films Mix With Three R's?
description: NORMA LAKE, a social studies teacher, said her sophomores' questions, during a field trip to see the R-rated ''Schindler's List'' and meet a concentration camp survivor, spoke for themselves. ''They were stunning in their grasp of the material,'' she said.

title: Enjoying Crafts, One Piece at a Time
description: Porcelain rats at the bank? A humidor at the library? These are just two of the objets de craft that the Peters Valley Gallery Without Walls has spread throughout Morristown. Each of the nine display sites provides a pedestal for the work of a New Jersey craft artist.

title: Watered Down? Never
description: Watercolor painting is flourishing in South Jersey. Numerous opportunities for exhibition, as well as professional organizations like the New Jersey Water Color Society, the Garden State Watercolor Society and the Philadelphia Water Color Club, encourage artists specializing in aqueous media. This spring, the Perkins Center for the Arts in Moorestown has again organized a formidable juried show.

title: Failure Holds New Fear for Florida Schools
description: Asked to write his name, Johnathan Rodriguez, a lanky first grader at the Orlo Vista Elementary School here, bent over his desk and seized his pen with the intensity of a surgeon about to use a scalpel.

title: Teeing Off Into the Past
description: THE golf ball flew in the air when I hit it, but my arms tingled with the vibration of impact still traveling up the wooden shaft of the bizarre but beautiful golf club in my hand, a driver with a club face shaped like the snout of a horse. On the first hole at Oakhurst Links in West Virginia, established in 1884 and the first organized golf club with a golf course in America, I hadn't hit a splendid drive. Still, the ball did arc over an unnerving pond to land in the fairway -- my humble opening shot on an intriguing journey to the past.

title: More Study Is Needed On Pleasantville School
description: Regarding the article on schools [''School Districts Ready Bond Issues for Vote,'' April 18], I would like to call attention to the amount of work done by the school board and Phase 2 committee in respect to school expansion in Pleasantville.

title: Heart Transplant Patient Was One of the Lucky Ones
description: To the Editor:

title: American Treasures
description: To the Editor:

title: A Noisy and a Silent Protest
description: Asserting that a policy instituted by Community School Board 9 effectively censors some people who wish to speak at its monthly meetings, two community groups staged strikingly dissimilar protests last week. Members of one group shouted at the board and shouted chants; members of the other covered their mouths in masking tape.

title: Computers? Near the Laundry
description: Apartment complexes often boast of having pools and exercise rooms. Now one development in Baltimore offers a different amenity: a shared home office.

title: Storytellers Vs. Toy Sellers: We All Lose
description: HOW quaint to recall the days when doubting a movie's honesty meant wondering whether its hero was standing on a box. Now there are more important things to question: whether the box is virtual or real, and whether it contains anything that the film might want to sell. With the growing prevalence of the many-tentacled corporate concept known as vertical integration, we've seen ever more ingenious ways to undermine what appears on screen. Would-be hits on the summer horizon offer an invitation to visit the Web site, buy the toys, wear the T-shirt, hear the soundtrack and play the video game. Oh, if there's time left over, see the movie, too.

title: Building the New Jerusalem
description: Israel and Europe

title: An Indoor Runway That Wants to Insure Happy Landings
description: The newest of the 120 buildings at the Federal Aviation Administration's William J. Hughes Technical Center in Pomona is longer than three football fields laid end to end. The $21 million testing center, which was unveiled last month, houses a 75-foot-wide machine made of steel girders and 12 airplane tires. It is used for testing the durability of runway surfaces.

title: Going For Broke
description: DIANNE LAWE, a private investigator, arrived early enough on an overcast morning last November to beat the garbage truck to Harry Leonhardt's home in a tranquil neighborhood north of Houston.

title: Les Paul's Mischief
description: To the Editor:

title: Helena Antoniades, Trent Lehman
description: Helena Birgitta Antoniades, the daughter of Dr. Kristina Antoniades and Dr. John Antoniades of Philadelphia, was married yesterday to Trent Robert Lehman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Lehman of Richardson, Tex. The Rev. Demetrios Katerlis performed the Greek Orthodox ceremony at the Cathedral of St. George in Philadelphia. Afterward, the Rev. David Farley, a Lutheran pastor, gave a blessing.

title: Liberties; Dissolves on Contact
description: By the time the Mayor of Rye was introduced, I had to stop myself from yelling over to the blonde in black, ''Hillary, turn back before it's too late!''

title: Visionaries With Their Eyes on the Truth
description: GOOD documentaries tell the truth in ways that fiction films cannot. They hear straight talk. They observe and reveal simple gestures that speak volumes. And they tackle issues of real importance without insisting on happy endings. They nonetheless remain second-class citizens in the film industry.

title: Hollywood Hitches Its Wagon to 'Star Wars'
description: NIKKI ROCCO, the president of distribution at Universal Pictures, and her colleagues are nervous. Who can blame them?

title: Arnie's Ardor
description: A GOLFER'S LIFE By Arnold Palmer with James Dodson. Illustrated. 420 pp. New York: Ballantine Books. $26.95.

title: Mr. Not-Quite-Right
description: COWBOY

title: Brownies on the March At a Cafe-Bakery
description: Presumably named for what's left after one of their trademark brownies is devoured, Sticky Fingers, a cafe and bakery owned by Rick Diaz and Nancy Tela, opened last week at 96 Orchard Street (between Broome and Delancey Streets). This is the partners' second store. The first opened five years ago at 121 First Avenue (near Seventh Street), and the expansion continues later this month, when another is to open at 153 Avenue C (near Ninth Street).

title: Public School Choice, at a Price; Many Pay to Transfer Children to More Affluent Districts
description: Len Sarver is on the school board here, so it is not surprising that he sends his 13-year-old son, Josh, to public school. But what bothers some school officials here is that he does not send Josh to public school in Mount Vernon.

title: Second-Class Status At Public Library
description: My nuclear family is a tax-paying, voting, community-active, eco-sensitive microcosm of suburbia. But we're banned from borrowing public library materials in our community.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEFENFELD, BERNARD
description: LEFENFELD-Bernard. On April 29, 1999 at the age of 87. Beloved husband of Lillian (nee Tragash). Loving father of Alice, Mark and Robert. Devoted brother of Beatrice Alpern and the late Harry and Jerry. Cherished grandfather of Barbara, Joel, Benjamin, Eric, Jacob and Zachary. Founding partner of Field Bros Clothiers. Services Monday in Florida.

title: It's Time to Divide and Conquer Perennials
description: PERENNIAL borders have made a big comeback in the last few years. There are many reasons, including aggressive promotion efforts by the nursery industry. Sales of these handsome plants have exploded and the beauty of many gardens has been greatly enhanced. But there is also a myth that perennial gardens are low maintenance. No way.

title: April 25-May 1; Palestinian Delay on Statehood
description: Backing down from a pledge that Israelis regarded as a threat, Palestinian leaders decided against declaring statehood on May 4, the end of the five-year interim period set up under the Oslo peace accord. Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, urged the Palestinian Central Council to abandon the idea of pronouncing the West Bank and Gaza Strip a Palestinian state less than two weeks before the Israeli elections. He told the council that American and European officials, and some Arab leaders, had asked them not to make a unilateral declaration at this sensitive moment in order to avoid rupturing the peace process.

title: Amelia Todd, Curtis Middleton
description: Amelia Fales Todd, the daughter of Pamela and Henry Todd of New Hope, Pa., was married yesterday to Curtis Roger Middleton, a son of Rosemary and H. Lane Middleton of Radford, Va. The Rev. Tracy Weatherhog performed the ceremony at the Doylestown (Pa.) Presbyterian Church.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: Huxley: From Devil's Disciple to Evolution's High Priest

title: Art for Everyone
description: To the Editor:

title: Rock Slide in the Income Gap
description: To the Editor:

title: 11 Are Killed as a Tourist Boat Sinks on Arkansas Lake
description: Eleven people drowned and one was injured today when the amphibious excursion boat on which they were passengers sank without warning in nearby Lake Hamilton.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHORE, CAROL TILLES
description: SHORE-Carol Tilles. Age 77. Loving wife and better half of Allan for 58 years; beloved mother of Allan Shore Jr., William Shore, and Marylu Simon & devoted motherin-law of Jill Shore; cherished grandmother of Jennifer, Beth, Chris, Michael and Julie; greatgrandmother of three and sister of the late Roy Tilles Jr. Her compassion and zest for life touched all who knew her. Formerly of Scarsdale, N.Y., resident of Palm Beach, Florida for 25 years. Active volunteer for the Helen and Harry Gray Cancer Institute at Good Samaritan Hospital, Hospice of Palm Beach County and the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation. Contributions in lieu of flowers may be made to the Helen and Harry Gray Cancer Institute at Good Samaritan Hospital, 1309 North Flagler Drive, West Palm Beach, Florida 33401. A memorial service will be held in West Palm Beach, Florida at 2pm on Saturday, May 8 in the Phillips Auditorium of the Good Samaritan Hospital, 1309 North Flagler Drive. Anyone wishing to pay tribute is welcome to participate.

title: Top Two Scorers Think of Victories
description: When Shaquille O'Neal and Allen Iverson were recently asked what it would mean to win the National Basketball Association's scoring title, each responded in an unselfish, thoughtful manner, the kind that makes coaches proud and footwear executives queasy.

title: Dubai Strategy Proves Inconclusive
description: It was a slingshot move that threatened to kick sand on the bluegrass: Worldly Manner rushed up at the mile mark today in the Kentucky Derby to briefly go nose to nose with the grinding leader Cat Thief. For a moment, the Dubai experiment of Sheik Mohammed bin Rashid al-Maktoum looked worth every penny of the $5 million he had shelled out for the colt last fall.

title: A White-Hot Growth Fund
description: Now that the Janus 20 fund has closed to new investors, a less-known fund seems poised to replace it as the most popular actively managed fund for new money: Alliance Premier Growth.

title: Click on the Corner Store
description: Last August, Mark Phillips set up a Web site to pay homage to the Gowanus Canal and to show off his photographs of its floating basketballs, bodies and even store facades. To his surprise, he said, the site attracted foreigners fascinated by the two-and-a-half mile stretch of fetid water, many of whom told Mr. Phillips they hoped to tour the canal and visit the area.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAYER, HENRY
description: MAYER-Henry. Henry, we will miss you. Our love to Ruth and family. Rudolf and Margaret Hertz and Family

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLORIN, WALTER
description: FLORIN-Walter. Beloved husband of Esther. Loving father of Mark and Joel. Cherished grandfather of Daniella, Samuel, David and Michelle. Also survived by many dear friends. Founded Micro Essential Laboratory, Inc. in 1934. Developer and inventor of Hydrion PH Products, which have been used worldwide for educational, industrial and medical testing.

title: We Have Gone Too Far to Protect Internet Speech
description: To the Editor:

title: Contemporary Tribute to Classical Past
description: THE classical world, especially ancient Greece, continues to be meaningful and relevant. The attention being paid to the thoughtful, new skylighted Greek Galleries at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in Manhattan is more evidence of this. Coincidentally, the Neuberger Museum of Art at Purchase College here pays imaginative tribute to that golden era in ''Contemporary Classicism.''

title: Indie Film Losing Its Vigor As It Ages
description: IN one of the most memorable scenes in ''Hype!,'' a playfully ironic documentary that was introduced at the 1996 Sundance Film Festival, a young fan laments the commercialization of the Seattle music scene that had spawned the grunge-rock movement of the early 1990's. A miserable expression clouds the youth's face as he recalls how he supported a particular group at the beginning of its career when it had a small following, only to watch its growing popularity ruin it as something meaningful to him.

title: Rock Slide in the Income Gap
description: To the Editor:

title: A Fund Provides a Summer Escape
description: When summer approaches and New York City's asphalt starts to sizzle, children are as eager as anyone else to escape to a place where they can bike, run and swim in the sunshine.

title: Hizzoners
description: THE AMERICAN MAYOR

title: P.B.A.'s Outside Shot Has All the Elements
description: The first Professional Bowlers Association outdoor championship, yesterday at Bryant Park in Manhattan, had everything its organizers could have hoped for: flawless weather, an overflow crowd and a folk hero.

title: Me Tarzan, Me Computer-Assisted
description: WHAT is the future of animation? In many ways, it's already here. The Walt Disney Company's ''Tarzan,'' which opens June 18, is a good example of where things will continue heading, at least technologically, in mainstream animated features.

title: They Might Even Meet Alan Greenspan Himself
description: It comes as no surprise that teen-agers would love to meet the Chicago Bulls or the Spice Girls. But how about shaking hands with members of the Federal Open Market Committee? Well, for high school students in the final rounds today and tomorrow of the Fed Challenge, a sort of monetary-policy bee for budding macroeconomists, the committee has star power.

title: Robert Siegelman, Jenifer Willmann
description: Dr. Jenifer Ruth Quoyoon Willmann, the daughter of Hilda Q. Willmann of Levittown, N.Y., and the late James T. Willmann, was married yesterday to Robert Siegelman, the son of Barbara Siegelman and Dr. Michael Siegelman of Houston. The Rev. Peter H. John, a United Methodist minister and a cousin of the bride, officiated in the Glass Pavilion at Johns Hopkins University in Baltimore.

title: Serbs Release 3 Captured U.S. Soldiers
description: Three American soldiers held captive for more than a month were released today and handed over to the Rev. Jesse L. Jackson for their trip home.

title: From Skeptic To Admirer
description: I HAD not cared much for minivans, preferring the handling of even a station wagon over these boxes on wheels. Then I took a family trip in a Plymouth Grand Voyager, hauled home a Christmas tree on the roof of a Toyota Sienna and took some Cub Scouts camping in a Ford Windstar.

title: Diet Aides on House Calls
description: Every Monday, Wednesday and Friday Annalisa Mastroianni makes a food drop. The needy, in this case, are celebrities and other indulgent dieters who pay $400 a week for three meals and two snacks a day, prepared by Annie's Edibles, a service Ms. Mastroianni introduced in Manhattan last month. A personal chef but not a nutritionist, Ms. Mastroianni, who started the company in Santa Monica, Calif., two years ago, prepares most meals according to Barry Sears's Zone diet, but accommodates clients' own preferences. Sandra Bullock insisted that raw onions and garlic be excluded, the actor Matthew McConaughey favored shrimp Veracruz and the architect Frank Gehry ''could eat sliced turkey all day,'' she said. When Kevyn Aucoin, the makeup artist, recently received a one-week gift certificate for Annie's Edibles, which is at (212) 946-6363, she honored his requests for macaroni and cheese and other dishes high in saturated fat and complex carbohydrates. ''He had hurt his back,'' Ms. Mastroianni said, ''and really just wanted to be pampered.'' BILL POWERS

title: Belichick Refusals Signal Jet Future
description: It appears that the Jets' defensive coordinator, Bill Belichick, was much more popular in recent months than most people knew. As teams began firing their head coaches during the off season, Belichick's name was among the first they turned to on their Rolodexes, as he quietly became one of the most pursued men in the coaching derby.

title: No Time for the Yips
description: The Majors

title: The Real Divide
description: Berman is on to something important, but his terminology is wrong. The categories he describes are not ''insiders'' and ''outsiders,'' but ''absolutists'' and ''relativists.''

title: Jane Sonders, Regis Courivaud
description: Jane Lindsay Sonders and Regis Courivaud were married last evening by Rabbi Benjamin Feller at Masterview Studios in New York.

title: Q&A/Dr. Carolyn M. Mazure; Women's Health, Women's Differences
description: WOMEN are different from men and those differences matter in women's health issues.

title: Space Invaders, Just a Desk Away
description: In the compressed world of the office, little things mean a lot. And when someone has an annoying habit or seems to think that any kind of behavior is acceptable, co-workers can suffer -- often in silence. And even when they speak up, their protests can go unheard.

title: Yielding, Yet Advancing
description: By releasing three captured American soldiers and offering to accept a lightly armed United Nations peacekeeping force to monitor a peace in Kosovo, the Yugoslav President, Slobodan Milosevic, has made it clear that he wants a bombing halt, and that he is ready to deal.

title: Unlocking The Cellar, Quenching The Thirst
description: AT 59, Bill Koch has a net worth well north of half a billion dollars, in the robust prime of life. Even so, he has some other numbers that are hard to ignore. He drinks one bottle or so of wine each week and has 28,000 of them in his cellar.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Art and Flowers

title: 1998 REPORT TOLD OF LAB BREACHES AND CHINA THREAT
description: A secret report to top Clinton Administration officials last November warned that China posed an ''acute intelligence threat'' to the Government's nuclear weapons laboratories and that computer systems at the labs were being constantly penetrated by outsiders.

title: The Curse of The Whitney
description: I have fond memories of the original Whitney in its old spot on Eighth Street, near Fifth Avenue: of wandering in to see still-wet deKoonings fresh from his studio just a few blocks away; of seeing vital new art that had earned its mark of fame while the artists might still be scuffling for the rent. There was a sense of intimacy shared, of a human and manageable scale, as if, perhaps, all you needed was a canvas with nail to claim space on a wall. But once it began its moves uptown, all that intimacy was lost. Arthur Lubow's article (April 11) detailing the power plays of executives and curators, the puzzling over mission, the trendiness, real estate and fashion, is perhaps worthy of Ayn Rand, but certainly the Whitney's original purpose has long been obfuscated.

title: One-Woman Red Cross For Reptiles
description: Last winter, Rhonda Hoelzer began making the rounds of downtown pet stores, checking on how reptiles were being treated. Although she praised the practices of some of the stores, she said others failed to provide reptiles with the quality of light they need to survive and overheated their living quarters.

title: SUMMER FILMS: THE FUTURE; Black Films: The Studios Have It All Wrong
description: NEVER has there been a better time to be an African-American filmmaker. The numbers don't lie: there are more and more films made for, produced by and directed by African-Americans (at least, African-American men). This is good.

title: Style; Footnotes
description: 1. Mono Lake, on the outskirts of Yosemite National Park, where these photographs were taken, may not be as private as the meditation rock garden that Donna Karan has in her Hamptons backyard or the yoga house that Lynda Guber built behind her Bel Air mansion. Still, for average mortals, Mono Lake is serene enough for a meditative experience in nature or an atmospheric fashion shoot.

title: Beyond Chops: Ways of Making the Most of Lamb
description: LAMB chops, french fries and watercress -- what could be better for a spring dinner?

title: Franchise for Little Jobs Around the House
description: WHO among us has never had a leaky faucet, a door that won't close or a broken porch railing? Nagging small repairs, to be sure, yet for the unhandy, finding someone else willing to take on small jobs has become almost impossible.

title: Young Ideas In Carryalls
description: A new generation has flung itself into bags sculptured to hug the torso and waist as an extension of clothing. And by discarding the status designer handbag, it has created a generation gap. The many styles of over-the-shoulder contour bags (far left) are an alternative to the backpack, with the box shape most popular. Its three-inch-wide strap has multiple pockets and closes in front with industrial Velcro, so the bag never has to go over the head. Saddlebags with a tie belt (below) are gracing young bodies as well. Also seen around town is the apron bag (right), a Canal Street find for under $20. Designers are adapting these street styles and selling them for $200 and up, depending on the materials used.

title: Long, Slow Buildup: Kubrick Was The Master
description: NICOLE KIDMAN is dawdling before the mirror, naked except for her eyeglasses and an earring that's giving her trouble. She fusses with it, but languorously, as might be expected amid her gilded surroundings. They suggest the kind of hotel where each room is a scaled-down version of the queen's bedchamber at Versailles. The lamps bathe Ms. Kidman in flattery. The ornate mirror frames a partial view of her front, though the full stretch of her back stands exposed to the camera.

title: The World; Only Congress Can Declare War. Really. It's True.
description: IT was the bombing of Cambodia and the national anguish over Vietnam that spurred Congress, over Richard M. Nixon's veto, to enact a law that it hoped would prevent any other President from waging undeclared war.

title: Crime
description: The intricate plot of Robert Goddard's CAUGHT IN THE LIGHT (Holt, $26) begins on a snowy winter morning in Vienna, where an English photographer falls madly in love with a mystery woman who steps in front of his camera. Their affair is recounted with breathless romanticism (''The imminence of passion -- of heat and flesh and broken taboos -- hung almost tangibly in the air''), and the photographer, Ian Jarrett, plays into the mood when he deserts his wife and daughter to run off with the woman he knows as Marian Esguard. The story shifts into dramatic suspense when Marian disappears and Ian discovers her ''true'' identity, as well as her belief that she is the incarnation of the ''real'' Marian Esguard, a pioneer photographer who vanished in 1820, along with her revolutionary inventions.

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: FLUSHING

title: It's Synergy, Baby, Groovy, Yeah!
description: WHEN ''Austin Powers, International Man of Mystery'' became a surprise hit back in May 1997, the executives at Time Warner did more than just congratulate the folks at their subsidiary, New Line Cinema.

title: A Stopover in a Renovated Train Station
description: IF the next stop is Pleasantville, commuters riding the Harlem Line may want to hop off for dinner at the Iron Horse Grill, lodged in the erstwhile train station. But have a reservation in hand; the restaurant has been discovered by diners from all shires.

title: Robbyn Footlick And Robert Drury
description: Robbyn Lynn Footlick and Robert Drury were married last evening at the Century Club in New York. Rabbi Alvin Sugarman, a cousin of the bride, officiated, and Rabbi Floyd Herman, another cousin, took part in the ceremony.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about violence by young people referred incorrectly to the case of Caril Fugate, who was 14 in 1958 when she was sentenced to life in prison for murder committed during the robbery of a Nebraska man. She had insisted that she was an unwilling hostage of Charles Starkweather, whose rampage left 11 people dead, including Miss Fugate's mother. She did not confess to any of the murders.

title: Man Rescued From Fire In Queens Later Dies
description: A Queens man who was rescued early yesterday from his burning apartment and resuscitated by firefighters died yesterday afternoon, the authorities said.

title: Environmental Teammates Are Now Foes
description: FOR more than a decade, the Morewood property has been a source of local controversy. The 453-acre site, used at different times as a landfill, garbage transfer station, dump site and sand mining pit, loomed along Hempstead Harbor like a boil on the back of Port Washington while residents debated what to do with it.

title: Keyboard Is Featured in Concerts
description: THE keyboard, played with other musicians and alone appears frequently in recitals and concerts this week.

title: Individualists at Play With Personality
description: JASON MORAN: 'SOUNDTRACK TO HUMAN MOTION'

title: Where Opera, For Good Or Ill, Is Grand
description: THERE is no other company like it, and yet the Metropolitan Opera may end up a model for the future. In the season just closed and the one to come, the Met continues a practice of self-sufficiency and free enterprise that is largely unfamiliar to the international opera world. But now we see the free-spending ways of government-subsidized opera houses being strenuously curbed. Indeed, the adventurous, the innovative and sometimes the reckless are no longer automatically underwritten by generous European ministries of culture.

title: Who Cares if Vouchers Violate the Constitution?
description: To the Editor:

title: Rohmer in the Vineyards
description: Eric Rohmer, 79, is as renowned for his unpredictable scripts as for the quirky romances he films from them. In ''Autumn Tale,'' which opens July 9, matchmaking friends complicate the life of Magali, a widow who owns a vineyard. In this excerpt, translated by Sylviane Gold, Isabelle, an old friend, visits Magali to buy wine for a wedding.

title: Melinda Wallace and Timothy Hale
description: Melinda Spencer Wallace, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William C. Wallace of Short Hills, N.J., was married there yesterday to Timothy Bickett Hale, a son of Prof. and Mrs. David G. Hale of Brockport, N.Y. The Rev. Paul Christopherson performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church.

title: Bonnie Lee And Gary Apple
description: Bonnie Jill Lee, a daughter of Phyllis J. Lee of Forest Hills, Queens, and the late Jerome J. Lee, was married last evening to Gary Apple, the son of Beverly and Jerome Apple of Old Bethpage, N.Y. Rabbi Joel S. Goor officiated at the Plaza in Manhattan.

title: BEST SELLERS: May 2, 1999
description: Weeks

title: In India, a Low-Budget Journey Frees the Spirit
description: TRIVANDRUM to Madras: Overland on Your Own'' These words appeared on the computer printout of my around the world itinerary to explain why there was a distance of nearly 500 miles between the flights I'd booked into and out of India. On the airline schedule it looked like a worrisome hole; but for me, that gap between plane rides -- overland on my own! -- represented the heart and soul of my journey. For it was the anticipation of the sheer delight I would experience traveling alone by rail, car and bus across and then up the southern tip of India that had led me to plan my big trip in the first place.

title: On Asian Silks, A Ph.D. Scholar Is Self-Taught
description: ON a recent Tuesday, Guido Goldman, 61, director of German Studies at the Center for European Studies at Harvard University and chairman of the First Spring Corporation, a private Manhattan investment company, strode into the gift shop of the Jewish Museum in New York and did a quick inspection of the stock. ''How are the mouse pads from the ikat show selling?'' Dr. Goldman inquired of the young man at the cash register.

title: For Subway Safety, Try Platform Railings
description: To the Editor:

title: Finally, Masur Gets To Call the Tune In New Music, Too
description: ''WHAT does the conductor actually do?''

title: Turning On the Lights Downtown; More Cities Are Banking on Live Theater (and Places to Eat) Being the Switch
description: AS Connecticut's cities search for ways to recapture the luster they once possessed, theaters and performing arts centers are increasingly playing a supporting role in those urban revitalization dramas.

title: Invesco European Fund
description: A LONGTIME fan of Manchester United, the English soccer team, Steven A. Chamberlain, manager of the Invesco European fund, can do something that most other sports enthusiasts can't: control a chunk of the sports franchise he follows so passionately.

title: After the Recovery Room, the Recovery Hotel
description: WHEN Paul Broadhead, chairman of Paul Broadhead Interests, a developer of retail space in Meridian, Miss., checked out of New York Presbyterian Hospital after having had a heart transplant in July 1996, he had to stay nearby during his four-month convalescence.

title: April 25-May 1; U.S. Eases Some Sanctions
description: Trade sanctions were once a preferred method of punishing nations linked to terrorism, like Iran and Libya. But a two-year Clinton Administration study has concluded that sanctions on food and medicine tend to backfire, doing little to counter terrorism while depriving innocent civilians. As a result, the White House announced that as a general rule, food and medicine will be exempt from sanctions. An early beneficiary will be Iran, which will probably be allowed to import $500 million worth of American grain and sugar. PHILIP SHENON

title: Charismatic Gives Derby a 31-1 Surprise
description: Bob Baffert missed his date with horse racing history today when none of his three horses ran in the money and D. Wayne Lukas's 31-1 long shot, Charismatic, won the 125th running of the Kentucky Derby by a neck over Menifee and by less than one length over another Lukas horse, Cat Thief.

title: The Way We Live Now: 5-2-99: The Body; The Breast Is History
description: The day before my appointment with the doctor to discuss having my right breast removed, I heard the news that shook the world (or at least the World Wide Web): Pamela Anderson was having her famous implants taken out. For a second I thought of Pamela Harriman, but my daughter showed me a photograph of the starlet, with her gigantic breasts caught up in a bit of transparent pink material, looking as if Portuguese men-of-war that had attached themselves to her torso. There was something fascinating about the sight. Also something daft.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGER, HELEN (NEE EISENKRAFT)
description: BERGER-Helen (nee Eisenkraft). On April 30, 1999, of Alzheimer's Disease. Loving wife of the late Philip. Beloved mother of Caryn and Allen Rich, and Dr. Kenneth Berger. Adored grandmother of Pamela. Dear sister of Sylvia Sichel. Services 1:30 PM, Sunday, at ''Boulevard - Riverside Chapel,'' 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, LI.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALEXANDER, OTTO (LOPEZ)
description: ALEXANDER-Otto (Lopez). Multi-talented artist, beloved brother and son. Loving friend and a beautiful human being whose memory will be cherished forever, died April 26 in an accident. Memorial service later in May. For information call 212-222-9184.

title: Sports of The Times; Amazin': Mets Fans Will Always Have 1969
description: RON SWOBODA loves the look on their faces. Well into middle age themselves, with the attendant wrinkles and gray hairs, they get this silly gaping smile on their faces when they realize who he is, what he was part of. ''It's a lovefest, man,'' Swoboda said.

title: An Ordinary Serb, Lost In Air Attack, Is Buried
description: In one of the ordinary epics of everyday life, they buried Tomislav Mitrovic today.

title: The Good Times, Rolling as Usual
description: THE trip to New Orleans from my home in Baton Rouge takes just an hour and a half, but it spans the distance between the here-and-now and the ever-possible. Indeed, every time I go to New Orleans, I walk around in a daze of sensory overload, like a drunken Impressionist. Maybe that's because New Orleans is not, actually, an American city. Nor is it a European city that just happens to have sprung up on the banks of the Mississippi. Rather, it is the urban equivalent of a seductress -- so stunningly lovely that it's hard to believe that for decades after its founding in 1718 as a colonial outpost of the French Empire, it was a wretched, disease-ridden, verminous, godforsaken swamp. It's where Rhett Butler took Scarlett O'Hara for their honeymoon, where Stanley and Stella duked it out in ''A Streetcar Named Desire,'' where the great Louis Armstrong was born and raised. It's also where my husband, Stuart, and I headed for a grown-up weekend, i.e., a vacation from the kids in late March.

title: Amy Jeffress, Casey Cooper
description: Dorothy Ames Jeffress, a Federal prosecutor, and Christopher Reid Cooper, a lawyer, were married yesterday afternoon at the Meridian House, a historic mansion in Washington. Judge Merrick Garland of the Federal Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit officiated, and the Rev. John Payne, a Roman Catholic priest, took part in the ceremony.

title: A Joyful Noise
description: Melanie Rehak lives in my head! I read her Lives column (April 11) before going to my piano lesson. I am relieved to know that there is another soul who finds playing both staffs at once, using the correct fingering, pushing the pedal and sitting bolt upright on the bench an overwhelming assignment for an adult beginner.

title: Misono Endo, CJ Wilson
description: Misono Endo and Clifton J. Wilson were married yesterday afternoon by the Rev. William Hargett at St. Alban's Episcopal Church in Washington.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MECHANIC, SONNY (SAM)
description: MECHANIC-Sonny (Sam). You were my life for 65 years. My love, my everything. You are locked in my heart forever. I love you dearly. Carolyn

title: PRIVATE SECTOR: DIARY; A Lively Discussion About Executive Pay
description: Graef Crystal minces executives, not words. He plans to get the last one in his feud with Linda J. Wachner, chief executive of Warnaco Group, a New York apparel company.

title: Straight to Mini-Series
description: The Book of Kings

title: Front-Line Hungary Feels Anxiety
description: At night, Attila Chikan's mother, a woman in her 70's whose generation recalls World War II, hears the bombers over Yugoslavia, even though, her son says, ''from where she lives, it's physically impossible.''

title: Clinton Says New Rule on Emissions Won't Impose Undue Costs
description: Defending his new plans for cleaner air against criticism from the oil industry, President Clinton said today that proposed regulations on gasoline and tailpipe emissions would not impose excessive costs.

title: State Buying 127 Acres On Great South Bay
description: New York State will buy 127 acres on Great South Bay in Oakdale for $3.8 million to protect Long Island's South Shore Estuary Reserve, Gov. George E. Pataki has announced.

title: Will This Island Be Rediscovered?
description: Columbus Circle is set to undergo a major face lift by 2003. But the circle, a gateway to Central Park and the Upper West Side, will get a temporary makeover before the final design is even selected. Last week, city officials outlined the interim plan, to mixed reviews, at a public hearing.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction; Put On Your Fireflies, We're Going Out!
description: Barry Yourgrau's sinuous, laconic fictions defy routine description. Reviewers find themselves resorting to imaginary amalgams -- two parts Borges, one part Kafka, a dollop of Andre Breton -- in trying to describe the snapshot-quick, surrealist prose doodlings that Yourgrau, the author of ''The Sadness of Sex,'' specializes in. In HAUNTED TRAVELLER: An Imaginary Memoir (Arcade, $23.95), his fourth book, Yourgrau presents us with 44 episodes that relate one man's wanderings through moody, fantastical landscapes -- a weird and airy travelogue, springing from the narrator's possession by what Baudelaire called the ''horror of home.'' Yourgrau's narrator takes us to flower-strewn islands where women wear mantles of drugged fireflies, to a lofty kingdom presided over by a chief who wears a ''turban of dyed cobwebs'' and aboard tramp freighters crewed by gorgeous but reticent cross-dressing women. As the narrator (who fancies himself a sort of nomadic po te maudit) confesses, ''I might traverse a whole world, pacing from one wall of my room to the other.'' In one dispatch, ''Map,'' he asks a barefoot woman where he might find the X on his map, and she responds by asking where he thinks it is. '' 'Why, somewhere over there,' I tell her, pointing. She nods at this, with the show of a strange, unamused smile. 'Yes,' she says. 'Tonight. That is where it is. But last night. . . .' She raises a worn hand, and indicates an entirely different direction.'' Ultimately, Yourgrau's vignettes add up to a strangely sublime collection that speaks less to travel than it does to alienation -- and to the restless yearnings of the human heart. Jonathan Miles

title: Michael Adams Scrambles Into the Ranks of the Elite
description: The world's top chess luminaries have for some time felt the breath of the British grandmaster Michael Adams close behind them, but in the Dos Hermanas International Tournament in Spain, April 6 to 17, they were blown aside as he took first place.

title: THEATER; To Fill a Club, There's Nothing Like a Story
description: IT seemed so New York, at first glance. On a recent brisk April evening on the Lower East Side of Manhattan, people jockeyed for position at the door of the Lansky Lounge on Norfolk Street, even though most of those in the line had R.S.V.P.'d. But this was not your typical velvet-rope situation. When the V.I.P.'s arrived (regulars, journalists, well-known writers and friends of the founder), even they were politely instructed to wait in line. There were no protests and no exceptions. Once relegated to the end of the line, people seemed almost shy. They smiled and looked one another in the eye, shook hands and chatted quietly until allowed entry.

title: GOOD EATING
description: FISH +

title: When the Alecks Are Too Smart, Their Gags Pall
description: LIKE a lot of parents with young children, I've done my share of hand wringing about the youth of today growing up too fast. But I've only recently realized that by the time my son's voice breaks, he may be ready for open-mike night at Bob's Chuckle Hut. At least that's the impression I've developed in the 19 months since he was born, as I've started paying closer attention to the smart-mouth comebacks of preadolescent sitcom characters.

title: Serenity Now
description: It's not just a funny 'Seinfeld' line. 'Serenity now' perfectly expresses the relaxed mood in men's wear this spring.

title: A Personal Ax To Grind?
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Ulster Lawyer's Killing Casts Suspicion on Police
description: Two months ago Rosemary Nelson, a prominent civil rights lawyer, spoke at a ceremony honoring a colleague whose killing in 1989 has long symbolized the danger of practicing criminal law in Northern Ireland.

title: War Photos Recall Death Camps
description: FIRST LIEUT. Albert Gaynes wrote hundreds of letters to his young bride, Debbie, during the two and a half years he was fighting overseas in World War II. Many recounted the monotony of war, his travels throughout Europe and the loneliness of a young man separated from his wife.

title: Legislator and Ex-Governor In House Runoff in Louisiana
description: Former Gov. David C. Treen and state Representative David Vitter finished atop the nine-person field vying to succeed Robert L. Livingston as the congressman from Louisiana's First District tonight, and advanced to a runoff scheduled for May 29.

title: Ideas & Trends; For Venezuelan Voters, A Nervous Honeymoon
description: HE is a head of state now, no longer a renegade colonel plotting a coup d'etat. At his insistence, a cowed Congress has given him the authority to rule by decree, and voters here last week convoked a Constituent Assembly that seems likely to greatly expand his powers and term of office. But three months after he was sworn in as president, Hugo Chavez continues to perplex and unnerve Venezuelans, not to mention the rest of Latin America.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: Swimming with Jonah By Audrey Schulman. Bard/Avon, $22.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PITMAN, ADRIANE KLEBAN
description: PITMAN-Adriane Kleban. In memory of a loving daughter, caring mother and fond grandmother who passed away April 26, 1998.

title: I-95's Exit 8AIs a Magnet To High-Tech Warehouses
description: THE Graybar Electric company is starting up a distribution center here whose managers promise overnight delivery of electrical parts as far away as Boston or the suburbs of Washington. ''If someone orders by 5 P.M., we'll have it on their loading dock before they open up the next morning,'' said Paul J. Milata, Graybar's regional manager here.

title: Keeping an Eye on TV News About the Island
description: WATCHING television news with Abby Kenigsberg is like taking a test. Both broadcasting executives and television viewers should heed the results.

title: Monuments of Junk Artfully Compacted
description: A FEW months ago, Nancy Rubins received a phone call from out of the blue. For her, it was like winning the Lotto. The director of a kunsthalle in Austria said he had heard that Air France had a defunct Concorde airplane. If Ms. Rubins was willing to create an installation at his kunsthalle, the director promised he would arrange for her to have the plane free of charge, not to fly but to use as material for her art. ''I was just salivating,'' she recalled. ''I couldn't wait to get my hands on an entire Concorde and cut it up.''

title: Leyla Morrissey And Cole Bader
description: Leyla Elise Morrissey, the daughter of Hatice Uskup Morrissey and Dr. Kevin P. Morrissey of New York, was married last evening to Cole Ramsay Bader, a son of Jean McCarty Bader of Mill Valley, Calif., and W. Reece Bader of Atherton, Calif. The Rev. John E. Halborg performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in New York.

title: Arizona High School Provides Glimpse Inside Cliques' Divisive Webs
description: Look around the sprawling Chaparral High School campus at lunch time, and the social geography of the 1,850 students is clearly mapped out.

title: Giving Multinationals An Index of Their Own
description: DIVERSIFICATION is one of the cardinal rules of investing, and it is on many people's minds as they put their money into various single-country index funds to spread risks among financial markets. But such a strategy may overlook the burgeoning influence of multinational companies on the national indexes.

title: For the Eco-Conscious, Tours in Canada's Parks
description: Visitors to Canada's national parks can collect water samples in streams and study breeding birds alongside professional researchers in a program called Parks Canada Research Adventures.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CAPLOW, A.I.
description: CAPLOW-A.I. May 2. Dear Cappy, always in my thoughts and very sorely missed. Mil

title: Uptown, Downtown: When and Where the Boards Meet
description: DISTRICT 1 -- Battery Park City, Civic Center, Financial District, South Street Seaport, TriBeCa; third Tuesday of the month; next meeting May 18, 5:30 P.M.; the Regatta, West Thames on the Esplanade, Battery Park City. Board chairwoman: Anne Compoccia. District manager: Paul Goldstein. (212) 442-5050. Agenda: To be announced.

title: Lisa Brody and Bruce Davis
description: Lisa Renee Brody, the daughter of Dr. Linda Brody and Arthur Brody of Columbia, Md., was married there on Friday to Bruce Philip Davis, the son of Linda and Robert Davis, also of Columbia. Blanca Acevedo, a deputy clerk of the Howard County Circuit Court in Ellicott City, Md., officiated. Last evening, Judge Kevin Thomas Duffy of Federal District Court in Manhattan, who is a cousin of the bride, led a celebration of the couple's marriage at the Belvedere, a hotel in Baltimore.

title: A Fold Here and a Cut There And Paper Becomes Magic
description: AURELIA FERNANDEZ cuts and folds like a virtuoso, fashioning intricate paper gardens with a few flicks of the wrist. Her supplies might be found in any kindergarten: crepe paper, tapioca starch (for making papier-mache), scissors and paste. But as with most virtuosos, the simplicity is deceiving. Ms. Fernandez has been recognized as one of the most accomplished folk artists in the county.

title: Laura Edmiston, Charles Carroll
description: Laura Mary Edmiston and Charles Francis Carroll were married yesterday by William O. Murphy, a Roman Catholic deacon, at SS. John and Paul Roman Catholic Church in Larchmont, N.Y.

title: Where to Have a Meal Honoring Mom
description: WHILE dining out is no longer the Big Deal it once was, there are still occasions -- like Mother's Day next Sunday -- that call for a restaurant where atmosphere, food and service are beyond the usual.

title: Stanley Adams, 76, Is Dead; Led Counterattack in Korea
description: Lieut. Col. Stanley T. Adams, who as an Army sergeant won the Medal of Honor in the Korean War for leading a counterattack that left more than 50 enemy soldiers dead in hand-to-hand combat, died on April 19 at the Oregon Veterans Home in The Dalles, Ore. He was 76.

title: Suspect Seized In Bomb Blast In London; Fear Persists
description: British police officers sped to a small Hampshire village southwest of London early today to arrest a man they said may be involved in a wave of extremist bombings that claimed three lives in a blast Friday night at a gay bar in Soho.

title: Some People Refuse to Lose
description: Internet stocks aren't all that's being bid way up in Silicon Valley.
