At a March auction for the Menlo School, a prep school in Atherton, Calif., Emma, a yellow Labrador puppy, fetched $17,000. The buyer? Robert Swanson, the founder of Genentech. The dog was donated by a veterinarian, said Maggie Pringle, co-director of the fund-raiser, which brought in more than $120,000. Four people bid, but only two continued past $10,000: Mr. Swanson and Eff Martin, a Goldman, Sachs partner. That $17,000 buys more than a best friend; extras included five training sessions and a portrait of the owners with their new pooch. LAURA M. HOLSON

title: John Jay High in Cross River Offers Corrected Test Scores
description: STATE Education Department officials said they have received corrected test scores from John Jay High School in Cross River showing that a far higher percentage of 12th-grade students had received a passing grade on Regents' English examinations than originally reported.

title: We Have Gone Too Far to Protect Internet Speech
description: To the Editor:

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: CHARLES BUKOWSKI

title: AT&T's Big Chance To Open The Door
description: SOME people call it communicopia. Others call it convergence. But as AT&T's $58 billion cash and stock offer for Mediaone Group amply illustrates, the move toward an intertwined landscape of data and voice communications, entertainment programming and electronic commerce also deserves to be called expensive.

title: SUMMER FILMS: THE FUTURE; A Digital Cinema Of the Mind? Could Be
description: IF only we could just stop that gentleman in the top hat coming out of the Metropolitan Opera -- no, that one, with the fur collar -- and ask him about the performance of ''Tannhauser'' he has just attended. Perhaps, if he were agreeable, we could walk with him up Broadway and let the conversation go where it might, since this is October in the year 1899, and one's thoughts have naturally turned toward the coming 20th century.

title: The View From/Purchase; Band Strives to Break Link of Drugs and Music
description: THE stereotype persists through all forms of music and all forms of drug and alcohol abuse: jazz musicians get hooked on heroin. Rock stars freak out on LSD. All of them guzzle great quantities of wine and whisky.

title: Elisa Haberman, Bradley Hirsch
description: Elisa Robyn Haberman, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Fredric Haberman of Saddle River, N.J., was married last evening to Dr. Bradley Adam Hirsch, a son of Rosalyn Hirsch and Dr. Jerrold Hirsch of New York. Rabbi Hyman Krantz officiated at Oheka, the Otto Kahn house in Huntington, N.Y.

title: The Way We Live Now: 5-2-99: Economics Of War; The High Cost of Intervention
description: There were celebrations in the Pentagon the night of March 27, when an American pilot shot down over Yugoslavia was rescued. But the whole episode couldn't have been much comfort to Air Force bean counters. In a flash, they had lost a $45 million F-117A -- and, quite likely, $60,000 in ''smart'' bombs. Worse, Congress wasn't about to pay for a replacement.

title: Express Bus? Not by a Long Stretch, Riders Say
description: Riders of an express bus from Far Rockaway to Manhattan say there is nothing express about it. After making 13 stops in the Rockaways and crossing the Cross Bay Veterans Memorial Bridge, the QM17 bus then makes 15 more stops, including 8 on a stretch of Woodhaven Boulevard north of Ozone Park that is already served by 28 express buses a day.

title: Eileen Simon, James Anderson
description: Eileen Stephanie Simon and James Ross Anderson, associates at law firms in New York, are to be married today at the Woodcliff Lake (N.J.) Hilton. Mayor Paul S. Ostrow of Teaneck, N.J., is to officiate.

title: Political Muscle: The Only Good Enemy is a [Strong/Weak] Enemy; When Allies Are Fierce Competitors
description: LATE in the day on April 6, Energy Secretary Bill Richardson showed up at the White House with some bad news for President Clinton: The leakage of nuclear secrets from America's weapons labs was far worse than anyone thought. The Chinese -- whose Prime Minister was on his way to Washington -- may have obtained computer codes that are the key ingredient for simulating nuclear weapons explosions.

title: HIS; Diet Aides on House Calls
description: David Kirsch, 38, gym owner and diet enforcer, not only trains clients at his deluxe Madison Square Club but also delivers low-fat meals to their doors and accompanies them to restaurants, nixing the carbohydrates and nodding to the protein on high-calorie menus. James King, 19, a model who strutted the Paris runways in March (shown with Mr. Kirsch at right), took him with her. She paid his way and his $150 fee for private workouts between fashion shows, and he was her nutritional watchdog at lunch and dinner.

title: There'll Always Be Something or Other
description: ANGLOMANIA

title: Q. & A.
description: Setting Sublet Fees In Co-ops

title: If You're Thinking of Living In / Bayville, N.Y.; Small Village, Large Views of the Sound
description: SURROUNDED by water and wealth, the Village of Bayville on the far northern tier of Nassau County's North Shore is a former summer colony that has matured into a relatively affordable year-round oasis in an exclusive setting.

title: 3 Wounded as an Argument Erupts in Gunfire
description: An argument at a McDonald's restaurant in Queens erupted in gunfire yesterday afternoon, leaving three people wounded, the police said.

title: Up in the Old Hotel
description: FINBAR'S HOTEL

title: The Power of Water
description: ELEVEN years ago, a worker on a construction project at 60 Centre Street in lower Manhattan drilled a hole in the floor of an elevator shaft and unleashed a surge of water four feet high. The source of the fountain? A pond below the foundation.

title: Cover Version
description: To the Editor:

title: Tourist Help Line Set Up in Portugal
description: The Portuguese Government has set up a new help line for tourists in Portugal. Called the Green Line, the number is (800) 296-296.

title: Shyness, in Severe Form, Is Serious but Treatable
description: To the Editor:

title: They Love New York
description: The Tisch family's latest investment technique is the New York Straddle. Having bet heavily on a Wall Street retreat, the Tisches hedged their exposure to further losses somewhat by betting $35 million on a continued New York boom. After finishing the renovation of the Regency Hotel on Park Avenue, flagship of their Loews Hotels, Jonathan M. Tisch, the Loews Hotels chief, came up with the week's best publicity stunt: an ultimate power breakfast, with politicians like the former Mayors David N. Dinkins and Edward I. Koch, and business people like Louis Rudin, the New York builder, to mark 25 years of breakfasts there.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; To Be Appreciated Someday
description: That an incredible trove of paintings by Vincent van Gogh has survived intact since his suicide more than 100 years ago is truly a family affair. ''Its very existence is cause for wonder,'' according to one of van Gogh's grandnephews, ''for it was utterly worthless when it was created.'' Seventy of these paintings are the subjects of VAN GOGH'S VAN GOGHS: Masterpieces From the Van Gogh Museum Amsterdam (National Gallery of Art, Washington/Abrams, $37.50). Richard Kendall's graceful essay walks the reader through van Gogh's surprisingly ordinary life as a little-known artist who ultimately made extraordinary paintings, and also his tender relationship with his brother Theo, who worked for Paris art dealers and always supported Vincent financially and emotionally. John Leighton, director of the Van Gogh Museum, gives a fascinating account of the provenance of these paintings, which Vincent gave to Theo over the years and which, following Theo's own sudden death six months after Vincent's, went to Theo's wife, Johanna, and their infant son, Vincent Willem, who eventually established the museum. Johanna made it her life's work to promote van Gogh's paintings, generating interest in part by publishing volumes of the brothers' correspondence. Leighton astutely comments that the melodrama of the van Gogh legend originated here, with Johanna's sentimentality about her dead husband and his belief in his brother. And it is impossible to read fragments from the letters (laced throughout Kendall's essay) without the knowing wink of hindsight. When Vincent moves from Paris to Provence he writes to Theo, ''I am getting an eye for this kind of country.'' Indeed, Provence was where he unleashed his approach to color and composition, creating his most fiercely original and famous works. In another letter Theo notes, after receiving a shipment of paintings, ''They have something so striking and so near the truth . . . they will undoubtedly be appreciated someday.'' Hilarie M. Sheets

title: A Colorful Lawyer Is Running for Mayor
description: In 35 years as a criminal lawyer, Oscar B. Goodman has won cases for clients like Meyer Lansky and Anthony (Tony the Ant) Spilotro. He has won acquittal for an oral surgeon accused of molesting female patients under anesthesia, defended a Federal judge against impeachment charges and a man accused of murdering another Federal judge.

title: Little College, Big Dreams
description: MARK LAMBERT realized he had his work cut out when he distributed questionnaires to prospective baseball players at Norwalk Community-Technical College in October of 1993.

title: Medical Center To Be Closed
description: Episcopal Health Services announced last week that the Medical Center of St. John's Episcopal Hospital of Smithtown will be closed to consolidate care and cut costs. The center's services will be relocated two miles away to the main hospital campus off Route 25A, also in Smithtown, over the next few months.

title: Deals and Discounts
description: STEAMBOAT SAVINGS -- For passengers who place a deposit of $300 a person by June 30, the Delta Queen Steamboat Company will include various discounts on five- to seven-night cruises departing Nov. 21 through Dec. 23. Most of the six cruises -- on the Delta Queen, American Queen or Mississippi Queen -- begin and end in New Orleans. The discounts range from 40 percent to a two-for-one deal to a 50 percent companion fare, depending on choice of itinerary. The 40 percent discount, for example, on a Dec. 10 to 15 voyage from Memphis to Nashville brings the fare down to $834 a person, double. Among the trips: a stop in Galveston, Tex., for Dickens on the Strand, a Victorian holiday festival, and a Christmas cruise on the lower Mississippi. Call (800) 543-1949 or a travel agent. Availability is limited.

title: William Brown, 89; Architect Oversaw Building of Lever House
description: William Brown, an architectural administrator who supervised the creation of 20th-century landmarks like Lever House on Park Avenue in Manhattan and the city of Oak Ridge, Tenn., died on April 4 at his home in Lexington, Mass. He was 89.

description: To the Editor:

title: GOING OUT
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

description: Before his trip to Belgrade last month, Representative Jim Saxton, a Republican from Mount Holly, was probably better known for his positions on fluke fishing than foreign policy.

title: Symphony at an Airport

The unorthodox arena is the backdrop for the performing forces involved: the Waterbury Symphony, the soloists Jennifer Bynum Green and Marietta Simpson, and a chorus of more than 200 drawn from various ensembles.

title: Spree-ality
description: As he stepped from a black stretch limousine in front of a modest Milwaukee house in January, Dave Checketts, the president of Madison Square Garden, knew a lot was riding on the interview he was about to conduct. Just how much, it would later turn out, he couldn't fully understand. Joined by Ernie Grunfeld, then the Knicks' president, their coach, Jeff Van Gundy, and another team executive, Checketts was there to gauge the character of Latrell Sprewell. A three-time All-Star guard, Sprewell had been on furlough ever since attacking his coach with the Golden State Warriors, P. J. Carlesimo, the year before, choking him, threatening to kill him and, 20 minutes later, returning to the gym to punch him.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   POTENZA, CONNIE
description: POTENZA-Connie. May 2, 1988 In the City's roaring boom, in the silence of my lonely room, I think of you, Connie darling, always and always. Jack ''Ronnie''

title: New Formula Yes. But Is It Improved?
description: A LOT of diversification-minded investors are gravitating toward a group of indexed stock mutual funds that may seem a far wiser choice than the familiar version tied to the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index.

description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Wendy Hannibal And Nigel Astell
description: Wendy Claire Hannibal and Nigel Gordon Astell were married yesterday at the Seamen's Institute in New York. The Rev. Richard Leonard, a Unitarian-Universalist minister, officiated.

title: Chinese Offspring Worthy of Its Parent
description: STANDOUT Chinese restaurants are rare on Long Island. There is a mediocre sameness about the choices. And a philosophy seems to prevail that if Chinese establishments just add a selection of sushi or a Thai dish to the menu, they will widen their appeal. When Lotus East opened more than a decade ago in St. James, this no-gimmicks place won our hearts. It was and still is the best Chinese restaurant in Suffolk County.

title: Susanna Denham, Andrew Meserve
description: Susanna Speakman Denham, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Willard Allen Speakman Denham of Greenville, Del., was married yesterday to Andrew Ellicott Meserve, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Leighton Meserve Jr. of London Grove, Pa. The Rev. John Martiner performed the Episcopal ceremony at Christ Church Christiana Hundred in Greenville, Del.

title: Diana Matcovsky, Gregory Nero
description: Diana Paige Matcovsky, the daughter of Joel and Carol Matcovsky of Larchmont, N.Y., was married last evening to Gregory Paul Nero, a son of Constance Nero and Dr. Louis Nero of Somers, Conn. Rabbi Jerry Heller officiated with the Rev. Gerald Heinan, a Roman Catholic priest, at the Orienta Beach Club in Mamaroneck, N.Y.

title: Final Return Of the Canal Colors Vote In Panama
description: The ''Trautenbels,'' a 484-foot cargo ship, was ushered from the Pacific Ocean into the Panama Canal by tugboats, and by two electric towing locomotives into a water lane. Steel gates snapped shut, enclosing the ship in a chamber, inside which it was lifted by rising water, a process repeated twice more at different points for a voyage up to 85 feet above sea level, across mountains now flooded by artificial lakes.

title: Ideas & Trends; Repeat After Him: The Party Isn't Over
description: THAT the Communist Party is losing touch with the masses is an open worry to leaders here. The latest shock to the system came last week with the sudden demonstration by the spiritual cult called Buddhist Law, a movement claiming tens of millions of Chinese members. So what is the party chief Jiang Zemin doing to create a more relevant Communist Party for the 21st century?

title: Unsettling Glimpse Of What Is to Come
description: TO be infirm in middle age, but not dangerously so, is a dress rehearsal, a visit to the other side. So this is what it feels like when the light changes before you can get across the street. So this is why my mother complains that there is no place to sit in the grocery store. So this is what it means to depend on the kindness of strangers.

title: Aiming for the Toms as the Hens Brood
description: As the days grow longer and warmer, wild turkeys in New York State are responding to ''the force that through the green fuse drives the flower,'' and hunters count on this to reduce the male's ability to notice that danger is nigh.

title: Powder With The Power Of C
description: A couple of ounces of white powder, scooped from a vial with a tiny spoon. No, it's not cocaine but Biomedic's Maximum C, a mix-it-yourself form of vitamin C, which is popular in skin preparations.

title: A Broadway Crossroads
description: It took 21 years for the Crossroads Theater Company to travel from New Brunswick to Broadway, but now it has.''It Ain't Nothin' but the Blues,'' which played at the theater's home last fall, opened at the Vivian Beaumont Theater at Lincoln Center on Monday, just two days before the deadline for Tony Award nominations. Tomorrow morning, when Swoosie Kurtz and Brian Dennehy announce this year's contenders, the revue is expected to be up for Tonys in several categories.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BRESSLER, ALFRED W.
description: BRESSLER-Alfred W. A lawyer and partner in the firm of Moses & Singer for over sixty years. A memorial service will be held on Monday, May 3, at 12 noon at Temple Emanu-El, 5th Avenue at 65 Street, Manhattan.

title: Patient and Kind
description: The pianist Samuel Sanders, right, on the waiting list for his second heart transplant, says he has been feeling so weak that he has canceled all his dates as a recital accompanist since January. Last week, he entered a New York hospital for care until a donor heart is found.

Call (415) 346-8461 after noon on Monday for time, date and location. In lieu of flowers, donations to ACLU of Northern California and Oxfam America.

title: If the Cityscape Is Only a Dream
description: DESPITE fortune cookie dialogue and a dubious Nietzschean subtext, ''The Matrix'' is a film that deserves to be a classic. It will certainly become one for those who value the power of sci-fi movies to crystallize moments of urban sensibility. ''Metropolis,'' ''Alphaville,'' ''The Tenth Victim'' and ''Blade Runner'' are also classics of this genre. Like them, ''The Matrix'' is basically an adventure in stylish mise-en-scene. The special effects offer more than eye-popping trappings. They're the heart of the plot.

description: INFURIATING Democrats, Republicans in the Nassau County Legislature approved a plan last week to accept a $70 million cash payment from the Metropolitan Transportation Authority in exchange for borrowing $140 million to finance authority purchases of trains and engines for the Long Island Rail Road.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: Crashing The Net:

title: Political Muscle: The Only Good Enemy is a [Strong/Weak] Enemy; Straining To See the Real Russia
description: BELIEVE it: The Russians are hopping mad. For 8, 10 years now, they followed American advice on how to become capitalists. They swallowed American foreign-policy handouts urging that Russia be ''integrated into Euro-Atlantic and global communities'' and built into ''a modern, market-based economy.'' They gave up on empire, cut up their missiles and ceded three of their clients to NATO. And for what? More than $60 billion in new debt. A beggar, rubber-ruble economy. A skeletal military. A short leash held tight by the International Monetary Fund. And now, the leveling of their one remaining friend in all Europe, Yugoslavia.

title: Brooke Erdos and Kevin Singer
description: Brooke Jennifer Erdos, a daughter of Sheila and Barry Erdos of New York, was married last evening to Kevin Jay Singer, a son of Janet and Robert Singer of Boca Raton, Fla. Rabbi Arthur Nemitoff officiated at the St. Regis Hotel in New York.

description: The Rev. Vanessa Rush Southern and Rohit Jerome Nicolao Joao Menezes were married yesterday at the Universalist National Memorial Church in Washington, where the bride is its minister. The Rev. John Buehrens, the president of the Unitarian Universalist Association of America, performed the ceremony, in which his wife, the Rev. Gwen Buehrens, an Episcopal priest, also took part.

title: Program Helps Ease The Trauma of Rape
description: THE young woman had been raped numerous times by the same assailant over an extended period before she finally summoned the courage to go to the police. After answering a round of questions from the police at the precinct house, she was taken to the emergency room of a local hospital to be examined for evidence that might assist the prosecution of her assailant.

title: Corrections
description: The Bookend page on April 11 misattributed the poem ''Lpiz Azul,'' by Lorna Dee Cervantes. While it also appears in an anthology, it should have been credited to Cervantes's book ''From the Cables of Genocide'' (Arte Publico Press, 1991).

title: U.S. Customs Shows A Friendlier Face
description: IF you're flying into Kennedy International Airport from abroad these days, it will be hard to miss the signs, literally, of a kinder, gentler welcome from the United States Customs Service. Newly installed at baggage carousels, the signs, which explain how to fill out Customs declarations or why returning travelers may be questioned, reflect the agency's latest effort to be more helpful without encouraging smugglers and other lawbreakers.

title: The Curse of The Whitney
description: Spaces that have been so successful in recent years have stuck tight to their visions: the Drawing Center, the Studio Museum in Harlem, the Visionary Art Museum in Baltimore, among others. Surely the vision as set forth by Gertrude Vanderbilt Whitney was not such a bad one. While it is true that American art has risen to the international forefront, it is also true that countless talented American artists have been overlooked by the mad rush for the ''cutting edge.'' In a system such as ours, with no government funding for artists, such omissions have banished into obscurity a large portion of our cultural output, a richness that lies untapped by the very museum created to serve it. I can't imagine Gertrude being happy about that.

title: Great Neck's Dubious Honor: Superfund Site
description: THIS area is known for top schools, prosperous neighborhoods, good rail service to Manhattan and fine local shopping. Now it will have a more dubious distinction: The newest entry on the Federal Superfund list, an environmental rogue's gallery.

title: Editorial Observer; When the 'Paranoids' Turn Out to Be Right
description: Black Americans live shorter lives than whites and are more likely to suffer stress-related maladies like high blood pressure, which contributes to stroke and heart attack. The medical profession has yet to list ''racism'' as a cause of death. But some social scientists now see tension related to discrimination as a health hazard on par with smoking and a high-fat diet. Among the day-to-day acts of discrimination that shadow African-Americans, none are more stressful or dangerous than those committed by police, some of whom treat black people as criminals until proved otherwise.

title: Conversations / Skender Vehapi; In a Harrowing Flight From Kosovo, Home and Homeland Are Lost
description: MARCH 24, the day NATO jets first dropped bombs on Yugoslavia, was hardly the beginning of troubles for the ethnic Albanians in Kosovo, or the starting point of their sorrowful exile. In the months leading up to the assault, the Yugoslav army and local police, often working in tandem, forced thousands of Kosovars to flee their homes. Refugees in their own land, they wandered from village to village in search of safety and shelter. With the bombing, the Serbian Government stepped up its tactics, and , some 700,000 Albanians eventually left Kosovo outright, about half of them crossing into Albania.

title: After Drug Arrests, the Tunnel Has License Reinstated
description: Two weeks ago, the police arrested more than a dozen people on drug-related charges at or near the Tunnel, a popular nightclub, and the state quickly suspended its liquor license. But while it seemed the discotheque might be shut for good, two days after the state's action its owner, Peter Gatien, won a court order to reinstate the license.

title: From Con Ed to Board of Ed
description: Built of brick and mortar in 1925 and topped with flagpoles, the imposing five-story Consolidated Edison building on Kingsbridge Road could pass as a schoolhouse. It could become one, too, if the efforts of a local nonprofit agency and the city's Board of Education pay off.

title: Spring Seeds Of Change
description: Raising money for the arts, black leadership and sports; previewing Christie's.

title: Sports of The Times; Coach Lukas's Program Thrives
description: BOB BAFFERT's dream died. D. Wayne Lukas went to heaven. It was the latest chapter in a compelling tale of dueling egos, of two striking, media-savvy trainers who have carved their profiles into the consciousness of a fading sport that was crying out for a Rushmore of stars.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABRAMS, ARTHUR L.
description: ABRAMS-Arthur L., 86, of Scranton, PA, on April 27, 1999. Beloved husband of Ruth Friedman. Cherished father of Judy Steinhardt, Ellen Abrams, Ann Lutz. Loved by his grandchildren, David and Daniel Steinhardt and Sara Berman, Lauren and Max Stossel, Emily and Ben Kaplan. Adoring greatgrandfather of Jacob Berman. Devoted brother of Mildred Golden and Natalie Gossels. Shiva Sunday, May 2, 3-8 p.m., 211 Central Park West, Apt. 15K, and Monday, May 3, 12-9 p.m., 1158 Fifth Avenue, Apt. 16A.

title: 2,000 May Pay $2,500 Just to Welcome in 2000
description: Will it be the party of the millennium or the wretched excess of an age?

title: Beds and Custom Pieces By a Woodworking Artisan
description: Anyone with a Manhattan apartment knows the significance of space and the value of space-saving strategies. Little wonder that custom-made Murphy beds, which fold up into a cabinet, are in high demand at Precision Woodworking, a made-to-order furniture studio in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, at 1205 Manhattan Avenue (near Eagle Street).

title: MetroStars Find Goals and Victories Hard to Come By
description: Los Angeles Galaxy Coach Sigi Schmid earned the nickname Cone Man from United States national team players during the 1994 World Cup, when he served as assistant coach to Bora Milutinovic.

title: Sports of The Times; With a Nifty Spin Move, A Champion Retires on Top
description: HIS curse turned into his blessing. As the Denver Broncos' quarterback in three embarrassing Super Bowl losses, it was as if John Elway had a tattoo that read, ''Can't win the big one.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARKIN, NORMAN
description: BARKIN-Norman. Beloved husband of Henrietta. Cherished father of Phillip, Mark, and Lisa and Mitchell Wieder. Adored grandfather of Samantha and Justin, and devoted brother of Dudley and Louise. Service at I.J. Morris, Hempstead, NY, 12:30 PM, today.

title: The Doctor Is In Trouble
description: The troubled doctor, in the case discussed by Randy Cohen (The Ethicist, April 11), was a psychiatrist. All psychiatrists are, by definition, physicians. Every physician should welcome and support a consultation with a colleague for review, and other diagnostic or treatment perspectives about a patient he or she is working with. In my own practice, I request such consultations occasionally, and I always respect and cooperate with them, if my patient requests them. The patient you describe should be advised to do this.

title: Hollywood's Latest Live Action; Raging Bulls, Part II
description: IN the hierarchy of values in Hollywood, money dominates. But no one likes to talk about it. While it's perfectly normal to discuss marital infidelities, drug addiction, sexual dysfunction and other intensely personal matters, money is, curiously, not mentioned because everyone is so obsessed with it.

title: A Touch of Capri Off Los Angeles
description: ON the clearest days it rises, as the old song says, ''26 miles across the sea,'' an apparition barely visible from the beachfronts of greater Los Angeles -- if not quite Bali Ha'i, certainly an ''island of romance.'' From the bubble of a speedy jet helicopter bearing down on the picturesque harbor of Avalon, the crags of Catalina Island rise more dramatically, like some Amalfi town plopped into the Pacific off the coastal plain of Southern California.

title: In America; America's Littlest Shooters
description: When's the perfect time to give your child a gun?

title: Fighting in the Balkans Stretches the Pentagon's Resources Around the World
description: The war in the Balkans is stretching the Pentagon's longstanding global strategy, which calls for dedicating enough forces to the Persian Gulf and the Korean peninsula to fight and win wars in both places at the same time.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEIGENBAUM, ARTHUR
description: FEIGENBAUM-Arthur. On April 30, 1999. Beloved husband of the late Ethel. Devoted father of Ruth Wimpfheimer and Michael Feigenbaum. Loving grandfather of Robert, Lori, Debra, Susan, Amy, Daniel, Nachum and his precious great-granddaughter, Yakira. Services Sunday 1PM Schwartz Brothers, 114-03 Queens Blvd., Forest Hills, NY.

title: OUT THERE: London; She Without Whom No Party Is Complete
description: THREE years, some 2,000 parties and dozens of widely read columns later, Tara Palmer-Tomkinson has mixed feelings about being London's longest serving Drop Dead girl.

title: In the Region /New Jersey; Brownstone-Style Homes Rising in 3 Communities
description: IN the mid- to late 19th century, brownstones were a housing staple and rows of these attached, narrow homes sprouted in cities throughout the state. Today, with their architectural flourishes and charm, they are much-sought-after residences.

title: April 25-May 1; New Gambling Curbs Seen
description: ''We are becoming a nation of gamblers,'' said Richard C. Leone, one of the nine members of the National Gambling Impact Study Commission. Mr. Leone proposed inserting that declaration into the commission's forthcoming report, which will be delivered to Congress and President Clinton on June, 18. The commission is expected to recommend changes to state lotteries, a ban on Internet betting, tighter regulations for Indian casinos and a moratorium on gambling expansion. BRETT PULLEY

title: Do They Have An Annuity for You
description: The variable-annuity business may never be the same. T.I.A.A.-C.R.E.F., the $255 billion pension plan, has begun offering the public a no-load, extremely low-cost variable annuity, Personal Annuity Select, in seven states and is planning to roll it out nationwide. The fund previously offered variable annuities only to employees of educational and research institutions as part of their retirement plans.

title: School's New Annex Too Close for Comfort, Neighbors Say
description: Flooded with applicants and flush with alumni contributions, Columbia Grammar and Preparatory School on West 93d Street is planning to put up a five-story building on a West 92d Street lot it bought 16 years ago.

title: Eau de Rain Forest
description: 'Red fruits at 2 o'clock,'' shouts the pilot from his gondola as he nudges the blimp through dawn mist rising from the exuberant greenery. We are in the equatorial rain forest of Gabon.

title: Carolina Bank Robberies Show That Friendliness Carries a Price
description: It is virtually impossible to drive past a major intersection here without seeing a bank. Some of the nation's largest banks -- including First Union and Nationsbank -- are based here, solidifying North Carolina's reputation as the banking state.

title: Severn Taylor, Scott Switzer
description: Dorothy Severn Taylor, a daughter of Frederieke Sanders Taylor and Willard B. Taylor, both of New York, was married last evening to James Scott Switzer, the son of Sandi J. Jirka of Omaha and Jerry W. Switzer of Shelburne, Vt. The Rev. Claudia Highbaugh, a Disciples of Christ minister, officiated at the Baldwin Memorial United Methodist Church in Millersville, Md. The Rev. James M. Warner, a United Methodist minister, took part in the ceremony.

description: KLEIN-Estelle. NCJW New York Section pays tribute to a beautiful lady. First Chairperson of Council Club for Older People now Council Senior Center. A member for 73 years, her spark and leadership will long be remembered. Bernice Friedes, Jean Krosner Co-Presidents

description: Karen Sandy Bernard and Thomas Maniscalco were married on Thursday by the Rev. Pamela Bloom, an interfaith minister, at the Castle, an inn in Tarrytown, N.Y.

description: To the Editor:

title: From Sculptor's Clay to Timeless Bronze
description: LATE one recent afternoon, Gino Giannaccini, who casts bronze sculptures at his foundry in the East Village, was sitting at a table and sipping Champagne. He was as cool as the bronze he was about to pour was hot. The molten metal glowed a brilliant orange in a graphite crucible, as hazy green flames danced above it. The crucible looked like a miniature volcano about to erupt.

title: Ortega Is Still Making Contact in the Ring
description: ONE minute, the slender middle-aged man with the dark mustache and blue beret was showing 24-year-old Luis Rivera of New Haven how to use his left jab more effectively. The next minute, he was demonstrating bob-and-weave tactics to a 15-year-old prospect from Meriden named Marco Lopez. A little later, he was calling out instructions to two 12-year-old Meriden boys, Christian Badillo and Marty Wilson, as they skillfully traded punches in the boxing ring at the Beat the Street Community Center in Meriden.

title: New Library Chief
description: After nearly a year's search, the Mount Vernon Public Library has hired Rolly (Rodney) J. Lee as director of the 103-year-old institution, which serves as the central library for the Westchester Library System.

title: The World; It Costs a Lot More To Kill Fewer People
description: FOR an air war that in the eyes of many American generals has been run on the cheap, tactically, bombardment of Yugoslavia could go down as the most expensive military campaign, bomb for bomb, in history.

title: Bid for Human Rights Panel Remains a Disputed Issue
description: NOT often in Westchester has an issue arisen that has polarized religious, political, civic and other organizations more than the proposal to establish a county human rights commission, which would include homosexuals among the groups protected from discrimination.

title: NATO Sees Russia Easing Objections Over Peacekeepers
description: Russia appears to be moving toward agreeing to a United Nations Security Council resolution that would authorize an armed international military force in Kosovo to allow refugees to return, even if Yugoslavia continues to refuse one, NATO officials said today.

description: Nancy Rita Hahr and Neil Joseph Weidner were married yesterday by the Rev. John Cullinane at St. Francis Xavier Roman Catholic Church in New York.

description: IT's all in the bidin' of time. Just as the current musical theater scene on Broadway couldn't be more of a downer, things are looking up at the Paper Mill Playhouse here.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MARKFIELD, PATRICIA ELLEN
description: MARKFIELD-Patricia Ellen. 8/5/47-5/5/96. Not a day goes by without us thinking of you, missing you and loving you. You are always, always in our hearts. Lovingly, Mommy and Dale

title: In the Region /Long Island; Using Leased Land to Reduce Housing Costs
description: AN innovative way of building housing for moderate-income families is about to be tested in Huntington Station, where an East Meadow developer, Steven A. Klar, will build 100 two- and three-bedroom town houses on land leased from the Town of Huntington's Community Development Agency.

description: TOKYO UNDERWORLD

title: A Gap Where a Gap Was
description: A flier advertising a benefit for Kosovo refugees, taped to the window of the shuttered Gap store at 86th Street and Columbus Avenue, flapped in the breeze as Gwen Parker, 42, walked by on her way to work at a nearby bank.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The bottom line of this is that bank robberies are just a foolish crime. There are easier ways to get more money.''

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-22

title: Ally McBeal Dusts Off Her Shakespeare
description: THERE were those in the team of British hair and makeup experts hired to give her the fairy-tale makeover for Michael Hoffman's adaptation of ''A Midsummer Night's Dream'' who expected nothing good from Calista Flockhart. And they told her so. Cast as the lovesick Helena, the television star was going to pop over from America and proceed to be finicky, imperious and exasperatingly unaware of just how horribly she was mangling the Bard's words.

title: April 25-May 1; More Damage in Spy Case
description: Government officials now say a scientist already suspected of spying for China may have given away secrets to virtually every nuclear weapon in America's arsenal. Mainly in 1994 and 1995, the scientist, Wen Ho Lee, downloaded computer codes from a classified system at the national laboratory in Los Alamos, N.M., and transferred the data to a widely accessible computer network at the lab, officials said. Senior members of Congress expressed outrage over the Government's failure to monitor Mr. Lee.

description: David Wetherell, chief executive of CMGI Inc., the Internet-venture fund company, said he expected about a dozen of CMGI's portfolio of 36 companies to go public in the next 12 months.

description: Successful Appeal, returning to the form he showed last year, held off a late rally from the favored Best of Luck to win yesterday's $150,000 Withers Stakes for 3-year-olds at Aqueduct by a half-length.

title: KOSOVO UPDATE
description: PRISONERS

title: Rating Vans: Who Has the Best Family Room for the Road?
description: CHRYSLER created the modern minivan, and for 15 years it has successfully fended off the arrows of a pack of challengers. But the rivals keep coming with ever more potent weapons, including new vans this year from Ford and Honda (on the heels of improved competition from General Motors and Toyota).

title: An Official's Head Scarf Upsets a Turkish Taboo
description: When Turkey's newly elected Parliament convenes for the first time on Sunday, it may face its first crisis even before members take their oaths of office.

title: Ling Chow, Gilbert Liu
description: Gon Ling Chow, the daughter of Hou Fan and Fat Chow of Elmhurst, Queens, was married yesterday to Gilbert Kuang-Shi Liu, a son of Dr. George C. K. Liu of Scarsdale, N.Y., and the late Yu-Yin Liu. The Rev. Richard D. Leonard performed the ceremony at the Unitarian Church of All Souls in Manhattan.

title: A Horror Movie?
description: Compliance officers at brokerage houses think of themselves in white hats, helping to protect the investing public by making sure that their colleagues play fair. So it is no small deal in their world that what is probably the first movie to feature a compliance officer as a main character makes him one of the bad guys.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBSON, HARRY L.
description: JACOBSON-Harry L. Born May 19, 1904. Of Boynton Beach, FL. and New Rochelle, N.Y. Beloved father of Richard (Joan) and Barbara (Bill). Proud grandfather ofJohn, Jodi, Lisa, Laura and great grandfather of Hadley, Ryan, Austin and Ross. Loving companion of Elaine Halpern. Officer of A.J. Contracting Company for over 75 years. He will be dearly missed. Services private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WINSTON, SARA CHAPIN
description: WINSTON-Sara Chapin. Of Gulfstream, FL, and Harbor Springs, MI, died at home in Gulfstream on April 27, 1999 at the age of 76. ''Sammy'' was born in Grosse Pointe Farms, MI, to Inez Tiedeman and Roy D. Chapin. Her father founded the Hudson Motor Car Company and served as Secretary of Commerce in the Hoover administration. Sammy graduated from the Ethel Walker School and attended Smith College. She had a lifelong love of flying and served with the Women's Airforce Service Pilots (WASP's) in World War II, flying B-25 bombers. After the war, she was the chief pilot for a private corporation for ten years. During that time she was also the Sports Car Club of America national women's racing champion and a women's SCUBA diving pioneer. In 1957, she married Charles Hassan of Cincinnati, OH. In 1979, she was remarried to Charles Winston of Lake Forest, IL. She is survived by her sons, Chip Hassan of Denver, Peter Hassan of San Francisco, and one granddaughter. In lieu of flowers, donations requested to the Little Traverse Conservancy, 3264 Powell St, Harbor Springs, MI 49740, 616-347-0991.

title: Correction
description: The Your Home column on April 18, about ways to save on the purchasing costs of a home, misstated the conditions under which a specific type of payment rate for title insurance can be obtained. The ''simultaneous rate,'' which is used when title insurance is being purchased to cover both an owner and the owner's mortgage lender, is applied automatically to the portion of the premium covering the lender's exposure. The use of the rate is unrelated to whether an existing policy is extended. And the rate does not depend on purchasing the insurance from the seller's title company.

title: Belugas and Seals Move In at Mystic
description: The Mystic Aquarium will continue its expansion this spring with the opening of a new outdoor marine mammal habitat in mid-May. Called the Alaskan Coast, the one-acre exhibit will be home to the Aquarium's beluga whales and harbor seals. Rocks, plants and trees characteristic of south-central Alaska surround the 750,000-gallon pool. Viewing stations offer the chance to see the animals above and below the water's surface.

title: A Plate Heaped With Romance; Hold the Gorillas
description: THERE'S something different about this year's crop of summer movies. Most of the action heroes are sitting the season out, so not a single comet, meteor, dinosaur or giant gorilla is poised to destroy us all. Instead there are a swarm of romantic comedies, lovable animated robots and apemen for the children, and more restorations, rereleases and directors' cuts than you can shake a light-saber at. In this selective list, some opening dates are for New York only and at least a few are sure to change even as you're reading this.

title: Zorro's Girl Outgrows Her Petticoats
description: NEVERRR trusht a naked woman,'' Sean Connery counsels in his sibilant Scottish burr in ''Entrapment,'' the new thriller about two thieves chasing the ultimate heist. Eshpeshally, he might have added, when the woman is Catherine Zeta-Jones.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DECARLO, ANTHONY
description: DECARLO-Anthony. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Anthony DeCarlo, associated with The Times since 1994.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CANTER, STANLEY D.
description: CANTER-Stanley D., 75. April 24, 1999. He was a man of great dignity and modesty, of elegant taste, intellectual clarity and profound generosity. His thoughtfulness, his kindness, his concern for those he loved and who loved him knew no bounds. His passions for music and painting enriched his life and ours. The world has lost a rare breed of man.

title: A Road Feel at Home For the Quirky Devils
description: Friday night's 4-3 victory over the Pittsburgh Penguins guaranteed the Devils at least one more home game in the Stanley Cup playoffs, perhaps as many as 13 more in the Meadowlands. This means more nights in hotels, even when the game is at home, a team tradition that has been slightly relaxed this spring.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BLECHER, MILTON
description: BLECHER-Milton. May 2, 1914. Dear Daddy, Happy Birthday. I miss you. Love, Nanie

title: Radishes: Easy to Sprout, Hard to Grow Right
description: SOMEHOW, radishes have earned the reputation of being easy to grow. Possibly this is because the seeds germinate so quickly. Radishes are often planted in a child's garden, because they will oblige with seedlings before the child has lost interest and can be ready to eat in less than three weeks.

title: Filly Does Well, but Baffert Ends 0 for 3
description: The good draw for post position led to the telephone call that put the formidable filly Excellent Meeting into the world's most famous race. It meant that the trainer Bob Baffert had three big chances to win an unprecedented third consecutive Kentucky Derby, with Excellent Meeting, General Challenge and Prime Timber.

title: For the Birds, And Other Forms Of Wildlife
description: CAROL DECKER has been a wildlife artist for 40 years. But she still had to scramble when she found out about a poster contest for International Migratory Bird Day on Saturday.

title: Complaint Dept.
description: FAMOUS AFTER DEATH

title: Matching Up, for Travel and More
description: FOR seven years after her husband died in 1977, Margaret Hayward didn't go out much. Then, in 1985, when she was 67, she went as a single traveler on a group tour of Europe. ''I found that rather lonely,'' she recalled.

title: Votes in Congress
description: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York.

title: Using His Bag of Tricks, Cone Is a Mystery to Royals
description: Hitting against David Cone these days is like trying to guess the winner in a 19-horse field. Opposing batters don't know if he is going to take them inside or if he is going outside, if he will stalk them with his slider late in the count or go to the whip with a high fastball.

title: Hershiser's Struggle: Stop. Regroup. Pitch.
description: The first time that Jordan Hershiser, celebrity batboy, was supposed to retrieve a foul ball from the screen behind home plate yesterday, the ball remained nestled in the netting, so the 10-year-old hesitated. When Jordan finally scampered to catch the tumbling ball, Orel, his father, was about to throw his next pitch. So Jordan's father stopped, regrouped and then pitched.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DENSON, LAWRENCE J., M.D.
description: DENSON-Lawrence J., M.D. Beloved son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Denson. Beloved brother of Ruth Denson Cohen, Harold Denson, and the late Allan I. Denson. Services to be held at Gutterman-Musicant Funeral Home, Hackensack, NJ, Monday, April 3, at 10:30 AM. Interment at Riverside Cemetery, Saddle Brook, NJ.

title: Soap Opera Leaves a Ring
description: Jerry Lanning, 55, waited for his car service limousine in front of the NBC television studio on East 14th Street off Avenue M. He had spent a business-as-usual Tuesday morning playing a judge on the soap opera ''Another World.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DE VRIES, LION J.
description: de VRIES-Lion J. Beloved husband of Tilly, loving father of Christina and Eveline, grandfather to Bridge and Michael, passed away on April 29, 1999. Memorial service will be held on Sunday, May 2nd, his birthday, at 4 PM, Marble Collegiate Church, 29th St, and 5th Ave.

title: New Direction for Transplants Raises Hopes and Questions
description: Transplant surgeons who once concentrated on vital organs like hearts, livers and kidneys are branching out, transplanting an array of body parts with surprising success, and possibly heralding a day when tissues not essential to life are routinely given to others.

title: At the Aldrich, a Pair of Unsettling Shows to Prod the Viewer
description: THe Aldrich Museum of Contemporary Art in Ridgefield has two exhibitions that are designed to unsettle viewers.

title: 70's Torturer In Cambodia Now 'Doing God's Work'
description: Cambodians know him as the cruelest of the Khmer Rouge torturers, the author of such directives as ''Use the hot method, even if it kills him'' and, in the margin of a list of 17 children, ''Kill them all.''

title: The Flashing Around Roof Joints
description: A HOUSE roof has joints between roof sections and around vents, skylights and chimneys. These joints are vulnerable to leaking because they usually connect different materials that expand and contract at dissimilar rates. The joints may also separate as the house settles.

title: PULSE; Press With the Coolest Iron
description: Once a throwaway novelty, paper clothing is being recycled this season by serious designers and collectors. Sotheby's is auctioning paper wear like the floral wedding dress, left, at ''Pulp Fashion'' tomorrow evening, and an exhibition of vintage clothes remodeled in paper opens at the Museum at the Fashion Institute of Technology in June. While paper garments have tended to the gimmicky -- the red, white and blue Nixon-campaign dress in the Sotheby's sale, for example -- the new models are fashion conscious. Vivienne Tam has shorts and jackets, left, in Tyvek, the stuff Federal Express envelopes are made of ($98 to $155; 99 Greene Street, at Prince Street). Prada has paper jackets and vests, right, ($390 to $680), and Martin Margiela 6 offers jeans and shells ($33 to $107). But what about wear and tear? Meghan Kinney, a designer, who is making long gathered paper skirts for fall, said the new paper fabrics are very durable -- unless they reach the dry cleaner or the dryer. ''You'll end up with a melted mess,'' she said. NANCY MacDONNELL SMITH

title: Perfect Picture
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Virginia Trial Will Bring Back Many of the Players in the Clinton Scandal
description: In a Federal courtroom here on Monday, Kenneth W. Starr's prosecutors will begin the trial of the first and only person to be charged with a crime related to the sprawling sex and perjury investigation that led to President Clinton's impeachment.

title: April 25-May 1; Court Rejects Theory In Espy Prosecution
description: With a narrow interpretation of the Federal gratuity statute, the Supreme Court made it substantially less likely that someone could inadvertently cross the line between bestowing gifts on a public official and committing a crime. The unanimous decision rejected the theory behind an independent counsel's prosecution of Mike Espy, the former Agriculture Secretary, and of an agricultural cooperative convicted of giving him tennis tickets and other items.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MALAMUT, MARGUERITE
description: MALAMUT-Marguerite. The entire Beth Israel Medical Center family joins with the leadership of its parent company, Continuum Health Partners, Inc., in acknowledging with sadness the passing of Marguerite Malamut, beloved wife of our dear friend and benefactor, Abraham L. Malamut, Treasurer of the Beth Israel Board of Trustees. To Abe, his family and all of his wife's loved ones, we extend our heartfelt condolences. Morton P. Hyman Chairman, Boards of Trustees, Continnum and Beth Israel Robert G. Newman, M.D. President and CEO, Continuum Matthew E. Fink, M.D. President and CEO, Beth Israel Henry Singman, M.D. President, Beth Israel Medical Bd.

title: Why the Foreign Film Has Lost Its Cachet
description: ONCE upon a time, people in my circle took it for granted that for grown-ups who knew the facts of life, and the truths of existence, the only ''mature'' films came from abroad. Hollywood was strictly for children, and adults with childish fantasies. Espresso in the lobby was still exotic, and the newly built Paris Theater in Manhattan advertised its ''love seats,'' deux par deux, for couples seeking the intimacies of forbidden ecstasies in such daring imports as ''Symphonie Pastorale'' and ''Devil in the Flesh.''

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: May 2, 1999
description: Weeks

title: Give a Dog a Bone
description: Like the hundreds of other shelters in the state, St. Hubert's Animal Welfare Center in Madison must provide not only space but also food. As about 110,000 dogs and cats are sheltered in the state each year, that's a lot of kibbled biscuit. So through next Saturday, the final day of national Be Kind to Animals Week, St. Hubert's is asking that those who shop for pet food pick up some extra, which the organization will distribute to shelters and animal rescue organizations. The campaign is the organization's first and, as far as the people there know, the first statewide pet food drive anywhere. St. Hubert's has enlisted a number of corporate donors like Milk Bone, Hills Pet Nutrition and Petsmart, and schools around the state are taking part. Donations may be dropped off at all 14 Petsmart stores in New Jersey, and at St. Hubert's sites at 575 Woodland Avenue and 22 Prospect Street in Madison and 3201 Route 22 East in North Branch. Information: (973) 377-7094, extension 237.

title: Festival to Festival, a Movable Marketplace
description: IN 1939, a cavalcade of Hollywood stars including Gary Cooper, Mae West, Norma Shearer, George Raft and Douglas Fairbanks Jr. set sail on a steamship bound for Cannes, France, for the start of the first Cannes International Film Festival. ''The Wizard of Oz'' was one of the movies scheduled to screen there, but it was never shown. One day into the event, Hitler invaded Poland and the festival shut down. It was not revived until 1947.

title: The Seven-Year Itch: Where Are They Now?
description: SEVEN years ago this week, my first Vows column appeared among the wedding announcements in the Styles section. The idea was, and still is, to tell the story behind one wedding each week, to report on everything from how the couple met to their first kiss to the exact shade of the bride's dress -- which has occasionally been difficult to capture. I've used every comparison, from tofu to melted coffee ice cream.

title: Building a Bridge for the Next 1,000 Years
description: IN the mostly Italian-American and Jewish neighborhood of Pelham Parkway in the Bronx where he grew up, Dr. Anthony J. Cernera said that strained relations between Christians and Jews was never an issue. Mutual respect and a celebration of religious differences were commonplace, he said.

title: Billboard Sets Off Angry Chorus
description: Just one day before the Colorado high school killings, an advertisement depicting a young basketball player holding a gun went up on Malcolm X Boulevard between 124th and 125th Streets, across the street from the Rice High School for Boys. Councilman Bill Perkins noticed the large billboard, which stretched across one face of a four-story building, on his way to work the day the sign went up, April 19. By the time he got to his office, he said, he had already received several calls from angry constituents.

title: Soapbox: Adding Insult to Injury; From the Illegal Hotel Downstairs, Unwelcome Commentary
description: THEY arrive in the middle of the night. Juiced up from the flight from the West Coast, they decompress by heading outside to smoke endless cigarettes on the tiny deck beneath my windows, which I keep open because my apartment is always warm. My downstairs neighbor left New York for a job in Los Angeles almost a year ago and has turned her rent-stabilized apartment into a hotel room rentable by the night.

title: Push-In Robberies
description: The police in Port Chester are trying to track down Spanish-speaking robbers who, they say, are entering apartments of immigrant laborers by force, tying up the occupants and stealing their money. Six such incidents have occurred in the village since last fall, Chief Joseph M. Krzeminski of the Port Chester Police Department said.

title: A Boutique Red
description: The winery, Ternhaven Cellars, is tiny, but its 1995 cabernet sauvignon (about $21) is big. The dark opaqueness and the bouquet signify that the wine is beefy, and the flavor delivers quick confirmation. Indeed, the wine should be served with prime ribs of beef and steak.

title: Roth Redux
description: Start marinating the fatted calf, Newark. Philip Roth is coming home.

title: Planet Hollywood Indeed
description: IN one of the later chapters of ''Gulliver's Travels,'' Jonathan Swift describes the flying island of Laputa, a block of earth four miles across that, thanks to its magnetized core, its inhabitants could raise, lower or pilot at will.

title: Traditional Italian With Old World Charm
description: THE trademarks of a traditional Italian restaurant are everywhere at Villa Borghese in Great Neck. First there is the generosity, quickly illustrated by free olive oil and tomato-soaked bruschetta for all hands and toast rounds spread with tapenade (not just one piece for each person, but extras as well). Lemon brandy at meal's end was also gratis. Second is the decor. It is anything but cutting edge, glitzy or glamorous. This restful green-hued dining room with its 19th-century statuary, urns and paintings, wine racks, antipasto table, parquet floors, Italian music, plants, dried flowers, widely spaced tables and very Italian waiters is an unapologetic throwback. It offers relaxed, Old World charm, not trendy, frenetic 1990's eating. No wonder, its owners also own a restaurant in Rome and have, at least in part, recreated it at 132 Middle Neck Road (466-1159).

title: Mariachi Memories Of a 30's Tone Poet
description: IN the calendar of saints, the last day of the year belongs to St. Sylvester, and it was on that day in the last year of the 1800's that the Mexican composer Silvestre Revueltas was born. Now, several months before his centenary, Sony Classical has released an exhilarating Revueltas album, with Esa-Pekka Salonen conducting the Los Angeles Philharmonic and its New Music Group, and other new releases round out the picture.

title: Literacy Groups: Filling One of Life's Needs
description: FOR one Yonkers mother, the turning point came when she could not read a bedtime story to her 4-year-old son. For a White Plains construction worker, it came when he was unable to fill out a health insurance form. A recent immigrant from China made her decision after she came home weeping from an open house at her daughter's school in Ossining because she had not understood a word, spoken or written.

title: April 25-May 1; An Import That Japan Likes
description: Don't worry. This isn't another Viagra joke.

title: Nothin' Left to Lose
description: SCARS OF SWEET PARADISE The Life and Times of Janis Joplin. By Alice Echols. Illustrated. 408 pp. New York: Metropolitan Books/ Henry Holt & Company. $26.

title: A 'Rough Year' Tarnishes a Prosecutor's Reputation
description: When Patricia A. Hurt was appointed just over a year ago as the Essex County Prosecutor, the accolades were quick to pour in. She was the first black woman to hold the job, and as a Republican in an overwhelmingly Democratic county, she brought what many considered a refreshing mix of law-and-order conservatism and social advocacy.

title: Ira Glass Is, Um (Pause, Delete) . . . Listening
description: Marshall Sella (April 11) describes some of the strange little tools Ira Glass uses to craft his show -- the pauses, the obsessive edits. But he forgot one: the swallow. Ira Glass swallows loudly all the time. He may agonize over the ums and giggles, but he indulges every one of his swallows.

title: The Counters Have Started The Countdown
description: THE countdown to the new millennium has everyone's attention, but for officials and community leaders, another countdown is under way: to the national census next year.

title: Opening The Pool For Summer
description: WITH summer fast approaching, homeowners with swimming pools are about to engage in an annual rite of spring -- opening up the pool in time for the Memorial Day weekend.

title: In Search of the Perfect Sector
description: ONE of the most popular strategies for mutual fund investors is sector rotation. More than 20 of the 66 fund newsletters tracked by the Hulbert Financial Digest pursue such a strategy at least in part, three times the total a decade ago.

title: The Nation; When Ideology Goes Where Actuaries Tread
description: AS legislation, the plan to overhaul the Social Security system announced last week by two influential Republican Congressmen is going nowhere.

title: Broncos Could Become Ordinary
description: There are excruciating draft day decisions, ones that keep personnel men in the National Football League awake for days afterward. And then there are the no-brainers. One day in 1983, Ernie Accorsi had an easy choice to make. No advanced degrees required.

title: Miss Herbert and Mr. Handwerger
description: Stephanie Alice Herbert, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene T. Herbert of Great Falls, Va., was married yesterday to Mark Richman Handwerger, the son of Gretchen Mann Handwerger and Joseph Handwerger, both of Washington. The Rev. William P. Billow Jr., an Episcopal priest and chaplain of the St. Albans School in Washington, performed the ceremony at the Washington National Cathedral.

title: Awnings Wage a Food Fight
description: Fairway and Citarella, the upscale food markets on Broadway between 74th and 75th Streets, have long competed, and not always politely, for the palates and pocketbooks of Upper West Side shoppers. But lately the two markets have become embroiled in a turf battle over awnings.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SWIECHOCKI, STANLEY
description: SWIECHOCKI-Stanley. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Stanley F. Swiechocki, associated with The Times since 1963 until retiring in 1989.

title: A Good Man Mad
description: A PRAYER FOR

title: Michi Weglyn, 72, Who Wrote Of Interned Japanese-Americans
description: Michi N. Weglyn, author of an acclaimed book about the internment of Japanese-Americans in the United States during World War II, died last Sunday at her home on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. She was 72.

title: It's Time to Divide and Conquer Perennials
description: PERENNIAL borders have made a big comeback in the last few years. There are many reasons, including aggressive promotion efforts by the nursery industry. Sales of these handsome plants have exploded and the beauty of many gardens has been greatly enhanced. But there is also a myth that perennial gardens are low maintenance. No way.

title: Bidders Without Faces
description: THE auction, it seems, is the emblematic transaction of our time, as characteristic of fin-de-siecle America as the potlatch in some tribal societies, or imperial land grants in colonial days. As a means of exchange, it encapsulates a good deal about us, with our emphasis on individual freedom, fair markets and, lately, technology. For while many of us still imagine a fast-talking, gavel-wielding auctioneer, or perhaps the desperate shouting of traders in the commodities pits, the rise of the auction is now fueled by computers.

title: Op-Art; Caption
Wibby Stevenson and Kent Sevener
description: Elizabeth Van Buren Stevenson, the daughter of John H. Stevenson 3d of St. Louis and the late Elizabeth Gamp Stevenson, was married yesterday to Kent L. Sevener, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Keith M. Sevener of Charlotte, Mich. Canon Alan E. Tilson performed the Anglican ceremony at Holy Trinity Church in Hamilton Parish, Bermuda.

title: We Have Gone Too Far to Protect Internet Speech
description: To the Editor:

title: Democratic Roots
description: To the Editor:

title: April 25-May 1; A Red Alert for America's Forests
description: Red maples, long seen as the poor relations of the maple family, are taking over America's Eastern forests.

title: Tricia Carine and John Scarlata
description: Tricia Lyn Carine, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur G. Carine Jr. of Cliffside Park, N.J., was married on Friday to John Christopher Scarlata, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John M. Scarlata of Melville, N.Y. The Rev. Timothy Tighe performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Fordham University Chapel in the Bronx.

title: Walter J. Cummings, 82, Dies; Appellate Judge Since 1966
description: Judge Walter J. Cummings, who at 36 became the youngest Solicitor General of the United States and went on to be one of the longest-serving Federal appellate court judges in the nation's history, died on April 24 at Northwestern Memorial Hospital in Chicago. He was 82 and lived in Chicago.

title: THEATER; Narrating a Play's Action While Taking Part in It
description: CONFRONTATION brews in a pool of white light. The surrounding area is bare, except for a table holding a few medical implements. A young man denounces a doctor for lies and hypocrisy. The accused regards him with growing annoyance and finally barks, ''You damn sullen, self-centered, self-pitying, arrogant, untested, know-nothing adolescent!''

title: Crediting Librettists
description: To the Editor:

title: Measuring the Numbers In Divorce Settlements
description: THEY may be four of the most unsettling words a spouse can hear: ''I want a divorce.'' That simple sentence can send families tumbling down a road of turmoil, emotional pain, and financial disaster. But once the words have been spoken, what's the next step?

title: The Good Side
description: To the Editor:

title: Co-op Prices In ZIP Code 11229
description: To the Editor:

title: An Indebted Israel Shelters Family of Kosovo Albanians
description: When Lamija Jaha and her husband were driven out of their apartment and herded with thousands of ethnic Albanians to trains that would take them from Pristina, the capital of Kosovo, she took a memento of her dead father in her pocket.

title: The Original Boss
description: ON Election Night, May 10, 1949, as word spread throughout Jersey City that the most powerful political machine in American history had been defeated. I recall people running down the streets shouting, ''Hague lost!'' People poured out of their homes, as a crowd of 25,000 converged on City Hall from all directions. Many of the revelers sang the theme song of the anti-Hague forces, ''Now is the Hour.'' One gang carried a mock coffin with a placard that said, ''Here lies the remains of the Hague machine -- 36 years of age.'' The doors of City Hall were forced open, and hundreds stormed into its once-forbidden corridors. Three of the new city commissioners made their way to the basement, where a furnace had been going full blast on this warm spring day, as Mr. Hague's henchmen shoveled secret documents into the fire in expectation of defeat.

title: The Way We Live Now: 5-2-99: Questions for Francis Fukuyama; The Unselfish Gene
description: Q: In your new book, you present the contentious view that on some fundamental, genetic level, human beings are built for consensus. Can you explain that?

title: The Glory Days of the Grand Turk
description: Lords of the Horizons

title: Correction
description: The Good Eating column last Sunday, about French restaurants on the East Side of Manhattan, carried erroneous rating symbols for Adrienne, Fifth Avenue at 55th Street. It should have been marked ''++,'' denoting a review in the Diner's Journal column (on Dec. 11, 1998), not ''****.'' [Rating: four stars]

title: A Gift of Summer, for a Child
description: Summer is a punishment for children who live in neighborhoods barren of grass, with streets so dangerous that parents confine boys and girls to the front steps or keep them indoors. For children like these, a yearly vacation in the country can make the difference between a childhood in the shadows and a childhood with sunshine, swimming and a chance to make new friends.

title: The Anthropologist Of Dressing Rooms
description: IN a dressing room deep in the men's department of Macy's in Paramus, N.J., a lone linty french fry nuzzled a balled-up Kleenex. A few cardboard strips, discarded from shirt collars, beckoned from across the maroon carpet. Straight pins glinted shyly under a bench.

title: River Village Plans For Life After G.M.
description: General Motors is almost done taking apart the massive plant here where it made 11 million cars. As workers cart off chunks of steel and long ribbons of aluminum in the shadow of the Hudson highlands, this village is beginning to feel less like a factory town and more like a river town.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, KATHRYN
description: FRIEDMAN-Kathryn. On April 30, 1999. The family of Kathryn Friedman notes her death with great sadness. She will be missed. Service Monday, 1 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Contributions in her memory to the DeWitt Nursing Home, 211 East 79th Street, NY NY 10021.

title: A Perfectionist Tries to Make a Fish Story Titanic
description: HE has spent the morning polishing his shark as if he were someone detailing a car -- meticulously examining the gleaming grillwork of its mouth, the coldness of its eyes, the rakish tilt of its dorsal fin -- and now Renny Harlin must face the music.

title: JERSEY DIARY
description: Sometimes a Jersey woman, approaching the Big Apple after a 45-minute ride on a Jersey bus, needs to be woken up. A look out the window at the truck in front of my bus did the trick. On its rear doors were these handpainted words: ''Warning. Driver Off Medication. Stay Back.''

title: The Perils of Investing On Automatic Pilot
description: WHILE stock investors applauded the Dow Jones industrial average's assault this week on another nice round number -- 11,000 -- it is likely that few of them were participating in the profits. That's because most investors have money in stocks listed not in the Dow but in the Standard & Poor's 500, which has risen only half as much as the Dow this year.

title: Pianist Who Hears the Call of the Wild
description: MAKE no mistake about it: to these animals, this is their world and you are their guest.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about the Doo Dah parade in Ocean City misstated the amount of money raised by one group of marchers, the Tristate Basset Hound Rescue League. It was more than $10,000, not more than $20,000.

title: Why a Priest
description: I walked away from the Catholic Church years ago but still enjoy taking my brother, who attends Mount Saint Mary's Seminary, out for a good meal whenever he visits the city.

title: Making History; What Grade Schoolers Learn About Their State's Past Can Shape Its Future
description: DONNA ROSS, a fourth-grade teacher, was explaining her classroom's four-foot-long jigsaw puzzle of New Jersey. The geography made sense; the accompanying artwork didn't.

title: I.G. Farben: A Lingering Relic of the Nazi Years
description: GERMANY is still haunted by many ghosts from the dark years of Nazi rule, but few are as enduring or as strange as the specter of I.G. Farben.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PHELPS, MIRIAM E.
description: PHELPS-Miriam E. April 26, 1999. Beloved sister of Elinor Schmitt. Loving aunt of Deborah Bussert, Janet Lordi and Gary Schmitt. Funeral Service were held on Wednesday, April 28th at Frank E. Campbell.

title: At the Scene Of a Crime?
description: Q. I recently discovered that the corporate division in which I am a manager has been engaging in practices that are at least questionable and possibly illegal. With a few discreet questions, I have learned that the vice president in charge of the division sanctions the activities and that my peers don't share my qualms. Without disclosing my reason, I have lined up a transfer out of the division, but it won't take effect for several months. In the meantime, how can I protect myself if things blow up? Should I talk to a lawyer?

title: Strange Fits of Passion
description: THE HIDDEN WORDSWORTH Poet, Lover, Rebel, Spy. By Kenneth R. Johnston. Illustrated. 965 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $45.

title: Mind Over Machine?
description: Sometimes it's the hardware. Sometimes it's the software. And sometimes it's just human error. Computer mistakes, malfunctions and glitches, beyond the obviously misdirected E-mail, continue to spread faster than a computer virus. What are your own most humorous or horrific stories? Send them to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: Putting a Braver Face On Japan's Bad Loans
description: ''HE'S Don Quixote,'' said Jun Satoh, chief manager of credit policy for the Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi, motioning to his senior colleague, Eiichi Haruki. ''I'm Sancho.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZWEIG, LEON A.
description: ZWEIG-Leon A. Of N. Bellmore, NY, April 29, 1999. He is survived by his wife Rusty, daughters Heda and Joni, granddaughter Madhurii, brother Stanley and sister-in-law Shirley. Services will be held at Gutterman's Funeral Home in Rockville Centre, Monday, May 3, at 10:30 AM.

title: Correction
description: An article on April 4 about Intercounty Judicial Services, a process-serving company accused of failure to serve legal documents after certifying delivery, misidentified the company that Ruby P. Rosenfeld, a Dix Hills resident, accused of failure to serve legal papers regarding a real estate deal. Though she had used Intercounty in other cases, her accusation in the real estate deal involved a different company, Interboro Process Service.

title: Sulawesi, Exotic and Worldly
description: SULAWESI, a disheveled starfish of an island that came to rest on cerulean seas between Borneo and the Moluccas, has long been home to people at ease with the wider world. But lacking expansive beaches and great historical monuments, Sulawesi has not had much chance to demonstrate its uncomplicated worldliness to tourists, who flock instead to other Indonesian islands: mystical, introverted Java or the nonstop arts festival that is Bali.

title: Code-Sharing: Cluing In Fliers
description: IF you want a view of the world turned upside down and inside out, study the airline practice known as code-sharing. The general theory of relativity is not too much more complex.

title: Jennifer Miller, Scott Romanoff
description: Jennifer Lauren Miller, a daughter of Carole Miller of Philadelphia and Andrew Miller of Rydal, Pa., was married last evening to Scott Adam Romanoff, the son of Leslie and Richard Romanoff of Edgewater, N.J. Rabbi William Dreskin officiated at the Metropolitan Pavilion, a loft space in Chelsea.

title: When Students Dont Clique
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Essay; The Price of Distrust
description: Congress is not only ambivalent about buying into ''Clinton's War,'' it is also of two minds about being ambivalent.

title: David Duke Misses Louisiana Runoff but Has Strong Showing
description: Despite having five viable and conservative alternatives, one of every five voters in Louisiana's First Congressional District voted on Saturday for David E. Duke, a former Ku Klux Klan leader and self-styled defender of the rights of European-Americans.

title: Compressed Data; Alexa's Crusade Continues Under Amazon.com's Flag
description: It began as a crusade: to archive for posterity the entire contents of the World Wide Web, which had reached some 13 trillion bytes at the latest count.

title: Jagr Plays With an Injury, but It's the Devils Who Feel His Pain
description: On the brink of capturing their opening-round Stanley Cup playoff series, the Devils were victimized by the Penguin star Jaromir Jagr today. Making an electrifying return from a groin injury that had kept him out of four previous games, Jagr tied the score with a goal late in the third period and sent the Devils to a 3-2 defeat with another goal in overtime.

title: Low-Wage Businesses Add to Number of Uninsured Workers
description: A long-spreading gap between the wages of undereducated workers in menial jobs and those of skilled college graduates is contributing to another gap, in workers' health benefits, a research journal reports.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SOUTHARD, ALICE DONNELLY
description: SOUTHARD-Alice Donnelly, May 3, 1998. Dear sister, the laughter, love and confidence we shared blissfully pervade my mournful thoughts. Always, Sabina

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: EVENTS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VETTER, WARREN H.
description: VETTER-Warren H. On April 30, 1999. Beloved brother of Margaret Jesser and Howard. Also survived by many nieces and nephews. Visiting Monday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM, at the Vernon C. Wagner Funeral Homes, Inc., 125 Old Country Rd., Hicksville, NY. Funeral Tuesday, 10 AM. Interment Calverton National Cemetery, Calverton, NY.

title: Bert Remsen, Actor on Stage And Screen, 74
description: Bert Remsen, a stage, screen and television actor for some 50 years, died on April 22 at his home in California's San Fernando Valley. He was 74.

title: Colombia's Offer to Rebels Appears Futile
description: Nearly six months ago, the Colombian Government ceded control of a Switzerland-sized area to the country's main Marxist guerrilla group, a good-faith gesture intended to jump-start peace talks here. But with a deadline for the Government's withdrawal from the zone less than a week away, the rebels appear reluctant to budge -- either from their jungle stronghold here or from a sweeping list of demands that stalled the discussions.

title: Internet Phone Venture Will Sell Stock
description: In what would apparently be the first initial public offering of stock in a company that focuses exclusively on transmitting phone calls using Internet technology, RSL Communications Ltd. plans to announce today that it intends to sell stock in its Delta 3 subsidiary.

title: Erik Johan Friis, 86, a Publisher and Translator
description: Erik Johan Friis, an editor and publisher whose work was well known to Scandinavian-American readers, died on April 5 at his home in Montvale, N.J. He was 86.

title: Grandstanding, Not Educating
description: Once again, Mayor Rudolph Giuliani is shrewdly leading us into a diversion: a discussion of the politics of education rather than the quality of education. Yes, the politics are sexier -- sound bites attacking the school bureaucracy and support of poll-tested programs certainly grab headlines. But let's not be fooled. The politics have nothing to do with the issue of how public school education can be improved.

title: Officer Rescues Woman From Burning Car, Twice
description: An off-duty police officer rescued a woman from a burning car on a Staten Island street early yesterday, only to watch in amazement as the woman ran back to the car and shut herself inside, the police said.

title: Dr. Jere Lord Jr., 88; Led Heart Association
description: Jere W. Lord Jr., a retired cardiovascular surgeon, a professor of clinical surgery and a former president of the New York Heart Association, died on April 20 at his home in Bedford, N.Y. He was 88.

title: From a Claimer to a Champ: Now That's Charismatic
description: Ten of the 19 horses who ran in the Kentucky Derby were booked today into the Preakness, the second race in the Triple Crown, including the top four finishers led by Charismatic, the 31-1 long shot who won the Derby in the final strides.

title: Pataki Tests National Waters, but Barely a Ripple Is Seen
description: Gov. George E. Pataki had just finished a 50-minute speech at Georgetown University about the Balkans when a student interposed a question that had little to do with Mr. Pataki's views on foreign policy: Why was a New York governor offering a major address in Washington on global problems in the first place? ''Normally, those are handled by Presidents and Vice Presidents,'' Matthew Payne, a government major, observed dryly.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BALANCHINE, GEORGE
description: BALANCHINE-George. A service in memory of George Balanchine will be held on Tuesday, May 4, 1999 at 7:30 P.M., at the Cathedral of Our Lady of the Sign, 75 East 93rd Street, New York, New York.
