title: TECHNOLOGY: E-Commerce Report; On-line security isn't expensive. But by ignoring it, many sites are risking customers and Government intervention.
description: TO placate those who worry about how secure it is to shop on line, companies typically proffer the idea that buying on the Internet is no more risky than giving a credit card to a waiter in a restaurant.

title: Few Clues in Accident As 13th Victim Is Found
description: A team of divers returned today to the bottom of the serene lake where a tourist boat slipped below the surface on Saturday, finding a 13th victim but failing to shed light on the cause of the swift deaths of so many people.

title: Fast Rise of CART Rookie Seems an Echo of Zanardi's
description: Juan Montoya's quick rise to Champ Car prominence is reminiscent of another aggressive and confident driver who seemingly came from out of nowhere to win consecutive championships in 1997 and 1998.

title: Pastor's Embrace of Giuliani Sparks a Debate
description: In the two weeks since he made headlines by embracing Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani at St. Patrick's Cathedral, the Rev. Calvin O. Butts 3d said he has been in a state somewhere between gratification and bewilderment.

title: Treasury to Sell Short-Term Bills
description: At Auctions Today

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OLSEN, HANNAH M.
description: OLSEN-Hannah M. Beloved wife of the late Harry Olsen, devoted mother of the late Laurence Olsen and caring sister of David Mahler. Died peacefully May 1, 1999, at 87 years. Interment private.

title: Media; Why was network television so attracted to the Littleton shootings? In part, it was bafflement.
description: WHEN the first frightening images flashed onto television screens from Littleton, Colo., on Tuesday afternoon, April 20, it was clearly a major story, one the cable news networks would cover around the clock.

title: The Big City; Juror Ponders The Severity Of Drug Laws
description: A JURY was being selected for a drug case, and as soon as I confessed my occupation the prosecutor raised a question: did I have opinions on drugs that would prevent me from being a fair juror? ''Well, I have opinions,'' I said, but I assured him I could set them aside. What else could I say without professional embarrassment? ''No, I'm such a biased journalist that my judgment is hopelessly impaired.''

title: United Nations Group Issues Report on Internet Addresses
description: Speculating in the registration and resale of potentially valuable Internet addresses would effectively be outlawed under new rules proposed by the intellectual property body of the United Nations. The proposal would also give companies and people with claims to famous words or trademarks first claim to certain Internet addresses.

title: James W. Kennedy, 93, Episcopal Church Rector
description: The Rev. Dr. James William Kennedy, a former rector of the Church of the Ascension in Greenwich Village, died April 21 at a retirement community in Fort Myers, Fla. He was 93.

title: A WOMAN'S PLACE: A special report; Lower-Caste Women Turn Village Rule Upside Down
description: Rani, an illiterate woman from the washermen's caste, changed into her prettiest sari one recent morning. Heavy with child, she boarded a series of crowded, ramshackle buses for the dusty, two-and-a-half-hour ride to the bureaucrat who has become her teacher in the art of governing.

title: Move Revives Memories of Bronx Blight
description: Like many neighborhoods in the South Bronx, the Longwood section has literally risen from the ashes. Once eroded by fires and abandonment, it has built new homes, rehabilitated old ones, and driven out drug dealers.

title: Gatekeeper to the Stars; A Strong-Willed Publicity Agent Has Changed the Rules
description: Pat Kingsley tends to minimize her role in Hollywood. But no one else does.

title: Man Charged in London Attacks Aimed at Minorities
description: The British police charged a 22-year-old engineer with murder today after three crude and brutal nail-bomb attacks on ethnic minorities and gays in recent days that killed 3 people, wounded more than 100 and confronted Britons with a violent challenge to their avowed tolerance.

title: Congress and Kosovo
description: To the Editor:

title: Gracefully Ruffling Feathers With a Provocative Esthetic
description: Love it or hate it, the first full-evening production of ''Swan Lake'' at the New York City Ballet is already the talk of the town.

title: Marketing Tied to Charities Draws Scrutiny From States
description: Nonprofit organizations take in roughly a half-billion dollars a year for lending their good names to the marketing of everything from nicotine patches to pain relievers. But consumers are sometimes confused about whether these are meant to be endorsements, and regulators are not amused.

title: NATO Admits Missile Hit Bus but Says Bridge Was a Legitimate Target
description: NATO acknowledged today that one of its missiles had accidentally hit a bus in Kosovo on Saturday but insisted that the bridge it was crossing had been a legitimate military target.

title: Patents; A system that makes taking supplemental vitamins as easy as breathing in and out.
description: CEREAL makers, milk producers and skin-care cosmetic companies put vitamins in their products and call them vitamin fortified, making consumers feel better about what they are ingesting or rubbing on their faces.

title: INSIDE
description: Arrest in London Bombings

title: For Coders, a Code of Conduct; 2000 Problem Tests Professionalism of Programmers
description: It is spelled out, right there in the code of ethics of the Association for Computing Machinery, one of the world's oldest and largest computer professional societies: ''An essential aim of computer professionals is to minimize negative consequences of computer systems, including threats to health and safety.''

title: Media Talk; A New Magazine's Debt to Its Writers
description: By all outward appearances, Icon Magazine, a glossy monthly aimed at the young men's market -- it features articles about action-movie directors, supermodels, Charlton Heston and how to get ahead in business -- seems to be doing as well as any two-year-old magazine could be.

title: A Pollock in Australia
description: To the Editor:

title: Equity Offerings Scheduled for This Week
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: Firing Was Justified
description: To the Editor:

title: POWER STRUGGLE EXPOSES CRACKS IN POLICE UNION
description: The Patrolmen's Benevolent Association has long served as the unified voice and jut-jawed defender of New York City police officers, the architect of a blue wall of solidarity that supports them, right or wrong.

title: Compressed Data; Dragon Systems Postpones Its Public Offering Indefinitely
description: Ever since Dragon Systems Inc. said earlier this year that it planned to sell a minority stake to the public, the company has challenged convention. Amid a crowd of flimsy software industry start-ups, it has a 16-year track record, real profits and no debt. In a field run by youngsters, its 50-ish founders are still in charge.

title: Sports of The Times; Jagr 'Smelled a Chance' For the Winning Goal
description: TWO weeks ago, Wayne Gretzky passed the torch to Jaromir Jagr, and yesterday Jagr burned the Devils with it.

title: Papers Battle to Control Hollywood's Buzz
description: Every weekday morning Hollywood awakens to ''the trades,'' Daily Variety and The Hollywood Reporter, which talk about the deals, the rumors and the announcements that spin out of film studios and cable and television networks.

title: CLINTON WILL MEET THE RUSSIAN ENVOY ON BALKANS TODAY
description: The White House said today that President Clinton planned to meet Viktor S. Chernomyrdin, the Russian envoy for the Balkans, on Monday to discuss possible solutions to the war in Kosovo. Administration officials said it was unclear whether the Russian was bringing any new proposals.

title: Prosperity for All?
description: To the Editor:

title: Media Talk; Newspaper Chain to Open Training Center
description: Can't find good young reporters? Can't keep them when you've found them? Thomson Newspapers thinks it may have the answer: grow your own. And grow your own journalism school to train them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALEXANDER, OTTO (LOPEZ)
description: ALEXANDER-Otto (Lopez). Multi-talented artist, beloved brother and son. Loving friend and a beautiful human being whose memory will be cherished forever, died April 26 in an accident. Memorial service later in May. For information call 212-222-9184.

title: Compressed Data; Free PC Plans to Announce A List of Big Investors
description: Free PC Inc., the company that started the free-computer movement in February by promising to give away 10,000 computers, contends that it now has the financial backing to support the first phase of its business model.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'DAY, DANIEL
description: O'DAY-Daniel. Age 92, of Rye, NY, on April 30. Husband of the late Ida Sadler O'Day. Father of Daniel O'Day, Jr. Funeral services will be held at 10:30 AM, on Wednesday, May 5, at Christ Church, Rye, NY. In lieu of flowers contributions to the Taft School, Watertown, CT 06795, or the Rye Historical Society, Rye, NY 10580, would be appreciated.

title: Op-Art
Paid Notice: Deaths  ABBOTT, RON
description: ABBOTT-Ron. On April 3, 1999. Broadway stage manager, TV producer/director. Later owner of The Abbott Group, Sherman Oaks, CA. Survived by Annie, Erika, Zoe, Richie Abbott, Dottie Yeoman.

title: Milosevic, The Perfect Dictator
description: If you are looking for an example of the genius of Slobodan Milosevic, the picture that appeared in newspapers over the weekend, showing him deep in prayer and hand in hand with Jesse Jackson, suffices quite well.

title: Saintly Friar Gives Rome a Drill for 2000 Jubilee
description: Padre Pio, an enigmatic friar and mystic who has a vast following in Italy and throughout the world, was beatified by Pope John Paul II today before 300,000 devotees, who had joyfully flooded into Rome for the ceremony.

title: Reporter Chasing Fraudulent Source Finds Methods Under Scrutiny
description: Seymour M. Hersh, a relentless digger and interrogator, has long been considered a premier investigative reporter. His work on the My Lai massacre won him the Pulitzer Prize three decades ago and was followed by newspaper, magazine and book exposes on such subjects as Henry A. Kissinger, Richard M. Nixon and the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: Terrorists, Not China, Are Threat
description: To the Editor:

title: Making His Own Choice in West Africa
description: All over the world artists have responded to the video era by coming up with new hybrids of music and theater. From Stephen Sondheim to Peter Brook to Robert Wilson to George C. Wolfe to Marilyn Manson, composers and directors are finding ways to transform the age-old union of story, song and dance. The impulse extends to Africa in the work of Souleymane Koly, a Guinean who lived in Paris before founding L'Ensemble Koteba d'Abidjan in Ivory Coast. The group performed Mr. Koly's African opera ''Waramba'' on Friday and Saturday at the Majestic Theater of the Brooklyn Academy of Music, presented by 651 Arts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHEAHAN, STEVE
description: SHEAHAN-Steve. Age 63, of Manhattan, on April 30, 1999. Cherished husband of Barbara Porter Sheahan. Beloved brother of Joan McGovern and twin of the late Carol Sheahan. Adored uncle and dear friend to countless others. Talented playwright and gifted actor, proprietor of Steve's Antiques on the Upper West Side. Contributions may be sent to the American Cancer Society, 19 West 56th St., NYC 10019. Services will be held Monday, May 3, at 7:30 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Private Grant Money For Spurned Artists
description: In the first large, national response to cuts in Government arts spending, nearly two dozen foundations and philanthropists have joined forces to support artists who challenge convention. The group wants to compensate for some of the individual Federal grants that ended in 1994 after controversy over works dealing with provocative themes like nudity and sexuality.

title: Rehabilitating a Body and a Bond
description: Sang Lan, the Chinese gymnast who was paralyzed in a warm-up vault at the Goodwill Games last summer, and her mother, Chen Xiufeng, were looking at an anatomy chart recently at the Burke Rehabilitation Hospital in White Plains, N.Y. The mother ran her hand along the chart's gray-colored regions, where her daughter will probably never regain feeling, and the two spoke in Mandarin for a few seconds before retreating into a familiar silence.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WERSTEIN, CHARLOTTE
description: WERSTEIN-Charlotte. The National Offices of Emunah of America mourn the loss of Charlotte Werstein, beloved sister of our Honorary National President and Financial Secretary, Shirley Billet. Charlotte was a woman who gave unstintingly of herself to her family, friends and Emunah. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Sylvia Schonfeld National President Emunah of America

title: Mr. Milosevic's Peace Overture
description: After more than a month of grim tidings from Yugoslavia, the release of three captive American soldiers is heartening. But Slobodan Milosevic's good-will gesture alone is not sufficient reason to suspend the air war. As President Clinton rightly noted yesterday, Christopher Stone, Andrew Ramirez and Steven Gonzales are headed home after 32 days in Serbian custody, but a million ethnic Albanians expelled from their villages cannot yet return to their homes. NATO leaders should intensify their diplomatic efforts, but until Mr. Milosevic takes the steps necessary to restore peace to Kosovo, there should be no bombing pause.

title: Internet Ad Revenue Surging, Report Says
description: Internet advertising more than doubled during 1998, according to a report for the Internet Advertising Bureau in New York prepared by the New Media Group of PricewaterhouseCoopers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOGIN, RUTH (NEE FLEISCHER)
description: BOGIN-Ruth (nee Fleischer). Suddenly, on April 30, 1999. Loving wife of the late George Bogin, beloved mother of Magda and Nina (Alain Buttard), adored grandmother of Cecilia and Valentine Buttard and Natasha Bogin. Lifelong friend. We are bereft, but will draw strength from her deepest qualities: her brilliant mind, her integrity and optimism, her commitment to a better world, her joy in life. Memorial service Thursday, May 6, 11:30 AM, at New York Society for Ethical Culture, 2 West 64th Street.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AARON, RUTH (PAT) KATZENSTEIN
description: AARON-Ruth (Pat) Katzenstein. Age 100, on May 2, 1999, at DeWitt Nursing Home, NYC. Physical education teacher at Ethical Culture School from 1918 through 1968. Beloved by many friends, colleagues and students. Funeral private. Memorial service to be announced. Memorial donations to Ethical Culture School, 33 Central Park West, NYC, would be appreciated.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Flying to the Moon, Her Heart on Her Sleeve
description: Say what you will about the banal pop theater songs of Frank Wildhorn. If nothing else, his big pumping ballads with their recycled melodies and sobbing crescendos are user-friendly for lusty-voiced heart-on-the-sleeve pop singers. And among that breed, Christine Andreas is about as good as it gets.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'NEIL, JAMES MARTIN
description: O'NEIL-James Martin. 71. Of New York City on May 1, 1999. Beloved husband of Anne Kennedy O'Neil. Devoted father of Anne Ocampo of New York City, and Martin O'Neil of Hong Kong. Loving grandfather of Molly, Julie, James, Mariko, and Anna. Mass of Christian Burial will be held at the Church of St. Thomas More, 65 East 89 St., Wednesday, May 5, 11 AM. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Church of St. Thomas More would be greatly appreciated.

title: Media Talk; A Literary Evening at the Playboy Mansion
description: For lofty moments in American letters little could top the Playboy Mansion party held last Friday evening by Grove/Atlantic to celebrate the book ''The Century of Sex: Playboy's History of the Sexual Revolution,'' which will be published this fall.

title: Charles Dawson, 88, Dies; Led Poison Ivy Study
description: Charles R. Dawson, a longtime chemistry professor at Columbia University who played the leading role in the discovery of the toxic compounds in poison ivy, died on Wednesday in a hospital in Wolfeboro, N.H. He was 88 and lived in Wolfeboro.

title: James Whittam, 49, President And Chief of Shaklee Companies
description: James H. Whittam, the president and chief executive of the Shaklee Companies, died April 15 at Stanford University Hospital in Palo Alto, Calif. Dr. Whittam, a resident of Hillsborough, Calif., was 49.

title: Pacers Give Knicks a Rude Awakening
description: The Knicks spent the past week flirting with everyone, winking and smiling and crooking their finger. But after all the attention Allan Houston and Latrell Sprewell had attracted for their recent flash of style, after all the Knicks had done to pitch themselves as a fun night out, they were exposed by the Indiana Pacers today.

title: Artax Sets Aqueduct Record
description: Artax, a 4-year-old who had not won a race in more than a year, broke Dr. Fager's 31-year-old track record for seven furlongs yesterday, taking the $200,000 Carter Handicap at Aqueduct in 1:20.04.

title: Cable Carrier Is Said to Prefer AT&T Merger
description: The board of Mediaone Group Inc., the big cable television carrier, sent a letter on Saturday to the Comcast Corporation informing the company that Mediaone wanted to proceed with a proposed merger with the AT&T Corporation, people close to the discussions said yesterday. In effect, the letter began a five-day timetable under which Comcast has until Thursday to come back with a counteroffer.

title: Asian Effects Blend With Western, Proving They Are Part of One World
description: Listeners who leaped up from Sofia Gubaidulina's new piece at Carnegie Hall on Thursday night and hurried across Central Park in time to hear Ms. Gubaidulina's new piece at the New York Philharmonic must have experienced something of a culture shock. ''In the Shadow of the Tree,'' as played by the NHK Symphony under Charles Dutoit, and ''Two Paths,'' a Philharmonic commission, ask different questions of the composer's art and occupy vastly separated worlds of style.

title: Blaze That Killed 3 Wiped Out Dreams
description: Ana Estela Lopez dreamed of saving enough money to return to El Salvador to open a clothing store and build a three-bedroom house. But her savings were destroyed in a fire that killed three people in a Long Island home crowded with 34 immigrants.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, JEFFREY L.
description: GOLDSTEIN-Jeffrey L. On April 30, 1999. Beloved husband of Carol. Devoted father of Michael and Jaclyn. Adored son of Matthew and Adele. Loving brother of Elaine Perlmutter and Steven. He will be missed by all and remembered forever. Services Monday, 10 AM, at ''Gutterman's, Inc.,'' 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, LI. Interment Beth Moses Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAZZA, CLARA D'ANDREA
description: MAZZA-Clara D'Andrea. Of Darien, CT on April 30, 1999. Mother of Anne M. Pirone, David L. Mazza and his wife Deborah, and Sr. Mary L. Mazza, CND. Calling hours are Monday, May 3, 1999 from 4-8 PM at the Edward Lawrence Funeral Home, 2119 Post Rd., Darien, CT. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held Tuesday, May 4, 1999 at 11 AM at St. Thomas More RC Church, 374 Middlesex Rd., Darien, CT.

title: A Great Defender of the Old Social Security Battles On
description: THE conventional wisdom these days is that any major change to Social Security is unlikely before next year's elections, but Robert M. Ball remains ever vigilant. In the unending debate over the nation's pension system, Mr. Ball stands as the great defender of traditional Social Security, the genius of its basic principles, the soundness of its basic approach.

title: Stanley D. Canter, 75, an Adviser to Corporations
description: Stanley D. Canter, who advised many of the world's best-known corporations on marketing and advertising matters during a career that spanned more than 40 years, died April 24 at the Jacob Perlow Hospice at Beth Israel Hospital in New York City, according to a longtime business associate. The cause was cancer. He was 75.

title: Survivor Tells of Massacre at Kosovo Village
description: It lasted no more than three minutes, three minutes of savagery unleashed without even a word. ''They just started shooting and I got hit in the shoulder. The dead bodies behind me pushed me over the cliff and into the stream. I was lucky because all of the dead bodies fell on top of me.''

title: Corrections
description: A correction in this space yesterday about Cliff Zukin, a Rutgers University professor quoted in an article on Saturday about Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey, referred incorrectly to his past polling work. Mr. Zukin, the director of The Star-Ledger/Eagleton Poll, has never worked for any political candidate or party.

title: Wisconsin Beats Boston University
description: The Wisconsin men's varsity crew won its second race in two days yesterday, defeating Boston University by 7.4 seconds on the Charles River in Boston in 5 minutes 45.8 seconds. The Badgers, who defeated Dartmouth and M.I.T. on Saturday, will next row at the Eastern Sprints regatta on Sunday at Worcester, Mass. WILLIAM N. WALLACE

title: Broadcast of Ethnic Remark Stirs Tensions in Israeli Race
description: Entering its home stretch, Israel's volatile election campaign generated fresh controversy today with the broadcast of remarks that had the ring of an ethnic slur.

title: Diplomatic Initiative Helps Strengthen Both Yeltsin and Russia
description: By dispatching his special envoy to Washington for talks on ending the Yugoslav conflict, President Boris N. Yeltsin has put Russia at the center of international diplomacy, reviving relations with Washington and NATO. Perhaps more to the point for Mr. Yeltsin, it also plays well at home.

title: Thompson and Kirshenbaum Bond are forming units to focus on the entertainment industry.
description: TWO agencies are joining the growing chorus along Madison Avenue singing ''That's Entertainment.''

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-14

title: Gill Sees Promising Future With Nets
description: When Kendall Gill signed his last contract, which will carry him through next season, he thought that he would probably end his career when that contract expired. Now, Gill wants to stay, and he envisions a switch from small forward to shooting guard, where he would compete for playing time with Kerry Kittles.

title: NATO Attack Darkens City And Areas Of Serbia
description: All of Belgrade and parts of Serbia were plunged into darkness just after 10 o'clock Sunday, when NATO warplanes hit a major hydroelectric power station west of the capital, in Obrenovac, said a Serbian Cabinet Minister, Goran Matic.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DONALDSON, JANE A.
description: DONALDSON-Jane A. On May 1, 1999. Graduate of Savage School for Physical Ed. Retired from St. John the Baptist Church. Survived by Lois Barry Lincoln and nine grandnieces and nephews. Friends may call at the Abbey, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., Monday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass at St. John the Baptist Church, 210 West 31 St., Tuesday, 10:30 AM. Interment Hudson Falls, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROGERS, HERMAN ''PETE''
description: ROGERS-Herman ''Pete''. Today marks one year that you are gone. We have you in our hearts and minds forever. Your family

title: Neal Hardy, 84, Former Head Of Federal Housing Agency
description: Neal J. Hardy, who headed the Federal Housing Administration in the Kennedy Administration, died on April 15 at My Country Home Adult Congregate Living Facility in Osteen, Fla. He was 84 and had previously lived in Orange City, Fla.

title: In Paris For Romance, By Night
description: American Ballet Theater featured works by George Balanchine and Leonide Massine, two of this century's greatest ballet choreographers, on Friday night at the Metropolitan Opera House. A special attraction was the company's first New York presentation since 1995 of ''Gaite Parisienne,'' a wonderful romp to music by Offenbach in which Massine depicts night life in a 19th-century Parisian cafe.

title: French Anti-Terrorist Officers Suspected in Explosion in Corsica
description: Bombs and fires have long been common tools for Corsica's separatists, but a recent explosion at a beach restaurant on the Mediterranean island has come with an unusual twist: Evidence has appeared that the blast may have been the work of the very crack police squad that was created to stem the guerrilla violence.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CLOSTER, RICHARD S.
description: CLOSTER-Richard S. May 3, 1997. Dear Reuven, your spirit surrounds us. Miss you deeply. Love, Miren and Dad

title: High School Cliques: Cool or Cruel?; Some Kids Are Different
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANK, MIRIAM
description: FRANK-Miriam. On May 2, 1999. Cherished wife of Bernard. Beloved mother of Helene and Gerry Resnick, and Steven Frank. Adored grandmother of Kimberly. Dear sister of Mildred, Rose and Al. Miriam was a woman of uncommon intelligence, passion and humor. A loving friend and beautiful human being whose memory will be cherished forever. Services Monday at 1 PM, Gutterman's, 175 Long Beach Rd., Rockville Centre.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSMITH, VIVIAN SCHRIER
description: GOLDSMITH-Vivian Schrier. Age 95, died peacefully on May 1, 1999. Adored wife of the late Mannie. Eldest daughter of Sarah and Ike Schrier. Predeceased by sisters Doris Mattikow and Blanche Pollard. Survived by sister Ruth Reiner. Mother ''Superior'' of Marvin and Lynne Goldsmith and Elaine and Chuck Satuloff. Treasured Nanna of Amy and Craig Lemle, Nancy Abraham, Michael Goldsmith and Sharon Goldsmith. Great-grandnanna of Jonathan, Clifford, Tracey and Eden. Devoted aunt. Vivi: our wonderful memories of you will be forever. Service Monday May 3, noon, Temple Israel of New Rochelle, 1000 Pinebrook Blvd., New Rochelle.

title: High School Cliques: Cool or Cruel?; Souls Are Crushed
description: To the Editor:

title: J.B. Macnab, 77, Former Pastor In Manhattan
description: The Rev. John Brown Macnab, pastor emeritus of the First Presbyterian Church in Greenwich Village, died April 20 at a hospital in Rehoboth, Del. He was 77 and had lived at a church manse in Brooklyn Heights before he retired in 1992 and moved to Rehoboth Beach, Del.

title: The Widow Of Ex-Leader Wins Race In Panama
description: Mireya Moscoso, the widow of a Panamanian President who stepped out on her own politically to become the main opposition leader here, narrowly defeated her main opponent tonight, electing her the country's first woman President.

title: Oliver Reed, Diverse Actor For Film and TV, Dies at 61
description: Oliver Reed, whose red-faced exuberance brought earthiness to film appearances as varied as a swashbuckling musketeer, a brutal Dickensian burglar and his best-known role as a coal mine owner's son in Ken Russell's version of ''Women in Love,'' died on Sunday while filming a movie in Malta. He was 61.

title: When Trumps Are Trapped, A Coup Can Forge Ahead
description: The world's biggest cash prize events are the Cavendish Teams and Cavendish Pairs, which will be played this week at the MGM Grand in Las Vegas, Nev. A year ago the Calcutta pool in the Pairs topped $1.1 million.

title: Parents Fear That Children Are One Click Ahead
description: It would be hard to find a parent more gung-ho about the Internet than Faith Maupin, the moderator of an on-line discussion forum for parents with teen-agers who spends much of her day exchanging E-mail and wandering the Web. But after the shootings in Littleton, Colo., last month, Ms. Maupin was shaken enough to sit her own two teen-agers down for a heart-to-heart about their doings in cyberspace.

title: George McKinley Lawyer, 95
description: George McKinley, a New York lawyer who was active in the Citizens Union and other civic groups, died April 15 at St. Luke's Hospital in Newburgh, N.Y. He was 95 and lived in New Windsor, N.Y.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: Editorial Observer; Anybody Want a Slightly Used Football Team?
description: The New England Patriots have decided there is not enough money in the world to make them move to Hartford. The Patriots' owner, Robert Kraft, agreed back in December that Connecticut could have the privilege of building him a $375 million stadium, guaranteeing the sale of all the luxury seating and underwriting virtually every other team expense except the Gatorade. But now Mr. Kraft seems to be planning to stay in Massachusetts, even though its offer of financial assistance is the major-league equivalent of pocket change. We have seen this story in dozens of teen-age movies, and Connecticut is stuck playing the spoiled cheerleader who gets dumped at the prom.

title: By Staying Away, Bush Is the Talk of New Hampshire
description: Maybe he was home washing his hair. Maybe he was up late with his foreign affairs coaches, refining his position on Kosovo. Or maybe the Governor of Texas was just fixin' to play possum a little bit longer.

title: High School Cliques: Cool or Cruel?
description: To the Editor:

title: Private Donors Unite to Support Art Spurned by the Government
description: Nearly two dozen foundations and philanthropists, reacting to cuts in Federal arts spending, have joined forces to support artists who challenge convention. The new group will attempt to make up for some of the individual grants the Government ended in 1994 after years of controversy over works dealing with nudity, sexuality and other provocative themes.

title: Corrupt Gift-Giving Made Easier
description: Confronted with ambiguous language in the Federal criminal statute that outlaws gratuities to public officials, the Supreme Court responded last week with a 9-to-0 ruling that, while not unreasonable in the abstract, will have the practical effect of making it hard, if not impossible, to prosecute cases of improper gift-giving.

title: Head Scarf Puts Assembly In Turkey Into Uproar
description: The newly elected Turkish Parliament erupted in fury today and prevented one of its female members from taking her oath of office while wearing a head scarf.

title: Selling the People's Gardens
description: Despite months of discussions and last week's highly public arrest of a demonstrator dressed as a sunflower, Mayor Rudolph Giuliani is ready to auction off more than 100 community gardens, many in the poorest neighborhoods in New York. Odd lots, strange sizes, these bits and pieces of city territory have become makeshift mini-parks, garden plots or community meeting grounds in areas where such amenities are scarce.

title: High Ideals, on the Eve of Destruction
description: A DANGEROUS FRIEND

title: Owner Says He Didn't Know 34 Were Living in House That Burned
description: Harvey Vengroff, the real estate developer who owns the Huntington Station, N.Y., house where three people died in a suspicious fire over the weekend, said yesterday that he had not known that 34 Salvadoran immigrants had been living in the place, which he said he and his family called home in the mid-1970's.

title: Elway, Unable to Ignore Injuries, Gives a Teary Goodbye to Football
description: It is something most athletes, especially great competitors like John Elway, find incredibly hard to say: that their bodies, after years of pounding, can no longer perform at a top level. In recent weeks Elway has stared at his ailing knees, remembered the painkilling shots he took for his injured ribs and tired of the rigorous physical therapy sessions he endured just to attend practice for the Denver Broncos.

title: Better Berlin Memorial
description: To the Editor:

title: Adele W. Sullivan, 91, Leader Who Stirred Interest in D.A.R.
description: Adele Woodhouse Erb Sullivan, who was president general of the National Society Daughters of the American Revolution in the 1960's, died on April 22 in Wilton, Conn., at the home of her daughter, Nancy E. Thorne. She was 91 and a longtime resident of Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: Washington Memo; A Melding of Extremes at Correspondents Dinner
description: Fellini could not have directed the scene better.

title: Maria Stader, A Concert Soprano, 87
description: Maria Stader, a soprano who was best known for the elegance of her Mozart performances, died on Tuesday in Zurich, The Associated Press reported. She was 87 and lived in Zurich.

title: Sports of The Times; The Knicks' Problem Will Not Just Go Away
description: NO less a legend than Larry Bird knows how it feels to be Patrick Ewing, an all-around peg trying to find comfort in the middle of a four-headed square. Bird has been there, the center of attention who is accomplished but aging, injured and anxious, determined yet tentative.

title: New System For PC Music Stirs Concern Over Piracy
description: In what may be the most ambitious digital-age challenge yet to the nation's recording industry, Real Networks, a leading maker of Internet audio software, plans to announce on Monday a system designed to let consumers copy, store and play audio CD's on personal computers. The system is also designed to enable people to play music transmitted via the Internet.

title: As Booksellers Shuffle, Readers Depart
description: The reviews are in for last year's books and the reading is not pleasant. A new industry study indicates that the popular market for literature declined, with the number of purchases dropping for the first time in seven years despite the growing presence of electronic bookstores and the easy availability of titles.

title: China's Rulers on Guard as Spiritual Sect Pushes the Envelope
description: The police were out in force in several Chinese cities this weekend, seeking to head off rumored plans for new demonstrations by a spiritual sect that staged a giant vigil in Beijing a week ago.

title: Another Caffeine Headache After Irabu's Latest Outing
description: Hideki Irabu looked as if he was having fun, for once. When he ran out of his right shoe while darting to cover first base in the first inning today, leaving half of his footwear on the mound, teammates teased him and Irabu laughed. He shifted his weight energetically between pitches, as if a 10th cup of coffee had taken effect, a radical departure from his sometimes lifeless demeanor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FARBER, SEYMOUR
description: FARBER-Seymour. Of San Francisco, CA, on April 30, 1999. Husband of Joyce Rabin Farber. Father of Seth C. Farber and father-inlaw of Patricia M. Farber. Grandfather of Allison, Andrew, Michael and Matthew Farber. Son of Lillian Farber. Brother of Mae Nettler and brother-in-law of Morton Nettler. Memorial service to be held during week of May 3. Call (415) 346-8461 after noon on Monday for time, date and location. In lieu of flowers, donations to ACLU of Northern California and Oxfam America.

title: With a Step to the Right, Yoshii Gives Mets a Lift
description: Masato Yoshii glanced down to his black shoes once, then twice, and only then began his windup. He repeated this several times yesterday, a new ritual that yielded tremendous results.

title: Rudolph Stewart, Carnegie Hall House Manager, 74
description: Rudolph Stewart, for 29 years a behind-the-scenes presence at Carnegie Hall, died in New York on Wednesday. He as 74.

title: High School Cliques: Cool or Cruel?; Why Not Shun Racists?
description: To the Editor:

title: T. Justin Moore Jr., 74, Ex-Chief Of the Virginia Power Company
description: T. Justin Moore Jr., a retired chief executive of the Virginia Power Company and a founder of an economic development group that sought to break down racial barriers in Richmond, died of cancer on April 24 at his home in Richmond, a family spokesman said. He was 74.

title: In Rare Move, New Jersey Debates Resume of Nominee for Its Top Court
description: For the first time that most lawyers can remember, the credentials of a nominee to the New Jersey Supreme Court are cause for lunch conversation -- and for debate, complaint and bewilderment.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''They were very kind to us. As we were leaving them, it was kind of sad to know there's this war going on and we're leaving and they're left behind.''

title: Images Assail, but Adventure Is Still an Open Book
description: When people hold forth about the death of literature, I will recall a series of lovely cemeteries I drove past in Mexico recently, small fenced-in spaces with white headstones and brightly colored decorations. They were clearly meant to be part of everyone's everyday life, and the same is true of literature.

title: Standards Invigorated With Passion
description: ''Passionate routine'' is the description given by the pop-jazz singer Paula West for the much-desired state that others call romantic permanence. And near the end of Tuesday's opening-night show of a three-week engagement at the Firebird Cafe, this San Francisco singer performed two numbers illustrating the difficulty of achieving that state.

title: Safety Is at Issue As 3 Spectators Die at Car Race
description: The automobile race track in North Carolina where three spectators were killed by flying debris on Saturday night had increased the height of its protective fence the past two years, including after another fatal accident in Michigan.

title: Accounts
description: * Cambridge Soundworks Inc., Newton, Mass., a unit of Creative Technology Ltd., to Ingalls, Boston, as the first agency to handle branding for the designer of speakers. Billings were put at $6 million to $10 million.

title: CRISIS IN THE BALKANS: THE G.I.'s; 3 G.I. Prisoners Reach Freedom In Good Health
description: After 31 days of virtual isolation in Yugoslav prison cells, where one man said he found comfort in an American flag he drew on toilet paper and others found comfort in prayer, three freed soldiers were cheered on their arrival here today and pronounced in apparent good health.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MELZER, SOL
description: MELZER-Sol. Died May 1, 1999. Loving husband of the late Ida. Beloved father of Sally and Joan. Father-in-law of Jerry. Adoring grandfather of Eric, Jennifer, David, Michael. Great-grandfather of John. Graveside service Monday, 1 PM, New Montefiore Cemetery.

title: Gladhanding the Mayor
description: To the Editor:

title: Terrorists, Not China, Are Threat
description: To the Editor:

title: PRO FOOTBALL; Players and Coaches Awed by Elway's Talent
description: For Denver tight end Shannon Sharpe, quarterback John Elway was like Halley's comet.

title: A 'Pocket Monster' a Grownup Could Love
description: To the Editor:

title: Crew and Mayor at 'Moment of Truth'
description: For three years, whenever Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew had a problem, they would meet privately in City Hall, march into the Blue Room together and tell the press corps that they had agreed to disagree, but remained the best of friends.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Arson Is Suspected in Fire That Killed 3 in Suffolk
description: The early morning fire that killed three Salvadoran immigrants on Saturday and left another fighting for his life appeared to have been deliberately set with gasoline, law enforcement officials said today.

title: KOSOVO UPDATE
description: PRISONERS

title: Yankees Receive Relief From an Unlikely Source
description: Don Zimmer is an equal opportunity manager. If you do the job, he's going to use you, and it doesn't matter if you have a multiyear contract or you are established with the Yankees, or, like the reliever Jason Grimsley, you are a journeyman.

title: Corrections
description: A correction in this space yesterday about Cliff Zukin, a Rutgers University professor quoted in an article on Saturday about Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey, referred incorrectly to his past polling work. Mr. Zukin, the director of The Star-Ledger/Eagleton Poll, has never worked for any political candidate or party.

title: After Deadly Fire, Hard Lives Get Harder Still; Obstacles Mount for Salvadorans, Alive but Homeless
description: For 14 months, ever since she swam across the Rio Grande to come to New York, Ana Estela Lopez has lived in fear. Fear that the police may stop her and report her to the immigration authorities because she had come to the country illegally. Fear that she may lose her $5.55-an-hour job in a chocolate factory. Fear that a car may run over her husband, who used to ride his bicycle to work every day before it was stolen.

title: Diet Drug May Face A Tough Sell At H.M.O.'s
description: People who hope to slim down with the help of Xenical, a newly approved weight-loss drug, may have to pay for it themselves. A number of managed care companies are categorizing Xenical as a life style product that they will cover only in exceptional cases -- for overweight people at risk for cardiovascular problems, or those with diabetes, breathing problems or brittle bones.

title: Charles Warren, 92; Introduced Top Sherpa to Everest Climbers
description: Charles Warren, a British physician who tried three times to scale Mount Everest in the 1930's, died on March 30 in his home in Essex, England. He was 92.

title: Casting Ballots Through the Internet
description: As president of Votehere. net, a start-up company that builds secure Internet voting systems, Jim Adler hears the same question from investors again and again. They don't ask about politics or security. They want to know what would happen if Microsoft moved into the election business.

title: After Littleton, Gun Dealers Put On a Low-Profile Show
description: The Great Westchester Gun and Knife Show came to town for perhaps the last time this weekend, with no advertising banners, no promotional brochures and as little media attention as its organizers could manage.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINSTEIN, NORMAN J.
description: WEINSTEIN-Norman J. Adored husband of Ann (Keiles). Beloved father of Maury (Ferne), Aaron (Lisa), Ken (Judy). Much loved Grandpa of Jeff, Ben, Ari, Dana and Evan. Dear brother of Sid, Rita and Rose. Services on Monday at 1 PM at Temple Beth-El, 67 Highway 206 South, Somerville.

title: 22-Year-Old Man Held for 3 Murders as Officials Hope Terror Is Ended : London Bombing Suspect Is Charged
description: LONDON  The police on Sunday charged a 22-year-old engineer with three counts of murder and causing explosions, bringing what officials hoped would be a swift end to a series of bombings that have spread terror through minority communities in London over the past two weeks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRUSH, ELLEN SPARRY
description: BRUSH-Ellen Sparry. Anthropologist, on May 1, 1999. Wife of Charles F. Brush III, mother of Karen A. and Charles F., stepmother of Barbara Brush Wright and Danielle Schmid, grandmother of Christina Wright and Kelly Schmid, mother-in-law of Diane H. Brush. Contributions in her memory may be made to Union Chapel in the Grove, Shelter Island, NY, and the Archaeological Institute of America, Boston, MA. A memorial service will be announced.

title: His Family's Refugee Past Is Thought to Inspire NATO's Commander
description: The American general who is leading NATO's military operation to stop Serbian troops from killing and expelling Albanians from Kosovo discovered as an adult that he is the grandson of a Russian Jew who fled his country to escape the pogroms there a century ago.

title: Limiting Travel, Serb Units Are Unfazed by Air War
description: At night in Kosovo this weekend, the only light was thrown by burning tires, set aflame by police apparently to alert the few drivers on the road that they were approaching a bridge.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: A partial list for this week.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Shares to Be Offered In Internet-Phone Business

title: At DDB, Changes And a Big Account
description: It was a busy Friday for DDB Needham Worldwide Communications Group in New York, a unit of Omnicom Group: DDB changed its name, designated the next generation of leadership and landed a large account. DDB Needham is dropping the ''Needham'' from its name, which dates to 1986 when Doyle Dane Bernbach and Needham Harper Worldwide merged to form the agency. Keith Reinhard, chairman and chief executive, said the decision to ''simplify our branding'' was spurred by the coming 50th anniversary of the founding of Doyle Dane.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WILLIAMS, HENRY
description: WILLIAMS-Henry. May 2, 1959. After 40 years, we still remember the friendship and the laughter. Thanks, Uncle Peck. The Hicks Famil

title: Castro Is Taking a Break From His Day Job
description: The Cubans were not in the building at the time they were originally advertised to be there, so the most compelling issue of the day was moot. The Cuban national baseball team was delayed in arriving here and did not land until about 8:30 P.M., so the evening workout that was to be closed to everyone else was canceled.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BRESSLER, ALFRED W.
description: BRESSLER-Alfred W. A lawyer and partner in the firm of Moses & Singer for over sixty years. A memorial service will be held on Monday, May 3, at 12 noon at Temple Emanu-El, 5th Avenue at 65 Street, Manhattan.

title: Species for Sale
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Foreign Affairs; Kosovo And Columbine
description: The failure of the House of Representatives to muster even a one-seat majority in favor of the Administration's air war in Yugoslavia has given birth to a new dictum: Foreign policy stops at the water's edge.

title: SPRINT TO ADD MMDS TECHNOLOGY WITH ACQUISITIONS
description: The Sprint Corporation, the long-distance giant, has agreed to buy interests in two wireless cable companies, Wireless Holdings Inc. and Videotron Bay Area Inc., from the Canadian telecommunications concern Groupe Videotron Ltd. for $180 million. The deal would make Sprint the latest long-distance company to invest in the wireless technology called multipoint multichannel distribution service, or MMDS, which offers high-speed Internet access and video transmission. Wireless Holdings, which is 62.5 percent owned by Groupe Videotron, holds MMDS assets and channel leases in California, South Carolina and Washington State. Videotron Bay Area, of Tampa, Fla., is wholly owned by Groupe Videotron. In addition, Sprint plans to buy Transworld Telecommunications Inc., of San Anselmo, Calif., which also owns licenses in California, South Carolina and Washington, for $30 million.

title: Authorities Refuse to Budge On Caged Rat
description: The rat hasn't won yet. But a Federal judge in Manhattan had sharp questions yesterday about the Police Department's seizure of a 30-foot inflatable rat balloon that has been used by union leaders to dramatize labor issues around town.

title: The Good and Bad Of Sun Exposure
description: Q. Is exposure to sunlight the best way to get the amount of Vitamin D that our bodies need? ALISHA BERGER

title: Capri-Codec Is Acquired
description: Cooper Industries, the maker of Crescent wrenches and Halo lighting fixtures, said today that it had acquired Capri-Codec S.A. of France to expand its electrical construction-materials business in Europe. Financial terms were not disclosed. The closely held Capri-Codec, based about 100 miles southwest of Paris, makes cable accessories and flexible conduits used by electrical contractors. It has about 200 employees and $25 million in annual revenue. Cooper's shares rose $1.8125 each, to $50.1875.

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: EUROPE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHINDLER, SAUL
description: SCHINDLER-Saul. Beloved husband of Estelle. Loving father of Roslyn and Scott and the late Daniel. Cherished grandfather of Jeff and Alan. Dear brother of Sam and the late Sarah, George and Louis.

title: Court Restricts Refugee Status for Criminals
description: Foreigners who have committed serious crimes in their home countries are ineligible for refugee status here regardless of the risk of persecution they face if deported, the Supreme Court ruled unanimously today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOODWARD, WILLIAM, III.
description: WOODWARD-William, III. On May 2, 1999. Husband of Lisa and father of Elizabeth. Servcies at St. Thomas Episcopal Church, 5th Ave at 53 St. Thursday 11am, Interment private. Contributions in his memory may be made to the William Woodward, Jr. Nursery School, 436 E. 69 St, NYC 10021 or the Central Park Conservancy, 14 E. 60 St, NYC 10022.

title: OBSERVATORY
description: Harvesting Proteins

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE YEN FALLS. The dollar rose on speculation that Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi was unlikely to disclose initiatives to lift Japan's economy out of recession. In New York, the dollar rose to 120.31 yen, from 119.40 on Friday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'DAY, DANIEL
description: O'DAY-Daniel. Age 92, of Rye, NY, on April 30. Husband of the late Ida Sadler O'Day. Father of Daniel O'Day, Jr. Funeral services will be held at 10:30 AM, on Wednesday, May 5, at Christ Church, Rye, NY. In lieu of flowers contributions to the Taft School, Watertown, CT 06795, or the Rye Historical Society, Rye, NY 10580, would be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WEINSTEIN, ABE
description: WEINSTEIN-Abe. A day doesn't pass without us thinking of you and missing you. Your Loving famil

title: Mets Spin Along, And Reed Steps Up To Rejoin the Ride
description: The Mets' season has been a little like a revolving door. The moment someone comes back into view, it seems that somebody else is gone.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRUSH, ELLEN SPARRY
description: BRUSH-Ellen Sparry. Anthropologist, on May 1, 1999. Wife of Charles F. Brush III, mother of Karen A. and Charles F., stepmother of Barbara Brush Wright and Danielle Schmid, grandmother of Christina Wright and Kelly Schmid, mother-in-law of Diane H. Brush. Contributions in her memory may be made to Union Chapel in the Grove, Shelter Island, NY, and the Archaeological Institute of America, Boston, MA. A memorial service will be held on Tuesday May 11th at 5 P.M. at The Norwegian Seamen's Church, 317 East 52nd St, NYC

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about Tenncare, the Tennessee health care program for the uninsured, misstated the number of people enrolled. As noted elsewhere in the article, it is 1.3 million, not 3 million.

title: Help for Opera Composers
description: One reason composers have such difficulty learning to write opera is that there are so few opportunities to try out works in progress. Asking a friend to sing through some of your score while you accompany at the piano is not the same. You need to experience your work in a theater with a cast onstage and an orchestra in the pit. And that is an expensive proposition.

title: MOLEX TO ACQUIRE CARDELL, A MAKER OF AUTO PARTS
description: Molex Inc., a maker of electronic and fiber optic connectors, agreed yesterday to buy the Cardell Corporation, a closely held auto-parts maker, for an undisclosed price to expand its automotive product line. Cardell, of Auburn Hills, Mich., had sales of around $100 million last year and has about 560 workers. It supplies companies that provide wiring harnesses to Ford Motor and DaimlerChrysler. Molex, of Lisle, Ill., makes electronic connectors and switches and operates 49 factories in 21 countries, employing 13,000 workers.

title: No Water, Power, Phone: A Serbian City's Trials
description: People were out in the sunny weather here today, on this national holiday to mark May Day, but few could hide their anxieties.

title: For Hikers, the Perils of High and Dry
description: Most mountain hikers are ending up high and dry, according to a University of Colorado study conducted in Rocky Mountain National Park.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: A group cites some progress in convincing companies to peddle their goods on the Internet.
description: TO address the nagging issue of how to make Internet advertising more effective and profitable, a group of advertisers and Web publishers formed an organization called FAST, or the Future of Advertising Stakeholders, last August.

title: Accounts
description: * Improve Net Inc., Redwood City, Calif., an on-line home-improvement service, to Left Field, San Francisco, as the first agency to handle the account. Billings were estimated at $20 million. TMP Worldwide, Los Angeles, continues to handle duties for Yellow Pages advertising.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CRIMMINS, EDWARD C.
description: CRIMMINS-Edward C. We mourn the loss of our dear friend and fellow Player who passed away on April 20, 1999. He served with distinction on the Board of the Players and the Hampden Booth Library. He was a wonder greeter of guests and a welcome sight in the Grill. Our thoughts and love go to Regina. We celebrate his life on Thursday, June 10th, 6PM at 16 Gramercy Park. The Players

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, LEE G., CPA.
description: FRIEDMAN-Lee G., CPA. Beloved husband of Gail. Devoted father of Steven and Joanne (Joseph). Loving grandfather of Amy and Demi.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENTHAL, ROBERT L.
description: ROSENTHAL-Robert L. The Board of Directors of The 360 East 72nd Street Owners Corporation mourn the loss of their esteemed Past President, Robert L. Rosenthal. A veteran of World War II (U.S.M.C.), attorney and community activist, he will be missed by all. Our deepest sympathy to his devoted wife, Alma, and many friends. Harvey Rothenberg, President

title: Columbine Gun Tied To a Former Student
description: A 22-year-old graduate of Columbine High School was charged with providing a powerful, semi-automatic handgun to one of the two attackers. The defendant was booked on a charge of providing a gun to a minor, a felony, and released on $15,000 bond. But a lawyer for the defendant said his client did not know how the gun would be used.

title: CERIDIAN AGREES TO BUY ABR INFORMATION SERVICES
description: The Ceridian Corporation, an information services provider, said yesterday that it would acquire ABR Information Services Inc. for $25.50 a share in cash, or about $750 million. ABR, based in Palm Harbor, Fla., provides benefits administration, payroll and human resource services. The Minneapolis-based Ceridian said the deal would slightly dilute earnings in 1999 and 2000 but was expected to increase the growth rate of Ceridian's human resources business. ABR projects revenues of around $120 million for its current fiscal year and employs some 1,500 people. Its shares soared 43 percent, or $7.50, to $25, while Ceridian slipped 50 cents, to $36.125.

title: Violent Games, Violent Deeds?
description: To the Editor:

title: CBS Will Make It Official: Gumbel Is on Morning Team
description: Bryant Gumbel's long-anticipated return to morning television will become official today when CBS announces that he has agreed to become the anchor of a revamped ''CBS This Morning'' program, which will be in a newly created studio on Fifth Avenue at the entrance to Central Park.

title: Still Opposed, Planners Let Airport Link Go Ahead
description: After voicing nearly unanimous disdain for a Port Authority plan to build a rail link to Kennedy International Airport, the New York City Planning Commission authorized the city yesterday to acquire several properties that will allow the project to proceed.

title: I.B.M. Set to Focus on Small Businesses
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that it would spend $100 million on a new marketing campaign aimed at small businesses.

title: Goldman Is Set To Go Ahead With Offering
description: After years of mulling it over and at least one false start, Goldman Sachs Group Inc. said yesterday that it would formally end its 130-year status as a private partnership by selling 69 million shares, or roughly 15 percent of the firm, to the public at $53 each, raising $3.66 billion.

title: As Heart Attacks Wane, Heart Failure Is on the Rise
description: In his blue jeans and T-shirt, walking laps around the corridors at the Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan, Joe Senatore could almost be mistaken for a visitor rather than a patient. What gives him away is the pole he wheels alongside him, hung with pouches of medication trailing intravenous lines that tether him to the equipment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MALAMUT, MARGUERITE
description: MALAMUT-Marguerite. The Officers, Trustees and members of the Forest Hills Jewish Center mourn the death of Marguerite Malamut, wife of our esteemed past President Abe Malamut. May her sweet memory be a sustaining source of strength and comfort. Gerald C. Skolnik, Rabbi Erno Grosz, Cantor Emeritus Carl Seldin Koerner, President

title: Woman in the News: Mireya Elisa Moscoso; Earnest Icon For Panama
description: For more than 20 years, Mireya Elisa Moscoso lived in the shadow of a man 45 years her senior who, she says, even told her how to wear her hair. But by the side of that man, her late husband, Dr. Arnulfo Arias, three times President of Panama, she also gained a political schooling that on Sunday helped transform her into ''Senora Presidenta,'' the first woman to become President of this country of 2.8 million people.

title: Report Offers Details on Police Bullets That Hit Diallo
description: The official autopsy of Amadou Diallo has found that of the 19 police bullets that hit him, one traveled up his right leg, while a second pierced the sole of his right sneaker, according to a report by the city's Medical Examiner's office.

title: U.S. Frees Assets of Suspect In Embassy Terror Bombings
description: The Treasury Department today unblocked more than $24 million in bank accounts held by Salih Idris, the Saudi owner of a pharmaceutical plant in Sudan that American cruise missiles destroyed last August after the terror bombings at American embassies in Kenya and Tanzania.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: OIL GAINS. Crude oil prices rose sharply as traders bet that producers would remain committed to cutting output despite much higher prices. In New York, crude oil for June delivery rose 19 cents, closing at $18.85 a barrel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRENCH, DR. JOSEPH HENRY
description: FRENCH-Dr. Joseph Henry. On April 29, 1999. Of West Orange, N.J. Beloved father of Lenore, Mark, Lisa and John. Grandfather of three. Brother of Dr. David French. Father-in-law of Caroline and Alison. Brother-in-law of Lawrence Doss. A memorial service will be held today, at 3 P.M., at Saint Peter's Episcopal Church, Livingston, New Jersey. Inquiries to Martin's Home for Service, Inc., 48 Elm Street, Montclair.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLARK, THOMAS CULBERTSON II.
description: CLARK-Thomas Culbertson II. Of Norfolk, CT, died suddenly May 1. President of The Denominator Company, Inc. Beloved husband of Dorothy Wadsworth Clark, father of T.C. Clark III, stepfather of Susan Colsman and William Painter. Three grandchildren. Memorial service is on Saturday, May 8, at 11:30 A.M., Church of Christ Congregational, Norfolk, CT.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SICHER, JOHN D.
description: SICHER-John D. May 2, 1999 at 84, in New Orleans, LA. Husband of Patricia; brother of Dan; father of John, Jr. and Michael; grandfather of Carolyn, Peter, Sam and Alexis; stepfather of Jill and Jack. Attended the Choate School and Harvard University. Executive Vice President, Liberty Throwing Co., 1946-1989. A memorial service will be scheduled in New Orleans. In lieu of flowers donations may be sent to the Humane Society.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MITCHELL, FLORENCE ROTH
description: MITCHELL-Florence Roth. Age 88. On May 2, 1999. Passed away three months after her beloved and adoring husband Moe (Morris). Survivors include son Jonathan (Sandra) of Dewey, AZ. and daughter Sarah (Telly) of New York City, grandchildren Barbara Mitchell, San Diego, David Anthony and Jessica Anthony, New York City, step grandchildren Karen Harris and Deana Douglas, Phoenix. Services private.

title: Ernest Gross, a Key Diplomat During Cold War, Dies at 92
description: Ernest A. Gross, a diplomat and an international lawyer who was closely involved in issues of war and peace from the Korean War to decolonization and disarmament, died on Sunday at his home in New York City. He was 92.

title: Some Companies Derail the 'Burnout' Track
description: Two years ago, Linda Davis, the Great Lakes-area sales manager for Hewlett-Packard, realized she had a crisis on her hands. Her sales team had been chalking up impressive revenues, but the strain of long work hours was showing. There were too many broken marriages, the attrition rate had risen to 20 percent in a tight labor market, and when asked on the annual company survey if they were ''experiencing excessive pressure'' on the job, more than 50 percent of her workers had said yes.

title: Corrections
description: A television review on Saturday about the television movie ''Noah's Ark,'' shown in two parts Sunday night and last night on NBC, misidentified the director of the 1972 film ''The Ruling Class,'' another film in which the voice of God has a role. It was directed by Peter Medak; Peter Barnes wrote both films.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERLIN, HELEN
description: BERLIN-Helen, 88. On May 2, 1999. Wife of the late Harry Berlin, mother of Joan Kutcher of Needham, MA, grandmother of Daniel and Elizabeth, and mother-in-law of Charles Kutcher.

title: Subway Push, And a Sister Feels a Chill
description: KIM WEBDALE had no sooner boarded an uptown No. 6 train at 23d Street one evening last week when the conductor announced that they would be going nowhere for a while. Someone had fallen ill at the 51st Street station, or so the conductor said.

title: Most Straphangers Unfazed By Closing of Bridge Lines
description: Irma Gayle, a seamstress and recent immigrant from Costa Rica, sat patiently on the B39W bus as it inched across the Williamsburg Bridge into Manhattan yesterday. She had already been on one bus, and planned to take yet another.

title: A Musical Autobiography With a Range of Styles
description: Of the many anecdotes told by the Israeli singer Dudu Fisher in his one-man show at the Jewish Repertory Theater, perhaps the most illuminating is that his grandfather wanted him to be a cantor and his voice teacher an opera singer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JONES, DAVID E., JR.
description: JONES-David E., Jr. 85. On May 2. Survived by wife Muriel Kemble Jones, daughter Margaret J. Mateer, son David E., III, seven grandchildren, one great granddaughter, sisters Alice Dineen, Marjorie Bassing, brother Paul E. Jones. Retired Regional Manager, Ebasco Services. Life Fellow ASME, licensed NY State Professional Engineer. Visiting Van Emburgh Funeral Home, Ridgewood, NJ, 7-9PM May 5. Funeral 11AM May 6, Nativity Church, Midland Park, NJ. Donations appreciated to Janet Cuttner Leukemia Research, Mount Sinai Hospital, 1 Gustave Levy Pl, NYC 10029 in memory of deceased daughter, Marion Petersson who died in 1984

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABRAMS, ARTHUR
description: ABRAMS-Arthur. The Board of Directors, faculty and staff of CLAL-The National Jewish Center for Learning and Leadership, extend deepest condolences to Judy Steinhardt, her husband Michael and the entire family on the passing of Judy's beloved father, Arthur Abrams. May his inspiration enhance the life of his family and may they be comforted by his loving memory. Barbara B. Friedman, Chairman Charles R. Bronfman, Honorary Chairman Rabbi Irwin Kula, President Donna M. Rosenthal, Executive Vice Chairman

title: Essex Prosecutor Fires Back, Accusing County Executive of Budget Shortfall
description: The political estrangement between the Essex County Executive, James W. Treffinger, and the County Prosecutor, Patricia A. Hurt, intensified today as the prosecutor charged that the budgetary pressures being exerted on her were caused by Mr. Treffinger's own manipulation of county budgets over the years.

title: Titan to Sell Assets
description: Titan Exploration Inc. said today that it had agreed to sell its Gulf of Mexico assets to Coastal Oil and Gas for $71.3 million. The sale would divest Titan of its interests in Louisiana and the gulf. Titan, an independent natural-gas exploration and production company, recorded a loss of $47.2 million, or $1.22 a share, in 1998. Coastal Oil and Gas is a unit of the Coastal Corporation of Houston.

title: With Budget Cutting, Medicare Spending Fell Unexpectedly
description: New Government data show that Medicare spending actually declined in the first half of the current fiscal year.

title: Ghosts, and Not the Friendly Kind
description: ANOTHER WORLD

title: Drug Offers Hope for Elderly With Eye Disease
description: A drug activated by shining light into the eye could offer hope for people suffering from age-related macular degeneration, the leading cause of severe vision loss in the elderly.

title: Mississippi Sues Consulting Firm
description: The shares of American Management Systems Inc. fell 9.5 percent today after the State of Mississippi canceled a contract and sued the consulting company for $985 million in damages. American fell $3.25 a share, to $31.125.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSMITH, VIVIAN
description: GOLDSMITH-Vivian. Temple Israel of New Rochelle records with sorrow the death of its cherished member and extends its heartfelt sympathy to the family. Amiel Wohl, Rabbi

title: By Design; Waves of the Future
description: After many years of straight, smooth hair, it seems to be time for a change to styles with a bit of texture. That should be good news for women with curls or waves or anyone whose hair gets unruly in summer humidity.

title: KOSOVO UPDATE
description: COMBAT

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOSTFOGEL, FRANCES C. (FANNIE)
description: LOSTFOGEL-Frances C. (Fannie). Beloved wife of the late Herman Lostfogel, on May 2, 1999 at age 101 years. Widowed with three infant children, she successfully pioneered as the first woman manufacturer's representative in the paper industry, raising her family to adulthood with uncommon strength and proud determination. Beloved mother of the late Charlotte L. and Dr. H. Harold Friedman, Phyllis and Burton Kossoff, Stanley and Ilse Lostfogel. Cherished Nana of Alan, Marsha and Betsy, the late Stephanie Lynn, Mitch and Pam, Linda and Eric and Ellen. Adored great grandmother of Stefanie and Brian; Joshua, Alec, Noah and Jeremy; Samantha, Andrew and Zachary. Her extraordinary devotion, wisdom and unfailing love have through the many years enriched our being. She is forever with us. Services Tuesday, May 4, 10AM at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Lehman to Buy Stake In German TV Unit
description: Lehman Brothers Holding Inc. agreed yesterday to buy 3.1 percent of Kirch Media K.G.a.A., the commercial television unit of Kirch Group, Germany's second-largest media company, for 191.7 million euros ($203 million). Lehman will make the investment through its Lehman Brothers Merchant Banking Partners L.P. unit and joins Fininvest S.p.A. of Italy and Prince Walid bin Talal, the Saudi billionaire, as outside investors in the company. Lehman is an adviser to Kirch, which announced the agreement.

title: F.A.A. Endorsing Requirement for Advanced 'Black Boxes' That Can Record More
description: The Federal Aviation Administration is calling for new ''black boxes'' on thousands of airplanes over the next five and a half years, including replacing the standard 30-minute cockpit voice recorders with models that capture two hours of sound.

title: 30 Deaths Reported in Plains Tornadoes
description: A band of vicious tornadoes streaked through Oklahoma and into Kansas yesterday, killing at least 30 people and injuring hundreds. The storms destroyed at least 2,000 homes, flattened entire towns and scattered cars on highways like pins in a bowling alley.

title: Closing In on 80
description: You're in church, all dressed up, and as you bow your head you see that your socks don't match. One is blue and one is brown. You didn't even come close.

title: INSIDE
description: Prodding Japan, Again

title: A Familiar Skin Hides an Evolving Space Shuttle
description: America's aging space shuttles, often criticized as monuments to 1970's technology, are slowly being replaced by much more modern spacecraft -- themselves.

title: Behind the Drop In Teen-Age Births
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOGARTY, JUDITH IRENE
description: FOGARTY-Judith Irene. Age 60. Died peacefully at home in Manhattan on May 2, 1999 after a long illness. A graduate of Fordham University, and a Copy Editor at ''People'' magazine, Ms. Fogarty loved New York and loved life. She will be greatly missed by her longtime companion, Marie P. Monaco, her mother Doris F. Weckworth, sister and brother-inlaw, Virginia and Gilbert Sharp, niece Deborah Ratel, nephew James R. Hausler, stepfather Charles Weckworth, and so many friends. A memorial service will be held at a later date. Contributions may be made to the Jacob Perlow Hospice, 1st Avenue and 16th Street, New York, NY 10003.

title: Violent Games, Violent Deeds?; Indicting Mass Culture
description: To the Editor:

title: Compulsive Gambling: Overlooked Addiction
description: The stories of compulsive gamblers could make the hardest heart weep.

title: Holdsclaw Is a Sure Thing to Be the Mystics' Top Draft Pick
description: Forget the magazine cover with her in a Knicks jersey. Ignore her sitting courtside at a Liberty game in Madison Square Garden last summer, drawing more attention from fans and reporters than the game itself. The comments saying she would like to play in New York? Put them on hold.

title: Clipped Rower Wings
description: To the Editor:

title: Gulf Remains Between Crew And Giuliani
description: After two weeks of bitter sparring, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew finally met face to face yesterday, but studiously avoided any mention of the issues that have divided them -- school vouchers and mayoral control of the public schools.

title: FRESH AMERICA TO MERGE WITH FRESHPOINT IN STOCK DEAL
description: The Fresh America Corporation agreed yesterday to buy the closely held Freshpoint Inc. for about $101 million in stock to form one of the world's largest produce distributors. Fresh America will issue about 5.5 million new shares, and Freshpoint investors will own about half the combined company's stock. The company, to be called Freshpoint America and based in Dallas, is expected to have sales of about $1.5 billion in 1999. Freshpoint has 27 distribution centers and is expected to have $750 million in sales this year. Fresh America, with 27 distribution plants, had $609.5 million in revenue last year.

title: Ronald Alley, 73, Modern Art Curator
description: Ronald Alley, a longtime staff member of the Tate Gallery in London and its first Keeper of the Modern Collection, died on April 25 in London. He was 73.

title: Ruling Narrows Rights of Debtors
description: Banks and insurers won new leverage in bankruptcy proceedings today when the United States Supreme Court ruled that judges should not give the owner of an insolvent company an exclusive right to buy a stake in a reorganized business.

title: With the Force but No Guns; Issue Haunts 'Star Wars' Gala in Denver
description: There were a lot of storm troopers wandering around without their blaster guns at the ''Star Wars'' Celebration here, the first convention and exposition dedicated to the 22-year-old movie series to win the approval and support of the films' creator, George Lucas.

title: Swedish Bank Moves To Expand Into Norway
description: Svenska Handelsbanken bid 1.55 billion Norwegian kroner ($199 million) in cash yesterday to buy Bergensbanken, a regional Norwegian bank, as it looks to expand throughout Scandinavia in response to stiffer competition in its home market of Sweden. Handelsbanken, the Nordic region's No. 1 bank by assets, offered 125 kroner a share for Bergensbanken. Bergensbanken shares jumped 47.50 kronor, or 73 percent, to 112.50.

title: Woman Is Sexually Assaulted in Central Park
description: A 23-year-old woman who was playing with her dog in Central Park was sexually assaulted and robbed early yesterday near the West 96th Street entrance, the police said. A 15-year-old boy was charged in the attack, and the police were questioning a second suspect last night.

title: To Clinton's Call, an Ambivalent Response
description: Entertainment executives find themselves in an uncomfortable position as a result of President Clinton's call for them to join educators, religious leaders and others next Monday at a White House conference on children and violence. While eager to show that they are as concerned about the issue as anyone else, they are also determined to avoid taking blame for incidents like the school killings in Littleton, Colo.

title: Fleeing Kosovars Dread Dangers Of NATO Above and Serb Below
description: Silvia Buzshila, just 16, sat huddled and shivering on the ground by the bus station in this Kosovo city, surrounded by her family and about 35 other Albanians -- surrounded but utterly lost.

title: A Meeting On Violence Is Sobering
description: After a morning spent listening to experts recommending ways that early childhood education could prevent youth violence, the state attorneys general gathered here heard a sobering message from Littleton, Colo.

title: Blair Makes Quick Visit to a Refugee Camp
description: Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain visited this tent city of 30,000 displaced Kosovars today, promising to double his nation's aid to Macedonia for handling the refugee crisis from to $64 million from $32 million.

title: Many Role Debuts in Classical Works
description: American Ballet Theater described its Saturday matinee and evening programs as all classical. The rich variety of those programs and of the performances, which included many role debuts, suggests that reports of the death of classical ballet are decidedly premature.

title: When High School Bands Get a Chance to Play Real Ellington
description: The Essentially Ellington High School Jazz Band Competition and Festival, presented by Jazz at Lincoln Center, ended its three-day run on Saturday night with a concert at Avery Fisher Hall. The hall was astir with emotion and expectation; three of the contest's 20 finalist bands performed a few Ellington songs, waiting to find out which would be the winner. To dilute the tension, Wynton Marsalis soloed long and hard with each band.

title: MEDIACOM TO ACQUIRE TRIAX MIDWEST FOR $740 MILLION
description: Mediacom L.L.C., a closely held provider of cable television and Internet services in small communities and rural areas, agreed yesterday to buy the closely held Triax Midwest Associates L.P. for $740 million, doubling its size. The acquisition, along with another previously announced deal, will make Mediacom one of the 10 largest independent cable TV companies in the United States. Mediacom, based in Middletown, N.Y., had revenue of $129.3 million last year. After its pending acquisitions are complete, it will serve more than 725,000 customers in 20 states. It currently has around 370,000 customers in 14 states. Triax, based in Denver, has about 342,000 subscribers in Arizona, Illinois, Indiana, Iowa, Michigan, Minnesota and Wisconsin.

title: Newspaper Industry Fails To Stem Circulation Drop
description: Months of effort by the nation's newspaper publishers to rein in price increases and to promote their publications aggressively failed to stem the industry's long-term circulation decline. The latest figures from the Audit Bureau of Circulations showed average daily circulation down five-tenths of 1 percent, while Sunday circulation dropped by 1 percent, for the six months ending March 30.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSHOLL, LEON HAROLD
description: GOLDSHOLL-Leon Harold, 79. On May 3, 1999. Of Rego Park, NY. Devoted husband of Evelyn for 53 years, beloved father to Ann Lynn Varsano and David Goldsholl, adoring grandfather of Joshua, Douglas and Jamie. Raised in Bronx, NY and Springfield, Mass., before graduating from DeWitt Clinton High School, with his father Abe and brother Saul, he founded Ann Revere Lingerie. From 1960 to 1990 he was a registered Representative, concluding his career with Gruntal and Company. In retirement, he was an arbitrator for the NASD and New York Stock Exchange. He was a member of the American Arbitrators Association. Memorial donations may be sent to the ACLU.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOEFLICH, BARBARA SU
description: HOEFLICH-Barbara Su. On May 2, 1999 at home. Devoted wife of Joe for 40 years. Loving mother of Michael, Randye, Adam, Lauren, Ernest, Karen and Denise. Doting grandmother of Jacob, Joshua and Erin. Best friend and sister of Ann Glazer. In place of flowers, donations can be made to the North Western Memorial Foundation for the Special Care Nursery, (312)-926-2033. Services 10:30am, Tuesday, May 4 at Beth Moses cemetery, Farmingdale, NY.

title: Playwrights of Old Flourish in Tony Nominations
description: In a season that brought works by Tennessee Williams, Arthur Miller and Eugene O'Neill to Broadway, those playwrights showed their staying power yesterday when their dramas led the Tony Award nominations for straight play.

title: An Uneasy Coexistence; Tensions Between Town and Shelter Flow Both Ways
description: The 13 homeless men stood apart from one another in the parking lot of the Chester Mall, afraid, one said later, of drawing hostile attention. So they tried to blend in, clutching their purchases of crackers, soda and instant soup, and anxiously scanning the horizon for the van back to Camp La Guardia, a 365-acre outpost of the New York City shelter system in Orange County.

title: Qatar Says It Cut Oil Output in March
description: Qatar, which has been one of OPEC's biggest quota busters, said yesterday that it had cut output as promised in March under a plan for 14 nations to reduce oil production to erase a global oil glut and increase prices. Qatar agreed to slash production by 47,000 barrels a day to 593,000 barrels a day. The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries and four other nations pledged to start cutting output on April 1 in a plan to trim world supply by 2.1 million barrels a day, or 2.7 percent.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Thursday about the effect of minimills on the United States steel industry misstated the surname of the founder of Weirton Steel. He was Ernest T. Weir, not Weirton.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ORZACK, EVERETT D.
description: ORZACK-Everett D. On May 1, 1999 after a long illness in Hamden, CT, formerly of River Edge, New Jersey.
