Loving husband of Mildred Levin Orzack; adoring father of Susan Posen, Karen Orzack-Moore & sons-in-law Stephen and Daniel; devoted grandfather of Alexandra, Zachary, Ari and Nathaniel. Brother of Louis and the late Alvyn. Services 1:30 PM on Wednesday, May 5th at Louis Suburban Chapel, Fair Lawn, NJ. Donations to a charity of your choice would be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TIMPANE, LILLIAN G.
description: TIMPANE-Lillian G. 73. Died May 2, in San Francisco, CA. Born in New York, she graduated with a nursing degree from the Jersey City Medical Center and was a nurse for more than fifty years. She is survived by two sisters, a brother, nine children and ten grandchildren.

title: Russian Brings Peace Proposal To Washington
description: President Clinton held an extended discussion today with the Russian special envoy for the Balkans. But the White House remained pessimistic about the prospect of a deal anytime soon to end the Kosovo conflict.

title: Several Big Auto Makers Posted Robust April Sales
description: In a further sign of consumers' willingness to keep spending in a robust economy, auto sales maintained their sizzling pace in April.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: SILICON VALLEY GROUP INC., San Jose, Calif., a maker of equipment used to manufacture computer chips, agreed to buy the semiconductor-equipment operations of Watkins-Johnson Co., Palo Alto, Calif., for about $46 million in cash and debt.

title: Dole Sticks to Stance on Guns In Challenge to Rifle Group
description: Taking on the National Rifle Association, long a sacred cow among many Republicans, Elizabeth Dole asserted today, ''I don't think that any special interest group should dictate what our position is going to be on particular issues.''

title: Violent Games, Violent Deeds?; The Court's Intent
description: To the Editor:

title: New Jersey Sizing Up Muresan
description: WIZARDS 113, NETS 102

title: Oslo and the Israeli Election
description: Five and a half years after the historic handshake at the White House by Yitzhak Rabin and Yasir Arafat, negotiations to reach a final peace agreement between Israel and the Palestinians are dormant. Today, May 4, marks the date that both sides had targeted for completion of an accord, yet the most difficult issues remain to be addressed, including the shape and status of a Palestinian state and the future of Jerusalem. Whatever government Israelis select in the coming election must revive the Oslo peace effort.

title: Officer Hints That 3 G.I.'s Were Beaten
description: Three American soldiers freed from a Yugoslav prison over the weekend met with their families in Germany today, and their commander suggested they had been mistreated while in custody.

title: When Worlds of Creation and Destruction Collide
description: His diary entry for one day in 1898 read: ''Fired cannon, pop and firecrackers all day. In evening had five sky rockets, three Roman candles, one large pinwheel and a Japanese match which I made.''

title: North Korean Team To Train in New Jersey
description: WOMEN'S WORLD CUP

title: SBC-Telmex Deal Seeks Phone Carrier In Puerto Rico
description: Betting on both wireless phones and the Caribbean economy, SBC Communications Inc. said yesterday that it had joined with Telefonos de Mexico S.A. in an agreement to acquire Cellular Communications of Puerto Rico Inc., the biggest wireless phone carrier on that island and in the United States Virgin Islands, for $464 million in cash.

title: Doctors Face the Business of Medicine
description: No one had ever said that starting her own allergy practice would be easy, but Dr. Cheryl Lynn Walker was not prepared for the anxieties that beset her after she opened her doors to patients.

title: Pataki Would Ease Drug Laws, But Ties Plan to Ending Parole
description: Gov. George E. Pataki proposed a plan today to loosen the stringent Rockefeller-era drug laws, which critics say have caused New York's prison population to swell over the last two decades with drug offenders who have been subjected to tough mandatory sentences.

title: De Niro and Miramax Face Problems in Film Studio Plan
description: Although Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, the actor Robert De Niro and Harvey Weinstein of Miramax Films announced a tentative agreement yesterday to build a movie studio at the Brooklyn Navy Yard, major elements of the deal to transform the cavernous shipbuilding complex into a glamorous film factory are not in place.

title: New York's Mental Health Laws Are Too Lax
description: To the Editor:

title: Deeper Truths Sought In Violence by Youths
description: They seemed, people said at the time, like normal children from normal families, rattling along the bumpy emotional road that most people believe represents the normal course of the teen-age years.

title: Old Names Stage Big Rally As Technology Issues Sag
description: The Dow Jones industrial average's charge above 11,000 yesterday was led by formerly stodgy stocks sensitive to the business cycle while money moved out of technology shares, continuing a trend that has been in place for weeks.

title: KINDER MORGAN BUYING CONTROL OF PLANTATION PIPE LINE
description: Kinder Morgan Energy Partners L.P., which owns more than 5,000 miles of United States pipelines, agreed yesterday to buy the Chevron Corporation's 27 percent stake in the Plantation Pipe Line Company for $124 million in cash to gain control of the company. The purchase would give Kinder Morgan a 51 percent interest in Plantation, which runs a 3,144-mile pipeline that delivers gasoline, diesel and jet fuel to markets in the Southeast. The Exxon Corporation owns the rest. Kinder Morgan, based in Houston, owns pipelines in 16 states.

title: A Casual Attitude Despite Uncertainty
description: This may seem a strange compliment to offer a rock star, but Sheryl Crow's great gift may be for understatement. Her songs observe uncertainty creeping up casually on people, from the apologetic partygoers in 1993's ''All I Wanna Do'' to the wryly regretful lover of last year's ''My Favorite Mistake.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEAVERS, KARL A.
description: DEAVERS-Karl A. Of Old Brookville and Manhattan. Suddenly on May 2. Beloved husband of Kerry. Loving father of Kary, Charlotte and Karl Jr. Dear brother of Okey, Robert and Barbara Wilson. Visiting Dodge Thomas Funeral Home, Glen Cove, New York, Tuesday 7-9 PM, Wednesday 3-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass St. Dominic's Church, Thursday 9:30 AM.

title: Hypothesis: The Artist Does See Things Differently
description: Can artistic talent be measured scientifically? A laughable notion, perhaps. And yet, according to ''The Painter's Eye,'' an intriguing small show at the National Portrait Gallery in London that runs through June 13, some of the secrets of the creative process are now being cracked by the latest biomedical technology.

title: Japan Recession Stifles Trade Climate, if Not Summit Talk
description: President Clinton and Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi of Japan professed fundamental agreement today on strategies to pull Japan from a seven-year slump and deregulate its economy. But their daylong meeting underscored how many of Mr. Clinton's once ambitious economic initiatives with Tokyo have been sunk by the Japanese recession.

title: Two Parties Seek to Exploit a Relentless Boom in the Suburbs
description: Anyone perplexed by the amount of time Vice President Al Gore has recently devoted to traffic jams and suburban sprawl should consider this: Fifty years ago fewer than a quarter of Americans lived in the suburbs; now roughly half do. Every 10 years, another 10 members of Congress represent predominantly suburban districts.

title: It's Not Pretty, It's Just the Knicks
description: The Knicks jumped to a 16-0 lead in the first quarter, the kind of start that means good things to come for a pro basketball team. But nothing comes easy for these Knicks, who were in a scrap for their post-season lives against the Boston Celtics, a lottery team, in the second-to-last game of the regular season.

title: Police Are Said to Have a Suspect In Long Island Fire That Killed 3
description: HUNTINGTON STATION, N.Y., May 3 -- A fire that destroyed a two-story house here Saturday and killed three of the 34 immigrants living in it was apparently set by a man who had been having a dispute with one of the tenants, officials close to the investigation said today.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Dow Surpasses 11,000 as Base Of Rally Grows
description: The Dow Jones industrial average blew past 11,000 yesterday as investors abandoned the beloved glamour stocks and elbowed their way into the shares of the most staid and unsexy of companies.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Pushing the Envelope at Sony; A Japanese Corporate Rebel With a Playstation Cause
description: It all started with a broken contract.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'NEIL, JAMES MARTIN
description: O'NEIL-James Martin. 71. Of New York City on May 1, 1999. Beloved husband of Anne Kennedy O'Neil. Devoted father of Anne Ocampo of New York City, and Martin O'Neil of Hong Kong. Loving grandfather of Molly, Julie, James, Mariko, and Anna. Mass of Christian Burial will be held at the Church of St. Thomas More, 65 East 89 St., Wednesday, May 5, 11 AM. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Church of St. Thomas More would be greatly appreciated.

title: State Panel Steps Up Its Inquiry Into City's Public Schools
description: Three months after it was set up by Gov. George E. Pataki, a special state commission examining possible mismanagement and corruption in the New York City schools is deploying lawyers, state troopers, auditors and construction engineers in what is becoming one of the largest investigations of the school bureaucracy in decades.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOSCO, MARY F.
description: BOSCO-Mary F. Of Hackettstown, N.J., on April 30, 1999. Devoted mother of Joseph A. and Anthony J. Bosco, Grace A. Smith & Donna F. Fina. Dear sister of Michael, John, and Ralph Salerno. Also survived by 12 grandchildren and eight great-grandchildren. Calling hours 2-4 and 7-9 P.M. Thursday, May 6, at the Cochran Funeral Home, 905 High St., Hackettstown, NJ. Funeral Mass 10 A.M. Friday, May 7, at Good Shepherd R.C. Church, Andover, New Jersey. Followed by interment at the F. Loescher Veteran's Memorial Cemetery, New Hempstead, NY.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: A Far Cry From a Barn

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OGILVIE, DR. JOHN B.
description: OGILVIE-Dr. John B. Passed away late Saturday evening, May 1, 1999, in his home in Riverside, CT. Dr. Ogilvie was born in New York City, March 3, 1910. He was a graduate of Yale College ('31) and Yale School of Medicine ('34). Dr. Ogilvie served as a surgeon with the rank of Captain in the Army's 9th General Hospital Unit from New York Hospital in New Guinea and the Philippines during World War II. After finishing his residency in New York Hospital, he moved to Stamford, CT, where he practiced general surgery until he retired in 1987. During his years in Stamford, he served as Surgeon in Chief at Stamford Hospital from 1966-1972, as well as president of the YMCA ('60-'65). He also served on the Yale Development Board and the prestigious Yale Dean's Council. During his retirement, Dr. Ogilvie was active in the Yale development offices, and was the recipient of Yale's first Peter Parker Medal for outstanding service to Yale School of Medicine and to medicine. He is survived by his wife, Donna; four sons, John, Donald, Peter and Andrew; three stepchildren, John Latham, Katharine Butler, and Karen Scheid; eight grandchildren and three step-grandchildren. A memorial service for Dr. Ogilvie will be held Wednesday, May 5, 1999, at 2:30 p.m., at the First Presbyterian Church of Stamford. Memorial remembrances may be made to Yale Medical School, PO Box 7613, New Haven, CT 06519, or Hospice Care at 1029 East Main St, Stamford, CT 06902. For more information, contact Bouton & Reynolds Funeral Home at 203-327-9800.

title: Groups Sue To Stop Sale Of Gardens Owned by City
description: Hoping to stop the auction of 112 community gardens next week, a coalition of elected officials, community boards and gardening groups sued the city yesterday, charging that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani violated state and city laws when he put the lots up for sale.

title: A Show of Security and Some Protests
description: As different as the atmosphere felt tonight inside Camden Yards, where the Baltimore Orioles completed their home-and-home series with the Cuban national team, so it was on the streets beyond the gates.

title: Knicks Follow Ewing's Lead Into the Playoffs
description: There had been a clamor for change, a call for a new twist on an old team during the summer. And so the Knicks looked around every corner, peered down every dark alley and found the kind of talent to ultimately phase out Patrick Ewing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOPCHIK, WOLF B.
description: TOPCHIK-Wolf B., 102, of Bethesda, MD, formerly of Passaic, NJ, on May 2, 1999. Beloved husband of the late Libby nee Pruzansky, loving father of Robert J., Dr. Abraham, and Sylvia Levine. Dear brother of Martin, Alfred, and George. Dear grandfather of 10 grandchildren and nine greatgrandchildren. Service will be Tuesday, May 4, at 1 P.M. from Jewish Memorial Chapel, 841 Allwood Road, Clifton, New Jersey.

title: Lyme Expert Developed Big Picture Of Tiny Tick
description: Looking out of the mist-covered window of his fourth floor office at Tufts-New England Medical Center here, Dr. Allen C. Steere inspected the urban sky on a warm spring day not long ago. ''More ticks,'' he warned gravely. ''If you have a mild winter and a warm, wet spring, those are good tick conditions.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KILCOIN, VIRGINIA R.
description: KILCOIN-Virginia R. 83, New York City High School teacher, retired. Widow of Edward Kilcoin. Survived by sister Elizabeth Gormley, daughters Mary Elizabeth Woodburn and Amanda McGehee, grandchildren Matthew Woodburn, James McGehee, Jessica Woodburn, Catherine McGehee and great granddaughter Delaney McGehee. Memorial Service to be held at East Ridge Retirement Village Chapel Sat. May 8th in Miami

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUBKOFF, ALLEN
description: SUBKOFF-Allen, 63. Third-generation antique dealer, died peacefully at home surrounded by his loving family, April 30, 1999. Memorial service Wednesday, May 5, at 2 P.M., at Eternal Light Funeral Home, 17250 West Dixie Highway, North Miami Beach, Florida. Loving brother to George, and uncle to Tracey, Gary, Tara and Daniel.

title: In Arizona Desert, a Bird Oasis in Peril
description: From a bird's-eye view, it is easy to see why the upper San Pedro River in southeastern Arizona is such an enticing rest stop. Surrounded by barren brown desert for as far as the eye can see, the river sticks out along the Mexican border like a big green sign on a long, lonely stretch of western highway saying: Gas, Food, Lodging.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEIBOWITZ, HENRY
description: LEIBOWITZ-Henry. On May 2, 1999. Dear husband of Audrey. Beloved father of Debra, David and Lori and Ellen and Steven Fishman. Adored Papa of Emma Rose and Rebecca. Loving brother of Arnold and Mike. Loving friend. Services Tuesday 1:30pm at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels'' 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, NY. Interment at New Montefiore Cemetery, Pinelawn, NY. Donations may be made to the American Diabetes Association.

title: After 5 Weeks, Jury Is Selected for Federal Trial of Officers in Louima Case
description: After five weeks of effort, a jury was selected yesterday for the long-awaited trial of four New York City police officers accused of brutalizing a Haitian immigrant. Opening statements and the first witnesses are expected today.

title: Coca-Cola Said to Renew French Talks
description: The Coca-Cola Company has reopened talks with the French Finance Ministry about its plan to buy the Orangina brand from Pernod-Ricard S.A., according to a report today in The Times of London.

title: Colombia and Guerrillas Agree to Start Peace Talks
description: After more than six months of on-again, off-again discussions, the Government and the main left-wing guerrilla group announced early today that they had agreed not only to begin formal peace negotiations aimed at ending 35 years of conflict, but also to invite international observers to sit in on the talks.

title: 3 Sets of Data Are Positive For Economy
description: Manufacturing grew in April for the third consecutive month, and personal income and spending and construction spending all rose in March, a private industry survey and Government reports showed today.

title: No More Comebacks for Elway
description: John Elway, who retired Sunday after 16 seasons as quarterback for the Denver Broncos, is the third exceptional athlete to leave the American sporting scene this year. Michael Jordan said farewell to basketball in January and Wayne Gretzky ended his hockey career in April. Elway does not rise to quite the same level as Jordan or Gretzky, each of whom may have been the best player in the history of his sport. It would be hard to make a case that Elway was the ''best'' of a breed that includes Sammy Baugh, Johnny Unitas, Joe Namath and Joe Montana. But he was certainly something special, and football will be poorer without him.

title: Roderick Thorp, 62, a Detective Turned Popular Crime Novelist
description: Roderick Thorp, a former private investigator whose best-selling crime novels became successful films, was found dead on Wednesday at his home in Oxnard, Calif. He was 62.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STANLEY, DAVID A., SR.
description: STANLEY-David A., Sr., of Summerfield, FL, formerly of Long Island, died May 2, 1999, at Ocala Regional Medical Center in Ocala, FL. Born October 7, 1931. Retired from the New York Times four years ago after 43 years as a Makeup Supervisor. He was a member of St. Timothy's Catholic Church in Lady Lake, FL. He is survived by his wife, Ruth, of Summerfield, FL; four daughters, Susan Stanley of White Plains, NY, Maureen Santos of Freehold, NJ, Nancy Vareles of Mt. Sinai, NY, and Patricia Noblett of Oak Park, CA; four sons, David of Sound Beach, NY, William and Russell, both of Trumbull, CT, and Gregory of Millbury, MA. He is also survived by two sisters, Barbara Attenborough of Spring Hill, FL, and Pamela Lopez of Troy, NY; two brothers, Robert Stanley of Merrick, NY, and Robert Gilson of Catasaqua, PA; and 15 grandchildren. Visitation will be Tuesday, May 4, from 2-4 and 6-8 p.m. at Hiers Memorial Chapel in Lady Lake, FL. Funeral Mass will be at 11:00 a.m. Wednesday, May 5, at St. Theresa Catholic Church, in Belleview, FL. For more information, contact Hiers Memorial Chapel at 352753-8353.

title: The Real American Savings Rate
description: Recently, the personal savings rate in the United States turned negative for the first time since the Great Depression. Even though the American economy is still growing at a sizzling rate, some economists have greeted the official claim that Americans now spend more than they make as evidence that clouds are gathering on the horizon.

title: Hormone in U.S. Beef Causes Cancer, EU Scientists Conclude
description: BRUSSELS  A European Union scientific committee said Monday that it had evidence to show that a growth hormone used in U.S. cattle production is a "complete carcinogen" and warned that other hormones could cause a variety of health problems.

title: Making a Connection
description: To the Editor:

title: In Mud, on Dirt, Over Logs, It's Cyclocross
description: Cyclocross, a sport that combines aspects of mountain biking, steeplechasing and Nascar auto racing, is beginning to develop a following in the United States after decades of popularity in Europe.

title: Turtles Vanish in Black Hole: Soup Pots and Pans of China
description: One of the world's great centers of turtle and tortoise diversity, Southeast Asia has long teemed with species found nowhere else in the world. But in recent years, researchers say, this biological treasure trove has become a gold mine for profiteers who have been gathering every turtle in sight for sale as food and medicinals in the turtle markets of China.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Dow Crosses 11,000 Mark Just 24 Days After 10,000

title: Loyalty as a Court Credential
description: Gov. Christine Whitman of New Jersey has described State Attorney General Peter Verniero, whom she has nominated to the New Jersey Supreme Court, as ''110 percent loyal.'' She has rewarded that loyalty by appointing him to ever-higher positions, making him her chief counsel, chief of staff and then Attorney General in 1996. But personal loyalty to Mrs. Whitman is not a good enough reason to promote Mr. Verniero to a seat on the state's highest court, a position that he may hold for 30 years. The Republican-controlled State Senate should reject Mr. Verniero's nomination for his lack of legal experience and his long failure to stop the use of racial profiling by the New Jersey State Police, which his office oversees.

title: Man Accused of Providing Gun Used in Colorado Attack
description: As Columbine High School students returned to classes today for the first time since the killings of 13 people here almost two weeks ago, a 22-year-old graduate of the school was charged with providing a powerful, semi-automatic handgun to one of the killers.

title: Behind the Drop In Teen-Age Births
description: To the Editor:

title: How Voice of NATO Honed His Delivery
description: NATO has called up reserves of spin in the information battle over Kosovo, trying to keep the offensive after suffering some tactical reverses on the ground in news briefings in Brussels.

title: Radio Station Acquisition
description: Big City Radio Inc., which owns radio stations in New York, Los Angeles and Chicago, said today that it would acquire four stations in Phoenix for about $37 million. Big City Radio plans to combine the signals from the four stations into two in an effort to increase ratings and revenue. The company, based in Hawthorne, buys stations and combines them to get wider coverage. After the Phoenix purchases, Big City Radio will have spent about $122.6 million to combine the signals of 16 radio stations into six.

title: Top Mexican Steelmaker Has Missed 2 Debt Payments
description: Mexico's largest steel manufacturer has defaulted on debt payments twice in the last few weeks, a reminder that the Asian crisis and its aftermath are still wreaking havoc on some Latin American companies, even though most of the region's economies have begun to recover.

title: Wing Is Reacquired
description: The Rangers acquired right wing Brad Smyth from the Nashville Predators for future considerations.

title: To Treat the Thousands: Sympathy and Aspirin
description: The butt of a Serbian rifle left the refugee's eyes swollen shut. In a crowded storage closet that is now his examining room, Dr. James Desmoore found the man was bleeding from the gash on the bridge of his nose. His cheek, his forehead and perhaps the back of his skull had probably been fractured by the beating.

title: Heidelberger Zement Bids For Scancem
description: Heidelberger Zement A.G., the world's fourth-biggest cement company, offered 21.7 billion Swedish kronor ($2.58 billion) to take control of Scancem A.B. from two Scandinavian companies as it expands overseas to offset sluggish growth in Germany. Heidelberger offered as much as 410 Swedish kronor for each Scancem A share and up to 390 for each B share to Aker RGI ASA of Norway and Skanska A.B. of Sweden for 73.4 percent of the Swedish cement company.

title: Delphi Financial Sells Unicover
description: Delphi Financial Group Inc. said today that it had sold Unicover Managers Inc., sending Delphi shares up 29 percent amid relief the company will not be responsible for losses linked to one of Unicover's insurance pools.

title: NATO Planes Flying Lower, Increasing Risk of Being Hit
description: NATO warplanes have begun flying more low-altitude bombing raids against Yugoslav forces in Kosovo, a practice that until now was ruled out as too dangerous, Pentagon officials said today.

title: Succession Fight Roils World Trade Organization
description: A leadership crisis disrupted operations of the World Trade Organization today after weekend negotiations collapsed, with no breakthrough in sight.

title: Man Whose Brother Died In Jail Is Arrested
description: The brother of a man who died in custody last month after being taken in for questioning about the shooting of a police officer was arrested during the weekend on charges that he shot a man in Newark.

title: Training With Guns; Money, Not Principle

title: Staying Vigilant for Choking Hazards
description: Meals served to young children outside the home may present a greater choking risk than those served at home, according to a report presented last week at a meeting of the American Society of Pediatric Otolaryngology. Dr. James S. Reilly, chairman of the department of surgery at Dupont Hospital for Children in Wilmington, Del., noted that care givers may not always be aware of the most appropriate foods for a given age group.

description: Is gold on its way to becoming just another commodity? The people who run the world's financial system are doing their best to secure that fate for the metal that once was viewed as the only ''real'' money.

description: Having to confront the tension of a seventh and deciding game was the last thing the Devils expected when they started their first-round Stanley Cup playoff series with the Penguins nearly two weeks ago. And who could blame them?

description: To the Editor:

title: NATO AIR ATTACKS ON POWER PLANTS PASS A THRESHOLD
description: By broadening the scope of its air strikes and attacking Yugoslavia's electrical system, NATO today crossed a threshold in the 40-day campaign, with bombing that had an immediate and widespread effect on the Yugoslav people.

description: The Baltimore Orioles took one small step for international diplomacy tonight and one huge step for their own humiliation.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BALANCHINE, GEORGE
description: BALANCHINE-George. A service in memory of George Balanchine will be held on Tuesday, May 4, 1999 at 7:30 P.M., at the Cathedral of Our Lady of the Sign, 75 East 93rd Street, New York, New York.

title: Dane N. Bath Picture Editor, 58
description: Dane N. Bath, a former picture editor of The New York Times and The Chicago Tribune, died on Wednesday at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. He was 58 and lived in Parsippany, N.J.

title: Outdated, Trivial, Adored: the Best-Dressed List
description: Although nobody was wearing white gloves or reminiscing about the good old days, last week's committee meeting of the Best-Dressed List definitely had a deja vu feeling. ''I felt like I was in a time warp,'' said one participant, among a dozen or so society figures and journalists who convened in secret at the Fifth Avenue apartment of Eleanor Lambert to decide who belongs and who doesn't on the world's oldest clotheshorse list.

title: Business Use Of Nuclear Site Worries Group
description: The Energy Department, which has been raising money for its costly environmental cleanup of old bomb factories by leasing them to commercial tenants, may be exposing ordinary factory workers to excessive radiation, an environmental group says.

title: Lawmaker Proposes Bills Regulating the Internet
description: In an attempt to regulate the Internet in New Jersey, a legislator yesterday proposed bills that would require ''junk'' E-mail messages to be labeled as advertising and require software to warn Internet users that their identities can be traced.

title: Young Tenor Shows the Value Of Care and Encouragement
description: Two years ago Gregory Turay, a Milwaukee-born tenor, gave a promising New York debut recital under the auspices of the Young Concert Artists Program. He seemed then a gifted singer with a pliant, attractive voice and sensitive musical instincts, though he clearly needed further coaching to realize his potential.

title: Orania Journal; Afrikaners Have a Dream, Very Like the Old One
description: There is still a whites-only enclave in South Africa.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The fact that lights went out across 70 percent of the country shows that NATO has its finger on the light switch now.''

title: Cigars and Wine Are His Bread and Butter
description: ''CHEAP cigars stink but well-made cigars have an elegant bouquet that people adore,'' said Marvin R. Shanken, as he lighted his Havana-made Hoyo de Monterrey Double Corona, a seven-and-five-eighths-inch specimen that cost about $15. ''This is rich and spicy, with notes of cherry and licorice.'' As the smoke billowed through his office, he caught sight of his visitor's reaction. Abruptly, he stubbed the thing out.

title: List of Final Witnesses Released in Microsoft Trial
description: The Microsoft Corporation and the Government both released the names today of the final witnesses each intends to call when the antitrust trial resumes later this month. The list indicates that the Government hopes to shore up its case, while Microsoft's goal, at least in part, is to change the subject of discussion to one that might make the Government's case seem irrelevant.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIXON, PATRICIA RILEY
description: DIXON-Patricia Riley. A 30-year resident of Houston, TX, born in Oklahoma City, OK, on October 25, 1927, passed away from cancer on Monday, May 3, at Methodist Hospital in Houston. Patricia was the only child of Louise B. and Patrick J. Riley of Oklahoma City. Patricia graduated from Marymount Academy, Tarrytown, NY, Marymount Junior College, Bel Air, CA, and Marymount College, Tarrytown, NY. Patricia also attended the University of Oklahoma for one year, where she was a member of the Kappa Alpha Theta sorority. Patricia served as co-chairman of the Oklahoma City Symphony Society and as president of the Houston Town and Country Garden Club. Patricia also served as a member of the Board of Trustees of the Houston Ballet Foundation, a member of the Metropolitan Opera National Council, of New York City, and served on the Executive Committee of the Museum of Fine Arts, Houston. She also served as an advisory trustee for the museum for three years. Patricia is survived by her husband, Frank A. Dixon, Jr., of Houston; three Dixon nephews: John I. of Thurmont, MD, Steven H. of Lee, MA, and Alexander F. of Minneapolis; and four first cousins: James E. Burke of Oklahoma City, Jane Ellen Plowden-Wardlaw of Taos, NM, Nancy Elizabeth Burke Grivel of Fribourgh, Switzerland, and Anne Duffy Burke of Milano, Italy. Funeral Mass will be celebrated at 2:00 p.m. Wednesday, May 5, at St. Anne's Catholic Church, 2140 Westheimer, Houston, with Rev. Charles Christopher, C.S.B., celebrant. The rite of committal will follow at Glenwood Cemetery, also in Houston. Honorary pallbearers will be William S. Snider of Dallas; F. Carrington Weems, S. Field Emerson and Isaac Arnold, all of Houston; and Herbert C. Oven of Tulsa, OK. Memorial contributions may be directed to any charity.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the listing of new equity issues in Business Day yesterday misspelled the name of a company with an initial offering of three million shares. It is Media Metrix, not Media Matrix.

title: MCI Is Said To Weigh Bid For Mediaone
description: Setting the stage for a showdown between two of the nation's biggest communications companies, MCI Worldcom Inc. is seriously considering joining the Comcast Corporation in its multibillion-dollar fight against the AT&T Corporation to acquire Mediaone Group, the big cable television company, executives close to the negotiations said yesterday.

title: Finally, Flushing an Infamous Canal
description: A little bit of Venice in Brooklyn?

title: A Simpler, Cheaper Plan for Fighting High Blood Pressure
description: People with high blood pressure often fail to respond to medication, leading their doctors to prescribe more and more pills for them. Instead, doctors should help them remember to take the pills they already have, according to an international expert in blood pressure control.

title: Taking the Long Way
description: Haile Gebrselassie, the world's greatest distance runner, arrived in Manhattan yesterday after a 16-hour flight from Ethiopia and made plans for an easy jog to stretch his legs. Of course, for him, easy means an hour running the roller-coaster hills of Central Park.

title: Try Harder To Win War, McCain Bill Would Urge
description: Nearly six weeks after the air war in Yugoslavia began, the Senate took up debate today over authorizing President Clinton to use all means necessary to win NATO's fight for Kosovo.

title: Changes in Accounts At Several Concerns
description: Several large advertisers said yesterday that they would make changes involving their accounts.

title: How Can the Vatican Stay Neutral?
description: Who, I wonder, is advising the Pope on the war in Kosovo?

title: TERRA INDUSTRIES TO SELL DISTRIBUTION BUSINESS
description: Terra Industries agreed yesterday to sell its distribution business for $361 million to the Cenex/Land O' Lakes Agronomy Company. The business, which has about 2,600 employees, had 1998 revenue of $1.73 billion. Cenex/Land O' Lakes, which is owned by the agricultural cooperatives Land O'Lakes and Cenex Harvest States, said it planned to offer employment to all the employees of the distribution. The sale includes about 400 farm-service centers in the United States and Canada as well as a 50 percent stake in the Omnium chemical-formulation plants in St. Joseph, Mo., and Blytheville, Ark. Terra Industries, a fertilizer, crop-protection and seeds company based in Sioux City, Iowa, had 1998 revenue of $2.55 billion.

title: Eagerly Lifted Out of the Pit Into the Light
description: Something extra happens when the enormously skilled and dedicated musicians of the Metropolitan Opera's orchestra perform symphonic programs at Carnegie Hall, especially when they take on a piece like Brahms's Second Symphony, the main work in Sunday afternoon's concert, the last of the season, conducted by James Levine.

title: Atlanta Water Park Sold

White Water-Atlanta is in the top 10 of water parks, with about 600,000 visitors a year, Premier Parks said. Premier, based in Oklahoma City, expects to complete the purchase early this month. The closely held Silver Dollar City is based in Branson, Mo.

title: Lasmo of Britain Bids For Smaller Oil Rival
description: The British oil company Lasmo P.L.C. offered yesterday to buy its smaller-sector rival, Monument Oil and Gas P.L.C., for $:600 million ($965.6 million). Lasmo, which recently broke off merger talks with Enterprise Oil P.L.C., said the combination with Monument would create a company with low-cost reserves, strong growth potential and high-quality cash flow.

title: Microsoft To Upgrade Windows 98
description: The Microsoft Corporation plans to announce Windows 98 Second Edition today, an upgrade to the company's desktop operating system for consumers.

title: Levitt Strongly Critical of Methods of On-Line Brokers
description: Maybe some tow-truck drivers do own islands that they bought with profits from trading stocks on line.

title: State Phones Swamped By Tax Rebate Response
description: The response to a telephone filing system for a state property tax rebate program has been so heavy that callers have received constant busy signals and state officials vowed yesterday to add hundreds more lines.

title: Must Vegetarians Eat Fat?
description: To the Editor:

title: Mystics Select Holdsclaw At No. 1
description: Chamique Holdsclaw stood on the podium holding her new jersey in front of her. The most notable thing about Holdsclaw's appearance -- aside from the professional hairstyling and makeup obviously preparing her for an endorsement bonanza -- was that it was not a New York Liberty uniform the best player in the game held, despite conspiracy theories that had dominated discussion about the Women's National Basketball Association draft.

title: KLM to Reduce Shares And Make Big Payout
description: KLM Royal Dutch Airlines said yesterday that it would reduce its equity base by up to 25 percent after it completes a reverse stock split and returns about 430 million euros ($454.3 million) to shareholders. KLM shares soared 7.9 percent, or 2.15 euros, to 30.55 euros. The transaction is linked to the recent sale of part of the airline's stake in its telecommunications unit Equant N.V. and the anticipated proceeds from the sale of its holding in Galileo International Inc., a provider of electronic distribution services for the travel industry.

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: EUROPE

title: Record U.S. Fine Set for German Company
description: SGL Carbon A.G., the world's No. 1 maker of graphite electrodes used to heat the furnaces of steelmakers, agreed today to pay a record $145 million United States antitrust fine and plead guilty to participating in an international conspiracy to fix electrode prices.

title: Notebook; Think Before Parking Here
description: In the latest experiment in motivating students, Nicolet High School in Glendale, Wis., an affluent suburb of Milwaukee, has decided to withhold parking privileges.

title: Asparagus: The Skinny
description: FAT asparagus spears have their charms, but pencil-thin spears have two distinct advantages in a time-sensitive kitchen. They can be cooked without peeling, because their outer sheaths are so tender, and they cook so much faster, which is an asset for roasting.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''It didn't collapse, it

title: About New York; Soccer Mom Who Fosters Lofty Goals
description: ''WHERE'S the rest of the team?'' Laurie Kilpatrick said as she paced the sidelines of a soccer field on Wards Island Sunday afternoon. ''Everybody's supposed to come. You know how we do it. We have a panic attack before the game.''

title: INSIDE
description: Inquiry Clears Holbrooke

title: U.N. Nominee Is Cleared After Inquiry By State Dept.
description: The State Department's inspector general said today that she had cleared Richard C. Holbrooke, President Clinton's nominee as chief American diplomat to the United Nations, after an investigation of speaking fees that he accepted while working as an unpaid White House envoy to the Balkans.

title: Skyline Shaper Widens His Own Horizons
description: AS a princeling born into one of New York's skyscraper dynasties, Joseph B. Rose could have shaped the city from the family real estate firm. Instead, he chose to shape the city in another way, through the politics of building.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE EURO GAINS. The dollar fell against the euro after the president of the European Central Bank suggested that the bank might buy euros if the currency continued to fall. The euro rose to $1.0617, from $1.0567.

title: So That's Why Walls Conceal Heating Vents
description: Tucked into the hollow walls of buildings, electrical wires do their work unsung and hidden from view. A few months ago Sheila Kennedy, an architect, gave wires their due. She delivered a lecture at Radcliffe's Bunting Institute in Cambridge, Mass., called ''Electricity, the Fairy and the Hollow Wall: Rethinking the Spaces of Infrastructure in Architecture.'' The infrastructure of buildings, crammed into chimneys, stairways, hallways and hollow walls, she said, has been ''feminized'' and ''repressed'' for too long.

title: Chefs and Authors Reap Their Plaudits
description: FOR the second year in a row, New York's restaurants and chefs have captured the majority of the major national awards bestowed by the James Beard Foundation.

title: Internet Venture Sets Off Hong Kong Market Frenzy
description: Investors here are usually entranced by tycoons rather than technology. Put them together, though, and it can whip up a high-technology frenzy to rival the Nasdaq at its frothiest.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the Showcasing American Composers project of the New York City Opera misstated the telephone number for reservations. It is (212) 870-7703.

title: Leaders of NATO Reject Proposal by General Clark to Fire on Ships That Defy Oil Embargo
description: NATO's political leaders have overruled a draft proposal by the alliance's senior commander to fire on ships that defy an oil blockade against Yugoslavia, raising questions about how effectively such an action can be enforced, officials said today.

title: The End of the Suburban Dream?
description: To the Editor:

title: As Cubans Take Home a Victory, One Coach Is Said to Seek Asylum
description: The game ended around midnight on Monday, and for the next few hours, the Cuban national baseball team and its band of noisy supporters continued celebrating a 12-6 victory over the Orioles in the downtown Baltimore hotel where the team and its 300-member delegation were staying.

title: What China Didn't Need to Steal
description: Americans are right to be outraged that a suspected Chinese spy may have stolen the computer codes for the entire United States nuclear arsenal. But the loss of this data is only half the story. The other half is about hardware.

title: DEAL WORTH $483 MILLION TO JOIN TORONTO REALTY TRUSTS
description: Riocan Real Estate Investment Trust said yesterday that it would take over Realfund Trust in a $483.8 million deal involving 1.45 of its units for each Realfund unit. Both companies are real estate investment trusts based in Toronto. Riocan had been offering 1.35 units -- which are convertible to stock -- for each Realfund unit. Realfund's trustees, who rejected the previous offer, have agreed to recommend the new offer to their unit holders. Realfund owns and manages properties including shopping centers and industrial buildings and office buildings. Riocan has 84 retail properties across Canada.

title: Monica Monica Tests Term Limits' Limits
description: The special election held on Saturday in Louisiana's First Congressional District was not just a test to see which of seven Republicans and two Democrats could make the May 29 runoff. Beyond all the focus on whether David Duke, the former Ku Klux Klan leader, would make the cut (he did not), political professionals were also watching to see what impact the term-limits issue might have on the outcome.

title: Excerpts From First Day of Brutality Trial
description: Following are excerpts from the opening statements in the trial of the police officers accused of torturing Abner Louima. The prosecutor, Kenneth P. Thompson, summarizes the Government's case:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LEE, ABRAHAMS NITA
description: LEE-Abrahams Nita. May 5, 1949December 8, 1989. Darling Nita, with us always the joy of your life and the agony of our loss. Your loving family

title: A New Hint of Missed Signals in Littleton
description: In the latest indication that law-enforcement officials missed early warning signs about the Columbine High School gunmen, the same sheriff's deputy who investigated their van break-in last year also took the telephone complaint not long afterward that they were setting off pipe bombs, a check of records shows.

title: ATEC TO MERGE WITH WAREFORCE.COM IN $38.3 MILLION DEAL
description: The Atec Group Inc., a computer maker, agreed yesterday to merge with Wareforce.com Inc. in a stock swap valued about $38.3 million. Atec, based in Hauppauge, N.Y., will issue three-quarters of a share for each share of Wareforce.com, which is based in El Segundo, Calif. Wareforce.com holders will own 54 percent of the combined company, and Atec holders will own 46 percent. Atec's shares fell $1.50 each yesterday, to $6.8125, in Nasdaq trading. Shares of Wareforce.com fell 68.75 cents, to $4.75, on the OTC Bulletin Board, a small-capitalization market. Wareforce.com provides hardware, software and networking services. Atec makes computers and software and sells computer graphics.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: SONOCO PRODUCTS CO., Hartsville, S.C., a maker of industrial and consumer packing products, agreed to acquire the composite can assets of Crown Cork and Seal Co., Philadelphia, the packaging producer, for an undisclosed amount of cash.

title: Mr. Pataki's Pallid Drug Reforms
description: Gov. George Pataki's proposed changes to New York State's rigid drug laws are utterly inadequate. Instead of overhauling the drug statutes that have filled state prisons with nonviolent drug offenders at a cost of hundreds of millions a year, he has proposed some tinkering that would allow very modest relief to a small number of felons who have received sentences that are out of proportion to their crimes.

title: Eisner Testifies in Katzenberg's Lawsuit Against Disney
description: The chairman of the Walt Disney Company, Michael D. Eisner, testifying today for the first time in the lawsuit by his former studio chief, Jeffrey Katzenberg, disputed Mr. Katzenberg's contention that Disney owes him hundreds of millions of dollars.

title: Tibor Kalman, 'Bad Boy' of Graphic Design, 49, Dies
description: Tibor Kalman, a graphic designer whose innovative ideas about art and society helped change the way a generation of designers and their clients viewed the world, died on Sunday at the Hyatt Dorado Hotel near San Juan, P.R. He was 49 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Sports of The Times; Brodeur Just Never Got Hot
description: IN the decisive seventh game of a Stanley Cup playoff series, it always boils down to the goaltenders. It always has. It always will.

title: Notebook; Revised Test Helps Girls
description: The number of girls winning National Merit Scholarships is up slightly for the class of 1999, the first to take a version of the Preliminary S.A.T. that had been revised to make it friendlier to girls, according to a new analysis.

title: DANCE IN REVIEW
description: In Hitchcockian Mode, With Anxiety and Secrets

title: Kosovo's Ravaged Capital Staggers Back to Half Life
description: Serbs and a few Albanians are trickling back to Pristina, Kosovo's capital. The sunny daytime streets, with a few pedestrians and shoppers, now display a poor imitation of ordinary life, so long as one doesn't focus too hard on the empty, looted Albanian districts, the bomb damage and the nearly total lack of children.

title: Weakening Treasury Issues Cause Drop in Most Indexes
description: Further deterioration in the bond market gave equity traders an excuse to sell stocks yesterday, and major market averages fell sharply.

title: Leaving Public TV
description: The Public Broadcasting Service has lost its chief programming executive, Kathy Quattrone, to a new venture of Discovery Communications, a multimedia company called Discovery Health Media Inc.

title: Speaker Hastert, AWOL
description: After Newt Gingrich, Republicans no doubt wanted a Speaker who was not a revolutionary. But the question is whether House Speaker Dennis Hastert is prepared to lead at all. Lately he has yielded his authority to Tom DeLay, the highly partisan Republican whip, who undercut Mr. Hastert last week by working to defeat a resolution backing military action in Kosovo. Today the Speaker has a chance to assert himself. Moderate Republicans are to meet with him to ask for an early vote on the campaign finance reform legislation sponsored by Representatives Christopher Shays of Connecticut and Martin Meehan of Massachusetts. Mr. Hastert should break with Mr. DeLay, who is trying to kill the bill, and listen. He needs to act like the Speaker he promised to be.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BASES, ISABELLE F.
description: BASES-Isabelle F. Beloved wife of the late Joseph G. Devoted mother of Robert and Samuel Matthew. Loving grandmother of David, Hugh, Daniel and great-grandmother of Rachel. Services were held May 4.

title: DANCE IN REVIEW
description: A Troupe's Resurgence With the Pulse of City Streets

title: Milk Cartel's Burden
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day on April 22 about the top cross-border deals in Europe misidentified the purchaser of Generale de Banque of Belgium and misstated the price. The buyer was Fortis A.G., a Belgian-Dutch company, not ABN-Amro Holding N.V. of the Netherlands. The price was $14.2 billion, not $12.2 billion.

title: Court Says Consumer Laws Apply to Medical Advertising
description: Doctors and other medical providers who advertise their services can be held liable under New York's consumer fraud and false advertising laws just like car dealers, clothing stores or any other kind of business, the state's highest court ruled yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WACHEN, RUTH A.
description: WACHEN-Ruth A. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Robert Wachen, loving mother of Dr. Harry and Liz Wachen, Helen and Walter Wertheimer, dear Omi of David and Kimberly Wachen, Mark and Hallie Wachen, dear sister of Greta Dobschiner. Interment private.

title: Tramping for Ramps, a Sure Sign of Spring
description: BILL BENSEN, the chef of the Palmer House Cafe here, was tramping through the woods two weeks ago, searching for signs of green ramp tips breaking the frosty ground cover, insisting that spring had arrived.

title: Pataki Proposes Tough Measure to Crack Down on Domestic Violence
description: Gov. George E. Pataki pressed ahead today with his effort to stiffen New York's laws against domestic violence, proposing lifetime orders of protection, tougher bail requirements for accused batterers and increased penalties for several offenses.

title: Australia Used Envoys To Aid Effort for Games
description: After months of disclosures, the litany of questionable conduct engaged in by cities around the world in their efforts to be awarded the Olympic Games has become familiar: lavish gift-giving, endless glad-handing, even direct cash payments.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DESJARDINS, KYMSON FORD (AKA MARK)
description: DesJARDINS-Kymson Ford (aka Mark). Age 47, died March 29, in Florida. Attorney, businessman and activist, Mr. DesJardins, formerly of Cos Cob, CT, moved to Ft. Lauderdale two years ago. Mr. DesJardins practiced law in Ft. Lauderdale, Manhattan, and Detroit. He was a principal of Ehrlich & Company, Branford, CT and served on the Board of Directors of Norwalk Rehabilitation Services. Mr. DesJardins will be remembered for a kind and generous nature, his high ideals and positive outlook, and his sharp intellect. He is survived by parents William E. and Barbara J., brother Kent M. (Victoria), two nieces, and grandmother Irene Snyder. A memorial service will be held on May 15, 1999, at 11:00 AM at the Orchard Lake Community Church, Orchard Lake, Michigan.

title: CALENDAR
description: Croatian Cuisine

title: Fort Dix, A Change of Mission
description: As relief workers in Macedonia took the final steps toward sending some 400 Kosovar Albanian refugees to the United States today, parishioners at the Church of the Good Shepherd in Willingboro, N.J., put together ''shoe box ministries'' -- boxes stuffed with shampoo, toothbrushes and other essentials that people uprooted from their homes would most likely miss.

title: Man Seeking To Play Hero Set Fatal Fire, Police Say
description: A 21-year-old Salvadoran immigrant told detectives that he had hoped to become a hero by setting a fire and then saving an old friend with whom he had been fighting, the police said. The man, Jose Umanzor, was charged with arson and murder today in the fire, which killed 3 people and injured 17 others early Saturday.

title: Yin and Yang Lite
description: OVER the last two years, there has been a growing genre of books on food as medicine. Some tell you the health-giving properties of familiar foods. Others encourage you to make curative tonics, otherwise known as soups.

title: Adviser Urges New Jersey High Court to Change Appeals of Death Sentences
description: A special judge appointed by the State Supreme Court to study New Jersey's death penalty has urged that the court consider ending the much-criticized two-step appeals process. But first, he said, the court must devise new safeguards to insure that the death penalty is applied equally, without regard to race and other factors.

title: Smiley Diners, Slick Plates
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSS, ALLEN
description: GROSS-Allen. 78. On May 4, 1999 of cancer. His passing is marked with great sorrow by Helene, his wife of forty-eight years, his children Daniel, Laurie, and Martin. His sister Carolyn, and his five grandchildren. He was a NYC teacher and school administrator and above all, a family man. He held graduate degrees from LIU and Columbia. Services Wednesday, 12 noon at Gutterman's Inc., 175 Long Beach Rd, Rockville Centre, LI.

title: Deep Secrets: Making the Perfect Fry; The potato of the moment is often a soggy disappointment. Time to take things into your own hands.
description: FEW foods cross as many boundaries as the french fry. It is trashy fast food in a paper pouch, it is the inseparable partner to hanger steaks in lively brasseries, it is the austere, perfect batonette, a work of fine chefs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHAMBLEE, EDWIN
description: CHAMBLEE-Edwin. Loving father of Chantal Rhodes. Dear brother of Roland and Alvin Chamblee. Devoted uncle.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOLDWEDEL, KIPP
description: SOLDWEDEL-Kipp, 86. On April 30th, at Lenox Hill Hospital. Recognized as one of the country's leading maritime artists. Yale graduate, Prix de Rome Scholarship. Beloved husband of Sally Backun Soldwedel, father of Peter. Trustee, National Art Museum of Sport; member, NY Yacht Club; member, Society of Illustrators; alumnus, St. George's School, Class of '33. Memorial services on Friday, May 14, 3 PM at St. Bartholomew's, Park Ave at 50th St, NYC. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to St. George's School, Newport, R.I. 02840.

title: Helicopter Crash Kills U.S. Pilot
description: An Apache helicopter crashed on a training mission in Albania, killing the pilot, United States military officials said. The pilot is believed to be the first American to be killed in the Kosovo crisis. The co-pilot is missing in the early morning crash.

title: HUNTSMAN BUYS POLYURETHANE BUSINESS FROM RHODIA S.A.
description: The Huntsman Corporation, the largest closely held chemical company in the United States, acquired the polyurethane materials business of the Paris-based Rhodia S.A. to strengthen its position in the global polyurethane market. Terms were not disclosed. Rhodia's plant in Mississauga, Ontario, will manufacture materials for polyurethane products and supply them to Huntsman, which is based in Salt Lake City, through the end of the year, after which production will shift to Huntsman's plant in Conroe, Tex.

title: The End of the Suburban Dream?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   L.A.P.
description: L.A.P. February 4, 1944-May 5, 1991. ''Whatever we were to each other that we are still.'

title: TRANSMONTAIGNE TO BUY A NETWORK FROM AMERADA HESS
description: Transmontaigne Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Hess Southeastern Pipeline Network of pipelines, storage tanks and terminal facilities from the Amerada Hess Corporation for $66.2 million. Transmontaigne said the network included 36 miles of proprietary pipelines and 5.3 million barrels of tank capacity. The Denver-based Transmontaigne stores, transports and distributes petroleum products. It had revenue of $1.2 billion in the six months that ended on Dec. 31. Amerada Hess, based in New York, is an oil and gas company and had revenue of $6.62 billion in 1998.

title: Vietnam Veteran Executed for 1980 Murder
description: Despite pleas for clemency from fellow Vietnam veterans, Manuel Pina Babbitt was executed early this morning at San Quentin prison for the 1980 murder of a 78-year-old woman.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEIBOWITZ, HENRY
description: LEIBOWITZ-Henry. We mourn the loss of our esteemed member and extend heartfelt condolences to his family. Temple Israel of Great Neck Sidney Freedman, President

title: No Palestinian State Today (Maybe It's Already Here)
description: If today had turned out to be the ''sacred date'' that Yasir Arafat had promised, the Artistic Studio Company here would have been cranking out Palestinian flags, stickers and T-shirts by the tens of thousands.

title: Commission President-Elect Issues Warning : Prodi Calls for Reforms As EU Post Seems Sure
description: BRUSSELS  The European Parliament was expected Wednesday to endorse Romano Prodi by a wide majority to become president of the European Commission after he demanded radical economic reforms and "tangible successes" in dealing with unemployment.

title: In School; In an Ivy League town, a charter school makes strides in academics, with a touch of chess.
description: Stephan Gerzadowicz, master chess player, likes to lace his lessons with maxims that sound like advice about life in general -- for instance, ''The easiest way you defend a pawn is with another pawn, and then you can get on with your life.''

title: OFF THE MENU
description: Brazilian and Italian

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEAVERS, KARL A.
description: DEAVERS-Karl A. Of Old Brookville and Manhattan. Suddenly on May 2. Beloved husband of Kerry. Loving father of Kary, Charlotte and Karl Jr. Dear brother of Okey, Robert and Barbara Wilson. Visiting Dodge Thomas Funeral Home, Glen Cove, New York, Tuesday 7-9 PM, Wednesday 3-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass St. Dominic's Church, Thursday 9:30 AM.

title: Anchovies From the Sea, Not From the Can
description: FRESH tuna? Of course. And fresh sardines? They, too, are showing up in markets and menus. Both fish no longer come just in cans.

title: Risking Death for Life
description: To the Editor:

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Business Travel
description: WITH the summer driving season approaching, the price of gasoline across the country has jumped sharply from historically low levels as major oil producing countries cut supplies of crude oil.

title: U.S. Quietly Intensifies Attacks on Iraq, Destroying Radar Sites
description: Even with Pentagon attention riveted on Yugoslavia, the United States has quietly stepped up what amounts to a low-level conflict with Iraq, with almost daily skirmishes that have resulted in destroying Iraqi radar sites and reports of the deaths of dozens of Iraqi civilians.

title: Black and Latino Legislators Oppose Verniero's Nomination to State Supreme Court
description: Members of the Legislature's Black and Latino Caucus formally announced today that they would oppose the confirmation of Attorney General Peter G. Verniero to the Supreme Court because his tepid response to complaints of discrimination by the state police proved that he lacked the judgment to sit on the state's highest court.

title: ESPN Sues Over Sunday Night Baseball
description: ESPN asked a Federal judge yesterday to halt Major League Baseball's termination of their contract after this season over the cable giant's plan to shift three Sunday night games in September from ESPN to ESPN2.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KALMAN, TIBOR
description: KALMAN-Tibor. The American Institute of Graphic Arts celebrates the extraordinary contributions Tibor Kalman made to design, always with wit and irony, even as designers nationwide mourn his loss. He nurtured some, goaded many and fascinated us all. Michael Bierut, President Richard Grefe, Executive Director On behalf of the Board and 14,000 graphic designers.

title: Liberties; Sugar Lips Rips N.R.A.
description: I was hiding from Lamar.

title: Account activity moves at a brisk pace, as a variety of advertisers make changes.
description: ACCOUNT activity along Madison Avenue continues at a frenetic pace as a variety of advertisers as disparate as casinos, vitamin companies and makers of kitchen fixtures hire agencies and make other changes.

title: Gore Pushes Mass Transit in the Heart of Automobile Country
description: Pursuing the suburban voters who may prove crucial in next year's Presidential election, as well as traditional Democratic constituents in cities, Vice President Al Gore called today in a speech here for reviving urban centers and reducing traffic congestion.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MCCALL, DAVID AND PENNY
description: McCALL-David and Penny. The family gratefully acknowledges the outpouring of love and remembrances. Memorial services will be held Friday, May 7th, at 11AM at the Abyssinian Baptist Church, 132 Odell Clark Place, New York City (formerly 132 W. 138 St, between Adam Clayton Powell Jr. Boulevard and Malcolm X Blvd., also known as 7th Avenue and Lenox Ave.). Donations in honor of David and Penny may be made to either Refugees International or 14 Angels, Inc., C/O Susan Pollack, Shepardson Stern + Kaminsky, 568 Broadway, 11th Floor, New York, New York 10012.

title: Democrat Elected to Fill Nassau Legislature Seat
description: Democratic voters turned out in heavy numbers here yesterday to elect Michael Zapson to fill a vacancy on the Nassau County Legislature left vacant when Bruce Nyman, leader of the Democratic minority, resigned to become Long Beach City Manager.

title: Calls to 911 Are Delayed For 2d Time in a Week
description: For the second time in seven days, callers trying to reach the 911 emergency response system yesterday encountered random delays of up to 30 seconds, the Police Department said. As in a slowdown reported on April 28, emergency calls were ultimately connected, and the system never shut off, as it did for an hour on Jan. 31, the police said.

title: POLITICAL BRIEFING
description: Monica Monica Tests Term Limits' Limits

title: Fairness in Profiling; Evidence as a Guide
description: To the Editor:

title: Report Raises Concerns About Bias in Crash Inquiries
description: The Government's system for organizing crash investigations is too dependent on work from groups with direct interests in the results, including manufacturers, operators and regulators, a draft report by the Rand Corporation says.

title: Who Pays for Art?
description: To the Editor:

title: KOSOVO UPDATE
description: COMBAT

title: Where 11 Died, Those Alive Find Litter-Filled Wasteland
description: There was never a whole lot to Bridge Creek. The church. The school. The Pinetree grocery. Ollison's convenience store. And perhaps 8,000 residents, a mixed community of farmers who have lived here for decades and Oklahoma City commuters who have flocked here more recently in search of space and solitude.

title: New Life for an Old Favorite; The Spaldeen, Stickball's Bouncy Foundation, Makes a Comeback
description: Although his head is covered with gray hair and his stride has become a little stiff, there is a youthful glow that comes over Tommy Davis's face when he remembers his prowess as a batter in the major leagues -- a baseball career that lasted 18 years and included play for 10 different teams, including the world champion Los Angeles Dodgers in 1963.

title: Milwaukee High School Team Wins Annual Test of Economic Wits
description: Seated around a vast conference table in the intimidating, vaultlike chambers of the Federal Reserve's Board of Governors, tomorrow's would-be Alan Greenspans gathered this week in a battle of economic wits.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARCIA, MARIA
description: GARCIA-Maria. Age 90. On May 1, 1999. She and her husband owned and operated El Charro Restaurant in Greenwich Village, N.Y. from 1948 until their retirement in 1967. She is survived by her husband, Menendo, son Tony, daughter Odulia Jacott, grandson Carlos Jacott, sister Loretta Trevino and brother Macario Garcia. Funeral private.

title: A Co-Finalist For Trade Post May Be Out
description: The diplomatic struggle over who should be the next head of the World Trade Organization continued unabated today while most work at the global trade forum seemed to grind to a halt.

title: Equalize City Pensions
description: To the Editor:

title: South Korea Quitting Rate-Cut Strategy
description: South Korea said yesterday that it was abandoning its 10-month drive to cut interest rates as the country's economic recovery gathers pace. The policy reversal follows a series of better-than-expected economic indicators from the first quarter that showed the economy on course to expand in 1999 after suffering its worst recession in about five decades last year.

title: Series a Straight Line In Tangled Tale for Jagr
description: Seven hours before the face-off, Jaromir Jagr kept answering the same questions the same way. What about the pressure of the seventh and deciding game against the Devils in the first round of the Stanley Cup playoffs?

title: Government and Red Cross Send Help to the Devastated Plains
description: President Clinton today declared parts of Oklahoma and Kansas disaster areas because of the damage caused by tornadoes on Monday, and the Federal Emergency Management Agency sent assistance that included communications equipment and a team of morticians and medical workers trained in identifying bodies.

title: Preserving Montenegro
description: Slobodan Milosevic is using the war in Kosovo to try to sabotage his most formidable political rival, Milo Djukanovic, the President of Montenegro. Mr. Djukanovic has brought economic reform and ethnic tolerance to his part of Yugoslavia, and calls the ethnic cleansing in Kosovo ''insane.'' The West should do everything possible to help him.

title: Intrepidly Navigating the Shoals of Schumann
description: It takes an inordinate amount of interpretive magic to make Schumann's F sharp minor Piano Sonata sound coherent. In fact, given the conceptual problems that plague Schumann's works in large forms, that goal may be unreachable. Krystian Zimerman, a pianist with a big technique and a lively imagination, braved the work's emotional torrents on Monday evening at Carnegie Hall. His solution was to play the sonata as a tense, quickly unfolding narrative, and if it did not entirely disguise the work's split seams, it made a plausible case for it.

title: U.S. Weighs Repatriating 2 P.O.W.'s To Yugoslavia
description: The United States is considering freeing two Yugoslav prisoners of war as a reciprocal gesture after the release of three American prisoners over the weekend, NATO and American officials said today.

title: On Road to Cup, Devils Take First Exit
description: The Devils won the Stanley Cup four years ago but are establishing an embarrassing legacy of thriving in the regular season and not surviving in the post-season.

title: U.S. Sees Gap Closing With Russia on Securing Kosovo Once Bombing Ends
description: Clinton Administration officials said today that they believe they have persuaded the Russian envoy to the Balkans that a military force, rather than just a monitoring mission, would be needed in Kosovo after the bombing campaign.

title: Democrats Bicker Over the Big Date
description: The last thing South Carolina Democrats need is a fight among themselves, given the political roll Republicans have been on in the state. But fighting they are.

title: Harry L. Kavetas, 61, Kodak's Finance Chief
description: Harry L. Kavetas, the chief financial officer who helped lead the Eastman Kodak Company through a huge financial upheaval that involved sweeping job cuts over the last few years, died yesterday at his home in Rochester. He was 61.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIEBMANN, PAULA
description: LIEBMANN-Paula. On May 4, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Lothar. Loving mother of Eleanor Temares. Adoring grandmother of Scott and Allison Temares and Stacy and Andrew Gellert. Great grandmother of Samantha Gellert. Funeral services Thursday, 10AM, Schwartz Bros-Jeffer Memorial Chapels, Queens Boulevard at 76th Road, Forest Hills.

title: The End of the Suburban Dream?
description: To the Editor:

title: Jesse Jackson Visits a War, This Time Over City Schools
description: Just days after engineering the release of three captured American soldiers in Belgrade, the Rev. Jesse L. Jackson turned his attention yesterday to one of the most contentious issues in New York City politics: the real and rhetorical battle over the city school system.

title: With Spiritual Aspirations And That Beat, Beat, Beat
description: The word ''Believe'' lingered on a screen behind GusGus onstage at Irving Plaza on Monday night. Strobe lights flashed, colored shapes drifted and fissioned and an earthshaking beat pounded behind a repeating, pulsating, two-note bass line. ''I'm not Jesus but I'm close to him,'' sang Daniel Agust, repeating it until his voice rose to a high, wordless ''ooh.''

title: OFFER IS WITHDRAWN FOR A FRANCHISER OF SPORTS STORES
description: Grow Biz International Inc., which develops franchises for retailing used merchandise through Play It Again Sports stores, said yesterday that its two top officers had withdrawn an offer to buy the shares of the company they did not already own. The chairman, K. Jeffrey Dahlberg, and the president and chief executive, Ronald Olson, who then held about 67 percent of the company's shares outstanding, made the offer of $14 a share in December, valuing the Minneapolis-based company at $71 million. Shares of Grow Biz fell 87.5 cents, to $9.75, yesterday in Nasdaq trading. Grow Biz had 1,231 stores in operation as of March 27.

title: New Hope in Prostate Cancer Therapy
description: Researchers say they have developed a simple method for estimating the risk that prostate cancer will recur and turn deadly in men who have already had their cancerous prostates removed.

title: G.O.P. Plays Politics On Balkan Crisis
description: To the Editor:

title: Senate Looks for Clues on Youth Violence
description: Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, openly rued the estrangement of too many parents from their children's lives. Senator Richard H. Bryan, Democrat of Nevada, decried the dearth of adequate counseling in schools.

title: Gore and Chernomyrdin, Familiar Partners in Talks, Seek Balkan Solution
description: Viktor S. Chernomyrdin, the stolid former Russian Prime Minister, and Al Gore, the stolid American Vice President, are engaged in an intensive search for a diplomatic exit to the bloodshed in the Balkans, an effort that brings some risk to both men, but potentially large benefits.

title: Airbus to Resume Talks on Status
description: The European consortium Airbus Industrie will resume talks in the fall on becoming a single corporate entity and has set a loose time frame of the second half of 2000 for the privatization, the consortium's managing director said today.

title: UConn's Hamilton to Enter N.B.A. Draft
description: Last year, Richard Hamilton flirted with entering the National Basketball Association draft but decided to return to school. It was a decision that helped make him an all-American and the Final Four's most valuable player and brought the University of Connecticut its first national title.

title: Singing The Phrases Of a Writer
description: ''I'm using a code name,'' said Beth Nielsen Chapman after she asked a mysterious person to join her onstage Monday night at the Bottom Line. She got no response, and grew more indiscreet. ''So Bonnie's really not here,'' Ms. Chapman said before beginning her ballad ''Sand and Water,'' whose recorded version features Bonnie Raitt on backup vocals.

title: International Monitoring of Serbia's Enriched Uranium to Resume
description: International nuclear inspectors have decided to return to Yugoslavia to inspect the nuclear reactor at Vinca and to insure that all its highly enriched uranium is still in place, inspectors said today.

title: Mapquest Soars in Debut
description: The stock of Mapquest.com Inc., which provides maps and travel directions over the Internet, closed 49 percent above the offering price today, its first day of trading. Mapquest.com, based in Mountville, sold 4.6 million shares at $15 each on Monday, raising $69 million. The shares sold amounted to a 14 percent stake and gave the company a market value of $482.5 million. The stock closed at $22.375, as 9.9 million shares were traded, some more than once.

title: Sports of The Times; Garden Misses Out on a Gem
description: LIFE is more often competitive than it is convenient. So while Natalie Williams is going home to Utah, Chamique Holdsclaw is bound for what was the worst team in the surviving women's pro basketball league.

title: THEATER IN REVIEW
description: The Pangs of Exile To a Mambo Beat

title: High-Priced Orioles Humiliated by Cubans
description: At some early-morning hour yesterday, Brady Anderson was putting toothpaste on his clubhouse toothbrush and said, ''It didn't look that good, did it?'' No, he was told. ''I thought that, too,'' he said.

title: DANCE IN REVIEW
description: Bonds That Survive An Age of Impermanence

title: THEATER IN REVIEW
description: Just See Who the Boys In the Back Room Will Hate

title: Morocco's King Meets Israeli Group and Makes a Plea for Peace
description: After three years of shunning the Israeli Government of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, King Hassan II of Morocco has returned to the role of potential Middle East intermediary by receiving a delegation of 50 Israeli legislators, religious leaders and businessmen at the royal palace in Marrakesh.

title: Ammirati Unit Appoints Executives
description: APL Digital in New York, the interactive division of Ammirati Puris Lintas, has named three top executives as part of plans to restaff after the departure last month of several senior managers.

title: Biographical Sound Bites? Well, These Have Teeth
description: Who was it who wrote a long letter, apologizing that he didn't have time for a short one? I don't remember, and I can't look it up. Too much to do; no time to do it. It is therefore something of a relief to pick up the first four volumes in a new series of books, biographies of 150 pages or so, well written by people who know.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Levitt of S.E.C. Criticizes Ads for On-Line Investing

title: Beyond Mozart, Works With a Stormy Oomph
description: The Portuguese pianist Maria Joao Pires made her reputation in the United States with a series of Mozart recordings that suggested that elegance and gracefulness were the salient features of her performance style. In concert and on disk lately she has shown that she has a more assertive side as well. Those qualities danced around one another appealingly in Ms. Pires's recital at Town Hall on Sunday afternoon as part of the inexpensive People's Symphony Concerts series.

title: Oklahoma and Kansas Dig Out From Tornado Ruins
description: Under incongruously clear skies, tens of thousands of residents across two states began grappling today with the aftermath of a series of monster tornadoes that killed at least 43 people, injured more than 500, destroyed more than 1,500 buildings and left behind mile after mile of twisted metal, denuded trees, crumpled cars and imploded buildings.

title: AT&T Is Seen Forging Link To Microsoft
description: The AT&T Corporation is close to forming a wide-ranging partnership with the Microsoft Corporation as part of an intricate web of deals that also would make AT&T the winner in the battle against the Comcast Corporation for Mediaone Group Inc., the big cable television company, executives close to the negotiations said last night.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Auditions for Hungry Muses at the House of Truth
description: HUMAN VOICES

title: Investor Shift Is Suggested As Prices Drop For Treasuries
description: Bond prices dropped sharply yesterday, pushing long-term interest rates to their highest level in nine months.

title: 8 European Stock Exchanges Form Alliance
description: Edging closer to the vision of a unified European stock market, eight stock exchanges agreed today to develop a common trading system for stocks in Europe's biggest companies.

title: G.O.P. Plays Politics On Balkan Crisis
description: To the Editor:

title: Truth in Packaging
description: The Fox network issued a rather sheepish statement on Monday promising that any staged re-enactments used in the popular ''reality specials,'' like ''World's Wildest Police Videos'' or ''When Animals Attack,'' would be clearly labeled as such in the future.

title: Supplies-Side Economics; When Disaster Strikes, Someone Must Provide the Tents
description: The fax in Joe Addis's makeshift office near Skopje, Macedonia, has been whirring since the Catholic Relief Services official set up shop near a refugee camp last month. Businesses and brokers have besieged him with sales pitches for tents, toothpaste, food, vegetable oil, laundry soap, sanitary napkins and medical supplies.

title: The Ham Is in the Bread, Not Between It
description: TO me, spring is a perfect time to cook a ham, whether for a big family dinner or for a more casual meal that results in lots of leftovers. With a ham, leftovers are half the fun.

title: Restaurants' Message: No Cell Phones
description: WALTER WEISS remembers the good old days, which in restaurants now means B.C. -- Before Cell phones.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; A Once-Sweet Bottling Plan Turns Sour for Coke
description: M. Douglas Ivester, the mastermind of Coca-Cola's worldwide bottling network, stood by like a proud uncle through most of the 1990's as the company racked up impressive gains in sales and profits.

title: FOOD STUFF
description: All About Chilies, Achocolatado to Xcatic

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALAIMO, ANITA E.
description: ALAIMO-Anita E. On May 4, 1999. Loving sister of Serafina Messina, Catherine Alaimo and the late Betty Jones, and Nicholas Alaimo. Dear sister-in-law of Matthew Messina. Beloved aunt of Michael and Francesca Messina and Elissa Jones. Visitation Redden Funeral Home, 325 West 14 Street, New York City, Thursday 7-9PM. Mass of Christian Burial on Friday 10AM, St. Bernard's R.C. Church. Interment Greenwood Cemetery.

title: THEATER IN REVIEW
description: A Long-Gone Ragtime Humorist Comes Back to Life in a Revue

title: High Water For Ratings
description: NBC's version of the biblical account of Noah's ark was the biggest mini-series of the season on television in terms of ratings and reaction.

title: On Avenue B, a French Bistro With Air Kisses
description: THE food at Casimir, a French bistro that is the latest restaurant to pop up on a once forbidding stretch of Avenue B in the East Village, is uncomplicated, easy to enjoy, occasionally inspiring and several dollars cheaper than at comparable spots. All very appealing, unless you mind inattentive service, a long wait for food, a crowd shoehorned into cramped quarters and lots of cigarette smoke.

title: 38% Asthma Rate Found in Homeless Children
description: A study has found that at least 38 percent of homeless children in the city's shelters have asthma, more than six times the national rate for all children and more than double the rate found by an earlier study of some of the city's poorest neighborhoods.

title: Don't Bash Programmers
description: To the Editor:

title: Confident in Their Bombs, Allies Still Plan for Winter
description: With no consensus on ground troops for Kosovo and no sign that President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia is wavering, allied leaders are beginning to face the prospect of housing half a million refugees through the bitter Balkan winter.

title: Commercial Real Estate; Disney Presses Ahead With Times Sq. Restaurant
