description: This would not seem to be the best time to get into the theme restaurant business.

title: DANCE IN REVIEW
description: War Stories: Movements of a Nightmare

title: A Dinner Party Among Intimate Strangers
description: CONTEMPLATING a navel not my own is hardly what I expected to be doing at an Upper East Side restaurant. But there I was on a recent spring evening, transfixed by the navel just above the elastic band of a lace-trimmed brown half-slip masquerading as a skirt. I should have been looking up at the wearer as she spoke to me, but her navel was at eye level.

title: Charges Dismissed in 2 Cases Involving Troopers Who Are Accused of Lying
description: In a continuation of the legal fallout from the state police racial-profiling scandal, judges have dismissed drug charges against two men who were arrested by troopers who are accused of lying about the race of drivers they had stopped and searched.

title: Record Label To Distribute Music on Line
description: Impatient with the recording industry's slow progress in finding a way to distribute music on line, Universal Music, the largest record company, said today that it was investing in technology to sell and distribute music over the Internet by the end of the year.

title: JANNOCK TO SELL ITS VINYL SIDING UNIT TO INVESTORS GROUP
description: Jannock Ltd. agreed yesterday to sell its vinyl siding unit to an investor group including Citicorp Venture Capital Ltd. for $157.5 million in cash and stock. Jannock said the vinyl group had 1998 sales equal to almost $250 million. Jannock, which is based in Toronto, said it had decided that it would achieve faster growth by focusing on making metal building products. The company decided in April to sell its brick-making group.

title: State Tax Agency Blames Computer for Bungled Notices on Tax-Relief Refund
description: Because of a computer glitch, the state tax agency erroneously notified 27,000 New York City taxpayers age 65 and older that they owed up to $125 more in state income taxes or that their refund checks were being reduced.

title: Lawyer Faces Runoff for Las Vegas Mayor
description: Oscar B. Goodman, a criminal defense lawyer for mob figures, won 49 percent of the vote in the Las Vegas mayoral race today, just short of the majority needed to win it hands down.

title: Poverty in Good Times
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOODWARD, WILLIAM III
description: WOODWARD-William III. On May 2, 1999. Beloved husband of Lisa and adoring father of Elizabeth, a kind and caring friend of many. Private services at St. Thomas Episcopal Church, 5th Avenue at 53rd Street, Thursday. Interment private. Memorial service to be announced at a future date. Contributions in his memory may be made to the William Woodward Jr. Nursery School, 436 East 69 Street, NYC 10021 or the Central Park Conservancy, 14 East 60 Street, New York City 10022.

title: Anger at 'Racial Profiling,' but Doubt on Who Is to Blame
description: Ask a few dozen New Jersey residents what they think of state troopers and racial profiling and they offer a host of decisive conclusions: it is ''segregation,'' ''Jim Crow'' and ''not something I'm proud of as an American.''

title: East Timor's Bloodiest Tradition
description: April 6, 1999. Another massacre. April 17. Another. Two more to add to an already lengthy list in East Timor. Since Indonesia invaded my homeland in 1975 and officially annexed it the following year, our history has seemed little more than a succession of massacres, one following the other in a depressingly predictable pattern.

title: Researchers Join in Effort On Cloning Repair Tissue
description: The Geron Corporation, developer of human embryonic stem cells and the cell-rejuvenating enzyme telomerase, said yesterday that it was forming a $20 million research alliance with the Roslin Institute of Scotland, cloner of Dolly the sheep.

title: After Phylloxera, The First Taste Of a Better Grape
description: IN 1992, the scene across the Napa Valley was desolate. In what had been some of the most beautiful vineyards in the world, piles of dead vines pulled from the soil were being burned. The pall of black smoke mirrored the mood of winemakers, who watched grimly as their lifeworks went up in flames.

title: Yanks, Playing Bad Baseball, Lose a Stinker
description: Something is missing. Maybe it's Joe Torre, or perhaps depth on their bench, or the laughter of Tim Raines, who reminded them they should always have fun. Maybe it's simply unfair to measure the 1999 Yankees against the incredible standards of concentration and execution they established in 1998.

title: Dancing Holds Its Own With Decor
description: Like his 1991 ''Sleeping Beauty,'' Peter Martins's grand new production of a four-act ''Swan Lake'' for the New York City Ballet is influenced by an unusually strong design element. But as debuts in many supporting roles showed over the weekend at the New York State Theater, dancing is always brought into relief by the decor, not dominated by it.

title: Banking-Law Debate Is Revived in Senate
description: The Senate began debate today on a broad measure to rewrite the nation's banking laws despite deep partisan disagreements over both regulatory authority and existing requirements that banks lend to minorities and others with little access to credit.

title: As Dancing Booms on Broadway; In a Changed World, More Jobs, More Competition, Same Old Drive
description: Aside from her spiky frosted hair, it was hard to pick out Amy Brewer in the two dozen or so black-clad dancers at the Broadway Dance Center strutting, twirling and kicking, doing the same routine 8, 10, 12, 14 times to the 30-second finale of Natalie Cole's ''Orange-Colored Sky.''

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: City Hall Proposes Forcing Unions to Reveal Finances
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani plans to introduce legislation that would require the city's municipal unions to disclose potentially embarrassing financial information, like the salaries of their leaders and other details of how the unions spend their money, a senior City Hall official said yesterday.

title: Graphic Details As Trial Opens In Louima Case
description: The trial of four officers accused of brutalizing a Haitian immigrant in Brooklyn opened yesterday with prosecutors and defense lawyers offering graphic details of their versions of events in a case that has inflamed racial tension in the city.

title: Hanok Journal; Bean Paste vs. Miniskirts: Generation Gap Grows
description: A blast of steam caught Park Ki Soon in the face as she peered into the caldron of beans and began stirring, feeling ever more sorry for herself.

title: Big Rumble
description: Tornadoes like the ones that devastated parts of Oklahoma and Kansas Monday afternoon, killing more than 40 people and obliterating whole neighborhoods, begin and end in strangeness. Before they form, the horizon seems to approach, to acquire a preternatural clarity against the deep black front of the storm. Houses and trees seem almost to leap into the foreground. And when the tornado has finally passed, it leaves behind a track that insists upon its unpredictability, forcing us to consider the knife edge that divides what was totally destroyed from what was barely touched.

title: Johnson an Unselfish and Unbending Knick
description: The luxury sedan was idling in the parking lot with the radio on when Larry Johnson slipped into the passenger seat and heard voices spilling out of the speakers. He cringed. He loathed talk radio and had little tolerance for anything a decibel above silence. He needed quiet and craved peace to sort out the issues crashing around his mind.

title: FOOD CHAIN
description: Identifying Fresh Garlic

title: 2000 Race Beckoned; Not Him, It Turns Out
description: This much is clear: Gov. Tommy Thompson would like to be President, or Vice President. The loquacious, oft-coy three-term Wisconsin Republican, generally regarded as one of the nation's more innovative and successful governors, has said time and time and time again that he would love nothing better.

title: Accounts
description: * Sharp International Corp., Rockville Centre, N.Y., to Milton Samuels Advertising,, New York, for its licensed watch brands like Jones New York and Etienne Aigner, which had been handled in-house and by various agencies for certain projects. Billings were estimated at $3 million.

title: Baxter Renews Shared Investment Plan
description: Baxter International, the No. 2 medical-products maker, said today that 142 of its executives had bought about $200 million in company stock after taking out loans.

title: William Woodward 3d, 54, Ex-Reporter and Candidate
description: William Woodward 3d, whose society family was known as much for its violent deaths as for its wealth, died Sunday on the Upper East Side of Manhattan after a 14-story plunge from his apartment. He was 54.

title: The End of the Suburban Dream?
description: To the Editor:

title: Avery Fisher Prize Goes To Women for the First Time
description: Three American violinists, Sarah Chang, Pamela Frank and Nadja Salerno-Sonnenberg, have been named winners of the 1999 Avery Fisher Prize. This is the first time in the 25-year history of the prestigious award, founded by Avery Fisher to support outstanding performing musicians, that the prize has gone to women.

title: CBS Steps Up Fight With New Morning Show
description: CBS's decision to bring Bryant Gumbel back to morning television, announced officially yesterday, raises the ante in the competition among network morning programs, an area gaining more attention from network executives because it offers far more potential for increased profits than prime time or any other hours of the day.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OESTREICHER, ANTHONY J.
description: OESTREICHER-Anthony J., 59, suddenly of cardiac arrest on May 3. A resident of Bernardsville, NJ, Tony graduated Dartmouth College in 1961. He was Creative Director for ad agencies in Chicago and New York and enjoyed writing for AT&T Solutions. Tony was active in his church and community theater groups and his volunteer work for the homeless. He is survived by his wife Georgette, his children Lisa, Cara and Jack, his brother David and his six grandchildren. Services Friday, 10:30am at Olph Church in Bernardsville.

title: April Auto Sales Impressive Despite Lower G.M. Results
description: Car and truck buyers were out in force in April, and as a result the auto industry turned in strong sales results just as it heads into the crucial summer selling season. Sales rose 3.9 percent over all in April, and the industry sold cars, sport utility vehicles, pickup trucks and minivans at a brisk seasonally adjusted annual rate of 16.3 million.

title: Critics Name 'Wit' as Best New Play
description: Adding to its list of honors, ''Wit'' was named best new play of the 1998-99 theater season yesterday by the New York Drama Critics' Circle. ''Closer,'' Patrick Marber's frank drama of sexual intrigue, was voted best new foreign play and ''Parade,'' a musical based on the turn-of-the-century lynching of an Atlanta Jew, received the award for best new musical.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ACCETTA, ANGELO
description: ACCETTA-Angelo. Dad, today marks twenty-five years that you are gone. We will always have you in our hearts and minds. Your spirit surrounds us and gives us strength. We miss you and love you. Your Family

title: India Schedules Ballot for Fall, Despite a Protest
description: In the contest to see who will be India's next Prime Minister, Sonia Gandhi, the widowed inheritor of India's founding political dynasty, will be matched against the veteran Hindu nationalist leader Atal Behari Vajpayee. Today the general elections were scheduled for September and the first week of October.

title: A Body on Mt. Everest, a Mystery Half-Solved
description: In the early hours of June 8, 1924, a 38-year-old British schoolteacher named George Mallory set forth with Andrew Irvine, a 28-year-old Cambridge student, from their canvas tent pitched 26,800 feet high on the northern slope of Mount Everest.

title: Facing Down His Color As a Path To Privilege
description: James Baldwin said that there was no hope for anyone who considered himself white. By that measure, Maurice Berger figures he has a chance at salvation.

title: The End of the Suburban Dream?
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Off the Menu column of the Dining section last Wednesday about Andrea Immer, the former beverage director of Windows on the World, misstated her professional credentials. She is a master sommelier, with a diploma from the Court of Master Sommeliers. (She does not hold the master of wine certification, conferred by the Institute of Masters of Wine.)

title: Shares of Goldman Rise 33% on First Day
description: Shares of Goldman Sachs Group Inc. soared on their first day of trading, making Wall Street's longest holdout its latest darling.

title: Annan Plans Relief Mission for Yugoslavia
description: Secretary General Kofi Annan announced today that he intended to send a mission to Yugoslavia to assess relief needs, but faced immediate skepticism from the United States and Russia.

title: A Rhapsodic Embrace of Language in a Cruel World
description: The door opens on an empty stage, a world clean out of love. Into this inhospitable domain, the symbolic habitat of a barren upbringing, marches Dael Orlandersmith, imposing in shape, and even more so in the shape of her suffering.

title: Astros' Starter Makes Leiter Pay
description: If he could have just one pitch back from the seventh inning last night, Al Leiter said, it would not be the two-run homer he surrendered to Derek Bell, or even the run-scoring double from Craig Biggio that broke a 1-1 tie. It was a seemingly harmless two-out pitch to the opposing pitcher.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, GREGG
description: MILLER-Gregg, 41. Of New York City, on April 30. Beloved daughter of Cindy Miller and of her late father, John Miller; loving sister of John J. Miller Jr. A memorial service will be held at Holy Cross Church, 329 West 42nd Street, Thursday, May 6, at 6 P.M. We ask that friends of the family send memorial donations to the Juvenile Diabetes Foundation in lieu of flowers.

title: Corrections
description: An article in House & Home on April 22 about the Willows, an estate in Palm Springs, Calif., built in 1927 and recently restored, misspelled the surname of its original owner. He was Samuel Untermyer, not Untermeyer.

title: Hoechst Is Pursuing Sale Of Industrial Gas Stake
description: Hoechst A.G., Germany's biggest drug maker, is in talks with several potential buyers about selling its 67 percent stake in Messer Griesheim G.m.b.H., a maker of industrial gas, Hoechst's chief executive, Jurgen Dormann, said yesterday at the company's annual meeting.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHONFELD, PHILIP
description: SCHONFELD-Philip. On Saturday, May 1, 1999. Of East Orange, N.J. Husband of the late Sara Wolfe Schonfeld. Father of Barbara Davies, Bethesda, MD., Norman J. Schonfeld, Morristown, N.J., and Reese W. Schonfeld, New York City. Grandfather of Alexander John Schonfeld, Ellen Bienstock, Orrin Schonfeld, Elizabeth Davies, William Schonfeld, J. Ida Schonfeld, Juliette Reverand, Eric Davies and Rebecca Schonfeld Foley. Also survived by eleven great grandchildren. Funeral services and interment private. Memorial contributions may be made to the United Jewish Appeal of Metro West, 901 Route 10, Whippany, N.Y. 07981. Inquiries DanzanskyGoldberg Memorial Chapels, Inc., 301-340-1400.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAUERHAFT, SIDNEY J.
description: SAUERHAFT-Sidney J. Of Chappaqua, NY, May 3, 1999. Husband of Helen (Sammet) Sauerhaft. Father of David, Daniel, Beth and Rebecca Sauerhaft. Brother of the late Max Sauerhaft. Grandfather of six. Funeral Service will be held at the Beecher Funeral Home, Pleasantville, NY, on Wednesday, 12:00 noon. Interment at Sharon Gardens Cemetery, Valhalla, NY. In lieu of flowers donations to the Autonomic Disorders Research Program, C/O Dr. Horacio Kaufmann, Mt. Sinai Hospital, Box 1052, New York, New York 10029 in his name would be appreciated.

title: THE CHEF
description: A FEW years ago, I ordered an unusual dessert in a small Mexican restaurant. Sweet-corn ice cream sounded intriguing, but it turned out to be a disappointment, riddled with distracting icy kernels. Still, I love corn and was taken with the idea of a perfectly smooth corn ice cream.

title: Rapidly Fatal Fever, Like Ebola, Kills 63 in Congo Mining Area
description: Sixty-three people in northeastern Congo have died of an unknown disease that has killed most its victims, nearly all of them gold miners, within six days.

title: Fairness in Profiling
description: To the Editor:

title: Head of Finance at Kodak Dies And an Acting Chief Is Named
description: The Eastman Kodak Company's chief financial officer, Harry L. Kavetas, died of an apparent heart attack yesterday, the company said.

title: Accounts Moving At Mad Dogs
description: Accounts are leaving and arriving at Mad Dogs and Englishmen in New York.

title: The Price of Relief
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Businessman Slain at Border In Carjacking
description: A Japanese businessman who, like thousands of executives, commuted from the United States each day to work at a factory on the Mexican side of the border, has been shot to death in Tijuana in an attempted carjacking, the police said.

title: Residential Sales
description: MANHATTAN

title: Plan for Filling Wetlands Opposed at Meeting
description: Environmentalists yesterday criticized a plan that would allow 465 acres of wetlands to be filled in for a proposed shopping mall and a truck depot.

title: Whitney Estate Sweetens Spring Art Sales
description: The round of important fine-art auctions that begins at Sotheby's in Manhattan on Monday evening might be described as a play in two acts. The first act could be called ''The Auctioneer's Dream'': the collection of extraordinary Post-Impressionist paintings from the estate of Betsey Cushing Roosevelt Whitney, the New York socialite and philanthropist who died in March. The Whitney collection, blockbuster material of pristine provenance, should make for a near-perfect auction on Monday.

title: Mets' Bullpen Takes On Vulnerable Look at Last
description: The routine had become routine for Bobby Valentine. When the game stretched into the late innings, he picked up the phone to the bullpen, summoned one of the Mets' superb relievers and watched them hold tight to another lead and secure another victory. Valentine's routine had become very routine and it was very successful.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OZER, MORTON
description: OZER-Morton. Beloved husband of Dorothy, loving father of Jay and Dennis and father-in-law of Debra, grandfather of Sadie, Adam and Jakob. Brother of Diane Newman, Selma Arnold and the late Ruth Ozer. Graveside services Friday, 1 PM, at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, New York.

title: Exhibitions, Classes And Walking Tours
description: Pomo Basketry

title: Banking Overhaul Set Back; Senate Defeats 2 Measures
description: Legislation to overhaul the nation's banking system was significantly set back today after the Senate defeated two measures endorsed by the Clinton Administration.

title: An Uncertain Step for Foreign Holders of Russian Bonds
description: When Russia defaulted on $40 billion in debt last August, most foreigners who had once been lured by the high interest rates on Russian Government bonds figured they would be lucky to get anything at all out of their investments.

title: Teaching Hospitals Battle Medicare-Money Cuts
description: Normally, the great teaching hospitals of this medical Mecca carry an air of white-coated, best-in-the-world arrogance, the kind of arrogance that comes of collecting Nobels, of snaring more Federal money for medical research than hospitals anywhere else, of attracting patients from the four corners of the earth.

title: Whitman Says She'll Stand By Her Nominee
description: A day after the state Bar Association declared Attorney General Peter G. Verniero unfit to fill a vacancy on the State Supreme Court, the Whitman administration pledged today to continue pushing for its increasingly embattled nominee to New Jersey's highest court.

title: Siding With Mayor, 4 on School Board Block a Crew Plan
description: The battle between Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew moved to a new front yesterday, as a four-member majority of the Board of Education backed by the Mayor rejected the Chancellor's five-year school construction proposal and agreed on its own version.

title: The Travels Of E-Mail
description: Q. Where does this E-mail message live from the time I hit the Send key to the time you read it?

title: Shooting Sheds Light on Problems Boys Face
description: To the Editor:

title: G.M. TO OFFER $500 MILLION OF CLASS H SHARES TO PUBLIC
description: The General Motors Corporation said yesterday that it planned a public offering of $500 million of its class H common shares, which track its Hughes Electronic Corporation unit. G.M., the nation's No. 1 auto maker, said proceeds would go to Hughes and that it would provide Hughes with an additional $500 million in equity. Hughes said it would use the $1 billion to improve its balance sheet and repay debt related to its recent acquisitions of Primestar Inc. and the U.S. Satellite Broadcasting Company. Hughes Electronics, based in El Segundo, Calif., is a leader in communications satellites and direct broadcast television. G.M.'s class H shares rose 56.25 cents, to $56.0625, and G.M. fell $2.0625, to $86.9375.

title: Slaves, Pashas And Pirates: Classical Escapism
description: For escapist entertainment and some of the best male dancing in ballet, there is nothing like American Ballet Theater's spectacular staging of ''Le Corsaire,'' a 19th-century adventure yarn about life on the bounding main.

title: Starr Witness Asserts Friend Sought Tabloid Cash for Story
description: Kathleen E. Willey testified today that she had repeatedly told her former friend Julie Hiatt Steele about an unwelcome sexual encounter with President Clinton at the White House in November 1993 and that Ms. Steele had offered to corroborate the story and help sell it to a tabloid.

title: The Politics of Hurricane Relief
description: The victims of Hurricane Mitch, which ravaged Central America six months ago, are still waiting for $600 million in promised humanitarian aid from the United States. Congress seems willing to make them wait forever. The money is stalled in a partisan fight that has nothing to do with the merits of helping Honduras, Nicaragua and other countries hit by the storm and other natural disasters.

title: Suspect in Fatal Fire Pleads Not Guilty
description: Suffering from burns to his hands and face, a 21-year-old man appeared to be in a daze as he pleaded not guilty yesterday to charges that he set a fire that killed 3 people and injured 17 others in Huntington Station.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAVETAS, HARRY L.
description: KAVETAS-Harry L. May 4, 1999 of Rochester and New Canaan, CT. He is survived by his wife, Sue; children, Betsy Kavetas & Lowell Paddock of Frankfurt, Germany, James and Caroline Kavetas of Westport, CT., and Kathy & Adam Rothschild of Chappaqua, NY; grandchildren, Ellen & William Rothschild and Jimmy Kavetas. A Memorial Service will be held on Friday, May 7 at 4PM in the First Presbyterian Church of New Canaan, 178 Oenoke Rd, New Canaan, CT. Contributions may be made in his memory to the Salvation Army of Greater NY, 120 W. 14th St, New York, NY 10011-7393 or Norwalk Community Technical College Foundation Inc., 188 Richards Avenue, Norwalk, CT. 06854.

title: Protesters Fight Auctioning Of Community Garden Sites
description: With performance art, musical medleys and a sit-in, hundreds of demonstrators closed down a one-block stretch of Chambers Street in lower Manhattan yesterday evening to protest the impending auction of more than 100 city properties now being used as community gardens.

title: Animal Rights Center Is Closed by Founder
description: The Rutgers University Animal Rights Center, which trained Rutgers Law School students through often pioneering litigation on behalf of pets and wildlife, has shut down, the law school said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIEGLER, JOHN G.
description: SIEGLER-John G. On May 3, 1999. Beloved brother of Thomas, Richard and Paul. Also survived by his 17 beloved nieces and nephews and 31 grand nieces and nephews. Reposing at the James RomanelliStephen Funeral Home, 89-01 Rockaway Boulevard, Ozone Park Friday, 2 to 5 and 7 to 10 PM. Mass of the Resurrection Saturday, at St. Helen's RC Church, at 9:30 AM. Interment St. John's Cemetery. In lieu of flowers send donations to Queen of Peace Residence, Queens Village, New York.

title: Defunct Brokerage Firm and Employees Indicted
description: The Manhattan District Attorney, Robert M. Morgenthau, announced yesterday the indictments of Duke & Company, a defunct New York brokerage firm; its chairman, Victor Wang, and 17 former Duke employees, charging that the firm was a criminal enterprise that conspired with other brokerage firms to manipulate the prices of six small stocks.

title: Playing the Blame Game
description: Ever since the tragedy in Littleton, Colo., the American preoccupation with finding a simple answer has been churning nonstop. In a nation that reduces everything to box scores (''Conventional Wisdom'' in Newsweek, etc.), the media and its pundit class have been obsessed with finding the immediate cause, like a zealous cop hellbent on making an early collar.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HANN, DOROTHY N.
description: HANN-Dorothy N. Of Bronxville, NY on May 3, 1999. Wife of the late Vincent R. Hann. Mother of Cynthia H. Roeser. Grandmother of Paige Roeser. Sister of John and Warren Niebling. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville between the hours of 7-9 PM Thursday, 2-4:30 PM Friday. Services at the Reformed Church of Bronxville on Friday, May 7 at 5 PM.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about troubled adolescents referred incorrectly to some research in the field. Information about which children are likely to ''break'' in stark ways comes from a growing number of ''psychological autopsy'' studies of youthful suicides and from less formal studies of adolescents who have committed murders, not ''less from studies of adolescents who have commited murders.''

title: Air War: Too Costly in Every Way
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBAUM, IRENE
description: GREENBAUM-Irene. At 88 years old. Beloved sister of Harold and loving sister and care giver of Evelyn Cohen. Loving aunt, great aunt and great great aunt. Services will be private. Donations to VNS New York Hospice Program, 1250 Broadway, 4th Floor, New York 10001.

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Stadium Financing? New Twist for N.F.L.
description: Imagine if George Steinbrenner volunteered to help pay for a new downtown Montreal Expos stadium. Better yet, think of the Expos agreeing to chip in for a $1 billion Yankee Stadium for the good of baseball.

title: First Union Is Sued Over 401(k) Switch
description: John T. H. Carpenter, a loan officer with Signet Bank in Virginia Beach, Va., put his 401(k) savings into three investments that turned in sizzling performances in recent years. So when he quit in November 1997, a week before the First Union Corporation took over Signet, he left those investments in place.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DEFLORIO, JEANN
description: DeFLORIO-Jeann. A service in her memory at Convent of the Sacred Heart, 1 East 91st St., NYC, on Tuesday, May 11th, at 6:30 PM. Donations can be made to the Creative Arts Scholarship Fund in her name.

title: J. John Sepkoski Jr., 50, Dies; Changed Field of Paleontology
description: Dr. J. John Sepkoski Jr., a professor and paleontologist at the University of Chicago who conducted important research illuminating large-scale patterns of evolution in the fossil record, died on Saturday at his home in Chicago. He was 50.

title: Preening On Metal's Rough Edge
description: Dave Wyndorf is one rock star who knows how to deploy a fan -- not the screaming human kind, but the type mechanically generating wind. At Irving Plaza on Tuesday night, one kept his black tresses flying skyward as he waved his muscular arms and led Monster Magnet through a metal-punk purist's fantasy.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary last Thursday about Max Hutchinson, an art dealer and gallery owner who was also a prominent athlete in Australia early in his career, misstated the year of the Melbourne Olympics, in which he played exhibition baseball. It was 1956, not 1948.

title: Paul J. Henry, 72; Headed Hospital Agency
description: Paul James Henry, a New York lawyer who served as chairman of the New York Health and Hospitals Corporation during the administration of Mayor Edward I. Koch, died Saturday at his home in Grasmere, N.Y. He was 72.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the Walt Disney Company's plan to open a restaurant, ESPN Zone, in Times Square later this year misstated the provision for food and drink service. Food will be served on the first two floors, and alcoholic drinks will be served on all floors, not just on the third.

title: A Fitness Coach With a Muscular Memory
description: The fit and not so fit were straining on weight machines and panting on treadmills the other night at the Ketchum Downtown Y.M.C.A. Grimacing with effort and dripping with sweat, they toned bodies that, in some cases, showed signs of a few dietary indiscretions.

title: News Corp. Has 47% Profit Drop
description: The News Corporation said today that its third-quarter profit fell 47 percent because of a drop in film revenue and losses at its Fox News cable network and Star satellite-TV business.

title: No Frank Capra Here, Or Jonathan Edwards
description: HOME TOWN

title: F.C.C. Chairman Urges More Spending for School Internet Program
description: The chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, William E. Kennard, said today that he would urge the commission to increase spending for a program that collects a fee on telephone bills and devotes the money to help schools and libraries in low-income areas connect to the Internet.

title: Open to Nature but Ready for Fire
description: SPLENDOR among the oaks, especially in the secretive canyons winding up into the mountains of Southern California, comes with the sobering caveat of fire -- walls of it, superheated and deadly. The house that embraces nature here must also defend itself from her tinderbox.

title: Supplies for Mexico's Needy Sit as Donor and Officials Argue
description: A yellow school bus loaded with wheelchairs, aspirin and pencils for rebel Indian villages in the southern state of Chiapas has been blocked for three weeks from crossing from Texas into Mexico, tangled in fierce suspicions between the Government and foreign aid donors who want to help anti-Government groups in the troubled state.

title: FMC TO SELL ITS PROCESS ADDITIVES UNIT TO GREAT LAKES
description: The FMC Corporation, the Chicago-based chemical and machinery manufacturer, said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its process additives business to the Great Lakes Chemical Corporation for $159 million in cash. The process additives business produces phosphate flame retardants, flame retardant fluids and lubricant additives, as well as specialty water treatment chemicals used in industrial applications and desalination. The business employs approximately 500 people. Great Lakes Chemical, based in West Lafayette, Ind., is a specialty chemical manufacturer. Shares of FMC rose $1.25, to $71, and Great Lakes stock was up 68.75 at $49.

title: Filtering the Web Won't Protect Kids; Foiling the Snoops
description: To the Editor:

title: Tony Barlow, 62, Lawyer and Philanthropist
description: Tony Barlow, a lawyer, banker and philanthropist who became active in religious efforts to encourage socially responsible investing, died on Tuesday at Beth Israel Medical Center-Petrie Division in lower Manhattan. He was 62 and lived on the Upper East Side of Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOULTON, RUTH, M.D.
description: MOULTON-Ruth, M.D. The William Alanson White Psychoanalytic Institute and Society note with profound grief the death of a woman whose abundant and eloquent life set the standard for generations of professionals. Resolute in her passion for her profession and for this Institute, Ruth Moulton Gilbert was among its most acclaimed architects. She was, and remains, heralded as a distinguished psychoanalyst, an astute, devoted therapist, an inspiring teacher, an uncompromising activist and a proud and tireless feminist. Her writings and achievements were numerous, as were her titles (Fellow Emeritus, Fellow Training and Supervising Analyst, Director of Training), her interests were expansive and cultivated, her directions were courageous and pioneering, her humanity was inexhaustible. As an agent for change, she accomplished goals with artful tenacity, utmost dignity and remarkable modesty. We shall miss her sorely, and oh how greatly will she be remembered. Our heartfelt condolences to her beloved family. Marylou Lionells, Ph.D., Director, White Institute Robert I. Watson, Jr., Ph.D., President, White Society

title: Ex-Officials Charged in Theft of $2.7 Million From Municipal Local
description: Prosecutors yesterday announced the indictments of six former officials of a large New York City union local, who are accused of stealing $2.7 million in union money, including $78,000 that was used for Super Bowl tickets and more than $10,000 for topless clubs.

title: Hints Seen That Milosevic Is Readying His People for a Deal to Resolve the Conflict
description: Analysts and local journalists say they detect small signs that President Slobodan Milosevic is preparing public opinion for an end to the war over Kosovo and for a deal with the West.

title: Internet Providers Impose Some Limits on 'Unlimited'
description: You might think that the meaning of the word ''unlimited'' is exceedingly clear, but if your Internet service provider is Prodigy, think again. The company, which advertises ''unlimited service'' for $19.95, recently informed more than 100 customers that their accounts would be terminated because of excessive usage, said Dan Levine, a Prodigy spokesman. Although there is no specific cap on the number of hours a customer can stay connected, Mr. Levine said, ''we identified during routine network maintenance a number of accounts where the excessively high levels of activity were symptomatic of improper activity.'' In March, Prodigy sent E-mail messages to nearly 300 excessive users to ''ask if they were forgetting to log off or if a user's password was stolen and used by someone else,'' Mr. Levine said.

title: Texas Official Says Favoritism Affected Fees in Tobacco Deal
description: The Texas Attorney General, in a court filing, has accused his predecessor of giving a fraudulent contract to a lawyer friend who was awarded $260 million in legal fees from the state's settlement with the tobacco companies.

title: Pettway Scratched From Title Fight
description: Vincent Pettway, whose No. 1 ranking with the International Boxing Federation sparked debate over that organization's ratings, has been scratched from a May 29 title bout against Felix Trinidad, the I.B.F. welterweight champion, because of a detached retina in his eye.

title: U.S. Suspends Sale of Handguns to Venezuela
description: The Clinton Administration has suspended sales of handguns to Venezuelan gun dealers, concerned that many of the guns are ending up in the hands of narcotics gangs and guerrilla groups in neighboring Colombia, American officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DOLGENOS, DAVID
description: DOLGENOS-David. January 9, 1931-May 6, 1997. Trying to walk in your footsteps. Please show us the way. Love always, Peter, Peggy, Carey, To

title: Discounts on 10th Avenue
description: Pay the tax, save the toll. As of this week, Manhattanites can enjoy outlet shopping without taking the bridge or tunnel to New Jersey -- that is, if they're looking for upscale bed and bath linens, lamps, rugs or upholstered furniture. Portico, known for high-end linens, has taken over the space at 233 10th Avenue (24th Street) once occupied by the Pottery Barn and Williams-Sonoma outlets and has stocked discontinued merchandise at 20 percent to 50 percent off. For information: (212) 807-8807. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: Touring the Museum With a Small PC To Serve as a Guide
description: THE WHITNEY MUSEUM'S recently opened exhibition ''American Century'' could be subtitled ''See the Last 100 Years of Art With the Technology of the Next.''

title: How Pagers Receive Messages, Even ('Hello' Upside Down)
description: IN the digital culture of the late 90's, being out of reach is the ultimate faux pas; people have come to expect instant access not only to information but also to one another.

title: Hasek, Jagr Still Around
description: Once again, form did not hold true in the opening round of the National Hockey League, not by a long shot, slap shot or wrist shot. When the semifinals begin tonight, many of the regular season's best teams will not be there - the Devils, the Ottawa Senators and the Phoenix Coyotes, all upset in the first round.

title: Elections Today in Scotland and Wales a Test for Blair
description: The Scots will be voting for their first Parliament since 1707. The Welsh will be electing their first ever. And Prime Minister Tony Blair will be looking for validation of his two-year-old Government's transformation of how the British run themselves.

title: Water-Damaged E.M.S. Hub in Queens to Be Evacuated
description: A building in Maspeth, Queens, that houses the communications center of New York City's Emergency Medical Service has been badly damaged by underground water leaks, and city officials plan to move dozens of dispatchers and related emergency equipment, including computers, into trailers that have been set up in the building's parking lot.

title: Air War: Too Costly in Every Way
description: To the Editor:

title: Exploring Neanderthal Lore on Line
description: NEANDERTHALS are not with us anymore -- or are they?

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: A New Chief Is Appointed For Barney's
description: Barney's Inc., the luxury retailer known for basic black everything, named a new chief executive yesterday whose most recent experience was running stores known more for affordable sweaters and blue jeans.

title: Graphic Vision: Art for People, Not Artists
description: THERE are a million stories in the naked city, but if they involve the night workers who clean the toilets and make the subways run on time, who cares?

title: Breaking the Isolation Barrier
description: LESS than a week after we moved to this new town being built by the Walt Disney Company, a neighbor dropped by to chat, and the topic turned to children. One of the great things about living here, he said, is that the kids will have so many adults watching over them.

title: GETTY IMAGES AGREES TO BUY ART.COM FOR $202 MILLION
description: Getty Images Inc., the world's largest provider of archived photographs, has agreed to buy the closely held Art.com, a top Internet seller of art, for as much as $202 million in stock and cash. Getty, which sells digital images mostly to businesses like advertisers, publishers and broadcasters, said Art.com's shareholders would get 4.51 million new Getty shares and as much as $84 million in stock and cash. Art.com, begun a year ago, has little revenue. Getty's sales last year were $185 million. Art.com, based in Chicago, is owned by its management and venture capital investors. Getty's shares rose $3.25, to $29.375. The stock was as low as $8.625 last October.

title: Speaker Pressed to Expedite Vote on Campaign Finance
description: Speaker J. Dennis Hastert met today with more than two dozen House Republicans who were pushing for an early vote on overhauling the nation's campaign finance laws, but he made no commitment to act earlier than the end of September.

title: 100 Arab Rights Activists Hold Furtive Conference in Morocco
description: When human rights activists from 15 Arab nations met here recently for the first conference of its kind in the Arab world, organizers were swiftly reminded of the suspicion with which many Arab governments view efforts to widen individual liberties.

title: The Songs Are Sad but the Beat Is Glad
description: ''This is a really jolly song,'' Graham (Suggs) McPherson of Madness announced at Irving Plaza on Friday night. ''It's called 'Grey Day.' '' Actually, ''Grey Day'' has glum lyrics from a character so lonely he wishes he could ''sink without a trace.'' But with a reggae backbeat and a bell-toned keyboard, the song was jaunty enough to keep the sold-out crowd dancing.

title: Appliances With Legs
description: IN the ''American Century'' exhibition that just opened at the Whitney Museum of American Art, the first five decades of the 20th century are represented by nearly 1,000 artworks, plus a few dozen carefully culled examples of the decorative arts and industrial design.

title: Another Theremin View
description: To the Editor:

title: Advertising Foundation Names New Chairman
description: The Advertising Educational Foundation in New York is naming a new chairman, David Bell, the chairman and chief executive of True North Communications.

title: Traveling a Country Road to Big-City Fame
description: On this spring day, at least, last period assembly at Russell High School was a special occasion with a distinctly local flavor. Julie Reeves, a 24-year-old country singer with a new recording contract, had returned from Nashville to her alma mater in the Appalachian hills to belt out a few tunes in the gym and give the seniors a pep talk.

title: INSIDE
description: House Passes Debt Bill

title: Dow Makes a U-Turn to Finish Solidly Ahead by 69.30
description: Stocks rebounded from early losses yesterday to finish solidly ahead, as investors showed renewed affection for the blue-chip growth stocks they had shunned lately.

title: Wasting Money, Curbside
description: To the Editor:

title: A Garcia Lorca Spinoff, Poetic, Angry and Macho
description: Eduardo Machado's new play, ''Crocodile Eyes,'' opens with six men sitting outside a large house discussing their gang-sex experience of the evening before. The women they are really interested in are inside the house, the focus of this poetically articulate, anger-charged one-act work. Audiences familiar with Federico Garcia Lorca's 1936 drama ''The House of Bernarda Alba'' know that behind the double doors on Mark Marcante's handsome minimalist set are a grieving widow with a powerful personality and her five frustrated daughters. The widow has forbidden her daughters to have contact with men until her mourning is over, and she's planning to wear black for a long time.

title: Doctor Sees Warfare Etched in Flesh
description: Dr. Rade Grbic, an orthopedic surgeon who directs Kosovo's largest hospital, has become a reluctant expert in bomb blasts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERTRAND, MAURICE A.
description: BERTRAND-Maurice A. Age 75, of Palm Beach Gardens, FL, died suddenly on Sunday afternoon, May 2, 1999. Former New York City restaurateur of LeManoir, Clos Normand, La Rotisserie. Survivors include his beautiful wife, Genevieve and loving brother, Valentin. Service May 6 at Price Funeral Home, North Palm Beach. Interment later at Vannes, France.

title: Humble Before the Future
description: To the Editor:

title: True North Adding Media Buying Agency
description: True North Communications in Chicago said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire KSL Media Inc. in New York, which handles media planning and buying for accounts with billings estimated at more than $500 million for clients including the Sony Corporation's Columbia Tristar unit, Robert Half International and Merle Norman Cosmetics. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Kosovo Town's Tale of Betrayal and Massacre
description: Betrayal is the theme of the story of Slovinje, a village in Kosovo. Of the 600 homes there, 40 belonged to Serbs and the rest to ethnic Albanians. The two communities lived on opposite sides of the river but got along without major problems. They shopped at each other's stores. Their kids competed at soccer. They knew each other's names.

title: Lab Directors Tell Congress Atom Secrets Lack Controls
description: Scientists at the Government's weapons laboratories can still download nuclear secrets onto computer disks and walk out without being checked, the directors of three of the labs told Congress today.

title: Destiny Brings Rivals Together
description: For 48 minutes on the floor last night at Madison Square Garden, Pat Riley kept his stars tethered to the bench, cautiously awaiting the start of the post-season and willing to finish the regular season with the likes of Rex Walters, Duane Causwell and Terry Mills.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the House & Home section last Thursday about Fitting Pretty, a company that sells slipcover anchors, misstated its annual sales as of 1996, when it filed a patent lawsuit against a competitor. They were more than $1 million, not $195,000.

title: A Plant Sale, Benefits And Classes
description: Annuals to Perennials

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, ROBERT J. (BOB BROWN).
description: BROWN-Robert J. (Bob Brown). On May 2, 1999. Loving husband, father, father-in-law, grandfather to Myra L. Brown, Renee and Roger Holt, and Meryl and Sheri Holt. We will miss you forever.

title: Checketts Is Delaying Compiling His List
description: Dave Checketts, the president of Madison Square Garden, has fielded calls from interested parties concerning the Knicks' vacancy at general manager. But he has made no decision about what he will do with that position or what it will take for Jeff Van Gundy to remain as coach next season.

title: Airport Rage? Just Make Believe It's the Porch, Sit Back and Rock
description: At North Carolina's Charlotte/Douglas International Airport, a row of 20 porch rockers is giving new meaning to the phrase ''first-class seating.'' A rocker, unlike typical chrome-and-plastic airport seats, makes waiting almost bearable. Charlotte, which spent less than $4,000 for the chairs, got a bargain: pride of place in an era of ''which hub is this, anyway?'' Indeed, the oak chairs, made in Asheboro by P&P Chair Company, are a striking advertisement for the state's furniture makers.

title: Nuclear Arms Labs Remain Vulnerable
description: Scientists at Government laboratories can still download nuclear secrets onto computer disks and walk out without being checked, directors of three labs told Congress. They said that new security measures, adopted after a scientist was suspected of spying for China and of transferring data from a classified computer system to an unclassified one at Los Alamos, will not prevent simple file transfers by scientists with security clearances.

title: Cavendish Opens Tomorrow With Interesting Pairings
description: The prestigious Cavendish Pairs beginning tomorrow in Las Vegas will have, as usual, a cosmopolitan flavor. Thirteen countries outside North America are represented, and two Italian pairs who won the world team title in Lille, France, in August will be among the favorites. American prospects are diminished because many top-ranked players are paired, for professional reasons, with partners of lesser stature.

title: Pennsylvania Set to Break Taboo On Reward for Organ Donations
description: With demand for human organs far outstripping supply and more than 64,000 Americans waiting to receive new hearts, lungs, livers, pancreases and kidneys, Pennsylvania is taking steps to become the first state to break a long-held taboo against providing a financial reward for organ donation.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: SUGAR UP SHARPLY. Sugar prices rose on signs of strengthening demand just as some of the world's largest growers are reducing their production. In New York, sugar for July delivery rose 0.21 cent a pound, to 4.82 cents.

title: Have Laptop, Will Travel
description: To the Editor:

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: The Young Palestinian Giant; Holding Company Close to Arafat Casts Widest of Nets
description: From his hillside offices, Munib R. Masri can look down on the neighborhood where his grandfather's family founded the city's first university and survey the old town center where uncles and cousins served as mayors.

title: Allies and Russia Planning Statement on Kosovo Force
description: Western allies and Russia have narrowed their differences over a future international force in Kosovo to the point where they will be able to issue a joint statement Thursday on ending the conflict in the Serbian province, American and NATO officials said today.

title: NATO Sees Need for 50,000 Peacekeepers
description: The NATO allies now believe they will need nearly twice the 28,000 peacekeeping troops they originally planned to station in Kosovo in a negotiated settlement, allied and American officials said today.

title: Did Michelangelo Have to Ask Permission?
description: If you blinked, you missed it. The matte-silver newsstand on the northeast corner of 14th Street and Third Avenue was recently -- and briefly -- an abstract landscape mural of bright red, yellow, green, turquoise and Poussin blue. Phyllis Segura, 55, had been seeking permission for the art project for about a year, and finally decided just to go ahead with it. She hoped her work would be the flagship piece for a program that would provide interesting projects for teen-agers required to perform community service.

title: Suspect in '91 Slaying Is Arrested at Airport
description: A man wanted since 1991 in a midtown murder and jewelry theft was arrested at Kennedy International Airport yesterday as he returned to New York after hiding for five years in China, the police said.

title: Key to Deal for Mediaone: Keeping the Losing Bidder Happy
description: Last Sunday afternoon, Brian Roberts, the president of Comcast, was resting at his home near Philadelphia after an exhausting week of negotiations. He had reason to be tired. After making a costly $53 billion stock bid for Mediaone Group, the nation's fourth-largest cable operator, a month earlier, Comcast found itself trumped by AT&T, which had muscled in with a $58 billion stock and cash offer.

title: Chance to Get Wireless E-Mail At Any Address You Choose
description: Skytel Communications, together with American Mobile Satellite and the pager manufacturer Research In Motion, earlier this week announced a nationwide wireless E-mail service that workswith a new Research In Motion pager.

title: Even the Devils' Post-Mortems Hurt
description: Scott Stevens was the picture of dejection as he sat at his locker in the Devils' training facility here this afternoon, his club having exited the playoffs in the first round Tuesday for the second straight season despite winning the Eastern Conference title.

title: What Did Disappearing Ink Grow Up to Be? Electronic Ink
description: Electronic ink, the technology that promises to change the way people read books and newspapers, made its commercial debut this week -- in the athletic wear section of a J. C. Penney store in Marlborough, Mass.

title: New High-Powered Glasses For Seeing the Web World
description: Wearable computers have received their share of hype in the last few years, but even technology fans will admit that bulky gadgets aren't in vogue. Microoptical, a company in Westwood, Mass., aims to change that with what it calls Eyeglass Displays, or E.G.D.'s.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STERN, HERMAN
description: STERN-Herman. The Officers, Trustees and staff of Jewish Child Care Association note with sorrow the death of Herman Stern. Mr. Stern came to Jewish Child Care Association's Edenwald Center in 1957 and retired in 1982 as the institution's Director. His devotion to troubled young people was a model for future generations. Our deepest sympathy to Mr. Stern's widow, Marian, his three children and eleven grandchildren. Joyce L. Kramer, President Irwin U. Goldberg, Board Chair Paul Gitelson, Exec. Vice Pres.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARLOW, TONY
description: BARLOW-Tony. On May 4. Born Milton McClintock Barlow and known to all as Tony, he was the beloved husband of Priscilla Winn Barlow, devoted father of Ethan and Benjamin, stepfather of Philippa and Nicola, loving brother of John Barlow and Sally Ittmann and dear son of Georgette Barlow of Kansas City. A former lawyer and banker, he was in recent years a member of the National Episcopal Church's Social Responsibility in Investments Committee and was an Episcopal Church representative at the Interfaith Center on Corporate Responsibility. A memorial service is being arranged with details to be announced. In lieu of flowers, donations should be sent to Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, Box E.

title: Shooting Sheds Light on Problems Boys Face
description: To the Editor:

title: In Bright Lights, Devils Dim
description: No, it is not a sign of success when your season ends with home fans throwing garbage on the ice and players hanging their heads in defeat. But this was the scene at Continental Arena on Tuesday night, when the Pittsburgh Penguins eliminated the Devils in Game 7 of the first round of the Stanley Cup playoffs. So an image of failure is the one that will linger. It was the Devils' third consecutive early departure from the tournament after winning the Eastern Conference championship in the regular season, the second successive season of first-round elimination.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about an attempt to climb Mount Everest in 1924 misstated the month that Edmund Hillary and Tenzing Norgay reached the summit. It was May 1953, not June.

title: Whitman Aides in Pique at First Lady
description: Aides to Gov. Christine Todd Whitman accused Hillary Rodham Clinton of trying to avoid sharing the media limelight yesterday during ceremonies to greet Kosovar refugees as they arrived at Fort Dix in New Jersey.

title: Metro Business; Trump Buys Stock
description: Donald J. Trump, chairman of Trump Hotels and Casino Resorts Inc., last month bought about $1 million in stock in the company, the largest casino operator in Atlantic City.

title: WINSLOEW FURNITURE APPROVES BUYOUT OFFER
description: Winsloew Furniture Inc., a maker of aluminum furniture for patios and offices, said yesterday that it had approved an increased buyout offer of about $278 million from the Trivest Furniture Corporation, which is controlled by the chairman of Winsloew, Earl W. Powell. The Powell-led company raised its bid for Winsloew, of Birmingham, Ala., a maker of sofas, chairs, futons and computer desks, to $34.75 a share from $33, topping a rival bid from the closely held Hancock Park Associates of $34 a share. Winsloew had 1998 sales of $141.4 million. Its shares rose $1.25, to $32.25.

title: Metro Business; Agreement to Repair Elevated Train Line
description: Conrail Inc. and CSX Corporation agreed yesterday to make emergency repairs to an elevated rail line that New York City had declared a safety hazard, said lawyers who sued the two freight haulers.

title: 2 U.S. Casualties Are the First for NATO : Crash of Apache Copter In Albania Kills Crew
description: PARIS  An Apache tank-busting helicopter crashed in a nighttime training exercise in Albania early Wednesday, killing the two U.S. airmen aboard.

title: A Store Without Any Vowels To Sell
description: Myxplyzyk, the hardest store to look up in the telephone book, has just issued its first mail-order catalogue -- 17 items culled from the Greenwich Village store's stock of well-designed merchandise. The 10,000 customers who will receive the catalogue will find offerings like Kraft paper desk organizers ($50 to $80), a colorful child's tricycle ($90) and three Japanese table lamps of rice paper and wire (above, $48 each). To request a catalogue, (800) 771-4328. Stay in touch: a Web site is coming. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: Dili Journal; In East Timor, Terror Inhabits Even the Hospitals
description: After a recent surge of violence here in East Timor, Julio Vicento limped into the Motael Clinic with a bullet buried in his ankle. He had fled the military hospital, he said, afraid that he might be killed there.

title: Doubts Surface Over Raise Being Planned for Military
description: Few issues have generated more bipartisan support this year or moved faster down the legislative track than the drive to increase pay and pensions for the armed forces.

title: When the Outlook Seems Bleak, A Parachute for the Plane Itself
description: IT works for pilots and passengers, so why not for whole airplanes? Next month, a company plans to market a single-engine plane with a parachute for the plane itself.

title: Phones at a Premium On the Albania Beat
description: The refugee crisis in Albania has given birth to a minor crisis of a different sort: journalists in need of mobile phones. At the beginning of April, the state-owned monopoly provider of mobile service, Albania Mobile Communications, canceled the roaming agreements that allowed subscribers from foreign services to make calls on its network. ''Our system was overloaded, mostly by journalists,'' said Rauf Elmas, an Albania Mobile executive.

title: $6 Million Goes to 179 In Guggenheim Awards
description: Among this year's 179 recipients of over $6 million in Guggenheim Fellowships are the playwright Jon Robin Baitz, the Pulitzer Prize-winning novelist Carol Shields, the biographer Claudia Roth Pierpont, the writer Junot Diaz, the choreographer Blondell Cummings and, by coincidence, two historians, Joseph H. Lynch and Robert C. Davis, who have adjacent offices at Ohio State University.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOODWARD, WILLIAM III.
description: WOODWARD-William III. On May 2, 1999. Beloved husband of Lisa and adoring father of Elizabeth, a kind and caring friend of many. Private services at St. Thomas Episcopal Church, 5th Avenue at 53rd Street, Thursday. Interment private. Memorial service to be announced at a future date. Contributions in his memory may be made to the William Woodward Jr. Nursery School, 436 East 69 Street, NYC 10021 or the Central Park Conservancy, 14 East 60 Street, New York City 10022.

title: Hello, Nice to See You Again: Knicks to Meet Heat
description: Coach Jeff Van Gundy ordered the scoreboards that circle Madison Square Garden turned off to prevent the Knicks from peeking at their playoff fate. But the crowd had cell phones and radios and members of the coaching staff had a team official whispering cliffhanger updates into their ears.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEBER, DENNIS R.
description: KLEBER-Dennis R. On May 4, 1999 of Muttontown, NY. Owner along with his wife Patricia of Hav-A-Home Kennels. Beloved husband of Patricia (nee Brumby). Survived by brothers Robert, Ray and Charles. Cherished son-in-law of Elizabeth. Dear brother-in-law of Gladi and Roberta. Memorial Service will be held on May 8, 1999, 2:30 P.M. at 232 Brookville Road, Muttontown, with the Reverend Allan Ramirez officiating. In lieu of flowers the family has requested donations to Nature Conservancy L.I. Chapter, 250 Lawrence Hill Rd, Cold Spring Harbor, N.Y. 11724 or to the charity of your choice.

title: Taiwan's Opposition Party Tones Down Call for Independence
description: Reaching for the political center as it prepares for a presidential election, Taiwan's main opposition party is softening its call for formal independence from China, once its defining trait.

title: The Non-Embargo
description: A blockade needs four things to work: enforcement, timing, endurance and cooperation among all countries.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE EURO RISES AGAIN. The dollar fell against the euro amid signs some investors were looking for better returns than those in United States stocks and bonds. In New York, the euro rose to $1.0741, from $1.0617 on Tuesday.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ARMSTRONG, FRANK
description: ARMSTRONG-Frank. Born October 8, 1895, died May 6, 1959. Always remembered, never forgotten.

title: Scrambling to Find Cupid in a Haystack
description: MYRON STAMMEN was still milking his cows when his guests arrived one Saturday evening, but nobody seemed to mind. It was an understanding crowd, single farmers like himself, well aware of the demands and routines of farm life.

title: Bigger Pay Package for Chief of Dell
description: The Dell Computer Corporation gave its founder, Michael Dell, a 24 percent increase in salary and bonus in its 1999 fiscal year as well as options on 12.8 million shares valued at more than $105 million, according to the company's annual proxy statement.

title: AT&T Grows Larger
description: Nearly three decades after AT&T was forced by antitrust laws to give up its most vital asset - ownership of a wire into most American homes - the company is trying to regain that access by a different means. Now it hopes to use the cable television wire into your home to get your telephone business.

title: Essay; Nudity and Energy: Qi Whiz!
description: One hundred fifty peaceful exhibitionists assembled at 6 A.M. in Manhattan's Times Square recently, stripped off all their clothes and together posed in the altogether for the photographer Spencer Tunick.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: HEWLETT-PACKARD CORP., Palo Alto, Calif., the computer maker, agreed to buy Dazel Corp., Austin, Tex., a maker of electronic information-delivery software, for an undisclosed amount.

title: The Shifting Colors of Satin
description: Gretchen Bellinger, a fabric designer, said she wanted to create a satin with a palette that's ''a celebration of light.'' ''Two Faces Have Eye,'' a collection of reversible silk satin weaves for drapery and upholstery, is the iridescent result. From top: ''Roses Have Thorns'' has a red warp and green weft; ''Green With Envy,'' an olive-yellow warp and gold weft, and ''Proud as a Peacock,'' an emerald warp and violet weft. $79.50 a yard to the trade at (518) 235-2828. ELAINE LOUIE

title: Heinz aims for more gold out of its famous red condiment.
description: WHEN the chief executive of the H. J. Heinz Company spoke before a group of Wall Street analysts in Florida in February, promoting his company's fresh take on its business, the souvenir handed out to everyone to remind them of the big changes at Heinz was . . . a bottle of ketchup.

title: House Votes to Make It Tougher to Escape Debt Through Personal Bankruptcy
description: With Americans filing a record 1.4 million personal bankruptcies last year, the House of Representatives tonight overwhelmingly approved sweeping legislation, proposed by the nation's largest banks but opposed by consumer and civil rights groups, that would make it harder for many people to erase their debts.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the Market Place column in Business Day yesterday, about the Coca-Cola Company's bottling network, misstated the year in which Coca-Cola Enterprises was spun off. It was 1986, not 1996.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KALMAN, TIBOR
description: KALMAN-Tibor. The Architectural League notes with great sadness the death of the designer, humanist, and provocateur Tibor Kalman. Tibor stirred things up, brilliantly. His absence will leave a huge hole in the design community, in NY and internationally. Frank Lupo, President Rosalie Genevro, Executive Dir.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOODY, LT. COLONEL WILLIAM ELLIOTT,
description: MOODY-Lt. Colonel William Elliott, AUS-Ret. Husband of the late Caroline (nee Bryson) of Haddonfield, NJ. May 4, 1999, age 73. Survived by a daughter, Caroline L. Moody, NY, NY, a son, Robert E. of Woolwich Twp, NJ, a sister, Marjorie Shiffer of Brownstown, PA., and a grandson, Robert Alexander Moody. Services Friday, 10:30 A.M., at The Holl-Murphy Funeral Home, 15 West End Ave, Haddonfield, NJ. Friends may call Thursday evening, 7 to 9 PM. Memorial contributions may be made to Williams College, P.O. Box 38, Williamstown, MA. 01267.

title: Accords Signed for Timor Autonomy Vote; Rights Lawyer Harassed
description: Indonesia and Portugal signed a landmark agreement today that will enable the people of the violence-plagued territory of East Timor to decide if they want wide-ranging autonomy, a vote that could eventually result in independence for the former Portuguese colony.

title: Shooting Sheds Light on Problems Boys Face
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-24

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REINIS, LILI H.
description: REINIS-Lili H. The Jewish Theological Seminary family records with sorrow the death of Lili H. Reinis, beloved mother of longtime board member, former treasurer and Louis Marshall Award recipient, Stephen M. Axinn. Mrs. Reinis finished first in her class at NYU Law School, established a thriving legal practice and instilled in her family a love of Jewish learning. Her granddaughter, Audrey Axinn, is a faculty member of JTS's Miller Cantorial School. She is survived by sons, Stephen and Daniel Axinn, six grandchildren and four great-grandchildren. May her memory be for a blessing. Ismar Schorsch, chancellor Gershon Kekst, board chairman

title: New York City on Screen: Love It or Fix It
description: NEW YORK CITY begs for simulation. It has been simulated in movies, books, paintings and avant-garde classical music, not to mention prime-time television. Inevitably, it has been assembled in digital media.

title: Mae Bertha Carter, 76, Mother Who Defied Segregation Law
description: Mae Bertha Carter, who defied gunfire and the loss of employment to send her children to previously all-white public schools in Mississippi, eventually winning a legal battle that confirmed their right to be there, died on April 28 at her home in Drew, Miss. She was 76.

title: CANDIDATES TAKE NOTE
description: May 5 marked the silver anniversary of the bar-code scanner. NCR Corporation introduced the device at the 1974 annual convention of the Supermarket Institute. A 10-pack of Wrigley's Juicy Fruit gum became the first retail item ever to be purchased with the technology when it was swiped across a scanner at the Marsh Supermarket in Troy, Ohio, six weeks later.

title: Carrying Little but Hope, Albanian Refugees Begin Arriving
description: With their families torn apart and their homes turned to ashes, the first 453 of 20,000 Albanian refugees arrived here from Macedonia today, taking the first step toward rebuilding their lives away from the battlefield their homeland has become.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALDRON, JAMES R.
description: WALDRON-James R. On May 4, 1999, aged 82 yrs. Beloved husband of the late Anne. Loving father of Brian & Richard and father-in-law of Carolyn & Jayne. Dear brother of Henry ''Jack,'' Alyce and Anne McAllister. Devoted grand-father of Cory, Jeremy, Jessica and Andrew. Mass of Christian Burial Saturday, 9:15 AM at Holy Name R.C. Church. Reposing M.J. Smith Sons, 248 Prospect Park, W. Bklyn. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Alzheimer's Assoc. of NYC, 420 Lexington Ave., NYC 10017 would be appreciated. Visiting Friday 2-5 and 7-9 PM.

title: Principals Offer a Plan to End Tenure
description: The New York City principals' union has offered to give up tenure, one of the thorniest issues in city schools over the last decade, in exchange for higher salaries and a guarantee that principals who lose their jobs will be able to stay in the system in other positions, union officials said yesterday.

title: GARDEN Q.& A.
description: Quince's Performance

title: Ladies and Gentlemen, New Acts of Derring-Do
description: Feats of circus art that reach literally breathtaking heights of skill are among the pleasures awaiting the children and adults lucky enough to make their way to the New Victory Theater, where the New Shanghai Circus is providing entertainment in abundance through May 23.

title: Sports of The Times; Campaign For Jackson In Full Swing
description: WHEN Phil Jackson was a player with the Knicks in the early 1970's, he would hear the coach, Red Holzman, and the trainer, Danny Whelan, inform the starting small forward, Bill Bradley, that when Bradley became President of the United States they wanted the jobs of checking the height of the water levels of the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans. Holzman would sit at one coast for six months and Whelan at the other, and then they would switch.

title: Microsoft Presses Rival on Details of a Deal
description: A lawyer for Microsoft tried to make the case today that America Online planned to use ''all of its marketing muscle'' to promote its newly acquired product, the Netscape Navigator Web browser. But an America Online executive disputed that, saying the company thought ''the browser business is dead.''

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: '''We will protect you,' they promised, and then when the army came, our own Serbs put on masks and joined in the butchery. They knew who to single out. They knew who had money.''

title: Air War: Too Costly in Every Way
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; It Has Not Been Easy Being a Knicks Fan
description: IS this the Knicks' year?

title: Bell Atlantic Is Blamed for 911 Woes
description: A day after callers to 911 from four boroughs heard up to 30 seconds of dead air before reaching emergency operators, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani put the blame for the problems squarely on Bell Atlantic, which maintains the telephone lines.

title: Air War: Too Costly in Every Way
description: To the Editor:

title: National Semiconductor Is Quitting PC Processor Business
description: Less than two years after paying $550 million for the Cyrix Corporation to enter the personal computer microprocessor business, the National Semiconductor Corporation said today that it was exiting that market.

title: Tree or Power Line May Have Brought Down Copter and Crew
description: The Apache helicopter crash that killed two American pilots early today in rugged mountains about 45 miles from here may have been caused by a rotor clipping a power line or a tree, military officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINTRAUB, BENJAMIN Z.
description: WEINTRAUB-Benjamin Z. On May 3, 1999. Beloved husband of the late Ida. Devoted father of Daniel and Joel. Cherished grandfather of David, Anita, Jeremy and Jody. Dear brother of Shirley Steier, Dorothy Finkelstein and Sylvia Rice. Graveside service Friday, 1PM at Mount Lebanon Cemetery, Glendale, N.Y.

title: Suit Is Dismissed Against Deloitte
description: Deloitte & Touche L.L.P. has won dismissal of a negligence lawsuit brought by a bankruptcy trustee who sought to hold the Big Five accounting firm accountable for the Foxmeyer Corporation's financial woes.

title: Poor Scores by U.S. Students Lead to 10-State Math Effort
description: Motivated by the mediocre performance of American eighth graders on an international math test, the Governors of 10 states said yesterday that they would help develop a new curriculum and rigorous exam designed to raise students' performance to that in foreign countries.

title: Cable and Wireless Enters Digital Battle
description: The digital war in Britain heated up yesterday as Cable and Wireless Communications P.L.C. said it planned to roll out digital interactive and cable television services. Cable and Wireless Communications said it would invest an additional $98 million in digital services the next 12 months. Commercial trials of the company's digital TV began yesterday in Manchester.

title: Killer of Girl Sentenced to 89 Years
description: A man who admitted killing a 10-year-old girl whose family had taken him in as a boarder was sentenced yesterday to at least 89 years in prison, officials said.

title: The Big City; How Vouchers Can Help Ease Overcrowding
description: IN his self-described crusade to ''rescue the children,'' the Rev. Jesse L. Jackson visited a public high school in Brooklyn on Tuesday and was appalled to find its 1,100 students had only 2 computers with Internet access. But he was just as appalled at the idea of letting any students escape to a better school.

title: Thin Skins And Thick
description: It is improbable fantasy to suppose that authors and publishers wouldn't do nearly anything to sell their books, so it's hardly surprising that Frank McCourt took the opportunity to do a television commercial for Barnes & Noble's on-line bookselling operation and plug not only the chain but his best-selling ''Angela's Ashes'' as well.

title: Have Laptop, Will Travel
description: To the Editor:

title: NORTHPOINT RISES 68% IN FIRST DAY OF TRADING, TO $40.25
description: Northpoint Communications Inc., a provider of high-speed Internet access over copper telephone lines, rose 68 percent on its first day of trading yesterday. The San Francisco-based company rose $16.25, to $40.25. Northpoint sold a 12 percent stake -- 15 million shares at $24 each, raising $360 million. That was at the top of the range set by Goldman, Sachs & Company, which handled the offering.

title: Rivals Team Up With National Geographic
description: The rival television networks NBC and Fox are teaming up with National Geographic Ventures to expand the National Geographic Channel to the United States.

title: GRUPO PICKING PACK OF SPAIN ACQUIRES WAGON HOLDINGS
description: Grupo Picking Pack S.A., a Spanish office supply and printing company, yesterday acquired the holding company that owns the Charrette Corporation, for $107 million, doubling its annual sales. Picking Pack bought Wagon Holdings, which owns Charrette, a printing, printing-equipment and office-supply company in Woburn, Mass. The purchase is Picking Pack's first in the United States. Wagon Holdings had revenue of $130 million from its 24 outlets in 1998, representing nearly all of Picking Pack's 1998 sales. Wagon's assets of $83 million represent 49 percent of Picking Pack's assets.

title: USA Today To Run Ads On Front Page
description: USA Today, the newspaper whose bright colors and strong graphics became a catalyst for the remaking of the industry's front pages a decade ago, yesterday announced plans to sell color advertising at the bottom of its front page.

title: Time and the River: A House Well Lived In
description: THE lowering sun illuminates the monumental columns of the Hudson River house like a kindly searchlight.

title: Fixing the Fight Game
description: The outrageous judges' decision in March's heavyweight title fight between Evander Holyfield and Lennox Lewis embarrassed New York's politicians. They had hoped for a fight that would establish an undisputed heavyweight champion and lead to a rebirth of big-time boxing in the state. What they got was a verdict that turned a clear victory for Lewis into a draw. Yesterday two of these officials, Gov. George Pataki and Attorney General Eliot Spitzer, answered with modest reforms and suggestions for bigger changes that could weaken the grip of boxing's monopolists.

title: On a Galaxy of Sites, 'Star Wars' Fever Rises
description: WITH about two weeks to go before the release of the new film ''Star Wars: Episode 1 -- The Phantom Menace,'' there are so many ''Star Wars'' sites on the Web that the creator of one site, Jedi Temple (www.spiderspace.net /jeditemple), felt compelled to list his favorite 100. And that barely scratched the surface.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCMILLAN, MICHAEL JOHN,
description: McMILLAN-Michael John, 53. Of West Bloomfield, MI., died on Wednesday, May 5, after a valiant fight against cancer. He was a partner with Ernst & Young LLP, Detroit. Upon graduation from the University of Toledo, he joined the Toledo office of Arthur Young and Co. Mr. McMillan was a resident in the National Office (New York City) from 1980 to 1983. He returned to Toledo as a partner in the firm and remained there until transferring to Detroit in 1987. Over the years, Mr. McMillan served on various boards and committees, including the American Heart Association, the Jamie Farr Toledo Classic, Leadership Oakland and the Detroit Compact. He was a member of the Michigan Society of CPA's and the American Institute of CPA's. Mr. McMillan served in the United States Army as a sargeant in the Infantry from 1968 to 1970, including a tour of duty in Vietnam, where he was awarded the Bronze Star for Meritorious Achievement in Ground Operations Against Hostile Forces. Mr. McMillan was an avid golfer and belonged to Orchard Lake Country Club, where he served on the Finance Committee. He particularly enjoyed traveling with his family. He was the childhood sweetheart and husband of 31 years of Mary Jo; loving father of Max (Rebecca) McMillan, West Palm Beach, FL; Molly (Stephen) Bodnar, Detroit; Nicholas McMillan, Chicago. Mr. McMillan is also survived by his mother, Ruth McMillan; sisters, Kathleen Connelly, Janet (Ronald) Klocinski and Susan Waxler, all of Toledo; brother, Jack (Deborah) McMillan, Chardon, Ohio; uncle, Dewey Blanchard, Sylvania, Ohio. The body will lie in state at Prince of Peace Catholic Church, 4300 Walnut Lake Road, West Bloomfield, at 10 a.m. Saturday, May 8, 1999, followed at 10:30 by the Mass of the Resurrection. Memorials may be made to the Toledo Association of Grocery Manufacturers' Representatives, PO Box 381, Maumee, OH 43637-0361. For more information, contact McCabe Funeral Home, 31950 West 12 Mile, Farmington Hills, MI, 248-553-0120.

title: Economic Scene; A wrong turn on the road to Social Security reform.
description: BIG plans to overhaul Social Security may or may not be dead in Congress this year. But regardless of what happens, Washington will eventually have to come up with a way to keep the system from running out of money when the baby boomers retire next century.

title: Parents Have a Right To Choose Schools; Change Can Help
description: To the Editor:

title: Lawyer for Mafia Leads in Las Vegas Vote
description: Oscar B. Goodman, a criminal defense lawyer for mob figures, won 49 percent of the vote in the Las Vegas mayoral race on Tuesday, just short of the majority needed to avoid a runoff.

title: KOSOVO UPDATE
description: COMBAT

title: Deal by American Express
description: The American Express Company, the world's biggest travel agency, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the corporate travel business Morris Travel of Salt Lake City as it expands its business travel operations in the West. American Express, which is based in New York, said Morris Travel's business travel unit had $100 million in annual sales and booked trips for small- to medium-size businesses in the West. Terms of the transaction were not disclosed.

title: Filtering the Web Won't Protect Kids
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUGOFF, RALPH JOSEPH.
