description: RUGOFF-Ralph Joseph. On May 4, 1999 in his 91st year. Beloved husband of Janice. Dear father of Stephanie Rugoff Locker and Ruth Rugoff Potischman. Loving grandfather of Philip Benjamin Locker and Joseph Ralph Potischman. Dear brother of Milton. Father-in-law to Michael Locker and Harold Potischman. Fordham University Law School Alumnus. Graveside services today, 1:30 PM, Mount Hebron Cemetery, Flushing, NY. Poet, wit, mensch. We will miss you.

title: Moving Beyond Blame
description: Ever since the tragedy in Littleton, Colo., the American preoccupation with finding a simple answer has been churning nonstop. In a nation that reduces everything to box scores (''Conventional Wisdom'' in Newsweek, etc.), the media and its pundit class have been obsessed with finding the immediate cause, like a zealous cop hellbent on making an early collar.

title: Clinton Flies To Europe To Bolster Troop Morale
description: Donning a brown bomber jacket in solidarity with the NATO forces in Yugoslavia, President Clinton began a two-day morale-boosting trip to Europe today that included a brief visit with the three American soldiers who were recently released from Serbian captivity.

title: Lost Pilot Had Aspired to Fly Apaches
description: The two helicopter pilots who died in Albania, the first confirmed American deaths in NATO's air campaign in Kosovo, had transferred from other branches of the military to the Army in order to fly the specialized Apache attack helicopters, associates said yesterday.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: This Chair Goes Indoors, Outdoors and Up and Up
description: Toy, despite its name, is an elegant, grown-up plastic chair designed for indoor-outdoor use by Philippe Starck. Its graphic Bauhaus form lets it stack 15-high, like a child's beach bucket -- rare for stacking chairs, said Nasir Kassamali, owner of Luminaire, a retailer of Italian furniture, who saw it last month in Milan. Made by Driade, the injection-molded chair has a hole to drain rainwater, arms that make it comfortable for dining use, and a palette of ivory, yellow, orange or gray. When it lands at Luminaire in Coral Gables, Fla., and Chicago this summer, it will sell for less than $100, with an optional slipcover. To order: (800) 645-7250. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: WITCO PLANS TO SELL ITS PETROLEUM ADDITIVES BUSINESS
description: The Witco Corporation, a maker of chemical additives used in products ranging from fabric softener to hair conditioner, said yesterday that it was planning to sell its petroleum additives business, which generated around $100 million in 1998 revenues. Witco, based in Greenwich, Conn., said it planned to use the proceeds of the sale, which it hopes to complete in 1999, to cut debt and pursue its strategy of focusing on high-growth specialty chemicals. Witco's shares fell 25 cents, to $18.8750.

title: Beethoven Among Friends (Batons Not Required)
description: Sometimes, when Orpheus plays, the absence of a conductor makes it easy to forget that the music is being performed at all: it just seems to be happening of its own accord. So it was on Tuesday night at Carnegie Hall, when Frank Peter Zimmermann was with the chamber orchestra to play the Beethoven Violin Concerto. Everyone was onstage waiting for a siren to disappear up Sixth Avenue, and then, as if from out of nowhere, those timpani strokes arrived as a gentle but firm knock on the door to open the piece.

title: Magic-Carpet Chairs of Virtual Reality
description: HAVE a seat in a chair of the future.

title: William Hunter McCrea, 94, Expert on Sun's Ingredients
description: Sir William Hunter McCrea, a British astronomer and mathematician who as a young researcher advanced the knowledge of the Sun's composition and more recently set forth his own theories on the formation of planetary systems and galaxies, died April 25. He was 94 and lived in Lewes, Sussex.

title: U.N. Condemns Ouster of Refugees and Calls for Peacekeepers
description: The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees said today that Kosovo was being ''brutally and methodically'' emptied by an ''ethnic cleansing'' campaign and that the 700,000 refugees from Kosovo would return home only if Serbian forces withdrew and an ''armed international force'' assured their safety.

title: Mountain Climbing as a Spectator Sport
description: THE MOUNTAIN ZONE

title: Studies Cite Lag in Year 2000 Projects
description: The prevailing optimism that Year 2000 computer problems will not seriously affect American business is premature, according to two new studies of Government filings by the nation's largest companies.

title: Victim's Kin Favor Sparing Killer's Life In Pizza Case
description: Moments after describing her family's anguish over her son's murder, the mother of one of two pizza deliverymen ambushed and slain in 1997 told a jury today that her family opposed the death sentence and hoped her son's killer would not be executed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRUSH, ELLEN SPARRY.
description: BRUSH-Ellen Sparry. The Society of Woman Geographers express their deep sorrow at the untimely death of our inspiring, beloved member, and former Chair, anthropologist Dr. Ellen Brush. Our thoughts are with her family.

title: Brutality Trial Told of Officer's Conduct
description: Prosecution witnesses at the trial of four police officers charged with brutalizing a Haitian immigrant testified yesterday that one of the officers had been acting aggressively during a melee outside a Brooklyn nightclub a short time before the alleged attack occurred.

title: Shooting Sheds Light on Problems Boys Face
description: To the Editor:

title: Their Own Homes Gone, Workers Console Others
description: Assistant Fire Chief John Hansen was on his first call after the tornadoes hit on Monday night, helping hundreds of dazed and injured students out of their ruined high school, when his eyes turned homeward.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day yesterday listing disaster relief efforts by governments and international organizations misidentified one country receiving relief. It is North Korea, not South Korea.

title: Whitman Is Counting on Power of Political Muscle
description: With the confirmation of Attorney General Peter G. Verniero to the State Supreme Court hinging on as few as two votes in the Senate, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman called in some political favors today and seemed intent on using political muscle to clear the path for her nominee.

title: Spock On-Line Advice
description: To the Editor:

title: New Jerseyans Keep Dialing In Pursuit Of Tax Rebate
description: It seemed too good to be true.

title: Pataki Announces Reforms Aimed at the Judges
description: Gov. George E. Pataki and the New York Attorney General, Eliot L. Spitzer, returned yesterday to Madison Square Garden, the scene of the controversial March 13 heavyweight unification bout between Evander Holyfield and Lennox Lewis, to announce a set of reforms to better screen and select boxing judges and to place greater controls on promoters and sanctioning organizations.

title: Arduous Search for the Missing In Tornado-Stricken Oklahoma
description: For the fifth time in three days, Capt. James Smith and a band of other National Guardsmen waded into a thorny thicket this morning to search a muddy creek bed near here for the bodies, or parts of bodies, of those who remain missing after Monday's tornadoes.

title: Air War: Too Costly in Every Way
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Brazil's surprising rebound still has a ways to go, though things could get choppy in the near term.
description: IT may appear to many investors that the sharp rebound in Brazilian stocks and bonds has passed them by. The stock market, in local terms, is up 71 percent this year and is almost back to its last peak in March 1998. Prices in the bond market have jumped, as the yields, which move in the opposite direction, have plunged. The yield on Brazil's benchmark long-term bond maturing in 2027 is down to 12.6 percent, from 16.9 percent just two months ago.

title: New York Hospitals Braced for Cuts
description: The fiscal knife that has begun to cut into teaching hospitals in Boston and other cities has not yet had the same dire effects -- layoffs or widespread operating deficits -- in hospitals around New York State.

title: Move Builds To Make Field Narrower In Israel Vote
description: Yitzhak Mordechai, the Center Party candidate for Prime Minister, is facing increasing pressure from inside and outside his party to drop out of the race and join forces with Ehud Barak, the Labor Party leader and front-runner.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHESLOW, NETTIE
description: SHESLOW-Nettie. At age 93. Of Miami Beach, Florida. Beloved wife of the late Julius Sheslow, loving sister of the late Philip Nadel, devoted mother of Seena Cowan and Everett Sheslow. Adoring grandmother of Stacey Kaplan, Jeffrey Cowan, Bruce Cowan, Faith Wheeler & Stephen Sheslow, revered great grandmother of Jared and Ryan Kaplan and Madeline and Elizabeth Wheeler. Services Friday, May 7th, 11AM Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Air War: Too Costly in Every Way
description: To the Editor:

title: Marbury's 41 Provide Bright Ending to Nets' Dismal Year
description: This was supposed to be the beginning, not the end. Tonight's regular-season finale against the Milwaukee Bucks was supposed to mark the start of the most successful post-season run in the Nets' 22-year history in the National Basketball Association. The young and talented team from New Jersey was a second-round lock, a potential Eastern Conference finalist and, with a little luck, maybe more than that.

title: A Neighborhood Park Draws Littleton Pilgrims
description: The television trucks and trailers rolled out of town at the first report of tornadoes in Oklahoma. But even without the encouragement of television coverage, people keep coming in a steady stream to visit the vast impromptu memorial created for the victims of the Columbine High School shooting. Andrea Lund was one of them.

title: The Universe Is a Flip Away
description: Not happy just creating a home page? Now you can create a universe without a computer. K-Dron is a bridge between a map and a globe, a visual aid for geography and astronomy fans packed into a three-and-a-quarter-inch plastic cube. Invented by Janusz Kapusta, an illustrator and designer, the K-Dron Universe flips up to become a map of the earth and of the celestial sky, depending on how it's arranged. The 11-sided spatial form that Mr. Kapusta patented in 1987 is $9.99 at the Literary Bookstore, 161 Java Street (Manhattan Avenue), Greenpoint, Brooklyn; (718) 349-2738.

title: In America; The Biggest Problem
description: ''I believe the voucher system in New York City would be very, very troublesome,'' said Mayor Rudolph Giuliani in a speech to the Wharton Club of New York in August 1995. ''Our system is so large that making that kind of transition would pose tremendous difficulties. Not to mention the constitutional and legal difficulties that would be entailed in providing tax relief and tax dollars for religious education.''

title: Ushering Out a Sitcom and a Television Era
description: ''Seinfeld'' was often called the prototype of the post-modern sitcom, and so it seemed apt that the last episode involved a strange dream sequence and a sinister finale for a group of self-absorbed singles stumbling in an amoral world.

title: The City Life; Uptown, Across Town, Out of Town
description: On the stage, theatricality means a fullness of effect, a knowing use of all the theater's dimensions, an awareness of how the right staging can ionize the very air an audience breathes. But a city's theatricality -- who conspires to produce that? New York rises above its crowded streets, a consolidated chaos of views, and the power of its scenic accidents is so great that they look purposeful, every last one of them, until you realize that only the eye's intent unites them.

title: CONCERNS RAISED AS AT&T PURSUES A NEW FOOTHOLD
description: A whirlwind of deals surrounding the AT&T Corporation's cable television ambitions raised concerns in Washington and in many high-technology quarters yesterday about the prospects for competition in the fast-growing communications industry.

title: PRIDE TO SELL SHARES WORTH $75 MILLION TO FIRST RESERVE
description: Pride International, the sixth-largest United States drilling company, said yesterday that it would sell shares valued at $75 million to the First Reserve Corporation, a closely held investment company. First Reserve will own about 11 percent of the Houston-based Pride, which said it would use some of the proceeds from the sale to pay off debt. Pride reported an unexpected first-quarter loss yesterday as lower oil prices cut demand for its services. The company's loss from operations was $10.6 million, or 21 cents a diluted share. Pride had been expected to show a profit of 4 cents a share, based on the average estimate of analysts polled by First Call Corporation. Pride says it has cut more than 4,000 jobs in the last 12 months to offset slumping revenue. Shares of Pride fell $1.125, to $10.8125.

title: Marks From the Underground; The Graffiti Esthetic Surfaces in the Arts
description: The day after the Dow Jones industrial average hit 10,000 this spring, a special report explaining the record-breaking news appeared on the Wall Street Journal's Web site: The headline was a panel of bold, 3-D letters layered one upon another, and a dollar-green bull leapt off the screen.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Clairvoyant Buffy Holds Her Fire

title: LIBRARY/MOUNTAINEERING SITES: Site-Seeing: Everest and Neighbors; Mountain Climbing as a Spectator Sport
description: ''Into Thin Air,'' a book by Jon Krakauer about the 1996 climbing disaster on Mount Everest, spent a long time atop the best-seller list, and the Imax film ''Everest'' enjoyed a long run in theaters. If you want to find out more about the disaster, in which five people died, here are a few Web sites related to it and to other climbs in 1996:

title: Abortion Foe Now Seen as Suspect in Killing of Doctor Near Buffalo
description: Federal law enforcement officials said yesterday that they had concluded that James C. Kopp, an impassioned and nomadic opponent of abortion, had fired the shots that killed a Buffalo abortion-clinic doctor last October.

title: Governing Party in South Africa Is Riding High in New Polls
description: A flurry of recent polls show that President Nelson Mandela's governing African National Congress is edging closer to the two-thirds majority that it is seeking in South Africa's second post-apartheid election, scheduled for June 2.

title: When Collection Software Runs, Debtors Can't Hide
description: WITH Americans taking on more and more debt, high-tech collection tactics are making it easier to find debtors and encourage them to pay up. Or else.

title: Oops, Cadillac Says, Lincoln Won After All
description: Here in the Motor City, auto makers take their annual battles for sales titles very seriously. Perhaps the most fiercely fought feud has been between Cadillac and Lincoln, as Cadillac struggled to keep its 57-year winning streak as the nation's best-selling luxury car.

title: Residents Watched on TV As the Tornadoes Neared
description: Tom Chase had been following the tornado for about 90 minutes on television, watching the little map in the bottom corner of the screen as it traced the twister's chewing path across central Oklahoma to the edge of his middle-class neighborhood a few miles south of Oklahoma City.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LICHTENBAUM, JEFFREY M.
description: LICHTENBAUM-Jeffrey M. Beloved son of Dorothy and the late Abe. Dear brother of Alan, Carol Laffer. Adored uncle of Adam, Andrew and Abby. Services Thursday 1:30pm at Schwartz Bros-Jeffer Memorial, Queens Boulevard at 76th Road, Forest Hills.

title: The Investigators Whose Job Is to Document the Worst of Abuses
description: Their job is to document many of the most gruesome and persistent abuses of societies around the world, including torture, disappearances and summary executions. They collect information, interview victims and weave those accounts into a pattern, usually one that tells of flagrant deprivations of human rights.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALDRON, JAMES
description: WALDRON-James. The Board of Governors of The New York College of Osteopathic Medicine (NYCOM) of New York Institute of Technology mourns the loss of James Waldron, beloved and devoted father of Brian Waldron, D.O., a graduate of NYCOM and member of the Board. Heartfelt condolences are extended to Dr. Waldron and his family.

title: Show-House Nuggets to Make Your Own
description: BIG changes aren't always required to refresh a tired room. Here are some accessible, even affordable, ideas culled from the Kips Bay Decorator Show House, at 2 East 82d Street until May 26th.

title: Finding Unity by Accepting a Lot of Individuality
description: It's a little unreasonable to expect outright novelty in jazz, an art that demands high, broad musicality and honesty. (Imagine deciding to warm up to new acquaintances only if you felt their personalities were breaking new ground, were going where no one had gone before.) If you value the idea of the new, it's easier to say of a good jazz group that it typifies a current mode of expression; its particular charms follow from the musicians' individual techniques and sensibilities, and how well they achieve what they're shooting for.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GERMAISE, HERBERT S. (MICKEY).
description: GERMAISE-Herbert S. (Mickey). Beloved companion of Debra Sabato. Devoted father of Scott, Susan and Lauren. Services ''Wien & Wien,'' 402 Park St., Hackensack, on Thursday, May 6, 1999, at 12:30. Contributions to a favorite charity would be appreciated. For information, 1-800-322-0533.

title: Parents Have a Right To Choose Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: Terrifying Precision, Just for Fun
description: I'M trapped inside a 50,000-square-foot, three-dimensional comic strip. Spiderman jumps down onto the hood of my high-tech reporter's vehicle with a thump and warns me that Doctor Octopus and his evil henchpersons are running amok in Gotham. But my editor at The Daily Bugle says I've got to get the story.

title: Deutsche Bank Reports 36.5% Surge in Profit
description: Deutsche Bank A.G., Europe's biggest bank, reported yesterday that its profit jumped 36.5 percent in the first quarter, exceeding analysts' estimates. Net income rose to 621 million euros ($660 million), from 455 million euros ($481.6 million) in the first quarter of 1998. Trading income of more than 1 billion euros ($1.06 billion) and lower taxes led gains.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: AT&T and Microsoft Poised To Tower Over Technology

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAPIRO, RABBI DAVID.
description: SHAPIRO-Rabbi David. The National Board of Hadassah, WZOA, mourns the death of Rabbi David Shapiro, beloved father of our esteemed colleague, Judith Saxe. Our heartfelt condolences to the entire family. May his memory be for a blessing. Marlene E. Post, National President Dr. Laura S. Schor, National Executive Director

title: Kosovar Voice For Pacifism Lands in Italy After Isolation
description: After weeks of enforced isolation, a leader of ethnic Albanians in Kosovo arrived in Rome today from Serbia as a guest of the Italian Government.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEAVERS, KARL A.
description: DEAVERS-Karl A. The board of Trustees, Headmaster, Faculty, Staff, and the Collegiate School community mourn the loss of former Trustee Karl A. Deavers. Mr. Deavers, an Elder of the Collegiate Church, served the school as a Trustee from 1987 to 1993. As an officer of the Board, his guidance and wise counsel were highly valued. We extend our sincere condolences to his wife, Kerry, his children, and the entire Deavers family. Robert Hollander, '51, President Of The Board Of Trustees Jacob A. Dresden, Headmaster

title: How Suburban Design Is Failing Teen-Agers
description: AS quickly as the word ''alienation'' can be attached to the idea of youth, the image of isolation can be attached to a picture of the suburbs. Is there an unexplored relationship between them? It is a question parents and urban planners alike are raising in the aftermath of the Columbine High School shootings in Littleton, Colo.

title: Pettitte Returns to the Top of His Game, and the Yanks Follow
description: Andy Pettitte lowers his chin when he stares in for the sign from the catcher, the bill of his cap dropping and nearly hiding his eyes. From this angle, Pettitte's sightline is no higher than the first few rows of the stands behind home plate.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: City's Last Waste Incinerator Is Torn Down
description: As more than 200 children sang songs, a crane hoisted away the smokestack of the city's last incinerator yesterday, marking the end -- for now, at least -- of what was once one of New York's most popular methods of disposing of garbage.

title: Parents Have a Right To Choose Schools; The City's Models
description: To the Editor:

title: After Officers' Indictment in Diallo Case, Arrests Drop in New York City
description: Arrests have fallen sharply in New York City in the month since four officers were indicted in the fatal shooting of Amadou Diallo, prompting concern among some officials about a possible work slowdown by police officers.

title: A Half-hearted War
description: A blockade needs four things to work: enforcement, timing, endurance and cooperation among all countries.

title: Picking Up the Pieces
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Justice Department to Investigate Handling of Spy Case
description: Attorney General Janet Reno said today that the Justice Department would examine whether Federal authorities had mishandled the investigation of a nuclear scientist suspected of spying for China.

title: Conceptual But Verbal, Very Verbal
description: ''Global Conceptualism: Points of Origin, 1950's-1980's'' at the Queens Museum of Art is an ambitious and groundbreaking exhibition. It is also tedious and confusing. With more than 240 works by 135 artists, it rejects the conventional art-historical focus on a few European and North American artists and tries to track a worldwide explosion in Conceptual Art. It groups works by regions but otherwise offers no overall framework by which to make sense of the bewildering diversity of forms that Conceptualism has taken.

title: Now, a Second Soap Opera Cable Channel
description: The Sony Corporation's Columbia television studio yesterday became the second owner of hit network soap operas to announce plans for a soap opera cable channel.

title: Senate Democrats Reach Outside Party
description: Democrats have always figured that the fight to regain control of the United States Senate would be all uphill in 2000, given that Republicans came out of the 1998 election with a 55-to-45 edge. And ever since three party stalwarts -- Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York, Frank R. Lautenberg of New Jersey and Richard H. Bryan of Nevada -- announced this year that they would not seek re-election, the hill has seemed even steeper.

title: Milosevic Optimistic for 'Fair Agreement'
description: President Slobodan Milosevic was quoted today as saying that he believed a ''fair agreement'' on Kosovo could be reached in negotiations with the West, ending the bombing and allowing the return of at least some refugees.

title: Man Charged in Stabbing Deaths Of His Girlfriend and Daughter
description: A man stabbed his girlfriend and 1 1/2-year-old daughter to death and critically injured the woman's other daughter last night in an apartment in Newark, the police said.

title: Nets Awaiting a Turn To Woo Phil Jackson
description: Four weeks after pulling off a trade for the spectacular Stephon Marbury in mid-March, the Nets' principal owner, Lewis Katz, was scheduled to meet with another prominent basketball personality about joining his team.

title: Residential Real Estate; Another Building in Wall St. Area Becomes Housing
description: After a $76 million renovation, the 67-year-old former office building at 99 John Street opened two weeks ago as the latest addition to the housing stock in Manhattan's financial district.

title: HOUSE G.O.P. BACKS BUSH AND PURSUES A COMMON AGENDA
description: House Republican leaders are so united behind Gov. George W. Bush of Texas for their party's Presidential nomination that they have already begun meeting informally with him to discuss a common agenda for the 2000 elections.

title: Vatican's Balkan Misstep; The Pope's Neutrality
description: To the Editor:

title: Almost Secret, Always Serene
description: Fair Quiet, have I found thee here?

title: Several agencies get new deals as many marketers shuffle their decks of assignments.
description: FOR many years, a certain newspaper would run a headline over its weekly patents column proclaiming ''Wide Variety of Ideas Covered by Patents Issued During Week.'' Now it is the advertising column that is all about a wide variety, in this instance advertisers in fields as diverse as computers, banks, baking mixes and appliances, which are all making account changes.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: S.W.A.K. From Spielberg

title: Honda Plans to Build Plant in Alabama for Larger Vehicles
description: In the latest sign that foreign auto manufacturers are shifting toward bigger vehicles and moving south in the United States, Honda announced today that it would build a factory in rural Alabama to assemble large sport utility vehicles and Odyssey minivans.

title: Miscellany
description: * Draft Worldwide, Chicago, part of the Interpublic Group of Cos., acquired DRS Advertising, London, which will become the London office of Draft. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Jeronimo Elespe
description: Audiello Fine Arts

title: High School Rocks the Vote, Then Stands It on Its Head
description: Election

title: RUSSIA IN ACCORD ON NEED FOR FORCE TO PATROL KOSOVO -- After Pact, New Issues
description: The Clinton Administration, anxious to find a political solution to the Kosovo conflict as soon as possible, managed to get the Russians on its side today.

title: Royal Dutch/Shell Says Profit Fell in Quarter
description: Royal Dutch/Shell Group, the world's biggest investor-owned oil company, said yesterday that its first-quarter profit fell a less-than-expected 26 percent as cost-cutting cushioned a blow from lower oil prices. The British-Dutch oil company's profit from operations fell to $1.44 billion, from $1.95 billion in the quarter a year earlier. The decline was less severe than the median analyst forecast for a 42 percent drop. Shell outperformed its top five United States rivals, which saw earnings fall by between 34 percent and 65 percent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZELNER, HYMAN
description: ZELNER-Hyman. Of Brooklyn, New York, in his 95th year. Passed away May 4, 1999. Will be remembered with love by Anna, his wife of 66 years; his sons, Martin and Larry, and their wives, Barbara and Marjorie; and his grandchildren, Bennet, Emily and Jonathan. Dedicated officer and active member of the Ocean Parkway Jewish Center. Services were held on May 6th at the Ocean Parkway Jewish Center in Brooklyn, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Ocean Parkway Jewish Center.

title: Retail Sales Increased 3% Last Month
description: Retailers' sales at stores open at least a year rose 3 percent in April as shoppers snapped up spring fashions at clothing chains such as the Ann Taylor Stores Corporation and department stores, according to the Goldman Sachs retail composite index.

title: FAMILY FARE
description: For Mother, Prince Charming

title: American Digs Up His Roots in an Irish Flashback
description: ''This is My Father'' follows a Chicago schoolteacher and his teen-age nephew back to their Irish homeland, where the latter strikes the fancy of a couple of schoolgirls. ''Is it true every American has a gun?'' they ask him jokingly. And: ''Do you know any murderers?'' The boy mentions an acquaintance who shot and killed a teacher in math class. This scene may mean to be facetious, but it stands out painfully in the midst of an otherwise gentle, picturesque romance.

title: Council Approves Bonds For Integration Projects
description: After months of dispute, the Yonkers City Council voted unanimously on Wednesday night to approve $32.5 million in court-ordered bonds for new construction projects related to school desegregation, thereby averting likely fines for being held in contempt of court.

title: Lawmakers, Backing Bill For Kosovo, Add Billions
description: The House voted tonight to spend billions of dollars for the NATO bombing campaign in Yugoslavia that it declined to endorse days ago. Its Republican leaders vowed to pour billions more into a military they said President Clinton had gutted.

title: F.C.C. Staff Cites Flaws in Phone Deal Plan
description: The proposed $62 billion combination of SBC Communications Inc. and the Ameritech Corporation, two of the nation's largest regional telephone companies, ''flunks the public interest test'' and should be blocked unless conditions to encourage competition are imposed, according to staff investigators for the Federal Communications Commission.

title: France to Sell Stake In Aerospatiale Matra
description: France said yesterday that it would sell a 17 percent stake in Aerospatiale Matra to the public next month in an initial public offering that will value the new company at between 6.9 billion ($7.4 billion) and 7.9 billion euros.

title: Agreement Reached on Internet Privacy
description: In its second Internet-privacy enforcement action, the Federal Trade Commission said today that a multibillion-dollar investment company had agreed to change the way its World Wide Web site treated information it gathered from children and teen-agers.

title: AT&T Conjures Up Its Vision For Cable, but Can It Deliver?
description: In a series of deals over the last year that culminated in its agreement this week to acquire Mediaone Group Inc., the AT&T Corporation has committed itself to spending more than $90 billion on a technological vision that is largely untested and that may not exist anywhere but on AT&T's drawing boards.

title: Panel Allows Senate Vote on Whitman's Pick for Court
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's nominee to the State Supreme Court cleared an important hurdle today, when the Senate Judiciary Committee moved to allow the full Senate to vote on his confirmation on Monday.

title: Running Fast, but Right in Place
description: For those wishful thinkers who believed the Atlanta Braves were ready to be dethroned and supplanted at the top of the division by the Mets, think again. A month into the season, this is how difficult a task the Mets face if they are to become National League East champions:

title: HEINZ TO TAKE $575 MILLION CHARGE FOR REORGANIZATION
description: The H. J. Heinz Company, the fifth-largest United States food company, said yesterday that it would take a pretax charge against earnings of $575 million in the year that ended April 28 to pay for a worldwide reorganization announced in February. The company, which makes Heinz ketchup, Star Kist tuna and 9-Lives cat food, said it had identified 17 of the 20 plants it planned to close. Those plants represent about 75 percent of the 3,000 to 4,000 jobs that will be eliminated over four years.

title: Decreased Expectations While Getting the Dickens
description: If competing with Charles Dickens were not daunting enough, moviemakers who take on his work also find themselves up against the memories of adaptations past, and none more memorably than ''Great Expectations.'' Fans may argue over whether the book is among Dickens's best, but the 1947 British adaptation, directed by David Lean and brought back with welcome frequency on television, is by any measure a fine movie.

title: Suburbs Enter the Presidential Race
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LINDLEY, NELSON O.
description: LINDLEY-Nelson O. of Falmouth, MA. Died May 2. Husband of the late Priscilla (Chapple) Lindley. Beloved father of twin daughters, Ann L. Grosz of Bedford, NY, and Margaret L. Moncy of Scituate, MA, and son, Nelson O. Lindley, Jr., of Comptche, CA. Also survived by seven grandchildren and a brother, John M. Lindley, Jr., of Montpelier, VT. Funeral services will be private. Memorial contributions to Hospice of Cape Cod, 923 Route 6A, Yarmouthport, MA 02675 or to Gosnold on Cape Cod, PO Box 929, Falmouth, MA 02541.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-16

title: French Restaurants
description: Of all the French restaurants in New York City, these 12 are among the Frenchest. (These summaries, written by Eric Asimov, are taken from Mr. Asimov's and others' dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRUSH, ELLEN SPARRY.
description: BRUSH-Ellen Sparry. The Board and Program Committee of the American Scandinavian Society notes with great sadness the death of Dr. Ellen S. Brush, a devoted and beloved member. Her dedicated and generous support to the entire Scandianvian community will be great missed. Our sincere condolences to husband Charles, children and step-children. The American Scandinavian Society.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FISHMAN, SEYMOUR
description: FISHMAN-Seymour. May 7, 1997. In our hearts and thoughts today and always. We love you and miss you. Your Family

title: SKYNET HOLDINGS IN DEAL TO BUY PONY EXPRESS DELIVERY
description: Skynet Holdings Inc., a package delivery company, entered a preliminary agreement yesterday to acquire Pony Express Delivery Services Inc., based in Atlanta. Financial details were not released. Pony Express has an existing revenue base in excess of $100 million annually, though it had recently experienced losses. It is one of the largest regional ground delivery services in the United States. Skynet, based in Los Angeles, contracts with more than 1,000 independent couriers and uses commercial flights to deliver its packages.

title: Rookies Told to Serve, Protect and Respect
description: In an effort to bridge cultural and racial divides, the Police Department yesterday started a one-day training program intended to help rookie officers become more sensitive to racial and ethnic differences.

title: Don't Lose Cool, Riley Says
description: Coach Pat Riley emphasized ''anger management'' to the Heat today and the need for his players not to get distracted by the Knicks' physical style.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  OSLER, GRACE AND DAVID
description: OSLER-Grace and David. On your 85th and 90th birthdays, we love and admire you, as always. We are forever grateful for your guidance. Lauly and Henry

title: The Living Undead And Icky Beetles
description: ''The Mummy,'' directed by Stephen Sommers, bills itself as ''a full-scale reimagining'' of the 1932 horror classic in which Boris Karloff plays a resuscitated mummy stalking a pretty English girl he believes to be the reincarnation of his long-lost sweetheart. In this remake, Arnold Vosloo, above, plays the mummy, and the woman is Rachel Weisz, playing a plucky English librarian who along with her brother and an American adventurer (Brendan Fraser) has stumbled upon his burial site.

title: Looking to Prosper as a Melting Pot; Utica, Long in Decline, Welcomes an Influx of Refugees
description: They have names like Pavel, Xuan and Fikret, and each has come here, to this defeated factory town in the heart of the Mohawk River Valley, for his or her own terrible reasons.

title: National Democrats Resist State Initiatives
description: Still another state Democratic Party is at odds with the Democratic National Committee over the scheduling of an event leading up to next year's Presidential election.

title: A New Kind of Whistle-Blower; Company Refines Principles of Coaching and Teamwork
description: Carrie-Ann Houser was a year out of college when the American Standard Companies hired her for an entry-level human resources job. A couple of years later, her ''coach'' -- whose main job is shepherding careers -- called on her to revamp the way benefits were administered. Scarcely a year later, she joined a benefits-administration team.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINSTEIN, MIRIAM C.
description: WEINSTEIN-Miriam C. Passed away on May 6, 1999 in Gaitherburg, Md. Devoted wife of David S. Weinstein, who pre-deceased her. Loving mother of Samuel (Sandy) and Marilyn, grandmother of Lisa, Jeffrey and Amy. We think of you and love you. Donations may be made to UJA-Federation.

title: Sports of The Times; Knicks Won't Start Cold This Time
description: SKIRMISH. It's an excellent word, as used by Jeff Van Gundy yesterday in a sentence that began, ''If a skirmish comes about, and inevitably it will. . . . ''

title: Americo Paredes, a Pioneer In Chicano Studies, Dies at 83
description: Americo Paredes, a writer, folklorist and one of the founders of the Chicano studies movement in the 1960's, died on Wednesday at Specialty Hospital in Austin, Tex. He was 83.

title: Lax Monitoring Let China Improve Missiles, Panel Says
description: Senate investigators have concluded that lax monitoring of the launching of American satellites in China and shortfalls in United States intelligence assessments contributed to Beijing's enhancing its ballistic missile fleet using American expertise.

title: Why Give Organs Away?
description: To the Editor:

title: URS AGREES TO BUY DAMES & MOORE FOR $300 MILLION
description: The URS Corporation, which provides infrastructure planning and design, agreed yesterday to buy Dames & Moore Group, an engineering and construction concern, for $16 a share in cash, or about $300 million. URS will also assume about $300 million of debt. Shares in Dames & Moore, which is based in Los Angeles, surged 25 percent, or $3.125, to $15.4375. The deal would create a global engineering company with revenues of about $2 billion and 15,000 employees in more than 30 countries. Its services will include planning, design and program and construction management. Shares of URS, which is based in San Francisco, rose 12.5 cents, to $23.625.

title: ART GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but ours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. *denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLE, ABRAHAM
description: COLE-Abraham. Young Israel of Oceanside expresses heartfelt condolences to our member, Howie Cole, and family on the loss of his beloved father. May the families be comforted among those who mourn for Tzion and Yerushalayim. Evan Torczyner, President Jay Yaacov Schwartz, Rabbi

title: Vatican's Balkan Misstep
description: To the Editor:

title: Adelphi Taps Ferry As Head Coach
description: In a move from a Division III Panthers team to a Division II Panthers team, Jim Ferry, who coached Plymouth State College in New Hampshire last season, was named head coach at Adelphi on Long Island. Ferry, a native of Elmont, N.Y., set a school mark for victories with a 22-8 record at Plymouth State in 1998-99.

title: Corrections
description: A photograph on Wednesday showing Conrad Anker, who discovered a body on Mount Everest last week that is believed to be that of the British climber George Mallory, omitted the credit. The photographer was Galen Rowell and the agency was Mountain Light.

title: Man Is Charged With Murder In '87 Killing of Police Officer
description: After a 12-year investigation, Queens detectives announced yesterday that they had arrested a suspect in the killing of a police officer who was shot during a botched attempt to steal a car radio.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: A Coup for Trump Handled Discreetly

title: Care at Rikers Island
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIRNBAUM, MILDRED
description: BIRNBAUM-Mildred. 84. Of Boca Raton, FL, died Wednesday, May 5 at the Boca Raton Community Hospital. Born in New York City to Phillip & Beatrice Behrman. Mrs. Birnbaum wintered in Boca Raton from New York and Connecticut before permanently moving here 12 years ago. Mrs. Birnbaum is the daughter of world-famous doll maker Beatrice Alexander of the Alexander Doll Company in New York City. Mildred was a renowned artist exhibiting her paintings in Palm Beach, Connecticut, and New York and was featured in Who's Who in American Art. She was preceded in death by her husband Richard E. Birnbaum in 1992. She is survived by her loving son William and his wife Kathleen of Greenwich, CT and beloved granddaughter Stephanie Birnbaum. A Funeral Service will be held at 11:00 am on Friday, May 7 at the Boca Raton Mausoleum with entombment to follow. The family requests expressions of sympathy be made to the Make A Wish Foundation, P.O. Box 17377, Fort Lauderdale, FL 33318.

title: INSIDE
description: China Report Released

title: Suburbs Enter the Presidential Race
description: To the Editor:

title: Detectors to Be Used In Elementary Schools
description: Elementary schools in Elizabeth will become the first such schools in the state to be protected by metal detectors, school officials said yesterday.

title: Belated Bragging Rights for Lincoln
description: AS the battle for first place in luxury vehicle sales heated up last year, the Ford Motor Company insisted that winning was not its goal for Lincoln. Rather, its priorities were building the brand, entering new segments of the market and attracting younger buyers.

title: Gay Group Faults Defense
description: A group of advocates of equal rights for gay Americans criticized a police officer's defense lawyer yesterday for suggesting that Abner Louima's injuries were caused by an act of consensual sex with another man, and not by an act of police brutality.

title: A Few Tips on a Couple of New York Cabbies Who Are Not Hailed
description: No pun intended, but the tale of two cabbies called ''Fare Games'' is pedestrian.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: After years of planning, Jean-Louis Palladin has finally opened a restaurant in New York. It has been a circuitous route from his native Gascony to Washington to Las Vegas, where he was one of the first celebrity chefs to brave the wilds of the desert, opening his restaurant Napa. But from the moment he arrived in Las Vegas, he plotted to make New York his home base.

title: Corrections
description: A highlight listing and program entry on page 47 of the Television section on Sunday, for a program on American Movie Classics at 10 p.m. tonight, is outdated. The premiere of the series ''Paramour'' has been replaced by an encore presentation of ''Remember WENN.''

title: Short Season, but Full-Size Playoffs
description: This year's post-season matchups don't include Chicago, but they do include last season's runner-up, the Utah Jazz, who will fight it out with a red-hot San Antonio Spurs team in the West. In the East, the Pacers could be poised to fill the playoff gap left by the Bulls.

title: NATO Says Bombing Has Serb Forces Pinned Down and Losing Equipment
description: NATO said today that its bombing had destroyed half the Serbian army's ammunition stores in Kosovo and 200 tanks and other armored vehicles, artillery pieces and trucks -- about 20 percent of all Serbian heavy equipment in the province.

title: The Armory as a Museum: From Veritas to Vanitas
description: People drawing up lists of art-viewing opportunities for this weekend might put the International Fine Art Fair near the top. The show, which opens today at the Seventh Regiment Armory on Park Avenue, is arguably, after the Asian Art Fair, the best New York has to offer.

title: New Video Releases
description: Another Day in Paradise

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BONOFF, CELIA
description: BONOFF-Celia Haubenstock, of New York City and Hillsdale, NY. Widow of Morris. Mother of Edith Leah Birnbaum and Barbara Gettinger, mother-in-law of Leonard Birnbaum and Stephen Gettinger. Grandmother of Richard, Jane and Peter Birnbaum and Andrew, Matthew and Thomas Gettinger, and twelve great-grandchildren. We will all miss her.

title: INSIDE ART
description: Lost Treasure To Be Auctioned

title: 'Depravity' Is Issue For Death Penalty Jury
description: A jury began considering yesterday whether Thomas Koskovich should receive a death sentence or life in prison for the murders of two pizza deliverymen he helped lure to a secluded, abandoned house in Franklin, N.J., in April 1997.

title: Macedonian Troops Said to Push 1,000 Refugees Back
description: Officials from the office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees accused Macedonian soldiers today of pushing as many as 1,000 ethnic Albanian refugees back into Kosovo on Wednesday night.

title: Dynamic Sisters Roll Along In Rome
description: The scene is the same this spring at the Foro Italico the clay just as red, the cypresses just as green -- but the women's roles are changing. The Williams sisters are walking tall and making big strides, and the vast majority of their competitors are not keeping up.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PERON, EVA
description: PERON-Eva. May 7, 1919. On your 80th birthday your star shines brighter than even you could have ever imagined. You are truly Santa Evita

title: On My Mind; 100 Brave Arabs
description: The Palestinian state will be created. It will be a dictatorship -- ranging from stifling to murderous, and most of the time both.

title: C.I.A. Veteran Retires Again, After Rebuilding Spy Operation
description: Jack Downing, a legendary cold warrior who came out of retirement two years ago to help revive the Central Intelligence Agency's badly depleted clandestine espionage service, is stepping down as the agency's top spy, officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EVERITT, EDGAR ROGERS.
description: EVERITT-Edgar Rogers. On May 5th, age 83 of Great Neck, New York. Beloved husband of Sylvia. Dear devoted father of Sue Hudgins, Judith and David. Loving grandfather of Charles, Karen and James Bohovich, Ethan and Seth Abrams, and Anthony & Gregory Everitt, and great grandfather of Kristin Bohovich. We will miss the calm strength of his presence, his kind gentleness and quick humor. He died peacefully at home-he left us too soon. Funeral services on Saturday at 10 AM, at Flushing Cemetery. The Fairchild Funeral Chapel, Manhasset.

title: A Measured Life Study Of a Mercurial Genius
description: JACQUELINE DU PRE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZEISEL, WILLIAMS, ILSE,
description: ZEISEL-WILLIAMS-Ilse, 89. Died on May 6, from emphysema in a nursing home in a suburb of Trenton, NJ, where she lived with her husband, Frederick W. Williams. Ilse was born in Austria, educated at the University of Vienna and the Sorbonne, collaborated in pioneering sociological research with her brother Hans (deceased), earned high credits as an athlete but refused the honor to compete for Austria in the 1936 Olympics in Berlin, moved to the USA and studied at Columbia University, entered the advertising research field, became a resourceful research entrepreneur, a life member of the American Association for Public Opinion Research. She is mourned by her many friends and relatives, notably among the latter her husband, her niece Jeane Richards Brolin, and her cousins, Elizabeth Beckman and Claire Beckman Morgan...Carried away on lilac-scented breezes, hail and farewell, dear warrior.

title: California Devises An 'Open' Primary
description: California officials believe they have finally found a way to hold an ''open'' Presidential primary next year as required by a new state law and at the same time not violate long-standing national party rules that forbid such primaries.

title: The British Vote in Elections Remodeling Political System
description: Britons voted today in elections that will give Scotland its first legislature in nearly 300 years and Wales its first ever.

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: MIDDLE EAST

title: 'Twain' Is Back, Peppery as Ever
description: The old man in the white suit puffs on a cigar and considers Satan, a figure blamed by everybody for the sins of everybody else. ''Let's hear his side,'' Mark Twain says. ''Anybody who's charged with being spiritual head of four-fifths of the human race, and political head of all of it, must have executive ability.''

title: Vatican's Balkan Misstep; Albania in Peril
description: To the Editor:

title: Please Don't Pet The Dragon
description: Americans see animals as pets. The Chinese see them as everything else: emblems of the four directions of the compass and symbols of longevity, good luck, protection and love of virtue.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: OIL PLUNGES. Crude oil fell 3.5 percent after the Royal Dutch/Shell Group said exporters might lack the discipline to curtail output. In New York, crude oil for June delivery fell 66 cents, to $18.32 a barrel.

title: West Point Looks for Private Money to Improve Its Campus
description: Forced to compete with increasingly wealthy universities while making do on a tight post-cold-war defense budget, the United States Military Academy at West Point today is announcing the first major private fund-raising campaign in the history of the service academies.

title: Irabu Pitches for His Job, Not to Beat a Countryman
description: When Hideki Irabu pitches against Seattle's Mac Suzuki at Yankee Stadium Friday night, it will mark what is believed to be the first time Japanese pitchers have started against each other in the major leagues. But Irabu will have no time to worry about beating a fellow countryman: he could be pitching to save his job with the Yankees.

title: Four Stowaways Found Aboard a Cargo Ship
description: Four men from Colombia were found hiding on board a cargo ship that docked in Elizabeth on Wednesday, the authorities said.

title: Elements of a Peace Deal
description: Much diplomatic work remains, but the framework for a reasonable political settlement in Kosovo may be falling into place, thanks in part to Russia's constructive role as a peacemaker. A critical move came yesterday, when Moscow parted company with Serbia and formally endorsed the use of an international security force in Kosovo after the war ends. In joining the United States and its allies in support of this and other core principles for a peace deal, Russia has left Slobodan Milosevic increasingly isolated in his fight with NATO.

title: Toll Increase Unlikely, Parkway Official Says
description: Tolls on the Garden State Parkway will probably not be raised next year, state highway officials said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAYTON, SCOTT J.
description: PAYTON-Scott J. On May 1, 1999. Beloved son of Doris Payton-Jacobs and the late Ralph W. Payton, loving brother of Heather K. Payton, Jasmine C.S. Jacobs, adored stepson of Brian L. Jacobs. He is mourned by two nieces, aunts, uncles, cousins and numerous friends. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, Sunday, May 9, 7 to 9 PM. Service Monday, May 10, 10 AM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street. Interment at Calverton National Cemetery.

title: Impasse Between ESPN and Major League Baseball Was Bound to Occur
description: As ESPN's chief baseball analyst, Joe Morgan is rarely called upon to analyze the corporate doings of his employer. But that changed on Tuesday when ESPN sued Major League Baseball in Federal court to block baseball's termination of the cable network's regular-season deal after this season. Baseball has been irate for 16 months over ESPN's plan to shift three Sunday night games in September to ESPN2 in favor of National Football League games.

title: Former Leader of Sweden to Examine U.N. Role in Rwanda Killings
description: Secretary-General Kofi Annan has chosen Ingvar Carlsson, a former Swedish Prime Minister, as co-chairman of an inquiry into the United Nations role in the mass killings in Rwanda in 1994, diplomats said today.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I'd like to name the baby America, but I have to talk to my wife and parents first.''

title: Nina Bovasso
description: Clementine Gallery

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANCUSO, HARRIET STEIN.
description: MANCUSO-Harriet Stein. Of New York City. Beloved wife of Robert, devoted mother of Rebecca, Miranda and Paul; daughter of Bernice and Bernard and sister of Frank, died on Wednesday, May 5, 1999 at age 48. The love of her family helped strenghten her during an almost four year struggle with pancreatic cancer. Her courage, especially during this past year, inspired her many friends and loved ones. Although her life was tragically cut short, her talents, love of family and generous spirit were abundant and will last forever. An honors graduate of New York University and Cornell Law School, she was a gifted and accomplished lawyer rising to partner at Davis and Cox. All who knew Harriet will miss her, each in a different and special way, for she touched all who were lucky enough to be her friend. In lieu of flowers the family suggests donations be made to The Calvary Hospice Fund, 1740 Eastchester Road, Bronx, New York 10461. Services were private.

title: Amid Timeless Village Greens, a Trove of Americana
description: One day, in a lazy, procrastinating mood, I spent an hour or so flipping through my road atlas. In between the curvy blue lines of the rivers and the straight purple interstates, there was some fine print in red that caught my eye: ''Hitchcock Chair Factory,'' ''Clock Museum,'' ''Lamp Museum.'' These places were clustered in the hilly northwestern corner of Connecticut, suggesting a kind of secret birthing ground of furniture and household objects.

title: FOR CHILDREN
description: Theater

title: SPARE TIMES
description: ATTRACTIONS

title: Foreign Affairs; The Rogues' Gallery
description: Imagine what it would sound like if the world's biggest rogues -- North Korea's Kim Jong Il, Iraq's Saddam Hussein, Serbia's Slobodan Milosevic and Syria's Hafez al-Assad -- had a conference call about Yugoslavia.

title: KOSOVO UPDATE
description: DIPLOMACY

title: Cleaning Up the Big Cars
description: The news from Detroit was heartening this week -- robust automobile sales, driven mainly by purchases of sport utility vehicles, minivans and a lot of those fancy pickup trucks that are beginning to look as comfortable as luxury cars. The news from Washington was equally heartening -- a set of tough new Federal regulations that, for the first time, will subject those very same vehicles to the strict pollution standards that apply to ordinary cars. For good measure, the Clinton Administration also announced new regulations that will force the oil companies to produce cleaner fuels.

title: No Right to Bear Arms; Nation of Gun Lovers
description: To the Editor:

title: Malfunction of F.A.A. Computer Creates Havoc at 3 Airports
description: An air traffic control computer on Long Island that is the first of a new generation being installed nationwide failed early yesterday, creating havoc at La Guardia, Newark and Philadelphia Airports.

title: A Rhinestone That's Worth Fighting For
description: A man's home is his you-know-what, even if that home is only a dilapidated eyesore built on toxic landfill and separated by a chain-link fence from an airport runway. But as they say, it's all in the eye of the beholder. And to Darryl Kerrigan (Michael Caton), a happy-go-lucky tow-truck driver and hero of ''The Castle,'' this property is nothing less than an irreplaceable little patch of heaven on earth, a storehouse of golden memories.

title: No Right to Bear Arms
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the softening of the call for formal independence from China by the main opposition party on Taiwan misidentified the founder of the governing Nationalist Party. It was Sun Yat-sen, not Chiang Kai-shek.

title: Stalking That Rare Recording
description: Take pity on the next generation of music fiends, for they may not know the pleasure of loitering in little record stores.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about the lists of witnesses in the Microsoft antitrust trial referred incorrectly to comments by Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson about the earlier testimony of a witness, Richard Schmalensee of the Sloan School of Management at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. The judge questioned an apparent contradiction in Mr. Schmalensee's testimony; he did not question his overall credibility.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Business Day yesterday with the continuation of a front-page article about AT&T's cable television ambitions misstated the role of the man shown, Amos B. Hostetter. He is the largest shareholder, not the chief executive, of Mediaone Group, the cable company that has agreed to be acquired by AT&T. The caption also gave an incorrect date; the picture was taken at a news conference in May 1997, not at a news briefing on Wednesday.

title: Trade Envoys Again Fail to Choose Leader
description: Negotiations over a new leader for the World Trade Organization are likely to remain deadlocked until at least next week, envoys to the group said today, and there was increasing speculation that neither of the two finalists would get the job.

title: Philips and I.B.M. in Software Venture
description: The International Business Machines Corporation, the No. 1 computer maker, and Royal Philips Electronics N.V. will jointly develop speech-recognition software to broaden its use on computers and electronics.

title: Fed Chief's Remarks Cause 3 Key Gauges to Stumble
description: Stocks fell yesterday, after Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, cast an early pall over trading with comments that revived fears of tighter credit.

title: Misplaced Patriotism
description: The nation owes two principled Democratic Senators from North Dakota its thanks. Kent Conrad and Byron Dorgan have both announced that they will oppose the so-called Flag Desecration Amendment approved by an 11-to-7 margin in the Senate Judiciary Committee last week. The constitutional amendment, which would allow Federal laws banning flag desecration, is a sad example of patriotism gone awry. It would undermine the right of free expression in the name of protecting the flag that symbolizes that freedom.

title: Jordan's King Heading West With a Plea on Debt
description: Since his father's death propelled him to the throne, King Abdullah of Jordan has been a man in motion. He has installed a new Government, moved to shore up his country's troubled economy and scurried around the region to patch up relations with Arab neighbors.

title: Suburbs Enter the Presidential Race
description: To the Editor:

title: Russians Satisfied at Return To the Diplomatic Spotlight
description: President Boris N. Yeltsin's foreign-policy aides greeted the new framework for peace in Kosovo with a hint of pleasure at their return to the diplomatic spotlight and a determination that the country not appear to be merely a tool of the West.

title: Helms, Citing Inquiry, Bars Confirmation Hearing for Holbrooke
description: Senator Jesse Helms, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, said today that it would be ''insane'' to hold confirmation hearings for Richard C. Holbrooke until the Justice Department had turned over internal documents about its ethics investigation of the longtime diplomat.

title: Fiona Rae
description: Luhring Augustine

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region.

title: Liquid Audio Plans Initial Stock Offering
description: Liquid Audio Inc., which makes software used to store, distribute and sell music digitally over the Internet, said this week that it had filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for an initial public offering.

title: Link to City Most Obvious When It Fails
description: MARTA COLON will tell you that all is far from perfect with Access-a-Ride, the program of door-to-door transportation for disabled people that is managed by New York City Transit. She found out the hard way. Then again, Miss Colon has found out most things the hard way since she was born with cerebral palsy 17 years ago.

title: Stock Plan Roils South Africa Company
description: Two board members of South Africa's most prominent black empowerment company have announced their resignations in the face of increasing outrage over a plan to award themselves and two other board members stock options worth more than $20 million.

title: Yugoslavia Agrees to Visit by U.N. Team
description: Officials said today that Belgrade has agreed to let a United Nations mission visit Yugoslavia, including Kosovo, to assess relief needs, and the leader of an advance team representing several agencies left immediately for Belgrade.

title: In AT&T Deal, Microsoft Buys Itself a Stake In 'Post-PC' Era
description: With a $5 billion investment in the AT&T Corporation, the Microsoft Corporation yesterday secured an inside track in supplying software for the high-speed communications networks of the future. But it has by no means assured that it will be the dominant supplier, as it is today in the personal computer industry.

title: With Shaking Finger, Accuser Points to Accused
description: He looked small and frail in a dark blue suit that seemed three sizes too large. Abner Louima gazed across the packed courtroom. He blinked several times, and his dark eyes seemed to widen at the sight of so many faces focused entirely on him.

title: L. N. Tallur
description: Bose Pacia Modern

title: FALCON PRODUCTS SAYS IT WILL ACQUIRE SHELBY WILLIAMS
description: The furniture maker Falcon Products Inc. said yesterday that it planned to acquire a competitor, Shelby Williams Industries, for $16.50 a share, or about $148 million. Falcon, a St. Louis-based maker of furniture for office and food service companies, had 1998 revenues of $143.4 million. Shelby Williams, a Chicago-based manufacturer of contract seating for the restaurant, lodging, health care and college markets, had 1998 revenues of $165.9 million. The shares of Shelby Williams rose 16 percent, gaining $2.25 each, to $16. Falcon stock rose 22 percent, gaining $1.8125, to $9.8125.

title: ON STAGE AND OFF
description: For 'Parade,' Life After Death

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO UP FURTHER. The euro rose for a third day as Russia agreed on the need for an international military presence in Kosovo, increasing speculation on a peace agreement. In New York, the euro rose to $1.0802 from $1.0741.

title: Knee Injury May Foil Any Deal for Bonilla
description: Bobby Bonilla's closest acquaintances say they believe the Mets are trying to trade the struggling 36-year-old slugger. But they also say they believe that Bonilla's ailing right knee is scaring suitors away and that Bonilla, who sustained a partial ligament tear early in spring training, may be better off taking more time off or going on the disabled list.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGMAN, DR. ROBERT P.
description: BERGMAN-Dr. Robert P. The Trustees, members and staff of the Association of Art Museum Directors mourn the death of Dr. Robert P. Bergman, Director of The Cleveland Museum of Art, and Former President of the Association. His leadership, intellect, and sense of humor will be missed by all of us who had the privilege of working with him. Dr. Bergman's commitment to making our museums truly receptive to diverse audiences at The Walters Art Gallery and at The Cleveland Museum of Art was a source of inspiration to his many colleagues throughout this country. Our deepest sympathy to his wife, daughter and members of his family. Vishakha N. Desai, President Association of Art Museum Directors Millicent Hall Gaudieri, Exec. Dir. Association of Art Museum Directors

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Before the Waiting Started, Beckett Loved His Mother
description: Before Gogo and Didi began their long wait for Godot, before Clov and Hamm wound up the alarm clock, before Krapp began making tapes, Molloy resolved to go and see his mother.

title: The Test for Governor Whitman
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey is facing a leadership test that will provide a measure of her fitness for higher office. For years she ignored or minimized complaints that state troopers were engaging in racial profiling, the practice of stopping motorists based on their skin color. Now, even as racial profiling is belatedly being curbed, she is pushing hard to get her Attorney General, Peter Verniero, a seat on the State Supreme Court. Mr. Verniero not only had oversight responsibility for the police agency that engaged in the profiling, he has been judged unqualified for the Court by the state bar association. By trying to muscle this nomination through the State Senate, Mrs. Whitman has shown herself more concerned with rewarding a flawed political ally than with making a high-quality judicial appointment.

title: John Irving Tale, Halved but Big
description: So after three hours and 15 minutes in the wilds of New England with orphans and abortionists, prostitutes and health nuts, cranky old trainmen, stouthearted nurses and mischievous tomboys, are you up for another three?

title: Guerrilla Pledge Not to Disarm Contradicts Goal of the Allies
description: A senior Kosovo Liberation Army official said today that the guerrilla force would not allow itself to be disarmed, though that is a central tenet of the proposed peace deal announced by allied diplomats in Germany.

title: Exodus From Kosovo Produces First United States Citizen
description: His fists balled tight and his eyes opened on a new world, the first American was born here today from the Kosovar exodus, less than 24 hours after his mother arrived from a refugee camp in Macedonia.

title: Litton Makes Bids for Two Shipbuilders
description: Litton Industries made unsolicited offers today to buy both Newport News Shipbuilding and Avondale Industries, two shipbuilders that were already planning to merge. The two transactions would have a total value of $1.8 billion plus $600 million in assumed debt.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: GENESIS HEALTH VENTURES CO., Kennett Square, Pa., said its Neighborcare pharmacy unit had selected Cardinal Health Inc., the second-largest U.S. drug wholesaler, as its primary pharmaceutical supplier.

title: BASEBALL: The Most Cosmopolitan Met; Olerud Is Enjoying the Sounds of a City and His Bat
description: He is a quiet man playing baseball in a rambunctious city and yet John Olerud is clearly thriving amid the noise, on the field and off.

title: High Court Says Drug Conviction Is Basis to Deny Teaching License
description: New York State's highest court ruled today that the New York City Board of Education has the right to deny teaching licenses to people convicted of drug offenses.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABRAMS, ARTHUR
description: ABRAMS-Arthur. The National Jewish Outreach Program mourns the passing of Arthur Abrams, father of Judy (and Michael) Steinhardt. The Steinhardts have played a vital role in NJOP's efforts to assure a Jewish future for American Jewry, and their leadership and philanthropy is recognized throughout the Jewish community. Our sincere condolences to the Steinhardts, to Judy's mother, Ruth Abrams, and to the entire family. Yehi Zichro Baruch. Rabbi Ephraim Z. Buchwald, Dir.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: 63 Deaths In Congo Laid to Virus Akin to Ebola
description: The disease that has killed 63 people in northeastern Congo is caused not by Ebola but by a similar virus that is nearly as deadly but not as contagious, doctors reported today.

title: Corrections
description: An article and chart yesterday about competing school construction proposals in New York City misstated the borough-by-borough allotment of new classroom space in some copies. Under Chancellor Rudy Crew's plan, 16.7 percent of all new classroom slots would be in the Bronx, 15.3 percent in Brooklyn, 6.9 percent in Manhattan, 59.5 percent in Queens and 1.6 percent in Staten Island. Under a proposal by a majority of the Board of Education, 15 percent of the new slots would be in the Bronx, 11.9 percent in Brooklyn, 6.1 percent in Manhattan, 63 percent in Queens and 4 percent in Staten Island.

title: Walls Are Few on a Block Where Tornado Survivors Take Stock
description: What is left of the 900 block of Windermere Drive still curves gently on this Oklahoma City suburb's western edge, but it is a jumble of splinters, shards and half-loaded pickup trucks now, its few remaining walls rarely rising higher than four feet.

title: Daisy Youngblood
description: McKee Gallery

title: Don't Quarantine Our Scientists
description: The evidence of Chinese espionage has cast much-needed attention on improving security at our nuclear weapons laboratories after years of security practices that have been insufficiently tough and vigilant.

title: Senate Votes to Drop Barriers Between Nation's Financial Industries
description: The Senate approved legislation tonight that would overhaul the nation's financial system, removing barriers largely created during the Depression that have limited the ability of banks, insurance companies and securities firms to expand into one another's businesses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHONFELD, PHILIP
description: SCHONFELD-Philip. On Saturday, May 1, 1999, of East Orange, N.J. Memorial contributions in his memory may be made to the United Jewish Appeal of Metro West, 901 Route 10, Whippany, N.J. 07981.

title: Insurers Agree to Pay on Victims' Pre-Holocaust Policies
description: Several large European insurance companies agreed for the first time today to pay claims on prewar policies of Holocaust victims, under a formula that reflects present-day values. The settlement could potentially result in billions of dollars in payments.

title: Democrats in Senate Offer Measures to Control Guns
description: Seizing what they hoped was new momentum for gun control after the shootings in Littleton, Colo., Senate Democrats today unveiled a broad package of proposals that Republicans, though skeptical, did not dismiss out of hand.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRASIER, DUDLEY
description: FRASIER-Dudley. 75. Died after a brief illness on May 2. A graduate of Harvard, he was Publicity Director at Little Brown in Boston for several years. He then moved to New York where he worked at Rinehart before becoming an executive editor at Popular Library and New American Library. He later worked as editor-at-large at Pocket Books where he remained until his retirement. Dudley will be greatly missed by all his friends and colleagues in the publishing community. In lieu of flowers, contributions to The Cabrini Hospice at 227 East 19th Street, New York, NY 10003 would be appreciated.

title: Cable and Wireless In Bid for I.D.C. of Japan
description: Cable and Wireless P.L.C. said yesterday that it would offer 55.1 billion yen, or $456.7 million, to acquire International Digital Communications Inc., a Japanese phone company. Cable and Wireless, a British telecommunications company, which already has a 17.7 percent stake in the Japanese concern, said it would also assume debt of 33.2 billion yen.

title: Corrections
description: A picture in the World Briefing column yesterday with a report about Nigeria was published in error. It showed Gen. Sani Abacha, the Nigerian President who died last year, not the current President, Gen. Abdulsalami Abubakar, who signed a constitution intended to insure a smooth transition to civilian rule.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Every U.S. Income Group Seems to Be Spending More

title: A Drug Pusher's Life Is Rotten in Denmark
description: ''Trainspotting'' was a darkly thrilling film about the lives of Scottish heroin addicts. ''Pulp Fiction'' was a brilliantly original look into petty criminals' lives, including heroin sale and use. ''Pusher,'' a new Danish film, is proof of just how boring a week in the life of a real heroin dealer probably is.

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Terps Are Hoyas' Prize for First Victory
description: Georgetown, which won its first National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament game in women's lacrosse on Wednesday, next faces mighty Maryland tomorrow in a quarterfinal match at College Park, Md. The undefeated Terrapins, seeking their fifth straight national championship, are seeded first in Division I, as is the College of New Jersey in Division III. The Lions, also unbeaten, are after their eighth title in the last nine seasons.

title: Kelley to Face Little-Known Fill-In
description: Kevin Kelley, a featherweight from Queens, is looking forward to his match in Las Vegas, Nev., tomorrow night on the undercard of the Erik Morales-Juan Carlos Ramirez featherweight championship show. Unfortunately, Kelley does not know whom he will be fighting.

title: 'Retroactive 1'
description: Martinez Gallery

title: Training Ford's Luxury Quartet to Sing in 4-Part Harmony
description: UNTIL recently, the Ford Motor Company's only prestige brand was Lincoln, which for decades was No. 2 to Cadillac in the American luxury market but was virtually unknown in much of the world. But in March, with Ford having acquired a fourth luxury marque, the company formed the Premier Automotive Group as an umbrella for Lincoln, Jaguar, Aston Martin and Volvo. That group is selling twice as many luxury cars as General Motors, and within five years its divisions expect to add at least 250,000 sales, putting Ford on par with the BMW Group and DaimlerChrysler, which produces Mercedes-Benz automobiles.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, GENE
description: SCHWARTZ-Gene. Beloved husband of Barbara, loving father of Toni and Douglas, beloved brother of Bob, died May 4, 1999. Gene was both an owner and a well liked and respected creative director of Laurie Records. He discovered and produced Hall of Famer Dion. He was also responsible for recording or discovering many other artists such as The Chiffons, Gary U.S. Bonds, the Snoopy Records, The Belmonts, The Mystics and many others. He died in Newport Beach, CA after a long illness. Gene is also survived by sisters-inlaw Vickie, Gloria and Jean, as well as three nieces and a nephew. Services at Abbey Bat Kol Chapel, 3340 John St. in Los Angeles, CA.

title: Another Bittersweet Victory for a Watchdog
description: AT last! Honest man discovered!

title: Louis R. Ross, 67; Ex-Ford Vice Chairman Had Key Taurus Role
description: Louis R. Ross, a former vice chairman of the Ford Motor Company who oversaw the introduction in 1985 of the Ford Taurus, which became one of its most successful cars and helped the company recover from low profits and quality problems, died on Sunday in Naples, Fla. He was 67.

title: MCI WORLDCOM SAYS IT HAS ENDED BID FOR NEXTEL
description: MCI Worldcom Inc., the No. 2 United States long-distance phone company, confirmed yesterday that its negotiations to acquire Nextel Communications Inc., the nationwide cellular provider, had ended without agreement. The companies did not give a reason. MCI Worldcom was negotiating to buy Nextel for a price that was said to be as much as $45 a share in stock, or about $16.9 billion. Nextel also has about $8 billion in debt. In January, MCI Worldcom backed out of a bidding war for Airtouch Communications Inc., the largest United States cellular company. MCI Worldcom's shares fell $5 each yesterday, to $84.625, after gaining $6.6875 on Wednesday, amid rumors that the talks had ended. Nextel fell 75 cents, to $35.125.

title: Retail Boom Isn't Reliant Only on Rich
description: Michael Gonzales, a waiter from Los Angeles who earns about $25,000 a year, has been in a buying mood lately. ''Things are going well for me these days,'' he reflected, while shopping at Home Depot in Los Angeles for supplies to refurbish his apartment. ''It's not like I'm spending mountains of cash. Just enough for a few comforts.''

title: Rethink Drug Laws? Rockefeller Would
description: To the Editor:

title: Album of the Week
description: RHYTHM AND BRASS: ''MORE MONEY JUNGLE . . . ELLINGTON EXPLORATIONS'' -- (Koch Jazz). Tributes to Duke Ellington's genius can take many forms, and Rhythm and Brass is the latest band to point this out. Its new album has a lot of the intelligent spunk that used to be associated with the best New York jazz of the 1970's and 80's: a brash way of working fast and loose on music with a high conceptual content, of being startling without striking a note of pretension.

title: Study Depicts Mainlanders In Hong Kong As Nightmare
description: With fears of an immigration crisis already at a fever pitch here, the Hong Kong government warned today that the former British colony would be economically devastated by an influx of well over a million newly eligible migrants from mainland China.

title: Excerpts From Speech To Bankers in Chicago
description: Following are excerpts from a speech yesterday by Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, at the 35th annual conference on Bank Structure and Competition of the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago:

title: Robert P. Bergman, 53, Head Of Cleveland Museum of Art
description: Robert P. Bergman, director of the Cleveland Museum of Art since 1993 and a nationally recognized spokesman for arts institutions, died yesterday at University Hospitals in Cleveland. He would have been 54 on May 17.

title: Grumbling and 'Oohs' at 'Star Wars' Screenings
description: Perish the thought! Will the new ''Star Wars'' prove to be a bit of a disappointment?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBERTS, MARY LEE.
description: ROBERTS-Mary Lee. Mary Lee Kilthau Roberts, 83, of Sanibel Island, Florida and part time resident of Cape Porpoise, Maine died Monday, May 3 at the Hilton Head Medical Center and Clinics, Hilton Head Island, SC. She was born in Lawrenceburg, IN, daughter of Raymond and Lucile Kilthau and attended school at Ogontz School, Rydal, PA. She lived in Port Washington, Long Island, NY while her husband practiced law in Flushing, NY and moved to Sanibel Island, Florida in 1988. After the passing of her husband, Donald W.
