Roberts, in March 1998, she entered The Preston Health Center at the Cypress, and later The Rogers Center at TidePointe, both on Hilton Head Island in South Carolina, for the treatment of various illnesses. Surviving are three sons, Donald B. Roberts of Cambridge, MA, Raymond K. Roberts of Savannah, GA, Phillip L. Roberts of Arvada, CO, and five grandchildren. A funeral was held Wednesday, May 5, at The Island Funeral Home, Hilton Head Island. Burial will be at the Flushing Cemetery, Flushing, NY.

title: Hitler Meets Freud on a Blood-Red Couch
description: Adolf Hitler may have been many things, but it seems unlikely that he was the colossal bore portrayed in the hyperthyroid hodgepodge of pseudo-psychotherapy called ''The Empty Mirror.''

title: Court Calls Limits on Data-Scrambling Software Unconstitutional
description: The United States Government's restrictions on the export of data-scrambling software are unconstitutional, a Federal appeals court in California ruled yesterday.

title: Long Island Jury Chooses Lethal Injection for Killer in the Brutal Slayings of 3 Women
description: A jury decided today that a former postal worker who had been found guilty of murdering three women should be put to death by lethal injection.

title: Court Finds Welfare Pays Too Little for Rent
description: An appellate court ruled yesterday that state officials do not provide welfare recipients with enough money to cover the rent for an apartment in New York City.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHESLOW, NETTIE
description: SHESLOW-Nettie. At age 93. Of Miami Beach, Florida. Beloved wife of the late Julius Sheslow, loving sister of the late Philip Nadel, devoted mother of Seena Cowan and Everett Sheslow. Adoring grandmother of Stacey Kaplan, Jeffrey Cowan, Bruce Cowan, Faith Wheeler & Stephen Sheslow, revered great grandmother of Jared and Ryan Kaplan and Madeline and Elizabeth Wheeler. Services Friday, May 7th, 11AM Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Scientist's Lawyer Makes a Vigorous Denial
description: Far from being an atomic spy, Wen Ho Lee is a loyal American who cooperated in the Government's hunt for real spies, his lawyer has told two newspapers.

title: Mexican Heir To Keep Reins At Televisa
description: The young heir who took over Televisa, Mexico's largest television network, has survived family feuds and management crises to finish refinancing his hold on the company without yielding control outside his family.

title: Ewing Gives Go Sign, Ice Bag or No
description: Patrick Ewing participated in each drill today as the Knicks began to prepare for their first-round playoff series against the Miami Heat. Afterward, an ice bag was wrapped around his sore left Achilles' tendon. Never fear, Ewing was confident that he would be in uniform for as many games as it takes to advance.

title: Churchill Adds Hollywood Park to Its Collection
description: Churchill Downs, where the Kentucky Derby was run last Saturday before a crowd of 151,051, announced yesterday that it had signed an agreement to buy Hollywood Park race track in Inglewood, 11 miles southwest of downtown Los Angeles, for $140 million in cash in the latest and longest step toward extending its racing and gambling operations coast to coast.

title: Stanley L. Rosenthal, 69, Expert On the Tracking of Hurricanes
description: Dr. Stanley Lawrence Rosenthal, a former Government meteorologist who advanced the technology of tracking the formation and movements of hurricanes, died on April 24 at his home in Miami. He was 69.

title: Poetic Landscape, Nightmarish Exile: A Chinese Victim of the 60's Revolution
description: ''Xiu Xiu: The Sent Down Girl,'' a tragic story spun out of China's Cultural Revolution, has irritated the Chinese authorities not just because it was made surreptitiously and without official approval, but because of its damning assessment of Mao Zedong's grandiose experiment in mass indoctrination.

title: In Germany, Clinton Listens To Refugee Tales of Misery
description: They lie on black metal bunk beds, eight to a room, but they do not sleep. They are safe now, but night after night these refugees from Kosovo relive the horrors of their homeland.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RENEHAN, JOHN P.
description: RENEHAN-John P. On May 6, 1999 of Bergenfield, New Jersey. Husband of Mary K. Renehan (nee Hanlon); father of Robert J., John R. & the late Richard Renehan. Grandfather of James, Vincent and Elizabeth. Funeral liturgy at St. John's R.C. Church, Bergenfield, New Jersey, Saturday at 10AM. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Valhalla, NY. Visiting at Riewerts Memorial Home, 187 S. Washington Avenue, Bergenfield, New Jersey, Friday 2-4 and 7-9PM

title: Suburbs Enter the Presidential Race
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHINDEL, FAY HIRSHOWITZ.
description: SCHINDEL-Fay Hirshowitz. On May 6, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Kalman S. Loved and loving mother of Jane Farman and Andrew and Stephen Schindel. Cherished grandmother of Janet Bernstein, Jonathan Schindel, Deanna Stecker, Emily Schmalholz and Sharon, Robert and Richard Farman. Adored great-grandmother of Joshua, Daniel, Zachary, Jessica and Alex. Graveside service Friday, 1:30 PM, at Mt. Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY.

title: Ugly Season In the Past: Now Payoff Is Playoffs
description: In more predictable times, the suspense was not whether the Chicago Bulls would win a championship but whether Michael Jordan would drop in the game-winning shot with 1.2 seconds left or at the buzzer. An entire season, it seemed, boiled down to a coronation each June. The other series were entertaining but merely sideshows. The real drama was tuning in to watch him. You could almost guess the outcome: the Bulls in five games or six.

title: Why Give Organs Away?; Animals Pay a Price
description: To the Editor:

title: Agencies Garner Creativity Awards
description: Two organizations in New York have bestowed their annual advertising awards.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLARK, THOMAS CULBERTSON II.
description: CLARK-Thomas Culbertson II. Of Norfolk, CT, died suddenly May 1. President of The Denominator Company, Inc. Beloved husband of Dorothy Wadsworth Clark, father of T.C. Clark III, stepfather of Susan Colsman and William Painter. Three grandchildren. Memorial service is on Saturday, May 8, at 11:30 A.M., Church of Christ Congregational, Norfolk, CT.

title: Accounts
description: * Cortina Leathers Inc., New York, to Burkhardt & Hillman Ltd., New York, as the first agency to handle its account. Billings were estimated at $1 million.

title: Yanks Say No to Game in Cuba
description: George Steinbrenner vehemently denied yesterday that the Yankees want to play a game in Cuba. But earlier this year, the Yankees were one of several teams that expressed interest in following the Baltimore Orioles to Havana, a baseball official said.

title: Crew Seethes at Board Vote Against His Spending Plan
description: After a bitterly contentious meeting, a majority on the New York City Board of Education rejected Chancellor Rudy Crew's five-year school construction plan yesterday in favor of one supported by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.

title: California Officers Cleared in Killing of Young Woman, Prompting Protests
description: A county prosecutor said today that four white police officers in Riverside, Calif., who shot and killed a black teen-ager as she sat apparently unconscious in a car with a gun in her lap, had probably made an error in judgment, but had committed no crime.

title: Michael Smith and Joshua White -- 'Open House'
description: New Museum of Contemporary Art

title: Senate Will Debate Gun Control Issues
description: Senate Democrats have unveiled a package of proposals on gun control issues like child safety locks on handguns and regulation of gun shows. The majority leader, Trent Lott of Mississippi, has promised to allow a few of the measures as amendments to a Republican juvenile justice bill that is scheduled for consideration early next week.

title: Abortion Foe Is Charged In Killing of Clinic Doctor
description: Hoping to intensify what is already an international manhunt, law enforcement officials today charged James C. Kopp, a roving abortion protester, with murdering a Buffalo abortion clinic doctor in a sniper attack last October.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Inflation Remains a Danger, Greenspan Warns
description: Despite a remarkable run of prosperity that he credited in large part to new technology, Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, delivered his bluntest warning in months today that the economy could still be derailed by its old nemesis, inflation.

title: Pascale Marthine Tayou
description: Lombard-Freid Fine Arts

title: Sarcophagus, Be Gone: Night of the Living Undead
description: More is more, right? More lollipop-colored laser effects, more glinting buried treasure, more camels with halitosis, more corpses dancing in the streets. So many famished zombies pop up through the Egyptian sands in ''The Mummy'' that by the end of this free-for-all horror spoof the entire dead population of the Nile basin seems to have risen from the grave. One militant faction of the undead even marches around in chorus line formation awaiting instructions on which side to take.

title: For Soldier and Civilian Both, Tension Rules in Kosovo City
description: An ethnic Albanian woman pulled her child's arm so hard to get away when a stranger said hello today that one could almost hear the tendons pop.

title: Scrutinized, Lawyer Takes Far Lower Tobacco Fee
description: A lawyer who was awarded $260 million from Texas' settlement with the tobacco industry backed down yesterday from efforts to collect the money from the state. His retreat followed by a day an accusation by the Texas Attorney General that the fee had been ''procured by fraud'' with the help of former Attorney General Dan Morales.

title: COX RADIO IS BUYING STATION FROM CLARKE BROADCASTING
description: Cox Radio Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the radio station WNGC-FM in Athens, Ga., from the Clarke Broadcasting Corporation for $78 million in cash. Cox, based in Atlanta, said the purchase included a construction permit from the Federal Communications Commission to construct a new radio tower, which will allow the station's signal to reach listeners in central and eastern Georgia, including the Atlanta metropolitan area. Cox Radio is the fifth-largest radio company in the United States, owning, operating or providing sales and marketing services to 58 radio stations in 12 markets.

title: Roni Horn
description: Matthew Marks Gallery

title: Populist Stockbrokers
description: To the Editor:

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on page 12.

title: The Moral Way to Pay for Human Organs
description: I recently helped a family friend in his quest for a liver transplant. He suffered from longstanding hepatitis and would die without a new organ. I directed him to an outstanding transplant center in New York. Like all transplant candidates, my friend entered a race against death where the finish line keeps changing. No one knows when a liver will become available because of the scarcity of organs. Furthermore, your name moves up or down on the waiting list depending on how sick you are. For three months my friend steadily deteriorated. On the brink of coma, he received the organ. His life was saved.

title: In Louima's First Day on Stand, He Tells of Brutal Police Assault
description: Nearly two years after leveling a police brutality charge that shocked New York City, Abner Louima took the witness stand yesterday and told a rapt courtroom audience a horrific account of being tortured by two officers in the restroom of a Brooklyn police station.

title: Stephen Antonakos -- 'The Chapel of the Heavenly Ladder and Other Works'
description: St. Peter's Church

title: Way Up in the Bronx A Hardy Spirit Blooms
description: Art in the Bronx, like the sprawling borough itself, is a resilient, clamorous, multifaceted thing, cosmopolitan in outlook but imbued with a spirit of place.

title: A Quick Replacement Jumps Into 'Swan Lake'
description: Miranda Weese stepped into the lead role in ''Swan Lake'' on an hour's notice on Wednesday night in a PBS ''Live From Lincoln Center'' broadcast of Peter Martins's new production for the New York City Ballet. Ms. Weese replaced Darci Kistler, who had been expected to dance the role of Odette-Odile, although no casting had been announced. Ms. Kistler did appear on the show, in a recorded interview conducted by Beverly Sills that was shown at intermission.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WAHLERS, SHEILA W.
description: WAHLERS-Sheila W. On May 6, 1999. Manager of Benefits and Communications at Butterick Company, Inc. Loving mother of Elisabeth W. Connors & Frederick W. Wahlers IV. Dear sister of Sandra Quine, Sharon Leary, Michael Whalen & the late Kevin Whalen. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St, Sunday, May 9, 5-8PM. Interment private. Memorial Mass at St. Vincent Ferrer Church, Lexington Ave. at 66th St., Monday, 2PM.

title: RUSSIA IN ACCORD ON NEED FOR FORCE TO PATROL KOSOVO -- Plans are Vague
description: The West and Russia agreed for the first time today on the need for an international military presence in Kosovo to keep any eventual peace. But the composition of such a force and conditions for its deployment remained in dispute.

title: Daniel Hoffman, Judge, 91
description: Daniel Hoffman, a former New York City judge in Criminal Court, died on April 23 at his home in Tamarac, Fla. He was 91.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARLOW, TONY
description: BARLOW-Tony. On May 4. Born Milton McClintock Barlow and known to all as Tony. He was the beloved husband of Priscilla Winn Barlow, devoted father of Ethan and Benjamin, step-father of Philippa and Nicola, loving brother of John Barlow and Sally Ittmann and dear son of Georgette Barlow of Kansas City. A former lawyer and banker, he was in recent years a member of the National Episcopal Church's Social Responsibility in Investments Committee and was an Episcopal Church representative at the Interface Center on Corporate Responsibility. A memorial service will be held at 4:00pm on Monday, May 10, 1999 at The Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine, entrance at 112th Street and Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers, donations should be sent to: Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, Box E.

title: Slide Takes Out Knoblauch, but Not for the Year
description: Chuck Knoblauch limped slowly into the Yankees' clubhouse late this afternoon, like a miracle at a religious revival. His teammates, who had expected Knoblauch to be rolled, carried or pushed to his locker with his left leg in a cast or splint, gawked in utter disbelief.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAUPT, ELLIOT
description: HAUPT-Elliot. Age 78. On May 6, 1999. Adoring father of Vicki and Steven. Brother of Melville and Blanche. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St., Sunday 2-4PM and 7-9PM. Funeral service Monday, May 10, at 9:45AM at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at 65th Street. Interment to follow at Mount Carmel Cemetery. Contributions in his memory may be made to Temple Emanu-El, 1 East 65th Street, New York, NY 10021.

title: Why Bankruptcy Became So Popular
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHINDEL, FAY
description: SCHINDEL-Fay. The Laura Rosenberg Foundation extends deepest sympathy upon the passing of Fay Schindel, beloved mother of Jane Farman, Founder and Trustee. Our sincere condolences to the entire Farman and Schindel families. The Laura Rosenberg Foundation

title: For Sprewell and Camby, It's Ready or Not
description: The last two Knicks in the gymnasium today were Latrell Sprewell and Marcus Camby, both lingering in the comfort and safety of home like naive freshmen before a week of hazing.

title: Henderson on Disabled List
description: When Steve Phillips, the Mets' general manager, signed Rickey Henderson and acquired Bobby Bonilla during the off season, there was speculation about whether the 40-year-old Henderson and the 36-year-old Bonilla would be able to coax their bodies through another season.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEGGANS, JAMES P. JR.
description: BEGGANS-James P. Jr. The Society of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick in the City of New York records with profound sorrow the death of James P. Beggans, Jr., a member of the Society, and extends sincere sympathy to his family. William J. Cronin, President Robert J. Reilly, Historian

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBERG, DIANA
description: ROSENBERG-Diana. Of New York City on May 6, 1999 at the age of 89 years. Dear friend, cousin and aunt will be missed by all. Graveside service Sunday 1:00 PM at Mount Judah Cemetery, Ridgewood, NY.

title: The Vatican's Many Appeals for Peace
description: On the evening of March 24, shortly after the NATO bombings began, I expressed the Vatican's position on the war on Kosovo with the following declaration: ''Recourse to the use of force is always a defeat for humanity. One cannot help but think of the eventual victims and the feelings of hatred that will inevitably arise. It makes one think of Pius XII's words on August 24, 1939: Nothing is lost with peace. All can be lost with war.''

title: Repsol Plans Asset Sales To Smooth YPF Deal
description: Repsol S.A, the Spanish oil company, said yesterday that it would sell its Argentine assets -- as many as 800 gas stations and an oil refinery -- to avoid violating antitrust laws in its planned takeover of YPF S.A., Argentina's largest oil company.

title: Jones Lawyers Want Clinton To Pay Them Over $496,000
description: Lawyers for Paula Corbin Jones told a Federal judge in Arkansas today that President Clinton owed them more than $496,000 as a result of extra work they say they were forced to perform because of his dishonest testimony in her sexual misconduct case.

title: Clinton Seeing Bosnian Model For Kosovo Use
description: President Clinton today described the peacekeeping operation in Bosnia as a model for the force that is envisioned to return and protect ethnic Albanian refugees to Kosovo.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SALTON, LEWIS L.
description: SALTON-Lewis L. On May 5, 1999, after a brief illness, peacefully and without pain. Beloved husband of Edith, proud father of William, Gillian & Justine, and devoted friend to Bonzo and Lucia. Born in Krakow in 1911, received M.S. in engineering from Brno, Czechoslovakia before escaping the Holocaust via Siberia and Japan. In 1940, emigrated to the United States, where he worked for RCA and Fisher Radio. Founded Salton Inc., in the early 50's and invented the Salton Hotray and other household appliances. in 1996, he was one of the first to join class action suit on behalf of Holocaust victims and survivors against three major Swiss banks. Recently, he was completing memoirs on his escape from Nazi Poland. His last healthly days were spent on the slopes of the French Alps. Funeral service will be held at Campbell's, 1070 Madison Ave, May 9, 10 AM. Further respect can be paid at the Salton residence in Connecticut on the afternoon of May 9th, and the New York City residence on May 10th, after 6 PM.

title: Imposing, Yet in Touch With His Cerebral Side
description: Inside the visitors' locker room at Madison Square Garden on Wednesday, some Miami Heat players were watching a videotape of their horrendous loss to the Knicks on April 25.

title: 2 Shippers Agree to Stay In Harbor
description: Two of the largest shipping lines in the world announced yesterday that they had accepted a lease proposal from Gov. Christine Todd Whitman and the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey that would allow them to remain in New York Harbor and expand their operations instead of moving to Baltimore.

title: Hess Had Thoughts About Sale Of the Jets
description: The death of Leon Hess, the owner of the Jets, not only marked the end of an era for the team but could also change the face of New York area sports if the team is put up for sale and attracts high-profile bidders.

title: Fund-Raiser to Detail Role of Chinese Intelligence
description: A fund-raiser who pleaded guilty to tax violations has told Government investigators that a Chinese general in charge of Beijing's intelligence service was behind $300,000 in payments that were used in part as contributions to the Democratic National Committee, officials said today.

title: Among Allies, Doubts and Disagreement on Oil Embargo
description: The bark of NATO's planned naval blockade of oil deliveries to Yugoslavia may be worse than its bite, allied diplomats said today.

title: Why Bankruptcy Became So Popular
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about the hidden psychological problems of violent youths misstated the affiliation of two experts who studied normal adolescents. The researchers, Dr. Daniel Offer and Dr. Kenneth Howard, work at Northwestern University, not the University of Chicago.

title: Heir to a Fortune, and to Tragedy; Suicide Ends the Life of a Wealthy, and Haunted, Man
description: William Woodward 3d was born to a family with few peers in New York society. The Woodwards had old money and blue blood, but they also had a penchant for self-destruction that inspired novels by Truman Capote and Dominick Dunne, and landed them in the headlines of newspapers around the world.

title: China Cracks Down on Foreign Satellite Transmissions
description: In a move that may reflect China's jitters during a year of politically charged milestones, the Chinese Government has begun to clamp down on the illegal reception of foreign television channels.

title: Jets Are Chartered For Israelis in U.S. To Get Out to Vote
description: In a trans-Atlantic expansion of one of America's oldest political practices -- getting out the vote -- supporters of the two major candidates for Prime Minister of Israel are arranging for thousands of Israelis living in the United States to fly home at cut-rate fares for the coming national elections.

title: Milosevic Aide on Kosovo Urges Albanians to Return
description: Last September, Zoran Andjelkovic, the Serbian minister for youth and sport, was assigned the unenviable task of trying to run Kosovo as it slid faster and faster toward civil war.

title: Always a Contender, Furyk Seeks a Major
description: Since 1997, only one player has finished sixth or better in all four major championships. The answer is not David Duval or Tiger Woods or Davis Love 3d or Mark O'Meara.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVIE, RICHARD R.
description: LEVIE-Richard R. Of New York City, on May 7, 1999. Survived by his beloved wife, Jeanne, and his very loving brother and sister-inlaw, Howard Levie and Blanche Levie. Dick's warmth, friendship and kindness will be deeply missed by all who knew him.

title: Who'll Take the Driver's Seat?; Barclays at a Crossroads, With Questions on Leadership
description: The shares of Barclays P.L.C. surged 39 percent in two months after Michael O'Neill, a top executive at Bank of America, was appointed chief executive in February.

title: Arabs' Civilization
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: A New Setback for Starr

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAYTON, SCOTT J.
description: PAYTON-Scott J. On May 1, 1999. Beloved son of Doris Payton-Jacobs and the late Ralph W. Payton, loving brother of Heather K. Payton, Jasmine C.S. Jacobs, adored stepson of Brian L. Jacobs. He is mourned by two nieces, aunts, uncles, cousins and numerous friends. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, Sunday, May 9, 7 to 9 PM. Service Monday, May 10, 10 AM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street. Interment at Calverton National Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WERNER, JULIE
description: WERNER-Julie. Beloved mother of Nancy Lerner. Grandmother of Adam and Amanda Lerner and sister of Norman Roth. We will miss you so. Graveside service at 12:30PM Sunday, May 9th, Beth David Cemetery.

title: ZIONS, UTAH-BASED BANK, IS BUYING PIONEER BANCORP
description: The Zions Bancorporation, the second-largest bank based in Utah, agreed yesterday to buy Pioneer Bancorp for $341 million in stock, as the bank increases its ranking in the Nevada market to third from sixth. The Salt Lake City-based Zions, which has about $17.5 billion in assets, said it would pay $35.70 for each share of Pioneer, which has more than $1 billion in assets and is the largest bank based in Nevada. Zions has banks in eight Western states from Utah and Colorado to Washington and California. The deal was disclosed after Zion's shares rose $2, $64.50, and Pioneer's, 75 cents, to $31.

title: Iran's Terrorist Ranking
description: To the Editor:

title: KOSOVO UPDATE
description: COMBAT

title: Lead of the Right Red Queen Spells Victory in Las Vegas
description: The Cavendish Team event in Las Vegas ended on Wednesday night in a victory for Steve Weinstein, Robert Levin, Chip Martel and Lew Stansby. Their total of 188 victory points was just 1 point ahead of Peter Boyd, Steve Robinson, Kit Woolsey and Frank Stewart. The favored group of Italian world champions finished fifth, in a world-class field that included players from 15 countries.

title: Not in Kansas Anymore . . .
description: Hot on the heels of deadly reality, literature's most beloved twister swirled into the Theater at Madison Square Garden on Thursday night, carrying a new season of performances of ''The Wizard of Oz.''

title: Paroled Man Is Suspected Of Committing 23 Robberies
description: Detectives identified a paroled robber yesterday as the man who has committed 23 recent holdups of bank customers in the Bronx and Manhattan and has shot three of his victims.

title: Ruling Allows U.S. To Try Follower of Sheik
description: A Federal judge in Brooklyn refused yesterday to drop an indictment against an Egyptian man whose lawyer had claimed that he was being unfairly prosecuted because of his political and religious associations.

title: Hurtado Status Doubtful As MetroStars Hit Road
description: The MetroStars have had many problems on offense this season, from their own lack of scoring to the fruitless search for a forward to fill the vacant foreigner slot on their roster. As if those struggles were not enough, the MetroStars are expected to be without Eduardo Hurtado when they travel to Washington to face D.C. United today.

title: Animal Transplants
description: To the Editor:

title: Setting Our Rivers Free
description: A bout this time each year, Kenny Mills takes two five-gallon buckets and a net to the foot of the old concrete dam on the Rappahannock River and dips yellow and white perch from the tumultuous water. When the buckets are full he carries them up and around the dam, then releases the fish so they can swim upriver, toward a final destination imprinted in their DNA like celestial coordinates.

title: The Telltale Phone
description: A person shrinks from dialing the phone these days. Caller ID -- that hardly seems sporting. Now you can buy a phone at the Counter Spy Shop on Madison Avenue (it's expensive, $3,900) that can detect the changes that occur in a person's voice when he is lying.

title: RESOUND, A HEARING-AID MAKER, IN TALKS TO BE ACQUIRED
description: The Resound Corporation, the sixth-largest hearing-aid maker, said it was in talks to be acquired for about $166 million. It would not name its potential buyer. The company, based in Redwood City, Calif., which makes high-tech hearing aids, is offering itself for $8 a share. Well-financed rivals like the European electronics giant Siemens A.G. beat Resound in bringing modern digital hearing aids to market. Sales fell 5.4 percent last year to $123 million, resulting in a loss. To diversify, Resound joined with Motorola Inc. and developed a line of wearable communicators for firefighters and the police.

title: Damascus Journal; 2 Who Decided to Have the Knot Tied for Them
description: Mohammed wanted a wife who was ''obedient and beautiful.'' Olaa wanted a husband who was ''tall, kind, rich and cultivated.'' Armed with those instructions, their mothers went to work in search of a match.

title: Pay the Legislators
description: Few New Yorkers are shedding tears for the State Legislature, whose members have not been paid in more than a month. The lawmakers have only themselves to blame. In order to get a pay raise from $57,500 to $79,500 last December, they agreed to have their paychecks withheld in each new fiscal year until they finally passed a budget. The pay freeze, demanded by Gov. George Pataki as the price for not vetoing the pay raise, has failed to work any magic. The budget, which is supposed to be passed April 1, is late for the 15th year in a row. But the idea of withholding pay was bad in principle and should be abandoned.

title: Jordan Backs Out Of Hornets Deal
description: Michael Jordan backed out of talks to buy a stake in the Charlotte Hornets after team management rejected his demand for complete control of the franchise, people familiar with the negotiations said today.

title: Thinkers Who Prefer to Be Free; For Many Uneasy in Universities, Independence Is Worth the Cost
description: When Judith Rich Harris published an article in a scholarly journal a few years back and put the words ''Middletown, New Jersey'' in the space usually reserved for an author's academic affiliation, she found herself deluged with what she now calls her ''who-the-hell-are-you mail.''

title: Developer Pursues Plans for Complex Along Brooklyn's Waterfront
description: One of Europe's most celebrated architects has been hired to design a controversial shopping and entertainment complex in Brooklyn that could transform the waterfront area north of Brooklyn Heights.

title: Police Officer And 2 Others Are Wounded In a Shootout
description: An off-duty police detective working as a security guard was wounded in the arm yesterday afternoon during a shootout that left two other people injured at a check-cashing business in Queens.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Worried Aid Officials Keep Watch Over a Silent Border
description: After nearly 25,000 Kosovo refugees flooded into Macedonia earlier this week, the border fell eerily silent today and refugee officials said they feared that Serbian forces were expelling ethnic Albanians from their homes but barring them from fleeing.

title: ENRON REJECTS BID FOR STAKE IN OIL AND GAS UNIT
description: The Enron Corporation said yesterday that it had rejected a bid from an unnamed suitor for its controlling stake in the Enron Oil and Gas Company because the offer was too low. Enron said in December that it had received an unsolicited offer for its 53.5 percent stake in the separately traded Enron Oil and Gas. Enron would not disclose who had made the bid. Oil and natural gas prices have surged as much as 50 percent this year, lifting stocks of exploration companies like Enron Oil and Gas. Its shares, which closed yesterday at $18.75, up 37.5 cents, have climbed 48 percent since the offer was disclosed Dec. 15. Enron's stake in Enron Oil and Gas is valued at about $1.6 billion, based on current stock prices. The oil exploration company has a total market value of $2.9 billion.

title: A Singing Nathan Lane Adds Ham to the Fizz
description: Hubert Cram, the bluntly drawn schlemiel of a hero in the musical ''Do Re Mi,'' is not a character to be served without sauce. He needs the twists, fizz and flourishes that only an outsize comic presence can provide, the sort of performer to whom shtick is an intricate and highly evolved art. In 1960, when the show first opened, Phil Silvers was on hand to come up with the necessary embellishments. Baroque shtick was Silvers's specialty, as it was to a whole galaxy of funny men whose style was descended from vaudeville, from Bert Lahr to Zero Mostel.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Heat's Plan Is to Make a Run for It Against Ewing
description: P. J. Brown will wear basketball shoes when the Miami Heat opens the playoffs on Saturday afternoon against the Knicks, but the power forward will be thinking like a runner.

title: China Calls Security Council To Urgent Talks on Attack
description: The United Nations Security Council met in an emergency session early this morning to consider the NATO bombing of the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CARRAMERICA REALTY CORP., -- Washington, a real estate investment trust, said it planned to spin off its temporary office leasing business, in an effort to increase its stock price.

title: Peace Plan Must Cover War Crimes
description: To the Editor:

title: Critic of Flawed CNN Report Is Named as a Source for It
description: A retired military officer who has been a leading critic of CNN's repudiated broadcast on the use of nerve gas against defectors in the Vietnam War was named yesterday as one of the confidential sources for the broadcast.

title: Chief of Staff Resigns At Prosecutor's Office
description: Less than a week after the Essex County Executive criticized her for ''profligate'' spending, including hiring a chief of staff for $90,000 a year, the Essex County Prosecutor, Patricia A. Hurt, announced yesterday that the aide would resign.

title: Talk Show Ordered to Pay $25 Million After Killing
description: In a case that has focused attention on confrontational talk shows, a jury here ordered ''The Jenny Jones Show'' to pay $25 million to the family of a gay man who was shot to death after revealing that he was sexually attracted to another man on the show.

title: Murdoch to Buy a Stake in TheStreet.com
description: The News Corporation, the entertainment and news conglomerate controlled by Rupert Murdoch, has agreed to buy a stake in TheStreet.com, the on-line financial news service.

title: Orchestral Color for a Piano's Black and White
description: It is usually the case that less-traveled places in this country wait with eager anticipation for cultural visits from the big city. The Cleveland Orchestra turns that proposition around, for it is we in New York who are the waiters, and this magnificent organization the itinerant dispenser of gifts.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Dow Surges to a Record As Inflation Fears Recede

title: Sports of The Times; Leon Hess Deserved More Thrills
description: WHEN the Jets were about to go to Denver for last season's American Football Conference championship game, Leon Hess was asked if he would make the trip.

title: More Kosovo Refugees Reach U.S.
description: An additional 407 ethnic Albanians, among more than a million pushed out of their homes in Kosovo by Serbian security forces, arrived at this training camp turned immigration center today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANTEL, HENRY, ZVI HIRSCH BEN MENACHEM MENDEL
description: MANTEL-Henry, Zvi Hirsch Ben Menachem Mendel, 84. Del Ray Beach, FL. Devoted husband of Ruth Mantel, loving father of Michael Mantel, Marsha Wagner and their spouses Anne Mantel, Leon Wagner, and Andrea Harmon. Grandfather of Gabriel, Daniel and Samuel. Henry was born and raised in Vienna, immigrated to the United States in 1939 and earned a Purple Heart during his meritorious service in World War II. Henry was a wonderful, talented and active man who will be missed by his family and many friends. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Congregation Ansche Chesed in Manhattan or the Rabbi Discretionary Fund of the Jewish Community Center of Harrison, New York.

title: Abroad at Home; When Leadership Fails
description: At the end of this terrible century, why was another murderous tyrant in Europe able to carry out mass killings and expulsions?

title: Jobless Rate In Germany Unexpectedly Turns Higher
description: In a worrisome sign that Europe's biggest economy is still sputtering, the German Government reported today an unexpected rise in unemployment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DE ROHAN, JOHN, 94
description: de ROHAN-John, 94. Died May 6, 1999. Born in Ireland, he lived in NY and Princeton, NJ since 1920. He was the husband of the late Mona Revis. He was an investment advisor on Wall Street and in Princeton. He is survived by many nieces and nephews here and in Ireland. For information, please call 212-794-2784

title: MCDERMOTT INTERNATIONAL TO BUY REST OF SUBSIDIARY
description: In a move to simplify its corporate structure, McDermott International Inc. agreed yesterday to buy the 37 percent interest it does not already own in the marine-construction services concern J. Ray McDermott S.A. for $513 million. McDermott International, an energy-services concern, will pay $35.62 a share for 14.4 million J. Ray McDermott shares. Shares of J. Ray McDermott jumped 15 percent, gaining $4.75, to $35.25, on the New York Stock Exchange, where shares of McDermott International rose $2.3125, to $30.25. The New Orleans-based companies began trading separately in 1995, when McDermott issued J. Ray McDermott shares as part of an acquisition of another company. McDermott International had revenue of $3.67 billion last year, and J. Ray McDermott had revenue of $1.86 billion.

title: About New York; Bronx Roots Still Nurture Career Paths
description: WHEN Louis J. Cappelli graduated from William H. Taft High School in 1949, he ended up doing what most of his buddies in the Bronx did: not much. There was a recession, and jobs were tight. He would walk from his home at Courtlandt Avenue and 160th Street, cross Park Avenue and head to their hangout on Morris Avenue and 165th Street, where the biggest attraction some days was watching the street get paved.

title: Corrections
description: A picture on Thursday showing Kosovo refugees lined up at McGuire Air Force Base in New Jersey carried an erroneous credit in some copies. The photographer was Keith Meyers of The New York Times.

title: Op-Art; Springtime Travel
With His Job on the Line, Irabu Silences Seattle
description: Hideki Irabu surely knew that his perilous future with the Yankees could get a lot murkier or a little clearer last night. He surely knew that another wretched performance could force the Yankees to bounce him from the rotation or consider demoting him to the minor leagues. He surely knew it was one of the most critical nights of his career with the Yankees. Actually, everyone knew.

title: Vouchers Offer a Chance
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CIMBRECK, DORIS BADE
description: CIMBRECK-Doris Bade, 85. of Greenville, SC, widow of John Cimbreck, died Wednesday, May 5, 1999. Born in Brooklyn, NY, daughter of the late John Henry and Henrietta Wehmann Bade, she was a graduate of Katherine Gibbs School in New York City. Before her retirement, she was secretary manager for Lybran Ross Brothers & Montgomery, accountants, of New York City, and at one time was secretary for the NY State Society of Accountants. Surviving one brother, John Bade, and his wife, Dorothy, of 3368 Hollywood Avenue, Medford, OR 97501. Services were held Friday, May 7, in Greenville, SC. For information Mackey Mortuary, Greenville, SC.

title: Lawyer Issues Denial for Los Alamos Scientist Suspected of Spying for Beijing
description: The lawyer for Wen Ho Lee, a scientist fired from his job at Los Alamos National Laboratory for violations of security rules, has issued his first detailed denial of allegations that his client spied for China.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAMBURGER, PHYLLIS LAMBERT
description: HAMBURGER-Phyllis Lambert. Phyllis passed away on Friday, May 7. She will be remembered with love by her daughters Amy and Hope and their husbands, her grandchildren, Abbye, T.J. and Evan, her brother Abbott and by her devoted caretaker Jennifer. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Alzheimer's Disease Research. Services Monday, May 10, 10:00 AM Frank E. Campbell, Madison Avenue, at 81st St.

title: The Need for Care as Well as Profit
description: Among other things, the 1990's will be remembered as the decade when developers and older, affluent, anxious Americans discovered each other with enthusiasm, with results both encouraging and worrisome. The concept that both they and Wall Street have embraced is called assisted living. There is no common definition of it. Each of the 50 states regulates it differently, and the Federal Government not at all. But to older retirees who can pay to live in the new and reconditioned spaces sprouting across the country, the assisted living communities offer something irresistible. It is the promise of Pleasantville, where they can live out their lives gracefully, with hotel services, assistance when they need it, and the chance to hold off or avoid what many of the aged most fear -- the nursing home.

title: Chinese Embassy Bombing May Hurt Bid to Win Support for Peacekeepers
description: The bombing of the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade is expected to complicate, and could even undermine, efforts by the United States and other NATO members to win United Nations endorsement of an international peacekeeping force for Kosovo, Administration officials acknowledged tonight.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TEWI, SCHLACHET, THEA
description: TEWI - SCHLACHET - Thea. Be loved wife of the late Charles. Devoted mother of Peter. Loving grandmother of David, Daniel, Lisa and Joshua. She will also be mourned by nephews, nieces, cousins and numerous dear friends and colleagues. Services will be held at Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapel, 114-03 Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills, New York on Sunday at 11:30

title: Peace Plan Must Cover War Crimes
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO SLIDES. The dollar rose against the euro for the first time in three days after a Labor Department jobs report eased concern that economic growth could stoke inflation. In New York, the euro fell to 1.0748 from $1.0802.

title: Two More Suits Seek to Stop Sale of Gardens
description: Two groups have filed separate Federal lawsuits to try to forestall an auction next week of more than 100 city-owned lots being used as community gardens. One suit alleges that the sale would violate the civil rights of minority New Yorkers, who ''have dramatically less access to green recreational space than its white residents.''

title: Swashbuckling Buccaneers
description: Being a pirate must be fun, especially if pirate bands resemble the one in American Ballet Theater's production of ''Le Corsaire.'' A new cast took over most of the major roles on Wednesday night at the Metropolitan Opera House, and although the ballet's story remained as silly as ever, the dancing was spectacular.

title: Senate Committee Reviews Holbrooke Inquiry Documents
description: The Senate Foreign Relations Committee is trying to determine whether it has sufficient evidence from the Justice Department to go forward with confirmation hearings for Richard C. Holbrooke as the top American diplomat at the United Nations, Congressional officials said today.

title: View From Moscow: Success for Its Diplomacy
description: While NATO leaders congratulated themselves on Thursday for nudging Russia over to their side in the search for a diplomatic settlement in Kosovo, Russian diplomats took another view, claiming a small but significant victory in their monthlong attempt to mediate a peace.

title: Foreign Presence in Colombia's Flower Gardens
description: The Acuarela flower farm here grows nothing but roses of every hue, and this morning workers were rushing to fill the last Mother's Day orders from American clients. They snipped, chilled and bundled thousands of delicate buds just starting to bloom, then quickly trucked them to the Bogota airport for a three-hour flight to Miami and next-day delivery.

title: Pittston Cancels a Payout
description: The Pittston Company said today that it had canceled the regular quarterly dividend for holders of Pittston Minerals Group common stock because of the group's earnings and cash-flow problems. The Pittston Company, based in Richmond, is a minerals, security and global-freight transportation concern. The company has paid holders of Pittston Minerals common stock a quarterly per-share dividend of 2.5 cents since May 1998.

title: Corrections
description: A listing of credits in Weekend yesterday with a film review of ''The Castle'' misidentified the composer of the score. He is Edmund Choi; Craig Harnath composed music for the version released in Australia.

title: Donors Flock to University Center Linked to Senate Majority Leader
description: An academic center under construction at the University of Mississippi and named for Senator Trent Lott, the majority leader, is being endowed with million-dollar donations from companies with huge stakes in pending Congressional legislation.

title: Can New York Make the Fights Fair Again?
description: To the Editor:

title: Blair's Party Finishes First in Scottish and Welsh Voting
description: Prime Minister Tony Blair has succeeded in holding off threats from nationalist parties in Scotland and Wales, with his Labor Party winning the most seats in the new legislatures there, election results showed today.

title: Democrats Try to Turn Focus Toward New Jersey Assembly Campaigns
description: The prevailing message of the New Jersey Democratic Party's annual conference in this fog-blanketed casino town today was conveyed succinctly in the blue-and-red stickers that almost everyone seemed to be wearing: ''It's the Assembly, stupid!''

title: COMING ON SUNDAY: CITIES ACROSS THE RIVER
description: Savor three satellite cities -- Brooklyn, Cambridge, Mass., and Ciudad Juarez, Mexico -- with idiosyncracies and pleasures of their own. Share an 8-year-old girl's holiday in a Spanish fishing town. Explore the Republic of Georgia. The Sophisticated Traveler, part 2 of the magazine.

title: Judge Orders Death Penalty With a 5-Year Deadline
description: Shortly after imposing the death sentence today on a 21-year-old man for his role in the ambush and murder of two pizza deliverymen in 1997, a New Jersey judge set a deadline of five years for the state to carry out the execution. If the state has not carried out the execution by May 7, 2004, the judge ordered that the sentence automatically be changed to life in prison.

title: China Assails 'Gross Violation of Sovereignty'
description: The Chinese Government called the attack on its embassy in Belgrade a ''gross violation of Chinese sovereignty'' in a statement read on television news today.

title: Role for Russian Peacekeepers Would Save Face for Moscow : Clinton Sees Bosnia As a Kosovo Model
description: PARIS  President Bill Clinton, quickening diplomatic cooperation with Russia in the search for a solution in the Kosovo crisis, said Friday that a peacekeeping presence in the Serbian province could be modeled on the NATO-led peacekeeping force in Bosnia, which includes Russian troops.

title: Why Bankruptcy Became So Popular
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANCUSO, HARRIET STEIN
description: MANCUSO-Harriet Stein. Her friends mourn the passing of Harriet Stein Mancuso. Harriet was a kind and intelligent lady, and we will miss her. Our thoughts and prayers are with Robert, Rebecca, Miranda, and Paul. Stephen Kelly

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OSTLUND, BARBARA
description: OSTLUND-Barbara. On May 6, 1999. Beloved wife of Calvert, adored mother of Abbey and Justin. Dear daughter of Sarah Grossman, cherished grandmother of Sarah Fern. Adored sister of Edward and Neil. Distinguished collector of antique furniture, paintings and books. Well-known member of the Roosevelt Island community. Service Sunday 9:45AM at the ''Riverside'' 76 & Amsterdam.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARPER, JEAN MCKEOWN
description: HARPER-Jean McKeown, of Briarcliff Manor, NY. Born July 7, 1940. Died May 7, 1999. A sharp mind, warm heart and deep strength for all she loved. Survived by three children, Beth, Lawton and Jennifer, and granddaughter, Katelyn Elizabeth. Visitation Saturday 2-4PM and 7-9PM at the Waterbury & Kelly Funeral Home, 1300 Pleasantville Rd., Briarcliff Manor. Services Sunday 2PM at the Briarcliff Congregational Church, and Monday 12-3PM at the Smith-McCracken Funeral Home, Newton, New Jersey.

title: Mrs. Clinton on Child Care and Marriage
description: In her seventh visit to New York State this year, Hillary Rodham Clinton donned a cordless microphone today to lead a free-flowing discussion with nearly 600 women about health coverage, child care and, to a swell of surprised applause, the difficulties of keeping a marriage together.

title: Facing Growing Competition, Instinet Scrambles for Position
description: With the competition intensifying for America's stock-trading business, the Instinet Corporation, a unit of Reuters Group P.L.C. and the nation's largest private electronic stock-trading network, announced a series of strategic moves this week aimed, not only at its competitors but also at its potential allies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WESTCARR, MARILYN
description: WESTCARR-Marilyn. May 8, 1932. Taken by God before we were born. In God always loving; in God forever loved. Sisters, Shirley and Lorraine;

title: Another Great Escape for Massacre's 'Boy in Window'
description: Kathy and John Ireland said they wanted the world to know that ''the boy in the window'' was steadily recovering and that his future remained bright. That boy is their son Patrick, 17, who was shot twice in the head and once in the foot two weeks ago before hoisting himself out the shattered window of the Columbine High School library, and dropping into the arms of SWAT team members.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHER, NICHOLAS T.
description: FISHER-Nicholas T. Beloved son of Philip B. Fisher and the late Emily N. Fisher, brother of Emily, Philip and Kate. Stepson of Diana Y. Fisher and stepbrother of Amory Y., Laughlin H., and Victoria A. L. Clarke. Memorial service Sunday, May 9, 6:00 PM, Church of the Heavenly Rest, 5th Ave. & 90th St.

title: Tipper Gore Says She Took Treatment for Depression
description: Tipper Gore, the wife of the Vice President, disclosed in a newspaper article published today that she was treated for depression after their 6-year-old son was severely injured in an automobile accident in 1989.

title: After The War In Serbia Is Over
description: Despite the current conflict, we remain committed to Yugoslavia's integration into Europe, and eventually into the European Union. The road to Europe is the only route that will help our country solve its considerable problems and build a lasting peace and stability throughout the region. It is difficult to imagine that any economic or political renewal can occur in Yugoslavia without unambiguous and long-term international support.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRUSH, ELLEN SPARRY
description: BRUSH-Ellen Sparry. The Board and Program Committee of the American Scandinavian Society notes with great sadness the death of Dr. Ellen S. Brush, a devoted and beloved member. Her dedicated and generous support to the entire Scandinavian community will be greatly missed. Our sincere condolences to husband Charles, children and stepchildren. The American Scandinavian Society.

title: Jury Deadlocked in Case Involving Starr Investigation
description: After jury members twice described themselves as ''hopelessly deadlocked,'' a Federal judge declared a mistrial today in the obstruction of justice trial of Julie Hiatt Steele, the Richmond woman who played a peripheral role in Kenneth W. Starr's investigation of President Clinton.

title: Top General Seeks to Deploy Long-Range Arms in Croatia
description: Hoping to widen the attack on Yugoslavia, NATO's commander, Gen. Wesley K. Clark, has asked the Pentagon to position additional long-range rocket batteries along Yugoslavia's borders, including some in the territory of its archenemy Croatia, American and NATO officials said today.

title: Religion Journal; Among a Religious Electorate, Overlooked Corners
description: When it comes to political activity by religious believers, the nation's evangelical Protestants often seem to get most of the attention from the news media and scholars.

title: World Briefing
description: AFRICA

title: The Study of Trauma Graduates at Last
description: As Soeren Buus Jensen got ready to give a seminar at New York University on treating the shaken Kosovars arriving at Fort Dix, he recalled the chaos of the Bosnian refugee camps where he worked four years ago.

title: Albany Notes; Houses Stay Busy, and Deadlocked
description: With Gov. George E. Pataki and lawmakers sniping their way to stalemates on even trivial matters, there haven't been a lot of laws made in Albany lately (not to mention a state budget now five weeks late). But it wouldn't be accurate to say that nothing is happening.

title: Corrections
description: An article and a chart in Science Times on April 20 about a procedure to detect the spread of breast cancer misstated the role of a dye and a radioactive isotope injected near the tumor. They are used to identify the lymph nodes that should be analyzed for cancer through a biopsy; the materials do not themselves indicate whether the nodes are cancerous.

title: Hingis Faces Williamses, One Following the Other
description: Martina Hingis and Serena Williams walked on court as equals today in the quarterfinals of the Italian Open, but when they walked off little more than an hour later, it was clear that Hingis was No. 1 and Williams still has a little way to go.

title: Thais Angrily Blaming U.S. For Deadlock on Trade Post
description: Protesters shouted at the gates of the United States Embassy today, voicing a growing wave of anger here that was summed up the other day by Prime Minister Chuan Leekpai: Something fishy is going on.

title: 4,000 Refugees Feared by Some As a Trigger for Ethnic Tension : Australia Edgy As Kosovars Start to Arrive
description: SYDNEY  The first of 4,000 Albanian refugees from Kosovo arrived here Friday at the start of an airlift that, officials emphasized, shows a compassionate face of Australia but which also reflects the volatility of the country's multiethnic population and politics.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOX, TRUDY
description: FOX-Trudy. The Hewlett-East Rockaway Jewish Centre mourns the loss of its friend Trudy Fox, and extends heartfelt sympathy to her family. Funeral services to be held at Riverside Chapel in Manhattan at 9:30AM Sunday morning. Rabbi Stanley Platek Norman Doctor, President

title: Britain Plans To Sell 58% Of Its Bullion
description: Britain surprised world financial markets today by announcing it would sell more than half the country's bullion reserves, a move that further eroded the value of what was once the safest and strongest measure of wealth.

title: Why Bankruptcy Became So Popular
description: To the Editor:

title: Statement by Suspect's Lawyer: He Assisted F.B.I.
description: Following are excerpts from a statement by Mark Holscher, a lawyer for Wen Ho Lee, who was dismissed from the Los Alamos National Laboratory over reported security violations:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVY, GILBERT
description: LEVY-Gilbert. Of Princeton, NJ. Devoted husband, father, grandfather. Preceded in death by his wife Roslyn and grandson Samuel Alpert. Survived by daughter and son-in-law Andrea and Arnold Alpert of Columbus, Ohio, son and daughter-in-law Joel and Rae Levy of Richmond, Virginia, grandson Michael Alpert. Service Sunday at 1PM at Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, West 150 Route 4, Paramus, NJ.

title: George Bush the Son Finds That Oil and Blood Do Mix
description: When George W. Bush first ran for governor of Texas five years ago, he had no record in politics, only a famous name and a business career that he described as a success ''by any objective measure.''

title: Boys Won't Be Prosecuted In Threat to Bomb School
description: Five students from Brooklyn who were reported to have talked of bombing their school days after the massacre at a high school in Colorado acted ''foolish and immature'' but did not commit any crime, city officials said yesterday in declining to prosecute them.

title: Britain's Quiet Revolution
description: In an atmosphere of civility and general good cheer, voters in Scotland and Wales this week ratified a historic shift in the way Britain is governed. The Scots voted for their first Parliament since 1707, the Welsh for their first National Assembly ever. This decorous revolution could have important consequences. Beyond its stated aim of decentralizing authority throughout the United Kingdom, it could invigorate Britain's politics and even its culture. Beyond that, it could provide a useful model for other European governments that are seeking ways to give restive parts of their own countries a measure of self-rule short of full independence.

title: Ivan the Terrible's Guide to Living
description: Ivan the Terrible's Guide to Living

title: Gas Company Gets Deadline On Offer by Columbia Energy
description: Seeking to force the Consolidated Natural Gas Company to respond to its $6.7 billion hostile bid, Columbia Energy Group said yesterday that it would send Consolidated's board a merger proposal today with a deadline of 5 P.M. on Monday

title: For First Time, a Pope Visits an Orthodox Country
description: Fulfilling a dream long denied, John Paul II arrived in Romania today for the first visit by a Pope to a predominantly Orthodox Christian country.

title: A Web Site for Year 2000 Problems
description: Personal computer users worried about whether their devices can handle Year 2000 dates will have a single industry-sponsored Internet site to turn to for answers starting Monday.

title: TRIGON HEALTHCARE TO STOP PROCESSING SOME CLAIMS
description: Trigon Healthcare Inc., the largest health insurer in Virginia, said yesterday that it would stop processing claims for a Medicare program in Virginia and West Virginia and cut 145 jobs, or 3.9 percent of its work force, to focus on its commercial managed health care business. The Richmond-based Trigon, which will stop processing Medicare Part A claims on Sept. 30 after 33 years, said a new processing company had not been named yet. The cuts come in the administration of Medicare Part A, which covers costs mainly associated with hospital expenses under the Federal health insurance program for the elderly. Trigon said benefits of members whose claims Trigon now processes would not change.

title: NATO RAID HITS CHINA EMBASSY; BEIJING CITES 'BARBARIAN ACT'; ALLIES ADMIT STRIKING HOSPITAL
description: NATO forces that were pounding the center of Belgrade struck and badly damaged the Chinese Embassy tonight during an attack that knocked out electricity across much of Yugoslavia and battered targets at the very heart of President Slobodan Milosevic's power.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BONOFF, CELIA HAUBENSTOCK
description: BONOFF-Celia Haubenstock, of New York City and Hillsdale, NY. Widow of Morris. Mother of Edith Leah Birnbaum and Barbara Gettinger, mother-in-law of Leonard Birnbaum and Stephen Gettinger. Grandmother of Richard, Jane and Peter Birnbaum and Andrew, Matthew and Thomas Gettinger, and twelve great-grandchildren. We will all miss her.

title: LEAR SELLING MOTOR UNIT TO JOHNSON ELECTRIC
description: The Lear Corporation, the world's largest auto-interior maker, agreed yesterday to sell an electric-motor business for $310 million to Johnson Electric Holdings Ltd., the No. 2 maker of small motors, shedding one of the units it bought this week from the United Technologies Corporation. Lear said the unit, which makes motors used in cooling fans, braking systems and pumps, does not fit with its main business of making car seats and interiors. The Hong Kong-based Johnson Electric makes small motors for auto parts as well as power tools, appliances and consumer products. The motor business, which had 1998 sales of $351 million, was part of Lear's $2.3 billion acquisition of UT Automotive.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGMAN, ROBERT P.
description: BERGMAN-Robert P. The Israel Museum and the American Friends of the Israel Museum deeply mourn the passing of Robert P. Bergman, Director of the Cleveland Museum of Art, an esteemed colleague, collaborator, and friend. Our heartfelt condolences to the Bergman family. James S. Snyder, Director, IM Maureen Cogan, Int'l Chairman Judy Steinhardt, President, AFIM Carolyn Cohen, Exec. Dir., AFIM

title: Longtime Member Loses Actors Guild Board Seat
description: Kelly Craig has won a hotly contested seat on the board of the New York Screen Actors Guild, displacing a longtime member, Jordan Derwin, the union announced yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STERN, RUTH
description: STERN-Ruth. Congregation Sons of Israel, Woodmere, NY records with sorrow the passing of its member and extends its condolences to the bereaved family. Bruce Ginsburg, Rabbi Dr. Saul I. Teplitz, Rabbi Emeritus Brian C. Rappaport, President

title: N.R.A. and the Marines
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIPTON, LOUIS J.
description: LIPTON-Louis J. Age 78. On May 6, 1999. Survived by his wife Lini and son Peter. A righteous man, loved and respected by his family and friends. Services on Sunday 12:30pm. Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave, at 81st St. Interment at Westchester Hills Cemetery. Contributions may be made to: The Blue Card, a Jewish aid organization for Holocaust survivors, 1 West 34 St, NYC, 10001.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PFEIFFER, MARTHA GOLDHAMMER NEE ADDIS
description: PFEIFFER-Martha Goldhammer nee Addis, formerly of the Bronx, New York, died on May 5, 1999. Born on September 25, 1908. Daughter of Henrietta nee Weinberg and Percy Addis, widow of Rubin Pfeiffer, predeceased by her first husband, Isidore Goldhammer, and her son, Dr. Robert Goldhammer. Survived by her daughter-in-law, Florie Brettler Goldhammer, of Pittsburgh; granddaughters, Anne M. Goldhammer Moore, of Chicago, and Elizabeth P. Kuzma, of Pittsburgh; a great-granddaughter, Emily Morgan Kuzma, of Pittsburgh; and a brother, Aaron Addis, of Delray Beach, FL. After receiving her Master's degree from New York City's Hunter College in 1933, Mrs. Pfeiffer taught French, Latin, Italian & German at James Monroe and DeWitt Clinton high schools in New York City until her retirement in 1973. Memorial services will be held at the Goldhammer residence on Sunday, May 9, at 1 P.M. Instead of flowers, contributions may be made to the Alzheimer's Disease Alliance of Western Pennsylvania, 5180 Campbell's Run Road, Pittsburgh, PA 15205, Attention: Martha Fenchak Bell.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COCOA PLUNGES. Cocoa fell almost 4 percent as demand slackened. Chocolate processors had stocked up last week when prices fell to a six-year low. In New York, cocoa for July delivery fell $39, to $1,003 a metric ton.

title: Black Ministers Oppose Nomination of Verniero
description: The Black Ministers Council of New Jersey said yesterday that it opposes the nomination of Peter G. Verniero to the State Supreme Court, calling him ''at best minimally qualified'' to sit on the state's highest court. The group also criticized him for an ''insensitive and indifferent'' response to initial reports that state troopers illegally singled out minority drivers for traffic stops.

title: Quaker Oats Raises Prices
description: The Quaker Oats Company, the fourth-largest cereal maker in the United States, has increased prices for almost half its cereals, including Cap'n Crunch and Life, by an average of 3 percent, following increases by General Mills Inc. last month. Quaker Oats told retailers early this week that it was planning to raise prices on about 45 percent of its ready-to-eat cereals, a spokeswoman said. The company said it would use the proceeds to develop new products and increase marketing.

title: Aerospatiale Matra Expects Profit to Fall
description: Aerospatiale Matra S.A., Europe's second-largest military contractor, warned yesterday that its profit for 1999 would fall significantly because of lower sales and higher costs, casting a shadow over next month's initial stock offering. The chief executive, Yves Michot, said the company expected fewer export contracts, higher research costs and one-time charges linked to cancellation of currency futures contracts. He gave the warning as the French Government prepared for the sale of 17 percent of the company's shares to the public.

title: Peace Plan Must Cover War Crimes
description: To the Editor:

title: Hershiser Flop Dooms Mets to 3d Straight Loss
description: No matter how many times the Mets tried to bail him out tonight, Orel Hershiser did not deserve to win. But the Mets' 14-7 loss to the Arizona Diamondbacks -- the most runs New York has allowed this season -- had to leave more than a few people in the crowd wondering how Todd Stottlemyre, who fully deserved to lose, picked up the victory instead?

title: Knoblauch Aches Badly, But What He Feels Is Lucky
description: Chuck Knoblauch was stretched out on the trainer's table with his left leg elevated for more than two hours yesterday. He rubbed his eyes, scratched his head and spoke to several Yankees as they trickled by him. Knoblauch did not start against the Seattle Mariners last night and will probably miss at least a few games, but the Yankees are still very relieved.

title: Leon Hess, Who Built a Major Oil Company and Owned the Jets, Is Dead at 85
description: Leon Hess, who took over his family's bankrupt fuel-oil business during the Depression and built it into a major petroleum company, but was perhaps best known as the steadfast owner of the long-foundering New York Jets football team, died yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. He was 85.

title: Teachers' Union Contests School-Repair Budget
description: The city teachers' union threatened yesterday to go to court over a $6.9 billion plan for school construction and repairs being proposed by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, charging that it fails to protect the ''basic safety'' of children forced to attend school in crumbling buildings.

title: Views on the Hudson
description: To the Editor:

title: Head of City Development Agency Resigns to Work for Prudential
description: Charles Millard, a top adviser to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani who has been president of the city's Economic Development Corporation since 1995, said yesterday that he was resigning to accept a position as a managing director at Prudential Securities.

title: Can New York Make the Fights Fair Again?
description: To the Editor:

title: More Groups Are Sharing In Job Growth
description: America's jobs boom is increasingly pulling many of the nation's most vulnerable citizens out of poverty and unemployment.

title: Phone Revenue Drops For Hong Kong Carrier
description: Hong Kong Telecommunications Ltd., the city's dominant telephone company, said yesterday that its full-year earnings had fallen for the first time. The company, the local unit of the London-based Cable and Wireless P.L.C., surrendered its monopoly over Hong Kong's $2 billion international call market in January. It said revenue from that business fell 18 percent as competitors grabbed market share. Income from other businesses also fell.

title: Smoky Chaos at Embassy
description: Smoke was streaming from the Chinese Embassy here early this morning, and a gaping hole could be seen in one side half an hour after bombs struck the modern six-story building, setting it ablaze.

title: A Guru and Grisly Acts: The Ira Einhorn Story
description: ''The Hunt for the Unicorn Killer'' distills real events into a grim inversion of ''Beauty and the Beast.'' This time, even unconditional love cannot transform the beast's dark soul. Just as sadly, the filmmakers' unconditional effort cannot overcome the limitations imposed by both the source material and the inflexibility of the network movie form.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KANTOR, ISABEL L.
description: KANTOR-Isabel L. On May 7, 1999, at 89 years of age, after a brief illness. Wife of the late Samuel T.; survived by daughter Elizabeth and granddaughter Sarah of San Francisco. Deeply interested in the arts and extremely active on behalf of such groups as Recording for The Blind, and the Womens' City Club of New York, her generous and indomitable spirit inspired all who knew her. Services at Frank E. Campbell, Madison Avenue, and 81st Street, Sunday, May 9th, at 10 A.M.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HESS, LEON
description: HESS-Leon. Peacefully on May 7, 1999 of complications from a blood disorder. Beloved husband of Norma; cherished father of Constance and Dr. Sankey Williams, Marlene Hess and James Zirin, John and Susan Hess; adored grandfather of Elizabeth and Jennifer Williams, Peter and Margaret Friedland, Michael, David and William Hess; dear brother of Betty Gilbert, dear brother-in-law of Ruth Hess, Warren and Rhoda Wilentz and the late Robert and Jacqueline Wilentz, treasured son of the late Ethel and Mores Hess and son-inlaw of the late Lena and David T. Wilentz. In lieu of flowers contributions to your favorite charity would be appreciated. Funeral services will be held at Park Avenue Synagogue, 50 East 87 Street, New York City on May 10, 1999 at 11AM.

title: A Military Contractor Aims To Raise Its Profile Quickly
description: Litton Industries, one of the nation's largest shipbuilders, has seldom made waves. As the arms industry consolidated around it in a series of megamergers, Litton contented itself with a string of small acquisitions.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Having temples built to yourself while you're still in power is a very dangerous proposition. It's very pleasant for the honoree, and very dangerous for citizens who are looking for a fair political process.''

title: Sports of The Times; Riley in Miami, Breathless Once Again
description: THE average plant manager or chief operating officer sticks his or her head into a bucket of ice water and is immediately suspected of having spent too much time in the sun. Pat Riley dunks himself and -- glug, glug -- he is lauded once again for masterfully motivating his Heat.

title: Mayor Says He's Responsible For Any Reforms in Schools
description: The public breakdown of the professional, if not private, relationship between Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew continued yesterday, as the Mayor asserted that he was primarily responsible for whatever reform was being planned for the city's school system.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARLOW, TONY
description: BARLOW-Tony. We extend hearfelt condolences to our colleague Priscilla Winn Barlow on the passing of her husband Tony Barlow. The Interschool Heads

title: Fighting the Good Fight Against Disease
description: GREAT changes are taking place in the horticultural world. Emphasis has been placed on environmental concerns and reduction in the use of pesticides.

title: At Fort Dix, a New Ellis Island Embraces Kosovo's Refugees
description: Selim Berisha sat in a barracks carefully made safe for old people and children, with pictures of murder running through his head.

title: 'I Have a Lot of Willy Lomans in My Life'
description: SOME people say there has never been a ''Death of a Salesman'' with a Linda Loman like that of Elizabeth Franz. The play's author is one of them.

title: Small Is Beautiful; Washington, La.
description: On a warm spring day, people in Washington, La., are sitting on their front stoops listening to zydeco or gospel and eating ham sandwiches and drinking bottles of Turbo Dog. It's spring, and it's so green you can't believe it: there are tendrils of lacy light green Spanish moss, thick patches of overgrown grass, rubbery leaves, shiny dark green magnolias the color of English club leather, vines growing around vines growing around thick lichen-covered trunks. Green grasshoppers and green lizards -- a crazy, patchwork quilt of green, the human creatures moving through it (drinking beer, eating potato chips) like fish. Or maybe it's just the frozen-in-time quality of the whole town: Brigadoon on Bayou Courtableau.

title: The Way We Live Now: 5-9-99: Salient Facts: Cheap Roses; The $4 Bouquet
description: Competition, oversupply and technology have brought the price of those Mother's Day roses lower than anyone thought possible. How does it all add up? And will Mom be able to tell how little you spent?

title: Finally, Artists Free of Government; Nudity Not Included
description: To the Editor:

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry
description: The Marching Season By Daniel Silva. Random House, $25.95.

title: Sandy Falk and Daniel Judson
description: Dr. Sandy Jane Falk and Rabbi Daniel Judson are to be married today at the Cordts Mansion in Kingston, N.Y., by Rabbi Zoe Klein.

title: How Much Protection For Bank Customers?
description: YOUR bank can collect details about your spending habits, like how much you charged last year at lingerie, liquor and lawn-and-garden stores, and then sell that information to companies that market bras, booze and bug killers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPEL, EMANUEL L.
description: KAPEL-Emanuel L. Age 98, of Florida, formerly of New York, died on Saturday, May 1st, 1999. Beloved husband of the late Betty. Devoted father of Dr. Saul (Harriet Chaprack) Kapel of Scarsdale, New York, and Arthur (Muriel) Kapel of FL. Loving grandfather of Dr. Sherri Kapel Kaplan (Dr. Marc Kaplan) of Scarsdale, NY; Karen Kapel Astrachan (Dr. David Astrachan) of CT, and Dr. Robert C. (Jamie Klein) Kapel of CT. Also, Clifford (Lee) Kapel, and Jorie (Gary) Rafelowski of FL and Heidi (Dr. Joel) Thirer of New York. Great grandfather of 14.

title: Will Less Be More In Seattle?
description: Lou Piniella was lamenting the state of his league-worst pitching staff yesterday. He cited, among other ulcer-producing elements, his middle relief problems.

title: Seeking the Death of the Poison Pill
description: WHEN the Chubb Corporation, an insurance company known for the gilt-edged coverage favored by some of the wealthiest Americans, held its annual meeting last month at its headquarters in Warren, N.J., there was a prickly item on the agenda.

title: Offerings on Line? Better Get in Line
description: Investors who signed up with on-line brokerages to get access to initial public offerings of stocks are instead getting a lesson in the laws of supply and demand.

title: The Best
description: I have to object to John Lukacs's description of Christopher Columbus as a ''loser,'' in the company of V.I. Lenin and Dom Perignon. If I have to lose, I would like to lose like this.

title: A Sculpture Garden at the National Gallery
description: The National Gallery of Art will open a sculpture garden on a six-acre site near its West Building on May 23, providing an outdoor setting for the works of such artists as Louise Bourgeois, Mark di Suvero, Roy Lichtenstein, Sol LeWitt, Ellsworth Kelly, Lucas Samaras, Claes Oldenburg and Coosje van Bruggen, and Tony Smith.

title: Donald Stewart, 69; Writer of Screenplays
description: Donald Stewart, a screenwriter who won an Academy Award for ''Missing,'' the 1982 Constantin Costa-Gavras film, died on April 28 at his home in Los Angeles. He was 69.

title: High Hopes Take a Hard Hit
description: The decision by Robert K. Kraft, the owner of the New England Patriots, to keep his team in Massachusetts left more than Gov. John G. Rowland and thousands of Connecticut football fans disappointed.

title: Food, Too, Is an Art in Bilbao
description: THE titanium skin of the Guggenheim Museum shimmers gold or silver as the light strikes it, a celestial castle in a constellation of twinkling stars.

title: INSIDE
description: Knicks Rout Miami

title: The Curse of the Whitney
description: Like all other American art museums, the Whitney has adapted to changing circumstances over its history. Arthur Lubow's article (April 11) found our history to be an exception when it is, in fact, the rule for all such institutions.

title: PULSE; Champagne on Ice
description: Raise your cones and make a toast? Cones Ice Cream Artisans (272 Bleecker Street) is offering Lemon D. P. sorbet, made with Dom Perignon Champagne. Cones has made a Champagne flavor in the past, with a lesser brand, but for its millennial flavor, the company's owner, Raul D'Aloisio, wanted to ''go really upscale.'' Upscale indeed. At $18 a pint, Lemon D. P. is twice the price of its other flavors; a thimble-size tasting spoonful is $1. Nonetheless, the maestro heladero, or master ice cream maker, as Mr. D'Aloisio would be known in his native Argentina, is already popping corks for a new batch. It is subtler than other Cones flavors like Zabayone, made with port, Marsala and Cognac. And since Mr. D'Aloisio uses only one bottle of Dom Perignon for every two gallons of sorbet, you can down a few cones and still drive home. KEVIN BISCH

title: Arrest of an Imam Splits Bengalis
description: A Muslim cleric from Bangladesh has been arrested on charges that he molested two boys, now 10 and 17, at his mosque near the border of Ozone Park, Queens, and East New York, Brooklyn. The accusations have divided Bengalis in the neighborhood and across the city.

title: Investors Ask: Where to Go From Here?
description: Markets around the world have been on pins and needles awaiting guidance from the United States. As overseas investors watched the week's divergent paths, they might have thought they had come upon a one-way sign with arrows pointing in opposite directions.

title: Ideas & Trends; Caution: Exploding Donkey
description: IN the film ''There's Something About Mary,'' a small dog flies out a window. In ''As Good as It Gets,'' a pooch is crammed down a trash chute. In ''EdTV,'' a love scene culminates in Matthew McConaughey falling on a cat. In ''Men in Black,'' an alien-pug confesses after it is mercilessly shaken. Even the preview for ''Idle Hands'' shows a cat being swung around by its tail.

title: Air Force Is Asked to Pay For Fire From Stray Bomb
description: Aerial bombs, especially errant ones, have been much in the news lately. Now, one in New Jersey has been blamed for a fire that damaged more than 11,000 acres of the Pine Barrens in Burlington County last week, and state forest officials want the Air Force to pay the bill.

title: Leagues Fear a Con Ed Rise
description: Every night on Staten Island, the Little Leagues take to the field, the crowds cheer, the bats ping and the lights buzz. Lately, it is the buzz that worries league organizers.

title: Bistro for Truckers? Mais Oui, on Route 1
description: DO not be deterred by the unprepossessing exterior of Cafe Routier, its pedestrian sign and subtitle, The Truck Stop Cafe, along U.S. 1 in Old Saybrook. One glance in the door was enough to lure us all the way inside. Everything seemed to sparkle: the glassware, the white walls, the pale turquoise free-form service plates.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLSTEIN, GILBERT
description: MILLSTEIN-Gilbert. Age 83, on May 8, 1999. Beloved husband of Barbara Head Millstein. Father of Ezra, Josh and Jon Millstein, and step-father of Tamar. Grandfather of Toby, Nathaniel, Jacob, Issac, and Nicholas. Memorial service to be announced.
