title: International Zone In the West Village
description: CAFE FES+

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAYER, GERALD
description: MAYER-Gerald. On May 8, 1999. Dear husband of Miriam. Father of Cynthia and Robert. Grandfather of Scott, Nick and Sam. Services Sunday, 12 noon, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th and Amsterdam.

title: The Nightmare of Glen Ridge Is Never Put to Rest
description: Once again, people here are bracing for the worst. Ten years ago, this town of emerald lawns and turn-of-the-century homes was rocked when a retarded 17-year-old girl was raped by a group of high school athletes.

title: Ms. Rosen, Mr. Blakeman
description: Rachel Lisa Rosen and Richard Dandridge Blakeman were married last evening at the St. Regis in New York. Rabbi Charles Lippman officiated at the ceremony, in which the Rev. R. John Nelson, a Roman Catholic priest, took part.

title: GOING OUT
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Hadassah Also Offers Literacy Tutoring
description: In the article on literacy groups [''Literacy Groups: Filling One of Life's Needs,'' May 2], various groups that help in reading or volunteering were mentioned, but the organization we represent was not listed. The Westchester Region of Hadassah has about 9,000 members and is participating in a Volunteer tutoring program called Read Write Now, sponsored by the U.S. Department of Education, plus Hadassah and other organizations.

title: A Garbage Heap Turns to Paradise; More Island Landfills Could Become Parks
description: WHEN Jay J. Pitti went crabbing on a patch of tidal marshland here as a youth back in the 1930's, it made a lasting impression that inspired him to action half a century later.

title: Paris Dining: Lemon Grass and Ginger? Oui et Non
description: I have lived in Paris for almost 20 years, following the birth and death, rise and fall, of the city's restaurants. From the heady and confusing days of nouvelle cuisine to the emergence of the superstar chef in the 1980's to the present, the Paris restaurant scene has been fluid, exciting and at times perplexing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHER, NICHOLAS T.
description: FISHER-Nicholas T. Beloved son of Philip B. Fisher and the late Emily N. Fisher, brother of Emily, Philip and Kate. Stepson of Diana Y. Fisher and stepbrother of Amory Y., Laughlin H., and Victoria A. L. Clarke. Memorial service Sunday, May 9, 6:00 PM, Church of the Heavenly Rest, 5th Ave. & 90th St.

title: Stars as Starlets
description: In the boardinghouse for theatrical girls, two adversaries, an aristocratic Katharine Hepburn and an earthy Ginger Rogers, are roommates. Their story, and those of other aspiring actresses, is the focus of STAGE DOOR, a 1937 film whose impressive cast includes Adolphe Menjou (above, with Ms. Hepburn), Andrewa Leeds, Ann Miller, Eve Arden and Lucille Ball. Originally a play by George S. Kaufman and Edna Ferber, the film was supposedly referred to as ''Screen Door'' by Mr. Kaufman, but never mind, it's all that an adaptation should be. The charm is in the homey, often prickly ambience of the boardinghouse and the peppery dialogue, which lend a superb authenticity to the proceedings. - WEDNESDAY at 8 A.M. and THURSDAY at 9:30 P.M. on TCM.

title: Views From an Old Distillery in Peekskill
description: WHEN forsythia bloom, all manner of spring chores suddenly need tending. Long hours in the garden leave little time for the kitchen, and spring and recaptured daylight somehow demand a fresh view. Along the lower Hudson's shores, abandoned industrial posts are being increasingly and lovingly translated into capacious restaurants, and the reclamation at Crystal Bay is one of the best.

title: Layover Laps
description: The Korean National Tourism Office has come up with a way to fill the hours for passengers with a layover at Kimpo International Airport in Seoul. The Seoul City Tour, designed for passengers who land in the morning and must wait at least six hours for their next flight, departs at 8:30 A.M. The destinations include the Blue House (the presidential residence), Kyongbokkung Palace and Chogyesa Temple, and there is a stop for lunch. The tour returns to the airport at 1 P.M.

title: He Leered. Did He Learn?
description: Q. During a recent office trip to a regional meeting, I had a run-in with one of the top executives. On the return bus ride, the executive, having had one too many that evening, took the seat next to me and proceeded to make advances -- verbal and physical -- for two hours. Not wanting to cause a scene, I sat quietly, trying to steer the conversation in a safe direction. (Many of my co-workers were asleep and probably didn't witness the incident.) The next day, the executive acted as though nothing had happened. After several days, I confronted him; he apologized and expressed great embarrassment. Three weeks later, I'm still enraged, hurt and uncomfortable at work. What should I do next?

title: Al Gore's Money Problem
description: The Vice President stood before 40 wealthy Democrats in the Fifth Avenue palazzo of the Lazard Fr res executive Steven Rattner, a stunning place with marble columns and a view over the Metropolitan Museum. The guests, bathed in candlelight, nibbled at apple crisp and whipped cream. To be here, each had promised to raise at least $35,000 for Al Gore's Presidential quest.

title: Faith and Medicine
description: To the Editor:

title: Our Towns; For Students, Security Rules Add to Unease
description: LAST fall, town officials wanted to put a full-time plainclothes police officer in South Brunswick High School. The hope was that students would get to know the police a little better and everyone would be a little safer. But some seniors objected on principle and the idea was shelved.

title: A Furniture Maker Who Paid Homage to the Tree
description: NEARLY 40 years ago, when Roland and Victoria Fiore went to a local fair at St. Martin's Church in New Hope, Pa., they won a small cherry wood stool by the designer George Nakashima, who lived in the area. The couple became friendly with him and, by the mid-1970's, Ms. Fiore, 77, a former opera singer, was spending Saturdays at his studio. For the next 15 years, she helped out there as a receptionist, receiving $100 every month, earnings that she diligently applied to buying her employer's furniture.

title: A Global Vote For U.S. Style Of Corporate Openness
description: IF the people who wield the big money have anything to say about it, country-to-country differences in corporate governance practices will give way to a homogenous global approach based largely on the American and British model.

title: Florio's (Land Use) Plan For Taking On Whitman
description: It has been called sustainable development and balanced growth and now smart growth. But the concept of controlling suburban growth has never yet been called a political winning hand. Until now.

title: POSTINGS: More New York City Movie Screens; A Multitude Of Multiplexes
description: New York City is in the midst of a movie theater building boom that will see the number of Manhattan screens available for viewing increase by 64 percent from 166 to 273 when projects under way or planned are completed, according to a study by PricewaterhouseCoopers, an accounting and consulting firm.

title: To Fly, Not to Shop
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVY, GILBERT
description: LEVY-Gilbert. Of Princeton, NJ. Devoted husband, father, grandfather. Preceded in death by his wife Roslyn and grandson Samuel Alpert. Survived by daughter and son-in-law Andrea and Arnold Alpert of Columbus, Ohio, son and daughter-in-law Joel and Rae Levy of Richmond, Virginia, grandson Michael Alpert. Service Sunday at 1PM at Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, West 150 Route 4, Paramus, NJ.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry
description: The Late Mr. Shakespeare By Robert Nye. Arcade, $25.95.

title: Not Doing What the Romans Do
description: WHEN Kay Ainsley of Detroit traveled to Saudi Arabia several years ago to sell the rights to open Domino's Pizza shops there, she felt the full force of being a woman in a man's land.

title: Q and A
description: Dude Ranches

title: Preserving Land Requires Bipartisanship
description: My good friend Martin Cantor knows more about economics than politics. In his letter ''Wrong Policy on Sale of Kings Park Site,'' [May 2], he correctly points out that it makes no sense to sell off state-owned property that is potential park land while the state is spending millions to buy other land for parks from private owners. He correctly faults the Empire State Development Corporation for trying to do this at the former Kings Park Psychiatric Center.

title: Editorial Observer; Bankruptcy Reform That Spares the Wealthy
description: Watching a rich man stiff his creditors while walking away with millions can grate on people. Yet a gaping loophole in the bankruptcy laws routinely allows that to happen.

title: IN PERSON: A Cloud Over the G.O.P.'s Silver Lining in Essex County; After a Troubled Murder Investigation in Orange, James W. Treffinger Tangles With a Protege
description: JAMES W. TREFFINGER'S wife, Janet, has a name for it. She calls the decision five years ago -- when her husband chucked his lucrative partnership at a Wall Street law firm to become the first Republican county executive in Essex County in 35 years -- his ''midlife crisis.''

title: In the Region / Long Island; Services for the Elderly Who Don't Want to Move
description: FOR Martin P. Rosenblum and his wife, Sally, who have lived in their Valley Stream ranch for 43 years, the idea of moving to a condominium or similar situation where many day-to-day chores are taken care of, holds no appeal.

title: Rowdy Irishman Wins by a Neck
description: Rowdy Irishman staged a furious drive for the last eighth of mile to win the $100,000 Iroquois Steeplechase for the second year in row yesterday in Nashville.

title: For Laughs
description: To the Editor:

title: Open-Space Referendum Takes Form of Legislation
description: In November, voters overwhelmingly approved a referendum dedicating $98 million a year for 10 years to preserve open space. But that cannot happen until a law is passed appropriating the money. A bill to do just that was introduced last week in the Senate and Assembly and is expected to move quickly through the Legislature.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZINOVITCH, MOSHE
description: ZINOVITCH-Moshe. Congregation Kehilath Jeshurun and its Sisterhood mourn the passing of the beloved father of their devoted member Zahava Kohen, and extend heartfelt condolences to all members of the bereaved family. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein Rabbi Joshua Lookstein Fred Distenfeld, President

title: The Road Not Taken
description: Leslie H. Wexner, chairman and chief executive of The Limited Inc., knows a good deal when he sees one -- and, presumably, a bad one, too. Last week, his board let him escape from one of the latter, a deal that could have forced him to sell nearly one-third of his Limited shares back at $25, half the current market price.

title: Using Ingredients of the Season Eliminates Some Frustration
description: BEFORE the cooking, the serving and the enjoying, there has to be the shopping. And when entertaining, it is important to plan meals that depend on readily available ingredients -- to avoid trouble. Taking seasonality into account is often useful. To plan a cranberry dessert in spring or one calling for rhubarb in November would only invite frustration in the supermarket.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PITKIN, LILLIAN
description: PITKIN-Lillian. On May 7, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Albert. Devoted mother of Carole Chanler, Joyce & Shelly Pitkin. Loving grandmother of Cliff & Lauren, Annie & Andy, Billy & Jen, Carla & Daniel, and Franklin & Sharon. Proud great-grandmother of Alexandra, Kaya, Casey, David and Alexis. Services at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave., New York City, on Monday, May 11 at 12:30 PM.

title: Social Climbers
description: HIGH EXPOSURE

title: Ms. Beldegreen, Mr. DiCandido
description: Lynne Julianna Beldegreen and Michael John DiCandido were married last evening at the East Side Marriott Hotel in Manhattan. Rabbi Marcia R. Rappaport officiated at the ceremony, in which Msgr. Martin P. Ryan took part.

title: SOAPBOX; My Kosovar
description: AN exhausted face looks up at me out of a picture in the morning paper. Just another Kosovar, looking sad and confused. Yes, it's all been seen many times before, and can't we move on to something more interesting?

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: May 9, 1999
description: Weeks

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: COOPER SQUARE

title: Q&A/Linda C. Fentiman; Call to Monitor Long-Distance Health Care
description: TELE-MEDICINE is a field where law and ethics are lagging far behind what is going on, said Linda C. Fentiman, director of the Health Law and Policy Program at Pace University School of Law in White Plains. It is a trend that not only has the potential to expand access dramatically to quality health care, she said, but also to make it more impersonal, to reduce health-care costs -- or even increase them -- and to destroy a patient's right to privacy. And, she asks, Who should be regulating such practitioners?

title: Lifelong Rivals, 62 and 68, Meet in a Nostalgic Match
description: Matches, one on one confrontations, are contested for serious objectives, like the world championship. They are also arranged as exhibitions, with the aim, as far as the players are concerned, of winning the prizes that the sponsors put up. These objectives usually overlap.

title: Baby Tarpon Provide Everglades Challenge
description: Somewhere among the endless mangrove forests and sawgrass prairies of North America's last tropical wilderness lies a brackish-water creek filled with baby tarpon -- fish in the 5- to-30-pound range that have perhaps never seen a fly. I found this out last year from a fishing guide I met in the Florida Keys who had returned from a sort of busman's holiday.

title: After Waiting for Years, Students in Wheelchairs Get Lift
description: Since 1993, a stretch of West Street near Chambers Street has been known as Suicide Highway to the wheelchair students of P.S. 811M, a small school for the handicapped that is based in Stuyvesant High School.

title: Sounds of Spring: Beeping Ball, Buzzing Base
description: THE normal instinct at a baseball game is to cheer. But as the ball soared into the air at the Long Island Bombers' season opener against the Long Island Shooters on a recent Sunday, the crowd on the sidelines was unnaturally quiet.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   BRUN, MARCIA
description: BRUN-Marcia 4/11/22-5/10/96. 3 long years, it is still painful without you. Happy Mothers Day. Hugs and kisses.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MALLER, DR. JULIUS B.
description: MALLER-Dr. Julius B. In loving memory of Dr. Julius B. Maller who passed away May 8, 1959. In our hearts, like yesterday.

title: La Plaza: 1 Life Used, 8 Left
description: If things continue the way they have, La Plaza Cultural, a community garden and performance area on city land in the East Village, may need to use all of its nine lives.

title: Rio Grande, Ciudad Juarez
description: A good part of my life has been spent looking at or living in Ciudad Jurez, Mexico. I am one of the chroniclers of the town, having written about it in two novels and many articles and essays. When I am away from Jurez, I wonder why I wandered, and when I am there, I wonder why I came back. It is one of the funniest and most tragic cities in North America, and no matter how many times I go back to it, Jurez is never the same. It has a history that would have pleased Heraclitus.

title: Tara Suit Dismissed
description: A Federal Appeals Court in Manhattan has upheld the dismissal of an Irish cultural organization's $250 million civil rights lawsuit against the Village of Briarcliff Manor. Ralph K. Winter, the presiding judge on a three-member panel of the Second Circuit Court of Appeals, said village officials did not violate the civil rights of Irish-Americans when Tara Circle tried and failed to buy the King's College campus in the village and establish an athletic, educational and cultural center.

title: Gulpers Need Not Apply
description: Roger Dagorn, the insightful wine director of the restaurant Chanterelle, offers J. J. Vincent's 1997 Domaine des Morats, Saint-V'eran, a minerally white southern Burgundy, by the glass ($8.50). The British critic Hugh Johnson might well approve. The Saint-V'eran appellation, he observes, abuts Pouilly-Fuiss'e: ''Similar wines, better value.''

title: An Impresario of Name Brands
description: JOHN SCHREIBER may resemble an advertising executive in some ways, but his casually rumpled look is clearly not one of them.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  REEVES, MINNA.
description: REEVES-Minna. Her beauty, charm, talent, and filial devotion are remembered this Mother's Day and everyday with love and gratitude.

title: Ruth Raskas, Nigel Ohrenstein
description: Ruth Sara Raskas, a daughter of Adinah Raskas and Dr. Heschel Raskas of St. Louis, is to be married this afternoon to Nigel Mark Ohrenstein, a son of Avril and Peter Ohrenstein of London. Rabbi Shlomo Riskin, the chief rabbi of Efrat, Israel, is to officiate at the Adams Mark Hotel in St. Louis.

title: At a Carwash Convention, Soft Soap Meets the Hard Sell
description: A HYPNOTIC fugue has fallen over the crowd watching the Mac Neil RW-102's. The powerful water sprayers gyrate frantically inside a stainless-steel cuff. Nearby, attached to an overhead arch like you might see at a carwash, the nozzles stop and turn, flip and churn, like choreographed stage lights at a Broadway musical. People wobble their heads unconsciously as they watch the water cannons dance.

title: Orange Will Indeed Never Be Knocked Out
description: To the Editor:

title: My Clubs, Please
description: To the Editor: Your article ''Meet Your Clubs on the Links'' (April 4), recommends sending your golf clubs ahead of you by Federal Express or United Parcel. It is an idea that I like.

title: Safety Board Says F.B.I. Withheld Jet Crash Report
description: After prolonged jurisdictional jostling between the F.B.I. and the National Transportation Safety Board over the investigation into why Trans World Airlines Flight 800 exploded three years ago, the safety board is throwing some political punches.

title: A Chance to Break the Pop Stranglehold
description: THERE are two great pop music dreams. And they usually follow each other, like marriage and divorce. The first great dream is to get together with friends in a basement or garage, write songs, make music, feel the magic and perform at local clubs until a big record label rushes in waving a contract. And then the label takes care of the rest: hit singles, arena shows, limos, parties, a new house for mom. But the dream, even for those few who actually get to live it, has usually been a nightmare.

title: Jeffrey Glassman, Ellen Polin
description: Ellen L. Polin, a singer, and Jeffrey M. Glassman, a foreign service officer, are to be married this afternoon by Rabbi Gershon Sonnenschein at Congregation Rodphey Sholom in Holyoke, Mass.

title: Truer to the Main Men Of 'The Third Man'
description: FROM the start of the director's cut of his ''Third Man,'' Carol Reed works a cascade of contrasts into the texture and rhythm of the movie. When it accelerates, it isn't because Reed feels he has to prod the audience; when it slows, it isn't because he has lost control of his yarn-spinning. He is simply proceeding on instinct to reveal the characters and the milieu in the most apt, musical way.

Ms. Kruth, the mother of two young children, said that's why the time is right for Green Onion, the children's store she opened two weeks ago at 247 Smith Street between Sackett and Degraw Streets. She said she intends the store to be an ''upscale but affordable'' one-stop shop for everything children, from newborn to age 7, need.

There is no more call for Mr. Dohnanyi's old quip that whenever he conducted well, it was Szell who got the good mentions.

title: In the Region /New Jersey; As Available Sites Dwindle, Housing Prices Rise
description: WHEN Alexandra M. Sirio sold her two-bedroom town-house unit in Mahwah last month, it fetched more than $10,000 above the $176,000 she paid for it two years ago. But she did not realize that trading up to a single-family detached house elsewhere in Bergen County would be fraught with frustration.

title: Sydney Sets the Stage For 2000 Olympic Games
description: EVEN as the scent of scandal pervades the Olympic Winter Games scheduled for Salt Lake City in 2002, Sydney, Australia, host of the 2000 Summer Games, is well along with its multibillion-dollar program to build and renovate athletic fields, stadiums, parks and infrastructure. In fact, some stadiums and fields are already holding events, in part to test the people-moving machinery, and tourists traveling to Sydney anytime soon might want to check them out.

title: Food; Let Them Eat Cheesecake
description: Sweet cheese is the trompe l'oeil of food. It will try to trick you; it supplies both the illusion of lightness and the satisfaction of having eaten something really, really sinful. Made fresh at home, it can be richer than anything sold in supermarkets, which is one reason for you to go through all that effort of curdling and draining. The other is the nuance and purity of truly fresh fromage. With fresh cheese desserts, you can remain innocent or cop to the indulgence -- whatever your pleasure. Just remember that deceit is central to even the most innocent of illicit allures.

title: In The Republic Of Georgia, Beauty And The Beast
description: As my plane full of foreign-aid workers, missionaries, diplomats and journalists descended toward Tbilisi, torrential rain began to beat against the windowpanes. I was delighted. Yes, it really was ''A Rainy Night in Georgia.'' It was well past midnight as I drove into town, so I was impressed by the astonishing number of brightly lighted, closet-size stores selling every imaginable variety of alcohol. The effect was decidedly festive, even on a rainy night, and it gave me my first hint of Georgian priorities.

title: East River, Brooklyn
description: I often forget that I grew up in Brooklyn, which is odd because Brooklyn is where I long ago came back to live. My memory lapse is not a sign of old age -- I've just turned 44 -- so much as it is an indication of the vastness and complexity of my hometown.

title: The Nation: By the Numbers; Science Looks at Littleton, and Shrugs
description: THE bullets were still ricocheting off the lockers at Columbine High School when the accusations began to fly. Clues were ignored: Gothic music, black trench coats, video games spelling combat with a K. The sheriffs missed the Web site ravings. The psychiatrist missed the hidden rage. The parents missed the pipe bombs. If only somebody had spotted the warning signs, a terrible tragedy might have been averted.

title: Manitoba's Bears
description: To the Editor: Joni Seager stayed in an army barracks. We were housed in a modern motel, of which there must be 20 or 30 in Churchill, all family operated. They look Spartan, but are actually very comfortable, most with three sets of doors into the lobby to avoid the cold winds. The rooms were small but had good beds with either heavy wool blankets or down comforters. The lounge or lobby had coffee and hot water for cocoa and tea. We were transported from motel to the tundra buggies in school buses.

Invitations get lost, and so do the guests. But now some galleries are taking practical steps to insure that the party goes on without a hitch by opening trendy hangouts within their own hallowed walls.

title: Standing Up, Being Counted
description: THE only clear thing about the critical reaction to ''The Clearing'' at Hartford Stage Company is that history repeats itself. The new play about the crushing of the Irish rebellion by Oliver Cromwell's parliamentary forces in the mid-17th century opened last month. It was clearly not meant as a textbook case study or as a history lesson.

title: Employee Stock Plans Pay Off in Performance
description: SETTING up an employee stock ownership plan improves companies' financial performance, not just staff morale, according to a new study of the plans by Hewitt Associates, a consulting firm based in Lincolnshire, Ill.

title: The Curse of the Whitney
description: The Whitney needs to let go of some of its past in the form of the present building. The lobby is tired; the downstairs space, a wasted exhibition area -- neither fish nor fowl. Tear the building down and rebuild it from scratch or build upward, with a restaurant and sculpture garden on the roof and nothing but galleries on the street and lower levels. (Or commit the lower level entirely to commerce in the form of a vibrant cafe and bookstore combined.) The downstairs open-air area has not been used -- or cannot be used for conservation and insurance reasons -- for the American Century exhibit. Perhaps it should be ingeniously covered with glass, still offering the passer-by a glimpse of alluring contents while creating a continuous covered exhibition area. And why not let those areas be free to the visitor, with paid admissions for the upstairs galleries only?

title: Help for Vast African Refugee Crisis May Suffer in Kosovo's Shadow, Aid Groups Say
description: There are no oranges at the refugee camp here, no canned fish or meat, no press-packed visits from the British Prime Minister, Tony Blair.

title: Corrections
description: The Working column on April 25, about personal questions in job interviews, misstated the legal treatment of interview questions involving a potential employee's pregnancy or child-bearing plans. Under Federal law, a company cannot use the answers to such questions in a decision on hiring, but it is not prohibited from asking them. The courts, however, usually regard such questions as evidence that pregnancy was a factor in refusing to hire someone, according to a lawyer at the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; The Secret Language of Quilts
description: In HIDDEN IN PLAIN VIEW: The Secret Story of Quilts and the Underground Railroad (Doubleday, $27.50), Jacqueline L. Tobin and Raymond G. Dobard present the fascinating theory that slaves created quilts coded with patterns to help one another flee to freedom. Though Quakers and other congregations, black fraternal organizations and American Indians helped slaves to escape, Tobin and Dobard state that ''far from being passive victims waiting to be rescued, enslaved blacks never ceased in their struggle for freedom.'' What seemed to be their simple quilting was much more: ''Since it was the law that slaves were not allowed to be taught to read or write, other methods were needed to insure successful efforts for escape.'' Quilts were set out in windows or on fences in front of slave cabins to signal trustworthy slaves to take particular actions. Despite its clunky academic writing and the lack of a much-needed index, ''Hidden in Plain View'' is mesmerizing. In 1994 in the Old Marketplace of Charleston, S.C., Tobin met an elderly black quilter, Ozella McDaniel Williams, who alluded to the role of quilts in the underground railroad to freedom. Tobin, who teaches women's studies at the University of Denver, and Dobard, a quilter and art history professor at Howard University, devoted themselves to cracking the code of the quilts. The Underground Railroad Quilt Code, they write, comprises 10 patterns. The Monkey Wrench pattern quilt, for instance, told slaves to begin their escape preparations by collecting tools for their journey; the Tumbling Boxes pattern indicated that it was time for ''packing up and moving on.'' Five square knots indicated distance and invoked the protection of God and the ancestors, something the slaves needed most of all. Andrea Higbie

title: Avoiding the Lines, For A Fee
description: Although managing lines has become a high art at theme parks, long waits -- sometimes up to two hours -- at the most popular attractions (some of which last less than a minute) are a fact of life. In Orlando, at Universal Studios Escape, it's possible to jump the lines -- for a price. For $1,500 (admission included), up to 15 people can take an eight-hour guided tour with unlimited access to rides. Visitors are escorted discreetly through a private entrance so that those who wait won't be aware that they've been bumped. A five-hour option with the same privileges is $110 a person. Reservations required; (407) 363-8295.

Now it's also a tourist mecca, with idling buses discharging out-of-towners eager to sample the latest attractions of Planet Hollywood and Motown Cafe.

title: Of Bad Manners In a Nasty Society
description: IN 1966, at the age of 34, the English playwright Joe Orton said, ''I'd like to write a play as good as 'The Importance of Being Earnest.' '' That was a year before he was hammered to death by his companion and collaborator, Kenneth Halliwell, who then swallowed 22 Nembutals and died faster than Orton.

title: U.S. National Team Has Redefined 'Soccer Mom'
description: They were pioneers as American soccer players, star defenders on teams that won a world championship in 1991 and an Olympic gold medal in 1996, and now they are plowing new cultural ground as soccer moms.

title: Making the Most of Life at Etna's Feet
description: IT took a long time and a new friend before I could warm up to Catania, Sicily's second city on the east coast. From the train station, Catania looked dark and dreary, even with snowcapped Mount Etna, Europe's largest active volcano, towering over it. I had only passed through on my way to the villages on Etna's flanks, and I always hoped that some day I'd meet a Catanian to show me the city through the eyes of one who loved it.

title: DNA Backs a Tribe's Tradition Of Early Descent From the Jews
description: The Lemba, a Bantu-speaking people of southern Africa, have a tradition that they were led out of Judea by a man named Buba. They practice circumcision, keep one day a week holy and avoid eating pork or piglike animals, such as the hippopotamus.

title: A Stairway to Heaven
description: I have craved rooftop dinners in springtime since I lived in Washington. The Georgetown and Adams-Morgan neighborhoods have many restaurants whose abutting roofs offer casual seating, candlelight, rejuvenating jazz and cool cocktails and a look at the festive street life below.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DRATT, ROSE
description: DRATT-Rose. As sorrow envelopes me so does loneliness and despair. But your wonderful love sustains me each heart brokern day. You taught me how to be brave. You will always be our guiding light. Your One and Only

title: Applying Tinted Film to Windows
description: MOST windows allow cold to pass through the glass in the winter, and heat in the summer. This can make the home uncomfortable and drive energy bills up. In an effort to make windows more efficient, manufacturers have introduced gas-filled tinted-glass windows. These windows are very efficient, but they are also expensive.

title: BENEFITS
description: Manhattan Theater Club

title: Nancy Klein, David Mannis
description: Nancy Linda Klein and David Andrew Mannis were married on Wednesday at the State Court of Claims in New York. Judge Albert A. Blinder, a retired judge of that court, officiated.

title: Kyra Chenoweth, Anthony Michelini
description: Kyra Marie Chenoweth and Anthony Joseph Michelini were married yesterday by the Rev. Kenneth P. Jasko, an Assembly of God minister, in a nondenominational ceremony at the Waterwitch Club House in Atlantic Highlands, N.J.

title: A New Fund Manager? Don't Worry, Be Happy
description: Those who bite their nails when a portfolio manager departs a favorite mutual fund may well be fretting needlessly. A new study by Value Line, the research firm, has found that funds with new managers tend to go through a one-year period of lagging performance vis-a-vis their peers, but then go on to beat them over the three-year period after the change.

title: For Heroin's New Users, a Long, Hard Fall; Couple's Addiction Reflects Lure of a Purer, More Potent Drug
description: After 18 years of marriage, Paul and Kathy Schroeder squabble not about money or in-laws but about heroin. ''She thinks I'm taking from her,'' he said, ''and I accuse her of taking from me.''

title: An Internet Play for Widows and Orphans
description: AT&T'S transformation from telecommunications dinosaur to technology-stock dynamo may have been clinched this week with the company's $58 billion deal to buy Mediaone Group, one of the nation's biggest cable television operators. The deal, combined with the recent purchase of Tele-Communications Inc., means that AT&T will become the largest cable company in the United States, with 16 million customers and networks reaching more than 26 million homes.

title: A Ragamuffin Tory
description: To the Editor:

title: Word for Word: Baseball Scouting Reports; Soft Hands, Bat-Breaking Kinks And Other Intimations of Immortality
description: SPRING is the beginning of the baseball season for 750 major leaguers, but for the scouts who scour the nation trying to locate the next generation of players, this is their pennant race.

title: Chinese Evacuate a Bombed Embassy in Serbia
description: Chinese Embassy personnel were packing up, loading up their cars and dragging suitcases across the forecourt of their bombed embassy, still dazed and shaken after a NATO raid hit the building overnight.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Best Bet

title: Congressman's Move Buoys a City's Hopes
description: As long as a member of Congress keeps a place back home, the exact address is usually of little moment. But when Representative Christopher Shays moved 20 miles up Interstate 95 this week, it was treated as a seismic political event in Fairfield County.

title: Calvert Saunders, George Moore
description: Mariah Calvert Claud Saunders, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas A. Saunders 3d of New York, was married last evening to George Braniff Moore, the son of Mr. and Mrs. George B. Moore of New Canaan, Conn. Bishop Richard F. Grein of the Episcopal Diocese of New York performed the ceremony at St. James' Church in New York.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry; The Freelancer
description: By the time he was 28, Anton Chekhov had published more than 500 short works of fiction, about half of them comic stories and farces. This apprentice writing, dashed off while he was ''chasing two hares at once'' -- his medical career and his modest literary pursuits -- has usually been regarded as negligible stuff, cut to the requirements of Moscow's popular magazines, which paid the young writer a few kopecks a line. Harvey Pitcher endeavors to correct this judgment in the 40 stories he has translated and assembled in CHEKHOV: The Comic Stories (Ivan R. Dee, $26). While a few of the earliest pieces are little more than sketches, most of these tales offer far greater pleasures, among them penetrating social satire and trenchant character analysis. In one, for example, a man of supposed high ideals rents a country house from a captivating young female, whose charms delight him until he is presented with a bill for the extras he took for granted during his long stay. In another, a lowly civil servant, kept awake at night by worries about how to use an exclamation mark, realizes that in 40 years of writing documents he ''couldn't remember a single line expressing delight, indignation or anything of that kind.'' In story after story, Chekhov displays techniques -- especially the use of a few telling details to suggest a whole -- that he would later employ to stunning effect. ''Everything I've written to date is nonsense,'' Chekhov wrote in 1888. This collection reveals how delicious such ''nonsense'' could be. Philip Gambone

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHLAGEL, HELEN
description: SCHLAGEL - Helen. Devoted mother and grandmother, wonderful professional woman, died on May 7, 1999, with her daughters Amy and Laurie and son-in-law Joe at her side. Shiva at 13417 Briar Path Lane, Silver Spring, MD. Contributions to Jewish Social Services Hospice, Rockville, MD.

title: Leon Barzin, 98, Conductor Of Ballets and Music Educator
description: Leon Barzin, musical director of the New York City Ballet in the 1940's and 50's and the head of the National Orchestra Association for 36 years, died April 29 at his home in Naples, Fla. He was 98.

title: Getting Hooked Faster, but Why?
description: As a nickname for heroin, P-dope has been around for years. But among many current users, the belief has spread that distributors are doctoring P-dope with adulterants to make it cut through methadone, the heroin blocker, to avoid losing customers to treatment clinics.

title: A Face Lift for Bloomingdale's in White Plains
description: RECALLING the opening of Bloomingdale's in New Rochelle more than 50 years ago, Robert J. Streger, president of the New Rochelle Chamber of Commerce, said: ''It was a big event. My mother and her friends were thrilled. Bloomingdale's had come to Westchester. Now they wouldn't have to go to the city to shop anymore.''

title: Debunking the Dual-Loyalty Myth
description: In the early 1980's, my father returned to China to visit his family for the first time since he had left in 1949. An old friend, whom he hadn't seen in decades, invited him to give a talk to the Chinese Light Industry Department. Although my father was happy to see his friend, he was careful not to discuss the research he was doing in the United States, even though he is not a nuclear scientist or a physicist but a chemical engineer specializing in paper.

title: Ideas & Trends; Fighting Words Become Best-Sellers
description: THE nation's military-literary-industrial complex is gathering might with the surprising success of new books that portray modern warriors as complicated heroes who confront enemies and their own mistakes with a mixture of courage and fear.

title: Town Houses May Rise Where Indians Once Made Their Homes; Adult Bookstores, Condos And Traffic Congestion Find Fierce Resistance
description: FOR more than a decade, no issue in this village of 1.5 square miles has generated so much passion as the future of a lazy creek and picturesque ravine leading to the banks of the Hudson River.

description: LETTERS FROM NEW-YORK By Lydia Maria Child. Edited by Bruce Mills. University of Georgia, paper, $19.95.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction

title: Sag Harbor-North Haven Bridge to Keep Flavor
description: THE quaint, scenic bridge that links Sag Harbor with North Haven is 60 years old and shows it. Because erosion has weakened the bridge's pilings, the weight limit for individual vehicles on the span has been cut in half, to 20 tons.

title: Developer's Land Is Not Quite on the Water
description: To the Editor:

title: Reporter's Notebook; About Demeanor, Decorum and Order in the Court
description: Grim and weighty issues mark the trial of four police officers who prosecutors say beat and tortured Abner Louima, a Haitian immigrant. But as the highly publicized trial goes into its second week tomorrow in Federal District Court in Brooklyn, issues have also emerged that are merely irksome, at least to the judge.

title: Bolivia, at Risk of Some Unrest, Is Making Big Gains in Eradicating Coca
description: Ever since drought drove his family from a rocky cornfield high in the Andes 15 years ago, Espinosa Leon has been chopping down tropical rain forest to grow coca bushes, which produce cocaine. Now, at 38, Mr. Leon finds himself at another crossroads.

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from the most recent listing to contract.

title: Correction
description: The What's Doing column on April 25, about Weimar, misstated the nationality of the poet Fernando Pessoa, whose play ''Ur faust, a Subject Tragedy,'' will be presented at the Redoute in June. He was Portuguese, not Spanish.

title: Real Quiet Has Baffert Smiling
description: A week after he lost the Kentucky Derby with three horses, Bob Baffert staged a day of redemption at Pimlico Race Course yesterday: His Derby and Preakness star of last year, Real Quiet, won the Pimlico Special over Free House by a nose. Baffert then said that he planned to enter both his fillies, Silverbulletday and Excellent Meeting in the Preakness next Saturday.

title: On Florida Bridge, Troopers Are Also Suicide Counselors
description: At the crest of the massive Sunshine Skyway Bridge, 200 feet above the jade-colored waters of Tampa Bay, Gary Schluter and James C. Covert of the State Highway Patrol have to persuade people poised on the edge of their own destruction to step back slowly, and live.

title: Variations on a Theme: Flexible Flashlights
description: Two new flashlights may interest travelers. One is ideal for backpackers; the other is powered by a hand crank and would be valuable when batteries fail, or as an automobile emergency light.

description: Alexandra Louise Heyman and Grayson Goodloe Nash were married last evening at the University Club in New York. Justice Stanley S. Ostrau, a retired justice of State Supreme Court in Manhattan, officiated. Afterward, Judge Thomas R. Brett of the Federal District Court in Tulsa, Okla., led a celebration of the marriage.

description: THE HUNGRY OCEAN

description: A real estate concern in Hartsdale reported last week that the Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Company has lowered the asking price for its shuttered store on Main Street in downtown White Plains, to $2.5 million from $4 million.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABRAMS, MURIEL (NEE FRANK)
description: ABRAMS-Muriel (nee Frank).Of North Bay Village, FL and formerly of Atlantic Beach, NY. Died April 27, 1999 in FL. Mrs. Abrams was the widow of Mr. Arthur Abrams. Mrs. Abrams is survived by a son Joseph Applebaum of Bethesda, MD.

title: May 2-8; A Deadline Passes With No Palestinian State
description: In the West Bank and Gaza, May 4, which was to have been a triumphal date, came and went without a declaration of Palestinian statehood. It also came and went without much notice, aside from a handful of small protests.

title: Business Best Sellers
description: HARDCOVER

title: Hillary Clinton Appeals For Gun Control Lobbying
description: Stepping up the Clinton Administration's campaign against gun violence, Hillary Rodham Clinton used an emotional White House ceremony today to call on Americans to press Congress to ''buck the gun lobby'' and pass several gun control measures.

title: Even the Dominator Can't Save 'Em All
description: Some people shrug into a hair shirt. Some attend confession. Some cast the blame like a fishing line. For Dominik Hasek, all it took was an afternoon of playing the focal point, and voluntary target, in a spirited series of decapitation drills at a suburban practice rink Friday to atone for the fact that he came up uncharacteristically mortal in Game 1 of the Eastern Conference semifinal series between his Buffalo Sabres and the Boston Bruins.

title: When Melted Cheese Isn't Simply Sandwich Material
description: For Cosimo Cavallaro, an artist who lives in SoHo, cheese is not just nourishment for the body, but also food for the soul. That is why he plans to cover a hotel room -- the walls, the furniture, the television set, even the coat hangers -- with 1,000 pounds of the stuff. The installation, called ''Room 114,'' will be on display beginning May 20 for three weeks at the Washington Jefferson Hotel at 318 West 51st Street.

title: A Woman's Work, 100 Years Ago
description: MODERN mothers don't know how lucky they are. They have day care for their children, nursing homes for their parents and equal opportunity for themselves. Best of all, they get to work outside the home.

title: Small Is Beautiful; Tongeren, Belgium
description: For archeology buffs, Tongeren, 55 miles east of Brussels, comes close to perfection. There are several excavation sites in the town itself, which is more than 2,000 years old, and more Roman artifacts have been found in the nearby countryside than anywhere else in Belgium.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PERLSTEIN, JEANNE S.
description: PERLSTEIN-Jeanne S. Mother dear, our 19th Mother's Day without you. We love and miss you. Audrey, Ellen, and Suzanne

title: The Caretaker
description: Carter Clay

title: Anne Kenny, William Urban
description: Anne Blackmon Kenny, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John C. Kenny of Richmond, was married last evening to William Goring Urban, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas N. Urban Jr. of Des Moines. Msgr. Charles A. Kelly performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Cathedral of the Sacred Heart in Richmond. The Rev. Edward Dougherty, an Episcopal minister, took part in the service.

title: The Day the World Shrank
description: AS progress and technology scheme to make the world smaller, they've also conspired to keep essences of that smaller world too far away to reach out and touch. The more convenient travel has become, the more like home destinations tend to be.

title: Q&A/Cynthia Winer; Homeless Children Find an Advocate
description: MORE than 600 students in the Hartford Public School system are homeless. ''These are the ones I know about,'' said Cynthia Winer, coordinator of Homeless Education in the Hartford Public School system.

title: For Captive Audiences, a Ride Turns Into Another World
description: Flushed and breathless, a young woman in an ornate wedding dress jumped into the downtown local No. 1 train at 86th Street and Broadway in Manhattan on a recent Wednesday evening, closely followed by two women wearing cocktail dresses.

title: The Fresh Air Fund; City Girl at Home With Fresh Air Family
description: MELISSA ESPINOSA has her own wooden dresser in the room she often shares with Catherine Cavanagh in the Cavanagh family's East Northport home. When the 10-year-old returned home to Brooklyn last week, she didn't have to pack a bag because she left some clothes and personal items in the dresser, knowing she'd be back for two weeks in July -- or maybe sooner.

title: Venturing From Victorian to a Modern Mode
description: THIS city has never been known for its devotion to contemporary architecture. Despite the recent incursion of Sir Norman Foster's bold exhibition center, which opened last year and which is known as ''the armadillo,'' the city has mostly been a place where planners appreciate an old Victorian building and where Charles Rennie Mackintosh, the great innovator of the late 19th and early 20th centuries, is still revered.

title: Czar Wars
description: THE IDEALISTS

title: 'Cool Britannia,' Artists at Work
description: THE exclamation point in ''Graphic!,'' the beginning of the title of a print exhibition at the Yale Center for British Art in New Haven, heightens expectations. Museums and galleries in Connecticut are replete with print shows these days, so viewers are seeking not only examples of various print media, but also super work that can cause them to leave the show with their outlooks a bit changed.

title: Marjorie Lederer Lee, 78, Poet And Novelist Who Wrote Songs
description: Marjorie Lederer Lee, a novelist and poet, died Monday at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. She was 78 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Lauren Moldawer, Daniel Soloway
description: Lauren Elissa Moldawer, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Moldawer of New York, is to be married today to Daniel Howard Soloway, the son of Mr. and Mrs. David Soloway of New Rochelle, N.Y. Rabbi Amiel Wohl is to officiate at Tappan Hill in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: Where Wolves Can Howl in Warren County
description: The howling of wolves in Warren County near the Delaware Water Gap is not a figment of the imagination. It is the inhabitants of the Lakota Wolf Preserve in Columbia, Knowlton Township, communicating with one another. The preserve, which recently won the Governor's Environmental Tourism Award, is home to 22 timber, Arctic and tundra wolves, all a variety of gray wolf. They were transported there from Colorado by Dan and Pam Bacon and Jim Stein. The oldest are 5 years old and the youngest could be born to one of the pregnant females any day.

title: Last of My Breed: A Square at the New Brooks Bros.
description: THE waiters wore white Brooks Brothers shirts, opened at the throat and with the sleeves rolled up to show off massive biceps. There were strobe lights; the music was loud. Set tastefully around the store were squares of plastic turf with rep ties rearing out of them like toothless serpents. ''This is Brooks Brothers for the millennium,'' said Joseph Gromek, the store's chief executive.

title: May 2-8; No Joy in Baltimore
description: If there is any stage on which Fidel Castro has always delighted in mixing competition with politics, it is sports. And if there is any sport that Cubans, including Mr. Castro, love, it is baseball.

title: Bargain Prices For Haute Cuisine
description: A half-price sale at the Paris Ritz? It's true. The two-star restaurant at one of Paris's fanciest hotels will soon be serving langoustines in dill jelly, breaded asparagus with morel mushrooms, a grenadin de veau, and cherries jubilee -- along with assorted wines and coffee -- for $85 a person.

title: Cars of the Famous and Infamous
description: Automobile museums all over the world hold splendid vehicles and some surprises. Just what did Elvis have to do with Geneva?

title: Forget 'Heritage Corridor,' Some Say
description: A proposal to turn 110th Street, bordering Central Park, into a ''heritage corridor'' commemorating famous black Americans was so popular among neighborhood and local business groups a few months ago that the Upper Manhattan Empowerment Zone was hoping to expand the design to include Lenox Avenue. But now some preservationists are opposing elements of the proposal, saying it will not be in keeping with the historic character of the park.

title: Off-Target Hardaway Is Trouble For Heat
description: Six-year-old Tim Hardaway Jr. sat next to his father in the Miami Heat's tomb-like locker room late this afternoon, tears streaming down his cheeks. Tim Sr. had just told him he could not pump up his basketball and go shoot baskets.

title: Dear Cat, Dear Pig
description: WINSTON AND CLEMENTINE

title: New Sounds, New Seating
description: Yo-Yo Ma is known in the music world as a cellist who can do anything he wants, technically. But the reason he stays on top of his game -- 12 Grammy Awards so far -- is that he puts his technique and his heart in the service of musical adventure. Besides accepted repertory, his recordings include a crossover hit, ''Hush,'' with Bobby McFerrin, and he has even allowed himself to be wired up, literally, for electronic compositions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURFOOT, DR. ROY ERNEST
description: BURFOOT-Dr. Roy Ernest. Of Queens, N.Y., Perth, Australia, Wellingborough, England. July 18, 1938-May 2, 1999. Loving memories today and always of our precious husband, father and granddad.

title: The Fresh Air Fund; Campers Come Home Entrepreneurs
description: Imagine a business convention where no one looks bored, everyone wears a T-shirt and the oldest entrepreneurs are 15.

title: The D.A.'s Husband Trouble
description: Jeanine Pirro, the Westchester County District Attorney, is in the back seat of a Crown Victoria, cruising from Manhattan to her office in White Plains and acting far too secure for a woman who, in the past nine months, has learned that her husband was under indictment and had fathered a child with another woman. ''We're fine,'' she's saying into her cell phone. ''Really. Life's a bowl of cherries.'' She hangs up and punches in another number, to her office: ''So did'ja make the bust or what?'' Suddenly her eyes narrow.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARPER, JEAN MCKEOWN
description: HARPER-Jean McKeown, of Briarcliff Manor, NY. Born July 7, 1940. Died May 7, 1999. A sharp mind, warm heart and deep strength for all she loved. Survived by three children, Beth, Lawton and Jennifer, and granddaughter, Katelyn Elizabeth. Visitation Saturday 2-4PM and 7-9PM at the Waterbury & Kelly Funeral Home, 1300 Pleasantville Rd., Briarcliff Manor. Services Sunday 2PM at the Briarcliff Congregational Church, and Monday 12-3PM at the Smith-McCracken Funeral Home, Newton, New Jersey.

title: Good Jamaican in Deer Park? Yes, Mon
description: DEER PARK is becoming a diverse ethnic enclave with a proliferation of very affordable restaurants. The latest entry is Cuyah, a spotless sunshine yellow and palm green Jamaican storefront at 831 Long Island Avenue (242-4352). It joins the now-established Turkish, Cuban, Italian and Chinese colony on, and just off, Deer Park Avenue. Like the others in this growing international contingent, Cuyah, a five-table, 18-seat eat-in-takeout cafe, stresses budget-skewed exotic dishes. Its stamp and go, bammy, escovitched fish, festival, johnny cakes, ackee and salt fish, curried goat and plantain tarts are served by smiling Jamaicans who want you to love their food as much as they do.

title: Susan Harrison, Peter Schwartz

title: 'What the Butler Saw' on Stage in New Rochelle
description: IN his prime at age 34 in 1966, Joe Orton said, ''I'd like to write a play as good as 'The Importance of Being Earnest.' '' That was a year before he was hammered to death by his companion, Kenneth Halliwell, who then swallowed 22 Nembutals and died.

title: The Best
description: Russell Baker's panel of elite academics arguing about the ''Best Time to Be Alive'' certainly made cogent and persuasive arguments in favor of the 14th, 16th and 19th centuries. But imagine needing surgery in the 14th century or, for that matter, the 19th.

title: Ava Shen, David Schaaf
description: Ing-Ie Ava Shen, a daughter of Chu-Mei and Yang-Lien Shen of Taipei, Taiwan, was married last evening to Dr. David Thomas Schaaf, a son of Judith O. Schaaf and Thomas K. Schaaf, both of Lyme, Conn. The Rev. Kevin A. McGrath performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Vincent Ferrer in New York.

description: A New Jersey trial judge's unprecedented -- and largely symbolic -- imposition of a five-year deadline on the state to execute a newly condemned man drew praise and criticism from legal experts yesterday, including those who oppose the death penalty.

description: HAMILTON-Betty. The Board of Directors, Staff and Children of the Girls' Vacation Fund regret the loss of Mrs. Harold Hamilton; dedicated Supporter and Board Member for over 25 years. We extend our sincere condolences to the entire Hamilton family. Mario Diaz-Cruz, III, Esq, Officer

title: Before Salon's Offering, Some Negative Reviews
description: IT is one thing for investors to bet their money on an initial public offering of an Internet company with a speculative but potentially lucrative business model. But analysts say next month's planned offering of Salon Internet seems to go several steps further, asking investors to put money into a flawed business model that happens to operate on line.

title: Venus Williams Topples Hingis at Italian Open
description: At the moment, American visitors are a strong presence in this capital city: lining up outside the Vatican, wandering and gesticulating inside the Forum, strolling up or down the Via Veneto with the strong dollar in their pockets and Italian couture on their minds.

title: Wendi Sanders, James Berger
description: Wendi V. Sanders, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Norman D. Sanders of Holmdel, N.J., was married last evening to James Aaron Berger, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ronald Berger of Mamaroneck, N.Y. Cantor Richard Berman officiated at the Essex House in New York.

title: U.S. Struggles to Contain Damage To Diplomacy and Air Campaign
description: The Clinton Administration struggled today to prevent the accidental bombing of the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade from either hobbling NATO's air campaign or stifling the nascent diplomatic search for a way to end the war over Kosovo.

title: Dirk Bogarde, 78, Matinee Idol Turned Serious Actor, Dies
description: Dirk Bogarde, who transformed himself from Britain's top matinee idol into a serious actor at the age of 40 and became an international star, died yesterday at his home in London. He was 78.

title: The Newest Elite
description: To the Editor:

title: After the Race, More Competition
description: THE SETTING At precisely 17 minutes and 21 seconds after 7 on Wednesday evening, the sweaty hordes who had just run the 3.5-mile Chase Corporate Challenge race began swarming around the food tables set up by their employers in Central Park, near East 72d Street.

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: TOPPING this week's movie menu are a classic Tarzan entry, a delightful comedy-fantasy, a bittersweet costume drama and a graphic story of rebellion in Nazi Germany.

description: Judge Judy had better watch out. Judge Gerry, her husband, is on his way.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DANIELS, NETTIE (GANS)
description: DANIELS-Nettie (Gans). Age 105. Passed away peacefully on May 7, 1999. She was the widow of the late Jack Daniels, mother of Alvin S. Lane, grandmother of Mary-Jo Lane Harris and Judith Lane Mattson, great-grandmother of Ian and Roger Mattson, sister of Myriam Gans. Service Monday, May 10, 12 noon, at Frank Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st Street.

title: The Curse of the Whitney
description: The interpretive paintings and collages that accompanied Arthur Lubow's article are evidence of one unspoken reason for the Whitney's perennial troubles: a failure of its architecture to delight the visitor. Most of your invited artists superimposed anthropomorphic themes on the facade, images that provide an apt commentary on an edifice whose architect neglected to accommodate fully the human being within.

title: All Roads Lead to Broadway, Some From Here
description: THREE weeks from tonight, theater and television audiences will find out if Broadway really likes Jersey best. In two cases, they already knows for sure.

title: NATO Says It Thought Embassy Was Arms Agency
description: A NATO aircraft bombed the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade on Friday night because the military command mistakenly believed that it was a headquarters for a Yugoslav arms agency, allied officials said today.

title: Dreams of Grandeur, Prices to Match
description: CHESAPEAKE BAY in Long Beach has dreams of grandeur, some realized, most not. The decor is certainly stylish, with two walls of French doors and another of rough brick. Pottery lanterns, shaped like fish, cast intriguing shadows on the walls. The rest is casual: bare wood floors, ceiling fans and butcher paper set over tablecloths.

title: Study Finds Some Strategies That Help Poor Students Learn
description: Low-income students are making significant academic gains in schools with educational strategies that include higher standards and more personal instruction, parent involvement and teacher accountability, according to reports made public this week.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

description: EXCUSE me, but did anyone notice how beautiful the men are in there?'' Camille Peri asked a group of writers standing in front of the W Hotel in midtown last Wednesday night.

title: Meredith Angert, Alexander Kenna
description: Meredith Renee Angert, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stuart H. Angert of Amherst, N.Y., was married there last evening to Alexander Bevans Kenna, a son of Elizabeth B. Kenna of West Hartford, Conn., and J. Stephen Kenna of Londonderry, Vt. Rabbi Martin L. Goldberg officiated at the Park Country Club. The Rev. Andrew Nagy-Benson, a United Church of Christ minister, took part in the ceremony.

title: Cairo
description: To the Editor: I enjoyed ''Teeming, Tempting Cairo'' (April 11) but hope to round out the picture.

title: Aiming at the Audience
description: IT didn't look like a rehearsal. On the periphery of a spacious studio on lower Broadway, a couple of dancers stood close together as if in conversation. Several others mingled casually in the center. The choreographer Bebe Miller, wearing baggy black pants and a simple black shirt, took a position in front of the wall-length mirror. A compact woman with dreadlocks, she faced front, then side, then back, and front again, allowing herself to be scrutinized. Over a tape recording came her mellow voice. ''Who is looking for gay men in the group?'' The questions are aimed at her audiences. ''Who is counting the white people?'' ''How important is it that these dancers work for a black choreographer?''

title: Mother's Mysteries
description: This Mother's Day business -- it's powerful stuff. Recently I heard about a child who, visiting his mother in prison, sat on her lap, looked up into her face and said seriously, ''I love you more than God.'' It reminded me of something: a day when I was very small, and my mother took me around to the side of the house to show me a garden of red and yellow tulips standing in full bloom in the morning sun. ''Where did they come from?'' I asked, and when she said she had planted their bulbs in the fall, I remember thinking she was practically God. In my child's eye, the garden seemed as large as a field, and my mother, who had done this, was tall and supreme.

title: Industrial Metals: The Tea Leaf Commodities
description: THE price of copper has jumped 15.4 percent since its low this year, to 70.78 cents a pound. The price of tin is up 12 percent from its 1999 low; nickel, 41.3 percent; lead, 11.8 percent, and aluminum, 17.1 percent.

title: There's Beauty In Bounty
description: Applause rings and dies away, leaving a quiet benediction: help for a worthy cause.

title: Hyun-Zu Kim, Tycho Stahl
description: Hyun-Zu Kim and Tycho Hermann Erich Stahl were married yesterday at the Old South Church in Boston. The Rev. Dr. Calvin R. Genzel, a United Methodist minister, performed the ceremony.

title: The Fresh Air Fund; Fresh Air Fund Forges Family Ties
description: ON Ajani Tyrell's sixth birthday, he began what could become a lifelong relationship with Karen and Howard Kellman and their children, Joshua, Rachel and Sarah. That was on July 21, 1994, the day Ajani first visited the Kellmans as part of the Fresh Air Fund Friendly Towns program. Not only did he receive an impromptu party and an unexpected trip to the toy store but he also started a yearly summer tradition.

title: School Districts Merge Studies and Technology
description: AMID the clutter of paintbrushes, chisels and lumps of clay in Jayne Karlin's classroom at Byram Hills High School here, there was something else that did not quite fit in: a computer, whose screen held moving images of camels against a backdrop of Egyptian pyramids and tombs.

title: Outside Agitator
description: Betty Friedan

title: Ann Morse and David Dickinson
description: Ann Bramson Morse and Dr. David Kelly Dickinson were married yesterday. The Rev. Lucinda S. Duncan, a Unitarian Universalist minister, performed the ceremony at the Follen Community Church in Lexington, Mass.

title: Where Auteurs Learn the ABC's
description: FOR Penelope Spheeris, it was four years of paradise. For Barry Sonnenfeld, it was three years of purgatory. But as these two successful Hollywood directors acknowledge, their common experience -- earning a graduate degree from a top-flight film school -- helped lay the foundation for their present careers.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SIGLER, LILLIAN H.
description: SIGLER-Lillian H. 1903-1972. Mother, teacher, grandmother. This day for you always, in loving memory. Your Family

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HESLIN, JAMES. DR. JAMES HESLIN
description: HESLIN-James. Dr. James Heslin, former director of the New York Historical Society, passed away on April 30th at St. Luke's Roosevelt Hospital, New York. Dr. Heslin was the husband of the late Phyllis Heslin and brother of the late Daniel and Helen Heslin. He is survived by his sister Mary Ryan of North Cambridge, MA. and brother William Heslin of Atlanta, GA. He leaves five nieces and nephews and twelve grand nieces and nephews. Dr. Heslin received his Doctorate at Columbia University. Services were private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STANLEY, DAVID A.
description: STANLEY-David A. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of David A. Stanley, associated with The Times from 1949 until retiring in 1994.

title: Jose Quintero Memorial
description: Jason Robards, Liv Ullmann and Edward Albee are to be among the speakers at a memorial for the director Jose Quintero on Tuesday at 2 P.M. at the Circle in the Square Theater at Broadway and 50th Street. Mr. Quintero, noted for his work with plays by Eugene O'Neill and Tennessee Williams, died on Feb. 26 at age 74.

title: Adams Sets Record As Maryland Coasts
description: Allison Comito scored six goals, and the three by Jen Adams set a single-season scoring record, as Maryland defeated Georgetown by 17-6 yesterday in the quarterfinals of the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I women's tournament at College Park, Md.

title: Elizabeth to Put Detectors In All Elementary Schools
description: Kindergartners and others at Elizabeth's 16 public elementary schools will soon join the rest of the district's 18,000 students in having to pass through stationary metal detectors, district officials said last week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINDLING, LEON DAVID
description: WEINDLING-Leon David. Of Manhattan. On May 8, at 78 years of age. Beloved husband of Sonia Weindling. Devoted father of Suzanne Burakoff and Steven Weindling and father-in-law of Dr. Steven Burakoff. Adored grandfather of Alexis Weindling Burakoff and brother of Irene Probstein and Irwin Weindling. He was the President of London Star, Ltd. A compassionate and generous man who enhanced the lives of his family, friends and colleagues, he served as an officer in both the Belgian and US armies during WW II. A beneficent supporter of many charities and a devoted friend to Israel. He will be missed by everyone he touched. Services will be held Monday, 1:15 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th and Amsterdam.

title: The Best
description: Your special issue (April 18) is, quite simply, the most astounding piece of journalism I've seen. From the introduction to the masterful and thoughtful concluding essay, I was held captive by the words and pictures. In addition to being entertained, I was educated and informed about so many topics, written about so beautifully by those who had such passion for their topics. Imagine, a screw as best tool!

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: PARK SLOPE; Where One Shops While the Significant Other Drops
description: On a recent Saturday afternoon, Nelson Bookbinder was dug in for the duration. His wife, Ronnie, had already spent nearly an hour shopping for clothes at Aaron's, a women's apparel store at Fifth Avenue and 17th Street. By Mr. Bookbinder's reckoning, she would be at it for three more hours.

title: Spreading the Gospel Of Talking It Through
description: FOR a country with a high decibel level and a habit of confrontation -- a national penchant for guns, litigation, divorce, in-your-face discourse and ax-thwacking employee downsizing -- America has a surprising appetite for books about talking things over quietly.

title: CHINA PROTESTERS RAGE AT AMERICA
description: Large, angry protests erupted around American Government offices in several cities after Chinese learned that NATO bombs had hit their embassy in Belgrade, killing at least three people sleeping inside. By this morning, the demonstration had left a consulate in flames and the embassy here in a state of siege with most of its windows broken by rocks.

title: The N.F.L. Barons
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Beyond the Three R's
description: The Disciplined Mind

title: Falling in Love With the Old Songs
description: AS the American popular song of the first half of the century drifts farther from commercial radio, Garret Stack's program ''Echoes of the Past'' grows more vital.

title: Village People
description: SPIDERWEB

title: The Jock Culture: Time to Debate the Questions
description: Yelling, ''Sports, sports, don't you get it, everything in Glen Ridge is sports,'' a teen-age Jeremiah runs through a forgettable television movie tomorrow night with an inescapable message: love it, hate it or try to ignore it, jock culture haunts our national daydreams.

title: COMMUNITY: The Fresh Air Fund; Five Acres And Family Transform A Summer
description: Janine Goumbala and Kristopher Daniel had never waded in a stream before last summer. As they looked at the fish swimming next to their feet, they asked: ''We can do this? We're not going to get arrested?''

title: Eve Took Charge
description: To the Editor:

title: Unshackled to Capture Their Country Again
description: AT the turn of the century, Hungary was the most photo-obsessed country in the world. Princes and princesses of the Austro-Hungarian Empire frequented photo exhibitions and proudly displayed their own prints. From a nation the size of Indiana emerged many of the leading names of modern photography, including Andre Kertesz, Brassai, Laszlo Moholy-Nagy and Robert Capa. But four decades of Communist rule isolated Hungarian photography from this artistic heritage, from the outside world and from many of its subjects.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POWELL, MELINDA
description: POWELL-Melinda. On May 5. Melinda and her beloved husband, Graham of Carmel, CA and formerly Stamford, CT were moving back to Rowayton, CT. She was taken ill while staying with her dear friend, Lois Peerce in New York City. Melinda, age 46, died unexpectedly from complications following surgery. She brought warmth and love immediately to all she knew. A service will be held at 4:00 P.M. on Tuesday, May 11 at the United Church of Rowayton. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Rowayton Senior Housing Corporation - Hilltop Homes, 210 Rowayton Ave, Rowayton, CT 06853.

title: The Best
description: Your issue was truly the best in many years of excellence. Regarding Elmore Leonard's contribution (''Morality Bites''), I agree that writers of all types would do well to read ''Everyman.'' But I want to point out that at least one popular television show (all right, it had a cult following) relied heavily on this morality play. In 1968, ''The Prisoner,'' starring and produced by Patrick McGoohan, made its debut. It was a 17-episode, allegorical and highly convoluted series (really, the first miniseries) about an apparent secret agent. The stories look into the nature of identity, politics, religion, trust, honor, revenge, education and other subjects.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WINTER, MARVIN S.
description: WINTER-Marvin S. 78. Of Manhattan and Delray Beach, FL, on May 7, 1999. Beloved husband of Eleanor. Devoted father of Benjamin and Susan Winter, James and Susan Winter, Douglas and Bonnie Winter, and Karen (Winter) and Barry Miller. Loving grandfather of David, Alison, Jennifer, Stacy, Kira, Eric and Jonathan Winter, and Nathan, Matthew and Dana Miller. Dear brother of the late Beatrice Spitz, Ethel Schanzer and Natalie Ballen. Funeral services on Monday, May 10 at 12:30 PM at Frank E. Campbell, Madison Avenue at 81st Street.

title: A Word the Town Did Not Want To Hear: Rape
description: WHEN I met Leslie Faber (a pseudonym) in December 1992, the day she testified against four of the boys accused of raping her in the basement of a Glen Ridge, N.J., home with a bat, a broom and a stick, she was shy and nervous. She had known most of these handsome, popular athletes -- the dream dates of high school girls -- since childhood, and she still believed they could be her friends. If she could only forget that three years earlier 13 boys (6 eventually left) had gathered in the suburban basement of Kevin and Kyle Scherzer to sexually abuse and humiliate her: ''It was set up like a movie,'' Leslie, a mentally retarded girl with an I.Q. of 64, told a packed courtroom that morning. ''There were chairs there and a big couch and stuff.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZANDER, ELAINE
description: ZANDER-Elaine. Died on May 5, at age 73. Loving wife of Murray of 52 years. Devoted mother of Barry (her Easter baby). Survived by sisters-in-law, Lily, Sarah, Rae and Mary; brothers-in-law, Joseph and Elliot. Predeceased by a son, Jeffrey.

title: The Best
description: By choosing the period as the best punctuation mark of the millennium, Alberto Manguel appears to be using historical impact as his main criterion. But if by ''best'' one means the mark that is the most subtle, and inflective, the semicolon wins hands down.

title: In America; Long Shots and Shadows
description: I keep running into people who tell me that Al Gore can't or won't win the Presidency. These are ordinary voters, not politicians or people in the media. Most are right in step with Mr. Gore philosophically. But they are saying the same things everybody seems to be saying about the Vice President. He's a cardboard figure. Doesn't connect with people. Gives lousy speeches. Al Bore.

title: Glass House
description: A winery is a fine place to tip a glass. One winery, in South Jersey, is also a fine place to admire one. The Renault Winery, besides encompassing 32 acres of vineyards and a restaurant, also houses a wineglass museum, with about 500 glasses. The oldest glass is Italian, from the 13th century, says Joseph Milza, owner of Renault. The rarest is a handpainted wineglass made for a single dinner in 17th-century France. And the most striking are nine French flutes from 1894, called Eiffel tower glasses. About 16 inches tall, they were probably made for drinking Champagne, he said, appropriate because one of Renault's specialties is blueberry champagne. The glasses can be viewed in cases in a couple of rooms that are the assembly point for vineyard tours, $2 a person, which are offered daily from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. (and from 11 on Sundays). The winery also serves lunch daily and a wine-tasting dinner Fridays, Saturdays and Sundays. Renault Winery, 72 North Bremen Avenue, in Galloway; (609) 965-2111.

title: Is This Wash Brushless? Yes, and Topless, Too
description: IN an economy as polymorphously diverse as America's, it seems unlikely that Harper's II Exotic Car Wash is the only one of its kind. But it could be. ''It's the only one I'm aware of,'' said Eddie Collins, who owns both the car wash and a nearby strip club.

title: Biography: A Love Affair or a Job?
description: ''But do you like him?'' (Or ''her''?) Every biographer who mounts a platform knows this one. Not so much a question, more a challenge, hurled with an edge to the voice, as if anticipating the unwanted answer.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BENBOW, TERENCE H.
description: BENBOW-Terence H. A memorial service for Dean Emeritus and Professor of Law Terence H. Benbow will be held Sunday, June 6, 1999 at 4PM in the Grand Courtroom of the Quinnipiac College School of Law. The Law School is located at 275 Mount Carmel Ave, Hamden, CT 06518-1947. Telephone 203-281-8655. The family would appreciate that donations be made in his memory to the Terence H. Benbow Professorship Fund, Attention Quinnipiac College Advancement Office, at the above address.

title: Finally, Artists Free of Government
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRAUSS, JOSEPH
description: STRAUSS-Joseph. Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York expresses to the family of our devoted member, Joseph Strauss, our deepest sympathies on the occasion of his passing. It is our hope and prayer that beautiful memories will linger as a legacy to his life. May all who loved him be comforted. David E. Marrus, President Herbert C. Bernard, Secretary

title: One Museum That's Happy Just to Be Its Tranquil Self
description: THE sign for the Noyes Museum of Art points east off Route 9 in Oceanville, but the entrance to Lily Lake Road is easy to miss. You'll know you've gone too far north if you pass the cluster of restored 19th-century buildings called the Historic Towne of Smithville. And if you hit Atlantic City, you will have gone far too south.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''As a young Chinese I've always felt a very friendly attitude towards the U.S. and its people. But now I feel a deep internal disgust and anger.''

title: Transferring A Co-op To a Trust
description: BUYING a home is one of the most significant investments of a lifetime. So when homeowners start thinking about estate planning, a major issue is what will become of that investment. While owners of houses and condominiums can usually do whatever they want with their property, co-op shareholders usually cannot.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry
description: THE SELF-MADE BRAIN SURGEON

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: A Horse Is a Horse

title: I Remember Mama
description: Fashion has pillaged the styles of everyone from hip-hop stars to Hindu swamis. Who is fashion's latest victim? Your mother. Here are a few styles the kids are stealing from Mom's closet. ELLEN TIEN

title: Passenger Slightly Hurt as Plane Skids
description: An American Eagle commuter plane from Baltimore skidded off the runway while landing at Kennedy International Airport yesterday morning and came to a stop in deep mud, said officials with the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.

title: Ms. Schreiber And Mr. Meisel
description: Courtney Anne Schreiber, a daughter of Pamela Schreiber and Dr. Alan Schreiber of Philadelphia, was married at her parents' house last evening to Zachary Franklin Meisel, a son of Allene Fisch and Dr. Frederick Meisel, both of Brookline, Mass. Rabbi Julie Greenberg officiated.

title: Security Council Expresses 'Shock and Concern' at Bombing
description: After weeks on the political periphery of the Kosovo crisis, the United Nations Security Council made a dramatic return to diplomatic center stage early yesterday, as an outraged China denounced the United States and its NATO allies for their bombing of its embassy in Belgrade and demanded an immediate halt to the air strikes.

title: Habitats /Upper West Side; In the Beginning It Seemed So Simple . . .
description: EVENTUALLY, it took two and a half years, tens of thousands of dollars and endless hours of effort. But it started with a very simple idea.

title: Floating Seminar
description: Most vacationers are busy spending money, but a seven-day Seminar at Sea cruise departing Jan. 30 will allow participants to make money as well. The cruise on the Princess Cruise Line's Grand Princess, sponsored by Individual Investor magazine, will feature talks by numerous financial advisers. It leaves from Fort Lauderdale with stops in St. Thomas, St. Maarten and a private resort island.

title: Italian Solo Sailor Breezes to Victory
