description: The slapping sound of slack sails and a fluttering rig tend to jangle the nerves of the most fervent yachtsman. Add to that the tension of being within 100 miles of setting a record in a round-the-world race, and you have Giovanni Soldini, the solo sailor from Italy.

title: Casey At the Beach
description: My granddaughter Casey and I are in the front seats of the bus we boarded in Oviedo, the capital of Asturias, a fertile region in northern Spain. We wind and wind around mountains so green the color needs a new name, ''Asturian green,'' perhaps.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KANTOR, ISABEL L.
description: KANTOR-Isabel L. On May 7, 1999, at 89 years of age, after a brief illness. Wife of the late Samuel T.; survived by daughter Elizabeth and granddaughter Sarah of San Francisco. Deeply interested in the arts and extremely active on behalf of such groups as Recording for The Blind, and the Womens' City Club of New York, her generous and indomitable spirit inspired all who knew her. Services at Frank E. Campbell, Madison Avenue, and 81st Street, Sunday, May 9th, at 10 A.M.

title: No Man's Land
description: THE PITY OF WAR By Niall Ferguson. Illustrated. 563 pp. New York: Basic Books. $30.

title: Black Artists Confront History
description: OUR nation's legacy of racial prejudice is based in part on misconceptions passed from generation to generation and by omissions and oversights in records. The exhibition ''Re/Righting History: Counternarratives by Contemporary African-American Artists'' at the Katonah Museum of Art here, confronts the pattern of oppression against blacks.

title: The World; A Land Of Tribes, Again
description: IN the nightly avalanche of television ads punctuating the Israeli election campaign, a commercial by a small Russian immigrant party stands out.

title: Three of a Kind
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: The Way We Live Now: 5-9-99: On Language; McCawley
description: Of all the Lexicographic Irregulars who regularly instruct, correct, clarify, amplify and berate the author of this column, none carried the scholarly authority of James D. McCawley, the University of Chicago's iconoclastic professor of linguistics, who died last month.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENTHAL, ROBERT L.
description: ROSENTHAL-Robert L. The Board of Directors of The 360 East 72nd Street Owners Corporation mourn the loss of their esteemed Past President, Robert L. Rosenthal. A veteran of World War II (U.S.M.C.), attorney and community activist, he will be missed by all. Our deepest sympathy to his devoted wife, Alma, and many friends. Harvey Rothenberg, President

title: Polly Spring, Breck Perkins
description: Polly June Spring and Breck Stuart Perkins were married yesterday afternoon in Stonington, Conn. The Rev. Mark K. J. Robinson performed the ceremony at Calvary Episcopal Church.

title: Old Trick: Daring To Conceal; Geisha chic's allure derives from wrapping and reticence.
description: IN ''Silk,'' Alessandro Baricco's cult novel of erotic enthrallment, a French silk trader travels to remotest Japan in 1861, where he meets a ravishing young courtesan. Her face is turned away, her body enfolded in layers of brocade. He catches only a glimpse of her hand peeking from her sleeve, but it is enough to spark an obsession that continues to haunt him for years.

title: Tomorrowland
description: England, England

title: Advice on Avoiding Telemarketing Scourge
description: To the Editor:

title: Wilted Corsages Are the Least Of Their Prom Disasters
description: Prom night, if popular movies and television shows are to believed, is nothing less than epochal in the life of a teen-ager. Wallflowers blossom into beauties, as Molly Ringwald did in ''Pretty in Pink'' and Drew Barrymore did last month in ''Never Been Kissed.'' In ''Footloose,'' defiant, dance-crazy kids convince their fundamentalist parents that the Lord smiles on those who boogie. And in a few spectacular instances of prom-night carnage in ''Carrie'' and the four ''Prom Night'' slasher films, the nasty kids finally got what was coming to them.

title: An Unhurried Journey to the Top
description: A LOT of musicians these days are already starting international careers before they have completed the early stages of professional development, so that they find themselves putting their clothes on in public. Into such a world suddenly comes Robert McDuffie, a violinist fully and impeccably dressed, ready to make his New York Philharmonic debut on Thursday evening at Avery Fisher Hall after nearly two decades of giving concerts.

title: The Challenge of Managing Supportive Housing
description: THE once-notorious Kenmore Hotel on 23d Street east of Lexington Avenue had its formal reopening last Tuesday as Kenmore Hall, a sanctuary of permanent housing with supportive services for low-income single adults. Public and community representatives assembled out front under a protective awning in the light rain to hear tributes to a five-year job well done.

title: Ideas & Trends; What They Took on Their Summit Vacations
description: MOUNT EVEREST, a brutal tower of subzero temperatures, sudden blizzards and the thinnest air, gives up its dead grudgingly. A week ago Saturday, the remains of the legendary George Leigh Mallory were identified by an American expedition retracing his route 75 years later. It was Mallory who answered the question, Why climb Everest with the deathless, Because it is there. Mallory, a 38-year-old British schoolteacher, and Andrew Irvine, a 28-year-old Cambridge student, disappeared on the northern slope in 1924, leaving behind a mystery that endures to this day. Did they reach the summit?

title: Family Politics
description: Madeleine Albright

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAUPT, ELLIOT
description: HAUPT-Elliot. Age 78. On May 6, 1999. Adoring father of Vicki and Steven. Brother of Melville and Blanche. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St., Sunday 2-4PM and 7-9PM. Funeral service Monday, May 10, at 9:45AM at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at 65th Street. Interment to follow at Mount Carmel Cemetery. Contributions in his memory may be made to Temple Emanu-El, 1 East 65th Street, New York, NY 10021.

title: Joshua Rogowsky, Michele Breslow
description: Michele Dyan Breslow, the daughter of Lorraine and Howard Breslow of Dix Hills, N.Y., was married last evening to Joshua Daniel Rogowsky, a son of Leslie Rogowsky of Great River, N.Y., and Edward Rogowsky of Brooklyn. Rabbi Howard Beuchler performed the ceremony at the Woodbury (N.Y.) Jewish Center.

title: Monuments of Stone, Testaments to an Island
description: TODAY the residents of Vinalhaven Island, Me., nestled in Penobscot Bay some 15 miles off Rockland, boast of their lobstering industry and an aversion to tourists. But nearly a century ago, the tiny island, roughly nine miles long and five miles wide, had another source of pride: its cliffs and knolls provided the granite for some of the nation's most imposing structures, among them the Brooklyn Bridge, the United States Custom House and the Cathedral of St. John the Divine in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RACZ, WILLIAM G.
description: RACZ-William G. May 1, 1999 of Brewster, MA, formerly of New York City. Early retiree from former Chemical Bank. Beloved husband of Lois (Quirk) Racz, loving uncle of several nephews, nieces and their families. Service Saturday, May 15 at 11:30 a.m., Federated Church of Orleans, MA.

title: Beautiful Losers
description: IN PRAISE OF ANTIHEROES

title: El Duque Finds Life in Big City Can Be Brutal
description: Orlando Hernandez ambled toward the dugout after his miserable day had ended yesterday, resembling a wayward tourist lost in Central Park. He pulled off his Yankee cap, rubbed his bald head and looked as if he did not belong. When the fans gave the bruised Hernandez a rousing ovation, the scene seemed even more incongruous.

title: The Nation; Where Joblessness Is a Way of Making a Living
description: WHEN Olivier Blanchard, a liberal economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, is asked why unemployment rates are higher in Europe than in the United States, he likes to tell audiences about a pamphlet he saw in a British library: ''Leaving School: What You Need to Know About Social Security.''

title: An Abundance of Performing Arts Nationwide
description: This list is selective. It is national in scope but concentrates on the Northeast.

title: An Albanian Family, War Scarred, Struggles On Among the Serbs
description: The Llugiqi family is hunkering down, hoping that the storm that has convulsed Kosovo has passed and that they are not simply in its eerie eye.

title: In Camden, A Hospital Finds Itself Seriously Ill
description: For Dr. Marilyn Gordon, it would be unthinkable that Cooper Hospital would turn away patients who can't pay their bills.

title: Style; Footnotes
description: 1. Mama mia, how icons change. Mom's apron has morphed into a fashion statement -- see Jussara's funky apron dress from her spring collection -- and apple pie is now tarte Tatin. For some of the season's best apron looks, try Marc Jacobs (163 Mercer Street), whose wraparounds go for a very unmotherly 600 bucks, while the best (repeat, best) apple tartes Tatin can be ordered from the Francois Payard P2/3tisserie, 1032 Lexington Avenue, from $20.

title: Supreme Fictions
description: The Best American Short Stories

title: The Best
description: In describing the best come-from-behind victory, Keith Olbermann seems to have forgotten the New York Giants. In August 1951, they were 13 1/2 games behind the Brooklyn Dodgers and eventually beat them on Bobby Thomson's ninth-inning home run in the third game of a three-game playoff series.

title: Susan Braham, Timothy Jensen
description: Susan Wright Braham and Timothy Sage Jensen were married last evening in Manhattan. The Rev. Louise Green, a United Church of Christ minister, officiated at Bridgewater's.

title: Sugar, Spice, Denim
description: Young women continue to reinvent fashion, creating a style that reflects their era and discards yesterday's formality. This spring, the blue denim jean jacket is a favorite of women all over the city, worn with skirts, pants and dresses, right. These former cowboy jackets added to a wardrobe calm down the over-femininity of fashion and give the wearer a nonchalant, rugged attitude. Many of the jackets come from big-brand labels, while those with shaping and small shoulders carry designer names -- and prices.

title: An Abundance of Performing Arts Nationwide
description: This list is selective, and programs are subject to change. More information is available through individual ticket offices.

title: Trash Alert! A Nickel's Blocking West 55th!
description: NEW YORK can be a dirty city, but on Monday it was a real mess. A bobby pin obstructed a pier on the Hudson River, a brochure carpeted the banks of Fresh Kills Creek in Staten Island, a nickel blocked 55th Street in Manhattan, a tissue covered a baseball diamond in Harris Park in the Bronx and dust bunnies drifted under the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge.

title: Alternatives to Cat Boarding Only Require Some Work
description: Let's hope readers don't take too much to heart David Bouchier's flip comments about boarding cats while their owners are away [''Out of Order,'' May 2]. Kennel accommodation, luxurious or not, is a terrible idea.

title: Demonstration Organizers Tend to Forget News Media
description: To the Editor:

title: Janel Plank, Craig Peters
description: Janel Katherine Plank, the daughter of Peggy and Christopher Plank of Lake Placid, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Craig Tillman Peters, the son of Nancy and Merz Peters of New York. The Rev. Mark Demers, a United Methodist minister, performed the ceremony at the Adirondack Community Church.

title: Software Cited in Air Traffic Error
description: The failure of a new air traffic control computer Thursday morning in Ronkonkoma, N.Y., which delayed thousands of passengers, was caused by a local software flaw and should have no effect on a nationwide replacement program, Federal Aviation Administration officials said Friday.

title: Sports of The Times; Tax Is Funny Money For Wealthy Owners
description: BERNIE WILLIAMS thought he was back in the 60's. That's what the Yankee center fielder said in Kansas City on April 30 when 2,000 fans staged a polite little protest at the ball park.

title: QUICK BITE/Montclair; Belly Dancers, Swords and Hummus, too
description: There's nothing quite like a belly dancer with your dinner, and if the dancer is wearing a chandelier with lighted candles on her head, so much the better. At Baladi, the new, and only, Egyptian restaurant in Montclair, Nancy, the blond belly dancer (from Manhattan not Egypt), can be counted on to dazzle on Friday and Saturday nights. Our son Miles, who is 5, was enchanted with Nancy, but not enchanted enough, apparently, to accept her invitation to dance. His 13-year-old brother, Paul, felt likewise. As no one else was invited to join her, we were free to concentrate on the swords that replace the chandelier and that she used to slash the air and, luckily, nothing and nobody else. All this and hummus too. ''My heart is in Egypt,'' says Neamet el-Sayed, 41, the owner and chef, who was born in Cairo and now lives in Hoboken. Baladi (pronounced balla-DEE) is Arabic for ''countryside,'' which Mr. El-Sayed approximates most glamorously. Under filmy dark blue tents, diners are served traditionally lamb-based Egyptian meals, among them mozza dani, apricot-braised lamb shank. For those who prefer their little lambs scampering safely with Mary, Baladi offers such entrees as samek bofteak (pistachio-crusted catfish with dried limes, baby okra and tahini) and vegetable tajine (sauteed artichokes, zucchini, butternut squash, chickpeas and potatoes with juniper essence and saffron couscous with dried cherries). Hummus (chicpea puree with tahini, lemon juice and garlic), baba gannouj (charred eggplant puree) and kebda (pan-seared calves' liver with pickled vegetables), all served with hot puffy pita triangles, are little meals masquerading as appetizers. Our dessert, konafa - dense Belgian chocolate topped and bottomed with crispy shredded phyllo - was as mesmerizing as Nancy's shimmies and shakes. But by this time Nancy had left the ubilding, and our forks did all the dancing.

title: Politics and the Schools
description: Term limits being what they are in New York City, Mayor Rudolph Giuliani's present job ends on Dec. 31, 2001. Thus, New York's Mayor has been casting an eye on other possibilities, most noticeably a run for the United States Senate in the year 2000. Such yearnings are now raising questions about how well the Mayor is balancing his quest for a new national office next year with his management of the most important and diverse city in the world. To put it more bluntly, will the Mayor's political ambitions harm New York City?

title: It's a Quotable Town
description: ''THERE'S something in the New York air that makes sleep useless,'' Simone de Beauvoir once wrote. Irving Browning's photomontage of Times Square (circa 1930), at left, has been paired with de Beauvoir's words in an exhibition -- ''Yadda, Yadda, Yadda: New York in Quotes'' -- opening on Tuesday at the New-York Historical Society. From John Adams to John Steinbeck, people from all walks of life have had something to say about New York, in excitement or admiration, disappointment or disgust.

title: If U Cn Rd Ths Msg
description: VISUAL INTELLIGENCE

title: What's Doing In; Los Angeles
description: The early 1990's were the plague years in Los Angeles, as wildfires, riots, a devastating earthquake and the worst recession since the Great Depression left Southern California badly shaken and tourists scared away. Many of the problems underlying that social unrest remain, but the decade is nevertheless ending on a triumphant note, with the local economy booming, good news abounding and civic boosterism in full flower.

title: Water Taxis Ride the River Again The Ease of Rowing on the River
description: FORGET about a chicken in every pot or a car in every driveway. Mike Davis envisions a rowboat within shouting distance for anyone yearning for a glide over local waters.

title: Many States Slow to Use Children's Insurance Fund
description: States are using less than 20 percent of the Federal money that Congress made available, with much fanfare, for a big new program to subsidize health insurance for children in low-income families.

title: Corrections
description: The Business World column last Sunday, about I. G. Farben, the German chemical company that has been in liquidation since shortly after World War II, misstated the value of overseas assets that figure in a legal dispute between the company and a Swiss bank, UBS. The assets are now worth an estimated 4.4 billion German marks ($2.39 billion), not 4.4 million marks.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: VARIOUS VOICES

title: Organ Donation Should Be a Gift
description: To the Editor:

title: A Hip-Hop Battle of the Sexes
description: AT the Vibe magazine style awards, held recently at the Toy Center in the Flatiron district, a battle of the sexes erupted on the celebrity-studded dance floor. As guests like the fashion models Tyson Beckford and Beverly Peele, hip-hop honcho Russell Simmons and MTV veejay Ananda Lewis mingled in their finery before the awards ceremony, the party's deejay, Biz Markie, dropped the needle on the fastest-selling single in the country, ''No Scrubs'' by TLC.

title: MY MONEY, MY LIFE; The First Step to Financial Independence
description: GROWING up, the only advice my father ever gave me about money was ''Don't worry.'' Beneath those words, of course, was an unspoken assumption: There will always be a man to take care of you.

title: The Very Model Of a Modern Major Museum; The Old Masters Still Have Their Place, But Today's Curators and Educators Promote New Ways of Seeing and Doing
description: NOT so long ago, museums were like temples -- temples dedicated to Art. Big, imposing and often neo-classical outside, they were quiet, often darkened places inside, where people went to look reverently at inanimate paintings and sculptures by dead white males, familiar mainly from textbooks. Sometimes they would take their children, who would be hushed into a similar state of intimidation under the eye of uniformed guards. Hardly anyone went to a museum for fun.

title: The Way We Live Now: 5-9-99; The Glass Half Empty
description: My approach to well-being, circa 1990: Scotch, chardonnay. Very direct, very effective.

title: Ready to Hike
description: To the Editor: I read with interest Emily Laurence Baker's article ''British Summer, Camp Included'' (April 10) about taking your children to Europe and enrolling them in camp.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLAUBMAN, JOSHUA
description: GLAUBMAN-Joshua. On May 6, 1999, age 97. Beloved husband of the late Sophie. Dear uncle to Richard Glaubman and Carol Kroch, great-uncle to four. He will be deeply missed. Service Monday 1 PM at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: The Ring That Enrages
description: To the Editor:

title: The View From/Mystic; The Big Move Is Over And 3 Whales Settle In
description: DAWN was just breaking last Tuesday when the staff at Mystic Aquarium began one of the final phases of the aquarium's most recent expansion: Moving its three beluga whales into their new quarters, a $9-million exhibit that mimics a stretch of Alaskan coast.

title: Lassiter, Once Again, Is Too Much
description: With all the troubles the MetroStars have had trying to find a way to score, it seemed almost unfair to have to contend with Roy Lassiter today.

title: A Bird's Nest Is A Crib, a Nursery, Not a Home at All
description: BIRDS' EGGS and birds' nests -- not the prefabricated Easter egg type but forms sprung from nature -- are extolled in an exhibition at the Stamford Museum and Nature Center.

title: Insurers and Uninsured Put Hospitals in a Squeeze
description: AFTER a run of profitable years, hospitals across the country face cash-flow problems -- squeezed, officials say, by slow-paying managed-care companies, cutbacks in government programs and rapidly growing numbers of uninsured patients. Pressured by rising costs, hospitals are aggressively trying to collect mountains of overdue bills for patient care.

title: Out of the Ashes, Good-Neighborliness Rises
description: JEAN FIELD said she was awakened by the screams and the agonized cries for help, then went outside her Huntington Station home and confronted a harrowing scene: dozens of people fleeing a burning apartment house directly across the street. She called 911, but in the early minutes of the disaster she could do little more than stand with others who had escaped the flames and watch as adults still trapped inside desperately tossed their children out of second-story windows.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANTEL, HENRY, ZVI HIRSCH BEN MENACHEM MENDEL
description: MANTEL-Henry, Zvi Hirsch Ben Menachem Mendel, 84. Del Ray Beach, FL. Devoted husband of Ruth Mantel, loving father of Michael Mantel, Marsha Wagner and their spouses Anne Mantel, Leon Wagner, and Andrea Harmon. Grandfather of Gabriel, Daniel and Samuel. Henry was born and raised in Vienna, immigrated to the United States in 1939 and earned a Purple Heart during his meritorious service in World War II. Henry was a wonderful, talented and active man who will be missed by his family and many friends. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Congregation Ansche Chesed in Manhattan or the Rabbi Discretionary Fund of the Jewish Community Center of Harrison, New York.

title: A Family That Hates Together
description: EVEN though Fiona, a hostile and hated woman, gets up and walks about, she is dead.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KESSLER, HOWARD
description: KESSLER - Howard. Memorial Service to be held on May 10, 1999 at 6:30pm Rodeph Sholom, 7 West 83rd St.

title: Long, Winding Way Around
description: With the Holland Tunnel crowds, morning and evening gridlock on Canal Street and the seemingly never-ending reconstruction of the West Side Highway, their traffic woes are legion. So residents of northwestern TriBeCa were especially put out last month when the city put up a sign banning evening rush left turns from Canal Street to Greenwich Street, the only practical southbound route into the area.

title: Bearing Lotus Blossoms And Hope, Not Guns
description: AT the age of 2, Tony Bui escaped Vietnam with his family after the 1975 fall of Saigon. Growing up in Sunnyvale, Calif., as one of the few Vietnamese in his community, he was intent on assimilation. ''My brother and sister and I didn't spend much time trying to learn our culture,'' Mr. Bui said. ''Vietnam, to me, was a past-tense word.''

title: The Best
description: O.K., so it provided some spare change to a group of good writers and offered a lot of elegant essays to those who like to read that sort of thing on Sunday, but what did your issue on the best of the last thousand years do for readers who are looking for news? And -- oh, gawd! -- it's the first of six on the millennium, which we'll all be so tired of when it arrives we won't want to read anything about it.

title: Brooke Roberson, Stefan Cushman
description: Merritt Brooke Roberson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert S. Roberson of Newport News, Va., was married yesterday to Stefan Hepburn Cushman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Roderick H. Cushman of Mill Neck, N.Y. Bishop C. Charles Vache, the retired bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of Southern Virginia, performed the ceremony at the Bruton Parish Episcopal Church in Williamsburg, Va.

title: OPINION; Cleaning, Till the Diagnosis Comes
description: I AM probably the least domesticated of late 20th-century women. A wholehearted feminist who raised three children, got a divorce, struggled to finish a master's degree and had an active psychotherapy practice, I am an embarrassment to homemaking arts and sciences.

title: The Best
description: Your magazine was interesting. However, you omitted an important medical discovery. I speak of anesthesia.

title: Patching an Appeal For Charity Donations
description: In recent advertisements for the Weatherproof Garment Company, consumers are urged to support something called the Weatherproof American Red Cross Storm Fund. The American Red Cross logo (the little red cross) also appears in the ads.

title: Wendy Merson, Eric Goldstein
description: Wendy Lyn Merson, a daughter of Susan and Lawrence M. Merson of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married in New York last evening to Eric Andrew Goldstein, a son of Elaine and Michael S. Goldstein of Roslyn Heights, N.Y. Rabbi Michael A. White officiated at the New York Palace.

title: Barbecued Data
description: Sometimes it's the hardware. Sometimes it's the software. And sometimes it's just human error. Computer mistakes, malfunctions and glitches, beyond the obviously misdirected E-mail, continue to spread faster than a computer virus. What are your own most humorous or horrific stories? Send them to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: Broadcast News
description: HUMAN VOICES

title: Would Vouchers Help the Poorest Students?
description: To the Editor:

title: Gibbs Won't Run Again
description: Mayor Frances S. Gibbs of Peekskill, 73, has announced that she will not seek a fourth term in the next election, said Joe Brady, chairman of the city's Republican Committee.

title: He Can Cook, Too
description: So, Chef Angelo, what's on the menu -- tea for two? Egg roll for Mr. Goldstone's table? Meat pies a la Lovett? That cake someone left out in the rain, all the sweet green icing flowing down?

title: Seeking the Soul of the City's Summer; Hearing the Crack of Old Bats, the Roar of Past Crowds
description: DANNY PERASA was 10 when his mother began giving him $1 on Saturdays and letting him go alone from Bay Ridge in Flatbush to watch the Brooklyn Dodgers play at Ebbets Field. A nickel each way for the subway, 60 cents admission, a nickel for a scorecard and a quarter to divvy up between hot dogs and sodas, which cost a nickel each. He saw more than 100 games in the next two years and fell in love with the perfect ball field.

title: Leftist Dove Is Netanyahu's Favorite Campaign Target
description: There could be no more mild-mannered lightning rod of controversy than Yossi Beilin, a soft-spoken, bespectacled academic who is serving as the right wing's voodoo doll in the current election campaign in Israel.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In /North Salem, N.Y.; Bucolic Vistas in Suburban Westchester
description: EVEN people who think they know Westchester County pretty well may not be familiar with North Salem, and that's just fine with many of the residents of this most bucolic town in Westchester County, prized for its sense of rural remoteness.

title: Sports of The Times; Hess Mulled The Return Of the Jets
description: IN early January, Leon Hess attended a National Football League owners meeting in Commissioner Paul Tagliabue's office. The subject: how the N.F.L. should coexist with the Internet in the 21st century. But when the owners broke for lunch, Hess put on his overcoat.

title: Organ Donation Should Be a Gift; As Leaders Disappear
description: To the Editor:

title: Minimal Chic, With Big Sushi
description: You can add the minimally decorated Japanese restaurant Wasabi, at 205 Bedford Avenue between North Fifth and Sixth Streets, to the list of new Williamsburg businesses that cater to the young, artistic and merely cool.

title: Katherine Dominus, Chris Robinson
description: Katherine Lee Dominus, the daughter of Patricia and Barton Dominus of New York, was married yesterday to Chris Robinson, a son of Arija Robinson of Leverett, Mass., and Peter Robinson of Shutesbury, Mass. Ann E. McDonough, a New Hampshire justice of the peace, officiated at the Hanover Inn in Hanover, N.H.

title: Many Researchers Say Link Is Already Clear on Media and Youth Violence
description: In response to the Colorado school shooting, President Clinton is to meet with entertainment industry executives and others at the White House tomorrow to discuss youth violence. And both the White House and Congress are considering asking the Surgeon General to conduct a comprehensive study of the effects of media violence on American youths.

title: Annuals That Make Lazy Gardeners Look Good
description: THROUGH sheer laziness, I had a beautiful retaining-wall garden last year.

title: Some Entrances Closed At Times Square Subway
description: Subway riders will encounter minor inconvenience in Times Square for the next few months, with two subway entrances and two ramps closed for renovation until next fall.

title: Girls Just Want To ...
description: Back in the mid-80's, a couple of high school girls were sitting around talking about what they would like to see in a magazine. Flash forward to the interactive telecommunications program at New York University in 1996. Now three young women were reflecting on their teen-age years, and agreeing that nothing they could find on the Web addressed the anxiety, confusion and insecurities of adolescent girls.

title: Woman Cadet Graduates at the Citadel, a First
description: She was not the first woman to gain admission to the Citadel, but today Nancy Mace became the first woman to graduate from this 156-year-old state-supported military college.

title: Charles River, Cambridge, Mass.
description: The great, gray, green Charles River, all set about with motorways, separates Boston from Cambridge. Boston is the capital of the state of Massachusetts. Cambridge is its own state of mind, the ''People's Republic of Cambridge,'' as it is called on radio talk shows and in the pages of the Boston Herald, the big city's daily tabloid newspaper. There is no passport control at the border, but the visitor will recognize a subtle change. Boston is a collection of ethnic and economic neighborhoods wrapped around a giant financial district that becomes uninhabited after 6 P.M. when the brokers, accountants and lawyers decamp to the suburbs. Across the river, the constant influx and exodus of students and junior faculty breaks down the insularity of neighborhoods into a multitude of multi-ness: racial, cultural, socioeconomic, intellectual and lingual. Cambridge has museums and parks and shopping experiences, but most of all, it has buzz.

title: At Lyndhurst, Students' Skits Relive History
description: THE scene was deceptively simple.

title: A Food Fight Over Trucks Near a Store
description: Hands shaking in anger, Joe Igneri leafed through a stack of three dozen snapshots. Each picture showed a different truck, some parked on sidewalks, some blocking driveways and some doubled parked. To Mr. Igneri, it was the same message: too many trucks.

title: May 2-8; Scotland and Wales Get New Powers
description: In voting that redrew Britain's political landscape, Scotland and Wales elected members of new legislatures in Edinburgh and Cardiff that will exercise many of the powers long held by the British Parliament in London.

title: Jackson & Co.
description: A BROTHERHOOD OF VALOR The Common Soldiers of the Stonewall Brigade, C.S.A., and the Iron Brigade, U.S.A. By Jeffry D. Wert. Illustrated. 413 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $25.

title: Naked Came the Raconteur
description: HIS heart may be enlarged, his knees increasingly fickle, but Quentin Crisp, 90, will not be slowed down by those pesky Don't Walk signals. ''What a silly waste of time,'' he said, stepping off the curb into Second Avenue traffic with a self-satisfied harrumph.

title: The Best
description: It is curious that Edward O. Wilson offers an explanation for each superlative under ''Best Species,'' with the notable exception of ''most intelligent'' -- humans -- as if this goes without saying. There isn't an ant worth its salt that would erect a 50-story building that wasn't according to spec. I've never heard of ducks knocking their mates and offspring senseless and setting the entire duck pond ablaze in a murderous moment.

title: They Led Two Lives
description: VENONA

title: Organ Donation Should Be a Gift; Made Whole Again
description: To the Editor:

title: 10,000 Things I Hate About You
description: No One Left to Lie to

title: El Al Marks Jubilee With Free Stop in Rome
description: To accommodate demand linked to celebrations in Rome and Jerusalem, beginning this summer El Al will offer a stopover in Rome at no extra charge to passengers traveling between New York and Tel Aviv.

title: From Slag Heap To Serial Gardens
description: Two former Yorkshire coal mines are the unlikely site of a new British attraction that celebrates environmental awareness. The Earth Center, a $160 million science center, opened last month in Doncaster, 172 miles north of London.

title: The Antidote to Violence
description: To the Editor:

title: Small Is Beautiful; Orvieto, Italy
description: For those of us who quiver with agoraphobia at the very thought of driving a car without the shelter of city traffic, ''perfect small town'' is an oxymoron. Yet I cannot find a thing wrong with the medieval center of Orvieto, where some 23,000 souls live atop a tufa outcropping, La Rupe, that rises majestically from the verdant Umbrian countryside.

title: Plant Some Annuals, Watch for Rust
description: Plant seeds of annual vines and other annuals that are best sown where they are to grow. Roll up seeds with tough outer coats like morning glories in moist paper towels, and keep in plastic bags for several days before planting. Begin transplanting warm weather annuals that have been sufficiently hardened off.

title: Looking to the Real In a Quest for Beauty
description: 'Realism '99'

title: Fighting the Good Fight Against Disease
description: GREAT changes are taking place in the horticultural world. Emphasis has been placed on environmental concerns and reduction in the use of pesticides.

title: The United Kingdom's Overhaul
description: With elections now completed for new legislatures in Northern Ireland, Scotland and Wales, Prime Minister Tony Blair has won the battle for a Britain with its politics radically reconfigured to his own design.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Musical Drama in Purchase

title: The World: Culture War; What It Would Take To Cleanse Serbia
description: ALONG the blood-spattered timeline of Slobodan Milosevic's Yugoslavia, Kosovo is merely the hideous Now. There was a Before -- in Croatia and Bosnia. Assuming that Mr. Milosevic retreats from Kosovo with his dictatorship intact, as now seems likely, Balkans experts foresee an unspeakable After.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHADWICK, HAROLD F
description: CHADWICK-Harold F. On May 8, 1999 (Retired International General Secretary Treasurer of the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employees). Beloved brother of Helen Guggino. Devoted uncle of Michael Guggino. Mass of Christian Burial Tuesday, 10:15 AM, at St. Patrick's R.C. Church. Visitation Sunday and Monday, 2-5 and 7-9, at McLaughlin & Sons, Third Avenue at 97th Street, Brooklyn.

title: To the Flea Market in Pajamas on Ebay
description: AMONG my friends, Ebay is hotter than Britney Spears.

title: Ronald Doerfler, Krystyna Keller
description: Krystyna Osiecki Keller, the director of sales for ABC News International in New York, and Ronald John Doerfler, a vice president and the chief financial officer of the Hearst Corporation in New York, were married yesterday. The Rev. Dr. J. Barrie Shepherd performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church in New York.

title: Sports of The Times; These Knicks Don't Wrestle, They Soar
description: TIM HARDAWAY made his way to family and friends yesterday afternoon. Hardaway is the spark plug of the Miami Heat, but he had misfired miserably on this day: 19 shots taken, 4 made, 10 points. The Heat hadn't done much better: Miami had shot 34 percent from the field.

title: May 2-8; Beware the Scarf in Parliament
description: At its first meeting, Turkey's newly elected Parliament turned not to pressing problems like inflation, human rights or educational reform, but to the question of the Muslim head scarf. The chamber erupted in pandemonium as Merve Kavakci, an American-educated deputy from Istanbul, sought unsuccessfully to take her oath of office while wearing a scarf.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RENUCCI, RAYMOND
description: RENUCCI-Raymond. The French Institute Alliance Francaise mourns the loss of our beloved colleague and friend. A first class professor of French specializing in business, Mr. Renucci held an MBA degree from the Institut d' Etudes Politiques in Paris and a law degree from the Paris Law School. A caring teacher, he encouraged his students by his example and love of his native language. Mr. Renucci is survived by his son Pascal Gilles Renucci of CA and his family in France, among them his two brothers Antoine and Gerard and a sister Magdeleine Frizzi. A memorial to celebrate his life will be held in the French Institute's Tinker Auditorium located at 22 East 60th St. on Friday May 14, 1999 at 12:00 PM.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry
description: Bad Judgment

title: Bananas
description: A: It's not a commonplace label. It's in four parts. I like it. You?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARSHALL, DONALD W.
description: MARSHALL-Donald W. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Donald W. Marshall, associated with The Times from 1931 until retiring in 1959.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, KAREN D.
description: GOLDSTEIN-Karen D. On May 8, 1999. Daughter of the late Bernard and Irene Hein. Loving mother of Philip, Penny and Greg. Devoted sister to Leslie. Adoring grandma to Emma, Ethan and Matthew. Services Monday 10 AM at I.J. Morris, Inc., 46 Greenwich St., Hempstead, L.I. In lieu of flowers donations should be made for ovarian cancer research.

title: There Is No Joy, But Wait a Year
description: THERE will be no professional baseball on Long Island again this season, no pop-ups rising impossibly high into the night sky, no diving catches in center or close plays at the plate, no rhubarbs or homers or scoreboard pyrotechnics. But wait until next year.

title: Cat in Hat Meets Hulk
description: IN Universal Studios' new billion-dollar theme park, Islands of Adventure, two Dr. Seuss characters called the Zax arrive by a roundabout route to confront each other in stubborn, frozen malice.

title: Organ Donation Should Be a Gift; Pay Those Who Give
description: To the Editor:

title: Mothers? Difficult To Please? It's the Job.
description: THE snowbirds are coming home from Florida. They are flying up, and driving up, from Boca Raton and Boynton Beach and Fort Lauderdale, wilted from playing golf in 90-degree heat, and eager to see their grandchildren again. They come bearing gifts and good intentions.

title: Votes in Congress
description: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York.

title: European Roots
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIPTON, LOUIS J.
description: LIPTON-Louis J. Age 78. On May 6, 1999. Survived by his wife Lini and son Peter. A righteous man, loved and respected by his family and friends. Services on Sunday 12:30pm. Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave, at 81st St. Interment at Westchester Hills Cemetery. Contributions may be made to: The Blue Card, a Jewish aid organization for Holocaust survivors, 1 West 34 St, NYC, 10001.

title: Air War Hurts Stability Of a Yugoslav Republic
description: It was a beguiling promise, ''To Live Better,'' that helped Montenegro's governing coalition win power last year. But few people in this ancient city would say their lives are better now than before.

title: The World: Shield Laws; Using the Press for Protection
description: AS soon as foreign reporters enter Yugoslavia by one of the only routes still open -- into the country's junior republic, Montenegro, by way of Albania -- a small squad of heavily armed police officers is there waiting for them.

title: An Outrage, Yeltsin Declares, and Warns of 'Consequences'
description: President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia today condemned the bombing of the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade as ''yet another flagrant violation of international law'' by NATO leaders and called on them to end their military action in Yugoslavia immediately.

title: Style
description: Despite fame, fortune and excellent wardrobes, these sons stay in touch.

title: Do Those Coughs Sound Familiar?
description: So that's why the new Nancy Lee and Perry R. Bass Performance Hall in Fort Worth looks so much like New York's Carnegie Hall, horseshoe-shaped tiers and all. There, in a first-tier Carnegie Hall box on a recent Sunday afternoon, sat Sid R. Bass, Perry's oldest son, and his wife, Mercedes, for one of the Metropolitan Opera Orchestra's sold-out concerts under James Levine.

title: May 2-8; Over Iraq, Another Air War Continues
description: Even as the Pentagon stepped up its air campaigns in the Balkans, another American military campaign continued apace against Iraq, with almost daily skirmishes reported over the last two weeks.

title: An Oasis of Literate TV Or Snobbish Escapism?
description: NOT long ago Tiffany & Company ran an advertisement for a choker. It was illustrated over a bold-face line reading ''Masterpiece Theater,'' and the copy mentioned that the $26,500 piece of jewelry was based on an 1860's design from the Tiffany Archives and composed of cultured pearls and diamonds set in platinum. The copywriter knew what he or she was telling the shopper: this is something Lady Marjorie Bellamy might have worn in ''Upstairs, Downstairs,'' arguably still ''Masterpiece Theater's'' most popular long-running series.

title: The Great Ape Massacre
description: Dieu-Donne Bima Bima is a nice young man with a gentle manner. With becoming modesty, he describes how the chopped-up bodies of three gorillas have come to be smoking over a fire outside his hut.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: She Came to Live Out Loud

title: Magazine Revises Its Span
description: Brooklyn Bridge may not be falling down, but the magazine can no longer afford to be published monthly, its owner and editor in chief, Melissa Ennen, said last week.

title: What John D. Doesn't Tell John Q.
description: An Orlando, Fla., divorce battle threatens to penetrate the secrecy surrounding the history, size and substance of the fabled fortune created by John D. Rockefeller. The case involves George O'Neill Jr., John D.'s 48-year old great-great-grandson, and Amy O'Neill, his wife of 10 years, who is 31.

title: Dreamscapes
description: WHAT is a child's dream of New York? Bridges, tall buildings, lights and shimmering water are all important elements, if the winning poems in a contest conducted by radio station WNYC are any indication.

title: Service With a Grip
description: Why does the Internal Revenue Service now call taxpayers ''customers''? When Barnaby Zall, a lawyer in Rockville, Md., asked at a recent meeting of the American Bar Association, this was the reply of Marcus Owens, who oversees tax-exempt organizations for the I.R.S.: ''It means we will shake your hand warmly, but we won't let go.'' DAVID CAY JOHNSTON

title: A Capitalist Hero Keeps On Pitching; The Corny Charm of Buffettpalooza
description: IF there's one thing that the thousands of pilgrims who made their way here last weekend would be loath to say about Warren E. Buffett, it's that he's shameless.

title: Pay Raise for American Soldiers Is Long Overdue
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. to Train Police Leaders For Indonesia In Riot Control
description: The Clinton Administration has decided to offer riot-control training to the Indonesian police in preparation for next month's national elections despite concerns from human rights groups over the abysmal human rights record of the police there, according to Administration officials.

title: Eastchester Example
description: Surrounded by dandelions and patches of clover, James E. Cavanaugh, Town Supervisor of Eastchester, recently began a campaign to alert homeowners to the dangers of overusing chemicals on their lawns.

title: Manitoba's Bears
description: To the Editor: I read the article about Churchill (''Fur Coats Are O.K. Here,'' April 12) by Joni Seager with great enthusiasm. My father and I traveled up last November to see the polar bears and, we hoped, the Northern Lights.

title: Hands, and Hearts, Filled With Twins
description: TWINS, these days, seem to be everywhere. Although septuplets and octuplets have attracted national attention lately, statistics show that twin births are up 47 percent nationwide from 1980 to 1996.

title: Liberties; Guns and Poses
description: When I went out to buy a gun one night, I had no idea it would be easier and less expensive than buying a pink cashmere sweater set.

title: The Way We Live Now: 5-9-99: Shop Talk; How to Win
description: What if the war in Kosovo were a purely military exercise? If, instead of fragile alliances, desperate refugees and nightly newscasts, there were only guns and soldiers? Could swift action bring the conflict to a close? We asked William Odom and Bernard Trainor -- both former lieutenant generals, both scholars of military history -- to ponder what the war would be like if all political considerations were suspended, and to show us how they'd fight it.

title: Sip With a Straw And an Agenda
description: Drink my clean water, and help protect yours: Robert F. Kennedy Jr., long an environmentalist, recently introduced Keeper Springs mountain spring water. Influenced by Paul Newman's charitable example, Mr. Kennedy pledges the profits to local water conservation groups. ''When people think of the environment, they think of global issues like the ozone layer or the destruction of the rain forest,'' he said. ''They don't think about their own backyard.''

title: The Best
description: In ''Every Dictator's Nightmare,'' Wole Soyinka names droit du seigneur as a despotic practice, then, astonishingly, identifies the ''cuckolded groom'' as its victim! Will it take another millennium before a Nobel Prize winner recognizes women as the victims of rape?

title: Blood Bright Dreams
description: Dailies & Rushes

title: Miss Petter, Mr. Egerton-Warburton
description: Anna Webb Petter, a psychotherapist in New York, was married on Monday to James Willoughby Egerton-Warburton, an insurance executive. The Very Rev. Morris Thompson Jr. performed the ceremony at Christ Church Cathedral in Lexington, Ky.

title: The Antidote to Violence; View From High School
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WEINTRAUB, SHEILA
description: WEINTRAUB-Sheila. Cherished mother, My first Mother's Day. Oh, how I wish you were here! Allison

title: Legislators Weigh Issue of Crime and Carting
description: AS the Board of Legislators prepares to enact a law aimed at keeping organized crime out of the garbage carting industry, it seems unlikely to act soon, if at all, on proposals aimed at closing bars earlier and limiting protests at abortion clinics.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MIDDLETON, ANITA ARDEN
description: MIDDLETON-Anita Arden. Died May 3 after a lengthy illness. Married to the late stage & screen actor Guy Middleton. Mrs. Middleton was a long time London resident and was a native New Yorker. She will be buried with her husband in England. Mrs. Middleton, an international actress whose credits include both American and British films, traveled with the USO and was a ''long stemmed rose'' for Broadway & Hollywood producer Billy Rose, early in her career. She is survived by deeply devoted friends in the U.S. and England, as well as cousins Vera Latham Bergman of Clearwater, FL, and Joan Latham Farewell of Atlanta, GA. She will be dearly missed.

title: John Hancock Emerging Growth Fund
description: PORTFOLIO managers who limit themselves to small-capitalization stocks face a recurring quandary: Their best performers grow into mid- and large-cap stocks, forcing them to sell.

title: 'England, England'
description: Her first memory, she said, was of sitting on the kitchen floor, which was covered in loosely woven raffia matting, the sort with holes in, holes she could poke a spoon into and make bigger and get smacked for  feeling safe because her mother was singing to herself in the background  she always sang old songs when she cooked, not the ones she liked listening to at other times  and even today when Martha turned on the radio and heard anything like `You're the Top' or `We'll All Gather at the River' or `Night and Day' she would suddenly smell nettle soup or frying onions, wasn't that the strangest thing?  and that was another, `Love Is the Strangest Thing,' which always meant the sudden cut and seep of an orange for her  and there, spread out on the matting, was her Counties of England jigsaw puzzle, and Mummy had decided to help her by doing all the outside and the sea to begin with, which left this outline of the country in front of her, this funny-shaped piece of raffia floor, a bit like a bulgy old lady sitting on a beach with her legs stretched out  the legs being Cornwall, though of course she hadn't thought that at the time, she didn't even know the word Cornwall, or what colour the piece was, and you know what children are like with jigsaws, they just pick up any old piece and try to force it into the hole, so she probably picked up Lancashire and made it behave like Cornwall.

title: Saving Lives In the Air
description: A talented young colleague of mine died suddenly in her kitchen a few years ago despite everything her husband and an emergency squad could do. I found the funeral particularly difficult because a medical expert had told me she need not have died; that a heart in cardiac arrest in an otherwise healthy person could be restarted with almost no damage provided it is done quickly.

title: Eire-to-Hair Mission: The Soft and Natural Look
description: Geoff Merritt, the owner of the two-month-old hair salon that bears his name at 210 West 79th Street between Amsterdam Avenue and Broadway, may speak with the brogue of an Irishman, but he sounds like a New Yorker.

title: Style; She Who Must Be Obeyed
description: Mothers can be a very tough room. They're the ones you instinctively turn to for validation, but they'll also blurt out the one innocent remark that'll deflate you like a stepped-on balloon. Even though my mother is always delighted when I report that I just saw, say, Madonna, she generally finds a mildly adorable way to bring me right back to earth. ''Did she give you money?'' she'll ask.

title: For Vacations Rated G
description: GIVEN the structure of the school year and the rhythms of the business world, summer travel is often family travel. Visits to museums, historic sites and restaurants must be leavened with diversions for children, and a family at the beach needs backup when it rains.

title: The Best
description: Your magazine is a major work summarizing human events of the second millennium. As for the ''pedants,'' they should consider that when a baby is born, or a century begins, that's Day 1, not the first birthday, which is 365 days later: 1999 is the 2000th year of 2M, and 2000 is the first year of 3M. Thus, Jan. 1, 2001, celebrates the end of the first year of the new millennium and the first day of the second year. Very simple, really.

title: Julie Eisenberg, Michael Pitman
description: Julie Suzanne Eisenberg, a daughter of Joyce and Arnold Eisenberg of Manhattan, was married in East Hampton, N.Y., last evening to Dr. Michael Jay Pitman, a son of Paulette Pitman and Dr. Mark Pitman of Syosset, N.Y. Rabbi David Gelfand performed the ceremony at the Jewish Center of the Hamptons.

title: Michael Ovitz Is on the Line
description: When Michael Ovitz gives a tour of his house, a big white neo-Georgian in L.A.'s Brentwood Park, it's the art he wants you to see. A white Jasper Johns flag painting hangs in the living room, where there's also a cubist-period Picasso to the right of the fireplace. A huge Dubuffet dominates the screening area. Three Lichtensteins shout from the entry. Upstairs, in the master bedroom, a red Rothko glows next to a glowering black-and-white Kline. There's art everywhere -- masterworks hung within inches of other masterworks. It's impressive, beautiful and telling. Ovitz loves his collection, but it is also a tool with which to dazzle, to impress. When a prospective employee, a young, talented Hollywood agent with a solid client list, asked Ovitz recently why he should come to work for him, Ovitz replied, ''Because I have a Picasso and you don't.'' Perhaps he was joking but probably he was not. ''Perception,'' Ovitz will say, again and again, ''is everything.'' So while he treasures his Picasso and likes to tell stories about how his white-on-white Rymans compelled Sean Connery to back the play ''Art,'' Ovitz's paintings are also meant to be advertisements. These paintings reassure him that he is who he thinks he is -- that he is Big. For Ovitz, these paintings silence his enemies, some of whom were once his partners and close friends.

title: Clinton Orders Job Relief In Aftermath of Tornadoes
description: Clearly shaken by the extent of the damage here from last Monday's tornadoes, President Clinton today promised the families who had lived in one devastated neighborhood that the Federal Government would temporarily hire thousands of Oklahomans who had lost their jobs in businesses that were destroyed by the storms.

title: Uniondale's Moore Races to 3 Victories
description: Jetoya Moore, a junior from Uniondale, N.Y., came away with three gold medals and a most valuable performer award yesterday in the 32d Loucks Games at White Plains High School. She won the 100-meter dash (12.21 seconds) and the 200 (24.95) and anchored Uniondale's winning 4x100 relay team (48.79).

title: Come On Baby, Fyodor Needs New Shoes!
description: AMONG the problems to be addressed or evaded in a coming report by the National Gambling Impact Study Commission, set up by Congress to look into the flourishing pastime, is the problem gambler. Since any such study requires that the panelists get a grip on the nature of the ailment, one hopes they have been introduced to the most vivid accounts of gambling addiction in world literature. They come from Fyodor Mikhailovich Dostoyevsky, who for miserable years was an unregenerate roulette punter in the casinos of Germany. ''Oh, the way they played yesterday,'' he wrote. ''The excitement was tremendous! If only I had some money.''

title: Officer Faces 25 Years
description: Anthony Ambrosovitch, a retired police officer who pleaded guilty to reduced manslaughter charges late last month, faces a maximum of 25 years in prison -- a sentence the District Attorney's office plans to seek. Judge Barbara G. Zambelli has scheduled sentencing for June 8 in County Court in White Plains.

title: The Best
description: I think you may have missed the single most influential invention of the last thousand years: the newspaper. Newspapers are the means by which the best ideas were transmitted to the masses. They are what made parliamentary democracy, universal suffrage and human rights possible.

title: In the Region / Westchester; Multiple Bidding Rages in a Tight Housing Market
description: AFTER looking at a three-bedroom spilt-level in Yonkers that had been on the market at $225,000 for only two days, Mark Ritchie acted quickly. ''I made the offer on the curb outside the house,'' Mr. Ritchie said.

title: Ballads Pay Tribute on Mother's Day in Peekskill
description: HOW better to celebrate Mother's Day today than with songs for mother by three grateful daughters? At 4 P.M. the Paramount Center for the Arts in Peekskill plays host to Susan McKeown, Cathie Ryan and Robin Spielberg, singing variations on themes of family ties, influences and memories. The warm-voiced artists offer a panoply of ballads and Celtic-flavored instrumental tributes, while also greeting a special guest on stage, Margaret Pataki, Gov. George E. Pataki's mother and New York's First Mother.

title: Stacey Bradford, Richard Greenberg
description: Stacey Lynn Bradford, a daughter of Eileen and Charles Bradford of New York, was married last evening to Richard Harris Greenberg, the son of Susan and Kal Greenberg of Chatham, N.J. Rabbi Amy Ehrlich officiated at the W Hotel in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAMILTON, ELIZABETH W.
description: HAMILTON-Elizabeth W. On May 1, 1999. Beloved mother of Lysette Hamilton & William E. Hamilton, grandmother of Kathryn, Lisabeth Anne, Gerald, and Alexandra. Great-grandmother of Gerald, Lindsay, and Song. Wife of the late Harold B. Hamilton, sister of Margaret Dreyer. Contributions in her name, may be sent to The Girls Vacation Fund, Inc., 370 Lexington Ave, Suite 913, NY, NY 10017. Memorial service on Monday May 10, 1999 at 4PM St. Luke's Church, 73 So. Fullerton Ave, Montclair, NJ.

title: A Battler for the New In American Music
description: AT a time when the New York Philharmonic celebrates George Gershwin one season and Aaron Copland the next, it is easy to forget that the groundbreaking music of American composers once went unheard in concert halls.

title: The Way We Live Now: 5-9-99: The Ethicist; A Novel Solution
description: I have a really crazy family. Dysfunction 'R' Us! I've been reading all these memoirs about people's messed-up childhoods, and even though I'm not a great writer or famous or anything, I thought I might try my hand at writing one. Do you think it's ethical to write a tell-all about your own family while the people in question are still living? - M.W., New York

title: Diallo Inquiry Focuses On Duration of Gunfire
description: Investigators reviewing the shooting of Amadou Diallo are focusing increased attention on how long it took the four police officers involved to fire 41 bullets at him, law enforcement officials say.

title: Help Abroad
description: Avis Rent a Car has expanded its On Call program, which provides toll-free telephone assistance 24 hours a day, to make it worldwide. For access to the service, Avis renters must call (800) 297-4447 before they leave the United States to get the toll-free or collect telephone numbers required in each country.

title: May 2-8; Pennsylvania May Pay For Donated Organs
description: Demand for human organs has for years far exceeded the supply.

title: Small Is Beautiful; Grand Marais, Minn.
description: Grand Marais. Even to pronounce the old French name evokes the peculiar allure of the place. The keening north wind passes through the boreal forest that rises to the north and west, and the memory of the voyageurs de bois is still resonant, canoes moving today, as in the 17th century, along the Boundary Waters rivers. The little town hugs the crescent harbor on the North Shore of Lake Superior, 108 miles north of Duluth, Minn. Local people will remind you, pointing to the sloping wolf-head shape of Superior on a map, that the direction, up Minnesota 61, is really east of Duluth, but the poetry of the place is true north.

title: FILM; Making Dreamscapes All Too Shockingly Real
description: IN a memorable sequence in David Cronenberg's dreamlike remaking of ''The Fly'' (1986), Seth Brundle (Jeff Goldblum) says to the woman he loves and has renounced, ''I am an insect who dreamed he was a man, and now the dream is over.'' In waking life, Brundle is being gradually transformed into a giant insect burdened by the awareness of his human (dream) self. Some critics felt that for all the poignancy of its doomed romance, ''The Fly'' was marred by too many grotesque effects. And ''The Fly'' -- the director's biggest commercial success -- is probably the least disturbing of his major films.

title: May 2-8; Motion for a Nomination, But No Progress
description: The long story of Richard Holbrooke's long-stalled nomination as the top American diplomat to the United Nations has overtones of the Perils of Pauline. Only days after a State Department ethics investigation found there was no reason to block the nomination over lecture fees he had taken, Republicans on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee tussled over whether the panel can schedule a confirmation hearing.

title: Lightening the Tax Load
description: State legislatures enacted tax cuts last year of a record $7.5 billion, for a total of $22 billion in cuts since 1995. Still, that is less than the $31 billion in increases that the states imposed from 1991 to 1994.

title: Cabbies at a Deli Keep Neighbors' Anger Meter Running
description: Eat Again Deli, on Ninth Avenue and West 20th Street, is popular among South Asian taxi drivers, who stop for lamb curry and aloo gobi while scanning Indian newspapers and catching up with compatriots. But a taxi stand installed three months ago across the avenue has upset neighbors, who complain that it has increased noise, garbage and clashes over parking spaces with the deli's owners and patrons.

title: Crosstown Rivalry: Mothers Inc.
description: IF you are an anxious new parent on the Upper East Side and you want to look for a little guidance and some comfort from the similarly situated, you may find yourself at the new mothers' luncheons held by Ronni Soled. If you are an Upper West Sider in search of the same thing, then your hostess may be Lori Robinson. But be warned. These women are not friends. You are now either a Ronni person or a Lori person, and the identities are as indelible as parenthood.

title: Company's Coming, so Tour Hosts Spruce Up Seriously
description: STEVE TANDY is house proud: proud of the Woodshed, known familiarly as this Victorian village's ''Greatest Painted Lady,'' and proud of the restoration work he has done in the last two years to bring his 18-room house ''up to the millennium,'' he said.

title: May 2-8; Another Record For the Dow. (Ho Hum).
description: Another month, another milestone. The Dow Jones industrial average topped 11,000 on Monday, just 24 trading days after barreling past 10,000.

title: Likelihood That India Will Sign Nuclear Test Ban Wanes
description: A year after India and Pakistan sent tremors of anxiety around the world by conducting nuclear tests, the once-strong likelihood that India would soon sign the nuclear test ban treaty faded this week to a very faint possibility.

title: Cutting Down on Cars Would Ease Sidewalk Crush
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BATES, PATRICIA ALEXANDRA
description: BATES-Patricia Alexandra. Died Wednesday, May 5 in her home in Deerfield Beach, Florida. Raised in Ardsley - on - the - Hudson, New York. Graduate of the Masters School. Devoted wife and mother and volunteer for Abbot House. She is survived by her three children, John Field Bates, Patricia Alexandra Bates, and Alexandra Cole Bates.

title: Pablo Neruda's House in the Sand
description: White-shirted peddlers enticed us with fresh, ripe strawberries. Boys held out baskets of warm empanadas, or coolers filled with ice cream, but we kept our car windows up, the air-conditioner on. Weekend tourists crowded the roads as we passed through sand-blown coastal towns (San Sebastian, Las Cruces, El Tabo) with their shuttered cottages, roadside eateries and wide public beaches. It was a blazing summer Sunday in Chile, mid-January, and we had driven our white rent-a-Suzuki some 60 miles on mostly good four-lanes from Santiago to Cartagena. Funneling off Highway 78 onto the narrow coastal road, we had only a scant 10 miles to go.

title: It Wasn't All About Winning
description: The recent passing, at age 80, of Jerold C. Hoffberger, a Baltimore businessman who once owned the Orioles, recalls a time when some sports-team owners had loftier goals than building the most luxurious sky boxes.

title: Grabbing My Sneakers And Spandex, Too
description: Spring has sprung, and everyone, it seems, is in the woods. And we're out with them. But we can't seem to get the clothes right. My husband says, ''It must be us.''

title: The Nation
description: BETWEEN the roar of an Amtrak train crash in March and the rampage of tornadoes last Monday, there was a terribly quiet moment in Arkansas last weekend.

title: A Monte Carlo Director Gambles on Novelty
description: WITH its Mediterranean vistas and posh casinos, the little principality of Monaco has reigned for generations as a playground for the rich and famous. It's not all fun and games, though, for Les Ballets de Monte Carlo, a local troupe that spent 48 weeks rehearsing and performing last year. Led by Jean-Christophe Maillot, an amiable young Frenchman with big ambitions, this 14-year-old company is striving to reconcile its loyalty to tradition with a passion for something new.

title: Honorable Mentions
description: Two renovated performance spaces are winning applause. The F. M. Kirby Shakespeare Theater at Drew University in Madison, which opened last June as the home of the New Jersey Shakespeare Festival, received a merit award from the United States Institute for Theater Technology at its conference in Toronto this spring. And the John Harms Center for the Arts in Englewood was honored by the New Jersey Business and Industry Association. . . . The New Jersey Youth Symphony, based in Murray Hill, is celebrating its 20th anniversary with a trip into Manhattan -- specifically, the stage of Alice Tully Hall at Lincoln Center, with a concert next Sunday at 4 P.M. Information: (908) 771-5544. . . . Princeton University has named its first musical ensemble in residence: the Brentano String Quartet. The Manhattan-based group, which has performed at Richardson Auditorium on campus, officially begins its three-year residency with a concert on Sept. 25 but is also scheduled to play this summer in the Princeton summer chamber concerts. . . . The New Jersey Theater Group, the state's consortium for professional companies, has a new affiliate: the New Jersey Repertory Company of Long Branch. The affiliate program is for developing and emerging theaters.

title: A HELPING HOME: A special report.; A Niche for the Elderly, and for the Market
description: Susan Faessler was recently helping her mother-in-law move into an apartment at an assisted-living center here, Heritage at Framingham, when her cell phone rang. ''It's Tom,'' Mrs. Faessler said, referring to her husband. ''He wants to know how you like it.''

title: Environment And Politics Enter Debate On Judgeship
description: Ted Stewart, chief of staff to Utah's Governor, would not seem a likely choice for President Clinton to want to nominate as a Federal judge.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEE, DR. MAN, BUN
description: LEE-Dr. Man-Bun, on May 1, 1999. The Board of Directors, staff, and students of Chinatown Manpower Project mourn the sudden passing of its Chairman, a community leader who tirelessly worked to better the lives of Chinese immigrants. Our deepest sympathy to his family.

title: Small Is Beautiful; Kanonji, Japan
description: Like many other towns on the island of Shikoku, Kanonji, where my husband, Atsunori, grew up with his three brothers, four sisters, parents and grandparents, was a community of a few thousand families engaged in farming and fishing. When I arrived from New York in the mid-1960's, gerrymandering had made this bit of inaka -- countryside -- a half-day train ride south of Tokyo into a city, albeit a provincial one.

title: Yoshii's Move Has Mets Back On Track
description: Seventeen inches may not sound like much. But it has made all the difference in Masato Yoshii's season.

title: Erase That Debt, or Take More
description: Weary consumers with stacks of monthly bills can turn to several Web sites to help them manage debt, including a new one, Credit Page, at creditpage.com. It started last month.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HASSE, GLADYS D.
description: HASSE-Gladys D. Loved friend and inspiring teacher, retired professor of English at Brooklyn College (CUNY) died in her 90th year at home in Newport, RI. A service in her memory will be held on Wednesday, May 12, at 2 PM, in Emmanuel Church, Spring and Dearborn Streets, Newport.

title: Cambodia
description: To the Editor: Increasing tourism to Cambodia will require a few changes (''Cambodia, Now at Peace, Hopes for Tourists,'' April 18). The cost of a 50-minute round trip in a prop plane from Bangkok to Siem Riep (Angkor Wat) is $359 a person. And Bangkok Air was our only choice. When you land there's a $20 entry fee for each person. Don't try to pay with a $100 bill: it is not accepted.

title: Is Midnight Near at the Technology Ball?
description: NO party lasts a lifetime, but since early November investors in technology shares of a variety of stripes have been in full boogie mode.

title: Susan Early, William Helman
description: Susan S. Early, an investment adviser, was married on Friday to William W. Helman, a former securities research director. The Rev. Dr. Herbert B. Anderson performed the ceremony at the Brick Presbyterian Church in New York.

title: Cheerleading Favors Male Sports, Still
description: This sentence, buried in the middle of the article ''Cheerleading Changes as Boys Join Sidelines'' on May 2, says it all: ''At the schools where the cheerleaders were interviewed, the squad still only went out to cheer for major boys' sports.''

title: Where City Meets Country
description: ONE day a few years ago, Fabienne Riesen found herself thinking about what it must be like to live in the city, just a few hours by car but a world away form the grass and trees of the countryside. The New Fairfield mother of two even raised the subject with her husband, Bernard. ''I was telling him how I felt about the people living in New York. Some people don't have cars and don't know that just a few hours away is -- nature.''

title: The Best
description: Your magazine was a pleasure to read, but inevitably readers will have a bone or two to pick with your authors. How, for instance, can Helen Vendler call ''Hamlet'' the greatest poem in a millennium that also includes ''The Divine Comedy''? It is in the lines of Dante's epic that the lyric voice of the Western ''I'' -- vulnerable, lost, self-righteous, regretful, hungry for love and glory and given sight by love -- was perfected.

title: 401(k)'s: More Stocks, More Options, More Assets
description: People in 401(k) and similar savings plans have been contributing more to stocks and less to safer investments, according to a new study by Spectrem Group of San Francisco.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: Two Guys From Verona: A Novel of Suburbia

title: The Nation: Granting Clemency; Being in the Wrong Place at the Right Time
description: IT is a bad time to be on death row.

title: A Real-Life Drama Still Lacks an Ending
description: It's altogether possible that immediately after ''The Hunt for the Unicorn Killer'' concludes tomorrow night, the news at 11 will supply an ending, or at least an important update.

title: Small Lot Is Termed Big Nuisance
description: A small parking lot on 10th Avenue at West 36th Street is causing some big headaches, according to nearby residents, the local community board and even the owner of the property.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WEXLER, MELISSA ANN
description: WEXLER-Melissa Ann. 5/9/58-9/ 12/81. Another birthday, another Mother's Day without you. Love, Mommy, Arline Joachim, Eddie, Sheri and Larry

title: Army Reverses Itself on Mercury Cleanup at the Shoreline
description: After asserting for more than a year that mercury found along the shoreline of Fort Totten posed no risk to the public, the Army Corps of Engineers, in a reversal, has decided to clean up the toxic metal.

title: 3 Ways a Frail Global Rally Could Come Again to Tears
description: WHEW. Glad that crisis is over.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILEO, MICHAEL E.
description: SILEO-Michael E. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Michael E. Sileo, associated with The Times from 1970 until retiring in 1979.

title: A True Embarrassment of Riches
description: UNTIL recently, my archetypal example of the credulous and crestfallen was an American flying saucer cult of the 1950's whose members persuaded themselves that (a) the world was going to end and (b) they would be raptured by aliens before the final buzzer.

title: SUMMER FESTIVALS; Ascending to a Musical Utopia in the Rockies
description: THE quintessential photograph from the early history of the Aspen Music Festival and School dates from 1949, the festival's first year. Arthur Rubinstein, the ever cosmopolitan pianist, is riding up Aspen Mountain on a primitive chairlift, looking rather bemused to find himself in the uncharted wilds of the Colorado Rockies. Aspen was then a virtually forgotten ghost town, reachable only by precipitous dirt roads and populated by a few hardy souls and diehard miners.

title: Origins of a Brazilian Original
description: GILBERTO GIL, like Caetano Veloso, Gal Costa and Carlinhos Brown, comes from the Brazilian state of Bahia. If the Brazilian-music fetishism of the moment centers too heavily on that northern region (and especially on the late-60's Tropicalia movement), it doesn't change the fact that ''Ensaio Geral,'' a 12-CD set of early work by Mr. Gil, from 1967 to 1977, is an extraordinary document -- a tracking of a distinctly Bahian but also fairly universal pop artist's growth and achievement. Taken as a whole, the set is one of the best arguments there is for the notion of world music.

title: Low-Key Thrills at Legoland
description: THERE'S something fascinating about other people's obsessions. Take Legoland, the newly opened theme park in the golfing mecca of Carlsbad, Calif., about 30 miles north of San Diego. The park is a sea of primary colors that covers 128 acres and includes the usual range of attractions and rides. But, at least judging by the interests of my two children, Marina, 7, and Sammy, 5, it was the odd, obsessive character of Miniland that most captured their attention.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WAHLERS, SHEILA W.
description: WAHLERS-Sheila W. On May 6, 1999. Manager of Benefits and Communications at Butterick Company, Inc. Loving mother of Elisabeth W. Connors & Frederick W. Wahlers IV. Dear sister of Sandra Quine, Sharon Leary, Michael Whalen & the late Kevin Whalen. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St, Sunday, May 9, 5-8PM. Interment private. Memorial Mass at St. Vincent Ferrer Church, Lexington Ave. at 66th St., Monday, 2PM.

title: Commercial Property; In New Orleans, Developers Rush to Add Hotels
description: THE enduring allure of the French Quarter coupled with the city's role as host to such spirited street parties as Mardi Gras and the annual New Orleans Jazz and Heritage Festival have secured its place as a top vacation spot. But increasingly travelers are in town on business -- at least for part of their stay.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLAKE, ARNOLD, M.D.
description: BLAKE-Arnold, M.D. Of Longmeadow, MA., on May 3, 1999. Brother of the late Dr. Melvin Blake of New York City. Beloved husband, father and grandfather. Prominent and compassionate pediatrician. His passing leaves a void in our hearts that will never be filled.

title: May 2-8; One Less TV Home to Improve
description: Here are a few of the things the mirror of television has shown Americans about the American family: Dad is the master and always wears a comforting cardigan (''Father Knows Best''); Dad is full of right-wing bluster and hates his son-in-law (''All in the Family''); Dad is a clueless shoe salesman with an oversexed wife and daughter and he bickers constantly (''Married . . . With Children'').

title: Fair Treatment for Legal Immigrants
description: When Congress makes a mistake that inflicts undue hurt on individuals and their families, it has a duty to correct the injustice.

title: An Abundance of Performing Arts Nationwide
description: The following list of performers and concert dates is selective. Performances are subject to change.

title: Mad, Bad and Dangerous to Know
description: BYRON

title: Concord Days
description: To the Editor: Perri Klass's ''Where 'Little Women' Grew Up'' (April 25) wonderfully evoked the spirit of both Concord and the Alcotts. Its references to Beth's piano and to attempts to ''create meaning through philosophy, through art, through drama, through literature'' reminded me strongly of another Concord enthusiast, Charles Ives, who in his ''Concord Sonata'' tried to create meaning through music.

title: Children of the Holocaust Follow Hearts to Kosovo
description: Mark Sarna was watching television in his comfortable house in Englewood last month when images of refugees fleeing war-torn Kosovo flashed on the screen.

title: The Curse of the Whitney
description: The curse is partly the building itself. I cannot think of an architecture more overtly hostile to the museumgoer. Those two massive overhangs are disturbing. The array of harsh ceiling reflectors in the lobby area recall some sinister examination lights. This is a public building that loathes the public.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HAIMES, MADELAINE
description: HAIMES-Madelaine. Our first Mother's Day without you, Mady. We miss the sweet, kind, lovable lady you were. Ted and Barbara are here with me to commemorate your first year away on Tuesday. We love you today and always. Alex

title: Fitting a Cellblock Within a Circle in a Square
description: ''WE want to put the audience in prison.'' That was the director Trevor Nunn's first comment when he enlisted the scenic artist Richard Hoover to design the set for the world premiere of Tennessee Williams's ''Not About Nightingales'' at the Royal National Theater in London.

title: Compassion on Death Row?
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: In Brooklyn, a Warm Refuge for Kosovo Kin
description: After six terrifying weeks fleeing war at home in Kosovo, Sytkije Deva and her family had finally arrived at Kennedy International Airport late Saturday night to great fanfare: they were showered with flowers and stuffed toys, surrounded by a gaggle of news reporters, and fussed over by politicians making speeches in a language they did not understand.

title: Tightrope for China
description: By depicting the United States and NATO as evil aggressors in Yugoslavia, China's leaders may have unleashed forces that will come back to haunt them. News analysis, page A8.

title: Sports of The Times; Yankees Missed the Chance For Another Positive Deed
description: Here from the inside, where Joe Torre recovers gallantly and another game comes daily, it seems perfectly natural for Don Zimmer to be limping along as an interim, martyred manager. He promised Torre he would be a good soldier, a G.I. Joe.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: A partial list for this week.

title: Teleglobe Expansion Plan
description: Teleglobe Inc., Canada's largest international long-distance phone company, plans to spend $5 billion (United States) over the next five years to increase the capacity and reach of its network.

title: The Senate Confronts Gun Control
