description: This week, the Senate will address an issue that has been part of living-room conversations all across America for the last two weeks. The issue is gun control, specifically a set of common-sense measures to keep guns away from children and criminals. The Democratic sponsors of the package -- basically a scaled-down version of President Clinton's proposal two weeks ago -- hope that their colleagues will treat the issue with the same gravity that Americans have ever since the Columbine High School massacre.

title: Art Dealers Combat Rumors of Nazi Links
description: Embarrassed by persistent rumors that it collaborated with the Nazi occupiers of wartime France, the Wildenstein family, the powerful French-Jewish dynasty of international art dealers, has brought a lawsuit seeking $1 million in damages against an American writer who repeated some of these allegations in a recent book.

title: Bookstore Extinction
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, HELENA
description: MILLER-Helena. Of Scarsdale, NY. On May 8, 1999. Wife of Henry G. Miller. Mother of Jennifer Rand, Henry C., Matthew, and Margaret Miller. Sister of the late Charles McCarty and Mary Schoos. Grandmother of Michelle, Stephen, Sam, Emma, and Healy. Friends may call at the Bennett Funeral Home, 824 Scarsdale Ave, Scarsdale, NY, on Tuesday, 2-4 and 7-9. Mass of Christian Burial, Immaculate Heart of Mary Church, Wednesday, 11 AM.

title: Armed Men Rob Theater After Tying Up Workers
description: Two armed men robbed a movie theater on the Upper West Side last night after tying up the manager and three other employees, the police said.

title: Beyond Blond and Gorgeous: L.A.'s TV Image Is Changing; New Approaches Try to Capture the City's Complexities
description: Everyone in Los Angeles is blond, beautiful and, duh, has an I.Q. capable of absorbing only one Leonardo. DiCaprio, not da Vinci. The town stops dead in its tracks every week for a late afternoon freeway chase that is more entertaining than anything else on television. Everyone over 30 gets facial surgery, and that includes the women. And you can't find a good bagel either.

title: Telephone Classes Link the Homebound
description: Sadye Woghin, 85, lives alone in a four-room apartment in the Riverdale section of the Bronx. Most of her friends have died and sometimes, she says, she wishes she had, too.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WAHLERS, SHEILA
description: WAHLERS-Sheila. The Board of Directors of the Knickerbocker Greys deeply mourn the loss of our past president and board member of over twenty years. Our condolences to her family.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITNEY, PHYLLIS (STEVENSON)
description: WHITNEY-Phyllis (Stevenson). Of Beverly Farms, MA, on May 7. Wife of the late George Whitney, Jr. Beloved mother of Joan Hollister of Denver, CO, Barbara Rogers of Oyster Bay, NY, and George Whitney of Brookline, MA. Also survived by nine grandchildren and seven great-grandchildren. A funeral service will be held Tuesday, May 11th in St. John's Episcopal Church, 705 Hale St, Beverly, MA, at 11 AM. Burial will be private.

title: Spending Plan Sacrifices School Improvements, Official Says
description: A school construction plan being pushed through by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani will sacrifice efforts to modernize science laboratories, update technology and improve athletic programs, the school official charged with developing the plan said yesterday.

title: Sprewell Alters The Equation
description: Latrell Sprewell was standing for the cameras after practice, decked with yellow-tinted, black-rimmed sunglasses to accessorize his hip braids and complete a look fit for the South Beach scene.

title: Pope's Visit Adds to Hope Of a Future With the West
description: As Pope John Paul II prayed at an open-air Orthodox Sunday Mass at the side of Patriarch Teoctist, Cristian Andrei, 40, examined the historic moment from Mammon's perspective.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINDLING, LEON DAVID
description: WEINDLING-Leon David. Of Manhattan. On May 8, at 78 years of age. Beloved husband of Sonia Weindling. Devoted father of Suzanne Burakoff and Steven Weindling and father-in-law of Dr. Steven Burakoff. Adored grandfather of Alexis Weindling Burakoff and brother of Irene Probstein and Irwin Weindling. He was the President of London Star, Ltd. A compassionate and generous man who enhanced the lives of his family, friends and colleagues, he served as an officer in both the Belgian and US armies during WW II. A beneficent supporter of many charities and a devoted friend to Israel. He will be missed by everyone he touched. Services will be held Monday, 1:15 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th and Amsterdam.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HILL, DR. FREDERICK A.
description: HILL-Dr. Frederick A. Of Ridge, LI. Formerly of Manhasset. On May 7, 1999. Age 86. Retired surgeon, Manhasset, NY. Beloved wife of Anne. Loving father of Frederick E. and John P. Hill, Anne Marie Fitzgibbon, Mary Berde, and Kathleen Olson. Dear grandfather of seven. Reposing 24, 7-9 PM, Monday, AlexanderTuthill Funeral Home, 6447 Rt. 25A, Wading River, NY. American Legion Service, 3 PM. Funeral Mass, 11 AM, Tuesday, Saint Mark's R.C. Church, Shoreham. Interment Calverton National Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations requested to the National Shrine of Immaculate Conception, 4th St., Michigan Ave, N.E., Washington, DC 20017.

title: Bus Crash on Casino Trip Kills 23 in New Orleans
description: A charter bus carrying at least 46 people from a New Orleans suburb to a Mississippi casino resort, many of them older women on a Mother's Day trip, veered across a busy interstate highway and into an embankment yesterday, killing 23 people and injuring 20.

title: Reports Show Scientist Gave U.S. Radar Secrets to Chinese
description: A scientist working on a classified Pentagon project in 1997 provided China with secrets about advanced radar technology being developed to track submarines, according to court records and government documents.

title: Dennis Riley, 55, a Composer Of Chamber and Vocal Works
description: Dennis Riley, a prolific composer with an extensive catalog of works published by C. F. Peters, died on Thursday at New York Presbyterian Hospital. He was 55.

title: Sports of The Times; For Ledee, Another Low Moment in a Career Full of High Promise
description: ON the way out to batting practice yesterday morning, Ricky Ledee, two bats under his arm and and a glove in his hand, stopped at the Yankees' clubhouse door to look at the lineup card that had been posted shortly before. The lineup, for the game that afternoon against Seattle, began: Curtis 7, Jeter 6, O'Neill 9, meaning, using scorekeeping shorthand, Chad Curtis leading off and playing left field -- Ledee's position -- followed by Derek Jeter, shortstop, and Paul O'Neill, right field.

title: Sports of The Times; Despite Van Gundy, Or Because of Him?
description: REPORTERS swarmed around Patrick Ewing yesterday as the Knicks ended their practice at Miami Arena. Did he think the Heat had an answer for the new look the Knicks had shown on Saturday, with its emphasis on speed and quickness? Ewing didn't have much to add to what everyone saw in the 20-point rout that gave the Knicks a 1-0 lead in their first-round playoff series.

title: Nation of Savers, or Just Spenders?
description: To the Editor:

title: Editorial Observer; Why Some Get Busted -- and Some Go Free
description: Drug arrests on the 10 o'clock news tend to show inner-city blacks and Latinos being led away in handcuffs. But Federal health statistics show only slight differences in the rates of drug use for whites and people of color -- and define the typical drug addict as a white male in his 20's who lives in a suburb where drug busts almost never happen.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLSTEIN, GILBERT
description: MILLSTEIN-Gilbert. On May 8, 1999, at age 83. Beloved husband of Barbara Head Millstein. Father of Ezra, Joshua, Jonathan and Tamar. Grandfather of Isaac, Jacob, Nicholas, Toby and Nathaniel. Brother of Ezra. Interment private. Memorial service Thursday, May 13, 10:30 AM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street.

title: Media Talk; A Talking Head Becomes a Hybrid, With a CNN Deal
description: Last week, James Carney, a prolific reporter who covers Washington politics for Time magazine, signed a contract with CNN and became a multimedia machine.

title: Don't Mix Medicine And Tax Deductions
description: To the Editor:

title: Sydney Is On Schedule But a Tad Skittish
description: In the countdown to the Sydney Olympics now fewer than 500 days -- the recent focus has been more on political problems than progress in preparations.

title: INSIDE
description: Hudson Is Hot Spot for Bass

title: To Enjoy the Park, You Must Get Out of the Car; Put Gardens to Good Use
description: To the Editor:

title: Embassy Attack Followed By Defiance Toward NATO
description: Chinese demonstrators protesting the bombing of their embassy here on Friday night held up a banner in the main square of the capital today, where a crowd was gathered for the daily rock concert: ''America the loser, Yugoslavia the winner,'' it read.

title: Seizing the Opportunity for Virtuosity
description: Few 19th-century classics have as many opportunities for virtuosity as American Ballet Theater's colorful production of ''Le Corsaire.'' The most recent standout performance came from Gillian Murphy, who stepped into the role of Gulnare, the ballet's second ballerina role, on Thursday night at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAXTER, STEPHEN BARRINGTON
description: BAXTER - Stephen Barrington. Age 37, award winning photojournalist for KXTV Channel 10, died of accidental causes on April 22, in Seattle, WA, while on assignment. In 1996, Baxter won an Emmy for outstanding individual achievement in news photography and was named photographer of the year in the western region. Known for his love of flying and aerial photography of major news events, Baxter was born in Texas and grew up in New York City where his mother was Director of the Episcopal School. He attended the Trinity and Collegiate Schools, was graduated from Southern Methodist University and became a news photographer for WFAATV in Dallas before moving to KXTV in 1986. He is survived by his wife Laura, daughter Whitney, age 6, and son Brooks, age 2, father Cash and mother Dr. Betty Baxter, sister Catherine Baxter Sidamon-Eristoff and grandmother Elizabeth Gleckler. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Trust Fund for Whitney and Brooks Baxter, Sanwa Bank, 3509 El Camino Avenue, Sacramento, CA 95821.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HESS, LEON
description: HESS-Leon. The Metropolitan Opera Association mourns with profound sadness the death of Leon Hess, a Member of the Association since 1969 and an Advisory Director since 1977. We recall with deep affection his commitment to the Met, including very generous leadership participation in all aspects of our activities, especially the building of the Opera House at Lincoln Center, the Patron Program, the creation of our first endowment fund and the current effort to ensure the Metropolitan Opera's continuing artistic excellence in the new century. We particularly remember Leon's presence at Opening Nights and his special pleasure in attending the Opera from the box he endowed when our company moved to Lincoln Center. His philanthropy leaves a memorable legacy to those institutions who were fortunate to know him as a friend and will be an inspiration for generations to come. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife, Norma, and his family. James Kinnear, Chairman Bruce Crawford, President Joseph Volpe, General Manager

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANTEL, HENRY, ZVI HIRSCH BEN MENACHEM MENDEL
description: MANTEL-Henry, Zvi Hirsch Ben Menachem Mendel, 84. Del Ray Beach, FL. Devoted husband of Ruth Mantel, loving father of Michael Mantel, Marsha Wagner and their spouses Anne Mantel, Leon Wagner, and Andrea Harmon. Grandfather of Gabriel, Daniel and Samuel. Henry was born and raised in Vienna, immigrated to the United States in 1939 and earned a Purple Heart during his meritorious service in World War II. Henry was a wonderful, talented and active man who will be missed by his family and many friends. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Congregation Ansche Chesed in Manhattan or the Rabbi Discretionary Fund of the Jewish Community Center of Harrison, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HOLAHAN, WILLIAM LAWRENCE
description: HOLAHAN-William Lawrence. May 10, 1998. It's the heart afraid of breaking, that never learns to dance. It's the dream afraid of waking, that never takes a chance. And the soul afraid of dying, that never learns to live. Thanks for the memories, Bill. Love you. Margaret and all of us

title: To Enjoy the Park, You Must Get Out of the Car; Cycle to the Office
description: To the Editor:

title: Equity Offerings Scheduled for Week
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: Compressed Data; Accusations Fly On Year 2000 Spending
description: House Republican leaders accused the Clinton Administration last week of mismanagement of emergency funds appropriated to help Government agencies meet the Year 2000 challenge.

title: Inspiration? Head Down the Back Road, and Stop for the Yard Sales
description: The Irish singer Christy Moore clips out ''Don't Forget Your Shovel,'' a song I like not only for its tripping rhythm and sly social commentary but for its advice to the diggers of the world, a group to which I belong.

title: Young Passion in a 'Romeo' to Remember
description: Ballet audiences tend to remember clearly every detail of their first encounter with Kenneth MacMillan's ''Romeo and Juliet.'' His version, presented by American Ballet Theater on Friday night and Saturday afternoon, is harrowingly dramatic.

title: Restraint for a Tragic Prince, Daring for a Swan Queen
description: It is even harder than usual to keep track of New York City Ballet casting these days. Carefully worked-out schedules for role debuts in Peter Martins's new production of ''Swan Lake'' have been wrecked repeatedly by ''illness and injury,'' as a program insert succinctly put it on Thursday night at the New York State Theater. And so Nilas Martins's scheduled first performance as Prince Siegfried was first delayed by a day, then suddenly moved two days earlier, to Thursday. Unsurprisingly, perhaps, the results were mixed.

title: Series Is Tied, but Players' Tongues Are Not
description: During some games, goalie Dominik Hasek of the Buffalo Sabres flips and flops and stops the puck in ways that draw gasps and sighs. In other performances, such as the one today, he shows off other skills. During Buffalo's 3-1 victory over the Boston Bruins, the fans in Fleet Center could see Hasek's skating ability, first when he angrily chased the Bruins' Kyle McLaren into the corner after a post-whistle whack at his glove, later when he carefully moved to center ice to avoid their last-minute barrage of beer and soda cups.

title: Pataki Shift on Pay Turns Union Friends Into Foes
description: The Pataki administration's relations with organized labor have suddenly turned bitter over contract talks and proposed budget cuts, and three unions that were on good terms with the Governor just months ago are now running advertisements attacking him.

title: Cila Leads Americans
description: The United States men's under-17 national team, playing yesterday without its top scorer, Landon Donovan, crushed El Salvador, 6-1, in the first game of a home-and-home total-goal series, played in San Salvador.

title: Baffert Takes 2-Filly Approach to Preakness
description: The trainers and their horses seemed slower than usual in making the move, but the Triple Crown scene was relentlessly shifting last week from Louisville to Baltimore while racing skeptics wondered how in the world the 31-1 long-shot winner of the Kentucky Derby could repeat in the Preakness.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: Media Talk; Papers Find a Common Advertising Theme
description: The Newspaper Association of America may have hired Sergio Zyman, the former head marketer at Coca-Cola, to lend spark to the business, but three New York-area dailies are not waiting for pointers. The Daily News, The Wall Street Journal and The Journal News, which is published in the city's northern suburbs, have found a common theme.

title: Don't Mix Medicine And Tax Deductions
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOTCHER, HARRY A.
description: KOTCHER-Harry A. On May 8, 1999. Beloved, of wife Shirley. Loving father of Leslie and Robert Shusterman, and Dana and Lawrence Choy. Proud grandfather of Cary and Andrew Choy. Devoted son of the late Gabriel and Carrie. Brother of Adele Sanders and Ruth Steinberg. Loving uncle of several nieces and nephews. Services today, 2 PM, at Sunset Chapels, 1285 Northern Boulevard, Manhasset, NY.

title: South Africans Mock an Anti-Corruption Effort
description: When President Nelson Mandela's governing African National Congress issued a 14-page booklet on ''moral renewal'' last week, South Africa's opposition parties barely paused for breath before labeling it ''insulting insincerity.''

title: Compressed Data; Now It Can Be Told: The Story of the PC
description: Who needs fiction when you can retell the history of the personal computer? That apparently was Martyn Burke's thinking when he contracted with TNT, the Turner Broadcasting Network's movie channel, to write and direct the first full-length movie retelling this oh-so-dramatic tale.

title: Those Nice Boys, Rapists? No, That Can't Be Possible
description: They do look like young gods at first. ''Such beautiful boys,'' as one neighbor says, strong and brave on the high school football field, glowing with confidence afterward; handsome, popular, golden. But half an hour into the ABC film ''Our Guys: Outrage in Glen Ridge,'' when these teen-agers walk into a room as a group, their red-and-yellow football jackets might as well be gang colors or the uniform of an enemy army. Privilege has bred a dangerous arrogance, even if the neighbors refuse to see it.

title: Heat Views Tape to See What Went Wrong
description: Normal, for Pat Riley, would have been to hold a marathon practice today. He would have run his players until they either dropped or realized how awful it was to lose their first home playoff game by 20 points.

title: 23 Killed on Bus Trip To Mississippi Casino
description: A bus carrying at least 46 people on a Mother's Day trip from Louisiana to a Mississippi casino slammed into an embankment, killing 23 people and injuring 20.

title: To Enjoy the Park, You Must Get Out of the Car
description: To the Editor:

title: Nation of Savers, or Just Spenders?
description: To the Editor:

title: Stripers Rebound, To Anglers' Delight; Schools in Hudson Are Largest, And Cleanest, in Many Years
description: The Hudson River, which for years was a forgotten waterway between more popular fishing grounds on the Atlantic Coast and the Great Lakes, has become one of the hottest spots for striped-bass fishing in the country.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ORTEGA, AURA A.
description: ORTEGA-Aura A. On May 9, 1999. Native of Santiago, Chile; physician. Beloved wife of Rafael. Devoted mother of Ralph. Friends may call at the Andrett Funeral Home, 353 Second Avenue, (at 20th Street) NYC, Tuesday, 7-9 PM. Memorial Mass, Wednesday, 11 AM, at Holy Family Church, Lakewood, NJ. Interment Saint Mary of the Lake Cemetery, Lakewood, NJ.

title: Palestinians Vow to Block Israeli Police From Closing 3 Offices in East Jerusalem
description: Vowing to block entry by the Israeli police, scores of Palestinians gathered today at the Palestine Liberation Organization's headquarters in East Jerusalem as Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu threatened to close three offices in the building forcibly.

title: For Starters, the Mets Sorely Lack Consistency
description: Only once over their first 31 games has a Mets starter lasted more than seven innings. And today, Rick Reed did not even make it out of the second inning.

title: Williams A Pigeon On Clay No More
description: This week, she became that rare American visitor who will leave Rome wealthier than when she arrived. And now, the next challenge for Venus Williams, clay-court neophyte turned clay-court master, will be to win her first Grand Slam singles title on the same slippery surface in Paris.

title: Dirk Bogarde, 78, Masterful Portrayer of the Complex, Dies
description: Dirk Bogarde, who transformed himself from Britain's top matinee idol into a serious actor at the age of 40 and became an international star, died on Saturday at his home in London. He was 78.

title: Argentina Investigating Army and Police Roles in Scandals
description: Recent evidence implicating elements of the police and armed forces in a string of scandals is raising unsettling questions among Argentines about violence, corruption and lawlessness by men in uniform 16 years after the end of military rule.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRAUSS, JOSEPH
description: STRAUSS-Joseph. On May 7, 1999. Beloved husband of Betty Strauss. Loving father of Kathie Strauss and Susan Hurwitz. Adored grandfather of Lily and Nicholas Strauss-Matathia and Leigh and Annie Hurwitz. Father-in-law of Ira Matathia and Harlan Hurwitz. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave, at 81st Street, Tuesday, May 11, 12-2 PM, and 7-4 PM. All respects to be paid at Frank E. Campbell only. All other arrangements private. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to Temple Emanu-El, 1 E. 65th St, NYC 10021, or to the University of Pennsylvania, The Penn Fund, 601 Franklin Bldg, 3451 Walnut St, Philadelphia, PA 19104-6285. For further information please call Frank E. Campbell, 212-288-3500.

title: Blair Rallies Public Support After China Embassy Strike
description: Prime Minister Tony Blair, the most outspoken of the allied leaders in championing NATO since the start of the war over Kosovo, said today that the attack on the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade should not and would not deter the alliance from intensifying its bombing of Serbia.

title: Mitsubishi To Underwrite CBS's Costs On HDTV
description: In an effort to jump-start the nation's sluggish transition to digital television, the Mitsubishi Electric Corporation, a major maker of television sets, has agreed to underwrite CBS's costs to broadcast most of the network's prime-time schedule in high definition beginning next fall.

title: Defining the On-Line Chief; Ebay's Meg Whitman Explores Management, Web Style
description: In a Valley of unexpected millionaires, Meg Whitman is the unlikeliest of billionaires.

title: Treasury Offering 5- and 10-Year Notes
description: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week offers today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and auctions of 5-year and 10-year notes on Wednesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINSTEIN, CONSTANCE G.
description: WEINSTEIN-Constance G. Beloved wife of the late Arnold. Cherished mother of Susan Schuyler and Tom Mullen and Steven and Ellen Weinstein. Doting grandmother of Jed, Josh and Lauren. Dear sister of Lucille Porter, David Gottlieb and the late Solon Gottlieb. Her proud and independent spirit, integrity and wise counsel will be missed by her family and many friends. Contributions may be made to the Arnold A. Weinstein Fund at the Henry George School of Social Science, 121 East 30th St., New York, NY 10016. For information, contact Riverside Memorial Chapel, 212362-6600.

title: Wrong Address of Embassy in Databases
description: Satellite-guided bombs from a B-2 bomber struck the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade on Friday night because C.I.A. analysts misidentified the building, and military databases used to catch such mistakes had the wrong address for the embassy, American officials said tonight.

title: Best Way to Fix Professional Boxing? Ban It
description: To the Editor:

title: Pakistan Acts Against Critic In Crackdown On Journalists
description: A prominent Pakistani journalist who has been harshly critical of the Government has been detained by Pakistani authorities and is being held in an unknown location. His wife said today that the police dragged him from his bedroom, shoeless and without his eyeglasses, in the wee hours of Saturday morning.

title: A Hot TV Deal Maker Tries Again
description: Brad Grey, who grew up in Buffalo studying show business so closely he all but memorized every line from the classic comedy ''The Honeymooners,'' certainly knows the name Max Bialystock.

title: China Suspends Some Ties as Bombing Adds Strains to Already Tense Relations
description: The Chinese Government tonight suspended high-level military ties and a new human rights dialogue with the United States in response to the mistaken NATO bombing of its embassy in Belgrade last week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROOKS, AURELIA L.
description: BROOKS-Aurelia L. Age 79. Of NYC. Died Saturday, May 8. Burial service at Saint Peter's Church, 346 West 20th Street on Wednesday, May 12th at 12 noon. She is survived by brother, Victor Markiewicz; daughters, Susan Kanellakis and Alison Bell; and two grandchildren, Elizabeth and Duncan. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the charity of your choice will be much appreciated.

title: Lowe's Awards Broadcast Account
description: The Lowe's Companies in North Wilkesboro, N.C., the national home-improvement retailer, has awarded its broadcast advertising account, effective July 1, to McCann-Erickson New York.

title: Joining Together to Win at E-Commerce
description: Some of the nation's biggest sporting goods retailers are banding together to back a single company that will run Internet stores for all of them. It is a novel plan fraught with potential conflicts. But the retailers hope that by joining forces with some of their traditional rivals, they will be able to block any of the Internet-only sporting goods companies, now small, from growing to dominate all of them.

title: Irving Stevens, 88, an Ex-Hobo, Author and Inventor of Fly Dope
description: Irving (Fishbones) Stevens, who became a folk hero in Maine for his tales of hobo life in the 1930's and his success developing a foul-smelling insect repellent called Irving's Fly Dope, died at the home of his sister Dorothy Glazier in Pittsfield, Me., on Tuesday. He was 88 years old.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''You help them now or never.''

title: More Trouble for Cyclists in France as Paris Drug Squad Arrests 5
description: Last summer, when Philippe Gaumont and his Cofidis teammates were competing in the Tour de France, the sponsor plastered billboards across France with him smiling in team uniform, standing in a field with an adoring young woman at his side. Somehow, this was supposed to generate business for Cofidis, which supplies consumer credit by phone.

title: A Regular Bloke Who's Rocking Britain
description: Robbie Williams worked the Bowery Ballroom on Tuesday night as if it were an arena. In his native England he has outlasted his past as a member of Take That, the British version of the Backstreet Boys, to become a full-fledged pop-rock star. He writes his own songs (with his keyboardist Guy Chambers); he chooses his own image, as a triumphant regular bloke whose most urgent imperative is ''Let Me Entertain You.'' Showing off big tattooed biceps and an occasional Take That dance step, he regularly glad-handed the people pressed up to the stage.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CONTIGUGLIA, JOSEPH
description: CONTIGUGLIA-Joseph. On May 9, 1999. Beloved husband of Frances (nee Schiro). Loving father of Joseph J. and Kathy Stone. Dear father-in-law of Sylvie and James Stone. Cherished grandfather of six. Fond brother of one sister and two brothers. Reposing at the Frederick Funeral Home of Flushing, Northern Blvd at 193 St. Visiting hours Monday 7-10 PM, and Tuesday 2-5 and 7-10 PM. Funeral Mass Wednesday, 9:45 AM, St. Anastasia R.C. Church. Interment Mt. St. Mary's Cemetery.

title: Man Bun Lee, 75, Known as the 'Mayor of Chinatown,' Dies
description: Man Bun Lee, sometimes known as the ''Mayor of Chinatown'' for his many public activities, including his long service as president of the Chinatown Consolidated Benevolent Association, the Manhattan neighborhood's largest civic organization, died at New York University Downtown Hospital on May 1. He was 75 and lived in Chinatown.

title: Nation of Savers, or Just Spenders?
description: To the Editor:

title: Piniella Accuses Grimsley
description: Jason Grimsley spent the last two years in the minor leagues, trying to rebuild his career. Now he is being accused of doctoring a baseball illegally.

title: Previous U.S. Intelligence Shortcomings
description: The attack on the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade is not the only apparent failure of the United States to gather intelligence or act on it. Some other examples:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Microsoft Looks to Nortel In Early Test for Network

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVY, LILLIAN G.
description: LEVY-Lillian G., 94. Of Bethel, CT. Widow of Bertram R. Levy. Died Saturday, May 8, 1999. Born February 10, 1905. Daughter of the late Anna and the late Maurice Goodman. Graduate of the Columbia School of Journalism, she was a reporter for the Brooklyn Eagle, author of magazines, stories and books. Loving mother, grandmother, great-grandmother and sister. She will forever be remembered. Funeral services on May 10, Temple Israel, 914-478-1343.

title: Market Place; Its decision to quit the PC chip business could make a big difference to National Semiconductor.
description: SHARES in the National Semiconductor Corporation evidently got a lot more attractive last week, after the company announced it was quitting the personal computer microprocessor business. National shares gained 21 percent on Wednesday, another 12 percent on Thursday, and gave up just 6 percent on Friday to close at $18.75 on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: F.B.I. Blocked Flight 800 Report, Investigators Say
description: Because he was convinced that terrorists could have been behind the 1996 explosion of T.W.A. Flight 800 off Long Island, a senior F.B.I. official tried to suppress an early Federal report that found the cause to be mechanical failure, not sabotage, according to investigators for a Senate subcommittee.

title: Compressed Data; Turning 'Sticky Traffic' Into Advertising Dollars
description: To ask Tom Phillips, the chief executive of Deja News, to describe the makeover he has given his business is to get a primer on Internet buzzwords.

title: Biker Run Reveals Heart Beneath Leather and Chrome
description: His hands held high over his head, Michael Warren jabbed at his thumb with a knife as bright and shiny as the phalanx of motorcycles that surrounded him. Some people in the crowd winced and turned away, but when they looked back again, Mr. Warren still had not managed to tease out the drop of ritual blood.

title: City Union Protests Ouster of Workers
description: New York City's largest union of municipal workers has accused a city contractor of engaging in crude anti-labor tactics when it dismissed six computer workers who were vocal supporters of a unionization drive.

title: Microsoft Hunts Its Whale, the Digital Set-Top Box
description: Has William H. Gates become the Captain Ahab of the information age?

title: DRAWING UP PLANS TO PAY FOR PILLS FOR THE ELDERLY
description: Prescription drugs were not a major issue when Medicare was created in 1965, and thus never included as a benefit. But 34 years later, medicine has been transformed by new drugs to treat the ills of old age, from osteoporosis to heart disease, and many of the elderly are struggling to pay the bill.

title: Microsoft Agrees to Experiment With Nortel's Optical Network
description: The Microsoft Corporation, known as a company that runs on E-mail, may be right when it says that it demands more from its internal data network than perhaps any other company in the nation. To expand the capacity of that network, Microsoft has turned, at least tentatively, to the Nortel Networks Corporation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRONMAN, CAROL J., ESQ.
description: KRONMAN-Carol J., Esq. Of NYC. On May 8, 1999. Mother of Audrey Boughton and Heather Lipkind. Daughter of Robert and Helen Kronman. Sister of Dr. Barry Kronman. Service from Prout Funeral Home, 370 Bloomfield Avenue, Verona, on Monday at 1:45 PM. Shiva will be observed at 2 Sutton Place South, NYC. A separate Memorial Service will be held in New York City later in the week, time and place to be announced.

title: Hollywood Jobs Lost to Cheap (and Chilly) Climes
description: Seamstresses, steel workers and electronics assemblers have all lost jobs as manufacturing moved from the United States to countries where costs were lower. Now complaints about similar job losses are coming from workers in a quintessentially American industry: Hollywood's film and television studios.

title: Rights Groups Shift Battle to New Front: Economic Issues
description: In a sign of the ways that both Congress and the leading civil rights groups have changed over the years, some of the biggest civil rights battles now are not about affirmative action plans or school choice, but about access to bankruptcy protection and bank loans.

title: James J. Heslin, 83; Led Historical Society
description: James J. Heslin, a former director of the New-York Historical Society, died on April 30 at St. Luke's Roosevelt Hospital in Manhattan. He was 83.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOBRER, BERNARD
description: DOBRER-Bernard. Passed away on Saturday, May 8, 1999. Survived by his beloved wife Annette; devoted daughters Marilyn and Georgia and son-in-law Nathaniel; grandchildren David, Jodie, Cheryl, Lisa, Thomas; great-grandson Justin; and brother Milton. Graveside services and interment will take place at Sharon Gardens Cemetery, Valhalla, NY, on Tuesday, May 11.

title: Secret Sorrow: Fantasy and Parable
description: ELEMENTALS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, TROTTA, WENDY IRIS
description: GOLDBERG - TROTTA - Wendy Iris. On May 7, 1999. 50 years old. Beloved wife to Nicholas. Devoted sister of Rosalind and Robert Danor. A prominent female business entrepreneur, she owned American Data Mart, a securities firm handling McGraw Hill, American Express and hundreds of other firms. A lover of harness racing, she owned world champion Imperfection and many others. Graveside services today, 1 PM, at Mt. Hebron Cemetery, Flushing, NY. Her warmth and dedication to her family will be sorely missed by all who knew her.

title: Princeton Crews Have an Easy Time
description: Princeton, which has become a rowing titan in the last five years, had winning crews in four of the six races yesterday at the Eastern Sprints Regatta in Worcester, Mass.

title: Torn by War, a Town Works to Recover
description: Three months ago, Milos Savic was frantic. He had been stopped at a checkpoint by the Kosovo Liberation Army close to this northern Kosovo city and dragged out of his car at gunpoint. The fear ravaged him, he said, and he lost nearly 40 pounds.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BADER, JULIA (NEE ALBERT)
description: BADER-Julia (nee Albert). On Thursday, May 6, 1999. Of Bronx, NY. Adored daughter of the late David Albert and the late Anna (nee Kramer). Dear sister of Lucille Sand and sister-in-law of Lou Sand. Beloved wife of the late Samuel Osheroff and the late Louis Bader. Devoted mother of Raphael Osheroff, M.D. Loving grandmother of Sam, Joseph, and David. Dear aunt of Paula, Thea, Candy, and Sandi. A highly cultured, gentle and caring lady beloved by all who knew her. Funeral services will be held at the Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vauxhall Road, Union, NJ, on Monday, May 10, 1999, at 1 P.M. Interment Beth Israel Cemetery, Woodbridge, NJ.

title: Brown Disposes of His Disposable Income
description: The National Basketball Association has suffered through a long, antagonistic labor fight this season and glumly weathered the retirement of the matchless Michael Jordan. Soon, however, it could face truly bad news.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WINTER, MARVIN S.
description: WINTER-Marvin S. 78. Of Manhattan and Delray Beach, FL, on May 7, 1999. Beloved husband of Eleanor. Devoted father of Benjamin and Susan Winter, James and Susan Winter, Douglas and Bonnie Winter, and Karen (Winter) and Barry Miller. Loving grandfather of David, Alison, Jennifer, Stacy, Kira, Eric and Jonathan Winter, and Nathan, Matthew and Dana Miller. Dear brother of the late Beatrice Spitz, Ethel Schanzer and Natalie Ballen. Funeral services on Monday, May 10 at 12:30 PM at Frank E. Campbell, Madison Avenue at 81st Street. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to UJA Federation or The American Heart Association.

title: Gates Gives $50 Million to Columbia School of Public Health
description: William H. Gates, the chairman of the Microsoft Corporation, has given $50 million to Columbia University's Joseph L. Mailman School of Public Health for a program to prevent mothers in developing nations from dying during childbirth.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COOKE, HENRIETTA (NEE FELLIG)
description: COOKE-Henrietta (nee Fellig). On May 8, 1999. A smart, complicated, wonderful person who lived life to the fullest. Will always be remembered by her children, Richard and Elizabeth, and their spouses Debbie and John, as well as the many young people she helped as a placement counselor. Preceded in death by George, her husband of 26 years. Last surviving of the Fellig children: Eli, Philip, Arthur (Weegee), Rachel, Jacob and Molly. Her wit will live on. Services private.

title: As Jay Chiat auditions shops for his new company's account, his old agency doesn't have the inside track.
description: A CO-FOUNDER of one of America's best-known agencies now wants to hire an agency. And it's not likely to be the agency he once headed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STERN, RUTH S.
description: STERN-Ruth S., 85. Of Woodmere, NY. Devoted wife of Sidney for 59 years. Loving mother to Alan, Larry, and Lenny & daughters-in-law Maxine and Babs. Proud grandmother of Becky, Sam, Jessie, Jake and Max. Loyal and affectionate friend. May her memory be for a blessing.

title: Giuliani Is Interested in Chancellor's Plan to Improve Worst Schools
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that he was interested in a plan by Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew to take control of nearly 100 schools that have been cited by the State Education Department as the worst in the city system.

title: This Week
description: EVENTS

title: TECHNOLOGY: Digital Commerce; A marketer says a simple step would help companies ease consumer anxiety about on-line privacy: being upfront.
description: EVERY consumer study on the subject of on-line privacy has been unequivocal: people fear being bled by data vampires on the Internet.

title: AT&T Service On Cell Phones Is Disrupted
description: A malfunctioning call-routing computer knocked out AT&T cell phone service across a wide band of New York City and its northern suburbs yesterday, and officials were not sure last night whether the problem would be fixed by this morning.

title: The Big City; For Women, Manhattan Is Prehistoric
description: HOW will men and women get along in the 21st century? Helen Fisher, a research associate in the department of anthropology at Rutgers University, has come up with a couple of examples for what will happen in societies around the world. One is the African savanna of a million years ago. The other is today's Manhattan.

title: BASEBALL: A Left-Handed Complement; Teams Save Spot for Rare Pitchers, Turning Old Discards Into Keepers
description: It was after midnight after a game two weeks ago, and Tony Fossas was munching on a TV dinner and watching sports highlight shows in his hotel room in Columbus, Ohio, when a reporter called. Even though the scene sounded drab, Fossas spoke excitedly about pitching for the Yankees' Class AAA affiliate and spoke hopefully about resuming his major league career.

title: Why So Many People Know to Wear Sunscreen
description: Never before has such mileage been milked from 675 words. The Chicago Tribune columnist Mary Schmich's column on June 1, 1997, dispensing life advice in a mock graduation speech, has gone on to become a mass E-mail message, a novelty book, and, now, a hit pop song.

title: Washington Memo; Searching for Answers After School Violence
description: When violence strikes yet again in the schoolyard, Washington's search for villains is never far behind. Democrats tend to point to guns and their powerful lobby, the National Rifle Association. Republicans are more inclined to blame Hollywood and the glorification of natural born killers in movies, music and video games.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICHTER, KATHERINE S.
description: RICHTER-Katherine S. On May 8, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Irving. Survived by her son, Albert (Sheila) and her daughter, Bonnie (Barry). Butterflies are free to fly, so fly away. Services 9:45 AM, Tuesday, at Gutterman's Inc, 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, NY.

title: Cashing In On the Ladies Who Release The Fantasy
description: ''Which one of you ladies wants to undress with me?'' teased R. Kelly during his risque extravaganza at the Nassau Coliseum on Saturday night. The resulting roar erased any doubts that some ladies present might have other plans. Undress they did, in their minds at least. And one lucky concertgoer went further than that, during the inevitable culmination of a show that took pop erotica further than even Madonna dared.

title: Essay; Connect China's Dots
description: I called three friends in the Departments of Energy, Defense and Justice and asked them to turn on their office computers and read to me the first banner that came on their screens.

title: Stanton Comes to Yankees' Rescue as a Starter
description: Mike Stanton grinned like a pig farmer who had been asked to play golf at a private club, after he was told he would start against the Seattle Mariners yesterday. Truth be told, the Yankees' coaching staff wished it had never had to submit the invitation.

title: Patents; Claritin and six other drugs hope to get a little Congressional help on further patent protection.
description: WITH this season's bumper crop of pollen, many allergy sufferers are turning to Claritin, a powerful antihistamine that subdues the sneezing and coughing and general misery of allergies without inducing drowsiness. Indeed, Claritin is one of the most popular prescription allergy treatments on the market, with $1.9 billion in national sales for its maker, Schering-Plough, last year.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HEILBRONNER, WALTER
description: HEILBRONNER-Walter. May 10, 1924 to February 27, 1998. Dad, thinking of you with love on your birthday. Miss you. Love Judy and David

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DANIELS, NETTIE (GANS)
description: DANIELS-Nettie (Gans). Age 105. Passed away peacefully on May 7, 1999. She was the widow of the late Jack Daniels, mother of Alvin S. Lane, grandmother of Mary-Jo Lane Harris and Judith Lane Mattson, great-grandmother of Ian and Roger Mattson, sister of Myriam Gans. Service Monday, May 10, 12 noon, at Frank Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st Street.

title: Nation of Savers, or Just Spenders?
description: To the Editor:

title: Disputes and Unknowns of Electronic Rights Roil the Book Industry
description: When Peter Mayer felt the slim weight of an electronic book in the palm of his hand, he suffered instant pangs of dread.

title: Media Talk; As Awards Cascade, New Yorker Weighs In
description: It is the oldest trick in the Publicity 101 handbook: Need press? Give an award. And the magazine industry is handing out statuettes and merit badges faster than editors can say, ''You like me! You really like me!''

title: 'Parade' Leads The Drama Desk Awards, Taking Six
description: ''Parade,'' the financial flop about a 1915 Atlanta lynching, led all contenders in the 1999 Drama Desk Awards last night, taking six awards including outstanding new musical. ''Wit,'' which was awarded the Pulitzer Prize for drama last month, was named outstanding play.

title: A City With Two Masters
description: With Israel's election a week away, neither Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu nor his two rivals have seriously addressed an important and upcoming issue: the future of Jerusalem.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGER, CHESTER
description: BERGER-Chester. On May 8, 1999. Beloved husband, father and grandfather. Serivces Monday 12 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th and Amsterdam Avenue, Manhattan.

title: Moscow Journal; World War II Veterans Now Angry at an Old Ally
description: On the 54th anniversary of the Allied victory over the Nazis, Viktor Chumakov, 73, a fighter-pilot-turned-sniper in what Russians call the Great Patriotic War, recalled the morning his division of infantrymen reached the Elbe River in Germany and saw their American allies on the other side.

title: Wrong Target in Belgrade
description: American officials spent a nervous weekend apologizing to China for NATO's bombing of its embassy in Belgrade, hoping meanwhile that the incident would blow over without irreversible damage to the nascent diplomatic efforts to restore peace in Kosovo. With luck, it will. With luck, the angry criticism in Moscow and the United Nations, and the dangerous demonstrations in China, will recede. But this was a very careless mistake, not only because several Chinese were killed, but because China -- as a member of the United Nations Security Council -- is a critical component of any negotiated solution in Kosovo.

title: New Group Seeks to Build on Newark's Gains
description: More than a decade and a half after he startled many people with his support for building the New Jersey Performing Arts Center in a lusterless Newark rather than in some lustrous suburb, Thomas H. Kean is back with more ideas for the state's largest city and a vehicle to promote them.

title: Cold Candor on Shootings From Veteran of Gun Violence
description: OF course there will be another schoolhouse rampage of gunfire, Congresswoman Carolyn McCarthy felt obliged to observe, cool as the trauma nurse she once was.

title: Ellen Brush, 65, Expert on Ancient Mexico
description: Dr. Ellen Sparry Brush, an anthropologist and expert in the archeology of western coastal Guerrero state in Mexico, died May 1 at her home on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. She was 65 and also lived on Shelter Island, N.Y.

title: Belgrade Is Spared Bombing For a Night
description: NATO spared Belgrade from bombing overnight Sunday, but said military targets there had not been taken off the bombing list despite the mistaken attack on Friday against the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: U S West Planning to Offer Web-Linked Screen Phones
description: The U S West Corporation intends to announce today that it will introduce a phone developed by Alcatel of France that includes a color screen, pop-out keyboard and one-touch access to the World Wide Web.

title: A Bit of Adventuring In a Pianist's Repertory
description: Emanuel Ax is full of surprises these days. After more than two decades of a solidly mainstream career, with the Romantic repertory as his principal focus and the modern concert grand as his instrument of choice, he has lately been exploring early pianos and contemporary music of every stylistic stripe. He has proved both eloquent and energetic in these new pursuits, and at a glance, this expansion makes sense: how long, after all, can a musician draw on the same constricted repertory? Yet most do. The more typical career path is to begin as a young adventurer and draw in the boundaries with age.

title: More Anti-U.S. Protests in Beijing as Officials Study Bombing Error
description: American diplomats said they felt like hostages in their offices on Sunday as tens of thousands of furious demonstrators marched to protest NATO's bombing of the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade and pelted embassy buildings with eggs, stones, paint balloons and chunks of concrete.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: Top Secret, but Easily Stolen
description: The possibility that an American nuclear-weapons lab harbored a spy for several years is surely cause for alarm. But much of the outrage has focused on the way the alleged spy may have compromised secret data -- that is, that a lab employee was able to freely hijack millions of lines of sensitive code from a high-security computer network and place them on an insecure computer, where they resided for years and could have been E-mailed around like so much spam.

title: WEEKEND TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARLOW, TONY
description: BARLOW-Tony. On May 4. Born Milton McClintock Barlow and known to all as Tony. He was the beloved husband of Priscilla Winn Barlow, devoted father of Ethan and Benjamin, step-father of Philippa and Nicola, loving brother of John Barlow and Sally Ittmann and dear son of Georgette Barlow of Kansas City. A former lawyer and banker, he was in recent years a member of the National Episcopal Church's Social Responsibility in Investments Committee and was an Episcopal Church representative at the Interface Center on Corporate Responsibility. A memorial service will be held at 4:00pm on Monday, May 10, 1999 at The Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine, entrance at 112th Street and Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers, donations should be sent to: Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, Box E.

title: Whitman Battles Her Party on Home Turf
description: She sits atop a party that solidly controls both houses of the Legislature. She is known across the nation as a modern and moderate Republican who has been able to slash taxes and speak out in support of abortion rights.

title: Commencement; Journalist Tells Graduates To Aim High and Take Risks
description: Charlie Rose, the television journalist, told more than 1,300 new graduates of Long Island University today that ''the most powerful story that any of you have to tell is your very own story.''

title: Dr. David Fox, 78, a Physicist Blacklisted in the McCarthy Era
description: Dr. David Fox, a physicist who was blacklisted and indicted for contempt when he refused to testify fully before the House Un-American Activities Committee at the dawn of what would become known as the McCarthy era, died last Monday at New York University Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 78 and lived in Setauket, N.Y.

title: China's Leaders Stoke Anger at U.S. at Their Peril
description: Through their extended campaign to portray the United States and NATO as evil aggressors in Yugoslavia, and now their endorsement of mass demonstrations that involved the unimpeded stoning of the American Embassy here, China's leaders may have unleashed forces that will come back to haunt them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HENCHY, CLOTHILDE B. (NEE BEDISIO)
description: HENCHY-Clothilde B. (nee Bedisio). On May 7, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Joseph. Loving aunt of Kathleen Hughes and Robert Beggio. Dear grandaunt of Barrett Hughes. Reposing at the Conway Funeral Home, Northern Blvd at 83rd St, Jackson Heights, until 9 AM, Tuesday. Mass of Christian Burial St. Joan of Arc Church, 9:30 AM. Interment St. John's Cemetery, Middle Village. Visiting hours Monday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM.

title: Exports to China
description: To the Editor:

title: Leaders at Cavendish Event Include Two Celebrated Pairs
description: Two world-class partnerships were among the leaders after the first final session of the Cavendish Pairs in Las Vegas during the weekend. Steve Weinstein, who placed second a year ago, was leading with his fellow American Bobby Levin. Paul Chemla of France, the dominant player in Europe for the last two years, was fourth with his countryman Christian Mari.

title: Birds of a Feather Flock to the Web
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUSTERMAN, BERNARD
description: LUSTERMAN-Bernard. On May 10, 1999. Beloved husband of Rebecca, devoted father of Ilene Schwartz and Russell Lusterman. Cherished grandfather of Marc, Jolene, Brittany, and Courtney. Services Tuesday, 12 Noon, at ''Gutterman's Inc.'', 175 Long Beach Rd, Rockville Centre, L.I.

title: Fighting but Not Fighting: Step by Step in the Balkans
description: If you've been having trouble sorting out the arguments over American policy in the Balkans, ''Give War a Chance'' should help. Although tonight's somewhat gruesomely titled edition of ''Frontline'' oversimplifies matters by personifying policy disputes, it illuminates the contrasting mind-sets of political and military leaders on decisions that continue to perplex the nation.

title: Officers' Lawyers Interrogate Louima on False Statements
description: Abner Louima underwent a grueling day of cross-examination yesterday by defense lawyers, who hammered away at lies he had admitted to telling and conflicts in his various accounts of his alleged beating and torture by Brooklyn police officers.

title: Spitzer Sues to Block Auction of Garden Sites
description: In yet another effort to delay Thursday's auction of 112 city lots that are used as community gardens, State Attorney General Eliot L. Spitzer sued the city yesterday on the grounds that putting the lots up for sale violated state environmental laws. The lawsuit, filed in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn, charges that the Giuliani administration did not abide by a state law that requires environmental reviews before the sale of certain public properties.

title: West Point Has No Peer
description: To the Editor:

title: Whitman Narrowly Wins Fight to Put Verniero on Top Court
description: Ending one of the most contentious battles of Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's six years in office, the Republican-controlled State Senate today narrowly approved Mrs. Whitman's nominee for the state Supreme Court, Attorney General Peter G. Verniero.

title: Corrections
description: A music column in the Arts & Leisure section on Sunday about the durable scores and outdated story lines of Bellini's opera ''La Sonnambula'' and Irving Berlin's ''Annie Get Your Gun'' misstated the date for a performance of the Bellini work by the Opera Orchestra of New York. (An opera listing in the section repeated the error.) The performance is tomorrow at 8 P.M. at Carnegie Hall, not tonight.

title: Student, 16, Is Stabbed At School in Chelsea
description: A student, 16, was critically injured yesterday when he was stabbed in the back outside his high school in Chelsea, the police said.

title: Preserving Genius
description: To the Editor:

title: Investigators Describe a Stubborn F.B.I. at Hearing on Jet Explosion
description: Some Government experts who worked on the investigation of the explosion of T.W.A. Flight 800 told Senators today that the F.B.I. had ignored them, mishandled evidence and suppressed their conclusions. But the F.B.I. agent who was in charge of the inquiry denounced the Congressional proceeding as ''a kangaroo court.''

title: Keller Loses Bid to Return to U.S. Women's Team
description: Debbie Keller, the No. 2 scorer on the United States women's soccer team last year, lost an arbitration decision yesterday in which she sought reinstatement to the team.

title: Your Average Traders
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUGONNET, ERNEST HENRI
description: HUGONNET-Ernest Henri. On May 9, 1999. Survived by his wife, Barbara; his sons, Mitchell and Peter; daughter-in-law, Pamela, and grandchildren, Madeleine and Emma. A memorial service will be held at Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church (enter at 73rd Street entrance), on Saturday, at 2 PM. Private interment service at Arlington National Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, contributions to a charity of choice in his name would be appreciated.

title: APOLLO MANAGEMENT INCREASES RARE MEDIUM INVESTMENT
description: Rare Medium Group Inc., an Internet software and venture-capital company, said yesterday that Apollo Management L.P. had agreed to increase its investment to $85 million from $75 million. Apollo, a New York investment firm led by the financier Leon Black, will become Rare Medium's largest shareholder, with a 25 percent stake. Apollo will also name three of Rare Medium's seven directors. The increased investment by Apollo, one of the country's largest private investment companies, gives a boost to Rare Medium's effort to expand beyond selling software into incubating new Internet companies. Rare Medium's shares rose $1.1875 each, to $15.9375.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MINER, BERNICE (LEVINSOHN)
description: MINER-Bernice (Levinsohn). Beloved wife of the late Abraham Levinsohn, devoted mother of Susan and Stanley Steinerman, and Harvey and Danielle Levinsohn, cherished grandmother of Alan, Kenneth, and Ellen, Nicole and Michael, Julie and Joshua, Andrew and Rona, Barry, Evan, and Joshua. Adored great grandmother of Noam. Services ''Boulevard-Riverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, Long Island, Tuesday 12:30 P.M.

title: Sports of The Times; Game 1? Forget Game 1
description: IN the wake of a 10-point loss last night, the Knicks' locker room was an interesting dichotomy of perspectives regarding what the loss really meant. The scorers -- Latrell Sprewell, Allan Houston, Marcus Camby -- were talking about intensity and needing to be more aggressive. The point guard, Charlie Ward, was talking about patience and trust.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRESS, YETTA G.
description: PRESS-Yetta G.. Of Hallandale, FL., formerly of New York City, passed away on Sunday, May 9. Beloved wife of the late Martin Press. Loving and devoted mother of Roslyn, Michael and Gary, and cherished grandmother of Micah. Yetta retired in 1980 after a rewarding career as a New York City school teacher. Interment Wednesday, 11 A.M., at Mount Moriah Cemetery in Fairview, NJ. For information, 203-255-9730.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FUCHS, MIMI
description: FUCHS-Mimi. On May 9th, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Alfred. Devoted mother of Barbara and Harry & mother-in-law of Bonnie. Cherished grandmother. Services Tuesday, 11 AM at ''RiversideNassau North Chapels'', 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, N.Y. In lieu of flowers contributions to Hospice Care Network, 900 Merchant Concourse, Westbury, N.Y. 11590 would be appreciated.

title: Leiter Can't End His Slide, And He Takes Mets Along
description: Seventy-five minutes before the game's scheduled start tonight, it began to snow. Hard. It stopped almost as suddenly as it had started. Too bad for Al Leiter.

title: Oklahoma Tornado Offers Hints Of How a Killer Storm Is Born
description: Editor's Note Appended

title: By Design; Citified Gingham
description: Thanks to designers like Karl Lagerfeld for Chanel and Stella McCartney for Chloe, gingham is no longer restricted to country picnics but has taken on a sophisticated look for spring.

title: Groups Debate Safety of Canned Tuna for the Very Young
description: Based on a sampling of mercury levels in canned tuna, a coalition of environmental and health care groups has written a report urging pregnant women to avoid the fish entirely and advised mothers of preschoolers to serve up no more than one tuna salad sandwich a week.

title: Round 3 in Cancer Battle: A 5-Year Drug Regimen
description: Having completed the first two phases of treatment for an early breast cancer -- a lumpectomy and six weeks of radiation therapy -- I have now begun the third and, in a way, the most exciting phase: five years of daily treatment with the drug tamoxifen.

title: TV-Net Deals: One May Flop, The Other Flies
description: Just as one betrothal of a television network and an Internet company was on the verge of breaking off yesterday, another engagement was being announced.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS
description: MIDDLE EAST

title: New Test of 911 System Finds More Delays
description: New York City's 911 system faltered over the weekend for the fourth time this year as test calls placed by the Police Department were met by delays of up to 30 seconds before they were answered by operators, officials said yesterday.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: 2 Oil Companies Reported In Talks on Possible Merger
description: The Chevron Corporation, the nation's third-biggest oil company, and Texaco Inc., the fourth largest, have held preliminary talks about a possible deal, according to a person close to one of the companies. It is unclear whether such talks are continuing, but the person said that no agreement was imminent.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  YOUNG, MILTON ''POPPY''
description: YOUNG-Milton ''Poppy''. Thanks to you, we don't put our fingers in the nozzle of the hose. Always missed, forever loved

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THEOBALD, MARY (NEE MURPHY)
description: THEOBALD-Mary (nee Murphy). Born January 19, 1902. Graduate of Teachers College, Columbia University, 1925. Worked for the Connecticut Dept. of Education. Wife of John J. Theobald, former Superintendent of N.Y.C. Schools. Mother of John and Tom, grandmother of Peter, John, James, Michelle, Tom, Martin, and Nicole. Great grandmother of nine. Survived by brother, Frank, niece, Carmella Watkee, and nephews, Tom Fitzpatrick, James and Tom Murphy.

title: Cafeteria Workers Seek Union at Goldman, Sachs and Metropolitan Opera
description: Cafeteria workers are waging a small but spirited drive for union recognition for 200 employees of a company that provides food service at two of New York's symbols of opulence: Goldman, Sachs & Company and the Metropolitan Opera.

title: Tokyo Journal; Vying for Korean Hearts: Kim Il Sung vs. Hip-Hop
description: On the walls of the classrooms are stern portraits of North Korea's late ''Great Leader'' and his son the ''Dear Leader,'' and a huge banner on the gymnasium declares, ''Great Leader Marshal Kim Il Sung Is With Us Forever.''

title: Labor's Troops Are Ready to March
description: With thousands of people expected tomorrow for what could be the city's largest labor demonstration in decades, union leaders were at odds yesterday over whether the rally should attack Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Gov. George E. Pataki.

title: America Online Banking
description: America Online Inc. said today that it had signed multiyear contracts with five banks as part of the restart of its full-service Banking Center within its Personal Finance Channel. Terms were not disclosed. The participating banks include the Bank of America Corporation, the Bank One Corporation, Citibank, the Unionbancal Corporation's Union Bank of California and Wells Fargo.

title: Man Is Accused of Killing 2 Women in Their 80's
description: A 36-year-old man was arraigned yesterday on murder charges in the fatal beatings last November of two elderly women who lived a few blocks away from him in Atlantic City.

title: YPF Board Backs Repsol
description: Board members of YPF S.A., the Argentine oil company, voted today to advise its shareholders to accept a $13.4 billion takeover bid from Spain's Repsol S.A., paving the way for one of Latin America's biggest takeovers. Support from the board helps clear the way for Repsol to take over Argentina's largest company. It also allows the Spanish company to avoid a hostile takeover.

title: Almost Anyone Can Easily Get Pill Meant for the Truly Obese
description: Some promoters are already treating it as the next magic potion for fighting obesity. And though orlistat, a diet pill approved for sale in this country two weeks ago and marketed under the brand name Xenical, is available only by prescription, it is being made easily available. That worries many health specialists, who say the drug may produce bad reactions or other problems if misused.

title: The 'Swan Lake' With a Difference Dances Its Farewell
description: The New York City Ballet's first full-length production of ''Swan Lake'' went out in a blaze of glory with a final and perfect new cast of principals over the weekend.

title: CALPINE COMPLETES PURCHASE OF 14 POWER PLANTS
description: The Calpine Corporation has purchased 14 geothermal power plants in California from the PG&E Corporation for $212.8 million, making it the largest United States supplier of power using steam heat from deep within the earth. Calpine, based in San Jose, now owns 18 geothermal power plants that can generate 800 megawatts, enough power to light 800,000 homes. The plants draw steam from within the earth to turn turbines and generate electricity. The San Francisco-based PG&E had agreed to sell the 14 plants in Northern California to FPL Group Inc., provided that Calpine, which owns and operates the steam fields that supply the plants, did not want them. Calpine exercised its right to match FPL's winning bid.

title: A Woods-Duval Match In Prime Time Aug. 2
description: The head-to-head showdown between David Duval and Tiger Woods that has yet to materialize at a major championship will take place in a made-for-television event this summer.

title: When the Dragon Awakes . . .; . . . and Finds That It's Not 1999 Anymore
description: When Zhang Qi, the state official who coordinates China's Year 2000 computer policy, began asking Government ministries last August for monthly reports on their readiness, most simply ignored her.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Seen as Next Hot Diet Pill, Xenical Raises Concerns

title: The Firm of Bell, Bell, Belle & McDougall
description: For those fans who are waiting for Mark McGwire and Sammy Sosa to reprise their home run show, here is another race to watch while they wait. Can Jay Bell and David Bell hit more home runs combined than Albert Belle?

title: Irish Buyer Entering Finnish Building Sector
description: CRH P.L.C. of Ireland, Europe's third-biggest building materials company, agreed yesterday to buy two Finland-based construction units from Scancem A.B. of Sweden for 3.73 billion Swedish kronor ($447 million) in cash and assumed debt. The company will buy the cement maker Finnsementti and the concrete producer Lohja Rudus Oy. The sale will complete the $2.5 billion purchase of Scancem last week by the German cement maker Heidelberger Zement A.G.

title: Canadian Utility to Buy U.S. Power Plant
description: The Transalta Corporation, one of the largest investor-owned electricity companies in Canada, agreed today to buy a Washington State power plant and coal mine for $554 million from a joint venture that includes Pacificorp.

title: Q & A
description: Suntans

title: NATO TO HIT SERBS FROM 2 MORE SIDES
description: NATO air commanders plan to open two new fronts in the bombing campaign against Yugoslavia, sending strikes from Turkey and Hungary in an effort to surround Yugoslavia militarily and further isolate it politically, according to allied officials.

title: Man in the News: Peter Gerald Verniero; Victorious Foot Soldier
description: A political climb and a zeal for Republican Party activism that began when he was a teen-ager reached its zenith today when Attorney General Peter G. Verniero was confirmed by the State Senate as a justice on the New Jersey Supreme Court.

title: Strawberry Is Facing Official Charges
description: Darryl Strawberry was officially charged with possession of cocaine and with soliciting prostitution yesterday, said Pam Bondi, the Assistant State Attorney in Tampa, Fla.

title: OBSERVATORY
description: The Big Flap

title: Ranch Hunting: One Person's Sport, Another's Slaughter; Business Grows; So Does Opposition
description: Eleven years ago, having given up on venison farming, Jerry Contento found a new and lucrative use for his sprawling property in Homer, N.Y. He imported some big-game animals, fenced in nearly 300 acres and opened a ranch where, for a fee, hunters can shoot Russian boar, Rocky Mountain elk, American buffalo or any of a dozen species of exotic deer and sheep.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOLTZBERG, WALTER M.
description: HOLTZBERG-Walter M.. On May 9, 1999. Loving husband of Joan, father of Celia (Larry) and Diana. Brother of Norman and Sam, brother-in-law of Steve, grandfather of Maxwell and stepfather of Stacey and David. A dear friend to many. He lived life to the fullest, fought a courageous battle and will be sorely missed. Services Wednesday, 10 AM, at ''The Riverside'', 76th St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Maids, Bellhops and Now, a Psychologist
description: For the anxious, stressed-out traveler, the Nob Hill Lambourne, a hotel in San Francisco that caters to business travelers, offers an unusual way to decompress: the front desk will arrange for a session with the hotel's psychologist.

title: Man Held in Shooting At Brooklyn Bus
description: An armed man who chased someone down a Brooklyn street yesterday afternoon and onto a city bus fired four shots into the bus but did not hit anyone, the police said. The man, David Williams, 19, was arrested as he tried to run from the police, said Officer Leslie Cardona, a police spokeswoman.

title: Prim and Precise, for All Her Abandon
description: Dolores O'Riordan loves to rock and roll. Tearing through a Wednesday night set with her band, the Cranberries, the Irish singer wheeled around like an overexcited toddler, arms flailing in sync with Fergal Lawler's drum fills. Working the edge of her reedy voice until it threatened to go tuneless, she took pleasure in pulling back just in time, salvaging the crispness that is key to her singing style.

title: ARTS ABROAD: A Crime Wave in Chateu Country; Burglars Scramble to Meet the Demand for French Antiques
description: Henri-Francois de Breteuil was saddened, though hardly surprised, when art thieves broke into his family seat, the Chateau de Breteuil, in January last year. ''It was the fourth time in 10 years,'' the soft-spoken Marquis de Breteuil recalled. ''I was at home every time. The alarm goes off at 3:30 A.M., you rush out and you see a truck leaving the plaza.''

title: Amy Fisher Is Released After Almost 7 Years in Prison
description: Amy Fisher was released from state prison this morning, ending nearly seven years behind bars for the shooting of Mary Jo Buttafuoco.

title: Turkey Has Tight Rein on Kurd Center
description: In what must be one of the most tightly controlled towns in the world, it was perhaps understandable that a young man in the billiards parlor wanted to talk only about the weather.

title: Making Brazilian Soccer a Bigger Deal
description: Luiz Carlos Faloppa loves rooting for his soccer team. Yet he has not attended a match in person for eight years, disgusted with the concrete slab seating and the irate fans who lob urine-filled plastic cups and brawl with supporters of rival clubs.

title: Whirlpool Ordered to Pay $581 Million
description: The Whirlpool Corporation, the largest United States appliance maker, was ordered to pay $581 million by an Alabama jury that said three people who bought satellite television dishes were misled over a credit agreement with the company's former finance unit.

title: Brain's Math Machine Traced to 2 Circuits
description: The ability to do mathematics -- everything from simple arithmetic to thinking up equations that explain an expanding universe -- may stem from the interaction of two brain circuits that handle numbers differently, two scientists have found.

title: Big, Baffling Brother
description: The big news for those who fear chaos in the year 2000 is that 1984 never took place.

title: Sixth Sense for the New Yields Something Old: The Caftan
description: Just because Muriel Brandolini lives in an elegant brownstone in the East 80's and is married to an Italian banker -- ''a scion,'' Vogue called him -- is no reason to think that she has everything. Before Mrs. Brandolini became a much-in-demand decorator, she was a fashion stylist, and before that she was a Vietnamese immigrant selling sheets at Descamps in Manhattan. Plain old, run-of-the-mill cotton is to the former Muriel Phan-van-Thiet what a radish was to Scarlett O'Hara.

title: New Energy for a New York Bank
description: HSBC Holdings P.L.C.'s agreement to buy the Republic New York Corporation may mean that one of New York's slowest-moving consumer banks may get a much-needed shot in the arm.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERKELHAMMER, JOEL
description: BERKELHAMMER - Joel. The Jewish Center mourns the passing of the father of its devoted members, Lisa Ziv and Dr. Leslie Berkelhammer. May his entire family be comforted among those who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Jacob J. Schacter, Rabbi Samuel Goldman, President Elza Weinman, Sisterhood

title: SHARES OF ZONAGEN, A BIOTECHNOLOGY CONCERN, TUMBLE
description: The shares of Zonagen Inc. plunged yesterday after the company, a money-losing biotechnology concern, said it believed that United States regulators would not approve its first product, an impotence pill that would compete with Pfizer Inc.'s Viagra. Zonagen's shares fell $9.1875 each, to $10.625, in Nasdaq trading. The company and its marketing partner, the Schering-Plough Corporation, said they expected the United States Food and Drug Administration to determine that the drug, known as Vasomax, cannot be approved based on research the companies have already submitted. The companies said they expected to submit more promising research in an amended application.

title: Forgery Defendant Charged In Murder and Bribery Plot
description: A Staten Island man awaiting trial in a Federal stock forgery case was charged yesterday with plotting to kill the judge and the prosecutor assigned to his case if they refused bribes to dismiss the charges against him.

title: Metro Business; Expansion by Reckson
description: Reckson Associates Realty has agreed to buy the mortgage on a Manhattan office building that is home to the law firm Skadden Arps Slate Meagher & Flom for $277.5 million, continuing its expansion into the New York office market.

title: Swiss Gun Policy
description: To the Editor:

title: Belgrade Says Pullout In Kosovo Has Begun
description: The Yugoslav Army announced today that it had completed its operations against the insurgent Kosovo Liberation Army and had begun a partial withdrawal of military and police forces from Kosovo.

title: Rheingold tries to revive a venerable New York brand by marketing a 'manly' beer.
description: STRIVING to put the ''gold'' back in Rheingold, the top executives in charge of reviving the venerable New York beer brand are revamping their marketing efforts with an overhaul that includes a new agency.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUSTED, JOHN G.W. JR.
description: HUSTED-John G.W. Jr.. Died on May 9, 1999 in Boston, Ma. of a sudden illness at the age of 72. A resident of Nantucket, Ma. Mr. Husted moved in 1939 to Bedford, NY from England. He attended St. Paul's School, graduating in 1949, and served in the American Field Service throughout the European theater during WW II. He was a member of the Class of 1950 at Yale University and spent a business career of over 30 years at Dominick and Dominick, a NYSE Member where he served as head of the Foreign Department. Moving from Bedford to Nantucket in 1982, he became active in town and community affairs as a member of The Nantucket Association, FINCOM and The Board Of The Nantucket Cottage Hospital. Mr. Husted leaves his wife, Elizabeth, daughter Pamela, son John, sister Anne, brother William, two stepchildren and seven grandchildren. The funeral service will be held at St. Matthew's Church, Bedford, NY on Thursday, May 13 at 11:30am. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The Nantucket Cottage Hospital or the Nantucket MSPCA.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Been There And Done That

title: Children Get a Direct Line to the Doctor
description: Can you get the blood out of someone while it is still blue? Do cats and dogs get sick from second-hand smoke?

title: A Ball Strikes a Chest on the Field, and a Young Life Is Lost
description: Eric Sopracasa, a 21-year-old University of Massachusetts lacrosse player, was participating in a routine practice last Wednesday, during the last week of the Minutemen's season. During one drill, he was struck on the chest by the ball, not an uncommon occurrence for a defensive player. The ball was not going particularly fast and seemed more like a pass than a shot, said some of the people at practice that day.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRUNDMAN, RHODA
description: GRUNDMAN-Rhoda. The Yeshiva University family mourns the passing of a respected member of the Jewish community, beloved wife of the late Irwin Grundman and mother of Dr. Jayne G. Beker, Board member of our Ferkauf Graduate School of Psychology. Dr. Jayne and Harvey Beker, YU Guardians, endowed FGS' Irwin Grundman Lecture Hall in the Louis E. and Dora Rousso Community Health Center and established the Beker Family Scholarship. We extend our heartfelt condolences to children, Dr. Jayne (and Harvey) Becker, Rodney (and Carol) Grundman, and Dr. Michael (and Margaret) Grundman, and the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University David S. Gottesman, Chairman Board of Trustees

title: Plugging Your Ears Is O.K. Here
description: The Bang on a Can Festival ended on Thursday evening with a spectacular concert of percussion music by Iannis Xenakis. Or should that be by Red Fish Blue Fish, the percussion ensemble that Steven Schick has formed at the University of California at San Diego? A string quartet playing Haydn is playing Haydn, but a percussion group playing Xenakis is really playing itself. The composer's score is much less an imaginary object, to be realized well or not so well, than a means of facilitating a performance.

title: When Neutrality Is Indefensible
description: To the Editor:

title: China's No. 1 Enemy
description: NATO's accidental bombing of the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade has revealed the fallacy at the core of the Clinton Administration's China policy. While Administration officials continue to yearn for a ''strategic partnership'' with Beijing, China's leaders make no effort to conceal the fact they consider the United States an enemy -- or, more precisely, the enemy.

title: Crillon Importers Names Gigante Vaz
description: Crillon Importers Ltd. in Paramus, N.J., has chosen Gigante Vaz Partners in New York as agency of record for all its brands of wine and spirits.

title: Clinton Approves Technology Transfer to China
description: The Clinton Administration notified Congress today that it had approved the export of technology to China to permit the launching of a communications satellite aboard a Chinese rocket next month.

title: Met Life Ends A Korean Bid
description: The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company has abandoned efforts to buy the Korea Life Insurance Company, leaving AXA S.A. of France and LG Group of South Korea as the likeliest candidates to take over the company, Government officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, HELENA
description: MILLER-Helena. Of Scarsdale, NY. On May 8, 1999. Wife of Henry G. Miller. Mother of Jennifer Rand, Henry C., Matthew, and Margaret Miller.
