Sister of the late Charles McCarty and Mary Schoos. Grandmother of Michelle, Steven, Sam, Emma, and Healy. Friends may call at the Bennett Funeral Home, 824 Scarsdale Ave, Scarsdale, NY, on Tuesday, 2-4 and 7-9. Mass of Christian Burial, Immaculate Heart of Mary Church, Wednesday, 11 AM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIPTON, LOUIS
description: LIPTON-Louis. The Friends of the Bezalel Academy of Arts and Design, deeply mourn the passing of our colleague Louis Lipton, beloved husband of Lini Lipton. Louis Lipton was a longtime supporter who gave generously to Bezalel. We extend our deepest condolences to Lini and to the entire family. Romie Shapiro, Chairman of the Board Harry Bauer, President Eillene Leistner, Executive V.P.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARZ, LOTTE
description: SCHWARZ-Lotte. The American Friends of Bar-Ilan University in Israel mourn the passing of the beloved mother of our esteemed benefactor Miguel Schwarz. We extend to Miguel and all his loved ones our sincerest condolences. His philanthropies were a source of pride to her even as he continues to inspire all who know him. May all the mourners derive solace from cherished memories. Rabbi Emanuel Rackman, Chancellor, Bar-Ilan University Prof Moshe Kaveh, President, Bar-Ilan University Charles Dimston, Chairman, American Board of Trustees Melvin Stein, President American Friends Brig. Gen. (Ret) Yehuda Halevy, Executive Vice President Bar-Ilan University

title: Vouchers Help Those Most in Need
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEINDAM, AARON
description: STEINDAM-Aaron. On May 7, 1999. 79 years old. Beloved husband of the late Charlotte. Survived by two sons, Michael and Richard, daughter, Benette Pizzimenti and five grandchildren. Donations to Hadassah.

title: Lyme Disease Coalitions
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCGEE, JOSEPH G.
description: McGEE-Joseph G.. The Society of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick in the City of New York records with profound sorrow the death of Joseph G. McGee, a Life Member of the Society, and extends sincere sympathy to his family. William J. Cronin, President Robert J. Reilly, Historian

title: Court Begins Hearing Man's Harassment Claim
description: Lawyers began presenting opening arguments yesterday in a lawsuit filed by a state prison guard who says he was the victim of reverse sexual harassment, his lawyer said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WINTER, MARVIN S.
description: WINTER-Marvin S.. The Officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the loss of a good friend, Marvin S. Winter, a dedicated supporter and champion of Jewish causes who left a legacy of philanthropy embraced by his family. Marvin and his beloved wife, Eleanor, contributed generously through our New York and Palm Beach Campaigns. We extend our deepest sympathy to Eleanor; to Marvin's son, Benjamin, and daughter-in-law, Susan; his son, James & daughter-in-law, Susan; his son, Douglas and daughter-inlaw, Bonnie; his daughter Karen Miller, and son-in-law, Barry; and his ten granchildren. Judith Stern Peck, Board Chair James S. Tisch, President Stephen D. Solender, Exec V.P.

title: Being Nice, Sometimes
description: In a simpler decade, like the 1970's, the sound of Jude's voice would have typecast his songs. It's the voice of the sensitive folk-rock wimp: a dulcet high tenor that glides up to an even sweeter falsetto, the kind of voice that made sincere, simpering hits for the likes of Jonathan Edwards, Jim Croce and Al Stewart. But Jude, who performed on Thursday night at the Mercury Lounge, doesn't try to come across as an unfailingly nice guy. In his songs, he's lonely, frustrated, wounded, jealous and cynical, and when he does decide to be sympathetic, it's clearly a choice.

title: Cyclocross, Even Tougher
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAVAN, FAY C.
description: LAVAN-Fay C.. May 10, 1999 in Lenox, MA. Survived by sons Spencer and Lawrence, daughterin-law Susan and seven grandchildren and a great grandson. Memorial service will be held at a later date.

title: Envoy Says Stoning Will End, Ties Won't
description: For the last three years, Ambassador James Sasser has toiled to build relations between China and the United States, a unflagging optimist about the potential for two such different countries to be friends.

title: EMBASSY BOMBING MAY BADLY IMPEDE KOSOVO DIPLOMACY
description: NATO's bombing of the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade threatens to drag out a diplomatic solution in Kosovo and to inflict long-term damage on an already-troubled relationship between the United States and China, officials said today.

title: NTL, A CABLE TV CONCERN, WINS FRENCH CONTRACT
description: NTL Inc., a New York-based company that provides cable television and Internet services over advanced broadband fiber networks to 25 percent of the homes in Britain, moved into the Continental European broadband market yesterday after it won a competitive tender for control of France Telecom's 1G Networks. 1G Networks, which NTL will acquire for 350 million francs ($57 million), provides multichannel television services in four areas of greater Paris totaling 176,000 homes and 90,000 homes in Toulon. NTL will hold exclusive licenses to provide analog and digital television services over 1G Networks.

title: Long-Distance Runner No Longer Lonely
description: Lydia Siegel ran the Boston Marathon last month and credits some of her success to the group she meets on Tuesday evenings in Central Park. ''It's a lot easier in the freezing rain to meet up with a group,'' said Ms. Siegel, a 27-year-old research assistant at Mount Sinai Medical Center. ''When people have similar goals, it makes it much more fun, and easier to train.''

title: Partners in Rehabilitation
description: To the Editor:

title: Survival Is Part of Being a Diva
description: To most people who remember her at all, Vicki Sue Robinson is the rough-edged pop-soul voice who shouted ''Turn the Beat Around!,'' one of the catchier disco hits of 1976. That sturdy dance tune occupies a special comic niche in ''Vicki Sue Robinson . . . Behind the Beat,'' her brash, engaging autobiographical show (an expansion of her popular cabaret act) at the Kaufman.

title: Vouchers Help Those Most in Need
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Credits were omitted in Science Times last Tuesday with five pictures of birds found in an imperiled oasis in Arizona. The pictures were by R. & N. Bowers (willow flycatcher), J. Dunning (green kingfisher), Johann Schumacher (song sparrow), Brian E. Small (Wilson's warbler) and B. K. Wheeler (gray hawk) and were supplied by Vireo.

title: Boston's Gallery Gods Must Be Smiling
description: On the wall above Anson Carter's locker in the Bruins' dressing room in Fleet Center are two famous faces among a row of plaques. Over one of Carter's shoulders is Phil Esposito; over the other is Woody Dumart. Both are members of the Hockey Hall of Fame and legends of this historic franchise. How does that make a young player feel?

title: U.S. Plans Airdrops to Refugees Inside Kosovo
description: The United States is planning to begin dropping supplies to the half-million Albanians forced from their homes and hiding in the Kosovo hills with little food or medicine, the State Department announced today.

title: The Misaimed War Machine
description: One can only sympathize with Westerners in Beijing who are being harassed or pelted with paving stones by Chinese mobs. My wife and I were among those in the British Embassy there in 1967 when Red Guards were incited to burn it to the ground. Other embassies and their staffs were assaulted. The Chinese record on respect for diplomatic immunity is itself far from unblemished.

title: Idealab Buys Pointcast Inc.
description: Pointcast Inc., a company that symbolized the concept of ''push'' technology on the Internet, was acquired late yesterday by Idealab Inc.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHARIG, JACK H., DR.
description: CHARIG-Jack H., Dr.. On May 9, 1999. Prominent Doctor of Dentistry. Beloved husband and best friend to Laura. Most devoted father to Bianca, David, Jeffrey and Candace. Adoring grandfather to Samantha. Interment private. Memorial Service at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St., Wednesday, May 12th, 4:30PM. Contributions in his memory may be made to St. Jude's Children's Research Hospital.

title: Teacher of Colorado Gunmen Alerted Parents
description: School district officials said today that the English teacher of Dylan Klebold and Eric Harris warned their parents one month before their shooting attack about the violent nature of their sons' writings at Columbine High School.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOLLOTEN, EVIE
description: BOLLOTEN-Evie. Formerly of New York City and Martha's Vineyard, died on March 31 of Alzheimer's Disease. A radiant spirit; much loved.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANDERSON, CHRIS (ARTURO FORTUNATO PALMA)
description: ANDERSON-Chris (Arturo Fortunato Palma). Died May 7, 1999. Born on November 15th, 1928, to Luigi and Elvira Palma. Theatrical entrepreneur, author, producer, actor and artist. Survived by his wife, Sharon; daughter, Dr. Melody Anderson; sister, Ann Confessore, and numerous nieces and nephews, and a host of friends who loved him and dearly miss him. Visitation Tuesday, 7-9 PM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue (at 81st Street), N.Y.C. Services Wednesday, 11:30 AM, at the Funeral Home. Interment Moravian Cemetery, Staten Island, NY. For additional information, visit www.obitdetails.com.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROSENSOHN, WILLIAM LASKER
description: ROSENSOHN - William Lasker. Oct. 19, 1921-May 11, 1995. Ever generous, ever kind, always there. You're deeply missed by all of us. Sam, Marguerite, Dan, Elizabeth

title: A Cezanne Leads a $128 Million Auction of the Whitney Art Collection
description: Sotheby's made a perfect score last night when it sold all 50 works from one of the world's fabled art collections: an exceptional group of Impressionist and modern paintings, drawings and sculptures from the estate of Betsey Cushing Roosevelt Whitney. The evening totaled $128.3 million, far above its $90 million high estimate, making it the second-highest single-owner auction in history.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: GOLD FALLS. Gold prices dropped on speculation that plans by Britain to sell more than half its reserves of bullion would prompt similar sales by other nations. In New York, gold for June delivery fell $5.30 an ounce, to $278.40.

title: Reflecting On a Life Of Treating The Dying
description: Dame Cicely Saunders is considered by many to be the world's foremost expert in the care of the dying. In 1967, she opened St. Christopher's Hospice in London, the first research and teaching hospice. Her vision of a place where people could die with dignity, surrounded by family and treated by specialists in end-of-life care, spread around the world and helped spawn a new medical discipline, palliative care. Dr. Saunders, now 80, still goes to work every day and lives around the corner from the hospice that she founded. She was in New York recently to deliver a lecture at Mount Sinai Medical Center. In an interview, she spoke about her life and her philosophy of death.

title: A New Suite Translates Poetry Into Wordless, Worshipful Songs
description: Tobias Picker emerged in the late 1970's as a rigorous composer steeped in Serialism, though not strict about it. Over the years he adopted a Neo-Romantic style and embraced moody tonality, most notably in his opera ''Emmeline.''

title: Benumed By Lethargy In Albany
description: THE torrent of news articles on the Balkans mess included one that described in depressing detail a hard trek that Kosovars had made. From their homeland to Albany, it said. Alarm bells went off.

title: 'I [Love] New York' Review Is Narrowed
description: The Empire State Development Corporation said yesterday that it had narrowed a mandated review for its account, known as the ''I [Love] New York'' campaign, to five finalists. Billings were estimated at $8 million.

title: Clinton Holds Youth Violence 'Summit'
description: Sarah Brady, a crusader for gun control, found common ground with Robert A. Ricker, a lobbyist for gun makers. Steve Case, chairman of America Online, and Doug Lowenstein, a lobbyist for video-game makers, agreed to try to prevent children from buying some games on the Internet. And Eric Heydenberk, 12, of Quakertown, Pa., said he was creating a Web page to tell other kids how to handle being bullied.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE EURO GAINS. The European single currency rose against the dollar as Yugoslavia announced a partial withdrawal of military and police forces from Kosovo. In New York, the euro settled at $1.0782, up from $1.0748 on Friday.

title: A Corporate Backlash Strikes China
description: BEIJING  Despite attempts to segregate trade issues from its growing diplomatic dispute with NATO, China suffered some commercial setbacks Monday.

title: RESOUND, MAKER OF HEARING AIDS, TO BE ACQUIRED
description: The Resound Corporation, which manufactures hearing aids, agreed yesterday to be acquired by GN Great Nordic Group of Denmark for $8 a share, or $167 million. Resound, based in Redwood City, Calif., which has distribution facilities in 14 countries, had revenue of $123.4 million in 1998. It said last Friday that it was in talks to be acquired, but it did not disclose the potential buyer. GN Great Nordic, a Copenhagen-based telecommunications and electronics company, said it would combine Resound with its GN Danavox hearing-products unit.

title: When Neutrality Is Indefensible
description: To the Editor:

title: Knicks Begin to Face The Tough Questions
description: With less than four minutes left in the first quarter, Patrick Ewing walked toward the Knicks' bench and straight past Jeff Van Gundy as if his coach did not exist. He wanted to stay in the game, find his rhythm on offense, produce in some way, any way.

title: Finch DNA Shows Darwin Was Right
description: When Charles Darwin landed in the Galapagos Islands on Sept. 17, 1835, he paid little attention to the finches, which seemed much the same from one island to another. He assumed they were varieties of a single species that had reached the remote islands long before and thought no more about them until after the British ship Beagle returned to London.

title: U.S. Loses Hold on Submarine-Exposing Radar Technique
description: Secrets that China stole in 1997 about a space radar that can expose submerged submarines could aid it in finding subs from commercial satellites or airplanes, and might also help it hide its own undersea weapons, intelligence experts say.

title: Sangstat Shares Soar on News Of Abbott Distribution Deal
description: Shares in the Sangstat Medical Corporation gained 23 percent today after Abbott Laboratories Inc. agreed to distribute the company's generic versions of a drug that helps prevent organ rejection in transplant patients in the United States.

title: East Orange Chief Is Sued By Backers of Predecessor
description: A white police chief who was promoted to his job after he filed a reverse discrimination lawsuit has himself been sued by 34 officers, most of them black, who say he has retaliated against them with demotions and reassignments.

title: First Round in Bottle Battle Goes to Ralph Lauren
description: They could have avoided all of this by teaming up and calling it Eternal Romance.

title: Highwoods Properties to Sell Some Assets
description: Highwoods Properties Inc., a real estate investment trust, said today that it was selling assets in South Florida and Baltimore in three transactions for $405.4 million to focus on fewer markets.

title: Divisive Politics in Israel
description: Next week's election in Israel will help determine the course of the peace negotiations with Palestinians and Israel's Arab neighbors. No less important, however, is the election's likely impact on achieving peace among Israelis themselves. At a time when Israelis have generally embraced conciliation with old enemies, it is startling that the nation is more fragmented than ever on ethnic and sectarian lines. Could the last curse bestowed by the 20th century be for Jews to split into feuding tribal divisions, like so many other countries? To help avoid that fate, Israelis can use the campaign to reinforce the values of tolerance and inclusion.

title: Pataki Report Says Tax Cuts Helped Upstate
description: As government officials in Albany remained deadlocked over the state budget, Gov. George E. Pataki released a report yesterday asserting that tax cuts enacted by his administration have prompted an economic revival in upstate New York.

title: The Chinese Mourn Dead And Raise Questions
description: They had laid her out in her best clothes and wound a long silk chiffon scarf around her neck and draped it down the length of her body. But the fine clothes could not hide the stitches that closed an ugly gash on the forehead, nor the black bruising that the bomb blast had inflicted.

title: Stewart Klein, 66, TV Critic; Leavened Reviews With Wit
description: Stewart Klein, a music, film and theater critic for Channel 5 in New York since 1967, died on Sunday at his home in Fort Lee, N.J. He was 66.

title: Hershiser's New Contacts Give Clear View of Bullpen
description: Like the rest of his teammates, Orel Hershiser could see more clearly here today once the afternoon snow was gone. Hershiser could see better, period, after visiting an eye specialist in Phoenix this morning. But for at least a week, Hershiser's new contact lenses will only help his view from the Mets' bullpen.

title: HSBC to Pay $10.3 Billion For Republic
description: HSBC Holdings P.L.C. announced today that it would purchase the parent company of the Republic National Bank of New York for $10.3 billion cash, the biggest foreign takeover deal for an American banking company.

title: Profiling and Prevention
description: To the Editor:

title: Airlines Are Moving to Add Jets to In-State Routes
description: Air travelers between New York City and upstate New York, who pay some of the highest fares in the country to fly in small, noisy turboprops that get badly buffeted in stormy weather, are about to get some relief: junior jets.

title: Gore Adds Former Whip To Campaign
description: Vice President Al Gore, seeking to add political firepower to his campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination, has enlisted former Representative Tony Coelho of California as a top strategist, several Gore advisers said today.

title: A State Department Report Documents Kosovo Abuses
description: The United States has gathered evidence from Albanian refugees of mass executions in at least 70 towns and villages in Kosovo since large-scale deportations began in late March, according to a report described by the State Department today as the most comprehensive documentary record to date on atrocities there.

title: KOSOVO UPDATE
description: DIPLOMACY

title: Pentagon Admits Its Maps Of Belgrade Are Out of Date
description: In confusing the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade for a Yugoslav arms agency, the Central Intelligence Agency relied on educated guesses rather than on first-hand information, Government officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRAUSS, JOSEPH
description: STRAUSS-Joseph. On May 7, 1999. Beloved husband of Betty Strauss. Loving father of Kathie Strauss and Susan Hurwitz. Adored grandfather of Lily and Nicholas Strauss-Matathia and Leigh and Annie Hurwitz. Father-in-law of Ira Matathia and Harlan Hurwitz. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave, at 81st Street, Tuesday, May 11, 12-2 PM, and 4-7 PM. All respects to be paid at Frank E. Campbell only. All other arrangements private. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to Temple Emanu-El, 1 E. 65th St, NYC 10021, or to the University of Pennsylvania, The Penn Fund, 601 Franklin Bldg, 3451 Walnut St, Philadelphia, PA 19104-6285. For further information please call Frank E. Campbell, 212-288-3500.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAPECI, THEODORE J., M.D.
description: CAPECI-Theodore J., M.D. Of Scarsdale, NY on May 8, 1999. Husband of Patricia A. Lohse. Father of Susan Capeci, Ellen Fithian. Grandfather of four. Former husband of Margaret Hyatt. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, between the hours of 2:00 and 4:00 and 7:00 and 9:00 Wednesday and Thursday. Mass of Christian burial St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville, on Friday, May 14 at 10:00 AM. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Lawrence Hospital, Bronxville, New York 10708.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINSTEIN, CONSTANCE G
description: WEINSTEIN-Constance G. Beloved wife of the late Arnold. Cherished mother of Susan Schuyler and Tom Mullen and Steven and Ellen Weinstein. Doting grandmother of Jed, Josh and Lauren. Dear sister of Lucille Porter, David Gottlieb & the late Solon Gottlieb. Her proud & independent spirit, integrity and wise counsel will be missed by her family and many friends. Contributions may be made to the Arnold A. Weinstein Fund at the Henry George School of Social Science, 121 East 30th Street, New York, N.Y. 10016. Service Wednesday, 11:15AM at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Cross-Examination Studiously Avoids One Subject
description: Unrelenting and indignant, defense lawyers yesterday dug into the smallest details of Abner Louima's allegations of abuse and torture by New York City police officers.

title: History Gets Helping Hands, Small Ones
description: Mary Cassatt did not really stand in her Paris studio in 1878, pause in her work on a painting she planned to show at the Salon and tell her teen-age niece, ''There's more to life than marriage, my girl.'' But it would have been nice if she had. That indulgent fantasy is at the heart of ''Mary Cassatt: American Impressionist,'' a thoroughly charming episode in the occasional series of HBO family dramas called ''The Artists' Specials.''

title: NATO Spending Bill Includes Executive Jets for 9 Generals
description: An urgent request from the Air Force is buried in the multibillion-dollar emergency bills that will finance NATO's air war in Yugoslavia.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CAMPBELL, MARION DANIELSON
description: CAMPBELL-Marion Danielson. A memorial service will be held 11AM Saturday, May 15, at Groton School Chapel-Groton, MA.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BART, JESSIE
description: BART-Jessie. Best friend and loving wife for 64 years of Harold. Devoted mother of Clifford and Barbara and Alan and Marsha. Cherished grandmother of Andrew, Deborah and Michelle. Services Wednesday, 10 AM, at the I.J. Morris Dix Hills Chapel, 21 East Deer Park Road, Dix Hills, N.Y.

title: A Conference on Youth Violence
description: In the past it was hard not to be struck by the way time seemed to roll over a tragedy like a school shooting, by the disparity between the enduring grief of parents who lost children in places like Paducah and Jonesboro and the swift distraction of the rest of us. This time, perhaps, things may be different. The Littleton shootings have forced upon the nation a feeling that many parents know all too well -- that of inhabiting the very culture they are trying to protect their children from.

title: Mexican Tycoon Buys Stake in CDnow
description: Carlos Slim Helu, Mexico's leading industrialist, has added to his Internet holdings through the acquisition of a 5.3 percent stake in the on-line music retailer CDnow Inc.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLSTEIN, GILBERT
description: MILLSTEIN-Gilbert. On May 8, 1999, at age 83. Beloved husband of Barbara Head Millstein. Father of Ezra, Joshua, Jonathan and Tamar. Grandfather of Isaac, Jacob, Nicholas, Toby and Nathaniel. Brother of Ezra. Interment private. Memorial service Thursday, May 13, 10:30 AM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street.

title: Distribution Deal Seen In Telecommunications
description: The NEC Corporation of Japan and the General Electric Company P.L.C. of Britain are close to announcing a deal in which NEC will distribute G.E.C.'s telecommunications products, according to the London newspaper The Sunday Telegraph. The paper said the companies would also buy more than $:100 million ($163 million) of one another's products annually and cooperate on research and development.

title: Questions on Signing Of Cuban by Yanks
description: The Yankees' signing of Michel Hernandez, a catcher from Cuba, is being reviewed for possible violations by Major League Baseball, a baseball official said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GINSBERG, BELLE
description: GINSBERG-Belle. On May 9 at the age of 88. Devoted wife of the late Harry Ginsberg, treasured by sons Jack and Joseph, daughters-in-law Louise and Micki, grandsons, Andrew and Peter, and many nieces, nephews and friends. She will be sadly missed. Service today at 11:30 AM at, ''Parkside'' Memorial Chapel, 2576 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn New York. Contributions to Deborah Heart and Lung Center in Browns Mills, NJ.

title: Gansler Helps to End The Wizards' 0-10 Skid
description: MAJOR LEAGUE SOCCER

title: Evoking Today's South Africa in a Spirit of Hope
description: With its performance here tonight at the New Jersey Performing Arts Center, Dance Theater of Harlem affirmed ballet as a truly international art. The program attested to this dance form's ability to depict a multitude of locales and to absorb influences from many cultures.

title: Patterns
description: Raising the Ante

title: Cambodia Detains Ex-Commander of Khmer Rouge Torture Camp
description: The chief interrogator for the Khmer Rouge is in custody and will soon be questioned himself by military prosecutors, a Cambodian Government spokesman said today.

title: New Group Will Promote Newark Airport
description: Continental Airlines and several chambers of commerce announced a coalition yesterday to promote the economic importance of Newark International Airport. The effort is being introduced as a proposed $1 billion upgrade of Continental's Newark terminal is threatened by political turmoil at the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

title: Sports of The Times; Glowing Words Amid Dark Suits, Dresses
description: POLICE vans, with blinking lights, blocked East 87th Street from Park Avenue to Madison Avenue yesterday, but every so often a long black limousine was allowed through the barricades. On the shaded sidewalk, men in dark suits and women in dark dresses waited in a slow-moving line to enter the Park Avenue Synagogue. Some of the 1,500 mourners had arrived as much as two hours before the 11 A.M. funeral for Leon Hess.

title: Shel Silverstein, Zany Writer and Cartoonist, Dies at 67
description: Shel Silverstein, whose goofy, gross and macabre yet always enchanting poetry for children sold more than 14 million books, was found dead yesterday morning at his home in Key West, Fla. He was 67.

title: Apple Offers Thinner Types Of Portables
description: A resurgent Apple Computer introduced a new lighter Powerbook today that the company maintained would permit it to retain its performance lead over the larger Intel-based computing world.

title: The Flat Knicks Can't Match the Heat's Fire
description: Two days ago, Allan Houston had been like a jaywalker darting between parked cars without fear of oncoming traffic. He was carefree, unafraid.

title: The Quest to Tie Strings: Particles and Quartets
description: The discovery of animal bones with holes drilled at regular intervals has encouraged paleoanthropologists to believe that Neanderthals were playing music on crude flutes 43,000 years ago. True or not, musical instruments have an ancient lineage firmly based on physics and mathematics.

title: A 3d Partner For Northwest And KLM
description: Alitalia said yesterday that it intended to join Northwest Airlines and KLM Royal Dutch Airlines in a broad partnership that would combine their services over the Atlantic.

title: Microsoft Is Acquiring 4% Stake in Nextel
description: Demonstrating that its ambitions are not tethered to the wired world, the Microsoft Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to pay $600 million in cash for about 4 percent of Nextel Communications Inc., a big national provider of wireless communications.

title: National Discount to Sell Equitrade Stake
description: National Discount Brokers Group Inc. said today that it had agreed to sell its stake in Equitrade Partners L.L.C. for an expected pretax net gain of $36 million in cash.

title: Mrs. Gore's Depression
description: To the Editor:

title: Edwin Dale Jr., 75, Reporter And an Expert in Economics
description: Edwin L. Dale Jr., a former economics reporter in the Washington bureau of The New York Times who later explained the intricacies of supply-side economics as a budget spokesman in the Reagan Administration, died today at the Washington Hospice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRONMAN, CAROL J., ESQ.
description: KRONMAN-Carol J., Esq.. Of NYC, NY, on May 8, 1999. Mother of Audrey Boughton and Heather Lipkind. Daughter of Robert and Helen Kronman. Sister of Dr. Barry Kronman. A memorial service will be held on Friday, May 14, at 9:30AM in the Rockefeller Chapel of Hope and Remembrance at the Health Care Chaplaincy, 307 E. 60th St., NYC, NY (212) 644-1111.

title: Protection From Trouble
description: To the Editor:

title: Foreign Affairs; Steady as She Goes
description: Is everybody done now?

title: New Books Revive Old Talk Of Spies
description: A tantalizing clue to the atom spies of a half-century ago centers on Santa Fe, just down the road from Los Alamos, where thousands of scientists and other experts worked on the bomb, Washington's great wartime secret, sheltered by the tall pines and deep canyons of the New Mexican wilderness.

title: State to Test Changes to Ease Burden of Grand Jury Duty
description: In an attempt to make service on grand juries less burdensome, New York State court officials said yesterday that they would set up experiments in six counties around the state, including Brooklyn, to try out different ways of reducing the length of a grand jury's term.

title: Some See Dramatic Subtext in Hare's Tony Shutout
description: Some say it signals a backlash against the British. Others say there was simply a surfeit of good plays this season, and those are the breaks. Still others are just scratching their heads about why not one of David Hare's three plays -- ''Amy's View,'' ''The Blue Room'' or ''Via Dolorosa'' -- was nominated for a Tony Award.

title: Imagination Comes Up With Bizarre Doings
description: It's best to forget about ''Madison'' in the title of John Jasperse's new work, ''Madison as I Imagine It.'' Nothing onstage appears to have anything to do with any city called Madison, certainly not the attractive lakeside community that is both the Wisconsin state capital and the site of the University of Wisconsin. Indeed, watching the John Jasperse Company perform the piece on Sunday night at Dance Theater Workshop suggested that the only really significant words in the title may be ''I Imagine.''

title: Why Not Sell Organs?
description: To the Editor:

title: Drug Review Is Effective, Agency Says
description: When the Food and Drug Administration was forced to ban five prescription drugs in a recent one-year period, critics said the agency had compromised patient safety as it hurried new medicines to market. Today, the agency's new commissioner responded, making public an internal review that found the agency's emphasis on speedy drug approvals was not to blame.

title: German Central Banker Sees 2% Global Growth
description: The president of the Bundesbank, Hans Tietmeyer, left, speaking as chairman of the committee of the Group of 10 central bank governors, said yesterday that the consensus forecast for 1999 global economic growth had stabilized around 2 percent. Briefing journalists in Basel, after the monthly meeting at the Bank for International Settlements, Mr. Tietmeyer said the global financial crisis appeared to have eased.

title: Intel Sets Up Fund for Internet Research
description: The Intel Corporation said today that it had set up a $250 million fund to invest in companies developing Internet applications for the company's new microprocessor technology.

title: Swiss Gun Policy
description: To the Editor:

title: Lyme Disease Coalitions
description: To the Editor:

title: Gilbert Millstein, 83, Reviewer Who Gave Early Boost to Kerouac
description: Gilbert Millstein, who wrote an early review of Jack Kerouac's novel ''On the Road'' that helped establish the fame of both Kerouac and the Beat Generation, died on Friday at Tisch Hospital of New York University Medical Center. He was 83 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARTIMER, HERMAN
description: BARTIMER-Herman. Tifereth Israel-Town & Village Synagogue mourns the loss of its beloved member of long standing and extends heartfelt condolences to his wife and family. Rabbi Laurence A. Sebert Rabbi Abby Sosland President Carol J. Green

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KADISH, HENRIETTA
description: KADISH-Henrietta. Died in her sleep at her home in Metuchen, NJ, on Monday, May 10, 1999. Born in Brooklyn, she lived in Millburn, NJ, and New Brunswick, NJ, before moving to Metuchen 32 years ago. She was the widow of Irving J. Kadish, a land developer and builder. She was a bookkeeper, a life member of Hadassah, B'Nai Brith, the sisterhood of Temple Neve Shalom, all of Metuchen, and the Senior Club of the Jewish Community Center, Edison. She was a friend of the Albert Einstein Society, the Sloan Kettering Hospital and Channel 13, Public Television. She is survived by her three children, Gerald, of New Jersey, Marcia K. Bershtein, of Edison, NJ, and Richard, of Rockville, MD. She leaves eight grandchildren and four great-grandchildren. Services will be held on Tuesday, May 11th, at Goldstein Funeral Chapel, 2015 Woodbridge Avenue, Edison, New Jersey, at 1 P.M., followed by interment in Beth Israel Cemetery, Woodbridge, NJ.

title: Vouchers Help Those Most in Need
description: To the Editor:

title: Double Duty for a Lifesaving Move
description: In 1974, a doctor named Victor Esch was on a beach when he saw a lifeguard pull an unconscious man from the water. The guard tried to resuscitate the man, but was unsuccessful and declared him dead.

title: $2.2 Billion Dutch Deal For an Investment Bank
description: ING Groep N.V., Fortis and ASR Verzekeringsgroep N.V. accepted an offer of 72.50 guilders a share, a total of $2.2 billion, yesterday for Nationale Investeringsbank N.V., an investment bank. The offer came from ABP and PGGM, the Netherlands' biggest pension funds. ING, Europe's seventh-largest financial company, had rejected an offer of 70 guilders a share last week.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Successors to Michael Price Apply Pressure, Too
description: The spirit of Michael F. Price has risen, and it is hovering over the Thermo Electron Corporation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPECHLER, DANIEL S.
description: SPECHLER-Daniel S.., 82. Died on Saturday, May 8, 1999. Beloved husband of Betty abd devoted father of Eleanor and Laura. He is remembered with love by his sons-in-law Dr. Jeffrey Ainspan and Robert Elton, and his grandchildren Liane and Eric. He was an accomplished Chemical Engineer and holder of several patents. He will be greatly missed.

title: Op-Art
Spencer's Revolving Door Circles Back to Yankees
description: There were only about 200 people at Ned Skeldon Stadium in Toledo to watch the Columbus Clippers play the Mud Hens last Thursday, which meant that the players were assured of hearing every barb.

title: Albanian Makes His Support for NATO Clear
description: Dismissing Yugoslavia's assertion today that it would withdraw some of its forces from Kosovo as ''unverifiable,'' the moderate Albanian leader Ibrahim Rugova made his clearest statement yet that he fully supports NATO's position in the war.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Just as there is a lifelong search for the fountain of youth, there is a lifelong search for an easy way to lose weight.''

title: New Owner and Stadium for Jets?
description: Naturally, the next owner of the Jets will want a new stadium. It would be the only way to justify a price tag that will probably exceed $500 million. The late owner Leon Hess never agitated for a new stadium or squawked that he had a less-than-grand deal at Giants Stadium, where revenues are split among the Jets, the Giants and the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority.

title: Inspired Heat Plays a Pick-Each-Other-Up Game
description: To Alonzo Mourning, it was a thing of beauty tonight to watch the Miami Heat turn defensively from Game 1 lambs into Game 2 tigers.

title: On the Trail of Fire-Detecting Beetles
description: During a forest fire, most insects and animals flee in all directions, flying, running, crawling and using every possible means to avoid the deadly flames. But there are exceptions, like some jewel beetles.

description: ENGLAND, ENGLAND

description: Rising Risk for U.S. Subs

description: TAUB-David S.. Happy Birthday, Dad. In our hearts and thoughts today and always. Kiss Mom for us. Love, Family Taub

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, LEONARD
description: GOLDSTEIN-Leonard. The Riverdale Jewish Center extends profound condolences to our member Marvin Goldstein on the loss of his beloved father. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jonathan I. Rosenblatt, Rabbi Tobias B. Schapiro, President

title: Hospitals Reaching New Patients On Line
description: As the Internet grows, so does the amount of health information available on line. But the sheer volume of information available on the Web does not equal a speedy, or accurate, search.

title: GE Capital to Sell Credit Card Portfolios
description: The GE Capital Corporation, the world's biggest finance company, agreed today to sell most of its Mastercard and Visa credit card portfolio to the Metris Companies.

title: Toys 'R' Us, Fidelity Choose Agencies
description: Two big advertisers -- Toys ''R'' Us and Fidelity Investments -- made decisions yesterday involving accounts, each with billings estimated at $50 million.

title: New Plans For Spending In Jerusalem Split Israelis
description: One week before the May 17 election, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is scoring political points but dismaying budget officials with new spending plans for roads and Jewish housing in Arab-dominated East Jerusalem.

title: The Pungent Passion of a Maestro of Cheese
description: MAX McCALMAN is in his office, or what passes for an office: the dank cheese cave at Picholine, a Lincoln Center dining spot. He is sniffing, stroking, turning, tasting and otherwise tending to his beloved Cheddars, Goudas and blues.

title: China Raises Then Lowers Tone In Anti-U.S. Protests at Embassy
description: Chinese officials choreographed protests against the American Embassy here Monday, with a relentless procession of tens of thousands of angry demonstrators that lasted into the night.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HESS, LEON
description: HESS-Leon. The Board of Trustees, faculty, and staff of The Rockefeller University mourn the passing of Leon Hess, a steadfast friend for more than 20 years and a former member of the RU Council. His quiet generosity helped to shape many of New York City's academic, medical, and cultural institutions, including this one, where he established the Leon Hess Professorship for a distinguished cancer biologist and provided significant funding for young scientists. We will cherish his memory. Our deepest condolences to his wife, Norma, and to the entire Hess family. Arnold J. Levine, President Richard B. Fisher, Chairman David Rockefeller, Honorary Chairman The Rockefeller University

title: To Tell the Truth, It's Awfully Hard to Spot a Liar
description: The 10 men on the videotape look earnest enough. Each appears for two minutes, stating his opinions on an important social issue -- capital punishment, for example -- then explaining to an ''interrogator'' why he thinks as he does and how long he has held his views.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Unidentified Dead Man Found in Central Park
description: The police are trying to identify a man who was found dead in Central Park yesterday morning. There were no signs of trauma on his body, and the cause of death was unknown, they said.

title: Aides Fear Clinton's China Deal Has Become Collateral Damage
description: In the days just before NATO mistakenly bombed the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade, Administration officials were already voicing fears that they might have missed their moment to strike a political deal to get China into the World Trade Organization.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARZIN, LEON
description: BARZIN-Leon. Peter Martins, Ballet Master in Chief, Howard Solomon, Chairman of the Board, Robert I. Lipp, President of the Board of Directors and the entire New York City Ballet deeply mourn the passing of Maestro Leon Barzin, one of the 20th Century's leading conductors and musical innovators, and a seminal figure in the lore and history of New York City Ballet, in combination with Lincoln Kirstein and George Balanchine, Leon Barzin was the original musical director of Ballet Society and New York City Ballet from 1948 to 1958. During that 10year span, as we sought to find our niche, both artistically and administratively as a fledgling company in the then rarified American dancescape, Barzin created an unparalleled orchestral foundation and set a musical standard, which, proudly 50 years thenceforth, remains firmly intact. His pivotal role in our creation and the legacy he has left us will never be forgotten. We express our heartfelt sympathies to his family.

title: Metro Business; New Yorker Hotel Recognizes Union
description: After initially fighting an organizing drive, the New Yorker Hotel has granted union recognition to the hotel's 386 nonmanagerial workers and reached a tentative agreement with the union.

title: Dreaming Of Baseball On Staten I.
description: It's not too long a ride from Yankee Stadium to the neighborhood in Staten Island where the Yankees' new Class A affiliate will be playing. But the trip from the major leagues to the minors can seem like forever.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVY, GILBERT
description: LEVY-Gilbert. Of Princeton, New Jersey, and Boynton Beach, Florida. Cousin of William I. Wolff, M.D., and close friend of the entire Wolff family which individually and collectively held him with high regard and affection. He will be sorely missed by all.

title: INSIGHT ENTERPRISES TO ADD ACTION COMPUTER
description: Insight Enterprises Inc., a maker of computer hardware and software, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Action Computer Supplies Holdings P.L.C. of Brighton, England, for about $150 million in stock. The deal will create an entity with a strong presence in North America and Europe and total annual sales of about $1.6 billion. Action is a direct marketer of computer products and services. Under the agreement, expected to close in September, Insight, based in Tempe, Ariz., will exchange 0.16 share for each Action Computer share. Insight expects to issue about 5.64 million new shares, representing 18.1 percent ownership of the company.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PHILLIPS, IRENE VLASTA
description: PHILLIPS-Irene Vlasta. May 11, 1906-April 18, 1997. Always in my heart and thoughts, Mother dear. Olga

title: Bank Group to Buy Republic New York
description: HSBC Holdings, an international banking group, agreed to buy the parent of the Republic National Bank of New York for $10.3 billion in cash, the biggest foreign takeover deal for an American banking company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIEGEL, ANITA C.
description: SIEGEL-Anita C.. On May 10, 1999. Beloved wife of Solomon. Devoted mother of Bonnie Siegel and Linda Solomon, and Wendy and Howard Greenberg. Funeral services Tuesday 10 A.M. from Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapels, Queens Boulevard and 76th Road, Forest Hills.

title: Tale of Triumph on Every Aspirin Bottle
description: In 1951, pediatricians in Sydney, Australia, were puzzled by the death of a 10-month-old boy. The child had been screaming and vomiting for 30 hours, and doctors believed that he had a systemic infection or meningitis. But it was neither.

title: Fleeing Accident, Driver Kills Man, Police Say
description: A driver who sped off when police officers stopped to question him yesterday at the scene of an accident in Queens struck and killed a 69-year-old pedestrian, the police said, then slammed his car into an elevated-train pillar. The man was drunk and driving with a suspended license, they said.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: MAGELLAN AEROSPACE CORP., Toronto, agreed to buy the closely held Ellanef Manufacturing Corp., New York, a aircraft-parts maker with 1998 sales of $88.1 million. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Protest Pays Off for Armstead
description: After consecutive Pro Bowl seasons, Jessie Armstead felt underpaid. So when the Giants' team leader, usually a fixture at the Meadowlands in the off season, stayed at home in Dallas this year, his absence was a silent protest at the team's conditioning program.

title: A New Turn in Defense of Affirmative Action
description: All over the campus of the University of Michigan, the signs of a racially and ethnically eclectic student body abound.

title: Candidates Falling Into the Open Arms Of High Technology
description: Vice President Al Gore makes a point in his Seattle visits of stopping at Internet companies like Amazon.com, the on-line commerce pioneer. Other Presidential hopefuls, including Senator John McCain, Representative John R. Kasich and former Senator Bill Bradley, have recently toured Microsoft's campus here.

title: Many Hiding Inside Kosovo
description: Hundreds of thousands of uprooted Kosovo Albanians are huddled in woods and fields inside Kosovo under the protection of Kosovo Liberation Army fighters, according to a rebel leader inside the Serbian province.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEIN, STEWART
description: KLEIN-Stewart, 66. The well known film and theater critic, of Fort Lee, NJ, formerly of Hillsdale, NJ, died May 10, 1999. He is survived by his wife, the former Barbara Bartenope; their son, Matthew; three children from his first marriage, Marjorie, Joseph and Joann; and two grandchildren. Mr. Klein is also survived by his brother, Victor, sister-in-law, Judy, and a niece and nephew. The family will receive their friends Wednesday, 3 to 5 and 7 to 9 P.M., at the Frank A. Patti & Kenneth Mikatarian Funeral Home, 327 Main Street, Fort Lee, NJ, opposite the Fort Lee Library. Religious service Thursday at 10 A.M. in the Funeral Home. Entombment will follow at George Washington Memorial Park, Paramus, NJ. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Actor's Fund of America, 1501 Broadway, New York, NY 10036. For further information, call 201-944-0100.

title: A Pattern of Extinction
description: To the Editor:

title: Vouchers Help Those Most in Need
description: To the Editor:

title: Trifling With Humanitarian Aid
description: House and Senate negotiators will meet today to consider two emergency spending bills that are ostensibly designed to help people ravaged by natural disasters and by war. As currently written, however, these bills would also serve as vehicles to further the political and ideological agendas of powerful members of both houses. It is an old Congressional trick -- find an emergency bill the President wants, then load it up with special-interest riders. The White House has threatened a veto, and rightly so. The conference committee should do everything it can to avoid a confrontation by stripping the bills of provisions that have no business being there in the first place.

title: Where in the World?
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: 4 Deaths, 4 Places, One Problem: An Increase in the Use of Heroin
description: A dentist from New Jersey is found dead in his maroon Oldsmobile on an East Village street. A young drifter dies on the same street in a tenement that he shared with squatters. A pressman dies at the TriBeCa printing company where he worked. And a 35-year-old man is found dead in his room at a Y.M.C.A. in Greenpoint, Brooklyn.

description: Two Landmarks

description: To the Editor:

title: Rosemary In Spring: Power With Restraint
description: NEARLY 17 springs ago, I was given a spindly little rosemary tree. Observed at a distance, it looked like bonsai; up close, it resembled the sort of brown stick topped with green cloud that a child might draw and call a tree. But unlike the naivete of a child's artwork, my rosemary tree never became more refined or precise. It grew taller and thicker and wild.

title: 2 Internet Trading Networks in New Alliances
description: The landscape of the stock-trading business continued to shift yesterday, with both Instinet, the dominant private trading system, and its scrappy rival, Island ECN Inc., announcing potentially important alliances with other players.

title: Koreans, Long Copiers, Try a New Road to Creativity
description: She may or may not become a great artist, but Ji Hyun Eun has the makings of a great photocopier.

title: Cool Analysis Meets Angst Of Bluebeard And Mahler
description: With typically deft versatility, the Cleveland Orchestra made a sharp turn midway through its series at Carnegie Hall on Saturday evening, at the same time weathering a program change made short weeks ago. After two programs of Ravel and Debussy conducted by Pierre Boulez, already reviewed in these pages, Christoph von Dohnanyi shunted the repertory toward Central Europe, with Brahms's Third Symphony and Bartok's opera ''Bluebeard's Castle,'' adding Mahler's Ninth Symphony on Monday evening.

title: Dependent On U.S. Now, Europe Vows Defense Push
description: Alarmed by their dependence on the United States in NATO's military campaign against Serbia, European officials vowed today to develop a strong common military policy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENEDICT, WILLIAM JOHN
description: BENEDICT-William John. New York and Weston, VT, on May 10, 1999. Loving husband of Helen, devoted father of Barbara B. Price and William J. Benedict, Jr.; father-in-law of Catherine and Joseph; loving grandfather of Alexander, Nicky, Will, Louis, and Liza. Services private. Contributions in his memory may be made to New York Presbyterian Hospital or Mountain Valley Health Center, Londonderry, Vermont.

title: Loroupe Slated for New York Race
description: Tegla Loroupe of Kenya, a two-time winner of the New York City Marathon, is in the field for the minimarathon to be held in New York on May 22.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL DROPS. Crude oil prices fell after the Royal Dutch/Shell Group said it had cut output at its European refineries, reducing demand for oil. In New York, crude oil for June delivery fell 48 cents a barrel, to $18.02.

title: Mystery Bidder Pushes Up Prices at Sotheby's Impressionist Auction
description: A mystery telephone bidder known only to the audience as L036 went on a wild shopping spree at Sotheby's sale of Impressionist and modern art last night, spending nearly $25 million for three Monets, a Rodin, a Sisley and a Signac. That was all it took to push prices for some offerings way above what many experts said they were worth.

title: Pipe Bomb Explosion Costs Man 2 Fingers
description: A Pennsylvania man had two fingers blown off by a pipe bomb on Sunday night, two days before school officials shut down the local high school because of a rumor that a bomb would go off, officials said.

title: THE MONEY TRAIL: A special report.; China Sent Cash to U.S. Bank, With Suspicions Slow to Rise
description: Late in the spring of 1996, Federal bank examiners discovered that the central bank of China was moving tens of millions of dollars into the United States, depositing it in a maze of accounts controlled by a fast-rising Chinese executive at a small California bank.

title: In Africa, Science Catches Up to Oral History
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MARKETS: Testing an Emerging Market; Can Wall St.'s Old Guards Cope With the New Trading?
description: Late last month, lawyers for Island ECN, a computerized stock-trading service that opened for business less than three years ago, applied to the Securities and Exchange Commission to become America's newest stock exchange.

title: Marsteller Makes Executive Changes
description: Marsteller Advertising in New York, a unit of Young & Rubicam Inc., has made a series of executive changes, including promoting Scott Wallace to chairman from president and chief executive.

title: Proposed Foreign Debt Swap Gets Mixed Reviews in Brazil
description: Brazil is going ahead with a plan to swap debt issued abroad by dozens of the country's largest private companies for safer securities partly backed by the Government, despite widespread criticism of the idea.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of the Solemnity of the Ascension holy day, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations are suspended in New York City tomorrow. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: In San Francisco, a Revival Of Newspaper Speculation
description: The family that owns the Chronicle Publishing Company in San Francisco has called in the investment bank of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette to evaluate its assets and advise it on possible financial strategies.

title: Love Letters in the Wind; A Private Affair of the Famously Private Salinger
description: Fourteen letters by J. D. Salinger, the most private of literary figures, are about to be auctioned in the must public of arenas -- Sotheby's New York -- in a move likely to raise vexing questions about the private rights of public figures.

title: Strong Growth Is Continued By Cisco Systems in Quarter
description: Cisco Systems Inc. beat analysts' third-quarter earnings estimates by a penny, as the company continued its robust growth.

title: Crew Says Schools Are Injured by Rift
description: New York City Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew said that his relationship with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani had reached a crisis point, and he appealed to responsible New Yorkers -- ''good people, influential people'' -- to intercede for the sake of the city's schoolchildren.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOLDWEDEL, KIPP
description: SOLDWEDEL-Kipp, 86. On April 30th, at Lenox Hill Hospital. Recognized as one of the country's leading maritime artists. Yale graduate, Prix de Rome Scholarship. Beloved husband of Sally Backun Soldwedel, father of Peter. Trustee, National Art Museum of Sports; member, NY Yacht Club; member, Society of Illustrators; member, Navy League of the United States; member, COGAP; alumnus, St. George's School, Class of '33. Memorial services on Friday, May 14, 3 PM at St. Bartholomew's, Park Ave at 50th St, NYC. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to St. George's School, Newport, R.I. 02840.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRANADY, DR. ALWYN HERSHAW
description: GRANADY-Dr. Alwyn Hershaw, a 35-year resident of New Rochelle, N.Y., passed away Sunday, May 9, at New York Presbyterian Hospital. He was 74 yrs old. After serving as a sergeant in the United States Army during World War II, Dr. Granady completed his undergraduate and medical education at Howard University in Washington, D.C. He served as an attending physician at Harlem Hospital and internist in the office he once shared with his father at 2588 Seventh Avenue for 37 years before retiring in 1995. A devoted husband, father, brother and friend, Dr. Alwyn H. Granady is survived by his loving wife of forty years, Mercedes; daughters, Dr. Lynelle Cecile Granady of New York, N.Y., and Lynda Ruth Granady of Washington, D.C., his brother, James T.W. Granady, Jr. of New York, N.Y., as well as several cousins and faithful friends. Funeral services will be held on Thursday, May 13, at 11 A.M., at St. Martin's Episcopal Church, 230 Lenox Avenue, New York, New York.

title: FOOD CHAIN
description: Rice Paper Secrets

title: UTILICORP UNITED BUYS EMPIRE DISTRICT ELECTRIC
description: Utilicorp United Inc., which sells power and natural gas in eight states and four foreign countries, said yesterday that it would buy the Empire District Electric Company for $505 million in stock, plus $260 million in assumed debt and $33 million in cash. Utilicorp, based in Kansas City, Mo., will pay $29.50 for each share of Empire, an electric utility that sells power to 145,000 customers in Missouri, Kansas, Arkansas and Oklahoma. Utilicorp is expanding its customer base in Missouri. Shares of Utilicorp fell 25 cents, to $23.9375, while Empire rose $4.25, to $25.50.

title: Unrelated Spending Divides Conferees on Emergency Bills
description: With $13 billion on the table, Congressional negotiators wheeled and dealed today over emergency bills to finance battles in the Balkans, projects for the Pentagon and aid to disaster victims in Central America, struggling farmers, big corporations and favored constituents.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YUSTMAN, SOL.
description: YUSTMAN-Sol. On May 10, 1999, of Boca Raton, FL, formerly of Brooklyn, NY. beloved husband of Jean and the late Betty. Devoted father of Eileen Boltin, Natalie Marder and Beverly Shabat. Dear brother of Joseph Justman. Also survived by six loving grandchilden and two adored great grandsons. Graveside services Thursday, 11am at New Montefiore Cemetery, Pinelawn, LI.

title: When Elderly Pay Too Much for Drugs
description: To the Editor:

title: Despite a bribery scandal, General Motors is committing big money to an Olympics campaign.
description: OTHER companies may be shying away from Olympic sponsorships after the bribery scandal involving the Winter Games in Salt Lake City, but the General Motors Corporation is stepping up its advertising and marketing plans.

title: Energy Secretary Outlines Plan to Improve Nuclear Security
description: Vowing to assert his direct control over the Government's fiercely independent nuclear weapons laboratories, Energy Secretary Bill Richardson today announced a wide-ranging program to strengthen security after allegations that China has repeatedly pried nuclear secrets out of the labs.

title: A Met Gallery Will Become a Restaurant
description: Since it opened in 1980, the Charles Engelhard Court in the American Wing of the Metropolitan Museum of Art has been a peaceful place, a glassed-in oasis endowed with trees, ivy and benches (not to mention superb art).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PHILLIPS, BARBARA A. (REEVES)
description: PHILLIPS-Barbara A. (Reeves). Age 93 of Mendham, New Jersey, on Saturday, May 8, 1999. Wife of the late Dr. Ralph F. Phillips; mother of Dr. Paul E. of Manlius, NY; grandmother of Hugh Phillips & Diane Thornton of Durango, CO, Margaret Phillips of Manlius, NY, and the late Christopher. Predeceased by two sisters and two brothers in England. Funeral service will be held Friday, May 14, at 11 AM at the Hilltop Presbyterian Church, Mendham. Memorial gifts may be made to the Carol G. Simon Cancer Center, ''Morristown Memorial Hospital,'' 100 Madison Avenue, Morristown, N.J. 07960. For information contact Bailey Funeral Home, Mendham, N.J.

title: Meet The Wallflowers Of Bordeaux
description: CAN'T afford Chateau Margaux any more? Or Chateau Latour, or Chateau Any-Other-Famous-Bordeaux? Have you thought of trying your favorite chateau's second wine?

title: The Tempest in China
description: As if the war in Yugoslavia were not complicated enough, President Clinton must now deal with an infuriated China as he tries to fashion a political settlement in the Balkans. That is just one of several serious problems facing Mr. Clinton in the aftermath of last week's mistaken bombing of the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade. Another is China itself, which showed an ominously volatile side in its response to the accidental attack. In his six years as President, Mr. Clinton has not faced a more difficult set of foreign policy challenges.

title: The No-Show Summit
description: When President Clinton convened a summit meeting on youth violence at the White House on Monday, we were disappointed to see that show business was largely a no-show. None of the chief executives of the major media conglomerates, the people who have such influence on the tastes and turns of America's teen-agers, bothered to accept the President's invitation.

title: Angels Throw Challenge At Yanks
description: If Troy Percival intentionally aimed a 95-mile-an-hour fastball at Derek Jeter last night, as some of the Yankees contend, then he would be guilty of gross stupidity. Anaheim was on the verge of beating the Yankees and snapping a four-game losing streak when Percival hit Jeter with a pitch and brought the tying run to the plate, and it strains logic to think the Angels' reliever created this situation purposefully.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLSTEIN, GILBERT
description: MILLSTEIN-Gilbert. On May 8, 1999, at age 83. Beloved husband of Barbara Head Millstein. Father of Ezra, Joshua, Jonathan and Tamar. Grandfather of Isaac, Jacob, Nicholas, Toby and Nathaniel. Brother of Ezra. Interment private. Memorial service Thursday, May 13, 10:30 AM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street.

title: Natural Foods Supermarket Takes Site in Chelsea
description: Whole Foods Market, a natural foods supermarket chain with 94 stores nationwide, is coming to Manhattan. The chain, based in Austin, Tex., has leased about 40,000 square feet at Seventh Avenue and 24th Street in Chelsea, where it plans to open its first New York City store late next year or early in 2001.

title: Notebook; Bad Week for a Tour
description: Fifteen honors students in Buddhism at the University of Louisville saw a three-week trip to China canceled on Monday while they were at a Japanese airport awaiting the last leg of their flight to Beijing.

title: U.N. Aide to Meet Milosevic, Angering Some
description: The United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights is to meet President Slobodan Milosevic this week to protest Yugoslavia's human rights abuses, a meeting that caused some surprise and consternation here today.

title: Editorial Observer; Days of Protest and Remembrance at Stanford
description: Stanford University is tranquil this spring, graced by the brilliant sunshine and eucalyptus fragrance that help give the campus its distinctive California accent. Long gone are the sights and sounds of my undergraduate days three decades ago -- windows shattering in the night, tear-gas canisters exploding, the president's office in flames.

title: Instead of All for One, the Knicks Went One on One
description: Dan Majerle was bumping Allan Houston near the shoulders, grabbing him around the midsection and challenging his quicker Knicks opponent to do something about it. There are times when the placid Houston will refuse such an offer and become the tentative player that maddens Knicks fans. But this was Miami, so Houston retaliated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WINOGRAD, EMMA
description: WINOGRAD-Emma. It is with great sadness that the families of the Canavan Research Fund mourn the passing of one-year-old baby Emma who was born with Canavan disease. Our hearts and prayers are with Andrea and Robert, Emma's adoring parents and dedicated CRF board members, and Emma's big sister, Madison Birnbaum. Her spirit will live on in all of us as we continue to fight for a cure. Canavan Research Fund Jordana Sontag, President Roger Karlin, Vice President

title: Seagram-Don Julio Pact
description: The Seagram Company, owner of Universal Studios and maker of Chivas Regal Scotch whisky, said yesterday that it would invest in the spirits company Tequila Don Julio S.A. of Mexico to take advantage of demand for premium tequila. The Montreal-based Seagram will distribute the closely held company's superpremium Don Julio and standard-quality Tres Magueyes tequila brands in the United States, Mexico and other international markets. Terms were not disclosed. Seagram shares rose $1.5625, to $60.125, in the United States, and fell $1.60, to $87.10 (Canadian) in trading in Canada.

title: Will England Gain by Losing?; Invitation to Anarchy
description: To the Editor:

title: Wal-Mart Profit Up by 34% in First Quarter
description: Wal-Mart Stores Inc. said today that its first-quarter profit rose 34 percent as it lifted grocery sales and kept a lid on costs.

title: JLG, MAKER OF AERIAL WORK PLATFORMS, WILL BUY GRADALL
description: JLG Industries, the No. 1 maker of aerial work platforms, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the construction-machinery maker Gradall Industries for $200 million in cash as it moves to diversify. JLG will pay $20 a share for Gradall, a 14 percent premium to its closing price on Monday. Gradall makes equipment used to move construction materials around job sites and excavators used to build roads. JLG, which sells its telescoping boom and scissor lifts mostly to distributors and rental companies, said the acquisition fitted with its strategy of diversifying its product line. Gradall rose $2.1875, to $19.6875. JLG climbed 62.5 cents, to $17.625.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO SLIPS. The single currency fell after Britain's Foreign Secretary said NATO saw no evidence the Serbs had started withdrawing troops in Kosovo. In New York, the euro settled at $1.0715, down from $1.0782 on Monday.

title: Court Blocks Closing of 3 Palestinian Offices
description: The Israeli Supreme Court today barred the Government from closing three offices at the Palestinian political headquarters in East Jerusalem, easing a crisis that had threatened to erupt in violence less than a week before the Israeli election.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about a lawsuit in Paris brought by the Wildenstein family of international art dealers against the American writer Hector Feliciano, for publishing allegations that the family did business with Nazis during World War II, misstated the title of Mr. Feliciano's book. It is ''The Lost Museum,'' not ''The Hidden Museum.''

title: Heroin's New Addicts
description: To the Editor:

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: SHOPKO STORES TO BUY PAMIDA, A RURAL MERCHANDISER
description: Shopko Stores Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Pamida Holdings Corporation for $11.50 a share, or $110 million, in a deal intended to provide the retailer with access to rural markets. Shopko will also assume $265 million in Pamida debt. The Omaha-based Pamida operates 147 mass-merchandise retail stores in rural communities in 15 Midwestern and Rocky Mountain states. It had sales of $672 million for the year ended Jan. 31. Shopko, based in Green Bay, Wis., has 158 stores in 19 Midwestern and Rocky Mountain states in markets with populations of 20,000 to 300,000. Shares of Pamida rose $2.9375, to $11.1875, while Shopko rose $3.125, to $37.50.

title: FOOD STUFF
description: This Little Book Went to Market

title: Spin Doctors for Your Salad Greens
description: NEXT to having fresh greens, the most important thing when making a salad is that the greens are crisp yet dry. If you wash lettuce and let it dry at room temperature, it will turn limp. If you wash lettuce and pat it dry in dish towels, you will never get all the water out of the crevices in the leaves, and the extra water will ruin the vinaigrette.

title: China Students Are Caught Up By Nationalism
description: Exactly 10 years ago, with protesters in Tiananmen Square, a small grassy triangle in the center of Beijing University became a shrine to democracy, plastered with tracts about liberty and freedom. In recent years it had become a temple for the professions, filled with notices about computers and law examinations.

title: Peanut Oil French Fries?
description: To the Editor:

title: Spanish Buyer Gets Control of Chile Utility
description: Endesa S.A., the top energy company in Spain, bought control of Chile's biggest generator of electricity yesterday, clinching a two-year, $4.8 billion quest to be the dominant force in the nation's power business and broaden Endesa's reach in Latin America.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOLTZBERG, WALTER
description: HOLTZBERG-Walter. The officers and staff at Mark Boyar & Company, Inc., and Boyar Asset Management, Inc., regret the passing of Walter Holtzberg, our longtime colleague and friend for more than twenty years. Your wit, wisdom and warmth, as well as your unyielding spirit and courage during a difficult few years will always be remembered. To the entire Hocheiser, Holtzberg families, our thoughts and prayers are with you. Wally, you will live in our hearts forever. Mark Boyar & Company, Inc. Boyar Asset Management, Inc.

title: When Elderly Pay Too Much for Drugs
description: To the Editor:

title: Apocalypse Then: Vietnam Marketing War Films
description: The black-and-white images are often blurry and rough, like very old home movies.

title: 0 for 31 This Year, but He's Dazzling in the Bullpen
description: Before each Yankee game, Mike Figga trudges across the field to the bullpen with an equipment bag over his shoulder. After every game, he picks up his bag and trudges back. This is the extent of his participation.

title: TV Notes; Arnett's New Job
description: Just three weeks after his official departure from CNN, Peter Arnett has found a new home for his international reporting, though it's not on television.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAUSER, MARY KAY EDWARDS
description: KRAUSER-Mary Kay Edwards. Of Greenwich Ct. On May 11, 1999. She was the Senior Vice President, Merchandising and Design, for Sara Lee Foundations. Mary Kay was a cherished wife and a loving mother. She is survived by her husband, Robert S. Krauser, a son, Robert Edwards Krauser, and a daughter, Kathryn Edwards Krauser, and a brother, Edward P. Edwards. A mass of Christian burial will be celebrated at St Michael's Church, 469 North St, Greenwich, Ct, on Friday, May 14, 1999, at 11 AM. Visiting hours will be on Thursday from 3-5 and 7-9 at the Leo P. Gallagher & Son Funeral Home, 31 Arch St, Greenwich Ct. Memorial contributions may be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center for Ovarian Cancer Research, 1275 York Ave, NY NY 10021, or Carlow College, 3333 5th Ave, Pittsburgh, Pa 15213.

title: METRIS STOCK RISES ON PLANS TO BUY CREDIT CARD HOLDINGS
description: Shares of the Metris Companies rose 10.6 percent yesterday after it agreed to buy most of the GE Capital Corporation's Mastercard and Visa credit card portfolio and said it would split its stock 2 for 1. Shares rose $6.6875, to $70. The stock of the credit card issuer has gained 39.1 percent this year. Investors and analysts said they were optimistic Metris's acquisition of $1.3 billion in credit card loans and 563,000 accounts from GE Capital, a unit of the General Electric Company, would add to earnings this year because of its success with previous purchases. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Sunday about Maj. John Howard, a British hero of D-Day, carried an incorrect photograph in some copies. It pictured another officer of the same name. The correct photograph showed Major Howard in retirement, visiting the strategic Pegasus Bridge seized by his troops in Normandy.

title: If Artists Are Great, and the Hall Is Even Greater
description: The respected violinist Vladimir Spivakov and the accomplished pianist Kun Woo Paik began their Sunday afternoon recital, part of Lincoln Center's Great Performers series, with two refined staples of the chamber music repertory: Schubert's Sonatina in A minor and Beethoven's Sonata No. 10, the ''Archduke.''

title: JOHNSTOWN AMERICA TO SELL STAKE IN FREIGHT-CAR UNIT
description: Johnstown America Industries, the second-largest United States maker of heavy-truck seats, said yesterday that it had agreed to sell 80 percent of its freight-car business to a management-led group to focus on producing truck parts. The group will pay $100 million in cash and a $20 million cash payment based on performance. The new company will adopt the Johnstown America name and assume $14.4 million in debt and $10.8 million in retiree benefits.

title: Albany Legislators Seek to Dilute New, Tougher Graduation Exams
description: An unusual bipartisan coalition of state lawmakers, whose constituents range from inner-city residents to affluent suburbanites, is pushing to scale back new, more stringent graduation requirements for nearly all public high school students.

title: Even Greens Can Tantalize
description: MY guess is that many people eat greens because they think they should more than because they actually like them. This is a circular problem: if you expect to dislike greens and put little or no effort into their preparation, the results are inevitably dull.

title: Compaq Losing A Top Officer
description: The Compaq Computer Corporation said today that John J. Rando, the senior vice president in charge of its services business, had resigned effective July 1. He is the second top executive to quit the computer maker in less than two weeks.

title: Louima Trial Postponed By Juror's Illness
description: The trial of four police officers charged with brutalizing Abner Louima, a Haitian immigrant, was postponed yesterday because of a juror's illness. Judge Eugene H. Nickerson said that he expected the trial to resume today in Federal District Court in Brooklyn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SALESKY, LOIS (NEE GORSON)
description: SALESKY-Lois (nee Gorson). On May 11th, 1999. Wife of David of Elkins Park, Pennsylvania. Mother of Susan Rudin and the late Harry Salesky. Grandmother of William, Inda, Joseph, Eve and Andrew. Also survived by ten great grandchildren. Relatives and friends are invited to services Thursday, 11AM, Joseph Levine & Son, 7112 North Broad Street, Philadelphia. Interment King David Memorial Park. The family will return to the late residence and respectfully requests contributions in her memory be made to the Cardiac Care Division at Albert Einstein Medical Center, Philadelphia, PA., or to the charity of one's choice.

title: Bowls That Eat Silverware
description: A HUGE white basin was placed before me at Veritas in the Flatiron district. Partway through the warm oysters and fingerling potatoes it contained, I paused to take a sip of wine, first placing my fork and sauce spoon in the plate, their handles against its rimless edge.

title: MOTOROLA AGREES TO SELL A CHIP UNIT
description: Motorola Inc., the world's No. 3 semiconductor maker, said yesterday that it had agreed to sell the Phoenix-based Semiconductor Components Group to the financier David Bonderman's Texas Pacific Group for about $1.6 billion in cash, notes and stock in the new company. The bid beat out a competing $1.6 billion offer from the TFG Acquisition Group, a group of former and current Motorola executives. Motorola is streamlining its chip business after prices tumbled last year and economic crises in Asia quashed demand. Motorola rose $4, to $85.875.

title: Cell Phone Aggression
description: To the Editor:

title: DAIMLERCHRYSLER ENDS TRUCK ALLIANCE WITH NISSAN
description: DaimlerChrysler A.G., the world's fifth-largest auto maker, said yesterday that it had ended a truck development alliance with the Nissan Motor Company, Japan's No. 2 auto maker, following Renault S.A.'s acquisition of a 37 percent stake in Nissan. DaimlerChrysler and Nissan's Nissan Diesel Motor Company began working together in July to jointly develop three- to nine-ton trucks. The break was expected. The light-truck concept remains ''economically viable'' and DaimlerChrysler will produce it through its Brazilian subsidiary, Kurt Lauk, DaimlerChrysler's management board member in charge of commercial vehicles, said in an in-house employee magazine.

title: Pregnant Woman Is Slain At Chelsea AIDS Hospice
description: A man stabbed a pregnant woman to death yesterday at an AIDS hospice in Chelsea where they both lived, then tried to kill himself by slitting his wrists, the police said.

title: Emphasis On Hospitality
description: Look for more television monitors, more picnic tables and more family-friendly accommodations when Belmont Park's 55-day spring-summer meet opens today. Even the horses will be younger, at least in the week leading up to the Belmont Stakes.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Light in Bedlam
description: To the Editor:

title: Sony Plans To Distribute Music on Line This Summer
description: Sony Music Entertainment says it will begin selling songs on line in digital form using Microsoft technology, accelerating the rush of record companies to the Internet even before the industry settles on a common standard.

title: Business Travel; The approach of summer's first holiday gives signs of a crowded tourist season ahead.
description: STILL haven't made reservations for summer vacation? Well don't wait any longer, because the AAA auto club predicted yesterday that from Memorial Day through Labor Day (the unofficial summer season) Americans would make a record 271 million trips of at least 100 miles from home. Over Memorial Day weekend alone, a record 33.3 million people are expected to get away.

title: New Asian Accents Amid Old World Details
description: ONCE there was a restaurant called the Park. Serving contemporary American fare, it opened in 1997 in the Lombardy Hotel, a sumptuous turn-of-the century building that is now an apartment house. Two years later, the restaurant has a new chef, a new menu and a new wooden floor. It also has a new name: Soma Park.

title: Mapping Unit Failures Laid to Reorganization
description: The Pentagon agency that drew up the outdated map used in the bombing of the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade has been embroiled in at least two other international incidents in the last 18 months.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DICKLER, EVA (NEE SPIEGEL)
description: DICKLER-Eva (nee Spiegel). Devoted wife of the late Jack. Loving mother of Richard and Suzanne. Dear sister of Belle Fidelman, Jean Probst, Herman Spiegel and Estelle Rose. Service 1PM today, Nieberg Midwood Chapel, Inc., 1625 Coney Island Avenue, Bklyn, corner Avenue M.

title: A Big Stake In Le Figaro Is for Sale
description: The Hersant Group, a heavily indebted French newspaper company, is seeking bids for up to 49 percent of its flagship paper, Le Figaro.

title: Body in Park Identified; Killing Is Suspected
description: A man found dead in Central Park on Monday was identified yesterday as a 33-year-old manager at Fortune magazine, and the police said they would investigate the case as a murder.

title: Ford Parts Unit In French Acquisition
description: The Ford Motor Company's Visteon unit, the second-largest maker of automobile parts in the world, is buying the automotive interiors business of Plastic Omnium S.A. of France for 457 million euros, or about $492 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAGID, HELAINE G.
description: MAGID-Helaine G. Beloved wife of Meyer Magid of Rye Brook, New York and Fort Lauderdale, Florida. Passed away on May 9th after a sudden illness.
