Prior to retirement, she was a stock broker at Kidder Peabody. She graduated Cum Laude from the University of Vermont and received a Master's Degree in Social Psychology from Columbia University. She was the Founder of the Community Synagogue in Rye, New York; was President of the National Council of Jewish Women in Westchester; and President of the American Field Service New York Chapter. She is survived by three loving daughters: Margo Magid of New York City, Dr. Donna Magid of Baltimore, and Kim Magid of Portland, Maine; her brother George Goldberg of Armonk, New York; and two grandchildren: Whitney and Torrey. Memorial services will be held at 1 PM, Friday, May 14th, at Community Synagogue, 200 Forest Avenue, Rye, New York. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that contributions be sent to The Beautification Fund, Community Synagogue.

title: Arms Cache Found in South Africa, Worsening Pre-election Jitters
description: The police announced today that they had uncovered a vast cache of arms and ammunition in a bunker in KwaZulu/ Natal Province, aggravating tensions as South Africa's second post-apartheid elections approach on June 2.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSEN, MATTIE
description: ROSEN-Mattie. On May 11, 1999, in her 96th year. Beloved wife of the late Joseph Rosen. Dear mother of Paul (Marilyn) & David (Marcia) Rosen. Adored grandmother of Warren, Raymond and Mark, and great-grandmother of Corey and Sydney. Graveside services Thursday, May 13th, 1PM, at Beth Olem Cemetery, Glendale, New York. Family will be receiving at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, Wednesday evening, 6-8PM. Contributions in her memory may be made to Association for Glycogen Storage Disease, P.O. Box 896, Durant, Iowa 52747.

title: TV Notes; Homer Meets Dr. Hawking
description: Homer Simpson, the dunderheaded father on ''The Simpsons,'' is renowned for his stupidity. Stephen Hawking, the Cambridge University physicist, is renowned for his brains. On Sunday night they met, fictionally speaking, when Dr. Hawking was a guest character on the popular animated sitcom.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PINCUS, RONALD
description: PINCUS-Ronald. On May 10, 1999, beloved husband of Golda, loving father of Michele Eller, and Jeff Pincus, cherished grandfather of Lindsay Eller, dear brother of Annette Siskel. Services Thursday 11A.M. at ''The Riverside'', 76th STreet and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Prom Queens, Evidently, Go for the Scholarly Type
description: Wrapped like candy in a sure-fire come-on of bouncing bosoms and firm young female bodies, ''Trippin' '' is a sermon aimed primarily at teen-age black male high school students.

title: James J. Humes Dies at 74; Did Autopsy on Kennedy
description: Dr. James J. Humes, one of two Navy pathologists who performed the autopsy on President John F. Kennedy, died on Thursday at his home in Ponte Vedra, Fla. He was 74.

title: Pataki Proposes to Broaden State's '95 Death Penalty Law
description: Gov. George E. Pataki today proposed broadening the state's death penalty law, including a change that would allow death sentences for defendants who have pleaded guilty to a murder charge, and not just those found guilty at trial.

title: AVONDALE TO START TALKS WITH LITTON ON ITS OFFER
description: Avondale Industries, a maker of amphibious assault vehicles and other military ships, said yesterday that it would start talks with Litton Industries, which made a last bid that topped Newport News Shipbuilding Inc.'s offer. Avondale said Litton's $504 million, or $38 a share, cash offer could lead to a proposal that is superior to its merger agreement with Newport News, and has authorized its management to begin negotiations. The Newport News purchase of Avondale has already been cleared by the Pentagon and is heading for shareholder votes as early as next month. Earlier this month, Litton offered $2.3 billion for Newport News and Avondale.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DENISON, HOMER RIDGWAY
description: DENISON-Homer Ridgway. Musician, composer, orchestrator and arranger. On May 2, 1999 at New York Hospital. Husband of Cara and father of James. Services will be held Thursday, May 13 at 10:30 AM, St. Mark's Episcopal Church, 34 Ave. at 81 St., Jackson Heights.

title: Will England Gain by Losing?; A Future Mini-Model
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GALLET, GERARD
description: GALLET-Gerard. Died Paris May 7, 1999. Born 1935. Survived by his wife Francoise and her children and his former wife Sally and their daughter Tabisa. Interment Paris private. His friends in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HESS, LEON
description: HESS-Leon. The Board of Directors, Staff, children and families of Berkshire Farm Center and Services for Youth express our deepest sorrow on the passing of Leon Hess. He was a valued supporter of Berkshire Farms Center for many years. The Hess Automotive Facility, a vocational training program, was established out of his generosity. His support has made a significant difference in the lives of many children. Our heartfelt condolences go to the entire family. William I. Spencer, Chairman Charles H. Mott, President Rose W. Washington, Executive Director

title: KOSOVO UPDATE
description: COMBAT

title: Across Town, a Thai Sibling With Western Touches
description: I HAVE always been a big fan of Holy Basil, the superb Thai restaurant in the East Village, so when Little Basil, a smaller sibling, opened in the center of Greenwich Village about a month ago, I expected to like it, too. But I didn't realize I would love it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAYLEY, DR. JAMES ELWOOD MCKEON, JR.
description: BAYLEY-Dr. James Elwood McKeon, Jr. Of Closter, NJ on May 10, 1999. Beloved husband of Carole (nee White). Cherished father of Priscilla Jane and James. Dear brother of Gertrude Linquiti, Andrew and Muriel Devercelly. Friends may call at the Barrett Funeral Home, 148 Dean Drive, Tenafly, NJ, Wednesday 2-4 & 7-9 PM. Funeral service Thursday, 10:30 AM. Interment, Ocean View Cemetery, Staten Island, NY. Memorials to Dr. Martin Tamny, Dean, c/o City College (Scholarship Fund), 125th St & Convent Ave, NYC would be appreciated.

title: Inflation Fears Continue to Lift Treasury Rates
description: Long-term interest rates, which have risen steadily since early April, jumped to their highest level in almost a year yesterday as investors continued to worry about inflation and the next meeting of Federal Reserve policy makers on Tuesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SVERD, DAVID
description: SVERD-David. Husband of Sylvia. Father of Susan & the late Morton Tillman, Dr. Jeffrey and Barbara. Grandfather of Pamela, Peter, Farryl and the late Jonathan. Brother of Clara and Norma.

title: Israeli Race for Prime Minister Is Down to the Wire, With Little Cheering
description: Six days before the Israeli elections, Chaim Yisrael, an elderly Hasidic Jew, hurried to complete his shopping near the ultra-Orthodox neighborhood of Mea Shearim. He was on his way to tutor Torah, he said, but he could spare a few minutes.

title: Delta Absorbing Airline
description: Delta Air Lines plans to begin operating Atlantic Southeast Airlines as a wholly owned subsidiary. Delta, which is based here, said it would start offering Atlantic Southeast flights to Daytona Beach, Fla.; Melbourne, Fla., and Montgomery, Ala., on June 1. Nonstop fights between Islip, N.Y., and Atlanta are to start on Aug. 1. In March, Delta increased its stake in Atlantic Southeast Airlines to 91 percent from 28 percent through a tender offer at $34 a share. It is now acquiring the remaining shares.

title: I.B.M. Sets a New Record For Magnetic-Disk Storage
description: I.B.M. plans to announce today that its researchers have set a new record in magnetic-disk storage density, packing bits of data in a space so small that 20 billion fit within a square inch.

title: Confronting the Speaker
description: The fate of campaign finance reform is in the hands of a few dozen Republican moderates afraid to stand up for what they believe. That much is clear from the refusal of House Republicans who support the Shays-Meehan ''soft money'' ban to sign a petition forcing the bill to the floor. At a meeting with Speaker Dennis Hastert last week, many of these Republicans asked for a vote before midsummer. The Speaker said he would think about it. A week has gone by, and he has not gotten back to them. With 191 Democrats on board to bring the legislation to a vote, it would take only 27 Republican signatures, out of 59 Republican supporters of the bill, to let the vote take place.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVY, GILBERT
description: LEVY-Gilbert. Of Princeton, New Jersey, and Boynton Beach, Florida. Cousin of William I. Wolff, M.D., and close friend of the entire Wolff family which individually and collectively held him with high regard and affection. He will be sorely missed by all.

title: Wynona Lipman, 67, Veteran In the New Jersey State Senate
description: State Senator Wynona M. Lipman, who in 1971 became the first African-American woman to be elected to the New Jersey Senate, died Sunday at her home in Newark. She was 67.

title: Four Universities Announce Their Journalism Fellowships
description: Four universities have named the recipients of journalism fellowships for the 1999-2000 academic year. The fellowships involve a range of study options.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RITTMAN, WILLIAM CAMPBELL
description: RITTMAN-William Campbell, of Bronxville, NY, died suddenly, May 10, 1999. He was a graduate of Harvard College and Harvard Law School. During World War II Major Rittman flew B25's in the 14th Air Force Squadron attached to the Chinese Air Force, spending three years in China. After the war, Mr. Rittman was involved in international business and retired as Vice President in charge of International Operations for Richardson-Merrell. He is survived by his wife Patricia, two sons, Walter F. and Frank S., daughter-in-law Fran, and two grandchildren.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'ROURKE, PATRICIA F.
description: O'ROURKE-Patricia F. Died on May 8, 1999 at her home in Yonkers, N.Y. Formerly of the Bronx, she was the only child of the late James and Frances O'Rourke. A dedicated teacher, she was the retired Principal of Intermediate School 180 in the Bronx. Friends may call at the Hastings Funeral Home, Inc., 15 Spring St, HastingsOn-Hudson on Wednesday and Thursday from 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass at Christ the King Church on Friday at 11 AM. Interment St. Raymond's Cemetery. In lieu of flowers contributions to the Patricia O'Rourke Scholarship Fund, Aquinas High School, 685 East 182nd Street, Bronx, N.Y. 10457-1801 preferred.

title: Moscow's Mood Uneasy as Vote on Yeltsin's Impeachment Nears
description: The Parliament is priming itself for a vote to impeach the President on charges that he brought Russia to ruin. The President's men talk darkly of dumping the Prime Minister, accusing him of leading the country back to its Communist past.

title: INSIDE
description: Clampdown at Nuclear Labs

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about airlines' plans to use jets for routes within New York State referred incorrectly to US Airways' cost per mile on the route from LaGuardia Airport to Rochester. The airline said 12 cents per mile was its average cost nationwide. US Airways does not disclose costs for individual routes.

title: Songwriter's Independence Isn't Easy to Hum
description: Adam Guettel, the young songwriter, was initially reluctant to do the concert of his work scheduled for tonight at Town Hall.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FELDMAN, CLAIRE
description: FELDMAN-Claire. 5/12/22-11/3/96 Claire dear, I note with much sorrow your third birthday since your passing. The heartache has not diminished one degree. Your goodness, beauty of character and smile will never be forgotten. I cherish the memories but-. Loved very much, Miriam

title: Holders' Group Seeks Ousters at Italian Bank
description: Holders of 20.7 percent of the shares of Banca Commerciale Italiana have requested the removal of its two co-chief executives and the nomination of a new board, the bank said yesterday. In a statement, the bank said its chairman would ask the existing board to discuss the issues at its meeting on Friday.

title: Research on Humans Is Curbed at Duke U.
description: The Department of Health and Human Services suspended all federally financed medical research on humans at the Duke University Medical Center after determining that the center could not adequately safeguard the safety of the subjects, a department official said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VERGOTTIS, MARY G.
description: VERGOTTIS-Mary G. It is with deep sorrow that we announce the death of Mrs. Mary G. Vergottis on the 7th of May, 1999. The burial service will take place at the Greek Orthodox Church, Avenue Florimont, Lausanne, on Tuesday, 18th of May, at 15:15 hours. Her sisters, Mrs. Thecla C. Marinidis, family and friends

title: State Senate Republicans Seek to Drop Commuter Tax
description: Saying that New York City should share its record surplus with suburban residents, Republican leaders in the State Senate announced yesterday that they would vote next week to abolish the commuter tax paid by suburbanites who work in the city.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIPPMAN, LOIS H. (NEE HIGGINBOTHAM)
description: LIPPMAN-Lois H. (nee Higginbotham). The New York Republican County Committee mourns the passing of a great lady and dear friend on May 8. Our sincerest condolences to her husband, Romeyne, and son, Marc. Memorial services to be announced at a later date. Senator Roy M. Goodman, Chmn. New York Republican County Committee Gertrude Hess Parker, Exec. Secy

title: I.B.M. to Make Game Part For Nintendo
description: Underscoring the growing significance of inexpensive video game machines in the computer industry, the International Business Machines Corporation and Nintendo Inc. plan to announce today a $1 billion agreement for Nintendo to build its next-generation system with I.B.M.'s PowerPC processors.

title: That Elusive Flavor? Sugar
description: THIS may seem a little odd for a sugar lover to say, but I don't like my sugar to be too sweet. Sugar connoisseurs, who appreciate the many qualities a great sugar can bring to a dish, know exactly what I mean. Too much sweetness can destroy all that is good in sugar, overpowering the subtleties of its many flavors and perfumes.

title: In Africa, Science Catches Up to Oral History
description: To the Editor:

title: A New List Of Species In Danger
description: For the first time since 1987, New York State yesterday proposed changing its list of imperiled animals to remove a handful of creatures that are clearly faring better -- like the Eastern bluebird -- and add scores of species of fish, butterflies, turtles and waterfowl that are now in danger of being wiped out.

title: The Urban Herb, or Life on a Windowsill
description: EVERY spring when the urge to grow sets in, New Yorkers carry home pots of herbs, imagining a garden on the windowsill where fresh basil and dill can be plucked with abandon. And every summer, both hopes and herbs wither and die. The inclination is always to blame a black thumb. But herbs are like people: not all thrive in an urban environment.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: About New York; Midnight In the Gardens Up for Sale
description: THE Lower East Side People Care Community Garden, a green sliver tucked between two drab apartment buildings on Rutgers Street, isn't on any tourist maps. Judith Harris, on vacation from Southern California, had to stumble across it on Monday afternoon while walking down the narrow streets.

title: Full Field Makes Draw Key Factor In Preakness
description: Seven horses from the Kentucky Derby held final dress rehearsals for the Preakness today, but they did it at Churchill Downs in Louisville, where the 31-1 long shot Charismatic won the Derby last week and scrambled the balance of power among 3-year-old horses.

title: Jarvis Denies Report He Discussed Wizards Coaching Job
description: St. John's Coach Mike Jarvis denied a published report yesterday that said he has interviewed for the head coaching job with the Washington Wizards. Jarvis said his meeting Monday in Baltimore with General Manager Wes Unseld, a longtime friend, was strictly to discuss players, especially the Red Storm's Ron Artest.

title: Norman Weissman, 74, Ex-Head of Agency
description: Norman Weissman, a former president of the Ruder Finn public relations agency in New York, died on Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 74 years old.

title: Teen-Ager Is Accused Of Sexual Assault on Boy
description: A 15-year-old boy has been charged with repeatedly sexually assaulting a 4-year-old boy in Atlantic City, the police said yesterday.

title: Independent Scholars
description: To the Editor:

title: When Elderly Pay Too Much for Drugs
description: To the Editor:

title: Two First Ladies, So Alike and So Different
description: SHE was the prelude to Hillary Rodham Clinton, a quietly rebellious First Lady of the late 1970's who sat in on Cabinet meetings, pushed Congress to pass mental health legislation -- and was asked by her party to run for United States Senator from Georgia after her husband left the White House.

title: THE CHEF
description: SOME people crave a small bite of something sweet to end a meal; others like to savor a rich, salty morsel of cheese, especially if they haven't finished their wine with dinner.

title: A Flawed Ranking System Will Be Gone Next Year
description: The 1999 slump has spread through the men's tennis tour like a computer virus: The No. 1 player lost six straight first-rounders; the No. 2 hasn't won a title since October; the No. 3 would be ranked 61st based on this year's performance.

title: In War, Mistakes Happen
description: One result of the tragically mistaken bombing of the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade last week is the ritual search in Washington for human sacrifice, someone to blame. Before the tumbrels roll, however, three things should be taken into account.

title: Weakened New York School Boards Lack for Candidates
description: When Siegfried Holzer was first elected to the board of Community School District 6 in upper Manhattan in the 1970's, New York City's 32 school boards wielded more power than most small-town governments.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOPPLE, ALFRED S.
description: KOPPLE-Alfred S. Textile executive, passed away on Sunday, May 9, 1999 at the age of 80. He was a highly decorated officer in the Air Force during World War II. He was greatly adored by his wife of 55 years, Marjorie, his daughter, Barbara and son, Peter. His grandchildren, Nicholas, Hilary and Sara will truly miss his love and friendship. His friends will miss his kindness, gentleness, sense of humor and his extraordinary companionship. Services will be held Wednesday, May 12, at 10 AM at the Riverside Gordon Memorial Chapel, Delray Beach, Florida.

title: Political Briefing; An Iowa Straw Poll Reserved for Iowans
description: In Presidential politics, Iowa is best known for its first-in-the-nation February caucuses. But earlier still, usually in August of the preceding year, the state's Republicans gather in Ames to talk up the coming caucuses and tease candidates and voters a bit by conducting a Presidential straw poll.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The money can't come from the sky. It would come from the taxpayers.''

title: Bonilla's Other Knee Hurt
description: Watching Bobby Bonilla limp on one bad knee was painful enough. Hoping Bonilla could play on two bum knees apparently was out of the question.

title: Whitman Vows to Bypass Bar Association
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman, still angry over the state Bar Association's rejection of her nomination of Attorney General Peter G. Verniero to the State Supreme Court, said today that she would not send any future Supreme Court nominees to the bar for review.

title: Political Briefing; Virginia Foreshadows Redistricting Battle
description: The focus during election year 2000 will be mainly on the Presidential race and Congressional contests. But on the ballot too will be the election of new governors and legislatures in most states.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Rising Stocks (and Wishful Thinking) in Japan
description: Japan's economy may be dead in the water, but the nation is once again the land of the rising stock market. The question is, when will Japan's economy, the world's second largest, begin to justify investors' increasingly high hopes?

title: Autopsy Finds Tuinei Died of Drug Overdose
description: Mark Tuinei, the former Dallas Cowboys offensive lineman who was found dead in his car last Thursday, died after taking heroin and a popular recreational drug known as ecstasy, authorities said yesterday.

title: Speaker Takes Few Risks and Tries to Keep G.O.P. United
description: Five months after he was tapped as the accidental Speaker, J. Dennis Hastert has turned out to be just what most House Republicans want: nearly invisible.

title: In One Kosovo Woman, An Emblem of Suffering
description: She's seen too much, Meli said. She wants a rest. She wants it to be over. She wants to leave, like her friends, and go to Macedonia. But she wants to stay, because her mother wants to stay, and it's her home and why should she leave it? And it seems to be getting better, she says, in Pristina, anyway.

title: Rock, Funk and Electronics In a Splashy 80's Sound
description: George Russell is usually given credit for coming up with the concept of modal jazz -- a music in which there are no chord sequences, only scales, to give the improviser maximum freedom. It happened during a close friendship with Miles Davis and Gil Evans in the late 1940's and early 50's, and after that all three often moved in similar directions. For one thing, they all thought deeply about how to join jazz with electronic music and rock without compromising any of those styles.

title: Technology and Internet Issues Brighten Wall St.'s Day
description: Stocks were buffeted by a further selloff in the bond market yesterday but recovered and moved higher, led by technology and Internet shares.

title: Marketing Hall To Induct Two
description: Hallmark Cards Inc. in Kansas City, Mo., and Amazon.com in Seattle are being named to the Marketing Hall of Fame by the New York chapter of the American Marketing Association. They will be honored June 10 at the annual ceremony presenting the Effie Awards, which recognize effectiveness in advertising.

title: Will England Gain by Losing?; Spain Took the Lead
description: To the Editor:

title: Doping Charges Again Embroil Top Cyclist
description: The star cyclist Richard Virenque has acknowledged using banned performance-enhancing drugs, the police said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WINTER, MARVIN S.
description: WINTER-Marvin S. The Officers and employees of Alliance Brokerage Corp. extend their deepest condolences to the family of Marvin Winter. He will always be remembered as a kind and thoughtful friend.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a Senate subcommittee hearing on how the F.B.I. handled its investigation into the explosion of T.W.A. Flight 800 misstated the date of the explosion in some copies. It was July 17, 1996, not July 16.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORDON, EVAN W., M.D.
description: GORDON-Evan W., M.D. The Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology at State University of New York Health Science Center at Brooklyn was very saddened to hear about the death of Dr. Evan W. Gordon. Dr. Gordon was an active member of the department for a period of 16 years at State University Hospital of Brooklyn and Kings County Hospital Center. Dr. Gordon was appointed to the faculty in the department as a clinical instructor at State University of New York Health Science Center at Brooklyn and as an attending physician at State University Hospital of Brooklyn and Kings County Hospital Center in 1970. In 1984, he was promoted to the level of a Clinical Assistant Professor. Dr. Gordon was an excellent teacher to the medical students and residents. The department extends its deepest sympathy to the family.

title: Do-It-Yourself Airline Meals
description: NOT so long ago, when I passed through the gate to board a Delta dinner flight from New York to Atlanta, I spied a stack of filled brown paper bags and assumed they contained leftover bagels from a breakfast flight.

title: Senate Debates Bill to Combat Youth Violence
description: As the Senate began debate on a bill intended to reduce crime among children, Republicans focused today on stricter law enforcement, Democrats emphasized better prevention programs and advocates of new gun-control measures faced the prospect that time would run out before their proposals could be considered.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: IT GROUP INC., -- Pittsburgh, a waste management company, acquired Emcon, of San Mateo, Calif., an environmental consulting, engineering and construction services company, for $62 million and the assumption of $8 million in debt.

title: While One Jones Wins, The Other Loses for Mets
description: Other than their given and proper names, and their current occupations, Robert Joseph Jones of the Mets and Robert Mitchell Jones of the Colorado Rockies have frighteningly little in common.

title: TV Notes; Calling Dr. Geiger
description: The wildly inventive mind of David E. Kelley was working overtime as the television season drew to a close, not only because he had to wrap up the seasons of ''The Practice'' on ABC and ''Ally McBeal'' on Fox, but also because he stepped in at the last minute to save his oldest surviving series, ''Chicago Hope'' on CBS.

title: Clinton Tries to Sell Executives on Inner-City Economics
description: Eager to keep his domestic agenda going, President Clinton flew here today to call for corporate investment in inner-city America and said he would tour some of the nation's pockets of poverty, which he characterized as great economic opportunities.

title: Sloan-Kettering May Buy Hospital Building
description: Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center announced yesterday that it planned to buy one of three buildings that make up the Manhattan Eye, Ear and Throat Hospital, and that a group of investors would buy the other two, sales that would essentially close the 130-year-old hospital.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUTELL, BEATRICE
description: KUTELL-Beatrice. Beloved wife of the late Paul. Devoted mother of Susan Freedman and Diane Frish. Adored grandmother of Jack Freedman, David Frish and Carlie Frish. Dear sister of Marion Liebsohn. Graveside services will be held at Linden Hill Cemetery, Ridgewood, NY, today at 1 PM.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Individuals Will Receive Priority in Nasdaq Lawsuit

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DEMARCO, DAWN L.
description: DeMARCO-Dawn L., 1970-1989. Each day floods with the yearning of embracing my sweet daughter, yet each day brings me closer to heaven's gate and eternal life with you. Thank you, Jesus. Dad and Family

title: G.O.P. Leader Bends on Time To Take Up Campaign Bill
description: In a new sign of flexibility by the Republican leadership, the House majority leader said today that he thought the House should consider legislation by the end of July to overhaul the campaign finance laws.

title: When Elderly Pay Too Much for Drugs
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDNER, NICHOLAS ''MIKLOS''
description: GOLDNER - Nicholas ''Miklos''. Dearest brother of Charles Goldner and Edith Steinlauf. Beloved uncle. Shiva will be observed at the Gibber residence, 515 West End Ave, NYC until Mon morning.

title: Yugoslavia Seeks a Legal Order to Halt the NATO Bombing
description: A parallel fight to the war in Kosovo is taking place here at the International Court of Justice, where Yugoslavia is asking for a legal order against 10 NATO nations to halt the bombing, and the NATO members are responding with scorn.

title: STRIP-SEARCH CASE LEAVES CITY FACING A BIGGER LIABILITY
description: A Federal jury has ordered New York City to pay $5 million to a woman who was strip-searched by jail guards, a verdict that could have broad financial ramifications for the city as it faces a class-action lawsuit filed on behalf of 63,000 people who say they were illegally strip-searched.

title: U S West Elects New Chairman
description: U S West Inc. said yesterday that Solomon D. Trujillo, the local phone carrier's chief executive, had been elected chairman.

title: World Briefing
description: ASIA

title: America Online Challenges Microsoft's WebTV
description: Only weeks after completing the purchase of the Netscape Communications Corporation -- the Microsoft Corporation's archrival in Web browsing software -- America Online Inc. announced yesterday that it would take on Microsoft in delivering the Internet over television sets.

title: Accessorize, Accessorize
description: To the Editor:

title: String of Rocket Mishaps Worries Industry
description: America's space rockets seem to be failing, blowing up or losing payloads at an alarming rate that has experts questioning the prowess of an increasingly competitive satellite launching industry.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HENDEL, JOAN
description: HENDEL - Joan. Ten Years. Gentle mother, never forgotten. Thank you for giving me life. With all my love, Dal

title: China Protests Crash White House Web Site
description: The White House site on the World Wide Web has been overwhelmed -- quite literally -- with E-mail from China protesting NATO's bombing of the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade.

title: Political Briefing; That Resignation? Just Call It Premature
description: Representative Martin T. Meehan has decided not to honor the pledge he made back in 1995 to leave Congress in early 2001 when his fourth term expires. Mr. Meehan, a Massachusetts Democrat, says that he has concluded that the concept of term limits has no political merit and that he can better serve his constituents by seeking re-election.

title: Notebook; Graduating on the Web
description: At this time of year, college newspapers are usually filled with classified advertisements from seniors desperate to find extra tickets to commencement ceremonies. Many colleges limit the number of tickets, so some siblings and grandparents never get to see the diploma handed out.

title: Istanbul Journal; Musings on Freedom, by Wearer of Muslim Scarf
description: Sitting demurely behind her desk dressed in immaculate white, Merve Kavakci does not look like someone who could send a nation of 65 million into turmoil. But because of what she wears, she has done exactly that.

title: Credit Suisse Unit Fined
description: Sweden's stock exchange fined Credit Suisse First Boston 2 million kronor ($240,000) today for irregular trades, ending a chapter in an embarrassing episode for the securities unit of Switzerland's second-largest bank. The Stockholm Stock Exchange fined the firm for irregular trading in shares of Stora A.B., a Swedish paper maker, by members of the bank's London-based index arbitrage team, known as the ''Flaming Ferraris'' for their favored after-hours cocktail. Credit Suisse dismissed three of the traders in March.

title: When Elderly Pay Too Much for Drugs
description: To the Editor:

title: Citing Safety, U.S. Stops Human Research Aid at Duke
description: The Government has suspended all federally financed medical research on humans at the Duke University Medical Center after determining that the center could not adequately guarantee the safety of the subjects, a Federal official said tonight.

title: Bid to Overturn Gigante Verdict Is Blocked
description: A Federal judge blocked the latest effort to overturn the murder-conspiracy and racketeering conviction of the Mafia boss Vincent Gigante by refusing yesterday to question the jurors who had convicted him.

title: Germany Nominates New Bundesbank Head
description: The German Government nominated Ernst Welteke, left, as Bundesbank president yesterday, signaling a new era for Germany's central bank, which analysts said would need to redefine its role in the aftermath of the January introduction of the single European currency, the euro.

title: TheStreet.com's New Shares Soar
description: Shares in TheStreet.com tripled in their first day of trading yesterday as investors piled into the Internet news service promoted by its co-founder, James J. Cramer, a hedge-fund manager and financial columnist.

title: Sports of The Times; Golden Bear Comes Back As a 'Solid 4'
description: JACK NICKLAUS is golf's Golden Bear and Steve Pedersen, a 37-year-old retired New York City police sergeant, is a 7 handicap, but as they met for the first time yesterday, they had something in common: a hip replacement. And when the Golden Bear was on his way to hitting a ceremonial tee shot opening the Golf Club at Mansion Ridge here yesterday, the 7 handicap approached him for an autograph.

title: In Death, a Fond Remembrance of Things Past
description: When we say we ''remember'' something, what exactly is it we recall? A feeling? A smell? Words? Facial expressions? Invited to relive an especially happy memory, how many of us would be able to go beyond recalling how we felt, and describe the setting and circumstances of that moment in precise detail? And even when we conjure vivid mental pictures of past events, how accurate are they really?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRONMAN, CAROL J., ESQ.
description: KRONMAN-Carol J., Esq. The Officers, Board of Directors and members of Professional Women in Construction (PWC) mourn the untimely passing of its dear friend, colleague and Board member. Her generosity and dedication to the advancement of business and professional women in the construction industry helped to shape many educational programs. We extend our deepest condolences to her entire family. Lenore Janis, President Theresa Vigilante, Exec. V.P.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CAMPBELL, MARION DANIELSON
description: CAMPBELL-Marion Danielson. A memorial service will be held 11AM Saturday, May 15, at Groton School Chapel-Groton, MA.

title: Giuliani Seeks Deal to Sell 63 Gardens to Land Group and End Suits
description: Faced with three lawsuits and the kind of bad publicity that comes when protesters are willing to risk arrest for the sake of lilacs and tomato plants, the Giuliani administration is trying to strike a settlement with various environmental groups opposed to its plan to auction off public lots that are used as community gardens.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-16

title: Brooklyn Pair Accused Of Posing as Officers
description: A husband and wife were arrested yesterday on charges that they posed as police officers and robbed a Brooklyn high school student, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPELKE, MIRIAM L.
description: SPELKE-Miriam L. Miriam Spelke, beloved wife, mother, friend and a longtime former resident of Stamford, CT., and widow of Norman Spelke passed away on May 9, 1999 from lymphoma at her home in Laguna Hills, CA. She was 86. She is survived by two children, Karen Sorensen of Kentfield, CA., and Richard Spelke of Pasadena, CA., and one granddaughter, Jenny Sorensen. Contributions in her memory may be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center (Special Projects), 1275 York Avenue, New York, New York 10021.

title: Have Funds, Could Run; Unknown but Rich, Corzine Becomes a Top Contender for Senate
description: When Goldman Sachs Group went public last week, its former chairman, Jon S. Corzine, became a very rich man. He also effectively became unemployed. Having lost a power struggle earlier this year, Mr. Corzine ended his formal relationship with the Wall Street firm once the public offering was completed.

title: PRO FOOTBALL: Let the Second Acts Begin; The 1999 Giants Have No Shortage of Comeback Stories
description: In the glare of a May sun, the 1999 Giants gathered today for the first time, a football practice in spring with an eye on a season still four months away. And from sideline to sideline, the new and old parts made a first attempt to meld as a team.

title: Body of Woman Found In a Lake in Queens
description: The body of an unidentified woman was found floating in a lake in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park in Queens yesterday evening, the police said.

title: Zagat Invites Web Surfers In
description: THE Zagat Survey went on line yesterday at www .zagat.com with every morsel of information that appears in the restaurant guide series, and more, all of it free for now. Users can electronically rate restaurants anywhere, whether Zagat has a guide to that locale or not. The site is also looking for input on a Diners' Bill of Rights, which will cover subjects like service and tipping, to give restaurateurs something to chew on.

title: Corrections
description: An article about Brooklyn on Sunday in The Sophisticated Traveler, part 2 of The Times Magazine, misstated the telephone number of John Cashman, who conducts tours of Green-Wood Cemetery. It is (718) 469-5277.

title: Liberties; The Coldest Cut
description: Jesse Jackson detected slights.

title: Bulgarians Bet Future On a Link To NATO
description: For Yugoslavia's Balkan and Central European neighbors, the war in Kosovo is becoming part of a familiar pattern of casting their lot with the perceived victor.

title: A Tribute for Jose Quintero at Circle in the Square
description: Friends and admirers of the director Jose Quintero gathered yesterday to pay tribute to a man whose compassion, humor and intensity they said inspired seminal productions of the work of Eugene O'Neill and other playwrights.

title: Heat Gets a Holiday (Riley Must Be Soft With Winning)
description: Pat Riley, whose affinity for three-hour practices is legendary, tried something different today. He gave the Heat the entire day off.

title: Will England Gain by Losing?
description: To the Editor:

title: BIG RAIDS RESUME AS NATO REASSERTS DEMANDS ON SERBS
description: Undeterred by calls from China and Russia to halt the bombing of Yugoslavia, American and other allied forces pounded targets across the country today as NATO leaders pledged to continue the air war until President Slobodan Milosevic agreed to meet all their demands.

title: The Parents' Lifeline
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; Spree Could Electrify Garden
description: GOOD grief. After a dismal lockout and a dreary season, the Knicks are still with us and, not only that, they have a chance to be around for a while.

title: Lechery and Loneliness In the Hazardous West
description: CLOSE RANGE

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Recalling a Cat Who Got Around

title: Immigrant Taking Cash to Honduras Is Killed
description: A 37-year-old immigrant who was on his way home to Honduras to take money he had saved to his wife and two children was shot and killed here early Monday. The police believe that the attack may have been planned.

title: A Novel Feature in Price-Fixing Settlement
description: Individual investors will be given an edge over institutional investors in the distribution of about $1 billion that Nasdaq dealers paid to settle a landmark 1994 antitrust class-action case accusing them of fixing prices on Nasdaq shares.

title: Pricewaterhouse In Europe Acquisitions
description: PricewaterhouseCoopers has bought two management consulting practices in Europe. The firm, the world's biggest in accounting and consulting, said yesterday that it had acquired Galgano & Merli, one of Italy's top consulting companies. The acquisition comes on the heels of Monday's announcement that it had acquired the entire Belgian consulting practice of its rival KPMG.

title: Reporter Fired for Lies About Her Illness
description: In a series of newspaper columns written over the past year, a 33-year-old Kentucky reporter described her imminent death from what she described to her readers as ''terminal brain cancer.''

title: Committee Told Of Beijing Cash For Democrats
description: A Democratic fund-raiser who has pleaded guilty to campaign-related bank and tax fraud told a House panel today that he met in 1996 with a high-ranking Chinese intelligence official who promised him $300,000 for use in the Presidential election and said, ''We really like your President.''

title: TENNIS
description: ITALIAN OPEN

title: CALENDAR
description: Inspired by Alice Waters

title: Metro Business; Bank Branches to Be Sold
description: First Union Corporation, the sixth-largest bank in the United States, will sell 14 bank branches in New Jersey to Sun Bancorp Inc.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAVAN, FAY C.
description: LAVAN-Fay C. May 10, 1999 in Lenox, MA. Survived by sons Spencer and Lawrence, daughterin-law Susan and seven grandchildren and a great grandson. Memorial service will be held at a later date.

title: Court Decision Upsets School District Measure for Kiryas Joel
description: New York State's highest court yesterday declared unconstitutional the third and latest legislative effort to create a special public school district for the disabled children of the Hasidic village of Kiryas Joel, saying that it still amounted to ''preferring one religion over others.''

title: Executive in Big Gold Scandal Faces Insider Trading Charges
description: The vice chairman of Bre-X Minerals Ltd. was charged with insider trading and other securities law violations today in connection with the company's fraudulent reports of a huge Indonesian gold discovery three years ago, one of the biggest financial scandals in Canada's history.

title: Crew Says Rift With Giuliani Hurts Schools
description: Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew said yesterday that his relationship with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani had reached a crisis point, and he appealed to responsible New Yorkers -- ''good people, influential people'' -- to intercede for the sake of the city's schoolchildren.

title: High Chinese Officials Talk To Russian Envoy on Kosovo
description: Russia's special envoy on the Kosovo crisis, Viktor S. Chernomyrdin, met on Tuesday with China's top leaders to discuss the issue, as rage continued to boil here in response to the NATO bombing of the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade.

title: Have Web, Will Travel!
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Economic Scene; Minimum wage bandwagon needs some skillful reining.
description: CONGRESS will almost certainly raise the minimum wage this year, probably to $6.15 an hour from $5.15, phased in over two to three years. Democrats, as always, are in full support. So, too, are at least 20 moderate House Republicans anxious about next year's election. But whatever the political attraction, does a higher minimum wage make economic sense?

title: Computer and Liquor Accounts Assigned
description: Two marketers named advertising agencies to their accounts yesterday.

title: Allies Detail Busiest Bombing Yet, but See Clash Continuing
description: Senior NATO and Pentagon officials said today that after the most intense 24 hours of bombing so far, NATO had weakened Yugoslavia's forces but still not broken their ability to fight.

title: Commuter Tax Games
description: Every once in a while, New York's politicians outdo themselves with acts of destructive one-upmanship. It is happening again, as the State Legislature moves toward repealing the New York City tax imposed on commuters, blowing a deep hole in the city's finances. The repeal of the tax is to be rammed through Albany next week because both Republicans and Democrats think it will help them win a heated State Senate contest in Rockland and Orange Counties. Democrats are also eager to embarrass Mayor Rudolph Giuliani. They want Mr. Giuliani, a Republican, to beg to keep the tax on the very suburbanites whose support he will be seeking in his campaign for United States Senate.

title: OFFICER TESTIFIES AGAINST HIS PEERS
description: The first police officer said to have come forward with information about the Abner Louima case provided a vivid account yesterday of the scene at a Brooklyn station house, testifying that one of the officers on trial emerged, agitated and brandishing a stick, from a restroom area where prosecutors say Mr. Louima was brutalized.

title: Plan Announced for New Criminal Courthouse for Manhattan
description: When the city unveiled its new Manhattan Criminal Courthouse at 100 Centre Street in 1941, about 31,690 defendants passed through its doors each year. Now, the Manhattan courts process more than 144,000 criminal cases a year, and officials are forced to send criminal cases into nearby buildings originally intended to handle civil cases and housing disputes.

title: Naval Officer Is Nominated Ambassador To Beijing
description: Ending a six-month search, President Clinton plans to nominate Adm. Joseph W. Prueher to be the next Ambassador to Beijing, a choice that the Administration hopes will signal the importance of working with China on critical national security issues dividing it from the United States, White House officials said today.

title: Ex-Livent Chief Says He Was Too Busy to Keep Its Accounts
description: Garth H. Drabinsky, the Canadian impresario who founded Livent Inc., said in court papers filed yesterday that he had been too caught up in the details of producing Broadway musicals like ''Ragtime'' to have had time to help keep the company's accounting books, which have been found to be false.

title: Sudden Deal Saves Gardens Set for Auction
description: A day before the Giuliani administration was to auction off city-owned lots that had been transformed into community gardens, the performer Bette Midler had her private conservation organization agree to buy dozens of the less desirable parcels, providing the final financing to preserve all 112 gardens that were set for sale.

title: 5th Term Is Opposed for Head of Weather Agency
description: A contentious campaign is under way over who will head the United Nations agency that tries to predict global weather disasters, with accusations of mismanagement and cronyism surrounding the current Secretary General's bid to secure a fifth term.

title: Now Playing in Los Angeles: 'Have Warehouse, Will Remodel'
description: With fast growth and turnover among young creative companies in new media, animation and advertising, there is a surge in warehouse remodeling in Los Angeles. Competition to top one another is high. See-and-be-seen is the theme at the new Marina del Rey home of Ground Zero, a five-year-old advertising agency, featuring glass-topped desks and a processional ramp that leads through an open, converted warehouse to a reception desk at the back. ''Having to walk through the entire space before you get to the beginning reflects our approach -- to peel away the outer layers of a brand to get to its soul,'' said Kirk Souder, a Ground Zero partner. Shubin & Donaldson Architects turned the building, a former sound stage, into an industrial-chic space with a bow-truss ceiling and meeting rooms (left) partitioned by ribbed plastic and steel walls. The ramp (below) begins in the parking lot and leads up the side into the second level before dropping. Ground Zero is a raw, more democratic (no one has his or her own office) variant of the TBWA/ Chiat/Day offices in Playa del Rey, also a village within a warehouse. FRANCES ANDERTON

title: Does 'Diversity' Improve Colleges?
description: To the Editor:

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: Casting for Trout and Catching a Bit of England
description: THE COMPLETE ANGLER

title: Sex Activity Complaints Prompt Lot Closings
description: The state will close three parking lots at Higby Beach Wildlife Management Area for the summer on May 24 because of complaints about sexual activity there, officials said.

title: Garden Q.& A.
description: Fragrance Saving

title: The Times Selects Chief Of News Services Division
description: The appointment of Thomas K. Carley as president of the News Services division at The New York Times was announced yesterday. He was previously director of business development for the division.

title: Tentative Accord Reached On Emergency Spending Bill
description: Ignoring their leaders' wishes to hold the spending down, Congressional negotiators tentatively agreed on Wednesday to spend $11.7 billion in emergency money to finance the fighting in Yugoslavia and a host of Pentagon programs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCKERNAN, JOSEPH PATRICK
description: McKERNAN-Joseph Patrick. On May 11, 1999. Beloved husband of Barbara (nee Flannery). Devoted father of Joseph and Jennifer. Loving son of Winifred McKernan. Beloved brother of Thomas McKernan, Ellen Yeaw and Kathleen Cameron. Also survived by many nieces and nephews. Visiting Leo. F. Kearns Inc, 6140 Woodhaven Boulevard, Rego Park, Thursday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Mass St. Margaret R.C. Church, on Friday, 10:30 AM. Interment in St. Charles Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations to Cabrini Hospice or Pancan would be appreciated.

title: Yeltsin Warns West It Must Accept Russia's Proposals on Kosovo : Moscow Shake-Up Clouds Peace Effort
description: WASHINGTON  Diplomatic efforts to resolve the Kosovo crisis were plunged into uncertainty Wednesday by the dismissal of the Russian prime minister, Yevgeni Primakov, one day after China and Russia demanded that NATO halt the air campaign against Yugoslavia.

title: Promoting Mother Goose Electronically
description: WHEN some parents and teachers bewail a loss of cultural heritage, they are not talking about knowing when the Civil War was or being able to pick Andrew Jackson out of a line-up.

title: MacMillan: 2 Nights, 2 Lovers, 2 Styles
description: Star-crossed lovers turned strong feelings into beautiful dancing in two performances of Kenneth MacMillan's ''Romeo and Juliet'' at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about a bus accident in New Orleans referred incorrectly in some copies to the number of people killed in a 1976 accident in Yuba City, Calif. That crash, the worst in the nation's history, killed 29, not 53.

title: LEADERS IN ALBANY PLAN TO ELIMINATE TAX ON COMMUTERS
description: Gov. George E. Pataki and legislative leaders promised unexpectedly today to eliminate a 33-year-old income tax for many suburban residents who hold jobs in New York City, disregarding Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's contention that those workers should help shoulder the cost of police and other city services.

title: A Dream Is but a Few Steps Away
description: When Joerg Kircheis, a Manhattan architect, wanted to maximize space in his city and country homes, he built loft beds. In the city, he lives and works in a 450-square-foot co-op apartment on the Upper West Side. By building two loft beds, the most clever of which is at top, he transformed a one-bedroom apartment into a two-bedroom home and office. The work area is behind the blue wall. One of the loft beds is above and to the left of the ladder. The loft is 7 feet wide, 10 feet deep and 5 feet high.

title: Denver's Tireless Patrons Enjoy the Art of City Living
description: Here amid the hubbub of Lower Downtown's hip eateries and art galleries, two and a half blocks from Coors Field baseball stadium and just blocks from the daytime hangout for many of Denver's transients, Frederick and Jan Mayer bought a parking lot and built the first private single-family residence to rise in this old industrial district in a century.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: BROOKSTONE INC., Nashua, N.H., the specialty retailer, agreed to buy the Gardeners Eden catalogue business from Williams-Sonoma Inc. for an undisclosed amount.

title: Tomorrow's Decoration, Today's Demolition
description: While minimalists may shrink from decorating with salvage, there's always a need for a good solid door. Demolition Depot, at 216 East 125th Street in Harlem, offers five floors of recycled architectural elements, from wood paneled doors (below, from $100) to shower rods ($10 to $15). An offshoot of Irreplaceable Artifacts, an East Village repository of glamorous salvage (bois de Versailles flooring, San Simeon leftovers), the new store stocks second-tier fixtures that would have landed in the dump. ''So many people wanted to buy stuff right off the trucks as we were unloading that we decided to make it a store,'' said Evan Blum (above) the owner, who had intended a warehouse.

title: Beverly Hills Turns Down Sales Tag Telling Fur Buyers of Gruesome Animal Deaths
description: Beverly Hills voters have overwhelmingly rejected a proposal to require that fur coats sold here carry a tag describing the grisly ways that animals used to make them may have been killed.

title: Infidelity and Forgiveness
description: To the Editor:

title: Does 'Diversity' Improve Colleges?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRAVELL, CLARK
description: TRAVELL-Clark, of Ponte Vedre Beach, FL, on May 9, 1999. Loving father of Susan, Blair, Jill and Phyllis. Devoted grandfather of seven; great-grandfather of two. Princeton Class of '45 graduate. B26 pilot in WW2. Long association with Austral Oil Company and trustee of Browning School, NYC. Memorial contributions to 320th Bomb Group Reunion Association, 4095A Palm Bay Circle, West Palm Beach, FL 33406-4088.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-16

title: A Contest Is On in Britain To Revolutionize Cable TV
description: Something is stirring behind Britain's television screens and its name is Microsoft.

title: Steamy Computer Chips Like The Touch of Refrigeration
description: The rush for faster desktop computers took a big leap forward last week when the chip maker Advanced Micro Devices demonstrated a version of its K7 computer chip running at a cool 1 gigahertz (1,000 MHz). The computer was able to run that fast because a special refrigeration system built by Kryotech removed most of the extra heat that would normally have caused the computer to malfunction.

title: Trade War Looms Over Hormone Beef Ban as EU Reiterates Health Fears
description: BRUSSELS  The European Union is poised to set off a trade war by ignoring a Thursday deadline set by the World Trade Organization to lift its 10-year ban on foreign beef produced with growth hormones.

title: Flynt Pleads Guilty in Ohio Obscenity Case
description: Larry Flynt, who has been battling the legal authorities in Cincinnati for two decades, pleaded guilty today to two counts of pandering obscenity in a deal that allows him to avoid any jail time.

title: Essay; Boris Strikes Again
description: On the eve of Bill Clinton's impeachment, the President of the U.S. changed the subject by firing missiles. On the eve of Boris Yeltsin's impeachment, the President of Russia dominated the news by firing another of his Prime Ministers. Both stunts were briefly effective; the Russian way is cheaper.

title: A Life After Prison
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINHOUSE, MARTIN A.
description: WEINHOUSE-Martin A. Beloved husband of Eleanor (nee Rosenblatt). Adored father of Dr. George Robert and Alan. Devoted brother of Muriel. Dear brother-inlaw of Sandra and Leon Rosenblatt. Uncle of Geri, Steven and Alisa. Funeral service Thursday, 12 noon, Plaza Memorial, 91st Street and Amdsterdam Avenue.

title: Saul Steinberg, Epic Doodler, Dies at 84
description: Saul Steinberg, the metaphysically minded artist and cartoonist and brooding doodler whose drawings appeared in The New Yorker for more than half a century, elevating comic illustration to fine art, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 84.

title: Once Again, Loretta Lynn Has Singin' On Her Mind
description: ''I just started going back on the road last year,'' said Loretta Lynn, her voice twanging in double-time over the telephone from her Nashville home. ''My husband was down for five years before he died, and I was with him. So I didn't work.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORDON, IRVING L.
description: GORDON-Irving L. Formerly of Brooklyn. On May 12, 1999 at age 84, in Dallas, TX. Beloved husband of Lois. Father of Meryl and Scott Nason, Jesse and Wendy, and Reena. Grandfather of Joshua and Naomi Nason and Elliott Gordon. Funeral 11AM Fri, May 14th, Old Montefiore Cemetery, Queens.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: No Third Degree For the Quindlens

title: Bomb Threat at Upstate School Forces Out Lieutenant Governor
description: Lieut. Gov. Mary O. Donohue was escorted out of an upstate high school yesterday afternoon after a bomb threat interrupted a discussion that she was having with students about the issue of school violence. The 1,900 students at Schenectady High School, however, were not evacuated while the building was searched.

title: Knicks' Perfect Night Has Heat Grasping
description: It was as if Latrell Sprewell had thrown a match down on the court just before the half and a flame quickly spread throughout the building. By the middle of the third quarter, the crowd looked on fire as they twirled their orange towels over their heads like helicopter blades and nearly lifted Madison Square Garden off its foundation.

title: NBC Faulted On Deletions In TV Film
description: NBC removed references to the transportation of nuclear waste from a television movie it will broadcast this Sunday night, citing inaccuracies in the depiction of how nuclear waste is handled.

title: Albany's Part-Timers
description: To the Editor:

title: Oxford Health Turnaround Is Still a Work in Progress
description: After a year on the turnaround track, Oxford Health Plans has backed away from the brink of bankruptcy by shedding thousands of loss-making members and raising the premiums paid by the customers who remained. But the big managed care company is still reporting a substantial cash-flow loss on operations and still struggling with the dysfunctional computer systems that nearly sank the company.

title: Van Gogh Sparkles in Christie's Evening of Surprisingly Strong Prices
description: Christie's inaugurated the main salesroom in its new Rockefeller Center home last night with an auction of 40 Impressionist and 19th-century artworks that was so strong it surprised even the most seasoned experts.

title: Lots of Agony, Little Ecstasy
description: The phone rang, and the writer Pat Jordan was saying that the experience of publishing his latest book, soon to be in stores, was rather like being smote on the head with a bong starter, and while what is happening to him was an extreme case, to be sure, it was leaving him wobbly in the knees and the mind. All he could do, he said, was take it with a caress of dark humor, assuring himself that in the end authorship isn't really as horrible as book publishing sometimes makes it.

title: Nets All but Packed to Leave The Meadowlands for Newark
description: The Nets are focused on a proposal to move to a $200 million downtown Newark arena and have all but informed the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority that they will leave the Meadowlands Sports Complex.

title: Election Could Affect Slovakia's Emergence From Isolation
description: Seven months after dumping Vladimir Meciar as Prime Minister and putting their small Central European country back on track for membership in the European Union and even NATO, Slovaks are again tussling over whether Mr. Meciar should have a share of power.

title: Does 'Diversity' Improve Colleges?
description: To the Editor:

title: Gang Members Indicted In Drug and Gun Sales
description: Thirty-five members of a street gang were indicted yesterday in connection with illegal sales of guns, drugs and stolen cars.

title: Curbing Jennys and Jerrys Without Curbing Rights
description: The Jenny Jones case is guaranteed to try the patience of defenders of free speech. By all the rules of First Amendment advocacy, Warner Brothers, which owns ''The Jenny Jones Show,'' should have won its case. Instead it was ordered to pay $25 million in damages to the family of a homosexual man, Scott Amedure, who announced during a taping of the show that he had a crush on another guest, his friend Jonathan T. Schmitz; a few days later, before the show was broadcast, Mr. Schmitz, who apparently is not homosexual, shot and killed Mr. Amedure.

title: Loyola Has Tough Road
description: Loyola of Maryland was the only men's team to go through the regular season unbeaten and was therefore ranked No. 1 and seeded No. 1 for the Division 1 tournament, which begins tomorrow. But the Greyhounds gained no favor from the National Collegiate Athletic Association committee that selected the field of 12 last Sunday.

title: Board Approves $7 Billion School Construction Plan in 4-to-3 Vote
description: With a turf war among borough politicians and between the Mayor and the Schools Chancellor still smoldering, the city's Board of Education adopted a $7 billion school construction plan yesterday that calls for the equivalent of 34 new schools to be built over the next five years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIPTON, LOUIS J.
description: LIPTON-Louis J. The Board of Trustees and the staff of The Aldrich Museum of Contemporary Art lament the loss of our esteemed trustee and generous supporter, Louis J. Lipton. We pass on our deepest condolences to his wife and family.

title: Season Opens to Belmont Faithful, Old and New
description: The kids are learning to count, Andrea Phillips figured. So why not get them started on handicapping?

title: Pruning With a Specialist's Touch
description: IT'S a matter of finding the tree in the tree,'' said William Miller, 41, an arborist who started a tree business on Long Island 13 years ago and does what amounts to behavioral analysis on each plant he prunes. ''When we first look at a tree, we look for what to encourage, what to discourage,'' he said. ''We want to accentuate forms, allow them to stand out. And we're also manipulating light.''

title: The Sommelier's Closet
description: The Sub-Zero refrigerator has siblings: four wine-storage units, each of which can maintain two different temperature zones. Crisp whites can be stored at around 48 degrees; fat, red Burgundies at around 61 degrees. The units, from an under-counter model that holds 46 bottles to a full-size one (left) for 147 bottles, sell for $1,650 to $4,500, excluding paneling, and can be ordered at (800) 222-7820 for October delivery. ELAINE LOUIE

title: Doctors' Review of 5 Deaths Raises Concern About the Safety of Liposuction
description: A team of doctors in New York is questioning the safety of liposuction, the immensely popular cosmetic surgery in which body fat is suctioned out through a tube to get rid of ''thunder thighs,'' ''love handles,'' pot bellies and other hated bulges.

title: Bette Midler Chips In To Rescue Gardens
description: A day before the Giuliani administration planned to auction city-owned lots that had been transformed into community gardens, the performer Bette Midler had her private conservation organization agree to buy dozens of the less desirable parcels, providing the final financing to preserve all 112 gardens set for sale.

title: Rated by Technology
description: To the Editor:

title: Attack Ads Roil Mayoral Contest in Philadelphia
description: It was the kind of day politicians locked in a close race only dream of. John F. Street, the former City Council president who is one of five Democrats running for mayor of Philadelphia, awoke on Tuesday morning to a long and ''heartfelt endorsement'' in the city's largest newspaper, The Philadelphia Inquirer.

title: Residential Sales
description: Manhattan

title: On China, Time To Face Reality
description: To the Editor:

title: The Big City; Bar Sinister: Lawyers Earn Public's Wrath
description: THE Abner Louima case has inspired diverse emotions, but there is one feeling shared by New Yorkers of every race, class and political persuasion. We all cringe at the lawyers.

title: Candidate for Beijing
description: Ending a six-month search, President Clinton plans to nominate Adm. Joseph W. Prueher as Ambassador to China. At least six former officials had declined the post.

title: Seoul Journal; Flower Shop as Symbol: Women's Careers in Bud
description: As Choi Yang Sook saw it, her place was in the home, cooking for her husband and cleaning up the house and raising their children.

title: A Winner in Las Vegas And a Hand to Show Why
description: The strongest pair event in the United States and arguably in the world is the annual Cavendish Calcutta, now played in Las Vegas after a long stint in Manhattan. These were the final standings when play ended on Sunday:

title: From 140 Pounds to 147, Mosley Wants It All
description: Shane Mosley, the International Boxing Federation lightweight champion, has decided to abandon the 135-pound division and move up to 140 pounds with an eye toward a bout in December against Oscar De La Hoya, the World Boxing Council welterweight champion, at 147 pounds.

title: Three Is a Crowd for Giants' Hamilton
description: Conrad Hamilton started 16 games at cornerback last season for the Giants. He was rarely beaten by opposing receivers and was second on the team in tackles with 91.

title: EXCEL LEGACY MAKES AN OFFER FOR PRICE ENTERPRISES
description: The Excel Legacy Corporation said yesterday that it had offered to buy Price Enterprises Inc., a real estate investment trust formed by the discount-warehouse pioneer Sol Price, for $8.50 a share, or a total of $116 million, in cash or a combination of cash and notes for Price's common stock. Both companies are based in San Diego. The announcement was made after Excel Legacy shares closed at $5, up 12.5 cents. Excel Legacy would also assume $360 million of Price's preferred stock and $115 million of debt. Excel said holders of 51 percent of Price's stock, including Sol Price, had agreed to vote their shares in favor of a merger. Price was spun off from the Costco Companies in 1997. It owns 31 shopping centers, anchored mainly by Costco stores.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEIN, MELVIN
description: KLEIN-Melvin. On May 11, 1999. Dearest love of wife Elaine, (nee Laks) of 47-1/2 years, most cherished father to Amy Klein and Cyd Tomack, darling grandfather to Brooke and Taylor Tomack, dear brother of Lorna Bernstein and dear nephew to Lee Feiner. Service at the ''Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue, Friday, May 14th, at 10:45 AM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRUNDMAN, RHODA
description: GRUNDMAN-Rhoda. The Board of Directors, faculty and staff of CLAL-The National Jewish Center for Learning and Leadership, extend deepest condolences to Jayne Beker, her husband Harvey and the entire family on the passing of Jayne's beloved mother, Rhoda Grundman. May her inspiration enhance the life of her family and may they be comforted by her loving memory. Barbara B. Friedman, Chairman Rabbi Irwin Kula, President Donna M. Rosenthal, Executive Vice Chairman

title: Accounts
description: * CNN, Atlanta and New York, part of Time Warner Inc., to Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos, Boston, part of the Interpublic Group, as its agency of record, for assignments that had been handled in-house and by various agencies on a project basis. Billings were estimated at $20 million to $25 million.

title: GOLDMAN SACHS IN $35 MILLION DEAL FOR SUBPRIME LENDER
description: The Southern Pacific Funding Corporation, a subprime lender based in Lake Oswego, Ore., has agreed to be acquired by an affiliate of Goldman Sachs Group Inc. for $35 million plus half the cash flow from certain of its assets, including mortgage loan pool certificates. According to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the sale will be completed as part of a reorganization plan by Southern Pacific, which sought Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection last October. Before completion of the sale, part of Southern Pacific's remaining assets will be distributed to a liquidating trust established for the benefit of company creditors. As a subprime lender, Southern Pacific makes mortgage loans to people with spotty credit histories.

title: Here's What Hit the Heat: A 32-2 Run
description: It was as unforeseeable as the harmony on the court between Latrell Sprewell and Allan Houston. With about four and a half minutes left in the second quarter last night, something struck the Miami Heat. Its execution became shabby, its shooting stroke went cold and its hopes of taking control of this series vanished.

title: Old Fogy Hoedown
description: SIX degrees of separation reached the melting point at the Harvard Club this week when Harrison Ford introduced a lecture on George Washington to benefit the famously idiosyncratic house of John Soane in London.

title: Rage at U.S. Is Sign of Deeper Issues
description: Most ordinary people in China have a double-barreled view of the United States, filtered by sharply competing emotions: admiration and suspicion, hope and fear, love and hate.

title: Dinner Just Off the Lobby
description: ''DINNER, madame, is being served in the dining room.''

title: LVMH Acquires Cosmetics Maker
description: LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton S.A., the French luxury-goods company, said today that it had purchased Hard Candy, a United States cosmetics maker aimed at the teen-age market.

title: It's Not Rocket Science, Maybe
description: Space experts are scratching their heads over a paralyzing series of rocket failures that have disrupted both military and civilian launches. In the last nine months there have been six serious failures of American rockets that have destroyed or nullified some $3.5 billion worth of intelligence, imaging and communications satellites. Four of the failures occurred in the past five weeks. This is the most serious launching crisis since the explosion of the space shuttle Challenger and other rocket failures in the 1980's.

title: Smart Technologies Sale
description: I2 Technologies Inc., which makes software that helps companies schedule manufacturing, agreed to buy Smart Technologies Inc. for about $68 million in stock, adding a new range of Internet-based services. I2 will exchange 2.1 million shares of its stock for all of the closely held Smart Technologies' stock and outstanding options. The Dallas-based company said the purchase price was based on its closing price on Tuesday of $31.625. Smart, of Austin, Tex., makes Internet-based customer-service software.

title: Opening Day Draws Only 7,526 Fans
description: With many of the 7,526 fans lingering outside in Belmont Park's expanded backyard on a warm and sunny afternoon, the track's quarter-mile-long grandstand seemed empty and cavernous on the opening day of its 55-day meet.

title: Handwritten Signatures That Can Open Digital Doors
description: A Silicon Valley start-up company is marketing a biometrics system that enables you to attach your signature to digital documents or sign your way into a secured Web site.

title: Earnings Rise at Federated and Kmart
description: Federated Department Stores Inc., which owns Macy's and other department stores, and the Kmart Corporation, the nation's second-largest discount retailer, said yesterday that their first-quarter profits rose as they sold more clothes and home furnishings and held down costs.

title: Senate Narrowly Rejects Plan To Restrict Gun-Show Sales
description: The Senate today narrowly defeated a Democratic measure that would have tightened regulations on the sale of firearms at gun shows, a clear illustration of lawmakers' limited appetite for gun control even after the school shooting in Littleton, Colo.

title: House Passes Bill Limiting Year 2000 Liability
description: Voting largely along party lines, the House of Representatives approved legislation today that would limit lawsuits arising from Year 2000 computer failures.

title: A Souped-Up Search Engine Uses a Network to Get Results
description: Editor's Note Appended

title: 33 Charged In Banker's Fraudulent Loan Scheme
description: He was a former loan officer at NatWest with a master's degree in finance. But Federal prosecutors say that Gary J. Confredo became a sham artist, helping clients who lacked credit -- including a part-time dancer at Chippendales -- to obtain $20 million in illegal loans from 11 banks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REINHARDT, ALFRED N.
description: REINHARDT-Alfred N., age 89. Beloved father, grandfather and great-grandfather, died at his home on May 11th in Miami Beach, Florida, where he has resided for the past seven years with his partner, Ruth Durlacher. He was a seeker and, at the age of 17, came to the U.S., where eventually he became a fine photographer and a skilled boatsman. Until his retirement he was co-owner of the Astoria Photo Service in Queens, Commander in the Great Neck Power Squadron and Commodore of the Sands Point Yacht Club. He was a widower of Flora Reinhardt and is survived by two daughters and sons-in-law, Joan and Mark Reiss of San Francisco, and Joyce and Irwin Spiegel of Lawrenceville, New Jersey; four grandchildren, Felice Ciccione, Warren Kudman, Craig Reiss, and Justine Reiss; and five great-grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions in his memory to the hospice, Vitas Healthcare Corp., 3700 Executive Way, Miramar, Florida 33025.

title: Updating the Russian Who's Who
description: Boris Yeltsin's sudden dismissal of Prime Minister Yevgeny Primakov may seem like an ill-conceived move by an impulsive and frail leader who has been backed into a corner by the Communist-dominated Parliament threatening to impeach him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINK, SAM H.
description: FINK-Sam H. Died peacefully in his home on May 11, 1999, at the age of 92. He will be sorely missed by all who knew him. He was proud to have served under General Patton in The 244th Field Artillery. He is survived by his two sons and their families, Stephen, Kathy and Rachel Fink, of Manhattan, and Marvin, Helene, Jessica, and Jeremy Fink, of Brooklyn, and his sister, Rose Braunstein, of Florida. The family sincerely thanks all who have contributed to making his final years meaningful, his friends and neighbors, the members of Zichron Moshe Synagogue, and his co-workers at Simpson, Thacher and Bartlett. For information about shiva calls, please call 212-663-2754. Contributions may be made to Morris Dees Southern Poverty Law Center, 400 Washington Avenue, Montgomery, AL 36104.

title: 109 Years of a Well-Worn National Treasure
description: THE COMPLETE NATIONAL GEOGRAPHIC

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEFF, I. BERNARD
description: LEFF-I. Bernard. May 6, age 90+. Beloved husband of the late Rose. Devoted father of Sandra and her husband Michel Kanter. Donations to Stroke Connection, 800-553-6321.

title: Arthur Andersen Cleared by Jury of Fraud
description: Arthur Andersen L.L.P., the second-largest accounting firm, will not have to pay damages to stockholders of UDC Homes Inc. after an Arizona jury found the firm did not defraud the home builder's investors.

title: Abbott Labs Awarded $1 Billion Contract
description: Abbott Laboratories, one of the top United States makers of medical devices and tests, said today that it had a contract valued as much as $1 billion over five years with Novation, a supplier to health care providers.

title: Expanding on 'Powers of Ten' To Convey Eameses' Genius
description: POWERS OF TEN INTERACTIVE

title: Snow White for the Summer
description: GRAB your goggles or your sunglasses. A blizzard of white sheets and curtains is ushering in the summer season. And why not? White is the perfect backdrop for the minimalist, the classicist -- even the floral fanatic. ABC Carpet and Home, with a 20 percent increase in white bed linen sales in the last year, is devoting 2,500 square feet solely to white sheets, said Evan Cole, ABC's president. They don't call them white sales for nothing.

title: Mr. Rubin Leaves the Treasury
description: Robert E. Rubin's decision to step aside as Treasury Secretary was responsibly timed in that the major crises in the world now are not primarily economic. Nonetheless he will be missed, in part because he anchored a changing cast of Cabinet and White House officials. The American economy -- and those of many other countries -- might be in far worse shape had not his expertise and calm determination helped steer the Clinton Administration's economic policies for six years.

title: Veteran Who Strides Into Thickets of Trade Policy
description: When Bill Clinton became the first Democrat in a dozen years to move into the White House, the party's cognoscenti saw the treatment of Stuart E. Eizenstat as a sign of the young Administration's disdain for the political skills of the old crowd of former top aides to Jimmy Carter.

title: One-Acters, From Poignant to Witty to Wilde
description: Mark Feuerstein steals the show in ''All About Al,'' which is clearly set at a Starbucks. As Lenny, the kind of jittery, insecure young man who Bill Gates might have been if he hadn't earned a gazillion dollars, Mr. Feuerstein -- who starred in the unpleasant, short-lived NBC sitcom ''Conrad Bloom'' -- reacts in horror as his friend Gil (Mark Giordano) announces his intention to break up with his terrific girlfriend.

title: China Pauses As Remains Of Victims Return Home
description: The ashes of the three Chinese killed by NATO bombs in Belgrade returned to China today, carried off the airplane by relatives wearing white flowers of mourning in a sad procession shown repeatedly on national television.

title: In America; Mississippi Learning
description: I stood beside the cotton field in the morning quiet of the Delta and listened to the echoes of the tortured souls from years and decades and centuries past. To enter Mississippi has always been, in my view, to descend to a lower place, a world of fanatical race hatred in which blacks were condemned by whites to a perpetual state of humiliation and often gruesome suffering.

title: A Literary Gala Persists Through the Din of Protest
description: The taxi stopped at the curb on East 42d Street. Victor Gotbaum, one of the city's best-known labor leaders, and his wife, Betsy Gotbaum, the president of the New-York Historical Society, climbed out.

title: Revolving Prime Ministers
description: Boris Yeltsin has given new meaning to an old Kremlin post, the disposable prime minister. Yevgeny Primakov is the latest, dismissed yesterday ostensibly for failing to revive the economy. The actual reason is doubtless more byzantine. Like Mr. Yeltsin's previous decapitations, the removal of Mr. Primakov and his Cabinet leaves Moscow's domestic and foreign policies in disarray.

title: Metro Business; Ruling for Gambinos In Suit Over Broker
description: A Manhattan court has barred a former broker from selling his home after he was accused of stealing $2 million from two reputed members of the Gambino organized crime family.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; S.E.C. sweep focuses on bogus securities offerings on the Web.
description: ONE company promised to turn iron-ore rocks into gold, generating profits of 2,600 percent a year. Another sought money to construct prefabricated hospitals in Turkey. A third offered an opportunity to invest alongside the original backers of Microsoft and Intel in a new venture that would sell software to operate Web sites.

title: Stricter Standards? Get S.U.V.'s Off the Road
description: To the Editor:

title: Old-New Granny Chic Is Rocking the Home
