description: HOME furnishing design is having a senior moment.

title: Like Beijing, Taiwan Courts Trade Forum
description: While international attention has been focused on Beijing's effort to join the World Trade Organization, Taiwan has quietly been moving ahead with its own application.

title: A Democrat Who's Kept Hands Clean
description: Sergei Vadimovich Stepashin, President Boris N. Yeltsin's fourth choice as Prime Minister in less than a year, is best known loyalty to his boss. But that description does not do him justice.

title: Colorado Man Is Suspected Of Planning Mosque Attack
description: A 39-year-old man who the police say intended to ''incinerate'' Colorado's largest mosque, was arrested today after fleeing the site in a car loaded with bomb-making materials, four guns and 1,000 rounds of ammunition.

title: A Night of Beautiful Pitching, But Not the Kind Cone Enjoys
description: The Yankees must have looked like knuckleheads to those watching on television, Paul O'Neill mused after last night's loss to Anaheim, because Chuck Finley kept throwing pitches in the dirt and the Yankees kept swinging at them.

title: A Walkman-Style PC Leads the I.B.M. Lineup
description: COMPUTER and consumer electronics manufacturers invest considerable time and money exploring design ideas, trying to hit on the next Palm Pilot, I.B.M. Thinkpad or Motorola Startac cellular phone.

title: Manager to Depart Euro RSCG Chicago
description: Mary Baglivo, one of three top managers who have run Euro RSCG Tatham in Chicago, will resign, the agency has announced, for personal reasons and return with her family to New Jersey.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAMMOND, FLORENCE (PIERSON)
description: HAMMOND-Florence (Pierson), of Cambridge, MA, on May 11, age 90. Survived by her beloved husband, Mason Hammond; devoted daughters, Florence Phillips, Anstiss Krueck, Elizabeth Llewellyn; loving grandchildren, Victoria Drake, Valentine Snell, Mason Drake, Ascha Drake and Jonathan Phillips; great-granddaughter, Angelica Evan Cook. Memorial service will be held in Story Chapel, Mt. Auburn Cemetery, 580 Mt. Auburn St., Cambridge, Monday at 11 AM. Memorial contributions may be made to Harvard Neighbors, Harvard University, 17 Quincy St., Cambridge, MA 02138.

title: Rich Struggle for British Phone Carrier
description: It is Britain's smallest mobile phone company and has yet to turn a profit. But One 2 One has ignited a heated bidding war between Europe's biggest telecommunication companies.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: ORANGE JUICE RISES. Orange juice prices climbed after an Agriculture Department report predicted Florida's crop would be 23 percent smaller than last year's. In New York, orange juice rose 4 cents, to 86.55 cents a pound.

title: Upheaval in the Kremlin May Add Another Obstacle to Finding Peace Through Negotiation
description: The turmoil in Russia today appeared to represent another impediment to the Clinton Administration's hopes of finding a diplomatic end to the war in Kosovo.

title: Catherine Brandel, 56, Muse And Chef of California Cuisine
description: Catherine Brandel, one of the quiet forces behind the culinary tide called California cuisine, died on Tuesday night at her home in Berkeley, Calif. She was 56.

title: Officer in Street Peddler Inquiry Is Indicted
description: A police officer who told investigators that his unit of officers routinely seized watches, handbags and other goods from illegal street peddlers and then sold the merchandise was arrested and indicted yesterday.

title: Style to Which They're Accustomed
description: IN April, when today's graduation ceremonies in Washington Square were still a month away, Erika Shay and Carol Villegas had a little shock. The cheerful New York University seniors had just looked at apartments to share after graduation at an apartment building near University Hall, the new dormitory where they now live.

title: Loewen Group Says Profits Fell by 77% in First Quarter
description: Loewen Group Inc., North America's second-largest funeral home and cemetery operator, reported a 77 percent drop in first-quarter profit today and warned that without an improvement its creditors might force the sale or reorganization of the company under United States or Canadian bankruptcy laws.

title: HARVARD INDUSTRIES MAY SELL UNIT TO REDUCE DEBT
description: Harvard Industries, an auto parts supplier to Ford and General Motors, may sell its Kingston-Warren subsidiary to reduce debt and raise money for acquisitions. Harvard, which is based in Lebanon, N.J., hired Lehman Brothers to advise it on alternatives such as the sale of the unit, which makes molded rubber seals, weather stripping and plastic seals. Kingston-Warren, based in Newfields, N.H., has 1,300 employees and generated about $140 million of the company's 1998 revenue of $690 million. The company said it had identified possible companies to buy. Harvard, which has about $70 million in debt, emerged from Chapter 11 bankruptcy reorganization in late November.

title: Oh, to Be Down and Out Living on the Bowery; Artists' Cheap Lofts, Found Decades Ago, Are Threatened by Development Project
description: Forty years ago, decades before stretch limousines choked the Bowery, discharging luminaries lured to the Bowery Bar, long before it was remotely hip to live on the Lower East Side, much less Skid Row, Kate Millett moved to what she dubs the ''street of sorrows.''

title: Family Tree Maker Software Now Has 1.5 Billion Names
description: If you are one of those people who has been meaning to compile your family history since ''Roots'' was broadcast in 1977, help is on the way. Broderbund's just-released Family Tree Maker Deluxe Version 6.0 contains a whopping 15 CD-ROM's of genealogical information, and the program promises access to 1.5 billion names so you can ''Find Ancestors Guaranteed!''

title: On China, Time To Face Reality
description: To the Editor:

title: E. P. Abraham, 85, Biochemist Who Helped Develop Antibiotics
description: Sir Edward Penley Abraham, a British biochemist and Oxford University professor who contributed greatly to the development of today's medical arsenal of antibiotics, died on Sunday at his home in Oxford. He was 85.

title: Conagra Enlisting in the March Toward a Leaner Food Industry
description: Conagra Inc., one of the world's largest food companies, said late today that it would lay off up to 8.4 percent of its work force, or about 7,000 employees, and close dozens of production, distribution and storage sites as part of an effort to reduce costs and bolster lackluster earnings.

title: A Second Act for the TV Musical? Producers Bet on It
description: Nearly 25 years ago Neil Meron, a senior at Brooklyn College, invited Craig Zadan, a writer who had just completed a book about Stephen Sondheim, to present a lecture to students about Sondheim.

title: Gains Seen in Consumer Privacy on Internet
description: A new study of consumer privacy on the Internet shows that nearly two-thirds of commercial Web sites display some type of warning if they collect personal information, a sharp increase since last year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PATERSON, NETTIE
description: PATERSON-Nettie. Of North Bay Village, Florida, and formerly of Sea Gate, Brooklyn, New York. Beloved wife of the late Nat Paterson. Active in Hadassah, pride of Judea Childrens Home of Brooklyn and Sisterhood, Temple Beth El of North Bay Village. Survived by sons and daughters-in-law; Bruce and Marlene, Sidney and Rita, and Fran, grandchildren; Lisa and Ron Kusse, Eric, Lori and Donna and Seth Tropper, great grandchildren; Sondra and Sarah. Services held in Miami Beach.

title: Inside a Minimalist's Mind
description: Jasper Morrison (top) -- the 40-year-old Englishman who made minimalism the last word in furniture design in 1988 with a plywood chair that had only the barest of backs -- speaks his mind in ''Morrison'' (Editions Dis Voir, $23.50), by Charles-Arthur Boyer and Federica Zanco. Mr. Morrison, who showed the color-form cabinets for Cappellini (above) at the furniture fair in Milan last month, claimed influences from Tin Tin and early Walt Disney cartoons for his distillation of design ''into almost ridiculous simplicity,'' he told the authors. WILLIAM L. HAMILTON

title: Travel Agent or Travel Site? It Depends on the Trip
description: BEFORE she flew to Paris this spring, Mary Shane looked for travel help on the Internet. There, she was told (1) not to pack such French fashion no-nos as sneakers or blue jeans, (2) that the budget hotel she was considering was clean and conveniently located and (3) that the best price available for a round-trip airplane ticket was $600.

title: Gene Identified in Worm May Offer a Key to the Aging Process
description: The microscopic roundworm Caenorhabditis elegans, studied by many biologists as a model organism, does not live long: a mere three weeks if amply supplied with its favorite food, bacteria. But the little creature has become of keen interest to students of longevity because it will live up to four times as long when mutations are engineered in certain genes.

title: Window-Shopping at an International Fair
description: Think of it as a big dog show for design. There will be lots of odd breeds of form and function afoot at the International Contemporary Furniture Fair at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center, from Saturday through Tuesday, but the new and nicely behaved usually outweigh the biters and the barkers.

title: AstraZeneca Agrees To Sell Chemicals Unit
description: AstraZeneca P.L.C., the world's largest drug company, said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its specialty-chemicals division to Cinven Group Ltd. and Investcorp, both private equity investors, for $2.1 billion, quitting a business it put up for sale last year to focus on drugs. AstraZeneca, the maker of the anti-ulcer drug Losec and Zestril for hypertension, said it would book an after-tax profit of $150 million on the sale.

title: YELTSIN DISMISSES HIS PRIME MINISTER IN A NEW SHAKE-UP
description: Ever the gambler, President Boris N. Yeltsin abruptly fired Prime Minister Yevgeny M. Primakov today, pushing Russia to the brink of a new political crisis.

title: A Key Architect Of Prosperity
description: There is a case to be made that his approach worsened the global financial crisis of the last few years. He could be politically tone-deaf, as when he initially resisted efforts in Congress a year and half ago to overhaul the Internal Revenue Service. At times he was stubborn and turf-conscious, traits on display in his continuing battle with the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, to preserve the Treasury Department's powers as a bank regulator.

title: Prosecution Witness Pierces 'Blue Wall of Silence'
description: The prosecutors called their next witness. Detective Eric S. Turetzky entered the courtroom, an F.B.I. agent at his side, and nodded at the five defendants, all fellow New York City police officers, who knew that what he was about to say might help send them to prison for years.

title: New Cement System Reins In Runaway Plane
description: A twin-engine commuter plane that touched down too close to the end of a runway at Kennedy International Airport was stopped from plunging into a tidal bay by a prototype ''arresting system,'' a kind of flypaper for runaway airplanes. Federal officials said today that it saved the lives of the people on board.

title: Yeltsin, Back to the Wall, Takes His Brashest Risk
description: Encircled by leftist opponents and reduced almost to a cipher in opinion polls, clearly ill and on the brink of impeachment, Boris N. Yeltsin rose today to dismiss a Government he had never embraced and to try once again to position himself as Russia's savior.

title: Heinz Werner Berendes, 74, Pioneer in the Care of Newborns
description: Heinz Werner Berendes, a pediatrician and medical epidemiologist for the National Institutes of Health who pioneered studies of birth-control safety and the care of newborns, died on May 6 at the N. I. H. Clinical Center in suburban Maryland. He was 74 and lived in Bethesda, Md.

title: Coalition Says State Lags on Clean Water
description: A coalition of environmental groups said yesterday that the State Department of Environmental Protection had failed to fulfill its three basic enforcement duties under the Federal Clean Water Act of 1972.

title: 2B + 2H + 2F = A 1990's New York Design for Living
description: QUESTION: How long does it take to put together a three-bedroom, two-bathroom apartment in the heart of Greenwich Village, with three working fireplaces and a terrace, overlooking an Italianate inner garden, and all for a total of $234,000? Answer: 21 years.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''If I'm a young Serb soldier, eating my lunch at two o'clock in the afternoon and out of the gray skies over my head comes a hundred plus Mark-82s, that ought to be a signal that we're entering a new phase of the air campaign and we're taking the gloves off a little more.''

title: Corrections
description: A picture yesterday with an article about Israeli voters' views of the national election on May 17 carried an incorrect caption. The picture showed the town of Ashkelon, where many Russian and Ethiopian immigrants have settled, not Jerusalem.

title: Rubin Resigning as Treasury Secretary
description: Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin, the chief architect of the Clinton Administration's economic policy during one of the strongest periods of American prosperity in decades as well as financial turmoil abroad, announced today that he was resigning.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WETTACH, MICHAEL F.
description: WETTACH-Michael F. The Board of Trustees and staff of The Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation deeply mourn the loss of Michael F. Wettach. The son of Fred Wettach, Jr., and Barbara Guggenheim and grandson of Solomon R. Guggenheim, Michael joined the Board of Trustees of The Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation in 1957. He was a member of the Executive and Finance Committee from 1958 to 1965, and a member of the Art and Museum Committee from 1958 to 1999. Michael was a generous donor to the Museum, and a trusted and valued friend. He is survived by his partner of 21 years, Robert C. Ludwig of Monkton, MD, his half-brother, Peter Lawson-Johnston of Princeton, NJ, three nieces, Wendy McNeil, Tania McCleery, and Mimi Howe of Princeton, Hopewell, and Tennington, NJ, respectively, and a nephew, Peter Lawson-Johnston II, of Greenwich, CT. A memorial service will be held on May 29 at St. James Church, Monkton, MD, at 4 PM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to The Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation, 1071 Fifth Avenue, New York, NY 10128. Peter Lawson-Johnston Honorary Chairman Peter B. Lewis, Chairman Ronald O. Perelman, President Thomas Krens, Director The Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundatio

title: A Life After Prison
description: To the Editor:

title: Ripken's Last Hurdle Is His Toughest
description: Michael Jordan, Wayne Gretzky, John Elway . . . Cal Ripken?

title: A Rejuvenated Sutton Playing as Well as Ever
description: The PGA Tour is in Texas this week, which means Hal Sutton is a good bet to play well.

title: On China, Time To Face Reality
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HESS, LEON
description: HESS-Leon. The Mount Sinai Children's Center Foundation extends heartfelt condolences to our board members Susan and John Hess on the passing of John's beloved father.

title: More on Star Wars
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAYLEY, JAMES E.
description: BAYLEY-James E. The Philosopy Department of City College mourns the loss of Professor James E. Bayley. For more than forty years, he served City College as a devoted teacher and an honorable colleague. Jim's scholarly writings, his teaching and his active participation in the College community all attest to his staunch character and his undying love for philosophy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, SHAYNE (SYLVIA)
description: FRIEDMAN-Shayne (Sylvia). On May 12, 1999. Deeply loved wife and best friend of Harold, adored Mommy of Melanie (Marc Melloment) and Bonnie (the late Jay Slotkin). Cherished Grandma of Jon, David and Sharon. She loved life. Services at Star of David, 7701 Bailey Road, North Lauderdale, Florida, on Friday, May 14th. 10:30AM. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Jay Slotkin Fund for Neuromuscular Research, Johns Hopkins Hospital, 600 North Wolfe St., Meyer 5-119, Baltimore, Maryland 21287.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REILLY, REV. JOHN H.
description: REILLY-Rev. John H. The Diocese of Brooklyn announces the death of the pastor of St. AnthonySt. Alphonsus Church, 862 Manhattan Avenue, Brooklyn, on May 12. Reposing at Leahy-McDonald Funeral Home, 111-02 Atlantic Avenue, Richmond Hill, Thursday, May 13, from 2 to 5 and 6 to 10 P.M. and on Friday, May 14, from 9 A.M. to 6 P.M. Funeral Mass Saturday, May 15, at 10:30 A.M. All priests are invited to concelebrate. He was a member of the Priests' Purgatorial Society. Most Rev. Thomas V. Daily Bishop of Brooklyn

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEIL, SIBYL
description: WEIL-Sibyl. May 11, 1999. Beloved and adored daughter of Hilde and Rudolf Littauer. Beloved sister of Andrew Littauer. Dear friend and sister-in-law of Wendy Weil.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR GAINS. The dollar rebounded from early volatility on expectations that the resignation of Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin would not disrupt the economy. In New York, the euro fell to $1.0653 from $1.0715 on Tuesday.

title: Knicks' Ol' Aches And Pains Chips In
description: The ice packs were off and the swelling had gone down. Patrick Ewing trudged toward the interview room favoring his left leg, dragging it gingerly behind the right one.

title: Bush's Run Casts a Shadow on a Hate Crimes Bill
description: Strange things happen in a state legislature when the governor becomes his party's front-runner in the next Presidential election. Everything is refracted through the national prism, which may be why a hate crimes bill named in honor of the black man who was dragged to death by whites in East Texas has unexpectedly emerged as one of the most emotional flash points of the current session.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANCHESTER, ELIZABETH ANN
description: LANCHESTER-Elizabeth Ann, 82, formerly of New York City and London, England, on May 11, 1999. Wife of the late Pilot Officer Henry Robert Lanchester, who was killed in action in 1941. She is survived by a son, Robert Lanchester, of Princeton, NJ, a daughter Christine Deirdre Champagne, of Littleton, NH, six grandchildren and a great grandson. Funeral service 4 P.M. Sunday May 16, 1999 at Trinity Church, Princeton, NJ.

title: Mets Chase Thomson, And Reed Hangs On
description: The pitching line was not particularly pretty. Nor was the bruise above Rick Reed's right hamstring. But Reed today became the Mets' first starting pitcher in four games to allow fewer than eight earned runs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STERN, BERNARD
description: STERN-Bernard. On May 12th, 1999. Beloved husband of Betty. Loving father of Henry and John. Cherished grandfather of Sean, Elissa and Joshua. Trustee of Joe and Emily Lowe Foundation of Palm Beach. Services Friday, 12:30 PM, at Menorah Gardens Funeral Home, West Palm Beach, FL.

title: Man Admits to Shooting New Jersey Policewoman
description: Condell Woodson, the fourth man taken into custody in the turbulent investigation into the shooting death of an Orange policewoman on April 8, pleaded guilty today to the murder and to robbery charges.

title: INSIDE
description: British Spy Scare

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PALAZZO, JEAN
description: PALAZZO-Jean. The Board, shareholders and staff of East 67 Tenants Corp extends heartfelt sympathies to Joseph Palazzo and his family on the loss of his beloved mother. Rita C. Chu, President

title: An Interactive Beauty Clinic Without the Hard Sales Pitch
description: TO brave the ground floor of any department store is to experience a confusing duality of inner yearning (for that tub of sumptuously colored goo or that architecturally masterful perfume bottle) and a take-no-prisoners defense against a sales force looking to spray, color test or exfoliate you within an inch of your life.

title: New Mini-Notebooks With Ample Keyboards
description: Mini-notebooks that easily slip in and out of briefcases are becoming increasingly attractive to business users and seemingly irresistible to manufacturers.

title: Senators Condemn Delay in Search of Atom Scientist's Computer
description: Senators told the top Energy Department lawyer today that they were baffled and appalled at the long delay in authorizing a search of the work computer of a scientist at Los Alamos National Laboratory suspected of spying for China.

title: Allied Air Chief Stresses Hitting Belgrade Sites
description: Despite the success allied warplanes are having against Serbian forces in Kosovo, NATO's top air war commander said today that the alliance needed to renew its attacks against the Yugoslav leadership in central Belgrade to force President Slobodan Milosevic to give in to NATO's demands.

title: USA Networks Drops Plan to Buy Lycos
description: USA Networks Inc., the media company run by Barry Diller, officially dropped its plan yesterday to buy Lycos Inc., the Internet search service, because of opposition from Lycos shareholders.

title: Sports of The Times; Speeches Don't Score Many Points
description: THE boulder came rolling down on Tim Hardaway and the Miami Heat last night, from the top of the mountain on which Pat Riley preaches. All the coaching axioms about force, work, desire and playing with pain merged into this huge rock that landed on Riley's team the way so many of its shots crashed into the rim.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEINBERG, SAUL
description: STEINBERG-Saul. The members of the American Academy of Arts and Letters note with sorrow the death of their esteemed colleague whose passing will be mourned by the world of art.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: CONSOLIDATED ACCEPTS DOMINION'S OFFER
description: The Consolidated Natural Gas Company has turned down a $6.7 billion unsolicited bid by Columbia Energy Group of Herndon, Va., and approved a revised $6.4 billion takeover offer from Dominion Resources Inc. of Richmond. Consolidated, which is based in Pittsburgh, said it preferred the Dominion deal owing to ''its certainty and timing'' and the strategic benefits of a gas and electric combination rather than a merger of two gas companies. Under the Dominion offer, which was revised late Tuesday, Consolidated shareholders will receive $66 a share in cash and common stock from Dominion. The combination will create one of the nation's biggest energy companies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCVEIGH, RUSSELL J.
description: McVEIGH-Russell J. Retired New York City Police Detective of Falmouth, MA, formerly of Montclair, NJ on May 12, 1999. Beloved husband of Betty. Dear father of Linda Beane, Patrick and Tracy McVeigh. Loving grandfather of five. Calling hours at Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, NY 2-4 and 7-9 PM Friday. Mass of Christian Burial St Mary's Church, Yonkers, NY on Saturday, May 15th at 10AM. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: Problem Bill for Bush
description: A hate crime bill has become a flash point in Texas, largely because Gov. George W. Bush is the Republican front-runner for the Presidential nomination. Some Democrats say his allies are trying to bottle up the bill to prevent his having to support it or oppose it publicly.

title: Pataki Defends Tougher Graduation Tests
description: Gov. George E. Pataki today strongly defended the stiffer graduation requirements that state education officials are seeking to impose on nearly all public high school students, and suggested that lawmakers should not try to water them down.

title: Police Unsure Park Death Is a Homicide, Despite Report
description: About the only thing the police can say for certain about the death of Matthew Herman, a 33-year-old magazine executive, is that it occurred about 7 P.M. on Sunday night in Central Park. Everything else about his death appears to be a mystery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVERSTEIN, SHEL
description: SILVERSTEIN-Shel. One Tennis Shoe, Poor Wanda, Japanese Doll and ''Mr. Right''. Thanks, Shel. Spaghetti will never be the same. Julia

title: Pollin Selling Capitals and Share of the Wizards
description: Abe Pollin, who poured millions of dollars into sports franchises that usually let him down by season's end, announced today that he was selling outright his hockey team, the Washington Capitals, and a minority interest in his other holdings, which include the Washington Wizards basketball team.

title: The Privacy Keys: How They Guard Secrets
description: Q. How does the PGP encryption software work?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VOGEL, WYNN E.
description: VOGEL-Wynn E. Mr. Erwin (Wynn) Vogel known as a true Renaissance man passed away Sunday, May 2nd, 1999. Mr. Vogel was an arranger and composer of music, a poet, a painter and designer, and an author of many ''how to'' books. A member of the Christian Science Youth Forum, Mr. Vogel was also an avid hiker. Wynn did it all, may he rest in peace.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: S.E.C. Sweep Uncovers Stock Frauds on Internet

title: 2 Salvadoran Generals Sued by Families of Slain Churchwomen
description: The families of four American churchwomen who were murdered in El Salvador more than 18 years ago have filed a wrongful-death lawsuit against two senior Salvadoran military officers who are now retired and living in Florida.

title: Unions Find Their Voice in a Rally at City Hall
description: In one of New York City's biggest labor rallies in decades, tens of thousands of union members marched past City Hall yesterday to demand that the city and state spend part of their budget surpluses on higher wages and on programs that help working families, like education and health care.

title: LESLIE FAY SAYS TWO FUNDS PLAN TO BUY A 51% STAKE
description: The Leslie Fay Company, the once-bankrupt New York apparel maker, said that two private investment funds planned to buy a 51 percent stake in it for as much as $23 million. The funds bought 2.16 million shares, or a 36 percent stake, for $6.95 a share from Dickstein Partners Inc., Leslie Fay's largest shareholder. The funds, advised by Three Cities Research Inc., may also buy 1.11 million shares for $7 a share in cash, the company said. Leslie Fay also said it planned to repurchase up to 1 million of its approximately 6 million shares outstanding for $7 a share. Its shares slipped 6.25 cents, to $6.3125.

title: New 'Star Wars' Trilogy, Episode I: The Wait for Tickets
description: They crossed continents and boroughs to find out how the story began. They spoke of their love of intergalactic heroes and the wonderment of distant planets. They camped out for days in sleeping bags.

title: Officer Gets 4 to 12 Years In Killing of Immigrant
description: A New York City police officer was sentenced yesterday to 4 to 12 years in prison for the off-duty killing of an Irish immigrant after a night of drinking in 1996.

title: Another Overtime, And Turgeon Wins It
description: BLUES 3, STARS 2

title: A Smart Dog With Megabytes
description: SONY unleashed a robotic dog on Tuesday. It has a metallic coat, flashing green eyes, wobbly knees and a propensity to wag its tail when you pat its head. Its name is Aibo, which means companion in Japanese. And for $2,500, it could be yours.

title: Cruises, Cars, Cash And No Stamps to Lick
description: EVERY day, Wendy S. Limauge spends an hour on line entering sweepstakes and contests, chasing after the four C's -- computer, cruise, car and cash -- the tantalizing prizes coveted by sweepstakes entrants everywhere.

title: Art on Line: The Internet Mounts A Masterpiece
description: YOU can't flip through its 32,600 pages, discovering a delightful image serendipitously. You can't hold it, feeling the weight of its scholarship in the heft of its volumes. You can't drift off to sleep in a club chair, an open volume on your lap awaiting your awakening.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOGAN, RUTH ALBERTA
description: LOGAN-Ruth Alberta. Age 79. Died in Honesdale, Pa. Ruth Logan, a Brooklyn NYC native spent her career as a Public Relations Specialist and Development Officer for numerous non-profit organizations in NYC. She is survived by her husband of 49 years Walter Logan. Ruth Logan graduated from New York University with her Bachelor of Arts Degree and later received her Masters in Physical Rehabilitation. In addition to her husband, she is survived by two nieces, Cheryl Foote-Johnson and Donna Foote and a nephew Cornelius Foote &and two grandnieces.

title: Turning Art and Sound Into Child's Play
description: SENSUOUS is not a word typically applied to multimedia. On screen, spectacle generally trumps texture and nuance. So it is a pleasant shock to encounter Midnight Play, which has collected so many international art prizes that its commercial doom in the United States is almost assured.

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Color Printers In Color
description: ONE of the advantages of ugly, boring computers is that they look relatively good when attached to ugly, boring peripherals, like printers. So when Apple Computer introduced its boldly fruit-colored line of iMac and G3 computers last year, it brightened millions of desktops but also called attention to the homeliness of most other peripherals in its general vicinity.

title: Bombed Villagers Ask, 'Why Are We Guilty?'
description: Stojan and Gordana Antic were asleep in their house in the Kosovo village of Lipljan about 11 P.M. last Wednesday when the missile came through the bedroom above their heads.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSMITH, BETTI SCHINASI
description: GOLDSMITH-Betti Schinasi, on May 12, 1999 of cardiac arrest at Southampton Hospital at age 70. Beloved wife of John M. Goldsmith, mother of Robert S.M. Goldsmith of Port St. Lucie, FL and Nancy Mistretta of New York, grandmother of Jonathan and Dana Goldsmith and Laura and Peter Mistretta. Private interment will take place at Ferncliff Cemetery, Hartsdale, New York. In lieu of flowers contributions may be sent to Southampton Hospital.

title: As Divisive Timorese Vote Nears, a Critical Voice Is Silenced
description: The editor was in New York, covering the signing of an agreement to end a generation of war in his small, remote homeland. But his articles never saw print. While he was away, thugs bent on scuttling the agreement destroyed the office of his newspaper.

title: Intense Romeo Shows His Knowledge of Love
description: Ethan Stiefel's debut as Romeo on Saturday night at the Metropolitan Opera House opposite Julie Kent's Juliet in Kenneth MacMillan's choreography of Prokofiev's most famous ballet score was carefully thought out and extremely well danced.

title: On China, Time To Face Reality
description: To the Editor:

title: Agency Forming New Business Unit
description: Biederman Kelly Krimstein & Partners in New York said yesterday it would form a division specializing in business-to-business accounts; it is hiring seven of 14 employees of a business-to-business agency, Hammond Farrell Inc. in New York, that closed on May 2.

title: DANIEL INDUSTRIES TO COMMENT AFTER HEAVY TRADING
description: Daniel Industries, an oilfield-equipment company in Houston that turned down a $292 million buyout offer in March, said yesterday that it would not comment until this morning on why its stock traded at unusually high volumes yesterday. Daniel shares rose 56.25 cents, to $19.5625, before being halted. At that price, the stock is worth more than $381 million. Sean O'Neill, a spokesman, declined to comment when asked if Daniel was being acquired. The company that made the bid in March was not identified. Daniel rejected the bid and hired Simmons & Company to help it review its options.

title: Teen-Agers in Suburbia
description: To the Editor:

title: In Close Israeli Race, Russian Voters Hold the Key
description: There is a pointed joke making the rounds in Israel:

title: It's Planet Hollywood, Even in Vancouver
description: To the Editor:

title: Ethics Lapses at Duke Halt Dozens of Human Experiments
description: Dozens of human experiments at Duke University Medical Center came to a halt today, surprising many staff members as they arrived on a warm and flowering spring morning at the huge medical complex here.

title: Eqbal Ahmad, Scholar and Antiwar Activist, Dies at 67
description: Eqbal Ahmad, a political scientist and peace activist who as one of the Harrisburg 7 was accused of planning to abduct Henry A. Kissinger to protest the Vietnam War, died on Tuesday in Islamabad, Pakistan. He was 67 and lived in Islamabad.

title: Bank of England Sees Possible Rate Cuts
description: The Bank of England said yesterday that further interest rate cuts would be needed if the pound stayed strong, though it added that sterling is likely to fall 4 percent by the first quarter of 2001. In its latest quarterly inflation report, the bank forecasts that British inflation will dip below its 2.5 percent annual target this year, as a strong pound cuts import prices and wage settlements decline. It will stay below target until the fourth quarter of 2000.

title: Pepsi starts a new campaign for its citrus soda, which so far hasn't taken anyone by storm.
description: IT may be named Storm, but it hasn't had much effect on the soft-drink landscape.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about an auction of Impressionist and modern art at Sotheby's on Tuesday misstated the sale price of Monet's ''Waterloo Bridge in the Fog'' (1889-1903) in some copies. It was $9.4 million, not $6.1 million.

title: With Playoff Pressure, Houston Is Maturing
description: With defenders converging on him last night, Allan Houston caught a pass beneath the rim. It was the opening moments of the third quarter, and the Knicks were trying to build on a halftime lead and put the Heat away in Game 3.

title: Cox to Acquire TCA Cable for $3.26 Billion
description: In the latest consolidation deal by a cable company preparing to offer telephone, Internet and interactive services as well as ordinary television to its subscribers, Cox Communications Inc., announced yesterday that it was acquiring TCA Cable TV Inc. for $3.264 billion in stock and cash.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Observatory column of Science Times on Tuesday about a flower pollinated by bats repeated a common misperception about the animals. Although most bats use echolocation as a primary means of navigating, they are not sightless. They can see well.

title: Making Peace With Museums To Celebrate Their Culture; Phoenix Points the Way To Full Indian Collaboration
description: Walls have come down at the Heard Museum, and not just the eight-foot-high berm that long separated the white stucco arches of this celebrated American Indian arts center from an emerging downtown arts district along Central Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SALESKY, LOIS
description: SALESKY-Lois. The Women's Committee of the Central Park Conservancy extend their sincere condolences to Susan Rudin and her family on the loss of her mother, Lois Salesky. Our thoughts and prayers are with you, your father, husband, children, & grandchildren at this sad time. May memories of your mother comfort you and your faith sustain you. The Board of The Women's Committee Toni Peebler, President

title: Celebration Is Not the Answer
description: To the Editor:

title: Pushing to Achieve the Full Monteverdi Effect
description: We are not sure where Monteverdi's ''Vespro della Beata Vergine,'' a glory of sacred music, was first performed. When the work appeared in print in 1610, Monteverdi was employed in the ducal court at Mantua. But he may have been using the composition as a tryout for the most prestigious musical post in Europe: maestro di cappella at the Basilica of St. Mark's in Venice. Monteverdi won the job three years later.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSEN, MATTIE
description: ROSEN-Mattie. The officers and employees of David Webb, Inc., mourn the loss of Mattie Rosen who was our colleague and friend for more than forty years. We extend our deepest sympathy to Paul and David and the entire Rosen family. David Webb, Inc. Nina Silberstein,

title: What About the Family Farm?
description: To the Editor:

title: Does 'Diversity' Improve Colleges?
description: To the Editor:

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of the Solemnity of the Ascension holy day, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations are suspended in New York City today. Other regulations remain in effect.

description: Crafts by African-Americans

description: To the Editor:

description: BETYE SAAR: DIGITAL GRIOT

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUSSMAN, SAMUEL J.
description: SUSSMAN-Samuel J., 88. Beloved husband of Ruth for 60 years. Adored father of Jeremy and Eric. Loving grandfather of Adam, Dana and Jesse. Before his retirement, he was a distinguished trial and appellate attorney. He gave many years of exemplary service to Central Synagogue in Rockville Centre. His generous spirit, kindness, leadership, wit and warmth will be sorely missed by all who loved him. Services will be held Thursday, May 13, at 2:PM at Gutterman's Inc, 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, N.Y.

title: Selling on the News, Wall St. Recovers
description: Wall Street flinched, but then quickly brushed off yesterday's announcement that Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin was resigning and being replaced by Deputy Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEE, MAN BUN
description: LEE-Man Bun. M.B. Lee will be sadly missed by his many friends at NYU Downtown Hospital. A passionate advocate of accessible healthcare for the people of New York's Chinese community, he was a valued advisor to the Hospital's Board of Trustees and senior management on ways to reach those people in greatest need. Mr. Lee was a devoted supporter of the Hospital's campaign to rebuild its emergency room, graciously attending many important meetings on the project and traveling great distances to meet with potential supporters. He will be remembered as much for his intelligence, wit and charm as for his devotion to his community. The Board of Trustees, senior management and the staff of NYU Downtown Hospital mourn the passing of this exceptional man. Nelson Schaenen, Jr. Chairman of the Board Leonard A. Aubrey President and Chief Exec. Officer NYU Downtown Hospital

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about a commencement address by Charlie Rose, the television interviewer, referred imprecisely to the graduation ceremony. It involved only the C. W. Post campus of Long Island University, not the entire university.

title: Preakness Field Is Full, Mostly of Questions
description: A full but fragile field of 14 horses was entered today in the Preakness, including two fillies from Bob Baffert's barn who were promptly installed as second and third choices to Menifee, who missed winning the Kentucky Derby by a neck.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: KOSOVO UPDATE
description: COMBAT

title: Retaliation for Jeter Still in On-Deck Circle
description: David Cone's stare was just a stare. On Tuesday night, Cone stood on the top step of the dugout and peered at the Anaheim Angels as they congratulated one another after a victory over the Yankees. Derek Jeter was almost drilled in the head by Troy Percival and Cone looked as if he were back in the playground, checking numbers and taking names for a future showdown.

title: Conservatives In Britain Seek Probe on Kosovo Policy
description: LONDON  The opposition Conservative Party demanded an official investigation Wednesday into the government's policy on Kosovo, the clearest evidence yet that support for the NATO bombing campaign is starting to waver in the country that has been the strongest supporter of its military action.

title: The Administration's Fiscal Closer
description: When Lawrence H. Summers gives a speech these days, he softens up the audience by facetiously suggesting that he sought advice about what to say from the two men who have served as his mentors the last six years.

title: Italy Picking President: Job Is Ceremonial, Process Baroque
description: On Thursday, the Italian Parliament will begin selecting the next President of Italy, a largely ceremonial figure.

title: Ex-Chancellor Recalls His Turn on Hot Seat
description: THE thwack of tennis balls. Palm trees and a lake view. Four grandchildren nearby. The leisurely calendar of a consultant who makes his own schedule.

title: Where the Sidewalk Transcends
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: 'The Poetic Landscapes of Samuel Colman'
description: Kennedy Galleries

title: Are We Pushing Our Teen-Agers to Violence?; Messiness of Life
description: To the Editor:

title: Silverbulletday to Skip Preakness for 'Susan'
description: ''I have to take care of her,'' Bob Baffert said this morning, and so he withdrew his prize filly, Silverbulletday, from the Preakness.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENFELD, LULLA
description: ROSENFELD - Lulla. Beloved mother of Josie, adored and adoring grandmother of Netalia. Devoted aunt of Elizabeth. Cherished friend and mother in law of Jonathan. Prominent author of books on the Yiddish theater, translator of her grandfather Jacob Adler's memoirs. Service will be held on Friday, May 14th at 12:15PM at Riverside Memorial Chapels, 180 West 76th Street, Manhattan.

title: With Prospects Bleaker, Netanyahu Lashes Out
description: There is a famous Israeli photograph from early in Benjamin Netanyahu's tenure as Prime Minister. It shows him on the beach with his family, trying to relax within a tight circle of secret service agents, their backs to him, their guns pointed outward.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEIN, MELVIN
description: KLEIN-Melvin. On May 11, 1999. Dearest love of wife Elaine, (nee Laks) of 47-1/2 years, most cherished father to Amy Klein and Cyd Tomack, darling grandfather to Brooke and Taylor Tomack, dear brother of Lorna Bernstein and dear nephew to Lee Feiner. Service at the ''Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue, Friday, May 14th, at 10:45 AM.

title: Latest Economic Report Card Shows a Whole Lot of B+'s
description: The economy continues to grow with few signs of accelerating inflation, Government reports showed today.

title: Wealth and Taxes
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KINSOLVING, LUCIE LEE
description: KINSOLVING-Lucie Lee., 98. Died March 20 Bridgeport. Born in Brazil to Episcopal Missionaries. During Red Cross service in WWII, was first woman ashore with Ike's landing in Oran. Served as Director of Volunteers for Lenox Hill Hospital. Memorial service 4pm, Sunday May 16, St. James Church, 71 St. Contributions may be made to the Red Cross or to St. James.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMON, SARAH
description: SIMON-Sarah. 90. On May 10, 1999 at Seacrest Residential Village, Encinitas, CA. Survived by her 3 sons, Melvin (Linda) of La Jolla, CA, Neal (Nancy Boughey) of San Rafael, CA and Michael (Susan) of Long Beach, NY, and her 9 grandchildren, Joshua, David, Rachael, Tali, Jacob, Daniel, Julie, Mark and Jonathan. Memorial contributions may be made sent to Seacrest Residential Village.

title: Sergio Hernandez
description: Associated American Artists

title: APOLLO AFFILIATE IS ACQUIRING CLARK'S STORE OPERATIONS
description: Apollo Management L.P. said yesterday that one of its affiliates had agreed to acquire Clark USA Inc.'s convenience store and gasoline operations for $230 million. The retail operations, which generated $1.3 billion in sales in 1998, include nearly 700 company-run stores and 200 franchised sites, all using the name Clark. Clark is a privately held company that is 68 percent owned by Blackstone Group L.P., the New York merchant bank, and 31 percent owned by Occidental Petroleum. It will retain its Midwest oil refining business. The transaction also calls for Clark to supply refined products to its former stores for two years. Apollo is a private investment firm based in New York.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the political upheaval in Russia and its possible effect on efforts for a solution to the Kosovo conflict misstated the title of Jacques Chirac, who arrived in Moscow for talks. He is the French President, not the Prime Minister.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HARRINGTON, JOHN T.
description: HARRINGTON-John T.. In memory of John T. Harrington. Although the skies seem blue and the fairways look green, how would one describe how a year without you would seem. The colors we all know are suddenly serene. I look to the sky and just ask why. If love could have saved you, you would never have died. It broke our hearts to lose you, but you did not go alone, a part of us went with you the day God took you home. We thank God when we close our eyes, we will always see your smile, share your laugh and feel your continuous embrace. What you mean to us can never be replaced. Always, S,V,A, Mr. P.

title: New Video Releases
description: Holy Man

title: A Shifting Financial Landscape
description: While the politicians in Washington have squabbled endlessly about how to regulate financial services companies, the financial architecture of the country has changed even as the laws have not. It is now entirely possible that the restructuring will be completed while Congress argues -- and in a way that seriously compromises the ability of the most important Federal regulators to supervise major financial institutions.

title: Competition Is Everywhere As the Liberty Opens Camp
description: Liberty Coach Richie Adubato was trying to make a point at the opening of training camp yesterday about how fierce competition for a job in his frontcourt would be by listing the eight players who will fight to fill five roster spots.

title: Lawyers Attack Testimony Of Detective In Louima Case
description: Lawyers defending two police officers in the Abner Louima brutality case yesterday attacked the credibility of another officer who testified against them, suggesting that he was motivated by self-interest and had offered a shifting account.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: One Cancellation Provokes Another

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TEPPERBERG, JEROME, M.D.
description: TEPPERBERG - Jerome, M.D.. Age 62. On May 12 from complications from cancer after a heroic battle. Cherished husband of Susann. Adored father of Suki, Ricky, Josh, Noah, Judy and Benjamin (deceased). Compassionate physician beloved by students, patients and colleagues. Jerry was the former Director of Pediatric Neurology and the current Chief of Pediatric and Neuroligical Services at Maimonides Developmental Center until his death. Professor of Neurology at SUNY Downstate. Services May 14 at Noon, ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. Shiva at home, Saturday evening, Sunday and Monday. Contributions may be made to the Benjamin Tepperberg Memorial Fund, Maimonides Medical Center, Brooklyn.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Korea First Bank Gets More Government Help
description: South Korea said yesterday that it would inject an additional 3 trillion won ($2.5 billion) into Korea First Bank to keep the lender in business because a planned sale to Newbridge Capital Ltd. had been delayed.

title: CASELLA WASTE SYSTEMS CUTS ITS OFFER FOR KTI BY 47%
description: Casella Waste Systems Inc., a solid-waste handler, agreed yesterday to cut the amount it would pay for KTI Inc. by about 47 percent, reviving a deal that was called off after KTI posted a fourth-quarter loss of $3.9 million. Casella said it would now pay 0.59 share, or $12.46, for KTI, a trash-disposal company based in Guttenberg, N.J., dropping the value of the transaction to about $179.4 million from about $338 million. Casella, based in Rutland, Vt., agreed in January to pay 0.91 share for KTI. Shares in Casella fell 12.5 cents, to $21.125. KTI shares fell 6.25 cents, to $11.0625.

title: Corrections
description: The headline of a time-line chart yesterday tracing political turmoil in Russia referred incorrectly to the successive changes. It should have said ''A Revolving Door in Russia's Government,'' not ''in Russia's Parliament.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, LEONARD
description: GOLDSTEIN - Leonard. S/A/R Academy offers heartfelt condolences upon the loss of the beloved father of Marvin Goldstein, a member of the Board of Trustees. May the entire family find comfort among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jack C. Bendheim, President

title: When Punishment Is Good for the Body
description: At 5:15 A.M. on a recent spring day, Jack Walston, a 33-year-old former Navy Seal, emerged from the darkness into the beam of a street lamp like an actor on a dimly lighted stage. His charges, a dozen of us, stood at attention in two horizontal lines. Cold rain streaked through the street lights at an angle, forming large puddles at our feet. Peeling off his jacket, he stood in a T-shirt in the 36-degree morning and eyed us carefully.

title: Are We Pushing Our Teen-Agers to Violence?; Truly a Trend
description: To the Editor:

title: The Senate and the N.R.A.
description: The Senate's first instinct in responding to last month's high school massacre in Littleton, Colo., was to obey the gun lobby by ducking any crackdown on weapons and, incredibly, even relaxing existing gun controls. Fortunately, this action was so perverse, so out of touch with the tides of public concern, that it triggered a backlash that has forced a partial retreat.

title: Temporary Microsoft Workers Win Stock Ruling
description: In a decision that could have wide ramifications for employment practices, a Federal appeals court has ruled that about 10,000 of Microsoft's current and former temporary workers are entitled to take part in the company's discounted stock-purchase plan.

title: Clinton Blames Milosevic, Not Fate, for Bloodshed
description: President Clinton said today that he had misread Balkan history and he apologized for any past suggestions that there is ''some Balkan disease'' that condemns all sides in Yugoslavia to an endless cycle of ethnic blood feuds.

title: Leon Thomas, 61, Jazz Singer Known for 'Yodel'
description: Leon Thomas, a jazz singer known for his bellowing glottal-stop style in free jazz of the 1970's, died on Saturday at Lincoln Hospital in the Bronx. He was 61 and lived in the Bronx.

title: Corrections
description: Two credits were reversed yesterday with pictures of the Israeli election campaign. The chess game between Natan Sharansky and Ehud Barak, the Labor Party candidate for Prime Minister, was photographed by The Associated Press. Campaign posters for Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu in Russian and Hebrew were photographed by Rina Castelnuovo for The New York Times.

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Snyder to Issue Internet Stock
description: Snyder Communications in Bethesda, Md., which owns agencies including Arnold Communications, said yesterday that it would issue a new class of stock to track the performance of its Internet businesses, which are to be combined under the name Circle.com.

title: Zimmer Manages Meetings His Way
description: If his players want to have a team meeting, Don Zimmer proclaimed yesterday, ''Let them rent a ballroom.''

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: American Airlines Accused Of Illegal Pricing in Texas

title: Residential Real Estate; Upper East Side Co-op Going Condo
description: After owning her cooperative apartment on the Upper East Side of Manhattan since 1989, Elizabeth V. Csordas is switching to a condominium -- but without changing her address.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  UNGAR, JOHN A.
description: UNGAR-John A.. In memory of John A. Ungar, a man of commitment and dedication. Miracle Hous

title: GATEWAY SAYS IT WILL BUY STAKE IN INTERNET VENTURE FUND
description: Gateway Inc., the No. 2 direct seller of personal computers, said yesterday that it would buy a stake in the Internet venture fund CMGI Inc. for $200 million. The companies will seek joint investment opportunities on the Internet and treat each other as preferred vendors, CMGI said. Gateway, which sells PC's on line, by telephone and at its Gateway Country stores, said it would combine some of its products and services with CMGI's Internet companies. Gateway, based in North Sioux City, S.D., had $7.47 billion in 1998 sales; CMGI, based in Andover, Mass., had $91.5 million. The stock of Gateway fell 56.25 cents, to $67.625, while CMGI was down $1.6875 at $238.0625.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLURMAN, SHIRLEY POTASH
description: CLURMAN-Shirley Potash., May 13th. After a long illness, at St. Rose's Home. Beloved wife of the late Richard, devoted mother of Michael, stepmother of Susan Emma and Carol. Contributions in her memory may be made to The Citizens Committee for New York City, 305 7th Ave., NY NY 10001.

title: Sports of The Times; No. 8 Team Leads No. 1: Very Strange
description: I START laughing every time I think of the Monty Python reunion last year, when they kicked over poor Graham Chapman's ashes. Right on cue, out come the vacuum cleaners and the brooms, and the lads start sweeping up their fallen comrade.

title: Study Links a Drop in Medicaid To Sweeping Welfare Changes
description: A new study estimates that 675,000 people lost Medicaid coverage and were without health insurance in 1997 because of sweeping changes in Federal and state welfare programs.

title: Foreign Affairs; The Accidental Peacenik
description: For the first time in Israel's history, its upcoming election is about who will control the Interior Ministry, not the Foreign Ministry. It's about what kind of Israel, not what size of Israel.

title: Everywoman's Experiences In a World That's Unyielding
description: Bebe Miller's new ''Rhythm Studies'' is a testament to Ms. Miller's intelligence and imagination as a choreographer and her daring as a performer. The opening piece in a program presented by the Bebe Miller Company at the Joyce Theater on Wednesday night, ''Rhythm Studies'' is essentially a powerful, gritty star turn for Ms. Miller as an Everywoman at large in an unyielding world.

title: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/Safety; The Unfulfilled Promise Of Drivers' Education
description: BEGINNING July 1, anyone applying for a license for the first time in Maryland will have to complete at least 30 hours of drivers' education in the classroom and 6 hours on the road. Maryland's drivers' ed requirement currently applies only to 16- and 17-year-olds -- as do the rules in most states that have requirements.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRANT, FRANCES
description: GRANT-Frances. Beloved wife of the late Sidney. Devoted mother of Brendi and Mort Drosnes and Dr. Michael and Annette Grant. Cherished grandmother of Erika, Adam, James, and Carrie and great-grandmother of Eli, Cody and Olivia. Dear sister of Estelle, Edna and Lennie. Loving nieces and nephews. Service Friday, 1PM at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91st Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Chef With a Side Dish: A Philosophy of Food
description: WHEN Alice Waters came from Berkeley to SoHo this week to teach her first class at the French Culinary Institute, she packed seven crates of organic vegetables wrapped in wet paper towels and an eccentric assortment of clothes more suitable to People's Park than to Prince Street.

title: Very Young Guns
description: Would your child pick up a gun? Would he shoot a friend? Shoot himself? Mine would, and so would dozens of other children at his day care center.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I am proud to stand on the floor of the United States Senate and proclaim myself a defender of the Second Amendment. I think it's possible to defend this Constitutional right and also defend the kids in the school cafeteria.''

title: EMERSON IN $460 MILLION DEAL FOR DANIEL INDUSTRIES
description: The Emerson Electric Company said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Daniel Industries, which makes measurement and control equipment for the oil and gas industries, for $21.25 a share in cash, or about $460 million. Emerson Electric, based in St. Louis, makes electromechanical and electronic products, including compressors, diesel generators, hand tools and welding equipment. Daniel, based in Houston, has manufacturing plants in Canada, Europe and the United States, and posted sales of $283 million last year. Its shares rose $1.375, to $20.9375, while Emerson's stock dropped $2.5625, to $67.0625.

title: Albemarle Ends Bidding For Albright & Wilson
description: The Albemarle Corporation, a chemical company in Richmond, said yesterday that it would not raise its offer for Albright & Wilson P.L.C. a second time and would not buy any more of the stock of the concern, a British specialty-chemical company, conceding defeat to Rhodia S.A. in the nine-week battle. On April 30 Rhodia increased its counterbid to 167.5 pence a share in cash, valuing the British company at $:526 million ($852 million). The battle began with an initial bid of 130 pence a share by Albemarle.

title: PLAYTEX IS ACQUIRING BABY MAGIC BRAND FROM COLGATE
description: Playtex Products Inc. signed an agreement to acquire the Baby Magic brand in the United States, Canada and Puerto Rico from the Colgate-Palmolive Company for $90 million in cash. Colgate will retain the rights to the brand for all geographic regions outside the United States, Canada and Puerto Rico. The brand includes infant-related bath, lotion, shampoo, oil and powder products. In 1998, the Baby Magic brand generated net sales of $48.9 million in the United States, Canada and Puerto Rico. Playtex had sales of $669.6 million in 1998.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORDON, IRVING L.
description: GORDON-Irving L.. Formerly of Brooklyn. On May 12, 1999 at age 84, in Dallas, TX. Beloved husband of Lois. Father of Meryl and Scott Nason, Jesse and Wendy, and Reena. Grandfather of Joshua and Naomi Nason and Elliott Gordon. Funeral 11AM Fri, May 14th, Old Montefiore Cemetery, Queens.

title: Back to Battle Lines
description: With a big and boisterous rally on Wednesday that drew tens of thousands of marchers, New York's labor unions signaled that they were on a collision course with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Gov. George E. Pataki -- one that could have major effects on coming contract talks and political campaigns.

title: Love for Sale?
description: To the Editor:

title: SPARE TIMES
description: ATTRACTIONS

title: Milosevic Refuses to See Top U.N. Rights Official
description: Mary Robinson, the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights, was frustrated in her aim to ask President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia about his Government's human rights record when he refused to see her here today.

title: I.B.M. Helps Push Dow and S.& P. to Highs
description: Stock prices mostly advanced yesterday, buoyed by economic reports that pushed down long-term interest rates.

title: Chromosomes End in Tied Loops, Study Finds
description: Biologists must have gazed thousands of times through microscopes at the 46 chromosomes in the nucleus of every normal human cell without perceiving what has now been discovered: the ends of the chromosomes -- the immensely long molecules of DNA that carry the genetic information -- are neatly tied in large, firmly knotted loops.

title: Our Bumbling Spooks Need More Than Money
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE ART
description: Museum Lays In Vintage Kellys

title: THE FINE PRINT: The Emergency Spending Bill; Relief Bill Is Laden With Special Projects as It Creaks Through Committee
description: On the face of it, the seven-year battle over a mining company's petition to blow a 900-foot hole in a mountain in northern Washington State and extract the gold inside would seem to have nothing to do with an emergency bill in Congress to aid war refugees in Kosovo and victims of the recent Midwest tornadoes.

title: Elevator Plunge Kills 2 Workmen
description: Two maintenance workers in South Kearny, N.J., were killed yesterday when a warehouse elevator they were trying to take out of service suddenly plunged four or five floors.

title: Yeltsin's Ouster of Cabinet May Prevent I.M.F. Help
description: President Boris N. Yeltsin's decision to dismiss his Cabinet may deepen Russia's economic troubles by jeopardizing a badly needed loan-refinancing program from the International Monetary Fund and negotiations with other foreign creditors.

title: Clinton's Remarks in Defense of Military Intervention in Balkans
description: Following are excerpts from President Clinton's speech to a veterans' group today on Kosovo, as recorded by The New York Times.

title: Meg Greenfield, Shaper of Washington Post Editorial Page and Public Policy, Dies at 68
description: Meg Greenfield, the editor of The Washington Post's editorial page, who brought a combination of sharp-eyed analysis and wry wit to bear on a generation of the nation's policy makers and politicians, died yesterday morning at her home in Washington. She was 68.

title: Zhang Peili
description: Jack Tilton Gallery

title: It Is the East, and Juliet Is Stripped to the Waist
description: Juliet is a tall hoyden who goes after her man. Her mother goes after not only Tybalt but also Paris. The head of the Capulet clan is nowhere in sight. Friar Laurence is Destiny, a master of ceremonies who cannot avert the course of events that his meddling sets in motion. Romeo becomes a pawn, and his friends and enemies make rude Italian gestures with their elbows. The spare and striking environment suggests an interplanetary clime.

title: 'Homicide' Is Canceled; NBC Cites Economics
description: NBC has canceled its critically celebrated police drama ''Homicide, Life on the Street,'' after seven seasons, the show's creator, Tom Fontana, said yesterday.

title: State Cracks Down on New York City Trash Transfer Stations
description: Chris Ruckert usually works in Long Island's pine barrens enforcing hunting and fishing regulations as an officer for the State Department of Environmental Conservation. But yesterday he was in a different world: a dusty, smelly garbage transfer station in Brooklyn.

title: A Many Gendered Thing, The True Nature of Love
description: The insecurities and turbulent desires of adolescence have rarely been portrayed more faithfully on screen than in ''Edge of 17,'' the latest and most poignant in a recent spate of teen-age male coming-out-of-the-closet dramas. Aside from its nationality, one thing that sets this American independent film apart from two likable British forerunners, ''Beautiful Thing'' and ''Get Real,'' is its sexual candor.

title: Second Supplier of Concrete Is Blocked From Park Work
description: For the second time in two months, the Giuliani administration has stopped a company from supplying concrete for the renovation of City Hall Park because of possible integrity problems.

title: Honolulu Journal; Nostalgia Flows as Beach Boy Is Returned to Waves
description: As the wind rose and the surf boiled and the last light leached from the wide sky over Waikiki on Wednesday night, Charlie Lambert, a prince of old Hawaii, went home to the waves he loved.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Wednesday about electronic stock exchanges misstated the name of a magazine edited by John Byrne, who commented on the difficulty of regulation in a rapidly changing marketplace. It is Traders Magazine, not The Trader magazine.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINBERG, SIDNEY R.
description: WEINBERG-Sidney R. age 73. Musician, beloved husband of Karen and father of John Short and Valerie Kaley, died of cancer on May 5. His humor, wisdom and companionship will be greatly missed. A Celebration of his life will be held June 5, Maitland (FL) Art Center. Remembrances may be sent to Central Florida Jazz Society Scholarship Fund, P.O. Box 540133, Orlando, FL 32854. For information call Central Florida 469 Direct Cremation. 407-292-7572.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WARREN, GAIL (NEE WASSERMAN)
description: WARREN-Gail (nee Wasserman). Of Great Neck, N.Y. on May 11, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Herbert. Loving mother of Barbara (Howard) and Stuart. Cherished grandmother of Jessica, Rachel and Phineas. Sister of Ted and the late Irving. Funeral service at 11am, Friday, May 14 at RiversideNassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck.

title: Phnom Penh Journal; Intrepid Lawyer Rises for First Khmer Rouge Trial
description: There is no diploma on the wall of Benson Samay's law office. But there is something better: photographs in which he poses with influential Government figures, the best credential in Cambodia's corrupt and politicized judicial system.

title: The Newest Ford Generation Takes the Company Spotlight
description: The gadfly investor Evelyn Y. Davis called him King William, and so he was: the heir to leadership of the Ford Motor Company, William C. Ford Jr., took the stage today to run the family-controlled company's annual meeting for the first time.

title: Per Kirkeby
description: Knoedler

title: Burt Barr -- 'August'
description: Patrick Callery

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Woods's 61 Leads Garcia by Only One
description: It was a record-tying day for Tiger Woods, and an attention-getting day for 19-year-old Sergio Garcia.

title: Are We Pushing Our Teen-Agers to Violence?; Kids Under Pressure
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Lawyers handling litigation against Cendant propose an innovative way to pay their fees.
description: FROM the first, the litigation touched off by the collapse of the Cendant Corporation's stock price in April 1998 has provided provocative entertainment to anyone lucky enough to have avoided being caught in the financial wreckage.

title: Shirley P. Clurman, 74, Editor and Producer
description: Shirley Potash Clurman, a retired magazine editor and television producer, died yesterday at St. Rose's Home in Manhattan. She was 74 and lived on the Upper East Side.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINBERG, RABBI MILTON
description: WEINBERG-Rabbi Milton. On May 12, 1999 at age 70. Beloved husband of Laurie. Devoted father of Hillel, David, Rebecca, and Ariel. Adored ''Sabah'' of Ben, Rachel, Sarah, Rafi, and Tovah. Services Friday at 11:30 A.M., New City (New York) Jewish Center, 43 Old Schoolhouse Road.

title: A Tale About the Distancing Of a Long-Distance Runner
description: ''Endurance,'' a docudrama based on the life of the Ethiopian long-distance runner Haile Gebrselassie, has the lofty goal of investing rural Ethiopian life with the primal dignity evoked by Robert Flaherty in his groundbreaking documentary studies of Eskimos and Polynesians. But its mixture of biographical hype and social studies quickly curdles.

title: ON STAGE AND OFF
description: Can the Fall Be Far Behind?

title: LASON REVISES ITS STOCK OFFER FOR M-R GROUP OF BRITAIN
description: Lason Inc., a manager of computer records, raised the amount of stock it would pay for M-R Group P.L.C. of Britain by 10 percent because its shares fell after 10 employees were charged with defrauding the United States Postal Service. Lason, based in Troy, Mich., said it would swap 5.376 shares for every 100 shares of M-R Group, which has about $90 million in annual revenue and provides laser printing, digital imagery and microfilming. Lason originally offered 4.877 shares per 100 M-R shares in late March. The revised offer values M-R Group at $126 million, less than the initial value of $145.2 million. Lason's shares fell $1.8125, to $41.

title: Sheik Abdelaziz bin Baz, Senior Saudi Cleric and Royal Ally
description: Sheik Abdelaziz bin Baz, the pillar of Saudi Arabia's religious establishment and a crucial ally of the royal family, died today in Taif. He was believed to be in his late 80's.

title: Jayson Williams Recovering Quickly
description: Jayson Williams, who throughout his nine-year pro career has become renowned for quick recuperative abilities, has done it again. Six weeks after having undergone surgery on his broken right leg, Williams, the New Jersey Nets' center, is walking. Doctors initially advised Williams to wait until May 29 to put weight on his leg.

title: Clinton Calls Gore 'Smart' To Maintain His Distance
description: In his first extensive comments thus far on how the 2000 Presidential race is unfolding, President Clinton tonight discussed his campaign tips for Al Gore and said it was perfectly understandable that the Vice President rarely uttered the President's name on the campaign trail.

title: A Train Hurtling Into Real-Life Issues
description: ''Atomic Train'' was not produced by that amorphous bogeyman that some people in Washington have blithely named the ''toxic culture.'' This is a silly two-part mini-series that works surprisingly well on the level of formulaic action. It is ''Speed'' on a train with Rob Lowe in the Sandra Bullock role, playing a hero who has to stop a runaway train hurtling toward Denver carrying a nuclear bomb.

title: Influence Cast In Stone
description: Richard Tuttle, who grew up during the 1940's in Roselle, N.J., remembers first going to the Metropolitan Museum of Art when he was around 6 and seeing the ancient Assyrian gates that used to flank the entrance to the south galleries. The gates are big stone sculptures of winged lions with human heads and five legs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VALAIRE, ROSEMARY
description: VALAIRE-Rosemary. Age 68. Born on June 11, 1930 in Crawley, Sussex, England. Died May 7, 1999 in her home in Los Angeles, CA. Member of the Royal Ballet from 1946 to 1954. Co-director of the Westside School of Ballet in Los Angeles from 1966 to 1999. Donations in her memory may be sent to the Rosemary Valaire Scholarship Fund, c/o the Westside School of Ballet, 1711 Stewart Street, Santa Monica, CA. 90404.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MASI, JOSEPH PAUL
description: MASI-Joseph Paul. Of NYC. Died May 13, 1999. He was 63. Born October 13, 1935 to Paul and Josephine Sicari Masi in New York. He is survived by a daughter, Michelle Didner of Rye, N.Y., stepson Jimmie Sundstrom of Rye, N.Y., two grandchildren, brother, George of Queens, and a sister Catherine Meade of Huntington, N.Y. Please call Coxe & Graziano Funeral Home at 914-698-5968 for funeral arrangements. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to The American Cancer Society, 2 Lyon Pl, White Plains, N.Y. 10601.

title: Heady Testimony To the Grand Agendas Of Etchers and the Rich
description: As its regulars know, the New York Public Library is about art as well as books. Consider, for example, its museum-quality trove of some 180,000 fine-art prints that cover the history of the field from the beginning to the present day. The library consistently puts together highly viewable shows from its collection, and the current ''Netherlandish Prints From the New York Public Library,'' 16th- and 17th-century woodcuts, etchings and engravings by Dutch and Flemish artists, is no exception.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEWTON, ROBERT
description: NEWTON-Robert. S/A/R Academy extends heartfelt condolences to Hilda Newton upon the loss of her beloved husband, friend and longtime Trustee and supporter. May the entire family find comfort in the memory of his many good deeds and acts of charity and kindness. Jack C. Bendheim, President NEWTON-Robert. The Riverdale Jewish Center mourns the loss of our former board member, Robert Newton. We extend profound condolences to his wife Hilda and the entire family. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jonathan I. Rosenblatt, Rabbi Tobias B. Schapiro, Pres.

title: Salem Beyond Witches: Legacy of a Lively Sea Trade
description: Stand by the second-story window of the nearly two-century-old Custom House here and you will find yourself gazing over a waterfront that once linked the young United States with the world's farthest corners.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DANCIK, NICHOLAS
description: DANCIK-Nicholas. On May 12, 1999. We mourn the sudden, tragic and untimely death of our dear son, grandson, nephew and cousin. We will deeply miss you. Memorial service will take place on Monday May 17, 1999 at 2PM at Camp Wayfarer Flat Rock, NC. Funeral arrangements to be announced. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Nicholas Dancik Memorial Fund at Davidson College, Davidson, NC 28036. The Dancik, Cornwell, Resnick families

title: Our Bumbling Spooks Need More Than Money
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUSSMAN, SAMUEL J.
description: SUSSMAN-Samuel J.. The members and staff of Hoberman, Sussman and Herman mourn the loss of our former partner and good friend. He was a true professional and always the perfect gentleman. Our sympathy is extended to Ruth, Jamie, Eric and the grandchildren Hoberman, Sussman & Herman

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day on Wednesday listing changes in United States nonfarm productivity misstated the comparisons of figures for the third and fourth quarters of 1998 and those a year earlier. Productivity increased by 1.8 percent in the third quarter, not 2.5 percent, and rose 2.7 percent in the fourth, not 4.6 percent.

title: ART GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. *denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAYEN, WILLIAM HENRY ''HARRY''
description: SAYEN-William Henry ''Harry''. Died of heart failure at his home in Princeton, NJ on May 10th. He was 77. He is survived by his wife of 53 years, the former Isabelle Burns Guthrie of Princeton; his four sons, W. Guthrie of West Hartford, CT, David of Princeton, George, of London and Henry, of Lawrenceville, New Jersey; and his grandson Walker, of Lawrenceville. A memorial service will be held in the Princeton University Chapel at 9:30AM on Saturday, May 22. Memorial contributions may be made to Isles, 10 Wood St., Trenton, New Jersey 08618.

title: Video Game Industry Gathers Under Siege
description: The video game industry opened its annual trade show here today in a mood part defiant and part defensive about accusations that violent video games contributed to the high school shootings last month in Littleton, Colo.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CITIGROUP INC., New York, the world's largest financial company, agreed to sell its five Canadian bank branches to Canada Trust Co., Toronto, a unit of CT Financial Services Inc., for an undisclosed amount.

title: China Honors 3 Killed in Belgrade, but the Street Protests End
description: In an elaborate ceremony at the Great Hall of the People, China's leaders bestowed the title of ''revolutionary martyr'' today on the three Chinese journalists killed by NATO's bombing of the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade last week.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: 76ers Pummel the Magic With Speed and Strength
description: The coach, Chuck Daly, owns two National Basketball Association championship rings. The starting power forward, Horace Grant, owns three. The two leading scorers, Penny Hardaway and Nick Anderson, have finals experience. And the Orlando Magic over all is far more seasoned than its upstart opponents, the Philadelphia 76ers.

title: As With Friends, These Five Show Off and Then Meld
description: If a string quartet is like a family, a wind quintet is more a group of friends. They value each other for their individual qualities, and relationships are more casual. This is the way of the instruments, and probably the way of the players, too.

title: FAMILY FARE
description: A Rhythm Fest In Red Hook

title: How Puzzle May Play Out in Moscow
description: Russia's last constitutional crisis ended badly, with a violent mutiny led by parliamentary leaders that was put down by the President with the help of army tanks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DYE, PETER SHERMAN
description: DYE-Peter Sherman. Age 58 of Oakland suddenly on May 11, 1999. Beloved husband of L. Patricia (nee Donnelly) Dye. Devoted son of Jean (nee Forsythe) Dye of Cleveland Heights, OH., loving brother of Kathleen L. Dye of Kingsville, OH., Richard F. Dye of Vernon Hills, IL., Alice D. Maechtlen of Albuquerque, NM., William T. Dye of Millinocket, ME., and Mary H. Dye of Kingsville, OH. Also surviving are ten nieces and nephews. Mr. Dye was a 1959 graduate of Cleveland Heights High School and a 1963 graduate of John Carroll University, in Cleveland, OH. He was a member of the American Institute of CPA's, New Jersey Society of CPA's, and a consultant for the Security and Exchange Commission. He was employed by the NJ Society of CPA's. Services were private. Information: Oakland Memorial Home. Oakland, New Jersey.

title: Bread and More
description: France distinguishes between pastry shops (patisseries) and bread stores (boulangeries). In the United States, pastries and bread are both produced by bakeries. In New York, more and more bakeries are offering food, while more restaurants are also becoming bakeries. Here are 12 that blur the usual categories. (These summaries, written by Eric Asimov, are taken from Mr. Asimov's and others' dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times.)

title: Boeing to Eliminate as Many as 7,000 Jobs
description: After losing a key order for its F-15 Eagle jet fighter two weeks ago, the Boeing Company said yesterday that it planned to cut as many as 7,000 jobs at its manufacturing plant in St. Louis by the middle of 2001.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITNEY, EDWARD F.
description: WHITNEY-Edward F.. On May 12, 1999. Beloved brother of Donald H. Whitney of Statesboro, GA. Devoted uncle of Peter D. Whitney of McLean, VA; Mary W. Hoch of Mt. Kisco, NY; Richard Whitney of Annapolis, MD and David Whitney of Malden, MA. He was a graduate of the Horace Mann School and Princeton University, class of 1936. A veteran of U.S. Navy, W.W. II. His career spanned more than 40 years in the controller's office with The Atlantic Mutual Insurance Companies. He was an avid athlete and sports fan who continued his sports interest and his own personal physical fitness until his passing. The family will receive friends at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, on Saturday, May 15 at 4 PM.

title: AIRLINE IS ACCUSED OF ILLEGAL PRICING
