description: The Federal Government accused American Airlines today of driving smaller competitors out of one of its most important markets by illegally slashing ticket prices below cost and increasing flights sharply.

title: Corrections
description: A picture from the town of Ashkelon on Tuesday with an article about Israeli voters' views of the campaign also carried an incorrect credit. It was by Rina Castelnuovo for The New York Times.

title: Mouligne Wins 50-Foot Class
description: It was a tormenting time at sea these last few weeks for J.P. Mouligne, the French skipper who won Class II yesterday in the Around Alone, a yacht race round the world for solo sailors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, DAVID S.
description: BROWN-David S.. May 12, 1999. Memorial service Chapel of Church of the Heavenly Rest, Monday, May 17 at 2:00 pm. In lieu of flowers, donations to Deerfield Academy, Deerfield, MA or C.L.H. Howard/D. Brown Scholarship Fund, McIntire School of Commerce, University of Virginia, Charlottsville, VA.

title: Starting Pitching A Concern For Mets
description: ''The standings only mean something when the season's over,'' Manager Bobby Valentine remarked after the Mets halted a three-game losing streak in Colorado on Wednesday afternoon.

title: World Briefing
description: ASIA

title: Riley at the Crossroads as the Unthinkable Looms
description: Pat Riley left New York in 1995 for power, money and sun. Packing his vision of a championship team, he arrived in Miami and found a franchise center, an improvisational point guard, role players with high pain thresholds and the ability to discern between being ''a'' winner and being ''the'' winner.

title: Chinese Exports Slowed Further in April
description: China's exports in April totaled $14.8 billion, falling 7.3 percent compared with the corresponding month a year earlier, as sales to Asia remained weak, the official New China News Agency reported today, citing customs statistics.

title: Britain Closes Web Site With Spies' Names
description: An embittered former British spy has used the Internet to make public the names of a large number of secret agents, but officials in London said today that the Web site had been shut down and that no duplicates had surfaced.

title: Accuser in Spy Case Accepts a Denial
description: Jeremy J. Stone, having accused a prominent American physicist of spying for Moscow while involved in the making of the first atomic bomb half a century ago, has now written him to accept his denial that he was the Soviet atom spy whom the Russians called Perseus.

title: China Is Installing a Warhead Said to Be Based on U.S. Secrets
description: China is close to deploying a nuclear missile with a warhead whose design draws on stolen American secrets, United States intelligence officials say.

title: Our Bumbling Spooks Need More Than Money
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANK, SAMUEL
description: FRANK-Samuel., 89, of Aventura, FL (formerly of Brooklyn) on May 13, 1999. Husband of the late Sylvia Schonwetter. Father of David Frank and Dr. Phyllis Kushins. Brother of Paul, Murray, Dorothy Efron & Pearl Gold. Grandfather of 5. Funeral Friday 2PM Mount Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY. Mount Sinai Memorial Chapels, East Brunswick, NJ.

title: Easy Approval Is Predicted For Summers
description: President Clinton's nominee for Treasury Secretary, Lawrence H. Summers, appears to be facing relatively little opposition in the Senate, even from Republican critics of the Administration's economic policy.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE YEN FALLS. The dollar rose on confidence that Lawrence H. Summers would maintain a strong dollar policy after becoming Treasury Secretary. In New York, the dollar settled at 121.85 yen, up from 120.95 on Wednesday.

title: Oracle Shares Tumble 9% Over Warning On Earnings
description: Shares of the Oracle Corporation dropped 9 percent today after several analysts suggested that the company might not meet earnings estimates for its fourth quarter, which ends May 31, because of a slowdown in sales of software that manages corporate information systems.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SARAZEN, GENE
description: SARAZEN-Gene. The Officers and Trustees of the New York Sports Museum & Hall of Fame regret the passing of a charter member of the New York Sports Hall of Fame on May 13 in Naples, Florida. Bill Shannon, President Jordan Sprechman, Secretary

title: Sean Landers
description: Andrea Rosen

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAMBAUGH, JAMES PHILIP, SR.
description: SHAMBAUGH-James Philip, Sr.. Died May 13, 1999 at his residence in Chevy Chase, MD where he has lived since his wife's death in 1991. Born in Kuling, China June 6, 1914 to American missionary parents, United Evangelical Church. Worked for Socony Vacuum Oil, now Mobil Corp. from 1939-1977 when he retired as Manager of Processes and Promotions. Coholder of various patents in the field of catalytic cracking an important petroleum refining for gasoline. A Mayor for the Village of Huntington Bay, NY from 19781982. Listed in Who's Who in Engineering and Who's Who in the East. Member over fifty years of the American Chemical Society and the American Institute of Chemical Engineers. Survived by his children, J. Curtis of New York, NY, J. Philip Jr. of Washington, DC and Signe Mayfield of Palo Alto, California, four grandchildren and one great-grandchild. Memorial contributions may be made to University of Illinois where he and his wife graduated or St. Francis Hospital, Roslyn, NY. Memorial service at Hyatt Classic Residence, 8100 Connecticut Avenue, Chevy Chase, MD., at 2PM May 16th.

title: Top Court Decides That, in an Attack, Teeth Are Not a Weapon
description: New York State's highest court decided yesterday to take the teeth out of the state's laws on assault.

title: Gap's Profit Up 49% in Quarter
description: Gap Inc., the nation's second-largest specialty clothing retailer, said today that its first-quarter profit rose 49 percent as shoppers scooped up drawstring pants and other casual fashions at its Old Navy chain.

title: Patriotic Vouchers
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DONNA, ANTHONY
description: DONNA-Anthony., on May 9, 1999. For information contact Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapels, 114-03 Queens Blvd, Forest Hills, New York. 718-263-7600.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: It is an enchanting idea: a restaurant that pays homage to California instead of the usual suspects, France and Italy. The Berkeley Bar and Grill, its menu says, reflects an ''idealized Berkeley that emanates somewhere out of Mediterranean France and has settled in the town across the bay from San Francisco.''

title: Arnold Big Winner Of Magazine Awards
description: Arnold Communications in Boston, owned by Snyder Communications, took top honors by winning four of the five awards, including the $100,000 prize for general excellence, at the 18th annual Kelly Awards competition sponsored by the Magazine Publishers of America.

title: Argentine Congress Rebuffs Leader on Budget
description: After a week of student demonstrations, the Argentine Congress has restored $280 million in aid to schools and universities that President Carlos Saul Menem had ordered cut to control a federal budget deficit.

title: The Politics of Guns: Tilting Toward the Democrats
description: Five years ago, when the Democrats lost their majority in Congress, they felt they had paid dearly for backing a ban on many kinds of assault weapons. But that was before a series of school shootings culminated in the massacre at Columbine High School. And today there were strong signs that both parties sense that the politics of guns and violence are shifting.

title: Secret-Stealing, Then and Now
description: Leaks of information on the highly important topic of nuclear weapons have been discussed widely. While I am not familiar with all the details, I can make a comparison with an important event half a century ago.

title: Buyers Are Selective at Christie's Modern Art Sale
description: A sophisticated group of collectors went to Christie's sale of 20th-century art last night prepared to buy, but only if the price was right. While clearly the market is hungry for modern art, bidders for the most part were a controlled group, willing to stretch their budgets but only so far.

title: Experts Say Repeal of Commuter Tax Seems Valid
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani vowed again today to challenge in court a plan by state lawmakers to end the city's commuter tax, but the legal objections he raised would probably not be enough to overturn the repeal, legal experts said.

title: Getting a Life, Episode One: The Un-Kids
description: A QUIET walk along Broadway the other day turned suddenly into a blast from the past.

title: In a Breach, German Party Backs 'Limited Halt' in Kosovo Air War
description: In a clear sign of the strains placed on Germany's Government by the Kosovo conflict, the environmentalist Green party today broke ranks with its coalition partners and other Western governments by calling for a ''limited halt'' to the NATO bombing of Yugoslavia.

title: Some Good Men Are Dodging Draft in South Korea
description: SEOUL  The images of young men in white T-shirts and green shorts flashed across television screens here as investigators asked why military doctors pronounced a significant number of them not as fit as they looked.

title: KOSOVO UPDATE
description: COMBAT

title: Halt in Studies At Duke Irks Researchers
description: As an expert on the effects of stress on health, Dr. Redford B. Williams Jr. does not want to say he is hopping mad about the abrupt shutdown this week of his and other federally financed research at Duke University Medical Center. But he is decidedly passionate about it.

title: Cadbury and Coca-Cola Said to Discuss Deal
description: A senior Cadbury Schweppes executive said yesterday that the company planned to sell its brands in France to the Coca-Cola Company after Coca-Cola completed its negotiations with the French Government over the purchase of the Orangina soft-drink brand.

title: AMERICAN TOPICS
description: A federal judge in Indianapolis has ruled that a male high school senior had the right to attend his senior prom the way he wanted: in woman's clothing.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FIDELSON, LEONA
description: FIDELSON-Leona. May 11, 1999. Beloved mother of Anne Oshan, of Andover, MA. Cherished grandmother of David Oshan, of Charlotte, NC and Kenneth Oshan of San Francisco, CA and Paul Oshan of Torrance, CA. Funeral private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRAGER, JOAN
description: TRAGER-Joan. Beloved wife of Seymour. Devoted mother of Michael, Barbara Katz and the late Marlene Kevy. Cherished grandmother of Eric, Rachel, Matthew, Jonathan, Jessica and Melissa. Dear sister of Lenore Spingarn. Mother-in-law of Larry Kevy and Cara Trager. Service Sunday, 9AM ''Sinai Chapels'', 162-05 Horace Harding Expwy, Fresh Meadows.

title: Study Compares U.S. and English Drug Crimes
description: Illegal drugs drive crime in England just as they do in the United States, says a two-nation survey that challenges assumptions that addicted criminals are a particularly American problem.

title: In a Texaco Deal, Chevron Wants Control
description: The Chevron Corporation and Texaco Inc. will continue merger talks next week, but they remain divided principally over Chevron's insistence that it control the combined company, executives close to the negotiations said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HENSEL, JOHN J.
description: HENSEL-John J.., 83, of Sag Harbor, formerly of Bronx, on May 13, 1999. Beloved husband of Dorothy nee Buhr. Loving father of Dr. Karen A. Hensel, Thea Nightingale, and Lillian Johnson. Dear brother of the late Harry. Also survived by one grandchild, Riana. Reposing at Yardley & Pino Funeral Home, 91 Hampton Street, Sag Harbor, Friday, 7-9 p.m. Funeral Saturday, May 15, 11 a.m., at First Presbyterian Church. Cremation private.

title: A 'Dream' of Foolish Mortals
description: Pot luck Shakespeare is enjoying a special film vogue now, what with the tempting prospect of hearing a ''forsooth'' or ''methinks'' from the least likely sources. The strategy of choice is picking a travel agent's dream setting, casting attractive actors no matter what (e.g., Keanu Reeves in ''Much Ado About Nothing''), giving an outrageous costume party and hoping for the best. But even for the Leo-does-Romeo set these productions need more than visual flash if they hope to work. Take away smooth ensemble acting and a unifying vision, and you're left with the dramatic equivalent of watching Noah load the ark.

title: Johnson Is on the Outside But Uses Space Wisely
description: The Knicks' Larry Johnson has a body built for the low post, but he has unveiled a surprising soft touch that has yet to sink in with the Miami Heat.

title: They Make People Gasp
description: Attention must be paid this season to the male dancers at American Ballet Theater. Rarely has so much talent at the top come together at one time: like planets converging in the night sky to symbolize an auspicious future, this cluster of men, with their virtuosity and diversity of style, has changed the look of the company.

title: With Prices Rising, Indians Go Up for Sale
description: Tantalized by escalating franchise prices, Richard Jacobs put his Cleveland Indians up for sale yesterday, less than a year after taking the team public.

title: Put Aside the Olympics: For Women, It's the World Cup or Nothing
description: It was a harmless victory ritual by the Norwegian soccer players, crawling on the ground, linked hand-to-ankle like human boxcars, but the memory of the celebration has been as indelible for Briana Scurry as the tattoo of a panther on her shoulder.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on page 12.

title: Hey There, Pardner, Speak Low if You Speak Love
description: There is always a sinking feeling when the lights come up for the performance of a play you think you know fairly well and you are suddenly confronted with action and dialogue you've never seen or heard in your life.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEINBERG, FREDA (NEE KORINS)
description: STEINBERG-Freda (nee Korins). Beloved wife of the late Dr. Philip. Loving mother of Bruce (Eve) and Fred (Ging). Devoted sister of Kitty Roan. Adored grandmother of Jeffrey (Julie), Daniel (Gabriella), Stacy (Larry), Philip and Suzan. Great grandmother of six. Service Sunday, 2:00 PM at I.J. Morris, 21 East Deer Park Rd, Dix Hills, NY.

title: Commencement; Rubin, a New Job Seeker, Addresses N.Y.U.'s 13,000
description: A day after announcing his resignation as Treasury Secretary, Robert E. Rubin addressed more than 13,000 graduates in Washington Square Park yesterday morning as the main speaker at New York University's 167th commencement.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: Bouncing Boy Sees Busy Days

title: A Quirky Tour By a Poet-Guide
description: It's not the sort of information one expects from a tour guide, even in New York City. ''Greenwich Village is one of those rare districts that occurs once in a while in human history,'' Timothy (Speed) Levitch says into a microphone from his perch atop a double-decker bus on the streets of Manhattan. ''Fear, a basic theme in all our lives, constantly afraid along the streets of Greenwich, under threat of assassination and the assassins are our dreams triumphant.''

title: $4 Million Awarded In Assault Lawsuit Against Gun Group
description: A Federal jury in Philadelphia awarded $4.4 million yesterday to an Iowa man who said he was assaulted last year by a security guard for the National Rifle Association at the group's annual convention there.

title: Wal-Mart Decides Against Selling a Contraceptive
description: Wal-Mart Stores Inc. has decided not to sell an emergency contraceptive approved last year for sale in the United States and widely available in drugstores nationwide.

title: Real Public Rage Stoked By Propaganda Machine
description: Ever since NATO bombs hit the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade last Friday, China's state-run media have dished up a ceaseless stream of banner headlines and jarring photos: of bereft parents crying over victims' bodies, of President Jiang Zemin in tears as he greeted families of the dead.

title: Miss M's Divine Intervention
description: There are many people who deserve praise for saving 112 community gardens that were due to be auctioned by New York City for other purposes. The gardeners themselves have earned a nod for weeding and cleaning and watering these odd-sized plots for years. The Trust for Public Land began earnestly negotiating a few months ago to try to buy some of the gardens. Activists planted lawsuits in recent days, stalling the date of the auction long enough to allow for a deal. Protesters converted themselves into ladybugs or sunflowers and marched off to jail for a good green cause. Even Mayor Rudolph Giuliani's administrators, the very ones readying these patches for auction to the highest and perhaps unsympathetic bidder, deserve thanks for agreeing to sell the land to those who wanted to develop little more than grassy triangles, bordered by nasturtiums or tomato plants.

title: Rushing to 'Justice'
description: To the Editor:

title: Problems In Goal Threaten Red Wings
description: The Stanley Cup reign of the Detroit Red Wings is in jeopardy because of injury and ineffectiveness in goal. The injured goalie is Chris Osgood, who has not played since the first round of the playoffs because of a sprained right knee. The ineffective goalie is Bill Ranford, who played so well in the first two games of this second-round series, both won by Detroit.

title: Murder and Arson Charged in House Fire
description: A 21-year-old immigrant from El Salvador was indicted by a Suffolk County grand jury yesterday in connection with a fire that killed 3 people and injured at least 10 others in Huntington Station.

title: Where to Go in Despair? To a Psychic, of Course
description: ''Iris Blond'' is a bittersweet romantic comedy that serves as a reminder of a time when frequent film imports from Italy and France constantly enriched what has come to be known as the quality of life in New York.

title: Crime in the Subways Declines Again
description: While the subway system may be a long way from shedding its image as a symbol of urban menace, new police statistics show that underground crime has dropped precipitously in the first four months of the year, continuing an eight-year decline that has been steeper than the city's overall drop in crime.

title: Album of the Week
description: RUFF RYDERS, ''RYDE OR DIE, VOL. I'' -- (Ruff Ryders/Inter scope). The crew is the organizing principle in hip-hop, uniting rappers, producers, executives and hangers-on in fealty to one clan. A hip-hop crew is like a software start-up crossed with a sports team crossed with a rock band, an enterprise propelled by productive arrogance.

title: Dostoyevsky, High Roller
description: To the Editor:

title: Brazilian Economy Expanded in First Quarter
description: The Brazilian economy defied pessimistic forecasts of stagnation in the first quarter and actually registered some growth, the Government said today in a report that showed Brazil's surprising resilience to the effects of the currency crisis that erupted in January.

title: On My Mind; Leading in Israel
description: During the Israeli election campaign now nearing decision time, the leader who showed the most political daring and skill, vastly outclassed his opponents in collecting international support and gave his followers his clear vision of the Israel-Palestine future has been Yasir Arafat.

title: Memories of Her Old Kentucky Home Trace the Roots of an Author's Fiction
description: CLEAR SPRINGS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCNEIL, LONNIE C.
description: McNEIL-Lonnie C.. On May 10, 1999. Of Massachusetts. Beloved son of Johnnie Mae. Also survived by four loving sisters. Grandson of Nettie C. Douglas. Funeral service to be held at Quinn Hopping Funeral Home, Livingston, New Jersey, Sunday, May 16, 12 noon. Visiting prior to service from 9 A.M. Interment Forest Lawn Memorial Gardens, Iselin, N.J. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Lonnie McNeil ''Inappropriate Fund'', C/O DeSisto School, P.O. Box 369, Stockbridge, MA 01262. Funds will help continue his vision.

title: Rushing to 'Justice'
description: To the Editor:

title: Elizabeth King -- 'Homunculus'
description: Kent Gallery

title: Are We Pushing Our Teen-Agers to Violence?; Stars Can Help
description: To the Editor:

title: Munching Scenery Like Crumpets
description: Call it ''Divas Live, 1935-1945.'' Or to be more accurate, ''Divas on Film.'' The grandes dames on parade in Franco Zeffirelli's sudsy, picturesque World War II drama, ''Tea With Mussolini,'' include Cher, Judi Dench, Joan Plowright, Dame Maggie Smith and Lily Tomlin. With the exception of Ms. Tomlin, playing the relatively thankless role of a butch, heavily suntanned archeologist stomping around northern Italy 60 years ago, these estimable actresses have been encouraged to chew up the scenery every chance they get. And oh do they grab at it!

title: Belgrade Blacked Out as NATO Planes Continue Assault
description: Parts of Belgrade sustained a blackout tonight as NATO warplanes struck at least one of the city's power plants in the heaviest strike in the capital since the Chinese Embassy was hit last Friday, Pentagon officials said.

title: No Squabbles, No Politics: Italy Names A President
description: Seeking consensus and political stability, the Parliament today chose Treasury Minister Carlo Azeglio Ciampi as Italy's new President.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Public Lives column yesterday about a decision by the writer Anna Quindlen to decline an honorary degree from Villanova University after threats of a protest by opponents of abortion misstated a phrase in some editions in quoting John Stanton, executive director of the Pro-Life Union of Southeastern Pennsylvania. He said of the opponents, ''They felt very badly that the university was honoring a pro-abortion person'' (not ''a pro-life person'').

title: End to Commuter Tax Nears With Jolting Speed in Albany
description: It began as just one more overture to voters in a special election for a State Senate seat northwest of New York City. First one candidate, then the other declared that the state should end the tax on commuters who work in the city, never expecting that repeal would amount to anything more than talk.

title: Historic Papers in Hiss Case Are Ordered Unsealed
description: In a potentially groundbreaking ruling that could help resolve some of the enduring mysteries of the cold war, a Federal judge in Manhattan yesterday ordered the Government to unseal thousands of pages of secret grand jury testimony from the investigation of Alger Hiss and the underground Communist movement in the United States.

title: Latest Crisis In Moscow Is One Bump After Many
description: There was a lot of smoke, but little debate today in the employees' lounge at the Master and Margarita Hair Salon on the busy Garden Ring Road, as two hairdressers reluctantly discussed Moscow's latest political crisis during a cigarette break.

title: WACHOVIA IS BUYING OFFITBANK HOLDINGS IN STOCK DEAL
description: The Wachovia Corporation, the Southeast's third-largest bank, agreed to acquire Offitbank Holdings Inc., a global money-management company catering to wealthy investors, for about $200 million in stock. Offitbank, based in New York, manages about $11 billion. It will retain its name and be a subsidiary of Wachovia. Morris W. Offit will continue to lead the company he formed in 1983. The stock of Wachovia, based in Winston-Salem, N.C., rose 93.75 cents, to $91.1875. Offitbank decided last year to delay a planned sale of shares to the public, citing a poor market for shares of fund-management companies.

title: Bill on Emergency Spending Hits $15 Billion at the Finish
description: After three days and nights of haggling, House and Senate negotiators tonight wrapped up an emergency spending package that ballooned to almost $15 billion, twice what the White House had sought, to pay for wars and disasters around the world.

title: Dangerous Sideshow in the Kremlin
description: It is probably too much to expect from Russia's Communist legislators, but they ought to drop their misguided impeachment drive against Boris Yeltsin before it further destabilizes the Kremlin. No good can come of this needless confrontation, and it could produce a protracted crisis that leaves Russia even more wounded than it is today.

title: INSIDE
description: A Bill for All Reasons

title: 'Rome and the Campagna' -- Oil Sketches by Auguste Jean-Baptiste Vinchon and Other French Artists and a Selection of European Sculpture
description: Simon Dickinson/Newhouse Galleries

title: Hoechst-Rhone Deal Passes Key Hurdle
description: The Kuwait Petroleum Corporation, Hoechst A.G.'s main shareholder, cleared a revised plan for the German company to unite with Rhone-Poulenc S.A. of France, paving the way for the creation of the world's biggest drug maker. Hoechst shareholders are expected to have a 53 percent stake in the combined company, to be called Aventis S.A.

title: Are We Pushing Our Teen-Agers to Violence?; Adults Shape the Images
description: To the Editor:

title: The Awful Anguish of a Wife Displaced
description: ''Leila'' was shown as part of last year's New Directors/New Films series. Following are excerpts from Stephen Holden's review, which appeared in The New York Times on March 28, 1998. The film opens today at the Cinema Village, 22 East 12th Street, Greenwich Village.

title: Chancellor Calls On Council to Raise School Spending
description: Taking his feud with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani to still another forum, Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew went on the offensive yesterday to rally the City Council to support billions more in spending for school construction.

title: In Speeches, Lawmakers Drub Yeltsin; He's Silent
description: With Russia's political and economic fates in suspended animation after the sacking of Prime Minister Yevgeny M. Primakov, the Communist-led Parliament began a surreal and mostly ritual struggle today over whether to impeach President Boris N. Yeltsin for treason, genocide and other crimes.

title: Rock Music Videos as an Art Form With a Festival of Its Very Own
description: Happening across the video for Fatboy Slim's ''Praise You,'' now in heavy rotation on MTV, channel surfers may wonder whether they've dropped into a dream state. Credited to the Torrance Community Dance Group, the video follows a singularly inept group of terpsichoreans as they set up a boombox at a crowded multiplex and leap, twist and flutter to this English hit maker's exuberant dance music. A wobbly camera captures moviegoers dodging the dancers and looking aghast at their creative efforts. The whole affair seems more like a guerrilla art attack than a commercial for a pop song.

title: Things Rare, Beautiful and Very French
description: The small, refined world of fine French antiques dealers in New York has just shrunk: Tony Victoria has sold his family's five-floor gallery on East 55th Street.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- The Hype Is With Us; The Lucas Empire Is Invading; Resistance Is Futile
description: Coming soon, a film with marketing more choreographed than a Fred Astaire version of ''Saturday Night Fever''! More skillfully planned than the mission to save Matt Damon! A campaign more orchestrated than all of Bernard Herrmann's scores for Alfred Hitchcock! Yes, a movie even more unsinkable than Titanic!

title: Sandro Chia
description: Tony Shafrazi Gallery

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-14

title: Memories of Series Past Moderate the Knicks' Giddiness
description: The Knicks streamed through the corridor clapping their hands and letting out a whoop or two as they crossed the threshold of a locker room that had a fraternity house feel to it. And then there was the buzz killer.

title: NCO AGREES TO BUY COMPASS INTERNATIONAL SERVICES
description: NCO Group Inc., a collection agency based in Fort Washington, Pa., agreed yesterday to acquire the Compass International Services Corporation, a provider of outsourced business services, in a stock deal valued at $112 million. NCO is to issue 0.23739 share of its own stock for each share of Compass. In conjunction with the acquisition, Compass will divest itself of its print and mail operation to the division's management for $35.1 million. Compass, based in New York, specializes in managing accounts receivable, mailing and telemarketing. Shares in both companies slumped. Compass shares were down 93.75 cents at $6.4375, while NCO fell $3.50, to $29.375.

title: Clinton Admits to Concerns As Gore Campaign Stumbles
description: President Clinton acknowledged tonight that he has been concerned that Vice President Al Gore's Presidential campaign was off to a sluggish start. He said he had personally coached Mr. Gore on how to loosen up and appear less remote and rigid on the campaign trail.

title: NBC Edits 'Nuclear Waste' From Program
description: What began as a generic disaster movie about a runaway train has turned into an unusual damage-control exercise for NBC, which went to great lengths to redub ''Atomic Train,'' a two-part mini-series to be broadcast on Sunday and Monday nights, to delete all references to nuclear waste.

title: REVERSING STANCE, REPUBLICANS URGE A GUN-SALE CURB
description: A day after Senate Republicans defeated a Democratic proposal to require background checks on buyers at gun shows, they turned around today and advocated a measure of their own that they said would do precisely that, a startling reversal that reflected their skittishness about being portrayed as soft on guns.

title: Golden Days For Painting In Denmark
description: Until about 15 years ago few people who had not spent a lot of time in Copenhagen had any sense of the quality of Danish painting between 1800 and 1850. Picture fanciers went to Copenhagen for the Old Masters and for the formidable concentration of Henri Matisse in the Statens Museum for Kunst. But no one beat the drum for the ''Danish Painters of the Golden Age,'' as they are now called.

title: Yinka Shonibare
description: Brent Sikkema Gallery

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGER, HANNAH
description: BERGER-Hannah. Beloved wife of the late Jack. Dear mother of Marvin (Lynn) and Arnold. Adored grandmother of David, Kenneth, Jennifer, Gregory and Andrea.

title: Lawyer Is Nominated for F.T.C. Position
description: President Clinton will nominate a Washington antitrust lawyer, Thomas B. Leary, to a vacant seat on the Federal Trade Commission, the White House said this week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANDSMAN, GERT (DUNAY)
description: LANDSMAN-Gert (Dunay). Age 93. A retired Florida licensed interior designer. Passed away on May 12, 1999. She was predeceased by her husband Paul. A loving mother, grandmother and great-grandmother. She is survived by a daughter, Dr. Bette (Dr. Robert) Holzberg, a son Richard (Helen) Landsman as well as five grandchildren, Lauren (Alan Mounty), Lisa (Fred) Daitch, Leslie (Frank) Schmidt, four great-grandchildren Alyssa and Meredith Mounty, Bradley and Alexandrea Daitch, and Jared Paul Landsman. A dynamic, vivacious and caring person. She will be missed by all who knew her.

title: Are We Pushing Our Teen-Agers to Violence?
description: To the Editor:

title: City Considering a Modern Fulton Fish Market at a New Site
description: The city is considering a multimillion-dollar plan to modernize and move the Fulton Fish Market from the storied but gritty site it has occupied for 166 years in lower Manhattan, a top Giuliani administration official said yesterday.

title: FOR CHILDREN
description: Theater

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRAVELL, CLARK
description: TRAVELL-Clark. Holland Lodge #

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MICHELL, JACQUES DR.
description: MICHELL-Jacques Dr.. On Wenesday, May 12, 1999. Loving husband of Irina, father of Monica and grandfather of Isabella. Dr. Michell was a dedicated internist in private practice in New Rochelle for thirty years, and on the staff of the Sound Shore Medical Center. He faced life with courage and humor and enriched the lives of all who knew him. Visiting will be tonight from 7-9 PM, at the George T. Davis Funeral Home, 14 LeCount Place, New Rochelle, New York. Service is on Saturday, 1 PM, at the funeral home chapel. Cremation will follow at the Ferncliff Crematory.

title: Gene Sarazen, 97, Golf Champion, Dies
description: Gene Sarazen, whose stylish, effective swing and dogged demeanor made him one of the finest golfers of the 1920's and 30's, died yesterday in Naples, Fla. He was 97.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HECK, SANDY (L.S. HECK, JR.)
description: HECK-Sandy (L.S. Heck, Jr.). died at home in New York City from complications of anorexia on April 16, 1999. He was 49. A freelance writer of architecture and design criticism for publications in New York, London, and Tokyo, he graduated from Oberlin College and studied at the Institute for Architecture and Urban Studies (New York), the Foundation Le Corbusier (Paris), and the Architectural Association (London). He is survived by his mother, Irma, of Pomona, CA; sister, Susan, of Pasadena, CA; niece, Elisa Schement; and many friends. A memorial service will be held at St. Mark's Church, 85 E. Main St., Mt. Kisco, NY, at 11 a.m. May 22. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Oberlin College, in memory of Sandy Heck, 1902 Bosworth Hall, Oberlin, OH 44074.

title: Corrections
description: The Making Books column yesterday, about Pat Jordan's troubles in having his latest book published, misspelled the surname of his agent. The agent is David Vigliano, not Vigiano.

title: Nuclear Power Industry Ads Called Potentially Deceptive
description: The Better Business Bureau said today that ads run by the nuclear power industry about the air pollution benefits of reactors ''have a strong potential to mislead customers'' and that it would ask the Federal Trade Commission and possibly state attorneys general to investigate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPOHN, ROBERTA R.
description: SPOHN-Roberta R.. On May 13, 1999, of New York City. Beloved wife of Santo J. Pafumi. She was cherished and loved deeply by her daughters, Jessica and Leine. Mother-in-law to Scott and David. Adoring grandmother to Alexandra, Julia, Leopold and Oliver. Services Sunday 10:45AM at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that memorial contributions be made to ''Citizens Advice Bureau,'' Bronx, NY.

title: Ethics Panel Gives Rare Rebuke
description: The House ethics committee has given a rare private rebuke to Representative Tom DeLay of Texas, the Republican whip, for badgering a lobbying organization over its hiring of a Democrat as its president, House aides said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, DOROTHY
description: LEVINE-Dorothy. Died on May 13, 1999 at 91 years of age. Mrs. Levine was a resident of Hallandale, FL. She is survived by her beloved husband Benjamin Levine, her sons Leonard and Herbert, her daughters-in-law Myrna and Linda and her grandchildren Amy, David and Michelle and her brother Bernard Kauffman. She was a past president of The United Order of True Sisters and was born and lived most of her life in Brooklyn, N.Y. Funeral services are at 12Noon on Sunday, May 16 at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad St, Mt. Vernon, N.Y. Contributions in her name may be made to the American Heart Association or the National Multiple Sclerosis Society.

title: Two Shutout Losses Make Yanks Look Suddenly Ordinary
description: The sheen of invincibility the Yankees donned last season is gone, the last of it peeled away last night by the Anaheim Angels, who completed a three-game sweep at Yankee Stadium with a 2-0 shutout, the first visiting team sweep since July 1997.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL RISES. Crude oil prices increased after OPEC confirmed progress in cutting production and Saudi Arabia predicted prices would continue to rise. In New York, crude oil for June delivery rose 46 cents, to $18.03 a barrel.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COFFEE RISES 3.6 PERCENT. Coffee prices jumped after the Agriculture Department said Brazil, the largest producer, would supply 26 percent less coffee this year. The July contract rose 3.75 cents, to $1.074 a pound.

title: Rockets Are Unreliable
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEINBERG, FREDA
description: STEINBERG-Freda. The Levine family, Larry, Jay, Susan (Kane), express their sorrow at the passing of one of our oldest friends, Freda Steinberg (Speedy), a wonderful lady. Our condolences to the Steinberg and Korins family.

title: Signs That Russia's Economy May Be Gradually Reviving
description: Against the backdrop of Russia's political turmoil, the economy seems to be gradually reviving from its collapse last summer, with increased consumer spending and industrial production, a Moscow research group said today in a widely followed monthly report.

title: Gaiman Journal; Just Think of It as a Little Wales With Cactuses
description: When guests arrive at the Hosteria Gwesty Tywi, a local bed-and-breakfast, Gwyn and Monica Jones pass around a gourd of mate, the potent herbal tea that Argentines drink communally to establish friendship.

title: Project to Rescue Needy Stumbles Against the Persistence of Poverty
description: Imagine what would happen if society could guarantee every poor person a path from poverty: an assured job at a sufficient wage, with child care and health care as well. How many would take it? How many would prosper?

title: Queens Finds Its Own Landmarks; One Resident's Poultry Market Is Another's Historic Site
description: The old factory building on 43d Avenue and 97th Place looks much like its neighbors in that industrial stretch of Corona, Queens. At one end, workers sell live chickens from big metal cages. In another section, seamstresses piece together ladies' garments.

title: Officer Who Broke the Code of Silence Defies Labels
description: After giving damning evidence to Internal Affairs investigators, Eric Turetzky, a rookie New York City police officer, emerged from an interview room at the 70th Precinct station house in Brooklyn. It was not yet dawn on Aug. 15, 1997, six days after a handcuffed defendant, Abner Louima, allegedly was tortured in a bathroom at the precinct.

title: Heat Answers With a Run of Its Own
description: Latrell Sprewell bounded off the bench and sprinted toward his teammates to dance and twirl around the court with them like kids hearing the last bell on the final day of school.

title: Socialism For the Rich
description: ''This is a free-market economy. Welcome to the era after Communism.'' So said Mayor Rudolph Giuliani in explaining his foiled plans to sell 112 community gardens to private developers -- destroying urban green space that helps build community.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SALEEBY, JAMES T.
description: SALEEBY-James T., husband of Evelyn E. (nee Tahan); loving brother of Samir, June Pearson, & Patsy Stein. It is with deep sorrow that we announce the untimely death of James T. Saleeby, born in South Carolina, raised in Lebanon and later in Bay Ridge where he was a renowned figure. He will be missed by all who had contact with him. Viewing will be at McLaughlin & Sons, 9620 Third Avenue, Brooklyn, New York, on Sunday May 16, 1999 from 2 PM to 5 PM and 7 PM to 9 PM. Service will be at The Church of the Virgin Mary at 216 8th Ave. Brooklyn, NY Monday, May 17, 1999 at 10 AM. May he rest in peace.

title: Now That Canada Has Gone Hollywood
description: A recent news report says that Hollywood, pressed by declining profits and ballooning expenses at home, has shifted production abroad, especially to Canada.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPOHN, ROBERTA R.
description: SPOHN-Roberta R. On May 13, 1999, of New York City. Beloved wife of Santo J. Pafumi. She was cherished and loved deeply by her daughters, Jessica and Leine. Mother-in-law to Scott and David. Stepmother to Nancy. Adoring grandmother to Alexandra, Julia, Leopold and Oliver. Services Sunday 10:45AM at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers, the family requests memorial contributions to ''Citizens Advice Bureau,'' Bronx, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  NELSON, DORIS SIEGEL
description: NELSON-Doris Siegel. In loving memory of our dearest mother, grandmother and mother-in-law who remains always in our thoughts. We miss you. Elizabeth, Margery, Jonathan, Karen, Amy, Andrea, Meredith, Bill, Laurie, Maisi

title: An Addict With One Weapon: Hope
description: Chris Antley, riding afternoon and night at two tracks, once won nine races in a single day. In 1991, he guided Strike the Gold to victory in the Kentucky Derby. And he was a savvy enough player of the stock market that he turned the $6 million he had earned riding race horses into a fortune big enough to insure that he would not have to work again.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOORSTEIN, MACCABAE, M.D.
description: BOORSTEIN-Maccabae, M.D. Beloved husband of Thelma. Devoted father of Jonathan and Carol. Service Sunday, 12 Noon, ''Sinai Chapels'', 162-05 Horace Harding Expwy, Fresh Meadows, N.Y.

title: Malcolm X's Diary for Sale, But Ownership Is in Doubt
description: City officials began investigating yesterday how the bloodied, bullet-riddled diary of Malcolm X, which was in his coat pocket when he was assassinated 34 years ago, got into the hands of a private collector who is now auctioning it off in California.

title: MetroStars Look to Regain Scoring Touch
description: Scoring only one goal in the first four games at home is not what the MetroStars had in mind in their attempt to lure soccer fans to Giants Stadium. The MetroStars will enter tonight's game against the Miami Fusion without having scored a goal in the last 280 minutes of action at home.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRAZER, LILLIAN (LEE)
description: FRAZER-Lillian (Lee). Beloved wife of Dan Frazer. Loving mother of Susan Frazer Hofmaier. Devoted grandmother of Luke and Tess. Fond sister of Marie and Edith Hogsett and Elizabeth Flemen. Memorial service at a later date.

title: Duke's Plan Ends the Ban On Research
description: A four-day ban on federally financed human experiments at Duke University Medical Center was lifted today after Duke agreed to overhaul its protections for human subjects.

title: Transit Union Seeks 30 Percent Raise, and Hints at a New Year's Eve Strike
description: Raising the possibility of a strike on New Year's Eve, the president of New York City's largest union is calling for a 30 percent raise over three years in coming contract talks with the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

title: DEUTSCHE BANK EXPECTED TO RETIRE BANKERS TRUST NAME
description: The Bankers Trust name is likely to disappear, even in the United States, after the acquisition of the Bankers Trust Corporation by Deutsche Bank A.G. of Germany. The expected demise of the name was first reported yesterday by the British newspaper The Financial Times. Deutsche Bank is expected to become the primary brand name in the United States, although the BT Alex. Brown investment banking brand will reportedly be widely used for marketing.

title: Graf Is Eliminated; Williams Pulls Out
description: The German Open lost two of its most prominent players yesterday after a hobbling Steffi Graf lost in three sets, and Serena Williams pulled out because of an arm injury.

title: Airline Suit: 70's Revival In Antitrust
description: By accusing American Airlines of lowering its prices in a deliberate attempt to drive smaller competitors out of its hub at Dallas-Fort Worth International Airport, as it did on Thursday, the Justice Department has adopted a risky legal strategy.

title: Political Briefing; Republicans Gaining In Democratic Bastion
description: Chalk up more Republican resurgence in the South, this time in Arkansas, perhaps the most Democratic state left in Dixie.

title: World Briefing
description: AFRICA

title: Will the Gore Campaign's New Chief Be a Boon or a Burden?
description: In 1981, when Ronald Reagan had just become President, Republicans had taken control of the Senate, and Democrats were desperately hanging on to the House of Representatives as a last bastion, Tony Coelho, a young Congressman from California in only his second term, was put in charge of raising campaign money for House Democrats.

title: ALBANIANS KILLED AS KOSOVO VILLAGE IS BLASTED APART
description: More than 60 Albanians were killed and scores more badly wounded late Thursday night when bombs blew apart a village in southwest Kosovo, near Prizren, Yugoslav officials and journalists at the scene said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOWARD, BARBARA A.
description: HOWARD-Barbara A. On May 14, 1999. Devoted cousin of Mrs. Robert Scott of Hanson, Mass. and Mrs. Robert Fernald of Mashpee, Mass. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street on Sunday from 2-5 and 7-9 P.M. Funeral Mass at Saint Stephen of Hungary Church, 414 East 82nd Street, New York City on Monday, 10 A.M. Interment West Medford, Mass.

title: Taking on Sex and the Single Saint; For Gary Wills, St. Augustine is Just the Latest Chapter in His Study of Culture
description: Sinners have always loved Augustine, the fourth-century saint, for he has seemed like such a great sinner himself. He was obsessed with sex, or so it appeared in his great work ''The City of God.'' And he was willing to undertake a rigorous self-analysis in writings like his ''Confessions,'' giving him an almost contemporary accessibility.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHULMAN, LEO
description: SCHULMAN-Leo. Died Friday, May 14, 1999. Husband of Florence. Father of Joan and Michael. Grandfather of Dana, Mara, Daniel and Molly. His neices, nephews and extended family will miss him greatly. In loving memory a memorial service will be held Sunday May 16th. at 12:30PM at George T. Davis funeral Home, 14 Le Count Place, New Rochelle,NY.

title: In One Deathly Business, Paying the Consequences
description: Before taking your seat for ''A Hotel Room in the Town of NN,'' you have to sidestep the body of an actor playing a groggy servant who is either too dim-witted or drunk or both to move out of the doorway.

title: The Striped Bass Return
description: No fish is more emblematic of New York's waterfront setting than the striped bass. ''Its symmetry, marks, and satin sheen,'' wrote Genio Scott 130 years ago, ''render it one of the most picturesque and interesting fishes in the world, independent of its great game, generous play, and luxury as a dinner fish.'' One rarely hears more enjoyable news than the report this spring, from up and down the Hudson River, that striped bass have returned in greatly increased numbers and sizes. There is even better news. In the lower river the bass have generally been testing below the Federal limit allowed for PCB's, which were released into the river years ago by General Electric.

title: Frank Stanton, 78, a Real Estate Investor and Entrepreneur
description: Frank Stanton, an entrepreneur and real estate investor who developed an early videocassette, died last Sunday at his home in Water Mill, on Long Island. He was 78.

title: Faced With 'Parvenu' or 'Pariah,' Ellison Settled on 'Artist'
description: Ralph Ellison will not have it easy in death, just as he did not have it easy in life. In a 1982 letter recently published in ''The New Republic,'' he complained about the harsh treatment he received ''from some of the so-called Black Radicals during the late 60's and most of the 30's.'' That included accusations that the author of ''Invisible Man'' (1952) was an ''Uncle Tom,'' a careerist producing ''obsequious bleatings of white appeasement.''

title: How I Kicked the Talk-Show-Guest Habit
description: So ''The Jenny Jones Show'' must pay $25 million to the family whose son was gunned down by one of her guests. A Michigan jury issued the verdict last week, though appeals await. The guest says Jenny tricked him into coming on her ''secret crush'' show in 1995 by implying that his admirer would be a woman, not a gay man.

title: Silicon Valley's New Think Tank Stakes Out 'Radical Center'
description: In Thinktankland, the main attractions are by now wearyingly familiar. The conservative Heritage Foundation and the American Enterprise Institute and the liberal-centrist Brookings Institution along with several others have for years competed to convert their ideas about taxes, foreign policy, the environment or whatever into policy in the real world.

title: Corrections
description: An article on May 5 about the outbreak of a disease in the Congo that has killed at least 63 people misstated a comment from Dr. Ray R. Arthur of the World Health Organization about recent cases of hemorrhagic fever around the world. He said that there had been 50 confirmed cases in the last two years, not that 50 such cases had been caused by the Ebola virus.

title: Yugoslavia Fears Loss of Its E-Mail
description: Internet users rushed to send last-minute E-mail messages at a downtown Internet cafe today, after word circulated that the United States was going to cut off Yugoslavia from the World Wide Web.

title: Political Notes; City Council Rematch Brews on Staten Island
description: With elections for the State Legislature and Congress a year away and New York City's next major municipal races a year after that, 1999 is likely to be a pallid year in local politics. But a heated rematch is shaping up in one corner of the city, a City Council district that includes the center of Staten Island and a slice of Brooklyn.

title: Libraries for All
description: To the Editor:

title: Woods Shares Lead by One on a 67-128
description: Tiger Woods held a share of the lead, 19-year-old Sergio Garcia held a share of third place, and the weekend at the GTE Byron Nelson Classic held intriguing possibilities.

title: Commuter Tax Helps City Compete; Why Not Just Leave?
description: To the Editor:

title: Hernandez and Yanks Set Off Distress Signals
description: The magic has vanished for Orlando Hernandez and the dominance has vanished for the Yankees. At least for now. Hernandez had another sluggish start in which he could not collect outs and the Yankees had another exasperating contest in which they could not produce much offense. The result was an 8-2 loss to the Chicago White Sox last night at Yankee Stadium.

title: First Lady Pays Visit To a Camp
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton swept through Macedonia today on a visit that illustrated Washington's continuing struggle to balance the diverse strands of its Kosovo policy.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: WILLIAMS BUYS STAKE IN BRAZILIAN PHONE COMPANY
description: The Williams Companies, the largest transporter of natural gas in the United States and the owner of a fiber optic telephone network, said yesterday that it had bought a 19 percent stake in Algar Telecom Leste S.A., a Brazilian cellular phone company, from Lightel S.A. for $265 million in cash. Algar Telecom provides cellular phone service to about 446,000 customers in the Brazilian states of Rio de Janeiro and Espirito Santo. Williams already owns 20 percent of Lightel, which was the first nongovernment telephone company in Brazil. Lightel, based in Uberlandia, Brazil, still owns 51 percent of Algar Telecom.

title: Senate Passes Republican Plan On Checking Gun-Show Buyers
description: In a squeaker of a vote, Senate Republicans today passed a measure to promote background checks at gun shows, one that Democrats, preferring a more stringent proposal of their own, almost solidly opposed.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: Libraries for All
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVY, SHELDON I.
description: LEVY-Sheldon I. Beloved husband of Barbara. Devoted father of Deborah Maher, Diane Cooper, and Daniel Levy. Proud grandfather of Joseph, Alison and Harry Maher. Past president of Community Reform Temple, past president of Gates of Woodbury Civic Association, past vice-president of YM-YWHA Plainview, Senior Law Partner, Levy, Davis, Maher and Klein. Services on Sunday, 11 A.M. at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, Long Island.

title: The Price to Rescue Kosovars Is High
description: Dr. Mustafe Abdyli and his family hid when they heard a car approaching on a recent Sunday morning.

title: Commuter Tax Helps City Compete; Try a Regional Fee
description: To the Editor:

title: Board Proposes Rent Increases For Apartments
description: A proposal by the city's Rent Guidelines Board to increase rents in stabilized buildings by 2 percent to 4 percent came as no surprise to city officials, landlords or tenants Thursday night. But it has nevertheless drawn criticism: landlords say the increase is too low to cover expenses and some tenant advocates call it unfair, especially for the elderly and others with limited incomes.

title: An Arcane Doctrine Surprisingly Upheld
description: In overturning a clean-air standard today, a Federal appeals court panel here focused on the ''nondelegation doctrine,'' invoking a phrase with an unfamiliar ring. Indeed, the notion that Congress can violate the constitutional separation of powers by delegating too much legislative-like authority to another branch of government has essentially been a non-issue since the early days of the New Deal.

title: Injured Cabby Disarms Man And Turns Him Over to Police
description: A Brooklyn livery-cab driver whose head was grazed by a passenger's bullet on Thursday night disarmed the gunman, chased him down and made a citizen's arrest, the police said yesterday.

title: Sears Is Fined $325,000 by U.S. For Violating Child-Labor Laws
description: The United States Department of Labor announced a $325,000 fine against Sears, Roebuck & Company yesterday after investigators uncovered child-labor violations at more than 60 percent of the Sears stores they visited.

title: KEEBLER WILL CLOSE NEW JERSEY PLANT
description: The Keebler Foods Company said yesterday that it planned to close its manufacturing plant in Sayreville, N.J. The company, the nation's second-biggest maker of cookies and crackers, said it was immediately ending most production at the plant, which employs 598 people, although about 150 of the employees would continue to work through September. Keebler attributed the closing to excess capacity within its 18-plant system. The company will incur costs of about $69 million from the closing, which will lower its second-quarter earnings by about 48 cents a share. For the second quarter last year, Keebler, based in Elmhurst, Ill., earned $19.4 million, or 22 cents a share, on sales of $490 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SARGENT, CLAUDIA E.
description: SARGENT-Claudia E. Of South Londonderry, Vermont, formerly of Cambridge, Massachusetts died on May 12, 1999 at home after a long illness. She is survived by her husband Paul Fienberg; her son Benjamin; her sisters Andrea Praeger, Alexandra Praeger, Manya Praeger and Julia Blaut; & her stepchildren Leah, Greta & Luke Feinberg. Memorial services at her home on Sunday, May 16, 1999, at 1PM. Contributions in her memory may be made to Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center (memo: ''C. Sargent Breast Cancer Research'') C/O Dr. Jerome Groopman, Harvard Institute of Medicine, 4 Blackfan Circle, Room 351, Boston, Massachusetts 02115.

title: Plan on School Promotions Advances
description: Toning down their feud, Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani met at City Hall yesterday and emerged reporting substantial progress on a plan to end the promotion of hundreds of thousands of failing students.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Spare Times listing in Weekend yesterday for the 10th Pathmark Multicultural Arts Festival, being held today from 1 to 6 P.M. at Kings Plaza in Brooklyn, misstated the telephone number. It is (914) 762-2868.

title: A Giant Of Labor Is Released
description: The Big Rat has been sprung, but for how long?

title: About New York; Still Unable To Proclaim: 'This Is Mine'
description: WHEN Celia Angel was growing up in Mexico, she was orphaned by her fifth birthday and sent to live with relatives who treated her more like a servant than kin. Maybe that's why she tried giving her 11 children the tenderness she never had. And maybe that's why she relished the affection her children and grandchildren gave her on Mother's Day.

title: IRIDIUM STOCK DROPS AS COMPANY'S TROUBLES CONTINUE
description: The stock of the troubled satellite phone company Iridium World Communications Ltd. slid more than 28 percent yesterday after the company said it would not meet key terms of its $800 million bank loan. Iridium, based in Washington, said it had hired Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette to help it review and restructure its debt. A consortium of telecommunications companies spent about $4 billion to launch Iridium's 66-satellite system, but the service has been dogged by technical, marketing and financial difficulties. Iridium reported a wider-than-expected first-quarter loss and had signed up only 10,300 customers by the end of March. Its debt covenants include a target of at least 27,000 customers by May 31. Shares of Iridium dropped $4.1875 each, to $10.3125, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Silverbulletday Zips to Victory For 8th in a Row
description: Silverbulletday, the filly who was scratched from the Preakness after she drew an outside post position, gave a commanding performance from the inside post position today as she won the Black-Eyed Susan Stakes for her eighth straight victory.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Circuits on April 28 about Echobuzz, a free voice mail service, referred incorrectly to messages to users of the service. Those may be sent by anyone, not only by Echobuzz members.

title: Why We Need Dams
description: To the Editor:

title: White House Gives Support To Measure On Spending
description: Eager for money to pay for the war in Yugoslavia, the White House today said it expected President Clinton to sign a nearly $15 billion emergency spending measure that doubles what the President had requested for the Balkan conflict, for Central American hurricane victims and for hard-pressed American farmers.

title: Op-Art
Manhattan's Loews Screens Won't Show 'Star Wars'
description: To movie studios, the Upper West Side of Manhattan is boom town. Movie theaters there generate the highest box office revenue of any area in New York City, which, in turn, is the biggest film market in the nation.

title: Stockton Forces A Game 5
description: JAZZ 90, KINGS 89

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEFSON, SYLVIA
description: LEFSON-Sylvia. Of Hallandale, FL. 1901-1999. Formerly of Morristown, N.J. Died May 14, 1999. Survived by daughters Sandra Lerner of Great Neck, N.Y. and Diane Sykes of Washington, D.C. Also survived by four grandchildren and nine great grandchildren. Funeral service at Doyle Funeral Home, Maple Ave., Morristown, New Jersey on Sunday, 2PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NELSON, BETTY
description: NELSON-Betty. Beloved wife of her late husband Nathan. Survived by her children Gloria (Arthur), Milton (Betty Rose), and Brenda (Dennis). Also survived by two grandchildren, Mirian and Daniel, and her great-grandson Natan. We will miss her, but she will live in our hearts forever.

title: Future Martyr Takes It a Day at a Time
description: As a drama, and maybe even as a history lesson, ''Joan of Arc'' works. This CBS mini-series, which begins tomorrow night, manages to present its 15th-century heroine as a real and fallible young woman without robbing her story of the required patina of legend. From Joan's sad little village to her devastating battles to the inquisition that condemns her, the film follows a course of emotional authenticity.

title: Banca Commerciale Rejects Unicredito Bid
description: Banca Commerciale Italiana S.p.A., Italy's No. 4 bank, yesterday rebuffed a takeover offer of 12.8 billion euro ($13.6 billion) from Unicredito Italiano, rejecting the largest bid ever for an Italian bank. The move came after a seven-hour board meeting.

title: Allies Say Assigning Blame Should Wait for an Inquiry
description: After Belgrade charged that a NATO warplane had fired on refugees in the southwestern Kosovo village of Korisa, Pentagon officials said today that NATO warplanes were attacking in the general area around Korisa, but that they had no evidence so far that any of the planes had been near the village.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ASTORINA, ANTONIA
description: ASTORINA-Antonia. On May 13, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Giuseppe. Devoted mother of Antoinette, Nicolina, John and Frances. Loving grandmother of John Paul, Joseph and Karen. Friends may call at the Andrett Funeral Home, 353 2nd Avenue (at 20th Street), Saturday and Sunday from 2-5PM and 7-9PM. Mass of Christian burial on Monday 10am at Epiphany R.C. Church. Interment St. John's Cemetery.

title: Accounting Panel May Delay Derivatives Rule
description: The nation's accounting rule makers may delay the date when companies must begin following a controversial new rule that requires them to record the value of derivatives in their financial statements.

title: A Legal Exit From Kosovo Mess
description: To the Editor:

title: Housing for the Elderly
description: To the Editor:

title: A 'Killing' Game at Schools Turns Worrisome
description: Beginning next week, 35 elite students from Staples High School here plan to arm themselves with plastic guns with names like Lock 'n' Load, Secret Shot II and Expand-a-Blast, then stalk classmates through town.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAUM, LEONARD
description: BAUM-Leonard. Loving husband of Estelle. Devoted father of Steven, Susan, Joyce and Gregory. Loving grandfather of Alexander, Adam, Robyn and David. Dear brother of Arthur, Toby and Lillian Sanders. Adored uncle. Services Sunday, 12 Noon, ''Gutterman's Funeral Home'' (Riverside Building), Amsterdam Avenue at 76th Street, New York, New York.

title: Commuter Tax Helps City Compete; Windfall for the Mayor
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Industry Back on Its Feet in a Wobbly World
description: When financial crisis swept through Asia, Brazil and Russia last year, American industry prepared to duck. With goods accounting for over 70 percent of exports, manufacturers were sure to take a hit.

title: Riley Quiets The Chants
description: I HAVE to admit to pulling for Pat Riley last night. That's a difficult thing to do, more difficult to admit to doing. Riley is not a sympathetic figure. Never has been. Not in his college days at Kentucky, when he drove the snazzy sports car; not in his journeyman career in the National Basketball Association, when he was mostly a hack, a physical presence. Not in the latter stages of coaching the Lakers and Showtime, when he began to take himself so seriously.

title: MEADOWCRAFT ACCEPTS SWEETENED BUYOUT BID
description: Meadowcraft Inc., the largest maker of wrought-iron furniture in the United States, has accepted a sweetened offer of about $53.2 million in cash from its chairman, Samuel Blount, for the 27 percent of the company his family does not own. Mr. Blount's MWI Acquisition Company will pay $10 a share, $2 more than his previous offer, for the remaining 5.32 million shares. The revised offer values the company, whose brands include Plantation Patterns and Salterini, at $197 million. Meadowcraft, based in Birmingham, Ala., had gone public just 18 months ago. Its shares rose $2.6875 each, to $9.6875.

title: Beware 'Safe' Leads And Doubles Into Game
description: The prestigious Cavendish Pairs has often produced long-shot winners, and it almost happened in Las Vegas last weekend. Curtis Cheek and Billy Miller outdistanced a field that included bunches of world champions, and were in the lead with one round remaining to be scored. They were then overtaken by Steve Weinstein and Bobby Levin, losing by one of the smallest margins in the history of the Cavendish.

title: Council Voices Distress Over Embassy Attack
description: A week after NATO missiles hit the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade, China and the United States hammered out a formal statement late Friday night expressing the Security Council's ''deep distress and concern'' about the attack.

title: Political Briefing; Et Tu, Tennessee? Bumps in Gore's Ride
description: It is an old story.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WINTER, MARVIN S.
description: WINTER-Marvin S. The Trustees, Faculty and Administration of New York University School of Medicine and Medical Center profoundly regret the passing of a loyal friend and supporter. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife Eleanor, his son James and his entire family. Henry R. Silverman, Chairman Board of Trustees NYU School of Medicine Robert M. Glickman, MD Dean, NYU School of Medicine Theresa A. Bischoff, President NYU Hospitals Center

title: Two Brothers Battling Bitterly in the Bedroom
description: IT must be the rule of their series, or the nature of the species. These familiar teams, these feuding Knicks and frothing Heat, play until they no longer can, like battling brothers squaring off in their bedroom.

title: Abroad at Home; On a Wing And a Prayer?
description: It would be hard to find stronger words in condemnation of Slobodan Milosevic than President Clinton used in a talk to World War II veterans the other day.

title: Charismatic Not Getting Respect in the Preakness
description: On the day before the Preakness, a wide-open race with no sure favorite and a dozen contenders, only one thing seemed certain today: Charismatic, the long shot who won the Kentucky Derby two weeks ago at odds of 31-1, was still something of a long shot to make it two straight in the Triple Crown series.

title: Bobbe Brox, 98, Vocalist in a Family Trio
description: Bobbe Brox, the last surviving member of the vocal trio who called themselves the Brox Sisters and who appeared on stage and in films, died on May 2 in Glens Falls, N.Y. She was 98.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: SHAW COMMUNICATIONS L.P., Calgary, Alberta, a cable television operator, will raise the equivalent of $178 million in a stock sale, taking advantage of this year's 73 percent jump in the company's share price.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TUGWOOD, REVEREND JAMES C.
description: TUGWOOD-Reverend James C. The Diocese of Brooklyn announces the death of the pastor of Our Lady of the Snows Church, 258-15 80th Avenue, Floral Park, on May 13. Reposing at Our Lady of Snows Chapel, Saturday, May 15, from 2 to 5 and 7 to 9 P.M. and on Sunday, May 16, from 2 to 5 P.M. Mass of Transferral Sunday, May 16, at 7:30 P.M. Funeral Mass Monday, May 17, at 10:30 A.M. All priests are invited to concelebrate. He was a member of the Priests' Purgatorial Society. Most Rev. Thomas V. Daily, Bishop Of Brooklyn.

title: Honda Says U.S. Sales Lifted Profit in Quarter
description: The Honda Motor Company of Japan said yesterday that its profit unexpectedly rose in the January-March period as booming sales in the United States compensated for declines in Asia and Europe.

title: Political Briefing; A Southern Welcome Quickly Worn Thin
description: In a Deep South state like Georgia, gun rights advocates are particularly plentiful, and many political candidates, whatever their party, welcome the endorsement of the National Rifle Association. So when the association helped elect a Democrat, Roy Barnes, as Governor last year, Republicans groused loud and long.

title: Someone to Thaw Serb's Cold Shoulder
description: Russia and NATO still differ on key issues for a peace settlement in Kosovo, but Deputy Secretary of State Strobe Talbott and the Russian envoy on the Balkans, Viktor S. Chernomyrdin, agreed this week on some ways to approach the Yugoslav leader, Slobodan Milosevic, the State Department said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLMAN, SAMUEL K. ''SANDY''
description: MILLMAN-Samuel K. ''Sandy''. Died May 12, 1999 at St. Peter's Hospital, Albany, NY. Owner of the Sandy Millman Publicity Company in NYC. Survived by wife Ellin, daughter Jode Millman and son Stuart Millman. Services are Sunday at noon at the Congregaton Schomre Israel, 18 Park Avenue, Poughkeepsie, New York.

title: Inflation Jumps Enough to Scare Wall Street
description: Inflation, driven in part by rising oil and gasoline prices, moved up sharply at the consumer level in April, the Government reported yesterday, leading analysts to say that the remarkable decline in inflation over the last several years may be over.

title: Corrections
description: The Classical Music and Dance Guide in Weekend yesterday misstated the Brooklyn Philharmonic's performance schedule this weekend at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. The orchestra played last night and will perform tonight at 8; it will not perform tomorrow.

title: Giuliani and Vallone See a Budget Tangle if the Commuter Tax Ends
description: After predicting for months that budget negotiations would be quick and relatively painless this year, city officials are now warning that the State Legislature's plan to repeal the commuter tax will seriously hinder the process, forcing Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and the City Council to prepare for the potential loss of up to $360 million in annual revenue.

title: Commuter Tax Helps City Compete
description: To the Editor:

title: Avidly Blurring the Line Between Art Song and Pop
description: A tantalizing question hung in the air during Adam Guettel's triumphant debut at Town Hall on Wednesday evening. Could this bashful, boyish 34-year-old composer, singer, and grandson of Richard Rodgers lead a nascent movement to rescue the Broadway musical from the abyss into which it has fallen? Or does his phenomenal talent augur a less commercial but esthetically loftier trend that will flower in nonprofit theaters and opera houses?

title: KOSOVO UPDATE
description: COMBAT

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about the Vietnamese Government's war film archives misspelled a surname in some references to an executive with the German company that is helping Vietnam market the films. He is Alexander van Dulmen, not van Dulman.

title: Knicks Haunted By Old Liabilities
description: They became younger and more athletic at several positions during the off season, but the Knicks failed to address one glaring weakness on their roster. And as their offense imploded in the second half of Game 4 last night, the decision to stay the course with their point guards may be prove to be a major factor if the Knicks fall short of their post-season goals.

title: For $6 Billion Hawaii Legacy, a New Day
description: In a raffish waterfront bar in a warehouse district, an unlikely band of allies gathered here this week to toast what they hope will prove a watershed victory in Hawaii's feudal world of one-party politics. The celebrators included a senior Federal judge, an outspoken law professor, the head of the state's Democratic Party and its former Attorney General -- plus scores of alumni, faculty and friends of the world's richest private school.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Sunday about genetic research suggesting that some members of the Lemba, a group of South African blacks, have Jewish ancestry, omitted attribution for two points. While The Times's account was gathered independently, The Jerusalem Report was the source of the fact that one researcher was in Toronto when he began thinking about ways of tracing Jewish lineage, and the fact that the Lemba number more than 50,000.

title: COMING ON SUNDAY: THE MILLENNIUM'S SHADOW STORY
description: When James Brown sang ''This is a man's world,'' he summed up most of the last thousand years. But with a steady decline in the importance of physical strength and with reverberating changes in fertility control, that attitude is fading fast.

title: When Country Sang to Just Plain Folks
description: Loretta Lynn's concert on Thursday night at Town Hall, her first New York City show in more than a decade, was a reminder of what country music was like before it embraced video clips, smoke bombs, power chords and line dancing. It was a homey concert: part shtick, part spontaneity, trusting in personality rather than spectacle. Ms. Lynn chatted with the audience, and she built her set from whims and requests. ''Anything you want me to sing,'' she announced. ''Just tell me the first line.''

title: Girl Bitten by Dog To Receive $1 Million
description: A 3-year-old girl who was severely bitten by a Siberian Husky in August will receive $1 million under a settlement with the dog's owners, her lawyer said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRAGER, JOAN
description: TRAGER-Joan. Beloved wife of Seymour. Devoted mother of Michael, Barbara Katz and the late Marlene Kevy. Cherished grandmother of Eric, Rachel, Matthew, Jonathan, Jessica and Melissa. Dear sister of Lenore Spingarn. Mother-in-law of Larry Kevy and Cara Trager. Service Sunday, 9AM ''Sinai Chapels'', 162-05 Horace Harding Expwy, Fresh Meadows.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE YEN FALLS. Japan's Economic Planning Agency said the economy was ''in a very severe situation,'' sending the yen to a two-month low against the dollar, which settled in New York at 122.73 yen, up from 121.85 on Thursday.

title: N.Y. Graduation Exam
description: To the Editor:

title: MONARCH TO PURCHASE HERR-VOSS INDUSTRIES
description: The Monarch Machine Tool Company, which specializes in making metal-shaping machinery, said yesterday that it would buy Herr-Voss Industries from a group of investors led by Three Cities Research Inc. for about $55 million in cash and 500,000 common shares, a total of about $59 million based on Thursday's closing price. It will also assume $19 million in debt. Shares of Monarch, based in Dayton, Ohio, rose $1.625, or 20 percent, to $9.375 on the New York Stock Exchange. Herr-Voss, based in Callery, Pa., manufactures coil processing lines, leveling rolls and components for the flat rolled metals industry. The company, which has six plants in the United States as well as operations in Britain and Japan, posted revenues of about $81 million in the year that ended on March 31.

title: U.S. BANCORP TO SELL 28 BRANCHES IN TWO STATES
description: The Minneapolis-based bank holding company U.S. Bancorp said yesterday that it planned to sell 20 bank branches in Kansas and 8 bank branches in Iowa. Financial terms of the deals were not disclosed. The Kansas branches will be sold to Intrust Bank N.A., based in Wichita, Kan. The Iowa branches will be sold to seven financial institutions in that state. After the deals close in the third quarter, U.S. Bancorp will have 21 branches in Iowa and none in Kansas.

title: INSIDE
description: Inflation Increases 0.7%

title: Commuter Tax Helps City Compete; Restrict City Services
description: To the Editor:

title: KENTEK TO BE ACQUIRED BY ITS CHIEF EXECUTIVE
description: Kentek Information Systems Inc., which makes laser printers and supplies, agreed yesterday to be acquired for about $39 million in cash by a group led by its chief executive, Philip Shires. Under the terms of the deal, each Kentek shareholder would receive $8.29 a share in cash. Kentek, which had sales of $45 million for the year that ended in June, has about 4.7 million shares outstanding. In November, Kentek said it would cut about 25 percent of its work force and take a charge to deal with declining sales and a delay in developing a new printer. Kentek's printers are designed for high-volume printing requirements like invoices and direct mail. Shares of Kentek, based in Boulder, Colo., rose 6.25 cents yesterday, to $7.6875.

title: Ruling Supports User of the Smirnoff Name
description: Diageo P.L.C., the world's largest maker of alcoholic beverages, did not infringe the historic Smirnoff vodka trademark in the United States because a rival company asserting ownership of the Russian name had not done business in the United States and waited too long to assert rights to the name, a Federal judge has ruled.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUZZEO, LOUIS
description: BUZZEO-Louis. Of Pound Ridge, NY. (husband of Cornelia, deceased). Our loving father passed away peacefully on the morning of May 13, 1999. A WWII veteran, entrepreneur and creative spirit. He will be dearly missed by his brother Mario, his children Paula, Martin, Bernadette, Elizabeth, Marie and Anthony and sons-in-law Michael and Richard. Reposing at Craft Memorial Home, 40 Leicester Street, Port Chester, N.Y.

title: Yoshii Wins Again as Mets Turn On Power
description: They had stumbled into Philadelphia, reeling and wrung out, insisting they were not worried about their slump but slipping behind the streaking Phillies in the standing all the same. But like fireworks that illuminate even the heaviest clouds, the Mets' hitters unleashed a bombardment that lifted them to a 7-3 victory tonight over the Phillies.

title: Moonlighting Scholars
description: To the Editor:

title: Who Is That Masked Man?
description: Anyone whose lips are exhausted from puzzling through the nearest comic book can take a respite with ''Black Mask,'' one of those dubbed action imports from Hong Kong that is long on flying bodies, bullets and blood and short on credibility.

title: Beliefs; On a milestone anniversary of his death, remembrances of a most improbable catalyst of a radical religious movement.
description: It is 50 years today since the death of Peter Maurin, one of the unlikeliest figures ever to ignite a religious movement. He died poor, as he had lived, and was buried in a donated suit and laid in a donated Brooklyn grave. But there were obituaries in Time magazine, on the front page of the Vatican's L'Osservatore Romano and in the Chicago paper of the remnant Wobblies -- the Industrial Workers of the World, the radical labor union of the early 1900's.

title: Terence H. Benbow, 69, Quinnipiac Law Dean
description: Terence H. Benbow, a lawyer and longtime community leader on Staten Island who was also the dean of the Quinnipiac College Law School, died in his sleep on May 4 at his home in Fairfield, Conn. He was 69 years old.

title: Sleepwalker Awakes And Sings
description: Ruth Ann Swenson has one of the most sheerly beautiful voices of any soprano before the public today. Yet in the touchstone coloratura roles of the bel canto repertory that she would seem born to, her work has lacked that final measure of dramatic intensity, textual incisiveness and vocal security.

title: Rear Adm. James Nance, 77, Influential Aide to Jesse Helms
