description: James W. Nance, a retired Navy rear admiral who took on a late-career job as the chief aide to his old boyhood friend Senator Jesse Helms of North Carolina, died on Tuesday at the National Institutes of Health in Bethesda, Md. He was 77 and lived in McLean, Va.

title: P. Scott Makela, 39, Pioneering Graphic Designer, Dies
description: P. Scott Makela, a graphic and multimedia designer whose audacious experiments helped create the esthetic of new computer-age media, died on May 7 at St. Joseph's Mercy Hospital in Pontiac, Mich. He was 39 and lived in Bloomfield Hills, Mich.

title: Profiling Doesn't Work
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALLEN, DAVIS B.
description: ALLEN-Davis B. 82. Six year Fort Lauderdale resident, coming from Hampton, NY, died Thursday, May 13, 1999, in Fort Lauderdale. He was a member of the Yale Club and the Santara Association. Survived by brother Thomas Allen of Santa Fe, NM, and friend Juan Garcia of Fort Lauderdale. A memorial service will be held Tuesday, May 18, 1999, at 7 PM, at Fred Hunter's Fort Lauderdale Home, 718 South Federal Highway, Fort Lauderdale, FL.

title: Knicks Fade, 87-72, as Miami Forces a Game 5
description: The Miami Heat turned the tables on the Knicks last night, running off a lopsided scoring streak of their own -- just as the Knicks had in a Game 3 victory on Wednesday -- to score an 87-72 victory in the fourth game of their first-round playoff series.

title: HICKS, MUSE BUYING A BRITISH FOOD COMPANY
description: The Dallas-based investment firm Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst Inc. agreed yesterday to buy Hillsdown Holdings P.L.C., a British food company whose products include Typhoo Tea, for $:464 million in cash ($752 million). It will also take on about $:286 million ($463 million) in debt. Hillsdown, which had sales of $:1.9 billion last year, makes a wide range of food products. The purchase would be the biggest to date in Europe for Hicks, Muse, which has been investing in companies across the Continent. It has been an active buyer and seller of food and beverage companies with C. Dean Metropoulos & Company.

title: Fired Reporter Says She Lied About AIDS, Too
description: The 33-year-old reporter in Kentucky who was fired on Monday after revealing that she had lied in her newspaper columns about having cancer to cover up the real diagnosis, AIDS, now says that she has never been treated for AIDS, either.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I've never had to deal with having a gun pulled on me. I asked myself, 'Am I throwing it in someone else's face? To do this in the name of fun, am I belittling the actual violence that goes on in the world?' ''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LILIEN, HELEN H.
description: LILIEN-Helen H. Who would have believed, you would leave us bereaved without saying good-bye. 50 years later, we continue to cry! Herbert

title: Leader of House Says It May Vote Today to Impeach Yeltsin
description: After a day of angry and vivid speeches that accused President Boris N. Yeltsin of crimes like treason and genocide, the Speaker of Parliament predicted tonight that the lower house would vote on Saturday to impeach him on at least one of the charges against him.

title: Internet Access for Schools
description: In its start-up year, the e-rate program created by Congress as part of the 1996 Telecommunications Act has helped tens of thousands of rural and low-income communities connect to the Internet. Given the growing needs, Federal Communications Commission chairman William Kennard has properly recommended that the program -- which subsidizes telecommunications services and Internet hook-ups for schools and libraries -- be financed at the maximum authorized level of $2.25 billion for the coming year. The commission is expected to vote on the plan this month.

title: Struggle Over the Tobacco Spoils
description: The dispute between Gov. George Pataki and Mayor Rudolph Giuliani over how to divide New York State's share of the multi-state settlement with the tobacco industry works to everyone's disadvantage. The fight, now in the courts, could delay the state's receipt of $306 million in tobacco money for 1999 and even hold up the $800 million the state is expected to receive in 2000. There is no reason the two sides cannot find a middle ground.

title: Fast-Growing Phone Concern Said to Discuss U S West Deal
description: Proposing what would be a formidable challenge to regulators, Global Crossing Ltd., an acquisition-hungry communications upstart, is in talks to merge with U S West Inc., the smallest of the Baby Bell local phone giants, in a stock swap valued at more than $30 billion, executives close to the talks said yesterday.

title: A Legal Exit From Kosovo Mess; Don't Let C.I.A. Hide
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JONES, REES
description: JONES-Rees. Died peacefully on April 27, 1999, at Beth Israel Hospital. Survived by his wife Betty, family members and many friends. He enjoyed life fully with his love of music, travel, lawn bowling, and the company of friends and family. Memorial service will be held at First Presbyterian Church, 12th St, and Fifth Ave., Manhattan. Sunday, May 16th, 1999, at 2:30pm. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions to First Presbyterian Church Music Fund, 12 W. 12 St., NY, NY 10011, would be appreciated.

title: World Trade Group Hiding Substance Behind Emotion
description: Anger and betrayal have colored the World Trade Organization's deadlocked talks to choose a new leader, but behind the emotions are three substantive issues -- the interests of workers, farmers and the environment -- that have generally polarized the 134-nation group, producing odd alliances of rich and poor, big and small.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POLOGE, GRACE
description: POLOGE-Grace. Wife, mother, grandmother and artist. Services Sunday, 11 AM at ''Gutterman-Musicant'' Hackensack, NJ. For information, 1-800-378-1892.

title: COURT OVERTURNS AIR QUALITY RULES
description: A Federal appeals panel today threw out air quality standards that have been a cornerstone of the Clinton Administration's antipollution strategy.

title: Chinese Finally Allow Clinton Time for a Telephone Apology
description: A week after the NATO bombing of the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade, President Clinton was finally able to express his condolences directly to Chinese leaders today in a telephone call that also touched briefly on Chinese efforts to gain entry to the World Trade Organization.

title: Wheels Bolognese; Ducati, Italy's Top Motorcycle Maker, Seeks Niche in the U.S.
description: Federico Minoli is not sure if he is selling a luxury accessory, a style of life or a means of transportation.

title: Pahrump Journal; A 'Sun City' for Gun Enthusiasts?
description: The sun was hot as Hades, but that hardly mattered to the 50 students gathered in the desert for Ignatius Piazza's free submachine gun training class.

title: Waging Peace in Colombia
description: Last June, Andres Pastrana won the presidency of Colombia by pledging to pursue an end to its 35-year-old civil war. He has courageously stuck with the peace process in the face of setbacks. He has also made some progress in the related task of controlling the armed forces, but military pressure has forced him to back off some of the most important measures. Mr. Pastrana needs more resolve, and steadier support from a Clinton Administration whose policies have at times undercut him.

title: Hardaway Finds His Range
description: And a Van Gundy turned on the Heat.

title: Thomas C. Cochran, 97, Scholar On American Economic History
description: Thomas C. Cochran, an authority on the economic history of the United States who liked to chronicle how economics and business had touched his fellow citizens' lives, died on May 2 at the Quadrangle retirement center in Haverford, Pa. He was 97.

title: Healtheon Is Expected to Join Forces With Internet Provider
description: The Healtheon Corporation, the Santa Clara, Calif., medical record-keeping Web site started by the founder of the Netscape Communications Corporation, Jim Clark, is expected to announce Monday that it is merging with WebMD, a privately held Internet provider of medical information.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: U.S. Threatens to Impose Punitive Duties in Beef War

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DANIEL, ELSA MUSLINER
description: DANIEL-Elsa Musliner. May 15, 1997. Remembered by her family and friends for her caring and good works.

title: In the Region /Connecticut; Stamford's First Spec Office Building in a Decade
description: THE first speculative office building in Stamford in a decade is to be built on the city's waterfront. The building is being planned by Collins Enterprises, which pioneered the waterside neighborhood but has not been active there for 20 years, and which faced opposition to the project from residents of some of the buildings it had built earlier. The 75,000-square-foot, $15-million office building is expected to be completed by the fall of next year.

title: O.K. of Housing Plan Ends East End Battle
description: CONRAD J. COSTANZO wakes up most mornings before dawn to run the cliffside trails just west of Ditch Plains Beach in Montauk. ''It's an energizing feeling,'' Mr. Costanzo said. ''In the springtime I hear the wind through the shad trees.''

title: Blessing Wheels and the Spirit for Perilous Travels
description: As the holy water, hurled by a white-robed church elder, fell upon their heads and on the handlebars of their 1962 Schwinn Twin tandem yesterday, Harris Silver and his wife, Roz Makarechi, exhaled and exchanged a relieved glance.

title: Religion, Law and Health Vie In Dispute Over Circumcision
description: Andrew Hollander is the same as he was when he came into the world on Feb. 20, 1996, at Monmouth Medical Center in Long Branch.

title: Guatemalan Bloodshed
description: To the Editor:

title: Applauding the Art, or Maybe the Money; Dealing With Nazis?
description: To the Editor:

title: Mandy Kraus, Barry Frank
description: Mandy Kraus, a daughter of Rosalind Joseph of Rochester and Dr. A. Lanny Kraus of Darnestown, Md., is to be married this evening to Dr. Barry Alan Frank, the son of Lynda and Ivor Frank of West Islip, N.Y. Rabbi Edward Boraz will officiate at the Hanover (N.H.) Inn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DECARLO, ANTHONY
description: DeCARLO-Anthony. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Anthony DeCarlo, associated with The Times since 1994.

title: BENEFITS
description: Songs for Scholars

title: Colombia Rebels Reign in Ceded Area
description: There are no immigration or customs controls at the rustic landing strip that passes for an airport here. But in most other ways, this muddy cattle town and a sizable swath of jungle and savanna around it have ceased to be a part of Colombia and are instead, with the Government's blessing, a dominion ruled by Marxist guerrillas.

title: Anne Louise Metz, Fred van Lynden van Sandenburg
description: Anne Louise Metz and Frederik van Lynden van Sandenburg were married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York. The Rev. Mark Hallinan performed the ceremony.

title: Vacant Schools Now Shelter the Elderly
description: CHURCH schools once built to serve the children of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Rockville Centre are now often empty. But they are finding new use as housing for the elderly. The diocese is in the midst of a program to provide low-income apartments for senior citizens, Long Island's fastest-growing age group, in vacant schools and other church buildings.

title: State Has Opportunity For Campaign Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: ONE MORE TIME The Best of Mike Royko. Commentaries by Lois Wille. University of Chicago, $22.

title: Nancy Balbirer, Joel Zighelboim
description: Nancy Lee Balbirer, a daughter of Patricia and Arthur Balbirer of Bethlehem, Conn., is to be married this evening to Joel Abraham Zighelboim, a son of Dr. Vivien Zighelboim and Dr. Jacob Zighelboim of Beverly Hills, Calif. Rabbi David Wolpe will officiate at Il Cielo restaurant in Beverly Hills.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRAZER, LILLIAN (LEE)
description: FRAZER-Lillian (Lee). Beloved wife of Dan Frazer. Loving mother of Susan Frazer Hofmaier. Devoted grandmother of Luke and Tess. Fond sister of Marie and Edith Hogsett and Elizabeth Flemen. Memorial service at a later date.

title: POSTINGS: Renovating an 1879 Apartment House; Past Recalled On East 86th
description: A 19th-century six-story brick apartment house at 244 East 86th Street, at Second Avenue, that was saved from the wrecking ball last year is to open this weekend as a modern rental building.

title: Firefighter Benefits
description: In an effort to retain a strong volunteer firefighting force, Mamaroneck voters have approved a benefits package, which would entitle the unpaid staff to pensions at age 65.

title: Editorial Observer; So, Exactly When Is Bill Bradley Going to Enter the Charisma Phase?
description: It was somewhere near the New Hampshire seacoast that Bill Bradley declined to tell reporters what books he likes.

title: Corrections
description: The Perspectives column last Sunday, about nonprofit housing with counseling and psychological services for tenants, misstated the name of the firm of Richard Vitto, an architect who commented on ways of avoiding an institutional appearance. The firm is Oaklander Coogan & Vitto, not Oaklander Cooper & Vitto.

title: Madam of Morristown Bordello Must Do Community Service
description: The Morristown bordello called Afternoon Delight is closed, but the woman who ran it, Judith Kelly Dempsey, will be working with prostitutes again. Last week, Ms. Dempsey pleaded guilty to promoting prostitution and was sentenced to 250 hours of community service at a Manhattan rehabilitation program for prostitutes and drug addicts.

title: 45 Laid-Back Feet Of Bar, Plus a Deejay
description: A mural at Mercury Bar, depicting a convivial scene, serves for the owners, two brothers, as a reminder of the relaxed atmosphere they set out to create when they opened the bar five weeks ago at 659 Ninth Avenue and 45th Street. The owners, Mario and Guiseppe Arcari, also co-own Joshua Tree in Murray Hill and two bars in Boston. On an average day, customers can be seen sidling up to the 45-foot-long bar to order one of the 15 beers on tap ($5) or a mixed drink ($5.50 to $7.50). Others are seated in burgundy velvet booths, eating Mercury Bar Burgers ($7.95), herb crusted tuna ($13.95) or chicken marsala ($10.95). And Thursdays through Saturdays, from 8 P.M. to 4 A.M., some have been spotted grooving to the sounds of a deejay. MICHAEL GOLDMAN

title: Hillary Kann, Clayton Lane
description: Hillary Francesca Kann, the daughter of Peter R. Kann of Princeton, N.J., and the late Francesca Dorothea Kann, was married yesterday to Clayton Gray Lane, a son of Carlana Lane and Dr. Dewey Hobson Lane of Pascagoula, Miss. The Rev. Leanne Simmons, an American Baptist minister, performed a Methodist ceremony at the Miller Chapel at the Princeton Theological Seminary in Princeton, N.J.

title: The Nanny State Is Stifling Future Einsteins
description: To the Editor:

title: Is Private School Worth It? That's an Essay Question; Parents and Educators Agree the Beauty Is in the Choices, But Studies Show High Achievers Will Do Well Anywhere
description: FOR Judith Corrente, it was the difference between an average and an exceptional education for her three children. She was willing to pay about $20,000 a year for each of them to get a high school education.

title: Yonkers Translator
description: A Yonkers resident, Violet Bucaj, is working for the American Red Cross at Fort Dix, N.J., as a volunteer translator for Kosovar immigrants. Before Ms. Bucaj, 32, left for Fort Dix, she volunteered at the Red Cross office in White Plains, taking calls from Albanians in Westchester who sought information about relatives in Kosovo.

title: Corrections
description: An article on May 2 about the soul-blues label Malaco Records misidentified the label that released the 1979 hit ''Ring My Bell.'' It was Juana Records, not Malaco.

title: Motionless Pictures
description: To the Editor:

title: 'The Fifth Miracle'
description: To the Editor:

title: PERSONAL BUSINESS: DIARY; That Take-Charge Style
description: The oppressed secretaries in the movie ''Nine to Five'' took the sharp edges off their autocratic workplace by tying up their fire-breathing male boss and putting their womanly instincts in charge. But despite the popular image of women as collegial and democratic at work, the real-life Boss Who Rules may more likely be a woman than a man.

title: No, That Wasn't a Squirrel. Some Call It an Invasion.
description: The last time Lisa O'Toole saw rats in Park Slope, she was 9 and playing hide-and-seek. Now she is 37, and the rats are back. ''We haven't had them in years the way we are having them now,'' said Mrs. O'Toole, who lives on President Street, between Eighth Avenue and Prospect Park West.

title: The World: Big Chill; It's Not the Cold War, but There's a Nip in the Air
description: IF a space traveler had returned to Earth last week after 35 years, he could have been excused for thinking that nothing had changed. Russia and China hated the West. Their leaders and citizens were angrily flinging words like ''imperialism'' and ''hegemony.'' A strange war in an obscure corner of the planet seemed to be the occasion for mounting global tension.

title: Spitzer Threatens Subpoena For Police Data on Frisking
description: State Attorney General Eliot L. Spitzer threatened yesterday to subpoena thousands of documents in his inquiry into whether the New York City Police Department's stop-and-frisk procedures systematically violated the civil rights of minority residents.

title: The Bad-Boy Voice of Wall St.
description: JONATHAN HOENIG, the 23-year-old founder of Capitalist Pig L.L.C., has just finished broadcasting his morning radio financial report for WNEW, a modern rock FM station in New York, and already he is showing why he is a hit with the MTV generation.

title: Finding The Union Label in A Fund
description: FOR years, organized labor has tried to counter the notion that unionized companies deliver inferior returns. Soon, members of the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers and other like-minded investors will be able to put their money where their mouths are.

title: Surveillance Cameras
description: Becoming the second municipality in Westchester to consider installing video cameras in public places, Mount Vernon recently proposed putting them in all city garages and on streets where the crime rate is high.

title: An Operatic 'Three Hermits' In an East Coast Premiere
description: FOR Stephen Paulus, a Minnesota-based composer whose music has been performed far and wide, Westchester is fertile ground.

title: Vietnam Sees War's Legacy in Its Young
description: In what amounted to a chance second-generation reunion from the war years, five teen-age girls laughed and chattered at a lunch table the other day, all of them patients in a hospital for severely deformed or mentally retarded children.

title: Satisfying an Age-Old Thirst
description: NEARLY half a century ago, on Feb. 21, 1952, the front page of The New York Times hailed a ''revolutionary process'' for turning sea water into drinkable drops. The process was complicated and expensive, requiring lots of energy to push water through membranes that filtered out salt. Still, the article predicted that desalting would ''open vast new reservoirs of fresh water'' for use ''wherever water is now scarce.''

title: Drug Trials Hide Conflicts for Doctors
description: When Thomas W. Parham visited his doctor in the summer of 1995, he expected just another routine checkup. But his doctor had something else in mind.

title: The Queen of the Bulls Still Stays the Course
description: For followers of Abby Joseph Cohen, investment strategist at Goldman, Sachs, it probably seems like a reflex reaction. Bad news prompts a market selloff. Ms. Cohen, a perennial bull, tells investors not to fret.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-21

title: Teen-Ager Is Charged In Shootings at Theater
description: A Brooklyn teen-ager has been arrested in connection with a movie theater shooting in Flatbush last month that left one patron dead and two others wounded, the police said.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the International Datebook listing on May 2 for Maya folklore festivals in Guatemala misstated the dates. They are July 22 to July 25, not June 28 to July 4.

title: China Picks Local Banker After Portugal Cedes Macao
description: For 442 years, Portuguese officials have ruled this spit of land on the southeast coast of China. Today, Macao got its first Chinese leader. A committee appointed by Beijing chose a local banker, Edmund Ho, to administer the colony after it reverts to Chinese rule in December.

title: A Friend of McGwire's Helps Griffey's Quest
description: If Ken Griffey Jr. should somehow get out of his rut and hit more than 56 home runs this season, say 71, just to pick a nice round number, Tom Lampkin might have to go into the Hall of Fame as the best good-luck charm in history.

title: Take a Hike? That's Easy for You to Say
description: THE premier foot-sloggers of Long Island belong to the Long Island Greenbelt Trail Conference. They are dedicated to the proposition that the only way to enjoy the remaining beauties of this island is to hike through them in a primitive, 19th-century way: no dirt bikes, no all-terrain vehicles, but just one foot in front of the other.

title: The Many Life Styles of Senior Housing
description: TIME was of the essence to Michele Edwards and her three siblings during the winter of 1998. Her mother, May, who was then 86 and who suffers from memory loss, had broken her hip and had been moved out of her home in Greenwich, Conn., and into the rehabilitation wing of a local nursing home.

title: Just Your Average 16-Year-Old
description: WHILE most 16-year-old girls might have headed for the mall on a rainy spring afternoon to try on tankinis at Club Monaco, a recent downpour gave Leelee Sobieski other ideas. Ms. Sobieski, a Manhattan-born actress, stepped into a limousine provided by 20th Century Fox, one of the movie studios she has been working for lately, and cruised a few blocks from her parents' apartment to Allan & Suzi, a vintage designer shop on Amsterdam Avenue that specializes in clothes from the 1970's. There, she plowed past racks of sequined Lycra and tie-dyed organza and immediately wrapped herself in a floor-length fake-Persian lamb coat. ''This,'' she said with the confidence of a fashion veteran, ''is really worth it.''

title: Irritating Women
description: Through the centuries, many women have made their marks by making trouble. They found leverage in persistence, a that has often been women's sharpest weapon. Here are some notable agitators.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLD, HENRY
description: GOLD-Henry. Of Upper Brookville, NY. Beloved husband of Laura, devoted friend of many. He will be deeply missed. Services Sunday 10 AM at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 N. Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY.

title: Adina Dubroff, Marc Dolfman
description: Adina Tzipor Dubroff, a daughter of Roslyn and Marc Dubroff of New Rochelle, N.Y., is to be married today to Marc Elliott Dolfman, the son of Eileen Dolfman and Dr. Michael L. Dolfman of Cheltenham, Pa. Rabbi Reuven Fink is to officiate at the Westchester Marriott in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: PULSE; French Restyle Fashion Houses
description: French fashion houses trying to do away with their frumpy images are rejuvenating their interiors to match freshly hip collections. The look is clean, lean minimalism with lots of subtle quirks. At Alain Mikli's new eyewear boutique by Philippe Starck there's a central table for trying on glasses, to encourage customers to ask each other's advice. The futurist Thierry Mugler recently opened a 3,800-square-foot two-story space, left, where dresses lie flat in display cases. Barbara Bui, who has three boutiques in Paris, has opened a trendy cafe with white chairs and benches, far left.

title: Q. & A.
description: IS There A Law on Carpeting?

title: Memories of Hepburn
description: To the Editor:

title: Pamela Meisel, Maurits Lugard
description: Pamela Gail Meisel, and Maurits Jan Frederik Lugard, both lawyers, were married last evening by Rabbi Steven Mason at Gedney Farm, an inn in New Marlborough, Mass.

title: Year of Living Dangerously For a Tycoon in Indonesia
description: A YEAR ago this week, Anthony Salim looked out from his 19th-floor office and watched his hometown go up in flames. Angry mobs rampaged through the streets, looting and torching cars, motorcycles, shops and anything else in their path. Plumes of smoke rose from Jakarta's Chinese quarter, where the crowds turned their rage on the terrified residents.

title: A Rogues' Gallery
description: SHE'S no Sam Spade. She doesn't have the trademark cynical grin, sallow complexion or hard-boiled humor of Dashiell Hammett's famous detective.

title: Nicole LaBarbera, David Kelley
description: Nicole Alexandra LaBarbera and David Noel Kelley, assistant United States attorneys in Manhattan, were married yesterday by the Rev. Darwin L. Price at St. Luke's Episcopal Church in East Hampton, N.Y.

title: Haunted House
description: ANOTHER WORLD

title: Geoffrey Wigoder, 76, Editor And Broadcaster in Jerusalem
description: Geoffrey Wigoder, a broadcaster, scholar and editor of Judaica, died on April 9 in Jerusalem. He was 76.

title: There's a Kind of Hush
description: ''YOU can be as romantic as you please about love,'' George Bernard Shaw wrote, ''but you mustn't be romantic about money.'' He wasn't wrong. Money -- the making of it and the spending of it -- is the No. 1 source of argument for couples.

title: A Job Fair Links Businesses and the Disabled
description: BASSAM SAXEGH works one day a week as a recreation aide for an agency for the mentally ill in Peekskill. ''It's not enough; I need more work,'' said Mr. Saxegh, who recently attended a job fair in White Plains. Mr. Sexegh, 28, said he left his resume with several prospective employers, filled out a number of applications and felt optimistic. ''I'm a diligent worker with experience,'' he said. ''I have hope.''

title: More C.I.A. Ineptitude
description: To the Editor:

title: May 9-15; Getting Out the Vote in 90210
description: Who says the voting public is apathetic?

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  NAROFF, VIOLA
description: NAROFF-Viola. Beloved grandma, deeply missed. Shayna V. knows all about you. So many cherished memories. Don't worry, I'm eating my fruit. Forever in my heart, Debbie

title: A Street Chess Club Goes to College
description: In the game room of the Paul Robeson Student Center at Rutgers University's Newark campus, a cacophony of rap music and the clicking and clacking of Ping-Pong and billiard balls ricochets over the bowed heads of the Downtown Chess Club. But what distraction could a few student activities be after you've played chess outdoors on a winter night?

title: The Truth About Sex -- at Any Given Moment
description: In 1068, a group of Norman women demanded that William the Conqueror release their husbands from military service so that they could return home and satisfy their wives' sexual needs. Four centuries later, the Catholic Church determined that the Virgin Mary had conceived her son through her ear and decreed therefore that this organ be covered in public. Sex is a function of its time. Throughout these thousand years, views on woman's sexuality have reflected the ebb and flow of morality, science and religious thought. Some of the following observations will seem remarkably advanced, some familiar, some bizarre. But when it was proclaimed, each rang with the confidence of truth.

title: Inger Hassel, Roger Savitt
description: Inger Catharina Hassel and Roger Scott Savitt were married on Thursday at the Stromsholm Royal Palace, a museum near Vasteras, Sweden. The Rev. Torvald Bergwall, a Lutheran minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Sixth Men May Decide Outcome of Fifth Game
description: Terry Porter sped upcourt at Madison Square Garden on Friday night, thinking for a moment that he might knife through the Knicks' defense all by himself. But he paused, thought about the 1-on-4 odds, and waited for his teammates so that he could steady the offense and keep the Miami Heat in the game.

title: What Visions Have I Seen!
description: EXPECTING ADAM

title: Her Name Is Mud
description: The White Bone

title: Spring Children's Books; Hints From Eloise
description: ELOISE

title: The Sheriff Switches, and Fights
description: THERE was laughter last month at the Suffolk County Republican Convention because the Democrats had found no one willing to run this fall against Robert J. Gaffney, the two-term County Executive.

title: Artist Rediscovers Creativity in the Ashes
description: THE life of the 50-year-old Hartford artist Chester W. Kempczynski has been described with simplicity by his friend and Hartford choreographer, Judi Tolomea: ''With hardship, something positive seems to happen,'' she said.

title: Listening to Men, Then and Now
description: A woman and a man meet at the end of the day. He asks how her day was, and she replies with a long report of what she did, whom she met, what they said and what that made her think and feel. Then she eagerly turns to him:

title: May 9-15; Pondering the Lessons Of the Roundworm
description: Can longevity be engineered into our genes? Biologists can double the life span of the roundworm, a standard laboratory organism, by manipulating certain of its genes, but it was not clear what these genes did.

title: Fans, Starved for Victory, Inspire 76ers to Triumph
description: Julius Erving was here during the glory years, when tens of thousands of fans would cheer on the Philadelphia 76ers during the post-season. The crowds in this basketball-loving city were raucous, especially when Dr. J and Moses Malone led the Sixers to their second league championship in 1983. Even so, Erving, who attended today's playoff game at the First Union Center as an official of the Orlando Magic, said he had never seen anything like this.

title: Recycling at 41 Percent
description: Westchester recycled more garbage in 1998 than it did in the previous year, but it needs to do better, County Executive Andrew J. Spano said earlier this month.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORGAN, FREDA (FREDI DUNDEE)
description: MORGAN-Freda (Fredi Dundee) Silver. On May 14, 1999. Beloved wife of Leonard. Dear sister of Sonia Fodor. Cherished mother of Elyse and Judy. Adored aunt of Karen, Neil and Martin. Freda was a joy and inspiration to many. Services Sunday, May 16, 1:15 PM, ''The Riverside'' 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue, NYC.

title: The View From/Washington; Library as Centerpiece At Celebrity Dinners
description: SINCE his best-selling memoir, ''Angela's Ashes,'' was published in 1996, Frank McCourt has given readings in libraries all over the country. But never, he said, has he seen anything quite like the Gunn Memorial Library in Washington.

title: Sports and School Violence: Is There a Connection?
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Corrections
description: The Practical Traveler column on May 2, about code sharing -- the sale of tickets by one airline on another line's flight, but under its own flight number -- cited one example erroneously. Delta is not seeking Government approval to put its code on Finnair flights to Moscow and St. Petersburg, Russia.

title: Fiber and Ceramics, Front and Center
description: AT the Bruce Museum, they are getting ready for their 14th annual Outdoor Crafts Festival. This year the festival will be open on May 22 and 23 from 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. Although by nature outdoor shows are more informal, the museum has always maintained standards with a competitive jurying process and crafts people encouraged to drop out every three years, to come up with new concepts and create room for fresh talent. ''We call it the art sabbatical,'' said Sue Brown Gordon, an exhibiting artist and the festival's coordinator.

title: The China Blind Spot
description: It is hard to imagine a more damaging American security failure than the serial hemorrhage of nuclear-weapons secrets and other military information to China over the last two decades. Each new disclosure adds to a picture of breathtaking incompetence by Federal agencies and lack of vigilance by Republican and Democratic administrations alike. The United States might as well have dumped its most sensitive defense secrets on Pennsylvania Avenue for Chinese spies to pick up.

title: May 9-15; Questions About Research At Duke University
description: Federal inspectors were dismayed last December when they found sloppy record-keeping on human medical research at the Duke University Medical Center, and angered when the problems were not corrected. So the Government suspended the center's Federally financed research, worth $175 million a year. But three days later, on Friday, the Government lifted the restrictions, saying Duke had come up with a satisfactory plan to improve. DAVID STOUT

title: The World; For American Jews, Israeli Politics Is a World Away
description: ON the Upper West Side of Manhattan the other evening, Jonathan Jacoby, an expert on Israeli politics, ended an hourlong forum on the fractious national campaign going on in Israel with a question to his audience: How much interest was there among American Jews in the contest for Prime Minister?

title: Are Lawyers Truly Evil, or Just Doing the Job?; Sharks Dressed in Prada
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SWIECHOCKI, STANLEY
description: SWIECHOCKI-Stanley. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Stanley Swiechocki, associated with The Times from 1963 until retiring in 1989.

title: Richmond Smiles on Jarrett, New Winston Cup Leader
description: This time, Dale Jarrett wasn't seeing red. He wasn't seeing anything but open track and the checkered flag waving when he crossed the finish line at the Pontiac Excitement 400 tonight.

title: No Man Is a Hero to His Sled Dogs
description: NANSEN

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DICKMAN, FRANCES
description: DICKMAN-Frances. May 11, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Milton, loving mother and mother-in-law of Stephen & Sharon Dickman of Syosset, NY and Lucy & Ronald Wetzel of Knoxville, TN devoted grandmother of Jocelyn Dickman and Paul and Nathan Wetzel. She spent a lifetime devoted to public service, professionally in her dedication to the New York City Public School system, privately by her involvement in many organizations. She had as well a life-long love of literature and the arts, which she enthusiastically shared with family and friends, who celebrate her life and mourn her passing. Memorial service to be arranged.

title: Baby in a Box
description: A month shy of giving birth to her first child, Laura Pouzer, a college chemistry teacher, reclines on a padded table at Johns Hopkins University, the luxuriousness of her belly and her wit on equal display as she takes the infamous Stroop stress test. Lists of words flash on a screen, each of them specifying a color -- blue, yellow, white, purple -- but each printed in a color other than the color it signifies. It is Pouzer's assignment to call out, as quickly as possible, the colors the words appear in, rather than the color they specify. I look at the slides over her shoulder and feel my brain lurch and creak. I see the word ''blue,'' I think the word ''blue,'' the tint it's written in be damned.

title: CYBERSCOUT
description: It's no strain to arrange a demanding excursion on the Web. Just go to your search engine and type in a key word like ''kayak'' or ''climb'' and follow the trail. When I typed ''backpacking'' into Yahoo's travel subsection, 16 sites were listed, ''kayak'' brought 7, and ''climb'' 171. There are scores of such sites, and following are examples of what you'll find.

title: A Musical Rendition Of the State's History
description: To the Editor:

title: Books in Brief: Fiction; Moonstruck
description: Struck by love, Norris Lamb, a middle-aged postmaster in a small English village, embodies Eudora Welty's observation that ''a sheltered life can be a daring life as well. For all serious daring starts from within.'' In Carrie Brown's unconventional and eloquent novel LAMB IN LOVE (Algonquin, $21.95), Norris -- who ''knows he is a victim of a delicious assault, a caress from a lion's paw'' -- sets out to win Vida Stephen after he comes upon her ''dancing in the moonlight in a ruined garden'' on the night of the Apollo 11 moon landing. Vida, who is 41 and plain, is dedicated to caring for Manford Perry, a 20-year-old retarded man who is unable to speak, in the mansion owned by his peripatetic father. Norris is too shy to declare himself directly, so he engages in an unusual courtship whose resolution hangs suspensefully in the balance until the very end. Along the way, he is surprised by his growing affection for Manford, whom he begins to see as Vida sees him: not damaged, but uniquely engaged with his world. ''Lamb in Love'' is, in fact, a book about seeing. Carrie Brown reveals her characters not as others perceive them but as they are able to see one another, and as they come to understand themselves. Norris and Vida are full of depth and longing, passion and poetry, that continually startle and delight. ''You have to have imagination to love anybody,'' Vita concludes, as you do to write a novel as magical and satisfying as Brown's. Linda Barrett Osborne

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCWHORTER, CHARLES K.
description: McWHORTER-Charles K. Age 77, May 10, 1999, from injuries sustained in an automobile accident in Hyannis, MA. Loving brother of Susanna Reckard and brother-inlaw to, Phyllis Mann, uncle to Scott, Frank, Matthew, Charles, Mark, Cheryl, Joseph and Michael. Graduated University of West Virginia, Harvard Law School, 1949. Served in WW II as a lieutenant in the Third Army under General George S. Patton, received Bronze Star and Purple Heart with two Citations. Chairman of the National Young Republican Club from 1955 to 1957, Chief Administrative Assistant to Vice President Richard M. Nixon from 1957 to 1961, former member of the National Council of the Arts, former President, Vice Chairman and Director of American Ballet Theater, Director, Alvin Ailey Dance Company and numerous other music, arts and dance companies. Trustee since 1966, of Interlochen Center for the Arts, Interlochen, MI, and ex officio President of Interlochen Alumni Association where he underwrote the cost of a rehearsal hall, winterized the lodge, fitness center, recreational halls, auditorium, studio and renovation of onsite summmer cabins. Executive Assistant and attorney, AT&T, from 1961 until 1987. Active in Republican politics, renowned for his encyclopedic knowledge and photographic memory of election results, and elected and former officials on the national, state and local levels. Memorial Services are planned at Interlochen Center for the Arts on August 6, 7 and 8, 1999, in Washington, DC; call Mr. Dell Smith, (202) 822-8300 for place and date, and in NYC, call Mr. E. Lisk Wyckoff, Jr., (212) 715-9519 for place and date. Those wishing to do so may make contributions in his memory to the Interlochen Center for the Arts, Interlochen, MI 49643.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLE, NEWCOMB D., SR.
description: COLE-Newcomb D., Sr. Of Kimball Farms, Lenox, formally of Williamstown, MA and New York City, NY died May 11, 1999. He was a retired Lt. Colonel in the U.S. Air Force Reserves. He held positions with the Debevoise Paint Company, Brooklyn, NY, Chase Manhattan Bank, Green, Ellis & Anderson Stock Brokers, and Inglas & Snyder Stock Brokers. He is survived by his son Newcomb D. Cole, Jr., and daughter Betsy Armbrust; four grandchildren, and two greatgrandchildren. Services will be in Westlawn Cemetery, Williamstown, MA June 26, 1999. Contributions may be made to the Village Ambulance Service or charity of donor's choice through the George M. Hopkins Funeral Home, 61-67 Spring St., Williamstown, MA 02167.

title: Sara-Ellen Amster and Brian Levin
description: Sara-Ellen Lori Amster and Brian H. Levin were married on Friday in Washington. Associate Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg of the United States Supreme Court, a cousin of the bride, officiated in the Lawyers Lounge of the Supreme Court, with Rabbi Gerald Serotta.

title: THE GUIDE
description: A Harlem Revue

title: Mexico Measures Identity in Dollars
description: A Mexican conference speaker exploring the possibility that his country might adopt the dollar as its currency displayed a slide of a 50 peso bill alongside a single American greenback. George Washington's benign gaze was fixed on his fierce-looking counterpart, Jose Maria Morelos, the father of Mexican independence.

title: Wrapping Up a Century At the Roslyn Museum
description: Helen Harrison and I certainly took opposite views of the current sculpture show at the Nassau County Museum of Art [''Bidding a Century Farewell With Sculpture,'' Art Reviews, April 25]. I thought it an exciting, stimulating show that caught the essence of the century. True, it was crowded -- but so thoughtfully installed that each work was appreciated as an entity. Of course it's not comprehensive. Even the Met couldn't do a complete vista of 100 years. But we must salute the curators who got so much together and made it all most enjoyable.

title: Shift in Train Schedule Leaves Out Mystic
description: THE Amtrak spring schedule that takes effect today temporarily eliminates a midday train that has been carrying tourists from New York to Mystic for seven days a week.

title: Getting a Jump on Summer
description: WHILE most musical organizations around the state have either closed out their seasons or are planning their final concerts, South Shore Music is getting an early start on its 66th year of summer chamber recitals. Unchanged through the decades is the South Shore mission: ''to discover young musical virtuosos, present chamber music concerts of exception quality, and foster the love, appreciation, knowledge and playing of classical music among people of all ages.''

title: Putting On A Happier Profit Face
description: SHAREHOLDERS of Go2Net Inc., a network of Web sites that includes the Silicon Investor bulletin boards, the Metacrawler search service and the Haggle auction site, might have thought they were imagining things when they saw the company's most recent earnings announcement.

title: Now, Before You Go Cruising You Must Do Some Choosing
description: JUST five years ago, if you wanted a cruiser motorcycle you bought a Harley. End of story.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALTER, HELENE
description: ALTER-Helene. We mourn the loss of our dearest friend. The Bobier Family

title: Through Women's Eyes, Finally
description: The history of women in art is such a great unruly subject that any curator trying to pull together a representative exhibition would probably start by having her head examined. Titian, to mention just one old master inspired to greatness by the female, made at least 39 paintings of the Madonna and 19 Venuses. At that, choosing from among the many thousands of similar works in the traditional Western canon might be easier than deciding which pieces among today's outpouring of paintings, sculptures, videos and installations are meant for the ages.

title: Locating The Heart Of an Epic
description: Nothing is harder to tell or more costly to mount on television than a simple story. Take ''Joan of Arc,'' the four-hour mini-series that CBS will broadcast tonight and tomorrow night at 9. To its producer and its director, the drama is an intimate coming-of-age story. But the scope of this historical epic, which stars Leelee Sobieski as the 15th-century warrior saint who fought for a unified France and was burned at the stake for her trouble, is nothing if not grand.

title: Our Towns; Must Hartford Keep Grasping At Big Time?
description: HOMER SIMPSON entered the ''How Low Will You Go'' gross-out competition in last week's episode of ''The Simpsons'' because the prize promised a trip to Hawaii. But it turned out the ticket was really to Hartford.

title: Spring Children's Books; New Kid on the Block
description: Missing Girls By Lois Metzger. 176 pp. New York: Viking: $15.99. (Ages 12 and up)

title: More Delays Foreseen For L.I.R.R. Diesel Cars
description: The manufacturer of the Long Island Rail Road's 134 new doubledecker diesel coaches is experiencing material shortages that may further delay deliveries, an independent engineering consultant warned the Metropolitan Transportation Authority last week.

title: Working for the Sake of Art, and Artists
description: FROM a corner of the stage at the Jericho Public Library, Shirley Blanc Romaine was narrating a mixed media program on the life and times of Isadora Duncan, a dancer she called ''the Divine Flame.'' As Beth Jucovy, a Duncan dance disciple from Great Neck, flounced about to a Chopin prelude, Ms. Romaine said Duncan was a pioneering feminist, international superstar and legend in her own time. Her very name elicited images of grace, passion and defiance.

title: Low-Budget, High-Energy
description: THE SETTING -- A dimly lighted, sparsely decorated hole-in-the-wall bar called Niva, which served as command central and box office for the first New York Lower East Side Film Festival, a four-day event featuring low-budget films that opened Thursday night.

title: In the Air, Violence You Can't Avoid
description: ABOUT 35,000 feet above the Great Plains late last year, Diane Samples and her husband, Mark Snyder, noticed that their 2 1/2-year-old son, Jacob, was engrossed in ''Lethal Weapon 4,'' the movie on the overhead video screen a few feet from their seats. Jacob, even without headphones, was giving the blow-'em-up, shoot-'em-down thriller an enthusiastic thumbs-up.

title: Station Has a Blueprint, but Still Needs Money
description: Thirty-six years after New York City tore down the original Pennsylvania Station in an act so widely condemned that it spawned a campaign for historic preservation, President Clinton in a visit to Manhattan on Wednesday is to inaugurate the renovation of the old station's surviving sister, the General Post Office on Eighth Avenue, into a new railroad terminal.

title: Gore Beats Bradley in Party's First Straw Poll
description: Nobody campaigned much. Really. And nobody gives much weight to it. Honest. But just for the record, Massachusetts Democrats, voting in the first party convention straw poll of the 2000 Presidential primary season, chose Vice President Al Gore over former Senator Bill Bradley by almost a 3-to-1 ratio today.

title: Anne Barthel And Dennis Kim
description: Anne Judith Barthel and Dennis Kim were married yesterday by the Rev. James Gilhooley at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Vincent Ferrer in New York.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In / Manor Heights, Staten Island; An Enclave High Above It All
description: MANOR HEIGHTS, says Thomas Baroz, is the kind of community where neighbors come by to introduce themselves to newcomers.

title: Teachers Union Will Pay To Develop a Curriculum
description: The New York City teachers union plans to spend $2 million of its own money to develop a core curriculum of school subjects that it said would raise academic standards for children at all grade levels and help stave off what the union regards as attacks on public education, such as school vouchers.

title: F.Y.I.
description: Black Cat in the Village

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: THE PIG FARMER'S DAUGHTER AND OTHER TALES OF AMERICAN JUSTICE

title: A Rainbow of Hope and Music, Polish and American
description: When Slawomir (Mark) Majik immigrated to New York 13 years ago, he brought a small wad of cash and a positive outlook. Despite initial setbacks, like paying $250 on arrival for a taxi from the airport to midtown, Mr. Majik's optimism has not wavered. Encouraged by the success of his first music store, Rainbow Music 2002 in the East Village, he opened a second store of the same name with his partner, Bill W. Kasper, two weeks ago at 95 Nassau Avenue near Manhattan Avenue in Greenpoint, Brooklyn. The name, Mr. Majik said, reflects his hope that the franchise will ''stretch like a rainbow across New York City.''

title: Spring Children's Books; Children's Books in Brief
description: One Present from Flekman's

title: Blair Sets New Deadline for an Ulster Government
description: Prime Minister Tony Blair tonight set a deadline of June 30 for the Northern Ireland parties to break the deadlock blocking progress in the peace settlement and to establish the new power-sharing government in Belfast called for in the accord.

title: New Breeds of Investors, All Beguiled by the Web
description: THERE is a myth that most of the people trading on the Internet are like Spyridon Ganas. Since opening an account with E*Trade on his 18th birthday in January, Mr. Ganas has taken to Web trading with a vengeance, betting not just on volatile technology stocks, but on the even more volatile options on technology stocks. A long-term investment is one he holds for more than a day or two.

title: IN MY... BRIEFCASE: NEAL STEPHENSON
description: Given that Neal Stephenson is one of the primary practitioners of the cyber science fiction novel, notably ''Snow Crash,'' he might be expected to travel with something appropriately high-tech: maybe a Sony Vaio 505 notebook computer or a Sharp Actius ultra-portable notebook. But his Hartmann leather briefcase actually contains a 15-by-10 inch Masonite board.

title: Where Schumann Meets Moby Grape
description: AFTER a century and a half, it doesn't matter that Schumann, who composed a magnificent piano concerto, suffered bouts of schizophrenia and an untimely death. His poignant themes and exhilarating passages even have a redemptive influence: hear and be healed.

title: A Singing Cowboy Goes to the Opry
description: WHEN a show's most alluring and most accurate selling point is its own description -- ''Where the dreams are as big as the hairdos'' -- all there is to say is, it's your call.

title: From Brewster Aerie, a View of a Reservoir
description: WITHOUT doubt, the panorama from Capriccio's aerie dining spot is outstanding: a bird's-eye view of the silvery East Branch Reservoir surrounded by hills of lush forest. Terraced and manicured, the immediate grounds have been designed to take full advantage of a landscape that can be observed from nowhere else. Energy and money have gone into maintaining this prospect, which is clearly what draws people to this restaurant's tables. These days culinary reasons are harder to find.

title: For Hospital's Planned Hotel, Little Local Hospitality
description: Ever since the Hotel Theresa in Harlem closed in the 1960's, there has been no sizable hotel above 96th Street in Manhattan. But last week the Upper Manhattan Empowerment Zone approved a $25 million investment that would help New York Presbyterian Hospital and a group of developers build a 300-room hotel and conference center at 165th Street and Fort Washington Avenue.

title: Old War Wounds
description: THE most striking character in Pat Barker's new novel is a centenarian war veteran named Geordie, who in his dying days manages to frighten, frustrate and charm everyone who comes near him. Geordie returned from the Great War with a bayonet wound in his stomach and a head full of guilty memories -- memories that readers of Barker's Regeneration trilogy will instantly recognize. Those novels, like ''Another World,'' owe at least part of their inspiration to Barker's childhood.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Best Bet

title: Look After the Lilacs and the Watering
description: Lilacs last longer when brought indoors if they're cut in the morning with plenty of wood and only half open. Recut stems on a 45 degree angle and slit vertically. Outdoors, propagate by bending a low branch to the ground, scoring the underside and covering with soil. After rooting, the new plant can be severed and moved.

title: You Can Leave the Rat Race Without a Hoard of Cheese
description: To the Editor:

title: To Play a Computer Quickly Is to Challenge Its Strength
description: It's a losing proposition even for very strong grandmasters to take on very strong computers in rapid play, but they still try it. And fail at it.

title: The Fresh Air Fund; Lessons in Perspective, Including Cow Stature
description: When Jevon Menendez-Briggs first saw cows he was shocked by how big they were. ''I thought they were the size of cats, but they were taller than me,'' said Jevon, 10. ''When I went near them they mooed at me.''

title: SOAPBOX; The Dog-Deprived
description: WE'RE like a cult. Our numbers are shady, membership requirements are vague, and our faith is unswerving. We meet in places like Washington Square Park, Tompkins Square Park, that lonely stripe of fenced-in concrete on the northwest corner of Mercer and Houston and -- our lodestar -- Central Park. We're a hardy bunch, withstanding the occasional rank odor of urine, guttural growls, rare flashes of a jawful of sharp teeth. Undoubtedly we all lead rewarding New York lives, working long weeks, sampling the riches of the city on weekends. But we are bound by a common lack that even dinner at Nobu or a ride up the Empire State Building can't cure: We are dog-deprived.

title: Q & A
description: Cruising to Charleston

title: 1999 Hasn't Been Stellar For Two Big Hedge Funds
description: George Soros and Julian H. Robertson, the managers of the world's biggest hedge funds, are losing money this year even as smaller rivals stage a comeback, according to investors and market news services.

title: Miss Hoffmann, Mr. Osborne
description: Catharine Burridge Hoffmann, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John B. Hoffmann of New York, was married yesterday to Alan Emmet Osborne, a son of Annette L. Mackie of Summit, N.J., and Robert E. Osborne of Sydney, Australia. The Rev. Andrew C. Mead performed the Episcopal ceremony at St. Thomas Church in New York. The Rev. Paul Tabor, a Roman Catholic priest, took part in the service.

title: The Ewing Era Is Idling At a Dramatic Crossroads
description: When Latrell Sprewell walked into the Knicks' locker room Friday night, a thick cluster of reporters migrated in his direction. And suddenly there was a clear view of a solitary Patrick Ewing sitting in his royal blue bathrobe, staring down the fibers in the carpet.

title: Mind Over Machine?
description: Sometimes it's the hardware. Sometimes it's the software. And sometimes it's just human error. Computer mistakes, malfunctions and glitches, beyond the obviously midsdirected E-mail, continue to spread faster than a computer virus. What are your own most humorous or horrific stories? Send them to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: May 9-15; No Loose Ends
description: It is almost as surprising as discovering a new bone in the human body. Biologists reported that chromosomes -- the lengthy DNA molecules that carry our genetic instructions -- end in neatly tied loops.

title: Food; But What Would Martha Say?
description: I want to be Martha. What married working woman with a family has remained untouched by the modern diva of domesticity?

title: When Big City Met Country, A New Radio Group Evolved
description: Its headquarters are in relatively bucolic Hawthorne, N.Y., and its revenues are still pint-sized by media company standards, $14.2 million in 1998. Still, Big City Radio Inc. has managed to live up to both its far-reaching name, as well as the collection of skyscrapers in its logo.

title: Fight Over Unused Rail Line
description: It has been 20 years since trains have rumbled along the High Line, a 1.5-mile stretch of elevated train tracks along 10th Avenue, between 33d and Gansevoort Streets.

title: How to Catch A Rising Star
description: Q. I own a small ad agency. We operate on an extremely tight budget and can't afford to pay the salaries our larger competitors do. As a result, we have difficulty hiring and holding on to qualified support staff. We are about to start yet another search for a business manager, and I'm desperate for tips on how to woo, win and keep a good person.

title: Click 1-2-3 for Cleavage
description: Will bra wonders never cease? Despite Pamela Anderson's implant removal, cleavage is certainly not out this season at Victoria's Secret, the lingerie company. After the success of its Miracle Bra, it is taking the push-up concept one step further and introducing the Click Bra, which offers adjustable cleavage. A plastic tightener, disguised as a front clasp (the bra actually fastens in the back), can be clicked one, two or three times, depending on how much cleavage is wanted. Victoria's Secret is promoting the bra as a day-to-evening accessory. ''A woman can begin the day at work with the lower level of cleavage-enhancement, go on to drinks with the middle level and then to dinner with the maximum level,'' explained Monica Mitro, the company's vice president for public relations. ''You have the versatility of three bras in one.'' The Click Bra, $42, will be in Victoria's Secret stores across the country on June 6. RIMA SUQI

title: Made in the Shade: The Native Foam Flower
description: WHEN there is something new to praise, especially new plants, the topic is worth pursuing. Yet, what follows is not so much about a new plant, as it is about a fascinating trend for a plant that to many may seem rather ordinary.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHULMAN, LEO
description: SCHULMAN-Leo. Died Friday, May 14, 1999. Husband of Florence. Father of Joan and Michael. Grandfather of Dana, Mara, Daniel and Molly. His neices, nephews and extended family will miss him greatly. In loving memory a memorial service will be held Sunday May 16th. at 12:30PM at George T. Davis funeral Home, 14 Le Count Place, New Rochelle,NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DECKER, JOSEPH M.
description: DECKER-Joseph M. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Joseph M. Decker, associated with The Times from 1956 until retiring in 1979.

title: OUTDOORS; From Game Fish to Games of Fishing
description: If you can't catch a real fish, you can always visit the International Game Fish Association Hall of Fame and Fishing Museum and line up at its virtual catch machines. In a state full of tourist attractions, this multifaceted facility in Dania, Fla., is unusual.

title: To Dance Flamenco, First Feel Pain
description: ABOUT halfway through my first flamenco class, when the instructor, Jorge Navarro, said, ''Lift your arms like the world is on them,'' I figured I was home free. That's how I feel all the time, anyway. But by the end of the class, feet throbbing, I was ready to surrender and I am no stranger to dance. Growing up as an overprivileged suburban child, I had years of ballet, jazz, even modern dance classes. My summers were spent -- Heaven help me -- at a camp that taught Israeli folk dancing. But never had I encountered anything as complex as flamenco, which blatantly defies three of America's favorite words: Easy. Now. Young.

title: A Man's Place
description: When the subject is women's economic progress, it's easy to get lost in the controversies of the moment. So The New York Times Magazine convened six experts to consider how that progress has played out over a longer stretch of history. They began by examining the transformation in the lives of working women, then looked at the power of women as consumers and finally appraised how well (or poorly) the economy has adapted to women's needs and desires.

title: Woods Collapses As Roberts Shoots a 62
description: It was a terrific day for Loren Roberts, a terrible day for Tiger Woods and a topsy-turvy day at the GTE Byron Nelson Classic.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption last Sunday about a Kosovar boy who had been living with a family in Summit reversed the identities of two boys. Gezim Shehu, the Kosovar, was at the right and Michael Gelber, a member of the family, at the left.

title: Downtown Houston Gets a Makeover
description: FIVE years ago, or even two, taking visitors for a night on the town would have been to court absurdity, unless your goal was to get them home early. Downtown Houston was a place where well-dressed people worked in their tunnel-connected, air-conditioned cocoons until about 5:30 P.M. and then beat feet back to the suburbs, leaving behind a dark, empty grid of glass canyons.

title: Grunfeld, Nursing Wounds, Still Roots for the Hometown Team
description: THERE is one longtime fan who thinks the Knicks ''have a good chance'' to win the deciding game in Miami this afternoon. He is Ernie Grunfeld, who, until April 21, was the president and general manager of this erratic team.

title: May 9-15; A Sharp Rise in Inflation
description: The Government reported that inflation moved up sharply at the consumer level in April, driven in part by rising oil and gasoline prices, and analysts said the remarkable decline in prices over the last several years may be over.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: Dating Miss Universe Nine Stories. By Steven Polansky. Ohio State University, $26.

title: Long Island Rose With European Spin
description: In varying shades of pink, semisweet white zinfandels like Sutter Home's have shaped Americans' popular notion of rose. But the 1998 dry rose from the tony Wolffer Estate/Sagpond Vineyards at Sagaponack on the South Fork of Long Island yields not a milliliter to this California starlet.

title: Turkish President Strips a Muslim Parliamentarian of Citizenship
description: A woman who was elected to Parliament last month but was denied permission to take her oath of office because she refused to remove her Muslim head scarf will be stripped of Turkish citizenship, Prime Minister Bulent Ecevit announced today.

title: Kaija Berzins, Peter Braus
description: Kaija Heather Berzins and Peter Lee Braus were married last evening by Rabbi Andrew Bachman at Wheatleigh, an inn in Lenox, Mass.

title: A Borough Celebrates Its Heritage of Work and Art
description: Roosevelt, tucked onto the western edge of Monmouth County, was created by the New Deal's Farm Security Administration as a haven for garment workers from New York City. Back in the 1930's, the residents went there to create a self-contained, cooperative community where they would make clothes to ship to wholesalers and raise their own food.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the growing dissatisfaction of pop artists with major record labels omitted the given name of a musician who has established her own label. She is Jonatha Brooke.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVY, SHELDON I.
description: LEVY-Sheldon I. Beloved husband of Barbara. Devoted father of Deborah Maher, Diana Cooper, and Daniel Levy. Proud grandfather of Joseph, Alison and Harry Maher. Dear brother of Doris Juster. title: FILM; From a Mud Hut in Ethiopia to Olympic Gold
description: IT would be the highlight of many a top athlete's career to break one world record. The distance runner Haile Gebrselassie of Ethiopia has broken 15. He has slashed hefty chunks off distance-running records, ranging from 2,000 meters on an indoor track to 10,000 meters outdoors. A repeat world champion and a 1996 Olympic gold medalist, he has frequently been hailed as the greatest distance runner ever.

title: 2d Group of Refugees Joins U.S. Relatives
description: A group of 208 Kosovo refugees, who have relatives ready to support and house them in the United States, arrived at Kennedy International Airport yesterday from camps in Macedonia.

title: Central Park Abloom
description: The perennial fashion spectacle was in full bloom earlier this month at the Frederick Law Olmsted Awards Luncheon, given by the Women's Committee of the Central Park Conservancy. Held in the Conservatory Garden in Central Park, at Fifth Avenue and 104th Street, the event raised $1.9 million for the restoration and upkeep of the park. Most of the 1,000 women who attended dressed in pastel suits or coats and matching dresses. Of those, 458 wore hats, a few decorated with fresh flowers. (One young woman wore a baseball cap.) Of 114 tables, only three were hatless. The star colors were shades of pink, rose and mauve. Executive women and corporate wives still cling to the romantic silhouette of the post-World War II Paris suits with small rounded shoulders and an hourglass waist, right and above left. The impeccably tailored guests in their Ascot-style hats offered a rare view of a nearly vanished romantic mode of dress. They carry on a vision of femininity from an earlier time, when appropriateness set the guidelines for clothing. The scene is one of the last grand displays of fashion, once commonplace at the races at Ascot, Paris and Saratoga.

title: Charles K. McWhorter, 77, Aide to Nixon
description: Charles K. McWhorter, an aide to Vice President Richard M. Nixon and later a lawyer for A.T.&T., died on Tuesday at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston after being injured on May 1 in a car accident on Cape Cod. He was 77 and lived in Manhattan and Los Angeles.

title: Janice Gault, James Vander
description: Dr. Janice Ann Gault, an ophthalmologist, and Dr. James Franklin Vander, a retinovitreal surgeon, were married yesterday on Hilton Head Island, S.C. The Rev. Dean D. Johnson, a Presbyterian minister, who is also the island's chaplain, officiated at the South Carolina Yacht Club.

title: Miss Huth, Mr. Farnham
description: Liana Lynn Huth was married yesterday to Nathaniel Gray Farnham at Studio 450 in New York. The Rev. Dr. George Koury performed the nondenominational ceremony.

title: BACKTALK; Wally's World Was a Place Like No Other
description: My school is a storybook college. I am happy when I walk up High Street on the cobblestone road and pass by the historic little shops where kids hang out. Shop owners call out, ''Hi, Wally!'' It's true, they do. I like seeing the old water tower and the redbrick buildings that are part of this town. Not too many campuses can compare to this one; nothing is too far to walk to. While big colleges are spread out like cities, this is a mom-and-pop place, a little campus in a small town. That is what makes up the mystique of Miami University and Oxford, Ohio, and my life for the past four years.

title: BACKTALK; Surrounded By Role Models; Honored as One
description: Now that my college years are almost at an end, I look back on the last five years -- I was injured and redshirted my freshman season -- with mixed emotions. The one thing I don't have are regrets. I have made the most of my time and opportunities, and I am ready to move on. I really am fortunate: fortunate to have had the athletic and academic ability to get through an elite institution like the University of Wisconsin, fortunate to have had people around me throughout my life who have held me to high standards, both as a student and as an athlete.

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer found a perfect vehicle for Hollywood's favorite songbirds, Jeanette MacDonald and Nelson Eddy, in Robert Z. Leonard's MAYTIME (1937), a festive and sentimental production based on the venerable operetta. The lingering plot involving love's sweet song is enhanced by a cornucopia of music, including Sigmund Romberg's title song, and the fire-and-ice performance of John Barrymore as MacDonald's jealous and alert manager and husband - Sunday at 1:30 P.M. on TCM.

description: SINCE Colonial times, winter flounder have generally been so plentiful in Niantic Bay that an angler could quickly fill the bottom of a small boat with the odd-looking but popular flatfish.

description: CAN you get rich investing in the companies that created the wealth of the Forbes 400? Or in those that Fortune magazine lists as America's most admired? You may soon be invited to find out.

description: AFTER making a name for himself largely by playing slick gangsters, Don Cheadle was given the kind of breakout offer that actors pray for: the part of Sammy Davis Jr. in the HBO movie ''The Rat Pack.''

title: Weaving a Counterpoint of Ideas
description: TOM ZE had just moved into a new apartment, and he apologized to a visitor for the disarray. The room he uses for a home recording studio was a jumble of cords, guitars, microphones and old recording equipment. Boxes awaited unpacking in the hallways; walls were bare. But the books were already on the shelves in neat rows: fiction and history and philosophy from Brazilian and Portuguese authors alongside Faulkner and Nero Wolfe mysteries by Rex Stout. ''Of course the books came out first,'' said Mr. Ze's wife and sometime translator, Neusa.

title: New York, Renewed and Restored
description: IF you're a roamer and a watcher, a traveler who bypasses the obligatory sights in favor of walking the streets until a place becomes a part of your history, no city is more compelling than New York. Much to the dismay of those who would stop time, it is always trans forming itself. Leave a place for a few years, and on your return it may be unrecognizable.

Last year, the trainer's Victory Gallop closed on Real Quiet in the Kentucky Derby but missed by a neck. In the Preakness, the colt was runner-up by a little more than two lengths.

This happens three different times as he drags on one Marlboro, but it would be foolish to interrupt. Tarasco has too much to say.

Though he once worked for the National Labor Relations Board and the National War Labor Board, the bulk of Mr. Kheel's career has been spent as a lawyer in private practice and as a mediator, not as a national labor official.

title: First-Time 'Customs,' Not Cookie-Cutters

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Art for Religion's Sake
description: While the enormous talents of the folk artist Edward Hicks (1780-1849) are often celebrated, it was his mission as a religious servant that inspired his illustrious allegorical series of paintings, ''The Peaceable Kingdom.'' In THE KINGDOMS OF EDWARD HICKS (Abby Aldrich Rockefeller Folk Art Center/Colonial Williamsburg Foundation/Abrams, $39.95), Carolyn J. Weekley, director of museums at Colonial Williamsburg, deftly chronicles Hicks's early training as a decorative painter, his journey into the Quaker world and his lifelong struggle to reconcile his spiritual beliefs with his material needs. Hicks's mother died when he was a toddler. Unable to support the child, his father sent him to live with family friends who raised him as a Quaker. As a teen-ager Hicks was apprenticed to a local stagecoach shop to learn decorative painting. He became a Quaker minister in 1811. He received no pay for this position and supported his family with his decorative painting, a practice that stood in direct contradiction to the utilitarian views of the Quakers. Increasingly Hicks's views diverged from those of the Quakers, and under the guidance of his cousin Elias Hicks, a Hicksite faction was formed. There was much animosity between the Hicksites and the orthodox Quakers, which had an irrevocable effect on Hicks. His many versions of the ''Peaceable Kingdom'' paintings symbolically reflect the urgency of that discord as well as his desire for peace between the two divisions. Using Isaiah's prophecy ''The wolf also shall dwell with the lamb . . .'' as a blueprint, Hicks's paintings, in varying degrees, mirror his personal agony about religious tension. Weekley has compiled a scholarly history of Hicks as both minister and painter, and of the turmoil these conflicting vocations wrought on his own kingdom. Amy Todd

title: SOAPBOX; The Little Girls of Spring
description: SHE does not naturally assume the posture of a softball player when she takes her place in left field. Rather, she pulls her glove off and begins twisting her lime green bubble gum around her finger.

description: I CAME upon them quite by accident. There I was, wandering the state's official botanical garden. Though I had a map in hand, I was lost. I wandered through a stand of lilacs, and when I popped out the other side, there they were:

title: Making a 'To Do' List For the Treasury Handoff
description: Lawrence H. Summers, Deputy Secretary of the Treasury, was nominated last week to succeed his boss, Robert E. Rubin. When Mr. Summers sits down for the first time at his new desk, he might might find a letter like this from his predecessor.

title: Entry Vehicle for an Indolent Tourist
description: I'VE always wished I were a more intrepid traveler, one of those hardy souls who go backpacking through Peru, or bicycling around the lesser-known provinces of China, or hiking through the mountains of Greece. The most daring thing I ever did in my life was find myself in Haiti during the political upheavals of the late 60's, and although the sight of unsmiling Tonton Macoutes bristling with weaponry made me shiver, I suspect that as a young American tourist I was in danger only in my dreams.

title: For Students, Saturdays Spent in Tutorials
description: HOMER GARCIA sat quietly at a library table, holding an English workbook as if he could absorb its lessons by osmosis. His classmate, Alejandro Zuniga, gripped his book with an equal measure of anxiety.

title: Will Streeters' Generosity Bloom?
description: The Dow has experienced 11,000, Goldman Sachs has gone public and mergers and acquisitions abound. But even Wall Street executives suggest privately that maybe their colleagues could do more with their fortunes besides expanding them.

title: Country Music Served With City-Slick Tactics
description: ITS headquarters are in relatively bucolic Hawthorne, N.Y., and its revenues are still pint-sized, adding up to just $14.2 million in 1998. Still, Big City Radio Inc. has already managed to live up to both its far-reaching name as well as the collection of skyscrapers in its logo.

description: To the Editor:
