description: To the Editor:

title: Fraud Most Foul
description: In Billy Wilder's DOUBLE INDEMNITY (1944), Barbara Stanwyck and Fred MacMurray play two greedy, determined lovers, with Edward G. Robinson hot on their trail. Brilliantly adapted from a story by James M. Cain, with which it has little in common, the picture details the lovers' adulterous scheming for a ripe insurance harvest in Los Angeles, which includes the ugly business of plotting the death of Stanwyck's husband. The realistic dialogue and ominous musical score by Miklos Rozsa, used sparingly, add to the suspense. There's not a dull minute - starting with the picture's opening dirge as a man limps toward the camera - FRIDAY at 6 P.M. and FRIDAY/EARLY SATURDAY at 12:05 A.M. on AMC.

title: Paige Ethington, Tripp Hardy
description: Laura Paige Ethington and John Basil Hardy 3d were married yesterday by the Rev. Robert Vassar at the First Baptist Church in Shelbyville, Ky.

title: One Cultural Center Stays, Another to Go
description: Two lower Manhattan cultural centers known for their radically different approaches to City Hall once again found themselves facing divergent fates last week.

title: A Rent Battle That Arose When Reagan Was President
description: In the sometimes Dickensian world of New York litigation, how long does it take to settle a case? Ask Peter and Alexandra Rose, who have been fighting with their landlord over their rent for 15 years. And it's not over yet.

title: Celebrating 75 Years Of Vermont's Parks
description: Vermont will mark the 75th anniversary of its state park system this summer with programs on crafts, wildlife and history. Aside from campsites, swimming areas and hiking trails, many of Vermont's 50-plus state parks contain remains of logging camps, iron smelters, early settlements, mills, railroad beds, mines and quarries.

title: AT THE COSTUME INSTITUTE WITH/POLLY MELLEN; When 'Absolutely Fabulous' Comes to Breathless Life
description: LAST Tuesday's guide at the Costume Institute of the Metropolitan Museum of Art was a lively lady with a short gray flip, a pony-print purse and black-framed glasses, which she regularly removed to emphasize pronouncements like ''I've always been enamored of Cinderella and rags and shredding!''

title: In Praise of the Most Unpopular Girl at Lawndale
description: THE older I get, the more I think about high school. This may explain my current, unseemly attachment to ''Dawson's Creek,'' a WB nighttime soap aimed at 14-year-olds. Every Wednesday night, its heroine Joey Potter (played by the unnaturally beautiful Katie Holmes) breezes through difficulties -- a classmate's accidental drowning, learning that the boy she's dating is gay, her on-again, off-again romance with Dawson (James Van Der Beek) -- with verbal and physical aplomb.

title: Finding, and Fixing, Leaks in Sinks
description: SINK leaks can develop in two places. The obvious leaks occur on top around the faucets. Remedies usually require opening the faucet and adjusting or replacing the valve components. Leaks can also occur under the sink in the drain pipes. These leaks sometimes go unnoticed if the pipes are enclosed in a vanity or cabinet. They are not as obvious as the faucet leaks because the pipes do not hold water under constant pressure, so the drips are not constant. Drain pipe leaks only drip when water is flowing out of the sink.

title: Geriatric Care Managers
description: To the Editor:

title: Kids' Insurance Fund
description: To the Editor:

title: A Race With an Uncertain Reward
description: WHEN voters in District 12 in the south central Bronx trickle in to their local school board election on Tuesday, -- and if turnout predictions hold, it will be a trickle -- Joyce Briscoe would seem to be a shoo-in. That is not because she has waged a particularly aggressive campaign, or because she has such radical ideas for changing the schools. Ms. Briscoe's is the only name on the ballot.

title: Turnstile Jumper Is Crushed by a Subway Train
description: A fare dodger was crushed to death by a J train in Brooklyn early yesterday after he leaped onto the tracks in an attempt to escape two transit officers, the police said yesterday.

title: Fresh Peas Good Enough to Eat Raw or Gently Cooked
description: AS anyone with a vegetable garden knows, there is nothing like fresh peas eaten straight from the pod. They are so sweet and tender, they do not need to be cooked at all -- and once you have started to eat them it is hard to stop. Courtiers of Louis XIV knew this only too well. In 1660 piselli novelli (as they were called in Italy, where their production dates from the Renaissance) were brought from Genoa to Versailles, where they became known as petits pois and were all the rage. Madame de Maintenoy reported that women at the court, ''having supped with the King, and supped well,'' would take to their private chambers and devour bowls of peas, heedless of indigestion, with the kind of insatiable appetite normally reserved for boxes of chocolates.

title: Rockin' the Clown
description: Jersey Shore rockers who've been plugging away since the early Springsteen days have put out an album that rolls 20 years of local pop history into one package. Their sound and energy have been captured on ''The Spirit of Asbury Park: Rockin' the Jersey Shore'' (Halcyon Records).

title: Greenpoint to Sheepshead Bay: When the Boards Meet
description: DISTRICT 1 -- Greenpoint, Williamsburg; second Tuesday of the month; next meeting June 8, 6:30 P.M.; 211 Ainslee Street, corner of Manhattan Avenue, Williamsburg; Community board chairman: Vincent V. Abate; District manager: Gerald Esposito; (718) 389-0009. Agenda: To be announced.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: A GOOD ENOUGH DAUGHTER

title: The Rest of the Story
description: For all their drama and insight, traditional histories of the last thousand years fall short. Written mostly by men, they introduced women into the standard parade of wars, revolutions, monarchs and parliaments only at moments like their ascension to inherited thrones or religious authority. In the 19th century, most male historians compounded the problem by making women's history sound as though women had only then begun making headway.

title: A Semistar Who Stays In the Shade
description: MOST songwriters would rather be dead than think of their life's work as kitsch. Not Lee Hazlewood. When Mr. Hazlewood heard that the ''Loser's Lounge,'' a bimonthly tribute show at the Manhattan club Fez, was planning an evening devoted to his music, he did more than just send his blessings. He got on a plane and delivered his blessings himself. He brought along his girlfriend, rounded up some New York cronies, reserved a sparkly vinyl banquette and bought drinks for everyone near him. Then the 69-year-old semi-legend sat back and joyfully beheld as a motley parade of punk-rockers, would-be crooners and self-styled musical comedians resurrected, revered, goofed on and massacred his songs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDNER, NICHOLAS
description: GOLDNER-Nicholas. We extend our sincerest condolences to Edith Steinlauf, our devoted friend and Silver Founder, and Charles Goldner, on the loss of their beloved brother. May the warm and loving memories of this special individual bring solace to the entire family and may they be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. American Committee for Shaare Zedek Medical Center in Jerusalem Erica Jesselson, Chair Menno Ratzker, President Stuart Tauber, Executive Director

title: The View From/Pleasantville; Day Spent in the Shoes Of Those Less Fortunate

After class, she plays basketball with friends, attends Hebrew school, comes home and eats pasta or a stir-fried dinner and logs on to the Internet. Then it is back upstairs to her room, where posters of Leonardo DiCaprio line the walls.

description: AFTER more than a year, restoration of the dome atop the State Capitol in Trenton is nearly complete. Workers recently began the final stage on the exterior, applying gold leaf to the 2,000-square-feetsurface.

description: Land and Sea Adventures

title: Heidi Segal, Eric Krautheimer
description: Heidi Jill Segal and Eric Michael Krautheimer, lawyers in New York, were married last evening by Rabbi Norman R. Patz at the Rockleigh Country Club in Rockleigh, N.J.

title: Baseball's Same Old Story
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: A Generation of German Pacifists Finds Itself at Odds Over the Kosovo Air War
description: Like many Germans of the generation born at the end of World War II, Heidi Bauer has spent much of her life opposing war, driven by an intimate sense of its horror and its indelible scars.

title: Nationalism Is Mood in Turkey's Kurdish Enclaves
description: An elderly man who is among the most respected denizens of Diyarbakir's twisting bazaar sat speaking about his memories of Kurdish struggle.

title: Spring Children's Books; Children's Books in Brief
description: The Trolls

title: Labor vs. Airline: A Split Decision
description: Faced with an effort by the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers to organize its 8,000 baggage handlers and other cargo workers, Continental Airlines called in a heavyweight labor specialist. Last month, with a vote pending on joining the union, the company put up posters that featured Larry Holmes, the former boxing champion, saying: ''You won the title by working together. Why let anyone get between you and another championship?'' He visited with workers in Cleveland, Houston and Newark on the airline's behalf.

title: Commencement; Stony Brook Gives Honor More Than Honorary
description: Charles Johnson has accomplished much in his life: a stretch as a syndicated cartoonist, a career as a professor of black literature, a philosophical book on race, and several well-received novels, including the National Book Award winner about the slave trade, ''Middle Passage.''

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption last Sunday about the Woodshed, an historic house in Sea Cliff, misidentified one of the two interiors shown. The room with the dining table is the dining room, not the foyer.

title: Mina Wachendorfer, Andrew Kessler
description: Mina Mary Wachendorfer, a daughter of Patricia and Paul Wachendorfer of Northport, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Lieut. Andrew Lawrence Kessler, the son of Martha and Steven Kessler of Garrison, N.Y. The Rev. Anthony M. Stanganelli officiated at St. Philip Neri Roman Catholic Church.

title: Dancing On Top of the World, With Malaise
description: DAVID PARSONS sounded distressed. ''Lately, every time I start a new project, I get unnerved,'' he said over lunch in Manhattan recently. Although this 39-year-old dancer-choreographer looks like a hunky, happy-go-lucky movie star, during this conversation he came across as an angst-ridden artist. ''In the back of my mind, there's always the word 'accessible' that's constantly thrown at me as an insult. What does it mean? That I attract the masses? That's bad? My work's not about getting people to love me. It's about following what I want to do.''

title: Impersonating The Insiders: Yes, It Pays
description: DO they or don't they? Do corporate insiders -- like company directors and officers -- know so much more than we do about their company's prospects that we can beat the market simply by imitating their purchases and sales?

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about a television movie on the sexual assault of a retarded girl in Glen Ridge 10 years ago misstated the number of children of Cherry Provost, a former school board member who said that the town has been trying to improve communications with its youth. She has three sons, not two.

title: Correction
description: The main front-page article in this section last Sunday, about New York baseball history, misidentified the New York Giant who contended for a batting title with Carl Furillo of the Brooklyn Dodgers in 1953, when Leo Durocher, the Giants' manager, was suspected of stepping on Furillo's hand. The Giant player was Don Mueller, not Willie Mays.

title: U.S. Has Finally Found a Reliable Goal Scorer
description: The player who is perhaps the brightest star in soccer's future in the United States was sitting on the bench last Sunday for what should have been one of the biggest games of his young career.

title: White House Is Bracing For a Chinese Backlash
description: The Clinton Administration, which once hoped that stronger bonds between China and the United States would be a centerpiece of its foreign policy legacy, is now bracing for a deep deterioration in relations that may not improve before President Clinton leaves office.

title: Photographs and Documents Re-create Eras of the Bronx
description: BECAUSE it involves a large block of time, ''Urban Mythologies: The Bronx Represented Since the 1960's'' promises to be a kind of epic. The Bronx, with its ups and downs, is a rich environment for self-expression, so this exhibition was eagerly anticipated. It also marks the reopening of the Bronx Museum after a major expansion.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: GRAVESEND; Speed Bump Turns Up on Block and Some Are Rattled
description: When a speed bump appeared a few weeks ago on East Third Street between Avenues T and U, part of a recent effort by the city to keep motorists from speeding, some people were surprised, and irritated that they hadn't been consulted.

title: Endpaper; Good Housekeeping
description: When I was in my 20's and inhabiting rooming houses, I was given a book called ''Cooking in a Bedsitter,'' by the formidable Katharine Whitehorn. It pointed out that although I was living in squalor, I didn't have to live in total squalor: with a hot plate, some herbs and a little foresight, a degree of elegance might be achieved. I have been a grateful reader of such advice books and their variants, women's magazine articles, ever since. (Grateful, though sometimes bemused: do I really want to marbleize an end table or make a gingerbread chalet? Not today.)

title: Circling the Globe In a Straight Line
description: AMARONE+

title: Newark Reduces Flights During Runway Repaving
description: One of Newark International Airport's three runways, closed since repaving work began earlier this month, will reopen for propeller planes on Thursday and jets on June 5, said William Cahill, a spokesman for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which operates the airport.

title: Repasts of the Past at Historic Houses in Britain
description: Several National Trust sites in Britain will offer visitors a chance to sample a taste of history this summer.

title: Mapping the Millennium; Interior Territory
description: In the 13th century, anatomical drawings -- our maps of the human territory -- were schematic, scarcely more than diagrams, with an untranslatable text, as in the ''Anatomy of Female Genitalia,'' from a manuscript at the Bodleian Library. The vagina is a rigid tube, and the ovaries swing freely away from the uterus, in which a cartoonish fetus declares the state of pregnancy. There is nothing to suggest that this is a woman's body.

title: Concerts That Appeal to Children
description: ADULTS can leave their wallets at home, but they should take their children to either of two free concerts today at 3 P.M. The Yonkers Philharmonic will introduce an 11-year-old violinist at the Saunders School in Yonkers, while the West Point Band will go to Rye High School with the fanciful tale of ''The Man Who Invented Music.''

title: Trying to Balance the Old Garde With the New
description: SOME changes come more easily than others. In 1979, when a bunch of scrappy performance artists transformed an abandoned public school in the East Village into a showcase for experimental dance and theater, they didn't even have to change the name. P.S. 122 (now Performance Space 122) stood as a vast ready-made home for the city's burgeoning performance-art community.

title: Manufacturers Are Courting Amateurs With a Fast Idea
description: It's usually the big, tricked-out Superboats with their churning, 1,000-horsepower engines that draw crowds at offshore powerboat races. Now, less-imposing production boats are beginning to draw crowds of their own. Their footsteps lead directly to the amateur boater's door.

title: When the Biker Style Includes Good Deeds
description: A GROUP of men with long hair and leather jackets embroidered with a skeleton riding a motorcycle nibbled hors d'oeuvres with a crowd of establishment types at a fund-raising event for a New Haven homeless shelter.

title: Ideas & Trends; For the Jaded Aesthete, A Dose of the Very Real
description: THERE is a moment in David Hare's ''Via Dolorosa'' when it becomes clear that the playwright's personal meditation on Israel's emotional state also expresses something that is happening in American culture.

title: In Alaska, Eco-Tours Start With a Copter
description: You've heard of heli-skiing. Why not heli-hiking? Outdoor enthusiasts will be able to drop into southeast Alaska this summer on Alpine Excursions Heli-hiking Tours, offered by Cape Fox Tours of Ketchikan, Alaska. Cape Fox's tours focus on history, native heritage and wilderness ecosystems. The heli-hiking expeditions, which will run through Sept. 30, will allow visitors to experience and learn about the diverse Alaskan ecosystem that thrives above the timberline, at 3,200 feet. Participants are flown 20 minutes by helicopter from George Inlet, 13 miles from Ketchikan, then led on a 90-minute hike through the alpine environment where wolves, black bears and three species of ptarmigans reside. Back at George Inlet, visitors tour an old cannery and take a short walk through the rain forest there.

title: Auto Pollution Plan Is Drawn Into a Vortex
description: An Administration plan to require cleaner gasoline and automobiles that emit less pollution, described by officials as the most ambitious anti-pollution initiative of the Clinton Presidency, is drawing heavy lobbying by environmentalists and industry and strong interest by politicians eyeing next year's Presidential campaign.

title: From Beverly to Benjamin
description: Cater-corner to the vast Waldorf-Astoria at 50th Street and Lexington Avenue, a far smaller hotel from the same era opened last month after getting a new name and a major renovation.

title: A Pair of Unsettling Shows to Prod the Viewer
description: THe Aldrich Museum of Contemporary Art here has two exhibitions designed to unsettle viewers. The discomfort is a prod to make them think about larger issues, and the exhibitions operate by skewering perceptions, making the long ago seem eerily present.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MIJUSKOVIC, MILUTIN B. (D.M.S.)
description: MIJUSKOVIC-Milutin B. (D.M.S.) The students, faculty, and staff of the New York University College of Dentistry record with profound sadness the loss on May 10, 1999 of our beloved teacher, colleague, and friend, Dr. Milutin ''Mike'' Mijuskovic, Associate Professor of Basic Sciences (Oral Medicine and Pathology). His devotion to the NYU College of Dentistry, the dental profession, and the community inspired us all. He will be deeply missed. Deepest sympathy to his long time companion Dr. Wilma Shochat. Division of Basic Sciences

title: The Nation; The Personality Cults Of Impersonal Economics
description: THE curse and the blessing of the global economy is that no one's in charge. To those it has flattened recently -- the Russians, many Asians, the Brazilians -- it resembles a bullet train on autopilot, roaring across borders and barreling over slower-moving vehicles while a bunch of wealthy Americans down champagne in the club car. To free marketeers, it is the triumph of the invisible hand, a system governed by economic laws and not meddling economic planners, fueled by the Internet instead of ideology.

title: In Israeli Vote, Arabs Hold Their Breath and Their Tongues
description: The Arab world is watching the Israeli election with a pretense of neutrality, although Ehud Barak, the Labor Party leader, is plainly the favorite.

title: Aiding Students To Go Overseas
description: THE number of United States college students going overseas for part of their undergraduate work is rising, and has been rising for some years. At Carleton College in Northfield, Minn., where the director of off campus study says courses overseas are ''part of the undergraduate experience, part of conversation at dinner,'' 310 students joined foreign study programs in 1997-98; this was 17 percent of a student body of 1,858.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NAREFF, ARTHUR A., M.D.
description: NAREFF-Arthur A., M.D. On May 13, 1999. Beloved husband of Florence. Cherished father of Jill Blauner and Jonathan Nareff. Adored grandfather of Seth, Matthew and Gretchen. Devoted brother of the late Colonel Max J. Nareff, M.D. A.B. degree, University of Alabama; M.D., University of Western Ontario. Family physician to the constituents of the Lower East Side, from 1941-1981. Physician on staff of Beth Israel Hospital for over fifty years. Medical Director, New York City Board of Education, 1978-1983. Fellow, Family Practice Association. Services Monday, May 17, 11:00 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to the University of Western Ontario, Medical School, London, Ontario, Canada, care of Alumni Hall, Room 11, N6A5B9.

title: John Minor Wisdom, Appeals Court Judge Who Helped to End Segregation, Dies at 93
description: Judge John Minor Wisdom, the New Orleans legal scholar who wrote opinion after opinion that desegregated courthouses throughout the Deep South and put blacks on juries, in the voting booth, in state legislatures and in integrated classrooms, died yesterday in New Orleans. He would have turned 94 tomorrow.

title: May 9-15; A Warning on Liposuction
description: Doctors warned that America's favorite cosmetic surgery, liposuction, can be fatal. A review of autopsy reports in New York City from 1993 to 1998 identified five deaths during or shortly after the procedure, in which surgeons use a suction device to remove fat from areas like the hips, thighs and abdomen.

title: Phillip Calenda, Susan Stern
description: Susan Marie Stern and Dr. Phillip James Calenda are to be married today in Scarborough, N.Y. Rabbi Burt Aaron Siegel is to officiate at the Sleepy Hollow Country Club. The Rev. R. John Nelson, a Roman Catholic priest, will take part in the service.

title: Wedded To Its Moral Imperatives
description: HERE amid the snow-covered pines near Lake Tahoe, Patagonia Inc. held its fourth annual weekend training conference last month. In what one participant called a ''summer camp for tree-huggers,'' community organizers in various environmental causes came from far and wide to learn how to be more effective.

title: GOING OUT
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Spectator Interferes With Race At Pimlico
description: Last year a power failure tainted Preakness Day; today it was a fan. In the stretch drive of the seventh race, the Maryland Breeders' Cup, a man made his way through Pimlico Race Course's infield and across the turf course and faced down a thundering herd of nine horses on the track.

title: May 9-15; It's My Turn. Again.
description: In his first letter to Joyce Maynard, J. D. Salinger urged her to be ''almost inhumanly cautious'' about accepting the offers and invitations likely to come her way in the wake of a widely read reminiscence she wrote at the age of 18 in 1972.

title: A Fertilizer Machine Fueled by Dirt
description: THE uneven surfaces of my concrete sidewalk and driveway gather pools of water after a heavy rain, and most times each pool has a couple of earthworms in it. The worms look dead, or dying, and I used to think it was unfortunate that they came to the surface to escape their flooding burrows only to expire in these temporary ponds.

title: Correction
description: An article on May 2 about the depiction of summer in European films misstated the surname of a character who kisses Lucy Honeychurch in the film ''A Room With a View.'' He is George Emerson, not George Benson.

title: Avoiding a Crash
description: THE RETURN

title: Minority State Troopers Forming Their Own Group
description: About 150 state troopers -- all of them women or members who consider themselves racial minorities -- have formed ''an association of people who are like us and can deal with our concerns,'' said one trooper, speaking on condition of anonymity.

title: Temptation, Temptation At Auction Houses
description: Auction houses -- especially their wine departments -- are outdoing the Vegas casinos in coddling customers.

title: The Future Is Ours to Lose
description: Standing at the turn of the millennium, how odd it seems that women, the majority of the human species, have not, over the course of so many centuries, intervened successfully once and for all on their own behalf. That is, until you consider that women have been trained to see themselves as having no relationship to history, and no claim upon it. Feminism can be defined as women's ability to think about their subjugated role in history, and then to do something about it. The 21st century will see the End of Inequality -- but only if women absorb the habit of historical self-awareness, becoming a mass of people who, rather than do it all, decide at last to change it all. The future is ours to lose.

title: Slovakia Picks a President
description: For the first time since Slovakia was created in 1993, its voters today chose a President by direct election.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRETT, CAROLYN S. (MACKIE)
description: BRETT-Carolyn S. (Mackie). On April 24, 1999, Carlsbad, CA. after a short illness. Born December 30, 1908, Englewood, NJ. Widow of David I. Mackie Jr. and Roger W. Brett. Graduate, Dwight School, 1927; Smith College, 1932. Avid horticulturist. Propagated ''Carole Mackie Daphne.'' 1st VP, Garden Club of America, 1965-67. Resident, Far Hills, NJ, 1946-67; Rancho Sante Fe, California 1967-1992. Survived by sons Arthur S. Mackie and David I. Mackie III, stepson Roger Brett and grandchildren Glen, Scott and Brette Mackie. Memorial services to be held at a later date in Rancho Sante Fe, CA. In lieu of flowers, memorials please to Quail Gardens, Encinitas, CA. Contact: David I. Mackie, 7315 Walnut Mill Landing, Cumming, GA. 30040.

title: Commercial Property/New Jersey; High-Tech Company Offices Expand in Monmouth
description: TO gain a presence in this country, J. D. S. Fitel, a Canadian company that develops fiber-optic products, opened a 14,000-square-foot office last June at Monmouth Executive Center, not far from Routes 9 and 33 in Freehold Township in Monmouth County. Since then the company has leased an additional 3,500 square feet there.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEIN, HOWARD M.
description: KLEIN-Howard M. Died peacefully on May 14 after a courageous and dignified battle with lung cancer. Beloved husband of Alice Kulick Klein. Parent and special friend to Renee and Tom Brodie; ''Gramps'' to Isabella. Father of David, Kenneth and the late Amy Shapiro. Brother of Dorothy and the late Maxwell, Hilda and Lawrence. Service Sunday at 2 PM at The Jewish Community Center of Harrison, 130 Union Avenue, Harrison, NY.

title: Whitman Pays Steep Price, And Evens Score, on Verniero
description: It has not taken Governor Whitman long to start settling her political debts over the State Supreme Court nomination of Attorney General Peter G. Verniero.

title: Spring Children's Books; Children's Books in Brief: It's a Mad, Mad, Mad, Mad Girl
description: When Sophie gets angry, she roars a fiery scarlet roar that surges and boils across a page of lush purples and reds, tumbling toys and books with it. She becomes a volcano, ready to explode in crimsons and yellows -- a sight familiar to any parent who has seen a child wrestling with her feelings. And then Sophie slams the door -- PABAM! -- and runs and runs, into a forest where she is surrounded by entrancing flowers and ferns and trees and birds. Finally, she reaches an old beech tree, painted to reach invitingly into the deep blue sky like a road for Sophie to climb. She climbs, and ''the wide world comforts her,'' with the tree enfolding her and a serene sea view soothing her. When she feels better, she climbs down and goes back to her bright, warm home, where Dad is reading a seed catalogue and her sister is putting together a jigsaw puzzle. Everyone is glad she's home.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GUSOFF, GERRY
description: GUSOFF-Gerry. May 17, 1994. Five years without you, an infinite void. Forever loved and etched upon our hearts. Ileen

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   BELLSEY, PETER MICHAEL
description: BELLSEY-Peter Michael May 14, 1953-August 20,1990 BELLSEY-Ronald Eric May 21, 1951-August 17, 1977 Remembered each day with love.

title: A Poet of Darkness Who Longs for the Light
description: IN the years since his death in 1984, Francois Truffaut has come to stand for a certain kind of Gallic humanism -- a life-loving, lightly romantic view of the world as a place filled with pretty girls, adorable children and heroes illuminated by a wise, warm understanding of the fleeting nature of love.

title: FIVE QUESTIONS for ALFRED E. KAHN; He Freed the Airlines. But What to Do Now?
description: THE Federal Government rocked the airline industry on Thursday when the Justice Department's antitrust division accused American Airlines of illegally adding flights and slashing prices at its Dallas-Fort Worth hub in order to drive out low-fare competitors.

title: Isn't It Romantic?
description: To the Editor:

title: Surviving in the Hamptons, And Doing It the Hard Way
description: I was most interested in your article about Jodi Della Femina's soon-to-be-published book, ''Jodi's Shortcuts '99'' [Long Island Journal, May 9]. For the last three years I have been publishing a guide to the Hamptons that rates more than 600 Hamptons merchants and service providers in more than 300 categories. I have sent you copies every year and have written you about it on several occasions, with no result. Yes, Ms. Della Femina's dad is Jerry Della Femina, the noted ad exec, Hamptons entrepreneur and columnist for the Independent newspapers. So, I think it safe to conclude that name recognition certainly helps to get your attention. But I was just curious: your reporter called Ms. Della Femina's forthcoming book a ''survival guide'' for the Hamptons (the reporter's words, not Ms. Della Femina's). My book is entitled ''The Hamptons Survival Guide.'' What should I make of all this? What would you make of all this?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUZAREVICH, WALTER LOUIS
description: HUZAREVICH-Walter Louis, 79, died Monday, May 10, 1999 in Fort Worth, Texas. Funeral services were held on May 15, in Fort Worth with burial following in Mount Olivet Cemetery. Walter Louis Huzarevich was born December 9, 1919, in Fort Worth, and served in the U.S. Army during WWII as sergeant with the 1276th combat battalion, combat engineers. Serving in the European Theatre, he participated in the Battle of the Herken Forest, the Battle of the Rhineland, and the DDay invasion. He received two Purple Hearts, the Bronze Star, the European Service Ribbon, and Two Bronze Service Stars. He was twice wounded in action, the second time severely on 24 March 1945 during the Battle of the Rhineland. In 1936 he began working at Fort Worth Linotyping Company eventually becoming the owner and Chairman of the Board. With his brother, Conrad, he founded Fort Worth Legal Brief Printing, Lino Typographers, and other companies. He was a lifelong supporter of the Democratic Party. He was preceded in death by his beloved brothers, Conrad and Julian Huzarevich.

title: Ignored Indeed
description: To the Editor:

title: Rosemarie Baiocchi, David Cohn
description: Rosemarie Baiocchi and David H. Cohn were married yesterday afternoon in Manhattan at All Saints Episcopal Church. The Rev. Steven Jay Yagerman performed the ceremony.

title: Love and Marriage
description: To the Editor:

title: JERSEY DIARY
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Jane Siegel, Mark Greene
description: Jane Lauren Siegel, a daughter of Shelley and Joel D. Siegel of Livingston, N.J., was married last evening to Mark Ira Greene, a son of Myrna and Harvey Greene of Neponsit, N.Y. Rabbi Chava Koster officiated at the Metropolitan Club in New York.

title: Bistro Fare (at More Than Bistro Prices)
description: WHITE OAK BISTRO in New Canaan has taken over the premises formerly occupied by L'Abbee. In the process, the small dining room has been expanded, lightened and changed considerably. While the space, which is entirely smoke free, resembles a conventional restaurant, the menu is certainly bistro style. In the course of various visits, with the help of friends, we easily ate our way through the short menu (which changes daily). Most appetizers were hugely appealing, though huge may not be the right word since portions were sensibly sized. Appetizers should be smallish, a mere tweak of the taste buds (though it would also be appropriate to have lower prices, to match the smaller portions). Duck foie gras (barely cooked, tremblingly soft) was nonpareil, adorned with lentil salad, onion, arugula and other lightly dressed greens. Almost as enchanting was a savory tart (with excellent thin crust) layered with wild mushrooms and rampions in a luscious Gruyere cream sauce. We used a slice of very good crusty sourdough bread to retrieve the last bit of sauce. The bread also came in handy with the remains of a delicious basil-pesto cream sauce that enveloped chicken mousse-filled raviolini.

title: Choose One Memory to Take With You, He Asks
description: THE afterlife. Today it rivals Vancouver as one of the most popular movie locations. Ever since Ernst Lubitsch sent a departed mortal hurtling back to earth in ''Heaven Can Wait,'' heaven itself has been fascinating Hollywood. When Wim Wenders sent his angels earthward in ''Wings of Desire,'' a trend was reborn. What with John Travolta, Robin Williams and Brad Pitt all going celestial, heaven has never been more hip. Heaven help future historians tempted to interpret this era's spiritual proclivities from a close reading of recent movies. Luckily, they -- and we -- now have some help from the Japanese director Hirokazu Kore-eda. His new film, ''After Life'' (at the Film Forum) redefines our notions of what comes next in a charming fable that's as profound as it is simple.

title: Corporate Park's Bucolic Appeal Is Lost in Traffic
description: Years ago, the office talk at Glaxo Wellcome's United States headquarters here was primarily the weather or the ease with which Duke's basketball team had just clobbered an opponent.

title: Individuality That Comes in Twos and Threes
description: Giglio Dante

title: Robeson's Journey
description: ''Paul Robeson: Artist and Citizen,'' a multi-media exhibition, is following a path not unlike the life of the celebrated actor, musician, athlete, lawyer, civil rights advocate and champion of left-wing causes. Having started out at the Zimmerli Art Museum at Rutgers University (Robeson's alma mater) last year for his centenary, it has since traveled and has now reached its last stop, New York City, where Robeson spent the last years of his life.

title: As Handover Nears, Panama's Class of '99 Ushers Out an Era
description: After Balboa High School seniors walk across the bright green grass and out into their futures this weekend, it will be more than just the class of '99 that will be gone. It will be a way of life.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBERTS, RALPH
description: ROBERTS-Ralph, age 82, died peacefully on April 30, in Salisbury, N.C. Our deepest sympathy to his sister, Mabel Hoffner, and his nephew and niece, Hap and Annette. Ralph served in World War II and the Korean War and retired as Lieutenant Colonel in the U.S. Army Reserve. His acting career, which spanned 50 years, included theater, movies and television. We shall deeply miss him and carry loving memories of the role he played in our lives. To celebrate his life, contributions can be sent to the Ralph Roberts Endowment of the Rowan Public Library, 201 West Fisher St., Salisbury, NC 28144, or to the Actors Fund. Betty Comden and Adolf Green Phyllis Newman Zoe Caldwell and Robert Whitehead Maureen Stapleton Ellen Burstyn Doris Blum Valerie Unger Joyce Lowinson

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOWNLEY, RALPH
description: TOWNLEY-Ralph. Age 75. Died May 13, 1999. Formerly of East 23rd Street, New York City. Residence: 51 Main Street, Marion, MA 02738. Husband of Phyllis (Leonard) Townley, father of Miranda T. Christoffersen and Christopher H. Townley. Memorial service June 12, 2 PM, in the Friends Meeting House, Mattapoisett, MA.

title: From Addict To Educator In Harlem
description: BLOSSOM MARTIN was once bound for college and career. But by 1991, she said, she had become so consumed by alcohol and drugs that she lost her job, was evicted from her apartment and landed on welfare. And her two children had been living in foster care.

title: One Way to Get Taller In a City of Giants
description: HERE'S a design that turns the wheel: a plan for a new addition to an old office building at 350 Madison Avenue, on the corner of 45th Street. Preservationists might call this elegant metal and glass design ''inappropriate'' to its midtown context. If so, that would not be the least of its attractions. It's time to admit how bankrupt the idea of appropriateness has become as a measure of architectural value. This bold design treats the addition to the tall building as a virtually new building type.

title: Outdoor Seats Outrage Some On Nassau St.
description: It seems like a small thing: a couple of outdoor tables where restaurant patrons can enjoy their lunch on bright spring days. But the residents of one downtown building don't see it that way, and their protests last week had officials of the Alliance for Downtown New York, lower Manhattan's business improvement district, paying attention.

title: From Dumping Ground to Destination?; Staten Island Makes a Bid to Shed Its Outcast Image
description: IN a photo promoting a recent television movie, Mike Logan, a police officer, glowers on the upper deck of the Staten Island ferry, Manhattan behind him. Logan's punishment for punching a politician was reassignment to New York City's southernmost and least dramatic borough. His hope is that if he can navigate the underworld links and possible police corruption involved in a local murder and solve the case, he can get back to Manhattan. He is, as the title of the movie proclaims, ''Exiled.''

title: Jenny Libien, Richard Goodwin
description: Jenny Melissa Libien and Richard Thomas Goodwin are to be married today at the Hermitage, a historic house in Ho-Ho-Kus, N.J. Rabbi Charles Lippman is to perform the ceremony, in which the Rev. Edgar Davey, a minister of the United Church of Canada, will take part.

title: A Man Who Traded Everything for an Indian Trove
description: AT 15, Frank T. Siebert Jr. became so frustrated at not finding the books he wanted to read on American Indians and the Western frontier in school or at the public libraries in Philadelphia that he began collecting. His first purchase, a 1904 reprint of John Eliot's ''Logick Primer,'' from 1672, cost 28 cents. Over the next 70 years, he became a pathologist, sold his blood to buy books, got married, then left his wife and children and lived for a while in his car. He sometimes paid dearly for the works he relentlessly tracked.

title: At the Field Museum, A Worm's-Eye View
description: The Field Museum in Chicago has just completed a 15,000-square-foot permanent exhibition that will, through the illusory magic of a curator's wand, shrink visitors to one-hundredth of their normal size and set them loose in a subterranean wonderland.

title: Under Chile's Volcanoes, A Blurring of Boundaries
description: IT used to be easy to draw a political map of Chile and readily identify the friends and foes of American corporations: When President Salvador Allende seized copper mines from Kennecott and Anaconda, the Nixon Administration worked to undermine him. After he was overthrown in 1973 by Gen. Augusto Pinochet, the latter's free-market policies became the toast of Wall Street.

title: Wendy DeMarco, Lazaro Fuentes
description: Wendy DeMarco and Lazaro Gonzalo Fuentes were married last evening at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York. The Rev. Walter F. Modrys performed the ceremony.

title: Safety Concerns Slow Tourism to Turkey
description: TWO contrasting sets of images are driving Turkish hotel managers and tourism planners to distraction.

title: Omaha
description: When the first tentative green digits of daffodils poke through the wan prairie turf in Omaha, it doesn't necessarily guarantee spring, an iffy and tempestuous season on the plains. But it does mean that in a few weeks, without fail, dozens of strapping young men in baseball uniforms and their fans and families of varying girth, adornment and dishabille will descend on our city for the College World Series. We can't wait.

title: First Kosovo. Then Russia. Now China.
description: Last week, President Clinton attempted a comprehensive defense of his Kosovo policy. Heavy on Balkan history and light on serious analysis, it did little to remove the sense that we are experiencing a foreign policy debacle, one in which bombs are serving as substitutes for thought.

title: Trying to Sort Out Legalities of Megan's Law
description: MORE than two years after New York enacted the Sex Offender Registration Act of 1996, commonly known as Megan's Law, Laura Ahearn of Stony Brook, a certified social worker and mother of two daughters, discovered that the Suffolk County Police Department had stopped enforcing it.

title: DATABANK: May 10-14; Ending Up With the Wrong Kind of Bang
description: Oh, those unforgiving Fridays. Investors ended the third week in a row pummeling the Dow Jones industrial average, pulling the sell trigger because of fears of inflation.

title: Despite Nasty Election, Weary Israel Seeks Unity
description: During a bitter, protracted election campaign, Israelis have grown weary of the way the candidates advocate unity, yet aggravate the many divides in this small, complex society.

title: Country Music Served Beyond the Skyline
description: ITS headquarters are in relatively bucolic Hawthorne, N.Y., and its revenues are still pint-sized, adding up to just $14.2 million in 1998. Still, Big City Radio Inc. has already managed to live up to both its far-reaching name, as well as the collection of skyscrapers in its logo.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREIDET, IRWIN (GURKEWITZ)
description: FREIDET-Irwin (Gurkewitz). 62, on May 13 in Sidney, Ohio, formerly of New York City. Son of the late Dora and Sam; brother of Rita Star; husband of Joan; father of Glenn, Hal, Zoe, Adela, Sam and Sarah. Service Sunday at Cromes Funeral Home, Sidney, Ohio.

title: Chinese Intellectuals in U.S. Say Spying Case Unfairly Casts Doubt on Their Loyalties
description: Many Chinese and Chinese-American scientists and engineers in the United States fear they are being tarnished and their careers threatened by accusations that another scientist, Wen Ho Lee, stole the design of America's most advanced nuclear warhead and gave it to China.

title: Tanned for Summer
description: Once, patent leather was for spring, suede for fall, white for summer and cashmere for winter, but such seasonal fashion dictates have become passe. Even pony skin, as people call calfskin with short smooth fur, has made the transition from cold weather to warm -- in bright colors and animal prints. ''We were nervous about pony skin selling in the spring, but we've had to reorder them twice,'' said Jack Cohen, merchandising director at Fendi, which has a pony skin jacket (above) in a white-and-black cow print with sterling silver buttons for $3,500. Bergdorf Goodman has Lambertson Truex's boxcar totes (above), $680 to $850, and Vicini's Sabrina mules in fuchsia and zebra print, $220. Barneys New York sells pony-lined flip-flops by Freelance (above) for $190. But can pony skin travel in the heat? Sure, says Beth Shepard, an owner of Kirna Zabete, a boutique opening in Soho in July, who wears aqua clogs by Marni, $290, at Barneys and Bergdorf's. ''It's great for summer because it's bright,'' she said. ''Also, there's a peep hole where my hot pink toenails can stick out, and it keeps my feet cool.'' ELIZABETH HAYT

title: Bush Is Hardly a Passive Fund-Raiser
description: On the frontiers of Presidential fund-raising, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas has shattered previous Republican records by quickly raising $13 million with help from ''the Pioneers.''

title: Clinton Urges Film Industry to Limit Violence on Screen
description: President Clinton today urged the entertainment industry to voluntarily limit the glorification of guns in movie advertisements and previews and to consider whether movies rated PG-13 contain excessive and gratuitous violence.

title: Pay Raises for Police? Where's the Money?
description: The police officers of Nassau County do not deserve a pay raise, nor is it in the county's best interest at this time.

title: A Social Glacier Roars
description: A century ago, people who looked ahead to 2000 had an exaggerated faith in the promise of pneumatic tubes. For some reason, when people then thought long-term, they saw everything from business correspondence to ready-cooked meals whizzing across town through underground pipes. Nobody imagined computers. Funny, the things we can't anticipate. When I was researching a book on the millennium a few years ago, I was struck by how people's predictions about the future say much more about the predictors' own era than about what will happen next.

title: Embassy Blast Churns Political Tea Leaves
description: Why did Zhu Rongji, China's popular Prime Minister, cry on TV?

title: Mexican Kitchen Pays Price for Popularity
description: PALOMAS RESTAURANT in Water Mill is a culinary double play. In an area with few Mexican spots and even fewer inexpensive restaurants, it is both. Because it opened late after the season last year, Palomas in the Water Mill Shoppes, 76 Montauk Highway (726-7007), might easily be overlooked by East End visitors this summer. That would be a shame since it has much to recommend it.

title: May 9-15; A Fundraiser's Story About Chinese Money
description: In his first public account of life as a globe-trotting Democratic fund-raiser, the California businessman Johnny Chung told a House panel how a top Chinese intelligence official wired him $300,000 for President Clinton's 1996 re-election. At a Hong Kong abalone restaurant, the intelligence official, Gen. Ji Shengde, spoke of the President to Mr. Chung: ''We hope to see him re-elected. I will give you 300,000 U.S. dollars. You can give it to the President and the Democratic Party.''

title: South Seas Gulag
description: The Mute's Soliloquy

title: S.A.S.E.
description: 30 Pieces of a Novel. By Stephen Dixon. 672 pp. New York: Henry Holt & Company. $30.

title: Out of Darkness
description: CITY OF LIGHT

title: Q & A/Dr. Sally Morgan Reis; Helping Smart Girls In Indifferent World
description: AFTER 20 years of research on talented girls and women, Dr. Sally Morgan Reis, poses the question, ''In 1999, if you have a young girl growing up with a tremendous potential in science, math, engineering or even literature, an area where girls are supposed to succeed, will they able to have the same single-minded devotion to their work as a young boy?'' Her response: ''No.''

title: May 9-15; A $60.5 Million Still Life
description: Things got so giddy at Sotheby's that you might have thought they were selling Internet stocks at half-price. But no: the contest was to pick the Impressionist Painting of the Moment. And when the anonymous, disembodied telephone bidders had spoken, the winner was ''Still Life With Curtain, Pitcher and Bowl of Fruit,'' going for a staggering $60.5 million, a Cezanne record. It was part of a collection left by Betsey Cushing Roosevelt Whitney to her daughters, who, like other mortals, had tax bills to pay. HUBERT B. HERRING

title: Earnings Revived
description: Reversing a downward trend in earnings, Reader's Digest Association in Chappaqua reported a 71 percent increase in third-quarter earnings as a result of cost cutting to offset lower sales.

title: May 9-15; Marine Pilot Sentenced In Ski Gondola Case
description: The Marine Corps pilot acquitted of manslaughter in the Italian ski gondola accident that killed 20 people was sentenced to six months in prison and dismissed from the corps for helping to destroy a videotape of the flight in which his jet sliced the gondola's cable.

title: Cautionary Tales of Wisdom in Ferocious Forms
description: FROM a nose-length away, Robert Thurman is scrutinizing the three glaring bull's-eyes and two fire-spouting horns of a fierce Tibetan deity. A row of skulls parades across the creature's blue-black head. Roaring red flames wreathe its body. But Mr. Thurman points to a peaceful face on the creature's headdress: Manjushri, representing sublime cosmic wisdom.

title: Prime Riverside Site Is Still Up for Grabs
description: THE scenic bend in the Thames River, where the Norwich State Hospital was established in 1905, has long been a strategic, defining place in southeastern Connecticut.

title: KOSOVO UPDATE
description: COMBAT

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISCHER, LESTER
description: FISCHER-Lester, November 11,1911-April 27,1999 The ''Iron Man of Football,1937 '', after a lengthy illness. Survived by his wife Sylvia, his daughter Mary Lynn and his son-in-law Whitfield Diffie.

title: Sheila Morrissey, Murray Stoltz
description: Sheila Joan Morrissey, a daughter of Emelda Henry Morrissey of Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., and Dr. Michael F. Morrissey of Southampton, N.Y., was married last evening to Murray Craig Stoltz, the son of Barbara A. Stoltz of Sacramento, Calif., and Morgan S. Stoltz of Auburn, Calif. Canon Petero A. N. Sabune performed the ceremony at St. James' Episcopal Church in New York.

title: Goats in Trial as Urban Weed Killers
description: A sign in a city park here says it all: ''Goats at Work.''

title: Habitats /Greenwich, Conn.; Underground Movies -- At Home, With Popcorn
description: IT'S too bad that Charles S. Cohen has to go to work. Or anywhere, for that matter. Because underneath his 16-room mansion in Greenwich, Conn., he has built a movie theater so evocative of the past, with its plush red velvet seats and ornate moldings, that emerging into the daylight, even on a spectacular spring day, is annoying. Who wants to go out into the real world when the fantasy has been so perfectly realized?

title: Rosemary Valaire, 68, Ballet Teacher and Director
description: Rosemary Valaire, a ballet teacher and a director of the Westside Ballet of Santa Monica, Calif., and a former dancer with the Royal Ballet of England, died on May 7 at her home in Los Angeles. She was 68.

title: Wings Hoping Osgood Is Stopper
description: Before Chris Osgood and the Red Wings flew to Denver for today's playoff game, the injured goalie practiced with his troubled team in Detroit, genuflecting repeatedly on his tender right knee like a reverent man in church. Up and down went Osgood, bouncing the padded knee off the ice, flexing it as he kicked at pucks.

title: Improvised Images in Molten Wax, as Fluid as Jazz
description: LEAVE it to modern artists to find intriguing beauty -- and expressive power -- in the gooey textures of waxy buildup. New materials and techniques have always attracted the avant-garde, but paradoxically, during certain periods in the 20th century, an ancient method of image making seized the imagination of many experimental artists. The results of some of those experiments are on view from Sunday through Aug. 15 at the Montclair Art Museum in Montclair, N.J., where ''Waxing Poetic: Encaustic Art in America'' examines its theme in more than 70 works by modern and contemporary artists, including Arthur Dove, Jasper Johns, Lynda Benglis and Michelle Stuart.

title: He Is The Egg Man
description: High in cholesterol, calories and the guilt it induces, eggs Benedict is still a ubiquitous dish on city menus, one that defines brunch itself. But have you ever wondered about what's in those eggs Benedict you scarfed down on Sunday? Or how they stack up against those served in other New York restaurants? If so, then hasten to Eggs Benedict New York, a Web site maintained by Josh Karpf, a 32-year-old copy editor for a medical and biological Web site.

title: Corrections
description: The Streetscapes column on May 2, about the West End Collegiate Church, misidentified the supervisor of the current roof repair. He is William Stivale. (The LZA Group is the structural engineer.)

title: First Person Female
description: Why did I think I might be able to write in the voice of a woman? Anyone who knows a novelist or poet very well has probably figured out that they are not dealing with a true intellectual. Intellectuals have a compulsion to be right and this urge is inimical to what John Keats called ''negative capability,'' the capacity a poem or novel must have to keep afloat a thousand contradictory people and questions in order to create the parallel universe of art. Rationality, to borrow from Foucault, may be an inferior level of discourse. This is a very high-minded thing for me to say, keeping in view the recent moment when my wonderful mother, who is 84 and of 100 percent Swedish derivation, said, ''You've made quite a living out of your fibs.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVAVY, BERENICE B.
description: LEVAVY-Berenice B. On May 14, 1999. For over 63 years she and her husband Zvi, who survives her, set standards of marital harmony and compatability. Devoted sister of the late Gladys Bardin, beloved mother of Bardin (and Sue-Ellen), adoring grandmother of Raphael and Sara Beth. She was a community leader of Perth Amboy, NJ for over half a century, and both teacher and student throughout her life. Loved, respected-and now missed-by all who knew her. Services Monday, Flynn & Son Funeral Home, Perth Amboy, NJ.

title: Status as First Lady Also Carries Pitfalls
description: As Hillary Rodham Clinton's advisers contemplate the possibility of a sitting First Lady running for office, they are beginning to realize that there are pitfalls as well as advantages inherent in Mrs. Clinton's status, from the daily encumbrances of her security to the conflicts with her duties as First Lady.

title: Futurama
description: TURN OF THE CENTURY By Kurt Andersen. 659 pp. New York: Random House. $24.95.

title: MUSIC; Transmuting Whitman Into Music
description: IT was in Germany that I learned to love Laurie Anderson. Like many Americans of an esthetic bent, in my youth I had regarded as suspect products of my own culture, including such sophisticated hybrids as the music of Ms. Anderson or the films of Woody Allen or even Cole Porter's ''High Society.'' Yet I found that what I viewed as middlebrow culture, my European friends experienced as fresh air blowing through centuries of stale history. ''Sparky's Day'' was not just a supermarket daydream; it was a modern-day vision of Nietzschean transcendence. Heard through this filter, the song ''sounded'' for the first time.

title: Flipping Burgers
description: No Shame

title: Are Lawyers Truly Evil, or Just Doing the Job?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Voice Of Caution In a Chorus Of Gamblers
description: WHEN Robert E. Rubin went to Washington in 1993 as chairman of President Clinton's National Economic Council, the Dow Jones industrial average was under 4,000, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index was trading at less than 500 and the Federal budget was $255 billion in the red.

title: You Had to Be There
description: Fresh from the runway of history, the actress Salma Hayek is the height of fashion.

title: Ancient Rite, Modern Means
description: The ''to do'' lists the Stulbergs drew up for their youngest son's bar mitzvah included a mixture of items, from standard and stressful to extraordinary and complex.

title: C. Earl Leslie, 91, Dies; Hand-Lettering Artist for Presidents
description: C. Earl Leslie, a retired White House artist whose decorative lettering embellished thousands of Government documents and proclamations issued by Presidents from Franklin D. Roosevelt to Dwight D. Eisenhower, died on May 6 at Washington House, a retirement home in Alexandria, Va. He was 91.

title: Among a Smart Set, More Bad Manners
description: HOW to celebrate the Noel Coward centenary? Not, alas, with a by-the-numbers production of ''Hay Fever'' (1925) by Stan Wojewodski Jr., at the Yale Repertory in New Haven.

title: For the Finale, Riley and the Heat Focusing on Defense
description: Atop Pat Riley's list of priorities when his Miami Heat players gathered today was more talk about defense. The Heat coach said it was telltale that Miami lost both games against the Knicks when it allowed 90-plus points, and won both when it held the Knicks below 80.

title: 50's Apple Pie and Fries, But the Music Sounds Funny
description: Serving frills with the fries, Johnny Rockets, the 50's-style diner franchise, made its New York City debut last month at 42 East Eighth Street (at Greene Street).

title: Tables, Yes. But Don't Give Walkers Crumbs, Board Says.
description: The owners of Deluxe, a small restaurant under construction on Broadway near 113th Street, recently applied to extend a cafe 10 1/2 feet onto the sidewalk for the summer. But the response from Community Board 9 went well beyond 113th Street.

title: Borrowed Lives
description: A PRIVATE LIFE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARTIN, CHARLES
description: MARTIN-Charles. Temple Israel, Lawrence, NY, mourns the loss of Charles Martin, beloved husband of Florence, loving father of our members Leslie and Irene Martin and Marilyn Martin, and grandfather of Andrew, Meredith and Samantha. We extend our deepest sympathy to the family. Brooks R. Susman, Rabbi David M. Land, President

title: Spring Children's Books; Hue and Cry
description: THE STORY

title: Egypt: The Convoy Route
description: WHILE I wasn't obsessed with security on my first visit to Egypt in late February and early March, I certainly had it in mind. And I wondered to what degree tourism had recovered from its near-collapse after the tragic massacre of 58 tourists by Islamic militants at the temple of Hatshepsut near Luxor in November 1997.

title: Robeson's Life and Struggle
description: NEW YORK CITY was a springboard for the career of Paul Robeson, the actor, singer and political activist, who sought to transform the representation of blacks in film and theater. In ''Paul Robeson: Artist and Citizen,'' a traveling exhibition from the Paul Robeson Cultural Center at Rutgers University, more than 170 items, including photographs and historical artifacts, depict Robeson's art, life and struggle. It appears at the Museum of the City of New York through Sept. 5.

title: Not Your Average Boys' Concert
description: Here's a howdy-do: the Newark Boys Chorus is singing an oratorio of medieval poems full of sex and booze. No women in the chorus, no chaperone. Sold out, too. Who thought this one up?

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BAY RDGE; Leaving a Marzipan Void
description: Six weeks after the death of her husband, Walter, Tordis Olga Jensen is still getting calls from people who want him to bake his Scandinavian cakes and Danish pastry for their weddings and confirmations.

title: Word for Word/Civil War Lit; Mine Eyes Have Seen the Coming Of a Lot of Wacky Stuff
description: GERTRUDE STEIN put it best: ''There never will be anything more interesting in America than that Civil War never.''

title: In the Region /Long Island; In Jericho, a Developer Is Buying a Rural Legacy
description: TIME is soon to catch up to a 19th-century farmhouse, several barns, and the nine acres of fields and paddocks surrounding them that have survived as a rural oasis on busy Jericho Turnpike just east of the Route 107 cloverleaf. They have been owned by members of one of Long Island's older families, the Underhills, for almost 130 years.

title: Spring Children's Books; Those Weren't the Days
description: The Way Things

title: One Never Knows
description: To the Editor:

title: Not the First Freight Train He's Hopped
description: Rob Lowe is a train freak. He said his fascination with trains was ''sort of in my genes.'' Several generations of men in his family worked on the old Nickel Plate Railroad in Indiana (the last rail line, he noted, ''to give up steam''). As a child he often tagged along with his uncle, a conductor, on his runs throughout the Midwest. About five years ago, while he was working on a screenplay titled ''Union Pacific,'' he and a friend, the actor Christian Slater, hopped a freight train in San Luis Obispo, Calif., and rode the 100 miles down to Los Angeles. Reminded that hitching rides on trains is dangerous, if not illegal, Mr. Lowe, 35, said: ''It's risky. That's part of the adventure of it.''

title: At Ivy Club, A Trip Back to Elitism
description: SHOULD the members of the Ivy Club ever face the withering scrutiny of a Fifth Avenue co-op board or a Fairfield County country club, they will be well prepared.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''It has not been a time of healing, that's for sure.''

title: Signs in Russian Give Other-Worldly Feeling
description: To the Editor:

title: Hotels Larger Than Life
description: THOSE glorious words ''grand hotel'' call to mind another era, more gracious and less hurried than our own, and surroundings, constructed at least decades ago, of heroic scale and a certain sumptuousness. The lobby should be enormous and shamelessly decorative, with crystal chandeliers suspended from an impossibly high ceiling and plenty of fat sofas for watching a parade of visitors from around the world. The surfaces that aren't gilded are covered with marble or carved wood. Rooms are spacious, reminiscent of a time when people chose to live in hotels. And the uniformed staff, never far from sight, can produce a heavy silver pot of coffee or a full-dress dinner in a twinkling.

title: Bookend; Curiouser and Curiouser
description: Pop quiz: How many Curious George books are there? How does the book ''Go, Dog. Go!'' go? Granted, these are not monumentally important questions. Still, as a former bookworm and a book-buying parent, I thought I knew the answers. But in this era of brand extension and exploitation of deceased authors (everyone from Ernest Hemingway to Margaret Mitchell), the children's bookshelves are getting crowded with knockoffs, making it difficult to judge classics by their covers.

title: 'When I Was Little, In 1995'
description: About 45 generations have passed during the last thousand years, generations in which a once profoundly unbalanced relationship between males and females has gradually shifted. But how far, exactly? Perhaps the best way to measure the change is to consult with Generation 46 -- girls and boys who are just becoming aware of the world beyond their playgrounds. The following selections from conversations with a variety of New York schoolchildren suggest that tomorrow's adults expect to live in a time when the playing field between the sexes will be very nearly level, but it is a triumph they know will not come easy.

title: The Nanny State Is Stifling Future Einsteins
description: To the Editor:

title: Big Blue, a Cup of Joe And a Little Perspective
description: EVERYBODY snickered last July when the Zapata Corporation, an obscure over-the-counter purveyor of fish byproducts, said that it was morphing into an Internet company. But when its stock more than doubled on the news, the snickerers went silent. If the gambit could propel shares of an unknown like Zapata, why not those of more established companies?

title: Brooklyn Rabbi Charged With Witness Tampering
description: A prominent Hasidic rabbi in Brooklyn has been accused of making death threats against a woman scheduled to testify against her father on rape charges, law enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENBOW, TERENCE H.
description: BENBOW-Terence H. The Board and staff of the New York Landmarks Conservancy mourn the death of our former Chairman. He was a dedicated preservationist and admired personally and professionally. Stuart Siegel, Chairman Peg Breen, President

title: Corrections
description: A review last Sunday about the Iron Monkey Restaurant in Jersey City omitted a byline. The reviewer was Catherine Jones.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BROCKMEIER, WILLIAM
description: BROCKMEIER-William, retired art director of Eastman Kodak and past-president of the Art Directors Club, on Thursday, May 20, 1999 at 6PM at the ADC Gallery, 250 Park Ave. So. at 20th St., NYC.

title: Hawthorne-Based Radio Covers a Broad Area
description: ITS headquarters are in Hawthorne, and its revenues are still pint size, adding up to just $14.2 million last year. Still, Big City Radio has already managed to live up to its far-reaching name and the collection of skyscrapers in its logo.

title: Sag Harbor Scraps Disputed Traffic Circle
description: The Sag Harbor Village Board has voted to eliminate a traffic circle on the main road into town that has caused an uproar in the community of 2,100 since its installation last October.

title: Group Seeks to Bridge Police-Community Gap
description: A GROUP organized under the aegis of the Westchester Coalition Against Bigotry wants to bridge what it calls the trust gap between the police and the community.

title: Are Lawyers Truly Evil, or Just Doing the Job?; Loser Shouldn't Pay
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEINBERG, SAUL
description: STEINBERG-Saul. The American Institute of Graphic Arts will always celebrate the extraordinary creativity and humor with which Saul Steinberg entertained and intrigued the American public. His contributions were timeless, yet graphic designers nationwide will mourn the loss of this AIGA Gold Medalist of 1963. Michael Bierut, President Richard Grefe, Executive Director On behalf of the Board of Directors and 14,000 graphic designers.

title: Success and Error
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from the most recent listing to contract.

title: My Lunch With Andre (And Wally)
description: ''MY DINNER WITH ANDRE,'' directed by Louis Malle, was a surprise success in 1981 and quickly became a cult movie favorite: a virtuosic colloquy between two old friends whose wide disparities were philosophical as well as personal.

title: Elizabeth Kuhns, Douglas Cotler
description: Elizabeth Linden Kuhns, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael L. Kuhns of Morristown, N.J., was married last evening to Dr. Douglas Ian Cotler, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Cotler of Elkins Park, Pa. Rabbi Sol Goodman officiated at Oceancliff, a condominium resort in Newport, R.I. Msgr. John Corr took part in the ceremony.

title: Marci Ende, Jonathan Seidman
description: Marci Ellen Ende, the daughter of Betty and Barry Ende of West Orange, N.J., was married there last evening to Jonathan Marc Seidman, the son of Marjorie E. Zeiger of Manhattan and Stephen R. Seidman of Fort Lee, N.J. Rabbi Barry R. Friedman officiated at the Crestmont Country Club.

title: Regulating Religious Life In the Office
description: ''IF you've studied history, religious wars are the longest, nastiest and bloodiest.''

title: Let's Make A Deal
description: WHEN state officials hired Anthony R. Coscia, a 29-year-old lawyer who had never been to Trenton, to run the State Economic Development Authority in 1991, they did not have much to lose.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUNT, REGINALD SAYRE
description: HUNT-Reginald Sayre. On May 12, 1999. Beloved son of the late John T. and Madeleine Hunt; brother of the late Bella Hunt. Retired executive of IBM and Ceridian Corp. Dear friend and valued member of Friendly Sons of St. Patrick and Knights of Columbus. A man who overcame so many obstacles and was an inspiration to all who knew him. Reposing at the Gannon Funeral Home, 152 East 28 St, NYC on Monday 7-9 and Tuesday 2-5 and 7-9PM. A mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated on Wednesday at 10AM, Our Lady of the Scapular and St. Stephens Church. Interment is in Calvary Cemetery.

title: DRIVE TO IMPEACH RUSSIAN PRESIDENT DIES IN PARLIAMENT
description: With a flood of venomous oratory, the Communist-led drive to impeach President Boris N. Yeltsin failed in Russia's Parliament today as nearly 100 members of the legislature unexpectedly stayed away from the session, and some ballots were thrown out because they carried no names or were defaced.

title: G.O.P. Publisher Who Insults His Own
description: BY party affiliation he is a Republican and he comes from an influential Yonkers Republican family, but this has not stopped Ralph R. Martinelli, the publisher of eight weekly newspapers in Westchester, from attacking some top Republican officials.

title: Uncertain Future for a Nuclear Plant Short on Space to Store Waste
description: All the fuel that the Indian Point 2 nuclear reactor has ever used since its first chain reaction 26 years ago is here at the bottom of a 40-foot-deep pool about the size of a basketball court.

title: In America; Haunted by Segregation
description: I was ushered into the modest office of C. Penn Owen Jr., the most powerful plantation owner and all-around operator in this rural county in northern Mississippi.

title: COLLEGE LACROSSE
description: DIVISION I MEN

title: As Far as Water Goes, In Yonkers, It's H2 Oh!
description: THESE days, Mayor John D. Spencer of Yonkers is a happy man. His city's water scored tops for taste and quality among entrants throughout Westchester in a recent water tasting contest.

title: Corrections
description: An article on May 2 about the choreographer John Jasperse misidentified the set designer for his new work, ''Madison as I Imagine It.'' He is Scott Pask, not Mr. Jasperse.

title: Kim Freehill, Nari Narayanan
description: Constance Therese Freehill and Singanallur Narayanan were married yesterday afternoon in New York by the Rev. Francis Boyle at Our Lady of Good Council Roman Catholic Church.

title: The Truth Is Down There
description: SPINNERS

title: Deborah Herfort, Vance Tiede
description: Deborah Scudder Herfort and Vance Russell Tiede were married yesterday morning by the Rev. John H. Branson at Christ and Holy Trinity Episcopal Church in Westport, Conn.

title: Lesley Bartlett, John Osborn
description: Lesley Jenckes Bartlett, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John F. Bartlett of Darien, Conn., was married yesterday to John Barbour Osborn, the son of Katherine Page Osborn of Boston. The Rev. Alan G. Dennis performed the Episcopal ceremony at St. Luke's Parish in Darien.

title: Back and Forth
description: The theatrical co-dependence is spreading: New York is getting two more new plays from New Jersey.

title: Two Paths, Intellectual And Earthy
description: THE two operas are closely linked: ''Wozzeck,'' a devastating success; ''Moses und Aron,'' a failure of epic stature. The pupil, Alban Berg, wrote the first; the teacher, Arnold Schoenberg, the second. Perhaps no opera since Mozart feels as complete as ''Wozzeck.'' ''Moses und Aron'' lies unfinished, although its first two acts were written some 20 years before the composer's death in 1951. The words for a third act awaited only the music for them.

title: The Benefits of Investing Just a Little at a Time
description: To the Editor:

title: Two Artists Sure Enough to Take Chances
description: A CONSUMMATE realist exhibiting in the same large room with an abstract painter who invests his forms with emotion would normally be considered a classic mismatch. But Gregory Gillespie and Bill Jensen are showing works together at the Joseloff Gallery, at the University of Hartford, in West Hartford, for reasons having nothing to do with painting. Both men were awarded the Richard Koopman distinguished chair in the visual arts, an honor that includes being a visiting professor at the university as well as having works in this exhibition.

title: Tavel, South Fork Style
description: In America, crowd-pleasing off-dry white zinfandels like Sutter Home's version shape the popular notion of rose. But Roman Roth's dry 1998 rose yields not a millimeter -- or milliliter -- to this California starlet.

title: Sarazen's Century of Perspective
description: ON the day Gene Sarazen died, Tiger Woods shot 61 in the GTE Byron Nelson Classic. To anyone who remembered a conversation at the 1996 Masters, it was as much a connection as a coincidence.

title: Rejuvenated Maple Leafs Defeat Penguins
description: The Maple Leafs missed the playoffs in 1998 and 1997, and coming into this year had not won a post-season series since 1994. But now they are one victory away from the Eastern Conference finals after a 4-1 victory over the Pittsburgh Penguins tonight in the Air Canada Center in the second round of the Stanley Cup tournament.

title: May 9-15; Airline Accused Of Predatory Pricing
description: American Airlines became the latest target of antitrust prosecutors in Washington.

title: Younger Than Ever -- And Freer.
description: On the border between youth and middle age, 35 stands like a sentinel. Growing older can no longer be denied: drugstores offer antiwrinkle potions, radio stations pitch mellow music and the American Breast Cancer Foundation recommends the first mammogram. Even so, 35 today is younger than ever. A thousand years ago, a 35-year-old woman would be just shy of menopause and only 20 or so years from death. Now, 35 is not even halfway there; years of fertility remain, and the highest-earning period probably lies ahead.

title: Marvin S. Winter, 78, Manhattan Developer
description: Marvin S. Winter, a Manhattan real estate developer for more than 50 years, died on Friday at New York University Hospital in Manhattan. He was 78 and had homes in Manhattan and Delray Beach, Fla.

title: Corrections
description: A theater listing in the Summer Festivals section last Sunday misidentified a festival in New Mexico and misstated the telephone number for the program listed. The program is that of Santa Fe Stages, not Shakespeare in Santa Fe, and the number is (505) 982-6683.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: Everybody Was So Young:

title: The Tax Rebate Line and Other Annoyances
description: EVER since receiving our New Jersey Saver Rebate Claim Packet in the mail, we have begun to see illogic everywhere.

title: Applauding the Art, or Maybe the Money
description: To the Editor:

title: Upstart Teams Showing No Respect for Their Elders
description: Allen Iverson scooted past Anfernee Hardaway in Orlando. Jason Williams and Chris Webber didn't respect their Utah elders. And a team that relies heavily on Isaiah Rider cruised into the second round.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: The Girl Who Loved Tom Gordon

title: Light Treatment
description: To the Editor:

title: Where the Chic Meet the Hip
description: To a product line that includes Givenchy couture, Louis Vuitton luggage and Dom Perignon Champagne, add Trailer Trash and Jail Bait nail polishes (in silver or pink-and-white swirl). Such are the brands LVMH Moet Hennessy picked up last week with its purchase of 75 percent of Hard Candy, a Los Angeles cosmetics company founded just four years ago by Dineh Mohajer and Benjamin Einstein, then both 22.

title: Camden's Mayor Retains Supporters in City Council
description: In what is regarded as a show of support for Mayor Milton Milan, Camden city voters on Tuesday elected three of four city council candidates endorsed by the Democratic mayor.

title: In Bangkok, Royal Treatment at Commoner Prices
description: ''BANGKOK. Fantastic! I've heard you can find a room there for as little as $6 a night,'' said the tiny voice inside my head (the voice of the good frugal traveler). A devilishly seductive baritone cut in: ''Hey, when are you going to tell that accountant to scram? You've been listening to him for six weeks and you haven't touched a soft white sheet since Cairo. Besides, honey, have you looked at your nails lately?''

title: Leiter's Night Can't Spoil Mets' Evening
description: The cat that scampered all the way from right field into the Mets' dugout during the third inning tonight was not black. But there must have been some kind of witchcraft at work.

title: Springsteen's on a Pedestal. Not His Statue.
description: In Bruce Springsteen's hometown, there is a fire truck with the words ''Born to Run'' painted on the side. The Boss donated the truck to the cash-strapped Borough of Freehold in 1991, in the same spirit that he played a concert two years ago to benefit the parish center affiliated with the St. Rose of Lima School there, his alma mater.

title: Twenty Injured In Riot in Florence
description: At least 20 people were injured, and one was reported in serious condition with stab wounds, following clashes between rival fans at the end of yesterday's Fiorentina-Lazio league game in Florence, police reported.

title: Abby Hirsch and Morris Weinstein
description: I'VE lived a life with the theme 'better hand to mouth than 9 to 5,' '' said Abby Quinn Hirsch, who is in her 50's and will say no more.

title: A Knockout Allergy Season; Pollen, Everywhere, Is Bringing Sufferers Down for the Count
description: DR. B. ROBERT FELDMAN did not require an official pollen count to confirm that this is a spring equal to few others in his career.

title: Not For The Faint Of Palate
description: MARANA JARAMILLO did not need to fuss with a menu when she sat down for a Mother's Day dinner last Sunday at Salinas, an Ecuadorean restaurant in Park Slope. She knew exactly what she wanted: the papas con cuy, or potatoes with guinea pig.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITHSON, SIMON
description: SMITHSON-Simon, 41. Of New York City. Loving husband of Susan Kang and devoted father of Natalie and Aaron, found peace from cancer on May 10, 1999. Simon graduated from Cambridge University and was a financial analyst for Dresdner, Kleinwort Benson, and Caspian Securities. He had lived and worked in London, Tokyo, Hong Kong and New York, and will be sorely missed by friends all over the world. He had a wide range of deeply held interests about which he was extremely knowledgeable. A lover of music and a voracious reader of modern history, he was also discriminating about food, wine, clothes and Japanese antiques. The most important things in Simon's life were his family, of whom he spoke most proudly, and friends, to whom he was loyal and generous. A memorial service will be held at 1:30PM Sunday, May 16th at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th St., NYC.
