Contributions in his memory may be made to support head and neck cancer research: Columbia University, Dept. of Otolaryngology/Head and Neck Surgery, c/o Lydia Reverton, Administrator; or Dr. Lanny Garth Close, Chairman, 630 West 108th Street, New York, NY 10032.

title: Ideas & Trends: Hey, Nice Headlights; In Detroit, a Sex Change
description: RUN your eyes over the Dodge Durango, one of the newest sport utility vehicles on the road. Muscles seem to ripple under its shiny sheet metal, causing its fenders to bulge. Its hood is lifted above the brawn, like the short neck of a wrestler rising from beefy trapezius muscles. Buyers imagine the Durango whispering huskily that it is strong and dependable. And many of its brother trucks at the forefront of Detroit's design efforts are even burlier.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: THE TRAGIC MENAGERIE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAPECI, THEODORE, J. MD.
description: CAPECI-Theodore, J. MD. The Board of Trustees and Medical Staff of Lenox Hill Hospital were saddened to learn of the recent passing of Theodore J. Capeci, MD, Honorary Physician, who joined our Department of Surgery in 1955 and served as the Chief of Plastic Surgery from 1986 until 1988. Dr. Capeci was highly respected by his peers and patients alike for his outstanding skills as a cosmetic surgeon. A kind and compassionate physician, he was also a devoted and gifted teacher. Lenox Hill Hospital honors the memory of this exceptional physician who exemplified the highest standards of his profession. We extend our deepest sympathies to his family. James S. Marcus, Chairman, Board of Trustees Gladys George, President & CEO Stephen A. Obstbaum, M.D., President, Medical Board Valavanur A. Subramanian, M.D., Director, Surgery

title: Liberties; Bill Says Chill
description: The pressure's on for Al Gore to relax.

title: Odysseus of the Outback
description: FREDY NEPTUNE

title: Comparing Old and New In Electronic Publishing
description: Exercises in valuing Internet-based businesses by traditional means can end in snapped pencils and thrown-up hands. New companies, new business models, no profits, no track record, no equivalent firm for comparison: the litany usually leads back to ''it's worth whatever people will pay for it.''

title: Q&A/Neil Waldman; A Book First Written for Van Gogh
description: IT began for Neil Waldman as a childhood fantasy. When he was 7 and living in the Bronx, he became fascinated with Vincent Van Gogh and he wanted to rescue him from his misery by showing him New York.

title: Defending Don Zimmer
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Spouses Owning A House
description: WHEN a married couple buy a house or apartment, the couple usually take title in the name of both spouses. And since most houses and apartments are purchased with at least some borrowed money, that means that in most cases, both spouses assume equal responsibility for repaying the mortgage.

title: Ian Fraser, British Doctor, 98; Led Wartime Penicillin Tests
description: Sir Ian Fraser, a British surgeon whose medical team took penicillin to the wounded on the battlefields of World War II and established that it effectively checked their blood infections, died Tuesday. He was 98 and lived in Belfast.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCSHERRY, NANCY
description: McSHERRY-Nancy. The entire Beth Israel Medical Center family and its parent company, Continuum Health Partners, Inc., join with the Department of Surgery in acknowledging with great sadness the death of Nancy McSherry, wife of Charles McSherry, M.D., our beloved friend, respected colleague and former Chairman of Surgery. To Dr. McSherry, his family and love ones, we extend our heartfelt condolences. Morton P. Hyman Chairman, Boards of Trustees Continuum and Beth Israel Robert G. Newman, M.D. President and CEO, Continuum Matthew E. Fink, M.D. President and CEO, Beth Israel Moses Nussbaum, M.D. Chairman of Surgery, Beth Israel

title: The State, Quite Contently, Goes Minor League
description: MINOR league baseball, once on the verge of extinction, is booming around the country, and nowhere is its resurgence more evident than in Connecticut.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUDY, STEPHEN J.
description: RUDY-Stephen J. Age 81, a retired patent lawyer, formerly of Greenwich and Manhattan, died May 13, 1999. Funeral services on Monday, 9:30 AM, at Lesko Funeral Home, 1209 Post Rd., Fairfield, CT, and 10 AM in St. Thomas Church. Interment to follow in St. Mary's Cemetery, Yonkers. Calling hours on Sunday, 4-8 PM.

title: Margaret Henry, Bradley Shaw
description: Margaret Barry Henry, a daughter of Justice and Mrs. Patrick Henry of Babylon, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Bradley Charles Shaw, a son of Alan R. Shaw and the late Joan M. Shaw. The Rev. James Kissane performed the ceremony at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church.

title: POSTINGS: 'Family-Sized' Apartments in Greenwich Village; Six Stories, Six Condos
description: Scaffold netting now drapes One Leroy Street, a six-story condominium with a copper mansard roof to be completed this summer at the corner of Bleecker Street in Greenwich Village.

title: The Dogs of The Dow, Are Having Their Day
description: It's hardly news to index watchers that the Dow Jones industrial average has been on a tear. Since April 8, it has returned 9.1 percent through last Thursday, beating the broader, more growth-oriented Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, which has returned just 3.2 percent.

title: Nothing New
description: To the Editor:

title: The Greatest Leap
description: To reach Zhang Hanzhi, one first has to navigate through a traditional Chinese home. Peaceful open-air courtyards lead to private rooms with shelves of Chinese classics and hanging scrolls. The place is a walled-in maze, like Chinese boxes within boxes. And so by the time you reach Ms. Zhang in her modern office with its computer loaded with Windows 95, the journey seems not only a relief but also a metaphor for the distance women have traveled in China these last 1,000 years.

title: After Honing Skills in the Undergound, A Newark Hip-Hop Group Sees the Light
description: DENZY bursts out the door of the Outhouse, a three-story former crack house that the Outsidaz have turned into their living quarters and recording studio. He wanders across South 20th Street, clutching the latest issue of The Source, a hip-hop magazine. It is turned to a full-page ad for Nappy clothes, in which he models with Redman, a rap superstar who grew up just blocks away.

title: Christina Kelly, Dalton Ross
description: Christina Marie Kelly, the daughter of Mary Burr Kelly of Pelham Manor, N.Y., and the late Robert F. Kelly, was married yesterday to Dalton David Ross, the son of Marta M. Dunetz and Stuart P. Ross, both of Washington. The Rev. Claudia Gould performed the Episcopal ceremony at the Little Sanctuary of St. Albans School in Washington.

title: Votes in Congress
description: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York.

title: New York's Baffling Zoning Code
description: New York City's antiquated zoning code runs about 900 pages and rivals the Internal Revenue Code in complexity. Unless you are a member of the coterie of zoning lawyers, the odds of accurately interpreting one section of the code in relation to another are slim to none. Joseph Rose, chairman of the City Planning Commission, now plans to rewrite parts of the code so that rules for building height and other crucial standards are not only clear, but sturdy enough to withstand attempts to twist them into pretzels.

title: OPINION; A Break for Taxpayers, Not Schools
description: THOSE Long Islanders who happened to read the materials mailed to them by their local school district in advance of the statewide school budget votes on Tuesday may have noticed a slight change in the way the tax impact of the school budget is figured. This year, some districts included in their calculations the tax breaks that homeowners will receive as part of New York State's new School Tax Relief Program, known as STAR.

title: Power Suffering
description: At sunset one evening in 1353, the 6-year-old Catherine Benincasa is said to have experienced the first of the mystical visions that would power her brief, extraordinary life. While returning to her home in Siena with her brother Stefano after a visit to their married sister across the valley, she gazed over the church of St. Dominic and saw Jesus drenched in light, flanked by SS. Peter, Paul and John. Jesus smiled at Catherine and blessed her. Stefano, finding his sister standing in the road gaping at the sky, shook her from her trance. The vision evaporated, and Catherine burst into tears.

title: Streetscapes / Henry Siegel and the 14th Street Store; The Rise and Fall of the Department-Store Napoleon
description: HENRY SIEGEL'S turn-of-the-century retailing operations rose and fell like Internet stocks. His 14th Street Store, opened in 1904 on Sixth Avenue between 13th and 14th Streets, was one of his biggest projects, and it fell apart a decade after he put it up. Now the building it occupied is being turned into residential loft condominiums.

title: The Loneliness, Elation and Doubts Of the Monologuist
description: THE British actor Alec McCowen warned me of a pitfall of the one-person show: ''Loneliness!'' Performing his highly successful ''St. Mark's Gospel,'' he remembers countless solitary dinners in cities as far-flung as Tallahassee, Pittsburgh and Des Moines.

title: The Nation: AT&T's Merger Deals; Hold on. Maybe We'll Connect You.
description: THE antitrust authorities barely whimpered last month when AT&T, the nation's largest long-distance company, acquired Tele-Communications Inc., the second-largest cable company. The deal advanced AT&T's audacious plan to feed phone calls and Internet data over the same wire that carries video channels -- offering customers a svelte package of every electronic service they can imagine. And this month AT&T moved to buy another large cable company, Mediaone, and to bring Microsoft into its cable and Internet operations.

title: No Starch, Please
description: If women can iron the kinks from their hair and creases from their clothes, why not wrinkles from their skin? At the Miano-Viel Salon, 14 East 52d Street, a facial technique introduced last month by Alla Katkov, a Russian woman with smooth, poreless skin, requires a tiny iron used with some force. Unlike some facials that leave skin red and blotchy, the Rejuvenating Facial Iron is meant to offer immediate, if temporary, smoothness -- good for a last-minute glow before going out. Ms. Katkov begins the treatment with a shoulder massage and minty-smelling masks. Before you can say ''weird science,'' she straps sheets of sheer plastic across the face and neck, turns off the lights, and rolls a tiny warm phosphorescent plastic iron up and down, from upper chest to forehead, causing a sparking sensation on the skin. ''This is the holo-electron neon iron,'' she says, and its electric impulses remove lines. It sounds like hokum -- and indeed it may be the mask's hydrating effect that eliminates lines -- but when she strips off the plastic the face resembles that of a well-rested 8-year-old. Downside: would a tub of Vaseline and a roll of Saran Wrap at home cost $100? ALEX KUCZYNSKI

title: An Appreciation; Style and Symbolism Meet In Design for Penn Station
description: Beaux-Arts on the rebound? No. A great act of civic vandalism undone? That was never in the cards. But if you can set such golden platitudes aside, you may begin to appreciate the intrinsic merits of the superb new plan to remodel the historic James A. Farley Building, the old general post office on Eighth Avenue between 31st and 33d Streets, into a future home for Pennsylvania Station.

title: Spring Children's Books; Stranger in Her Own Land
description: TEA WITH MILK Written and illustrated by Allen Say. 32 pp. Boston: Walter Lorraine Books/ Houghton Mifflin Company. $17. (Ages 5 to 9)

title: First Lady's Perks May Also Be Pitfalls in a Race for Senate
description: On a recent Friday morning, an Air Force jet carrying Hillary Rodham Clinton left Andrews Air Force Base for Buffalo, where a motorcade assembled by the Secret Service took her to a fund-raiser for an upstate Democratic Congressman. From there, it was on to an A.F.L.-C.I.O. forum jammed with cheering women, where Mrs. Clinton spent an hour discussing the Democratic issues with which she has identified herself in recent months.

title: INSIDE
description: Bush's Cash Network

title: Spring Children's Books; Children's Books in Brief
description: A HIVE FOR THE HONEYBEE

title: BEST SELLERS: May 16, 1999
description: Weeks

title: A Century of Piano That Can Last for Weeks
description: IS it possible to sum up the vast recorded legacy of the piano? One answer has begun to arrive in recent months. Philips has been releasing the first volumes of Great Pianists of the 20th Century, which it says is the largest recording project ever.

title: History Meets The Helpful
description: Raising funds for housing, arts and education, and taking note of a restaurant and quilters.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUZZEO, LOUIS
description: BUZZEO-Louis. Of Pound Ridge, NY. (husband of Cornelia, deceased). Our loving father passed away peacefully on the morning of May 13, 1999. A WWII veteran, entrepreneur and creative spirit. He will be dearly missed by his brother Mario, his children Paula, Martin, Bernadette, Elizabeth, Marie and Anthony and sons-in-law Michael and Richard. Reposing at Craft Memorial Home, 40 Leicester Street, Port Chester, N.Y.

title: Redonda Miller, Albert Polito
description: Dr. Redonda Gail Miller and Dr. Albert John Polito were married yesterday by the Rev. John O'Brien at Corpus Christi Roman Catholic Church in Baltimore.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAMIL, JENNA
description: KAMIL-Jenna. It is with great sadness that we mourn the tragic loss of the daughter of our dear friends, Linda and Gideon. Our hearts and prayers are with them and their family. Her spirit will live on in all of us. Honey and Mike Ellis Lisa and Mark Ellis Sidney Gluck and Janet Kantor

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SCHOEN, RITA
description: SCHOEN-Rita. Happy birthday. We love you. We wish you eternal life. Marco Del Forn and famil

title: Be Our Guest
description: Black tourists spend $35 billion a year in the United States, notes Gloria Bryant, who was hired to put together a guide to help New Jersey draw its share of those visitors and their dollars. Ms. Bryant, owner of the Writing Company, a public relations and marketing company in Newark, produced ''African-American Black Heritage Guide to New Jersey,'' available free by calling (800) 847-4865, extension 9940. The 28-page booklet describes sites like Timbuctoo in Westampton, an all-black settlement established around 1820; Community Hospital in Newark, established in 1928 as the city's first black hospital, and the graves of slaves in Union County. It also includes cultural centers and events, jazz clubs and jazz and blues festivals and short biographies. Ms. Bryant says she does not think African-Americans will plan a trip to New Jersey to see an old church, but she sees the guide as added value to a trip or an impetus for a business traveler to take the family along. The state plans similar booklets for Hispanic and Asian tourists.

title: Yeltsin Survival: Ouster Failed but the Discord Festers
description: With impeachment now off the political agenda, President Boris N. Yeltsin wins, and his Communist opposition loses. An old balance of power rocks back into place, and Russia's latest political crisis begins to recede.

title: It's Showtime In Queens As Studios Plan to Grow
description: New York's biggest borough is rapidly becoming one of the country's biggest film and television production centers, too. Two studios are expanding and another may be on the way. Hollywood, apparently, sees the flickering light at the end of the Midtown Tunnel as more filmmakers shout: ''Lights! Camera! Queens!''

title: Puzzling History
description: To the Editor:

title: A Red-Carpet Ride
description: ''I CAN'T really believe I'm here,'' said Richard Mason, a novelist and Oxford University student, as he toured the book party thrown for him at the offices of The New Yorker magazine last Monday night. ''I keep expecting that at some point I'm going to wake up and be a 12-year-old back at boarding school.''

title: Ailing Childs May Not Play
description: The Knicks today were not planning on having point guard Chris Childs available for the deciding Game 5 of their first-round playoff series in Miami on Sunday.

title: NATO Admits Village Attack And Casualties
description: NATO said today that it had carried out an attack on a military command post in southern Kosovo and acknowledged that civilians were accidentally killed in the attack.

title: The World; Kosovo War Doesn't Do Much for U.S. Recruitment
description: A DECADE ago, Americans watched the United Nations' entry into the gulf war almost as if it were a video game, distant and unreal. Each night's newscast brought a fresh batch of satellite pictures of Iraqi targets exploding as smart bombs zeroed in.

title: Brookhaven Supervisor Announces for Re-Election
description: Felix J. Grucci Jr., the two-term Republican supervisor of the scandal-ridden Town of Brookhaven, announced last week that he will seek a third term in November.

title: You Can Leave the Rat Race Without a Hoard of Cheese
description: To the Editor:

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: Coast to Coast

title: Riders Try to Curb New Bus Route
description: Covering some 10 miles each way, the M10 is one of Manhattan's longest bus routes, snaking its way, often through heavy traffic, from Harlem to the Battery and back. Transit officials say the route is too long and want to split it in two. But that idea has alarmed many people, who say the M10 is a vital link between important destinations on the West Side.

title: The Nation: No Way Out; Still Gawking After All These Years
description: THE once-and-future queen of our tabloid domain was released from a prison in upstate New York last week. After a seven-year hiatus, Amy Fisher is among us again, and it seems that since we cannot escape her, we may have no recourse but to pursue, analyze and perhaps even worship her.

title: May 9-15; Republicans Shift On Gun Measure
description: Senate Republicans did a U-turn, first voting down, then pushing through a measure to promote background checks of buyers at gun shows.

title: For the Reeling Yankees, Small Victories Are No Consolation
description: The Yankees have apparently become so futile that their fans grasp at any positive development to root for. They found one in the seventh inning of a lopsided game yesterday when Derek Jeter beat the ball into the ground along the third-base line and raced to first base for a single.

title: Leveling the Gender Playing Field
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PISKIEL, GUTA (NEE KUTNER)
description: PISKIEL-Guta (nee Kutner). On Friday, May 14, 1999. Of Brooklyn, NY. Beloved wife of the late Morris, devoted mother of Harold Piskiel and Susan Piskiel Blackburn, cherished grandmother of Audra, Jason and Marisa. Funeral services were conducted on Sunday, May 16, 1999, from the Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vaux Hall Road, Union, NJ.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: Balancing Speech Against Violence
description: To the Editor:

title: Change at the Top At Ayer Detroit
description: Luana Floccuzio has been appointed executive vice president and managing director at the Detroit office of N. W. Ayer & Partners, part of MacManus Group, assuming the duties of Danielle Colliver, who had been president of the Ayer Detroit office since February 1991.

title: U.S. Orders 2 Yugoslavs To Be Freed As P.O.W.'s
description: President Clinton has ordered the release of two Yugoslav soldiers who were captured in Kosovo last month, the Pentagon said tonight. The two men could be freed as early as Monday.

title: In Subtle Ways, Yugoslav Republic Guards Against Serb-Led Coup
description: This capital city nestled in mighty mountains has been telling two tales since NATO's air assault on Yugoslavia began.

title: INSIDE
description: Revolt Against Mrs. Gandhi

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We're not racists in this organization. We're snobs, but not racists.''

title: 2 CANDIDATES QUIT IN ISRAEL ON DAY BEFORE ELECTIONS
description: In a stunning turn of events, two minor party candidates withdrew from the Prime Minister's race today, paving the way for what polls predicted would be a conclusive victory for the Labor Party's leader, Ehud Barak, in the election on Monday.

title: Bozell Said to Buy 2d New York Shop
description: Bozell Worldwide in New York, a unit of True North Communications, will acquire Berenter Greenhouse & Webster, according to agency executives briefed on Bozell's plans.

title: Start-Up Leads Phone Cause in Battle for Internet Access
description: Michael W. Malaga, chairman of Northpoint Communications Group Inc., stood at a whiteboard in his office here and explained how his newly public company planned to change the Internet business.

title: Milosevic Is Said to Be Ready For Deal but Not Humiliation
description: After more than 50 days of air raids and with his troops still entrenched in Kosovo, President Slobodan Milosevic is prepared for a settlement, so long as the process can be portrayed as negotiation and not capitulation, Yugoslav officials and analysts say.

title: Men Who Put Foes in Headlocks Now Try to Get a Grip on Politics
description: When Bob Backlund hits the campaign trail as a Republican candidate for Congress in greater Hartford, he is not asked about school vouchers or abortion or Kosovo, but about the ''cross-face chicken wing.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LINSKY, PHILIP
description: LINSKY-Philip. Died Saturday, May 15, 1999, in Fort Lauderdale, Florida. Formerly of New City, NY, and Queens, NY. Beloved husband of Anne. Devoted father of Stan Shmuel and Shammai. Grandfather of Riana, Miriam Sarah, Tzivi, Moshe, Eliana, and Natania. World War II veteran, U.S. Air Corps; former proprietor, Spotlight Restaurant. Will be missed by all. Service Monday, 9:30 AM, Jeffers, Fort Hamilton Parkway, Brooklyn, New York.

title: Equity Offerings Set for This Week
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: Refugees Tell of 100 Civilians Massacred by Serbian Forces in Rebel Strongholds
description: Serbian forces have killed more than 100 civilians in three villages in the region that is the birthplace of the guerrilla group fighting for Kosovo's independence, refugees arriving in Macedonia in recent days have reported.

title: Mets Waste Solid Effort by Hershiser
description: Phillies pitcher Paul Byrd staggered into Veterans Stadium today looking like a man who had not had much recent contact with his pillow or his hairbrush. He rubbed his red-rimmed eyes and headed drowsily for the clubhouse, having spent a nearly sleepless night trying to contain his toddler son Colby, who recently learned how to get out of his crib. But Colby's father had just enough energy in his pitches -- and just enough jump in his step on a wild defensive play -- to contain the Mets for six and a third innings and deliver the Phillies a 5-2 victory.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOVETT, BESS
description: LOVETT-Bess. The officers and members of Temple Sinai of Roslyn record with profound sorrow the passing of Bess Lovett. Our condolences to the family. Michael A. White, Sr. Rabbi Norman Kahan, Rabbi Emeritus Michael J. Paul, President

title: Let Teen-Agers Try Adulthood
description: The national outpouring after the Littleton shootings has forced us to confront something we have suspected for a long time: the American high school is obsolete and should be abolished. In the last month, high school students present and past have come forward with stories about cliques and the artificial intensity of a world defined by insiders and outsiders, in which the insiders hold sway because of superficial definitions of good looks and attractiveness, popularity and sports prowess.

title: Success Helps Ease Jarrett's Mind
description: Dale Jarrett had been stuck in second for much of this season. Consistently good, he had not been good enough for victory lane. The frustration of coming so close week after week -- he had finished second three times -- was wearing at his team's morale, and his own.

title: U.S. Faults Medical Study At CUNY and Mount Sinai
description: A Government watchdog agency has warned the City University of New York and the Mount Sinai School of Medicine to comply with ethical rules for federally financed research on human subjects, an agency official said yesterday. Violating those rules could imperil the institutions' permission to engage in such research.

title: Danger on the Pharmacy Shelves?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Delicate Tenor Saxophone Makes for a Quiet Evening
description: Mark Turner

title: Commencements; Graduation Speakers Stress Courage and Social Justice
description: St. John's University's Alumni Hall in Jamaica, Queens, is frequently filled with screaming fans watching basketball players run, jump and dunk, but at yesterday's commencement ceremonies, the stands were filled with proud parents and friends of graduates who sat quietly and listened to a speech by a man paralyzed from the neck down.

title: Giuliani and McCall Fight Repeal of Commuter Tax
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and State Comptroller H. Carl McCall, so often at political odds, teamed up yesterday to denounce plans by the State Legislature and Gov. George E. Pataki to repeal a tax on suburbanites who work in New York City.

title: Danger on the Pharmacy Shelves?
description: To the Editor:

title: For All the TV Pilots, There's Just Not Enough Youth to Go Around
description: Robert Hutchinson had done a few television commercials as a middle school student here, then lost interest in acting. But he did a few more commercials recently and then, hearing about more opportunities for young people, decided this spring, as a 16-year-old, to try for a part in a pilot for a new television show.

title: Balancing Speech Against Violence
description: To the Editor:

title: Compressed Data; Lessons in Not Blocking The Ads That Feed You
description: Real Networks is trying to dodge a bullet, one that is headed straight for its own foot.

title: U.S. to Offer Search Service That Links Its On-Line Sites
description: The Federal Government plans to put a World Wide Web service into operation today that is designed as a quick and easy way to find Government documents and resources on line. But the service will not be free, stirring criticism that the Clinton Administration has forgotten its promise to make the Internet and Government data more accessible to everyone.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DANIEL, JACK D.
description: DANIEL-Jack D., 59. Passed away on May 14, 1999 at Austin Hospice Christopher House. Of Austin, Texas. After a long illness of cancer. He is survived by his mother, Edith L. Daniel; three brothers, Don, Gordon and Glenn; and a sister, Robin, all of Austin. Donations may be made in his memory to the American Cancer Society. Funeral information, Amey Funeral Home, 7811 Rockwood Lane, Austin, Texas, (512) 452-4001.

title: Turnover Puts Heat In Position For More
description: When it was over, Tim Hardaway sat slumped against a wall in the Heat locker room, his face reduced to a lifeless stare.

title: South Africa After Nelson Mandela
description: Few nations that have made a transition to democracy have emerged with as solid a political system as South Africa's. The five years of Nelson Mandela's presidency, which ends next month, have seen a genuine change of political power, widespread respect for the rule of law and none of the political revenge killings that have marked other societies in transition. South Africa has many problems, such as desperate poverty and terrifying crime. But its suffering would have been infinitely greater absent the moral authority and democratic, inclusive spirit that made Mr. Mandela a giant as leader of the liberation movement and as President.

title: Persevering Roberts Succeeds In Overtime
description: The first six times that Loren Roberts entered the GTE Byron Nelson Classic, he missed the cut.

title: Treasury Will Offer 3-  and 6-Month Bills
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUNT, REGINALD SAYRE
description: HUNT-Reginald Sayre. On May 12, 1999. Beloved son of the late John T. and Madeleine Hunt; brother of the late Bella Hunt. Retired executive of IBM and Ceridian Corp. Dear friend and valued member of Friendly Sons of St. Patrick and Knights of Columbus. A man who overcame so many obstacles and was an inspiration to all who knew him. Reposing at the Gannon Funeral Home, 152 East 28 St, NYC on Monday 7-9 and Tuesday 2-5 and 7-9PM. A mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated on Wednesday at 10AM, Our Lady of the Scapular and St. Stephens Church. Interment is in Calvary Cemetery.

title: In a Journey From Classic to Modern, Love Remains Ruthless and Ardent
description: ''La Bayadere'' has romantic intrigue galore, a death by snakebite and a crumbling temple to recommend it. The Minkus score is a similarly operatic bundle of grand -- and melodic -- passions.

title: Trying to Move On-Line Radio Beyond a Niche
description: Until recently, it might have been fair to enlist the cliche ''those crazy kids'' to describe people who listened to radio on the Internet. But a series of announcements last week signals that the demographic profile of on-line listeners is expanding beyond 20-somethings to include the corporate set.

title: China's Liberals Look for Silver Lining
description: In assessing the impact of last week's nationalistic, anti-American outburst on their cause, Chinese liberals and political dissidents say there may be more immediate hard-line attitudes from the country's leaders, but hope that the outburst of activism will galvanize a generation forced to keep quiet for the last 10 years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEIN, HOWARD M.
description: KLEIN-Howard M. Died peacefully on May 14 after a courageous and dignified battle with lung cancer. Beloved husband of Alice Kulick Klein. Parent and special friend to Renee and Tom Brodie; ''Gramps'' to Isabella. Father of David, Kenneth and the late Amy Shapiro. Brother of Dorothy and the late Maxwell, Hilda and Lawrence. Service Sunday at 2 PM at The Jewish Community Center of Harrison, 130 Union Avenue, Harrison, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NAREFF, ARTHUR A., M.D.
description: NAREFF-Arthur A., M.D. On May 13, 1999. Beloved husband of Florence. Cherished father of Jill Blauner and Jonathan Nareff. Adored grandfather of Seth, Matthew and Gretchen. Devoted brother of the late Colonel Max J. Nareff, M.D. A.B. degree, University of Alabama; M.D., University of Western Ontario. Family physician to the constituents of the Lower East Side, from 1941-1981. Physician on staff of Beth Israel Hospital for over fifty years. Medical Director, New York City Board of Education, 1978-1983. Fellow, Family Practice Association. Services Monday, May 17, 11:00 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to the University of Western Ontario, Medical School, London, Ontario, Canada, care of Alumni Hall, Room 11, N6A5B9.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIS, SUSAN
description: DAVIS-Susan. Of Muttontown, NY, died on May 16, 1999. Wife of Gary. Daughter of Edith Sinovsky. Mother and mother-in-law of Amy and Brandt Josephson, Jericho, NY, Elisa and Robert Hecht, NY, NY. Devoted grandmother of Danielle and Jenna. Funeral services at North Shore Synagogue, Syosset, NY, May 17, 1999, 1:30 PM. Susan graduated Hofstra University and was a teacher in NYC schools. She worked in publishing for Scholastic Publications for 15 years. Susan's greatest love after her family and friends was golf. She won seven club championships at Cold Spring C.C., Glen Oaks and Admiral's Cove. Susan competed in numerous MGA events. In 1997 she won the MGA Sanford Cup. Susan has been serving as President of Long Island's Cross County Golf Association. Susan was also accomplished at bridge, Scrabble and crossword puzzles. Any charitable donations may be made to the American Cancer Society or the Stepping Stone Day School.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STONE, BERNARD

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about the use of the Heimlich maneuver on near-drowning victims referred incompletely to its value. The American Heart Association says the maneuver should be used only after cardiopulmonary resuscitation has been tried, and if CPR cannot proceed because of a blockage of the airway.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FENTON, DAISY
description: FENTON-Daisy. On May 13, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Irving. Devoted mother. Loving sister. Cherished grandmother and greatgrandmother. Services were held Sunday, May 16th, 1999. Interment in Beth Moses Cemetery. All contributions should be made in her memory to Hadassah.

description: A Staten Island man died early yesterday after his car hit an unmarked police car driven by a uniformed officer, the police said.

description: Even as a revolution rages around them, television network executives have sat in rooms over the last few weeks, taking part in an annual ritual as old as the medium itself: They were picking sit-coms for the fall season.

title: Deutsche Telekom Won't Revise Its Initial Bid for Telecom Italia
description: Deutsche Telekom A.G., Europe's largest phone company, dashed investors' hopes during the weekend that it would sweeten its $82 billion offer for Telecom Italia S.p.A. before Olivetti S.p.A.'s hostile bid closes at the end of the week.

description: If descendants of Thomas Jefferson ever accept as their relatives people who claim as forebears Jefferson and Sally Hemings, one of his slaves, the first steps were taken this weekend, however small they were.

title: Indonesia Ousts Doctor Serving Strive Victims
description: An American doctor whose small clinic here treated victims of militia violence left the province of East Timor today after a visa dispute with Indonesian authorities.

description: The newest version of the Random House Webster's College Dictionary makes its debut this spring with ''New Words for the New Millennium'' plus a reader-beware feature: warning labels for some 300 words that are flagged for odiousness.

description: It was a few days before Miningco.com was scheduled to go public in March. Scott Kurnit, the company's founder and chief executive, called its lawyer to ask whether there was any law that prevented a company, on the day it goes public, from changing its name.

title: Madelaine Chambers, 72, Opera Singer
description: Madelaine Chambers, a lyric soprano who sang at the Metropolitan Opera and the New York City Opera in the 1950's and 60's, died on April 30 at the University of Pennsylvania Hospital in Philadelphia. She was 72 and lived in Allentown, N.J.

title: Health Network Interests Dell
description: The Dell Computer Corporation and two other companies are seeking to invest as much as $30 million in Drkoop.com Inc., the on-line consumer health care network co-founded by the former Surgeon General, C. Everett Koop.

title: 'Diversity' and Affirmative Action Aren't the Same
description: To the Editor:

title: Study Says Few Women Rue Preventive Breast Operation
description: A new survey of women who took a drastic measure to prevent breast cancer, having both healthy breasts removed, shows that nearly 70 percent are satisfied with their decision and would make the same choice if they had it to do over.

title: The Difficulty in Being Earnest; Efforts to Reinvent The Los Angeles Times Falter
description: Mark H. Willes, the chairman and chief executive of the Times Mirror Company, began a corporate meeting last September by asking dozens of his top lieutenants how they felt about the company's financial goals. As he watched the results tallied on an overhead projector, his easy smile faded.

title: Jacob Javits to Be Honored With Dedication of Statue
description: A bronze statue of Jacob K. Javits, the tailor's son who became a United States Senator, will be dedicated tomorrow at the convention center that bears his name.

title: A Bad Trump Split Is Fine In Top Consolation Play
description: Consolation events, for competitors who fail to make a cut, are seldom played nowadays. When they are, there is a general lack of enthusiasm and the standard tends to be low.

title: In a Degas Show, Hints of Family Rifts; Impression of New Orleans's Tangled Past
description: Charles Musson, an engineer for an oil company here, stood in front of a portrait of a child at the New Orleans Museum of Art, astonished. The painting, of a well-groomed dark-eyed boy of 9, dates from 1855. The painter was Edgar Degas, then 21. The subject was his brother Rene.

title: Merger Is Seen Of Two Makers Of Farm Gear
description: The Case Corporation and New Holland N.V., two of the world's largest makers of farm and construction equipment, are expected to announce plans to merge on Monday, people who have been briefed on the talks said today.

title: The Greek Trilogy of Ballet In a Stravinsky Mini-Festival
description: Two straight weeks of Stravinsky's music is not what you encounter in concert halls nowadays. But that is what the New York City Ballet has been offering since Tuesday, when the company returned to its repertory programs following the 10-day run of ''Swan Lake'' that opened its spring season.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: WEEKEND MOVES

title: Patents
description: PERHAPS it was inevitable that someone would one day patent the act of inventing. Certainly the age of computer modeling and powerful, nimble technical software has made it possible for a group of inventors to now own what it calls an ''invention that creates new inventions.''

title: Companies Lag on Year 2000 Repairs, Study Says
description: The largest companies in the nation continue to fall behind their schedules for Year 2000 repairs, and most suspect that their budget estimates for the remaining work are too low, according to a survey in April that was the latest in a closely watched series that began in 1994.

title: Danger on the Pharmacy Shelves?
description: To the Editor:

title: Republicans Giving Ground On Gun Control Amendments
description: Senate Republicans signaled a willingness today to approve yet another gun control measure -- namely, a requirement that child safety devices be sold with handguns -- even though a similar proposal failed by a decisive margin in the Republican-controlled Senate less than a year ago.

title: Media Talk; Pulitzer Prize Judges Speak Their Minds
description: Every April, the Pulitzer Prizes are announced with trumpets blaring. But the selection process, which is run by the Graduate School of Journalism at Columbia University, usually goes unexamined.

title: On Trip to Mend Ties, Iran's President Meets Saudi Prince
description: Iran's President met today in Saudi Arabia with the kingdom's Crown Prince, taking a crucial step in a process of fence-mending that is every bit as significant and tricky as the warmer relationship he has begun with the West.

title: U S West Seen In a Merger That Is Valued At $37 Billion
description: Global Crossing Ltd., the telecommunications upstart that went public only last year, is expected to announce today that it is merging with U S West Inc., the smallest of the regional Bell phone companies, in a stock swap valued at about $37 billion, people close to the talks said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLEESON, REV. JOSEPH M.
description: GLEESON-Rev. Joseph M. On May 13, 1999. Ordained for the people of New York on May 29, 1965. Born on March 28, 1939, the son of Joseph M. and Marie White Gleeson. He was raised and educated in New York City, a graduate of Regis High School, Fordham University and Saint Joseph's Seminary. He fulfilled his ministry at Saint Thomas the Apostle and Church of Our Savior in Manhattan, Holy Family in Staten Island, Saint Peter's in Yonkers, and Sacred Heart in the Bronx. He served as Chaplain in Bronx Lebanon Hospital for many years, completing his ministry at the Veterans Administration Medical Center in Saint Albans, Queens. He is survived by: three sisters, Kathryn L. Gleeson of New York City, Marie G. Amoroso of Scarsdale, and Loretta G. DiLorenzo of Scarsdale; one brother, Richard W. Gleeson of Boston, MA; three aunts, Helen W. Coogan of Somers, NY, Mary White of Riverdale, NY, and Miriam McCormick of Richmond, VA; nieces and nephew, Kate, Claire and Sarah DiLorenzo, Lori, Nancy, Michael and Beth Amoroso, Molly and Jesse Serventi-Gleeson. The family will receive friends at the Bennett Funeral Home, 824 Scarsdale Avenue, Scarsdale, New York, 914725-1137, on Friday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial will take place on Saturday, 11 AM, at Saint Barnabas Church, Martha Avenue and East 241 Street in the Bronx. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Carmelite Communion, 139 DePuyster Ave., Beacon, NY. 12508-3504 will be appreciated.

title: The General at the Center of the Stage
description: For Douglas MacArthur, ''theater of war'' was more than just a casual image. Throughout his often brilliant, often contentious career he saw himself at stage center, the protagonist of battles against his country's enemies and his own military and civilian superiors. With his orotund phrases (''Let no heart be faint; let every arm be steeled''), selected props (the riding crop, the battered cap, the corncob pipe) and an affection for the first-person singular (''I shall return''), he was never the model American general, yet for many he was an inspiring leader of American forces through momentous decades.

title: Sports of The Times; For Now, All Quiet On the Yankee Front
description: DURING batting practice yesterday, Don Zimmer was sitting in the Yankee dugout, talking about how Joe Torre's return was approaching. One educated guess was that Torre will be managing the Yankees on Friday night in Chicago.

title: Public Anger Against U.S. Still Simmers In Beijing
description: Anger continued to percolate here today over the NATO bombing of the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade, even as both Chinese and American officials gave signs that the height of the crisis had passed.

title: Accounts
description: * Earthlink, Pasadena, Calif., to BBDO West, Los Angeles and San Francisco, part of the BBDO Worldwide unit of Omnicom Group, as agency of record for the Internet service provider. BBDO West will test a consumer campaign in five markets; if it is successful, the ads would run nationally in the fall with a budget estimated at $50 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEMETRIOU, KYRIACOS (''MR. KAY'')
description: DEMETRIOU - Kyriacos (''Mr. Kay''). May 14, 1999. Beloved husband of Niki. Loving father of Gloria and father-in-law of Paul Galietti. His noted talents as a barber were well known throughout the world. The contents of his Broadway Barbershop were donated to the Museum of the City of New York. For further information please call Frank E. Campbell at 212-288-3500.

title: The Coach's Son Passes the Course on Pressure
description: When Allan Houston was playing at the University of Tennessee, his coach and father, Wade, used to tell him to block out everything. Half-crazed fans. Defenders trying to bait him into a bad shot. Off-court controversy surrounding the team. Everything.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVAVY, BERENICE B.
description: LEVAVY-Berenice B. On May 14, 1999. For over 63 years she and her husband Zvi, who survives her, set standards of marital harmony and compatability. Devoted sister of the late Gladys Bardin, beloved mother of Bardin (and Sue-Ellen), adoring grandmother of Raphael and Sara Beth. She was a community leader of Perth Amboy, NJ for over half a century, and both teacher and student throughout her life. Loved, respected-and now missed-by all who knew her. Services Monday, Flynn & Son Funeral Home, Perth Amboy, NJ.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a proposal for Mexico to adopt the United States dollar as its currency referred incorrectly in some editions to the Mexican patriot pictured on the 50-peso bill. He is Jose Maria Morelos, not Miguel Hidalgo.

title: E-Commerce Report; An idea that seems to benefit almost everyone is catching more interest: bill delivery and payment in cyberspace.
description: SEEING opportunity in every crevice of the economy, a growing number of Internet commerce companies now want to serve as the bearers of bad news -- in this case, delivering bills on line.

title: Mr. Jenkins, 'beloved Tanqueray figurehead,' disappears, and new ads stress London heritage.
description: THE marketers of a well-known gin are shaking, not stirring, its advertising, replacing a pitch based on fantasy with one based on reality -- well, as realistic as you can get on Madison Avenue.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on May 5 with an article about the Spalding Company's plan to reintroduce the pink rubber ball known as a spaldeen misstated the location of of the stickball game shown. It was East Ninth Street in Manhattan between Avenues B and C, not A and B. In some copies, the credit omitted the year the picture was made. It was 1968.

title: The Art of the Musical: Lessons From the Civil War
description: There is certainly a civil war going on in the American musical theater. On one side is the musical as a big costly spectacle, mobilized to overwhelm the audience with sets, special effects and choreography that alternates tableaux with frenetic aerobics. On the other is the musical as a vocal and physical ritual, featuring human beings with personality and sometimes even character, people with voices and bodies that receive and transmit rhythm and melody, whether singing and dancing or walking and talking.

title: Danger on the Pharmacy Shelves?
description: To the Editor:

title: Idle Hands in Albany
description: The idea was that it would be a good political ploy. To rally support for their candidate for a State Senate seat north of New York City, several Democrats endorsed what has long been little more than a suburban whim. They announced that they wanted the State Legislature to end a commuter tax for suburbanites who work in New York City. State Republicans, not to be outdone on what is normally a Republican issue, quickly supported the concept, adding that the Republican-controlled State Senate would approve legislation. Because the Governor could be expected to endorse the measure, the Democratic Assembly with its Democratic Speaker, Sheldon Silver of New York City, was considered the fail-safe that was sure to stop the plan this week.

title: White House Is Quietly Pro-Barak
description: The Clinton Administration has maintained a studied public neutrality in the Israeli campaign for Prime Minister. But it has made little effort to conceal its interest in a victory for Ehud Barak, the Labor Party candidate.

title: In School District, Corruption Fed by Ethnic Division
description: They called him ''Wild Bill'' Rogers, and for 20 years he was the law in the schools of Williamsburg and Greenpoint in Brooklyn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCWHORTER, CHARLES K.
description: McWHORTER-Charles K. Age 77, May 10, 1999, from injuries sustained in an automobile accident in Hyannis, MA. Loving brother of Susanna Reckard and brother-inlaw to, Phyllis Mann, uncle to Scott, Frank, Matthew, Charles, Mark, Cheryl, Joseph and Michael. Graduated University of West Virginia, Harvard Law School, 1949. Served in WW II as a lieutenant in the Third Army under General George S. Patton, received Bronze Star and Purple Heart with two Citations. Chairman of the National Young Republican Club from 1955 to 1957, Chief Administrative Assistant to Vice President Richard M. Nixon from 1957 to 1961, former member of the National Council of the Arts, former President, Vice Chairman and Director of American Ballet Theater, Director, Alvin Ailey Dance Company and numerous other music, arts and dance companies. Trustee since 1966, of Interlochen Center for the Arts, Interlochen, MI, and ex officio President of Interlochen Alumni Association where he underwrote the cost of a rehearsal hall, winterized the lodge, fitness center, recreational halls, auditorium, studio and renovation of onsite summmer cabins. Executive Assistant and attorney, AT&T, from 1961 until 1987. Active in Republican politics, renowned for his encyclopedic knowledge and photographic memory of election results, and elected and former officials on the national, state and local levels. Memorial Services are planned at Interlochen Center for the Arts on August 6, 7 and 8, 1999, in Washington, DC; call Mr. Dell Smith, (202) 822-8300 for place and date, and in NYC, call Mr. E. Lisk Wyckoff, Jr., (212) 715-9519 for place and date. Those wishing to do so may make contributions in his memory to the Interlochen Center for the Arts, Interlochen, MI 49643.

title: Ebay and Skytel In a Venture
description: Ebay Inc., the No. 1 on-line auctioneer, and Skytel Communications Inc., the second-largest United States paging company, plan to introduce a service that lets customers monitor and participate in auctions away from their computers.

description: Joelle Leandre

title: It's Not The Job, But How It's Filled
description: It is now obvious Congress will not renew the Independent Counsel Act when it expires next month. Although we held different views about the act when we served in the Senate (Mr. Dole opposed, and Mr. Mitchell supported, the last reauthorization), we agree that an alternative is required to fill the vacuum that will follow its demise.

title: Crime Fell 7 Percent in '98, Continuing a 7-Year Trend
description: Crime in the United States dropped sharply last year, the seventh consecutive year it has fallen, according to preliminary figures released by the Federal Bureau of Investigation yesterday.

title: Its Economy Ailing, Hawaii Hangs Some Hopes on Hollywood
description: The biggest economic fish caught in Hawaii this year is not a new factory or a high-tech software start-up or a planeload of Asian tourists, whose financial troubles continue to keep them away. The biggest fish is David Hasselhoff, the hunky head lifeguard of ''Baywatch,'' which is to begin filming here in July, rechristened ''Baywatch Hawaii.''

title: Local Race, Statewide Ripples; Parties Place High Value On Seat In New York Senate
description: Seats in the State Senate become vacant with all the frequency of snow in May, and incumbents usually depart for better jobs, retirement or the hereafter, not because they have lost an election. A real contest is rare. One with implications for control of the Senate is rarer still.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: A partial list for this week.

title: It's Up, It's Good: Houston Sends Knicks to Round 2
description: There was the deafening noise, and still Alonzo Mourning's baritone voice was able to cut through a vibrating Miami Arena as he cried out: ''One stop. One stop.'' One surreal instant later, Allan Houston put down a forceful dribble, curled around Dan Majerle as tightly as a stripe on a candy cane and discovered a shaft of light.

description: To the Editor:

title: Gandhi's Party Leaders Revolt, Saying Indian-Born Should Rule
description: The Congress Party's governing committee will hold an emergency meeting today to discuss an open revolt within the party -- the first of its kind -- against the candidacy for Prime Minister of Sonia Gandhi, the Italian-born widow who inherited the mantle of India's founding political dynasty.

title: Vern Countryman, 81, Professor and Commercial Law Expert
description: Vern Countryman, an expert on commercial law, particularly bankruptcy, died on May 2 at Mount Auburn Hospital in Cambridge, Mass. He was 81 and lived in Cambridge.

title: PRO FOOTBALL: There's Life Beyond Football; Having Hit Bottom, A Wiser Kerry Collins Picks Up His Career
description: Kerry Collins has seen the videotape of himself walking from North Carolina's Mecklenburg County Jail last November, a cigar in his mouth and a slight smirk on his face, four hours after his arrest for drunken driving.

title: A Nice Piece of Change for a Simple Guy
description: The Internet is responsible for some odd things -- the ability to monitor strangers' lives 24 hours a day comes to mind -- but last week it created something truly weird: a wealthy magazine editor.

title: Ludony Journal; How Mother Russia Plucks Her Pensioners Clean
description: Another spring, this one cold and raw, finds Aleksandra Varfolomeyeva in her one-story wooden house on the road halfway between Pskov and St. Petersburg. She lives here with her husband, her 40-year-old son, six sheep, two cows, two calves, a horse, a piglet and a dog named Fog.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCSHERRY, NANCY (NEE RYAN)
description: McSHERRY-Nancy (nee Ryan). Loving wife of Dr. Charles K. Beloved mother of Maureen. Grandmother of her special angel, Casey. Dear sister of Patricia Kruger Struck. Devoted friend to many. She is survived by 19 nieces and nephews and 29 grandnieces and nephews, and godmother to five boys. She served on the Board of Directors of the Ladies of Charity and was a member of the Auxiliary of the New York Hospital. Reposing Chas. Peter Nagel Funeral Home, 352 East 87th St., NYC, Monday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass 10 AM, Tuesday, at St. Joseph's R.C. Church. In lieu of flowers send donations to the Ladies of Charity, 1011 First Ave., NYC 10022, or St. Joseph's Church, 404 East 87th St., NYC 10128.

title: 'Feeling Ashamed' on Gun Issue, Senator Is Moved to Act
description: SENATOR Gordon H. Smith, Republican of Oregon, was endorsed by the National Rifle Association. He owns guns and has taught his two sons and his daughter how to use them. And though he has ''always melted in the face of Bambi,'' he occasionally goes hunting for pheasant and duck.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Albany Poised To Relax Law On Insurance
description: After two years of intensive lobbying by rental-car companies, the New York Legislature appears poised to repeal, or at least soften, the state's stringent law on insuring rental cars, several lobbyists and key legislators say.

title: Real Networks Plans Deal for Internet Search
description: In a deal that will aim advertising at the growing millions who listen to music and watch video on the Internet, Real Networks Inc., a multimedia software maker, and Snap.com, an Internet hub, plan to announce on Monday that they are starting a search engine that will find content on the Web.

title: Balancing Speech Against Violence
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANE, MIRIAM
description: LANE-Miriam. Our dear, sweet Grandma Mitzi. You were a very special person in our lives, always there for us, caring, kind and compassionate. We love you. Donna, Simon, Allison and Herbert

title: Brown Dominates Eastern Finals
description: Brown's crews proved dominant yesterday in the finals of the Eastern Association of Women's Rowing sprint championships in New Preston, Conn. Brown repeated as varsity eight-oared champion, captured the novice eight title for the second successive year, won the varsity four with coxswain race and missed sweeping the regatta with a tenth-of-a-second loss to Virginia in the junior varsity event.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WHITE, ROWENNA L. WIGHT
description: WHITE-Rowenna L. Wight. May 17th, 1980. Interment on her 19th birthday. The Cathedral of St. John the Divine. Private. Called back September 2nd, 1998, Peggy's Cove, Nova Scotia. ''Loud from its rocky caverns, the deep-voiced neighboring ocean Speaks, and in accents disconsolate answers the wail of the forest.'' H.W. Longfellow Love always, Rows-Mother

title: Bank of America Settles Charges on Bonds
description: The Bank of America Corporation will pay $187.5 million to settle charges it illegally kept unclaimed bond proceeds from the State of California and more than 1,000 cities, counties and public agencies statewide.

title: People
description: * Richard J. Marino was named to the new position of president at CNET, San Francisco. He had been president and chief executive of PC World Communications, San Francisco, a unit of International Data Group. In addition, Shelby Bonnie, chief operating officer at CNET, was named to the new position of vice chairman.

title: Fact, Fiction and the Media Fishbowl
description: Kurt Andersen knows everybody.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NUSSBAUM, CHERIE
description: NUSSBAUM-Cherie. Of New Rochelle. Died peacefully on May 15 with her family by her side. She was the blessed wife of Morton. Cherished mother of Eric and his wife, Fredda. Loving sister of Renee and Sidney Reiff. Adored grandmother of Daniel and Sarah. Devoted aunt of Isabel, Kenneth, and Russell. She was the co-owner of The Larchmont Store with her husband Mort. She was also a graduate of Hunter College and a dear friend of the Hunter Girls and many others. She will always be remembered. Service today, Monday, at the Zion Memorial Chapel, 785 East Boston Post Road, Mamaroneck, at 11:30 AM, followed by interment at Sharon Gardens. Memorial donations may be made to the United Ostomy Association, 36 Executive Park, Suite 120, Irvine, CA 92714.

title: Bouncy Stravinsky Music For a Playful Conversation
description: 'Four Norwegian Moods'

title: Danger on the Pharmacy Shelves?
description: To the Editor:

title: Trust Shattered In Crew's Feud With the Mayor
description: Just two months ago, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew held a news conference at City Hall to profess their mutual affection and respect. They vowed to work together to improve public education and assured everyone that a philosophical disagreement on one issue had not damaged their friendship.

title: Links to Freudian Analysis, Inside and Outside the Hall
description: 'Chamber Music From Vienna'

title: GE Capital to Buy $11 Billion In Loans From Japanese Bank
description: The financial services arm of the General Electric Company said today that it would buy the $11 billion United States commercial loan portfolio of the Long-Term Credit Bank of Japan, the unit's fifth acquisition or venture in Japan since last year.

title: Torre Is Keeping His Return Date Close to the Vest
description: Joe Torre, who turned over his responsibilities as Yankee manager to Don Zimmer after being found to have prostate cancer more than two months ago, knows exactly what day he is planning to return. ''Just go ask him,'' Zimmer said before yesterday's game, adding that Torre has known the target date now for more than a few days.

title: Charismatic vs. Menifee, Again
description: Charismatic was standing serenely in his stall at Pimlico Race Course this morning, one victory from completing one of the most remarkable sagas in racing history. Three months after being offered as a claimer to anybody willing to risk $62,500, he has a chance to sweep the Triple Crown. And his trainer, D. Wayne Lukas, who won the Kentucky Derby and the Preakness with his claimer in the last two weeks, said he would go on to the Belmont Stakes determined to send out the 12th horse in history to win all three.

title: With Six You Get Musical Beds
description: Three copulating couples populate Peter Ackerman's new sex comedy, ''Things You Shouldn't Say Past Midnight,'' but only a single pairing arouses more than a few predictable snickers. It's the one that pits straitlaced Jeffrey Donovan against naughty Clea Lewis. He plays a prudish mobster with a hankering for highbrow culture; she is, in Mr. Ackerman's symmetrical scheme, a randy art historian looking for some down-and-dirty pleasure. When these naturally funny actors are negotiating the terms of their bedtime arrangements, they turn the mating dance into a ribald gavotte.

title: Tommy Hilfiger Adds an Agency
description: The Tommy Hilfiger Corporation has expanded its agency roster by adding Kirshenbaum Bond & Partners in New York to handle creative assignments including the Tommy Jeans brand, with billings estimated at $20 million to $25 million.

title: Dr. Ruth Moulton, 83, Analyst Who Wrote on Female Sexuality
description: Ruth Moulton Gilbert, a practicing psychoanalyst in Manhattan for over 40 years, died on April 30 at her home in Clinton Corners, N.Y. She was 83.

title: Asrat Woldeyes of Ethiopia, Doctor and Dissenter, Dies
description: Asrat Woldeyes, a British-trained Ethiopian doctor who was a leader of opposition to his country's present Government, died on Friday in the hospital of the University of Pennsylvania in Philadelphia. He was in his early 70's.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ORNSTON, MIMI
description: ORNSTON-Mimi. Of New York City and Sarasota, FL, age 70, of complications during heart surgery. We have lost a beautiful person. Irreplaceable. Beloved wife and best friend of Sidge; deeply loved Mom of Richard, Wendy, Lynn, Mary and Mick; devoted step-mom of Patricia, Marjorie, Deedee and Chris; adoring grandmother of Sarah, Sammy, Lucy and Jamie; cherished daughter of the late Lillian and William Gilbert. Loved by Elaine and Jerry, nieces Joann and Barbara, and nephew David. Services Tuesday, May 18, 1999, 12 PM at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave., New York City.

title: Health Care Minimums
description: To the Editor:

title: TV Networks Are Scrambling to Deal With Era of New Media
description: Even as a revolution rages around them -- one they acknowledge is changing their world in ways they cannot yet begin to calculate fully -- television network executives have sat in rooms in the last few weeks, huddled in small groups, taking part in an annual ritual as old as the medium itself:

title: Girardi Has the Reins as Pettitte Halts Slump
description: George Steinbrenner, who grabbed tickets on every horse but Charismatic on Saturday, tried picking another winner yesterday at Yankee Stadium, a task complicated by the fact that his team had lost five consecutive games. ''You've always been our stopper,'' Steinbrenner told Andy Pettitte, the left-hander with the broad shoulders eight hands wide.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EVERETT, LEE KAYE
description: EVERETT-Lee Kaye. 68, of New York City, NY, on May 14, 1999. Loving mother of Karen Millet of Hilton Head, SC, and Anthony Everett of Wayland, MA. She is also survived by her five grandchildren. Ms. Everett had been a fashion executive at Vanity Fair Mills, Hoechst Fibers, Bonwit Teller, and Women's Wear Daily. She was President and CEO of her own consulting company, Corporate Accessories. In addition, she was involved in many charitable works, notably Childville. In lieu of flowers her children request donations be made to The Mary Manning Walsh Home, 1339 York Avenue, New York, NY 10021.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about a Queens Historical Society program honoring historic buildings referred incorrectly to the status of the Marine Air Terminal at La Guardia Airport, the Unisphere in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park and the Corona home of Louis Armstrong. All have official New York City landmark status, not the historical society's designation.

title: Tidbits From Publishing (And Many a Lunch Table)
description: ANOTHER LIFE

title: This Week
description: EVENTS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ULSTRUP, CARL C.
description: ULSTRUP-Carl C. Age 74, of Cumberland, ME, a civil engineer and bridge designer, died of cancer May 11. Mr. Ulstrup grew up in Norway and moved to the United States in 1946 to attend Columbia University. In 1987 he received the prestigious Roebling Award for eminence in design and rehabilitation of bridges throughout the world, including design of the Chesapeake Bay Bridge, the Poplar Street Bridge in St. Louis, the Kanali Bridge in Nepal, the Angostura Bridge in Venezuela and the Panama Canal Bridge, and rehabilitation of the Brooklyn and Queensboro Bridges in NYC. He retired in 1992 from the Steinman Company in New York. Mr. Ulstrup is survived by his wife Jane, three stepchildren, six grandchildren, one sister and two brothers. Contributions may be made in his name to the Nature Conservancy, 14 Maine St., Brunswick, ME 04011.

title: As Political Spouse, Bob Dole Strays From Campaign Script
description: For all his devotion to Elizabeth Dole, and for all the blessings he offers her campaign for President, Bob Dole is nobody's compliant, stick-with-the-script, gaze-lovingly-at-your-mate political spouse.

title: An Introverted Child Heroine, From MacMillan's Home
description: 'Romeo and Juliet'

title: Guatemalans Deny Changes For Indians And the Army
description: Guatemalans today appeared to have voted down constitutional changes to recognize officially for the first time the rights of the country's Mayan majority, a rejection that supporters of the measures said would set back efforts to consolidate peace after a 36-year civil war.

title: Gore Seizes Education as Campaign Platform
description: In what political aides described as his first policy speech of the Presidential campaign, Vice President Al Gore called today for ''revolutionary change'' and substantial Federal investment in education. He advocated universally available preschool for 3- and 4-year-olds, the creation of a teachers corps of new graduates for neglected schools, rigorous tests for new teachers, the elimination of large high schools and legal protection allowing parents to leave work to visit their children's teachers during the workday.

title: Sports of The Times; A Banged-Up Ewing Won't Take Back Seat
description: ALONZO MOURNING turned to face Patrick Ewing, with the ball, to the left of the basket, a 1-point lead set up perfectly to become 3. One on one, friend on friend, student against teacher. There was a minute and a half left in Game 5 yesterday, the Knicks and the Heat, survival at stake, and here was Mourning's chance to emphatically state that his time had come and Ewing's had passed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVERMAN, HAROLD
description: SILVERMAN-Harold. Age 87 years. Died peacefully in his sleep after a long battle with Alzheimer's disease. Beloved and cherished husband of Evelyn, adored father of Nancy and Norman, grandfather of Morgun and William. Harold was a devoted son, husband and father, who used his gifts of uncommon wisdom, compassion and insight to inspire and improve the lives of many who knew him. He rose to meet the many challenges in his own life with indefatigable determination, a clarity of purpose and an abundance of humor. We will miss him. Services today in San Diego, CA. In lieu of flowers, the family would appreciate a donation to the Alzheimer's Association, 360 Lexington Ave., New York, NY 10017.

title: Balancing Speech Against Violence
description: To the Editor:

title: Third Death on Street May Be Tied To Heroin
description: A man was found dead yesterday morning on East Ninth Street in Manhattan, apparently of a heroin overdose, the third such death on that street within a week, the police said.

title: Chief Is Named at Hachette-Filipacchi
description: Jack Kliger, the executive vice president of Parade Publications Inc., a subsidiary of Advance Publications, has been named president and chief executive of Hachette-Filipacchi Magazines, a unit of Lagardere Group of Paris.

title: South African Liberal Party's Gains Draw Fire
description: Even out here in this arid, desolate part of the country where the polls say the National Party -- now rechristened the New National Party -- will do well, Marthinus van Schalkwyk does not make a stop without lashing out at the Democratic Party.

title: A Festival Of Mysteries In New York
description: In 1841 Edgar Allan Poe wrote ''The Murders in the Rue Morgue,'' inspired by events in New York City, thus becoming the father of the crime fiction genre and insuring the city's place on the literary mystery map.

title: The Big City; Newest Thing To Watch: Hawk TV?
description: AS usual, tourists were lined up yesterday afternoon in Central Park to peer into the telescopes trained at the top of an apartment building at 74th Street and Fifth Avenue. They were looking at a nest where two fuzzy white chicks were being preened by their mother, Blue, and fed by their father, Pale Male.

title: 2d Allegation of Police Abuse Is Expected at Louima Trial
description: As the third week of testimony begins today in the Abner Louima trial, new witnesses are expected to include a second man who prosecutors say was assaulted by one of the police officers accused of torturing Mr. Louima.

title: Essay
description: After a week of whipping up hatred of Americans by accusing us of deliberately murdering Chinese journalists in Belgrade, President Jiang Zemin deigned to accept a call from The Great Apologizer.

title: Teen-Age Girl Is Fatally Shot in Elevator of Harlem Building
description: A 17-year-old girl was shot and killed yesterday afternoon and her boyfriend was wounded when a gunman ambushed them in a Harlem housing project, the police said.

title: Penguins Are Facing A Double Knockout
description: They joke in Pittsburgh, ruefully, that the Penguins could leave the Steel City and even exit the National Hockey League before they are out of the current Stanley Cup playoffs. That was never quite true, but any of the above could occur soon. Injured and fatigued on the ice while battling bankruptcy in court, the Penguins could be eliminated tonight by the Toronto Maple Leafs in Game 6 of the Eastern Conference semifinals in Pittsburgh's Civic Arena.

title: Weathering the Weather
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Panel Hears Testimony On H.M.O. Fee Bill
description: The Assembly Insurance Committee heard testimony yesterday on a bill that would impose a surcharge on health maintenance organizations to pay more than $140 million in doctor and hospital bills left over from the recent collapse of two H.M.O.'s.

title: Is This Fight Necessary?
description: Sure, Mayor Rudolph Giuliani has the raw political strength to run Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew out of town. He clearly believes that as an ''agent of change,'' he has the right to rout anyone he thinks moves too slowly. But this would be a good time for the Mayor to show that strength can be used for conciliation as well as raw conquest. Keeping Dr. Crew in place would be good for the stability of New York City's school system. It would allow time for analyzing the managerial and educational progress the Chancellor says he has made. It would also serve Mr. Giuliani's political interest by showing that he can curb the authoritarian streak that troubles many of his supporters.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISGLASS, STEPHEN
description: WEISGLASS-Stephen. A dear friend and special person who was always there for us. We will miss you, your wisdom and your backhand volley. Our condolences to Wiki and the entire family. Love, Ellen and Jeff

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEANE, SARAH
description: BEANE-Sarah. Age 86. Of Bronx, N.Y. Died May 17, 1999. Born in Norwich, CT on October 3, 1912. She was a daughter of the late Phillip and Anne Lidofsky. She was pre-deceased by her husband Irving Beane and her sister Celia Greenberg. She is survived by her sister Ida Lacy, her brother Leon Lidofsky, loving children Joanne Beane and Edward Beane, loving grandchildren Rachel and Eric and loving nieces and nephews.

title: A Moth in Search of a Lifesaving Encounter
description: When it comes to reproduction, there are many males in the animal kingdom that contribute little more than a moment of time and a bit of sperm. But not the rattlebox moth, whose generosity while mating suggests many males have more to offer their mates than researchers had ever suspected.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on May 6 about the passage of bankruptcy legislation in the House of Representatives misstated the increase in personal filings in 1998. There were about 48,000 new ones, not 300,000.

title: From Gay Teen-Agers, a Cry for Help
description: Teen-agers who are gay or bisexual are more than three times as likely to attempt suicide as other youth, according to a Massachusetts study reported this month in The Archives of Pediatric and Adolescent Medicine. Young men are at particular risk, the report found.

title: Notes Are Lower on Concerns About Fed's Position on Rates
description: Treasury note prices fell yesterday, pushing 10-year yields to their highest level in a year, on concern that Federal Reserve policy makers will signal they are leaning toward a rate increase after they meet today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GUMPEL, MORRIS S.
description: GUMPEL-Morris S.. Marine Surveyor, suddenly and peacefully on May 17, 1999 aged 75. Cherished husband of Maxine (Reiner), predeceased by brother, Jay and sister, Helene Brauninger, survived by caring brothers, Dr. Roy (Jane) Gumpel, Hugh (Virginia) Gumpel, most loving stepfather to Steven (Shoshana), Allison (Av), Clifford (Elyssa), most devoted uncle of fifteen nieces and nephews. Morris, we wil miss your sweet ways, unconditional and unfailing love. Funeral services Tuesday May 18, 1999, 10 A.M. at Temple Israel of New Rochelle.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-14

title: Israel Selects a New Leader
description: The decisive election victory of Ehud Barak, and the rejection of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu after three years in office, is a political earthquake in Israel and throughout the Middle East. Now Mr. Barak, one of the most decorated military men in Israeli history, confronts a full range of opportunities and perils. He has promised to unify the country's feuding factions, revive peace negotiations with the Palestinians and energize the economy, though he has provided few details on how to achieve these aims. His first priority must be to form the broadest possible ruling coalition in Parliament, consistent with his principles and the need for bold action.

title: By Design; Scarves as Shields
description: Last year, hip downtown girls were wrapping their heads in little triangular kerchiefs tied under their hair in back. The scarves were not so easy to find then but are now widely available in a variety of colors and patterns and a range of prices. Aside from being fashionable, they are useful in summer for protecting the hair from sun damage.

title: Insuring Our Children
description: To the Editor:

title: Mob Captain Sentenced To More Than 4 Years
description: A captain in the Bruno-Scarfo crime family in New Jersey was sentenced to four years and seven months in prison on racketeering charges yesterday.

title: Dow Jones and Reuters Create Net Service for Professionals
description: Dow Jones & Company and Reuters Group P.L.C., perennial rivals in the business of business information, are combining forces to create an Internet-based service providing corporate news and information for professionals, the two companies announced yesterday.

title: Harcourt's Plan For Retail Stake
description: Moving to simplify its business, the publisher Harcourt General Inc. said today that it planned to spin off much of its 54 percent stake in the retailer Neiman Marcus Group.

title: This Pop Diva Wows 'Em In Arabic
description: They came streaming in by the thousands, from Brooklyn and Buenos Aires, from Calgary and London and Washington and innumerable other cities, all of them wild to hear a rare live concert by the Arab world's most famous singer.

title: Sheila Gruson, Sculptor, 48
description: Sheila Gruson, an artist who worked as an assistant director with many opera companies around the world, died yesterday in Tiverton, in Devon, England. She was 48.

title: Legislature Acts Quickly To Repeal Commuter Tax
description: The State Legislature brushed aside Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's protests today and rescinded a 33-year-old tax on commuters in the state who work in New York City, unabashedly using its power to try to influence an upcoming suburban election.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LINKER, RUTH
description: LINKER-Ruth. Beloved wife of Murray. Loving mother of Donald Linker and Amy Bonoff. Devoted grandmother of Jennifer Koppel, Daniel Bonoff, Thomas, William and Katie Linker. Services were held. The family will receive friends at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Bonoff at 12 Split Tree Road, Scarsdale, from Tuesday evening until 12 Noon Thursday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WELLING, HERBERT M.
description: WELLING-Herbert M.. The beloved husband of Evelyn Welling. Father of Thomas J. Welling, Diane M. Cipollone, Karen A. Welling and the later James A. Welling. Also survived by eight grandchildren. Died on Monday, May 17, as a result of injuries caused by a recent fall. Friends may call at the Kalas Funeral Home, 2973 Solomons Island Road, Edgewater, MD (410-956-4488), on May 19, from 2 to 5 and 7 to 9 PM. Mass will be held at St. Mary's Church in Annapolis on May 20 at 9 AM.

title: Study Finds the Richest Got Richer in 1998
description: The world's richest people got 12 percent richer last year despite the turbulence caused by the world economic crisis, according to an annual study of global wealth released today by Merrill Lynch & Company.

title: One Russian Oil Company to Acquire Another
description: Lukoil, Russia's largest oil company, announced today that it planned a new share issue and stock swap to acquire another domestic oil company, a move analysts said would give Lukoil a sizable presence in one of the most promising oilfields in the country.

title: China Stews; A U.S. Trade Deal Falters
description: While China officially remains committed to joining the World Trade Organization, Chinese economists say that apparent divisions in the nation's leadership are likely to further stiffen Beijing's negotiating position and make agreement difficult to achieve in coming months.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHAFER, GEORGE E.
description: SCHAFER-George E.. Of Pond Eddy, New York. A retired investment banker for Brown Brothers, Harriman & Co. Died May 15, 1999 at his home in Pond Eddy. He was 73. The son of the late John H. and Florence E. Postel Schafer. Born February 26, 1926 in Brooklyn, N.Y. He is the widower of Florence Hammell Schafer. Survivors include two sons, Thomas J. Schafer of Hackensack, N.J. and Richard H. Schafer of Brooklyn, two daughters, Karen A. Conway of Chester, Vermont, and Ellen S. Decker of Newport Beach, CA., a brother John W. Schafer of Wolfboro, N.H., nine grandchildren, four great grandchildren and two nephews.
