Visitation today, May 18th, 2-4 and 7-9PM at the KnightAuchmoody Funeral Home, 154 East Main Street, Port Jervis, N.Y. Services will be held May 19th, 11AM in the Pond Eddy Methodist Church. The Rev. Nancy Vonderhorst will officiate. Burial in Glen Spey Cemetery, Glen Spey, New York. Contributions may be made to the Pond Eddy Methodist Church, Pond Eddy, N.Y. 12770.

title: Lott Warns He May Shelve Bill With Gun Restrictions
description: The Senate majority leader, Trent Lott, warned Democrats today that if they did not agree to strictly limit debate and get to a vote on a juvenile-crime bill, preferably by Tuesday night, he might put the legislation on the shelf so that the Senate could proceed to other business.

title: World Briefing
description: ASIA

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANE, MIRIAM COLM (NEE MENDOZA)
description: LANE-Miriam Colm (nee Mendoza). On May 16, 1999. Beloved aunt of Judith Mendoza, Zoe Brown, Betty Viereck. Dear stepmother to Robert and Susan Lane, Harriet Lane, Arthur and DeDee Lane, Richard and Susan Lane. Cherished sister-in-law of Lynn Pressman Raymond. Grandmother and great grandmother. President of William I. Sirovich Memorial Association, she was a special lady and a great friend to all. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street on Tuesday evening 6-8 PM. Funeral Wednesday 1:30 PM. In lieu of flowers please send a donation to the Sirovich Senior Center, 331 East 12 Street, NYC 10003.

title: Making a First-Place Team Better
description: George Steinbrenner was host of a staff meeting after the Yankees' game on Sunday, and as always, he wanted answers, he wanted input, he wanted accountability, and he probably wanted to yell at somebody. The Yankees are 21-15 and good enough to win the American League East, but they have been playing far less effectively than anyone expected, including the players themselves.

title: Decongestant Is Found Useless for Young Fliers' Earaches
description: A new study finds that giving children a decongestant does nothing to ease the earaches they often suffer during takeoffs and landings, or, indirectly, the headaches that some neighboring passengers sustain from the crying that follows.

title: A Brand-New Old Guard Presides at Cannes
description: Just before heading into his news conference to discuss his film ''Felicia's Journey,'' Atom Egoyan sat in all black sipping morning Champagne as he fielded a ringing cell phone. (He guessed this must be a call from the nanny.) He acknowledged the link between his new film, adapted from a novel by William Trevor, and his own previous ''Family Viewing.''

title: Q & A
description: Bends in the River

title: A Passion That Won't Stay on the Ground
description: Dancegoers were held spellbound by a 19th-century tale of love, duty, revenge and mysticism when American Ballet Theater once again presented ''La Bayadere'' on Saturday night at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: Climate Experts' New Worry: Altered Air Patterns
description: Scientists have long been convinced that global warming, whether natural or caused by human action, would amount to more than a simple, uniform rise in temperature. One response of the climate system to warming, for instance, might be the creation of new patterns of large-scale atmospheric circulation -- the big, swirling global air currents that dictate where it is warm and cold, wet and dry, and where storms go.

title: Philippine Airlines Gets New Ultimatum
description: In yet another twist in one of Asia's longest-running corporate dramas, Joseph E. Estrada, the President of the Philippines, has given the embattled owner of Philippine Airlines a week to come up with $200 million for the debt-ridden company.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  NEAGLE, JULIA S.
description: NEAGLE-Julia S.. A Memorial Service for Julia S. Neagle who died January 22, 1999 will be held Saturday, May 22nd at 2:30PM at St. Luke's Church, 18 James Lane, East Hampton, New York.

title: Philips to Buy Stake in Korean Business
description: Royal Philips Electronics N.V., Europe's largest maker of consumer electronics, said today that it would buy half of LG Group's flat-panel display business for about $1.6 billion, a record foreign investment in South Korea.

title: Accounts
description: * CG Technologies, Brea, Calif., a unit of Ericsson, the Swedish telecommunications company, to Bozell Worldwide Southern California, Costa Mesa, Calif., a unit of True North Communications, for the American introduction of its new Cybergenie PC cordless phone system. Billings were estimated at $5 million.

title: Market Place; Soros Advisers To Establish Separate Firm
description: Three top investment specialists at Soros Fund Management, the hedge fund company headed by the billionaire investor George Soros, are leaving the company to start their own investment firm.

title: Weining Journal; Habitat Nearly Full Leaves People's Lives Empty
description: Deep in the ravaged mountains of southwest China, one of nature's jewels improbably endures, a shallow grassy lake that is a crucial wintering ground for dozens of species of migratory waterfowl.

title: ISRAELIS CHOOSE A NEW LEADER AND REMAKE THEIR PARLIAMENT
description: Israelis overwhelmingly elected Ehud Barak, the Labor Party leader, as their Prime Minister on Monday, rejecting the tumultuous leadership of Benjamin Netanyahu, whose galvanizing character has dominated Israel for three years.

title: Corrections
description: A table in Circuits on Thursday with examples of travel prices found in Web searches for various itineraries misstated the type of flights available on British Airways from New York to Milan and from Rome to New York. Each flight involved a stopover; the flights were not nonstop.

title: Tenants Sue Landlord, Alleging Toxic Mold
description: Tenants of two apartment buildings on the East Side of Manhattan have sued their landlord, alleging that toxic mold has sickened hundreds of people and possibly hastened the deaths of others.

title: Reviving Tradition, Tribe Kills a Whale
description: With repeated thrusts from steel harpoons and two finishing shots from a .50-caliber armor-piercing assault rifle, the Makah Indian tribe today conducted the first legal killing of a gray whale in American waters in nearly 75 years.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: SUGAR FALLS SHARPLY. Sugar prices fell amid expectations that a recent increase in producer selling would continue at a time of weak demand. In New York, sugar for July delivery fell 0.27 cent, to 4.63 cents a pound.

title: General Dynamics to Acquire Gulfstream
description: The General Dynamics Corporation, a military contractor that specializes in making nuclear submarines, surface ships and tanks, announced yesterday that it would acquire the Gulfstream Aerospace Corporation, a maker of corporate jets, for $5.3 billion in a deal that returns General Dynamics to a business it once shed.

title: Should High School Be Abolished?
description: To the Editor:

title: Should High School Be Abolished?
description: To the Editor:

title: Norman Foster to Redesign Boston's Museum of Fine Arts
description: Sir Norman Foster, the 1999 Pritzker Prize-winning architect who oversaw the recent redesign of the Reichstag in Berlin, has been commissioned to produce a master plan for the expansion and renovation of the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCWHORTER, CHARLES K.
description: McWHORTER-Charles K.. Age 77, May 10, 1999, from injuries sustained in an automobile accident in Hyannis, MA. Loving brother of Susanna Reckard and brother-inlaw to, Phyllis Mann, uncle to Scott, Frank, Matthew, Charles, Mark, Cheryl, Joseph and Michael. Graduated University of West Virginia, Harvard Law School, 1949. Served in WW II as a lieutenant in the Third Army under General George S. Patton, received Bronze Star and Purple Heart with two Citations. Chairman of the National Young Republican Club from 1955 to 1957, Chief Administrative Assistant to Vice President Richard M. Nixon from 1957 to 1961, former member of the National Council of the Arts, former President, Vice Chairman and Director of American Ballet Theater, Director, Alvin Ailey Dance Company and numerous other music, arts and dance companies. Trustee since 1966, of Interlochen Center for the Arts, Interlochen, MI, and ex officio President of Interlochen Alumni Association where he underwrote the cost of a rehearsal hall, winterized the lodge, fitness center, recreational halls, auditorium, studio and renovation of onsite summmer cabins. Executive Assistant and attorney, AT&T, from 1961 until 1987. Active in Republican politics, renowned for his encyclopedic knowledge and photographic memory of election results, and elected and former officials on the national, state and local levels. Memorial Services are planned at Interlochen Center for the Arts on August 6, 7 and 8, 1999, in Washington, DC; call Mr. Dell Smith, (202) 822-8300 for place and date, and in NYC, call Mr. E. Lisk Wyckoff, Jr., (212) 715-9519 for place and date. Those wishing to do so may make contributions in his memory to the Interlochen Center for the Arts, Interlochen, McWHORTER-Charles K. The trustees, artists and staff of American Ballet Theatre mourn the passing of their friend and colleague, Charles K. McWhorter, a trustee since 1970, as well as a past president and vice chairman. Charlie will be remembered always for his great kindness and dedication to ABT. Hamilton E. James, Chairman Anne M. Tatlock, President Kevin McKenzie, Artistic Director

title: America's Love for Guns
description: To the Editor:

title: WASTE MANAGEMENT TO BUY ALLIED'S CANADIAN ASSETS
description: Waste Management Inc., the largest United States trash-collection company, agreed yesterday to buy the Canadian solid-waste operations of Browning-Ferris Industries Inc. for $501 million in cash from Allied Waste Industries, which is buying Browning-Ferris. Allied Waste, the No. 3 United States waste company, said it was selling Browning's Canadian assets to focus on its United States-based solid-waste operations. Allied Waste agreed to buy Browning-Ferris in March for $9.1 billion in cash and assumed debt. Waste Management already is the biggest trash hauler in Canada. Browning's Canadian operations generate annual revenue of about $200 million and include collection and recycling operations, transfer stations and landfills.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHITEMAN, IRVING, MD
description: CHITEMAN-Irving, MD. On May 16, 1999. Loving husband of the late Nellie. Beloved father of Barry and Robert. Dear brother of the late George, Sally and Leah. Beloved family physician of 68 years who was respected by both his patients and colleagues. Visitation Tuesday evening 7-9PM. Services Wednesday 12:30PM at I.J. Morris, Inc., 1895 Flatbush Ave, Bklyn. (1 block north of Kings Highway).

title: KOSOVO UPDATE
description: COMBAT

title: A Bold Rush To Sell Drugs To the Shy; Huge Market Expected To Treat Social Phobia
description: Hasan Yildiz has never visited a friend's house because he has never had a friend. He has never dated, either. And he never goes to bars, restaurants or ball games because his chest tightens and he breaks into a sweat when he is around people.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIS, SUSAN
description: DAVIS-Susan. The Board of Governors and the Members of Glen Oaks Club express their deepest sorrow at the passing of their member, Susan Davis, and extend their heartfelt sympathy to her husband, Gary, and their family. Board of Governors Richard A. Horowitz, President

title: Gandhi as Premier? Her Party's in Turmoil
description: Sonia Gandhi, the Italian-born widow who inherited the mantle of India's founding political dynasty, submitted her resignation today as leader of the Congress Party after three party leaders revolted against her candidacy for Prime Minister.

title: SYNETIC AGREES TO BUY MEDICAL MANAGER
description: Synetic Inc., a provider of communications services for the health care industry, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Medical Manager Corporation for $1.4 billion in stock. Synetic, based in Elmwood Park, N.J., will pay 0.625 share for each share of Medical Manager, valuing the company at $59.6875 a share, based on Friday's stock price. Medical Manager's shares jumped 42 percent, gaining $14, to $47.75, in Nasdaq trading, where Synetic's shares plunged $4.50, to $91. Medical Manager, based in Tampa, Fla., provides information systems that help doctors and other health care providers communicate with one another.

title: The Female Condition, Re-explored 30 Years Later
description: THE WHOLE WOMAN

title: AT&T Digital Music Unit Loses More Than Half of Its Workers
description: In a blow to AT&T's efforts on the digital music frontier, more than half the employees of its A2B music initiative are leaving the company to join another venture.

title: Walton Talks Himself Into Post-Season Form
description: Bill Walton was so jazzed for a Knicks-Indiana game last month on NBC that he held a basketball for the entire telecast. ''I caressed it all game,'' he said yesterday from Indianapolis. ''I could never hold onto it enough.''

title: Gay Couple Allowed To Adopt Second Child
description: Two men who became the state's first gay couple to jointly adopt a child in December 1997 were granted their second adoption yesterday, the men said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JEAN, DR. PRISCILLA
description: JEAN-Dr. Priscilla. We will miss the wit, clarity of thought and resourcefulness of our beloved colleague, Dr. Priscilla Jean. Her legacy is the success of the many learning disabled students she taught. Jeannette Jansky, Katherine Hurd, Sharon Drucker and Jeane Gazdag

title: United States Roster Reveals No Surprises
description: There were no surprises on the 20-player American roster that was announced yesterday by Coach Tony DiCicco. The deadline for announcing the roster is June 9, but DiCicco wanted to name the team early to prepare for the tournament, which will open June 19 at Giants Stadium in East Rutherford, N.J.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VELKOFF, SYLVIA
description: VELKOFF-Sylvia. Beloved wife of the late Hyman, mother of Kenneth, Jan and CLiff. Sister of Beatrice Fields and the late Samuel and Leon Black. Services Thursday 11 A.M. at ''The Riverside'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave.

title: I.N.S. Releases Jailed Refugees and Will Let Them in U.S.
description: Four Kosovar refugees, who had been sent to jails in Pennsylvania for having misled immigration officials in Macedonia in order to reach the United States, have been released and sent back to the refugee camp at Fort Dix, N.J., where they will remain eligible for residency in the United States, a spokesman for the Immigration and Naturalization Service said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLAUS, IDA
description: KLAUS-Ida. Of New York City, on May 17th, 1999 after a long illness. Beloved daughter of Sarah and Michael, sister of Sam and Jack, and cousin of many. Funeral service Wednesday, May 19th, at noon at Campbell's, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street.

title: European Drug Makers Agree to Speed Merger
description: Hoechst A.G. and Rhone-Poulenc S.A. have agreed to complete their $22 billion merger in November to create the world's biggest drug maker, accelerating their combination. The Paris-based Rhone-Poulenc will offer three shares for every four Hoechst shares, giving the German company's owners 53 percent of Aventis, the new company.

title: Robert Goldman, 60, Bridge Ace Who Won 4 World Team Titles
description: Robert Goldman, the winner of four world bridge titles, died of a heart attack on Sunday. He was 60 and lived in Highland Village, Tex.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The state's legitimate interest in saving money provides no justification for its decision to discriminate among equally eligible citizens.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCGREEVY, THOMAS P.
description: McGREEVY-Thomas P.. Of West New York, N.J. Formerly of New York City. On May 17, 1999. Husband of Ursula (nee Krauss). Father of Christian. Brother of Kathleen Palmer, Eileen Wipfler and Angela Clark. Also survived by nieces and nephews. Funeral Thursday, May 20, 10AM from the Vainieri Funeral Home, 5923 Kennedy Blvd (corner 60 St), North Bergen, N.J. Funeral Mass Saint Joseph of the Palisades R.C. Church, West New York, 11AM. Visitation Wednesday, 3-7PM. Donations American Cancer Society.

title: St. John's Chooses a State Judge To Be Its Next Law School Dean
description: St. John's University yesterday named an alumnus, trustee and former faculty member -- Joseph W. Bellacosa, the senior associate judge of the New York State Court of Appeals -- as its next law school dean, effective August 2000.

title: Clinical Research Is a Plus for Patients
description: To the Editor:

title: Terror Suspect's Indictment To Be Sought as Talks Fail
description: After eight months of secret negotiations in which the Government sought to win the cooperation of a suspected chief lieutenant to Osama bin Laden, talks have broken down between the parties, and Federal officials have decided to seek his indictment, lawyers said yesterday.

title: Ford Pickups' Air Pollution To Be Cut to That of Cars
description: The Ford Motor Company said today that starting this autumn its new pickup trucks, including the nation's best-selling vehicle, would produce no more air pollution than that of cars.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  UNGER, LAURENCE NEIL, DR.
description: UNGER-Laurence Neil, Dr.. We miss and love you, by all who laughed with you, on this day especially

title: Kyriacos Demetriou, Barber Wedded to Tradition, Dies at 80
description: Kyriacos Demetriou, a master barber whose old-fashioned barber shop on the Upper West Side of Manhattan was such an authentic butterfly in amber that it went into the Museum of the City of New York when he retired in 1996, died on Friday. He was 80.

title: Israel's Battle Fatigue
description: The leftist Meretz party presented the political commercial most insulting to Benjamin Netanyahu during this election campaign. It showed him dancing furiously, faster and faster, to the music of a klezmer band whose musicians were ultra-Orthodox politicians. It was merciless mockery of Israel's Prime Minister.

title: Conference Divided Over High-Dose Breast Cancer Treatment
description: Cancer experts at an international conference here today were in such disagreement over the best way to treat advanced breast cancer that one, Dr. Karen Antman of Columbia University, said she was jokingly advised by her colleagues to wear a flak jacket while making her presentation.

title: Sound of F.C.C. Silence in a Big Merger
description: In all of the analysis of yesterday's $37 billion merger of U S West Inc., the smallest of the regional Bell phone giants, and Global Crossing Ltd., the international communications upstart, the most telling commentary may have been the sound of silence coming from the Federal Communications Commission.

title: Bomb, Arrests and School Plot Unnerve Small Michigan City
description: A third of the desks sat empty today at Holland Woods Middle School, which was closed on Friday along with the 22 other schools in this district after four students were accused of planning a mass killing and, in what may be a separate incident, a bomb was found outside the school.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRYSTOWSKY, FLORENCE
description: PRYSTOWSKY-Florence. Died May 17, 1999 at age 90 after a heroic battle against cancer. Beloved wife of the late David. Devoted mother of Seymour (Cochava) and Steven (Gail). Loving grandmother of Elan (Galila), Donna, Aliza and Shana. Burial in Israel; Shiva in U.S. Dedicated her life to teaching Torah. Any donations may be made to Beth MiriamBeth Jacob School, 2126 Barnes Avenue, Bronx, New York.

title: What Fills a Child's Garden of Fears
description: Things may still go ''bump'' in the night, but school-age children are actually more afraid of sharks and snakes, according to an Ohio State University study examining children's fears and anxieties.

title: Knicks and Hawks Are Aching for the Tip-Off
description: Patrick Ewing was grimacing and laboring like a man staggering through the desert by the end of Sunday's Game 5 in Miami. Worn down by injury, depleted by exhaustion, he pushed the boundaries of his threshold for pain to help win a first-round playoff series for the Knicks that had everything riding on the outcome.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHANLEY, BROTHER MATTHEW (JOHN), F.S.C.
description: SHANLEY - Brother Matthew (John), F.S.C.. Age 74, of Lincroft, New Jersey, died on Saturday, the feast day of St. John Baptist De La Salle, founder of the Brothers of the Christian Schools, at De La Salle Hall, Lincroft. His teaching assignments included St. Cecilia's, Sacred Heart, St. Jerome's and Holy Name Schools, St. Peter's, Cardinal Spellman and St. Raymond's High Schools. He was a dedicated & knowledgeable devotee of the tenor John McCormick. Even after suffering a severe stroke at the end of 1981, which effected his memory, he managed to retain much information about Mr. McCormick. Through friends and associates he managed to continue his interest in the tenor and impart some of his knowledge about the man. The wake will be held at De La Salle Hall, Lincroft on Tuesday from 7-9 P.M. and Wednesday 2-4 and 6:30 to 7:30 P.M. The Funeral Liturgy will be celebrated on Wednesday at 7:30 P.M. at De La Salle Hall. The interment will be held at St. Gabriel's Cemetery, Marlboro, on Thursday leaving from De La Salle Hall at 10:00 A.M. Memorial donations to De La Salle Nursing Development, 810 Newman Springs Rd, Lincroft, N.J. 07738 would be appreciated.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE YEN FALLS. The dollar rose against the yen as Treasury yields climbed to their highest level in a year, making United States bonds more attractive to the Japanese. In New York, the dollar rose to 123.49 yen, from 122.73.

title: SECURITY FIRST TO BUY 2 ON-LINE BANKING CONCERNS
description: The Security First Technologies Corporation agreed yesterday to buy two on-line banking companies for $1.4 billion and also formed a strategic alliance with Intuit Inc. Security First will buy the Brussels-based FICS Group N.V., a privately held software company specializing in corporate-finance solutions, and the Edify Corporation, a Santa Clara, Calif., on-line banking software company. Security First, an Atlanta-based developer of Internet applications for financial products, will issue 20 million shares for the FICS deal, which is valued at $1.08 billion based on Security First's closing price on Friday. Under its agreement, Intuit, which is based in Mountain View, Calif., will invest $50 million for about 971,000 shares of Security First.

title: Avrett, Free Gets Dewar's Assignment
description: Bacardi-Martini U.S.A., in Miami, said yesterday that it had awarded the American creative part of the Dewar's white label Scotch whisky account, with billings estimated at $15 million to $20 million, to Avrett, Free & Ginsberg in New York, part of Bozell Worldwide, a unit of True North Communications.

title: Job Fears Push I.R.S. Workers To Relax Effort
description: Internal Revenue Service tax collectors, under intense pressure from Congress to be nicer to taxpayers, have drastically scaled back efforts to collect unpaid taxes, newly available statistics show.

title: Bombing May Have Hardened China's Line
description: China's leaders are continuing to condemn the United States in harsh terms as seeking global domination in the wake of the NATO attack on the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade, reflecting what may be an important shift in China's view of global politics.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CASEY, JAMES J.
description: CASEY-James J.., on May 16, 1999. Husband of Helen M. (Donahoe). Beloved father of James, Robert, Alice Dean and Helena Dempsey. Also survived by six grand-and four great-grandchildren. Retired from NYC Fire Department 1956. Reposing Flynn Memorial Home, 325 South Broadway, Yonkers, NY. Mass St. Denis Church on Wednesday, 10 AM. Interment Calvary Cemetery. Visiting Tuesday, 2-4, 7-9 PM.

title: Wal-Mart Settles A Hefty Lawsuit
description: Wal-Mart Stores Inc., the world's largest retailer, agreed on Sunday to settle a lawsuit that produced a $624 million jury award over the breakup of a distribution partnership with a Mexican company.

title: Sports of The Times; Suddenly, Ewing Has A 'Presence'
description: DID you hear what Steve Smith had to say about Patrick Ewing after Smith and the Atlanta Hawks finished off Detroit and set the Knicks in their playoff sights?

title: Chancellor Seeks City Council's Support for His School Initiatives
description: Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew asked the City Council yesterday to find the money he needs to carry out plans to end the promotion of failing students, take over the worst of the city's failing schools and reduce class size in the middle grades.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: The Duke's Crew And Dr. Crew Too

title: Surgeons Leaving The O.R. For the Office
description: The ancient art of surgery is on the move again. For hundreds of years most surgical procedures were done at home on the kitchen table. Only in the last century did advances in medical technology move them into hospital operating rooms.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANE, MIRIAM (MITZI)
description: LANE-Miriam (Mitzi). President and Founding Board Member. Tirelessly devoted to the Sirovich Senior Center for 65 years. As a young woman, she personally gave her time to help poor immigrants on the Lower East Side with food and money through the Rose Sirovich Relief Society. A leader and a friend. We will all miss her. William I. Sirovich Memorial Association

title: CHARTER ONE TO BUY ST. PAUL BANCORP FOR $1.2 BILLION
description: Charter One Financial Inc., the nation's fourth-largest savings and loan company, agreed to buy St. Paul Bancorp for $1.2 billion in stock to expand in Chicago. Cleveland-based Charter One will pay 0.945 share for each share of Chicago-based St. Paul. That values St. Paul shares at $29.12 each, compared with yesterday's closing price of $24.6875. The deal was announced after the stock market closed. Charter One ended at $30.1875, up 53.125 cents. Charter One, the holding company for Charter One Bank, has $24.6 billion in assets and 340 branches in Ohio, Michigan, New York, Massachusetts and Vermont.

title: Editors' Note
description: A picture in Science Times last Tuesday about research on tornadoes showed a funnel in Texas. The Times has since learned that the picture, supplied by an independent photo agency, was altered by computer, to lengthen the funnel, sometime before transmission by the agency.

title: Financial Holdings Stay Steady For Clinton, but Legal Fees Soar
description: President Clinton's financial holdings have remained steady throughout the last year, but because of his impeachment his legal bills soared, according to financial disclosure forms released today by the White House.

title: British Press Allies On Ground Troops
description: Britain is renewing its pressure on NATO allies to consider a land attack in Kosovo so refugees can return home before winter sets in. At NATO headquarters and with fellow foreign ministers from the European Union, Foreign Minister Robin Cook has revived an earlier British proposal to send ground troops into Kosovo without a peace agreement. The troops would be sent in after weeks more of allied air bombardment once Yugoslav forces were weakened to the point at which they could only put up scattered resistance.

title: NBC Expands Drama Lineup for Fall
description: NBC announced a new fall program schedule yesterday that signaled a significant shift away from half-hour comedies and toward drama, some based in comedy.

title: Heeding the Warnings From Dangerous Dogs
description: Now that people and pets are spending more time outdoors, the incidence of dog bites is about to soar, which is why the Humane Society of the United States in conjunction with other concerned agencies is once again urging the public to learn how to act around dogs and what to do to prevent dog bites.

title: Council Faults Buildings Department Over Elevator Inspections
description: Three years after Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani suspended three-quarters of New York City's elevator inspectors in a crackdown on corruption, the Department of Buildings has still not fully instituted a system of internal audits and other safeguards to prevent graft, according to the results of a City Council investigation released yesterday.

title: Metro Business; Lefrak Set to Build A New Office Tower
description: A year after breaking ground on one of the region's first speculative office buildings since the market collapsed in the late 1980's, the Lefrak Organization said it will break ground today on another building without tenants lined up.

title: Columbia Giving Awards to Reporter and Novelist
description: Charlie LeDuff, a reporter for The New York Times, and Joan Didion, a novelist and contributor to The New Yorker magazine and The New York Review of Books, are scheduled to receive awards from Columbia University's Graduate School of Journalism today.

title: Mutombo Is Up For the Challenge
description: If the Knicks-Heat matchup was prime-time drama, the Knicks-Hawks is akin to MacNeil and Lehrer reuniting. New York and Atlanta have not played against each other in the post-season since 1971, and their current rivalry is based on a litany of grind-it-out, halfcourt games that cause viewers to channel-surf for Allen Iverson and Kobe Bryant.

title: Merger Is Set By Makers of Farm Machines
description: The deal that was struck today to combine the Case Corporation and New Holland N.V., two of the world's largest makers of farm and construction equipment, is just the latest effort to consolidate an embattled farm industry.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the graphic designer P. Scott Makela on Saturday referred incorrectly to a digital typeface he designed. The name, Dead History, should have been capitalized as a trademark.

title: Enforce Campaign Laws
description: To the Editor:

title: Words Of Love, Priced To Sell
description: There is no more poignant moment in American literary history than that recorded by Nathaniel Hawthorne in June 1853.He was 49 and had been married to his wife, Sophia, since 1842:

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about a visit by President Mohammad Khatami of Iran to Saudi Arabia misidentified the Saudi leader shown greeting him. It was King Fahd, not Crown Prince Abdullah.

title: 'Smart Toilet' Keeps Track of Health
description: In Tokyo, the electronics giant Matsushita is working on a prototype house of the future chock-full of gadgets to keep track of the owner's health -- right down to the toilet.

title: Winnick Weaves Single Trans-Atlantic Cable Into Communications Empire
description: Two years ago, Gary Winnick, a financier with little experience in telecommunications, undertook a project to lay an optical fiber cable across the Atlantic Ocean.

title: Odom Opts for the Pros
description: With the blessing of his coach and some advice from Kobe Bryant, Lamar Odom left the University of Rhode Island yesterday after just one season to enter the National Basketball Association draft.

title: Goldman Sachs tries something new: promoting itself to the public as a brand worth knowing.
description: GOLDMAN SACHS GROUP, which went public earlier this month when it sold shares, plans to go public again, this time with its first global advertising campaign.

title: New Jersey Fans Will Hear Crack, Not Ping, of the Bat
description: The movement within college baseball to return exclusively to wood bats took a swing in that direction yesterday. All six teams that received bids to the Mid-Atlantic Regional of the National Collegiate Athletic Association's Division III tournament have agreed among themselves to use wood bats.

title: A Bit of Diplomatic Tact And a Study in Contrasts
description: Franz Welser-Most's New York Philharmonic concert on Thursday was curious but tactical. Problem: how to fill out a program already crowded with Bruckner's Fifth Symphony. The answer: something short enough to make a comfortable two-hour evening yet long enough to justify an intermission.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EWELL, JAMES
description: EWELL-James. Age 62. Passed away on May 17, 1999 after a long battle with lung cancer. He'll surely be missed by many people. A kind man with a heart of gold. Howard Koeppel, Mark Hsiao

title: Jousting With Tornadoes
description: To the Editor:

title: Political Stars Fail to Save Ferraro Benefit
description: Everything was set: A room at the Yale Club was reserved for tomorrow evening, a formal invitation was issued by New York's two United States Senators, and, best of all, there was the promise of an appearance by President Clinton. It was all in the service of helping Geraldine A. Ferraro raise money to pay back the debt from her unsuccessful Senate campaign last year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIS, REV. WILLIAM J.
description: DAVIS-Rev. William J.. The Diocese of Brooklyn announces the death of the pastor emeritus of Our Lady of the Miraculous Medal Church, 62-81 60th Place, Ridgewood, on May 17. Reposing in the Lower Church at Our Lady of the Miraculous Medal, Tuesday, May 18, from 2 to 5 and 7 to 9 P.M., and on Wednesday, May 19, from 2 to 5 P.M. Mass of Transferral on Wednesday, May 19, at 7:30 P.M. Funeral Mass on Thursday, May 20th, at 10:30 A.M. All priests are invited to concelebrate. He was a member of the Priests' Purgatorial Society. Most Rev. Thomas V. Daily Bishop of Brooklyn

title: Mexican Tourists Warned
description: Mexican officials say they may issue a travel advisory about the dangers of visiting Houston, where three Mexican citizens have been killed by police officers since 1997, according to Mexican news reports, which did not name the officials.

title: Raise Teacher Standards
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NAREFF, ARTHUR A., M.D.
description: NAREFF-Arthur A., M.D.. The entire Beth Israel Medical Center family mourns the passing of our friend and former colleague, Arthur A. Nareff, M.D., a long-time member of Beth Israel's department of medicine. To Dr. Nareff's family and friends, and all who loved him, we offer our heartfelt condolences. Matthew E. Fink, M.D. President and CEO Stephen G. Baum. M.D Chairman, Dept. of Medicine Henry S. Singman, M.D. President of the Medical Board Robert L. Salant, M.D. President, Doctors Alumni Assoc.

title: The Importance of Lying
description: To the Editor:

title: PRECISION CASTPARTS TO ACQUIRE WYMAN-GORDON
description: The Precision Castparts Corporation agreed yesterday to acquire the Wyman-Gordon Company, a maker of forgings and castings, for $721 million. It will also assume debt of $104 million. The deal creates a company that will be a key supplier of both castings and forgings for aircraft engines. Shares of Wyman-Gordon soared $5.6875, to $18.9375, on the New York Stock Exchange, where shares of Precision Castparts , fell 62.5 cents, to $40.375. Precision Castparts, based in Portland, Ore., had revenue of $1.47 billion for the year that ended on March 28. Wyman-Gordon, based in Grafton, Mass., had 1998 sales of $752.9 million.

title: 'I Remain Loyal'
description: To the Editor:

title: Macho Literary Update: Big-Game Healer
description: YOU think you're traveling too much for work? Consider the life of Dr. William B. Karesh, a wildlife veterinarian.

title: Three Japanese Banks Agree on a Merger
description: Three Japanese banks -- Daiwa Bank Ltd., Bank of Osaka Ltd. and Bank of Kinki Ltd. -- plan to merge next April 1, the Japanese news service Kyodo reported yesterday. The three banks, all based in Osaka, are expected to announce the merger plans this week.

title: Patterns
description: A Pants Flowering

title: Island Continent's Challenge /23,000 Miles of Poorly Guarded Coastline : Australia Takes Steps to Halt Illegal Immigrants
description: SYDNEY  Australia's reputation for having an easygoing, affluent lifestyle has its downside, especially when many countries in Asia and the Middle East are struggling with economic difficulties and political tensions.

title: Pataki's Evasiveness Feeds Speculation That He May Run for Senate
description: He didn't really say anything. He hedged, hinted and dodged, but in the end, Gov. George E. Pataki said absolutely nothing today about either his political plans or a gathering shrouded in secrecy that he has called for next Monday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIPTON, GERALD
description: LIPTON-Gerald. 75. Of Wilmette, Il. Beloved husband of 47 years of Geraldine (nee Sholder); cherished father of Allan and Richard (Amy); adored and adoring grandfather of Lianna and Justin; brother of Leonard (June). In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory to WilPower Inc., 444 Frontage Rd., Northfield, Il 60093 would be appreciated.

title: PRIZE ENERGY TO ACQUIRE PIONEER OIL AND GAS FIELDS
description: The Pioneer Natural Resources Company, which explores for oil in the United States, Canada and Argentina, agreed yesterday to sell oil and natural gas fields in Texas and Oklahoma to the closely held Prize Energy Corporation for $245 million in cash and preferred stock to reduce its debt. Two Pioneer board members and one executive have resigned to run Prize, whose primary assets will be the 400 fields it is buying from Pioneer. Prize will pay Pioneer $215 million in cash and $30 million in preferred stock, giving Pioneer a 32 percent stake in Prize.

title: 3 On-Line Book Retailers Cut Prices on Best Sellers
description: In an escalating battle of the books, Amazon.com Inc., the on-line retailer, cut the prices on best-selling books by 50 percent yesterday, a move that was matched hours later by its Internet rivals, Barnesandnoble.com and Borders.com, all of whom will almost certainly lose money on the bargain sales.

title: Beautiful Baby? Just Wait Till She's a Sexy 6-Year-Old
description: Who are the main players in the country's proliferating baby beauty contests? The stars, those painted, besequined tots whose routines owe a lot to Las Vegas and more than a little to the strippers of yesteryear? Their mothers, who are also their managers and taskmistresses? The entrepreneurs who make a living out of show-biz hopefuls, three million of them, age 3 months to 16 years?

title: Quiet Jubilation That Unlike the Last Time, Washington's Preferred Candidate Won
description: The Clinton Administration today greeted the results of the Israeli election with public decorum, congratulating the winner, Ehud Barak, but with private satisfaction that Benjamin Netanyahu had lost.

title: Louima Jury Hears Officer Describe Bloody Gloves
description: A police officer testified yesterday that a fellow officer charged with torturing Abner Louima had borrowed a pair of gloves from him, and that the gloves were returned with blood on them. Investigators later identified that blood as Mr. Louima's.

title: Police Bias Case Spins a Web of Venom
description: There are many allegations of racial discrimination and retaliation in the lawsuit filed earlier this month by police officers here, and the document is full of bitter complaints against the police chief and the city.

title: Lonely but Profound
description: To the Editor:

title: Battered Pioneer Presses On for U.S.
description: At halftime of the United States' 5-0 exhibition victory over the Netherlands on Thursday, Michelle Akers approached Coach Tony DiCicco and said, ''I have to come out.'' Nothing more was said, and DiCicco immediately found a replacement. Akers had a familiar flushed, hollow look of exhaustion. After so many years together on the soccer field, DiCicco can read her face as if it were an X-ray.

title: VITAL SIGNS: PRO & CON; Are Sports Drinks Better Than Water?
description: Q. When exercising in warm weather, are sports drinks necessary to stay hydrated? JULIE WALSH

title: New Pressure For Whitman On Abortions
description: Hoping that the political pressure of a Senate race will cause Gov. Christine Todd Whitman to yield on the issue, Assembly Republicans have begun their most promising effort yet in a decade-old fight to require parental notification before an abortion can be performed on a minor.

title: Dreaming Up Gadgets That Play Doctor
description: Every week, a group of doctors, engineers, scientists and computer specialists get together at the University of Rochester to talk over ideas that might sound outlandish to most people, including the notion that the future of medicine lies in devices that are high-tech, cheap and controlled by patients.

title: Fire Under Street Sends Manhole Lids Aloft
description: An underground electrical fire on the East Side sent four manhole covers flying into the air yesterday morning and released enough carbon monoxide to force the partial evacuation of an apartment building nearby.

title: A Picasso Is Severely Slashed By a Dutch Mental Patient
description: A Dutch psychiatric patient wielding a kitchen knife severely slashed a Picasso painting called ''Nude in Front of the Garden'' in Amsterdam's Stedelijk Museum of Modern Art on Sunday, then went to a newspaper office to brag about his act. The police were called to the office, where the man was arrested.

title: U.S. Arrests An Australian In Spying Case
description: A former Australian military intelligence analyst was charged today with trying to sell more than 700 highly classified American defense documents to an undercover F.B.I. agent who posed as an overseas spy, the Justice Department said.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Court to Decide Whether States Can Reveal Information on Drivers
description: The Supreme Court broadened its exploration of Federalism issues today by agreeing to decide whether Congress had violated states' rights when it prohibited state motor vehicle agencies from revealing personal information about drivers who did not consent to the disclosure.

title: Redistricting Ruling
description: The Supreme Court ruled that a Congressional district could have a concentration of black voters, as long as the motivation was political.

title: Book, Movie, War, Reality
description: Taking a detour into the absurd, a Yugoslavia official, Goran Matic, claimed last week that there are no real Kosovar refugees. That the people we see acting like refugees are just that -- actors, 3,000 to 4,000 of them, getting paid $5.50 a day by NATO. The way it was in the film ''Wag the Dog.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEMETRIOU, KYRIACOS
description: DEMETRIOU - Kyriacos. ''Mr. Kay'' loved life, work, people, judging them shrewdly. After retirement continued meeting customer-friends, recently re-enacting a 1940s Churchill speech for me amidst haircutting. Missed already Leonard A. Gordon

title: Clemens Set To Return At Fenway
description: There will be a harmonic convergence Thursday night at Fenway Park, where many Calvinists have believed in fate: Roger Clemens, a five-time Cy Young award winner, is expected to pitch against the Boston Red Sox, in perhaps the last game managed by Don Zimmer.

title: Clinical Research Is a Plus for Patients; Detection Incentives
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOODBREAD, SOPHIE ROMER
description: GOODBREAD - Sophie Romer. Born on June 13, 1909 in New York City, died on May 5, 1999. Wife of David Goodbread, mother of Julia Motylinski, and Joseph Goodbread, grandmother of Miriam Roiter. She was an example and a teacher to us all.

title: U.N. Team Arrives to Study Kosovars' Plight
description: A United Nations mission has arrived here on its way to Kosovo, where it hopes to establish the fate of tens of thousands of refugees in the Serbian province.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOUT, HERBERT LEE
description: HOUT-Herbert Lee., 69. Beloved husband of Phyllis E., son of Lilly, brother of Lawrence, Betty Smith and Jeanine Cole, in Houston, Texas, on May 17th, after a long illness; survived by four children, seven grandchildren and six greatgrandchildren.

title: Truce With Yeltsin Seen When House Votes on Premier
description: After the fireworks of a failed impeachment attempt, the Russian Parliament's vote on Wednesday on a new Prime Minister promises to be surprisingly tame -- and it is likely to be a ''yes'' vote.

title: Hillsdown Chief Backs Bid by Candover
description: The chief executive of Hillsdown Holdings P.L.C., Michael Teacher, said yesterday that he would support an acquisition offer from Candover Investments P.L.C., a British private equity company, breaking with other directors who back an agreement to sell the company for $:750 million ($1.2 billion) to Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst Inc. of Dallas.

title: Corrections
description: The View column in the Westchester section on Sunday, about a Mitzvah Day project organized in the county by the UJA-Federation of New York misstated the number of commandments under traditional Jewish law. The error was also erroneously attributed, later in the article, to Eric Goldschmidt, the project organizer. The commandments number 613, not 617.

title: Blair Under Domestic Pressure on Ground Forces
description: Prime Minister Tony Blair is coming under increasing pressure to use his close friendship with President Clinton to challenge him on the issue of using ground troops in Kosovo.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: I.R.S. Agents Ease Up On Collecting Unpaid Taxes

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSE, MACKAY, VICTORIA
description: ROSE - MACKAY - Victoria. For merly of NYC and Alford, MA. May 2, in Colorado Springs, CO. Daughter of the late B. Holly and Franzeska Rose. Niece of Milton C. Rose of Alford, MA. Services May 17 in Colorado Springs, CO.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOEWENSTEIN, REGINA
description: LOEWENSTEIN-Regina. Passed away May 16th. Survived by beloved sister Martha, special surrogate daughter Patricia Arrington and devoted longtime companions Clara Randolph and Veronica Philbert. Predeceased by her loving and caring parents Frieda and Solomon Loewenstein and adored sister Norma Drabkin. Interment private. A memorial service will be held at the New York Society for Ethical Culture, 2 West 64 Street, on May 20 at 11:00 AM.

title: Metro Business; Gateway to Open Store
description: Gateway 2000, the No. 2 direct seller of personal computers, is to open a Gateway Country store in midtown Manhattan next week, its first store in a major downtown area.

title: Pitching (Surprise) Gives Boston a Boost
description: Almost by way of introduction, Jose Offerman would begin spring training interviews by saying, ''I'm not Mo Vaughn.'' It was not a line from a comedy routine like the one that gave the Broadway play ''I'm Not Rappaport'' its title. The newest member of the Boston Red Sox was simply explaining that no matter how much the team paid him, he was not going to hit home runs and drive in runs the way Vaughn did.

title: British Pressing Partners To Deploy Ground Troops
description: Britain is renewing its pressure on NATO allies to consider a ground attack in Kosovo so that refugees can return home before winter sets in.

title: Foreign Affairs
description: So I'm listening to the radio last week reporting on the stoning of the U.S. Embassy in Beijing, in retaliation for NATO's bombing of China's Belgrade embassy. But I can't help chuckling at the last line of the news report. It quotes China's Minister of Tourism as saying that despite the rock-throwing, China is perfectly safe and American and other tourists shouldn't think of staying away. Translation: We burn U.S. flags, not U.S. dollars.

title: Hewlett-Packard's Profits Exceed Expectations Again
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company reported second-quarter earnings today that beat Wall Street estimates for the third consecutive quarter, although revenue growth remained sluggish. But orders grew by 10 percent, and executives said they expected double-digit revenue growth in the second half of the year.

title: In Prizes for Science and Religion, the Person of Faith Is Richer
description: Despite recent peace negotiations and displays of good fellowship by partisans on both sides, it doesn't look as if the centuries-old row between religion and science is any closer to resolution than it was when Galileo nearly went to the stake for defending the Copernican view of the solar system.

title: OBSERVATORY
description: A New Role for Tobacco

title: A Leap From Childbirth to Ballet Stage
description: As Margaret Tracey floated across the Lincoln Center stage on Sunday afternoon, every line of a perfectly fit ballerina's body where every line ought to be, it was impossible to believe that little more than six months ago she was, as grandmother used to say, great with child.

title: Clinical Research Is a Plus for Patients; Unethical Referrals
description: To the Editor:

title: SHELL TO SELL TRANSOK UNIT TO OGE FOR $527 MILLION
description: The Royal Dutch/Shell Group of Companies said yesterday that it agreed to sell Transok L.L.C. to the OGE Energy Corporation for $527 million. Shell will also assume debt of $173 million. Transok, which is based in Tulsa, Okla., gathers, processes and transports natural gas in Oklahoma. OGE Energy, an electricity and gas concern based in Oklahoma City, will make the purchase through its Enogex Inc. unit. The transaction is part of the reorganization of Shell Oil's downstream gas and power assets in the United States.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CLAYTON, ROBERT HESTER, JR.
description: CLAYTON-Robert Hester, Jr.. Memorial Service being held on Thursday, May 20, 1999 at 5PM at Christ Church, 520 Park Ave., NYC.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EICKELBERG, PROF. W. WARREN B.
description: EICKELBERG-Prof. W. Warren B.., of Amityville, LI on May 15, 1999. Beloved husband of Marilyn Banks Eickelberg. Loving father of William Eickelberg, Peggy Larkin, Dr. Robert Eickelberg, Janet Beshlian, and step-father of David Banks, Jane Banks Stanfield, Stephen Banks and Lawrence Banks. Also survived by nine grandchildren and five step grandchildren. Mr. Eickelberg was a Professor of Biology and Chairman of the Pre-Medical Council at Adelphi University from 1953 to 1996. He also served as Vice President for Development and as consultant to the National Center for Disabilities Services. Widely recognized as an outstanding educator and researcher, Professor Eickelberg was named Professor of Biology Emeritus and Centennial Professor of Life Sciences. Visiting will be Tuesday, 2-4:30 and 79:30 PM at the Powell Funeral Home, Inc., 67 Broadway (Rt 110), Amityville. Mass of Requiem Wednesday, 11:00 AM, St. Mary's Episcopal Church, Amityville. Interment Woodlawn Cemetery, the Bronx. Family will appreciate donations to the W. Warren B. Eickelberg Scholarship Fund at Adelphi University Biology Department, Garden City, NY 11530.

title: Why Squeeze Every Last Penny From the Bankrupt?
description: Early this month, with the support of more than 300 of my colleagues, the House of Representatives approved sweeping changes in our national policy on bankruptcy. Generally, these are much-needed reforms, but one part of the legislation could leave some debtors without enough money for basic needs.

title: Mexico's PRI Party Approves a Primary To Choose Nominee
description: The governing party today formally broke with the tradition of Mexican presidents' handpicking their successors, by approving the first nationwide presidential primary.

title: Saving City Gardens
description: To the Editor:

title: Review Finds Police Union Just Sloppy In Accounting
description: A retired judge hired by the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association to conduct an inquiry into its financial affairs has found only minor problems with the union, whose finances have been the subject of a two-year Federal investigation.

title: Houses With High Ceilings; Home Prices and Demand Soar, as 'For Sale' Signs Dwindle
description: Jeri Kelley had a home buyer coming in 10 minutes. She tapped the customer's price range into the computer -- $450,000 to $480,000 -- to see what was available in this genteel town on Long Island Sound, home to Paul Newman, Martha Stewart and other luminaries.

title: Court Gives Wriggle Room To Racially Drawn Districts
description: Revisiting a much-disputed North Carolina Congressional district, the Supreme Court ruled today with surprising unanimity that even a conscious concentration of black voters did not automatically make a district unconstitutional, as long as the state's primary motivation was potentially political rather than racial.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CONVERSANO, LEONARD
description: CONVERSANO-Leonard. Of Armonk N.Y. Beloved husband of Marie, loving father of Mark, cherished grandfather of Lisa and Mark, stepfather of Manna, Randa and Badrie. Visitation 7-9PM, May 18, 1999, at Cassidy-Flynn Funeral Home, Inc., Mount Kisco N.Y. Services 11 A.M., Wednesday at the funeral home. In lieu of flowers, donations preferred to American Heart Association.

title: CVS Makes an Internet Move, Purchasing an On-Line Drugstore
description: In a move that could signal tough competition for on-line pharmacies, the CVS Corporation said yesterday that it had purchased Soma.com, the first Internet drugstore, for $30 million in CVS stock.

title: 3 Acquisitions For WPP Group
description: WPP Group P.L.C. in London has made three acquisitions for undisclosed terms.

title: Should High School Be Abolished?
description: To the Editor:

title: Canadians' New 'Swan Lake,' Full of Passion and Perversity
description: Any major ballet production by James Kudelka is of interest, and the new $1.6 million ''Swan Lake'' he has staged for the National Ballet of Canada is no exception.

title: Toys 'R' Us Says Profit Falls 11%
description: Toys ''R'' Us Inc., the nation's second-largest toy retailer, said today that its first-quarter earnings fell 11 percent, less than expected, as sales rebounded.

title: Still Wrongly Accused of Murder, but Her Hair Color Has Changed
description: ''Girls Town'' is a wonderfully trashy 1959 movie in which Mamie Van Doren, as a gum-chewing platinum blond delinquent, is sent to a Roman Catholic orphanage-rehab center-reformatory. It may be the first (and last) movie in which the word ''fantabulous'' stands out.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAGER, FRIEDA
description: TAGER-Frieda. AMIT is deeply grieved by the passing of the beloved Past Chairwoman of our National Memorial Committee and long time member of our National Board. A caring, compassionate, sensitive and true Woman of Valor, Frieda Tager lived a life devoted to Torah, the State of Israel, and Klal Yisrael. Heartfelt condolences to her children, Ruth Shulman and Eddie Tager, and the entire family. Evelyn Blachor, Nat'l President Marvin Leff, Executive Director

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ORNSTON, MIMI
description: ORNSTON - Mimi...Mimi, we're going to miss you so much; your warmth, beauty, courage, caring, straight-talk advice. We'll always love you-Remember us. Phyllis, Bruce, Keith and Susan Buckler ORNSTON-Mimi. Distance could not diminish our friendship or love. Our memories span years and generations. Kind, thoughtful, endearing Mimi. We shall miss you. Ann and Harvey Tigler ORNSTON-Mimi. Sleep in peace dearest friend. You will be in our hearts always. Elaine and Jerry

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: NOVARTIS A.G., Basel, Switzerland, the world's No. 2 drug maker, said its Ciba Vision eye-care unit had bought the surgically implanted lens business of Mentor Corp., Santa Barbara, Calif., for $38 million.

title: Suspect Is Arrested In Ambush on Couple
description: A 24-year-old Harlem man was arrested yesterday and accused of ambushing a young couple riding an elevator in his building on Sunday afternoon, fatally shooting a 17-year-old girl and wounding her boyfriend, the police said.

title: Newcomers to States Have Right To Equal Welfare, Justices Rule
description: With a ringing endorsement of the right of equal citizenship for rich and poor alike, the Supreme Court ruled today that state welfare programs may not restrict new residents to the welfare benefits they would have received in their home states.

title: Enlightening Conversation
description: To the Editor:

title: Bottom Line on Kosovo
description: To the Editor:

title: '98 Victory Changed Hayes's Outlook
description: Before last year's Buick Classic, J. P. Hayes recalled, heading off to a golf tournament brought on a feeling that mixed anxiety with dread. ''My wife taking me to the airport to go off to play was kind of like taking a kid to see the dentist,'' he said.

title: Allianz to Buy Rest of Life USA Insurer
description: Allianz A.G., Europe's second-largest insurer, agreed today to buy Life USA Holding for $540 million.

title: Fugitive in Rent Strike Theft Faces Charges
description: He left behind his gold watch. He abandoned his beloved Jaguar. He didn't even pause to make his bed. The year was 1990, and Steven N. Delit was in a rush to get out of the way before his complicated life crashed upon him.

title: Albany Acts As if Suburbs Owe Nothing
description: LEAVE it to Albany's political leaders. The first time all year they decide to prove they can walk and chew gum at the same time, and they clip New York City with a sucker punch.

title: THE ISRAELI VOTE: Man in the News -- Ehud Barak; A Commanding Presence
description: The man who was elected Prime Minister of Israel on Monday is accustomed to being in command: Ehud Barak, 57, left the military just four years ago, after a beribboned 36-year career as platoon leader, tank-battalion chief, senior intelligence analyst and, from 1991 to 1995, head of the Israeli Army general staff.

title: Lemke Turns to Mound And Returns to Minors
description: Mark Lemke played 11 seasons in the major leagues as a second baseman, but for fun during warm-ups he would toy with a knuckleball. When no team called him this winter about signing, Lemke decided to treat the pitch as more than a recreational hobby. Yesterday he signed a minor league deal with the New Jersey Jackals of the Northern League East as a pitcher.

title: New Jersey Rabbi to Head Reform Conference
description: There could hardly be a more transformative moment than this to take over the reins of the largest rabbinical organization in the country, the Reform movement's Central Conference of American Rabbis.

title: Milstein Sues Redskin Officials, Alleging Sabotage of Bid
description: Howard Milstein charged yesterday in a Federal lawsuit that his group's $800 million bid to acquire the Washington Redskins was sabotaged by John Kent Cooke, the team's president, and Charley Casserly, the general manager.

title: Where the Median Is the Conservation Message
description: Nestled between the eastbound and westbound lanes of Route 17 here in Tioga County is one of the nation's most unusual nature preserves, a 50-acre strip of bog and forest that boasts a herd of white-tail deer, several beaver dens, a bird sanctuary and a nature trail.

title: Editorial Observer; Politics: Taking the 'Help' Out of 'Helpmate'
description: If Elizabeth Dole seriously wants to be a Presidential candidate, the first thing she is going to have to do is lock up her husband.

title: Mets Can't Overcome Jones's Woes
description: Consistency is something Bobby Jones has strived for since he put together an All-Star first half of the 1997 season. But after a strong start this year, Jones has been struggling. In that sense, he has been much like the rest of the Mets' starting rotation.

title: Shares End Mixed, With the Dow Dropping 59.85 Points
description: Stock prices were mixed yesterday, in large part because of an afternoon rally in technology shares. But with Federal Reserve policy makers scheduled to meet today to discuss a possible increase in interest rates, investors were reluctant to make new commitments.

title: How the Moon Turns Pilots Into Poets
description: The men chosen to fly to the Moon, among them two who walked on its surface for the first time 30 years ago, were not picked for their poetic minds or for their photographic skills.

title: Goldbergs Sponsor Some New Variations
description: Is there anyone out there called Diabelli, Eroica or St. Anthony? If so, you might want to imitate Judy Goldberg and her husband, Robert, who, finding themselves sharing a name with a celebrated set of variations, decided to commission more on the same theme. Hence the ''New Goldberg'' Variations, written for Yo-Yo Ma, who introduced them to New York on Saturday evening at the Carnegie Hall recital he gave with Jeffrey Kahane.

title: Lott Item Goes, but Much Remains in 'Emergency' Bill
description: A little item temporarily attached itself, like a barnacle riding a whale, to the $15 billion emergency spending deal lashed together by Congressional negotiators last week.

title: The Genome's Combative Entrepreneur
description: It is like visiting a boxer in his training camp a few days before the big fight. The display of muscle. The brassy predictions of victory. The forecast that the world will be changed after the dazed opponent has been carried from the ring feet first before a jeering crowd.

title: Should High School Be Abolished?
description: To the Editor:

title: Drawing Maxims From History's Cycles
description: If anyone could give vital musical point to the turn of the century, you might have thought, it would be Leon Botstein: conductor, educator and thinker of big thoughts. But Mr. Botstein and the American Symphony Orchestra ended their seasonlong series at Avery Fisher Hall, ''The 20th Century: A Kaleidoscope,'' on Wednesday evening, with a program, ''Fin de Siecle,'' that proved surprisingly muddled in concept.

title: As a National Tour Ends, Ellington Is in Focus
description: Duke Ellington sounded stupendous on Saturday night. During the Lincoln Center Jazz Orchestra's all-Ellington program at Alice Tully Hall, you could almost see the music moving, as if sections of the band suddenly popped out in relief when a phrase passed through it. It was repertory performance on an unusually high level; justice to the arrangements was served.

title: U.S. to Pay Albanians For Housing Of Kosovars
description: With the refugee population in Albania expected to exceed 900,000 this summer, the United States announced today that it would pay thousands of Albanian families to take new Kosovo refugees into their homes until a peace settlement is reached.

title: For Those at Home on the Range, Guns Don't Kill
description: Short, slight, boyishly frail-looking at 60, James F. Laughland can pierce the pupil in the eye of a bull, or its paper equivalent, shot after shot, with his .22-caliber Winchester rifle or his mightier M-1A. A badge on his shooting fatigue jacket says ''President's Hundred,'' putting him in the top rank of thousands of target shooters who compete in a national tournament.

title: A Daredevil Soprano Tackles Early Verdi
description: As Verdi gained pragmatic experience with opera over the years, he figured out how to write roles for singers that were amply demanding yet vocally negotiable. But many of his early works have roles of punishing difficulty, none more so than his seldom-performed ''Giovanna d'Arco,'' the 7th of his 28 operas, composed in late 1844 when he was 31.

title: Pearl Lang's Rituals Set Into Motion
description: Dance fashions come and go. But old-fashioned virtues, like a respect for craft and the clear exposition of themes, linger on in work by a handful of New York-based choreographers of an earlier generation. One of those choreographers is Pearl Lang, a leading dancer with Martha Graham in the 1940's and 50's. Two new works presented by the Pearl Lang Dance Theater on Saturday night at Kaye Playhouse suggested that there has been no diminution of Ms. Lang's appetite for exploring ideas and dance as an expressive medium.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARON, HERBERT
description: BARON-Herbert. Kindred spirit of Shirley, beloved father of Fran Levinson & Edward Baron, cherished grandfather of Caren, Andrew, Becky and Jeffrey. Services Tuesday, 2:00 PM at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels'', 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, New York.

title: U.S. Search Engine Is Stopped Hours After Debut
description: A few hours after starting a fee-based search engine for Federal Government Internet sites and documents, the Commerce Department put the project off today to review whether it conflicts with the Clinton Administration's policy on unrestricted access to Government information.

title: Betsey Johnson: Honor for a Life of Celebrating Youth
description: When Betsey Johnson bounces into a room exuding energy, her rag-mop of blatantly dyed red hair swinging, you half expect her to turn a cartwheel. But no. ''I do only two cartwheels a year,'' she said. That would be at the finale of her spring and fall runway shows, where they are as much of a signature as the colorful jersey prints and sweaters, the laced-up corsets and frilly petticoats she finds new ways of showing every season.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAPECI, THEODORE J., DR.
description: CAPECI-Theodore J., Dr.. In loving memory of my brother, Dr. Theodore J. Capeci. This genius was an inspiration to me all my life. He had the rare capacity of being a dreamer and a doer. A great Doctor and a man of the people. QUICK SILVER! Mrs. Jacqueline Capeci Wenz

title: Excerpts From Court's Welfare Ruling and Rehnquist's Dissent
description: Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court's decision today barring states from paying lower welfare benefits to newcomers than to longtime residents. The vote in Saenz v. Roe was 7 to 2. Justice John Paul Stevens wrote the majority decision, and Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist wrote the dissent.

title: INSIDE
description: Ford to Build Cleaner Trucks

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOESER, JOHN R.
description: MOESER-John R.. On May 14, 1999. Suddenly, of a heart attack. His colleagues at HCFP/Brenner Securities mourn his passing and extend their sympathies to his family.

title: War and Peace
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Liberties; Leech Women in Love!
description: A colleague once brought me a present from Sunset Strip: a vintage poster of a B movie called ''The Leech Woman,'' a 1959 horror classic. The poster showed a voluptuous woman ensnaring a young man, with the legend: ''LEECH WOMAN! She drains men of their love and lives!''

title: My Son's First Words? 'Pedal' and 'Metal'
description: WE live in an automotive culture, and little boys have always been fascinated by things that go. This I know intellectually. Still, as the mother of a 2 1/2-year-old car buff, I'm staggered by the number of products on the market today that encourage this fixation.

title: Loehmann's Seeks Bankruptcy Protection
description: Loehmann's Inc., the Bronx-based retailer that offers designer apparel at bargain prices, filed for bankruptcy protection yesterday in Wilmington, Del.

title: Dell's Earnings Increased By 42% in First Quarter
description: The Dell Computer Corporation posted first-quarter earnings yesterday that matched analysts' estimates, but the results disappointed some investors.

title: Throwing Your Own Surprise Party
description: Joe Torre wanted to sneak back into the dugout with the Yankees. Fool everyone and show up at Fenway Park a few days earlier than expected. Let the players finally spot him in his uniform, let the coaches finally see something beside an empty office and let the news media cease predicting his future. Torre did not know if it would work, but he had a plan to surreptitiously return to managing yesterday.

title: 12th Death Row Inmate in Illinois Is Cleared
description: For the 12th time in the last 12 years, an Illinois inmate on death row has been spared by evidence showing a wrongful murder conviction.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINNEGAN, HON. LAWRENCE J., JR.
description: FINNEGAN-Hon. Lawrence J., Jr. On May 17, 1999 of Bayside, NY. (Justice, Queens County Supreme Court and Ethics Professor at St. John's University.) Beloved husband of Jacqueline (nee Grogan). Devoted father of Lawrence J. III and Kerian A. Finnegan. Fatherin-law of Christopher J. Czarkowski. Dear brother of Brian and Kevin. Reposing at the Lloyd Funeral Home, 39th Ave. at 215th St., Bayside, NY, today, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass Sacred Heart Church, 12 noon Thursday. Donations to Don Monti Memorial Research Foundation at North Shore University Hospital, Manhassset, NY 11030 would be appreciated.

title: New Jersey and Connecticut Jump In
description: As the Governors of New Jersey and Connecticut prepared court challenges to the elimination of New York City's commuter tax for New York State residents, one suburban lawmaker today suggested retaliatory action on several new battle fronts, including the ticket booths of Broadway and Yankee Stadium.

title: The White House, Buoyed by Political Change in Israel, Pushes to Revive Peace Talks
description: The White House lost little time today in trying to capitalize on the victory of Ehud Barak in the Israeli election for Prime Minister to invigorate stalled Middle East peace talks.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Hopeful in Bind? Hardly, G.O.P. Says
description: Even though it is very early in the Presidential campaign season and a lot can happen between now and the Republican convention next summer, the odds remain long that Representative John R. Kasich of Ohio will win his party's nomination. He continues to bump along at the bottom of the polls, seldom rising much above 1 percent.

title: Ex-Councilman Wins Philadelphia Primary
description: A long and often nasty Democratic primary campaign ended Tuesday when John F. Street, the former City Council president and Mayor Edward G. Rendell's chosen successor, defeated five other candidates to win the party's nomination.

title: Where Old Cars Go to Gleam
description: AN automobile concours d'elegance is a beauty pageant for rare and elegant cars. For vintage car enthusiasts in the South, the Fourth Annual Amelia Island Concours d'Elegance, off the coast of Florida, provided an opportunity to admire 205 cars that represented a kaleidoscope of automotive history.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLEESON, REV. JOSEPH M.
description: GLEESON-Rev. Joseph M. On May 13, 1999. Ordained for the people of New York on May 29, 1965. Born on March 28, 1939, the son of Joseph M. and Marie White Gleeson. He was raised and educated in New York City, a graduate of Regis High School, Fordham University and Saint Joseph's Seminary. He fulfilled his ministry at Saint Thomas the Apostle and Church of Our Savior in Manhattan, Holy Family in Staten Island, Saint Peter's in Yonkers, and Sacred Heart in the Bronx. He served as Chaplain in Bronx Lebanon Hospital for many years, completing his ministry at the Veterans Administration Medical Center in Saint Albans, Queens. He is survived by: three sisters, Kathryn L. Gleeson of New York City, Marie G. Amoroso of Scarsdale, and Loretta G. DiLorenzo of Scarsdale; one brother, Richard W. Gleeson of Boston, MA; three aunts, Helen W. Coogan of Somers, NY, Mary White of Riverdale, NY, and Miriam McCormick of Richmond, VA; nieces and nephew, Kate, Claire and Sarah DiLorenzo, Lori, Nancy, Michael and Beth Amoroso, Molly and Jesse Serventi-Gleeson. The family will receive friends at the Bennett Funeral Home, 824 Scarsdale Avenue, Scarsdale, New York, 914725-1137, on Friday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial will take place on Saturday, 11 AM, at Saint Barnabas Church, Martha Avenue and East 241 Street in the Bronx. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Carmelite Communion, 139 DePuyster Ave., Beacon, NY. 12508-3504 will be appreciated.

title: Porter W. Heaps, 92, Musician Who Made an Organ Sound Big
description: Porter Warrington Heaps, an organist and composer whose work on the popular Hammond organ transformed a crude-sounding electronic keyboard instrument into one that could approximate the sounds and colors of larger pipe organs, died on May 3 at his home in Palo Alto, Calif. He was 92.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HARAN, JACQUES F.
description: HARAN-Jacques F. You are always missed and loved by your friends in New York and Paris. A Vous, William F.F

title: Abolish High School? Let the Market Decide
description: To the Editor:

title: Stepashin Is Pressing Parliament On Reforms
description: Russia's Acting Prime Minister told Parliament today that he would demand a vote of confidence in his new Government if the lawmakers refused to enact economic reforms on which Western lenders have conditioned billions of dollars in new loans.

title: Senate Passes Bill Requiring Safety Devices for Handguns
description: By a vote of 78 to 20, the Senate today approved a measure that would require child safety devices with each of the millions of handguns sold by licensed dealers in the United States every year.

title: Yearly Profit Down 43% At Matsushita Electric
description: The Matsushita Electric Industrial Company, the world's largest maker of consumer electronics, said yesterday that its profit fell 43 percent in the year that ended on March 31 as weak demand forced it to cut prices for computer monitors, hard disk drives and computer chip parts.

title: Despite Party's Entreaties, Gandhi Insists She's Out of Politics
description: Sonia Gandhi stayed behind the high walls of her heavily guarded compound today and firmly refused the pleas of senior Congress Party leaders that she change her mind about resigning as president of the party.

title: Valentine's Protest of a Protest
description: Mets Manager Bobby Valentine never used the word. But he indirectly accused Milwaukee Manager Phil Garner of gamesmanship last night.

title: NATO SAYS SERBS, FEARING LAND WAR, DIG IN ON BORDER
description: Anticipating that NATO may eventually mount a ground offensive, Yugoslav Army brigades have been stationed along the likely attack routes from Macedonia and Albania and are trying to fortify the border, allied officials say.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on April 25 about Norman Williams, a British lawyer and stamp expert, misstated his length of service as a court reporter and omitted a survivor. Mr. Williams's term began in 1962 and extended 35 years, not 64. The survivor is a brother, David, of Bloomfield, N.J.

title: On the Shaken Right, a First-Day Challenge
description: Laying down a challenge to Ehud Barak a day after he was elected Israel's Prime Minister, Jewish settlers began digging foundations today for a new housing complex in an Arab neighborhood of East Jerusalem.

title: A Failed Foreign Policy
description: To the Editor:

title: Abolish High School? Let the Market Decide
description: To the Editor:

title: GTE Holders Give Thumbs Up To Merger With Bell Atlantic
description: Shareholders of the GTE Corporation approved the $52.9 billion merger with the Bell Atlantic Corporation yesterday, even as a $37 billion merger agreement announced on Monday between U S West Inc. and Global Crossing Ltd. helped define the regulatory challenges to the Bells' ambitions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEINBERG, CECILE
description: KLEINBERG-Cecile. Died peacefully on May 18, 1999 in her 93rd year. Loving sister of Lucie Friedman, Armand Kleinberg & sisterin-law of Barbara Kleinberg. Cherished aunt of Joan Anderman, Jane Lebowitz, Terry Kleinberg & many great nieces and nephews. Services on Thursday, May 20, 10:15 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Klammer Still on Slopes After '76 Downhill Feat
description: Franz Klammer can recall every tiny detail, every sharp turn and every steep angle of his dramatic downhill race at the 1976 Winter Olympics in Innsbruck, Austria. Halfway down the Patscherkofel course, he trailed Bernhard Russi, and needed something special to make up time.

title: Hong Kong Tries to Limit Court Ruling On Residency
description: Desperate to stem a possible flood of migrants from mainland China, Hong Kong said today that it would ask the Chinese Government to overturn, in effect, a court ruling that granted Hong Kong residency to more than a million people.

title: New Shop Set Up In San Francisco
description: Three longtime agency executives are opening a shop called Collaborate in San Francisco.

title: Canadian Copper Mine Is Shut After Workers Reject Contract
description: Canada's largest copper mine has been shut down indefinitely following the unionized work force's rejection of a cost-cutting contract that management called critical to the operation's profitability.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  NEAGLE, JULIA S.
description: NEAGLE-Julia S. A Memorial Service for Julia S. Neagle who died January 22, 1999 will be held Saturday, May 22nd at 2:30PM at St. Luke's Church, 18 James Lane, East Hampton, New York.

title: It's a Car Name -- It Doesn't Have to Make Sense
description: BREEZE, Neon, Contour, Prism, Mystique, Cirrus, Stratus, Alero, Intrigue, Aspire, Excel -- washday miracles, perhaps, or soft drinks or cheap cigarettes. But car names? Welcome to the deconstruction of the automobile model name, as not only traditional superlatives but meaning itself yield to perky-sounding word blips, signifying weird things (Silhouette), the wrong things (Mirage, Eclipse) or nothing at all (Elantra, Maxima, Impreza, Altima, Camry, ad infinitum). What does an Avenger avenge, a Tracer trace? Exactly what accent does an Accent carry? Forget meaning; just tell me what parts of speech are Sentra, Bravada, Lumina and Sephia?

title: Honored, a Year Later
description: A year after they were denied membership in the National Honor Society because they had become pregnant out of wedlock, two Kentucky high school seniors have been inducted as new members.

title: Martin Can Use Cart in Open
description: Will Casey Martin be entitled to a cart for all stages of the coming United States Open? On Monday, Lee Abrams, the United States Golf Association's outside counsel, apparently suggested that if he won a similar case that ended yesterday in South Bend, Ind., Martin might well have to walk. But yesterday the U.S.G.A. backpedaled fast.

title: Industry Critics Single Out Spots
description: For a third year, national advertisers are being roasted by critics who oppose what they consider the commercialization of American culture and the manipulation of consumers.

title: Every Job's a Stretch in This Shop
description: PERHAPS a more appropriate name for Empire Coach, a huge two-floor garage in a former bus depot in Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn, would be Torquemada's Auto Body.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CASSEL, CHARLES MOORE JR.
description: CASSEL-Charles Moore Jr. At the age of 82. The Henry L. Schwartz Department of Geriatrics and Adult Development of Mount Sinai Medical Center extends our deepest sympathy to Dr. Christine K. Cassel, our Chairman, and to her family, on the loss of her father. Mr. Cassel was the son of the late Charles and Ruth (Brown) Cassel. A graduate of the United States Naval Academy, Mr. Cassel was a veteran of W.W. II and the Korean Conflict.
