He was the Executive Officer of the Destroyer USS Satterlee (DD626) which supplied the only gunfire support for the first wave that invaded Normandy. His ship was also the lead ship of four destroyers escorting British Minesweepers which cleared the transport area beginning some four hours before H-H Hour. He was involved extensively in the Pacific front and participated in the Battle of Midway and Guadalcanal. He was the recipient of many awards including the Bronze Star. Mr. Cassel retired as a Captain from the U.S. Navy in July of 1969. Following his retirement from the service, he worked in the Malden Public School System as a Guidance Counselor, retiring in 1981. Mr. Cassel was the past President of the Boston Guild for the Hard of Hearing, a volunteer at the Bedford V.A. for 18 years and also enjoyed golf and tennis. Mr. Cassel was the husband of the late Virginia (Anderson) Cassel and is survived by his two daughters Christine K. Cassel, M.D. of Manhattan, N.Y. and Virginia C. Buckley of Sudbury, MA. He is also survived by his sister Julia Cassel of Gainsville, FL, and two nephews. Memorial contributions may be made to the Boston Guild for the Hard of Hearing, 283 Commonwealth Avenue, Boston, MA 02115.

title: Robert L. Turner Dies at 89; Helped Create Eastern Shuttle
description: Robert L. Turner, who pushed Eastern Air Lines to create its shuttle between Boston and New York in 1961, died on Saturday in Columbus, N.C. He was 89.

title: Gutkowski Leaving Firm He Founded
description: Bob Gutkowski is leaving the Marquee Group, the sports and entertainment production, marketing and representation firm he co-founded in 1995. Two months ago, Marquee was acquired by SFX Entertainment, whose chairman, Robert Sillerman, provided the seed money to start Marquee.

title: People
description: * Greg Kurowski was named president of Periscope Marketing Communications, Minneapolis, succeeding Jeff Wright, who is leaving. Mr. Kurowski had been senior vice president for strategic development at Martin/Williams Advertising, Minneapolis, part of Omnicom Group.

title: Mother Charged With Starving Baby Tells of Frantic Effort to Save Him
description: Breaking down on the witness stand in a Bronx courtroom yesterday, a woman charged with second-degree manslaughter in the starvation death of her infant son described a frantic cab ride to a hospital when she realized that the boy was dying.

title: Has Welfare Created A Culture of Defeat?
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Fed Leaves Rates Alone But Hints at Increase Later

title: ABC Lineup Rearranges Hit Shows
description: ABC announced a fall schedule yesterday that moves several of its established shows to new times, adds three comedies and three dramas, and preserves the network's Friday lineup of child-oriented shows, once thought to be near extinction for next season.

title: Mad as Hell, but Not Going to Get Away With It Any More
description: SGT. JANET HARRISON sits in her Ford Bronco, parked on the shoulder of the Capital Beltway, surrounded by some of the most sophisticated technology ever used to monitor one of mankind's most primitive behaviors -- unbridled aggression.

title: The Swiss Discover Virtue of Marketing
description: LONDON  Swiss bankers like to keep a low profile; it is one of their attractions to their clients. But Swiss banks have been forced to rethink and remold their public image following various troubles, including the settlement last year for more than $1 billion of claims related to the Holocaust.

title: Before the Beginning, After the End
description: Most viewers will recall the chronological discontinuity at the beginning of the first ''Star Wars'' film, which appeared in 1977. In the opening text that scrolled up the screen, ushering audiences into the unknown, there were two puzzles. ''Star Wars,'' subtitled ''A New Hope,'' was a science-fiction movie set in the remote past, and it was also called ''Episode IV.'' The old Horatian advice to poets is to begin ''in medias res,'' in the middle of things. That adage still applies, but for a different reason than Horace had in mind. If you call the first ''Star Wars'' film ''Episode IV,'' you enclose the audience, as Horace understood, in an already onrushing vehicle. But if your story is as entertaining as ''Star Wars'' was, you also build demand for the missing episodes, for what is now called the prequel, a word unknown until the early 1970's.

title: On Campus; It's that season at Chicago, and Ph.D.'s have taken a back seat to a degree of silliness.
description: ''People think of the University of Chicago and they think the students are weird,'' says Tom Howe, a junior from Atlanta. Having taken off his chicken suit, he is wearing a cardboard crown from a Burger King Kid's Meal. ''We want to show that intellectual doesn't necessarily mean stuffy.''

title: Classics From 60's Are Big Draw at Sotheby's Sale
description: Strong examples of classic contemporary artists -- household names like Warhol, Calder and Bacon -- were snapped up in short order at Sotheby's sale of contemporary art in Manhattan last night.

title: Unity? In Israel?
description: Ehud Barak's landslide in the Israeli elections on Monday was so stark because Israel seemed incapable of it. Over and over, politicians and pundits told us, Israel was too divided to give anyone a clear mandate. The left and right blocs, the secular and religious factions, the pro-peace and pro-nationalist camps were so polarized, the commentators said, that any new election would just make the divisions worse.

title: Abolish High School? Let the Market Decide
description: To the Editor:

title: Internet Phone Caller Plans Offering
description: In apparently the first initial public offering of stock in a company that focuses exclusively on transmitting phone calls using Internet technology, Net2phone Inc., a subsidiary of the IDT Corporation, filed yesterday for an initial public offering with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Johns Hopkins Tries For Revenge at Hofstra
description: In the playoffs, when teams are so evenly matched, is there really a home-field advantage? It is a pertinent reflection with regard to the first quarterfinal match of the men's Division I National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROFMAN, CLARA
description: ROFMAN-Clara. Age 93, May 18, 1999. Wife of the late Joseph Rofman, devoted mother of Ethan Samuel Rofman and Irwin Israel Rofman, cherished grandmother of Jonathan, Robert, Susan, Amy and Julie, great-grandmother of Rachel, William, Sarah and Edward. Services at the Riverside 21 West Broad Mt.Vernon, NY at 12 noon Thursday May 20. All contributions should be made in her memory to the Pioneer Women or the Jewish National Fund.

title: Environmental Literacy
description: Students are gaining awareness of the environment, reports the Environmental Literacy Council, a nonprofit group, but that does not mean they know very much about it.

title: Commuter Tax Is a Social Pact
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HESS, LILLIAN (NEE RYAN)
description: HESS-Lillian (nee Ryan). Peacefully on May 15, 1999 in Denver, CO. Former resident of Breezy Point, NY. Beloved wife of Arthur. Cherished mother of Mary Janes, Patricia Hodne, Lillian, Barbara, Victoria Owens, Arthur Jr., and Catherine Zaccaro. Loving grandmother of fourteen and two greatgrandchildren. Friends may visit Thursday, 7-10PM at N.F. Walker Funeral Home, 87-34 80th St., Woodhaven, NY. For directions, call 718-296-4343. Funeral Mass St. Edmonds R.C. Church, Breezy Point, NY, Saturday, May 22, 1999, at 9:45AM. Interment Evergreen Cemetery, Brooklyn, NY. The family requests donations may be made to the Society for the Propagation of the Faith, 191 Joralemon Street, Brooklyn, New York 11201.

title: Wine Talk; Spain's New Vintners Leave Rioja in the Dust
description: AS long as anyone can remember, red wine in Spain has been synonymous with Rioja, the fertile valley of the Ebro River in the northernmost reaches of the country, not far from the western Pyrenees and the French border. In recent years, however, Rioja has begun to confront some formidable competition.

title: After Acting Out the Inner City, A Writer Radiates Inner Peace
description: One would expect Dael Orlandersmith to be angrier in person. The material in her searing one-woman play is, after all, largely based on her own experiences, and those experiences are hard to hear about, let alone live through: a little girl physically and emotionally abused by her alcoholic mother; a large, book-loving girl teased by her peers for being big and being different; a teen-age girl raped by her best friend's father.

title: Annan Takes Critical Stance on U.S. Actions in Kosovo
description: Reflecting frustration over his organization's marginalization in Kosovo, Secretary General Kofi Annan criticized the United States today for taking military action without Security Council blessing and China and Russia for having ignored the ethnic purging that led to NATO's bombing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GANNETT, SARAH DERBY
description: GANNETT-Sarah Derby, 78. Died at home in Brattleboro, Vermont on Monday after a long illness. A granddaughter of President Theodore Roosevelt born in Oyster Bay. Survived by her husband, Robert T. Gannett; her daughter, Alden G. Taylor of Mequon, Wisconsin and William of New York City and nine grandchildren. A private memorial service will be held at the convenience of the family.

title: Commuter Tax Is a Social Pact; More Than Fair
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Unveils Plan to Aid 68 Species in Everglades
description: Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt unveiled an ambitious plan today to save more than 68 endangered and threatened species in South Florida, taking a regional approach to disappearing wildlife that the Clinton Administration hopes will become a national model.

title: Deal Involves Trade Shows
description: Penton Media Inc., which organizes the annual Internet World trade show, said today that it had agreed to buy New Hope Communications Inc. for $82 million, including $41 million in cash and about 2.1 million shares. Penton may also pay $15 million based on New Hope's profit performance in the next three years. New Hope, a closely held company based in Boulder, Colo., organizes trade shows and publishes magazines and journals on natural foods, dietary supplements and herbal medicine.

title: Clearing the Air In the Land of Smog
description: IN the summer of 1943, a year and a half after the attack on Pearl Harbor, people were still nervously scanning the skies here to see if anything was going to materialize above the horizon.

title: Harmonic Style and Form By a Couple in 'Bayadere'
description: Dancing the leading male role in ''La Bayadere'' for the first time in New York, Angel Corella was nothing short of perfect with American Ballet Theater on Monday night.

title: Bill Ballantine, 88, Clown, Artist and Writer
description: Bill Ballantine, an artist and writer who peppered his work with images of circus life, died on Friday at the Pine Nursing Home in Sarasota, Fla. He was 88 and lived in Sarasota.

title: About New York; The Day Job: Learn English With Sinatra
description: SOON after he arrived in New York from Ecuador in 1994, Juan Pablo Fajardo began to learn English while working as a busboy in a midtown deli. His first teacher was Abraham Bonilla, the deli's manager, who shared long talks with him in bookstores, parks and at home. They discussed America, science fiction and life. He also introduced the young man to his second teacher: Frank Sinatra.

title: Spence School Gets Treatment Center Mansion
description: A stately mansion on East 93d Street that was long a place of recovery for wealthy alcoholics and more recently the object of struggle between a benefactor and a hospital will become part of the Spence School.

title: Law Effects Changes In Treatment of Homeless
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani signed legislation yesterday that makes it illegal for the city to force homeless families to sleep on the floor of its emergency assistance office.

title: Serbs Open the Border and Expel Kosovars to Macedonia
description: Emerging from the darkness without warning, a mile-long column of 80 tractors carrying between 1,000 and 1,500 Kosovo Albanian men, women and children abruptly arrived at this remote border crossing at 8:15 P.M. today, aid workers said.

title: A Family Shooting and a Twist Like No Other
description: Georgette Smith will be allowed to die, as she wishes, but not until she helps prosecutors build a murder case against her own mother, who she said has robbed her of the will to live.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LINKER, RUTH
description: LINKER-Ruth. Beloved wife of Murray. Loving mother of Donald Linker and Amy Bonoff. Devoted grandmother of Jennifer Koppel, Daniel Bonoff, Thomas, William and Katie Linker. Services were held. The family will receive friends at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Bonoff at 12 Split Tree Road, Scarsdale, from Tuesday evening until 12 Noon Thursday.

title: THE CHEF
description: STRAWBERRIES are best eaten cool and raw, which makes them a true harbinger of summer. It also makes them a challenge for a pastry chef: how to serve them interestingly without obscuring their natural, sweet-tart goodness? My first impulse for a strawberry dessert was a bowl of berries topped with a snowy dollop of whipped heavy cream.

title: Bad Decision on Clean Air
description: In a bizarre and tortured decision, a three-judge Federal appeals panel last week invalidated air-quality regulations imposed by the Clinton Administration to ease the suffering of millions of Americans with asthma and lung disease. If upheld, the decision would repudiate one of the Administration's main environmental achievements and award victory to a coalition of industries and state governments that have fought the regulations in Congress and in the courts. It could threaten a series of other clean-air initiatives as well, and overturn a half-century of jurisprudence that has allowed Congress to delegate important rule-making powers to Federal agencies. For all these reasons, the Administration is obliged to appeal this decision -- first to the full Court of Appeals, and, if that fails, to the Supreme Court.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAGER, FRIEDA
description: TAGER-Frieda. Yeshiva University Women's Organization mourns the passing of its past National Vice President, Frieda Tager, who played a major role as Chair of the YUWO Opera Benefit and was an important and dedicated leader for more than fifty years. Condolences are extended to her children, Edward (and Ellen) Tager and Ruth (and Rabbi Herman) Shulman, children, grandchildren, great grandchildren and the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dinah Pinczower National Chairman, YUWO

title: Commuter Tax Is a Social Pact; A Temporary Deal
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLARKE, MILDRED SHANLEY
description: CLARKE-Mildred Shanley. On May 15, 1999 in Greenwich, CT. Lovingly remembered by husband George, daughter and son-in-law Judith and William Turner of Montclair, NJ, four grandchildren and four great-grandchildren. Predeceased by one daughter, Jane Boller. Services at a later date.

title: State of the Heat
description: Pat Riley said that another disastrous playoff elimination would not lead him to scrap his Miami Heat blueprint for a title. ''To me that was an aberrational series, because now the Knicks can actually start the playoffs,'' Riley said after meeting with his players for an hour in Miami. ''Or if we had won, now we could start the playoffs.

title: Dual Interests Leave Speaker In the Middle
description: For five years as the Speaker of the Assembly, Sheldon Silver has struggled, often against a torrent of Republican criticism, to deliver this message: his Democrats are not the party of taxes, and are not solely the party of New York City.

title: A Wife Gives the Go Sign
description: When Ali Torre sat across from her husband, Joe, at a steakhouse in Manhattan on Monday night, she could tell that he was exasperated. He was weary of the endless medical tests that have become part of his recuperation from prostate cancer surgery and he was weary of being away from managing the Yankees.

title: Text of Statement by Fed
description: Following is the text of a statement released by the Federal Reserve yesterday after the Federal Open Market Committee said it had left interest rates unchanged but had adopted a stance to raise borrowing costs in the future:

title: Two Students Charged In Bomb-Making Scheme
description: Two seventh graders at Emerson Junior-Senior High School have been charged with stealing chemicals from a science room in hopes of making a bomb to detonate at the school, officials said yesterday.

title: Coach House: Attempting A Sequel
description: IT takes nerve to name a place the Coach House. The original, of course, was legendary -- owned by a Greek, the beloved Leon Lianides, and dedicated to serving classic American food in an era when fine dining spoke French.

title: Just Between Friends, And Nothing More
description: Bill Bradley's former New York Knicks teammates have been a big help when it comes to raising money for his Presidential run. At various times, the likes of Dave DeBusschere, Willis Reed and Phil Jackson have joined him out on the campaign cash circuit, talking not just about back-then with their old friend but also about the dollars that old friend will need if he is to have a real shot at winning the Democratic nomination.

title: World Briefing
description: ASIA

title: Jazz Detective Unravels an Ellington Puzzle
description: IN a studio at WKCR-FM, the music roars and Phil Schaap, the New York jazz disk jockey, is ablaze with the eternal present. His long fingers wiggle, slim hips waggle, the chin bops and bobs. Here come the drums. ''Go, Sam, go!'' he yells. ''Yeah, yeah, yeah!''

title: Federal Reserve Leaning to Rise In Interest Rates
description: The Federal Reserve put investors and consumers on notice today that it might raise interest rates in coming months if it continued to see signs that inflation was brewing.

title: Sports of The Times; Van Gundy Has Earned A New Term
description: LIKE jets stacked up in a holding pattern, everybody is waiting, waiting, waiting, to see what happens with the Knicks. Nobody can go anywhere until they stop performing their erratic loop-the-loops.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVAVY, BERENICE
description: LEVAVY-Berenice. The Trustees of The Morris J. & Betty Kaplun Foundation note with profound sorrow the passing of Berenice Levavy, beloved wife of our President, Zvi Levavy and the mother of their son, Bardi. Glorie Isakower, Larry Marin, Aaron Seligson, Moshe Sheinbaum

title: ISRAELI IS WEIGHING A BROAD COALITION TO FURTHER PEACE
description: In the morning after his euphoric victory rally, Ehud Barak, the next Prime Minister of Israel, woke up to the sobering task of cobbling together a coalition broad enough that he can pursue peace without facing civil strife.

title: Sips; Irish Whisky With a Vintage and a Pedigree
description: SCOTLAND produces more than 100 single malt whiskies, but Ireland very few, the best known of which is probably Bushmill's malt, made in Northern Ireland. Now, there is another, and a most unusual whisky it is. For starters, it is bottled and sold by an American.

title: Business Travel; A survey of passengers finds that the airlines do indeed have a customer-satisfaction problem.
description: WARRANTED or not, the image problem of airlines continues. The latest critics are subscribers to Consumer Reports, who, according to the June issue of the magazine, rate airlines ''only slightly more favorably than they do cable TV companies and commercial diet programs -- cellar dwellers in the magazine's customer satisfaction rankings.''

title: Two Rarities By Beethoven Add Interest To a Program
description: Misha Dichter has been playing wonderfully in recent seasons, but he seemed out of sorts through much of his recital at the 92d Street Y on Saturday evening. He offered a promising program, with two minor Beethoven rarities, Schumann's ''Davidsbundlertanze'' and the Prokofiev Sonata No. 7 among the attractions.

title: Fish on a Bed Of Potatoes
description: IN cooking, the whole is often greater than the sum of the parts, and this dish is a perfect illustration. In a Mediterranean spirit, it combines fish with four common ingredients to produce wonderful flavor, texture and even elegance. Chances are you have everything you need to make it (you'll have to shop for fish, of course), but given the simplicity of the process and the components, the taste is quite complex.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HYMAN, DR. HERBERT HENRY
description: HYMAN-Dr. Herbert Henry. The clergy, officers and trustees and members of Temple Sinai of Roslyn record with profound sorrow the death of senior past president, Dr. Herbert Henry Hyman. We grieve together with his beloved wife, Edith, his children, Edward and Deborah, Gerald and Sandra, Jeanne and Kenneth and his grandchildren, Cameron, Devon, Gregory, Jesse and Eric. His wit, integrity and passion for Judaism will be deeply missed. We pray that his memory will continue to bless us. Services at Temple Sinai on Thursday, May 20, at 12 noon. Michael A. White, Sr. Rabbi Norman Kahan, Rabbi Emeritus Michael J. Paul, President

title: Abolish High School? Let the Market Decide
description: To the Editor:

title: ALLIED WASTE CANCELS DEAL WITH WASTE MANAGEMENT INC.
description: Allied Waste Industries said yesterday that it had ended an agreement to purchase certain solid-waste handling assets from Waste Management Inc. in a deal that had been valued at about $85 million. Allied Waste said that approval from the Justice Department would have taken longer and been more difficult than had at first been expected. The Waste Management properties -- transfer stations, collection facilities and other operations for waste handling -- were in the New York City area and elsewhere in Northeastern states. Allied Waste, based in Scottsdale, Ariz., had 1998 revenue of $1.57 billion. Waste Management, based in Houston, had 1998 revenue of $12.70 billion.

title: Home, James, and Steer Clear of Those Awful Limousines
description: BILL BUTLER, a man about town who divides his time between Manhattan and Rhode Island, sums up the attitude about limousines on the Upper East Side: ''Limo is not in my vocabulary. Let's say it's one of those 'U' and 'non-U' things,'' he said, citing the terms made popular in Nancy Mitford's 1956 book, ''Noblesse Oblige,'' that separate the upper class (the ''U'') from the rest of the population.

title: Allies Check Satellite Pictures For Evidence of War Crimes
description: NATO is examining new clues to try to determine whether Yugoslav forces are digging up mass graves and reburying the bodies to hide evidence of war crimes against Kosovo Albanians, an allied spokesman said today.

title: The Envelope, Please: Cooking En Papillote
description: THE cooking method known as en papillote -- for the parchment paper that encloses the food in an envelope -- has held its own through any number of culinary fashions. It was especially favored in the days when haute cuisine was more ceremonious, allowing the server to open the package at the table in a show of erupting aromatic steam. It was ideal during the height of the healthy eating movement, because the method requires little or no additional fat.

title: Abolish High School? Let the Market Decide
description: To the Editor:

title: DIGITAL ENGINE ROOMS: A special report.; Computing Centers Become The Keeper of Web's Future
description: As Walt Grom tours his domain row upon row of hulking black computers -- he speaks of the importance of ''fundamental engineering disciplines'' and ''brute force experience.'' The vast room is spotless, brightly lit and chilled by air-conditioning, an austere interior designed for the care and feeding of big computers.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   BROAD, MONROE MAXIMILIAN, MD.
description: BROAD-Monroe Maximilian, MD. Physician, Surgeon, Soldier 25 February 1909-19 May 1987

title: The Bowery Held Hostage
description: An imbroglio fueled by a plan to develop New York's Bowery is an oddment on the city scene. In this case, the clash is not implacable foe against implacable foe -- a commonplace in New York.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Renaissance Man Is Remembered

title: CALENDAR
description: Baked in Clay (Really)

title: Stocks and Speeches Fatten Wallets of Presidential Contenders
description: Their bottom lines expanded by a booming stock market and lucrative speaking fees, six of the candidates for President reported assets of more than $1 million, according to financial disclosure forms filed this week.

title: G.O.P. in Congress to Cut Domestic Spending by $26 Billion
description: Republicans in Congress completed a plan today to cut domestic spending by tens of billions of dollars next year. Their leaders warned that it would cause ''sticker shock'' and political pain. The White House called it ''a blueprint for political chaos.''

title: Special Team Cars Are Looking for a Few Good Buyers
description: THE ''grabber orange'' paint is bright enough to singe retinas, visible proof of how hot a car is Ford's Special Vehicle Team Mustang Cobra R. At the recent unveiling of the 2000 model before a group of devoted Mustang owners, Ford's specialty vehicle marketing manager, Tom Scarpello, trumpeted the new car as ''the fastest production Mustang in its 35-year history.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBINO, ELISABETH J.
description: RUBINO-Elisabeth J. On May 16, 1999. Beloved sister of Therese Belsito. Loving aunt of Jeanne Wilson, Teresa-Gail Clayton, Victoria Elisabeth Prince and Christine Poutot. Her career spanned many years in the metropolitan area with notable people in literature, theatre and architecture. Funeral private.

title: Republicans Decide On Cuts in Spending
description: Republicans in Congress completed a plan to cut domestic spending by tens of billions of dollars next year, adhering to caps that Congress and the White House agreed to in 1997 to force down Federal spending.

title: Where to Put the Golf Clubs? Right Next to the Hydrogen!
description: THE two small cars that rolled up to the State Capitol in Sacramento did not seem much different from other cars -- until you saw the hydrogen tanks in their trunks. The vehicles, one by DaimlerChrysler and the other by Ford, were propelled by fuel cells, which are nonpolluting and are seen by many experts as the technology that will replace the gasoline-burning internal-combustion engine.

title: A Teacher Takes Charge of a Stirring History Lesson
description: The United States Holocaust Memorial Museum here has chosen a charter member of its own staff as its director. She must preside over a museum that has unexpectedly become one of the city's top tourist attractions while trying to smooth over the problems created by the acrimonious ouster of her predecessor last year.

title: Appellate Panel's Ruling Favors Charter Schools
description: A state appellate panel has ruled against five school districts seeking to avoid the financing of charter schools.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CLAYTON, ROBERT, JR.
description: CLAYTON-Robert, Jr. The North Carolina Society of New York regrets the passing of their devoted past President, Robert H. Clayton, Jr. A memorial service will be held Thursday, May 20th, 5 PM, in New York at Christ Church.

title: Mexican Interior Minister Resigns to Run in November Primary
description: A day after the governing party voted to pick its presidential candidate in a primary election, the man who is widely believed to be President Ernesto Zedillo's preferred choice announced today that he would resign his post to run for the nomination.

title: White House Will Propose Public School Choice Plan
description: As part of the law that determines how billions of dollars in Federal money is to be spent for education over the next five years, the Clinton Administration plans to propose on Wednesday that every school district allow low-income parents to send their children to any public school in their town, officials say.

title: Can Motor City Come Up With A Clean Machine?
description: WILLIAM C. FORD JR., the new 42-year-old chairman of the Ford Motor Company, became an environmentalist the way many baby boomers did. As a boy, he loved to hike, fish and go camping; he hated to revisit a spot only to find that someone else had made a mess of it. In high school, he volunteered to spend afternoons picking up trash along a nearby river. At Princeton University, he read books by radical environmentalists and stayed up late discussing how to save the earth.

title: Ogilvy Interactive Wins a Grand Clio
description: Ogilvy Interactive in New York was awarded a gold Clio and the first-ever Grand Clio Interactive award for its work with IBM Internet Technology at the Clio's first Interactive Advertising Show.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: Accounts
description: * Northern Light Technology L.L.C., Cambridge, Mass., to Mullen Advertising, Wenham, Mass., a unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies, as its first advertising agency. Billings were estimated at $12 million to $15 million.

title: Earnings Off Slightly At Deutsche Telekom
description: Deutsche Telekom A.G., Europe's biggest phone company, said yesterday that its first-quarter pretax profit fell 2 percent because of price cuts amid stiff competition. Pretax profit from ordinary operations in the first three months of the year fell to 1.18 billion euros ($1.26 billion) from 1.21 billion a year earlier.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZMAN, DOROTHY K.
description: SCHWARTZMAN-Dorothy K. On May 18, 1999. Of New York City. Beloved wife of the late Daniel. Devoted mother of John and Sheila Schwartzman, Ellen and Richard Kelson. Adored grandmother of Peter, Joseph, Carolyn, Melinda and Adam. Cherished great grandmother of Kyra and Laura. Services today, 10:45AM at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Tpk, Woodbury, L.I.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIGGIO, JACK W., DDS
description: RIGGIO-Jack W., DDS, of Southampton, NY, age 69, succumbed to lung cancer on May 17, 1999, after a lengthy illness. He was the son of the late Dr. Jack and Virginia Riggio of Port Jefferson, NY. He is survived by his wife Gilda (nee Aramburu), sons Bob, John and Bill, four grandchildren and a brother, Dr. Robert Riggio. He was an Alumnus of Dartmouth College and Georgetown University Dental School. He served in the U.S. Air Force as a First Lieutenant. His interests were many but his skill as an artist was clearly his forte. His works (oil on canvas) depicting the local scenery of Long Island won him several awards throughout this second career. He will be waked at Brockett's Funeral Home in Southampton Thursday, 7-9PM, call 516-283-0822. Burial Rites will begin Friday, 10AM at The Sacred Hearts of Jesus and Mary Church in Southampton NY.

title: When Things Get Out of Hand, These Cars Take Over
description: IT'S the second emergency turn that smashes cars.

title: Turnout Is Decidedly Tepid in Schools Vote
description: There was a school board election in New York City yesterday, but Soledad Fermin, a candidate in District 6 in upper Manhattan, found few people interested in what she had to sell.

title: Intimations of the Sea at a Venetian Trattoria
description: IN a city already saturated with Italian restaurants, how does one more make its presence felt? For some ambitious new places, the solution has been to emphasize the regional nature of their cuisines.

title: A Wait-and-See Welcome For Netanyahu's Successor
description: Palestinians from the senior leadership to the streets of Ramallah today welcomed the decisive vote that ousted Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel but they stopped well short of embracing his successor, Ehud Barak, who is viewed nervously as a hawk in dove's clothing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AGRANOFF, JOAN L.
description: AGRANOFF-Joan L. On May 14, 1999. Beloved sister of Arthur, devoted aunt of Susan Sassoon, Stuart M., Michael and the late Jeffrey. Visitation is on Thursday, 2-4 PM, at the Greenwich Village Funeral Home, 199 Bleecker Street, N.Y.C. In lieu of flowers or gifts donations may be made to the charity of your choice.

title: Ganderkesee Journal; Mulching the German Mark
description: Into a stinking mixture of potato peels, apple cores, animal excrement, grass, wilting cabbage and rotten carrots, Gerald Vollmer-Heuer casually tosses about 100,000 German marks, or $57,000.

title: Poetic Echoes In the Temple: 60 Years of Y And Whither
description: In his wheelchair up on the stage at the 92d Street Y on Monday night, Reynolds Price read his poem about a friend who dreamed that Mr. Price could walk again.

title: Ticketmaster Agrees to Acquire Match.com
description: Ticketmaster Online-CitySearch Inc., the No. 1 on-line seller of event tickets, has agreed to buy Match.com Inc. from the Cendant Corporation for about $50 million, adding dating services to its on-line features.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNFELD, ALAN L.
description: BERNFELD-Alan L. Of Hallandale, FL. Died May 18, 1999. A dear, sweet, gentle man. Loving husband of Lillian. Father of Bruce and Fran. Father-in-law of Eileen. Grandfather of Susannah. Brother-in-law, uncle, great uncle and friend. His 90 years were filled with abounding love and deep devotion to and from his family and friends. He loved life, work and people. His laughter and humor will be missed and always remembered. Graveside service 1:30PM Wednesday, May 19th at Menorah Gardens, 21100 West Griffin Road, Fort Lauderdale, FL 33332.

title: CORT BUSINESS REJECTS BID, FAVORING MANAGERS' BUYOUT
description: The Cort Business Services Corporation, a furniture rental company that agreed in March to be acquired by its management, rejected a higher offer from Brook Furniture Rental Inc., Brook said yesterday. Brook said it had bid about $367 million, or $28 a share, for Cort, which agreed March 26 to be bought by an investor group that includes the company's management for $24 in cash and $2.50 in preferred stock for each Cort share. Officials of Cort, which is based in Fairfax, Va., were not available for comment. Shares of Cort Business rose 37.5 cents yesterday, to $24.75, on the New York Stock Exchange. Brook, which is privately held, is in Arlington Heights, Ill.

title: Clinton Resists Renewed Calls for Ground Troops in Kosovo
description: Under increasing public pressure to resolve the conflict in Kosovo, President Clinton said today that he would not rule out the use of ground troops but that he was hopeful that diplomatic efforts under way with the Russians would be successful.

title: Hartford Chief Says Racism on His Force Must End
description: With racial tensions rising after the fatal shooting of a black teen-ager last month by a white police officer, the Hartford Police Chief said today that he had become convinced that his force was infected with racism. He urged white officers to take steps to change their mind-set, suggesting that they refuse to attend social gatherings unless black or Hispanic people were present.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL DROPS. Prices for crude oil fell on expectations that refiners will buy less in the weeks ahead after making more gasoline than motorists need. In New York, crude oil for June delivery fell 83 cents a barrel, to $17.11.

title: Torre Returns to Witness a Dismal Performance by Yankees
description: Before returning as the Yankees' manager today, Joe Torre missed his time in the dugout. He missed hearing the voices of his players, watching their reactions closely, analyzing their body language, all of those ways a manager measures his team.

title: A Presidential Primary for Mexico
description: Mexico was already headed toward a lively three-party presidential contest next year. Now the contest will begin even earlier, with this week's welcome decision by the Institutional Revolutionary Party, or PRI, to choose its nominee through a national primary election open to all voters.

title: BANK ONE TO REPURCHASE UP TO $4 BILLION OF ITS SHARES
description: The Bank One Corporation, the fifth-largest United States bank, said yesterday that it would repurchase as much as 5.5 percent of its outstanding stock, worth about $4 billion at its current price, in the next few years. The bank, based in Chicago, said it would buy back as many as 65 million shares. Bank One said the repurchased shares would be used for general corporate purposes, including employee benefit plans. Bank One shares rose 81.25 cents, to $61.125. Bank One has assets of more than $250 billion and about 2,000 branches in 14 states in the central United States.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIVETZ, DOLORES L. LUCHS
description: KIVETZ-Dolores L. Luchs. 62. Of Warren, NJ formerly of Toledo, OH on May 17, 1999. Wife of the late Jack Harold Kivetz (1984). Mother of Michael A. Kivetz of Warren, NJ. Sister of Dr. Saul M. Luchs of Cliffside Park, NJ. Funeral services will be held Wednesday 12:00 noon at the Higgins Home for Funerals, 752 Mountain Blvd, Watchung, NJ followed by interment at Beth El Cemetery, Paramus, NJ. Donations may be made to the American Cancer Society for Breast Cancer Research by contacting 1-800-227-2345.

title: Not for Just an Hour, Not for Just a Day
description: IRVING BERLIN

title: INSIDE
description: Mocking Mr. Gore

title: Pulp Friction
description: Coke promotes its ''secret formula'' for achieving uniformity of taste from Tulsa to Timbuktu. Pepsi scoffs, saying its product is just plain better and boasting that its market appeal gives it a big advantage over its archrival.

title: Expert Charged in Sale of Tiffany Glass Stolen From Tomb
description: Alastair Duncan has long been regarded as one of the world's leading experts on Tiffany stained glass. A former consultant to Christie's auction house in New York, he has written books and articles on the subject, and has advised the F.B.I. in its investigations into thefts involving the valuable objects.

title: In the Beginning, the Future
description: Things look dicey for the new ''Star Wars'' crew when their undersea craft is threatened by a large aquatic critter. But then an even mightier beast appears, and it swallows up the first. ''There's always a bigger fish,'' observes the Jedi sage Qui-Gon Jinn, speaking for more than marine life on the planet Naboo, where the sequence takes place. That description also sums up the earthly atmosphere into which George Lucas's pathologically anticipated ''Star Wars: Episode I -- The Phantom Menace'' arrives today.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: LYCOS INC., Waltham, Mass., an Internet search directory, said it would purchase up to a 9 percent stake in the closely held on-line auctioneer Fairmarket Inc., Woburn, Mass., for undisclosed terms.

title: Don't Call Me Mom; Grandma Will Do
description: Jane Scott collects antiques, served in the Navy during World War II and owns a senior citizen bus pass. On May 3 she turned 80. She also happens to be the oldest working rock journalist. Just after the Beatles arrived on these shores, Ms. Scott has been writing about rock for The Plain Dealer in Cleveland, watching subjects like the Who, Bruce Springsteen and Lou Reed grow up.

title: From Mother's Ugly Duckling To Chic and Expensive Swan
description: CINDY BURROWS had it all: a successful husband, three bright, attractive children and a showplace home on Philadelphia's Main Line with a fully loaded, leather-upholstered Chrysler Town and Country van in the driveway.

title: Calpers Allows Increases in Health Premiums
description: In the first sign that the cost of health care insurance could rise 9 to 11 percent again next year, the nation's second-biggest buyer of health benefits said yesterday that it had agreed to an average increase of 9.7 percent in premiums for California's state and local government workers.

title: Even in Cleaner-Running Machines, Looks Will Count
description: The vroom is gone, or going. So is the heft of steel and the muscular body. Made of magnesium, aluminum and plastic composites, powered by sustainable-source fuels, the coming generation of pollution-conscious cars is ultraquiet and ultralight. They promise to change the rules of how a car feels, looks and operates, as well as how it affects the environment.

title: Judges Reinstate Charges Over Campaign Donations
description: In a victory for the Justice Department's campaign finance investigation, a Federal appeals court panel today reinstated five criminal charges against a Democratic fund-raiser that had been thrown out by a district court judge.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOVETT, MARTIN
description: LOVETT-Martin. Of Concordia, Cranbury, NJ, age 78. Loving husband of Helen Stein Lovett. Devoted father of Phyllis and Larry Mazer of Raleigh, NC, and Ronald of Amesbury, MA. Adored Grandfather of Erick Eidus of Chicago, IL., and Zachary Mazer of Raleigh, NC. Survived also by many lifelong and dear friends. Services at Mt. Sinai Memorial Chapels, East Brunswick on Wednesday 12 Noon. Memorial contributions in his name to the Alzheimers Association for research.

title: Girl, 13, Falls Under a Bus In Manhattan And Is Killed
description: A 13-year-old girl was killed on her way home from an Upper West Side school yesterday when she slipped on a rain-slicked street and fell beneath a city bus, the police said.

title: Alternating Currents: Houston and Sprewell
description: Two days ago, Allan Houston sprinted defiantly down the Miami Arena floor and punched his fist into the air after his dramatic shot that eliminated the Miami Heat.

title: Starts of New Homes Fall To Lowest Level in a Year
description: New-home construction starts fell in April to their lowest level in a year after surging in the first quarter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZ, ELEANOR
description: KATZ-Eleanor. Cherished wife of Irving. Loving mother of Rena. Dear sister-in-law & aunt. Funeral service Thursday, May 20, at 1:30PM at Parkside Chapel, 98-60 Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AMKRAUT, SARAH
description: AMKRAUT-Sarah. Beloved sister, grandmother, great-grandmother and friend. Died on Monday evening at the age of 85 in Brooklyn. She had a heart attack while recuperating from back surgery. Mrs. Amkraut, widow and life long companion of the late Hyman Amkraut, will be sorely missed by all who knew and loved her. Fondly known as Grandma, Aunt Syd, and Grandma Sarah, her affection touched the lives of many. She is survived by her sister, Pauline, grandchildren, Eric, Brian, Daniel and Fran, granddaughters-in-law, Helen and Davida, and greatgrandchildren, Julian, Ruthy, and Shai.

title: Weapons Makers Seek Rise in Pentagon Spending
description: Whatever lessons the war with Serbia may teach NATO's military planners, American weapons makers are already anticipating that Kosovo may help secure a strategic victory for them -- not on the battlefield, but in Congress.

title: Correction
description: An Editorial Observer on May 9 erred in stating that Martin A. Siegel, the former investment banker who was convicted of insider trading, used a loophole in bankruptcy laws to avoid paying creditors. Mr. Siegel has paid his creditors and never filed for bankruptcy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOEWENSTEIN, REGINA
description: LOEWENSTEIN-Regina. Passed away May 16th. Survived by beloved sister Martha, special surrogate daughter Patricia Arrington and devoted longtime companions Clara Randolph and Veronica Philbert. Predeceased by her loving and caring parents Frieda and Solomon Loewenstein and adored sister Norma Drabkin. Interment private. A memorial service will be held at the New York Society for Ethical Culture, 2 West 64 Street, on May 20 at 11:00 AM.

title: Prices End Day Down a Bit But Well Above Their Lows
description: Stock prices closed slightly lower yesterday but well above their lows of the session, as traders and investors reacted with relative equanimity to the decision by the Federal Reserve Board to adopt a more hawkish stance on interest rates.

title: Mets Lose as an Old Foe Of Benitez Beats Him
description: Armando Benitez was not going to give in and throw his second-best pitch.

title: Corrections
description: An article on April 21 about an investigation into Richard C. Holbrooke's nomination as chief American diplomat at the United Nations referred incompletely to a speaking fee. Mr. Holbrooke's financial disclosure filings with the State Department included the information that he spoke to the Siemens electronics company in October 1998 for a $24,000 fee. But on April 22 Mr. Holbrooke amended his filing to show that the speech had been canceled and no fee paid.

title: Penney Plans Initiatives to Raise $6 Billion
description: J. C. Penney reported lower first-quarter earnings yesterday but announced two initiatives that could raise as much as $6 billion in revenue. The news sent the company's previously lagging stock price up 9.7 percent.

title: The Trip From Purr and Rumble to Rattle and Roar
description: THE man who invented Gatorade, Dr. Robert Cade, had a thing for old Studebakers. By the early 1970's, of course, there were no new Studebakers. The company was as extinct as a dodo. But Dr. Cade had seven or eight of them roosting around his house, near the University of Florida medical school, like a flock of molting birds: Golden Hawks and Silver Hawks and Sky Hawks from the mid-50's, their beaked noses rusting gently against one another's tired fenders.

title: Mirroring the Pain and Hope of Whitman's Poetry
description: This season, Dennis Russell Davies and the American Composers Orchestra began ''20th-Century Snapshots,'' a series of thematic concerts meant to explore musical responses to the artistic, philosophical and political currents of the century now ending. Conceived as a grand finale to his tenure as the orchestra's music director, the series is to run through 2001, and has already touched on the music of Cuba and the confluence of jazz and classical composition.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAZAR, LEONARD
description: LAZAR-Leonard. Age 80. Beloved husband of Mary Faith. Brother of Herbert and Nathan. Father of Gerald, Howard, Marvin, Andrew, Lawrence and Cynthia. Grandfather of eight and great-grandfather of eight. Funeral services to be held on Thursday, May 20 at 11AM at Riverside Funeral Chapel, 76 Street and Amsterdam Ave

title: Black Man's Death Raises Racial Tensions in Detroit
description: The beating death of an unarmed black man in front of his children at a neighborhood gas station has sparked four days of protests here that have brought into the open the festering racial tensions between blacks and Arab-Americans who own many small businesses in the inner city.

title: Many Arabs Feel That the Victory Over Netanyahu Means They Won Too
description: Arabs loved to hate Benjamin Netanyahu, so his trouncing in Israel's elections was welcomed by many in the Arab world today with a kind of triumphalism -- a sense that the Israelis had finally seen the light.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Higher Rates May Not Hurt Foreign Recoveries
description: A jump in interest rates in the United States -- which the Federal Reserve indicated yesterday was likely -- would raise the risks for the world's emerging markets just as they begin to recover from a financial crisis that began almost two years ago.

title: House Republicans, in a Shift of Focus, Begin a Public Campaign Against Gore
description: After years of battling with President Clinton, House Republicans are shifting their sights to Vice President Al Gore and using ridicule as their weapon of choice.

title: Commencements; At Teachers College, Crew Offers a Lesson
description: Rudy Crew, the Schools Chancellor, offered a parable of perseverance as he accepted a medal of honor at the 102d commencement exercises yesterday for Teachers College at Columbia University. Some 1,350 degrees were granted.

title: Abolish High School? Let the Market Decide
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUTNER, ALICE
description: KUTNER-Alice. On May 17, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Manuel. Devoted mother of Ellen. Services were held privately.

title: Big Japan Trading Company To Eliminate Half of Its Jobs
description: The Kanematsu Corporation, a large and financially troubled Japanese trading conglomerate, announced a three-year plan today to cut more than half of its work force of 17,000, spin off or farm out assets, and seek forgiveness of more than $3 billion of bank debt.

title: A Sixth Night for WB, for Under 35's Only
description: Continuing its campaign to dominate the television habits of people under 35, the WB network announced an expansion yesterday to six nights a week from five, adding Friday, in a new fall schedule that includes six new series, one for each night.

title: Happy Match: New Group and Early Music
description: The inaugural season of the New York Collegium has not even ended and already the period orchestra and choir have become essential to fanciers of Baroque music in the city. This should come as no surprise given that the Collegium was founded by the renowned early music conductor Gustav Leonhardt and regularly attracts distinguished visiting conductors, like Andrew Parrott, who offered ''Music for the English Chapel Royal,'' a program mostly of choral works by Purcell and Handel, on Saturday night at the architecturally and acoustically splendid St. Vincent Ferrer Church on the Upper East Side.

title: A Latin Caramel Sauce Wends Its Way Into the Mainstream
description: DULCE DE LECHE, a homey caramel that has long satisfied the Hispanic sweet tooth, is suddenly finding a wider audience. It has the potential to rival vanilla and chocolate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROPER, LEO, D.D.S.
description: ROPER-Leo, D.D.S. Of NYC, Pound Ridge, NY and Ajijic, Mexico. Died peacefully May 16 at age 92 in his Pound Ridge home. He is survived by his daughter, Elizabeth Marcus, his brothers, Herman Rose and Jesse Rappaport, and his two grandchildren.

title: They're Johnnies-on-the-Spot in the Land of Bondo Buggies
description: A few years ago, while shopping for a family doctor, my husband noted that while we had no regular physician, we counted four auto mechanics among our car-care providers. They were Ernie LeBlanc, our ''general practitioner,'' who changes the oil and does routine maintenance on our fleet of aging, rusting vehicles, and on whom we depend for referrals; Paul Ibey, the body man and orthopedist; Leon Betts, the Saab internist, and Joseph Monteith, a Volvo specialist of such renown that he is called, simply, ''Volvo Joe.'' If we had had a doctor, and no mechanics, we would have been much more worried.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIROFF, RUTH T.
description: LIROFF-Ruth T. Of Deerfield Beach, FL. Beloved wife of the late Jacob S., devoted mother of Stefanie Yosso, David and Richard Liroff, adored grandmother of Jonathan, Benjamin and Adam Liroff, Dara Yosso, Brooke Mezza. I.J. Morris Funeral Directors.

title: Commuter Tax Is a Social Pact; Pandering for Votes
description: To the Editor:

title: The Fed Edges Toward Action
description: The Federal Reserve's decision yesterday to leave interest rates unchanged but to warn that it was thinking of raising them in the future reaffirms how unsure the policy makers are about the state of the economy.

title: Chicago Board and Eurex Revive Negotiations Aimed at a Linkup
description: Eurex, the world's largest derivatives exchange, and the Chicago Board of Trade, the world's second largest, have resumed talks aimed at forging an alliance after the board voted against a planned link in January.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''It's not like we have a bunch of favorite recipes to work with. This may be an ancient tradition, but it's all new to us.''

title: Muscle, Muscle Everywhere
description: TAIL FINS went, round headlights gave way to square ones, and then chrome all but disappeared. But the biggest change in cars over the last few years is not cosmetic. It is under the hood: the engine is on steroids.

title: Hawks Reach Round 2, But Fans Don't Follow
description: Advance ticket sales for Game 1 did not approach 17,000. Privately, Atlanta Hawks team officials were banking on a large walk-up crowd tonight to give the Georgia Dome a playoff ambience. The hope was that a few thousand Knicks fans would help fill the cavernous building. But only 18,513 fans attended the game tonight.

title: Commercial Real Estate; Brokers Turning to Computers to Get Retailers Into the Tent
description: Retailing, it has been said, is a form of show business, with a store's signs, decorations and merchandise displays all intended to entice passers-by to come inside.

title: From Chefs, Comfort Food
description: BETWEEN them, Martin Peikof and Jenny Rodriguez have cooked in some of New York's most ambitious restaurants, including Montrachet and Nobu. So, are they content turning out what toney chefs might disparage as ''comfort food'' at BESSIE'S , their cafe and takeout shop, which opened about five weeks ago in Greenwich Village?

title: With VW Driving, Skoda Turns Corner
description: IT is never good form to bad-mouth your own company, but the bottom line was this: Detlev Wittig and his German colleagues were afraid to drive the cars.

title: Music Concern Files With S.E.C.
description: MP3.com, which runs an on-line site from which consumers can download music, has filed to raise $115 million through an initial public offering.

title: Michael Wettach, 66, Equestrian Who Was Guggenheim Trustee
description: Michael F. Wettach, an equestrian, restaurant owner and trustee of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation, died on Sunday in Baltimore. He was 66 and lived in Monkton, Md.

title: EBAY TO BUY ON-LINE BILL PROCESSOR AND A CAR AUCTIONEER
description: Ebay Inc., the No. 1 on-line auctioneer, agreed yesterday to buy Kruse International, auctioneers of collectible cars, and Billpoint Inc., a provider of on-line payment services, for a combined $275 million in stock. Ebay is expanding the variety of goods it handles as competition in the on-line auction business intensifies from Amazon.com Inc. and other new entrants. Last month, Ebay said it would buy the Butterfield & Butterfield Auctioneers Corporation, a San Francisco-based auction house, for about $260 million in stock, adding high-priced art and other collectibles to its service. Billpoint is based in Redwood City, Calif. Kruse International is based in Auburn, Ind. Both companies are closely held. The stock of Ebay, which is based in San Jose, Calif., fell $8.875 a share, to $189.5625.

title: Suit Against Securities Auditor Is Dismissed
description: A Federal judge dismissed a lawsuit on Monday in which the bankruptcy trustee for the brokerage firm A. R. Baron & Company, which is now defunct, contended that negligence by the accounting firm BDO Seidman L.L.P. had enabled A. R. Baron to pursue a huge stock fraud.

title: Executive Changes
description: HOOVER INC., Austin, Tex., a leading Web-based provider of business information, said Elisabeth DeMarse had joined the company as executive vice president for content, strategy and acquisitions.

title: Dudley Displays Muscle
description: When he joined the Knicks in 1997, Chris Dudley's lasting legacy in the National Basketball Association revolved around his ability to bang bodies and miss free throws.

title: Has Welfare Created A Culture of Defeat?
description: To the Editor:

title: OFF THE MENU
description: Company Dinners

title: FOOD STUFF
description: Midtown Pie Makers Find A Second Home Downtown

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on May 10 about an electronic commerce venture backed by several sporting goods retailers misstated the name of a comparable Internet site supported by wine and spirits wholesalers. It is wineshopper.com, not wineshipper.com.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TACCHELLI, MARY J.
description: TACCHELLI-Mary J. Of 440 E. 62 Street, passed away Sunday, May 16, 1999. She is survived by her special friend, Betty Nichols, with whom she resided, and several other relatives in upstate NY.

title: Democrats Risked Scorn in Supporting Repeal of Tax
description: ''How many have ducked you?'' Assemblyman Joseph R. Lentol asked a reporter today, hinting at the predicament of the New York City lawmakers who supported a repeal of the commuter tax on Monday and thus faced an array of jeers from Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and other city officials (turncoat was among the milder ones).

title: O'SULLIVAN INDUSTRIES ACCEPTS A BUYOUT BY MANAGEMENT
description: O'Sullivan Industries Holdings Inc., the third-largest United States maker of ready-to-assemble furniture, accepted a $350 million buyout offer yesterday from senior managers and a financial partner. A New York-based investment concern, Bruckman, Rosser, Sherrill & Company, and the managers will pay $17.50 a share in cash and one share of preferred stock, valued at $1.75, for each O'Sullivan share. The group will also assume an undisclosed amount of debt. Shares of O'Sullivan, based in Lamar, Mo., fell 75 cents, to $16.625.

title: 13 Told They Didn't Pass Bar Exam After All
description: Whoops. Thirteen would-be lawyers who were initially told that they had passed the New Jersey bar examination have now been told that there was a grading error: they did not pass after all.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Procedures Proposed for New Special Prosecutors
description: A bipartisan commission headed by two former Senate majority leaders recommended today that when the independent counsel law expires next month it be replaced with new procedures allowing the Attorney General to appoint special prosecutors to investigate whether top officials have committed crimes.

title: Search for Life Beyond Earth Gets a Leader
description: NASA gave new prominence today to its search for extraterrestrial life by appointing a Nobel laureate to head its recently formed Astrobiology Institute, dedicated to studying the origin, distribution and destiny of life in the universe.

title: Japan's Legislators Tighten The Ban on Under-Age Sex
description: The Japanese Parliament enacted a law today that aims at banning child prostitution and child pornography.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLES, JOAN CULLEN
description: COLES-Joan Cullen. Died peacefully on May 18, 1999 at her home on Shelter Island, NY, after a courageous battle with Parkinson's Disease. Deeply loved wife of Michael Coles; devoted mother of Caroline Scudder, Alison Aldredge, Isobel Coleman, Richard Coles, and Douglas Coles; beloved grandmother of Alison, Robert, Richard, Hilary, Sarah and Molly Scudder, Margaret, Alexandra and Hayden Aldredge, Cullen, Struan & Julian Coleman. She will be remembered most for her great generosity of spirit, her deep sense of humor, and her enormous love for her family. There will be a private funeral service. A memorial service is planned for mid-June. In lieu of flowers the family would welcome donations to the Inner City Scholarship Fund or the Nature Conservancy, Mashomack Preserve, Shelter Island.

title: From One Platform Many Models Grow
description: CAR buyers love choice. Car makers love low production costs.

title: S.E.C. Punishes On-Line Broker In Fund Shift
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission said yesterday that it had imposed sanctions against Datek Online, one of the nation's fastest-growing on-line brokers, for filing a false financial report and dipping into customer money last year, in part to pay off company expenses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EWELL, JAMES
description: EWELL-James. Age 62. Passed away on May 17, 1999 after a long battle with lung cancer. He'll surely be missed by many people. A kind man with a heart of gold. A small memorial service will be held on Thursday, May 20, 10 AM, St. James Episcopal Church, 865 Madison Avenue at 71st St. Howard Koeppel, Mark Hsiao

title: Has Welfare Created A Culture of Defeat?
description: To the Editor:

title: SUN INTERNATIONAL TO BUY DESERT INN FROM STARWOOD
description: Sun International Hotels Ltd., owner of the Atlantis resort in the Bahamas, agreed yesterday to buy Starwood Hotels and Resorts Worldwide Inc.'s Desert Inn for $275 million in cash, making its first entry into Las Vegas, Nev., the world's largest gambling market. Starwood, the largest hotel owner, is selling its major casino resorts to focus on its Sheraton and Westin hotel chains. Last month, it agreed to sell its Caesars World casinos to the Park Place Entertainment Corporation for $3 billion in cash. Starwood bought the Desert Inn and Caesars as part of its $14.6 billion purchase of the ITT Corporation last year. Shares of Sun International, based on Paradise Island, the Bahamas, rose 93.75 cents, to $47.125. Starwood, in White Plains, rose 25 cents, to $34.75.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WARD, SALLY FISHER
description: WARD-Sally Fisher. On May 17, 1999 of Forest Hills, NY. Wife of Captain Arthur D. Ward, USNR. Reposing at Fox Funeral Home Inc., 98-07 Ascan Avenue, Forest Hills, New York, on Saturday 7-9, Sunday 2-5 and 7-9. Funeral mass Our Lady of Mercy RC Church, 7001 Kessel St., Forest Hills, New York 11375, Monday, May 24, 1999 at 9:45 AM. Interment at Calverton National Cemetery in Calverton, NY. In lieu of flowers contributions to Our Lady of Mercy School would be appreciated.

title: Clemens to Sit Versus Boston
description: It is a returning manager's prerogative to change a decision. Don Zimmer, the Yankees' interim manager, had chosen to start Clemens against the Boston Red Sox on Thursday after being activated from the 15-day disabled list. But Joe Torre, who returned tonight, altered that decision.

title: Tunnel Vision on Dams
description: To the Editor:

title: Xerox-Microsoft Deal Links Variety of Technologies
description: Xerox and Microsoft today announced an alliance aimed at bridging the worlds of paper documents and computers.

title: Lemke's Future Is Fluttering in the Wind
description: Walking through the tunnels at Yogi Berra Stadium and onto the field, Mark Lemke humbly said hello to each ballplayer or stadium employee he passed, looking very much the part of a polite 33-year-old rookie with a knuckleball and a dream.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about television networks' efforts to find young actors for new youth-oriented shows included an outdated reference to ''Roswell,'' which is about teen-age space aliens. After the article went to press, the Fox network said it had decided not to use the show, which will now be seen on the WB network.

title: Clinton Keeps Option For Ground Troops
description: Under increasing public pressure to resolve the conflict in Kosovo, President Clinton said he would not rule out the use of ground troops, because he was not willing to ''take any option off the table.''

title: SPECIAL TODAY: Cars
description: It has taken a while, but Detroit is finally making cleaner-running cars, thanks to growing consumer concern with the environment and a more active generation of leaders, exemplified by William C. Ford Jr., chairman of the Ford Motor Company. A report by Keith Bradsher.

title: KOSOVO UPDATE
description: COMBAT

title: Witness Recalls Louima, Screaming and Bleeding, in Cell at Police Station
description: A Brooklyn teen-ager who had been in a police station holding cell testified yesterday that he heard banging and screaming in a restroom next door at the time prosecutors say Abner Louima was being tortured there by officers.

title: DaimlerChrysler's Smart Car Is Lone Sore Spot at Meeting
description: The snub-nosed Smart can turn on a dime, squeeze into half-sized parking spaces and switch from manual to automatic transmission at the push of a button.

title: Between the Feuding Rudys; Parents Like Giuliani and Crew, but Fear for the Schools
description: Like countless other New York City parents, Nancy Gasparino and her husband, Frank, a firefighter, have considered moving from their home in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, to the suburbs. But over the past few years, with crime falling and the economy booming, they have made their fragile peace with the city.

title: The Other Side of Title IX
description: It was a glorious spring day for baseball in Providence, R.I., last Saturday, in which the home team, the Providence College Friars, was about to play the Villanova Wildcats.

title: Law Limiting Medicaid for Needy Immigrants Is Overturned
description: A state judge has struck down a law that has denied Medicaid benefits to thousands of needy legal immigrants in New York.

title: Fighting the Road's Lullaby
description: LATE at night, a young man yawns. His eyelids slowly drift down; one arm slides to his side. For the next 12 seconds he is sound asleep -- barreling along a ruler-straight stretch of highway, his left arm locked into position on the steering wheel. A slight bump in the road rouses him, and he drives blearily on.

title: Zinfandel by Mail? Well, Yes and No; Shippers Are Able And Willing
description: ON a recent trip to the Napa Valley, when the vineyards were ablaze with carpets of yellow mustard flowers, my friend was hoping to purchase a case of wine she had been unable to find in New York. She thought it would take no more than a phone call. Instead, it turned into a 90-minute odyssey that required her to drive to the vineyard, pay for the wine, have the case put in her car and then transport it to a shipping service suggested by the winery.

title: The Latest in Automotive Fashion Calls for Mix and Match
description: HORTICULTURISTS have given us better-tasting tomatoes, more beautiful, hardier roses and more prolific varieties of corn by creating hybrids -- marrying the best traits of two or more strains again and again until the desired result is achieved.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLINE, ELMER
description: KLINE-Elmer. Playwright, poet, artist and art merchant. A world of loving friends. Your sunshine radiates our lives, your love knows no bounds. Funeral service Thursday 12 Noon, Wien and Wien, 152 Second Ave, NYC. Tom O'Horgan, Mack Gilbert

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VELKOFF, SYLVIA
description: VELKOFF-Sylvia. Beloved wife of the late Hyman, mother of Kenneth, Jan and CLiff. Sister of Beatrice Fields and the late Samuel and Leon Black. Services Thursday 11 A.M. at ''The Riverside'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave.

title: After the Hunt, Bitter Protest and Salty Blubber
description: Some jubilant Makah Indians feasted on the blubber and raw whale meat and declared themselves spiritually transported back in time. Others spat the meat out onto the beach or struggled to wash it down with that most traditional of beverages, Coca-Cola. Protesters called, ''Shame on you!'' from boats huddled out in the coastal fog of Neah Bay.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR IS LOWER. The dollar eased against leading currencies after the Federal Reserve declined to raise rates but said it would now lean toward an increase. In New York, the euro rose to $1.0680, from $1.0665 on Monday.

title: The Knicks Run, Gun And Have a Lot of Fun
description: There was a man behind the Knicks' bench last night, trying desperately to get the attention of Jeff Van Gundy and his players.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YARSHATER, LATIFEH (NEE ALVIEH)
description: YARSHATER-Latifeh (nee Alvieh). 73. On May 17, 1999 after a courageous battle against cancer. Survived by her husband, Ehsan, and her sisters Vadieh Stanger, Monir Arjomand, Evelyn Alvieh, their families, and many friends. She served as cultural advisor to the USIS in Tehran (1951-61), was founding member of the National Council of Women of Iran, after settling in New York in 1961 joined the US National Council of Women. She authored articles in both English and Persian and served as the Outreach Coordinator of Columbia University's Middle East Institute (1986-90). Funeral services will be on Saturday, May 22, 1999 at 10:00 a.m. at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel (1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St.). We will miss her.

title: Two Men, Two Italys, Two Ragouts
description: THIS is the story of two men, two memories, two regions of Italy, an adopted country and a mania for one pure thing -- real Italian ragout.

title: Editors' Note
description: A report in the News Watch column of Circuits on Thursday about a new Internet searching service reported that a survey had found that the World Wide Web comprises 500 million to 600 million pages. The finding was attributed to a market research company, Forrester Research Inc.

title: Zinfandel by Mail? Well, Yes and No; Strict Laws May Get Stricter
description: PROPELLED in part by increased alcohol sales on the Internet, intensive campaigns to restrict wine distribution further are afoot in state legislatures and in Washington.

title: A Failed Foreign Policy
description: To the Editor:

title: Change at the Top, But No Revolution
description: Presidential candidates come and Presidential candidates go in New Hampshire. But few manage to pass through in primary season without being subjected to the passionately partisan scrutiny of The Manchester Union Leader, the state's largest and most influential daily.

title: In Twist, Charges Against Former Morgan Stanley Analyst Are Dropped
description: The case of Christian Curry was already strange enough, with the lurid photographs and the forged E-mails and allegations of racism and homophobia within one of Wall Street's biggest firms.

title: Wanted: A Breath of Fresh Air
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Henry Jones, 86, Familiar Face In Theater, Films and TV Roles
description: Henry Jones, a Tony Award-winning character actor who had a long career on Broadway, in films and on television, died on Monday at U.C.L.A. Medical Center in Los Angeles. He was 86 and lived in Santa Monica, Calif.

title: NATO's Battle Within: Is Leadership Missing?
description: As President Clinton wrestles over the question of dispatching combat troops to Kosovo, NATO's strategy for bringing the war to a successful close is starting to unravel.

title: Mrs. Clinton's Perks
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BERNSTEIN, SHIRLEY
description: BERNSTEIN-Shirley. 1923-1998. Remembered and loved always. Lumumba

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: Justice Dept. Reopens Case On Demjanjuk for War Past
description: Reopening a case that has haunted the Justice Department for more than two decades, Federal prosecutors went to court today to try again to strip United States citizenship from John Demjanjuk, a retired auto-worker from Cleveland who the Government charged was a Nazi death camp guard.

title: Editors' Note
description: The Books of The Times column on April 8 reviewed ''Woman: An Intimate Geography,'' by Natalie Angier. Because Ms. Angier is a science reporter for The Times, the editors selected a nonstaff reviewer, Marilyn Yalom, a senior scholar at the Institute for Research on Women and Gender at Stanford University. She called the book dazzling.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the reinstatement of five criminal charges against Maria Hsia, a Democratic fund-raiser, referred incorrectly to Vice President Al Gore's role in the case. He was not identified as legally responsible in any way in connection with the charges against her.

title: How Tough Is Your Laptop?; For Off-Road Typing, and a Rugged Look, Computers Built Like Tanks
description: LARRY GARRETT, a Sears technician, didn't get a chance to see what was wrong with the riding mower during a service call on April 3 near Benton, La. He was barely in the door of the customer's mobile home when a tornado set it and Mr. Garrett tumbling.

title: RESIDENTIAL SALES
description: MANHATTAN

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENSTOCK, JANE
description: BENSTOCK-Jane, age 92, died peacefully at her home in Brightwaters, NY on May 19, 1999. Wife of the late David. Devoted mother of Mochelle Stettner of Allentown, PA and Gerald Benstock of Belleair Beach, FL. Cherished grandmother of 8 and great-grandmother of 15. Memorial contributions to the Bayshore Jewish Center.

title: Women Protest Draftees' Kosovo Duty
description: Women in two towns in southern Serbia continued their street protests today, demanding that their sons be allowed home from army service in Kosovo.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOEWENSTEIN, REGINA
description: LOEWENSTEIN - Regina. The Weizmann Institute of Science and its American Committee express their deep sorrow at the passing of Regina Loewenstein, sister of Martha Loewenstein, a long-time Weizmann supporter, both as a professional and as a lay leader. We extend sincere condolences to the entire family. Gershon Kekst, Chairman Weizmann Institute of Science Haim Harari, President Robert H. Asher, Chairman American Committee Albert Willner, M.D., President Martin Kraar, Executive VP

title: Tyco to Pay $1.4 Billion for Raychem
description: Tyco International Ltd., the No. 1 maker of electronic components, agreed today to buy the Raychem Corporation, gaining Raychem's wiring and tubing to offer customers a single source for industrial electrical products.

title: Northern Light to Proceed With Service
description: Northern Light Technology Inc., whose new fee-based service for searching Federal Government data bases fell victim to a bureaucratic bungle this week, said today that it would begin the service with or without the Clinton Administration's backing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTHENBERG, ROBERT
description: ROTHENBERG - Robert. The Board of Directors extends their sincerest condolences to the family of Harvey Rothenberg, AICF's Treasurer, on the death of his beloved brother. Vera Stern, President America-Israel Cultural Foundation

title: New campaign to focus on Lands' End's cybercatalogue.
description: THE longtime New York editor Lee Eisenberg said he felt as if he were on Neptune when he first landed in Dodgeville, Wis., last March to become the top creative executive for Lands' End Inc. catalogues.

title: Family Says Hospital Lost Track of Body
description: Michael McClester disappeared one winter day in 1992 after being taken to a Bronx hospital in an ambulance. Hospital officials told his family that he had been treated and released, so they started searching for him.

title: Economic Scene; You can call an airline a bird of prey, but can you make it stick?
description: THE Justice Department's antitrust suit against American Airlines accusing it of predatory behavior is easy to mock.

title: It's Europe's Turn To Lead NATO
description: To the Editor:

title: Treasury Investors Send a Vote of Confidence to the Fed
description: Rates on short-term Treasury securities held steady yesterday, while longer-term rates fell sharply, as investors seemed to send a vote of confidence -- at least for now -- to the Federal Reserve.

title: A Guaranteed Job
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SABLOVE, ALBERT J.
description: SABLOVE-Albert J. Age 79. Devoted husband of Selma (nee Brodsky), loving father of Barbara and Robert, dear father-in-law of Barry and Audrey, cherished Grandpa of Peter, Matthew, Robyn, Paul, and Samuel. Funeral services Thursday, 11:30AM at I. J. Morris Inc., 46 Greenwich Street, Hempstead, New York.

title: Coming Soon (Maybe) to a Screen Near You
description: LOS ANGELES is no stranger to action sequences and special effects. But for three days in May, the Electronics Entertainment Expo put on a light show that was extreme even for Hollywood. The sprawling behemoth that is the Los Angeles Convention Center was packed to the rafters with video games -- CD-ROM's, console games, handheld games -- peripherals and accessories of all descriptions, as well as thousands of software developers, publishers, retailers, investors and journalists.

title: New Themes for a Summer Place
description: THIS season, do the unexpected to ''summerize'' your home. Add a few leaves in the bathroom, some reeds on the porch or -- of all things -- a bug on the wall. Spring brings an array of fresh, inexpensive and easy-to-care-for summer furniture and accessories. Ordinary materials like kraft paper, cardboard egg crates and plastic drinking straws have been cleverly reworked into window shades, footstools and lamps.

title: Peace Opponent Pulls Out of Israeli Politics, Aiding Barak
description: The politician considered the one truly principled opponent of peace with the Palestinians suddenly stepped out of public life today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAZAR, LEONARD
description: LAZAR-Leonard. Age 80. Beloved husband of Mary Faith. Brother of Herbert and Nathan. Father of Gerald, Howard, Marvin, Andrew, Lawrence and Cynthia. Grandfather of eight and great-grandfather of eight. Funeral services to be held on Thursday, May 20 at 11AM at Riverside Funeral Chapel, 76 Street and Amsterdam Ave

title: Power Plant Overload
description: State by state, government regulators are trying to reform the electric utility industry. They should spend some time reforming themselves as well.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HYMAN, HERBERT H.
description: HYMAN-Herbert H. On May 18, 1999. Beloved husband of Edith. Devoted father of Jeanne Lewis, Edward and Gerald Hyman. Dear brother of Nadine Wray. Loving grandfather of Jesse, Cameron, Gregory, Eric and Devon. Services today 12 noon at Temple Sinai, 425 Roslyn Road, Roslyn Heights, L.I.

title: GERMANY'S LEADER PLEDGES TO BLOCK COMBAT ON GROUND
description: Divisions among the allies over using ground troops in Kosovo burst into the open today when Germany's Chancellor came to NATO and declared that his country would block the alliance from fighting a land war.

title: GE CAPITAL TO BUY PHOENIX HOME'S LIFE REINSURANCE UNIT
description: The GE Capital Corporation, the world's largest nonbank financial services company, said yesterday that it had agreed to take over the Phoenix Home Life Mutual Insurance Company's life reinsurance operation. Terms of the transaction were not disclosed. The deal will vault GE Capital's Employers Reinsurance Corporation to fourth from sixth among the nation's life reinsurers. Phoenix Home had $105.5 billion in policies last year. Jody Beresin, a Phoenix Home spokeswoman, said the company was selling its life reinsurance business, in which a company buys policies from a life insurer in exchange for a share of the premiums, to focus on its main insurance, retirement savings and investment management businesses.

title: More Control Center Problems Cause Plane Delays in New York
description: An air traffic control center on Long Island that suffered a computer failure earlier this month was knocked out of service twice again today, causing widespread delays in the late afternoon at the three major New York airports and in Philadelphia.

title: When Drug Trials Hurt Patients; The Placebo Problem
description: To the Editor:
