title: CVB FINANCIAL TO BUY ORANGE NATIONAL FOR $76 MILLION
description: The CVB Financial Corporation, a Southern California-based bank holding company, said this week that it had agreed to buy Orange National Bancorp for $75.9 million in stock to expand in Orange County, Calif. Orange National has six offices and assets of $279 million. CVB, which is based in Ontario, Calif., has 24 offices and assets of $1.5 billion. CVB Financial said late Tuesday that it would exchange 1.5 of its shares for each share of Orange National, valuing Orange National at $37.22 a share. Orange National's shares rose $2.75 yesterday, to $31.75, while CVB was down $1.3125, to $23.50.

title: Repression in Pakistan
description: For most of its history, Pakistan has been ruled by military dictators. In the last 10 years, however, Pakistanis have managed to break from their authoritarian traditions and enjoy the freedom of elections and free speech. Now this trend is in peril, with the arrest this month of a respected and outspoken journalist, Najam Sethi, by the military's intelligence branch.

title: Mandela Aide Tries to Allay Fears
description: The African National Congress has no plans to change the Constitution if it wins a two-thirds majority in the election on June 2, Deputy President Thabo Mbeki says.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZWEIGMAN, ANNE (NEE GRAUMAN).
description: ZWEIGMAN-Anne (nee Grauman). Of West Palm Beach, Fla. On May 14, 1999. The Grauman, Steckler and Tannenbaum families mourn the loss of their dear sister, aunt, great-aunt and greatgreat aunt. She will be lovingly remembered and sadly missed.

title: You See, Doctor, My Pillow Hit Me
description: HERE'S a fact for you. According to the latest Statistical Abstract of the United States, in one year nearly 400,000 Americans suffered injuries involving beds, mattresses or pillows. Think about that for a minute. That is more than 1,000 bed, mattress or pillow injuries a day. In the time it takes you to read this piece, four of my fellow citizens will somehow manage to be wounded by their bedding.

title: SWISSAIR'S PARENT BUYS AIRLINE CATERER FOR $780 MILLION
description: SAir Group, the holding company for the European airline Swissair, said yesterday that it had acquired the United States airline caterer Dobbs International Services Inc. from the Viad Corporation of Phoenix for $780 million. Dobbs, based in Memphis, is one of the world's largest airline caterers and the nation's largest rail caterer. The merged company will have annual sales of more than $2 billion. The integration of Dobbs is expected to reduce earnings by 3 percent to 4 percent a share in the first 18 months. Viad shares rose $2.3125, to $31.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the announcement by the Mexican Interior Minister, Francisco Labastida Ochoa, that he will resign and run for President misstated his age. He is 56.

title: Prosecutors Hit Snag in Case Against Group of Brokers
description: The Federal Government's high-profile case against a group of stockbrokers charged with illegal trading on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange has run into a significant snag.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LANDAU, SAMUEL J.
description: LANDAU-Samuel J. May 20, 1989. In remembrance. Bo

title: East Timor Group Sues Over Renaming Street
description: A New York group favoring independence for East Timor, the island annexed by Indonesia in 1976, has filed a Federal lawsuit against the city because it twice denied a request to rename temporarily a part of East 68th Street in Manhattan in support of the group's cause.

title: PAUL ALLEN'S CABLE TV COMPANY TO EXPAND INTO MICHIGAN
description: Charter Communications Inc., a cable-television operator owned by the Microsoft co-founder Paul Allen, agreed this week to buy Avalon Cable Television for $845 million to expand its operations into Michigan. With the purchase of Avalon and the completion of other acquisitions, Charter will have 3.9 million customers nationwide. Avalon, which is backed by Boston's ABRY Partners Inc., a private equity fund, serves about 260,000 customers, primarily in Michigan and Massachusetts. Charter already has operations in Massachusetts. The company, which is based in St. Louis, said the transaction would include the assumption of an undisclosed amount of Avalon's debt. Charter is already committed to $3.7 billion in cable purchases this year.

title: Planning for Greatness to Come
description: There are not enough names for the emotions that great architecture inspires, and as a result the names of buildings themselves become shorthand for the complex impressions they leave behind. Grand Central is one name for many feelings, and so, in a different key, is the United States Custom House and Rockefeller Center. These constructions are a homage to reason, to the constraints of site and the possibilities of engineering. But they also allude to the human susceptibility to space, to the way remarkable buildings remodel the emotional interior of the humans who pass among them.

title: Bronx Woman Convicted in Starving of Her Breast-Fed Son
description: A jury needed only two and a half hours yesterday to convict Tabitha Walrond of criminally negligent homicide for the fatal starvation of her infant son, but acquit her of second-degree manslaughter, a more serious charge.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABEL, WALTER
description: ABEL-Walter. On May 19, 1999 of Port Washington, NY. Beloved husband of Mary Ellen. Dear father of Janine M., and David W. and Amy J. Services today, 1:30 PM, at Sunset Chapels, 1285 Northern Boulevard, Manhasset, New York.

title: Being Privileged Can Take a Lot of Trouble
description: OSTENSIBLY Marina Rust is another pretty young thing being honored for good works by a charity tonight in hopes that the charity, the Henry Street Settlement, will attract more P.Y.T.'s and their money. It's a good bet: In the junior committee world of in-training society doyennes that encompasses 25 blocks of the Upper East Side, Ms. Rust has, for now, broken out ahead in the cashmere-sweater set.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBLUM, LILLIAN (DIDI),
description: ROSENBLUM-Lillian (Didi), on May 18. Born on June 20, 1900. Widow of Morris. Survived by daughters Jerry and Elly and their husbands Roger Newburger and Israel Kopmar, seven grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. Services private. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to your favorite charity.

title: Lights! Camera! Keyboard!
description: PORTABLE computers have come a long way since Compaq introduced its inaugural model in 1982, an oblong, 28-pound suitcase with a fold-down keyboard and 9-inch, black-and-white monitor.

title: When Drug Trials Hurt Patients; Light Sentence
description: To the Editor:

title: Truly the Greatest Show on Earth
description: I WAS in one of those down-at-the-mouth moods one morning last week as my cab tore down Fifth Avenue, when a horse-chestnut tree hailed me from Central Park. Its pyramidal white blooms, like giant vanilla cones, rose high above the other trees, and I could swear some kind of cosmic wink passed between us.

title: Cold War's Heavy Cost
description: To the Editor:

title: AT HOME WITH: Tony Hiss; A Son's Debt of Honor
description: IN the center of the mantel, there's an eight-inch wood plaque bought in the gift shop at the Federal penitentiary in Lewisburg, Pa. The painted plaque shows the prison as it looks now, and as it looked when Tony Hiss's father, Alger Hiss, occupied a cell there, convicted of perjury back in the 1950's for saying he didn't pass secrets to Whittaker Chambers, an admitted Communist spy.

title: Referee Finds Disney Breached Katzenberg Pact
description: The referee presiding over Jeffrey Katzenberg's contentious lawsuit against the Walt Disney Company ruled today that Disney had breached its contract with him and that he had not forfeited his bonus by leaving Disney before his contract expired.

title: Breaking Out of Old Categories; Jessye Norman and Bill T. Jones Create a Performance
description: There was a moment in rehearsal, Bill T. Jones said, when his partner Jessye Norman used her voice to say something about herself that went beyond words and music. She started out with an opera, slid into something jazzy and then ambled into a land of soulful notes.

title: World Bank Delays Aid So Indonesians Can't Use It to Buy Votes
description: Top Clinton Administration officials said today that they had pressed the World Bank to make sure that more than a billion dollars in aid to Indonesia was held up for several weeks so that the country's Government could not use it to buy votes in the first free election there in more than 40 years.

title: Pornography Cited in Ouster At Harvard
description: In a case that has raised questions of privacy and propriety on the Harvard University campus, university officials said today that the dean of the Divinity School was forced to resign last fall because pornographic images had been discovered on his university-owned computer.

title: State Sports Official To Quit for N.B.A. Job
description: The head of the state agency that operates the Continental Airlines Arena said Tuesday that he would quit to become the National Basketball Association's vice president for business operations.

title: Election Panel May Yield on Internet Giving
description: Responding to burgeoning political activity on the Internet, the Federal Election Commission is expected on Thursday to bring Presidential fund-raising into the age of electronic commerce.

title: Ernst Seeks Large Subsidy To Move to Times Sq. Tower
description: Ernst & Young, one of the country's largest accounting and consulting firms, has asked state and city officials for a $65 million subsidy to move to an expensive new office tower in Times Square, according to public officials and real estate executives.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about the Israeli election referred incorrectly in some copies to the year Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin was assassinated. It was 1995, not 1993.

title: CONTIFINANCIAL AGREES TO BE ACQUIRED BY UNIT OF G.M.
description: The Contifinancial Corporation, a mortgage and home-equity lender, said yesterday that it had tentatively agreed to be acquired by a unit of the General Motors Corporation. Contifinancial, which is based in New York, and its biggest shareholder, the Continental Grain Company, signed an agreement to sell the company to the Residential Funding Corporation, the mortgage unit of the General Motors Acceptance Corporation, the finance subsidiary of G.M. Terms of the acquisition have yet to be worked out. Contifinancial shares rose 56.25 cents yesterday, to $7.1875.

title: Sticking to Issues Pays Off for Philadelphia Mayoral Primary Winner
description: In winning the Democratic primary on Tuesday to succeed Edward G. Rendell as Mayor of Philadelphia, John F. Street held tightly to his issue-oriented message in the face of personal attacks that nearly defeated him.

title: Devils' Hoboken Plan Enlists Cablevision
description: A plan by the Devils' owner, John McMullen, to build an arena in Hoboken is getting a boost from Cablevision, which is becoming a 50-50 partner in the venture.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GALLAGHER, MARIE C.
description: GALLAGHER-Marie C. Of Great Neck. On May 18, 1999. Beloved mother of Gail, Susan and Kevin. Also survived by four grandchildren and five great-grandchildren. In repose at Fairchild Sons, 1570 Northern Boulevard, Manhasset, Thursday 7 to 9 PM. Funeral Mass St. Aloysius Church, Great Neck, Friday, 10:30 AM.

title: Aides Say First Lady Inches Closer to Run
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton has told friends in recent days that she is likely to form an exploratory committee that would allow her to raise money and pay bills associated with a campaign for a New York seat in the Senate, several associates of the First Lady said yesterday.

title: After the Menu, a Quiz
description: TALK about chewing scenery.

title: Judge Approves Fine Host Plan
description: The Fine Host Corporation, a food-and-drinks caterer for sports stadiums and convention centers, received approval today from a judge for a bankruptcy reorganization plan designed to wipe out $175 million in debt.

title: Microsoft Head Gives $5 Million to Charities
description: The chairman of the Microsoft Corporation, William H. Gates, and his wife, Melinda, donated $5 million yesterday to help charities hurt by the collapse of the United Way of Santa Clara County, Calif., which gave away more money than it took in until it went broke on May 1.

title: Essay; An Unorthodox Election
description: Ehud Barak won a landslide victory in Israel because of who he was not.

title: Study Finds TV Alters Fiji Girls' View of Body
description: ''You've gained weight'' is a traditional compliment in Fiji, anthropologists say.

title: Hundreds of Yugoslav Troops Said to Desert
description: Hundreds of Yugoslav soldiers deserted their brigade in Kosovo on Tuesday, defying their officers and fighting through a military checkpoint to return to their homes in Krusevac, to the north, NATO officials said today.

title: A Guaranteed Job; Gains Against Poverty
description: To the Editor:

title: Mexico Falters in 2 Drug Cases
description: Efforts to prosecute the Amezcua Contreras brothers, whom American authorities say rank among the world's largest producers of illegal methamphetamines, appear to be collapsing.

title: Augusto Pablo, 46, Musician; Helped Shape Reggae's Sound
description: Augustus Pablo, a widely influential reggae producer, died on Tuesday at University Hospital in Kingston, Jamaica. He was 46 and lived in the hills outside Kingston.

title: An Art Form That's Precise But Friendly Enough to Wink
description: YOU may not have heard the term before, but the chances are strong that you've seen a lenticular image or two. In fact, it's almost impossible not to go past one without stopping, cocking your head and swaying back and forth to get a better look. They've been stuck on cereal boxes, advertising awnings, department store displays, postcards and buttons -- and even, in a very crude form, on CD covers. And in every case, they contain some kind of eye-catching animation or a 3-D perspective on a picture, or both.

title: INSIDE
description: Russian Premier Approved

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: INSILCO HOLDING CO., Dublin, Ohio, an industrial parts maker and publisher, said it had agreed to buy Thermal Transfer Products Ltd., Racine, Wis., a maker of industrial oil coolers with 1998 revenue of $28 million, for an undisclosed price.

title: Clearing Your Computer's Deck
description: Q. I've been trying to run Scan Disk on my C drive, but this message appears: ''Scan disk has restarted 10 times because Windows or another program has been writing to this drive. Quitting some running programs may enable Scan Disk to finish sooner.'' I have no other programs running and have even disabled the virus scan. What's wrong?

title: A Great Champion Is Dead; One Deceit Was a Classic
description: The bridge world lost a great player when Bob Goldman died in Dallas on Sunday from a heart attack at age 60. In a 35-year tournament career, he won four world titles, including the Bermuda Bowl three times, and had many national titles. These included the Spingold Knockout five times, the Vanderbilt Knockout five times and the Reisinger Teams three times.

title: A Guaranteed Job; Living-Wage Ordinances
description: To the Editor:

title: GARDEN NOTEBOOK; Primordial Embraces Modern
description: ''I HAD never done a modern garden till I got here,'' said Richard Hartlage, a garden designer and horticulturist from Seattle, who is now working on his first two private gardens in the New York area. ''I had teethed on Gertrude Jekyll.''

title: Distributor Settles Fraud Case Against Coca-Cola Enterprises
description: A Maryland soft-drink distributor that sued Coca-Cola Enterprises in Federal court, accusing the bottler of fraud, wiretapping and other tactics intended to drive the distributor out of business, has agreed to drop the charges and settle its case.

title: AT&T RAISES ESTIMATE FOR PROFIT AFTER BUYING MEDIAONE
description: The AT&T Corporation expects its acquisition of Mediaone Group to cut profit by about half as much as previously estimated because of lower borrowing costs and a $5 billion investment from the Microsoft Corporation. AT&T expects the purchase to reduce earnings next year by about 9 percent, or 15 cents to 16 cents a share. It expects to earn $2.11 to $2.15 a share after including the effect of its purchase of Mediaone, AT&T's chief financial officer, Daniel Somers, said. AT&T agreed to buy Mediaone, the No. 4 United States cable-television provider, earlier this month for about $62.5 billion in a move to become the largest United States cable-TV provider. At the time, AT&T said the purchase could reduce 2000 earnings by as much as 30 cents a share.

title: College Students Learn to Transform Daydreams Into Hands-On Reality
description: WHEN Mary Schmidt Campbell, the dean of the Tisch School of the Arts at New York University, walked onto the fourth floor of the school's main building on May 12, she thought she knew what to expect. It was the second day of the new-media art show, an annual event where frenetic crowds and crazy computing projects have become standard fare.

title: Hoechst to Purchase Rest of Celanese Canada
description: Hoechst A.G. said yesterday that it planned to offer the equivalent of about $306 million for all the common shares of Celanese Canada that it does not already own as it prepares to spin off Celanese, a chemical business, to shareholders before its November merger with Rhone-Poulenc S.A. of France. Hoechst, Germany's biggest drug maker, said it would offer $25 (Canadian) a share for the 17.98 million shares in Celanese Canada it does not own, which represent 44 percent of the unit. The stock closed at $19.05 on Tuesday. Five institutional shareholders, holding about 21 percent of Celanese Canada's common stock, have provisionally agreed to accept the offer, Hoechst said.

title: Some Abandon Water Cooler For Internet Stock Trading
description: In Florida, a young dentist tracks stocks between patients, sometimes even between an X-ray and a filling. In Washington State, a freight-company manager logs on to a financial Web site for four to six hours of his workday. A designer at a California architectural firm gets so absorbed in the market that his productivity falls 25 percent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GAMBLE, ETHEL ANN (NEE O'BRIEN).
description: GAMBLE - Ethel Ann (nee O'Brien). Born January 29, 1911 in the Bronx, New York and departed peacefully on May 19, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Frank G. Dear mother of Kenneth G. of New Rochelle, N.Y., Thomas J. of Biddeford, Me, Mary Tobin of Short Hills, N.J., Theresa Basralian of Millburn, N.J., Anne Gamble Ordonez of Millburn, N.J., and the late Frank M. Cherished grandmother of Gregory, Thomas, Kristin, Kelley, Theresa, Megan, Peter, Christopher, Denise, Daniel, Sofia, Berj, and Raffi. Great-grandmother of Madison and Ashley. Fond sister of Eugene O'Brien of Hollywood, Fl. Reposing David J. Hodder & Son Funeral Home, 899 McLean Ave, Yonkers. Visiting hours Thursday, 7-9 P.M., Friday, 2-4 and 7-9 P.M. Funeral Mass Saturday, 9:45 A.M., Saint Barnabas Church. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery. May she rest in peace. In lieu of flowers, kindly make contributions to Catholic Charities, c/o Msgr. James J. Murray, 1011 First Ave., New York, N.Y. 10022.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report on Tuesday about two gay men in Hackensack, N.J., who adopted a second child misspelled the given name of the judge in the case. She is Judge Sybil R. Moses, not Cybil.

title: Police Rescue Woman After East River Plunge
description: A 26-year-old woman who fell or jumped into the East River yesterday afternoon was rescued more than a mile downstream after a team of police officers in scuba gear leapt from a helicopter to save her, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  QUASH, RHODA
description: QUASH-Rhoda. The Board of Governors, Administration and the entire Sound Shore Medical Center family deeply mourn the passing of Rhoda Quash. As the Medical Center's Director of Government Affairs, Ms. Quash was an effective and tireless advocate for providing the highest quality patient care to all who sought it. She collaborated skillfully with her colleagues in both City and State government to enact legislation that promoted access to affordable health care, build our City and enhance the quality of life for all its residents. Her contributions to the City of New Rochelle, including the creation of the Summer Jobs Program for young people and expanding employment opportunities for African American citizens, are permanent legacies that will reap benefits for future generations. We will always remember her strength and dignity under pressure, her willingness to forge ahead and overcome insurmountable obstacles and her beautiful smile. We will greatly miss her. We extend our deepest sympathy to her husband Tom, son Quentin and all the members of her family. Clark E. Walter, Chairman Board of Governors John R. Spicer, President and Chief Executive Officer Sound Shore Medical Center of Westchester

title: Big L Smoothes Over Knicks' Little Gripes
description: Marcus Camby was sulking after Game 1, perhaps wondering why Charles Oakley had been more of a presence in the Georgia Dome stands on Tuesday night than Camby had been on the bench. The angular 7-foot forward had played a measly 10 minutes, all in the second quarter.

title: 2 From Mexico's PRI Out of Race
description: Two influential governing party politicians today ended weeks of mystery about their presidential aspirations, declining to compete for the party's nomination against Interior Minister Francisco Labastida Ochoa, who is said to be President Ernesto Zedillo's choice.

title: The Big City; Car Renters Face Hot Seat On Insurance
description: THE philosophers in the New York State Legislature are grappling with a subtle question: Is it right and just for a rental-car company to hustle you out of $9 a day?

title: Pataki and Silver Backing Forced Aid for Mentally Ill
description: Gov. George E. Pataki and the Assembly Speaker, Sheldon Silver, today joined the ranks of those advocating a state law that would make it easier to compel mentally ill people to undergo treatment, and in some instances to commit them to hospitals.

title: Program to Give Some Elderly 2d Meal a Day
description: Citymeals-on-Wheels, which provides daily hot lunches for homebound elderly people, will begin delivering a second meal to some clients because of a sharp jump in the number of people 85 or older who are at risk of malnutrition, city officials said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AGRANOFF, JOAN
description: AGRANOFF-Joan. Kind friend, artist, sculptress, her wonderment of life's gifts now stilled forever. She will be greatly missed. Friends and neighbors of E. 9th St.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Friend of Cosby? Now, That's Cool

title: Novels Haunted By Actors' Faces
description: Does an enduringly successful movie or television mini-series of a novel determine our perception of a compelling fictional character? Are these imagined people forever more perceived as different from what their creators might have intended? When readers sit down with ''Hannibal,'' the sequel to ''The Silence of the Lambs,'' will they see in their minds Anthony Hopkins and Jodie Foster? And, if they do, is that a plus or minus for the reader and the writer who created the character in the first place? Moreover, can a great actor steal a great character from the writer?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BESHARIM, DAVID
description: BESHARIM-David. Young Israel of Harrison mourns the passing of David Besharim, beloved father of its devoted member, Shlomo Besharim and extends heartfelt condolences to Shlomo and Karen and the entire bereaved family. Yaakov Bienenfeld, Rabbi Ed Leventhal, President

title: Effort to Overhaul Social Security Is Revived
description: A bipartisan group of Senators will propose a plan on Thursday to deal with Social Security's looming problems while there is tentative maneuvering at the White House and on Capitol Hill to revive an issue that had seemed all but dead for this year.

title: Alvin Rockwell, 90; Lawyer Helped Mold A Postwar Germany
description: Alvin John Rockwell, a prominent San Francisco lawyer who as a Government attorney helped to draft the legal system for a democratic postwar Germany, died yesterday in San Francisco, where he lived. He was 90.

title: KLM Operating Loss Triples in Quarter
description: KLM Royal Dutch Airlines N.V., Europe's fourth-largest carrier, said yesterday that its fourth-quarter operating loss had tripled, as recession in Asia and increased competition on North Atlantic routes brought fares down. The operating loss for the three months that ended on March 31 widened to 236 million guilders ($126.9 million), from 62 million guilders a year earlier. The net loss for the period was 88 million guilders against a loss of 96 million a year earlier.

title: When Drug Trials Hurt Patients; Scheming Materialists?
description: To the Editor:

title: In Trenton, G.O.P. Moves on Gun Control
description: Amid growing public support for stronger gun control laws, Republican legislators in New Jersey are moving quickly on bills to require childproof trigger locks on guns sold in the state and are considering a bill that would create strict criminal penalties for parents whose children use their firearms.

title: Little Latin Area Effect Seen From Fed's Alert
description: The possibility of an increase in United States interest rates, as suggested by the Federal Reserve this week, is unlikely to undermine the steady improvement in Latin America's economic outlook, forecasters said today.

title: But What Exactly Does It Do?
description: Sometimes antique value is not as important as usage value, said Richard Maslow, a furniture dealer who will be selling refinished, lightly modernized Chinese antiques -- oak, teak, mahogany, walnut and linden wood -- on Memorial Day weekend at Richard's Traveling Home Furnishings Sale on Long Island at the Southampton Center.

title: Corrections
description: A profile on Tuesday about Ehud Barak, Israel's Prime Minister-elect, misstated the location of the Heffer Valley, the site of the kibbutz where Mr. Barak was born. It is about 20 miles north of Tel Aviv near the Mediterranean coast; it is not near the Lebanese border.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We are real grateful, happy and proud that our ancestors are on their way home,''

title: Mobilizing on Line for Gun Control
description: PETITIONS that circulate on the Internet are an iffy proposition. Many of them, no matter how lofty the cause, smack of spam. Understandably, people often ignore them.

title: Jerome Wolken, 82, Scientist Who Gave Sight to Some Blind
description: Jerome Jay Wolken, a biophysicist at Carnegie Mellon University in Pittsburgh who delved into the mysteries of sight and light and invented a lens system that gave sight to some legally blind people, died on May 10 at his home in Pittsburgh. He was 82.

title: Exhibitions of Quilts, Art and Table Settings
description: A Critical Look

title: NEWS WATCH
description: In just a few months, half of the new televisions sold in the United States will be required by Federal law to include a V-chip, a device that enables parents to block programs from appearing on their television screens. But there's just one problem: the rating system that makes the V-chip possible has been out for more than a year, but it isn't used by most parents. In fact, the number of parents using the ratings has declined to 22 percent from 31 percent in the last year. The figures come from a survey of 1,000 parents that was conducted last month by the Kaiser Foundation and the Center for Media Education.

title: Altered Corn May Imperil Butterfly, Researchers Say
description: All around the country, farmers are about to finish sowing millions of acres of a genetically altered form of corn that protects itself from pests by producing a toxin in its tissues. But researchers report today that this increasingly popular transgenic plant, thought to be harmless to nonpest insects, produces a wind-borne pollen that can kill monarch butterflies -- a species that claims the Corn Belt as the heart of its breeding range.

title: First Lady Likely to Form Senate Committee, Aides Say
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton has told friends in recent days that she is likely to form an exploratory committee that would allow her to raise money and pay bills associated with a Senate campaign, several associates of the First Lady said yesterday.

title: A Consultant Reports a Flaw In Ebay's Web Site Security
description: Nothing lasts for long on Ebay, the popular on-line auction house, except, apparently, potential security flaws.

title: Power Nesting at Warp Speed
description: IT had been a volatile week on Wall Street. On the Big Board, trading was heavy; the Dow marched steadily toward 9000. But last July, Carey Maloney and Hermes Mallea were busy orchestrating their own big deals.

title: Where Miss Liberty Welcomed Huddled Masses, Now on CD
description: Just as Ellis Island was the port of entry for millions of immigrants, South Peak Interactive in Cary, N.C., is hoping that its new CD-ROM, The Ellis Island Experience, will be the port of entry for millions of computer users when it is released next year.

title: Fewer Names for Mac Users
description: To the Editor:

title: Schroder's Blunt 'No' to Ground Troops in Kosovo Reflects Depth of German Sensitivities
description: The categorical declaration today by Chancellor Gerhard Schroder that Germany would not countenance a NATO ground war in Kosovo reflected the sensitivities of a country for which even bombing Yugoslavia has already stretched political possibilities.

title: Anger at Orthodox Revives a Party
description: When Tommy Lapid left a successful career as a political commentator and television talk-show host to head the secular Shinui Party two months ago, it was limping along with barely enough support to win a seat in Parliament.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERENSTEIN, HARRY T.
description: HERENSTEIN-Harry T. Beloved and devoted husband of the late Ruth Spitz Herenstein. Loving brother of the late Louis Hernstein, Gladys Cohen, Lester and Moe Herenstein, Dorothy Sollar, Perry & Henry Herenstein. Caring brother-in-law of Pearl Herenstein. Dear uncle of Arlene Asher, Doris Fine, Arnold R. Sollar, Herman Herenstein, Elaine Sollar Eisen, Ira Herenstein, Francine Gilstein, Arnold Herenstein, Charna Herenstein & the late Larry Herenstein. We have all benefited from his wisdom, wit and love. And we will miss him and cherish his memory. Service on Sunday 11 A.M., at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Essex Chief Offers Plan for County-Run Waste Disposal for Communities
description: The Essex County Executive, James W. Treffinger, unveiled his county-managed waste disposal plan for the 22 communities in the county today and said he believed that he was making them an offer that they couldn't refuse.

title: When Drug Trials Hurt Patients
description: To the Editor:

title: A Final Four With Many Stories
description: After Colorado ended Detroit's Stanley Cup reign Tuesday night in Joe Louis Arena, the teams formed the traditional handshake lines and the Avalanche's Claude Lemieux extended his hand to the Red Wings' Darren McCarty. But McCarty snubbed him. Through the bitter four years of rivalry between their two teams, these two men have epitomized the hard feelings and have contributed to some of the bloodshed. McCarty has ignored Lemieux's hand before. Although this series was not as mean-spirited as those in previous seasons, McCarty was not in a forgiving mood.

title: Sergeant and Firefighter Suspended After Charges
description: A police sergeant has been charged with theft and a volunteer firefighter has been charged with arson after a vacant house was broken into and burned, officials said yesterday.

title: Bowery Feud's History
description: To the Editor:

title: Bomb Blast Badly Wounds 2 in a Neighboring Balkan Land
description: A powerful bomb exploded today on a busy street in a crowded ethnic Albanian neighborhood here, severely wounding two men and raising fears of more violence as the huge influx of ethnic Albanian refugees from Kosovo continues.

title: Software Snares
description: To the Editor:

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Sampras Follows Reneberg's Lead
description: Pete Sampras overcame a lapse in the second set to beat Karol Kucera, and Richey Reneberg was an upset winner yesterday as the United States beat Slovakia to go 2-0 in the World Team Cup in Dusseldorf, Germany, a tuneup for the French Open.

title: In Surprise, Witness Says Officer Bragged About Louima Torture
description: In surprise testimony, a police sergeant said yesterday that the officer accused of torturing Abner Louima boasted to him of carrying out the attack shortly after prosecutors said it took place in the restroom of a Brooklyn police station.

title: Chancellor Media to Form Internet Units
description: The Chancellor Media Corporation said today that it would form three Internet business units to offer its programs and other services electronically.

title: U.S. Discounts Discord for Sake of Talks
description: The Clinton Administration today played down the divisions among its NATO allies over the air war against Yugoslavia, in what appeared to be a conscious effort not to accentuate those differences as delicate talks for a peace settlement were under way.

title: A Headset Offers Movie Sound Without Going to the Theater
description: Surround sound, a movie-theater-like audio experience, is becoming increasingly popular in living rooms by way of many-speakered home entertainment systems and personal computers bearing speakers bigger than the computers themselves. But you no longer need to be surrounded by a battery of expensive speakers to get surround sound.

title: Giuliani Snubs Clinton's Visit For Rail Hub
description: President Clinton flew to New York yesterday to join Republican and Democratic leaders in celebrating a $484 million proposal to transform the General Post Office on Eighth Avenue into a new Pennsylvania Station. But Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani boycotted the ceremony, disparaging both the cost and the scope of a project that has gathered wide support among New York political and civic leaders.

title: Campaigns Find All Talk Turns to Littleton
description: The school shooting in Colorado is so dominating Presidential politics that Dan Quayle took the occasion of the seventh anniversary of his ''Murphy Brown'' speech today to deplore the polluted culture he said had contributed to the shooting. In the process, Mr. Quayle, a Republican candidate for President, played down the role of guns in the Littleton killings and emphasized personal responsibility.

title: Official Leaving Times Co.
description: Stephen Golden, president of the forest products group of The New York Times Company, said yesterday that he would resign on June 30 to pursue a law degree and a master's degree in American Indian studies at the University of Arizona. Jennifer C. Dolan, who has served as controller for the forest products group, was named acting director.

title: GPU BIDS $390 MILLION FOR NEW ZEALAND POWER COMPANIES
description: GPU Inc., a New Jersey electricity provider, said yesterday that it had offered to buy two New Zealand power companies for $390 million in cash as it seeks further opportunities to sell power outside the United States. GPU said it had made separate offers for Centralpower Ltd. and neighboring Powerco Ltd., which serve about 9 percent of New Zealand's population. GPU offered $117 million for Centralpower and $273 million for Powerco.

title: SETTLEMENTS SEEN IN VITAMIN PRICING
description: The Justice Department is expected to announce shortly that two of the world's largest drug and chemical companies have agreed to pay as much as $700 million to settle criminal charges that they were part of a global conspiracy to fix prices in the sale of vitamins, according to people close to the negotiations.

title: Hawks' Backcourt Loses a Bit Of Luster
description: Mookie Blaylock was exhausted on Tuesday night. Early in the fourth quarter, the player entrusted to kickstart the Hawks' offense committed a turnover that led to a jump shot by Allan Houston on the other end of the court. He did not bother to run downcourt to play defense, and a minute later he asked to be taken out of the game by Coach Lenny Wilkens.

title: Insider Bemoans What He Wished For
description: As Republican national chairman, Haley Barbour designed his party's campaign to cut the growth of Medicare. Now he has taken on a new assignment. As a lobbyist for a dozen large nursing home companies, he pleads with Congress for relief from the law he helped write.

title: Britain Names A Laureate Of Poems, Not Surprises
description: Andrew Motion, a 47-year-old London poet, critic, biographer and professor of creative writing, was chosen today to become Britain's poet laureate, succeeding Ted Hughes.

title: On CBS, It's Not a Fountain of Youth
description: CBS, the only broadcast network not infatuated with youth, announced a fall lineup yesterday that blends young actors with older ones in its new shows, and mixes new shows and established ones on the schedule.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBINO, ELISABETH J.
description: RUBINO-Elisabeth J. On May 16, 1999. Beloved sister of Therese Belsito. Loving aunt of Jeanne Wilson, Teresa-Gail Clayton, Victoria Elisabeth Prince and Christine Poutot. Her career spanned many years in the metropolitan area with notable people in literature, theatre and architecture. Funeral private.

title: A Filmmaker's Staircase Leads to Love
description: If there were more films like Bernardo Bertolucci's new one, ''Besieged,'' opening tomorrow, there could be a new profession: architectural film historian. But there aren't many movies that make old buildings into living characters by using emotive cinematography and scoring -- and scant script.

title: People
description: * Neil A. Johnston was named managing director of Enterprise IG Health, Parsippany, N.J., a new joint venture of two units of WPP Group P.L.C.: Commonhealth and Enterprise IG, formerly Anspach Grossman Enterprise. He had been executive vice president for business development at Enterprise IG.

title: To Zimmer, Managing Was Mostly Painful
description: The 21 victories and 15 losses compiled during Don Zimmer's tenure as the Yankees' interim manager will be applied to Joe Torre's career record, said Steve Hirdt, the executive vice president of the Elias Sports Bureau.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GOLDSTEIN, HARRY L.
description: GOLDSTEIN-Harry L. In loving remembrance. Barbara and Family

title: Keeping 'Star Trek' Alive As the TV Series Goes Dark
description: Also from Electronics Entertainment Expo: Fans of ''Star Trek: Deep Space 9'' need not worry about losing track of their favorite characters as the television series ends its seventh and final season next week. The space opera, full of souls looking for peace and redemption, can go on in the claustrophobic world of a new 3-D computer game.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Adventure Goes Out of Style; Deemed Unsafe, 60's Playgrounds Are Being Replaced
description: In the eyes of 6-year-old Margherita Cicognani, the twirling tire swings at a deliberately rustic Central Park playground on East 72d Street are deliriously giddy fun. ''I don't like regular playgrounds,'' explained the forthright little girl with the luminous dark eyes. ''They're boring.''

title: Pueblo Awaits Its Past In Bones From Harvard
description: In what experts believe is the largest-ever single return of Indian remains, the bones of nearly 2,000 Pueblo Indians set out for home today.

title: One Nation, for Rich and Poor
description: In a closely watched welfare case, the Supreme Court this week struck down a California law that discriminated against newcomers by holding them, for one year, to the benefit levels of the states from which they had moved. Fourteen other states, including New York, have similar laws that are now in jeopardy. By implication, the ruling also negated a provision of the 1996 Federal welfare overhaul approved by Congress that specifically authorized states to offer disparate benefits.

title: Helping Children Navigate Their World
description: CAPTAIN KANGAROO: LIFE'S FIRST LESSONS, ADVENTURE No. 2

title: A Rare Look at an Early Modernist
description: Ralph Rapson is best known as the designer of the Guthrie, Minneapolis's landmark of theater design, but because he worked, taught and competed with most of the world's first modernists -- Wright, Mies, Corbusier, Saarinen -- his elder son and biographer calls him ''the Forrest Gump of architecture.'' ''Ralph Rapson: Sixty Years of Modern Design,'' by Rip Rapson, Jane King Hession and Bruce N. Wright (Afton Historical Society Press, $35), documents the architect's vast career and uncanny associations.

title: KOSOVO UPDATE
description: DIPLOMACY

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Large Settlement Expected In Vitamin Price-Fixing Case

title: Sports of The Times; A New Fenway Park Offers Yanks a Lesson
description: EVER since the Fleet Center replaced the Boston Garden, basketball has never been the same where, more than 200 years ago, America's jockey, Paul Revere, yelled, ''The British are coming.''

title: Sports of The Times; Mutombo Downsizes His Dreams
description: AS a child he dreamed of being a doctor, but when he grew to be 7 feet 2 inches tall, Dikembe Mutombo modified that dream. Now he would build a hospital where doctors can save lives in his home country of Congo.

title: A Race to the Wireless; British Company Seeks Lead in Smart-Phone Software
description: A visitor to the Psion plant here was inquiring recently about the competition facing the company, which is best known in Britain for its palm-size organizers. ''Well,'' one top executive replied, ''there's a guy on the West Coast of the U.S.A. . . .''

title: Booking Travel on Line
description: To the Editor:

title: Leiter Will Pitch Doubleheader Opener, Hoping to Improve His Mind-Set
description: Approach Al Leiter. Without waiting to be asked, he will tell you that he is not worried, that he does not want to hear the word ace and that he has heard enough about the $32 million deal he signed with the Mets last fall.

title: Sprewell Still Reluctant As Sixth Man, but It Works
description: There are still those uneasy moments when Latrell Sprewell leans forward in his seat on the bench and glares at Coach Jeff Van Gundy like a bull staring down a red cape.

title: Before Rain Delay, Notre Dame Leads
description: After a rain delay of more than five hours, the first day of the Big East championships at Trenton was suspended, pushing the schedule back one day. The first of the day's three scheduled games was in the seventh inning, with top-seeded Notre Dame holding a 3-0 lead over West Virginia. The game will be resumed from that point today at noon.

title: Senators Near Vote On Gun Bill
description: After several days of escalating feuds between Republicans and Democrats, the Senate pulled back from the brink of a partisan collapse tonight as party leaders pushed toward the possibility of a final vote on Thursday on a juvenile-crime bill that has become a vehicle for several gun-control measures.

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: GOLD FALLS. Gold prices dropped on fears that a rising dollar will hurt demand even as Britain and other nations are expected to sell reserves. In New York, gold for June delivery fell 70 cents an ounce, to $273.50.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLES, JOAN C.
description: COLES-Joan C. The members of the Nature Conservancy's Mashomack Preserve Board of Trustees record our deep sorrow at her passing and express sympathy to her husband, children and grandchildren. We are forever grateful to her as a great benefactor, organizer and friend of Mashomack, who served on its board with distinction and who had been an untiring volunteer and generous supporter of Mashomack since its inception, ensuring that it will remain wild and beautiful forever.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNEIDER, CAROLINA M.
description: SCHNEIDER-Carolina M. Of Bloomfield, NJ on Tuesday, May 18, 1999. Sister of Henry Schneider of Virginia, Harold Schneider of Union, NJ, Raymond Schneider of Hawaii and Helen Klein of Orange, New Jersey. Also survived by many nieces, nephews, grandnieces & grandnephews. Funeral service to be conducted at the Quinn Hopping Funeral Home, 145 East Mt. Pleasant Ave (Rte 10), Livingston, NJ on Saturday, May 22, at 10:30 AM. Interment, Restland Memorial Park, East Hanover, NJ. Visiting Friday, 5-7 PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPECTOR, HENRY
description: SPECTOR-Henry. Of Brooklyn, New York died peacefully at age 87. Beloved husband of Gertrude. Loving father of Lori Spector and Sue Collina-Cooper. Devoted grandfather of Joseph & Kristofer. Brother of Seymour Spector and Mildred Werbel. Service Sunday, May 23rd, 11:30 AM, ''Parkside'' Memorial Chapel, 2576 Flatbush Ave., Brooklyn, NY (near Ave. V).

title: A Dance of Arabesques
description: Choosing the proper table lamp is tricky. Decorators tend to put silly hats on pieces of ''sculpture.'' Architects often ban the things and sink bulbs into the ceiling. Where's middle ground? The lamps in McGuire's new collection have shapely bases made of hand-hammered copper with or without silver or 24-karat-gold plating. The Grand Arabesque, left, $1,625 in copper; the smaller Arabesque, right, $1,775 in silver, and Fountain, inset, $1,725 in silver, have thorny profiles, both organic and tribal. Information: (415) 626-1414.

title: Library Board Chooses a New Chairman
description: A Wall Street lawyer whose love affair with libraries began in the sixth grade has been elected chairman of the New York Public Library's board of trustees.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBIN, PETER JAY.
description: RUBIN-Peter Jay. April 28, 1964May 18, 1999. Firstborn child and beloved son of Barbara and the late Walter. Devoted and dear brother of Randy. Loving grandson, nephew, cousin and friend. Peter had a deep love for Torah and Israel, closely followed by his love for the Knicks and English football. He traveled the world in search of knowledge and inner peace, which we pray he has found. Now he is together with his dad. His memory for a blessing. We will love him and miss him forever. Services will be held on Sunday, May 23 at 12:00 noon at Gutterman's, Woodbury. Barbara and Randy Rubin

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOBERMAN, MORRIS I.
description: HOBERMAN-Morris I. Beloved husband of Audrey, loving father of Barry, Donna, and Richard, cherished father-in-law of Elizabeth, adored grandfather of Cindy, Blake, Nicholas, Alexander, Maxwell, Kyle, & Caitlin. Services 11:30 A.M. Thursday at ''Boulevard Riverside Chapel'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, New York.

title: Group to Study Johnson's Bid
description: The International Amateur Athletic Federation, the world governing body of track and field, said yesterday in Seville, Spain, that a three-member committee would examine a bid for reinstatement by Ben Johnson of Canada.

title: American Topics : Foreigners Dominating Doctoral Physics Studies
description: Step into Room 212 of the Osmond physics laboratory at Pennsylvania State University, and the scene is much the same as in any other college physics lab. The only thing missing is Americans. Two-thirds of the students are Asians.

title: Central Bank Resolve to Fight Inflation Helps Send Dow Up
description: Stocks rose on optimism that the Federal Reserve's resolve to fight inflation will accelerate gains in the market.

title: From Car to Living Room, Rough and Ready Seating
description: Peter Danko wishes buyers would look beyond style to admire the beauty of rationally designed furniture, new materials and smart production methods. His Arborline Chair is firm but resilient. The webbing recalls familiar forebears -- Shaker chairs, Alvar Aalto and 1950's folding lawn chairs -- but is woven of new surplus: automobile seat belts in many colors, some translucent. With its belts, rated for 6,000 pounds of tensile strength, and solid maple frame with optional struts, the chair can withstand much abuse. The Arborline ranges in price from $308 to $317. For sales and information: (800) 882-5300.

title: U.S. Charges Ex-Soldier, Calling Him Plotter With bin Laden
description: The Government indicted a former United States Army sergeant yesterday on charges of collaborating with Osama bin Laden in a global conspiracy to kill Americans abroad, and asserted publicly for the first time that the group linked to Mr. bin Laden had plotted to attack the United States Embassy in Kenya as early as 1993.

title: Commencements; At Rutgers, a Graduate Is Not That Young at 15
description: At age 15, Sehrope Sarkuni is the youngest member of Rutgers University's class of 1999. Yet he is a late bloomer compared with his brother, Hannes, who was 14 when he graduated from Rutgers in 1996.

title: Buchanan Kin Is to Surrender Over Threats
description: A brother of Patrick J. Buchanan, the Presidential candidate and conservative commentator, will surrender to the police on charges that he threatened people with a handgun at the home of a relative of a top State Department official, the Buchanan family said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SWEENEY, MAJ. GEN. ARTHUR H., JR.
description: SWEENEY-Maj. Gen. Arthur H., Jr. USA retired. 78 of Richmond, VA. Died Monday, May 17, 1999. Surviving are his wife Veronica D. Sweeney, two sisters and their families. Services will be held in Richmond, VA. Interment Arlington National Cemetery.

title: S.S. Weisglass, 70, Investment Banker
description: Stephen S. Weisglass, the executive managing director of Conifer Securities, a San Francisco investment banking firm, died on Sunday at his home in Miami. He was 70.

title: Cash Sought From Big Firm In '98 Letter
description: Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, a leading securities firm embroiled in a racial discrimination dispute with a former employee, received a letter last August demanding a $15,000 payment from a police informant who helped arrange a sting operation that was about to result in the employee's arrest.

title: A World Of Choices To Plug In To the Net
description: CONSIDER the Internet service provider. Depending on your on-line habits, it can be the home of your familial interactions, the envelope for your business memorandums, the conduit of your deepest desires. It can get about as much intimate use as the lenses of your glasses or the pages of a journal. It is the choice of a way to view Web pages and to send E-mail, and as such it should not be approached without proper introspection and circumspection.

title: Jail Sentences With No End
description: Gov. George Pataki wants to eliminate parole in New York State. The truth is, it has already been practically eliminated.

title: New Palm Pilot Links to Internet Wirelessly
description: Untethering the Internet from desktop computers, the 3Com Corporation intends on Monday to introduce the first version of its popular Palm Pilot hand-held computer that can tap into cyberspace using wireless links.

title: It's Europe's Turn To Lead NATO
description: To the Editor:

title: The Cars May Still Flip, but the Tethered Tires Will Not
description: Just weeks after three spectators were killed when parts of a race car hurtled into the stands, the second fatal incident involving fans in nine months, Championship Auto Racing Teams is taking steps to make the grandstand safer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALSH, MILDRED J.
description: WALSH-Mildred J. Peacefully, on May 19. Beloved mother of Norman and Judith and cherished great-aunt. Services today, 10 AM, at Gramercy Park Memorial Chapel, New York City, New York.

title: Brand Signs With Falk
description: Duke University center Elton Brand signed with David Falk, giving the influential agent his first high-profile client from this year's National Basketball Association draft class. Brand left the Blue Devils after his sophomore season, during which he averaged 17.7 points and 9.8 rebounds and won the Naismith and Wooden Awards as the nation's best college basketball player.

title: A Wealth Of Ambiguity, An Economy Of Words
description: Ray, a hard-drinking Lothario of a college professor in Conor McPherson's ''Lime Tree Bower,'' is not a fancy talker, at least not by academic standards. His sentences and his words tend to be short, but they nonetheless summon entire landscapes of sharp, conflicted sensations.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  NEAGLE, JULIA S.
description: NEAGLE-Julia S. A Memorial Service for Julia S. Neagle who died January 22, 1999 will be held Saturday, May 22nd at 2:30PM at St. Luke's Church, 18 James Lane, East Hampton, New York.

title: Kosovo Refugee, 78, Dies on Flight to U.S.
description: Mevlude Maxhuni had made it out of Kosovo, out of Macedonia and onto a jet taking her to a safe haven in the United States.

title: Before Winter Arrives in Kosovo
description: Summer is still a month away, but next winter is already starting to drive decisions about the war in Yugoslavia. The logic is inescapable: either hundreds of thousands of displaced ethnic Albanians need to be safely resettled in Kosovo before freezing temperatures return to the Balkans or the United States and its allies must winterize refugee encampments in Albania and Macedonia and help Montenegro do the same. If the combination of air power and diplomacy fail to make repatriation possible soon, NATO will quickly have to confront some hard decisions, including whether to retain the option of using ground troops later this year to evict Serbian troops from Kosovo.

title: Through a Dark Wood, Before Seeing the Light
description: ''Fill the Woods With Light'' proved a good title for the work given its New York premiere by the Parsons Dance Company on Tuesday night at the Joyce Theater. David Parsons's choreography sent dancers wandering through a dark forest in which glowing shapes emerged from gloom, thanks to the lighting of Howell Binkley.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OECHLER, CONVERE M.
description: OECHLER-Convere M., 87. Of New York, on May 13, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Henry J. Oechler, devoted mother of Hugh McAden and Henry, Jr., devoted mother-in-law to Joanne and Kathleen and devoted grandmother of James, Sarah, Joshua, Sean and Jack. Services will be on Monday, May 24 at 11 AM in St. James Episcopal Church, NYC. In lieu of flowers, the family requests contributions to The Rector's Discretionary Fund of the St. James Episcopal Church, 865 Madison Avenue, NYC.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-17

title: Law Favors Risk-Takers
description: To the Editor:

title: A Trade Magazine's About-Face
description: Hey, what's a glamour puss doing on the May cover of Architecture, a magazine about buildings? Didn't those trades stop running sexy advertisements -- babes in towels selling faucets -- decades ago?

title: Car Transporters Confronted By Threat of Teamsters' Strike
description: In a move that would likely limit the selection of vehicles available to consumers, the teamsters' union is threatening a strike by drivers against the trucking companies that carry new cars to dealerships. But such a move would not affect the economy as much as a strike at an auto factory.

title: Torre Has His Work Cut Out For Him
description: After witnessing a listless performance by Hideki Irabu and a lethargic effort by the Yankees against a 23-year-old pitcher who was recalled from Class AAA today, Joe Torre might want to reconsider his decision to return to manage this sputtering team. It would have been easier for him to watch this torturous display on television.

title: Saatchi Forms New Division
description: Saatchi & Saatchi P.L.C. in New York, a division of Cordiant P.L.C., said yesterday that it had combined two of its agencies to form a unit called Rowland Communications Worldwide, based in New York.

title: In Nervous Hartford, Nothing Is Routine
description: In a city on edge, even a purchase order can be provocative.

title: Fingernails, Cake Boxes: The Fear Is Everywhere
description: HEARTBREAKER

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of the first and second days of Shabuoth, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City tomorrow and Saturday. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Top Officials Pay Tribute To an Aide
description: After the organist had begun playing and just before the soprano soloist began singing ''Swing Low, Sweet Chariot'' at Rear Adm. James W. Nance's funeral, Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright was ushered down the aisle and seated in a front pew next to Senator Strom Thurmond.

title: Accounts
description: * Tommy Hilfiger Toiletries, New York, part of the Aramis division of Estee Lauder, to PGR Media, Providence, R.I., to handle broadcast and outdoor media duties for its account, previously at Bates New York, part of the Bates Worldwide division of Cordiant Communications Group P.L.C. Bates retains print duties. Billings were estimated at $15 million to $20 million.

title: The Man Who Invited His Audiences to Fly
description: Once asked which came first, the words or the music, Sammy Cahn replied ''the phone call.'' And in Jeff Harnar's smart, entertaining new cabaret show, ''Sammy Cahn All the Way,'' which opens this evening at the Firebird Cafe, the singer remembers these and other sayings by the cocky lyricist from Brooklyn who died six years ago.

title: Cleaner Nuclear Power?
description: To the Editor:

title: Klerksdorp Journal; For New Party, the Man of the Hour Is . . .  a Man
description: In a field of professional politicians, Louis Luyt stands out. There isn't another fertilizer magnate turned beer baron turned rugby czar in the running.

title: Rights Groups Say Logbook Lists Executions by Guatemalan Army
description: Lucrecia Vasquez wavers from one day to the next about whether her brother is dead or alive.

title: 1999 Women's World Cup: Beautiful Game Takes Flight
description: There was so little news media and public interest in the American victory at the inaugural Women's World Cup of soccer in 1991 in China, few people knew the United States had a team, much less the best team on the planet. The players kept their friends and relatives informed by sending faxes, which were distributed like chain letters, the equivalent of technological smoke signals.

title: Telecom Italia Takes Its Case To Big Funds
description: Telecom Italia made a last-minute bid today to lure big shareholders who are undecided about whether to accept a hostile $65 billion takeover bid from Olivetti over a friendly merger deal with Deutsche Telekom.

title: GARDEN Q.& A.
description: Zucchini Blues

title: In America; Police Restraint
description: Rachel Ellen Ondersma, a 17-year-old high school senior, was stopped by the state police in Grand Rapids, Mich., early on the morning of Nov. 14, 1998. She had been driving erratically. When she failed a Breathalyzer test, the cops placed her under arrest.

title: History's Shadow Foils Nanking Chronicle
description: More than a half-century after the Japanese invasion of the ancient Chinese city of Nanking, a tense international literary tug of words has flared over the Japanese translation of a bestselling book in the United States, ''The Rape of Nanking,'' which was scheduled to be published in Japan this year.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an obituary yesterday about Bill Ballantine, a clown, artist and writer, misstated his connection to the book ''Circus! From Rome to Ringling.'' He reviewed it for The Times in 1956; the author was Marian Murray.

title: When Drug Trials Hurt Patients; Similar to H.M.O.'s
description: To the Editor:

title: Stepashin Is Easily Confirmed as Russian Prime Minister
description: The new Prime Minister, Sergei V. Stepashin, won an easy confirmation vote today in the lower house of Parliament, bringing the brief political crisis to an eerily peaceful end.

title: Citizens' Electronic Inquiries Get Governments' Attention
description: GOODBYE, phone-menu torment. Adios, disembodied operators taking calls in the order received. A revolution in customer service is emerging on the government pages of the Web.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE YEN SLIDES. The dollar rose against the Japanese yen on expectations that the Federal Reserve will increase interest rates before inflation gains force. In New York, the dollar settled at 124.21 yen, up from 123.20 Tuesday.

title: Got a Computer? Help Find E.T.'s Home by Calling From Yours
description: There's something irresistible about the idea that anyone with a PC and a connection to the Internet could discover evidence of extraterrestrial intelligence.

title: Computer Designed for Granny Offers a Friendly Interface
description: WHO is the person in the family who hasn't learned how to use the computer either by writing notes at work or playing games after school? It's Grandma or Grandpa, of course. But the computer industry is turning its attention to this group of potential users.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DESSAU, ALFRED
description: DESSAU-Alfred. On May 16, 1999. Age 91. Loving husband of Sitta. Honored father of Dr. Ralph and Dr. Margaret. Loving grandfather and great grandfather.

title: Business in China: Longer-Term Worries
description: When anti-American demonstrations erupted in Chinese cities 10 days ago, executives at several United States companies went into crisis mode and evacuated employees. In Beijing and Shanghai, some Americans felt trapped inside their homes, fearful that angry students could turn into unruly mobs.

title: Searching for a Modern Machiavelli
description: The subject was Machiavelli's relevancy to Beltway politics, and at first Representative Henry J. Hyde listened far more than he talked. He was strategically quiet in his own way, even when he was praised as ''the great expert on the ruling couple's Machiavellianism.''

title: City Wins Ruling on D.W.I. Crackdown
description: A state judge yesterday upheld the Giuliani administration's policy of seizing the cars from people arrested on drunken driving charges, handing the city its first court victory on a crackdown that has been criticized by civil libertarians.

title: Ida Klaus, 94, Labor Lawyer For U.S. and New York, Dies
description: Ida Klaus, a labor law pioneer who became a high-ranking New York City official in the 1950's and who wrote the law that gave city employees the right to bargain collectively, died on Monday at her home in Manhattan. She was 94.

title: Assembly Democrats Won't Act On Pataki Call to Ease Drug Laws
description: Concerned about appearing soft on crime in the next election, the Democratic legislative leadership plans to shelve Gov. George E. Pataki's proposal to scale back New York's strict drug laws and appears unwilling to support other such efforts this year.

title: An Upstart Unveils Rival to the Game Boy
description: With millions of Game Boys sold worldwide, Nintendo has practically owned the handheld computer amusement market for a decade. At the recent Electronics Entertainment Expo in Los Angeles, SNK, a game maker best known for its presence in video arcades, unveiled its effort to end Game Boy's reign.

title: 3 Executives Start an Agency
description: Three women executives have formed Goose Ltd. in Philadelphia, a new shop specializing in what it terms ''gender oriented marketing,'' a research process intended to identify the roles played by men and women in the buying process.

title: Reno's Handling of Reports of Chinese Spy Is Criticized
description: Senators at a closed-door hearing of the Intelligence Committee today lashed out at Attorney General Janet Reno for what they said was her failure to aggressively manage the case of a suspected spy for China at the Los Alamos nuclear weapons laboratory, Government officials said.

title: U.S. BANCORP TO BUY SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA BANKS
description: U.S. Bancorp said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Western Bancorp for $958 million in stock, expanding its operations in the Midwest and West into Southern California. U.S. Bancorp, which is based in Minneapolis and has about 1,000 branches and $76 billion in assets, will add 31 branches with the purchase. Western Bancorp, which is based in Newport Beach, Calif., and is the parent of Santa Monica Bank and Southern California Bank, has $2.5 billion in assets. U.S. Bancorp said that it had agreed to exchange 1.2915 of its shares for each Western share, which valued Western at $44.40 a share, based on Tuesday's closing share prices. Western Bancorp shares rose $1.3125, to $40.3125. U.S. Bancorp shares fell $1.8125, to $32.5625.

title: WASHINGTON MUTUAL TO BUY CALIFORNIA MORTGAGE LENDER
description: Washington Mutual, a financial services company, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Long Beach Financial Corporation, a California mortgage lender, for $350.4 million, or $15.50 a share, expanding its presence in the residential mortgage market. Washington Mutual, based in Seattle, has 2,000 offices and assets of $174 billion. Long Beach Financial, known as a subprime lender, makes mortgage loans to customers with spotty credit records, usually at high interest rates, then packages its loans and sells them to institutional investors. Shares of Long Beach jumped 16.8 percent, gaining $2.0625, to $14.375. Shares of Washington Mutual climbed 75 cents, to $39.75.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; A bill proposed by brokerage firms draws mutual fund fire.
description: THE Securities Industry Association, Wall Street's lobbying arm in Washington, is encountering stiff opposition to a recent proposal that would make it easier for brokerage firms to do business with their own mutual funds.

title: Records Set for 11 Artists in Contemporary Sale
description: Bidding was fast, furious and often surprising at Christie's sale of contemporary art last night. Records were set for 11 artists, and works often exceeded their high estimates many times over.

title: A Woman Wounded By Her Own Mother Is Permitted to Die
description: Georgette Smith, saying she could not bear to live after a bullet left her paralyzed from the neck down, was allowed to die today in an Orlando hospital.

title: School Violence: Is It in Your Backyard?
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page picture caption on May 10 about demonstrations in Beijing over NATO's bombing of the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade misidentified the building at which a protester was throwing a rock. It was the American Ambassador's residence, not the American Embassy.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: ON THE STREET

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region.

title: Sports of The Times; Imported Noise In Atlanta
description: YOU could hear they were New Yorkers even before spotting the orange and blue colors supporting the Knicks.

title: On My Mind; Awaiting Ehud Barak
description: On a day in Israel in June 1992 I talked separately with the four men I considered most important to their country. I asked them all the same question, most important to its people and future.

title: Charismatic Finally Looks Like Favorite
description: Charismatic, the onetime claimer who won the Kentucky Derby at odds of 31-1 and two weeks later won the Preakness at 8-1, was back in his barn at Churchill Downs in Louisville, Ky., yesterday preparing for the Belmont Stakes two weeks from tomorrow. Charismatic will probably face a full field of 15 rivals, but will no longer be a long shot.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABRAMOVITZ, ANN
description: ABRAMOVITZ-Ann. The trustees and staff of the Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services are saddened by the May 19th passing of Ann Abramovitz, the mother of Dr. Robert Abramovitz, our esteemed colleague and Chief Psychiatrist. We extend our deepest sympathies to Dr. Abramovitz; his wife, Dr. Mimi Abramovitz; and other members of his family. Joseph S. Kaplan, President Seymour R. Askin, Jr, Chairman of the Board Alan B. Siskind, Ph.D, Executive Vice President Paul Levine, CSW, Associate Executive Vice President

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  OGORZALY, HANK AND STAN
description: OGORZALY-Hank and Stan. Beloved husband, father and grandfather, and cherished uncle. Brothers now reunited, always in our hearts and in our thoughts

title: Police Wall of Silence Shows Some Cracks in Torture Case
description: The wall of silence continues to crash down on Officer Justin Volpe.

title: Contemplating a Fatal Mistake
description: The war in the Balkans now appears to have led to a conflict within NATO, between those who would send in ground troops (notably the British) and those who would not (notably the Germans). President Clinton has been caught in the middle, but the pressure for a ground invasion -- an idea that seemed dead a few weeks ago -- is once again strong.

title: The Right to Hire and Fire Is Granted : Foreign Managers Get New Powers in China
description: NANJING, China  In a big step away from its socialist, protectionist past, China has permitted foreign control in the strategic steel industry.

title: Congress Party Expels 3 Who Opposed Gandhi
description: The Congress Party tonight expelled three dissident leaders who opposed Sonia Gandhi's candidacy for Prime Minister because she was born in Italy.

title: British Official Warns U.S. Not to 'Lose Nerve'
description: The British Foreign Minister, Robin Cook, came to Washington today to tell Congress and the American news media that ''this is not the time to lose our nerve'' over Kosovo, and to say that NATO should have troops and equipment ready to advance if Serbian forces collapse.

title: SLUMS BEHIND SHUTTERS: A special report.; Wages and Squalor for Immigrant Workers
description: In a dark, musty garage in the Long Island city of Glen Cove, a child sleeps under rags and old clothes. Rain drips down into an electric light socket. The ceiling is caving in. The five people who live there bathe from buckets and pay $1,000 a month in rent. ''What can I do?'' says Rosa Benitez, the child's mother, a 31-year-old immigrant from El Salvador. ''I ask the landlord to fix it. He says if I complain I will be on the street.''

title: Sheldon Judson, 80, Professor And Author in Geo-Archeology
description: Sheldon Judson, an archeologist and a retired professor of geosciences at Princeton University, died yesterday in his home in Princeton, N.J. He was 80.

title: Sports of The Times; Abbott's Inspirational Return
description: SOME people may surely be surprised to see Jim Abbott back on a major league mound, after what happened last year, or the year before, and, to be sure, the year before that. Even the first part of this season.

title: Killings in Littleton Pierced Soul of the Nation, Clinton Says
description: Against the grim backdrop of yet another school shooting, this one in Georgia, President Clinton told this grief-racked but determined Rocky Mountain town today that the massacre here had ''pierced the soul of America.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAGATT, JOHN J.
description: LAGATT-John J., 79. Died May 19, 1999 at Albany, NY. John was an assistant Dean to the College of Arts and Sciences, St. Louis, MO. and was an assistant commissioner for the Dept. of Civil Service, Albany. John was the husband of the late Angela Hurley Lagatt and is survived by a son, David J. Lagatt, Albany; a daughter, Mrs. Nathan (Jeanne M.) Wood, Albany, NY. Funeral Service will be Saturday 9 AM at St. Teresa of Avila Church, Albany. Friends are also invited to call at the Tebbutt Funeral Home, Friday 6 to 8:30 PM.

title: ON STAGE AND OFF
description: Two Musicals From One Poem

title: Asking Students to Do More With Less
description: Gov. George Pataki sounded tough last week about making high school graduation requirements stricter, telling reporters that ''we should not back down one iota from our efforts to raise students' performance standards.'' But his utterly inadequate education budget would make it difficult for most New York State school districts to meet those standards, and practically impossible for districts serving the poorest students.

title: Fed Policy Makers Voted 11-0 In March to Hold Rates Steady
description: Federal Reserve policy makers were unanimous in deciding not to change the overnight bank lending rate at their March 30 meeting and continued to take a wait-and-see attitude on what to do about rates in the future, minutes of the session showed today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YOURMAN, JACK
description: YOURMAN-Jack. Age 80. Died peacefully on May 17, 1999. He will be greatly missed. Husband of Gladys. Father of Carol, Judy, and David. Grandfather of Sarah and Rachel Kass. Stepfather of Bobette Lister and Leslie Wexler. Stepgrandfather of Jennifer Cooper, Julie Lister, Paul Lister, Eric Wexler, and Todd Wexler. Step greatgrandfather of Rebecca Cooper, Rachel Cooper, and William Feinberg.

title: WEEKEND WARRIOR; Skate Men Can't Jump: Basketball on Wheels
description: Angling through the lane, I took two hard dribbles, cradled the ball and headed for the hoop. Actually, I headed right by the hoop and flew onto the grass behind the baseline, windmilling my arms the whole away. My layup attempt caromed off the side of the backboard and I ended up on my back, my rented Rollerblades sticking up in the air. It wasn't very graceful, but, as I was discovering, even easy layups become adventures when you're playing roller basketball.

title: Mazda Reports First Annual Profit in 6 Years
description: The Mazda Motor Corporation, the Japanese car maker controlled by the Ford Motor Company, reported its first annual profit in six years today and its best results in 14 years, the clearest sign that Ford's efforts to turn the company around are succeeding.

title: 3 Options for Washington, All With Major Risks
description: Encumbered by some testy NATO partners and by a desire to wrap up the war over Serbia, the Clinton Administration is facing several unpleasant options under the pressure of a looming deadline.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in New York City this weekend. *denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Governing Party in Nepal Gains Majority in Parliamentary Election
description: Political stability may have finally come to this small Himalayan nation after elections that concluded this week. The governing Nepali Congress seems on its way to a parliamentary majority, ending four and a half years of fractious coalitions that brought five governments to one of the world's youngest democracies.

title: MCN ENERGY AGREES TO SELL PROPERTIES FOR $115 MILLION
description: The MCN Energy Group said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its second package of natural gas and oil exploration and production properties for $115 million. It did not name the buyer. The Detroit-based MCN is the holding company for the Michigan Consolidated Gas Company, the utility that is selling its properties in four separate packages. The latest sale involves the company's midcontinent and Gulf Coast reserves. Earlier this spring, MCN received about $165 million for its western exploration and production package. MCN is negotiating the sale of the other two packages.

title: Suspect in Slaying Was Tipped Off by a Neighbor, Police Say
description: A man charged with fatally shooting an 8-year-old witness in a murder case was tipped off to the boy's whereabouts by a neighbor who paged the gunman when the boy and his mother returned from grocery shopping, according to a police account released today.

title: Far From Other Galaxy, Fandom's Final Frontier
description: Philosophers, physicians, psychologists and poets have struggled for centuries to fathom obsessive love. So it is probably hopeless in the presence of ''Trekkies'' to do anything but sit back -- amused, bemused and astonished -- and watch the devotions of fans of the various incarnations of ''Star Trek.''

title: DEVON ENERGY TO BUY UNIT SPUN OFF BY PENNZOIL
description: The Devon Energy Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Pennzenergy Company, the oil exploration and production business spun off last year by the Pennzoil Company for $675 million. Devon, based in Oklahoma City, had revenue of $388 million last year. Pennzenergy, based in Houston, was created last year when Pennzoil merged with the Quaker State Corporation. Under the agreement, Pennzenergy shareholders will receive 0.4475 share of the new company for each share held. Based on Wednesday's closing prices, the deal valued each Pennzenergy share at $14.10. Shares of Pennzenergy fell 12.5 cents, to $14.50. Shares of Devon rose $2.25, to $33.75.

title: With Cars, a Name Is More Than Just a Name
description: To the Editor:

title: Forks Through Windows And Other Grotesqueries
description: TOUGH, TOUGH TOYS FOR TOUGH, TOUGH BOYS

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: Manhattan has gone Pan-Latin, but it is still possible to find restaurants that fly a single flag. One of the newest is Orinoco, an unusually attractive Venezuelan spot on the Upper East Side, which Miriam Cordoba, the chef and owner, has turned into a showcase for traditional Venezuelan dishes.

title: From Minolta, a new marketing campaign focuses on inspiration instead of hardware.
description: THE Minolta Corporation, the Japanese maker of copiers and cameras, is counting on a new ad campaign using photographs by a number of highly acclaimed artists to buoy its brand in the United States.

title: Late Selloff in Computer Issues Pulls Major Gauges Down
description: A late selloff in Internet and other computer-related stocks helped drag down major stock market averages yesterday, erasing modest gains that had prevailed for most of the session.

title: U.S. Outlines How Makers of Vitamins Fixed Global Prices
description: Every year around August or September, the senior executives from the world's largest producers of vitamins would gather clandestinely for a few days at a European hotel or an executive's home for what some called the ''top-notch meeting'' and others the ''summit conference'' to plan ''the budget for Vitamin Inc.,'' Federal prosecutors said today.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: A Poorly Scripted War
description: To the Editor:

title: McCain Harsh In Criticizing Clinton Policies
