description: In a speech outlining his own views on foreign affairs, Senator John McCain of Arizona was harshly critical of President Clinton today on issues from Kosovo to the Middle East to international trade.

title: In Israel, Winning Is Not Everything
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE ART
description: Old Hand, Young Plan

title: Disabled Golfer's Cart Request Denied
description: A Federal judge yesterday denied a disabled professional golfer's request to use a cart in a local qualifier for the United States Open.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Sales Rise 32% At Mannesmann Unit
description: Mannesmann A.G. said yesterday that its first-quarter telecommunications sales rose 32 percent as the concern, an engineering company that runs Germany's biggest mobile phone network, seized business from rivals by cutting prices. Sales at Mannesmann's telecommunications unit, composed of mobile and traditional phone services, rose to 1.326 billion euros ($1.39 billion) in the quarter.

title: Andrea Modica
description: Edwynn Houk Gallery

title: FAMILY FARE
description: The Souls Of Shoes

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''On a daily basis for the past 10 years, every American consumer paid to eat and drink or use a product whose price was artificially inflated.''

title: Battle of the Unbuilt Billboard; In Times Square, a New Problem for a Troubled Tower
description: With visions of world domination dancing in his head, Frank G. Zarb, the chief executive of Nasdaq's parent, decided that his electronic stock market had to erect the biggest, most dazzling billboard in Times Square for all the world to see.

title: Medical Records Company Announces Spree of Deals
description: The Healtheon Corporation, a rapidly growing Silicon Valley start-up with big ideas for changing the health care system, said yesterday that it would buy WebMD Inc., a seven-month-old Internet company, in a stock deal valued at $7.85 billion.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Does Whale Hunt Revive a Stolen Tradition?
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEINBERG, SYLVIA
description: STEINBERG-Sylvia. 79. On May 20, 1999. Beloved wife of Harry. Cherished mother of Mara and Curt Gruskin and Lisa and Lee Snow. Dear sister of Esther Snyder and Nathan Friedman. Devoted grandmother of Amy, David, Michael and Raffi. Services Sunday, 12 noon, at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Thoughts Are on Mound, And Not Back in Cuba
description: It was late on Wednesday night when Joe Torre, Mel Stottlemyre and Orlando Hernandez all happened to be in the hotel elevator at the same time. The manager and the pitching coach turned into amateur psychologists and told the struggling pitcher he would be the Yankees' stopper against the Red Sox tonight.

title: Progress Reported Toward Leetch Deal
description: Jay Grossman, the agent for the Rangers' Brian Leetch, said that negotiations for a new contract are continuing and that we're making progress toward a deal keep the captain of the team off the free-agent market on July 1. Grossman said the negotiations have been in progress for about two weeks with Neil Smith, the president and general manager of the Rangers.

title: Hess Family Likely to Hire Goldman Sachs for Jets Sale
description: Leon Hess's death two weeks ago stirred speculation about who would be the Jets' next owner. Although Hess's will has not been filed, the family's anticipated hiring of the investment firm Goldman Sachs to identify a buyer clarifies a belief that Hess did not want to pass the team to his family as a legacy.

title: With a Cool Temperament, Giving Warmth to Standards
description: Demure, polite, blessed with near-perfect intonation and a coloratura register that is as precisely deployed as it is flexible, Maureen McGovern is the very model of a cabaret singer who moves comfortably from conservative jazz to soaring movie themes, from classic pop standards to operetta. If the pronounced nasality in her mid-to-upper range recalls Barbra Streisand, Ms. McGovern projects little of Ms. Streisand's drive and neediness. When she focuses her technique on standards like ''The Man I Love'' or ''The Nearness of You,'' two of the high points in her new act, Ms. McGovern is as good as a traditional pop singer gets.

title: City's Unemployment Rate Stays at Its Lowest, Reassuring Wary Economists
description: New York City businesses continued to add new jobs at a rapid pace in April and the unemployment rate remained near its lowest level in a decade, reassuring some economists who had feared that it would rebound after its sharp drop in March.

title: The British Invasion? Surrender
description: Much has been made of the fact that British culture has of late been flooding these shores with almost colonial aplomb. Just look at Broadway, the argument goes: it's British; British; British; ''Cats''; British, British. (Come to think of it, ''Cats'' is British, too.)

title: Fox to Wade Deeper Into Sex and Violence
description: Making more changes than any other network and reaching for programs deliberately aimed at breaking new ground in terms of sex, language and violence, Fox announced a fall television schedule yesterday with eight new series, including a reshaped, half-hour version of ''Ally McBeal'' that will play the night after the hour version.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary headline yesterday about a reggae musician misspelled his given name, and the article omitted a survivor. The musician was Augustus Pablo, not Augusto. Survivors include his brother Mark Swaby.

title: Woman's Body Is Found In Large Plastic Cooler
description: The authorities are looking for the killer of a woman whose body was found stuffed into a large plastic drink cooler in a Jersey City apartment building.

title: 6 Plead Guilty to Charges Of Illegal Stock Trading
description: Six stock traders, including four who worked on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange, pleaded guilty yesterday to felony charges of illegal stock trading in a case that has raised questions about the integrity of trading on the nation's biggest stock market.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBEL, FERDINAND
description: RUBEL-Ferdinand. The officers and directors of Gemiluth Chessed and Palisades Gardens express their deep sorrow to the family at the passing of Ferdinand Rubel who was a long time board member of our organizations. Gemiluth Chessed Palisades Gardens

title: Lionizing Athletes
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: Whitman Backs Abortion Bill

title: Today's Lesson: Soda Rights; Consultant Helps Schools Sell Themselves to Vendors
description: Dan DeRose, marketing consultant, was busy doing the math for his new client, the Newark Public Schools.

title: Political Memo; Waiting for Pataki: City Hall Holds Breath and Fears Worst
description: Traditional salutations are no longer offered around City Hall these days. Instead of ''Good morning, that's a nifty tie,'' one is more likely to hear variations of the following:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  NEAGLE, JULIA S.
description: NEAGLE-Julia S. A Memorial Service for Julia S. Neagle who died January 22, 1999 will be held Saturday, May 22nd at 2:30PM at St. Luke's Church, 18 James Lane, East Hampton, New York.

title: ART GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. *denotes a highly recommended show.

title: A Warning From the Butterflies
description: ''Bt'' is short for Bacillus thuringiensis, the name of a naturally occurring soil bacterium that produces a toxin capable of killing some insects while leaving others unharmed. For farmers who closely monitor their crops and are willing to manage its application with care, Bt has been a resounding success since the early 1960's. But for those same reasons, Bt has never been widely adopted by conventional farmers, who prefer longer-lasting pesticides and whose fields are so large that effectively timing the use of Bt is impractical.

title: Guillermo Kuitca -- 'Castle to Castle'
description: Sperone Westwater

title: 4 at Lucas Varity Won't Be Joining TRW
description: TRW Inc., the world's No. 2 maker of automobile air bags, said today that four top executives from the newly acquired Lucas Varity P.L.C. would not be joining the company, leaving vacant the top job at its automotive business, which represents 70 percent of total sales.

title: New Protection for Refugees From Right-Wing Oppression
description: Reversing decades-old cold war policy, the Federal Government announced today that hundreds of thousands of immigrants who fled repression from right-wing governments will now be eligible for many of the same protections from deportation that had been reserved for immigrants from left-wing or Communist countries.

title: A Classroom Display? No, a Game of Mirrors
description: The first premiere of the New York City Ballet's spring season is ''Scenes de Ballet,'' an extravagant bouquet of a special ballet, beautifully imagined and realized by its choreographer, Christopher Wheeldon.

title: Pomo Indian Basketry: Window Into a Culture
description: In the rage for things Indian that gripped the United States at the turn of the century -- when the Indians themselves had been all but wiped out -- Pomo baskets were on many a collector's list. Considered among the world's most beautifully wrought, they were produced by the Pomo Indians of northern California from painstakingly prepared roots and shoots. In subtle geometric designs, they ranged in size from feast bowls that could feed a tribal gathering to miniatures so tiny they could be mistaken for seeds.

title: Clear Case of Murder
description: To the Editor:

title: Passenger Dies in Fall From Staten Island Ferry
description: A 24-year-old man died after falling or jumping off a Staten Island Ferry last night, the police said.

title: Ford Officer Leaving to Seek Other Job Possibilities
description: Eager to be a chief executive someday, John M. Devine, the Ford Motor Company's chief financial officer and executive vice president, announced today that he would retire at the end of September and intended to pursue ''wider responsibilities'' elsewhere.

title: Choeung Ek Journal; A Word to the Dead: We've Put the Past to Rest
description: With a pyramid of bleached skulls seeming to stare directly at them this morning, a choir of young women sang a horrifying dirge.

title: James Broughton, 85, Poet
description: James Broughton, a poet and filmmaker, died on Monday at his home in Port Townsend, Wash. He was 85.

title: Debra Priestly
description: June Kelly Gallery

title: Breakdown At Air Center Unexplained
description: The Federal Aviation Administration said today that 362 planes were delayed on Wednesday afternoon and evening -- many for more than an hour -- by a computer system breakdown at an air traffic control center on Long Island.

title: EATON PLANS TO SELL A VICKERS BUSINESS THAT IT ACQUIRED
description: The Eaton Corporation, the world's second-largest maker of hydraulics equipment, plans to sell an electronics business acquired in the purchase of Aeroquip-Vickers Inc. Eaton said the business, Vickers Electronic Systems, did not mesh with Eaton's long-term plans. The unit makes electronic motion control systems used in manufacturing. It had 1998 sales of $130 million and employs about 800 workers in Cincinnati; Bedford, England, and Casella, Italy. The Cleveland-based Eaton is selling businesses and issuing stock to help finance last month's $1.7 billion purchase of Aeroquip-Vickers. Shares of Eaton rose $3.3125, to $89.5625.

title: For Houston, It's a Disappearing Act
description: Allan Houston wasn't in foul trouble, he was just out of it. He sat on the sideline and played the part of a towel-waving cheerleader for most of the game. How strange.

title: Annual Budget Follies
description: To the Editor:

title: SCHRODER VENTURES TO BUY 90% STAKE IN DANKA SERVICES
description: Danka Business Systems P.L.C. said yesterday that it had agreed to sell a 90 percent interest in its Danka Services International unit for $300 million to a new company controlled by the investment firm Schroder Ventures. Danka Services, which is based in Rochester and provides document management services, had revenue of $275 million in the year that ended on March 31. Danka Business, based in London, sells photocopiers, fax machines and other office equipment, and will retain a 10 percent interest in the new company. Schroder Ventures is a unit of the London-based merchant bank Schroder P.L.C.

title: Harvest From the Sea
description: Immediately after the gray whale gave up its life to the Makah people on Monday morning, our whaling crew prayed as best we could under the noise of circling helicopters and the scrutiny of live television. Then, the crew members raised their paddles in the air and celebrated success. It was an occasion of great joy.

title: Fatigue at War Sets In for Serbs
description: As the NATO air campaign continues into its ninth week, inflicting mounting casualties -- including several civilians in a Belgrade hospital -- war fatigue is growing in Yugoslavia, encouraging the splintered opposition to consider what the country could look like after the war, and even after President Slobodan Milosevic.

title: FOR CHILDREN
description: Theater

title: A Poorly Scripted War
description: To the Editor:

title: Law Weans Cabbies From Cell Phones
description: The notoriously garrulous New York City taxi driver is about to become a little less talkative.

title: Hawks, Down by 2-0, Are Running on Empty
description: Steve Smith stood out on the perimeter with less than a minute left in Game 2 last night, trying to shake himself free for a 3-pointer. At 6 feet 8 inches, he is big for a shooting guard and he uses his reach to score over smaller defenders.

title: Eric Heather Chan Schatz
description: Basilico Fine Arts

title: Business Group Hits Nassau With Scathing Fiscal Report
description: Long Island's largest business organization issued a withering analysis of Nassau County's fiscal morass today and urged officials to cut nearly 1,000 jobs, replace Nassau's antiquated tax assessment system and outlaw the sale of county assets to plug budget gaps.

title: Lena Cronqvist -- 'In the Age of the Girl'
description: Tricia Collins

title: Wives Protest And General Sends Troops Back Home
description: Five days of demonstrations by women in southern Serbia who were angry because their men had been drafted for military service in Kosovo ended today when many of the men returned home.

title: Senate Votes Gun Curbs, Hours After School Shooting
description: By a vote of 73 to 25, the Senate tonight passed a juvenile-crime bill that contained an array of new gun-control measures, the fruit of the most significant debate over gun control in Congress in half a decade.

title: Quality of Life: Blind Rule 1, True Love 0
description: DECIDE for yourself whether enforcement of the law was fair in the following case and, if so, whether fair also means sensible. The tale is offered without judgment. Sort of.

title: Met Opera Association Names President
description: Paul M. Montrone was elected president and chief executive officer of the Metropolitan Opera Association at its annual meeting yesterday. The association oversees the company's financial affairs, and although it has no direct artistic input, it is responsible for hiring both the general manager and the artistic director. The term of office is one year, with no term limit.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Sunday about John Minor Wisdom, who wrote many major civil rights decisions as a Federal appeals court judge in the 1960's, misidentified the unsuccessful Supreme Court nomination he opposed in 1969. It was not that of Judge Clement F. Haynsworth Jr. but that of Judge G. Harrold Carswell, who was nominated next.

title: New Video Releases
description: Saving Private Ryan

title: With Cars, a Name Is More Than Just a Name
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Staff at the Hospital Asks Why 4 Had to Die
description: A body lay curled up under the broken masonry of what had been the neurology clinic. Under the monochromatic gray dust that covers everything after an explosion, amid the broken tiles, filthy blankets and scattered bed rails, one could slowly make out the curve of the buttocks and thighs.

title: Barclays to Cut 10% of Jobs in Britain
description: Struggling against bloated costs and increased competition, Britain's second-largest bank, Barclays P.L.C., announced today that it would cut almost 10 percent of its 65,000-member British work force this year.

title: DDB Worldwide Wins 30 Clios
description: DDB Worldwide in New York has won the most honors at the 1999 Clio Awards ceremonies.

title: Once Feared, De La Hoya Is Fighting to Regain Respect
description: Oscar De La Hoya awoke five weeks ago, startled by a realization: he was no longer the fighter that he was.

title: Worth 1,000 Words? More Like a Gazillion
description: ''The Saragossa Manuscript'' was shown as part of the New York Film Festival in 1997. Following are excerpts from Stephen Holden's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Sept. 27, 1997. The film -- in Polish, with English subtitles -- opens today at the Walter Reade Theater at Lincoln Center.

title: 'Second Israel' Hails First Big Election Triumph
description: Natan Yehuda is still elated, three days after a long, joyous night of beef and wine celebrating the staggering electoral triumph of his political party and spiritual home, Shas.

title: Plan for Arena Is Announced
description: Cablevision and the Devils formally announced a plan yesterday to build a $350 million arena complex in Hoboken, N.J., that would include a retail and entertainment center in the adjacent Lackawanna Ferry Terminal.

title: An Abstractionist Dancing With Color
description: A mid-1950's photograph of the painter Hans Hofmann (1880-1966), in the catalogue for the Metropolitan Museum's current show, portrays him in a sort of joyous dance before his easel, doing the work with exuberant body language that gives new dimension to the catch phrase Action Painting. And Hofmann's vitality as an artist carried over into his life. In 1964, after the demise of his beloved wife, Miz, with whom he had lived for more than six decades, he met Renate Schmitz (1931-1992). A German-born emigre like Hofmann, she was 52 years his junior. They were married in 1965; he died the next year. The short union was apparently a productive one for Hofmann, who attacked his art with renewed vigor.

title: Enron Says It Will Broker Fiber Optic Deals
description: The Enron Corporation said today that it would offer contracts that allow customers to buy or sell space on fiber optic telecommunications networks in the United States.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WINSHIP, HARRY RAY
description: WINSHIP-Harry Ray, on May 17. Beloved father of Tim, Dorian and Abby, and grandfather of Julien, Sabine, Zachary and Dylan. Longtime New Yorker and summer resident of Fire Island Pines. Memorial service on Monday, May 24 (please call 212-222-7796 for time and location).

title: With the Force as Ever, A Generation Far, Far Away
description: Star Wars: Episode I -- The Phantom Menace

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MAYNARD, AUBRE DE L., M.D.
description: MAYNARD-Aubre de L., M.D. Memorial Service will be held on Monday May 24, 1999, 3 P.M. at Harlem Hospital Center, 506 Lenox Avenue, NYC.

title: CHANCELLOR EXPLORES THE SALE OF ITS BILLBOARD BUSINESS
description: The Chancellor Media Corporation, the radio broadcasting and outdoor-advertising concern, said yesterday that it had hired the investment firms of Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Company and Greenhill & Company to assist in exploring the sale of its billboard operations. The move continues a revamping of the Dallas-based company, which is changing its name to AMFM Inc. Chancellor has been disappointed in its return on the billboard business, which is expected to generate flat second-quarter results. Chancellor paid about $1.6 billion for the two predecessors of its current billboard operations. Shares of Chancellor fell $2.4375, to $54.25.

title: Foreign Affairs; The Price Of Admission
description: The overwhelming sense coming out of Israel today, in the wake of the landslide victory of Ehud Barak over Benjamin Netanyahu, is that of a national nightmare having ended. While Mr. Netanyahu helped to create the new center in Israel, by breaking down the divide over peace with the Palestinians, he was reluctant to lead that new center forward. Instead he actually tried to divide it and run against it, and in the end that center not only defeated him but evicted him from Israeli politics. Israelis declared that they wanted peace at home and peace abroad, they wanted differences healed, not exploited, and they wanted to get on with it already.

title: Comparing Quality Ratings
description: IT is a question that anyone who drives cars for a living is asked over and over: What's the best car, or truck, to buy? Well, it depends -- on your price range, on your driving style, on the importance you place on quality, design, performance and other factors.

title: Confidence in Economy Slides in Germany
description: German executives were more pessimistic in April than in March, as war in Kosovo and rising unemployment raised concern that economic growth would slow. The Ifo institute, which polls some 6,000 executives about investment, orders and earnings each month, said yesterday that its index of western German confidence fell to 89.7, matching a two-and-a-half-year low reached in February. Ifo's index for eastern Germany, representing about a tenth of the economy, fell to 103.6 from 106.5.

title: Accounts
description: * Sage Products Inc., Crystal Lake, Ill., to CPM Inc., Chicago, as the first agency to handle media duties for its new Comfort Bath product account. Billings were estimated at $5 million.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of the first and second days of Shabuoth, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City today and tomorrow. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Easy Credit Demands Tough Laws
description: To the Editor:

title: Acting Is in Their Blood, Blood Is in Their Eyes
description: Quentin Tarantino has already blasted himself a niche in cinema history, but his full impact on the gross national product may not be measurable until the last of his filmmaking disciples has exorcised the demon that impels them to imitate ''Pulp Fiction.''

title: UPN Adds Wrestling to Fall Lineup
description: The madcap mayhem of pro wrestling has invaded broadcast television. UPN announced yesterday that it would give its two hours of Thursday night prime-time to ''W.W.F. Smackdown,'' a production of the World Wrestling Federation.

title: A Hard-Working Queen and Her Men
description: It's big, it's bad, it's ''Cleopatra!'' What else could anyone expect? Onscreen, Cleopatra's legend has always been about spectacle, not character. So ABC's expensive two-night mini-series includes chariots, warships, battle scenes on horseback, the Pyramids, the streets of Rome, and countless varieties of Egyptian headdresses. But this is a spectacle going nowhere except off the deep end. Shakespeare may have described Cleopatra's power best when he praised ''her infinite variety,'' but here her charms are finite.

title: Only a Start on Gun Control
description: The debate over gun control took a dramatic turn yesterday. Hours after another frightening school shooting episode -- this time at a high school outside Atlanta -- Vice President Gore cast a tie-breaking vote in the Senate to tighten existing gun control laws, dealing an important defeat to the National Rifle Association.

title: So, That's Who Kellerman Is!
description: ''I started to try to get this done 19 years ago, and now I can hold it in my hand,'' said Herb Gardner. It's been a long wait for the film with the endless title, but on Tuesday ''Who Is Harry Kellerman and Why Is He Saying Those Terrible Things About Me?'' will be released by Fox for the first time on tape.

title: Democrats Gain Ground, an Inch, on Gun Control
description: In the past two extraordinary weeks in the Senate, Democrats and gun-control advocates accomplished far more than any of them had ever thought possible. But for all of the celebration, the package they assembled was still modest, falling short of the proposals President Clinton offered after the Colorado shootings, much less anything as far-reaching as a ban on cheap handguns.

title: Congress Passes Antimissile Defense Policy
description: After two decades of debate over whether to create a ''Star Wars'' defense program, the House voted overwhelmingly today to enshrine in national security policy the intention to field a system to protect the country against ballistic missiles.

title: KOSOVO UPDATE
description: COMBAT

title: Rutgers Defeats St. John's
description: Rutgers, last year's winner of the Big East baseball championship, scored a 13-9 victory over St. John's yesterday in Trenton in their opening game of the league tournament.

title: CHINA STOLE DATA, REPORT CONCLUDES
description: A House committee has unanimously concluded that China systematically stole significant American nuclear design secrets, enabling Beijing to accelerate its weapons program so that it now possesses thermonuclear weapons design information on a par with the United States.

title: Ventura's Bat Rescues All The Mets But Leiter
description: Theirs were the two faces and divergent moods of the Mets yesterday. Pitcher Al Leiter stalking off the mound after each inning, his face etched with a grimace, muttering words of frustration to himself, nearly every pitch a struggle, while Robin Ventura floated effortlessly around the bases after two nearly identical grand slams.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DRAPER, CATHERINE
description: DRAPER-Catherine. Native of County Lietrim, Ireland. Loving wife of the late Patrick. Devoted mother of Robert E., Mary P. and Patrick F. Survived by six grandchildren. Family will receive friends Sunday, May 23 from 25PM and 7-9PM at Williams Funeral Home, 5628 Broadway at 232 Street, Bronx. Mass of Christian burial St. John's R.C. Church (Kingsbridge), Monday, May 24 at 10:45 AM. Interment Gate of Heaven cemetery.

title: A Love That Soars Above Words
description: In an age when televised psychobabble presumes to unlock life's greatest mysteries, it's easy to forget that love isn't the product of words and therapeutic negotiation. Civilized relationships are one thing; the raw force we call love is another. One reason why ''Besieged,'' Bernardo Bertolucci's new film, feels so bracingly fresh is that the love that grows between its two main characters, Jason Kinsky (David Thewlis), a wealthy expatriate English pianist living in Rome, and his black housekeeper, Shandurai (Thandie Newton), who has fled an oppressive African regime, has little to do with words. This is one contemporary love story in which you won't hear terms like ''boundaries'' and ''narcissistic'' thrown around. You won't even hear the word ''relationship.''

title: New Jersey Senate Moves on 'Smart Gun' Legislation
description: A Senate committee today unanimously approved a requirement that all handguns sold in the state five years from now be equipped with so-called smart-gun technology, computer chips or other features that make the guns inoperable by anyone other than their owners.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COFFEE SLUMPS. Coffee ended a four-day rally as concern eased that crops in Brazil would be damaged by freezing weather this week. In New York, coffee for July delivery fell 3 cents, or 2.4 percent, to $1.20 a pound.

title: Trade Deficit Rises Faster Than Forecast
description: The nation's trade deficit reached another record in March, the Commerce Department reported today, providing fresh evidence that the American economy continues to absorb imports at a prodigious rate.

title: Cosmopolitan Makeover for a Tidewater Backwater
description: Hampton Roads, the natural harbor where the James River and several lesser streams meet Chesapeake Bay, has had a balcony seat for history.

title: An Affinity for Weapons, But No Signs of Anger
description: Almost every teen-ager in the neighborhood knew what was in Thomas Solomon's basement. They could hardly have missed them.

title: Top Prosecutor In Queens Plans To Run Again
description: Queens District Attorney Richard A. Brown said yesterday that he planned to run for a third term.

title: U.S. Aide Due in North Korea With Deal to Lift Sanctions
description: President Clinton is sending an envoy to North Korea next week with a proposal that the 50-year-old economic embargo against the country be lifted gradually in exchange for a series of major concessions, including an agreement that the North will end its long-range missile program, officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEVENS, SANFORD, M.D.
description: STEVENS-Sanford, M.D. The members of the Psychoanalytic Association of New York and the faculty of the NYU Psychoanalytic Institute mourn the passing of their distinguished colleague, Sanford Stevens. A graduate of the Institute, and training analyst for many years at both NYU and Columbia, his skilled teaching, scholarly contributions, and devoted treatment of his patients enriched us all. He will be sorely missed. Leonard Barkin, M.D. President, PANY Arthur Lew, M.D., Secy., PANY Michael Singer, D.O., Director NYU Psychoanalytic Inst.

title: Does Whale Hunt Revive a Stolen Tradition?; Tribe Has Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DONAHUE, MARY, T.
description: DONAHUE-Mary, T. On May 19, 1999 formerly of Whitestone. Beloved friend to many. Friends may call at Andrett Funeral Home, 353 2nd Ave. (at 20th St), NYC, Saturday and Sunday 2-5 and 7-9PM. Mass of Christian burial Epiphany R.C. Church, Monday 11AM. Interment Mount St. Mary's Cemetery.

title: Meetings in Moscow May Be Showing Progress
description: Negotiations toward a political settlement over Serbia seemed to inch forward today when the Russian mediator, Viktor S. Chernomyrdin, met outside Moscow with Deputy Secretary of State Strobe Talbott and President Martti Ahtisaari of Finland.

title: Willie Doherty
description: Alexander and Bonin

title: Atlantic City Declares Water Emergency Over
description: A water emergency that had shut down restaurants and threatened fire protection since Monday was declared ended yesterday.

title: Lembit Oll Chess Grandmaster, 33
description: Lembit Oll, an Estonian chess grandmaster who was preparing to take part in a qualifying competition for the International Chess Federation's world championship match this summer in Las Vegas, Nev., died on Sunday in a plunge from a window of his fourth-floor apartment in Tallinn, the Estonian capital, press reports there said. He was 33.

title: SOLECTRON TO BUY SEQUEL TO EXPAND SERVICES BUSINESS
description: The Solectron Corporation, which provides manufacturing services for electronics companies, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the closely held Sequel Inc. for an undisclosed price. The transaction gives Solectron control of Sequel's operations in San Jose, Calif.; Memphis, and Reading, England. Solectron said it would keep all of Sequel's 550 employees. Sequel, based in San Jose, specializes in notebook computer and liquid crystal display repair service and support. After acquiring Sequel, Solectron plans to offer a telephone support service for repairs and trouble-shooting. The stock of Solectron rose 25 cents, to $55.5625.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SKOLNICK, GLORIA
description: SKOLNICK-Gloria. The staff of Rich Worldwide Travel mourns the untimely passing of our esteemed colleague. Condolences to her entire family. Ina Rich, President

title: An Unsigned Letter Sends the Sparks Flying
description: Loblolly by the Sea, the jauntily named New England town that is the setting for ''The Love Letter,'' is the kind of idyllic seaside retreat that could exist only in a cheery children's folk song or a yuppie sitcom. The place radiates an alarming perkiness. And for its first three-quarters, ''The Love Letter,'' which takes place in the summer, hurtles toward a seemingly inevitable fairy-tale ending in which its nice middle-class characters all end up snugly coupled before the first nip of autumn frost.

title: NATO'S COMMANDER REPORTED TO URGE BUILDUP OF TROOPS
description: NATO's commander, Gen. Wesley K. Clark, is advocating that the alliance begin soon to assemble 45,000 to 50,000 troops on Kosovo's borders, American and NATO officials said today.

title: Fascinating Features on Sidelines Outsparkle Main Event at Cannes
description: Spike Lee's ''Summer of Sam'' arrived here today and shot off some sparks. It's a hot, sprawling New York story rocked by the trends and events of 1977, and it centers on the effects of David Berkowitz's ''Son of Sam'' killing spree. Finding pretexts for visiting tourist attractions from CBGB to Plato's Retreat, it weaves its nostalgia into the tale of how an insular Bronx neighborhood closes ranks against anyone different, even though virtually everyone in the movie leads some kind of double life. Adrien Brody, as a self-styled punk, and John Leguizamo and Mira Sorvino, as restless young marrieds with a ''Saturday Night Fever'' dance habit, head a large cast of actors with a conspicuous common trait.

title: Corrections
description: Because of editing errors, an article on Monday about government warnings to the City University of New York over compliance with ethical rules for federally financed research on human subjects referred incorrectly in some copies to CUNY's medical program. CUNY indeed has a medical school, situated at City College.

title: 76ers' Wild Card Remains Iverson
description: Allen Iverson is free. No longer hindered by the constraints of playmaking, he is finally able to be himself on the basketball court. He does not have to set up shots for his teammates or force himself to think pass rather than shoot. And oddly enough, as a shooting guard, he is now doing what he seldom did as a point guard. He is making his Philadelphia 76ers teammates better.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBIN, PETER JAY
description: RUBIN-Peter Jay. April 28, 1964May 18, 1999. Firstborn child and beloved son of Barbara and the late Walter. Devoted and dear brother of Randy. Loving grandson, nephew, cousin and friend. Peter had a deep love for Torah and Israel, closely followed by his love for the Knicks and English football. He traveled the world in search of knowledge and inner peace, which we pray he has found. Now he is together with his dad. His memory for a blessing. We will love him and miss him forever. Services will be held on Sunday, May 23 at 12:00 noon at Gutterman's, Woodbury. Barbara and Randy Rubin

title: Yugoslav Politicians Carefully Maneuver for Day Milosevic Is Gone
description: War fatigue is growing here as casualties mount in the fight with NATO, prompting a circumspect political debate and encouraging the splintered opposition to think about what Yugoslavia could look like after the war, and even after President Slobodan Milosevic.

title: Merrill Charged With 2d Firm In Copper Case
description: Federal regulators filed a lawsuit yesterday against the Global Minerals and Metals Corporation, a Manhattan commodities merchant, and Merrill Lynch & Company, the investment firm, contending that the two companies took part in an illegal scheme to manipulate world copper prices in the mid-1990's.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERENSTEIN, HARRY T.
description: HERENSTEIN-Harry T. Beloved and devoted husband of the late Ruth Spitz Herenstein. Loving brother of the late Louis Hernstein, Gladys Cohen, Lester and Moe Herenstein, Dorothy Sollar, Perry & Henry Herenstein. Caring brother-in-law of Pearl Herenstein. Dear uncle of Arlene Asher, Doris Fine, Arnold R. Sollar, Herman Herenstein, Elaine Sollar Eisen, Ira Herenstein, Francine Gilstein, Arnold Herenstein, Charna Herenstein & the late Larry Herenstein. We have all benefited from his wisdom, wit and love. And we will miss him and cherish his memory. Service on Sunday 11 A.M., at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: In Israel, Winning Is Not Everything
description: To the Editor:

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: Two Lovebirds And a Bookshop

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BROWNSTEIN, NOAH
description: BROWNSTEIN-Noah. 5/21/'52 to 8/ 1/'92. Happy birthday in heaven to our dear cherished Noah. You are spending your 47th birthday so far away from us, but our love and broken hearts are with you. Only distance keeps us from hugging and kissing your sweet face, but in our hearts you are never far away. We'll kiss your pictures and wish you a peaceful birthday. Hugs and Kisses, our sweet angel. Mom and Dad

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTHENBERG, ROBERT
description: ROTHENBERG - Robert. Of Brooklyn, N.Y. Died May 18 at the age of 75. Brother of Harvey E. Rothenberg. Brother-in-law of Judith and loving uncle of Alan and Suzanne Rothenberg, Anne and Glenn Roberts and great-uncle of Jessica, Jillian, Jake, Jonathan and Joel. He will be remembered and sadly missed.

title: Open Short Sales Rise On Big Board and Amex
description: Open positions of short sales on the New York Stock Exchange increased 1.9 percent in the most recent month, to 3.72 billion shares, the exchange said yesterday.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on page 8.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on May 11 about mercury levels in canned tuna misstated the Food and Drug Administration's safe limit for human consumption of methyl mercury. It is 1.0 parts per million, not 0.1 part.

title: It All Works for Hernandez As Yanks Win One Under Torre
description: Confidence had been replaced by self-deprecation in the Yankees' clubhouse. Tino Martinez lounged in front of his locker before batting practice today and joked that he could not stand to watch ESPN highlights anymore, because it was as if everybody except him was driving the ball.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCGOLDRICK, MURIEL R. (NEE FULLEN)
description: McGOLDRICK-Muriel R. (nee Fullen), May 19, 1999, retired educator and social worker. Beloved wife of the late Arthur. Devoted mother of Muriel Donohue, Arthur, Adrian Sutton, and Jean. Loving grandmother of Matthew, the late Sean, & great-grandmother of Sean Michael. Dear sister of the late Chester Fullen. Reposing at Denis S. O'Connor Funeral Home, 91-05 Beach Channel Drive, Rockaway Beach, NY. Mass of Christian Burial on Monday, 9:45AM at Saint Francis DeSales Church, Belle Harbor. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery. Visiting Sunday, 2-5 and 7-10PM. In lieu of flowers, donations to Terence Cardinal Cooke Health Center, 1249 5th Avenue, NY, NY 10029.

title: Legislature Of Nebraska Votes Pause In Executions
description: Responding to concerns that the death penalty was being applied unfairly, the Nebraska Legislature voted today to impose a two-year moratorium on executions.

title: Sports of The Times; On the Radio, a Voice Echoes as Big as Life
description: WHEN Gus Johnson calls a Knicks game on the radio, he visualizes his audio audience: fans in their cars, tired truckers, eager to get home, needing a boost for two and a half or three hours. People who need to keep their spirits up as they drive.

title: Agassi Plans To Compete
description: Andre Agassi said yesterday he intended to compete at the French Open, which begins Monday in Paris. The 29-year-old Agassi, seeded 13th at Roland Garros, withdrew from this week's World Team Cup Championship in Dusseldorf, Germany, due to a flare-up of tendinitis in his right shoulder, but he said the injury had responded so well to treatment that he was back on the practice court Wednesday.

title: As Intimate as the Touch of an Artist
description: It may or may not have anything to do with the arrival of spring, but Manhattan has broken out in some superb exhibitions of modern drawings -- arguably the most overtly delectable of all art forms.

title: Cecilia Vicuna -- 'Cloud-Net'
description: Art in General

title: Knicks Rattle the Rims, and the Hawks
description: The tinsel-thin Marcus Camby cupped the ball in his hand and rose into the air from the far corner of the free-throw lane, a distance saved for playground bets and commercial shoots.

title: Residential Real Estate; West Side Tower to Have Park Views
description: Sales began last week for the 53 apartments at the Park Laurel, a 40-story tower at 15 West 63d Street that was conceived more than a decade ago. Preliminary site work is under way and the developer expects the building to be ready for occupancy in 2001.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE EURO FALLS. The dollar rose after economic reports showed further weakness in Europe, giving traders cause to shun the single European currency. In New York, the dollar settled at $1.0623, up from $1.0657.

title: Ethiopia's Wami To Test Loroupe
description: Gete Wami of Ethiopia has never competed in a road race in the United States, but she is viewed as a prime challenger to Tegla Loroupe of Kenya in tomorrow's Avon Mini Marathon in Central Park.

title: Irish Style: A 'Stepson' Gains Favor
description: Ireland seems to be entering a golden age. There is the promise of peace. The country is in the midst of a boom: the so-called Celtic Tiger's economy is growing at a faster rate than Europe's. Many computer companies have large operations there, and Dublin has a new International Financial Services Center, where banks like Chase are congregating.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: STAGE STORES INC., Houston, a clothing chain with annual sales of more than $1 billion, will close 35 stores in the next six months because of declining sales and higher promotion costs.

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Corrections
description: The listing of lottery numbers yesterday misstated the results for Wednesday's New York Lotto drawing. The correct numbers are 6, 14, 25, 30, 31 and 42, with the supplementary number 48.

title: Betty Robinson, a Pathfinder In Women's Track, Dies at 87
description: Betty Robinson Schwartz, who in 1928 as a 16-year-old high school junior became the first woman to win an Olympic gold medal in track and field, died Tuesday in Colorado. She was 87.

title: Resettlement of Refugees Begins
description: With little more than hope, anxiety and a few pieces of carry-on luggage between them, the first three families of Kosovar Albanians left the haven of this Army base, where they were embraced just two weeks ago, and fanned out across the American landscape to begin their new lives in this country.

title: Easy Credit Demands Tough Laws
description: To the Editor:

title: MTV Is Buying Two Services From TCI Music
description: Just weeks before it is to unveil a new on-line music venture, MTV Networks announced yesterday that it was acquiring music services on the Internet and on cable television.

title: Giuliani Plans to See if City Can Control Roosevelt Island
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, responding to complaints about the state's management of Roosevelt Island, said last night that he would explore ways of bringing the two-mile-long island under city control, a move that would likely escalate tensions between the Mayor and Gov. George E. Pataki.

title: Highlight Film Includes Tribute
description: The Jets' 1998 season was so good that the team's highlight film runs 15 minutes longer than usual.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Gentleman, Stop Your Keyboard

title: No Explanation on Payment As Yet by Morgan Stanley
description: Amid the swirling allegations and counterclaims that surround a racial discrimination lawsuit filed against the Wall Street powerhouse Morgan Stanley Dean Witter by a former employee, one question stands out: Why did the firm pay $10,000 to a police informant involved in the employee's arrest last year?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEGAN, HELEN ALVORD (NEE BROWN)
description: FEGAN - Helen Alvord (nee Brown). Daughter of George A. Brown and Charlotte (nee Pitts). Predeceased by her dearest brother Cyril Brown, beloved sister Ethel Mae Fegan (Brown) and devoted husband Matthew W. Fegan. Initially a librarian in the Brooklyn Public Library, she was for many years Library Director of the East Rockaway Free Library on Long Island until her retirement. Survived by her cherished nephews, Matthew W. Fegan, Jr. and Jerard Gliner. Reposing Sunday at Connell Funeral Home, Huntington, NY 3-5 & 7-9 P.M.

title: Easy Credit Demands Tough Laws
description: To the Editor:

title: Another Officer Testifies Against Volpe in Trial
description: Another police officer testified yesterday that the officer accused of torturing Abner Louima made statements linking himself to the reported attack in the restroom of a Brooklyn police station.

title: Tokyo Takes A Hard Look At Foreigners
description: The Financial Supervisory Agency, Japan's financial watchdog, has begun taking a serious look at the foreign financial community here after having scrutinized the books of Japan's major banks.

title: Europeans Reassessing Bioengineered Corn
description: The European Union said yesterday that it would suspend the approval process for a genetically modified corn from Pioneer Hi-Bred International Inc., the world's largest seed-corn company, after a United States study found bioengineered corn could kill butterflies. Regulators will also review earlier European approvals of genetically altered corn produced by the Monsanto Company and the Novartis Company in light of the findings.

title: Gerald J. Lieberman, 73, Provost At Stanford and Statistics Expert
description: Gerald J. Lieberman, a former Stanford University provost and an expert in statistics and operations research, died on Tuesday at his home on the Stanford campus in Palo Alto, Calif. He was 73.

title: Ovitz Helps Form On-Line Entertainment Venture
description: Michael Ovitz, the talent manager once known as the most powerful man in Hollywood, is trying to extend his reach into cyberspace.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANKLIN, WILLIAM D., M.D.
description: FRANKLIN-William D., M.D. Died suddenly in his home in Aventura, FL on May 16, 1999 after a heart attack. Lifelong resident of Great Neck, NY. Member of Phi Beta Kappa and Alpha Omega Alpha. Graduate of Tulane University, B.S. 1943; M.D., 1945. Diplomate American Board of Internal Medicine, Fellow and member of Governing Council, American College of Cardiology. Served in the U.S. military as Captain, M.C. Deeply involved in philanthropic activities, he was instrumental and a key figure in the formation of a health clinic for migrant workers in Boynton Beach, FL and through his efforts secured all medical equipment required for the clinic. Beloved husband of Elaine Silver, and the deceased Josephine Solomon. He is survived by his daughters Deborah A. Elice, Wendy Franklin Opotzner, Amy Beth Franklin, Cathy Franklin Eckstein; his stepchildren Jane Asche and Ronald Asche; his sisters Bernice S. Tannenbaum and Selma Wyman; and ten grandchildren. Memorial donations to the Southern Poverty Law Center.

title: Being Angry Helps in Directing TV News
description: THE essential story about Paula Walker Madison, the news director of WNBC-TV's Channel 4 and one of the few black female news directors in the country, took place at Cardinal Spellman High School, circa 1969, when she was growing up in Harlem on welfare.

title: Ewing Dons White Hat (for Now)
description: It took a gallant performance against the Miami Heat last Sunday for Patrick Ewing's legacy to take a positive swing. At least until he misses a game-winning shot.

title: New Mark IV Buyback
description: Mark IV Industries, the world's largest maker of automobile camshafts, plans to repurchase as many as 10 million more shares, or 20 percent of its common stock outstanding, to raise its stock price. The company completed the repurchase of 10 million shares at an average price of $16.55 a share under a program begun in May 1998, following an earlier buyback that began in March 1997. Mark IV has bought back 17.3 million shares, or 26 percent of its stock, in the last 26 months. The company's shares have risen 43 percent this year.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Coty Is in Talks to Acquire Debt-Ridden Revlon
description: Coty Inc., a leading seller of fragrances and cosmetics, is in talks to acquire part or all of Revlon Inc., the debt-ridden cosmetics company controlled by the billionaire Ronald O. Perelman, executives close to the negotiations said.

title: Black Guests Sue a Florida Hotel, Saying It Discriminated
description: In a Federal lawsuit filed today, black plaintiffs charged that the Adam's Mark Daytona Beach Resort, one of the more luxurious hotels here, discriminated against African-Americans who had gathered in April for the Black College Reunion, an annual social event that draws young black men and women from across the country.

title: Correction
description: An editorial on Wednesday erred in suggesting that the original ''Star Wars'' film, released in 1977, was called ''Episode IV'' and subtitled ''A New Hope.'' The subtitle ''Episode IV: A New Hope'' was appended in 1980.

title: For Takeout
description: Sometimes the only way to get dinner on the table is to bring it home with you. Here are a dozen prime candidates for takeout. (These summaries, written by Eric Asimov, are taken from Mr. Asimov's and others' dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times.)

title: Made for a Medieval Queen, a Tiny Book That Created a Style
description: Manhattan's four-star attractions come in every size. Among the very smallest of them is the 14th-century prayer book known as ''The Hours of Jeanne d'Evreux'' in the collection of the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: Album of the Week
description: TOM WAITS: ''Mule Variations'' (Epitaph). Tom Waits's tunes sound as if they've been unearthed, not composed. They are blues vamps and parlor songs, gospel call-and-responses and country waltzes: primordial American music, as basic as mud.

title: Youth With 2 Guns Shoots 6 at Georgia School
description: One month after the deadly shootings at Columbine High School in Littleton, Colo., a 15-year-old student armed with two guns walked casually into the indoor commons area of Heritage High School here this morning and opened fire, wounding six of his fellow students before surrendering in tears to an assistant principal, the authorities said.

title: Abortion Limit Gains Support Of Whitman
description: For the first time in her political career, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman said today that she would support legislation restricting some abortion rights, endorsing an Assembly bill that would require parental notification before a teen-age girl can get an abortion in the state.

title: Olivetti Doubles Telecom Italia Holdings
description: Olivetti inched closer tonight to possible victory in a $65 billion hostile bid for Telecom Italia by amassing nearly 20 percent of the shares in its larger rival, roughly twice the stake it held 24 hours earlier.

title: Julian Schnabel -- 'Plate Paintings, 1978-1997'
description: Pace Wildenstein Gallery

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OECHLER, CONVERE M.
description: OECHLER-Convere M., 87. Of New York, on May 13, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Henry J. Oechler, devoted mother of Hugh McAden and Henry, Jr., devoted mother-in-law to Joanne and Kathleen and devoted grandmother of James, Sarah, Joshua, Sean and Jack. Services will be on Monday, May 24 at 11 AM in St. James Episcopal Church, NYC. In lieu of flowers, the family requests contributions to The Rector's Discretionary Fund of the St. James Episcopal Church, 865 Madison Avenue, NYC.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICH, MILDRED B.
description: RICH-Mildred B., 83. On May 11, 1999. She is survived by her daughter Alice, son Harvey, granddaughter Jessica, cousins Mickey Spira and Dorothy Sekeley, nieces Tara, Avra, Mavra, Amy, and Hali, nephews Ira and Andy, and many grand-nieces and nephews. Beth El Cemetery in N.J.

title: Police Officer Kills Suspect in a Robbery
description: A White Plains police officer yesterday shot and killed a bank robbery suspect who became stuck in rush-hour traffic as the suspect attempted to enter the Hutchison River Parkway, the police said.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: U.S. Details Global Cartel That Fixed Vitamin Prices

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELKINS, MARGARET WIESS
description: ELKINS-Margaret Wiess. Loving wife, mother, grandmother and friend died on May 19, 1999. Born October 26, 1922 in Houston, TX to Olga Keith and Harry Carothers Wiess. She attended Kinkaid School, The Ethel Walker School and Pine Manor College. Due to her interest in all of the citizens of Houston, she was involved in numerous cultural and civic activities. Predeceased by her parents and her sister, Elizabeth Wiess Smith. Survived by her husband of 54 years James Anderson Elkins, Jr., her children, Elise Elkins Joseph and husband Russell, James Anderson Elkins III and wife Jenny, and Leslie Elkins Sasser and husband Shannon; and her grandchildren Jennifer Carroll Joseph, Russell Charles Joseph, Jr., Christopher Elkins Joseph, Margaret Wiess Elkins, James Anderson Elkins IV, Buck Arnold Elkins, John Caldwell Elkins, Harry Carothers Elkins, Samuel Hill Elkins, Lucy Gray Elkins, Caroline Elise Sasser; her sister Caroline Wiess Law; and her nieces Sandra Smith Smith, Sharon Smith Keller, and Sydney Smith MacPherson. A memorial service will be held at 2P.M. Saturday May 22nd, 1999 at Christ Church Cathedral, 1117 Texas Ave., Houston, TX. Private services at Glenwood Cemetery will be held at a later date. In lieu of flowers the family suggests that memorial contributions may be directed to Christ Church Cathedral, 1117 Texas Avenue, Houston, TX, 77002; Baylor College of Medicine, One Baylor Plaza, Houston, TX 77030; M.D. Anderson Cancer Center, 1515 Holcombe Blvd., Houston, TX 77030 or her friends' favorite charities. For further details contact Geo. H. Lewis & Sons, Houston, TX 713-789-3005.

title: Lionizing Athletes
description: To the Editor:

title: Legends and Lore
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEYERSON, FRIEDA
description: MEYERSON - Frieda. Beloved wife of the late Morris. Dear mother of Ellen Zelmanowicz and Harvey. Loving grandmother of Adam and Matthew. Dear sister of Minna Wolfson. Services Sunday 1PM, Gramercy Park Memorial Chapel, 152 Second Ave, NYC.

title: Ghost Story From Spain, Both Wild And Elegant
description: It takes force of will and some help from the outside to escape the confinements of national identity. Countries with powerful ethnic music tend to eat individual creativity alive. The strong survive, but for every Smetana and Dvorak there are the reams of operas and symphonic pieces that bow to the Central European folk tradition, achieve loyalty at home, but have little relevance in the wider world. Brazil has possibly the most beautiful popular music in the world and not much beyond Villa-Lobos.

title: Senate Approves TV Measure To Help Satellite Companies
description: The Senate approved legislation late Thursday aimed at helping satellite-television companies like the Echostar Communications Corporation compete more effectively against cable-TV providers.

title: Revived Offense Is Losing Hurtado, at Least for Tonight
description: After their best production of the season last Saturday in a 3-2 victory over Miami, the MetroStars will clash with the Colorado Rapids in Denver tonight with renewed spirit, even though they will play without Eduardo Hurtado, one of the league's most efficient goal scorers.

title: Kosovo Insurgents Report Killing Russian Officer in Battle With Serbs
description: In a development that could complicate Russia's role in the Kosovo crisis, rebels fighting for the territory's independence claim to have killed a Russian captain in a battle with Serbian troops in Kosovo.

title: Yugoslavs Demand a Role In U.N. Kosovo Settlement
description: Yugoslavia insisted today that it must play a central role in negotiations within the United Nations to end the war and bring a political settlement to Kosovo, and that Belgrade would not simply let NATO dictate a solution.

title: Depositions Continue in Microsoft Case
description: Midway through a deposition today, Stephen M. Case, chairman of America Online, looked quizzically at the Microsoft lawyer who was questioning him and asked, ''Did I wander into the wrong room?''

title: Possible Strike Leaves T.W.A. At Crossroads
description: After passing through bankruptcy court twice since 1992, Trans World Airlines, the airline made famous by Charles Lindbergh and Howard Hughes, is once again at a crossroads.

title: School Shootings Changed a Senator, and in the End a Crucial Vote
description: As someone who once had to carry an assault rifle in his job, losing an arm and both legs when he was a soldier in Vietnam, Senator Max Cleland of Georgia has always thought deeply about the role guns play in American life.

title: FIFTH THIRD BANCORP TO BUY VANGUARD FINANCIAL
description: Fifth Third Bancorp said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Vanguard Financial Company, a closely held commercial-mortgage company. Terms were not disclosed. The deal, which is expected to close sometime this spring, will increase Fifth Third's servicing portfolio to $2.7 billion. Fifth Third, based in Cincinnati, is a commercial real estate finance company with 1998 assets of $28.92 billion. Vanguard Financial, also based in Cincinnati, originated more than $400 million in financing and equity transactions last year. Its loan servicing portfolio exceeds $700 million. The stock of Fifth Third slipped 6.25 cents, to $70.

title: CRISIS IN THE BALKANS: Washington Memo; Clinton's Aims: Win the War, Keep the U.S. Voters Content
description: Between the two options that President Clinton has declared unacceptable -- doing nothing or all-out war -- the White House has devised a new type of warfare for Yugoslavia.

title: Under All the Meanings, It's Still Music
description: Meaning in music has always been a vexed question. A symphony heard innocently, without the goading of program notes or introductory lectures, can mean radically different things -- or nothing at all -- to different listeners. Shostakovich's music is a textook example of this problem. Music was freighted with meaning for him. His works are often pictorial, and they carry an emotional weight that, if nothing else, conveys the complexity and turmoil of their creator's inner life. Yet if the opinions and commentary included in Solomon Volkov's ''Testimony'' are truly those of Shostakovich, the composer himself often gave conflicting explanations of his pieces.

title: A Roof, Guaranteed
description: To the Editor:

title: Abroad at Home; Something Out of Kafka
description: Bonnie Blackwell is a Canadian scientist, the inventor of a new technology for dating ancient objects. She was in New York earlier this year when her mother became fatally ill in Canada. This is the story of how employees of the U.S. Immigration and Naturalization Service kept her from seeing her mother before she died.

title: West Indies Wins
description: Two-time champion West Indies beat underdog Bangladesh by seven wickets yesterday in a World Cup match in Dublin to earn its first points in Group B.

title: Killing in Italy Stirs Fears of a Revival of Terrorist Times Past
description: Italians scoured their newspapers today with a sickening sense of deja vu: blaring headlines about the assassination of a government official, blurry photographs of the widow leaving the police station, and a five-pointed star that terrified Italy for two decades, the emblem of the Red Brigades.

title: Hidden Commuter Tax
description: To the Editor:

title: Vacation Spots in New York Suddenly Appeal to Clintons
description: President Clinton, as he is fond of reminding everyone from time to time, cannot run again for re-election, which frees him from certain political calculations. One of these, you would think, would be where to spend his summer vacation, a decision that in the past has been so fraught with image-conscious polling that he twice went off to Wyoming just to please environmentalists when he really wanted to go back to Martha's Vineyard.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of the second day of Shabuoth, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City today. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-7

title: 3 Officers Found Guilty of Corruption
description: After a four-year Federal investigation into wholesale bribery, extortion and theft by the Police Department in West New York, N.J., a Federal jury in Camden convicted three officers yesterday of only a handful of charges among the dozens brought against them. A fourth officer, Lieut. Richard Hess, was acquitted of all charges. The jury did not convict any of the officers on the principal counts of racketeering that had been brought by the prosecution.

title: Let the Kosovars Defend Themselves
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OECHLER, CONVERE M.
description: OECHLER-Convere M., 87. Of New York, on May 13, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Henry J. Oechler, devoted mother of Hugh McAden and Henry, Jr., devoted mother-in-law to Joanne and Kathleen and devoted grandmother of James, Sarah, Joshua, Sean and Jack. Services will be on Monday, May 24 at 11 AM in St. James Episcopal Church, NYC. In lieu of flowers, the family requests contributions to The Rector's Discretionary Fund of the St. James Episcopal Church, 865 Madison Avenue, NYC.

title: CLINTON IS PUSHING FOR 50,000 TROOPS AT KOSOVO BORDER
description: The Clinton Administration announced today that the United States would press its allies to move quickly to deploy what was described as a peacekeeping force totaling 50,000 troops on the borders of Kosovo.

title: Tyson Receives Parole After Spending 4 Months in Jail
description: Mike Tyson, the former world heavyweight champion, was granted parole yesterday by the State of Maryland and will be released from the Montgomery County jail no later than June 4.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: MAY DEPARTMENT STORES IS PLANNING AN EXPANSION
description: The May Department Stores Company, the seventh-largest United States retailer, disclosed a $500 million expansion program, which includes the opening of 18 new stores and the remodeling of 29 others this year. The St. Louis-based company also announced plans to repurchase $500 million of its common shares, which at current prices would amount to about 3 percent of its outstanding shares. May operates nearly 400 stores including Lord & Taylor and Filene's. May shares rose $1.0625, to $44.6875, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Cable and Wireless Sets $6.1 Billion Borrowing
description: Cable and Wireless P.L.C., Britain's second-largest telephone company, said yesterday that it would borrow $:3.8 billion ($6.1 billion) for acquisitions and network expansion, using a mobile phone asset as collateral. The move will allow Cable and Wireless to tap the cash value of its 50 percent stake in One 2 One, Britain's fourth-biggest cellular company, before a public offering or outright sale later this year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERENSTEIN, HARRY T.
description: HERENSTEIN-Harry T. Beloved and devoted husband of the late Ruth Spitz Herenstein. Loving brother of the late Louis Hernstein, Gladys Cohen, Lester and Moe Herenstein, Dorothy Sollar, Perry & Henry Herenstein. Caring brother-in-law of Pearl Herenstein. Dear uncle of Arlene Asher, Doris Fine, Arnold R. Sollar, Herman Herenstein, Elaine Sollar Eisen, Ira Herenstein, Francine Gilstein, Arnold Herenstein, Charna Herenstein & the late Larry Herenstein. We have all benefited from his wisdom, wit and love. And we will miss him and cherish his memory. Service on Sunday 11 A.M., at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about efforts to sell Revlon misidentified the owner of a possible buyer, Coty. It is a unit of Joh. A. Benckiser G.m.b.H., not Benckiser N.V.

title: WEATHERFORD TO PURCHASE DAILEY INTERNATIONAL
description: Weatherford International Inc., which makes and rents tools used to drill oil and natural-gas wells, agreed yesterday to buy Dailey International Inc., a maker of tools that remove obstructions in wells, for $195 million in stock. Weatherford, which had 1998 sales of $2.01 billion, plans to complete the transaction once Dailey files for bankruptcy protection. Dailey, based in Conroe, Tex., had 1998 sales of $132 million. Holders of Dailey's 9.5 percent senior notes will get Weatherford stock representing $185 million of the $275 million they are owed. Dailey's stockholders will receive $10 million in Weatherford stock. Dailey expects to file for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection and reorganization by June 1. Weatherford's stock rose $1.75, to $34.6875.

title: Prolonging The Punch Of a Lone Punch Line
description: Just how far is it possible to stretch a punch line? How long before it sags, snaps or disappears altogether?

title: Nissan and Autonation Settle Dispute
description: Autonation Inc., the world's largest automotive retailer, and the Nissan Motor Corporation said on Thursday that they had reached an agreement that ended the auto maker's lawsuit over Autonation's right to buy more dealerships.

title: Stravinsky As a Force Behind the Movements
description: Murmured trepidation soon died down as the New York City Ballet moved through one of the last programs in its 50th-anniversary Stravinsky mini-festival. This was Stravinsky for comparative easy-listeners, in three dances that made one understand better the lure of that often difficult composer.

title: Credit Suisse Apologizes For Actions in Japan
description: Credit Suisse Group, Europe's sixth-largest bank, apologized yesterday to Japanese regulators for obstructing an investigation that threatens to stunt its growth in Japan. The inquiry by the Financial Supervisory Agency, the first into the operations of a foreign bank, focuses on allegations that Credit Suisse helped Japanese clients hide investment losses. The bank could face fines, a forced reorganization or the loss of some Japanese licenses.

title: Home Run in 11th Lifts St. John's
description: Mike Dzurilla's teammates describe him as a pure hitter, and like most pure hitters he was not interested in cluttering his mind with details when he stepped to the plate with two runners on base in the bottom of the 11th inning yesterday in Trenton.

title: Miramax Unit in Book Deal With Historian
description: The historian Simon Schama has signed a deal to publish his next work of nonfiction with Talk Miramax Books, a division of Talk Media, which is owned by Miramax Films. The book, titled ''Brittania,'' will be a history of Britain from the time before the Roman invasion to the year 2000, and it will accompany a 12-part BBC series, directed by Mr. Schama, that ABC will broadcast in the fall of 2000.

title: Waiting for Trout in Montana
description: The oldest cottonwoods along the Bighorn River have fissured bark nearly as deep as a man's palm is wide, and where cattle have rubbed against them their bark is pale. Beneath the cottonwoods, morels grow in the new grass. To hunt for morels is to remember something unsettling about the task of looking. One day last week, I searched the partial shade of each tree along a quarter mile of riverbank, and as I did I tried to concentrate on seeing the fawn-brown cranial effusion that is a morel. But concentrating didn't make the morels appear. They were there or not there, and nothing could induce them to appear where they weren't.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: DONALDSON, LUFKIN RAISES SIGHTS IN UNIT'S SHARE SALE
description: Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc. increased by 45 percent the amount it hopes to get selling shares of its DLJ Direct on-line brokerage unit, responding to soaring demand for Internet-related stocks. Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, the eighth-biggest United States securities firm, increased the planned sale to 16 million shares, priced at $18 to $20 each. At the range's midprice, the sale could fetch $304 million. Earlier, DLJ said it would sell 15 million shares for $13 to $15, raising $210 million at the midprice. The sale is expected Tuesday, with shares to start trading on the New York Stock Exchange the next day. The shares of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette fell $2.1875, to $71.375. Donaldson is 71 percent-owned by the Equitable Cos., which is 58 percent-owned by the French insurer AXA S.A..

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAPIRO, HOWARD
description: SHAPIRO-Howard. On May 21, 1999. Beloved husband of Suzy. Loving father of Deborah and Kenneth and stepfather of William Peterfriend. Dear son of Milton Shapiro and the late Sophie. He will be profoundly missed by his family and friends, and deeply mourned by his staff at D.C. Planning. Service Monday 9:30am at The ''Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Squeeze by a Master Solver Brings Home a Grand Slam
description: The timing of the next World Championship is appropriate in one way, but perhaps inappropriate in another. The Bermuda Bowl will be played in Bermuda exactly half a century after it was initiated on that island, but since it starts on Jan. 8 there could be a Y2K problem. Some of the players and officials arriving from around the world may experience airline difficulties.

title: Who Needs a New Penn Station?; The Invisible 'Hub'
description: To the Editor:

title: Crunch Time for Reform
description: The time has come for House Republicans to save Speaker Dennis Hastert from humiliating himself. Even Dick Armey, the grumpy Republican majority leader and no fan of cleaning up campaign laws, apparently agrees that it looks appalling for Mr. Hastert to fight the will of the majority of the House on campaign finance reform. Mr. Armey wants to schedule a vote and get it over with. Yesterday Mr. Hastert again said the issue could not be taken up until the fall, which is his way of burying it. Republican reformers, who have been dithering over whether to confront Mr. Hastert, have no choice but to sign a petition forcing legislation to the floor.

title: Olivetti Prevails in Hostile Bid For Far Bigger Telecom Italia
description: Olivetti S.p.A., the former typewriter maker that transformed itself into Italy's No. 2 telephone company, triumphed tonight in the biggest hostile corporate takeover ever, gaining control of Telecom Italia, a rival more than five times its size.

title: Dan Sanders, 69, a Teacher and a Labor Leader
description: Dan Sanders, a former executive vice president of the New York State United Teachers and a principal architect of the teacher labor movement in the state, died on Thursday at the Veterans Affairs Medical Center in the Bronx. He was 69 and had lived in Putnam Valley, N.Y.

title: Halt in Pay For Legislators Ruled Invalid
description: A Brooklyn judge ruled today that a new law withholding state legislators' pay until a budget is passed is unconstitutional. His decision dealt a blow to an attempt to speed the state's notoriously lethargic budget process.

title: DIALOGUE: Two Views of the Commuter's Curse; Isn't It Obvious? Cutting Taxes Helps the Economy
description: Higher taxes mean fewer jobs, lower taxes mean more jobs. That is why I am going to sign the bill that eliminates the tax on the state's commuters to New York City. Our rate of job growth now matches the national rate, thanks in part to our tax cuts. And in New York City, state tax and economic policy has helped the city regain all of the 350,000 jobs it had lost during the 1990-92 recession.

title: HOUSE DEMOCRATS PRESS EARLY VOTE ON FIREARMS BILL
description: Fresh from their victory on gun control in the Senate, Democrats today trained their attention and oratory on the House, calling for a gun-control vote within the next week and lambasting Republican leaders as laying out a less immediate course.

title: Scared Off Medicare
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: M. A. HANNA CO., Cleveland, a specialty chemical company, said it would sell a resin distribution business serving the western United States and western Canada to Interplastic Corp., St. Paul, for an undisclosed price.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Weekend yesterday about the UPN television network's fall schedule misattributed an observation about interracial casting. It was not the network that said its young-adult sitcom, ''The Grown-Ups,'' differed from those of other networks in that it had an interracial cast. The article writer made that observation.

title: Restrictions Ease for Studies On Marijuana as Medicine
description: Despite intense interest in the medical benefits of marijuana, only a handful of scientists are studying it because the Government has always required that such work be paid for by scarce grant money from the National Institutes of Health.

title: Dunleavy Named Coach of the Year
description: Mike Dunleavy was voted the National Basketball Association's coach of the year yesterday after guiding the Trail Blazers to their first Pacific Division title since the 1991-92 season.

title: FLORIDA ROCK INDUSTRIES TO BUY HARPER BROS.
description: Florida Rock Industries, a supplier of construction materials, agreed yesterday to buy the Florida mining company Harper Brothers Inc. for $87 million in stock, increasing its supply of sand and gravel, known as aggregates. The closely held Harper, based in Fort Myers, is a supplier of aggregates in southwest Florida and recently doubled its plant's capacity. To comply with a Justice Department agreement, Florida Rock will sell its Fort Myers quarry as well as Harper's sand mine in nearby Glades County, Fla., before the transaction can be completed. Florida Rock is based in Jacksonville.

title: Campaign Finance Is Put on Back Burner
description: In his first confrontation with Republican moderates, Speaker J. Dennis Hastert has spurned their request for an early vote on campaign finance legislation.

title: Columbine Families Try to Reclaim Privacy
description: As graduation at Columbine High School approached, Sara Martin, a senior and one of the commencement speakers, said, ''I hope it's not going to be televised.''

title: Small-Print Provisions of Gun Bill Please Federal Officials Most
description: A handful of relatively little-noticed provisions in the crime bill passed by the Senate on Thursday may do as much or more to curb the flow of illegal guns to criminals and juveniles than the much-debated measures that require child safety locks and background checks at gun shows, senior Treasury Department officials said today.

title: Not Too Soon To Prepare For the Pacers
description: THE Knicks wake up this morning sitting on top of a new world in the National Basketball Association. They overcame Miami in Round 1 and hold a 2-0 lead against Atlanta in Round 2 with a chance to close the Hawks out in Games 3 and 4 tomorrow and Monday at Madison Square Garden.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HADLEY, HERBERT FRANKLIN
description: HADLEY-Herbert Franklin, 74. On May 19th, 1999 in Houston, TX. Native of Lake Charles, LA; lived in NY, NY. Member of the Methodist Church. Graduate of LSU and Princeton. World War II veteran. Worked for Prentice-Hall Publishing Company. Retired Vice President of Pension and Retirement Plan after 25 years from American Standard. Survived by one sister, Dorothy M. Hadley, of Lake Charles. Service today, 11 AM, at Hixson Funeral Home, Lake Charles. Burial in Prien Memorial Park, Lake Charles.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUSCIO, JANE YOUNG
description: RUSCIO-Jane Young. Of West Lebanon, NY, on May 20, 1999, at age 66. She is survived by her husband Nicholas P. Ruscio, children Ian, Jessica and Ross Lanier, grandchildren Ian and Jorie Lanier, father Theodore John Young, and brother George W. Young. She will live always in our hearts.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Flags of Inconvenience; Union Campaigns Against Some Foreign Ship Registry
description: The Lakhta is a rusting hulk that usually hauls scrap metal to Japan, but since February the vessel has sat idle here in the largest port in the Russian Far East, her superstructure painted in Russian and English: ''WE ARE ON STRIKE. WE WANT OUR MONEY!''

title: 8 Are Hurt as Van Jumps Curb in Brooklyn
description: A van that witnesses said was racing to pass another vehicle jumped the curb last night and plowed into a throng of shoppers on Flatbush Avenue in Brooklyn, the police said.

title: Rift Over Sunday Night Games
description: A nasty battle over ESPN's proposed shift of Sunday night baseball games in September to ESPN2 widened yesterday when Major League Baseball replied to ESPN's recent Federal lawsuit with a countersuit of its own.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAPPEL, FRANCES KARP, M.D.
description: RAPPEL-Frances Karp, M.D. On May 20, 1999. Physician, 55+ years in Long Beach. Known for generosity, caring for all people and loving devotion to family and friends. Beloved wife of the late Louis Rappel. Mother of Dr. Stephen (Evelyn) and Susan (Dominick). Grandmother of Dr. Sharon (Kenneth) Krumins, Michael (Lynn) Bogin, David Rappel, Robin (Bryan) Maizlish, and six greatgrandchildren. Services Sunday, 10 A.M. at ''Gutterman's Inc.'', 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, Long Island.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIDSON, NATHAN J.
description: DAVIDSON-Nathan J. On May 21, 1999. Resident of Westport, CT. Formerly of New York City. An Executive in aerospace industry. Devoted husband of Kathleen. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St, Sunday 3-5 and 7-9PM. Funeral Mass at Saint Ignatius Loyola Church, Park Avenue at 84 St on Monday, 10AM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCWHORTER, CHARLES K.
