description: McWhorter-Charles K. The Alvin Ailey Dance Theater Foundation mourns the passing of Charles K. McWhorter, who served with great distinction on its Board of Trustees from 1974 to 1995. During his tenure as a Trustee, his commitment and dedication to the Ailey organization were unwavering. His caring presence will be greatly missed.

title: INSIDE
description: Olivetti Beats Goliath

title: COMING ON SUNDAY: THE MENTALLY ILL HAVE NOWHERE TO GO
description: Long before Andrew Goldstein pushed a woman in front of a train, he pleaded for help, and couldn't get it. That's his problem -- and society's. A report by Michael Winerip, in The Times Magazine.

title: Expectant 76ers' Fans See Hopes Slip Away
description: While the hometown fans were jubilant with anticipation of being host to a home playoff game, it was no secret that a 76ers defeat tonight would put the team in a terrible bind. It would sink the 76ers to three games to none against the Indiana Pacers and put them one step from elimination, with Game 4 on Sunday.

title: Vallone Sees Layoff Threat After a Tax Is Eliminated
description: Peter F. Vallone, the City Council Speaker, warned yesterday that the loss of up to $360 million a year in commuter tax revenue could force the city to lay off workers at some point in the next few years.

title: Merrill Unit Tops Bid By Soros for Greycoat
description: Mercury Asset Management Group P.L.C., a unit of Merrill Lynch & Company, offered yesterday to pay cash for all Greycoat P.L.C. shares, valuing the London office property company at $:282.5 million ($452 million) and topping a bid from Delancey Estates P.L.C., controlled by the billionaire investor George Soros.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''There's nothing like the lottery. You can always make a little money from that.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBIN, PETER JAY
description: RUBIN-Peter Jay. April 28, 1964May 18, 1999. Firstborn child and beloved son of Barbara and the late Walter. Devoted and dear brother of Randy. Loving grandson, nephew, cousin and friend. Peter had a deep love for Torah and Israel, closely followed by his love for the Knicks and English football. He traveled the world in search of knowledge and inner peace, which we pray he has found. Now he is together with his dad. His memory for a blessing. We will love him and miss him forever. Services will be held on Sunday, May 23 at 12:00 noon at Gutterman's, Woodbury. Barbara and Randy Rubin

title: In Small Middle-Class Town, Big Lottery Sales
description: The municipal building in this central New Jersey community is an old white clapboard house. The Mayor is a retired doctor who practiced here for 44 years and now walks to his office each day, dressed casually.

title: Carr Is Not Dissuaded By Backseat Treatment
description: Oba Carr feels like the forgotten man in his title bout with Oscar De La Hoya, the World Boxing Council welterweight champion.

title: The Mayor Stonewalls, Again
description: Mayor Rudolph Giuliani's instinct is to stall investigations into any aspect of his administration. He has already lost court battles to deny information to Public Advocate Mark Green and State Comptroller Carl McCall. Now he is refusing to cooperate at this time with State Attorney General Eliot Spitzer's investigation into the stop-and-frisk policies of the New York Police Department.

title: Plea Deal Said To Be Rejected In Louima Trial
description: Federal prosecutors have refused a plea deal sought by the police officer charged with torturing Abner Louima in a restroom of a Brooklyn police station, people close to the case said yesterday.

title: Nicklaus Is Back With a New Hip, and Goes 2 Over Par
description: He hit some good shots, he hit some poor shots, but for Jack Nicklaus, it was another mission accomplished.

title: Lottery Cost Is Heaviest On the Poor
description: As a method of producing income for New Jersey, the lottery is far less equitable than other historical sources of government revenue, an analysis by The New York Times has found. At a time when tax-conscious politicians are searching for ways to reduce taxes on income and property, lotteries represent an inviting option.

title: DIALOGUE: Two Views of the Commuter's Curse; The City Already Pays More Than Its Fair Share
description: The New York Legislature, known mostly for being unable to pass a budget on time, has moved at breakneck speed to eliminate the 0.45 percent tax on wages of in-state New York City commuters. More time was spent deciding to rename the West Side Highway for Joe DiMaggio than discussing the implications of this legislation.

title: Executives Chafe at Audit Watchdog Plan
description: The nation's largest group of corporate financial officers is lobbying to weaken a plan that would make it easier for directors of public companies to know when managements are being too loose in the way they tally profits.

title: F.B.I. Agents to Assail Senator Over Inquiry
description: Agents of the New York office of the F.B.I. are preparing to deliver a sharply written letter next week to a United States Senator, accusing him of being biased and unfair in his examination of how the bureau's New York office investigated the crash of Trans World Airlines Flight 800.

title: Corrections
description: Front-page picture credits yesterday with the article about the school shooting in Georgia were reversed. The picture of the suspect was by The Associated Press; that of a mother holding her daughter was by John Spink of The Atlanta Journal-Constitution.

title: Corrections
description: An art review in Weekend yesterday about ''Pomo Indian Basket Weavers, Their Baskets and the Art Market,'' at the National Museum of the American Indian in lower Manhattan through Aug. 15, misstated the name of the site for another basket exhibition in Manhattan, and its closing date. ''Bamboo Masterworks: Japanese Baskets From the Lloyd Cotsen Collection'' is at the Asia Society (not Asia House), on Park Avenue at 70th Street; the show, which was to close May 30, has been extended through June 27.

title: Who Needs a New Penn Station?
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL RISES. After Iraq, which supplies about 2.5 percent of the world's oil, announced that exports would be delayed, prices climbed. Crude oil for July delivery rose 34 cents, or 2 percent, to $17.41 a barrel.

title: WILLIAMS ENERGY IN DEAL WITH AMERADA HESS
description: The Williams Energy Service Inc. unit of the Williams Companies agreed yesterday to buy three storage and distribution terminals from the Amerada Hess Corporation on the Gulf Coast. Terms were not disclosed. The terminals are in Houston; Corpus Christi, Tex., and Marrero, La. They have marine, pipeline, rail and truck capabilities for loading and unloading. Total storage capacity for crude oil, refined products and petrochemicals is about 13.3 million barrels. Williams's existing storage capacity is 28.8 million barrels. Ameriada Hess's stock was up $1.3125, to $63.875, and Williams's stock fell $1.125, to $48.875.

title: When a Game of 'Tag' Becomes a Real Threat; Signs of Violence
description: To the Editor:

title: Hawks Need Stop Button To Use Against Sprewell
description: Two games too late, Latrell Sprewell finally showed up on the Hawks' radar screen today. And that was during a film session at practice.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE YEN EDGES UP. Rising Japanese Government bond yields supported the yen, as did a call by Vice Finance Minister Eisuke Sakakibara for currency stability. In New York, the dollar settled at 124.01 yen, down from 124.40.

title: NATO Jets Hit Prison, Killing 19, Serbs Report
description: NATO warplanes assigned to attack a military compound in northwestern Kosovo today struck what Yugoslavia's official news agency described as a nearby prison, killing at least 19 inmates and guards.

title: School Official Charged With Molesting Student
description: An assistant principal at Stuyvesant High School was arrested yesterday and charged with molesting a student who was working as his assistant, officials said.

title: A Schnittke Tribute to Berg Echoing 'Happy Birthday'
description: Alfred Schnittke, who died last year at 63, has acquired almost a cult following in the last two decades. Yet musicians seem to be divided about his music. For some, Schnittke is an affecting musical mystic who defies categories. For others he is a pretentious purveyor of mumbo-jumbo with a penchant for pastiche.

title: Modern Orthodox Jews Have a Hero but Not All His Words
description: When nearly 1,500 modern Orthodox Jews gathered several months ago for their inaugural conference, the figure who dominated the proceedings was nowhere to be found among the rosters of speakers or panelists or people there. Rabbi Joseph Dov Soloveitchik had died six years earlier and had ceased most public activity nearly a decade before that.

title: Germany Makes Citizenship Easier for Foreigners to Get
description: Acknowledging what a mixed society it has become, Germany adopted a new immigration law today that will make it easier for many of the country's seven million residents of foreign origin to become citizens.

title: 1940's Racism, So Far and Yet So Near
description: Don Cheadle has already shown film and television audiences his range as an actor. Among other roles, he has been memorably believable as the earnest young prosecutor in the series ''Picket Fences,'' as the volatile psychopath Mouse in the film ''Devil in a Blue Dress'' and as the self-deprecating Sammy Davis Jr. in the television movie ''The Rat Pack.'' Now, in ''A Lesson Before Dying,'' tonight on HBO, he faces the challenge of transforming himself within a single performance. He succeeds, helping to elevate a tear-stained parable into an exploration of the human spirit.

title: When a Game of 'Tag' Becomes a Real Threat
description: To the Editor:

title: Let the Kosovars Defend Themselves
description: To the Editor:

title: Prosecutor Is Accused of Driving While Drunk
description: A longtime Manhattan assistant district attorney was arrested early yesterday and charged with drunken driving, leaving the scene of an accident and impersonating a police officer, the Queens District Attorney's office said.

title: Big Japanese Banks Report Steep Fiscal-Year Losses
description: Underscoring the challenges they face in recovering their health, Japan's biggest banks reported steep fiscal-year losses today and most were records.

title: Rafter Leads Australia Into Final
description: Patrick Rafter breezed past Pete Sampras, 6-3, 7-5, yesterday and led Australia into the final of the World Team Cup with a 2-1 victory over the United States in Dusseldorf, Germany.

title: Note Hints Fund-Raiser Knew of Bribery Issue
description: The Justice Department has obtained a note from the Little Rock office of Yah Lin Trie, a Democratic fund-raiser, that suggests he was aware of a bribery problem.

title: Knoblauch's Game Still Hurt by Roll Block
description: Chuck Knoblauch remembers the day, remembers the play and remembers the player. It was May 6, it was a crushing collision at second base and it involved Minnesota's Corey Koskie. How could Knoblauch forget?

title: Judge Rules School District Erred on Religion in Classrooms
description: A Westchester County school district violated its students' First Amendment right to religious freedom by allowing schools to engage in activities like having third graders make likenesses of a Hindu god and including New Age prayers at a high school Earth Day celebration, a Federal District Court ruled today.

title: As a Gauge Of Social Change, Behold: The Breast
description: One way of looking at breasts -- other than head on, from underneath or in profile -- is to see them as public property. They never fully belong to the women who live with them. They arrive as uninvited buds and slowly blossom into a social concern.

title: About New York; Images Show The Realities Behind Labels
description: IVELISSE REYES once thought designer labels conferred instant status. Now she has been thinking about the status of the people behind the labels. She realized that some big-name labels rely on poorly paid, no-name workers to make shoes and shirts coveted by her classmates at Manhattan's High School of Graphic Communication Arts.

title: State Says Potential Pitfalls Still Plague H.M.O. Industry
description: State officials, fresh from the chore of cleaning up the bankruptcy and liquidation of HIP Health Plans of New Jersey, said this week that the rapidly evolving health insurance industry could still present new problems.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the election of Paul M. Montrone as president and chief executive of the Metropolitan Opera Association referred imprecisely to the association's role in hiring. The association is responsible for hiring the Met's general manager. It is the general manager, not the association, who hires the artistic director.

title: Political Notes; From Judge to Pawn in a Grudge Match
description: No matter how many times good-government groups demand that the judiciary remain as free of politics as possible, the whiff of back-room cigars occasionally permeates the process of electing judges. Consider the case of Judge Walter B. Tolub of Manhattan Civil Court.

title: Religion Journal; The Boy Scouts, a Battle And the Meaning of Faith
description: For years, national surveys have reported that 19 of 20 Americans say they believe in God. What is missing from those findings is some indication of what people mean when they say that, what concepts of God they hold in a nation with many different views of religious faith.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: 30-Year Treasury Yields Decline to 5.75 Percent

title: When a Game of 'Tag' Becomes a Real Threat; Picture Perfect?
description: To the Editor:

title: Commerzbank Says Profit Fell in Quarter
description: The big German bank Commerzbank A.G. said yesterday that its profit fell 3.7 percent, to 340 million euros ($359.6 million), in the first quarter, largely because of higher costs. Operating expenses rose 17 percent as its work force grew and and its back-office infrastructure expanded rapidly.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARONS, GEORGE
description: ARONS-George. Died Thursday, May 20 in Stamford, CT. He was 67 years old. Funeral services will be held Sunday, May 23 at 12:30 P.M. at the Congregation Agudath Sholom, 301 Strawberry Hill Avenue, Stamford, CT. Burial will follow at the Agudath Sholom Cemetery in Stamford. He is survived by his wife, three sons, and seven grandchildren. Donations can be made to the Congregation Agudath Sholom Hebrew School or the Bennett Cancer Center.

title: The Dangers of Letting a President Read
description: How do books influence public policy, or more specifically, how do some books come to be read by policy makers while others are not?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CUCCI, VINCENT E., ESQ.
description: CUCCI-Vincent E., Esq. Formerly of Manhattan, on May 20th, 1999. He was 89 years old. Vincent was born July 26, 1909 in Manhattan. He earned a Bachelor and Law degree from St. John's University in 1933. He practiced law in the state of New York for over 60 years until his retirement in 1993. Mr. Cucci provided advice and counsel on numerous investigations for the Manhattan District Attorney's office. He was a respected member of the New York State Bar. Beloved husband of the late Phyllis Barba Cucci. Loving father of Dorothy A. Siclare, Vincent, John and Richard Cucci. Dear brother of Flora Green and Rose Barba. Adored grandfather of Vincent III, Nicole, Grace, John, Michael, Phyllis, Christen, Joseph and Dorothy Esther. Funeral from the Casey Funeral Home, 350 Slosson Avenue, Staten Island, New York on Monday. Funeral Mass, St. Teresa's Church, Staten Island, NY, 9:30 AM. Interment Calvary Cemetery. Friends will be received Sunday 2-4 PM and 7-9 PM.

title: Four-Year Extension Keeps Leetch With Rangers
description: With the specter of free agency looming, Brian Leetch and the Rangers were not playing games during contract negotiations. So, Leetch will be wearing a Blue Shirt for at least the next four years.

title: Op-Art
Gains Are Reported in Decoding Genome
description: The publicly financed effort to decode the human genome, the three billion units of DNA at the heart of every human cell, is now 10 percent complete and is on track to meet its goal of finishing a first draft of the genome a year from now, officials of the National Institutes of Health said today.

title: WAITING FOR RICHES: A special report.; Living Off the Daily Dream Of Winning a Lottery Prize
description: Inside Home Dairy, a sliver of a store that sells candy, cigarettes and newspapers here, people mill around all day searching for phantom riches: writing down numbers and scratching tickets in a nonstop frenzy that amounts to $14,400 in average weekly lottery sales.

title: Corrections
description: A music listing in the Arts & Leisure section last Sunday misstated the date of a New York Youth Symphony concert this weekend at Carnegie Hall. It is at 2 P.M. tomorrow, not today.

title: Pataki's News? Seems He's for Bush
description: No, it seems, Gov. George E. Pataki is not going to resign. He apparently is not going to declare his candidacy for the United States Senate, either. He won't announce that former Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato is getting back in the game, or even endorse the Representative from Long Island who may fight Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani for the Republican Senate nomination.

title: Enthusiastic Stars Coach Finds Healthy Balance
description: During the recent Stanley Cup playoff series against St. Louis, Coach Ken Hitchcock of the Dallas Stars grew displeased with the play of Brett Hull, one of his sharpshooters. So he demoted Hull to a checking line and cut his ice time. And when Sergei Zubov turned over the puck to accidentally help create a winning goal by the Blues in overtime, Hitchcock was publicly critical of the defenseman who quarterbacks his power play.

title: Patients for Hire, Doctors for Sale
description: People go to doctors because they assume the doctor will tell them what they need to do to stay healthy or get well. But in articles published in The Times on Sunday and Monday, the reporters Kurt Eichenwald and Gina Kolata have opened the door on a practice of medicine that few of us knew existed -- a warped world in which patients have become commodities, lured into research projects for the profit of their doctors.

title: Let the Kosovars Defend Themselves
description: To the Editor:

title: A 6th Suspect Said to Be Tied To bin Laden Is in Custody
description: Under cloak of secrecy, the Government has taken another suspect into custody in the investigation of Osama bin Laden, the Saudi exile charged in the bombings of the United States Embassies in East Africa last year, according to several people knowledgeable about the case.

title: The ABC's of Graffiti
description: Eric Felisbret grew up in the East Village and began tagging subway cars with his graffiti signature in 1975, when he was 11 years old. By the time he was 15, he wanted to graduate to something bigger. So he began taking the train to the Bronx, where the city's most notorious graffiti makers, known among themselves as writers, gathered.

title: Roche Officers Say Scandal Is a Surprise
description: One day after admitting that some senior executives were ringleaders in a nine-year price-fixing cartel for vitamins, the chairman and the chief executive of Roche Holding A.G. pronounced themselves blameless and clueless today.

title: Marijuana Research Faces Fewer Limits
description: The Clinton Administration has eased restrictions on research into the possible medical benefits of marijuana, announcing that it would sell Government-grown marijuana to researchers and allow them to secure their own financing for studies.

title: Urgent, But Not All That Important
description: I'll never forget Roger Clemens. It was one of those cozy, slow winter mornings. Mr. Coffee was making funny bubbly noises, competing for attention with Regis Philbin, who was being held in the air by a woman wrestler. I poured another cup of coffee. Suddenly Regis disappeared from the television screen, replaced by a written announcement: ''Breaking News.''

title: Put Out the 'For Sale' Sign: Bidding to Begin for the Jets
description: The estate of Leon Hess announced yesterday that it was selling the Jets and had hired the investment firm Goldman, Sachs & Company to handle the process.

title: Friend of President Admits to Violating Fund-Raising Laws
description: A Democratic fund-raiser and longtime Arkansas friend of President Clinton pleaded guilty today in a Federal court in Little Rock, Ark., to two charges related to his political fund-raising, and agreed to cooperate with the Justice Department's long-running campaign finance inquiry.

title: Mapping Thoughts and Even Feelings
description: Thanks to advanced new imaging techniques, the internal world of the mind is becoming more and more visible. Just as X-rays reveals our bones, the latest brain scans reveal the origins of our thoughts, moods and memories. Scientists can observe how the brain registers a joke or experiences a painful memory; they can find clues to what may cause addiction and conditions like autism, depression and attention deficit disorder.

title: Computer Shares Fall; Investors Shift to Small Companies
description: Stocks fell yesterday, led by computer-related shares such as the Microsoft Corporation, as investors shifted from large companies that gained the most in recent years to laggards, including small stocks and utilities.

title: Columbine Inquiry to Extend Into Summer
description: One month after the killings at Columbine High School, 80 law-enforcement investigators are planning to labor through the summer to determine whether any friends of the two teen-age gunmen aided them or knew about the attack beforehand.

title: Who Needs a New Penn Station?; Honor Labor's Battle
description: To the Editor:

title: Boy Took Parent's Guns For Attack, Sheriff Says
description: T. J. Solomon, the 15-year-old accused in the shooting of six students at a suburban high school, broke into his stepfather's locked gun cabinet to get two weapons and then carried them aboard a school bus, the authorities said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CITRON, DANIEL
description: CITRON-Daniel. On May 21, 1999. Beloved husband of the late Helen. Devoted father of Andy Citron and Amy Dubow. Loving brother of Jerry and the late Estelle Kay and Fred. Cherished grandfather of Rachel, Jared, Risa and Erica. Services Sunday, 9:30 AM at ''Gutterman's Inc.'', 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, L.I.

title: Another Restaurant Fire Makes a Neighborhood Uneasy
description: Ten weeks after a restaurant fire swept a landmark cooperative building on the Upper West Side and left hundreds of residents temporarily homeless, a fire in another restaurant a block away heavily damaged another Broadway apartment building yesterday and left a sense of deja vu in a jittery neighborhood.

title: Bench Players for Knicks Improvise Way to Success
description: Chris Childs is glad for the company. For so long, he was alone in performing an improvisational act on the floor that was frowned on by a Knicks team that was once as stuffy as a butler.

title: Sao Paulo Journal; U.S. Dominance Wanes, At Least in Bad-Taste TV
description: This is a society that prides itself on having a tolerant, even permissive attitude toward human predilections. But even in Brazil's liberal climate there are limits on sex, violence and the bizarre -- and the newly minted television stars who go by the names Auntie and Little Rat have set off a fierce controversy by exceeding them.

title: Health Panel Recommends A Reprieve For Smallpox
description: Prompted by fears of a new outbreak of one the world's deadliest scourges, a World Health Organization panel in Geneva decided today to postpone eradicating the world's known remaining stocks of the smallpox virus until at least 2002.

title: Doctor Faces Investigation In the Death Of a Relative
description: A Jersey City podiatrist whose sister-in-law's body was found stuffed into a plastic cooler this week was arrested Thursday night on a fugitive warrant in Pennsylvania, and the authorities said they were investigating her in connection with the death.

title: Take My Shows, Please; Network Extravaganzas Peddle Fall Lineups to Advertisers
description: Irwin Gotlieb was being up front about the up-fronts, the television networks' annual May ritual that is one part Madison Avenue salesmanship, one part Las Vegas-style showmanship and one part revival-meeting discipleship.

title: Panel Says Agency Lags in Assessing Children's Needs
description: New York City's child welfare agency often fails to assess the needs of abused and neglected children promptly and to find the most appropriate foster homes for them, a panel of national experts responsible for evaluating the agency said yesterday.

title: F.D.A. Approves Merck's Vioxx Painkiller
description: Merck & Company, the world's No. 3 drug maker, won United States approval today for its once-a-day painkiller Vioxx, a rival to the Monsanto Company's Celebrex in the $8-billion-a-year arthritis painkiller market.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINE, ROSE
description: FINE-Rose. Beloved wife of the late A. Harry Fine, co-proprietor of the Harflex Camera Exchange. Devoted mother of A. Kenneth, Stephen and the late Richard. Adoring grandmother of five. Dear sister of Hyman and Alex Levin, Lillian Goldberg & the late Abe & Sarah. Rose & Harry often danced at the Palladium Ballroom in New York City. Services are on Sunday, 11AM at ''Sinai Chapels'', 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, New York.

title: Who Needs a New Penn Station?; Confidence Building
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: William Alfred, 76, Who Wrote the Play 'Hogan's Goat,' Dies

And that was only the second biggest surprise of the day.

description: For most of this season, the Mets have been the opposite of what they were a year ago. Their revamped offense has been productive, but their starting pitching has yet to come around.

title: Theater Voices From the Past, A Taste of Present Motion
description: ENTER the lobby of the Westport Country Playhouse, and listen to the walls. The voices of the stars of yesteryear -- Shirley Booth, Lillian Gish, Gloria Swanson and, of course, Eva le Gallienne, a longtime neighbor in Weston -- are speaking low, but the walls are exploding with theater history, crammed with posters from 1930 on.

title: Bedlam on the Streets
description: Maybe they should have just stenciled it in large letters on Andrew Goldstein's forehead: ''ticking time bomb. suffers schizophrenia. if off medication, run for cover!'' The news accounts of his arrest for pushing Kendra Webdale under a subway train in New York that first Sunday afternoon in January must have sent a cold shiver through the hundreds of psychiatrists, therapists and social workers who had treated this seriously mentally ill man.

title: The Love That's Forever: Making Matches
description: ONE of the ''What if?'' games we movie lovers play is trying to imagine our favorite films cast with stars other than the ones whose names glittered on the marquee and lodged in our memories as irreplaceable. Think of ''Casablanca,'' then of Ronald Reagan and Ann Sheridan. Laughable? Nevertheless, they were the original team meant to play the ''We'll-always-have-Paris'' lovers, but Warner Brothers had to settle for Humphrey Bogart and Ingrid Bergman (and Paul Henreid in the role originally intended for Dennis Morgan).

title: Another Bomb Error
description: NATO bombed an important Kosovo Liberation Army base, thinking it was still in the hands of Yugoslav troops. The Kosovo rebels said 7 fighters were killed and 25 wounded.

description: AT the first hint of summer, the madness starts.

title: Now You See a Pension. Now Maybe You Don't.
description: A 96 percent cut in a pension check would meet almost anyone's definition of a retirement nightmare. So Hope Walden, who spent 28 years with Pan American World Airways as a flight attendant and manager, was predictably unhappy to be told recently that it might come true. To compound the insult, the news came from the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation, the Federal agency that is supposed to be protecting private pensions.

title: May 16-22; Another Drop in Crime
description: For the seventh consecutive year, crime in the United States fell sharply in 1998, according to preliminary data from the Federal Bureau of Investigation. Violent crimes and property crimes each fell 7 percent, declines criminologists attributed to several factors, including an expanding economy, a larger prison population and a lower demand for crack cocaine.

title: POSTINGS: Offices to Condominiums in Art Deco Tower; Well-Lit Luxury in TriBeCa
description: Windows, windows and more windows -- 28 in the floor-through apartments -- punctuate Franklin Tower, a 17-story tan-brick Art Deco office building being converted into 25 luxury condominiums in the TriBeCa East Historic District.

title: Tracking Suspicions About China's Atom Spying
description: The congressional investigation into China's suspected theft of American technology began as a gleam in Newt Gingrich's eye. Today, a year later, it has become the decade's deepest look into a realm of cloaks and daggers that lives on after the cold war.

description: THE East End has long been known for its potatoes. But not its potato juice.

title: U.S. Issues, Then Lifts, A Warning on China
description: For several days, the State Department urged Americans to postpone travel to China because of the angry response to the NATO forces' bombing of the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade. It issued a travel warning on May 9 because street demonstrations began outside the American Embassy in Beijing soon after the accidental bombing in Belgrade on May 7. American businesses were also attacked and citizens harassed.

title: The Thrill of Floating With the Wind
description: IN a matter of fact way, Robert Zirpolo announced that he would set his hot-air balloon down on a grassy field, which appeared to his half-dozen passengers to be an impossibly small target the better part of a mile away.

description: A MONTH before he was resoundingly defeated last Monday by Ehud Barak, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu explained in an interview that attacks on his personality reflected one key thing: the Israeli left's continuing need to blame somebody for the assassination of Yitzhak Rabin.

title: The Business of Summer Rentals Starts When It's Snowy
description: FROM the deck of the summer cottage, Peter Newman, a 34-year-old windsurfer and Manhattan commercial real-estate broker, looked out over Nepeague Harbor on a recent Saturday afternoon, hunting for a place to rent for the summer.

title: Commencement; Fordham Class Hears Magician and Peacemaker
description: In 1974, David Copperfield performed a vanishing act three weeks into his freshman year at Fordham University, dropping out to take the lead in a Chicago-based musical, The Magic Man.

description: Vanessa Scharven Chase and Robert Worth Bingham 4th were married yesterday at the 1860 Farm, a historic house in Princeton, N.J. Judge Gilbert Merritt, of the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit in Nashville, officiated.

title: Ms. Heckscher, Mr. Tribolet
description: Elizabeth Winslow Heckscher, the daughter of Sarah S. Heckscher and Martin A. Heckscher, both of Philadelphia, was married yesterday to Perry Allan Tribolet, a son of Guadalupe and Michael Tribolet of Lakewood, Calif. The Rev. Peter Paul Silvinskas, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Washington Memorial Chapel in Valley Forge, Pa.

title: When Sargent Turned His Back on Fashion
description: FOR half his life, from 1890, when he was at the height of his career, until his death in 1925, John Singer Sargent was under contract to produce murals and decorative schemes for public buildings in Boston. The son of an expatriate New England doctor, Sargent lived mostly in Europe; but in Boston he had close friends and family, and he visited often. Boston was the American city closest to his European sensibility; it understood him best. And thanks to ''Sargent Summer,'' a series of exhibitions timed to coincide with the last stop of the Sargent retrospective at the Museum of Fine Arts (June 27 through Sept. 26), Boston is once again the city where one can come to a new understanding of the reticent artist and his art.

title: PULSE: HERS; Young, Urban And Glossy
description: ''We want our magazine to reach all the women that are feeling Lauryn Hill,'' said Kierna Mayo, editor in chief of Honey, a new fashion/life-style publication for black women 18 to 34. Put out every other month by Harris Publications, whose other titles include Slam, an urban sports magazine, Honey, which made its debut in February, crosses the sophistication of Marie Claire and the urban spunk of The Source, the hip-hop monthly, where Ms. Mayo was formerly an editor. Ms. Mayo, 28, started the magazine with her Hampton University classmate Joicelyn Dingle, Honey's editorial director. ''We weren't seeing enough women like us represented,'' Ms. Mayo said, ''and none of the magazines were really speaking to us.'' With a circulation of 250,000, Honey aims to be a Gen-Y contender to Essence, which has dominated the black women's market since the 1970's. But while Essence speaks to readers interested in parenting tips and 401(k) plans, Honey strikes a gutsier tone with provocative cover lines like ''Girls Who Cheat'' and interviews with the hip-hop star Lil' Kim and the controversial Black Panther fugitive Assata Shakur.

title: If Wanderlust Calls, Try Biking the Aqueduct Trail
description: AS a child growing up on the Jersey Shore, I channeled my wanderlust through my 10-speed bicycle. The terrain was flat and the traffic almost nonexistent as I headed inland and meandered for miles along country roads, whizzing past cow pastures, horse farms and wooded parks.

title: May 16-22; Round One to Katzenberg
description: Jeffrey Katzenberg came out ahead in the first round of his acrimonious legal battle with the Walt Disney Company. The referee overseeing the case ruled that Disney had breached its contract with its former studio chief. So Mr. Katzenberg is entitled to a bonus plus interest based on the profits of movies he made while at Disney.

title: School Voucher Opponents Unite to Fight Mayor's Plan
description: A broad-based group of religious, civic and political leaders has organized to fight Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's push for publicly financed school vouchers in New York City.

title: East River Seaplane Operator Has an Eye on the Hudson
description: A new seaplane operator has been buzzing tourists around town since January, using a busy stretch of the East River for takeoffs and landings. But the company wants to increase operations and base planes on the Hudson River, and those ideas have some boaters worried about safety, while others question if seaplanes truly bring fantasy-island charm to Manhattan, or just more noise and air traffic.

title: Interest in Golf Is Growing, And So Are the Courses
description: EARLY arrivals at the Pequabuck Golf Club outside Bristol, Conn., found that tee times had been delayed by an hour and a half because of frost -- on May 1, no less.

title: After Pushcarts Comes a Catwalk
description: WHAT was the woman in the lime-green and gray suit, with shoulders sharp enough to poke an eye out, doing in the middle of Orchard Street?

title: May 16-22; The Hype Was With Them
description: Well, yes, of course, ''Star Wars: Episode 1 -- The Phantom Menace,'' playing at 2,970 theaters, often around the clock, set an opening-day record. (On a school night, yet!) To be exact, $28,542,349, or nearly $7 million more than ''The Lost World: Jurassic Park'' took in two years ago. Armed with galactic hype, ''The Phantom Menace'' didn't need any raves, and its reviews were indeed mixed. But here's the real question: If you stumble to a movie at 3:30 A.M., are you staying up late or getting up early?

title: Juilliard Tries to Nurture Well-Tempered Artists
description: HOW do you get to Carnegie Hall? Practice hard, for sure, but take care, too, that your mental and spiritual development keeps pace with the physical and technical, to produce a well-rounded individual and artist.

Funeral Mass Immaculate Conception Church, Irvington, on Tuesday at 10 AM. Entombment in Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: Big, Bigger and Biggest Houses: Towns Trying to Set Limits
description: EVEN before the first shovel had been put in the ground for Ira Rennert's Sagaponack mega-mansion, Southampton and East Hampton town officials began drafting legislation to limit the size of new houses. The new limits, up to 20,000 square feet, say a lot about the excess that has marked the latest building boom. A house that size is about 10 times larger than the average Long Island home.

title: Synagogue Caterer Ordered to Stop Leaving a Bitter Taste

title: Marie Saunders, William Reger
description: Patricia Marie Saunders and William Thomas Reger were married yesterday afternoon by the Rev. Thomas Valenti, a Roman Catholic priest, in St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University in Manhattan.

title: Jewels and Crowns
description: Walk-a-thons and races are a Sunday city ritual from early spring through autumn, and some participants do it with style. Last week's 6.2-mile AIDS Walk New York raised more than $4.2 million for the Gay Men's Health Crisis and attracted nearly 40,000 participants. Many individuals, as well as members of corporate employee teams and family groups, including pets, wore gold crowns, awarded to those who raised $1,000 or more. Nearly as popular were cell phones. Anna Wintour, top left, between her children, wore this year's button like a jewel in the center of her sweater. Others wore a collection of buttons from years past.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DECARLO, PHILIP J.
description: DeCARLO-Philip J.. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Philip J. DeCarlo, associated with The Times from 1994.

title: A Game Boy in the Cross Hairs
description: Hiro's on a rampage. He's a vaguely Asian crusader with giant muscles bursting through an armored torso, but since you're watching the world through his eyes, all you see is his Ion Blaster gun and dungeon floors and walls hurtling by so fast your stomach somersaults into your throat. Whoa, look out! It's Superfly Johnson -- Hiro's gargantuan bald and black nemesis -- streaking by, blasting away with his Sidewinder gun. Hiro leaps to avoid the rocket-powered missiles, then pivots and fires. Green laser beams ricochet off the fortress walls, exploding like fireworks. Superfly's fragged! Body parts drop from the sky like bloody rain, gibs splattering the walls -- and if you don't know that's short for giblets, slang for chunks of flesh, then you're a llama, a newbie loser, and shouldn't be hanging around Kyoto 2455 A.D. in the first place.

title: Where East Has Come West
description: Michelle Liao's parrot jabbers, whuffs and shrieks like Joan Rivers at the Oscars. Ollie, an African gray, presides over the Liao Collection, a Philadelphia emporium (607 Bainbridge Street, 215-925-1809) that mixes urban-America hip and pre-Mao China. Most Manhattan boutiques catering to the current craze for Asian goods are spare and precious; the Liao Collection is a cavernous space teeming with bamboo vests, woven peasant jackets and artifacts (cricket cages, jade necklaces). The cache is not an undiscovered one. The late Tina Chow made annual pilgrimages for crystal ink pots and wooden Mingei bowls. Today, Ralph Lauren stockpiles Ms. Liao's cotton shirts and jackets; Vivienne Tam, her chi paos (formal Chinese dresses). Donna Karan was spotted scooping up lambskin robes, indigo linen kimonos and leather Shanxi jodhpurs at Ms. Liao's booth at one of Manhattan's Vintage Fashion and Antique Textile Shows.

title: Multiplex Choice Question: Who's on First?
description: For the past year, homeowners living near the Queens Center Mall have been fighting plans for two multiplexes within five blocks of each other. While one of those projects seems to have fallen through, residents are now keeping their eyes on yet another developer's plan, this one for a 3,200-seat theater atop a nearby Stern's department store.

title: The Class of Prop. 209
description: Your article was so offensive that it is difficult to know where to begin. You can regard the relegation of California's black students to second-tier schools as good news, as James Traub does, only if you assume that blacks are second-class citizens. While denouncing affirmative action, your writer supports ''fiddling'' with entrance requirements; he would have us ''fiddle'' while we burn.

title: The World; Yes, Investors Panicked. But Brazil Didn't.
description: PRESIDENT FERNANDO HENRIQUE CARDOSO traveled to the United States early this month and everywhere he went, the same people who just four months before were worrying about an Asian-style meltdown of Brazil's economy praised him for his astute leadership. At the White House, President Clinton led the chorus, expressing relief at ''the substantial progress'' Brazil has made in recovering from the fiscal crisis, which led to a 40 percent devaluation of its currency in January.

title: For an Actor, a Role Is an Enigma Till the Final Cut
description: WHEN actors sign up for a movie, they rarely have much notion how it -- or they -- will end up looking on screen. David Thewlis learned that some years ago with Mike Leigh. He duly followed the British director's ritual of spending weeks creating a character down to the tiniest detail. With ''Life Is Sweet,'' he was reduced to licking chocolate off Jane Horrocks's breasts. With ''Naked,'' on the other hand, he won the best actor prize at the 1993 Cannes Film Festival.

title: The Way We Live Now: 5-23-99: The Ethicist; Jailhouse Confession
description: In 1979 I was sentenced to life in prison; I come up for parole in 2003. One of the principal factors in winning parole is an admission of guilt. But I am not guilty of the convicted offense, and I am loath to state otherwise. Claiming to have 'found Jesus' also greatly enhances one's prospects, but that would be contrary to my true beliefs. I am content to remain honest and spend the rest of my life in prison. But my incarceration has hurt my family greatly, and I hate to inflict more pain. Should I lie? - J.Q., Florida

title: May 16-22; An Old Tradition, a New Furor

That is when the Makah Indians, who live at the very northwestern tip of the lower 48 states and had relied on the whales for a large part of their diet for centuries, stopped hunting the grays.

The Rev. Joel M. Ives performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Episcopal Church on Nantucket. Sister Regina A. Murphy, a Roman Catholic nun and an aunt of the bridegroom, took part in the service.

title: Audrey Kirnon and Dario Emans
description: Audrey Christina Kirnon, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James M. Kirnon of the Bronx, is to be married this morning to Dario Genaro Emans, a son of Luz M. McKelly and Santiago Sierra, both of the Bronx. The Rev. Winston O. Cato is to perform the nondenominational ceremony at the Fountainhead, a catering hall in New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: Learning to Love the Land and the Magic of Watching Things Grow
description: MY twin boys, Anthony and Paul, now almost 13 years old, have still not learned to love the taste of okra, but in Connecticut, they learned at least how to pick it. We taught them at a pick-your-own farm in Avon how to hunt for the smallest and best okra pods and how you sometimes had to turn over a leaf to spot what you were looking for. In the orchards of South Glastonbury, the boys learned about hunting for the best berries, ripe enough to be soft when you picked them, but not so ripe as to turn gooey in a day's heat. And they gained a basic knowledge of what varieties of apples would ripen first in the fall, which came last, which ones were good for eating and which for cooking.

title: A Life of Housework
description: ROY FOX has one of the best deals in New York City. He lives free in a sunny, spacious, high-ceilinged two-and-a-half story mansion.

title: Beaches Beckon, but oh, Where to Park?
description: THERE was a time not too long ago when most of the many beaches in the Hamptons were open to all comers. But with the increase in summer visitors came an increase in local regulations barring visitors from using beaches unless they purchased a sticker, and in some cases barring outsiders altogether.

title: Ship of Foes

On Feb. 4, Ms. Skolnick, a BancBoston Robertson Stephens managing director, dropped her ratings on four stocks in the assisted-living care sector, citing the possible effects of an impending General Accounting Office report on the industry.
