title: May 16-22; Breaking Up a Vitamin Cartel
description: For nearly a decade, executives at the world's leading producers of vitamins would plot in secret to control the prices, production and distribution of nutrients and additives used to enrich food products. That cartel came to an abrupt end when Hoffmann-LaRoche Ltd., the Swiss pharmaceutical giant, pleaded guilty in Federal court to violating the Sherman Antitrust Act and agreed to pay a $500 million fine, the largest criminal penalty ever imposed by the Justice Department. A second company, BASF A.G. of Germany, agreed to pay $250 million. Executives of both companies, along with others, remain under investigation.

title: A Ride to the Hamptons, and to the End of Single Life
description: IN May 1987, I rode the Hampton Jitney for the first time. I'll never forget it. I had just quit my job as an editorial assistant at Esquire magazine and rented a room for the summer with three friends in a rickety-but-quaint house in Bridgehampton. I was told there was a view of the ocean from the rooftop.

title: Diverse Views of a Changing Landscape
description: THE East End's shoreline, farms, treescapes and deep vistas have long inspired well-known artists. Thankfully, nature's elements have not changed, but comparing a painting from a century ago, the work of Thomas Moran (1837-1926), with recent interpretations by Jane Freilicher and Jane Wilson emphasizes differences in land use, social attitudes and artistic goals.

title: A Just and Necessary War
description: We are in Kosovo with our allies to stand for a Europe, within our reach for the first time, that is peaceful, undivided and free. And we are there to stand against the greatest remaining threat to that vision: instability in the Balkans, fueled by a vicious campaign of ethnic cleansing.

title: BEST SELLERS: May 23, 1999
description: Weeks

title: Check the Fed's Pulse. Call Us in the Long Term.
description: JAMES W. PAULSEN, the chief investment officer at Wells Capital Management in Minneapolis, says he is only tilting. Marshall Acuff, the equity strategist at Salomon Smith Barney, is just moving at the margin. And Jeffrey M. Applegate, the chief United States strategist at Lehman Brothers, is only trimming his expectations for returns.

title: A Cottage on the Housatonic, Fly Fishing in the Bargain
description: HOUSATONIC ANGLERS, a fly-fishing guide service and tiny bed and breakfast in West Cornwall, is a business, but it's also a way of life for Rob and Nell Nicholas, the couple who own and operate it.

title: May 16-22; Ford to Cut Pickup Emissions
description: Starting with the 2000 model year, new Ford pickups will produce less air pollution than many cars. Ford is certifying them and advertising them as low-emissions trucks, which are only allowed to emit two-thirds as much smog-causing gases as regular pickups. But the new pickups will actually be much cleaner, emitting only one-sixth of the pollution allowed even by low-emissions pickup standards. The auto maker said that it would not charge extra for the clean pickups.

title: NATO Mistakenly Hits Rebel Base in Kosovo, Killing 7
description: NATO aircraft mistakenly bombed a key base that had been seized by the rebel Kosovo Liberation Army six weeks ago, allied spokesman said today.

title: Corrections
description: An article on April 11 about Alfred Hitchcock misspelled the surname of an actor of whom Hitchcock spoke highly in an interview with Peter Bogdanovich. A reader pointed out last week that he is Roscoe Lee Brown, not Browne.

title: Heard It On the PC Grapevine
description: WHEN employees gossip about their jobs at the proverbial water cooler, the atmosphere is often one of hushed tones and over-the-shoulder glances. But no such discretion applies at the Electronic Watercooler, an on-line network of uncensored bulletin boards intended to attract employees and job seekers at more than 800 companies.

title: Hardaway's Problems With Magic Mostly of His Own Doing
description: Anfernee Hardaway decided he was being disrespected by the Orlando Magic again last week, treated badly by a franchise that has merely acquiesced to his every demand since 1995. The fussy Hardaway, grumpy and fed up, said he would exercise an option in his contract to move to another team in the off season.

title: Living Aboard
description: CAPTAIN MIKE reached into a cooler on the teak deck of the Southern Cross, his 32-foot sailboat and home, and popped open an ice-cold can of Bud. ''What a day,'' he said, spreading his arms out to the sunny blue sky and the dark waters of Pelham Bay in the Bronx.

title: Case of Arborcide, City Says
description: The cooperative board's members wanted to make an overgrown section of their property cleaner and safer. The landscaper they hired to remove 35 trees just wanted to get paid the $6,500 he was promised for the cleanup.

title: May 16-22; Gandhi Roils Indian Politics
description: The Congress Party, once India's dominant political force, appeared to be poised to make gains in general elections this September, but the abrupt resignation of the party's president, Sonia Gandhi, has thrown all political calculations into disarray.

title: Lifeguards Line Up for Beach Duty
description: The city Parks Department will have enough lifeguards to open all the beaches on Staten Island and Coney Island by Independence Day, overcoming a shortage of qualified guards that had led the city to close miles of beaches in recent years, an official said Friday.

title: The Class of Prop. 209
description: Your article was unnecessarily compromised by including the argument that teaching, the planned career of ''a large fraction of the female students'' at the University of California at Riverside, is ''a very modest ambition compared with pursuing a Ph.D. in cultural psychology'' (at Berkeley). It is just this kind of thinking that keeps the teaching profession undervalued, unrespected and underpaid.

title: Looking for Love, and Following Signs That Point East
description: THE season has begun, and now you will see them every weekend, their cars clogging the Montauk Highway, their tanned bodies spilling onto the sidewalk from the restaurants that have turned into singles bars, trolling in packs from their group houses, or with a friend from their expensive solos.

title: In the Region/New Jersey; Providing Modest-Income Assisted-Living Units
description: WITH its ballooning population of residents 60 years of age and older, New Jersey has become fertile ground for all types of housing for the elderly, especially assisted-living residences, which offer apartment living with meals, social services and personal care.

title: The Joys Of Getting There Ahead of Warren Buffett
description: No, Frank V. Jennings did not raise a toast to Warren E. Buffett last Tuesday, when news surfaced that Berkshire Hathaway, Mr. Buffett's company, held a 2.2 percent stake in the liquor giant Allied Domecq.

title: Another Shooting, Another Search for Lessons
description: To the Editor:

title: Susan Stone, Thomas Gavin Jr.
description: Susan G. Stone and Thomas Peter James Gavin Jr. are to be married today in New York. The Rev. Thomas M. Eisele is to officiate at the nondenominational ceremony at the home of Cynthia Harris, an actress who is a friend of the bride.

title: 'Dangerous' Playgrounds Help Kids Learn; Too Much Safety
description: To the Editor:

title: Q. & A.
description: Biweekly Mortgage Benefits

title: Duncan Puts Spurs On Verge Of Sweep
description: This series is proof of the impact a dominant big man can make on a team. But the big man is not Shaquille O'Neal and the team is not the Los Angeles Lakers.

title: Summer Theater as a Challenge
description: WHEN the season's first show stars 37 marionettes and carries the warning ''not suitable for children,'' you know that summertime theatergoing on Long Island isn't easy.

title: Amy Washam and Mark Masterson
description: Amy Lawrence Washam, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wisner McCamey Washam of New York, was married yesterday to Mark Harrison Masterson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James E. Masterson of Oakton, Va. The Rev. James L. Burns performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: ROGER FISHBITE

title: Is Someone Calling For a Third Party?
description: Of all the candidates, announced and unannounced, in next year's Presidential race, the most improbable is probably Senator Robert C. Smith, a granite-hard Republican conservative from New Hampshire. He has little money, little organization and almost no standing in the polls, even in his home state, which, of course, holds the first primary.

title: Snow Will Cover Walls In Brooklyn in Summer
description: The Brooklyn Museum of Art is offering a last chance to see ''Impressionists in Winter: Effets de Neige,'' an exhibition of snowy scenes that has already drawn big crowds at the Phillips Collection in Washington and at the Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco.

title: In the Region /Westchester; Office Market Lags, but Bullish Notes Are Sounded
description: EVEN as Westchester's office market continues to struggle with a tarnished image and an overall vacancy rate of around 18 percent, some investors are snapping up buildings and sounding positively bullish about the county's overall prospects.

title: Like an Old Studio Apartment With Everything for Sale
description: For Ana Reyes, running Ana's Opus, the store she opened two weeks ago at 224 Smith Street between Douglass and Degraw Streets in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, is a way to pay the bills during retirement while fulfilling a lifelong passion.

title: A Violinist, Passing the Torch, Closes a Circle
description: ONCE upon a time in America, when minorities meant Jews and Roman Catholics, the idea of post-modern was as unimaginable as a moon landing and Horace Stoneham had not even dreamed of leaving the Polo Grounds, there were already three little San Francisco giants. All took up the violin.

title: Sports of The Times; Knicks Dominate Their Opponents and, for Entire Spring, Our Minds
description: ALL hands on deck. All shore leaves canceled. Nobody is going anywhere while the Knicks are on a rampage.

title: Meet Kara and Lynn, 'Mainstream Cool Teens'
description: KARA HAMILTON, 18, and Lynn Liran, 17, look pretty much like teen-agers do across the country. On a recent sunny Monday afternoon, Kara had on scuffed white Nikes, faded Levis and a cream-colored, knitted Gap shirt. Lynn wore a lavender tank top of indeterminate provenance, brown boot-cut Gap jeans, worn brown boots and green eye shadow. The two best friends, seniors at the Spence School in Manhattan, had their backs turned resolutely on Madison Avenue and seemed eager to munch on apple crumb pie at Sarabeth's restaurant and to patiently discuss subjects both dear and foreign to them.

title: When Dining Out Means Out of Doors
description: IN the summer almost everyone thinks about dining al fresco, especially with a water view. Besides its expansive coastline, Connecticut also has its share of inland, lakeside water views.

title: May 16-22; New Deal on Korea Sanctions
description: Since the Korean War ended in stalemate in 1953, Washington's approach to North Korea has been pretty straightforward: Isolate the place, and hope it will collapse in Stalinist rubble. But somehow it has held together, starving but building missiles and aspiring to build nuclear weapons.

title: A Lawn Chair or a Philosophy of Life?
description: WHEN I was little and we lived in a modest working-class neighborhood, the grown-ups used to sit on folding lawn chairs in their front yards on summer nights, while the kids played Crazy Ball or sharpened Popsicle sticks in the cul-de-sac out front.

title: The Fresh Air Fund; Sharing a Bounty of Gifts From a Country Summer
description: Debra Anderson, a single mother from Franklin, N.H., has six children between the ages of 4 and 15. The house where she has lived for 13 years was sold at a public auction in April, and she does not expect to be in it after June.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about living in Manor Heights, Staten Island, misspelled the surname of the coordinator of the Scholars' Academy program of Susan E. Wagner High School. She is Joan Iervese, not Iovese. The article also misstated the size of the school's entering class last September. It was 549, not 350.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: NEVER ENOUGH WORDS

title: DATABANK: May 17-21; A Surprise Showing by Small-Cap Stocks
description: Cinderella finally showed up at the ball. For whatever reason -- a presummer lull or concern about how blue-chip companies would be affected by rising interest rates -- small-capitalization companies were the market's stars last week. But for how long?

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: Victor Hugo

title: Style; Footnotes
description: 1. The director Tim Burton surprised his fiancee, Lisa Marie, with her own Keane portrait. (She's holding their dog, Poppy.) Poppy now makes occasional appearances in Keane's paintings, as do Keane's Siamese cats, Pikaki, Peter and Paradise.

title: May 16-22; Guilty Plea by Fund-Raiser
description: The Justice Department got a lift in its campaign finance inquiry when a Democratic fund-raiser and Arkansas friend of President Clinton pleaded guilty in Federal court to two political fund-raising charges. Yah Lin Trie, a Taiwan-born naturalized American citizen known as Charlie, also agreed to cooperate with the department in its investigation into the financing of Mr. Clinton's 1996 campaign.

title: A Copland Premiere
description: To the Editor:

title: Women at War
description: WE BAND OF ANGELS

title: Meredith Shin, Jonathan Rozoff
description: Meredith Suejung Shin and Jonathan Mark Rozoff were married yesterday at Blantyre, an inn in Lenox, Mass. Rabbi Donald Pollock officiated; a Korean cultural wedding celebration was held earlier in the day.

title: The Giuliani Way: Sue and Be Sued, and Sometimes Win by Losing
description: Most people dread going to court, but not Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani. He has repeatedly demonstrated during his five years at City Hall that he loves a legal battle.

title: Holiday Blitz On Seat Belts Set in 42 States
description: Police agencies are planning another highly publicized enforcement blitz to encourage people to wear seat belts during the Memorial Day weekend Safety experts have concluded that the twice-yearly crackdowns are causing lasting increases in the numbers of people who buckle up.

title: Kimberly Reilly, Terence Smith
description: Kimberly Ann Reilly, a daughter of Noreen and James J. Reilly of Chatham, N.J., was married yesterday to Terence Richard Smith, the son of Diane and Richard F. Smith of Wakefield, R.I. Msgr. Frank Del Prete performed the ceremony at SS. Peter and Paul Church in Hoboken, N.J.

title: Transforming Found Objects Into Art Prints
description: SEVERAL times in recent months, the graphics designer Ivan Chermayeff packed an odd-ball assortment of found objects in his BMW and drove from New York to this village 50 miles east of Burlington. When he arrived at Cone Editions, an art-print workshop, on one occasion in March, he had five suitcases stuffed with old gloves, flattened steel buckets, rusted iron numbers, hole-riddled boards, mailed envelopes with canceled stamps, food choppers, boot jacks, buttons, beach pebbles and rope winders, stuff he had collected over decades.

title: Bed & Breakfast, Pleasure & Frustration
description: WHEN Bill Dalton retired as Deputy Commissioner of the New York City Parks Department, he never dreamed he would be flipping pancakes and frying omelets every morning for 10 hungry guests.

title: An Elegant Brownstone You Can't Live In
description: Neighbors who opposed the construction of a gymnasium for the Berkeley Carroll School on President Street between Sixth and Seventh Avenues feared that the work, which began in December, would harm a 137-year-old oak tree.

title: The Story
description: To the Editor:

title: The Cuckoo Clock
description: To the Editor:

title: Mr. Wisniewski, Ms. Lewnowski
description: Ann Barbara Lewnowski, a daughter of Elfriede and Oskar Lewnowski of Pembroke, Bermuda, was married yesterday to Thomas Wisniewski, a son of Lois Wisniewski of Montclair, N.J., and Chester Wisniewski of Menemsha, Mass. The Rev. Glen P. Baptiste performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Cathedral of St. Teresa in Hamilton, Bermuda.

title: Doubts About Mexico's Reforms
description: Long before governing party politicians were finished casting ballots this week on how to change the way their presidential nominee is chosen, party leaders were busy handing out advance copies of a speech thanking them for selecting the method preferred by President Ernesto Zedillo.

title: Where Cellos Find Ensembles to Suit
description: Sleek yet curvaceous French type brassy blonde desires partner(s) for intensive summer weekend of music making.

title: For Video Warriors, A Fight to the Finish
description: The tournament had all the trappings of a big-league sporting event: large cash prizes, pre- and post-game interviews and a broadcast team perched above the action, providing play-by-play and color commentary.

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/2000 Nissan Maxima; Revved Up at a Pared-Down Price
description: IN the modern pantheon of hot cars, the Nissan Maxima ranks as a minor deity -- not up there with, say, the BMW 3-Series, yet forever to be honored as the first midsize sport sedan at about the same price as a drab family hauler.

title: The World: A Better System in the 19th Century?; At This Rate, We'll Be Global in Another Hundred Years
description: IF anything seems obvious today, it is that globalization is a new and powerful force that is erasing national borders and linking the world in an unprecedented web of trade and investments. As one tycoon put it: ''The world is a city.''

title: Proper Pair of Boots Conquers Any Trail
description: Beware of enterprises that require new clothes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JULIBER, I. GERARD
description: JULIBER-I. Gerard. 85. Died peacefully after a hard-fought battle. Beloved and devoted husband of Roslyn. Loving and supportive father of Ilene and Stan (Barshay), Lois and Jon (Adams). Grandfather of Larry and Lisa, Scott and Melissa, and Missy, great-grandfather of Jennifer, Emily and Seth. Retired Senior Vice President of Revlon. He taught us the meaning of family, loyalty, courage and love. We will miss him dearly, and cherish his memory. Funeral Monday at Gutterman's, Woodbury, New York.

title: Wow! A New Sitcom About Five Singles!
description: HELP! Is there anyone at the television networks interested in shows for viewers over 35? Is there a world beyond 20-something angst in which roommates in improbably fancy apartments are obsessed with two quite boring issues, the boys worried about commitment, the girls looking for Mr. Perfect? Do viewers really crave more than one show with a happy gay roommate (a trend since the success of ''Will and Grace,'' a series about a woman and her gay roommate)?

title: A Small Bookstore Under Big Pressure
description: NORMAN LAURILA is in trouble. The owner of A Different Light bookstore in Chelsea, Mr. Laurila is a prime purveyor of books for gay men and lesbians. He owns book shops in San Francisco and West Hollywood as well the one in Chelsea, a white hot precinct with one of the largest homosexual populations in the country.

title: 'Dangerous' Playgrounds Help Kids Learn; City's Real Hazards
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HENNESSY, THOMAS P.
description: HENNESSY-Thomas P.. Of Lynbrook, suddenly on May 20, 1999. Beloved husband of Anne. Loving father of Susan Flood and Jennifer Hennessy. Cherished son of Elizabeth. Dear father-in-law of Joseph. Adoring grandfather of Katherine and Kevin. Also survived by his brother David. Family will receive friends Sunday and Monday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM, at the Flinch & Bruns Funeral Home, 34 Hempstead Avenue, Lynbrook. Mass of Christian Burial, Tuesday, 10 AM, at Our Lady of Peace R.C. Church, Lynbrook. Interment Calverton National Cemetery.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Neighborhood Report pages last Sunday about the installation of a speed bump in Gravesend, Brooklyn, misspelled the surname of the chairman of Community Board 15, who complained that the board had not been notified. He is John E. Nikas, not Nickas.

title: Hopkins Triumphs In a Homecoming
description: Johns Hopkins was the visiting squad yesterday when it defeated Hofstra, 11-7, in a quarterfinal of the National Collegiate Athletic Association men's Division I tournament. But the Blue Jays were making a homecoming of sorts: a dozen of their players are from Long Island.

title: Corrections
description: An article on April 18 about the romance between King Henry VIII and Anne Boleyn misidentified the person who gave Henry the title Defender of the Faith. It was Pope Leo X, not Henry himself. The Pope bestowed it on Henry before Henry met Anne Boleyn; the Catholic Church withdrew the title after Henry broke with the church, in 1534.

title: Beyond Ice Cubes: Clever and Cool
description: FRUITY COOLERS AROMA FAN

title: The Giving May Be Easy. Planning Isn't.
description: NORMALLY, the season of giving begins in December, with the ringing of Salvation Army Santas. But in the Hamptons, the floodgates of philanthropy lift on Memorial Day weekend, when local charities and social service agencies release a stream of summer fund-raising events.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRIEF, OSCAR, M.D.
description: TRIEF-Oscar, M.D.. Of Fort Lee, NJ, May 19, 1999. Beloved husband of Renee (nee Usman). Devoted father of Dr. Harold and Dr. Paula Trief-Himmelsbach. Stepfather of Dr. Leonard and Dr. Steven Boral. Dear brother of Vushka Weiser. Loving grandfather of Joshua, Adam and Daniel Himmelsbach; Nathaniel Trief; Heath, Brooke, Benjamin & Austin Boral. Services will be held at ''Gutterman-Musicant,'' corner of Passaic and Park Streets, Hackensack, New Jersey, today, at noon.

title: Innocents on Death Row
description: Last week, Illinois exonerated Ronald Jones for the rape and murder that was scheduled to send him to his death. When DNA tests were finally performed eight years after he was sentenced to die, they proved that the crime could not have been committed by Mr. Jones, who says that he confessed because Chicago police beat him severely. Since Illinois reinstated the death penalty in 1977, it has executed 12 men. It has also exonerated 12 after they were able to prove their innocence. Some had come within days of execution.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MONTGELAS, BARBARA TROWBRIDGE
description: MONTGELAS - Barbara Trowbridge. Of Darien, CT on May 18, 1999. Wife of the late Rudolph M. Montgelas. Mother of Michele, Daphne, Rudy, & Mark. Memorial Service will be held at St. Luke's Episcopal Church, Darien, CT on Monday, May 24, 1999 at 11:00 AM. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be made to: Person-to-Person, 1864 Post Road, Box 3128, Darien, CT 06820 or Guiding Eyes for the Blind, 611 Granite Springs Road, Yorktown Heights, N.Y. 10598.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLAUS, IDA
description: KLAUS-Ida. Region II of the National Academy of Arbitrators note with sadness the passing of our esteemed colleague, Ida Klaus. A pioneer of her profession, she was a brilliant attorney, a respected arbitrator, and a valued friend. We shall miss her very much. John E. Sands, Chair Mattye M. Gandel, Vice Chair Rose F. Jacobs, Sec.-Treasurer

title: The Class of Prop. 209
description: As a clear beneficiary of affirmative-action policies in California (Stanford '87, U.C.L.A. Law '91), and as an admissions officer at a selective private institution, I found James Traub's article (May 2) on the future of race in admissions disturbing. The phenomenon described as ''cascading,'' which is called ''serious, but not tragic,'' is a terrible consequence of the elimination of affirmative action in California. No one denies that U.C. Riverside provides an excellent education. Neither can you deny that U.C.L.A. and Berkeley are likely to provide better opportunities in the long run.

title: Ms. Fontanella, Mr. Culhane
description: Adrienne Fontanella and Peter Francis Culhane were married yesterday at the Apawamis Club in Rye, N.Y. Judge John Alfano of the Rye Municipal Court officiated, and the Rev. Arthur Leone, a Roman Catholic priest, also took part in the ceremony.

title: All About Eve
description: WOMAN

title: Romantic Dining Interludes for Those on Tight Budgets
description: SEARCHING for an inexpensive, romantic restaurant on the East End of Long Island is a bit like looking for love in all the wrong places.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLARK, STANLEY I.
description: CLARK-Stanley I.. Beloved husband of Eleanor. Devoted father of Marcia and Harry Lippman, and Roberta and Herbert Selzer. Cherished grandfather of Caleb, Jennifer, Jordan, Lauren and Brian. He was a prominent attorney for over 50 years. Services Sunday, 10 AM, at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels,'' 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, New York.

title: The World: Protecting Xanadu; Hong Kong Seeks Its Own Chinese Wall
description: CHINA'S newest city is crowded, expensive, polluted and mired in its worst recession since World War II. And yet to listen to Hong Kong's leaders, every person in mainland China with the slightest claim to live here would scramble across the border if the gates were opened.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BASTIS, CHRISTOS G.
description: BASTIS-Christos G.. On May 21, 1999, at his home in Palm Beach, FL. Beloved and devoted husband of Josephine. Loving and supportive father of Betty, George, Christopher and Jason. Loving grandfather of seven and great-granfather of three. His strength, courage and determination was unyielding, and his great love of family, friends and life will always be cherished. We all love him and will miss him dearly. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st St., Monday and Tuesday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral services at The Greek Orthodox Cathedral of the Holy Trinity, 319 East 74th St., Wednesday, 10 AM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SKOLNICK, GLORIA
description: SKOLNICK-Gloria. The Board of Governors and Members of Fenway Golf Club record with profound sorrow the passing of its longtime member, Gloria Skolnick and extend to her bereaved husband Harvey, and the members of her family, our sincere condolences. Joel Langer, President Marvin Leffler, Secretary

title: The Way We Live Now: 5-23-99: Salient Facts: Cables; Plugged In
description: WHAT ARE ALL THESE SWIFTLY MERGING PHONE AND CABLE COMPANIES AFTER?

title: Taming the North Atlantic, And Doing It in a Hurry
description: Teams on race boats with a craving for adventure are tied up at yacht harbors around New York, all eager for a chance at toppling the trans-Atlantic speed record. Each covets a brisk breeze, a windy low-pressure system that will carry its sailboat into a record-breaking passage across a notoriously tricky North Atlantic.

title: Sound Bites Over Jerusalem
description: What better way to insure that the least-qualified man will be elected in Israel than to hire the same folks who gave the Clintons to the United States?

title: Mary Cox and Herbert Golden
description: Dr. Mary Lathrop Brown Cox, a child psychologist in Brooklyn, was married last evening to Herbert Lincoln Golden, a retired banker. Judge Millard Midonick, who retired from Surrogate's Court in Manhattan, officiated at the bride's apartment in Brooklyn.

title: Town Officers for the Summer
description: TRAFFIC control officers will never rate highly in popularity polls.

title: Exploiting a Computer's Strategic Myopia
description: The only game Judit Polgar won in her ill-fated quickplay match with the computer Fritz5.32 in Budapest last month was the ninth. Not surprisingly, it was the only game in which she exploited the human advantage of superior positional grasp. When Fritz5.32 was put to the test, it failed to identify the classic strategic disadvantage of an isolated pawn, and it accepted a position in which that was the main factor.

title: 'East Is East,' and West Is an Off Broadway Stage
description: AYUB KHAN-DIN grew up in the north of England in suburban Manchester, the eighth of 10 children born to an English mother and an emigre father from Pakistan, who between them ran a fish-and-chips shop.

title: Margot Fell, Joseph O'Connor
description: Margot Sullivan Fell, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Laurence T. Fell of New York, was married yesterday to Joseph Vincent O'Connor, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Daniel J. O'Connor of Falmouth, Mass. The Rev. Thomas S. Prout, a cousin of the bride, performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in New York.

title: The Way We Live Now: 5-23-99: Questions for Joan Chen; The Revolution of Little Girls
description: Q: Your new film, ''Xiu Xiu: The Sent Down Girl,'' focuses on the plight of children during the Chinese Cultural Revolution in China. What was life like for you during those years?

title: THE GUIDE
description: Whitewater Weekend

title: Pueblo Indians Receive Remains of Ancestors
description: Pecos and Jemez Pueblo Indians welcomed home the remains of nearly 2,000 of their ancestors early this morning, with about 1,000 Pueblos and well-wishers walking with a semi-truck carrying the remains and hundreds of artifacts for the final mile of the truck's 2,200-mile journey.

title: Fund-Raising: Vying for Time and Money
description: TOM CRUISE and his family are going to miss today's Penguin Ball in Stamford. So is David Letterman. And Whoopi Goldberg. But 500 mothers, fathers and children wearing everything from tuxedos to jeans will be there to raise money and awareness for a charity called Kids Care Clubs in New Canaan.

title: Pets Need Assistance To Deal With the Heat
description: AS soon as people start making summer plans, they should start thinking about the needs of the family pet. The warm months that bring people such pleasure can be the most difficult for the four-footed set to endure. Helpless to influence their own environment, they depend on the foresight and concern of their owners.

title: The Complete and Candid Schilling
description: Whether he is fairly paid or underpaid, Curt Schilling earns his money. No, he more than earns it. He works overtime, both on days when he is supposed to work and on days when he is supposed to be off. In an era of pitch counts and pitcher pampering, Schilling is the square peg in the round hole. He just doesn't fit.

title: Style; An Eye for an Eye
description: 'It's Keane! It's pure Keane,'' Diane Keaton squeals when presented with a big-eyed painting in Woody Allen's 1973 futuristic comedy, ''Sleeper.'' ''No, no! It's greater than Keane -- it's Cugat!''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARX, CLAIRE
description: MARX-Claire. 89. Died at home early Mother's Day morning. Strong, courageous, devoted happily and entirely to her family, she now joins Stanley in peace and love, and will be remembered and admired by her daughter Pat forever. A service was held.

title: Old Colors Won't Fade in Tractor Deal
description: NEVER mind the Wall Street reaction. When two big farm equipment makers, New Holland N.V. and the Case Corporation, announced last week that they would merge, one question seemed to be on every customer's mind: What color?

title: Noise: Nuisance Or Health Hazard?
description: To the Editor:

title: Where Strategy Means Keeping Up With the Kids
description: JOHN CABELL Jr. likes to tag along when his 14-year-old daughter, Elizabeth, heads to the mall. That is because Mr. Cabell, as co-manager of the $930 million USAA Aggressive Growth fund, is hungry for insight into what the under-21 crowd is buying.

title: The Pubs That Brew Their Own Suds
description: ''I WAS always a Budweiser drinker, and still am to some extent,'' said Bill McCarthy. That's quite an admission, coming as it does from an owner of the Trout Brook Brewhouse, which, as its name suggests, makes its own beer. Trout Brook, in Hartford and Wallingford, ranks among a dozen or so Connecticut restaurants brewing their own.

title: Exploring Bounty of Outdoor Sculpture
description: AS summer approaches, warmer weather should inspire art lovers to explore a wealth of public sculpture throughout Westchester County.

title: Sixty Years and a Treasured Letter
description: They met in 1934, in Konigsberg, the capital of East Prussia. Max Ziemann was 12 and lived in a Jewish orphanage, having been abandoned by his mother when he was 5. Ruth Czerninski, now Ruth Dubow, was 20, fresh from a year at college, and she had come from her native Danzig to be the schoolmistress at the orphanage.

title: You Can't Kick the Tires, But You Can Lick the Stamps
description: PSSST! Wanna buy a nice old car -- cheap? The post office has some Model T Fords, half a Gatsby-era limousine and some flamboyantly finned 1950's models including a turquoise '57 Chevrolet Bel Air, all going for 32 or 33 cents.

title: Truth, Fiction And Real Estate
description: THE House That Ate The Hamptons,'' subtitled, ''A Novel of Lily Pond Lane,'' is James Brady's third novel set in the Hamptons in three years.

title: From the Nude to the Nutty: There's an Attraction for Everyone
description: SOME people call Connecticut ''The Land of Steady Habits,'' a place where people are conscious of their place in history. And if they are not, there are plenty of museums, mansions and roadside markers to remind them.

title: The Class of Prop. 209
description: Regarding admissions criteria and recruitment policies, Traub writes, ''Conservatives think that fiddling undermines the principle of merit.'' But fiddling with an eye to changing the racial and ethnic mix is also illegal discrimination. It is no different from de-emphasizing the S.A.T. because too many Jews do well on it, or avoiding recruitment in Chinatown.

title: With a Nod to the Economy, the Art Market Is Flourishing
description: A DECADE ago, the East End's art galleries attracted more window shoppers than buyers, and were seldom patronized by serious collectors. As one local gallery owner remarked, what was for sale in the Hamptons was considered ''second-rate art for second homes.''

title: Swim Teams Mix Clubs and Towns
description: SMELLING faintly of chlorine, about 2,000 youngsters 6 to 18 will be spending hours in the swimming pool this summer, practicing to respond to the words ''Swimmers, take your marks . . . ''

title: City Council To Curtail Planned Tax Cuts
description: City Council leaders announced yesterday that the State Legislature's repeal of the commuter tax had forced them to abandon proposals for at least $443 million in tax cuts for city residents, including $173 million worth of cuts proposed by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about the sparseness of interest among American Jews in the Israeli election referred incorrectly to the Arab-Israeli war of 1967. It was the Six-Day War; the Yom Kippur War was in 1973.

title: Spin Doctoring 101
description: Truth to Tell

title: Reaching the Beach on the Parkway Can Take a Toll
description: FRIDAY afternoon, warm. The sea air beckons. The suitcases are in the trunk. Lighthearted, you race out of work, jump in the car and head down the parkway for a weekend at the shore. Five minutes later, you're stuck in traffic.

title: Sound Bites Over Jerusalem
description: I had great fun reading Adam Nagourney's article (April 25) about James Carville's and Arthur Finkelstein's adventures in the Holy Land. The serious part is that Israel is selling the little that's left of its soul to foreign cultures.

title: Rites of Survivorship
description: IT was fitting that this financial revelation came in church.

title: Liberties; Bile in Bloom
description: For many years, the favorite rite of spring in Washington was awaiting the mating of the pandas at the National Zoo.

title: Melissa London, Eric Hilfers
description: Melissa Elizabeth London and Eric Walker Hilfers, associates at the New York law firm of Cravath, Swaine & Moore, were married yesterday by Rabbi Peter Kessler at the George Peabody Library in Baltimore.

title: The Nation: Bland Ambition; In Politics, Dull Isn't Deadly
description: POOR Al Gore. As if President Clinton's keening that his loyal No. 2 needs to unbend were not enough, now the Republicans have made Mr. Gore a punch line.

title: A White That's 'Fruit Driven'
description: Since 1983, its first vintage, the Lenz Winery in Peconic on the North Fork of Long Island year after year has made one of America's two best gewurztraminers. Its rival is Navarro in Mendocino County, Calif. Both estates find their inspiration in Alsace's dry, full-blown gewurztraminers, Europe's model.

title: Housing in the Old Taystee Bakery? Perhaps Fish?
description: Though the Taystee cake bakery on 126th Street near Amsterdam Avenue has been shuttered since the last cake was baked there 20 years ago, it looked like plans to turn it into a moderate-income housing complex were moving along. But now at least one other player, Citarella Fish Company, which runs two upscale fish markets in Manhattan, has taken an interest in the site.

title: Old for One's Age
description: The Drowning People

title: The World; Kosovo Isn't Just an Air War; It's a Blair War
description: WHAT was a British Prime Minister doing dressed down in an open-neck shirt and short sleeves and sitting cross-legged and shoeless in a refugee tent in Albania? And why was this leader of a spent imperial power passing as much time this month in places like Aachen, Bonn, Brussels, Bucharest, Chicago, Mons, Sofia, Skopje, Tirana and Washington as in London?

title: Aliza Kaplan, David Plotkin
description: Aliza Bapya Kaplan and David E. Plotkin are to be married today in Manhattan. Rabbi Lori Forman is to perform the ceremony at Congregation B'nai Jeshurun.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Seaford, N.Y.; A Certain Chemistry on the South Shore
description: LAST fall Seaford High School's football team topped off a winning season with a 23-to-12 victory over Babylon to take the Long Island Class 4 championship.

title: Making the Best of a Congested Bridge
description: IF the thought of being in Friday afternoon or Sunday evening summer traffic heading across the Tappan Zee Bridge makes you shudder, here is some advice from the experts:

title: Alison Stern, Aaron Simard
description: Alison Rebecca Stern, the daughter of Stephanie and Richard L. Stern of New York, was married yesterday to Aaron Marcus Simard, the son of Pamela and Cadman Simard of Elk Grove, Calif. Judge Thomas Roumell, an uncle of the bride who is retired from the Wayne County Circuit Court in Detroit, officiated at Gedney Farm, an inn in New Marlborough, Mass.

title: Christos Bastis, Mediterranean Restaurateur, Dies at 95
description: Christos G. Bastis, a restaurateur and art collector whose Sea Fare restaurants brought a sophisticated Mediterranean understanding of seafood to New York, died Friday night at his home in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 95 and lived in Manhattan and Palm Beach.

title: Kristin Bowen, Samuel Cohen
description: Kristin Ann Bowen, the daughter of Jean N. Bowen of Danbury, Conn., and Ronald Bowen of Brewster, N.Y., is to be married this afternoon to Samuel Schlesinger Cohen, a son of Phyllis B. Romm of New York and Judge Richard S. Cohen of Plainfield, N.J. Dr. Judith Wallach, the president of the New York Society for Ethical Culture, is to officiate at the Bryant Park Grill in New York.

title: Brazil's Women Gaining Respect
description: Luis Miguel Estevao had what seemed an impossible mission. Even in Brazil, where soccer is a secular religion, women who wanted to play were often met with closed minds instead of open arms.

title: Adventures in the Book Trade
description: Another Life A Memoir of Other People. By Michael Korda. 530 pp. New York: Random House. $26.95.

title: Undercutting Diversity
description: To the Editor:

title: Deteriorating Standards
description: To the Editor:

title: Beyond Bland: Art Houses Draw the Faithful
description: EACH summer moviegoers on the hunt for a good story trudge into theaters, knowing that between super stunts and superstars, their only guaranteed pleasure will be powerhouse air-conditioning.

title: St. Anthony's Wins Two Team Titles
description: St. Anthony's High School of South Huntington, N.Y., swept the boys' and girls' team titles yesterday in the outdoor championships of the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association at St. John's University.

title: F.Y.I.
description: Out-of-the-Way Saint

title: A World of Ice Cream Waiting to Be Explored
description: ICE CREAM and summer go together like Mark McGwire and home runs, canoes and rivers, hamburgers and cookouts. Hard is the heart -- or strong the will power -- that can spot an ice cream place along the road and not slam on the brakes.

title: In America; What Makes the Pols Run?
description: As the Rolling Stones famously warbled, you can't always get what you want. So New York's top politicians are doing the next best thing -- scrambling to take what they can get.

title: All The Town's A Stage
description: FROM my first visit to Almagro, midway between Andalusia and Madrid, I knew it was more than just another dusty town on the plains of La Mancha. As a little research revealed, Almagro was a prominent, prosperous town of 16th-century Spain, populated by nobility and renowned for its celebrated theater -- a theater recalled to life every July in a three week festival of classic comedy and drama.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VORSCHIRM, GERTRUDE
description: VORSCHIRM-Gertrude. Beloved wife of the late Herbert. Devoted mother of Franklin. Adored grandmother of Hillary Soffer and Eric. Great-grandmother of Sabrina Soffer. Services Sunday 12 noon at Schwartz Bros-Jeffer Memorial, Queens Boulevard and 76th Road, Forest Hills.

title: The Nation; Finding Spies Is the Easy Part
description: REPORTS from an investigation by a House committee last week seemed to leave little doubt: Beijing's theft of secrets from American nuclear weapons laboratories led to spectacular gains by China in creating a modern thermonuclear arsenal. And the penetration went deeper and was more devastating than anyone had imagined.

title: As Dresses Decompose, Designs, Presumably, Are Born
description: Eighteen containers, the size and shape of shower stalls, constructed from wood and sheets of plastic, form two rows in the cathedralesque chambers of the anchorage of the Brooklyn Bridge. Suspended within the containers are a selection of clothes by the innovative Belgian designer Martin Margiela.

title: Carol McFate, Robert Jensen
description: Carol Ann McFate, the treasurer of the American International Group, the insurance company in New York, is to be married this afternoon to Robert Wayne Jensen, a broker at William Pitt Real Estate in Old Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Dr. Richard D. Mallory, an Episcopal priest, is to officiate at the Roger Sherman Inn in New Canaan, Conn.

title: INVESTING WITH: Joseph E. Stocke; Evergreen Select Special Equity Fund
description: WHAT makes for successful stock-picking? Simple number-crunching, or the evaluation of more qualitative matters, like management talent?

title: A Story of Humble Origins, Less Humble Now
description: The producer acknowledges that the Governor wasn't entirely pleased about his life story being made into a television movie. ''He told me, 'The guy who runs your TV company -- I'm going to pull his hair out follicle by follicle,' '' said John Davis, an executive producer of ''The Jesse Ventura Story,'' to be shown on NBC tonight at 9.

title: Rome, Paris, Warsaw? Polish Tourism Gains
description: POLAND has no Eiffel Tower or Colosseum, and the soot of a half-century of Communism is only beginning to wear off. But according to the latest statistics of the World Tourism Organization, since Communism's collapse 10 years ago, Poland has catapulted itself from 18th place among European countries as tourist destinations, to No. 5.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARX, GERTRUDE
description: MARX-Gertrude. Beloved wife of the late Fred. Devoted mother of Evelyn and Michael Pollack. Dear sister of Else (Walter) Loewenstein, Lore (Henry) Stern and Hilde Gablinger. Services at Schwartz Bros. For information call: 718-263-7600.

title: Brooklyn Fire Kills 3; Arson Is Likely, Officials Say
description: Three men were killed and 13 other tenants were injured early yesterday when fire engulfed their apartment building in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn, forcing many residents to leap from second- and third-story windows.

title: Correction
description: Two pieces were misplaced in the diagram accompanying last Sunday's game, which was also between Polgar and Fritz5.32.

title: Running To and Fro
description: THE UNCERTAIN SCIENCES

title: Supply and Demand
description: Ireland is a conservative Catholic country with a liberal national health system: Among other benefits, approved prescription drugs are dispensed by doctors at no cost to patients.

title: America's Promise, Found in the Army; To More Immigrant New Yorkers, A Better Life Begins in Uniform
description: It was only four years ago that Fernando De Souza and his family arrived in New York from Lima, Peru. Mr. De Souza, the eldest of four children, scrambled to learn English at John Bowne High School in Flushing, Queens, kept his grades in the high 80's, and dreamed of studying medicine in college.

title: A Monarchist Marxists Could Love
description: On the 200th anniversary of Balzac's birth, we can more than ever recognize the truth of Oscar Wilde's claim: ''The 19th century, as we know it, is largely an invention of Balzac.'' Born at the tail end of the 18th century, on May 20, 1799, Honore de Balzac, as he styled himself (that pseudo-aristocratic ''de'' was his own addition), would be the first analyst of a new era. He invented the 19th century by giving form to its emerging urban agglomerations, its nascent capitalist dynamics, its rampant cult of the individual. By conceptualizing, theorizing and dramatizing the new -- all the while deploring it -- he initiated his readers into understanding the shape of a century.

title: The Nation; The Gun Debate Has Two Sides. Now, a Third Way.
description: THE Senate made a bit of history last week, passing gun-control legislation that had been left for dead just a week before.

title: V.A.T. Refunds
description: To the Editor:

title: Concerts to Fill Summer Air With Music
description: For classical music fans, there is something happening almost every week throughout the summer, starting June 14 when Pianofest opens its season. Based at Southampton College, the program, which brings advanced students from all over the world to the Hamptons for six weeks of coaching and performing, gets under way at 4 P.M. in the Avram Theater on the college's campus.

title: Community Theater on the Cutting Edge
description: NO surprise, summer theater in Westchester does not mean summer theater in Westchester, professionally speaking. But it thrives, with an artistic purpose, in nearby counties, as if to fill the void of the rest of the year.

title: No Stopping: What It Takes to Make a Bed and Breakfast Work
description: DIANE and Henry Tremblay are hoping that their bed and breakfast, the Manor House in Norfolk, will be their ticket out of the corporate culture.

title: Lines in the Sand: The Beach as Battleground
description: MOST of this oceanfront community vanished underwater in the 1980's and 90's when harsh storms washed away 190 homes, along with the narrow strip of sand on which they were precariously perched.

title: Commercial Property /Trinity Real Estate; Longtime Landlord Ponders Becoming a Developer
description: AS the subsidiary of an institution that is 302 years old, Trinity Real Estate tends to take the long view of things. For the last decade and a half it has been transforming most of the 5.5 million square feet of industrial buildings it acquired -- unwillingly -- during the 1930's into office space.

title: Places to Go, Sites to Visit and Numbers Galore
description: Here are organizations, addresses and phone numbers to help you get around the East End:

title: Jeffrey Geller and Leigh Dyson
description: Leigh Hudson Dyson, a daughter of Kathe and John Dyson of Manhattan, was married yesterday afternoon to Dr. Jeffrey Albert Geller, the son of Elisabeth and Herbert Geller, also of Manhattan. The Rev. John C. Harper, an Episcopal priest, officiated at the Flagler Memorial Chapel at the Millbrook School in Millbrook, N.Y. Rabbi Abraham Krantz took part in the ceremony.

title: Dryden's Drive For Success In Toronto
description: Ken Dryden is a tall man accustomed to high achievement. After entering the hockey Hall of Fame as a goalie, earning a law degree and prospering as an author and television documentarian, Dryden became president and general manager of the Toronto Maple Leafs, who are to hockey in English-speaking Canada what Notre Dame is to college football in the United States, only more so.

title: Summertime Is the High Season for Thieves, As Well
description: DON'T let the softness of summer days lull you into letting your guard down. Summer homes, especially those unoccupied for days at a time, are a burglar's dream. People who would never leave their car windows open or their keys in the ignition the other nine months of the year get careless during the summer. You may be on vacation but it is high season for thieves. By taking the proper precautions, crime-prevention specialists say, you can insure that no unpleasant surprises will interfere with your rest and relaxation.

title: Providence to Meet St. John's in Final
description: With two victories yesterday in the Big East Conference baseball tournament, Providence College continued to transform its lame-duck season into a possible storybook finish. At Waterfront Stadium in Trenton today, the Friars will play St. John's for the championship and an automatic bid to the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament. Rain is forecast.

title: Beyond Ice Cubes: Clever and Cool
description: AROMA STONES AND ESSENTIAL OIL

title: Raising Money, and Spirits, With Rock
description: THE claim has been made that more money is raised in the Hamptons in the summer than anywhere else in the country, and the winning formula is almost always the same: invite an A list of deep pockets to spend an evening dining and dancing in a tent decked out as a rain forest, an ocean liner or some other high-toned fantasy; bring in celebrity chefs with plenty of food, and charge a few hundred dollars per person.

title: Valerie Miller, Patrick Norton
description: Valerie Michelle Miller, the daughter of Marilyn and Philip Miller of Cedarhurst, N.Y., was married yesterday to Patrick Joseph Norton, a son of Lillian and Joseph P. Norton of Middletown, N.J. Judge Jay Stuart Dankberg, a retired judge of the Civil Court in Manhattan, officiated at Philip Marie, a restaurant in Greenwich Village.

title: Off Go Paul And Jamie, Realistic To the End
description: WHEN ''Mad About You'' began its seven-year run on NBC in the fall of 1992, a run that ends tomorrow night, it was seen on Wednesdays at 9:30 P.M., right after ''Seinfeld.'' The two shows seemed like a perfect match at the time: both were set in New York, both displayed an edgy comic sensibility pegged to the absurdities of everyday life, and both starred stand-up comedians known for their observational humor.

title: In a Climate of Fear, a Belgrade Serb Who Is Documenting the Horror of Kosovo
description: Much of the time in Belgrade, it feels as if nothing is happening in Kosovo. People complain endlessly about the NATO bombing, and they talk politics all day, but there is a large hole in the conversation. Barely anyone mentions Kosovo, let alone the horrors that are occurring there.

title: POSTINGS: Moderate-Income Housing; 22 Condos For Yonkers
description: Ground will soon be broken in Yonkers for the first moderate-income housing to be built under a decade-old desegregation order requiring the city to remedy years of confining its public and private subsidized housing in the southwest section of the city.

title: Celebrating Women's Success
description: Once the women numbered only eight. This week, 800 were at the annual Financial Women's Association dinner at the Grand Hyatt Hotel in Manhattan, honoring Abby Joseph Cohen, who as Goldman, Sachs's chief United States market strategist is Wall Street's most influential bull, and Charlene Barshefsky, the United States Trade Representative.

title: New Aquarium Flows From Denver to Asia
description: On June 21, Denver joins the growing list of landlocked cities that have aquariums. The aquarium, Colorado's Ocean Journey, will feature 15,000 specimens representing more than 300 species of fish, birds, mammals and invertebrates. Two exhibits will simulate two major waterways: the Colorado River and the Kampar River in Sumatra.

title: BENEFITS
description: An Alvin Ailey Assortment

title: Leslie Colin and J. J. Rosen
description: Leslie Ivy Colin, a daughter of Samuel A. Colin of New York and the late Roslyn B. Colin, is to be married this afternoon to Jerold Lee Rosen, the son of Hazel and Larry L. Rosen of Old Tappan, N.J. Rabbi Fredric S. Pomerantz is to officiate at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx.

title: There's a Striped Bass Invasion Off Manhattan
description: Bounding down Upper New York Bay under a soft May sun on Friday, New York Harbor alive with pleasure boats, ferries and tankers, it seemed a far better day for sightseeing than competitively chasing stripers. But at 3 P.M., Manhattan's first major striped bass fishing tournament had officially begun with a horn blast at Chelsea Piers. The first annual Manhattan Cup, a two-day competition designed to focus attention on the wealth of stripers that exists today in the Hudson River and New York Harbor, was under way.

title: The City Life; Surviving the Gowanus Canal
description: On a sunny afternoon recently, the green stuff shimmering in Brooklyn's Gowanus Canal looked a lot like water. It was a fairly viscous form of water, of course, with the occasional streak of putrescence that has made the Gowanus famous as one of the most unsafe and environmentally unsound places in New York City.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAKER, CLIFFORD M., JR
description: BAKER-Clifford M., Jr. 82, of Far Hills, NJ. Husband of Jane Myers. Son of the late Clifford M. Baker, Sr., and Margaret D. Baker of Plainfield, NJ, and predeceased by two brothers, John and Robert. He was a World War II Navy veteran, and a graduate of Princeton, Class of 1938. He is survived by four children, seven grandchildren, and a sister Katherine B. Aldridge of Burnsville, NC. Memorial service Tuesday, 11 AM, Lamington Presbyterian Church, Lamington, NJ. In lieu of flowers, the family requests contributions to Bonnie Brae, Millington, NJ 07946.

title: A Slice of New Orleans in Mount Vernon
description: WALKING into the Bayou, you might not immediately notice the 10-foot alligator skeleton hanging from the ceiling or the 50 brassieres dangling like a canopy over the bar. But once you hear the blues playing and smell the warm, spicy food, you will get the message.

title: Dana Klein, Michael Borkow
description: Dana Elyse Klein and Michael Andrew Borkow are to be married today by Rabbi Stanley Platek at the Plaza in New York.

title: Deluxe Ellingtonia: The Works, 24 CD's of Them
description: RCA's 24-disk ''Duke Ellington Centennial Edition: The Complete RCA Victor Recordings (1927-1973),'' released in honor of the 100th birthday of jazz's most celebrated composer, is the BMW of boxed sets. Stylish ly designed, handsomely engineered and strictly limited to an edition of 10,000 copies worldwide, it'll fill your jazz-loving friends and neighbors with high-octane envy -- assuming that you're prepared to drop $325, more or less, to own it. (Though the official list price is $407.42, many retail outlets are selling the set at a heavy discount.) But do you really need 24 CD's worth of Ellington? For that matter, does anyone need that many CD's by any jazz musician? And if so, is a boxed set the best way to acquire them?

title: Venice
description: Venice in June can be hell, and not just because of the heat and mosquitoes. St. Mark's Square and the Rialto are teeming with tourists, vendors and competing gondolas. The war in Yugoslavia has not yet dampened visitors' enthusiasm. While some cruise lines have changed their itineraries to bypass Venice, local officials have not reported any dramatic drop in hotel reservations.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Best Bet

title: Crime
description: The insular world of London's Docklands is less a picturesque backdrop than a living presence in KISSED A SAD GOODBYE (Bantam, $23.95), by Deborah Crombie, an American author with strong feelings for England's past. The guilty secrets of two families surface when Annabelle Hammond's lovely corpse turns up in the tall grass of Mudchute Park, on the Isle of Dogs. Annabelle may have been her father's pride and her fiance's darling as well as the driving force behind the family tea company, but she apparently seduced her sister's husband and had an affair with her father's archenemy. ''She can't have been all that perfect, or someone wouldn't have killed her,'' notes Duncan Kincaid, the sensitive Scotland Yard man in this series, who discovers that she also had an affair with her lover's son.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: THREE MONTH FEVER

title: Reunion With Wannstedt Lifts Johnson's Spirits
description: In the tumult of January, when Jimmy Johnson's mother died and he quit as the coach of the Miami Dolphins and then, in a flash, returned, Johnson called a friend: Dave Wannstedt.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GAFFNEY, MILLER SCHLAGER
description: GAFFNEY-Miller Schlager, 88. Died in Binghamton, New York on May 18, 1999. His first wife, Adelaide Smith Gaffney died in 1974. He is survived by his widow, Mary Collins Gaffney and by three sons, David M., Philip W., and James T. and by his sister, Marie G. Barry. He graduated from Princeton University Class of 1933. Following graduation from College, he became an investment banker for the Wall Street firm of Dicke & Merrill Smith in New York. He entered the Army in 1940 as a Captain of Field Artillery and served in China and Burma during World War II where he rose to the rank of Colonel. Also during this time he was employed by Lincoln First Bank where he was Executive Vice President and Director until his retirement in 1975. Funeral services will be held at Trinity Memorial Episcopal Church in Binghamton, New York on Tuesday, May 25 at 2 P.M. For information McDevitt Bros. Funeral Home, 8890 Front St., Binghamton, NY.

title: It's All Her Fault
description: THE First Partner

title: Now, If Only for a Week, Getting to Sand and Surf Is Still Summer's Dream
description: THE season along Connecticut's shoreline will not officially begin until Memorial Day, but Lynne Perrelli already has a tan fit for Labor Day. It is just past breakfast, and she is lounging on her deck overlooking Long Island Sound after a two-mile walk in the sand, which she interrupted to rescue three horseshoe crabs stranded by high tide.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRANDIS, ESTEL
description: GRANDIS-Estel. Wife of Eugene. Mother of Mitchell, Janice and Stuart. Grandmother of Melissa, Justin, Jeremy, Jessica, Chelsea and Jenna. All our love always.

title: Lodgings On the Cheap
description: GONE are the days when the family piled into the car and drove off willy-nilly, selecting roadside motels or cabins as they appeared. The tourist cabins on the blue highways are big resorts now, and in summer almost everything requires a reservation.

title: On the Beach, Cautiously Dipping Toes Into the Sound
description: JEROME COFIELD and Robert Bradham can smell summer coming, in the warm briny gusts blowing off the tidewater, in the muggy redolence of the salt marshes, and so they have been toiling to get their beach in shape.

title: Charleston
description: To the Editor:

title: Kelly Stein, Matthew Marcus
description: Dr. Kelly Ann Stein, the daughter of Barbara and Tony Stein of Boca Raton, Fla., is to be married today to Dr. Matthew Alexander Marcus, the son of Edith and Nathaniel Marcus of Long Beach, N.Y. Rabbi Loring Frank is to officiate at the Wyndham Miami Beach Resort.

title: A Tele-Miscommunications Deal
description: Jack Grubman, the telecommunications research analyst-cum-investment banker at Salomon Smith Barney, brooks no challenges to his status as one of the most influential analysts on the Street. For starters, Mr. Grubman, also one of the best paid, has the ear of Bernard J. Ebbers, MCI Worldcom's chief executive. Earlier this month, in voice-mail messages to clients, he made it clear that he regarded the circumstances surrounding the collapse of merger talks between Nextel Communications and MCI Worldcom as an affront.

title: School Contractor Under Scrutiny
description: Hundreds of preschool children who received speech, physical and other types of therapy found themselves without therapists last month after a company under scrutiny by school officials defaulted on its contract, Board of Education officials said.

title: Iran's Diplomatic Initiatives
description: Last week's trip by Iran's President, Mohammad Khatami, to three Arab countries was a revealing effort to ease Teheran's isolation from most of its Mideast neighbors. Mr. Khatami's tour got off to a disturbing start in Syria, the one major Arab country with which Teheran has maintained close relations since Iran's 1979 revolution. Among other things, Syria allows Iran to arm and train anti-Israeli Hezbollah guerrillas in Lebanon. Regrettably, Mr. Khatami met in Damascus not only with Hezbollah's leadership, but also with representatives of radical Palestinian groups that reject the peace agreements between Israel and the mainstream Palestinian leadership under Yasir Arafat. Iran's position is that it would accept any peace treaty with Israel agreed to by Mr. Arafat -- or by Syria's President, Hafez al-Assad.

title: Backtalk; McCaffrey Must Not Stop With Andro
description: Gen. Barry R. McCaffrey, President Clinton's drug policy adviser, called last week for the Federal Government to study the health effects of androstenedione, the over-the-counter supplement that became popular among children last year after Mark McGwire acknowledged using it as part of his training program. I congratulate McCaffrey for this long overdue action and for his leadership on the question of doping in sport. Androstenedione, better known as andro, is a steroid. Despite all disinformation to the contrary, it is neither merely a food supplement nor is it innocuous.

title: Mammals and Birds and Reptiles and Amphibians, Oh My!
description: WHEN European settlers arrived in Connecticut in 1633, they found its forests and wetlands teaming with deer, otter, fox, beaver, bobcat, rattlesnakes, wild turkey and bear, among others.

title: Youthful Optimism Powers Mormon Missionary Engine
description: With its utilitarian appearance and youthful population, the cluster of low-rise buildings in the shadow of the Wasatch Mountains here resembles a small state college. But its hallways are decorated with religious art, the campus bookstore does a brisk business in language textbooks and white button-down shirts, and the student body is turning over all the time.

title: Ms. Rosenbaum And Mr. Malis
description: Jessica Tara Rosenbaum, a Legal Aid Society lawyer, and Jonathan Martin Malis, an assistant United States attorney, both in Washington, are to be married in Great Neck, N.Y., this afternoon by Rabbi Mordecai Waxman.

title: Flight Patterns
description: THE MIGRATION

title: No One Cries 'Rat' as Officers Take Stand in Louima Trial
description: Listen hard for the slurs like ''rat'' or ''cheese eater.'' Listen again for the hissing anger that New York City police officers often show toward colleagues who tell on their brethren.

title: Sadness and Triumph Underlie Columbine's Pomp and Circumstance
description: The name Jeanna Park rang out today at the commencement ceremonies for Columbine High School. Miss Park stood up carefully and then started to walk toward the outstretched diploma, her gait slowed by a bullet wound in her foot and bullet fragments lodged behind her knee.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page picture caption last Sunday with an article about payments by drug companies to private doctors conducting research referred incorrectly in some editions to the document shown. It was part of a letter to a doctor from Clintrials Inc., a testing company working with Janssen Pharmaceutica, describing terms of a confidential research contract. It was not an advertisement.

title: Hitler's Other Battlefield
description: THE NAZI WAR ON CANCER By Robert N. Proctor. Illustrated. 380 pp. Princeton, N.J.: Princeton University Press. $29.95.

title: The Death of a Baby
description: To the Editor:

title: Blushing and Fumbling, Yet Very Sure of Himself
description: IS Hugh Grant the very model of a modern English gentleman?

title: A Ruling on Co-ops and Disability
description: THE New York City Commission on Human Rights has issued a wake-up call of sorts to property owners -- including co-op and condominium boards as well as landlords -- about discriminating against tenants with disabilities.

title: The Way We Live Now: 5-23-99: On Language; War Words
description: Every sailor enforcing a blockade knows the term of art for the warlike act of stopping a ship suspected of carrying contraband: board and search. However, in cutting off the supply of oil to Serbia, NATO's crack nomenclature specialists devised a more blockade-runner friendly term so as not to offend vessels being frisked. The new, sugarcoated pill of war: search and visit.

title: New Vending Machines Aren't Some Residents' Cup of Tea

They say the additions, put up by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, the insurer that owns the complex, are unattractive and may pose dangers.

title: Blair's Countercultural Plan for Welfare: Get Work
description: There were dozens of job opportunities listed at the shiny new Palmers Green job center in the far north of the city, but they were not of immediate concern to James Baxter, who has been unemployed for several months and gets about $:50 pounds a week, or $80, in dole money.

description: Shortcake is shorthand for family and childhood, which may explain why everyone has an opinion about it. Like religion or politics, shortcake discussions can turn dangerous in defense of a family recipe.

title: Drug and Alcohol Arrests Increase at Colleges
description: Drug arrests rose by 7 percent and alcohol arrests by more than 3 percent on college campuses in 1997, the sixth consecutive year of increases, according to a survey being released on Monday by The Chronicle of Higher Education, a national newspaper that covers education and academic life.

title: Invisible Hand
description: Next month, random house will finish the job that ralph Ellison never could. It will publish ''Juneteenth,'' a novel culled from the incomplete manuscript Ellison struggled with for four decades before his death, in 1994. The work's protracted gestation, in the wake of Ellison's 1952 classic, ''Invisible Man,'' was legendary. Portions of the manuscript burned in 1967, but Ellison refused to abandon it. Sections were published in small magazines and read by Ellison at lectures; in interviews, Ellison's sometimes expansive remarks (on other occasions he could be reticent and defensive) described a swelling manuscript of more than a thousand pages that seemed intended to encompass the entirety of black experience in this century. There appeared to be at least three plot lines, a dozen or more different narrators and a time scheme that, while centered on events taking place in the mid-1950's, spiraled back to the beginning of the century and looked forward to the tumultuous 60's.

title: Gifts From the Sea on Brittany's Menus
description: BRITTANY'S rugged, windswept northern border begins immediately west of Mont-St.-Michel. The weather here seems to change every five minutes, and the panorama transforms itself dramatically twice a day -- when the tide flows in and when it retreats.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POTTER, ZAIDEE TILLINGHAST

Born on August 10, 1902 in Gloucester, MA to Joseph John and Zaidee (Hedges) Tillinghast, Mrs. Potter graduated from the Winsor School in Boston. A recent resident of Venice, she had lived in New York City for 65 years. Her husband Dr. Philip C. Potter predeceased her in 1960. Survivors include three sons: Dr. Robert T. Potter of Manasota Key, FL; Philip C. Potter, Jr. of Greenwich, CT; Nicholas B. Potter of Hinsdale, IL; eight grandchildren & seven great grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at a later date. Memorial contributions in memory of Zaidee Potter may be made to Northern Adirondack Planned Parenthood, 66 Brinkerhoff Street, Plattsburgh, New York 12901 or to Village on the Isle Memorial Fund, 920 South Tamiami Trail, Venice, Florida 34285.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEIN, PRISCILLA CHAPMAN
description: KLEIN-Priscilla Chapman. Born October 28, 1926, in Connersville, IN, died May 21, 1999, after a long illness at the White Plains Hospital in White Plains, NY. Mrs. Klein, a graduate of Hanover College in Hanover, IN, was a member of the Junior League of Washington and New York, and a member of the Episcopal Church. She accompanied her husband, a foreign service officer, on his many assignments abroad in Asia, Africa and South America, and in Washington and New York, where he was assigned to the United States Mission to the United Nations. While her husband was stationed in Korea, she was a Gray Lady at the Eighth Army Hospital in Pusan, directed the Water Safety Program for American Dependents as a Red Cross Volunteer and worked with Korean Army paraplegics, victims of the Korean War. When her husband was stationed in Saigon during the Vietnam War, Mrs. Klein, not allowed to accompany him, lived in Bangkok, Thailand. On several ocassions she ''sneaked'' into Saigon where she lived under the alias Pamela Townshend and worked in a Vietnamese orphanage with children orphaned by the war. Later, in Washington, she did volunteer work at both the Walter Reed and Bethesda Naval Hospitals, tending wounded service men from the Vietnam Conflict. When her husband was assigned to New York, she served on the Mayor's Commission to the United Nations, greeting newly arrived diplomats and their families posted to New York. She spent 19 of the last 20 years living quietly in Elmore, VT, with her husband. Last year the couple moved to NYC. She is survived by her husband of 52 years, a daughter, Christine Scherman of NYC, a son, Kurt of Batavia, IL, a brother of Myrtle Beach, SC, and four grandchildren. Viewing Tuesday afternoon, May 25, at the White-Fiess Funeral Home, Morrisville, VT. Graveside services Wednesday morning, May 26.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIFSCHITZ, EVA
description: LIFSCHITZ-Eva. AMIT is deeply saddened by the passing of the beloved mother of Esther Landsman, our most devoted Associate Chairwoman of the AMIT National Board. A true Woman of Valor, Eva Lifschitz was a lifetime benefactor of our AMIT children and lived a life devoted to Torah, Israel, family and loving kindness, continuing the tradition of her mother Bluma Zisfein. She will be very much missed by all who knew her. Our hearts reach out with consolation to her beloved husband, the respected attorney Hyman Lifschitz, devoted daughters, Sheila (Rabbi David) Halpern, Esther (Dr. Stanley) Landsman, and beloved son, Joseph (Miriam) Lifschitz, and the many loving grandchildren and greatgrandchildren. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Evelyn Blachor, Nat'l President Marvin Leff, Executive Director

Mother of Claude D. ''Skip'' Watts of Wilmington, NC. Sister of Lillian Nelson of Sun City, AZ. Also survived by three grandchildren and four great-grandchildren.
