Contributions to Children's Center for Therapy and Learning, 15 Halko Dr., Cedar Knolls, NJ 07927, would be appreciated. For information call Mackey Funeral Home, 107 Essex Ave., Boonton, NJ, 973-334-5252.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   LIEF, LIBBIE
description: LIEF-Libbie 1908-1995 Remembered with love by her family.

title: A Marathon Of May Parties
description: Celebrating art, education and photography and welcoming a new chairman for the library.

title: May 16-22; Indictment in Terror Case
description: A former United States Army sergeant was charged with collaborating with Osama bin Laden in a worldwide terrorist conspiracy against Americans abroad. A Federal indictment described Ali A. Mohamed, 46, as a crucial aide to Mr. bin Laden, the Saudi exile who has been accused of masterminding two embassy bombings in Africa last year. Mr. Mohamed's lawyer said he planned to fight the charges.

title: A Bike Haven With a View And Near a Statue
description: I COULD probably get thrown out of my native habitat (Manhattan) for saying this, but I have never understood biking in Central Park. It's manic and crowded, and getting there, if you live more than a few blocks away, is no picnic either. Riding up Sixth Avenue or Eighth Avenue, following a bus, sucking up fumes.

title: Styles From the Dark Side of Summer
description: GONE are the days when sunglasses were strictly a summer accessory, reserved year-round for the most sought-after celebrities who hid behind their dark lenses in a quest for anonymity.

title: In the Region /Long Island; From Sandpits to Sand Traps, and Housing
description: FOR decades, it was known simply as the sandpits because years of sand mining had stripped off most of the vegetation. But now a 460-acre tract along West Shore Road in this unincorporated area of the Town of North Hemsptead has begun to turn a lush green.

title: Sports of The Times; Yogi Joins Some Famous Foes From Brooklyn
description: UP on the screen in grainy black-and-white film, the Yankees were playing the Dodgers in their six World Series from 1947 to 1956 and every so often Yogi Berra would appear, swinging a bat or in his catcher's mask. And now, in the Yogi Berra Museum's theater, Lawrence Peter Berra himself stood up Friday for his induction into, of all things, the Brooklyn Dodger Hall of Fame.

title: We're All Authorities
description: THE HORIZONTAL SOCIETY

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: Live By The Sword

title: Mind Over Machine?
description: Sometimes it's the hardware. Sometimes it's the software. And sometimes it's just human error. Computer mistakes, malfunctions and glitches, beyond the obviously misdirected E-mail, continue to spread faster than a computer virus. What are your own most humorous or horrific stories? Send them to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43rd Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and and may be published in any medium.

title: No Battle Over Bowery
description: To the Editor:

title: Bulls to Have First Choice In Mixed Bag
description: Winning the National Basketball Association championship six times in the last eight years proved that the Chicago Bulls and their general manager, Jerry Krause, could be good. Today they found out that they could be lucky, too, earning the No. 1 overall pick in this year's National Basketball Association draft.

title: How Narrow Is Too Narrow?
description: The western end of Eighth Street, between Broadway and the Avenue of the Americas, has been a shoe shopper's magnet for decades. But the narrow sidewalks are often crowded, and neighborhood groups are divided over a plan to widen them.

title: Making the Most of the Least Glamorous Roles
description: TO prepare for her part in the ballet ''Romeo and Juliet,'' Kathleen Moore didn't spend hours at the barre or stand transfixed in front of a mirror perfecting her arabesques. She hopped on a subway and looked at fat people.

title: Norma Desmond Had It Wrong: The Picture Makers Got Small
description: WITH his easy manner and casual dress, Dan Chuba looks more like a Silicon Valley nerd than a Hollywood mogul. But Mr. Chuba, at 38 already a veteran of special-effects wizardry, and his partners at Hammerhead Productions are counting on their mastery of digital technology to help them build the new model of the 21st-century Hollywood studio.

title: Hamm Establishes Scoring Mark
description: The American forward Mia Hamm became soccer's career leading scorer last night with her 108th goal in a 3-0 exhibition victory over Brazil in Orlando, Fla.

title: PULSE; Froufrou At the Cannes Festival
description: Hugh Hefner and his bunnies jetted in, but the 52d annual Cannes Film Festival wasn't the glamorous Riviera scene of old. Red carpets and private yacht parties aside, this year's style sightings may have left some cineastes wondering, Was that Cannes or Coney?

title: Courville Keeps Quest on Track
description: The championship of the Travis Invitational, one of the most prestigious amateur tournaments in the New York metropolitan area, has thus far eluded Jerry Courville Jr., a two-time member of the United States Walker Cup team and winner of a United States Mid-Amateur.

title: Christin Couture, William Hosie Jr.
description: Christin Anne Couture, a painter, and William Alexander Hosie Jr., a sculptor, were married yesterday at their home in Shelburne Falls, Mass. The Rev. J. Thomas Leamon, a Congregational minister, officiated.

title: Muddy Waters and Bessie Smith Come to Istanbul
description: EVERY Saturday night, radio listeners in Istanbul can hear a voice in heavily accented Turkish welcome them to another evening of blues music. The announcer says, ''Yalniz gercek blues caliyorum,'' which means, ''I only play real blues.''

title: Bad Inning Knocks Out Jones and Agbayani
description: Benny Agbayani's storybook stretch appeared to come crashing to an end yesterday, like the coach turning into a pumpkin at the stroke of midnight, even though it was only about a quarter to three in the afternoon at Shea Stadium. Agbayani, the Mets' rookie surprise, was carted away on a motorized cart after sliding into the right-field retaining wall and smashing his left knee on its concrete base.

title: Amid Turmoil, Knicks Talked With Jackson
description: Nearly a month ago, with the Knicks in disarray and in danger of missing the playoffs for the first time in 12 years, Dave Checketts, the president of Madison Square Garden, sensed disastrous regression for the franchise. In secret, he met with Phil Jackson.

title: There's No Getting Around the Gridlock
description: THERE are secrets closely held by people who live in the Hamptons, and some who visit, about certain back roads that artfully avoid traffic-clogged Montauk Highway, the main east-to-west road through the South Fork.

title: Miss Cragin, Mr. Heintz
description: Grace Sherlock Cragin, the daughter of Margaret and Stuart Cragin Jr. of Cos Cob, Conn., was married yesterday to Christopher Grover Heintz, the son of Laura and Bruce Heintz of Weston, Mass. Canon Sydney Woodd-Cahusac performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich, Conn.

title: If You Liked the Cheeses, Try the Uptown Salads
description: ''Our crowd is elegant and smart,'' says Pando Andonopulo, owner of the Ninth Avenue Cheese Market, near 43d Street. On Saturday, Mr. Andonopulo hopes to draw a similar crowd when he opens another store at 856 Ninth Avenue between 55th and 56th Streets.

title: VOTES IN CONGRESS
description: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey, and New York.

title: Amy Stevens, Mark Scanlan
description: Amy West Stevens, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Timothy M. Stevens of Pine Orchard, Conn., was married yesterday to Dr. Mark William Scanlan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James W. Scanlan of Westport, Conn. The Rev. Gary W. Smith, a Congregational minister, performed the ceremony at the Pine Orchard Chapel.

title: Midsummer Night's Idyll: Opera in the Orangery
description: AFEW years ago, after a long search through the English countryside, Wasfi Kani, a conductor, found the ideal location for a new summer opera festival. Ideal because it continues the English tradition of opera in a country-house setting, in this case, the Grange in Hampshire. An hour and a half from London, the Grange Park Opera opened for its first season last July, and will offer a second season this summer from July 3 to 18. (The 2000 season is expected to last three weeks, with three operas.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OECHLER, CONVERE M.
description: OECHLER-Convere M.., 87. Of New York, on May 13, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Henry J. Oechler, devoted mother of Hugh McAden and Henry, Jr., devoted mother-in-law to Joanne and Kathleen and devoted grandmother of James, Sarah, Joshua, Sean and Jack. Services will be on Monday, May 24 at 11 AM in St. James Episcopal Church, NYC. In lieu of flowers, the family requests contributions to The Rector's Discretionary Fund of the St. James Episcopal Church, 865 Madison Avenue, NYC.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: MANLY PURSUITS By Ann Harries. Bloomsbury, $24.95.

title: The Flight To Precious Plastics
description: FOR 15 years, the American Express Platinum card has stood alone among charge cards, offering its affluent holders valuable goodies from free companion tickets in first or business class on international flights to complimentary massages at chic resorts.

title: Ms. Sullivan, Mr. von Siemens
description: Fiona Frederica Sullivan and Constantin von Siemens were married yesterday afternoon by the Rev. Jerome Holland at Most Holy Redeemer Roman Catholic Church in New York.

title: A Slap on the Cyberwrist
description: ARTHUR LEVITT has talked plenty tough about policing the Internet.

title: The Way We Live Now: 5-23-99; Greenback Blues
description: I was in Ahmadabad, India, when I was 17, listening to a railway clerk explain that I could stay there forever for all he cared. So I squeezed a dollar bill into the filthy bundle of rupees I was toying with. Without missing a beat, the clerk heaved open a ledger and began combing it for late cancellations.

title: The Nation: Citizenship Has Its Privileges; The Court Resurrects A Civil War-Era Ideal
description: IN constitutional law, as in geology, things can look perfectly stable on the surface -- until the tectonic plates shift underneath.

title: San Francisco
description: To the Editor:

title: May 16-22; I'm Your No. 1 Fan, Hon. Really.
description: Elizabeth Dole said her husband, Bob, was in ''the family woodshed'' for his less-than-supportive remarks about her campaign for the Republican Presidential nomination published early last week in The New York Times. Mr. Dole even said he was thinking of contributing to one of her rivals, Senator John McCain of Arizona.

title: Summer Shares, by the Day: Low-Cost Allure of State Parks
description: RAY DOBBINS has never been one to close the gates just because it gets a little crowded at Orient Beach State Park, a 342-acre peninsula of wetlands and waterfront near the tip of Long Island's North Fork.

title: Corrections
description: An article on May 9 about restaurants in Bilbao, Spain, misstated the city's political status. It is the capital of the province of Vizcaya, not of the Basque Country. The capital of the Basque Country is Vitoria (or Gasteiz, in the Basque language).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHMAN, BUNNY (BERNICE)
description: FISHMAN-Bunny (Bernice). We loved our friend. She went away from us. There's nothing more to say. The poem ends. We loved our friend. Gerry and Paul Melinger

title: Memorial for Lucille Lortel
description: A memorial tribute to the actress, producer and theater owner Lucille Lortel will be held on Monday at 6 P.M. at the Lucille Lortel Theater, 121 Christopher Street, in Greenwich Village. Ms. Lortel died in April at the age of 98.

title: Dr. Beckerman, Ms. Ballenzweig
description: Susan Ballenzweig and Dr. Mark William Beckerman are to be married today at Pier 60 at the Chelsea Piers sports complex in New York. Rabbi Avi Winokur is to officiate.

title: Do Something -- Anything!
description: FREEDOM FROM FEAR

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTHENBERG, ROBERT
description: ROTHENBERG - Robert. The Board of Directors of the 360 East 72nd Street Owners Corporation extends deepest sympathy to their President, Harvey Rothenberg, and his family on the death of Harvey's beloved brother. Robert will be missed by Harvey, Judy and their children Anne and her husband Glenn, and Alan and his wife Suzy, who were a constant source of devotion and support during his illness. Dawn Pohl, Vice President Barbara Kumble, Secretary

title: Book Club Where Sisterhood Still Reigns
description: THE Palisades watch over the scene here, offering subtle clues to the passing of time. Ninety years ago women gathered on the hills overlooking the river to discuss books, watching, as the shadows lengthened on the Palisades, for the time to return home to their children.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; The King Is Dead? Never!
description: Fifty million Elvis fans can't be wrong -- or can they? In life, Elvis Presley was the king of contradictions: svelte and bloated; druggie and Nixon admirer; rebel and mama's boy; and, as Erika Doss, a professor of fine arts at the University of Colorado, Boulder, suggests in ELVIS CULTURE: Fans, Faith, and Image (University Press of Kansas, $24.95), a visual as well as an aural icon. Post-mortem, Presley seems omnipresent: Graceland, his home in Memphis, is the second most visited American residence after the White House; at last tally there were 525 official Presley fan clubs in 44 countries (contrasted to only 65 at the time of his death, in 1977), including the Snorkeling Elvises out of Key West, Fla., and there may be as many as 20,000 Elvis impersonators, or ''Elvii,'' as they are known. Doss interviews the most avid collectors of Elvis detritus, like Paul MacLeod of Holly Springs, Miss., who curates a museum of 10 million Presley items, and Kim Epperly, who maintains a dollhouse-sized ''Miniature Graceland.'' With images ranging from velvet Elvises to graveside offerings, the book itself is a remarkable Presley artifact. However, Doss presents a muddled tautology that the meaning of Presley's ''multivalent'' image is ultimately what we read into it. By focusing on Presley's face almost to the exclusion of his voice, she sidesteps how the dead legend speaks most directly to his legions of fans. Eric P. Nash

title: State Wineries Offer Promise and Quality
description: CONNECTICUT has carved out a clear-cut identity as a progressive, if small, wine region. In promise and quality, its wines resemble those of Mendocino County, Calif., in its earliest wine making years.

title: Jordan's King Makes Most Of His Visit To the States
description: Call him the unorthodox royal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAPIRO, HOWARD
description: SHAPIRO-Howard. The East End Hospice Board of Directors, staff and volunteers mourn the untimely death of Howard Shapiro, a valued friend and loyal supporter. We will be forever grateful to Howard for his dedication and commitment to East End Hospice and to the East End Hospice Open, a tennis tournament to benefit Hospice. We send our deepest sympathies to his wife Suzy, his family and to his many friends and colleagues. W. Michael Pitcher, President East End Hospice, Inc Westhampton Beach, NY

title: INSIDE
description: Hindsight on Gun Debate

title: Taking Time for a Look At Art in the Open
description: THE Connecticut landscape is dotted with works of sculpture that commemorate interesting personalities or charge their surroundings as artistic creations -- or perhaps might simply strike viewers as whimsical for being in a particular place.

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH: Kim Heirston; Meet, Greet, Buy, Sell
description: I KNOW being fabulous is a full-time occupation,'' Gregory Crewdson, an artist, said recently. ''But what exactly does she do?''

title: Ms. Sklar Meiskin And Mr. Shalam
description: Rebecca Karen Sklar Meiskin, a daughter of Ellen and Karl Sklar of Burlington, Vt., was married last evening to Ari M. Shalam, a son of Jane and John Shalam of Old Westbury, N.Y. Rabbi Michael White officiated at the Harvard Club in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WURZBURG, FREDERIC W.
description: WURZBURG-Frederic W.. On May 13, 1999, in Dover, NH. Devoted husband of the late Mary Stewart. Beloved father of Toni Viertel and Eric. Grandfather of Jessica and Joel Viertel, and Justin. Memorial contributions may be made to the Alzheimer's Foundation.

title: Ways to Be Safe, Rather Than Sorry
description: THE months of May through August ought to come with a warning label: Caution. Don't let summer's sunshine blind you to its dark side.

title: Strawberry Fields Are Not Forever. Enjoy Them Now.
description: BONA fide strawberry lovers manage to keep their appetites for lush, sweet berries in check until June, when the local crop begins to perfume the fields and farm stands. Then, like the corn connoisseurs who insist on sticking to the season to risk a lapse of no more than eight hours from picking to plate, they are yearly rewarded with an incomparable treat.

title: Anne Dziubak, Allan Gold
description: Anne Samantha Dziubak and Allan Robert Gold were married yesterday at the City Hall of the fifth arrondissement in Paris. Alexandre Baetche, the Deputy Mayor of the fifth arrondissement, officiated.

title: The Truth About Love
description: LATER AUDEN By Edward Mendelson. 570 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus& Giroux. $30.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAWRENCE, REV. DENNIS
description: LAWRENCE-Rev. Dennis. Of Old Greenwich, CT. Died May 13th. Ordained Deacon of the Anglican Church of the Advent in Greenwich. Fleet Chaplain Old Greenwich Yacht Club. Former member RAF Squadron 206. Survived by his wife Jane E. (Crusoe) Lawrence, daughters Hilary Lawrence, Avery L. Belicka, Alison L. Buxton and five grandchildren.

title: Indonesia's Election
description: To the Editor:

title: Pennies From Heaven (or Jars)
description: Good news for merchants in southeastern Missouri: the Great Cape Girardeau Penny Shortage is over.

title: Corrections
description: A music entry in the Summer Festivals listing on May 9 misidentified the conductor for the concert at the OK Mozart International Festival in Oklahoma on June 13. He is Pinchas Zukerman, not Itzhak Perlman.

title: Why Are We In Kosovo?
description: If only Susan Sontag's moral and political rationale for intervention in Kosovo (May 2) were also NATO's. Then nothing short of the trial of Slobodan Milosevic and his cronies for crimes against humanity would be an acceptable outcome. Instead, we hear daily excuses for the failure to engage in ground combat to end the expulsions, rapes and pillage of innocents. Evidently, what is at stake for NATO is simply its own prestige at age 50.

title: The Western Front
description: Certainly illegal guns were enabling instruments in the Columbine massacre, but I wonder if William Kittredge (May 2) has seen the transcripts released to date of the Web site and the diary of one of the boys who shot up the high school: poisonous diatribes so obscene, so filled with venom, spewed at such a wide range of potential victims that you are left gasping. You have to wonder whether the spirit behind the attractive face of this lad, so clever at conning his observers, was actually human. ''There is radical evil in the world,'' Susan Sontag writes in her article in the same issue.

title: Dr. Schlossberg And Mr. Goodman
description: Dr. Hope Robin Schlossberg and David Joel Goodman are to be married today by Rabbi Henry Glaser at the Rockleigh (N.J.) Country Club.

title: Schnittke, an Iconoclast, Becomes an Icon
description: IN a just world, Alfred Schnittke would not have been condemned to the purgatory of the Soviet Union for the first 56 years of his life. He would not have suffered a series of increasingly debilitating strokes at the outset of his most productive years. Nor would he have been taken from us last August at 63.

title: SOAPBOX; To Beat the Clock
description: EACH year that I have lived in New York City I have become more and more obsessed with saving time. My obsession began six years ago when I moved to Manhattan from Long Island, where I grew up. I don't save time to devote it to my job or any particular hobby. I feel that to justify the high price of living in Manhattan it must be convenient, more convenient than anywhere else in the world.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction; Slacker in the City
description: When Claudia Steiner is caught cheating on a fifth-grade math test, her mother, a Freudian psychology professor, offers this explanation for sending her to her room: ''It isn't the copying,'' she says, it's that Claudia's ''superego'' should be more developed by now. In Kate Christensen's breezy and confident first novel, IN THE DRINK (Doubleday, $22.95), Claudia -- who is now Swarthmore educated, living in Manhattan and on the verge of turning 30 -- still has some work to do in the superego department. Barely able to afford her studio apartment on her salary as a ghostwriter for a Park Avenue socialite-novelist, Claudia still can't control her spending sprees at Bloomingdale's. She frets about being single but lunges constantly at her longtime crush, a lawyer named Billy Snow, by whom she is sure to be rebuffed. To say nothing of her predilection for nips of vodka in the evening, the random swig from the bottle of gin stashed in her underwear drawer or the beers she might drink on the street while walking to a friend's apartment. While most of these attributes are common to the blithely miserable, self-aware but immature urban women who have become increasingly popular in recent literature, Christensen sends Claudia on a slacker odyssey that encompasses situations far more alienating than fielding nasty interoffice E-mails or gaining 10 pounds. With few and selfish friends, an evil boss, unavailable parents and a mean cat, Claudia takes her only comfort in impulsively grabbing what the city has to offer, and we're not talking about opera at the Met -- her city means East Village dive bars, a diet of chow mein and hot dogs and sex on the Christopher Street piers. Bridget Jones would be quaking in her loafers. Vanessa Grigoriadis

title: TIME RUNNING OUT FOR NATO TO PLAN A KOSOVO INVASION
description: Senior NATO officials say that within the next three weeks the alliance will have to face a decision about whether to prepare a ground force powerful enough to fight its way into Kosovo, one of the most fateful and uncertain steps of its 50-year history.

title: A Manhattan Variation on the Time-Share Theme
description: MILLENNIUM PARTNERS, the developer of the three mixed-use buildings known as Lincoln Square on Broadway in the West 60's, had a deal in mind for a property swap a few years ago that it thought the Chinese Government could not refuse -- and it didn't.

title: Booming Job Market Draws Young Black Men Into Fold
description: For nearly three decades, in good times and in bad, young black men with little education and few skills lost ground. Facing high unemployment, falling pay and persistent discrimination, a depressingly large number never really joined the work force or drifted out of it, getting by on handouts, hustling or crime.

title: Strange Bedfellows in the Inventory
description: AT Live Opera Heaven, the Three Tenors and the Fantastic Four join forces to pay the rent.

title: Political Memo; In Hartford, New Battleground for an Abortion Debate
description: For most of the decade, supporters of abortion rights at the Connecticut Capitol wanted little more than to bask in the state's reputation for friendliness toward their agenda. They had insurance -- in 1990, the Legislature had enacted the provisions of Roe v. Wade into state law, in case the Supreme Court ever reversed that decision -- and a vote on any other abortion measure was seen by women's groups as asking for trouble.

title: Tracy Ehrlich, Andrew Auchincloss
description: Tracy Lee Ehrlich was married last evening to Andrew Sloane Auchincloss at Wave Hill in Riverdale, the Bronx. The Rev. Richard Leonard, a Unitarian-Universalist minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Florida Democrats Feeling a Thorn
description: Ever since Senator Connie Mack of Florida announced that he would not seek re-election this fall, the political scene in the Sunshine State has resembled a free-for-all. No fewer than 12 people have expressed interest in replacing Mr. Mack, a two-term Republican, proving yet again that an open seat in politics is like honey to the bee.

title: Police Unit Gets a Bit of Glitz
description: THE SETTING -- Drinking wine and eating cheese and crackers, hostage negotiators from the New York Police Department basked in stardom at a reception held at the John Jay College of Criminal Justice on Monday evening. The gathering saw the premiere of a two-hour documentary, ''Talk to Me: Hostage Negotiators of the N.Y.P.D.,'' to be broadcast this evening on the A&E Network.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ASHMAN, ELEANOR (NEE WYLE)
description: ASHMAN-Eleanor (nee Wyle). Beloved wife of the late Dr. Hyman Ashman, beloved cousin, dear friend and patient. Mrs. Ashman attended the University of Rochester in the 1930's. She served as Executive Director of The Jewish Welfare Society. She then headed the Resettlement Program for European refugees at The Federation Of Jewish Charities in Atlanta and worked for The Jewish Welfare Fund during its annual fundraising drive. For over 30 years, she worked for The American Jewish Committee in the Community Services Dept. Mrs. Ashman voluteered for many years for The League For The Hard of Hearing, she served as friend of the Chamber Music Society at Lincoln Center for over 25 years. Mrs. Ashman will be sorely missed.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Poor blacks never lost faith in work, education and individual effort. What's different now is that they can do something about it.''

title: At Shepperton Studios, Stars in the Sand
description: When people think of Cleopatra, they usually think of the Sphinx and the Nile, of devastating sexual power, heavy geometric jewelry and an asp with a fatal bite. And if they are over a certain age, they probably also think of one of the most indelible Hollywood images of the last 40 years: a thickly made-up Elizabeth Taylor in a huge square wig and clunky gold necklace, canoodling adulterously with Richard Burton, the man who twice became her real-life husband.

title: Departure Delays
description: Just how ethical is it for an ethicist to use his column to espouse his political and social views on mass transit, vehicle safety and air and noise pollution? If Randy Cohen wishes to opine on such matters, he should write an Op-Ed piece.

title: Corrections
description: The Practical Traveler column on May 9, about defibrillators, misstated the telephone number for information about Red Cross classes for corporations. It is (212) 875-2024.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CHAIFETZ, CHARLOTTE
description: CHAIFETZ-Charlotte. Mom, although 14 years have passed since you left us, you are in our hearts and thoughts every day. Rest in peace. Love sons Barry and Alan, daughters-in-law Maureen and Lynn, brothers Daniel, Abraham and the family.

title: Another Shooting, Another Search for Lessons
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; For 76ers, the Taming Of the Shrewd Iverson
description: WHEN we made a run, they were chillin','' said Tyrone Hill, assessing the damage after his Philadelphia 76ers got whipped again by Indiana, 97-86, Friday night here in First Union Center. ''They're a veteran team. We're a young team. But we're learning.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SINGER, GOLDIE
description: SINGER-Goldie. Of Reseda, CA (formerly Queens). Beloved wife of the late Saul. Devoted mother of Rena Kaufman and Elliott Singer and four grandchildren. For info ''Wien & Wien'' 1-800-322-0533

title: PERSONAL BUSINESS: DIARY; Soapsuds With a Heart
description: With a big ''if,'' consumers would rather buy from a company that is involved in a social or charitable cause, a survey of 2,000 adults suggests. Roper Starch Worldwide in New York did the study for Cone Inc. in Boston, which does so-called cause marketing, linking companies to good works. Sixty-six percent of the respondents said they would switch to products of a company connected with a cause -- like Ford Motor, which sponsors breast-cancer research, or Home Depot, which helps with affordable housing -- if the price and quality were equal to those of rivals.

title: An Unspoiled Treasure, and Spiritual Home, in Groton
description: FOR years I spent my summer vacation lolling on the beach in southeastern Connecticut. Then I discovered Bluff Point.

title: Ms. Pan Marshall, Mr. Herszenhorn
description: Christina Marie Pan Marshall, a lawyer, and David M. Herszenhorn, a newspaper reporter, were married yesterday at the Church Center for the United Nations in Manhattan. Rabbi Roy A. Rosenberg performed the ceremony with the Rev. Gerald F. Carr, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: May 16-22; Demjanjuk Case Is Revived
description: Reviving a case that had deeply embarrassed the Justice Department's Nazi hunters, Federal prosecutors went to court again to strip United States citizenship from John Demjanjuk, a 79-year-old retired auto worker.

title: A Pushkin Celebration on His Family's Estate
description: Aficionados of Russian literature who are visiting Russia next month can join the anniversary celebration of the national poet, Aleksandr Pushkin. This year marks the 200th anniversary of the birth of the poet, who died in a duel in 1837. Pushkinskiye Gory, a town in the rolling green countryside of the Pskov region, about 225 miles south of St. Petersburg, that is the site of Pushkin's estate, Mikhailovskoye, is bracing for an onslaught of tourists for the festivities on June 6.

title: Getting an Answer
description: To the Editor:

title: The Zither Ploy
description: To the Editor:

title: Of Course Brooklyn Has Something to Read
description: To the Editor:

title: For Tom Hayden, Almost Old Times
description: He's back!

title: Streetscapes/The Andrew Freedman Home; A Retirement Home Built for the Formerly Wealthy
description: IT is the Grand Concourse's grandest building, a broad limestone palazzo set back behind a wide grassy lawn between 166th and McClellan Streets in the Bronx. But the building, paid for by the somewhat mysterious Andrew Freedman, is not a mansion or a museum. It is a home for the elderly, and it has an unusual history. The 1924 building, the Andrew Freedman Home, operated by the Mid-Bronx Senior Citizens Council, has its own signs of age, and of rejuvenation.

title: PULSE: HIS; Young, Urban And Glossy
description: Larry Flynt is putting out a new men's magazine next month. But if you're looking for buxom blondes dressed in nothing but their bare essentials, you'll be disappointed with Code, a sleek, upscale style magazine for African-American men that will hit newsstands in June. A California-based monthly, whose first issue features Samuel L. Jackson on the cover, it is aimed at readers 25 and up. Leaning more toward GQ than Maxim, Code will cover serious issues, ranging from police brutality to racism in the workplace. Columns like Bar Code and Dress Code offer advice on mixing martinis and picking out the perfect tie. The magazine's ideal demographic was on view at the New York launch party last Tuesday at Metronome, jammed with Salomon Smith Barney investment bankers and celebrities like the model Tyson Beckford and the actor Malik Yoba. ''We're not just performers, athletes or criminals,'' said Quincy Troupe, the poet, who is Code's editorial director. ''We're far more complex, and this magazine gives us an opportunity to redefine the black man's image, the way others look at us and the way we look at ourselves.'' LOLA OGUNNAIKE

title: A Multiplex of a Museum Turns On the Lights
description: THE Visavox was a proto-television device developed here in the 1920's by the electronics wizard Frank Sprague, founder of the Sprague Electric Company. The appliance was more accurately a personal cinema, synchronizing sound and image for the first time, but awkwardly requiring you to stick your head up inside a box. Among Sprague's more successful products before the plant closed in 1986 were capacitors that enable radio, television and other appliances to spring to life at the flip of a switch.

title: Van Gundy History Lesson: There's No 2-0 Sure Thing
description: Jeff Van Gundy remembers sitting next to Pat Riley and watching a promising Knicks post-season perish terribly at the hands of the great Michael Jordan. It was 1993, and the Knicks, seemingly en route to their first appearance in the National Basketball Association finals in 20 years, led their series with the two-time defending champion Chicago Bulls by two games to none.

title: Libraries Set Their Book Sales
description: IMAGES of genteel scholars and lovers of literature fly out the window when hordes of people gather like an army, camped out on lawns and in their cars the night before a major book sale at one of Connecticut's libraries.

title: Two Plays Illuminate Each Other and Their Author
description: THE British playwright David Hare, now at the Booth Theater in ''Via Dolorosa,'' his own one-man play about the Arab-Israeli stalemate, reports with some amused chagrin Dame Judi Dench's response to his performance, which marks his debut as a professional actor. A few blocks away, Dame Judi, a longtime pro and a legitimate Dame, is starring in Mr. Hare's ''Amy's View'' at the Ethel Barrymore. Though both productions were hits in London earlier, Dame Judi apparently hadn't had a chance to catch ''Via Dolorosa'' until she came to New York.

title: Landmarks Agency Votes to Protect Bird's Jazz Nest
description: For the last eight years, Judy Rhodes has sought to have city landmark status accorded to the four-story row house on Avenue B between Ninth and Tenth Streets where she lives and where Charlie Parker, the alto saxophonist who was a creator of bebop jazz, lived from 1950 until 1954.

title: The Way We Live Now: 5-23-99: Economics Of: Unemployment; Labor Pains
description: Alan Greenspan doesn't think you should get a raise. And he doesn't want you to feel too secure in your job, because otherwise you might demand that raise.

title: At Ivy, Women Are Welcome
description: To the Editor:

title: French Strikes At Museums Timed to Raise Tourists' Ire
description: French workers appear to be particularly skilled in timing their strikes to cause the most irritation. Last summer, just as France prepared to welcome tens of thousands of foreign soccer fans here for the World Cup finals, Air France pilots went on strike. This year, with warm weather finally announcing the start of the tourist season, it is now the staff of Government-owned museums and historic chateaus that are out on strike.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WIGOR, RUTH TAUB
description: WIGOR-Ruth Taub. 89. Died peacefully on May 16th, 1999 in Newport Beach, CA. She was a graduate of Brooklyn Law School, past member of the National Board of Hadassah and ardent Zionist. She worked for Israel Bonds and practiced law in NYC. Surviving are her daughter, Dr. Joyce Miller of Irvine, CA, her granddaughters, Lisa Marland of Irvine, CA and Kathy Weilerstein of Pelham, MA, her grandsons-inlaw, James Marland and Philip Weilerstein, her great-granddaughters, Shelby Marland and Kira Weilerstein, her brother, Arnold Taub, and sisters, Beatrice Corenthal, Florence Stein, Esther Goldfarb and Rosamond Cobert. Also surviving are her many loving nieces and nephews. Her life was celebrated by her family at her funeral service that was held at Cedar Park Cemetery in Emerson, NJ on May 19th, 1999.

title: Danielle Coppola, Edward Kilbourne
description: Dr. Daniele Coppola and Edward Judson Kilbourne were married yesterday afternoon by Msgr. Walter E. Nolan at St. Paul's Roman Catholic Church in Princeton, N.J.

title: A Summer Sampler for Day and Night
description: Today

title: Animals Need Help In Warm Weather
description: AS soon as people start making summer plans, they should start thinking about the needs of the family pet. The warm months that bring people such pleasure can be the most difficult for the four-footed set to endure. Helpless to influence their own environment, they depend on the foresight and concern of their owners.

title: The Chow Dynasty
description: The stingy reference to Tina Chow in Nell Scovell's article (April 25) about Michael Chow sent chills down my spine. How disrespectful to Tina's memory and how cold!

title: With Assets Pumped Up, Few Worry About Inflation
description: INFLATION is back: Not rising prices, except for an uncharacteristic spurt in April, but the perennial debate about the sacrifices that must be made when inflation does turn into a problem.

title: GOING OUT
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Not Sorry To Bother You at Home
description: Q. I'm a manager at a large corporation. I work long hours and regard my time away from the office as an invaluable chance to recharge and to relax with my family. But supervisors and colleagues call me constantly at home (or page me or call my cell phone), often asking that I rush back to the office. I can't just turn off my pager and cell phone, because I'm expected to be on call for emergencies. Increasingly, however, I am called about not-so-important matters. How do I cut down on these annoyances without having my dedication questioned?

title: The Past Is Gone, But Not Forgotten
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Americans Are Building a Camp But Few Kosovars Are Drawn to It
description: In a place called Fier there is a camp called Hope, and the Americans who are building the camp hope that thousands of Kosovo refugees will come to safety here until they can return to their homeland.

title: Checketts Says Jackson Was Contacted in April
description: After denying he had had any contact with the former Bulls coach Phil Jackson, Madison Square Garden's president, Dave Checketts, admitted during yesterday's Game 3 that he had used an intermediary this past April to gauge Jackson's interest in taking over as coach of the Knicks.

title: Prisoners Need Hope of Parole
description: To the Editor:

title: Jenkins Beats Thorpe in Playoff
description: BELL ATLANTIC CLASSIC

title: 2 Sites Are Evacuated After Bomb Scares
description: Investigations into two bomb scares yesterday in separate incidents in New Jersey led to the evacuations of an airport terminal and a shopping mall, the authorities said.

title: For Safer Drug Trials
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DWORETSKY, MARTHA
description: DWORETSKY-Martha. On May 22. Beloved wife for 55 years of Ephraim. Loving mother of Ray and Aliza, Harold and Laura, Eli and Rena. Cherished grandmother of Adena, Michael, Alan, Michelle, Ilana, Moshe, Shira, Tamar, Ariela, Asher and Nava. Devoted sister of Elizabeth Megoff. A true Aishes Chayil. Shiva being observed at the Dworetsky home in Bayside, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZUCKERMAN, GERTRUDE D.
description: ZUCKERMAN-Gertrude D. May 20th. Age 95. Widow of Dr. George Zuckerman, Assistant Superintendent of Schools, NYC. Survived by daughters Lorette Zirker and Nina Schindler. She will be truly missed by her six grandchildren and nine great-grandchildren.

title: Media Talk; TV Networks Using Strong-Arm Tactics
description: The deal-making became so intense inside the war rooms of the networks assembling their prime-time lineups last week that studio executives used terms like ''brutal,'' ''bloody'' and ''vicious'' to describe the action. They made it sound as if the process had become the television industry's version of Verdun.

title: For Latin Music, New Worlds To Conquer; English-Speaking Fans Discover a Spanish Voice
description: Ricky Martin, Ricky Martin, Ricky Martin. The name has become some sort of Gertrude Stein exercise since Mr. Martin put a match to the tinder of the pop-music world with his performance at the Grammy Awards in February. He has not dropped out of sight since, riding his hit ''Livin' la Vida Loca.'' He has become a symbol on two sexy feet of Latin culture's new mainstream status in the United States.

title: De La Hoya, Hindered by a Sprained Hand, Shows His Skills and Heart
description: Oscar De La Hoya's final left started around his knees and came looping over Oba Carr's right arm. With speed and force the punch landed on Carr's chin with a solid thud and sent him spilling to the canvas like a rag doll. Carr had felt that left hand all night. It had dropped him in the first round when he was caught with a hook to the jaw.

title: Providence Extends Last Season
description: When the game was over today and Providence College had completed its improbable run to the Big East tournament title, the senior co-captains, Marc DesRoches and Angelo Ciminiello, were called to accept the trophy at home plate. But they wouldn't go until the entire team had joined them on the walk, and the players crowded around the trophy, celebrating with smiles and hugs, saving their tears for another day. Providence's administration decided in October to disband the baseball team at the end of this season in a move to comply with Title IX, but the players have not given up. Today, they secured the goal that they had set when they learned that the program would be dismantled, and the 6-1 victory over St. John's provided the Friars with an automatic bid to the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament.

title: American Volunteer Finds Frustrations and Joy at Crowded Refugee Clinic
description: There are moments when the pure exhilaration of being here leads Dr. Jennifer Walser to wish she did not have to return to New York. But there are also moments when her efforts to alleviate misery are dwarfed by the sheer scale of the tragedy unfolding before her.

title: An Appraisal; A Stunning Pier Hotel Design Stands Out Amid a Flawed Plan
description: Sensationally great new building. First-rate park design. Half-baked master plan.

title: THIS WEEK
description: EVENTS

title: Serbs' Dark Humor Finds Many Targets
description: Residents of Belgrade, convinced that they are right to be fighting for Kosovo but weary of war, are telling jokes that capture their general mood of helplessness, irony and pessimism.

title: Going to a Gun Show on a Spring Sunday
description: It was a perfect day for rifle shopping. A lazy, hazy Sunday, when the gun show inside a building at the County Fairgrounds would be cool and dark and inviting.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARACCIOLO, CARMINE ''SKIPPY''
description: CARACCIOLO-Carmine ''Skippy''. The Playbill Magazine Sales and Editorial colleagues of our dear ''Skippy'' mourn his tragic passing and salute his joyful life which enriched us all. He lived his long life on Grand Street and his loving nature endeared him to the entire community. Heaven is surely a merrier place with his arrival.

title: The Big City; The Moochers From Upstate? Cut 'Em Loose
description: THE city's politicians are desperately trying to keep the bullies in Albany from taking away our commuter tax, but there's a much more lucrative way to preserve our fiscal honor. The revenue from the current tax is chump change compared with the billions that could be extracted from commuters if the city seceded from the rest of the state.

title: A Financial Player Who's a Master Of the Squeeze
description: Men who are highly successful in the financial world tend to do their work out of the public eye, and those among them who are bridge enthusiasts usually do their playing in similar seclusion. Jack Dreyfus, octogenarian founder of the Dreyfus Fund, is a regular in the tough money game at the Regency Club, 15 East 67th Street, in Manhattan. On the diagramed deal played there in February, he found a way to make a game by avoiding an obvious play.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: Machiavellian? To Some That's a Compliment
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DENMARK, BARBARA SHAW
description: DENMARK-Barbara Shaw. Of Eastchester, NY. On May 20, 1999. Wife of the late Joseph Denmark. Sister of Douglas T. Shaw of Pawling, NY. Loving aunt of three. Service and interment private.

title: Congress to Weigh What a President Is Worth
description: If the job were offered in the help-wanted advertisements, it might not sound very attractive:

title: Despite Tough Guys, Life Is Not the Only School for Real Novelists
description: The occasion for this piece is the publication by the University of Iowa Press of ''A Community of Writers,'' essays and recollections regarding the university's writers' workshop, collected and edited by Robert Dana, the poet and retired Cornell English professor. I taught full time at the workshop in 1965 and 1966 and began writing my novel ''Slaughterhouse-Five'' while there.

title: Aznalcazar Journal; Year-Old Spill Poisons Farms and Wild Food Chain
description: Jose Antonio Alvarez tours his domain, his voice breaking as he recalls the poisonous black mud that surged from the river and rolled across his farm in an unstoppable tide.

title: Kremlinology 101: The More Things Change . . .
description: Having fired a Government, squelched an impeachment drive and installed a colorless but loyal police commander as Prime Minister and potential successor, President Boris N. Yeltsin headed south on Friday for what his aides described as a well-deserved vacation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HICKS, RUTH ILSLEY
description: HICKS-Ruth Ilsley. 91, died May 9, 1999, in Menno-Haven, Chambersburg, PA. Born May 12, 1907, in Jamaica, Long Island, NY. Daughter of the late Shirley N.C. and Minnie Clarke Hicks. Graduate of Vassar College and Johns Hopkins University. From 1933-34, she was Assistant Curator of Classical Art at the Brooklyn Museum. She was Professor Emeritus of Classics at Wilson College, Chambersburg; and received the Linback Teaching Award and Eminent Educators Award. Burial will be in Norland Cemetery, Chambersburg. Memorials to Classics Collection, c/o Wilson College, 1015 Philadelphia Ave., Chambersburg, PA 17201.

title: Bertelsmann Chief Pushes Public Growth
description: In a drive to become a dominant force in the digital world and take advantage of investor enthusiasm for Internet stocks, the sprawling media conglomerate Bertelsmann A.G. is laying plans to take more of its on-line operations public.

title: Reporter's Notebook; A Sergeant's Testimony Turns a Trial
description: Early in the trial of the Abner Louima case, Marvyn M. Kornberg -- the pugnacious, streetwise defense lawyer -- exuded the brash confidence of someone who had everything under control. He assured reporters that his client, Officer Justin A. Volpe, would be cleared of charges of torturing Mr. Louima. Mr. Louima's internal injuries, Mr. Kornberg said, could have been the result of consensual sex with another man, and DNA tests would show that this was possible. Just wait and see.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Dividend Meetings
description: A partial list for this week.

title: Oracle Takes Aim at Two Small Software Rivals
description: Investors, analysts and customers of the Oracle Corporation have grown accustomed to hearing its executives make caustic remarks about competitors. Usually, they aim their sharpest invective at giants like the Microsoft Corporation and I.B.M. or top executives at those companies.

title: Refugee Flow Speeds Up; New Reports Of Evictions
description: Bringing fresh accounts of atrocities and worsening conditions inside Kosovo, more than 13,000 ethnic Albanians surged across the border here in the last two days, with possibly many more people behind them.

title: Save the Whalers?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAKER, CLIFFORD M., JR.
description: BAKER-Clifford M., Jr. 82, of Far Hills, NJ. Husband of Jane Myers. Son of the late Clifford M. Baker, Sr., and Margaret D. Baker of Plainfield, NJ, and predeceased by two brothers, John and Robert. He was a World War II Navy veteran, and a graduate of Princeton, Class of 1938. He is survived by four children, seven grandchildren, and a sister Katherine B. Aldridge of Burnsville, NC. Memorial service Tuesday, 11 AM, Lamington Presbyterian Church, Lamington, NJ. In lieu of flowers, the family requests contributions to Bonnie Brae, Millington, NJ 07946.

title: Congressional Budget Chaos
description: Congress's recent self-destructive budget maneuvering suggests no one with a guiding philosophy is in command. Last week the Republican leadership was pushing a budget blueprint that, if implemented, would slice tens of billions of dollars from vital domestic programs. At the same time, Republican lawmakers admitted that they lacked the votes to get these cuts passed in appropriation bills. Then, while preaching fiscal discipline, they passed a bloated emergency spending bill that tapped the surplus for pork-barrel spending that they say they deplore.

title: The Met Is Expanding Its Audio Tours to 6 Languages
description: Most weekday mornings for the last two months, Philippe de Montebello, the director of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, has been spending an hour or two speaking French, Spanish, Italian and German. It's all part of the job.

title: With Pitching Unsettled, Isringhausen Called Up
description: In an effort to bolster a starting rotation hit by injuries, the Mets recalled Jason Isringhausen from their Class AAA farm club yesterday and said he would start tonight against the Pirates in Pittsburgh.

title: Panel Seen Backing Use of Embryo Cells
description: A Presidential commission is expected to recommend that scientists using Federal grants be allowed to conduct a specific kind of research on abandoned human embryos, ending a three-year Congressional ban. The research, involving the embryonic stem cells from which all tissues and organs develop, could help those with Parkinson's and other diseases.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALPERN, GEORGE
description: HALPERN-George. The Officers of Women's League for Israel are saddened by the death of George Halpern, beloved husband of Estelle, a valued officer of long standing. We extend our heartfelt condolences to the entire family. Harriet Lainer, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OECHLER, CONVERE M.
description: OECHLER-Convere M., 87. Of New York, on May 13, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Henry J. Oechler, devoted mother of Hugh McAden and Henry, Jr., devoted mother-in-law to Joanne and Kathleen and devoted grandmother of James, Sarah, Joshua, Sean and Jack. Services will be on Monday, May 24 at 11 AM in St. James Episcopal Church, NYC. In lieu of flowers, the family requests contributions to The Rector's Discretionary Fund of the St. James Episcopal Church, 865 Madison Avenue, NYC.

title: The Executive Who Captured Telecom Italia
description: When Roberto Colaninno emerged earlier this year as the quarterback of Olivetti's plan to buy Telecom Italia, the biggest hostile takeover ever in Europe, people who follow business in Italy reacted with surprise, and then, after a quick reassessment of the man, with total comprehension.

title: Strange Bedfellows: Dudley and 14 Points
description: A hobbling Patrick Ewing was figuratively and literally on ice, playing sparingly and then soaking his tender left Achilles' tendon in a large bucket of ice. Dikembe Mutombo, the proud and gracious center of the Atlanta Hawks, could do no right on offense as his team fell into an 0-3 abyss.

title: Recommendation Is Near On Embryo Cell Research
description: After six months of deliberation, a Presidential commission is close to recommending that scientists supported by Federal grants should be allowed to conduct a specific kind of research on abandoned human embryos and that Congress should not block such research, as it has done for the past three years.

title: A Carnality of Pose and Preparation
description: Few stages have been prepped so well for a star as was the one at Tramps on Tuesday night for the tenor-voiced, rubber-bodied love ambassador Ginuwine.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIPPS, DONALD
description: LIPPS-Donald. On May 22, 1999. ''He was a prince among men.'' Loving husband of Roslyn and the late Sylvia. Adored father of Valorie and Patty. Caring stepfather of Howard and David. Devoted father-in-law of Bobby, John, and Randi. Most cherished and amazing poppy and grandpa Donald of Eric and Nancy, Jonathan, Scott, Elizabeth, Jenna, and Laurie. Greatgrandpoppy of Julia. Dear brother of the late Arthur, Esther, Frances, and Alice. Thank you for all the wonderful memories. You will live in our hearts forever and ever. We love you. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Monday, May 24, at 1 PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAPIRO, HOWARD
description: SHAPIRO-Howard. What does one say of a friend that could possibly express the multiplicity of that relationship? How, in a remarkably short time, we became bound by the gentle reins of friendship? Howard, we shall miss your winning ways on the tennis court, your enthusiasm for the motorcycle, your support for community activities, your creativity at work, your pleasure in being on the water, your thoughtful dinner conversation. We shall miss the irrepressible George Barton and the singular exploits of his youthful creator. We shall miss you in every way, and treasure the too few moments we shared with you. Your Westhampton Friends

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Suit Complicates Offering Planned by John Hancock

title: Jefferson's Descendants
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CORRIGAN, PAUL M.
description: CORRIGAN-Paul M. On May 21, 1999. Gifted writer. Beloved son of Consuelo Reyes Corrigan and Paul Korzevinski. Loving brother and mentor of Ethan Corrigan. Dear step-son of Arnold Corrigan. Loving and loved by innumerable relatives and friends. Funeral service private. Memorial service to be arranged.

title: Prisoners Need Hope of Parole
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITE, LT. COLONEL KENNETH ALAN K.
description: WHITE-Lt. Colonel Kenneth Alan K. St. J., C.D., Commanding Officer (ret'd), Toronto Scottish Regiment, Chairman (ret'd) Royal Trustco Limited. At Oakville, Ontario. On Saturday, May 22, 1999, in his 86th year. Beloved husband of 53 years of Joan. Loving father of Dr. R. Alan White, Peterborough; Kenneth R. White, New York; and the late C. David Crombie, Toronto. Adoring grandfather of Robyn, Bradshaw, Martha, Tara, Gregory, Tighe, Megan, Scott, Andrew, Emily, and Alanna. Funeral service at St. Jude's Anglican Church, 160 William Street, Oakville, Ontario, on Tuesday, May 25th at 11 AM. Contributions may be made to the Canadian Cancer Society, 20 Holly St, Suite 302, Toronto, Ontario M4S 3B1. Athlete, soldier, business leader and devoted family man, he served his country with energy, pride and integrity. A man of great accomplishment, generosity and compassion, he will be sorely missed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JULIBER, I. GERARD
description: JULIBER-I. Gerard. The clergy, officers and members of Temple Sinai of Roslyn record with profound sorrow the passing of I. Gerard Juliber. We grieve together with his beloved wife Roslyn and his children Ilene, Stanley, Lois and Jon, his grandchildren Scott, Melissa, Larry, Lisa and Missy, and great grandchildren. May his memory be a blessing. Rabbi Michael A. White Rabbi Norman Kahan, Emeritus Michael J. Paul, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BASTIS, CHRISTOS G.
description: BASTIS-Christos G. On May 21, 1999, at his home in Palm Beach, FL. Beloved and devoted husband of Josephine. Loving and supportive father of Betty, George, Christopher and Jason. Loving grandfather of seven and great-granfather of three. His strength, courage and determination was unyielding, and his great love of family, friends and life will always be cherished. We all love him and will miss him dearly. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st St., Monday and Tuesday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral services at The Greek Orthodox Cathedral of the Holy Trinity, 319 East 74th St., Wednesday, 10 AM.

title: Media; Network news magazine shows may look similar but each has its own personality traits.
description: THE list of television shows coming from just one producer this fall is impressive: ''Chicago Hope,'' ''The Practice,'' ''Ally McBeal'' and a new show called ''Snoops.'' Nobody produces more hours of prime-time programming than Michelle Pfeiffer's husband, David E. Kelley, right?

title: Compressed Data; Gateway's Concept: Think PC Petting Zoo
description: The entire personal computer industry is moving toward the direct-sales model, which is built on a one-to-one relationship with customers, build-to-order manufacturing, razor-thin inventories and higher profit margins.

title: INSIDE
description: Elderly Saudi Monarchy

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POPOVITS, SADIE
description: POPOVITS-Sadie. On May 23, 1999. Of Forest Hills, NY. Beloved wife of the late Edward M. Devoted mother of Sheldon and Ruth P. Amster, Herbert P. and Doris Sydney. Loving grandmother of Madeleine, Gary, Peter, Debra, Susan, Kenneth and Mara. Cherished great - grandmother of Adam, Joshua and Alexander. Services today, 1 PM, at New Montefiore Cemetery, Pinelawn, New York.

title: SERBS REINFORCING TROOPS IN KOSOVO CLOSE TO ALBANIA
description: As NATO enters its third month of air attacks, the Yugoslav military is sending fresh troops into Kosovo to reinforce positions near the border with Albania, alliance officials said today.

title: Treasury's Schedule of Offerings for Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week offers today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills, as well as a 52-week bill and a two-year note that will be auctioned tomorrow and Wednesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGEN, HARRY M.
description: BERGEN-Harry M. On May 23, 1999. Beloved husband of Florence (nee Kupiec). Loving father of Thomas and Harry. Devoted grandfather of Manuel, Matthew, Michael, and Christopher. Greatgrandfather of Stephanie. Visitation on Monday and Tuesday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM, at Michael's Funeral Home, 7922 Metropolitan Avenue, Middle Village, NY. Mass of Christian Burial on Wednesday, 10 AM, at Saint Raphael's Church, Long Island City, NY. Interment to follow at Calvary Cemetery.

title: Newsweek's Young Turk Turns Heads
description: Jon Meacham, a stolid fellow known in the Newsweek offices for his neatly combed hair and carefully chosen words, has a bust of George Bush on the shelf next to his desk. An authority on civil-rights history and World War II arcana, Mr. Meacham drinks Jack Daniels, loves to talk about his wife, Keith -- ''she's a real Mississippi Delta girl,'' he said -- and goes to church on Sundays.

title: Man Killed and 2d Hurt Close to Police Station
description: One man was killed and another was wounded early yesterday in a shooting that took place so close to a Brooklyn police station that the officers inside heard the gunfire and rushed out to help, the police said.

title: Coca-Cola's former advertising philosopher sees the end of marketing as he knows it.
description: CONSUMERS might not have guessed, but the death of Diana, Princess of Wales, had a profound effect on the marketing of Coca-Cola in the days that followed.

title: Budget Surplus Puzzle: Spend Today What Could Vanish Tomorrow?
description: Like athletes clutching a trophy, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and City Council leaders have held up New York City's $2.1 billion budget surplus in recent months as proof of their own financial prowess and the city's exceptional fiscal health.

title: 2 Marketers Select Agencies
description: Two advertisers have made decisions involving accounts in review.

title: 'Star Wars' Fans Give 'Menace' a Little Less Force Than Expected
description: That George Lucas film, in its first five days, broke a box office record or two and performed just fine. But expectations were dashed that what is perhaps the most eagerly awaited movie ever made would somehow turn into a bonanza that would crush every previous blockbuster.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-17

title: Smallpox Could Still Be A Danger
description: In 1986, when the world was becoming enthralled by perestroika, Mikhail Gorbachev signed a secret plan for a new Soviet weapons program. The five-year, $1 billion plan authorized Russian military scientists to turn smallpox and other deadly microorganisms into instruments of war.

title: Accounts
description: * Worldspy Corp., Ardsley, N.Y., to McCann-Erickson New York, part of the McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising unit of McCann-Erickson World Group, owned by the Interpublic Group of Cos., as the first agency to handle the on-line research and shopping service's account. Billings were estimated at $12 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAYAN, RABBI DOCTOR SOLEYMAN
description: DAYAN-Rabbi Doctor Soleyman. The Young Israel of Holliswood/ Holliswood Jewish Center is deeply saddened by the passing of its esteemed member, Rabbi Dayan. He was a brilliant Jewish scholar and clinical psychologist who led the Persian and Holliswood/Jamaica Estates Jewish communities to ever higher levels of spirituality. Survived by his wife Naima, son Isaac, daughters Yafa and Esther and three grandchildren. Burial in Jerusalem. May his family be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Marc Penner, Rabbi Norman Horowitz, Esq. Dr. Neil Stein Presidium

title: Complete Victory: Mets' Nickel in 9th Stuns Schilling
description: Curt Schilling, the major league leader in complete games, completed another one yesterday. But it was not exactly what he had in mind.

title: Sports of The Times; Focusing on the Game, Not on a Coach's Anxiety
description: THE modest office Jeff Van Gundy shares with the Rangers' coach, John Muckler, has only a television, a telephone and a desk. There is no nameplate on the door. The room has none of the warmth of the players' domain across the hall. Its walls are bare, except for a color photo of Mark Messier scoring in the 1994 hockey finals against the Vancouver Canucks.

title: Stunned Hawks Staring At Sweep
description: The Atlanta Hawks sat in the visitors' locker room at Madison Square Garden yesterday looking like Mike Tyson after his stunning loss to Buster Douglas. There were no bruises or black eyes, but the lifeless expressions that accompany shock were there in abundance.

title: Save the Whalers?
description: To the Editor:

title: Abortion Opponents in New Jersey Draw New Energy From a Strategy of Politics
description: After years of futile attempts to impose limits on abortions through protests at clinics and raucous demands for constitutional changes, abortion opponents in New Jersey have changed their strategy -- relying as much on petitions, polling and back-room political negotiations as on blockades and bullhorns.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Former Oracle Executive to Join Peoplesoft
description: Peoplesoft Inc. plans to announce on Monday that Craig A. Conway will become its president and chief operating officer.

title: A Court Becomes a Model Of Conservative Pursuits
description: The Federal appeals court based in Richmond, Va., has quietly but steadily become the boldest conservative court in the nation, in the view of scholars, lawyers and many of its own members who say the court has issued some remarkable rulings and taken a striking tone on several issues.

title: Equity Offerings Scheduled for Week
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: Commencements; Yale Graduates Urged to Heal Social Ills
description: Nearly 7,500 alumni, family members and friends came out despite frequent downpours today to attend Yale University's Class Day, the college's traditional preamble to its graduation ceremonies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ULLMAN, MARIE MICHAELSON
description: ULLMAN-Marie Michaelson. On May 22, 1999, after a long illness. President of the Ullman Devices Corporation of Ridgefield, CT. Beloved wife of the late Robert Ullman. Survived by her sister, Dorothy Gordon; nieces, nephews and many friends. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Tuesday, 1:30 PM. Interment to follow at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY.

title: Schools Look Hard At Lockers, Shirts, Bags and Manners
description: The members of the Coweta County Board of Education are not naive enough to think that they vanquished school violence two weeks ago when they voted to prohibit students from carrying book bags unless the bags were transparent or made of mesh.

title: Thin Support and Red Tape Mire New York City Development Zone
description: Nearly five years after the Clinton Administration chose parts of upper Manhattan and the South Bronx as a special target for economic development, the project has ground to a virtual halt, with millions of dollars going unused.

title: Essay; Clinton's Compulsion
description: We have a President who has a problem: he lies when he doesn't really have to.

title: Bringing a Noble Grandeur To a Low-Caste Temple Role
description: American Ballet Theater Metropolitan Opera House

title: Clinton Proposes Using Surpluses To Extend Family Leave Benefits
description: Seeking to expand one of his most popular programs, President Clinton said today that he would direct the Labor Department to explore ways to allow states to use surplus unemployment insurance funds to subsidize parents who take time off to care for a new child.

title: Man Is Charged in Fatal Brooklyn Fire
description: A 39-year-old homeless man was charged early this morning with setting the fire that killed three people in Brooklyn on Saturday, the police said.

title: Editorial Observer; Why 'Racial Profiling' Will be Tough to Fight
description: The ''racial profiling'' scandal in New Jersey has quieted down while civil rights lawyers and Federal officials mull over how to discourage state police from targeting and searching motorists based solely on race. Black New Jerseyans had complained for years about this practice and felt vindicated when the Justice Department threatened to sue if New Jersey did not work on a remedy. After years of stalling, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman conceded that some state troopers had deliberately singled out black motorists.

title: Save the Whalers?
description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CONCEPCION, RENE
description: CONCEPCION-Rene. Three years went by without you but your smile and your courage will always stay with those you loved. You'll be in our hearts forever. With love, Steven and Adolfo

title: Futuristic Family With Age-Old Subtext
description: TURN OF THE CENTURY

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KELLY, THOMAS CONNOLLY
description: KELLY-Thomas Connolly. Of Summit, NJ. On May 22, 1999. Graduate of All Hallows High School and Fordham University. Survived by his wife, Marguerite and his children, Thomas, Jack, Tracy, and Christy; and two grandchildren, Shaun and Clare. He is also survived by his sister, Catharine Kelly. A Mass will be held on Tuesday, May 25, 1999, at Corpus Christi Church, Chatham Township, NJ, at 10 AM. Visitation at Dangler Funeral Home, Summit, NJ, on Monday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Incarnation Children's Center or All Hallows High School, both New York City, would be appreciated.

title: Media Talk; Hearst Boldly Searches for an Editor
description: One thing's for sure: Bonnie Fuller is a woman with a lot of chutzpah.

title: Syracuse and Virginia in Semis
description: Syracuse conducted a clinic in all aspects of lacrosse yesterday, eliminating top-seeded Loyola, 17-12, in a quarterfinal match of the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I tournament at Princeton Stadium.

title: Sampras Is Preparing For the Red-Clay Wars
description: Never say never. That's the mantra Pete Sampras takes into the only Grand Slam event to defy him. Sampras's aversion to the French Open's red clay is reminiscent of Ivan Lendl's terminal allergy to Wimbledon's grass, and it's an aversion Sampras shares with a couple of unlikely soul mates, top-ranked Martina Hingis and 13th-seeded Andre Agassi. Like him, they have found Slam gratification every place but here at the clay-court marathon that represents the missing link in their Grand Slam biographies.

title: Garland for Understudy as Hasek Sits
description: A much-discussed feature of the new Air Canada Center is the corridor by the locker rooms, where fans from the rink-level seats can gather to see players walk to and from the ice. When visiting players are angry or fans are heckling, it creates some tension. And when a star player is out of uniform, unexpectedly, it generates a buzz of gossip that shoots like an electric current from the ground floor to the highest seat in the arena.

title: Courtney Love Shows Her Control by Letting Loose
description: Courtney Love was in control at Hole's Roseland show Tuesday night, and she clearly felt excellent about it. ''Let them up here if they're not insane!'' she instructed the guards helping her fill the stage with young fans as Hole played its smartly constructed set. Ms. Love hoisted admirers up herself when not riding the shoulders of a bouncer to shake their hands or orchestrating the dishevelment of her slippery evening dress. She showed the blend of raucous spontaneity and intense calculation that makes her a remarkable rock star.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  STARR, SAM
description: STARR-Sam. 5/24/89. Well, Darling, here we are. I feel your spirit with me at all times. I'm sure you are proud of Kim and Ivan: what courageous, honest, compassionate and loving adults they have become. I guess we've adjusted, and we have grown. Still, how we miss you. Your Nanc

title: When Spouses Ride The Campaign Trail
description: To the Editor:

title: Robert Rhodes James, 66, a Historian of Britain, Is Dead
description: Sir Robert Rhodes James, a British historian and biographer who had been a Conservative member of Parliament and an investigator of Kurt Waldheim's war record, died on May 20. He was 66 and lived near Sandy, in Bedfordshire, England.

title: 2 Works On Their 2d Time Around
description: For a composer with a new piece, the second performance is often more difficult to arrange than the first. The negative explanation is simple: performers and audiences learn their lesson at the premiere. The more benign attitude says that repetition makes the heart grow fonder.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''For anyone who has spent more than five days in Serbia, and wasn't drunk all the time -- which is hard, but spies should be sober for at least half-an-hour a day -- it should have been obvious that the bombing would set off a humanitarian catastrophe and empower this Government, maybe forever.''

title: Yanks Find Magic in the 9th And a Victory in the 10th
description: Magical. Joe Torre employed the word before today's game to describe the 1996 season, when the Yankees were not as invincible in winning the World Series as they were during the phenomenal 1998 season. It was an appropriate day to make the reference.

title: Boutros-Ghali's Book Says Albright and Clinton Betrayed Him
description: In a new book, former Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali lashes out at what he perceives as a betrayal by Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright and the Clinton Administration for denying him a second term.

title: A Reprise of the Creativity At the 1972 Stravinsky Festival
description: New York City Ballet New York State Theater

title: Congo's Weary Masses Lose Faith in Once Popular Rebel
description: When Laurent Kabila's army neared this capital two years ago to topple the country's long-ruling dictatorship, Bernardin Mungul Diaka urged residents to wear white armbands, wave white flags and greet the rebel leader as their liberator.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HENNESSY, THOMAS P.
description: HENNESSY-Thomas P. Of Lynbrook, suddenly on May 20, 1999. Beloved husband of Anne. Loving father of Susan Flood and Jennifer Hennessy. Cherished son of Elizabeth. Dear father-in-law of Joseph. Adoring grandfather of Katherine and Kevin. Also survived by his brother David. Family will receive friends Sunday and Monday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM, at the Flinch & Bruns Funeral Home, 34 Hempstead Avenue, Lynbrook. Mass of Christian Burial, Tuesday, 10 AM, at Our Lady of Peace R.C. Church, Lynbrook. Interment Calverton National Cemetery.

title: Macromedia Planning a New Internet Strategy
description: The multimedia software publisher Macromedia plans to introduce an Internet entertainment strategy on Monday based on a ''media player'' program, similar to player software developed by Real Networks, Microsoft and Apple Computer.

title: Save the Whalers?
description: To the Editor:

title: Market Place; A nasty fight with a former top aide may end up bruising the image of Michael Eisner of Disney.
description: THE financial feud between the Walt Disney Company's chairman, Michael D. Eisner, and his former lieutenant, Jeffrey Katzenberg, may have made headlines. But few of the customers examining Mickey Mouse backpacks or Disney T-shirts at the Disney Store in Times Square on Friday even knew a dispute was going on.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLANCY, KENNETH
description: GLANCY-Kenneth. Of New York City and Cagnes-sur-mer, France, on May 23, 1999. Loving husband of Maida, devoted father of Suzanne (Michael) Gallagher, proud grandfather and great-grandfather. Former CEO and President of RCA Records. Memorial donations may be made to the New School Jazz and Contemporary Music Program, 55 W. 13 St, New York, New York 10011.

title: Compressed Data; I.B.M.'s Deep Blue Has a Business Plan
description: Remember Deep Blue, the I.B.M. supercomputer that beat the world chess champion Garry Kasparov?

title: Editors' Note
description: An article on April 26 described disputes over access to public land in Montana. The article focused on a court dispute between the Combs family, which owns a dude ranch in Montana, and Jon and Scott Fossel, who own a 10,000-acre ranch near the dude ranch. The case centered on access to a Federal wilderness area through the Fossel ranch. The article said some newcomers to Montana were trying to limit access to public trails on their private ranches.

title: Patents; A chemist who languished in a prefeminist-era DuPont lab looks back on her invention of Kevlar.
description: WHEN Stephanie Kwolek went to work for the DuPont Company in 1946, it was the dawning of a synthetic era. Chemists were turning coal, castor oil and antifreeze into new plastics and products, many of which were for the ostensible benefit of womankind.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SACKS, SHIRLEY
description: SACKS-Shirley. How I miss those early morning telephone calls. Love Amy

title: KOSOVO UPDATE
description: COMBAT

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHEPARD, HAROLD JON
description: SHEPARD-Harold Jon. 48. Beloved son of June C. Shepard. Brother of Allyn C. Shepard. Nephew, cousin, godfather to Lily. Dear friend and colleague. Uncle to Tramp and Bonnie; and longtime companion of James L. Homan. Died on Sunday, May 23, 1999, at his Manhattan apartment of a glioblastoma multiforme brain tumor. A graduate of Columbia, Temple and Fordham Universities, Harold made his Broadway debut in the original production of ''Joseph and the Amazing Technicolor Dreamcoat.'' Respected and loved for his intelligence, wit, talents, and encyclopedic knowledge of opera-in addition to a kind and generous nature; he will be lovingly remembered in the hearts of all those whose lives he shared. A memorial service will be held at the Fourth Unitarian Universalist Society in the near future. Memorial contributions to the Harold J. Shepard Neuroscience Nursing Fund, c/o Dr. Cynthia Caroselli, Box 1507 at the Mount Sinai Medical Center or the Cabrini Hospice are suggested.

title: Chicago Museum of Science Sometimes Strays
description: Yes, its front lawn is newly filled with jumbo sculptures by Keith Haring. But no, the Museum of Science and Industry -- Chicago's special hometown blend of Barnum & Bailey, Popular Mechanics, Smithsonian Institution, Mr. Wizard and World's Fair -- has not suddenly gone arty.

title: TECHNOLOGY: Digital Commerce; Artists at the easel, collectors and investors on the prowl: Stories from the success of the auction giant Ebay.
description: IN addition to being the most important invention since fire, the commercial Internet is, apparently, the perfect parking lot for a global flea market.

title: Chicken Soup and Possible People to Marry
description: Subtlety is not Irene Nathan's middle name. Her first question at an encounter is likely to be, ''Are you Jewish?'' The second, ''Do you want to get married?'' Or maybe, ''Would you marry a goy?'' If so, that client is not for her.

title: Team Force Leads Funny-Car Series
description: Team Force continued its domination of the National Hot Rod Association's funny-car series yesterday at Raceway Park in Englishtown, N.J., with both John Force and his teammate Tony Pedregon, in Ford Mustangs, advancing to the third round of the Mopar Parts Nationals before rain forced the third and fourth rounds to be postponed until today. Force, the eight-time Winston funny car champion and winner of five events this season, posted a top quarter-mile time of 4.866 seconds at 315.93 miles an hour. TARIK EL-BASHIR

title: Lawsuit Revives Questions About Hancock
description: For months, the John Hancock Mutual Insurance Company had been steaming smoothly toward a major reorganization that would permit the sale of shares to the public, raising the likelihood of nice bonuses for policyholders and considerable wealth for some top executives.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALSH, GLORIA MONTERUBIO
description: WALSH-Gloria Monterubio. Died May 20, 1999. Survived by her son James, daughter Victoria, her brother Fred, and sister Rose. She was a Veteran of the U.S. Marine Corps in World War II and a graduate of Barnard College. Gathering of friends 7-9 PM, service at 7:30, Thursday May 27, Volk Leber Funeral Home, 789 Teaneck Rd, Teaneck, NJ. Donations in her name may be made to the charity of choice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MASSARSKY, REUBEN W.
description: MASSARSKY-Reuben W. Revered husband, father, grandfather, sibling, and friend, age 89, died on May 21, at 10:50 PM, at Saint Mary's Hospital in the city of his birth, Hoboken, NJ.
