Mr. Massarsky was both an active attorney-ar-law and counselor-at-law, having served at the bar for more than fifty years, operating as a sole practitioner. He distinguished himself also in his endeavors at investment assessment. He held the world's record for being the fastest man in the world in a 1928 championship track heat in the 440 yard classification at his alma mater, Iowa State. His athletic abilities turned to ice figure skating which he actively pursued until he was 75 years old. For his entire life he was an active scholar with particular interest in philosophy. He also wrote several short stories. He is survived by his wife of fifty-six years, Kaylyn; his son, Vaud; his grandchildren, Tara and Kurtlan; and his siblings, Bernard, Irving and Gertrude.

title: Media Talk; The Head of Fox's TV Studio Is on a Roll
description: The big personal winner when the television networks announced their fall shows last week was Sandy Grushow, the head of the Fox television production studio, Twentieth Century Fox Television.

title: Reviving Hopes for Mideast Peace
description: The election of Ehud Barak as Israel's next Prime Minister has created an encouraging new atmosphere for peace talks with the Palestinians and Syria. Though Mr. Barak's negotiating positions are not that different from Benjamin Netanyahu's, the new leader's more positive attitude has drawn favorable notices in much of the Arab world. Mr. Netanyahu saw the Oslo peace agreement as an obligation to be carried out as grudgingly as possible. Mr. Barak views carefully negotiated treaties as ways to make Israel safer and stronger. The Clinton Administration, whose relations with Mr. Netanyahu were always tense, now has a willing partner in efforts to complete the peace.

title: Eger Wins Easily
description: In a remarkable display of consistency and accuracy in adverse weather conditions, David Eger captured the Travis Invitational with a 4-and-3 triumph over Greg Rohlf in the championship match yesterday at rain-soaked Garden City Golf Club in Garden City, N.Y.

title: A Social Democrat Is Elected the New President of Germany
description: Johannes Rau, a moderate Social Democrat, was elected today to be Germany's eighth postwar President, a largely ceremonial post whose chief significance lies in its influence on the nation's conscience.

title: Selling Backpacks on the Web Is Much Harder Than It Looks
description: Head south on Interstate 5 from downtown Seattle and you cannot miss the huge terra-cotta office tower that commands the horizon from a nearby peak.

title: Belgrade's People Still Defiant, but Deeply Weary
description: The daily rock concerts in downtown Belgrade continue, because officials said they would until the bombing stops, but the audiences have dwindled from 10,000 to a few hundred.

title: Prisoners Need Hope of Parole
description: To the Editor:

title: Canon Plans to Expand Its Network of Dealers
description: Canon U.S.A., which has been nipping at the heels of the Xerox Corporation in the market for expensive high-speed copiers, is now trying to bite chunks out of Hewlett-Packard, Xerox and Lexmark in the market for slower cheaper printers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MONTGELAS, BARBARA TROW BRIDGE
description: MONTGELAS - Barbara Trow bridge. Of Darien, CT on May 18, 1999. Wife of the late Rudolph M. Montgelas. Mother of Michele, Daphne, Rudy, & Mark. Memorial Service will be held at St. Luke's Episcopal Church, Darien, CT on Monday, May 24, 1999 at 11:00 AM. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be made to: Person-to-Person, 1864 Post Road, Box 3128, Darien, CT 06820 or Guiding Eyes for the Blind, 611 Granite Springs Road, Yorktown Heights, N.Y. 10598.

title: The Torturers' Notebooks
description: The disclosure this week that a Guatemalan army officer kept detailed records of the murders of political prisoners helps expose one of the most brutal military regimes in recent memory. And it raises an interesting question. What makes such functionaries keep notes about the killings, torture and ''disappearances'' they perpetrate?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRUBMAN, HARRY
description: GRUBMAN-Harry. Loving father of Roberta Fink, Francine Grubman, Sharon and Stuart Reben. Dear brother of Irene Grubman. Devoted grandfather of Tara, Todd, Mark, Dayan. His long life was a celebration for all who knew him. Services were held May 23.

title: Shepherding a China Report Past the Partisan Routines
description: HE is something of a closet Renaissance man in the House, one who speaks Russian, savors Ayn Rand and seeks out the latest translation of Omar Khayyam. For a hobby, he reads book after book on mathematicians.

title: Pacers Bury the 76ers, And Then Praise Them
description: No one on the Indiana Pacers brought out a broom to signify a sweep over the 76ers this afternoon, or made any kind of motion that they had just cleaned house in the First Union Center. There was no strutting or boasting or chest-thumping.

title: Unveiling a Bold Vision for Brooklyn's Waterfront
description: To most New Yorkers, the little-used stretch of Brooklyn waterfront between the mighty stanchions of the Brooklyn and Manhattan Bridges is the stuff of faded picture postcards, vaguely recalling a majestic past but hardly worth the trip. With its abandoned Civil War-era warehouses, its cobblestone streets and a tiny state park, the area, known as Dumbo, commands sweeping views of lower Manhattan but few visitors.

title: Robert Doyle, 78, TV News Executive During NBC's Early Years
description: Robert Carr Doyle, a media executive whose work in television's early years ranged from charming President Truman to pondering what President Eisenhower had really meant to say in his responses at press conferences, died on Friday at a hospital in Bethesda, Md. He was 78 and lived in Chevy Chase, Md.

title: After Many Misses, Pentagon Still Pursues Missile Defense
description: After decades of flops, $100 billion in costs and sharp rises in the political stakes, the Pentagon is trying again to defend the United States against missile attack.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBS, HOWARD R.
description: JACOBS-Howard R. On May 22, 1999. Beloved husband of Janet. Devoted and loving father of Jodie and Brad, and devoted and loving father-in-law of Lori and George. Cherished grandfather of Brian and Ariel. Services Monday, 1 PM, at Gutterman's Funeral Home, Rockville Centre, NY.

title: Alumni Performers Return For a Doug Varone Premiere
description: Second Avenue Dance Company Tisch School of the Arts

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TENZER, DORIS
description: TENZER-Doris. Of Jupiter, FL. We mourn the loss of our dear cousin. Wife of Jay. Mother of Susan and Judith. Our thoughts are with you. Michael Tenzer Family Circle

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VON NESSI, PETER P.
description: von NESSI-Peter P. Of Mountainside, NJ. On May 22, 1999. Husband of the late Theresa (nee Fedorczyk) and the late Helen (nee Fedorczyk). Father of Peter P. von Nessi, Jr., Karen Vega, and Gregory von Nessi, Sr. Also survived by five grandchildren and two greatgrandchildren. Funeral in the McCracken Funeral Home, 1500 Morris Avenue, Union, NJ, on Wednesday at 9 AM, with a Mass in our Lady of Lourdes Church, Mountainside, NJ, at 10 AM. Entombment Holy Cross Chapel Mausoleum, North Arlington, NJ. Visiting Monday, 7-9 PM, and Tuesday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM.

title: Faces on TV Get Younger And Comedy Is Not King
description: The main impressions from the unveiling of new shows for the fall television season: The new shows you will be seeing in September will be filled with teen-agers, sex, gay characters and glamorous-looking white people; they will not be filled with comedy, adults over 40, rural characters and African-Americans.

title: At Louima Church, Hymns and Hopes for Trial's Reckoning
description: In a Pentecostal church in Brooklyn yesterday, hundreds of men and women from Haiti sang a traditional hymn in Creole about a clarion trumpet announcing the coming of Judgment Day.

title: When Spouses Ride The Campaign Trail; Too Good to Vote For
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; Hawks Find Knicks Are Too Fast to Hack
description: BEFORE yesterday's game at the Garden, the Atlanta Hawks' coach, Lenny Wilkens, suggested an ominous antidote to the new, high-flying Knicks: rock-'em, sock-'em basketball. Wilkens recalled a play in Game 2 last Thursday in Atlanta, when a Hawks player reached in on Latrell Sprewell and lightly fouled him. Sprewell scored anyway; Wilkens was angry because it hadn't been a hard foul.

title: Pilots Assert F.A.A. Ignores Safety Rule Airlines Oppose
description: The country's second-largest airline pilots union is accusing the Federal Aviation Administration of refusing to enforce a safety rule because many airlines find compliance too costly.

title: Farewell to Lakers, and to Forum
description: With precision and ease, the San Antonio Spurs helped the Los Angeles Lakers turn out the lights at the Great Western Forum by flipping the switch on the Lakers' season.

title: Jerkens, Mr. Upset, Has Mount In Belmont
description: Allen Jerkens, a trainer with a history of springing upsets, reared his head again yesterday at Belmont Park when his colt Best of Luck won the Peter Pan Stakes in the mud and thrust himself into the Triple Crown path of Charismatic.

title: The Wisdom of a Saudi King: Choosing an Heir to the Realm of Abdel Aziz
description: The King of Saudi Arabia, long ailing, is 78 years old. His designated successor, the Crown Prince, is 76. The Defense Minister, seen as next in line for the throne, is 75.

title: In Search of Free Library Access for All
description: In recent weeks, a public commission has been on the road, studying the future of New York's libraries and looking for ways to insure that all state residents have free access to their services.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TURTELTAUB, REBECCA SHALLIT
description: TURTELTAUB-Rebecca Shallit, the author, died Friday evening May 21, 1999, at St. Joseph's Hospital in Yonkers, NY. She was 89 and had been recently living at the Hebrew Home for the Aged in Riverdale. Born in Nome, Alaska, in 1909, she was the daughter of Charles and Bertha Shallit. Her father, a Russian immigrant, lived in Seattle, Washington, and Nome, where he was a gold prospector, mining engineer and surveyor. Mrs. Turteltaub, writing as Rebecca Shallit was the author of more than 100 published short stories. During the 1940's and 1950's these stories appeared in magazines such as McCall's and Mademoiselle, Seventeen, Woman's Home Companion, Redbook and others, as well as being adapted for television and included in short story anthologies. She was represented by Lurton Blassingame and Carl Brandt, prominent literary agents of the time. She was a graduate of the University of Washington in Seattle and did graduate work at the University of Minnesota in St. Paul. Married to the late David Turteltaub, she settled in New York to pursue her literary career. She is survived by a daughter, Ruth Rosenblatt of NY; two grandchildren, Paul Rosenblatt of Pittsburgh, PA, and Judy Rosenblatt of NY; two great-grandchildren, Lucas and Ella of Pittsburgh; and a sister, Myra Kurshan of Sands Point, New York.

title: The Up-and-Down Knicks Are Up and Thinking Sweep
description: In the middle of the Knicks' showroom floor of hot-rod players, with Latrell Sprewell and Marcus Camby all but painted with racing stripes, there stood Chris Dudley, like a Chevy straight from the days of sock hops and soda fountains.

title: A Belgian Film Wins Top Prize at the Cannes Festival
description: Accepting his award as best director tonight at this year's Cannes International Film Festival, Pedro Almodovar (''All About My Mother'') thanked his fellow filmmakers Atom Egoyan (''Felicia's Journey''), David Lynch (''The Straight Story''), Jim Jarmusch (''Ghost Dog'') and Arturo Ripstein (''No Letter for the Colonel''). Somebody had to do it, and this year's jury was not about to. The jury was headed by David Cronenberg, who at an early news conference had avowed a desire to favor offbeat films. But the judges, including Holly Hunter, Jeff Goldblum and the director Andre Techine, chose two simple, bleak films about suffering as the year's big winners.

title: Food for Thought
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHACKNAI, SELMA
description: SHACKNAI-Selma. On May 24, 1999 after a long illness. Wife of Gideon Shacknai, mother of Jonah Shacknai and Adam Shacknai. Recently retired, she was an educator and therapist during her adult life. She was educated at the University of Pennsylvania, Brooklyn College, Sarah Lawrence College and Bank Street College. Loving grandmother of Gabriele and Ethan Shacknai & sister of Natalie Strauss. She is also survived by her mother, Mitzi Robinson. Donations to the American Cancer Society in lieu of flowers will be appreciated by the family. Selma will be missed by her family and friends. Services today at 10 A.M., at The Reform Temple of Suffern, 70 Haverstraw Road (Route 202), Suffern, New York.

title: With Leetch in Fold for 4 Years, Rangers Set to Chase Top Talent
description: Now that the Rangers have accomplished their No. 1 goal and re-signed defenseman Brian Leetch, the team can focus on other ways to improve a team that failed to make the playoffs the last two seasons.

title: Prosecutors Move to Drop Cases Linked to Racial Profiling
description: Acting in what they called ''the interests of justice,'' prosecutors have moved to drop drug and weapons charges filed against 21 motorists by two New Jersey state troopers who have been indicted on charges that they singled out black and Hispanic drivers for stops and tried to cover up the fact.

title: Excerpts From Decision on Sexual Harassment
description: Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court's decision today holding school districts liable for damages if they fail to stop a student from the severe and pervasive sexual harassment of another student. The vote in Davis v. Monroe County Board of Education was 5 to 4. Justice Sandra Day O'Connor wrote the majority opinion, and Justice Anthony M. Kennedy wrote the dissent.

title: A Literary Executor Tidies Up Ellison's Unfinished Symphony
description: JUNETEENTH

title: The Phantom Of Albany Strikes Again
description: THE most hyped local event not linked to the new ''Star Wars'' film unfolded at the Sheraton New York Hotel yesterday. On second thought, this production could also have been called ''The Phantom Menace.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENSTEIN, RACHEL
description: ROSENSTEIN-Rachel. On May 22, 1999. Beloved wife of the late David. Loving sister of Emma Greenfield. Devoted mother of Melvyn. Cherished grandmother of Michael, Peter, Joshua and Tracy. Great-grandmother of Madeline and Ryan. Graveside service Wed11:30am, at Beth David Cemetery. For information, contact Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapels, 114-03 Queens Blvd., Forest Hills, N.Y. 718-263-7600

title: Foreign Affairs; A River Runs Through It
description: So here's my question for the day: Why is it (beyond issues of personal character) that Mikhail Gorbachev, Bill Clinton, Benjamin Netanyahu and Tony Blair engender so much passion, hatred and adulation from their supporters and detractors?

title: Big Board to Speed Plans for Evening Sessions
description: The New York Stock Exchange, which had been planning to expand its trading hours next year, is accelerating its timetable and could commence evening sessions as soon as this summer, the exchange's chairman said yesterday.

title: Did We Ever Really Try Diplomacy on Kosovo?
description: To the Editor:

title: Essex County Prosecutor Paints Bleak Financial Picture
description: The embattled Essex County Prosecutor, Patricia A. Hurt, said tonight that the budget proposed for her office this year by the County Executive would force her to lay off 52 people beginning next month and leave her unable to fill 41 vacancies.

title: Futures Brokerage Firm Settles Dispute Over Record Keeping
description: Refco Inc., a futures brokerage firm, will pay $8 million to settle allegations of record-keeping violations involving a California financial adviser.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; An Argentine 'Domino Effect' on Brazilian Stocks
description: When news of pressure on the Argentine peso started to scroll down the computer screens on trading floors here last week, traders mainly chuckled, stoking the historic rivalry between Brazil and its neighbor to the south.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: UNITED RENTALS INC., Greenwich, Conn., an equipment rental company, agreed to acquire Raytheon Co.'s Arayco Inc. rental unit, which has annual revenue of $25 million, and seven other companies with about $80 million in combined annual revenues. Financial terms were not disclosed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MONTGELAS, BARBARA
description: MONTGELAS-Barbara. The volunteers and staff of Guiding Eyes for the Blind mourn the passing of our dear friend and longtime supporter, Barbara Montgelas. Through her outstanding generosity, the lives of many blind and visually impaired individuals have been, and continue to be, forever enriched. We, and the blind community she touched, will miss her.

title: Corrections
description: An article on May 11 about airlines' plans to use jets for routes within New York State referred incorrectly to planes being acquired by Business Express, a unit of American Eagle. The line will acquire only 37-seat versions of a new Brazilian jet, not 50-seat versions.

title: Did We Ever Really Try Diplomacy on Kosovo?; Not a NATO Disaster
description: To the Editor:

title: China Shifts on How to Resettle Million People for Giant Dam
description: In an implicit admission that severe problems bedevil the giant Three Gorges Dam project, Prime Minister Zhu Rongji has announced a major change in strategy for resettling at least 1.3 million people who will be driven from their homes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REINGOLD, DAVID J
description: REINGOLD-David J. Of Delray Beach, FL. On May 22. Beloved son of Estelle and the late Jacob. Loving brother of Joel, Daniel and Michael and adored uncle of Joshua, Adam, Corey, Sarah, Rachel, Rebecca, Amy and Noah Reingold. We deeply mourn the loss of our dear son, brother and uncle whose warmth and kindness touched each of us in a special way. He will live on in our hearts forever. Services were held.

title: The Rhythms Are Free And So Is the Mood
description: The opening night of the Vision Festival on Friday defined both the New York flavor of free jazz (searing, chaotic) and the character of the crew that plays it (mystical, willfully vanguardist). In its fourth year, the 11-day free-jazz festival's new setting is a church basement, which is appropriately homey for the anti-commercial feeling of the gathering. Run by a group of musicians and artists, it remains the only sizable jazz festival in New York that operates without a corporate sponsor.

title: Protests Are Resumed by Families of Yugoslav Reservists Ordered Back to Duty in Kosovo
description: Protests have begun again in towns and villages in Serbia as army reservists, supported by their mothers, wives and other family members, have resisted orders to go back to Kosovo after a short leave.

title: LIFE AFTER WELFARE: One child's story; For 2 Improbable Pals, A Few Notable Weeks
description: With his brief career as a central-city grocer coming to a close, Tremayne Franks displayed the uncommon charms that have won him local renown.

title: In Cosmic Blasts, Clues to Black Holes
description: Frustrated by the mystery of gamma ray bursts, cryptic messages from what must be the most violent events in the universe, astrophysicists have for the last 30 years had reason to envy the certitude of Clarence Oddbody, George Bailey's guardian angel in the evergreen movie ''It's a Wonderful Life.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARON, MARILYN
description: BARON-Marilyn. Congregation Kneseth Israel, Far Rockaway, NY, mourns with heartfelt sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, and extends condolences to the entire family. Tzvi Flaum, Rabbi Ralph Pelcovitz, Rabbi Emeritus Noah Fleschner, President

title: G.M. Is Set to Spin Off Parts Division
description: The General Motors Corporation is pushing Delphi, its auto parts maker, out of the nest and into its shareholders' portfolios on Friday.

title: Albright Says Hussein's Foes Are Building Unified Front
description: Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright met leaders of Iraqi opposition groups today, the first encounter that she has had with such leaders and an indication of the Clinton Administration's efforts to build a more cohesive opposition against Saddam Hussein.

title: WHO Defers Destroying Stocks of Smallpox
description: GENEVA  Bowing to concerns that smallpox virus stocks be left intact to counter possible bioterrorist attacks, the World Health Organization agreed Monday to recommend delaying destruction of the world's last known virus samples until no later than the end of 2002.

title: In 4 One-Acts, The Soul Is Crushed At Every Age
description: Alienation for all ages is the cold, hard theme running through the second part of Ensemble Studio Theater's series of one-act plays. Whether expressed in the ambition-guided guile of young White House aides in Michael Louis Wells's ''The 'I' Word: Interns,'' the faithless despair of a stranded middle-aged tourist in Susan Kim's ''Dreamtime for Alice'' or the aimless ennui of the old in ''The Golf Ball'' by Frank D. Gilroy, the focus is the crushing of the soul by cynicism and disenfranchisement.

title: Checketts Admits He Met Jackson, Then Denied It
description: A conciliatory Dave Checketts acknowledged yesterday that he had met with Phil Jackson nearly six weeks ago, after denying on Sunday that he had met with the former Bulls coach for exploratory talks about potentially coming to the Knicks.

title: . . . While Some Americans Are Saying, 'Just Shoot the Man'
description: The arguments have become familiar and, despite their poignancy, so have the images. More than two months into the NATO bombing operation, people who said at the start that they were following every move now see the war over Kosovo as a story with a recognizable cast of characters and few plot surprises. The only mystery -- how it will all end -- is not gripping enough to sustain attention.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUSSMAN, LOIS PASTERNAK
description: SUSSMAN-Lois Pasternak. Of Palm Beach, Florida and Lenox, Massachusetts died on May 24, 1999 in the comfort of her home. Mrs. Sussman was the childhood sweetheart and loving wife of Richard Sussman to whom she was married for 54 years. She was the beloved mother of Steven Sussman of Roslyn, NY and Ellen Meyers of Worcester, Massachusetts; grandmother of Jennifer and Lori Sussman and Eric LeShay; sister of Elaine Italiaander and lifelong friend of Ruth Storyk. She was an extraordinarily elegant woman who loved her family and friends dearly and lived her life to the fullest. Her personal strength and courage were an inspiration to the many lives she touched. Contributions in Lois' memory may be made to the American Cancer Society, 235 South County Rd, Palm Beach, Fl. 33480.

title: PEARSON TO SELL BUSINESS BOOK UNIT FOR $82 MILLION
description: The British media company Pearson P.L.C. said yesterday that it had agreed to sell Jossey-Bass, a publisher of business and professional books, for $82 million to John Wiley & Sons Inc., taking another step in its plan to sell such businesses in the United States. Jossey-Bass publishes books, periodicals and on-line products on management of businesses and nonprofit institutions, as well as health care, psychology and other professional topics. Wiley is based in New York. Pearson said in January that it planned to divest itself of a number of reference and business and professional businesses.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DUNNINGTON, WALTER G. JR.
description: DUNNINGTON-Walter G. Jr. A gathering of friends celebrating rememberances of his life. The Chapel at Saint Bartholomew's, Park Avenue at 50th Street, 4:30 P.M., Wednesday, June 2nd, 1999.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on May 13 about Cox Communications' acquisition of TCA Cable TV misstated the scope of a previous agreement by Cox, involving Media General. Cox purchased Media General's cable operations in northern Virginia, not the entire company.

title: Wave of Albanians Flees From Pristina; Largest in Weeks
description: More than 10,000 ethnic Albanians fled from Kosovo into Macedonia overnight in the largest one-day exodus in three weeks.

title: High-Tech Plants May Threaten Us, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: Did We Ever Really Try Diplomacy on Kosovo?; Marshall Plan for Serbia
description: To the Editor:

title: MANAGERS AND INVESTMENT GROUP TO BUY ICF KAISER UNIT
description: ICF Kaiser International Inc., a provider of engineering, construction and consulting services, said yesterday that it had agreed to sell 90 percent of its consulting unit to the unit's management and a privately held investment group for about $70 million. ICF Kaiser, which is based in Fairfax, Va., said the sale would allow it to focus on engineering and construction. The consulting unit, which serves government and commercial clients, had revenue of $105 million in 1998. The investment group, CM Equity Partners, is affiliated with Carl Marks & Company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOFFMANN, WILLIAM L.
description: HOFFMANN-William L. On May 22, 1999. Of Basking Ridge, N.J. At age 84. Beloved husband of Catharine B. Loving father of John B. and James S. Hoffmann and Anne H. Moore and Ellen H. Wallop. Also survived by seven grandchildren. Reposing Tuesday 5-7PM only at the Brockett Funeral Home, Inc., 203 Hampton Road, Southampton, New York. Funeral service on Wednesday, 11:30 AM, at St. Ann's Episcopal Church, Bridgehampton,. N.Y. Interment Edgewood Cemetery.

title: When Kids Get Guns
description: To the Editor:

title: Olerud Only a Face In Crowd
description: John Olerud may have delivered the game-winning hit in the bottom of the ninth inning on Sunday as the Mets rallied from a 4-0 deficit to defeat Curt Schilling at Shea Stadium. But Olerud was merely another anxious traveler at La Guardia Airport yesterday afternoon. And an inconspicuous one, at that.

title: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING
description: AFRICA

title: Coke Pursues Scaled-Down Cadbury Deal
description: In the face of resistance from regulators around the world, the Coca-Cola Company scaled back its agreement yesterday to buy the soft-drink brands of Cadbury Schweppes P.L.C.

title: Did We Ever Really Try Diplomacy on Kosovo?; Try the Criminals
description: To the Editor:

title: Assault With a Fiscal Weapon; As Swindlers Branch Out, Victims Want to Be Heard
description: Myrna Barzelatto knows that what happened to her is not, technically, a violent crime.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Accounts
description: * Autoconnect L.L.C., Atlanta, to Doner, Southfield, Mich., as the first agency to handle off-line duties for the account of Autoconnect.com, an Internet-based used-car retailer. Billings were estimated at $15 million. Left Field L.L.C., San Francisco, handles the on-line duties. Autoconnect is a joint venture of Manheim Auctions, a division of Cox Enterprises Inc., and the Dealer Services Group, part of Automatic Data Processing Inc.

title: Isringhausen Returns for Mets, but the Result Is Sadly Familiar
description: There were flashes tonight of why Jason Isringhausen was once considered the future of the Mets' pitching staff.

title: Love's Power, Especially for Those Made of Snow
description: There is a great deal of music-treading in ''The Snow Maiden.'' Principal performers have only one extended chance at bravura dancing. And so they must rely on developing characters in this charmingly old-fashioned fairy tale ballet, created by Ben Stevenson to John Lanchbery's arrangement of Tchaikovsky scores. Two casts did just that when American Ballet Theater presented the ballet on Saturday afternoon and evening at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: Judge Finds Improvements In Procedures For Welfare
description: Finding that New York City had significantly improved the process for people applying for welfare, a Federal judge ruled yesterday that the Giuliani administration could expand its job center program, which encourages the poor to seek alternatives to public assistance.

title: IN HARSH TESTIMONY'S WAKE, OFFICER ACCUSED IN TORTURE OF LOUIMA TO PLEAD GUILTY
description: Confronted with devastating testimony by fellow officers and a crumbling defense, the policeman accused of torturing Abner Louima in the bathroom of a Brooklyn station house in 1997 will plead guilty to all charges today and throw himself on the mercy of the court, his lawyer told a Federal judge yesterday.

title: ESPN Sunday Night: Truth is Somewhere
description: Lawsuits are being lobbed so rapidly between Major League Baseball and ESPN that Bat Track technology may be required in Federal court to determine who slugs harder, Bud Selig, the baseball commissioner, or George Bodenheimer, the ESPN president.

title: 3 Venture Capital Firms Take Stake in Datek Online Holdings
description: Three prominent venture capital firms, including one financed by Paul G. Allen, a co-founder of the Microsoft Corporation, have agreed to jointly purchase a minority stake in the Datek Online Holdings Corporation for a total of $300 million.

title: Mr. Pataki's Public Safety Failure
description: Gov. George Pataki portrays himself as a law-and-order politician who makes public safety a top priority. The Governor is very vocal about his desire to keep even nonviolent prisoners in jail for longer periods of time. But meanwhile, on his watch, mentally ill people with histories of violent behavior are being sent to live in the community without adequate supervision.

title: Metro Business; Tribune to Buy TV Station
description: Tribune Company, part owner of the WB television network, said it agreed to buy a television station in Schenectady, N.Y., for an undisclosed price, and would convert its affiliation to the WB from the Public Broadcasting Service.

title: Doomed Lovers in Another Telling
description: The Swiss composer Frank Martin, who died at 84 in 1974, never fit comfortably into any particular heritage. Rigorous German aspects to his work are counterbalanced by a French restraint and feeling for color. He wrote in a shifting, highly chromatic harmonic language that occasionally incorporated 12-tone elements but never lost faith in the resources of tonality.

title: Editorial Observer; American-Style Capitalism Wins One in Italy
description: The battle for Telecom Italia has ended with the victory of an American-style leveraged buyout over a more genteel international merger of two former state monopolies. But it is far from clear that Olivetti, the victor, can successfully operate the Italian phone company.

title: Prized Goal: Coexistence
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FENNELLY, JOHN R.
description: FENNELLY-John R., 79. Of Eastchester, on May 23, 1999. Devoted husband of Suzette, loving father of John Jr., Keith E. (Irene), Suzette M. Keenan (Thomas), and Jolie-Marie Sherman (Scott). Adored grandfather of Tom Jr. (Christa), Justin, Margeaux, Shannon, Keith Jr., and Mark. The family will receive friends at the Westchester Funeral Home, Inc. Tuesday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian burial Wednesday, May 26, 10:45 AM, Immaculate Conception Church. In lieu of flowers, friends who wish may contribute to the Jansen Memorial Hospice, 69 Main Street, Tuckahoe, New York 10707 or the Immaculate Conception School, 53 Winterhill Road, Tuckahoe New York 10707.

title: National News Briefs; Emergency Inspection Ordered for Boeing 727's
description: The Federal Aviation Administration issued an emergency order tonight that airlines flying Boeing 727's must inspect wires in fuel tanks, replace them if chafing is found and wrap them in a protective layer of Teflon.

title: TOSHIBA TALKS WITH ELECTROLUX
description: Hit hard by an economic slump, the Toshiba Corporation of Japan is in talks with the Swedish appliance giant Electrolux about forming an alliance in refrigerators and washing machines. A Toshiba spokesman declined to give further details about the talks, adding that an announcement would be made once an agreement was reached. Nikkei News reported that the talks were centering on the two companies' supplying parts to each other and jointly developing new refrigerators and washing machines. The companies may also cooperate on sales and technology, the report said.

title: Library May Hire Company Cited in Suit
description: The trustees of the Jersey City Public Library plan to hire as consultants a private company that was scheduled to manage the library before a judge voided the management contract.

title: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: AMERICAS; MEXICO RETAILER EXPANDING
description: Mexico's largest retailer, Cifra S.A. de C.V., said it would invest $600 million to open 43 new stores by the end of next year. Cifra, which includes a department store chain, a restaurant chain, two supermarket chains as well as Wal-Mart and Sam's Club outlets, said the new stores would increase floor space by 30 percent. The company reported strong first-quarter earnings after nearly two years of sluggish growth. Cifra's 1998 sales were $5 billion. Rick Wills (NYT)

title: ZIFF-DAVIS CONSIDERING SALE OF MARKETING SERVICES UNIT
description: Ziff-Davis Inc., the No. 1 publisher of computer magazines, said yesterday that it is considering the sale of its marketing services unit to reduce debt and raise its stock price. Ziff-Davis, the publisher of PC Week magazine and the owner of the Comdex computer trade show, said it had hired the investment bank Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Company to explore options for the unit -- ZD Market Intelligence -- including a possible merger or sale. The company said it had received expressions of interest in ZD Market, but it declined to elaborate. Ziff-Davis also declined to disclose the unit's annual revenue. ZD Market provides marketing services to technology companies.

title: Arm the K.L.A.
description: Slobodan Milosevic can defeat NATO on any one of three fronts.

title: 3 Forwards Waived
description: The Liberty said yesterday that it had waived forwards Vanessa Nygaard, Bridgette Gordon and Dale Hodges. Nygaard spent last season on the injured list, recovering from knee surgery.

title: Yankees' Offense Stalls As O'Neill Is Slumping
description: Caught in the grips of a slump and gasping for hits, Paul O'Neill was asked yesterday if he had thought about quitting, and he smiled knowingly, as if a traffic jam of doubt filled all lanes of his mind each time he made an out.

title: Police Violate Privacy in Home Raids With Journalists
description: The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that the police violate ''the right of residential privacy at the core of the Fourth Amendment'' when they take journalists and photographers into people's homes to witness searches or arrests.

title: Wallace-Commercial Deal
description: Wallace Computer Services Inc., a printer of business forms, labels and other materials, agreed today to buy closely held Commercial Press Inc. to expand its commercial-printing business to the San Diego area. Terms of the cash-and-debt transaction were not disclosed. Wallace, based in Lisle, said the addition of the profitable Commercial Press increases the number of Wallace commercial printing operations to 25. Commercial Press, which prints annual reports, brochures and catalogues, has 200 employees and projected sales this year of $26 million.

title: RADISYS TO BUY TEXAS MICRO FOR $115 MILLION IN STOCK
description: The RadisysCorporation, which designs and makes computer systems for such things as bar-code scanners and automated teller machines, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Texas Micro Inc., a maker of computer equipment for industrial uses, for $115 million in stock. Radisys, based in Hillsboro, Ore., will pay the equivalent of $8 in stock for each Texas Micro share. The stock of Radisys fell $3 a share, to $31, while Texas Micro jumped 26 percent, gaining $1.25, to $6.125. Texas Micro is based in Houston.

title: In Aisle 3, Medieval Studies; Relic of Lost Era, Department Store Giant Is Reborn as a Graduate School
description: Right on the main floor, where generations of shoppers once fingered silks, velvets and embroideries, a new generation of students will soon be swarming to a library and a recital hall. On the second floor -- in the former domain of women's blouses, dresses and coats -- doctoral-candidate worker bees will study in a blocklong reading room illuminated by tall arched shop windows. And the Oriental rug department on the fifth floor will soon be the terrain of Medieval studies.

title: Did We Ever Really Try Diplomacy on Kosovo?; Lesson of Vietnam
description: To The Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOSEPH, HELEN H.
description: JOSEPH-Helen H. On May 22 at her home in Brooklyn, NY. Beloved sister of Gwendolyn Heyliager of Brooklyn, NY and Vivian J. Edwards of Raleigh, NC. She had just retired from The Associated Press where she had worked for over 35 years. She is also survived by a nephew, Seth C. Edwards of Brooklyn, New York, and niece, Jeanne Edwards of Providence, RI. Funeral services will be held on Thursday, May 27 at 9 AM at St. Phillip's Episcopal Church, 334 MacDonough Street, Brooklyn.

title: Ultramar Sells Some Operations in Michigan
description: The Ultramar Diamond Shamrock Corporation, the independent oil refiner and marketer, said today that it would sell its marketing and transportation operations in Michigan and close its refinery in Alma, Mich.

title: NATO Calls Transformers A Key Target In War Plan
description: Despite poor weather, NATO planes attacked electrical transformers throughout Serbia early today in an attempt to cut off the Yugoslav military communications and supply links to Kosovo, Pentagon and NATO officials said.

title: 2 Law Firms Plan to Bridge The Atlantic
description: Senior lawyers at Rogers & Wells in New York and Clifford Chance in London have voted to join forces in what would be the first overseas merger of large law firms.

title: Fired Substitute Teacher Had a Long Record
description: A Queens substitute teacher who was dismissed in March after an arrest had been hired by the Board of Education despite 14 other arrests dating back to 1977, a special investigator said yesterday.

title: New Look At Dieting: Fat Can Be A Friend
description: Now hear this: avocados, walnuts, salad dressings with oil, sauteed vegetables, fatty fish and some kinds of margarine may be back on the menu for health-conscious Americans, even for those trying to lose weight, if the findings of recent studies are to be believed.

title: Standing Up to E.P.A.
description: To the Editor:

title: Kenneth Donald Glancy, 74, A President of RCA Records
description: Kenneth Donald Glancy, a former president of RCA Records who helped foster the careers of such disparate artists as Woody Herman, Pierre Boulez, David Bowie and Cleo Laine, died on Sunday at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. He was 74 and had homes in Manhattan and Cagnes-sur-Mer, in southern France.

title: Killer Smallpox Gets a New Lease on Life
description: Smallpox, the ancient disease, was eradicated 20 years ago. Smallpox, the virus, is on death row, frozen in two highly protected laboratories in the United States and Russia. Like lawyers filing last-minute briefs, American scientists have come up with new arguments for reprieve.

title: TOYOTA PROFITS TUMBLE
description: The Toyota Motor Corporation, Japan's largest car maker, reported a 21.6 percent decline in profits for the year that ended March 31, despite more robust sales. The results partly reflected the company's increased stakes in the mobile telephone operator, the IDO Corporation, and the Daihatsu Motor Company, which were not included last year. Profits fell to 356.1 billion yen ($2.8 billion), from 454.3 billion yen a year earlier. Sales rose 9.2 percent, to 12.7 trillion yen. Toyota said it hoped to proceed with the long-awaited listing of its shares on the New York and London stock exchanges in the second half of this year. Stephanie Strom (NYT)

title: Bangladesh Earns First Points Ever
description: The West Indies posted a seven-wicket victory over New Zealand, and Bangladesh earned its first points ever in Cricket World Cup competition with a 23-run victory over Scotland yesterday in Southampton, England.

title: Moya Bounces Back, but Chang Can't Avoid the Exit
description: On the opening day at the French Open, the clay was a slippery place to conduct business.

title: U.S. and Uzbeks Agree on Chemical Arms Plant Cleanup
description: The United States and Uzbekistan have quietly negotiated and are expected to sign a bilateral agreement today to provide American aid in dismantling and decontaminating one of the former Soviet Union's largest chemical weapons testing facilities, according to Defense Department and Uzbek officials.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  UNGAR, GEORGE
description: UNGAR-George. Passed away May 21, 1999. Beloved husband of Susan Von Rohony Ungar. Father of Vivien Stern, Joan Silverman Sanchez and Kimberly Rhodes. Grandfather of Tracy, Dana, Russell, Dylan and Evan. Great grandfather of Sarah and Will. A courageous survivor of the Holocaust. Successful entrepreneur & builder. Services will be held Wednesday, 12:15PM, at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: INSIDE
description: A Chinese Spy Story

title: Knicks Put the Hawks Away And Breeze to Eastern Finals
description: The Knicks' remarkable transformation from a team teetering near collapse a month ago to one with a chance to turn its season into something special continued last night as they emphatically claimed Game 4 to sweep the Atlanta Hawks and take this second-round National Basketball Association playoff series.

title: History Counsels Caution on Diet Pills
description: The weight-loss drug Xenical, approved last month, had barely reached the market when Web sites selling the drug sprang up to tap into the intense consumer demand that accompanies the debut of anything marketed to make people lose weight.

title: Unspoken Question With Hasek Concerns Starting, Not Stopping
description: Darcy Regier understood the unspoken implication of the question. Regier, the general manager of the Buffalo Sabres, was being asked about the injury to Dominik Hasek, his star goalie, who missed Game 1 of the Eastern Conference finals with a groin injury. Hasek missed practice today because he was back in Buffalo, visiting doctors for extensive testing. And Hasek could miss Game 2 against the Toronto Maple Leafs on Tuesday night in Air Canada Center.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BASTIS, CHRISTOS
description: BASTIS-Christos. The Board Of Trustees and the Staff of the Brooklyn Museum Of Art record with deep sorrow the passing of long-time friend and generous supporter of the BMA, Christos Bastis, a member of the Museum's Advisory Council of the Board Of Trustees. He was a member of the BMA's Egyptian, Classical, and Ancient Middle Eastern Art Council, an area in which he was an important collector, as well as a donor and lender to the Museum. Robert S. Rubin, Chairman

title: Norman Rossington, British Actor With Roles Onstage and in Film, 70
description: Norman Rossington, a veteran British character actor whose career embraced films, theater and television, died on Friday in a hospital in Manchester, England. He was 70.

title: When Kids Get Guns
description: To the Editor:

title: Equal Coverage of Physical and Mental Ills Is White House Goal for Federal Employees
description: The Clinton Administration intends to require that private health insurance plans for Federal employees provide coverage for severe mental illnesses comparable to that for physical ailments, say Administration officials and Tipper Gore, who is heading a White House conference on mental health next month.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENJAMIN, WILLIAM
description: BENJAMIN-William. On May 23, 1999. In Pembroke Pines, Fla. at 92 years. Beloved husband of his adored late wife Ida. Dear father of Marlene Scherr and Myrna (Micki) Kleeman and father-in-law of James Kleeman. Cherished by his grandchildren Mitch, Randy and Linda, and their spouses Laura, Deborah and Frank, and his great-grandchildren Corey, Brian, Sarah, Allie, Elizabeth, Daniel and William who loved their Poppa Willy. Also survived by his brother, Harry. Graveside services at Riverside Cemetery, Rochelle Park, N.J. Tues., May 25 at 1PM.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Old Masters' Voice Is in 6 Languages

title: Court Backs Privacy
description: By taking reporters and photographers with them into homes to watch searches and arrests, the police violate ''the right of residential privacy at the core of the Fourth Amendment,'' the Supreme Court held in a unanimous ruling.

title: Dallas Evens the Series
description: STARS 4, AVALANCHE 2

title: In Tests on People, Who Watches the Watchers?
description: In H. G. Wells's novel ''The Time Machine,'' a flourishing, modern civilization is maintained by an unseen underground tribe that carries out its work behind the scenes.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: ORANGE JUICE RISES. Orange juice rose on concern about dry weather in Florida and the discovery of a new variety of fruit fly. In New York, frozen concentrated orange juice rose 2.7 cents, to 87.90 cents a pound.

title: A Shift in the Spotlight
description: They acted as if he were not even in the same courtroom.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARX, VIRGINIA WISE
description: MARX-Virginia Wise. Born May 26, 1905 in St. Louis, MO, died May 23 at White Plains Hospital in White Plains, NY. Beloved wife of Leonard. Sister of Muriel Ducibella, Jane Smith and Rudolph Wise, Jr. Loving mother of Leonard Marx Jr., Mary Lynn Bianco, and Jennifer Gruenberg. Mrs. Marx was a tireless volunteer on behalf of children and families. She earned a bachelor's degree in psychology from Washington University and a master's degree in child psychology from Teachers College at Columbia University. She is survived by six grandchildren; Richard Marx, Nancy Marx Better, Ned Solot, Claire Solot, Wendy Gruenberg and Jon Gruenberg, and by five great-grandchildren; Carolyn Cohen, David Better, Charlie Better, Sarah Better and Griffin Kehl. Funeral services will be held at Congregation Kol Ami/ JCC, 252 Soundview Avenue, White Plains, NY, Wednesday, May 26th, at 10:00 am. In lieu of flowers, the family requests contributions to the Virginia Marx Children's Center at Westchester Community College or to the Virginia and Leonard Marx Lecture Series at Teachers College of Columbia University.

title: Oil Flowing to Yugoslavia Despite NATO's Exertions
description: As part of the campaign against President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia, the Clinton Administration and NATO have tried to cut off his oil supply and his bank accounts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEENAN, MARIE T.
description: KEENAN-Marie T., 74. Died Saturday in White Plains surrounded by her family. Marie was an inspiration to her three daughters Terry Keenan Kass and Linda Erin Keenan of Manhattan, and Joellen Keenan Gardner of Albany. She worked full time running her own business and still found plenty of time to be a loving mother. Marie was especially devoted to her four grandsons James Patrick Keenan, Nicholas and Andrew Gardner, and Benjamin Keenan Kass. She will be dearly missed by her two surviving sisters, and 18 nieces and nephews. Friends can call from 4-8 PM Tuesday at the Hearley Funeral Home in Albany, NY. Funeral services will be held on Wednesday at 10 AM at St. Mary's Church in Albany.

title: High-Tech Plants May Threaten Us, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: Barnesandnoble.com Raises $450 Million
description: Barnesandnoble.com Inc., the on-line bookseller owned by Barnes & Noble Inc. and Bertelsmann A.G., raised $450 million yesterday in an initial stock sale that tapped into investors' belief that the company will challenge Amazon.com Inc.

title: Gandhi's Choices: Be Indian, and Lead Party
description: On Friday, the eighth anniversary of former Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi's assassination, his widow, Sonia, canceled all her speeches, donned a white sari bordered in black and made a sorrowful visit to the memorial where he was cremated.

title: Hawks Had Bravado But Knew It Was Over
description: The Atlanta Hawks talked tough before Game 4, just as they had before this mismatched series began. Dikembe Mutombo, who had guaranteed that Atlanta would win the series, went on and on about how he would muster up the fortitude to avoid being swept last night. Grant Long, reminding reporters that the Hawks had made more free throws and more steals and grabbed the same number of rebounds as the Knicks, boldly proclaimed, ''Don't throw dirt on us yet.''

title: Van Gundy Could Feel The Truth
description: JEFF VAN GUNDY probably did not need to be told it was true, that Dave Checketts had been talking to Phil Jackson. Van Gundy could feel it, right between his shoulder blades, from the lack of enthusiasm at the top of the organization.

title: First Lady Raises Money for Someone Else
description: Amid new indications that she is preparing to move to New York to run for the United States Senate, Hillary Rodham Clinton returned to Manhattan last night as the featured speaker at a political fund-raiser for Representative Nita D. Lowey -- the Westchester Democrat who is hoping that Mrs. Clinton does not run, so that she can.

title: New King of Jordan Asserts Syria Wants Peace With Israel
description: King Abdullah of Jordan, ending his first visit to America since ascending the throne, said yesterday that he believed that Syria was now ready to make peace with Israel and that once Israel's new Government was installed, there would be ''quick movement'' toward peace.

title: Sanitation Department Hints of Flexibility on Plans to Export Trash
description: A top Sanitation Department official signaled yesterday that the city was open to working with community groups on how to export its residential garbage, suggesting that it might not be committed to building huge waste transfer stations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENTHAL, EDYTHE
description: ROSENTHAL-Edythe. Of Forest Hills, N.Y. On May 20, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Sidney. Mother of Norman and Larry. Grandmother of Lynn, Randi, Marshall, Paul and Marc. Great grandmother of Laura, Katie, Daniel, Hailey, Jordan and Miriam Shira.

title: Hospitals Face Lawsuit by Kin Of Victim In Subway Push
description: The family of Kendra Webdale, the Manhattan woman pushed to her death in front of a subway train, will file a lawsuit against the hospitals that discharged the mentally ill man charged with killing her, the family's lawyer said yesterday.

title: Writing Songs (Sometimes Even for Real Instruments)
description: In a thoroughly memorable and rare New York performance, Tom Ze, a small, earthy, 62-year-old Brazilian, sometimes shouted his songs like a coffee shop radical on a conspiracy rant. Sometimes he cooed them like a doting grandmother, and sometimes he made brave stabs at the romantic samba crooning of the 1930's. He wasn't a graceful dancer: he crouched, moving like a puppet operated from the elbows. And for rhythmic effect he gargled water into the microphone.

title: Earle Palmer Brown Wins Top Ace Award
description: Earle Palmer Brown in Philadelphia took the Best of Show award last week at the 29th annual Ace Awards ceremony.

title: BRITISH ECONOMY STALLS
description: Figures released by the Office of National Statistics showed that British economic growth ground to a halt in the first quarter, the first time that has happened since the second quarter of 1992, the end of the last recession. The data raised expectations that the Bank of England, which has cut interest rates by 2.25 points, to 5.25 percent, since October, would cut rates further this summer to stimulate growth. Analysts said they expected a gentle resumption of growth. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Murder Charge Weighed In Death of Merchant
description: The authorities plan to bring murder charges against a robber who tied up the owner of a newsstand over the weekend and left him in a bathroom, where he died, apparently of a heart attack.

title: I.B.M. Is Selling Off Its Leased Computers
description: The International Business Machines Corporation, the world's No. 1 computer maker, is selling its leased computers and related equipment in a plan to save $400 million to $500 million in the next four years.

title: Turning the Tables on School Choice
description: CHICAGOAllow me to propose a thought experiment for my fellow Democrats. Imagine Trent Lott puffing himself up in the well of the Senate and announcing a new Republican education proposal. (Another Republican Senator can be substituted here; Jesse Helms would work nicely.)

title: After Littleton, Gun Industry Sees Wider Gap With the N.R.A.
description: After years of depending on the National Rifle Association to carry their fight, many of the nation's largest gun makers are breaking free of their powerful patron, supporting limited gun-control measures they hope will ward off lawsuits and more sweeping gun restrictions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOHERTY, MATILDA ANN (NEE MULLEN)
description: DOHERTY-Matilda Ann (nee Mullen). On May 24th in her 89th year. Beloved mother of Ann & Dan DiPietro, Jim & Gerry Doherty, Joan Doherty & Bob Neuhoff & Eileen & Kevin Heneghan. Loving Nonny to Daniel, Justin, & Gillian DiPietro, Jimmy III & Shannon Doherty & Jeremy, Kim, Tara, Jessie, Luke, Keira, Jena & Kaci Heneghan. Devoted sister to Mary Ellen Voccoli & the late Woody Mullen. Friends May visit at the R. Stutzmann & Son Funeral Home, Inc. 224-39 Jamaica Avenue, Queens Village, NY. Wednesday 2-5 & 7-10 pm. Funeral mass Thursday, 9:45 am at Our Lady of Lourdes R.C. Chapel. Internment at Long Island National Cemetery, Pinelawn, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations to the charity of your choice would be greatly appreciated.

title: The Rapids Get Ahead By Moving Forward
description: The Colorado Rapids, under the direction of Coach Glenn Myernick, have a six-game winning streak primarily because they take the most direct route to the goal every time they have possession. They scored a 2-0 victory over the MetroStars on Saturday even though the MetroStars had the ball 56 percent of the time.

title: It Ends Not With Bang, but a Whisper
description: The sign of an end to a case alleging singular police brutality came quietly late yesterday afternoon, in a courtroom whisper.

title: Vietnam Awash in Graft Trials, but They Don't Clean Up Graft
description: Just before a huge corruption trial began here this month with 77 defendants, including powerful bankers and business executives, local reporters were taken aside and handed envelopes of cash worth more than a month's pay.

title: High-Tech Plants May Threaten Us, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: IRELAND BANK TALKS
description: Ireland's largest bank, the Bank of Ireland P.L.C., and Britain's sixth-largest mortgage lender, Alliance and Leicester P.L.C., confirmed that they were considering a merger. The combination would create a lending institution with assets of $103 billion, making it the fifth- largest mortgage provider in Britain and the largest in Ireland. The possible merger, which the banks said would create $320 million in savings and strengthen profits, requires approval of the Irish and British banking authorities.

title: Corrections
description: A table in Circuits on Thursday comparing Internet service providers referred incorrectly to one service, Erol's. The RCN Corporation acquired Erol's last year and now serves Boston, Philadelphia, New Jersey, Delaware, Rhode Island, Virginia, Maryland, New Hampshire, New York and Connecticut as RCN.com; the service does not operate under the name Erol's in those areas. The Erol's service covers only the Washington and Baltimore metropolitan areas. The number for service outside Baltimore and Washington is (800) 746-4726.

title: Nelson Mandela: Man, Leader and, of Course, Legend
description: The title ''legend'' is generously handed around these days, used especially in television as a synonym for the hour's celebrity. So calling Nelson Mandela a legend is an inadequate tribute. Careful though he is of his image, he also guards his privacy and is too aloof to pander to the tabloids. Even many who acclaim him as an authentic hero of our time know little about him other than that he was held as a prisoner of apartheid for almost three decades and that on his release in 1990 instantly became his nation's pre-eminent politician.

title: Some Shape Up by Surfing the Internet
description: For various reasons, including a busy schedule and two herniated discs in my neck, I got out of shape. Or, more specifically, I got into another shape altogether.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEINBERG, SYLVIA
description: STEINBERG-Sylvia. Bnai Zion, the fraternal Zionist organization, mourns the loss of Sylvia Steinberg, a longtime member and wife of Harry Steinberg, Founder and Chairman of ''Writers and Artists for Peace in the Middle East,'' with which we have had an ongoing relationship. She was an ardent supporter of Israel and a lifelong exponent of social justice. She will be sorely missed by all who knew her. We express our profound sympathy to Harry, her children and grandchildren. Hon. Alan G. Hevesi, National President Mel Parness, Exec. Vice President Raymond M. Patt, Honorary Chair

title: N.A.A.C.P. Chief Rules Out Running for Mayor of Baltimore
description: Ending months of uncertainty over his future, Kweisi Mfume said today that he would forgo running for mayor of Baltimore to remain as president and chief executive of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.

title: Deutsche Telekom Lost More Than Just Telecom Italia
description: It is still Europe's biggest telephone company and it still seems intent on spending billions of dollars on acquisitions around the world.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIKET, JAMES JR.
description: SIKET-James Jr. Of Hampton Bays, Retired Executive Director of the NYC Board of Elections. Died on May 23, 1999 at the age of 84; for 62 years beloved husband of Louise (Antal); Loving father of the late James Michael Siket and survived by his daughter-in-law Debra Siket; Dear brother of Elizabeth Schiffer. Also survived by his granddaughter Lauren Siket, his niece Linda Tenney and her husband James Perrone and his grand-niece Julie Tenney. Religious service at the J. Ronald Scott Funeral Home, Hampton Bays, NY on Tuesday, May 25th at 11AM. In lieu of flowers, donations to the American Cancer Society would be appreciated.

title: Bombardier Gets New York Order
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority of New York has ordered 192 electric rail cars from Bombardier Inc. to replace commuter trains on the Long Island Rail Road, the company announced today.

title: Times Co. Consolidates Its Internet Units
description: The New York Times Company said yesterday that it would consolidate its numerous Internet properties into one division.

title: Pataki, Laying Own Dreams Aside, Endorses Bush
description: Gov. George E. Pataki yesterday became the 16th Republican governor to endorse the candidacy of Gov. George W. Bush, the Texas Republican who is viewed by many party leaders as the front-runner for the Presidential nomination. With his announcement, Mr. Pataki effectively abandoned his own flirtation with running in 2000.

title: NKK TO CUT JOBS
description: After announcing a loss for the year that ended on March 31, the NKK Corporation, a Japanese steelmaker, said it would reduce the number of its employees by 2,000 this year. NKK lost 108.56 billion yen ($874.9 million) for the year, compared with a profit of 14.28 billion yen a year earlier. NKK also said its sales fell 6.5 percent, to 1.81 trillion yen ($14.58 billion). The company said previously announced cost-cutting efforts proved insufficient to offset sharp falls in steel sales.

title: Telecom Italia's Share Price Drops by 3%
description: Telecom Italia shares fell 3 percent today, the first day of trading after the announcement late Friday that its smaller rival Olivetti S.p.A. had purchased control of Telecom, Italy's biggest phone company.

title: Doubts Fail to Deter 'The Diet Revolution'
description: It was the early 1970's, the heyday of mini-skirts and quick weight-loss schemes, when fashion magazines and celebrity dieters propelled Dr. Robert C. Atkins's ''diet revolution'' into a national phenomenon. His book, ''Dr. Atkins' Diet Revolution,'' promoted a high-fat, high-protein diet spurning most carbohydrates.

title: Vanessa Brown, 71, An Actress in Film And on Broadway
description: Vanessa Brown, who originated the role of the girl upstairs in the Broadway production of ''The Seven Year Itch,'' a role played in the film version by Marilyn Monroe, died on Friday at the Motion Picture Country Home in Los Angeles, Calif. She was 71.

title: Surgery Misconceptions
description: To the Editor:

title: Head of Federal Drug Agency Says He'll Retire This Summer
description: After 39 years in law enforcement, Thomas A. Constantine abruptly announced yesterday that he would step down as the Administrator of the Drug Enforcement Administration, which he has headed since March 1994.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Technology Shares Lead A Broad Market Selloff

title: A Double Breakthrough
description: Inside the walls of the New York Athletic Club, once a white male bastion of amateur athletics, stood Carolyn Peck, a black woman, who was about to become the first black female college coach to receive the club's Winged Foot Award.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LEBOWITZ, HERB
description: LEBOWITZ-Herb. 4/20/98. Your lovely humor is with us always. Matt, John and Louis

title: Wenner Parts Company With Fallon McElligott
description: Wenner Media Inc., which publishes Rolling Stone, Us and Men's Journal magazines, is undertaking a review of its account, with billings estimated at $2 million, after parting ways with Fallon McElligott in Minneapolis, its agency of 15 years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KARP, FRANCES, M.D.
description: KARP-Frances, M.D. The Board of Trustees and the medical staff of Long Beach Medical Center record, with profound sorrow, the passing of Dr. Frances Karp. From 1940 to 1993, she served her patients, her hospital and her community with compassion and great kindness. She brought an understanding of human frailties to her practice of medicine. We are all diminished by her loss. Alfred I. Osterland, Chairman, Board of Trustees Mordecai Bluth, President, Medical Board Martin F. Nester, Chief Executive

title: By Design; Dancing With Mules
description: Two current trends in footwear -- ballerina flats and mules -- have converged for summer as the (unfortunately named) ballet mule. In solid colors or with contrasting toes, the new mules are trimmed with the little bow-tied loops that mark dancers' shoes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SNOW, RUSSEL W. JR.
description: SNOW-Russel W. Jr. Of Liberty Corner, NJ on May 22, 1999. Beloved husband of Ruth Peiffer Snow. Father of Carl and David. Brother of Mrs. Jacquelyn Hinds. Also survived by 3 grandchildren. Funeral Services will be held at the Wm. A. Bradley & Son Funeral Home, 345 Main St. (Rt. 124) Chatham, NJ on Thursday May 27, 1999 at 11am. Friends may call Wed. 7-9pm. Those who wish may contribute in his memory to the American Cancer Society.

title: Undermining the Latin Press
description: The Clinton Administration has been a champion of freedom of the press in Latin America. So it is dismaying to see Washington sponsoring a declaration in the Organization of American States that would endorse limits on media freedoms. The draft declaration, which seems to be a fumble by the Administration rather than a policy reversal, has been approved by the ambassadors of the 34 member nations. It should be withdrawn. When hemisphere foreign ministers meet next month, they should not be asked to approve a declaration that would give governments license for further restrictions on Latin America's besieged journalists.

title: Surgery Misconceptions
description: To the Editor:

title: What Stress Can Mean to Teen-Age Girls
description: Many teen-agers experience stress, but the patterns of stress girls encounter may leave them more vulnerable to depression than those boys experience, according to a study that appears in the current issue of the journal Child Development.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHANDALOW, MAY G.
description: SHANDALOW-May G. Formerly of NYC. Died suddenly on May 23, 1999 in Princeton, NJ., age 94. Cherished mother, grandmother, great grandmother, aunt, cousin, and friend. Mrs. Shandalow received her undergraduate degrees at Maxwell Training School for Teachers and Brooklyn College, and her M.A. at N.Y.U. and taught in the elementary grades in Brooklyn from 1926 to 1941. Over the years Mrs. Shandalow was active in, and held leadership positions in, numerous organizations. She served as President of the Prospect Heights Hospital Auxillary; member of the Board of Directors, Brooklyn Women's UJA Federation; member of the Board of Directors, Midwood Chapter, ORT; Delegate to the 1972 Democratic National Convention; Vice-President of the NYC League of Women Voters; President of the Institute of Retired Professionals, NYC; and member of the Board of Directors, Hebrew Educational Society. She was also a member of Quest, the independent peer learning organization at CCNY, and was a former congregant of Union Temple in Brooklyn. Wife of the late Sol. L. Shandalow, MD, and mother of the late Jeffrey Seth Shandalow. Mrs. Shandalow is survived by her daughter Shan (Merna) and son-in-law, Bert Ellentuck; grandchildren Jeff and Sharlene Hunt Ellentuck, Kinnereth and Stephen Remington, Tamar Ellentuck, and Rebecca and John Reuter; and great grandchildren Lena Remington, Zev Reuter, and Hunter and Elliot Ellentuck; by numerous nieces and nephews and cousins; and by even more numerous friends. Funeral services will be held at Riverside Chapel in Manhattan on Tuesday, May 25th, at 12:30. Internment will be at Wellwood Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions to an educational institution of your choice would be appreciated.

title: Gore Backs Federal Money for Church Social Service Programs
description: At a campaign stop in Atlanta today, Vice President Al Gore said churches and other religion-based groups should be eligible in certain instances to receive Federal money to help fight homelessness, substance abuse, youth violence and other social ills.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBMAN, HERMINE
description: RUBMAN-Hermine. Devoted to her family, active in the community, an inspiration to those around her. She is survived by her daughter Ruth Wood, son Lewis Rubman, and four grandchildren. Memorial service to be announced.

title: Q & A
description: Cosmic Collision

title: World Briefing
description: ASIA

title: Versaces Halt Unauthorized Book on Slain Designer
description: Like her late brother Gianni, Donatella Versace is no shrinking violet when it comes to revealing the more sensational aspects of her public life. Ask her about her diamonds, her famous friends or the time she flew a New York hairdresser to Milan to give her and Naomi Campbell extensions while they ate spaghetti in Ms. Versace's marble bathroom, and she will tell all.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about efforts by Bertelsmann, the media company, to increase its public recognition misstated the name of a women's human rights group for which the company held a fund-raiser last week. It was Equality Now, not Quality Now.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ULLMAN, MARIE MICHAELSON
description: ULLMAN-Marie Michaelson. On May 22, 1999, after a long illness. President of the Ullman Devices Corporation of Ridgefield, CT. Beloved wife of the late Robert Ullman. Survived by her sister, Dorothy Gordon; nieces, nephews and many friends. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Tuesday, 1:30 PM. Interment to follow at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY.

title: BELDEN TO BUY CABLE SYSTEMS COMPANY FOR $180 MILLION
description: Belden Inc., an electronic wire and cable maker, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Cable Systems International Inc., the former copper-cable division of the AT&T Corporation, for $180 million in cash. Cable Systems, which is the second-largest United States maker of copper cable for telecommunications, was formed in October 1995 when AT&T sold the division to an investor group and senior managers. The company, which is based in Phoenix, is the operating unit of Cable Systems Holding Co. Belden is based in St. Louis.

title: FORMAL OFFER FOR YPF
description: Repsol S.A. of Spain began its $16 billion takeover offer for the Argentine oil producer YPF S.A. The offer of 44.78 Argentine pesos a share ($44.78) closes on June 23. If successful, the takeover will create the world's eighth-largest oil company. The Argentine Government, which sold Repsol a 15 percent stake in the former state-owned company for $2 billion in January, has already pledged to sell the 5 percent of YPF it still owns.

title: Out Today: Nuclear Thriller With Ending as Yet Unwritten
description: Inside the Congressional report on Chinese espionage due out on Tuesday is a first-rate spy story. Trouble is, no one is sure what it means.

title: N.B.A. PLAYOFFS: Sports of The Times; Turnaround, and It's Good
description: The moment comes soon enough, and it belongs to Latrell Sprewell and no one else. The coach calls his name sometime during the first quarter, and the building erupts as soon as he stands. Sprewell does not start the game at Madison Square Garden. He restarts it and jams it into the highest possible gear.

title: For Its Big Clients, Merrill Does Not Shy From Internet
description: Merrill Lynch, criticized for a go-slow approach to on-line trading for consumers, is trying to stay ahead of the Internet curve when it comes to its core corporate and institutional clients.

title: Outdated Views on Ulcers Hinder Cures
description: Though it has been well established that most peptic ulcers are caused by a bacteria called Helicobacter pylori, or H. pylori, and can be effectively treated with antibiotics, recent studies show that the information has not gotten out to ulcer sufferers and that a large number of doctors are continuing to treat with standard acid blockers only.

title: James Blades Is Dead at 97; A Percussionist for Victory
description: James Blades, a popular British percussionist whose most frequently heard work was the ''V-for-victory'' Morse code signal broadcast by the BBC during World War II, died on Wednesday at his home in Cheam, in Surrey, England. He was 97.

title: Training the Children
description: To the Editor:

title: 95% Regain Lost Weight. Or Do They?
description: It is a depressing article of faith among the overweight and those who treat them that 95 percent of people who lose weight regain it -- and sometimes more -- within a few months or years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLANCY, KENNETH
description: GLANCY-Kenneth. Of New York City and Cagnes-sur-mer, France, on May 23, 1999. Loving husband of Maida, devoted father of Suzanne (Michael) Gallagher, proud grandfather and great-grandfather. Former CEO and President of RCA Records. Memorial donations may be made to the New School Jazz and Contemporary Music Program, 55 W. 13 Street, New York, New York 10011.

title: PLUS: AUTO RACING -- INDIANAPOLIS 500; Wheel-Restraining System to Be Used
description: Nearly a month after three spectators were killed and several others were injured by a flying wheel from a race car in Charlotte, N.C., the Indy Racing League announced yesterday that it would require its cars to use a wheel-restraining system starting with next Sunday's Indianapolis 500.

title: OBSERVATORY
description: Untangling Speech

title: New Dawn for Flag That Was Still There
description: Using technology as new as space age fabrics and as ordinary as the chemicals from the corner dry-cleaning shop, scientists and historians here have taken on the job of cleaning and preserving the Star-Spangled Banner, the flag that flew over Fort McHenry in Baltimore in 1814, so that it might last at least another 185 years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HABER, IRVING
description: HABER-Irving. The Riverdale Jewish Center extends profound condolences to Alan Haber on the loss of his father. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jonathan I. Rosenblatt, Rabbi Tobias B. Schapiro, Pres.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE YEN CLIMBS. The dollar posted its biggest drop against the yen in almost a month, dragged down by a decline in United States stocks. In New York, the dollar settled at 123.21 yen, down from 124.01 on Friday.

title: High-Tech Plants May Threaten Us, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TURNER, NATHAN
description: TURNER-Nathan. Park East Synagogue and Rabbi Arthur Schneier Park East Day School mourn the passing of Nathan Turner beloved father of Jill, Co-President of our Parents Association, and Josef Kohen and grandfather of Jesse, student in our Early Childhood Program. Deepest sympathy to the entire family. Rabbi Arthur Schneier Michael Scharf, President Jerry Forst, Vice President Jack Rosen, Vice President

title: VITESSE TO BUY XAQTI TO EXTEND RANGE OF CHIP PRODUCTS
description: The Vitesse Semiconductor Corporation, which makes computer chips for high-speed telecommunications, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Xaqti Corporation for $65 million in stock to extend its range of Internet products. Xaqti's processors, which help drive computer data networks, work alongside Vitesse's chips in equipment that directs Internet traffic. Analysts said the combined company would be more of a one-stop shop for companies building computer networks. Shares of Vitesse, which is based in Camarillo, Calif., gained $1.375 a share, to $52.625. Xaqti is based in Santa Clara, Calif.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEYER, YISRAEL (JULIUS)
description: MEYER-Yisrael (Julius). The Yeshiva University family mourns the passing of the brother of Mr. Manfred H. Meyer, who, with his wife Eva, is a Guardian of Yeshiva University and established the Eva and Manfred H. Meyer Course in Modern Jewish Problems at Stern College for Women. Yisrael Meyer of Jerusalem was a long-time and highly-respected member of the community. Heartfelt condolences are extended to Manfred and Eva Meyer and all the members of their family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University David S. Gottesman, Chairman Board of Trustees

title: CBS Executive Reportedly Set to Retire
description: The president of the CBS Corporation's television station group, Jonathan Klein, plans to retire after 30 years with the broadcasting company, according to an internal memo sent by Mr. Klein to company managers.

title: Sanctuary Or Prison? Perhaps It Is Both
description: I have never seen Karen Finley smear her body with chocolate, the performance art gesture she is best known for. But now that I have seen Jesusa Rodriguez smear her face, arms and bare torso with flour and beaten egg, I am far more willing to believe that it could be a moving, powerfully symbolic act.

title: SEX HARASSMENT IN CLASS IS RULED SCHOOLS' LIABILITY
description: School districts can be liable for damages under Federal law for failing to stop a student from subjecting another to severe and pervasive sexual harassment, the Supreme Court ruled today.

title: Yankees Teach a Youngster a Painful Lesson in Old-School Tactics
description: If Bill Simas is right, what has this end-of-the-century baseball game come to?

title: Patterns
description: Stars of the Show

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GERMANO, ANN F.
description: GERMANO-Ann F. On May 23, 1999 at the age of 78. Beloved wife of the late George. Loving mother of Edward, Mary Ann Lanier and Georgette D. Domenico and their spouses, Janice and Jerry. Adoring grandmother of Troy and his wife Erica, Danielle, Megan, Brooke, Jared and Austin. Great grandmother of Jake Edward. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 Street, Tuesday 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral mass at St. Vincent Ferrer Church, Lexington Avenue at 66 Street, on Wednesday 10 A.M. Interment St. Charles Cemetery. Contributions in her memory may be made to the T.J. Martell Foundation, Ann Germano Fellowship for Cancer Research, 6 West 57th Street, New York, N.Y. 10019.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NATHAN, HENRY R.
description: NATHAN-Henry R. The Congregation of Westchester Reform Temple mourns the death of its longtime member and extends sympathy to his bereaved family. Marjorie Miller, President Richard J. Jacobs, Rabbi Stephen Merkel, Cantor Kenneth M. Chasen, Asst. Rabbi

title: Reduced to a 'Caveman' Life, Serbs Don't Blame Milosevic
description: In the Belgrade suburb of Zemun this morning, people were complaining that even McDonald's did not have coffee, because there was no water and no electricity.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-17

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEYER, PETER
description: MEYER-Peter. On May 24, 1999. Beloved husband of Ruth. Devoted father of Philip, George Andrew and Dorothy. Proud grandparent of Christina, Brooks and Casey. Loving brother of Mary Jane. Past president of Scleroderma Federation. Member, board of directors, National Scleroderma Foundation. Past president of Westchester Flying Club. Former trustee of Jewish Community Center of White Plains, N.Y. Services Wednesday, May 26, at 1PM at Kol Ami Jewish Community Center, 252 Soundview Ave., White Plains, New York. Contributions to the National Scleroderma Foundation, 89 Newbury Street, Danvers, MA. 01983. (phone 1-800-422-1113).

title: COMPAQ TO SELL AN INTERNET SERVICES UNIT TO ABOVENET
description: Abovenet Communications Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Palo Alto Internet Exchange from the Compaq Computer Corporation in a deal valued at $75 million. Palo Alto Internet provides services for Internet connections and traffic. Compaq, of Houston, acquired the unit when it bought the Digital Equipment Corporation last year. Abovenet said the purchase price included $70 million in cash and an agreement to provide services. Abovenet, which provides Internet connections and search services, is based in San Jose, Calif., and had 1998 revenues of $3.4 million. Abovenet's shares fell $2.25, to $31.5625.

title: Arts in America; Determined To Preserve Haitian Arts In Miami
