description: When Dade County approved the renaming of several blocks of Northeast Second Avenue, in the Little Haiti section of the city, in honor of Felix Morisseau-Leroy, the revered Haitian poet who died last fall, the planning of the ceremony in the neighborhood fell to a man named Jan Mapou, who runs the parking operations at Miami International Airport. It's a more sensible choice than it may sound, for Mr. Mapou is probably Miami's leading advocate for the Haitian arts.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: When a Tormented Child Cried Stop
description: LaShonda Davis was 10 when she told her mother it was time to hire a lawyer.

title: Sitting in the Ultimate Hot Seat: the Kinsey Institute
description: For the last four years, Dr. John Bancroft, sexologist, sex therapist, psychiatrist, has been at the helm of the Kinsey Institute for Research in Sex, Gender and Reproduction at Indiana University.

title: Young & Rubicam Names 2 to Detroit Jobs
description: Young & Rubicam Inc. in New York has named two executives to new top positions in Detroit.

title: A Tighter Look the Second Time Around
description: Like Christmas in July, ''The Snow Maiden'' returned to American Ballet Theater at the Metropolitan Opera House with a stellar cast that plunged into its winter wonderland with startling passion.

title: Price Steadies For 30-Year Treasuries
description: Treasury bond prices were little changed yesterday amid speculation that economic growth will slow enough to keep inflation tame.

title: Mating Poetry to Music But Not to the Audience
description: The Ensemble Sospeso attracted a substantial number of listeners to Gould Hall on Thursday, and many presumably came for the rare opportunity to hear a touchstone work by Elliott Carter, ''Syringa'' of 1978. If so, they were roundly defeated by the programming, for what remained when the Carter work started, a weighty two hours into the evening (two and a half if David Schiff's preconcert lecture is included) was a mere sprinkling of listeners.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HONIG, SOLOMON
description: HONIG-Solomon. The Ramaz School family mourns the untimely passing of the beloved husband of its devoted member of the faculty, Dr. Edith Lazarus Honig, and the father of our alumnus Yechezkel and our senior student Rivkah. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to all the members of the bereaved family. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein, Principal David N. Kahn Chairman, Board of Trustees Dr. Jay Stone Chair, Faculty Council

title: Board Denies Bid by Doctors in New Jersey to Unionize
description: In a setback to doctors' efforts to unionize, the National Labor Relations Board's regional office in Philadelphia ruled yesterday that more than 500 New Jersey doctors working for a health maintenance organization were independent contractors -- not employees -- and therefore could not form a union.

title: Cendant Will Sell Unit to Avis, Increasing Stake in Auto Renter
description: The Cendant Corporation agreed today to sell its automobile fleet unit to Avis Rent a Car Inc. in a deal that raises the company's stake in Avis to 34 percent from 19 percent.

title: Judge Wisdom Memorial
description: A service for Judge John Minor Wisdom of United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit, in New Orleans, a legal scholar who played a central role in racial integration in the Deep South, was scheduled for 2:30 P.M. Thursday at the Court of Appeals Building at 600 Camp Street, New Orleans. Judge Wisdom, who had remained active in retirement, died on May 15 at 93.

title: Body Computer Shows Shape of Things to Come
description: I have seen the future -- and I prefer the past. Or is it the other way around?

title: Brewing Potent Elixirs From Musical Alchemy
description: Mixing jazz with pop is not easy; it's serious business, dependent on literacy in both forms. And mixing Afro-Latin rhythms with jazz needs the same kind of conceptual muscle. In her performance at the Blue Note on Thursday, the singer Dianne Reeves managed to sidestep a lot of the sticky cliches that can abound with such fusions. At the same time she maintained direct control over her audience; she is a complete professional.

title: Harlem School Vandalized; Graffiti Warned of Bomb
description: A landmark high school in Harlem that underwent a $47 million renovation six years ago was badly vandalized over the weekend and was cleared of classes all day yesterday after graffiti warning of a bomb was discovered, the police said.

title: The extremely creative Kaplan Thaler Group agrees to be acquired by MacManus Group.
description: THE agency responsible for that much-discussed Clairol Herbal Essences campaign in which women simulate sexual ecstasy now has some excitement of its own: a new owner.

title: Dating for Profit
description: To the Editor:

title: Thermo Electron Plans to Sell or Shut Several Businesses
description: No longer will the Thermo Electron Corporation operate a network of spas that offer hair removal by laser. Gone will be its once-promising Wyoming plant that scrubs coal to make it burn more cleanly. And the company will jettison a European business set up to convert contaminated petroleum into usable oil products.

title: Students and Sexual Harassment
description: A bitterly divided Supreme Court affirmed yesterday the legal obligation of schools to protect students from severe and pervasive sexual harassment by other students. The 5-to-4 decision marked an important turning point for education and for civil rights. Most significantly, it recognized that student-on-student sexual harassment not only disrupts a victim's ability to learn but, in egregious cases, may also amount to a violation of Title IX of the Education Amendments of 1972, the law that bars sex discrimination in schools and colleges receiving Federal funds.

title: California Cities to Sue Gun Makers Over Sales Methods
description: Two groups of California cities, led by Los Angeles and San Francisco, plan to sue gun manufacturers tomorrow in a novel use of a sweeping state business law that government officials and gun-control advocates hope will force the manufacturers to change the way they market firearms.

title: Justices, 9-0, Find No Inherent Conflict Between 2 Laws on Disabled Workers
description: The Supreme Court today examined two Federal laws aimed at protecting disabled workers and concluded that contrary to a lower court's view, there was no inevitable conflict between them.

title: Whitman's Nominee Is Confirmed as State Attorney General
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's nominee for Attorney General, John J. Farmer Jr., was confirmed unanimously by the State Senate today, winning the the state's top law enforcement job at a time when the office and the state police are under intense scrutiny because of racial profiling.

title: New Giuliani Fund-Raiser and Her Handler
description: LAURA VAN HOVE, the new 32-year-old finance director for Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's

title: Assurance And Anxiety After Ruling
description: Educational administrators, exhausted by weeks of focus on school safety and discipline after the shootings in Littleton, Colo., worried yesterday that the Supreme Court's decision on student sexual harassment would be yet another burden.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: Losses in Shares Are Wide And Gauges Fall Sharply
description: Stock prices staged a broad, steep selloff yesterday, led by big declines in Internet and technology issues.

title: When a Novel 'Reveals Itself'; Ward Just Reflects on the Delusions of People and Nations
description: No place is more gray than Berlin in winter, a layered gray that begins in the sky, permeates the air, penetrates the buildings and gathers with bottomless intensity in the city's lakes. It is a grayness that Ward Just, the novelist, calls ''an atmosphere,'' and in atmospheres lie the germ of his imaginative voyages.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''They make you send your kids to school, right? So don't you think they should protect them while they're there?''

title: Vietri sul Mare Journal; 'Eco-Monster' Hotel Bites the Dust
description: The ''eco-monster'' that ate the Amalfi coast is sinking back into the sea.

title: Making Every Song New, as if Each Time Were the First
description: How does a cabaret legend stay fresh year after year? Ask Bobby Short, who makes every performance at the Cafe Carlyle a lesson in refreshment and self-renewal. Although his newest show is grounded in staples that he has performed season after season, in his seemingly spontaneous renditions, they well out of him like bursts from a fountain.

title: Gun Makers Change But Still Face Suits
description: In an effort to ward off lawsuits and sweeping restrictions on guns, many of the nation's largest gun makers are breaking free from the National Rifle Association, for years their powerful patron.

title: Guards' Toughest Test Still To Come
description: Mookie Blaylock was skittering around the perimeter, trying to find a nook or a cranny to release a jump shot. Sometimes he found room, and other times he wandered into a trap and had to force the ball to a covered teammate.

title: All in the Mitochondrial Family
description: The family tree at right shows the relationship between some intimately related species: the great apes and humans. It is based on a single genetic region, part of the DNA of the cellular organelles known as mitochondria. Trees generated from other regions of DNA might differ in some details.

title: In the Publics Eyes
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARX, VIRGINIA WISE
description: MARX-Virginia Wise. Born May 26, 1905 in St. Louis, MO, died May 23 at White Plains Hospital in White Plains, NY. Beloved wife of Leonard. Sister of Muriel Ducibella, Jane Smith and Rudolph Wise, Jr. Loving mother of Leonard Marx Jr., the late Ellen Marx, Mary Lynn Bianco, and Jennifer Gruenberg. Mrs. Marx was a tireless volunteer on behalf of children and families. She earned a bachelor's degree in psychology from Washington University and a master's degree in child psychology from Teachers College at Columbia University. She is survived by six grandchildren; Richard Marx, Nancy Marx Better, Ned Solot, Claire Solot, Wendy Gruenberg, Jon Gruenberg, and five great-grandchildren. Funeral services will be held at Congregation Kol Ami/JCC, 252 Soundview Avenue, White Plains, NY, Wednesday, May 26th, at 10:00 am. In lieu of flowers, the family requests contributions to the Virginia Marx Children's Center at Westchester Community College or to the Virginia and Leonard Marx Lecture Series at Teachers College of Columbia University.

title: NATO MOVES AHEAD ON A KOSOVO FORCE OF 50,000 TROOPS
description: NATO today approved plans for a heavily armed peacekeeping force of about 50,000 soldiers for Kosovo, part of a broad campaign by the alliance's top commander to increase the political and military pressure on President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia.

title: Losing a Taste for the Cheap Stuff
description: FOR wine enthusiasts, the opening of a winery is exciting news, especially if it's in the Napa Valley and it plans to make only about 500 cases a year. It's the same in Europe: the biggest buzz invariably is about the people who make the least amount of wine, which often is the most expensive.

title: Housing and Confidence Data Buoy Realtors
description: Home resales beat expectations in April, and consumer confidence rose for the seventh consecutive month, suggesting that the economy will continue to grow as consumers spend more on homes, cars and merchandise.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COYNE, HELEN E. (NEE OETTIG)
description: COYNE-Helen E. (nee Oettig). On May 24th. Beloved wife of Edward T. Loving mother of Ann Sullivan, Edward, Patricia McGrane, Paul, Peter and Clare Gallagher. Cherished grandmother of Elizabeth, Ryan and Craig. Reposing at the Kennedy-Roth Funeral Home Inc., 41-45 58 St., Woodside, N.Y., Wednesday and Thursday 2-5 and 79pm. Mass of Christian Burial Friday, 9:30am at St. Mary's Winfield Church, Woodside, N.Y. Interment to follow at Calvery Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KRISS, BRUNO R., M.D.
description: KRISS-Bruno R., M.D. May 26, 1965. A unique personality & friend painfully remembered always. ITTOM

title: Mystery Grows Over Payment by Morgan Stanley
description: Many people on Wall Street are scratching their heads as to why Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, America's largest securities firm, would pay $10,000 to a middleman who helped secure the arrest of a former employee. Now, it turns out, even the middleman had doubts.

title: House Speaker Sees Approval of Gun Bill
description: House Republican leaders announced that they were drafting a broad package of gun-control measures similar to those passed by the Senate last week.

title: Yoshii Keeps Emerging As the Mets' Star Power
description: No matter how ridiculous it would have sounded at the start of the season, Masato Yoshii is the ace of the Mets' staff right now.

title: Senate Clears 2 Pearl Harbor 'Scapegoats'
description: The Senate voted today to clear the names of the two senior military officers who were accused of dereliction of duty as a result of the bombing of Pearl Harbor in 1941. The vote came after an emotional debate among the dwindling number of World War II veterans left in the Senate.

title: Commencements; Historian Urges Balance In 'Work, Love and Play'
description: A former White House intern and best-selling author delivered an impassioned keynote address yesterday at Cooper Union's 140th commencement, at the Great Hall.

title: Fear Still Accompanies Many South Africans to Polls
description: The campaign procession for President Nelson Mandela's African National Congress began in the rural town of Nongoma on Friday with an armored vehicle leading the convoy and ended with a truckload of soldiers in bulletproof vests bringing up the rear.

title: THE CHEF; A Savory Summer
description: IN New York City, it seems to me, restaurants are all about interior. Here, it's the outdoors, the Napa Valley itself, that sets the tone and guides our expectations.

title: Irabu Hustles to Cover First, but Falters on Mound
description: Hideki Irabu is blessed with two great talents. He can throw a baseball very hard, and with equal force he can throw away good will with exceptional timing and efficiency.

title: Pungent Life With Father, Serving Love And Chips
description: The smell is what you notice first, even before you've taken a proper look at the stage from which it emanates. It's the thick aroma of fat heated up for deep frying, mixed with fleeting suggestions of spice, and you can't shake it out of your nostrils for the rest of the evening.

title: Stanley Works Shifts Account
description: Stanley Works in New Britain, Conn., the tool maker, has consolidated its account by awarding duties for its industrial division to Mullen Advertising in Wenham, Mass., part of the Lowe Group unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

title: China Labels Spying Claims 'Groundless'
description: Accusations that Chinese spies stole nuclear weapon designs and missile technology from the United States are ''totally groundless,'' China's Foreign Ministry said today.

title: WEAKER POUND SOUGHT
description: The Governor of the Bank of England, Eddie George, said that he would prefer a weaker pound but that there was little he could do to produce one. The strong pound has hurt exporters while the domestic economy remains relatively buoyant. The central bank's key money-market lending rate would be higher now if not for the external environment, Mr. George noted, and the pound's strength is helping to check inflationary pressures in the domestic economy. Much of sterling's strength is a result of weakness in the economies of the 11 countries that use the euro currency, Mr. George said.

title: Metro Business; Ex-Executive Fined In Securities Fraud
description: A Federal judge has ordered the former president of a New Jersey brokerage, now defunct, to pay $271 million in fines and refunds on charges of defrauding 1,700 investors in a Ponzi scheme involving office equipment leases.

title: On War And Peace
description: Many commencement speakers reflected on the dark side of war or the light of peace, grappling with ways to understand violence in the wake of bombings in Yugoslavia and shootings at American high schools.

title: Officer, Seeking Some Mercy, Admits to Louima's Torture
description: In a faltering, hesitant voice, Justin A. Volpe admitted yesterday that he rammed a stick into Abner Louima's rectum and then thrust it in his face, an act, the police officer acknowledged, intended to humiliate and intimidate the handcuffed Haitian immigrant.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEYER, PETER
description: MEYER-Peter. Congregation Kol Ami records with sorrow the passing of our cherished member and former Trustee and conveys sincere condolences to his bereaved family. Rabbi Tom Weiner Rabbi Shira Milgrom Mark A. Hershey, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NATHAN, HENRY R.
description: NATHAN-Henry R. On May 23, 1999. Loving husband of Ursula (nee Eisner). Devoted father of Lester. Dear brother-in-law of Mechtild Eisner. A native of Berlin, Germany he began his training in banking before he was forced to immigrate to N.Y. in 1938. His career on Wall St. continued to 1984. He served the U.S. during WWII and received the Bronze Star. Funeral Thursday, 10:15am at Fox Funeral Home, 2080 Boston Post Road, Larchmont, New York. Phone (914) 834-0144.

title: 'Leaner, Meaner' OECD Rides the Global Waves
description: PARIS  Since its birth in 1961, the OECD has often been portrayed as the rich man's club of multinational organizations. It is an elite economic research outfit, critics say, that has idled away its years in Paris representing the interests of the world's cosseted economies, as it assesses the economic pulse of the globe, passing policy judgments and occasionally admitting new members to its own clique.

title: A Turf Battle Over Handling Of Fraud Case
description: A purloined prisoner in an important state securities fraud case has put two powerful prosecutors on a collision course.

title: Sports of The Times; For Knicks, It's Turmoil And Success
description: WHAT a fine time for pro basketball fans in New York. The Knicks, after a five-year wait, are playing for a conference championship beginning Sunday. The team has taken on a sleek, fast-moving style of play and the franchise, which has seen dark days, is enjoying a triumphant moment.

title: Woman and 3 of Her Children Are Killed by an Amtrak Train
description: A woman and three of her four young sons were killed early this morning when they were hit by an Amtrak train as the woman crossed the tracks in a last-second attempt to rescue one of the children from the locomotive's path, the State Police said.

title: Whose Guilt in Kosovo?; Split Country in Two
description: To the Editor:

title: Baffert's Filly Runs A Dazzling 6 Furlongs
description: Silverbulletday, the best 3-year-old filly in racing, worked a sizzling six furlongs at Churchill Downs yesterday. But her trainer, Bob Baffert, would still not say that she would try to thwart Charismatic's bid to sweep the Triple Crown in the Belmont Stakes one week from Saturday.

title: Cable Deal For $3.6 Billion Is Expected
description: Charter Communications Inc., the cable-television operator owned by Paul G. Allen, one of the co-founders of the Microsoft Corporation, is expected to announce as early as today that it is buying the cable assets of Falcon Cable Holdings of Los Angeles in a stock swap valued at more than $3.6 billion, people close to the talks said.

title: Going From Yogurt to Developing Office Space on Staten Island
description: ''Yogurt is really sour milk,'' Richard Nicotra said a few days ago. Mr. Nicotra has become the leading private developer of office space on Staten Island in recent years, but as the man who founded the 250-store Everything Yogurt chain 23 years ago, his heart is still very much in the yogurt business.

title: Officer's Plea Could Hurt, But Also Help, Co-Defendants
description: Three New York City police officers and a sergeant are to return to court today, still facing charges in the explosive Abner Louima brutality case after Officer Justin A. Volpe admitted torturing Mr. Louima.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREEMAN, MARY
description: FREEMAN-Mary. Of Babylon Village, Long Island on May 23, 1999. Beloved wife of the late H. Frank Freeman II. Loving mother of George W. Freeman, Mary Kate Rockey, Richard H. Freeman, and the late H. Frank Freeman III. Dear sister of Bernard Wheeler. Cherished grandmother of eleven and great-grandmother of three. Retired school nurse of West Islip Schools. Memorial Service at St. Joseph's R.C. Church to be scheduled at a later date. For information contact Fredrick J. Chapey & Sons West Islip Funeral Home.

title: More a Love-In Than a Play-In Between Israeli and Fans
description: With a recital like the Monday night appearance by the Israeli-born pianist Mordecai Shehori at Alice Tully Hall, I wonder whether it matters what a critic thinks.

title: Do State Lotteries Dupe the Poor?
description: To the Editor:

title: Sampras, Chasing History, Refuses to Fade Away
description: On his first match point, Pete Sampras soared like Superman to hit a forehand stretch volley that would have ended his first-round ordeal at the French Open. But Sampras wound up on his belly in the red dirt as his shot, and his noble intentions, buried themselves in the net.

title: Peru's Delights Are Waiting: Here's Where
description: THE Peruvian restaurants in New York are mostly casual, family-style places. Most are in Queens, but a few are scattered elsewhere. Here are six of my favorites.

title: Switch in Defense Planned at Minicamp
description: Despite emerging as one of the National Football League's top teams, the Jets will begin tinkering this week with their defense -- switching to a 3-4 alignment -- occasioned by returning injured players who could give the team extraordinary depth at linebacker.

title: A Rathskeller-Cafe Hybrid
description: THE pretzel-croissant at City Bakery sounds like a doomed merger. Maury Rubin, the chef and owner of the bakery, said that customers who ask about it are a bit skeptical at first.

title: RESPITE FOR STEELMAKER
description: The holding company of Mexico's largest steel manufacturer, Altos Hornos de Mexico S.A., has been authorized by a court to suspend payments to creditors. The suspension gives Altos Hornos, which has $1.9 billion in debt, time to restructure but also brings it a step closer to bankruptcy. Altos Hornos shares, which fell nearly 29 percent on Monday, rebounded 3.3 percent on speculation the company might find a partner. Julia Preston

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAHILL, ELLEN JACOBSEN
description: CAHILL-Ellen Jacobsen. On May 23, 1999. Beloved wife of Richard. Loving Mother of Frederick Parenteau III and Suzanne Shacklett. Devoted Grandmother of two Grandchildren. Visiting Wednesday 2-4 and 7-9PM at the John J. Fox Funeral Home, Inc. 2080 Boston Post Road, Larchmont, NY. Mass Thursday, 10AM at Saints John & Paul Church in Larchmont.

title: Time and Smoke, the Soul of Barbecue
description: GRILLING may lie at the heart of the American summer, but barbecue is its soul, for true barbecue possesses a personality and depth of flavor you simply can't achieve with grilling.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BANDES, EDNA
description: BANDES-Edna. On May 25, 1999. Beloved widow of Arthur. She is survived by son Barry. Funeral service will be held at Gutterman's 175 Long Beach Rd, Rockville Centre on Friday, May 28, 9:30AM.

title: A Refugee River, Dammed at the Border
description: Over 4,500 ethnic Albanians fled into Macedonia today, including hundreds of women from the town of Kacanik in southeastern Kosovo, many of whom accused Serbian forces of separating hundreds of fighting-age men from their group before expelling it.

title: Whose Guilt in Kosovo?
description: To the Editor:

title: Peruvian Cuisine Takes On the World
description: OUTDONE by visions of gauchos on the pampas, outromanced by images of Brazilian beaches and Carnival, and overwhelmed by the familiar flavors of Mexico and the Caribbean, Peru may seem like just an anonymous shade in the pan-Latin palette that has painted many New York restaurants.

title: State Plans to House Sex Offenders in Kearny
description: The State Department of Corrections said it would move forward with plans to house sex offenders in Kearny, despite fierce opposition from residents and a pledge by local officials to sue the state to block the plan.

title: National News Briefs; Congress Is Told to Invest In Reform of the I.R.S.
description: Reform of the Internal Revenue Service will fail unless Congress makes steady, annual investments in training and technology, the tax commissioner said today as he repeatedly, but gently, told Congress that years of budget cuts for the agency must end.

title: Civil Action Accuses Yugoslavs of War Crimes
description: Two Kosovar Albanians filed a lawsuit today in a United States District Court charging President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia, his wife and senior members of his Government with genocide and other war crimes.

title: Nasdaq Reports Slight Drop In Its Uncovered Short Sales
description: Open positions of short sales on the Nasdaq stock market declined one-tenth of a percent in the most recent monthly period, the National Association of Securities Dealers, which oversees the market, said yesterday. The decline came after increases in the two preceding months, including a 3 percent rise last month.

title: Brazil Market Is Down 10% This Week
description: Already weakened by concern over troubling economic developments in neighboring Argentina, Brazilian markets reeled for a second day following new developments in a scandal over the Government's handling of the privatization of the country's telecommunications monopoly.

title: Do State Lotteries Dupe the Poor?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRELITZ, LEONARD R.
description: STRELITZ-Leonard R. The officers and executive staff of United Jewish Communities deeply mourns the passing of Leonard R. Strelitz, United Jewish Appeal National Chairman for 1977 to to 1978 and Honorary National Chairman 1979 to 1999. A larger than life personality, Leonard Strelitz's passionate and indefatigable leadership of the American Jewish community on behalf of Israel and Jews in need around the world was legendary. His legacy of a lifetime of support and assistance to Jewish communal causes is continued by the entire family and currently by his daughter, Bonnie Brand, incoming Women's Campaign Chairperson for the United Jewish Federation of Tidewater and by his son-in-law David Brand, President of the United Jewish Federation of Tidewater., Our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Joyce, and children Brian, Bonnie & E.J.

title: Spying Charges Against Beijing Are Spelled Out by House Panel
description: A long-awaited Congressional report that describes a pattern of systematic and successful Chinese espionage to learn American nuclear secrets was released today, and President Clinton said he agreed that national security should be improved.

title: Do State Lotteries Dupe the Poor?
description: To the Editor:

title: From the High Court, a Voice Quite Distinctly a Woman's
description: During her 18 years as a member, Sandra Day O'Connor has often been the Justice in the middle of a sharply divided Supreme Court. On Monday, in the 5-to-4 decision on sexual harassment in the schools, she was, perhaps more clearly than ever before, the woman in the middle as well.

title: A Trinity of Anguish: Father, Son and Death
description: Steve Paxton has been attracting attention since the 1960's for dances based on ordinary movements. The virtues of his plain style were apparent in ''Ash,'' one of three solos he presented on Friday night in the Silver Series of the Danspace Project at St. Mark's Church.

title: How Right Is Report? Caveats By Experts
description: The Cox Committee's report on China's nuclear espionage ''is alarming,'' Representative John M. Spratt Jr., a member of the committee, said today. ''But is it accurate?''

title: Liberties; Siamese Senators
description: There is no other conversation here.

title: Clinton Has a Few Fine Words for Gore
description: President Clinton and Vice President Al Gore crossed paths here today, a public pairing that inadvertently highlighted just how far the Vice President had to go in matching his mentor's political skills.

title: WATERFORD TO ACQUIRE ALL-CLAD FOR $110 MILLION
description: Waterford Wedgwood P.L.C., a Dublin maker of crystal and fine china, said yesterday that it would purchase All-Clad Metalcrafters Inc., a closely held maker of cookware based in Canonsburg, Pa., for $110 million. The acquisition gives Waterford a slice of the fast-growing United States market for high-end kitchenware. All-Clad, which originally made pots and pans for professional chefs, has been growing rapidly by reaching into the consumer market. Waterford said the acquisition would increase its sales to more than 600 million Irish pounds, or $807.3 million.

title: Woman Avoids Murder Charge Over Daughter
description: When an Orlando woman chose to end her life last week by removing herself from a life support system rather than live paralyzed from the neck down, prosecutors said they would very likely charge the woman who crippled her, her mother, with murder. But today, the state attorney in Orange County said it would be ''inappropriate'' to charge Shirley Egan, 68, with the murder of her daughter, Georgette Smith, 42.

title: Toys 'R' Us Settles Federal Antitrust Case
description: Several leading players in the toy industry agreed yesterday to pay 44 states $50 million in cash and merchandise to settle antitrust charges.

title: Pan Latin Fusion Reigns in Miami
description: IT is now four decades since exiles from Castro's Cuba first arrived in Miami, and were soon followed by a small army of family restaurants that served up heaping mounds of steaming black beans and rice and other Cuban staples like fried plantains and mojo, the fragrant sour-orange marinade.

title: Art Dealer Charged in Threat to Kidnap Lawyer's Child
description: Andrew Crispo, the New York art dealer who was rebuilding his life and filing for personal bankruptcy after serving three years in prison for tax evasion, was charged yesterday with threatening to kidnap the 4-year-old daughter of a lawyer formerly involved in his bankruptcy case.

title: Starr Drops All Charges Against 2 Women
description: Kenneth W. Starr said today that he would drop all charges against two women he had accused of hindering his investigation of President Clinton but was unable to convict in trials that ended in bitter setbacks for the independent counsel's office.

title: SCHINDLER IN BRAZIL
description: In a deal that will make Schindler Holding A.G. of Switzerland the biggest elevator manufacturer in Brazil, the company bought a controlling stake in Elevadores Atlas for about $280 million. Atlas, founded in 1918, gives Schindler a more varied product mix. Schindler sells elevators in Brazil mainly for modest residential buildings, while Atlas has been shifting production to more sophisticated elevators for newer commercial buildings. Schindler said it would use Brazil as a base for exporting to other Latin American countries and to some markets in Africa. Simon Romero

title: Wall St. Is Given Year 2000 Ideas
description: Mutual funds should make year-end payouts to investors before Christmas, and all United States financial markets should close at the same time early in the afternoon of New Year's Eve, according to a report released yesterday by a securities industry group that has studied contingency planning for Year 2000 computer problems.

title: Passing Along Torch of Wisdom to Next Century's Leaders
description: The purpose of a commencement address, as Diane Ravitch, senior fellow at the Brookings Institution, told graduates of Alverno College, is ''to give your boat a push to help propel you forward.'' And so this month and next, speakers proffer tender advice, witticisms and warnings intended to get that boat offshore, and in the process take the nation's pulse. Excerpts were gleaned from transcripts provided by colleges and universities.

title: Scientists Closer To Determining Age of Universe
description: Using eight years of measurements by the Hubble Space Telescope, astronomers have calculated the rate at which the universe is expanding, a number that is vital for determining the age, size and fate of the universe.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HITTNER, RICHARD
description: HITTNER-Richard. Of Cliffside Park, N.J. on May 24. Beloved husband of Rebecca. Adoring father of Tom and Gail. Loving grandfather to Emily and David. Servicces ''Gutterman-Musicant'', corner Passaic and Park Sts, Hackensack, today, 10AM. In lieu of flowers, the Hittner family requests that a donation be made to Children's Make a Wish Foundation.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SCILKEN, DAVID (SHADI)
description: SCILKEN-David (Shadi). 5/26/91. We love you and miss you. Your talent, insight and humor added enormously to the quality of our lives. Poll

title: U.S. to Hear Complaints About Police
description: The United States Civil Rights Commission will focus a national spotlight on police practices in New York today by holding a public hearing on police treatment of minority groups in a city still reeling from a white officer's admission that he tortured a black man in a station house restroom.

title: Kosovo Crisis Strains Already Struggling Albania
description: As spooky reminders of a dark, suspicious, past, more than 500,000 Communist-era bunkers still poke through the ground throughout Albania.

title: What China Knows About U.S. Missile Technology: A Chronology
description: Following is the overview from the report of the Select Committee on U.S. National Security and Military/Commercial Concerns With the People's Republic of China. References and a few duplicate sentences have been deleted.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEPRIN, JOEL
description: WEPRIN-Joel. We are saddened by the loss of a very special man, Joel Weprin, on May 22, 1999. He brought love and sunshine into all our lives, and will always be remembered by his family, friends & the students that he influenced. He is survived by his wife, Amy (Kassin) & his children, Julia, Loy (Martin), Peter & Eric. He leaves his sister, Ruth, his brothers, Barry & Earle, and his grandchild, Conor Alexander. Services were held on Sunday, May 23.

title: Op-Art; OPERATION EUPHEMISM
Bonilla Plays a Waiting Game
description: Bobby Bonilla is eligible to come off the disabled list Wednesday, but he will probably wait until Monday, an associate of Bonilla's said today.

title: From Kosovo to 'Potato City,' Idaho, the Hard Way
description: As Mirsade Bejiqi and her family flew from Fort Dix to their new home here, she braced herself for loneliness and isolation. Perhaps nobody would bother meeting them, a handful of near-penniless refugees from Kosovo hurtling toward Potato City, as she called Idaho's capital.

title: Guilty Plea Set By Fund-Raiser For Democrats
description: John Huang, the prolific fund-raiser at the center of the furor over Democratic Party financing of President Clinton's re-election, will plead guilty in Federal court to a single felony count of conspiring to make illegal contributions, the Justice Department and Mr. Huang's lawyer said today.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRUNDT, RHODA
description: GRUNDT-Rhoda. Loving wife of the late Harry. Devoted mother of Lenora Resnick, Richard, Melvin and Arlene Grundt. Devoted grandmother of Sharon, Sol Packer, Nancy, Stanley Rosenfeld, Marla, Martin Rosenthal, Bruce, Andrea Grundt, Steven and Miriam Grundt. Cherished greatgrandmother and great-great grandmother. Services 10am Wednesday at Norman L. Jeffer Community Chapels, Inc., corner of 47th St and Ft. Hamilton Parkway.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GERMANO, ANN F.
description: GERMANO-Ann F. On May 23, 1999 at the age of 78. Beloved wife of the late George. Loving mother of Edward, Mary Ann Lanier and Georgette D. Domenico and their spouses, Janice and Jerry. Adoring grandmother of Troy and his wife Erica, Danielle, Megan, Brooke, Jared and Austin. Great grandmother of Jake Edward. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 Street, Tuesday 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral mass at St. Vincent Ferrer Church, Lexington Avenue at 66 Street, on Wednesday 10 A.M. Interment St. Charles Cemetery. Contributions in her memory may be made to the T.J. Martell Foundation, Ann Germano Fellowship for Cancer Research, 6 West 57th Street, New York, N.Y. 10019.

title: On a Greek Odyssey by Land, Sea and Poetry
description: INVENTING PARADISE

title: In San Jose, Floor Sleeping for $180 Month
description: Ricardo Ramirez would walk 17 miles home from his night restaurant job in San Jose, California, whenever he worked so late that he missed the last bus. After many nights of making the grueling trek, he finally found a cheap place to live closer to work. He rented a floor. For $180 a month, he got a corner of a living room for eight hours a night.

title: Do State Lotteries Dupe the Poor?
description: To the Editor:

title: Out of Nowhere, Sprewell And the Knicks Reappear
description: On the cover of the Knicks' playoff guide is a figure that looks like a life-size cardboard cutout from a supermarket display standing between a stoic Jeff Van Gundy and the broad-shouldered Chris Dudley.

title: German Pegs Quick Peace To the Role Of Russians
description: German Foreign Minister Joschka Fischer said here today that Germany was counting on a diplomatic outcome to the war in Kosovo, with the backing of Russia, in the next several weeks.

title: Gone but Not Unforgotten
description: Every once in a while, a television program comes along that truly defines an era. ''Home Improvement,'' which starred Tim Allen and played for many years on one of this nation's premier networks, was one such television program. And now, unless we have this wrong, it has gone off the air. Whatever day it was on -- our best guess is Tuesday -- is never going to be the same.

title: Struggling Racing Bodies May Decide to Reunite
description: Four years after Championship Auto Racing Teams and the Indy Racing League split up, damaging the appeal of open-wheel racing in the United States, the two rival series may be secretly planning a reconciliation.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LENNARD, FLORENCE
description: LENNARD-Florence. In life, you were always there. It's been 13 years since you left-but you are still here. Everlasting love. Jules

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''This is an exercise in truth telling. Where do we go from here? We have to go up, obviously.''

title: Former Movie Palace Is Named a Landmark
description: What was once the biggest, most famous movie theater in Queens -- now a church but once a rococo palace celebrated for generations as the place to take a date on Saturday night -- was designated a landmark yesterday by the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission.

title: Most 4th Graders Fail Albany's New English Test
description: More than half of all fourth graders across New York State failed the new English test given last January, results released yesterday showed. The test replaced an old-fashioned multiple choice test with a three-day marathon that required children to read long passages and write essays.

title: TOSHIBA REPORTS LOSS
description: The world's largest notebook computer maker, the Toshiba Corporation, posted its first loss in 23 years as sales of computer chips, household electronics and nuclear power equipment slumped in Asia. Toshiba, Japan's No. 2 chip maker, reported a net loss of 13.9 billion yen ($113 million) for the year that ended on March 31, down from a profit of 7.3 billion yen the year before. Sales declined 2.9 percent -- more than expected -- to 5.3 trillion yen from 5.46 trillion yen.

title: With Artist's Devotion and Long Hours, Unusual Bible Takes Shape
description: In a cozy and neatly kept studio at his home here, the artist Barry Moser has been working on a task that recalls a much earlier historical era, creating hundreds of individual images to illustrate the Bible, from Creation to Apocalypse.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GENTILE, CONSTANCE
description: GENTILE-Constance, 89. Beloved Mother, a beautiful and elegant lady. Survived by her devoted and loving son, daughters, grandchildren and great-grandchildren. We shall miss her greatly.

title: As Chefs Reach for the Stars, A Fortuneteller Points the Way
description: WHAT does a four-star chef do before making a big decision about his restaurant, his personal life, his career goals?

title: Well, Is He A Spy -- Or Not?
description: After serving almost five years in the Clinton Administration, I've learned a number of things about Washington -- and one of them is how innuendo can ruin a reputation in no time.

title: A Fusion of Talent, With Highlights Alone
description: Whatever Bill T. Jones and Jessye Norman are looking for together as major performers, they have not found it. But the search may still be worthwhile, as their collaboration at City Center suggested on Monday night.

title: Event for Giuliani Raises More Than $2 Million
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani received a generous birthday present last night when organizers of a fund-raising dinner, held ostensibly in honor of his 55th birthday, announced that the event had raised $2.1 million. Bruce Teitelbaum, the executive director of Mr. Giuliani's political action committee, Solutions America, said it was $600,000 more than expected.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SELBY, RAYMOND C.
description: SELBY-Raymond C. Of Staten Island, N.Y. on May 24, 1999. Loving husband of Loretta (nee Byrnes). Loving father of Suzanne M., Steven J., Andrew C. and Edmond M. Selby. Dear brother of Marjorie Selby and father-in-law of Lucy Selby. Reposing Harmon Home for Funerals, 571 Forest Avenue, Staten Island, Wednesday and Thursday 2 to 4 and 7 to 9. Mass of Christian Burial Our Lady of Good Council Church, Friday, 10 A.M. Committal private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAHN, SAMUEL A., CPA
description: KAHN-Samuel A., CPA, 88. A caring, gentle man, passed away May 24. Beloved husband of Mimi Eisenberg. Devoted father of David (Debbie), Bradley (Karen) and the late Scott. Grandfather of six. Loving uncle. Shiva in Long Beach

title: China to Overhaul a Heavily Indebted State Company
description: Softening its tone toward foreign lenders, China announced a plan today to overhaul a debt-ridden state company, with the banks and the Government sharing the losses.

title: Lyndon Lyon Is Dead at 94; A Breeder of African Violets
description: Lyndon Waldo Lyon, a horticulturist who was turned into an African violet fanatic by a single leaf and who played a major role in making the African violet one of the country's favorite houseplants, died last Wednesday at Little Falls Hospital in Little Falls, N.Y. He was 94.

title: Money and Medicine
description: To the Editor:

title: Too Many Guns, Too Many Laws; Senate Acted Rashly
description: To the Editor:

title: In South Korea, Layoffs Fuel Enterprise
description: For nearly two decades, Jang Chang Ik trudged up the corporate hill, clocking long hours and following orders from his bosses until he became one of them.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-22

title: What Israel Should Offer
description: To the Editor:

title: Ratings Hieroglyphics
description: With the television season and the May ratings sweep grinding to their official ends tomorrow, the networks were analyzing the ratings results yesterday like archeologists searching ancient scribblings in the hope of finding the secret chamber of gold.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MELTON, MARY ANN
description: MELTON-Mary Ann of Tequesta, FL and Dorset, VT, formerly of Brightwaters, NY died on May 24, 1999 at the age of 76 in Jupiter, FL after a brief illness. Mrs. Melton was the devoted wife of Mr. Andrew J. Melton Jr. for 55 years, and was the daughter of the late Sanders and Marjorie Shanks. A loving and dedicated mother of eight and grandmother of twentytwo, Mrs. Melton was also an accomplished artist, interior designer and avid sailor. For the past thirty years she has wintered in the Tequesta, FL. area and summered in Dorset, VT. Beyond her loving and supportive participation in her children and grandchildren's lives, she was particularly active with the Southern Vermont Art Center. Mrs. Melton is survived by her husband, Andrew and children: Diana Lemmen, Bremen, Germany; Andrew J. Melton III, Greenwich, CT; Col. Robert Melton, USMC, Fairfax, VA; Karen Fox, Palm Beach Gardens, FL; Marjorie Walsh, Morristown, NJ; Sandra Lessing, Cold Spring Harbor, NY; Michaelle Stott, Riverside, CT; Edward Melton, Stanford, CT; and her sister, Sandra Hoverkamp, Jupiter FL and Dorset, VT. A funeral mass will be held in her honor at St. Christopher's Church, Hobe Sound, FL at 10:00 AM on Friday, May 28, 1999. Contributions in lieu of flowers are suggested for the Southern Vermont Art Center, in Manchester, VT.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: At the Beacon

title: Reformer Liked by West Will Direct Russian Economic Policy
description: Finance Minister Mikhail M. Zadornov, an advocate of tough fiscal policies, will take charge of Russia's economic policy, Prime Minister Sergei V. Stepashin said today.

title: Strawberry to Be Arraigned Today
description: Darryl Strawberry is scheduled to be arraigned this morning on charges of possession of cocaine and solicitation of prostitution in Tampa, Fla., with his immediate baseball future hanging in the balance.

title: Hope Rides High on $2.5 Billion Equity Issue by Korea Telecom
description: One of the surest signs that South Korea has won back the confidence of international investors will show up on Wednesday when shares of Korea Telecom, the country's leading telephone carrier, begin trading for the first time.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLANKENSTEIN, HERMAN BIBI
description: BLANKENSTEIN-Herman Bibi. Beloved husband, father, grandfather and brother. Died at age 91. He was a true lover of sports who excelled in tennis and later in golf. We shall miss his sense of humor.

title: Reporting Prizes Are Announced
description: The Cleveland Plain Dealer, Minnesota Public Radio and ''60 Minutes'' were among the news organizations honored by the 1999 Gerald Loeb Awards for Distinguished Business and Financial Journalism. The awards, which are administered by the Anderson School at the University of California at Los Angeles and honor both print and broadcast media, were announced on Monday.

title: President's Sober Response Assures Public of Counterespionage Measures
description: The White House responded in a low-key and respectful manner to the release today of the Cox Committee report on Chinese nuclear espionage, acknowledging that a serious security breach exists while assuring Congress and the public that the Administration is working hard to improve security.

title: CALENDAR
description: Salad For All

title: Danger in the Parks
description: To the Editor:

title: A Tale of Two Jalen Roses: Which One Will Show Up?
description: Two coaches named Larry observed at different times two players named Jalen Rose. The two coaches were separate entities, while Jalen Rose was solely the party of the third part.

title: Nets Devise a Big Plan To Offer Jackson the Sky
description: By the time the Knicks begin their Eastern Conference championship series against the Indiana Pacers on Sunday, the Nets hope to have solved the latest controversy at Madison Square Garden. Within the next few days, the franchise plans to put the finishing touches on a substantial contract offer they hope will be too lucrative for Phil Jackson to turn down, according to two people in basketball with knowledge of the negotiations.

title: Desperate for Treatment, And Battled Every Step; Addicts and Mentally Ill Seen as Vulnerable to H.M.O.'s
description: Robert Payton's mother had a premonition that she would never see her son again when she dropped him off at the ferry in Weehawken that muggy day last summer. ''She turned around to wave goodbye to him from the car,'' recalled Mr. Payton's sister, Maureen Hussey, ''and she didn't see him. She told me later that it seemed like an omen to her.''

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: DYERSBURG CORP., Dyersburg, Tenn., a maker of fleece, jersey and stretch-knit fabrics, will close its plant in Hamilton, N.C., eliminating 422 jobs. It will also relocate its Trenton, Tenn., yarn-production operations.

title: N.F.L. Approves $800 Million Purchase of Redskins
description: The tortuous, sometimes bitter, process of selling the Washington Redskins concluded today when the National Football League unanimously blessed the $800 million acquisition by Daniel Snyder, a 34-year-old communications entrepreneur.

title: About New York; Traveling Music at End Of a Rainbow
description: AT the end of a late afternoon deluge last month, a rainbow appeared over the South Bronx. Its shimmering hues were wondrously electric, gracefully arcing over the skies of Hunts Point until it landed like a kiss in Mott Haven. Forget about the pot of gold; just the sight of it hovering protectively over this corner of the earth was its own reward, a suggestion of providence and life. It lingered for a few minutes before it dissolved into the darkness that washed over the city.

title: US Airways Is Replacing Its Noisy 727's In Northeast
description: As competition heats up to win over the business executives, politicians and celebrities who regularly fly between Washington, New York and Boston, US Airways plans to announce today that it will retire its fleet of noisy, 30-year-old Boeing 727's and replace them by the end of the year with roomier and quieter Airbus A-320's.

title: Hubble Telescope Yields Data for Recalculating Age of Universe
description: After eight years of measurements by the Hubble Space Telescope, astronomers think they have finally established a reliable value to the expansion rate of the universe, the indispensable number required for determining the age, size and fate of the universe.

title: Limelight at Last for Britain's Edgy Foreign Secretary
description: Representing his country at a gathering of foreign ministers in Brussels, defending the Government's war strategy in the House of Commons, meeting Clinton Administration officials in Washington -- Robin Cook is attaining a prominence in the Kosovo crisis that has eluded him in his two troubled years as Britain's Foreign Secretary.

title: Importance of Being Persuasive; Daimler-Chrysler Merger Made an Art of Making a Case
description: Jurgen E. Schrempp, the man who reigns over DaimlerChrysler, has a weak spot for trial movies.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BASTIS, CHRISTOS G.
description: BASTIS-Christos G. Shakespeare could have been thinking of Chris: ''When he shall die, Take him and cut him out in little stars, And he will make the face of heaven so fine that all the world will be in love with night, and pay no worship to the garish sun.'' Bill and Deborah Zabel

title: Former Volunteers Sue AOL, Seeking Back Pay for Work
description: Two former volunteers for America Online have filed a lawsuit in Federal Court in Manhattan in an attempt to obtain back wages, saying that they and thousands of other volunteers should have been compensated for their work.

title: INTEL INVESTS $200 MILLION IN WILLIAMS COMMUNICATIONS
description: The Intel Corporation, the No. 1 computer chip maker, agreed yesterday to take a $200 million stake in Williams Communications Inc. and plans to use Williams's high-speed network in its server farms that will host Web sites. Intel will use Williams's fiber optic network to connect the Intel Internet Data oerations, which will be large buildings full of servers that can be used to store and manage Web sites for companies that lease computing power. Williams is the telecommunications unit of the Williams Companies, the largest United States natural gas transporter.

title: INSIDE
description: Starr Rejects Retrials

title: The Knicks' Amazing Run
description: The dreaded Indiana Pacers come next, so now is the time to savor the advance of the New York Knickerbockers, who seemed dead in April, to the Eastern Conference finals. The Knicks first beat the heavily favored Miami Heat, exacting delightful revenge against former coach Pat Riley, then swept the Atlanta Hawks in four games. They did it with their crippled superstar, Patrick Ewing, playing at half speed; with a creative second unit that has outplayed everyone else's first team, and with Latrell Sprewell, a talented player and erratic personality best known for choking his former coach before the Knicks brought him to New York.

title: East Orange School Wins Music Awards
description: Fairly or not, East Orange is identified more with the sound of police sirens than with Mozart. But it was a selection from that composer's ''Exsultate, Jubilate,'' that helped the city's Washington Academy earn first place in the chamber choir competition at Musicfest Orlando last weekend at Walt Disney World.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on May 15 about a Federal court ruling on regulations about air pollution misstated the size of particles covered by standards overturned by the court and the size covered by a separate set of rules already in force. The overturned standards governing pollutants so small that they can travel deep into the lungs set limits for the amount of fine soot particles -- those 2.5 millionths of a meter (2.5 microns) in diameter or less -- in a given volume of air. A different rule regulates coarser particles, those with a diameter up to 10 microns.

title: Giuliani Agrees to Give the State Police Documents on Frisking
description: The Giuliani administration agreed yesterday to give the State Attorney General access to thousands of documents relating to the Police Department's policy of stopping people on the streets and searching them for weapons.

title: Lecture Trail In the U.S. Is Attracting Netanyahu
description: Withdrawing from active politics after his electoral defeat, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu will give up his seat in Parliament and most likely write a book and go on the lecture circuit in the United States, his spokesman said today.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Monday about Kurt Vonnegut Jr., with the continuation of his article about teaching creative writing, misstated the year. He was shown in 1998, not 1988.

title: NATO Says Bombs Hit Villa Used by Milosevic and Staff
description: With allied officials describing the Serbian air defense system as increasingly crippled, NATO planes bombed several targets overnight, including the villa and compound outside Belgrade that is a headquarters of President Slobodan Milosevic and his leadership, Pentagon and NATO officials said.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on May 18 about the Cannes International Film Festival misspelled the given name of the director of ''Cradle Will Rock.'' As noted in the article, he is Tim Robbins, not Tom.

title: Danger in the Parks
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAPIRO, ROSLYN ELGART
description: SHAPIRO-Roslyn Elgart. On May 25, 1999 in her 94th year. Loving mother of Jane Millstein and Donald and Arlene Shapiro. Proud grandmother of Rona and David Shapiro Franklin, Claudia and Harry Falk, Emma Morgan, Elizabeth Millstein, and Edward Shapiro. Adoring great grandmother of Noa Shapiro Franklin and Michael Heller Falk. For Ros, family was everything. May she rest in peace knowing how much she was loved by all of them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NAPP, EUGENIA ''JEANNE''
description: NAPP-Eugenia ''Jeanne'', on May 24, 1999. Beloved daughter of the late Jesse and Mary. Lifelong resident of Malverne, L.I. Malverne High School, Class of 1955. Lifelong active parishioner of Our Lady of Lourdes R.C. Church, Malverne. Retired long-time employee of ABC Corporation. Cherished friend to many. Friends may call Thursday 2-4 & 7-9 P.M. at the Flinch & Bruns Funeral Home, Inc., 34 Hempstead Avenue (corner Peninsula Blvd.) Lynbrook. Mass of Christian Burial Friday, May 28 at 9:45 A.M. Our Lady of Lourdes R.C. Church, Malverne. Interment St. Patrick Cemetery, Huntington, N.Y. Contributions in Jeanne's memory may be made to a favorite charity.

title: And Now, Unmistakably, From the Pacific Rim
description: IT comes on suddenly -- that overpowering urge for a sweet buttered crab pizza topped with asparagus, onion and melted Brie. It's an itch, and in New York, only Roy's can scratch it.

title: Uricks Lead Georgetown to Finals
description: Like other college undergraduates, Scott Urick comes home when he is hungry, needs a haircut or money, his father said.

title: Applebee's Account Put Into Review
description: Applebee's International in Overland Park, Kan., which operates 950 restaurants under the name Applebee's Neighborhood Bar and Grill, has placed its account in review after seven years at Wyse Advertising in Cleveland. Though billings were not disclosed, spending last year was reported at $35.5 million by Competitive Media Reporting.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIFSHITZ, EVA
description: LIFSHITZ-Eva. The Board of Directors, faculty, staff and entire student body, of 2000, at Associated Beth Rivkah Schools-Lubavitch extend sincere condolences to our devoted friend and supporter, Mr. Hyman Lifshitz upon the recent passing of his wife, Eva. Her pride in her heritage and devotion to Jewish traditions were her greatest attributes as a wife, mother and grandmother. A true personification of the biblical ''Woman of Valour'', Mrs. Lifshitz was privileged to raise an illustrious family, committed to worthy communal causes. In particular, she joined her husband in promoting the welfare of our Beth Rivkah educational network, and vitalizing its growth and progress. While her memory will live on in our halls of Torah learning, her presence in our midst will be missed. May our dear friend and patron, Mr. Lifshitz and his entire family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Rabbi Leima Minkowicz Executive Director Associated Beth Rivkah Schools 310 Crown Street Brooklyn, NY 11225

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Some Special Graduates for Whom a Diploma Also Signifies a Triumph in Life
description: For some members of the class of '99, work, school and life were intertwined in ways that made getting a diploma an unusually rich and satisfying experience.

title: Beverly Lewis, 51, Editor at Bantam Books
description: Beverly Lewis, a vice president and senior editor at Bantam Books, died on Monday in Manhattan. She was 51 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Cohen Puts Off Trip to China
description: Secretary of Defense William S. Cohen has postponed his trip next month to China, citing tension between Washington and Beijing, the Pentagon announced today.

title: Osubi Journal; That's No Airport. In Nigeria, It's a Grand Illusion.
description: Palms swaying deferentially before him, J. R. Udofia of Shell Petroleum strolled onto the tarmac to show off his company's new $30 million project.

title: Another Label, Another Life
description: Few bands were happier than Texas about the sale of Polygram's record labels to Seagram last year. A Scottish group with four albums under its belt and some 10 million albums sold around the world, Texas felt that its American label, Mercury, hardly did a thing to promote or distribute its last album, ''White on Blonde.'' The extensive executive dismissals and label overhaul, including the dissolving of Mercury, meant that the band would have another chance with Universal, a company owned by Seagram.

title: C-COR SET TO ACQUIRE SILICON VALLEY COMMUNICATIONS
description: C-Cor Electronics, a maker of cable TV network equipment, said yesterday that it would buy Silicon Valley Communications Inc. for more than $50 million in stock and assumed debt to offer more fiber optic products. C-Cor, which makes signal amplifiers, processors and network-management equipment mainly to deliver TV programs, did not disclose terms. Silicon Valley, based in Santa Clara, Calif., makes transmitters and receivers for video and Internet applications on fiber optic networks. C-Cor, based in State College, Pa., said last week that it was buying the Convergence.com Corporation, an Internet technical-services company based in Atlanta, and would change its name to C-Cor.net after the purchase is completed.

title: Baby Cilantro Comes of Age
description: OPEN a box of frilly little leaves of baby cilantro, and a clean fresh aroma wafts out. It is not at all like the smell of mature cilantro, which can seem musty, especially to those who don't like it. Like other micro greens, baby cilantro is much subtler than the grown-up version. It also has a touch of pepperiness and a bit of grassiness lacking in its older siblings.

title: A Family United By Home And Want
description: All things considered, Iree Bowling, the wizened matriarch at the center of Rory Kennedy's fine documentary film ''American Hollow,'' is pleased with the way her life has turned out. With her husband, Bass, this lean, weatherbeaten woman whose family has lived for more than a century in the wilds of eastern Kentucky, has brought up 13 children and is grandmother to more than 30. Now 68, she still has the energy to care for her bedridden mother, visit her mentally retarded sister, tend the large vegetable garden that sustains the Bowlings, pluck chickens and cook meals for her sprawling extended family.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: HOG PRICES FALL. Hog prices fell to a five-week low on expectations that retail demand for pork would weaken after the Memorial Day holiday weekend. In Chicago, hogs for June delivery fell 1.3 cents, to 53.6 cents a pound.

title: Do State Lotteries Dupe the Poor?
description: To the Editor:

title: KELSO TO ACQUIRE UNILAB FOR ABOUT $275 MILLION
description: Kelso & Company, a New York-based private investment company, said yesterday that it would acquire the Unilab Corporation for $5.85 a share in cash, or about $275 million. It will also assume about $145 million in debt. Unilab, based in Tarzana, Calif., is the largest provider of clinical laboratory testing services in California, with primary testing centers in Los Angeles, San Jose and Sacramento and more 300 regional service and testing operations across the state. Unilab's shares rose 43.75 cents, to $5.3125, in Nasdaq trading.

title: World Briefing
description: ASIA

title: GLOBAL INDUSTRIAL REJECTS SWEETENED OFFER FROM WHX
description: Global Industrial Technologies Inc. said yesterday that its board had unanimously rejected an $11.50-a-share tender offer from the WHX Corporation. Last week, WHX raised its offer from $10.50 a share. Global recommended that shareholders reject the offer -- worth $253 million based on Global's 22 million shares outstanding -- because it is in talks to sell or merge with another company. WHX currently owns 9.8 percent of Global, a Dallas-based maker of industrial products. WHX is a holding company based in Wheeling, W.Va.

title: Unremarkable Past And Unspeakable Act
description: What Justin Volpe did to Abner Louima in the bathroom of the 70th Precinct station house on Aug. 9, 1997, is now as plain as the words Officer Volpe spoke in court yesterday. Why he did it, however, remains painfully, perhaps permanently, inscrutable.

title: Wish That Didn't Cover All the Bases
description: George Steinbrenner apparently never learned the admonition that you had better watch what you wish for because you might get it. All right, so Steinbrenner never wishes for something; he demands it. But in the case of Hideki Irabu, a k a the fat toad, it came down to the same idea.

title: America's Stolen Secrets
description: A devastating pattern of security lapses is laid out in the Congressional report on China's acquisition of America's most vital nuclear and missile secrets. Beijing remains far from nuclear parity with the United States. But a bipartisan House committee, headed by Christopher Cox, Republican of California, found that China has systematically exploited poor security at American nuclear weapons labs, lax satellite licensing and weak export control laws to speed work on a new generation of nuclear weapons and missiles.

title: In Brooklyn, Relief and More Expectations
description: As word of Justin A. Volpe's guilty plea in the brutalization of Abner Louima trickled through Crown Heights, Brooklyn, the words ''justice was served'' were repeated by several residents of the neighborhood, home to a large portion of Brooklyn's West Indian population.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BASTIS, CHRISTOS G.
description: BASTIS-Christos G. The Board of Directors of Atlantic Bank of New York, the Chairman, Theodoros B. Karatzas, the President and CEO, Peter L. Venetis, along with all the officers and staff, express their deepest sympathies to the family of our beloved and faithful Director Emeritus Christos Bastis. One of the most successful GreekAmerican immigrants to this country, he was a pioneer in his professional, cultural and community activities. To Atlantic Bank, as its longest sitting director, he was a contemplative leader that bridged the gap between the newly arrived and the settled and who taught us to appreciate and preserve Hellenic art, culture and spirit. We extend our sincere condolences to his widow Josephine; children Christopher, George, Jason and Betty; and all the grandchildren and great-grandchildren.

title: Marketing and the mob: a marriage of convenience now a Madison Avenue favorite.
description: MADISON AVENUE is getting mobbed up, as gangster and Mafia imagery and language become increasingly common in advertising.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Saturday about a deal between the author Simon Schama and Talk Miramax Books, a division of Talk Media, to publish his next work of nonfiction, ''Brittania,'' misidentified the television outlet for a series based on the book. It is the History Channel, not ABC.

title: Once Again, McKesson Is Revising Its Earnings
description: In what is becoming a serial calamity, McKesson HBOC Inc. announced yesterday that it would make further revisions to its fiscal and quarterly earnings because of improperly recorded sales at HBO & Company, a software maker it acquired in January.

title: Queen of Broadway is Remembered
description: Lucille Lortel, the longtime theater producer known as the Queen of Off Broadway, was remembered at a memorial tribute on Monday as a benefactor of the arts whose stubborn devotion to the playwrights she loved helped foster some of the most celebrated theater of the 20th century.

title: Telecom Italia's Chief and Board Resign
description: The chief executive and the board of Telecom Italia S.p.A. resigned today in the aftermath of their defeat by Olivetti in the recent battle for control of the telecommunications giant.

title: Petrie Is Named Executive of Year
description: Geoff Petrie, the Kings' vice president of basketball operations, was named executive of the year in voting by his fellow National Basketball Association executives.

title: House Speaker Expects a Gun Bill to Pass
description: House Republican leaders announced today that they were drafting a broad package of gun-control measures similar to those passed by the Senate last week, and Speaker J. Dennis Hastert predicted that at least some of the provisions would succeed in the House as well.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOBIN, LOUIS
description: SOBIN-Louis. On May 25. Beloved husband of Mae. Devoted brother of Alice. Survived by many loving nieces and nephews. A gentle and loving man who set a wonderful example. Service today, 1PM, at ''Gutterman-Musicant'', 402 Park Street, Hackensack, New Jersey.

title: Fund-Raising Figure Had Spy Case Role
description: A new Congressional report has determined that there is a connection between a key figure in the campaign finance controversy and China's theft of sensitive military-related technology from the United States.

title: The Maple Leafs Feast On Hasek-less Sabres
description: When Dwayne Roloson gave up four goals in Game 1 of the Sabres-Maple Leafs Eastern Conference final series, he was seen as sort of a super substitute, a successful replacement for Dominik Hasek, the injured Buffalo goalie. That was because Roloson's teammates scored one more goal than the Maple Leafs to win the opener, 5-4.

title: BRITISH PUB DEAL
description: The world's second-largest liquor company, Allied Domecq P.L.C., agreed to sell its British pubs to Whitbread P.L.C. for $:2.4 billion ($3.8 billion) in stock as it scrambles to keep up with the beverage market leader, Diageo P.L.C. Whitbread will pay Allied investors with 230 million new shares and assume $:25 million of debt. After the sale, Allied's chief executive for eight years, Tony Hales, 51, plans to step down and make way for the finance director, Philip Bowman, to replace him. Shedding the 3,500 British pubs will allow Allied to focus on its Ballantine's Scotch, Beefeater gin and other liquor brands.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HART, OWEN
description: HART-Owen. Our sincerest condolences to his family on his untimely passing. Al Dayton and Family

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Warning by First Union Draws Heap of Scorn
description: In glitzy, futuristic television advertisements, the First Union Corporation has been proudly promoting itself as ''The Mountain.'' But the ground beneath that mountain is trembling.

title: A Matter of Perspective
description: The House panel's conclusions, classified and unclassified, do not all dovetail with those of the American intelligence community. Page A20.

title: Studio to Rein In Violence on 'Jerry Springer'
description: The studio that owns ''The Jerry Springer Show'' -- the daytime talk show notorious for violence, profanity and physical confrontation -- announced yesterday that it will edit those three elements out of future shows.

title: Barnesandnoble.com Rises 27%; Exceeds Market Value of Parent
description: The initial offering yesterday of Barnesandnoble.com, the Web business spun off by the giant bookseller Barnes & Noble Inc., was a success as measured by historic market standards, but it was a distinct yawner as Internet offerings go.

title: In Pivotal Contest, Republicans Hold On to Senate Seat for Rockland and Orange
description: In a closely watched special election that was the catalyst for repealing New York City's tax on commuters, Republicans today held on to a pivotal State Senate seat from Rockland and Orange Counties.

title: Ruth Gilbert, Editor, 88
description: Ruth Gilbert, a retired editor at New York magazine and The New York Herald Tribune, died on Thursday at her home in Manhattan. She was 88 years old.

title: In Albany, Battle Grows Over Budget
description: Because the state budget is late, legislators have gone almost two months without pay, and some angry and frustrated Democrats want to make Gov. George E. Pataki do without, too.

title: Business Travel; In New York City, it is not impossible to find a discounted hotel room, at least for the moment.
description: DISCOUNTED hotel rates are currently available in New York City, despite public perception to the contrary.

title: Volpe Recounts Night of Brutality, Threats and Rage
description: Following are excerpts from the transcript of the guilty plea entered by Justin A. Volpe in United States District Court in Brooklyn yesterday before Judge Eugene H. Nickerson. In making the plea, Mr. Volpe was required to disclose details of his participation in the crime.

title: Too Many Guns, Too Many Laws
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Patterns column yesterday about the American Fashion Awards misstated the name of an actress who is expected to present one. She is Julianna Margulies, not Joanna Margolies.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE YEN GAINS. The dollar fell against the Japanese yen as concerns about rising United States interest rates hurt stocks and sapped demand for dollars to buy them. In New York, the dollar settled at 122.70 yen, down from 123.21.

title: FRENCH ON-LINE DEAL
description: A French book and music retailer, FNAC, moved to shore up its position on the Internet with a deal to buy the on-line bookstore Alize. FNAC, which is controlled by Pinault-Printemps-Redoute S.A., recently created its own Web site for books and CD-ROM's. Alize started the Alibabook on-line bookstore last December, one of a number of new Internet shopping services in France. Pinault-Printemps, controlled by Francois Pinault, did not disclose the sale price. Edmund L. Andrews

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  COWIN, DANIEL
description: COWIN-Daniel. Dearest friendplease come back-everything is precisely as you left it. Those of us who knew you best miss your unfailing warmth, wisdom and kindess-daily. Intensely. Love, Joyce and family.

title: Clinton Sets Safety Goals For Truckers
description: The Clinton Administration today set a goal of reducing deaths from truck crashes by 50 percent over 10 years and promised quick action on safety questions that had stymied it for years, including revising the 62-year-old rules on how many hours a day a driver can work.

title: A. P. Rios, 84, An Organizer In Politics
description: Anthony P. Rios, a veteran political organizer among Hispanic Californians, died on May 19 at Kaiser Permanente Hospital in Baldwin Park, a suburb of Los Angeles. He was 84 and lived in Los Angeles.

title: A Troubadour for Soccer Moms and Their Restless Generation
description: Mary Chapin Carpenter turned mischievous with an encore at Tramps. To a tender melody, she sang ''If I Were a Diva,'' mocking Madonna, Shania Twain, Mariah Carey and Celine Dion. Ms. Carpenter, of course, is no diva. Without affectations or pretensions to glamour, she represents baby boomers, especially women, who are trying to muddle through the lowered expectations of adulthood.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Market Continues Its Slide Led by Technology Shares

title: Just a Garnish? Still Be Careful
description: PARSLEY very often is a garnish that is left on the plate. Which makes the discovery that parsley was responsible for seven outbreaks of shigellosis, a food-borne illness, last summer all the more remarkable.

title: FOOD STUFF
description: Pastry on Lexington: Guy Pascal Branches Out

title: NATO TV Is Sent to Serbs, Who Are Harsh Critics
description: The picture is grainy, the sound poor, but if people here really want to, and if they have electricity, they can tune into NATO TV, beamed into Serbia on Channel 21 every evening from an American Hercules plane.

title: Shares Again Fall Steeply; Nasdaq Loses Nearly 3%
description: Stocks slumped for the fourth consecutive session yesterday as a selloff continued in technology and Internet issues.

title: KOSOVO UPDATE
description: DIPLOMACY

title: Mental Patient Fatally Shot After Attack on an Officer
description: A man who had a record of violent behavior and was released from a state mental hospital six months ago stabbed a police officer in Queens yesterday and was then shot to death by the officer's partner, the police said.

title: U.S. JOINS WHISTLE-BLOWER SUIT AGAINST COLUMBIA/HCA
description: The United States Justice Department joined a whistle-blower lawsuit yesterday against the Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation that accuses the company, the nation's largest hospital chain, of paying doctors to refer patients to it. Federal law prohibits hospitals from offering cash or other inducements for the referral of patients covered by Medicare or Medicaid. The lawsuit, filed by Sara Ortega, a former employee of the Nashville-based Columbia/HCA, is the fourth that the Justice Department has joined as part of its sweeping Medicare-fraud investigation of the company.

title: The Fast Way To Grill
description: FOR all the pleasures of slow smoking on a grill, speed is why we usually most value a grill in the backyard. I constantly get requests for a simple but unusual, fast-cooking, great-tasting recipe for the grill, and I always recommend spicy shrimp.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VAN BRUNT, EDWIN D.
description: VAN BRUNT-Edwin D. Of Somers, N.Y. On May 23, 1999. Beloved husband of Marion Rydholm Van Brunt. Devoted father of Laurie Van Brunt Schoen and Carl. Brother of Albert of New York and East Hampton and the late Robert of Sarasota, FL. Grandfather of Nicholas, Bryan and Trevor Van Brunt and Daniel Schoen. Retired Chairman of Van Brunt and Company, AdvertisingMarketing, Inc of New York. Advertising executive for over 55 years. Long-time resident of Chappaqua and Mount Kisco. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Guiding Eyes for the Blind, 611 Granite Spring Road, Yorktown Heights, N.Y. 10598.

title: A Guitar to Vanquish the Twerp Within
description: In the songs Doug Martsch writes for Built to Spill, his guitar is his best friend in the world. It doesn't let him down like the friends and lovers he sings about. It's sturdier than his high, reedy voice. And it's a constant inspiration, generating riffs and melodies to create a sonic architecture that elevates even his petty complaints. With his guitar in hand, Mr. Martsch is no longer a twerp who can't ever get what he wants; he has a chance at majesty and something like heroism. And he speaks to other long-suffering and resentful souls.

title: Sonia Gandhi Reclaims Congress Party and Its Members' Devotion
description: Sonia Gandhi, the Italian-born heiress to an Indian dynasty, made a triumphant return today as leader of the political party that has ruled the nation for most of the last half-century and is now trying to regain power.

title: A Blue Wall of Witnesses
description: It is too soon to suggest that the Abner Louima case has finally brought down the ''blue wall of silence'' that has long prevented New York City police officers from testifying against their colleagues. But a crack of potentially seismic proportions began to open when the sickening testimony of a series of his peers forced Officer Justin Volpe to plead guilty yesterday to charges that he tortured Mr. Louima two years ago in a Brooklyn police station bathroom.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEYER, YISRAEL (JULIUS)
description: MEYER-Yisrael (Julius). Bar-Ilan University and its American friends mourn the passing of Yisrael Julius Meyer, the beloved brother of our honorary alumnus, Manfred H. Meyer, whose generosity made possible the publication of one of the most important biographies that the University has ever published, that of Rabbi Jacob Hoffman, of blessed memory.
