May the family draw solace from inspiring memories and be comforted among all the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Rabbi Emanuel Rackman, Chancellor, Bar-Ilan University

title: RECORD FOR NTT MOBILE
description: Bucking the trend of losses and declining profits at large Japanese companies, NTT Mobile Communications Network Inc. reported record profit for the year that ended on March 31. The company, which will change its name to NTT Docomo Inc. next year, said its profit soared to 204.82 billion yen, about $1.7 billion, up 69.8 percent from the previous year. Operating revenue was helped by brisk sales of cellular phones, notably car phones, and the company has grabbed about half of the cellular market. Sheryl WuDunn

title: From Trailblazing to Losing Their Way
description: This season Dr. Kate Austin on ''Chicago Hope'' joined NASA and planned to go into outer space (many of us thought this annoying character belonged there in the first place.) ''N.Y.P.D. Blue'' resorted to dream scenes about Detective Andy Sipowicz's father and acted out the plot of a noir detective novel. And ''E.R.'' gave Dr. Mark Greene his very own stalker.

title: BRITISH AIRWAYS' NET DOWN
description: Profits at British Airways fell 61 percent in the year that ended on March 31, down to $:225 million ($367 million) from $:580 million a year earlier. The company attributed the plunge to the world economic slowdown and weak demand, particularly on its Asian routes, for first- and business-class seats. It said its strategy would be to reduce the number of discounted seats and offer added services to holders of premium seats. Warren Hoge

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Asbestos Removal Shuts a Restaurant

title: Shuttle Ready for Thursday Launching in Mission to Space Station
description: With the first load of supplies for the international space station packed in its cargo bay, the space shuttle Discovery is poised for launching on Thursday, NASA's first human space mission in six months.

title: Contrarian New Hampshire To Honor Dr. King, at Last
description: New Hampshire lawmakers today approved a permanent holiday honoring the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., ending years of such protracted and contrarian resistance that the long-awaited vote prompted one civil rights advocate to exclaim, ''Free at last, free at last, thank God almighty, I'm free at last!''

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the continued flow of oil to Yugoslavia, despite NATO's cutoff efforts, referred incorrectly to the cold war political status of Bulgaria and Romania, signers of the Danube Convention of 1948 calling for free movement of ships. They were part of the Soviet bloc, not the Soviet Union.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STERN, CAROL
description: STERN-Carol. Of Fort Lee, N.J. and Longboat Key, FL. Wife of Howard Stern. Daughter of Lillian Davis and the late Lester I. Mother of Rebecca Stern and stepmother of Patricia Stern and John Stern. Sister of Steven Davis. Funeral service at ''GuttermanMusicant'' 402 Park St, Hackensack NJ Thursday, May 27th, 1PM. Contributions to American Cancer Society would be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RABINOWITZ, CLARA
description: RABINOWITZ-Clara. Trained first as a social worker and then as a psychologist, devoted much of her life to community service, including service at the local & national levels. She died in her home on May 23, 1999. She is survived by a sister, Zelda Meranze & a brother, Albert Rabinowitz, eleven nieces and nephews, 26 grandnieces and nephews in addition to several great-grandnephews and great grandnieces. She will be interred today at the Woodbine Brotherhood Cemetery in Woodbine, NJ. A memorial service is planned for a later date. Contributions may be made to Psychologists for Social Responsibility and Doctors Without Borders.

title: AUTONATION MAY CREATE SEPARATE STOCK FOR NET UNIT
description: Autonation Inc., the largest United States auto retailer, has hired Merrill Lynch & Company to explore creating a separate stock and other options for its Internet business, where sales are rising faster than expected. Autonation now forecasts Internet-based sales of $750 million for this year, up from the $500 million it predicted earlier. Sales are expected to rise to $1.5 billion next year and $3 billion in 2001, Steven Berrard, the co-chief executive with H. Wayne Huizenga, said yesterday at the company's annual meeting in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. Autonation, which changed its named from Republic Industries in April, chalks up a sale to the Internet whenever the Web played a role such as customer referrals or price comparisons. Autonation shares fell 37.5 cents, to $15.625.

title: A Restaurant Reborn Without Changing Name or Owner
description: I LIKED Indigo well enough when Scott Bryan opened it more than three years ago as a casual, Asian-influenced sibling to Luma in Chelsea, his more formal, more expensive restaurant. But change is the nature of the restaurant business, and a lot has changed since then. Mr. Bryan closed Luma, replacing it with Siena, a less-expensive Italian restaurant. In the Flatiron district, he opened Veritas, and he no longer devotes much time to Indigo. And I've changed the way I feel about Indigo.

title: Philanthropy Rose 11% in 1998, Report Says
description: Pushed by a healthy economy and the rising stock market, charitable giving by Americans climbed 11 percent to a record $175 billion last year, according to estimates in a report made public yesterday.

title: Ode to a Cone (Fill It Up)
description: A SURE sign of Memorial Day -- along with the appearance of picnic coolers and barbecue tools -- is usually a deluge of ice cream books. But this year, there is only a sprink ling on bookstore shelves. Has it become too easy just to buy a pint of passion fruit or chocolate-chocolate-chocolate chunk?

title: Politics of Drug Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: Person Returns $14,000 That Fell on Turnpike
description: A package that arrived Monday at the office of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey contained more than $14,000, toll proceeds from the Holland Tunnel that fell off the back of an armored truck last week on the New Jersey Turnpike.

title: Ive Got Your Number
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Corrections
description: A listing of credits on Monday with a television review of ''Me and My Matchmaker,'' a documentary shown Monday night on Channel 13 in New York, misidentified one writer. The film was written by Robert DeMaio, who also edited it, and Mark Wexler. The producers, as noted, were Mr. Wexler and Hajira Majid.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PIECH, PETER M.
description: PIECH-Peter M. 80, of Boca Raton, FL, died Tuesday, May 25, 1999 at the Boca Raton Community Hospital. Mr. Piech was a member of The Producers Guild of America in California, N.A.T.A.S., and was the Executive Producer of the Rocky & Bullwinkle Show, Underdog, and Judge Roy Bean. He is survived by his wife Olga and two children, Pam Sampson and Peter, both of NJ, and four grandchildren. Services will be held in Boca Raton, FL. For information contact, The Babione Funeral Home, Boca Raton, FL.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEWART, GEORGE TAYLOR
description: STEWART-George Taylor III, 74, of Lynchburg, VA, died Tuesday, May 25, 1999, at Virginia Baptist Hospital after a lengthy illness. He is survived by his wife of 52 years, Bonnie Myers Stewart. He is also survived by his daughter Diane Stewart Carrington & her husband, Fredrick W. ''Rick'' Carrington; by his daughter Susan Stewart Dupuis; and by four grandchildren, Paul Carrington, John Carrington, Leigh Carrington & Taylor Dupuis, all of Lynchburg. Mr. Stewart was born in Manhattan December 29, 1924, the son of the late Fargo Calvin Stewart and Berthe Pelleton Stewart. Mr. Stewart grew up on Long Island, graduating from Brooklyn Tech in 1943 and Wesleyan University in 1947. He also attended Williams College and New York University School of Law. He served as an officer in the U.S. Navy during World War II in the Pacific and Atlantic theatres of operations. He began his career in 1947 with the Hartford Accident and Indemnity Company. He was an insurance stock analyst with Geyer & Company and Shelby Cullom Davis & Company and was in charge of the insurance stocks department with Blyth and Co. He was also a member of the New York Society of Security Analysts for over 40 years. In 1963, he joined First Colony Life Insurance Company in Lynchburg as a director and was its chairman and chief executive officer from 1965 until his retirement in 1992. He was also chairman of American Mayflower Life Insurance Company of New York. Mr. Stewart served as a director or trustee of numerous companies, including Ethyl Corporation, Crestar Financial Corporation and Media General, Inc. A member of First Presbyterian Church of Lynchburg, he served as an ordained elder for over four decades and as a long-time teacher of the Manson-Stewart Bible Class. Mr. Stewart was a vital part of Lynchburg civic activities and charitable organizations and the recipient of many awards for such endeavors. His contributions to the community included service as chairman of the board of trustees of Lynchburg College, where he was awarded an honorary doctorate degree of humane letters. He was a major leader in the restoration of Jefferson's Poplar Forest. He also served as chairman of the board for the Greater Lynchburg Community Trust and president and director of the Greater Lynchburg Chamber of Commerce, and was the Pro Opera Civica award recipient in 1982. He was on the advisory board of the Salvation Army, a board member of Step With Links, Inc., and formerly served as chairman of the Special Finance Committee of Thomas Road Baptist Church. In 1988, he was named the recipient of the Douglas Mooers Award of Excellence, given by the National Association of Independent Life Brokerage Agencies. He was a member and former director of Boonsboro Country Club and the Piedmont Club, and a member of the Metropolitan Club of New York. A service will be conducted at 2 P.M., Thursday, May 27, at First Presbyterian Church in Lynchburg. The family requests that memorial contributions be made to Jefferson's Poplar Forest, Forest, VA. 24551, to the Greater Lynchburg Community Trust, or to the First Presbyterian Church, 1215 V.E.S. Road, Lynchburg, VA 24503. For further information, contact Heritage Funeral Services at 804-239-2405.

title: Separated By the War, 4 Siblings With Scars
description: It's not just that no one knows what to say anymore; it's that no one knows what to feel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOEWE, MILDRED
description: LOEWE-Mildred (Schiffer) on May 26, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Arthur. Loving mother of William and Judith Loewe. Dear sister of Morton A. Schiffer, MD. Cherished grandmother to Michael and Christopher, and greatgrandmother. Services Friday, 12pm at ''The Riverside'' 76th Street & Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAYOR, ROSE
description: MAYOR-Rose, M.D. The Missionary Sisters of the Sacred Heart and the medical staff of Cabrini Medical Center mourn the loss of their esteemed colleague who served our institution for more than 20 years. Dr. Mayor was a dedicated physician who always showed sincere concern for her patients and for Cabrini Medical Center. Our heartfelt sympathy and condolences to her family. Maurizio Daliana, M.D. President, Medical Staff Morton Davidson, M.D. Med Dir Jeffrey Frerichs, President Cabrini Medical Center

title: A Non-U Double Take
description: Well-heeled Beverly Hills has its first check-cashing store, but don't try to use it. Replicating the facade and interior of a check-cashing store on the east side of Los Angeles, down to the last scratch and Spanish-language flier, Glen Seator has inserted an installation, with city permission, into an entrance of the Gagosian Gallery, with its pristine Richard Meier design. The idea is visual dissonance, says Mr. Seator, a Brooklyn artist, who even used the same sign maker. The artist claims no intentional social comment, but the work (depicted in the gallery invitation, above) underscores the separate worlds of the wealthy of Beverly Hills and the largely immigrant staff that keeps it running. ''Three'' is up through mid-July at the gallery, 456 North Camden Drive. FRANCES ANDERTON

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: A Jazz Mystery, A Sultry Memory

title: A Pyrrhic Victory for Albany
description: On Tuesday, a Republican county legislator named Thomas Morahan defeated a Democratic county legislator named Kenneth Zebrowski for an open seat in the New York State Senate. As a result, the Republican majority's control of the Senate will rise from 35-25 to 36-25. For this, the Legislature killed a tax worth $360 million to New York City.

title: School Orchestras' High-Octane Conductor
description: JONATHAN STRASSER, music director of the InterSchool Orchestras, conductor of many a school orchestra (that was him playing himself as the wildly enthusiastic conductor at the High School of the Performing Arts in the movie ''Fame'') speaks with such velocity and intensity that finally one collapses on the sofa of his art-filled duplex as if hit by a hurricane, begging for a break, or at least a slowdown, from the storm of words.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a woman and three of her children who were killed on Tuesday when they were hit by an Amtrak train in Fairfield, Conn., misidentified the police force headed by James O'Donnell, who spoke at a news conference. It is the Metropolitan Transportation Authority Police, not Connecticut State Police.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STERN, CAROL
description: STERN-Carol. Of Fort Lee, N.J. and Longboat Key, FL. Wife of Howard Stern. Daughter of Lillian Davis & the late Lester I. Mother of Rebecca Stern and stepmother of Patricia Stern and John Stern. Sister of Steven Davis. Funeral service at ''Gutterman-Musicant'', 402 Park Street, Hackensack, New Jersey Thursday, May 27th, 1 PM. Contributions to American Cancer Society would be appreciated.

title: Metro Business; Plans in Jersey City For Offices and Hotel
description: Three new developments with a total of 900,000 square feet of space have been announced for the Harborside Financial Center office complex in Jersey City by Mack-Cali Realty Corporation, a real estate investment trust based in New Jersey.

title: TRIBUNAL IS SAID TO CITE MILOSEVIC FOR WAR CRIMES
description: The international tribunal in The Hague has decided to indict Slobodan Milosevic, the Yugoslav President, for war crimes and will formally announce the action on Thursday, Western officials said today.

title: Surviving Boy Was Misidentified in Amtrak Deaths
description: The police and railroad officials, continuing their investigation into the death of a 48-year-old woman and three of her four sons who were on the railroad tracks early Tuesday when they were struck by an Amtrak train, said today that the wrong boy was identified as the sole survivor of the accident.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DUNNINGTON, WALTER G.
description: DUNNINGTON-Walter G. Jr. A gathering of friends celebrating remembrances of his life. The Chapel at Saint Bartholomew's, Park Avenue at 50th Street, 4:30 P.M., Wednesday, June 2nd, 1999.

title: Making I.S.P. Choices
description: To the Editor:

title: Update Indian Treaties
description: To the Editor:

title: Girl, 14, Is Found Hanged in a Bronx School Bathroom Stall
description: A 14-year-old girl was found hanged with a clothesline in a bathroom stall at a Bronx high school yesterday in what officials said appeared to be a suicide.

title: G.O.P. Chief In Dutchess Is Accused Of Extortion
description: The chairman of the Dutchess County Republican Party was arrested by Federal authorities yesterday on charges that he forced developers to make payments to the local party and himself in exchange for permits and tax breaks.

title: A Farce That Takes Aim At Old Yet Modern Targets
description: Of all the farces written in the last 300 years, few would seem more suitable for today's audience than ''Tartuffe,'' Moliere's hilarious raillery against religious fanatics, hypocrisy and sex -- topics all too familiar in our recent national life. The Acting Company, the traveling troupe of young actors, has brought its touring production to New York, and while it is an energetic and loud one, it often seems to forget that the play is a comedy.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LIPPMAN, BERT J.
description: LIPPMAN-Bert J. 18 years today you left us. Not a day goes by that we do not think of you lovingly. We miss you. You are forever in our hearts. Ruth, Jane, Robin, Chuck, Stefan, Jessica - Class of '99, and Bradley, your namesake, Class of '99.

title: If Lawmakers Call for Blood, They May End Up With Reno's
description: A Congressional committee's conclusion that China systematically stole nuclear secrets has roused angry lawmakers in both parties to look for a high-profile official to blame, and increasingly they are taking aim at Attorney General Janet Reno, for failing to respond aggressively to the threat.

title: GARDEN Q. & A.
description: Tough Tomatoes

title: Air Force Is Told to Suspend Retirements
description: The Pentagon ordered a sweeping suspension of retirements from the Air Force today to insure that enough pilots and other personnel are available to continue waging NATO's air war in the Balkans.

title: Privacy and Ride-Alongs
description: The Supreme Court followed understandable legal reasoning this week when it barred the police from allowing reporters and camera crews to go with officers into private homes that are being raided. The unanimous decision, which cited ''the right of residential privacy'' as a core principle of the Fourth Amendment, will mean fewer television shots of drug busts. Even so, it is very important that the police see the Court's action for what it is, a narrow reinforcement of traditional residential privacy rights, and not use it to deter serious newsgathering and journalistic investigations.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about the spinoff of Delphi Automotive Systems by General Motors, which owns 82.3 percent of it, misstated the distribution of shares. G.M. shareholders will receive 80.1 percent of Delphi; 2.2 percent will go to a nonpension retirement plan. The remaining 17.7 percent of Delphi is already publicly held.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Diplomats Trying to Find Solution Will Try Again
description: Negotiations toward a solution to the Kosovo crisis broke up unusually late tonight with no clear evidence of progress, but representatives of Russia, the United States and the European Union planned to try again on Thursday.

title: A Female Shaman With Wagnerian Zest
description: WHEN a video game genre gets long in the tooth and it seems that there are no themes left to exploit (Green Berets, extraterrestrials, comic books, cyberpunks, 3-D, been there, done that), designers generally sit back, let their minds wander and arrive at the next obvious solution: women.

title: After a 20-Year Cleanup, a Brighter, Clearer 'Last Supper' Emerges
description: After 20 years of painstaking chipping, dabbing and scrubbing, Leonardo da Vinci's ''Last Supper'' is at long last restored and ready to be shown on Friday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LASSAR, EMANUEL
description: LASSAR-Emanuel. Congregation Shaaray Tefila in Lawrence mourns the passing of Emanuel Lassar, longtime devoted member and esteemed Past President. Loving husband of Adele, father of Naomi and Steve Lassar, Hanina and Louis Rottenberg. Grandfather of Bess, Moshe, Jacob, and Erik. Services Thursday, 9:30AM, Boulevard Chapel, Hewlett. We extend heartfelt condolences to the entire family. Martin Klein, President David Weinberger, Rabbi Dr. Walter S. Wurzburger, Rabbi Emeritus

title: Good News on Jobs, Or Just Good Times?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LEVINE, ADA
description: LEVINE-Ada. Passed away 30 years ago on this date. Remembered with love and respect for her devotions to her husband, Leon, who predeceased her, to her children George and Claire, to their spouses, Shirley and the late Howard Silverman, and to her grandchildren, Shari (and husband Neil), Edward and Leonard. Her time with us was too short in years, but long in the positive impact that she had, and continues to have on our lives. We miss you Mom, but know that you and Daddy continue to watch over and guide us. Thank you for the legacy that, together, you left us.

title: Knicks Depending on Camby's Agility to Catch Up to Pacers
description: Last June, when the Knicks sent their beloved Mr. Hustle, Charles Oakley, to the Toronto Raptors for the gangly yet graceful Marcus Camby, they named the Indiana Pacers as the impetus. In eliminating the Knicks from the Eastern Conference semifinals in five games a month earlier, the Pacers' younger, more athletic forwards had sped around Oakley and his slow-footed teammates for rebounds and dunks at crucial junctures.

title: A New Arts Center Opens Against All Odds
description: There is likely to be a huge sigh of relief in this corner of the Berkshires on Sunday with the opening of the $37 million Massachusetts Museum of Contemporary Art after 13 roller-coaster years and a last-minute scramble to install the giant artworks it was designed to display. MASS MOCA, as the center has become known, is a marriage of art and urban renewal fraught by politics, economic constraints and uncertain artistic ambitions.

title: RESIDENTIAL SALES
description: Manhattan

title: Essay; Follow Up the Cox Report
description: In the CNN parking lot the other night, after a Larry King telecast about the hemorrhage of our secrets to China, Representative Chris Cox told the Senate Intelligence Committee chairman, Richard Shelby: ''We're out of business. Now it's up to you.''

title: High-End Dueling Televisions
description: FROM the outside it's hard to believe how passionate electronics engineers, people who are only a few years too young to have carried pocket protectors, can become about issues as arcane as this one: Does a high-resolution television picture look better using the high-definition format favored by many television manufacturers, or the so-called 480-P format used by the computer industry?

title: India's 318 Runs Are Second Highest
description: India made the second-highest total in Cricket World Cup history yesterday to defeat Sri Lanka by 157 runs, and South Africa defeated Kenya for its fourth consecutive victory in matches at Taunton, England.

title: The Hum Heard Across America
description: AS Memorial Day looms, few pronouncements strike more terror in the heart than those inevitable words, ''Hazy, hot and humid.''

title: Sitting Pretty in Palm Beach
description: Addison Mizner (1872-1933), the architect whose Mediterranean-style confections dominated Palm Beach, Fla., in the 1920's, also made furniture. ''Addison Mizner: Rare Photographs, Circa 1930'' is an exhibition of 60 photographs of his designs, like a vanity (left) and dining table (bottom). The chaise (below) is a piece that he copied.

title: E-Mail Becomes Snail Mail
description: COMPATIBILITY. That's a big word in computers, especially to novices who forever find themselves, hexagonal peg in hand, steam emanating from ears, staring at an octagonal hole, and who, in having the effrontery to think they can download with the big boys and girls, continually get messages like ''You just made a type x2z46tf error, you numskull!''

title: Death-Penalty Logic
description: To the Editor:

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We've already bombed his house, we've already bombed his wife's business. If that didn't wound him or change his thinking, I don't think an indictment will.''

title: Euro is Seen Falling Below The $1 Level
description: Where's the bottom for the euro?

title: Press Effort on Police Strictures in Limbo After a Private Meeting
description: After years of complaining that New York City police have blocked press access to crime scenes and public events, sometimes by confiscating press passes, several of the city's major news organizations got together recently to force that access, by filing a lawsuit, if necessary.

title: John Tigrett, 85, Entrepreneur And Inventor in Tennessee
description: John Burton Tigrett, a Tennessee entrepreneur who made a fortune on things like the Glub-Glub drinking duck novelty, befriended financiers like Sir James Goldsmith and musicians like Isaac Hayes and advised politicians like Vice President Al Gore, died on May 18 in a hotel room in Washington. He was 85.

title: A Success A Year Later
description: When I first became acquainted with Elisabeth Schmitz, about 15 months ago, she had become publishing's overnight sensation. The first book acquired and edited by this young editor was a literary novel that was not only critically acclaimed but also became a mighty best seller. The book was ''Cold Mountain,'' and the tantalizing question was, could she keep up the heat in a world that gobbles up ideas and people so quickly?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAYWARD, RETIRED VICE ADMIRAL JOHN T.
description: HAYWARD-Retired Vice Admiral John T. ''Chick'', who helped develop the atomic bomb dropped over Nagasaki, Japan, died Sunday at his home in Atlantic Beach, Florida. He was 90 years old. He also developed systems for ground- and air-launched rockets and became a pioneer in the development of weapons used to fight submarines. He was promoted to rear admiral in 1961 after commanding the aircraft carrier USS Franklin D. Roosevelt from the West Coast to Mayport, FL. He also commanded the first nuclearpowered task force in naval history, leading the USS Enterprise. In 1966, as a vice admiral, he was named president of the Naval War College in Newport, RI, and remained there until his retirement from the Navy in 1968. He went on to work for General Dynamics as vice president for international programs before starting his own consulting business. Admiral Hayward is survived by a sister, Marjorie Madey, of Baton Rouge, LA; a son, John T. Hayward, Jr., of Newport, RI; daughters, Jennifer Bramhall, of Oakland, CA; Marion Pontzer, of Sterling, VA; Victoria Hayward of Neptune Beach, FL; and Shelley Klein of Fern Park, FL; 22 grandchildren and 21 greatgrandchildren. The funeral will be held 12:45 p.m. Monday, June 14, 1999, at the Fort Myers Chapel at Arlington National Cemetery, Arlington, VA. Memorial contributions may be made to Hope Haven, 4600 Beach Blvd, Jacksonville, FL 32207.

title: Political Briefing; Some Big Thunder In Big Sky Country
description: Representative Rick Hill, a conservative Republican who is sparsely populated Montana's sole House member, won his first two elections by fairly comfortable margins of about 10 percentage points. But his third campaign is shaping up as a much closer contest -- and maybe one of the most mean-spirited in the nation.

title: Flare-Up in Kashmir
description: The snow has usually melted in the Himalayan foothills by this time of year, and it is not uncommon for India and Pakistan to engage in artillery fire across their disputed border. Yesterday, however, tensions between these two nuclear powers escalated sharply with an Indian air attack on alleged infiltrators from Pakistan in Indian-held territory in Kashmir. The new hostilities are dangerous. Both nations should exercise military restraint, pull back from their confrontation and renounce the use of force to settle their conflict.

title: Political Memo; A Clinton Candidacy Divides Democrats
description: Former Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York says the best thing for Vice President Al Gore's campaign for President would be if Hillary Rodham Clinton stays put and does not run for the Senate from New York.

title: W.T.O. STILL SEEKS HEAD
description: Amid warnings that the upcoming Seattle trade meeting could be wrecked by continuing dissension, the member nations of the World Trade Organization met again to hash over the selection of a new leader. Mike Moore of New Zealand currently leads Supachai Panitchpakdi of Thailand by a thin margin. But Ali Mchumo of Tanzania, who is coordinating the search, said ''there has been an increase in the number of countries which have intimated'' their support of Moore.

title: NEWS WATCH
description: The Internet must be a community because now you can tell on your neighbors. The F.B.I. and the National White Collar Crime Center announced recently that they were creating an Internet Fraud Complaint Center on line this summer. Anyone who sees signs of on-line identity theft, E-mail pyramid schemes or any other Internet-based criminal activity will be able to file a report on the Web site.

title: State Legislator Proposes Renaming the Turnpike
description: Assembly Speaker Jack Collins proposed yesterday changing the name of the New Jersey Turnpike -- one of the most recognizable symbols of the state -- to the New Jersey Veterans Highway.

title: It's Month II, Scene 1: A New Bonilla Tempest
description: Bobby Bonilla was furious today at a suggestion that a rift has developed between him and Mike Piazza.

title: Coming Era of High-Speed Net Access Is Here and Now on College Campuses
description: EVERY time Barry Mason, a sophomore at Columbia University, logged on to the Internet in his dormitory room this past year, he experienced what most home users still consider a luxury of the future: a high-speed Internet connection.

title: Universal Music and BMG Form Team for Web Venture
description: The frantic push by record companies to sell copyrighted music over the Internet is making for a kind of technological polygamy.

title: Good News on Jobs, Or Just Good Times?
description: To the Editor:

title: Giuliani Calls for Removing Principals
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani called on Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew yesterday to remove principals from at least the bottom third of all New York City elementary schools, saying that new leadership was the quickest way to reverse the high rate of failure in city schools.

title: Sports of The Times; No Contest Should Equal No Sympathy
description: LIKE everybody else at Yankee Stadium yesterday, Joe Torre was talking about the Yankee who wasn't there.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: GOLD DROPS. Gold fell on expectations that Governments will sell some of their holdings and overwhelm demand from jewelers and investors. In New York, gold for June delivery fell $1.30, to $269.50 an ounce.

title: Device Confers on Computers A Welcome Touch of Stereo
description: As the market for MP3 music files, sophisticated games and DVD movies grows, a computer's subwoofer capacity is becoming almost as essential as chip speed. Future Power, a new computer company based in Santa Clara, Calif., has developed a stereo amplifier and digital graphic equalizer that makes home computers sound more like stereos and less like, well, home computers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEIN, ELAINE B.
description: KLEIN-Elaine B. KLEIN-Robert L. Temple Beth-El of Great Neck records with profound sorrow the passing of its members. We extend heartfelt sympathy to their bereaved family. Shelley M. Limmer, President Jerome K. Davidson, Rabbi

title: Robinson Is Added To Coaching Staff
description: Robbie Ftorek of the Devils could be looking over his shoulder next season. Larry Robinson, an assistant on the 1995 Stanley Cup club, rejoined the team yesterday after four years in Los Angeles.

title: A Real World Locale Fit for a First Couple?; As Clintons Consider Next Move, Westchester Gets Into the Swing
description: As Hillary Rodham Clinton ponders life after 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue, Westchester County has popped up on the radar screen. And why not? It offers such amenities as leafy privacy, relative proximity to Le Cirque 2000 and, perhaps most important, something to occupy her husband: golf.

title: Metro Business; Free Internet Service
description: Consolidated Edison Company, New York's largest electric company, said a subsidiary would offer free Internet service for two months through AT&T to serve some customers who have chosen it as their energy supplier.

title: Informix to Settle Lawsuit for $142 Million
description: The Informix Corporation, the No. 5 data base software maker, said today that it had agreed to settle for $142 million a shareholder lawsuit resulting from the restatement of its revenue and earnings in November 1997.

title: Seeking Advice of Seasoned Trail Walkers
description: FROM Memorial Day weekend to the end of summer, wilderness trails across the nation surrender to hikers searching for a taste of nature, spectacular views and isolation. Embarking on their treks, most people (that is, most courteous people) leave behind conveniences like cellular telephones and laptop computers.

title: Mobster and Son Found Hanged in the Basement
description: A convicted organized crime figure and his son have been found hanged together in the basement of the father's Saddle Brook home in what the police say was a double suicide.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday with a review of ''East Is East'' at the Manhattan Theater Club misidentified the actor at the right. He was Rahul Khanna, not Dariush Kashani.

title: Making I.S.P. Choices
description: To the Editor:

title: Judge Affirms Liability Of Gun Makers to Victim
description: A Federal judge upheld a precedent-setting verdict yesterday against three gun makers, ordering them to pay more than $522,000 in damages to the family of a Queens teen-ager who was shot and severely wounded with an illegally obtained handgun.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: BELL ATLANTIC CORP., New York, said its wireless division, Bell Atlantic Mobile, would buy one million digital wireless phones and accessories from Motorola Inc. to satisfy demand for its flat-rate calling plans.

title: NINTENDO EARNINGS JUMP
description: The profit of the Nintendo Company rose last year to a six-year high, beating analysts' expectations, as the company, the world's second-largest maker of home video games, scored hits with a color version of its hand-held Game Boy machine and new software titles for the Nintendo 64 console. Nintendo, based in Kyoto, Japan, creator of Pikachu and other Pokemon characters, said its pretax profit before one-time items rose 4.9 percent in the year that ended March 31, to 165.2 billion yen ($1.35 billion). Sales increased 7 percent, to 572 billion yen.

title: Tours, Auctions and Exhibitions
description: East River Waterfront

title: The Semi-Pros Thrive on Homemade CD's and Prizes
description: It is unlikely that a local string bean named Baker Maultsby will be catapulted to international celebrity by the songs about Wal-Marts, high school delinquents and greasy-food joints that he recorded with a friend in his childhood bedroom here.

title: Coca-Cola Diversity Group
description: The Coca-Cola Company, the world's biggest beverage company, said today that it had formed a council to advise its chairman and chief executive, M. Douglas Ivester, on racial diversity, after the company was sued for discrimination. Jack Stahl, president of Coca-Colae's North America division, and Carl Ware, a senior vice president who oversees the company's African operations and is its highest-ranking black employee, will lead the council, according to an internal memo. Coca-Cola confirmed the memo, though it declined to comment.

title: Ramon Rubial, 92, a Spaniard Who Embodied Socialist Cause
description: Ramon Rubial, a veteran of the Spanish Civil War who spent nearly 20 years in prison under the Franco regime, died Monday at his home in Bilbao. He was 92.

title: Special Prison Security Likely for Volpe
description: Justin A. Volpe, the former New York police officer who confessed on Tuesday to torturing Abner Louima, is spending his first days in custody segregated from other inmates for his own protection.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BASTIS, CHRISTOS
description: BASTIS-Christos. The Directors of the American Friends of the Cycladic Art Foundation mourn the passing of their beloved Honorary Trustee, Christos G. Bastis. He was a devoted friend, wonderful collector and extraordinary gentleman. He will be greatly missed. Shelby White, President Mrs. Nicholas P. Goulandris (Honorary Chairman)

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANDEL, ELEANOR
description: MANDEL-Eleanor. The Faculty, Administration, and Board of Directors of Manhattan Day School/ Yeshiva Ohr Torah record with profound sorrow the passing of Eleanor Mandel, mother of our esteemed former Board member and parent, Rabbi Joseph (Benjy) Mandel. May the entire family be comforted in this hour of their untimely loss. Rabbi David Kaminetsky,Principal George Karasick, President Elliott Gibber, Chairman of the Board

title: Only 13 Central Computers Serve the World : What's Lurking Behind Those Slow Downloads
description: PARIS  We all know the Internet does not run fast enough. What we often do not know is why. When a Web page is slow downloading, we usually attribute it to the kind of computer we have, the speed of the connection or the time of day.

title: Polarized Courts Are Out of Sync
description: To the Editor:

title: Making I.S.P. Choices
description: To the Editor:

title: Home Scanners Come Close to Their Costlier Cousins
description: AS a movie and television line producer in Santa Clarita, Calif., Dennis Sugasawara spends his working life around sharp 35-millimeter film images. So when he wanted to send shots of his newborn boy via E-mail to relatives around the world, he faced a decision: buy one of the latest digital still cameras and load the pictures directly into his computer or buy a cheap flatbed scanner.

title: To Surprise of Many Experts, Housing Boom Keeps Rolling
description: Now that she has taken the plunge, Ptosha Ford likes to pull off Shelby Drive, on her way from her job as a hospital nurse, and visit the construction site of her new home. A yellow earthmover, parked for the night, has cleared the weeds and grass from her small square of land on a cul-de-sac. And Ms. Ford, still in her white uniform and white shoes, walks gingerly across the dusty earth, inspecting the day's progress.

title: Pacers Whisper Sweet Nothings
description: After their first full practice since sweeping the Philadelphia 76ers Sunday, Reggie Miller and the Indiana Pacers were on their best behavior today, offering nothing but compliments for the rejuvenated Knicks, their opponent in the Eastern Conference finals.

title: TV Azteca Chief Turns Over Wireless Unit and Lifts Its Ambitions
description: Ricardo Salinas Pliego, the chairman of Mexico's second-largest television network, summoned all his showmanship today to portray an 11th-hour rescue of his fledgling wireless telephone business as a bold foray into the interactive Mexico of the future.

title: Vice Adm. John Hayward, 90; Helped Design Bomb for Nagasaki
description: Vice Adm. John T. Hayward, a weapons expert who helped develop the atomic bomb dropped on Nagasaki, Japan, in the closing days of World War II, died on Sunday at his home in Atlantic Beach, Fla. He was 90.

title: Squeezing 80 'Cups' of Data Into 1 Cup
description: AFTER recent crashes knocked out America Online and parts of AT&T, there were widespread fears that ever-spiraling Internet use would create network gridlock in the United States. Aside from some glitches, that hasn't happened.

title: Making I.S.P. Choices
description: To the Editor:

title: Framing the Sleepers and Their Dreams
description: Lucy Guerin's ''Heavy'' will be filmed for Australian television in September, set in an abandoned ward and the underground tunnels of a hospital in Melbourne. But the piece, performed on Friday at Dance Theater Workshop, doesn't really need a change of scene. ''Heavy'' creates a world of its own through dance and music alone.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LUDMAR, MILTON W.
description: LUDMAR-Milton W. May 27, 1993. Dear Dad today, on the 6th anniversary of your passing, all my thoughts and prayers are with you. I feel joy in knowing you're with God in heaven. Thank you for enriching my life, and those who loved and knew you, in the most wonderful way. You are forever in my heart and soul. Your loving son. Love Scott

title: U.S. LETS NEW YORK SHIFT MOST POOR TO MANAGED CARE
description: Federal officials said today that New York can begin moving more than one million poor people in New York City into managed care health plans as early as July in one of the most ambitious efforts of its kind in the nation, according to state and Federal officials.

title: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: AMERICAS; STEELMAKER'S SHARES SUSPENDED
description: The Mexico and New York stock exchanges halted trading in the shares of Altos Hornos de Mexico S.A., Mexico's largest steelmaker, following the news that it had received a court order allowing it to suspend payment of all debts. The company owes about $1.9 billion and is searching for a strategic partner. Its shares have fallen 64 percent this month because of debt problems. Rick Wills (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WELCH, MARY M.
description: WELCH-Mary M., 96. Died Tuesday, May 25, 1999, in Centerville, Ma. Beloved daughter, sister and aunt. She is survived by numerous nieces and nephews. Mary resided in NYC from 1935-1973, where she directed public relations for the Elizabeth Arden Company. She retired in 1973 to West Hyannisport, MA., and Fort Lauderdale, FL. With a generous heart, quick wit and lively spirit, Mary was devoted to family and friends. A funeral Mass will be held at 10:00 AM on Saturday at Our Lady of Victory Church in Centerville, MA.

title: U.S.-European Union Talks On Privacy Are Sputtering
description: After months of negotiations that had appeared headed for success, the United States and the European Union have veered away from each other in a dispute over privacy protection that could disrupt trans-Atlantic electronic commerce.

title: Reaching Out to Really Chat, Even With 10 Friends at a Time
description: People who use instant typed messages to ''chat'' on line can now do so literally, by talking to each other through their computers. Yahoo Pager, a system that enables people to type messages back and forth in real time, has started a free service called Voice Chat that allows up to 10 people to speak to one another using microphones wired through their computers.

title: OMNIPOINT NEAR AGREEMENT FOR STRATEGIC INVESTMENT
description: The Omnipoint Corporation, which provides wireless telephone services in the Midwest and along the East Coast, is close to an agreement with a strategic partner for an investment to help it pay off debt, its acting chief financial officer, Harry Plonskier, said yesterday. Omnipoint's chief executive, Douglas Smith, canceled an appearance yesterday at a Banc of America Securities conference in New York. Mr. Plonskier, who filled in for Mr. Smith, said the chief executive could not attend because he was in the midst of negotiations. Omnipoint, which is building wireless networks, has been looking for investors for about a year. Shares in Omnipoint, which is based in Bethesda, Md., rose $1.3125, to $17.625.

title: Knoblauch And O'Neill Give Yanks Signs of Life
description: Paul O'Neill will be the cover boy of any Yankees slump, for helmet-launching and bat-throwing translate easily into signs of frustration. When O'Neill and the Yankees are losing, anybody who can identify a flying water bottle will know it.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a book review yesterday about ''Inventing Paradise: The Greek Journey, 1937-1947,'' by Edmund Keeley, misstated the involvement of the writers Lawrence Durrell and Henry Miller with the Elgin marbles. The passage should have read, ''Durrell and Miller were the first generation of those who, literarily at least, restored the marbles'' (not ''literally at least'').

title: The Big City; Keep Politics Out of Reach Of Celebrities
description: OF all the threats to New York's economy, the most fearsome may be Rosie O'Donnell's mouth. Her recent clash with Tom Selleck over gun control has cast a pall on the future of the media and entertainment industries.

title: Just Where Is Credit Due?
description: To the Editor:

title: ABC-Panasonic Deal on HDTV
description: The Panasonic Corporation has agreed to lend the ABC television network millions of dollars worth of new equipment so that ABC can broadcast its Monday night football games and the Super Bowl in high definition starting this fall.

title: To Save the Flounder
description: To the Editor:

title: Calling N.Y.U. Home
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRUBMAN, HARRY
description: GRUBMAN-Harry. Loving father of Roberta Fink, Francine Grubman, Sharon and Stuart Ruben. Dear brother of Irene Grubman. Devoted grandfather of Tara, Todd, Mark, Dayan. His long life was a celebration for all who knew him. Services were held May 23.

title: BAIN CAPITAL PLANS TO SELL STAKE IN CONTACT LENS MAKER
description: Bain Capital Inc. said yesterday that it would seek to sell its remaining 31 percent stake in Wesley Jessen Visioncare Inc., a maker of contact lenses based in Des Plaines, Ill. Wesley Jessen's shares fell $3, to $29.875 yesterday. Wesley Jessen registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission for the sale of at least 4.6 million common shares held by Bain and its affiliates. The Bain group may offer as many as 5.3 million shares, or its entire stake, once the S.E.C. approves the filing. That stake is worth $158 million at today's prices. Bain, based in Boston, acquired the company from the Schering-Plough Corporation in 1995 and helped take the unit public in 1997.

title: For Wildflowers, Worker Bees to the Rescue
description: IN the fall of 1998, the Newton Pride Committee, the volunteer beautification army for this grand old Boston suburb, took a quantum leap from planting tulips.

title: A (Sort of) Lesson for Youth
description: Over the years, the remarkable New York Youth Symphony has been visited by some renowned guest soloists. The inspired young musicians can learn something from these role models, who always perform without a fee.

title: Sliding Doors for the Cluttered or Clean
description: In Italian, ''senza fine'' means ''without end.'' And Senzafine is the name of the flexible storage systems from Poliform, an Italian furniture manufacturer with a New York showroom to the trade. You can have a zillion drawers -- or none. The sliding doors come in sandblasted glass, reflecting glass, walnut, pear or cherry. Pack rats may want wood closets with lots of drawers; minimalists may prefer glass with racks for 24 shirts hung just so. The newest design has four-foot-wide doors (left, in sandblasted glass, $8,500); (212) 355-5444. ELAINE LOUIE

title: The Dummies Don't Talk
description: Step inside Look, a new store in TriBeCa, and it looks as if the merchandise were missing. In a loft space at 174 Hudson Street (Vestry Street), Look is filled with aluminum and plastic shelving, tables and racks -- and little else. But that's Look's inventory: retail displays that can be adapted as home furnishings. Opened by James Maharg and Zenda Snyder, designers to the trade, Look was an instant hit with loft owners. It has a whimsical side, too: mannequin torsos are $170 for a man, $160 for a woman. ANNE JARRELL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEIN, ELAINE AND ROBERT L.
description: KLEIN-Elaine and Robert L. The firm of Becker Ross Stone DeStefano & Klein mourns the sudden passing of our devoted partner, Robert, and his beloved wife, Elaine. We have treasured Bob's brilliance, friendship and leadership over the years and will always remember them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRODER, LEON C.
description: BRODER-Leon C., of Boca Raton, FL, died May 26, 1999. Loving father of Doris (Stuart) Zeuner and Toby (Larry) Brown. Cherished grandfather of Michael and Craig Zeuner; Shari Schwamm; and Brian, Sharon and Marci Brown. Adored great-grandfather of Rachel and Rebecca Zeuner, Ryan and Hallie Schwamm, and Louis and Ross Brown.

title: 6 Republicans Break Ranks on Campaign Finance Issue
description: The chief House Republican proponent of changing the nation's campaign finance laws defied his party today by signing a Democratic petition designed to force the issue to the House floor. He also accused Representative Tom DeLay, the House majority whip, of offering to donate money to a primary challenge against him and cast the issue as part of a larger struggle over the soul of the party.

title: End of Commuter Tax May Cost Us All; New Station, No Benefit
description: To the Editor:

title: 2d American In Top Rank As Diversity Hits Sumo
description: A second American muscled his way into the top ranks of sumo today. The wrestler, Musashimaru, a Hawaiian whose given name is Fiamalu Penitani, became the 67th yokozuna, or grand champion, in the 300-year modern history of the sport.

title: India Jets Strike Guerrilla Force Now in Kashmir
description: Indian combat jets and helicopter gunships attacked a large guerrilla force dug into the snow-capped mountains of Kashmir on Wednesday and today, sharply increasing tensions in the nuclear-armed subcontinent.

title: LIZ CLAIBORNE'S STAKE IN DESIGNER COST $54.5 MILLION
description: Liz Claiborne Inc., the maker of women's career clothing, paid $54 million for an 84.5 percent stake in the closely held sportswear designer Segrets Inc., according to a regulatory filing. The terms were not disclosed when the purchase was announced in January. The company, based in Wakefield, Mass., produces labels that include Sigrid Olsen Sport, the Sigrid Olsen Collection and SO Blue by Sigrid Olsen. Segrets has annual sales of about $60 million. The designer, which operates showrooms in New York, will continue to be headed by Edward Jones 3d and Sigrid Olsen, founder and creative director of the brand, Liz Claiborne said.

title: Del Webb Assigns A New Account
description: The Del Webb Corporation in Phoenix, which builds retirement communities under names like Sun City, said yesterday it had awarded a new account, a consolidated national campaign, to the Chicago office of Publicis & Hal Riney, a unit of Publicis S.A. Billings were estimated at $10 million to $15 million.

title: The Sabres' Nice Guy Had Better Tough It Out
description: Many of Michael Peca's Sabres teammates were still on the ice today, working through practice in Marine Midland Arena. Among them were Dominik Hasek, the superb goalie with the severe groin pull, and Miroslav Satan, the high-scoring forward with the badly bruised foot.

title: A Visit From 'Wall Streeters'
description: To the Editor:

title: Remembering American Soldiers on a Virtual Wall
description: Nothing on the Internet can replicate the experience of standing in front of the Vietnam Veterans Memorial in Washington, scanning the thousands and thousands of names of American soldiers inscribed on the black granite wall. But if you cannot get to the capital, or want a quick way to find a specific name this Memorial Day, several sites offer the wall on the Internet.

title: INSIDE
description: CUNY Chairwoman Resigns

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARX, WILLIAM
description: MARX-William (born Wolf) Louis, 92, died Wednesday May 26, after a valiant fight. Beloved husband of Murielle. Adored father of Jane and of the late Paul. Devoted brother of Nettie Rosenblum, Anna Goldberg, Adelaide Rubin and the late Benjamin. Cherished brother-in-law of Elaine and the late Kenneth Kleinman and Gloria and Gilbert Bloom. Devoted uncle He received a B.S. and M.S. from NYU and attended Harvard Business School. He was a proud veteran of W.W. II and a recipient of two Bronze Stars. He loved being an accountant and auditor. His compassionate life reflected his soul. Services today at 1:30 Boulevard-Riverside Chapels, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, New York.

title: End of Commuter Tax May Cost Us All
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S.-Canada Agreement On Magazines
description: Canada and the United States averted a trade war today with an agreement that resolves a protracted dispute over Canadian barriers to American magazines.

title: NEW RUNWAY IN HONG KONG
description: Hong Kong's new airport opened its second runway, with the arrival of a flight from Shanghai. The airport began operating last July, but with the economy mired in recession, officials were in no hurry to complete the second runway. Traffic is picking up, however, and Hong Kong's No. 2 official, Anson Chan, said the additional runway would relieve congestion and reduce waiting time for planes.

title: Guards Charged in Fatal Beating Of Inmate at Nassau County Jail
description: Three guards at the Nassau County jail were charged today with violating the civil rights of an inmate who prosecutors say died from a vicious beating at the hands of two of the guards in January. Prosecutors say the third guard acted as a lookout during the beating.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: ROCHE TO KEEP DUAL SHARES
description: Roche Holding A.G. said the Hoffmann and Oeri-Hoffmann families, who own a majority of its voting rights, will take control of the shares owned by the Swiss conductor and music patron Paul Sacher, who served on Roche's board for about 60 years before his death yesterday. (Obituary, Page B11.) Roche shares jumped amid speculation that Mr. Sacher's death might prompt the company to adopt a single share class -- a move that would make it easier to merge or make an acquisition through a share swap. But Franz Humer, the chief executive, said Roche had ''no intention'' of scrapping its two-tier share structure.

title: Let's Go to the Tape: N.F.L. Unveils a System
description: The 16 newest teams in the National Football League will not wear uniforms, run, catch, or block. But in the unglamorous positions of communicator, technician, replay assistant and video operator, they may be crucial to every game each week.

title: Churchill Downs The Site in 2000
description: The Breeders' Cup announced yesterday that it would run its first series of championship races in 2000 at Churchill Downs on Nov.4. And it said that Belmont Park would most likely be the site of the 2001 races.

title: Champagne in the Park
description: To the Editor:

title: End of Commuter Tax May Cost Us All; Out-of-State Burden
description: To the Editor:

title: TELLABS TO BUY TELECOMMUNICATIONS UNIT FROM ALCATEL
description: Tellabs Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Alcatel S.A.'s DSC Communications unit in Europe for about $110 million. Tellabs said the unit, which provides products and services for electronic data transmission, has operations in Drogheda, Ireland, and Copenhagen. Tellabs also will acquire sales and support offices in England, India and Poland, and an interest in Fibcom India Ltd., a joint venture based in India. Tellabs, which is based in Lisle, Ill., and makes telecommunications equipment, had 1998 revenues of $1.66 billion. Its shares rose $2.8125, to $55.25. Alcatel, based in Paris, is a communications, transportation and energy infrastructure company.

title: Sports of The Times; The Way The Knicks Can Win
description: LATRELL SPREWELL says that the Knicks' second team regularly beats the Knicks' first team in practice so decisively that ''the first team doesn't want to play us anymore.'' And no one on the Knicks disputes this.

title: Echostar Shares Split
description: The Echostar Communications Corporation, the third-largest United States satellite-television company, will split its shares two for one after its stock price more than doubled this year. The split, to be paid July 19 to shareholders of record on July 1, is the company's first. It will increase Echostar's outstanding stock to 32 million class A common shares and 59.6 million class B shares. Shares of the company have soared on investor optimism that more consumers will choose satellite television services rather than cable TV. The shares closed today at $102.25, up 12.5 cents.

title: Reform Judaism Reconsiders Rituals It Shed a Century Ago
description: By an overwhelming margin, the rabbinical leadership of Reform Judaism, the largest and most liberal major branch of American Jewry, today approved guiding principles that for the first time encourage observance of traditional rituals, like wearing skullcaps, keeping kosher and the wide use of Hebrew that were set aside at the movement's founding but have become an increasing part of its adherents' lives.

title: Senate Rejects Pentagon's Request to Close More Military Bases
description: A week after Congress approved a $15 billion package to finance the war in Kosovo and other Pentagon programs, the Senate rejected today the Clinton Administration's request to close more military bases and save money.

title: London Journal; Royal Fiancee Is Unveiled. 'Cruelty,' Says Palace.
description: In a rambunctious renewal of the war between Britain's tabloids and the royal family, The Sun today published a decade-old private snapshot of Prince Edward's fiancee, Sophie Rhys-Jones, with a breast bared.

title: GUCCI BATTLE INTENSIFIES
description: Two French billionaires fighting for control of Gucci Group N.V. appear headed for court a second time, after Francois Pinault (pictured) accused Bernard Arnault of defamation. Mr. Arnault, who controls Givenchy fashions and Christian Dior perfumes through LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton S.A., is accused of saying in an article in Paris Match that Mr. Pinault defrauded minority shareholders when the company he controls, Pinault-Printemps-Redoute S.A., bought a 42 percent stake in Gucci without bidding for the entire company. The two men are already facing off before a court in the Netherlands, where Gucci is incorporated. The court is to decide today whether to allow Gucci's alliance with Pinault or approve instead a bid for Gucci by LVMH.

title: A Role for Serb In Peace Talks Isn't Ruled Out
description: The Clinton Administration has concluded that an indictment of President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia on charges of war crimes would not preclude direct negotiations on Kosovo with the Serbian leader, senior American officials said today.

title: State Plans Return of Jersey City Schools to Local Control
description: More than a decade after the state took over the Jersey City School District because of corrupt leadership and failing test scores, David A. Hespe, the State Commissioner of Education, will propose a plan next week to return the district to local control in a gradual, three-year process.

title: Hingis Perseveres as Kafelnikov Disappears at Open
description: The No. 1 player in the world fell in an upset today at the French Open, but not the No. 1 whose match against the fourth-most popular athlete in France had been infused with the hype of a heavyweight prizefight and the gravity befitting a moral debate.

title: In America; Public vs. Private Gore
description: Al Gore was critiquing his own performance. He knew he had not done well. He had been onstage Tuesday afternoon with Bill Clinton, who makes it look so easy. The President was the warm-up act in Edinburg, a town of 40,000 near the southern tip of Texas. He praised the Vice President. He got the crowd ready. And then the spotlight moved to Mr. Gore.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HOWELL, HAMPTON P.
description: HOWELL-Hampton P., Jr. There will be a memorial service on Saturday, May 29th at noon at St. Mark's Church, Westhampton Beach, LI for Mr. Howell who died in Providence, R.I. last February 11th. Donations may be sent to Westhampton Beach Historical Society Westhampton Beach, NY 11978 or Open Space Council, PO Box 275 Brookhaven, NY 11719.

title: Ministry Plans a Danish Arts Festival
description: Speaking on behalf of the Danish Ministry of Culture, Victor Borge, the Danish-American pianist and humorist, announced plans on Tuesday for ''The Danish Wave '99,'' a two-month festival that promises to bring the best of Danish arts and culture to 17 New York City locations beginning on Sept. 9. The festival's 80 events will constitute ''the biggest Danish cultural wave outside the country ever,'' Mr. Borge said at a news conference in Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  JACOBSON, STUART EDWARD
description: JACOBSON-Stuart Edward. A perfectionist who taught us to settle for ''ONLY THE BEST.'' A humanist who instilled in us ''THE ART OF GIVING.'' We miss him and cherish his memory. Mother, Dad and Kyle

title: Macintosh's Blinking Question Mark
description: Q. When I start up my Macintosh, I see an icon of a blinking question mark on a floppy disk for a couple of seconds and then it begins to boot up normally. Why does it do this?

title: Corrections
description: An article in Circuits on May 6 about hand-held electronic guides misidentified the developer of a device used in a Kuala Lumpur museum. The device was developed by employees of DMCD Inc. and Anway & Company. They included Paul Trapido, who was not an independent exhibition designer at the time and was not the sole developer.

title: Former Union Official Pleads Guilty to Theft
description: The former treasurer of District Council 37, the umbrella group representing 120,000 New York City municipal workers, pleaded guilty yesterday to stealing more than $50,000 from the union.

title: No-Contest Plea Dims Future for Strawberry
description: In a county courthouse in Tampa, Fla., yesterday, Darryl Strawberry offered a plea of no contest to charges of drug possession and solicitation of prostitution and was given 18 months probation as part of his sentence. Now his future as a baseball player rests with Major League Baseball, which is expected to suspend Strawberry as a repeat offender of its drug-aftercare program.

title: Arkady Renko, Back on the Scent
description: HAVANA BAY

title: Guards Are Charged In Fatal Jail Beating
description: Three guards at the Nassau County jail were charged yesterday with violating the civil rights of an inmate who prosecutors say died from a vicious beating last January. They could all face life in prison, and a fourth correction officer charged with preparing a fake report could receive up to 15 years. The inmate, Thomas Pizzuto, died of a ruptured spleen several days after the beating in his jail cell. He quickly became a symbol of what many former inmates and prisoners' advocates said is a long history of brutality at the jail.

title: The First Portable PC's
description: To the Editor:

title: I.B.M. Devises a Program To Enliven On-Line Ads
description: Can banner ads be effective or even (gasp) interesting? I.B.M.'s new media group thinks so and, to that end, has released a new Web development tool called Hot Media.

title: Digital Projectors Use Flashes of Light to Paint a Movie
description: WHEN the first $100 million worth of paying customers crammed into movie theaters last week to see the highly anticipated ''Star Wars'' film ''The Phantom Menace,'' few of them may have realized or even cared that only 5 percent of its 130 minutes are free of digital enhancements like computer-generated characters and backgrounds. But if George Lucas has his way, the entire movie experience may soon be reduced to ones and zeroes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SNIADO, JEAN
description: SNIADO-Jean. On May 25th, of Garden City, New York, in her ninety-second year. Visiting at the Fairchild Chapel, Franklin Avenue at 12th Street, Garden City, Friday 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial, at St. Joseph's Church, Garden City, on Saturday, at 9:45 AM. Interment, St. Charles Cemetery, Farmingdale, New York.

title: STRONGER NTT EARNINGS
description: The world's largest telephone company, the Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation, made record profits in the year ended March 31 because of strong results at its cellular phone subsidiary, NTT Mobile Communications Network. The parent company's earnings doubled to 602.6 billion yen, or $4.96 billion. It has a 67 percent stake in the cellular subsidiary, which has about half of Japan's thriving mobile phone business.

title: Chairwoman of CUNY Resigns, Leaving Yet Another Vacancy
description: In another blow to the troubled leadership of the City University of New York, Anne A. Paolucci, the university's chairwoman, announced yesterday that she was resigning from CUNY's board on June 1.

title: Legislators Ask Pause in Relations With China
description: Members of Congress from both parties pressed today for a pause in relations with China and a reversal of years of liberalized high-technology sales to Beijing, arguing that evidence of Chinese espionage undercuts the Clinton Administration's policy of engagement.

title: On Unofficial Level, at Least, Chinese Value Ties to the U.S.
description: One recent afternoon, as the Chinese press continued to rage against ''American imperialism,'' a 36-year-old lawyer named Wang darted from the newly opened Starbucks back into the law conference he was attending -- in place of an American delegate who felt uneasy about traveling to Beijing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANC, ROBERT
description: FRANC-Robert. Former longtime French announcer for USIA, passed away on May 24, 1999 in New York City at age 94. He will be buried in France.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POMMER, NAOMI
description: POMMER-Naomi. On May 23rd, 1999. Beloved daughter of Frieda Abbey. Loving mother of Ted and Nicolas. Cherished wife of Marvin Koenigsberg. Devoted sister of Greg and Gita. Dear aunt of Luke, Emily, Wally, Donald, Todd and Greg. Memorial to be held on June 5th at 4 PM at Marylou's, 21 West 9th Street, New York City.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Price Flights for Internet Shares Are Less Dizzying
description: Stocks generally rebounded yesterday from a four-session losing streak, but not all Internet stocks caught the wave.

title: Officer Shoots Armed Stabbing Suspect as He Charges, Police Say
description: Police officers in Brooklyn who interrupted a teen-ager while he was stabbing someone shot the youth in the ear yesterday after he came at them with his knife, the authorities said. Neither he nor the stabbing victim was seriously injured, the police said.

title: Honey, I Programmed the Blanket
description: THE average middle-class American household has about 40 microprocessors in it. If you own a PC, with all the paraphernalia that goes with it, that number increases to about 50.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENE, PHILIP M.
description: GREENE-Philip M. Age 79, of East Hampton, died on May 22nd, in Southampton Hospital of Emphysema. Survived by his wife Constance, five children, Sheppard, Basking Ridge, NJ, Philippa Mulford, Duxbury, MA, Stephanie Radwan, Chapel Hill, NC, Matthew, Esopus, NY, Lucia Connolly, Woodbridge, CT., and eleven grandchildren. Services are private. Interment in family plot in Hamilton, New York.

title: Making I.S.P. Choices
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOS, AGNES C.
description: BOS-Agnes C. (nee Mahoney). Of Miami Beach, FL on May 1, 1999 at her home of complications from cancer at 80 years of age. Former How-To Editor at Family Circle Magazine, Writer, Educator, Home Economist, Artist, and WWII naval veteran. Beloved wife of the late Willem A. Bos; loving mother of Tineke Lucero of Buffalo, NY, William F. Bos (Veronica) of Shelter Island, NY and James A. Bos (Susan) of East Hampton, NY; grandmother of twelve, great grandmother of five, predeceased by three brothers and five sisters; survived by sisters Mary Galvin of Buffalo, NY, Catherine Lahiff of Hollywood, Florida, and 21 nieces and nephews. Memorial mass at St. Ambrose Church, 65 Ridge Road, Buffalo, New York on June 5. Inurnment will be at Arlington National Cemetery on June 29, with full military honors. In lieu of flowers, family asks donations to American Cancer Society or local Hospice care org.

title: Parcells Says Coaching Job And Team Control Is Secure
description: Despite the for sale sign on the Jets, the club's fortunes on the field will remain under the control of Bill Parcells and his staff this coming season, the coach said today.

title: A Fixture Never Invited Home, Until Now
description: THE last time a urinal was the center of attention, it was signed by Marcel Duchamp and hanging upside down in a show of avant-garde art. Today, the urinal has taken its stand alongside the bidet and the working fireplace as the latest must-have in the well-appointed bathroom suite.

title: A Favored Foursome Loses, And a Slam Aids the Victors
description: A disastrous start led eventually to the elimination of a favored foursome in the New York Grand National Teams final, played on Sunday in Manhattan at Honors Club and the Beverly Club. After 14 deals of a scheduled 56, Jim Cayne, Alan Sontag, David Berkowitz and Larry Cohen found themselves trailing by 64 imps. They surged at the finish but lost by just 8. The winners, who will represent New York City in national playoffs in San Antonio in July, were Jon Greenspan, Jim Sampson, Bob Blanchard, Jim Krekorian, Glenn Milgrim and Jared Lilienstein.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, JONES, MARIE T.
description: MILLER-JONES-Marie T. (William), 92, formerly of New York and Cape Cod, died May 17 at the home of her daughter, Anna Marie (David) Dickerson, Atlanta, GA

title: U.N. Presses Wealthy Countries for More Aid to Third World
description: Reflecting concern that the war in Kosovo is diverting political energy and scarce resources from other conflicts, Secretary General Kofi Annan appealed today to world leaders to do more next month at the meeting of major industrialized nations to help the developing world.

title: Evening Session for Nasdaq May Win Approval Today
description: Directors of Nasdaq, the nation's second-largest equity market after the New York Stock Exchange, forwarded to its parent regulatory group yesterday a recommendation that trading hours be extended to encompass an evening session. That set the stage today for possible adoption of the proposal.

title: Mixing It Up: Silverbulletday Joins Belmont Field
description: She was fast in her workout on Tuesday, and frisky in the stall afterward. And so her trainer, Bob Baffert, has finally decided that his standout filly Silverbulletday is ready to take on the colts. In New York. At the Belmont Stakes. Against a strapping overachiever named Charismatic, who is a mile and a half away from capturing the Triple Crown.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  YOUNG, ROBERT F.
description: YOUNG-Robert F. Bob, the love of my life, you are missed. Jud

title: Polarized Courts Are Out of Sync
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Directors, 2 Styles: Dreaminess And Vigor
description: It isn't every choreographer and company director who invites his dancers to contribute new repertory. David Parsons has done that, however, and the results were presented on Tuesday night at the Joyce Theater. The program of dances by Mr. Parsons and Robert Battle will be performed with changing casts through Sunday afternoon at the Joyce.

title: Mets Win, but Isringhausen Winces
description: Orel Hershiser had his second straight strong outing tonight in the Mets' 5-2 victory over the Pirates. But, after the game, the Mets received troubling news about Jason Isringhausen, once considered one of their most promising young pitchers.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Housing Surge Continues In Spite of Expectations

title: Officer Critically Wounds Unarmed Youth After a Struggle
description: An unarmed 16-year-old youth was shot and critically wounded early yesterday morning by a police officer from the department's Street Crime Unit after a chase and a brief struggle on a dark Bronx street, the police said.

title: 2 Die as Shelling Spills Over Into Albania From Kosovo
description: The fighting in Kosovo spread today to four small villages inside Albania, which West European and Kosovo rebel officials said were shelled by Yugoslav Army forces from over the border. Two people died in the attack, an Albanian man and his daughter, the officials said.

title: Durable Goods Report Signals Factory Gains
description: Factory orders for durable goods other than aircraft and cars rose in April for the second straight month, suggesting manufacturing is on the mend, Government figures showed today.

title: The Line Is Out the Door At a Genealogy Library
description: The Mormon Church's new genealogy Web site opened this week and immediately became known for attracting more Web traffic than the library's servers could handle. Given the popularity of on-line family searches, the slowdowns were probably inevitable. The site, www .familysearch.org, developed by the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, gives millions of users access to the world's largest genealogy library.

title: E.D.S. Selects Fallon McElligott
description: Electronic Data Systems said yesterday that it had named Fallon McElligott in Minneapolis as its worldwide agency of record, succeeding Bates Worldwide in New York, which has worked for the company since 1995.

title: Businessman Is Charged With Leading Organized Crime Ring
description: Daniel Provenzano has dabbled in an assortment of businesses, from delivering fish to producing a movie called ''Vampire Vixens From Venus.'' On the surface, his investments seem lucrative; he lives with his wife and infant son in a 15-room New Jersey home valued at more than $1 million and motors around in a Mercedes-Benz and a Ferrari.

title: Assembly Approves Pay For Governor
description: The Governor got paid today, after all.

title: Polarized Courts Are Out of Sync
description: To the Editor:

title: Japan Officials Get Tough With U.S. Financial Firms
description: For years, American officials have called on Japanese regulators to be tougher on the financial services industry here, but they hardly expected that the result would be raids on American companies.

title: Flawed Missile Defense
description: To the Editor:

title: Polarized Courts Are Out of Sync
description: To the Editor:

title: Retirements Suspended
description: The Pentagon has ordered a sweeping suspension of retirements from the Air Force to insure that enough pilots and other personnel are available to continue waging NATO's air war in the Balkans. The order suggests that NATO is preparing to conduct its military campaign well into the summer or fall.

title: Polarized Courts Are Out of Sync
description: To the Editor:

title: Breakfast the Nontraditional Way
description: A nook is by nature cozy -- and it can also be sleek. Such is the dining nook that Fu-Tung Cheng, a designer in Berkeley, Calif., made for a client. Sunlight pours through the window onto a maple table with a raked edge (below). The banquettes are framed plywood upholstered in leather. The unit, including the concrete window ledge on which the table rests, cost $12,000.

title: PAYOFF DISCLOSED
description: Tadashi Okuda, a former chairman of one of Japan's largest financial institutions, Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank, confessed in court that he gave loans worth $96 million to Ryuichi Koike, a racketeer who had threatened to disrupt the bank's annual shareholder meetings from 1994 to 1996. Mr. Koike, who is serving a nine-month sentence, was arrested in a scandal that tainted Dai-Ichi, Nomura Securities and other financial institutions that had paid Mr. Koike not to intervene at stockholder meetings.

title: Naya learns the hard way the downside of relying on Coca-Cola Enterprises as its main distributor.
description: NAYA INC., a Canadian bottled-water company that has watched its sales surge in the last five years, now finds itself paddling hard.

title: ITALIAN BANK DROPS BID
description: Italy's No. 3 bank, Unicredito Italiano S.p.A., has abandoned its takeover offer for Banca Commerciale Italiana S.p.A., the country's fourth-largest bank, bringing an end to Italy's largest battle ever for a bank. The retraction saves the Bank of Italy, which must review all such mergers, the embarrassment of vetoing the offer, which it would have done after Banca Commerciale Italiana's board rejected Unicredito's 12.8 billion euro ($13.6 billion) offer this month.

title: Not So Friendly
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STIEFEL, EDWARD HENRY
description: STIEFEL-Edward Henry. On May 23, 1999. A retired partner of the law firm of Milbank, Tweed, Hadley & McCloy LLP. Two daughters survive, Barbara Anne Rebell of Seneca, S.C. and Margaret Jeanne Bergman of Ridge, N.Y., as well as five grandchildren and six great grandchildren. He was predeceased by his wife of fifty-nine years, Anna Lucille Tibbals Stiefel.

title: Israeli Vote Prompts Arab Call for Solidarity
description: Anticipating renewed peace efforts after the election of Ehud Barak as Israel's Prime Minister, the Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat met here today with King Abdullah of Jordan to set a common agenda.

title: Word of Indictment Stuns Serbs and Blights Hopes
description: Word that President Slobodan Milosevic may be indicted for war crimes on Thursday, the day a Russian envoy is due here to discuss a peace settlement for Kosovo, stunned Serbs tonight, dampening hopes for an end to the war.

title: Worriers, Start Your Engines; Contingency Plans Hit Their Stride for Year 2000
description: Donald Rose, the head of the Intel Corporation's global drive to prevent Year 2000 computer problems from derailing microchip production, is focused these days on 500 critical suppliers of materials and basic services like power and telephones.

title: Two Polar Views of Police And Race at U.S. Hearing
description: The yawning chasm between the Police Department and many of the people it serves was evident yesterday as Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and other witnesses gave the United States Civil Rights Commission two starkly divergent visions of how the New York City police treat black and Hispanic people.

title: The Art of Making Surfboards Has Become More of a Science
description: WITH a slow surfer's drawl, John Gillis describes his creation as ''unreal,'' an adjective not generally used by most inventors. But then, most inventors don't surf.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEISTEIN, ROY
description: HEISTEIN-Roy. The Board of Directors of Lawrence Houses Owners Corp. is shocked and saddened by the untimely death of our longtime Board member. Deepest sympathies to Cindy. Roy was a remarkable man. We will miss him tremendously. Jesse Yaverbaum and Herbert Donner, Co-Presidents

title: Upstart Sinks Find A New Level
description: THIS from American Standard's Web site on bathroom sinks:

title: In Heart Attacks, Closest Hospital May Not Be Best
description: For someone who is having a heart attack, getting to the right hospital -- one that treats many heart attack victims -- is more important than getting to the closest one, and may mean the difference between life and death, researchers say.

title: A Renaissance in American Judaism, or Illusion?
