description: At its outset, the documentary ''Jewish Soul, American Beat'' posits that increasing numbers of young Jews are returning to their religion in defiance of the prognoses of demographers and other experts who foresee an ineluctable decline in American Judaism as a result of assimilation and intermarriage.

title: House Acts to Protect Social Security Surplus
description: Keenly aware of the political volatility of Social Security, the House today overwhelmingly passed legislation that would put new hurdles in the way of spending any surpluses that come from the program.

title: New Jersey Ends 24 Cases After Troopers Are Indicted
description: A state judge dismissed drug, assault and weapons charges against 24 people today because the two state troopers who arrested them have been charged with singling out black and Hispanic drivers for stops and then trying to cover this up.

title: Brutality Trial Resumes for 4 as Mistrial Motion Fails
description: A day after Justin A. Volpe interrupted his trial to plead guilty to torturing Abner Louima in a Brooklyn police station, the judge refused to declare a mistrial yesterday and resumed the testimony against three other police officers and a sergeant also charged in the case.

title: A New Slave Is Sinuous In 'Corsair'
description: The pirates once again performed their choreographic deeds of derring-do when American Ballet Theater presented ''Le Corsaire'' on Monday night at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: Guns in the House
description: House Republicans can read the polls as well as anyone. Thus G.O.P. leaders who just a week ago were adamant about blocking any action to curb guns are now planning to graft an array of gun-control measures onto a juvenile crime bill due to hit the floor next month. But if Speaker Dennis Hastert and his colleagues want to persuade Americans that they are finally serious about keeping guns away from juveniles and criminals, they will have to do a lot better than the meager menu of changes currently being considered.

title: Have We Forgotten The Path To Peace?
description: After the cold war, many expected that the world would enter an era of unprecedented peace and prosperity. Those who live in developed nations might think this is the case today, with the possible exception of the war in Kosovo. But at the Carter Center we monitor all serious conflicts in the world, and the reality is that the number of such wars has increased dramatically.

title: Paul Sacher Is Dead at 93; Conductor and Arts Patron
description: Paul Sacher, a conductor, champion of contemporary music and arts patron, whose family fortune, based on a controlling share of the Roche pharmaceutical empire, amounted to an estimated $13 billion, died yesterday after a long illness. He was 93.

title: KOSOVO UPDATE
description: WAR CRIMES

title: Hernandez Has the Mound (and Infield) Covered
description: Orlando Hernandez is so nimble that he raises his left knee to his ear every time he winds up to unleash a pitch. Hernandez's unusually athletic motion also enables him to land neatly in front of the rubber so that he is in position to handle grounders. El Duque is not a statue. He is a fifth infielder.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENFELD, FRANCES
description: ROSENFELD-Frances. On May 24th. Beloved wife of Stanley. Mother of Andrea and Drs. Cheryl and Michael. Sister and sister-inlaw of Howard and Grace Fleischman, Sheila and Kenneth Pincus and Gerald Rosenfeld. Aunt and great aunt.

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: EUROPE

title: For an Undecided Mayor, a Fund-Raiser Is a Decided Hit
description: After concluding a somber news conference yesterday that centered on the low test scores of schoolchildren and the stop-and-frisk practices of the Police Department, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani entertained one more question: Any comment on his political fund-raising dinner of the night before?

title: Holiday Dress for the Backyard Picnic
description: FOR a brighter holiday picnic, check out the colorful new paper, plastic and tin tableware. There's nothing downscale about these wares -- they can set a stylish table. And tumblers in new clear-as-crystal plastic will fool even the most formal guest.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GERARD, ROSE S.
description: GERARD-Rose S. On May 26, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Raphael C. Gerard. Loving mother of Stephanie Ziltzer, Henry Gerard, Ruth Gerard. Adoring grandmother of Amy & Robert, Michael and Andrea, Robert and Vivian, Scott, Lisa and Scott, and seven wonderful, loving great grandchildren all of whom she was deeply devoted to. Funeral service Friday 1 P.M. at Larchmont Temple in Larchmont, NY. Interment at Cedar Park Cemetery in Paramus, New Jersey.

title: Little League, Big Network
description: MIKE HAND is fanatical about Little League. A father whose 11-year-old son plays ball, Mr. Hand says he eats and sleeps the Bloomfield Little League in Macon, Ga. He is the embodiment of an aphorism by Yogi Berra: ''Little League is a very good thing because it keeps the parents off the streets.''

title: Cloned Sheep Showing Signs Of Old Cells, Report Says
description: The scientists in Scotland who created Dolly, the sheep that was the first animal that was a clone of an adult, report today that the genetic material in her cells may show a sign of aging, appearing, in effect, older than Dolly herself.

title: Neo-Classicism That Restraint Forgot
description: It's astonishing how much mileage has been sucked out of classicism. Whether in Renaissance Rome, Georgian Edinburgh, 19th-century Washington, Belle Epoque Monte Carlo or late-20th-century Las Vegas, the Greek language -- of columns, pilasters and pediments, of mathematical proportion and delicate balance of solid and void -- has been rehashed to convey tradition and grandeur.

title: Storm Over South Florida Building Codes
description: Hurricane Andrew blew the roof off decades of shoddy building practices in South Florida, exposing support columns filled with wadded-up newspapers instead of concrete, and knocking down walls made with cheap particle board that crumpled like cardboard in the driving wind and rain. Roof beams that should have been tied down with steel straps were found, after the storm lifted them up, up and away, to have been tied down by nothing.

title: Chuasiriporn Plans To Make Pro Debut
description: Jenny Chuasiriporn, who lost to Se Ri Pak on the second sudden-death playoff hole in last year's United States Women's Open, will play her first tournament as a pro next week, when she returns to the Open.

title: Bid Expected For Troubled Show Producer
description: A company controlled by a New York entrepreneur who made a fortune with radio stations is offering to buy Livent Inc., the financially struggling company that brought shows like ''Ragtime'' to Broadway, for at least $100 million, a person close to the negotiations said yesterday.

title: Political Briefing; With Elway Free, It's Speculation Time
description: When John Elway, the All-Star quarterback for the Denver Broncos, first started talking about retirement a couple of years ago, it was as sure as a pass on third-and-long that speculation would follow about whether he would run for Congress.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STIVANELLO, ANTHONY L.
description: STIVANELLO-Anthony L. The New York Grand Opera Company notes with sorrow the passing of our esteemed associate, Anthony Stivanello. Anthony has been invaluable to the Company since its inception as stage director and costume designer. His special talents and rare fund of knowledge can never be replaced. We extend deepest sympathy to Yolanda, Roberto and family. Vincent La Selva Artistic Director

title: BRIGHTER CANADIAN OUTLOOK
description: The Governor of the Bank of Canada, Gordon Thiessen, said consumer and business spending would rise in coming months, reflecting interest rate cuts and declining unemployment. Mr. Thiessen made his comments before the parliamentary finance committee a week after the central bank said it was revising its 1999 economic growth forecast to 3.25 percent from November's 2.75 percent.

title: Economic Scene; Time isn't money if you are a parent badly in need of both.
description: PRESIDENT CLINTON'S Council of Economic Advisers issued a report this week that it hopes can turn the notion of a ''time crunch'' into a rallying cry for the Administration's agenda for families.

title: ADC AGREES TO BUY MAKER OF PARTS USED IN FIBER OPTICS
description: ADC Telecommunications Inc., a supplier of voice, video and data systems, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Spectracom, which develops parts used in fiber optic networks, for as much as $105 million. ADC, based in Minnetonka, Minn., said it would pay $60 million up front and might pay another $45 million, depending on future technology developments. ADC said the purchase would strengthen its position in the expanding optics market in the telecommunications area. The acquisition of Spectracom, a closely held company in White Bear Lake, Minn., is ADC's third purchase of an optical component company in four years. ADC's shares fell $1.78125, to $47.4375.

title: Suits Hold Microscope Over Gun Makers
description: When Los Angeles and San Francisco filed lawsuits against the gun industry on Tuesday, the growing legal assault on gun makers gained its best opportunity to subject the industry to a wide-ranging investigation that might reveal damaging internal documents similar to those that led tobacco companies to settle with the states, lawyers familiar with the gun cases say.

title: And Now Meet The Flintstone Floor
description: IT could have been the ultimate faux pas: Blake Sherlock and Andrew Sloan had just moved to New York to create artworks (at their Sloan/Sherlock Gallery in Chelsea), and I was asking if they would redo my bathroom floor.

title: Political Briefing; Putting Family First In a Louisiana Race
description: The special-election runoff on Saturday in Louisiana's First Congressional District is still too close to call.

title: Long Days for Gore on Rival's Terrain
description: The Governor down here is thinking of running for President. You might have heard something about it.

title: COMCAST AND ADELPHIA TO EXCHANGE SOME CABLE SYSTEMS
description: The Comcast Corporation and the Adelphia Communications Corporation, two of the largest United States cable TV operators, agreed to exchange cable systems that together serve about 900,000 customers to consolidate their regional subscribers. The swap will give Comcast and its Jones Intercable Inc. affiliate 464,000 more customers in their East Coast and Midwest markets and add 440,000 customers to Adelphia's systems in Los Angeles and Palm Beach, Fla. Comcast is based in Philadelphia and Adelphia is based in Coudersport, Pa. The companies said the systems would be independently appraised and any difference would be made up in cash or more cable systems.

title: Turning a Nine-Button Keypad Into a Discreet Communicator
description: A New York design firm and a Scarsdale psychiatrist have teamed up to turn the standard nine-button keypad of telephones, pagers, Palm Pilots and even television remote controls into a full keyboard.

title: A Picky Renovator Tells How It's Done
description: IMAGINE a prewar bathroom with a deep, deep porcelain tub and gleaming (but not too gleaming) nickel fittings: a wide sunflower shower head and those little porcelain buttons marked ''hot'' and ''cold'' in the middle of gutsy crossbar handles. There are reproductions, of course, but the dream is the real thing. It was my dream.

title: Life Lessons
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: AMERICAS; SLIM'S SHOPPING SPREE
description: Mexico's largest phone company, Telefonos de Mexico, controlled by the nation's wealthiest businessman, Carlos Slim Helu, has agreed to buy $100 million of stock in Williams Communications Group, which has filed for an initial public offering. Williams Communications is a unit of the Williams Companies, an energy and fiber-optic company based in Tulsa, Okla. The two companies plan to offer long-distance service in the United States and Mexico. Rick Wills (NYT)

title: Energy Aide in Spying Case to Be Honored
description: The Energy Department intelligence official who first raised the alarm about China's theft of American nuclear secrets will receive a special award Friday from Energy Secretary Bill Richardson for persisting in his inquiry despite numerous bureaucratic roadblocks, officials said today.

title: Two Familiar Tales in Unfamiliar Settings
description: Since 1982 the Center for Contemporary Opera, founded by the conductor Richard Marshall, has presented productions of 37 new or recent operas. No company large or small has a better record of service to the cause. On Tuesday night in Kaye Playhouse at Hunter College, Mr. Marshall and his forces presented two more, each in one act, each by an American: the world premiere of Jack Beeson's ''Sorry, Wrong Number'' and Elie Siegmeister's ''Angel Levine,'' which received its premiere at the 92d Street Y in 1985 and has languished since.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on page 7.

title: Watchdog Group Finds Cuts in Bus Service
description: Despite a three-year surge in bus ridership, New York City Transit has cut service on about 20 percent of its routes, including some of the most popular, according to a report released yesterday by the Straphangers Campaign, a transit watchdog group.

title: Philip Taaffe
description: Gagosian Gallery

title: I.R.L. and CART In Reconciliation Talks
description: Tony George, the Indy Racing League's president, acknowledged yesterday that he met privately with Andrew Craig, the chairman of Championship Auto Racing Teams, in Indianapolis last week, and that the two discussed in general terms the parameters of a reconciliation between the rival open-wheel circuits.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: Eric Ripert, the chef at Le Bernardin, has decided to clean his plate. Last week, he introduced a fixed-price menu called the minimalist, which shines a clear light on six kinds of seafood, each presented without vegetables or side dishes, in relatively simple preparations.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; The Crowds of Internet Investors Begin to Thin
description: How much more do Internet stocks have to fall before many investors lose interest? Not much, according to the latest mutual fund data.

title: Buckle Up on Buses
description: To the Editor:

title: McCann-Erickson Gets Windows Account
description: The Microsoft Corporation in Redmond, Wash., said yesterday that it had named McCann-Erickson North America as agency of record for the Windows operating system in the United States, effective July 1. Spending has not been determined pending planning to introduce Windows 2000; spending for previous versions of Windows ranged from $10 million to $100 million.

title: Capitol Hill Memo; Democrats Leave Stamp On the G.O.P. Congress
description: On the Capitol lawn today, gleefully defiant Democrats announced a petition drive to force the House to consider a bill to regulate health maintenance organizations. In another corner of Capitol Hill, Vice President Al Gore demanded that House Republicans enact even more restrictions on guns than the Senate reluctantly did.

title: Holiday on Monday
description: Memorial Day will be observed.

title: FAMILY FARE
description: They Won't Grow Up

title: Pushed to a Wall by Lawmakers, Reno Defends Herself
description: In an unusual defense of her handling of a nuclear espionage case, Attorney General Janet Reno said today that she was never fully informed of a dispute between the Justice Department and the F.B.I. over a proposal to wiretap a scientist suspected of spying for China.

title: A Summary of the Prosecution's Case
description: Four police officers remain on trial in the Abner Louima brutality case after the guilty plea this week by Justin A. Volpe, who admitted torturing Mr. Louima in a restroom at the 70th Precinct station house in Brooklyn. Here is a summary of the evidence prosecutors have presented against the other defendants.

title: On My Mind; Girl With a Skullcap
description: Sometimes when I am nearing the end of a trip to a nation that has a special meaning in my life, happy or dismal, I make a list of the words, images and memories that will keep fresh the people, and happenings, that shaped my attitudes and emotions about that country.

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: The Military's Myopia
description: To the Editor:

title: Some Fears Over Talks; Aides Worry
description: Publicly, the Clinton Administration has applauded the indictment of Slobodan Milosevic, a move that appears to change the Yugoslav President's status from potential deal maker to pariah.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOBLER, RICHARD
description: KOBLER-Richard. Inventor and Electronic Engineer. Died in JFK Medical Center in Ft. Worth, FL on May 8, 1999 at the age of 90. Mr. Kobler had over 100 patents to his name, was a pioneer in the field of sound recording and developed the first automated teaching machine called the ''Talking Typewriter''. Mr. Kobler was born and studied in Vienna, Austria where he later on had a patent office. His escape from Nazi Austria in 1938 was arranged by the film actress Gloria Swanson, documented in her autobiography, ''Swanson On Swanson''. In the U.S. he became European Manager of Engineering in Ms. Swanson's firm, Multiprises, Inc. Subsequently, Mr. Kobler became Vice President of Thomas A. Edison Industries and was appointed Director of Thomas A. Edison Industries Laboratories. Mr. Kobler invented the ''Voicewriter'', a remote-controlled dictation device which was installed in large institutions such as hospitals for the dictation of patient records. He invented the ''Rapidial'', the first phone to store and automatically dial frequently used numbers. Mr. Kobler developed several teaching machines, the first in the early 1960's. His ideas about the didactic power of technology were consummated by his ''Talking Typewriter'' proving consistently successful even with autistic and retarded children, despite the fact that the machine to teach reading & writing was designed primarily for very young children. In 1970, Mr. Kobler moved to Switzerland, where he lived for 25 years. In 1995, he took up residence in Florida. Mr. Kobler is survived by his wife, Dr. Edith Kobler and three children by a previous marriage, Arthur, Raymond, and Linda.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEIN, ROBERT L.
description: KLEIN-Robert L. NYU School of Law & The Law Alumni Association mourn the passing of one of our greatest citizens. Always there to guide and to help, Bob was a model lawyer and a wonderful friend. We note his passing with great sorrow. Carol Arber, Law Alumni Association President John Sexton, Dean

title: Is a Kosovo Ground War Inevitable?; Overzealous Albright
description: To the Editor:

title: Looking for a Book And Finding a Man
description: The most romantic notion in ''Notting Hill'' is that a Hollywood star of Julia Roberts's wattage would be out alone browsing for a book. That's what Ms. Roberts's Anna Scott is doing when she notices that the store's bashful proprietor is actually the most camera-ready sight on Portobello Road in London. So Anna takes a shine to Hugh Grant's William Thacker (a character perhaps named by a bookseller in a hurry), and ''Notting Hill'' throws together two beaming if oddly matched leads. The movie has lots of glossy charm even if Ms. Roberts and Mr. Grant seem less like lovers than members of a support group for the desperately attractive.

title: A Tradition Of Mothering Modernists
description: The accent was on fun on Monday when the 92d Street Y took a fast glide through its august history as a cradle of American modern dance. But there were also reminders of the role played by the Y and William Kolodney, its tireless arts programmer from the mid-1930's on, in encouraging dance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHERRILL, LAURENCE
description: SHERRILL-Laurence, on May 27, 1999. Beloved husband of Nancy. Loving step-father of Jessie and Eric. Private memorial service.

title: Nuclear Secrets and Spin Doctors
description: There's no spin that can make the allegations of Chinese espionage a good story for the White House. If cutting-edge nuclear technology made its way from Los Alamos to the People's Liberation Army, that is a bad story -- not just for the Clinton Administration, but for the United States as well.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ROYAL BANK L.P., Toronto, said it planned to sell its nonbranch buildings valued at more than $850 million (Canadian) and focus on its core business of banking.

title: C.L. Migden, 78, Actors' Lawyer
description: Chester L. Migden, a labor lawyer whose work for the Screen Actors Guild helped to establish the principle of paying actors for repeat showings of the television programs, feature films and commercials they appear in -- a practice that produces nearly $1 billion today -- died on Sunday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 78.

title: Pratt Journal; A Young Voice of Alarm Shakes Up an Election
description: Excitement seems to reach this town southeast of Charleston about every 90 years or so, not counting the fire truck that rolled into the Kanawha River a few summers ago because someone forgot to set the emergency brake.

title: Manhattan Official Seeks Inquiry on Schools
description: The Manhattan Borough President, C. Virginia Fields, said yesterday that she would ask Federal education officials to investigate the ''persistent and chronic failure'' of the city's public school system, and would file a complaint with the Department of Education's Office of Civil Rights charging that the state has not adequately financed the school system.

title: BRITISH CAUTION ON EURO
description: With the euro falling steadily, Eddie George, the Governor of the Bank of England, warned that British membership in the network of nations adopting the single European currency would be an ''act of faith'' carrying ''some kind of risks.'' Mr. George cited Britain's stronger growth projections, strong pound and relatively high interest rates as evidence of its economic divergence from Continental Europe. Britain is not expected to decide on joining the euro before 2002.

title: Quick Course in Jazz: Play It by Ear
description: Let's say you have no functional knowledge of jazz. You've heard that its history can teach you something about the evolution of American culture. You've heard that its range of expression -- from rhythms based in Afro-Caribbean models to harmony and structure grounded in 20th-century European music, from intellectualism to dance bands to the art/pop fusions in between -- is unparalleled in other contemporary music. You're intrigued.

title: From a Claimer to Acclaimed: The Saga of Charismatic
description: The day after Charismatic won the Kentucky Derby, less than three months after he had run in a claiming race for the second time, the telephone rang in the Hollywood Park barn of Richard Mandella, the world-class trainer.

title: WARRANTS SERVED FOR SERBS' LEADER AND 4 ASSISTANTS
description: The international tribunal issued an arrest warrant here today for Slobodan Milosevic, the Yugoslav President, charging him and other senior officials with crimes against humanity in Kosovo, including the murder, forced deportation and persecution of ethnic Albanians.

title: Whitney Gives Up a Gift, and Competitors Blanch
description: When the hammer came down on the sale of Alexander Calder's ''Constellation'' at Sotheby's on May 18, there was joy in the auction room. The painted wood-and-wire sculpture fetched $1.9 million from an anonymous private collector, more than double the presale estimate.

title: Morgan Stanley Suspends 2 Over Payment to an Informer
description: Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, the nation's largest securities firm, suspended two executives yesterday in connection with a $10,000 payment that led to the arrest of a former employee.

title: Hasidic Village Has Few Ways to Get Own School District
description: With New York State lawmakers reluctant to make a fourth attempt to create a special school district for the handicapped children of Kiryas Joel, its leaders have been looking for other ways of sustaining the school district.

title: Corrections
description: A dance review yesterday about a performance by the Robert Parsons Dance Company at the Joyce Theater misstated the given name of the composer of the music for ''Rush Hour'' and ''Variation.'' He is John Mackey, not Robert, and the music was played by the John Mackey Ensemble.

title: ALBUM OF THE WEEK
description: CHARLES LLOYD: ''JUST BEFORE SUNRISE'' -- (32 Jazz)

title: Deutsche Telekom to Keep Seeking Foreign Mergers
description: Stung by the collapse of its $81 billion attempted acquisition of Telecom Italia, Deutsche Telekom A.G. is now scrambling to rescue a global partnership with France Telecom and the Sprint Corporation.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE YEN GAINS. The dollar suffered its biggest drop against the yen in almost four months, dragged down by falling United States stocks. In New York, the dollar settled at 120.38 yen, down from 122.17 on Wednesday.

title: U.S. Accuses 3 of Smuggling Mexican Babies
description: Federal prosecutors today accused two Long Island women and a prominent lawyer near the Arizona-Mexico border of running a baby-smuggling ring in which at least 17 Mexican infants were illegally sold to unwitting adoptive parents in the New York area for $20,000 or more.

title: DIME IS BUYING 28 LONG ISLAND BRANCHES FROM KEYCORP
description: Dime Bancorp Inc. said yesterday that it would buy all 28 Long Island branches of Keybank N.A., a subsidiary of Keycorp, for $210 million. Under the agreement, Dime, based in New York, would gain about $1.3 billion of deposits and acquire $415 million of business and consumer loans. Dime, which is to pay a premium of 16.25 percent of deposits assumed, said the purchase would double its branch network in Nassau and Suffolk counties to 51 offices. Keycorp, based in Cleveland, said the sale was part of a plan to invest in higher-growth markets in the West. Shares of Keycorp fell 81.25 cents, to $34.4375, while Dime's stock was down 31.25 cents at $20.50.

title: ABC and Indy Still a Twosome
description: When ABC Sports officials began planning their Indianapolis 500 coverage four months ago, they viewed Sunday's race, which begins at 11 A.M., as possibly their last after 35 years. Fox looked like the favorite to grab the rights.

title: Mitchell Aiming to Fill a New Role for Jets
description: When last seen in the Jets' locker room, Johnny Mitchell had removed the nameplate from his cubicle.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TUFANO, ANTHONY
description: TUFANO-Anthony. May 26, 1999. Beloved husband of Gina. Loving father of Anthony. Devoted brother of Theresa. Cherished nephew of Ralph. Mass Saturday 9:30 AM at St. Thomas Aquinas RC Church, 9th St. Reposing at Joseph G. Duffy, Inc. 255 9th St., Brooklyn, NY. Visiting hours 2-5 and 7-9 PM. The Park Slope Butcher, you're in our hearts forever.

title: NORWEGIAN OIL DEAL
description: The Norwegian state-owned oil company Statoil agreed to sell its 20 percent stake in Saga Petroleum to Norsk Hydro in a move that could insure the success of Hydro's $3.9 billion bid for the rest of its smaller rival. The state-controlled Hydro, which on May 10 announced plans to acquire Saga, said it would give Statoil about 20 percent of Saga's holdings in Norwegian oilfields in return for the stake. Hydro will exchange $1.6 billion in stock with other Saga shareholders and assume $2.3 billion in debt.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Serbs Dismiss Indictment as Just Another Enemy Tactic
description: The Yugoslav Government scornfully dismissed the indictment today of President Slobodan Milosevic and four other top leaders on war crimes charges in Kosovo and repeated its desire to solve the conflict through negotiation.

title: Virgil Marti
description: Holly Solomon Gallery

description: There is a lunatic attempt by out-of-work cold warriors in Washington and retrograde Chinese nationalists in Beijing to use the latest Chinese spying scandal and bombing of the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade to put China and the United States on a collision course. It is times like these when you need a President who is ready to get right in the face of both his critics and the Chinese leadership and say the following:

description: ON THE STREET

title: Corrections
description: A brief report yesterday about new development at the Harborside Financial Complex in Jersey City misstated the square footage of a proposed office building. It is 185,000 square feet, not 150,000.

title: KOSOVO UPDATE
description: WAR CRIMES

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLAN, BEN
description: KAPLAN-Ben. Uncle of Deborah Kirschner, Libby Karol, Harvey Kaplan and Marilyn Markson. Also survived by several grandnieces and nephews. Services Sunday, 10 AM, Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91st and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Despite Indictment, Politicians and Diplomats Control Milosevic's Future
description: In handing up an indictment of Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic, the prosecutors have spoken. But, as has been the case since the outbreak of the wars in the former Yugoslavia, Mr. Milosevic's fate is still in the hands of politicians and diplomats.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOEWE, MILDRED (SCHIFFER)
description: LOEWE-Mildred (Schiffer). On May 26th, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Arthur. Loving mother of William and Judith Loewe. Dear sister of Morton A. Schiffer, MD. Cherished grandmother to Michael and Christopher, and greatgrandmother. Services Friday, 12PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: More a Backstage Bacchanal Than a Midsummer Dream
description: Those unsung heroes of the theater, the scenery-hanging, prop-moving light-stringers known as the techies, open their mouths and sing in the Moonwork theater company's broadly farcical reimagining of ''A Midsummer Night's Dream.'' The director Gregory Wolfe has turned Shakespeare's enchanted romp into a modern backstage comedy with a mincing dresser of a Puck, a Titania in vamp's clothing and a kick line of nymphs out of a Busby Berkeley spectacle.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Central Station

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PASSERMAN, MIRIAM R.
description: PASSERMAN-Miriam R. On May 26, 1999. In her 98th year, of Boca Raton, FL. Formerly of NYC and Chappaqua, NY. She was acknowledged to have been the oldest Alumna of the Columbia School of Journalism, Class of 1925. Beloved wife of the late Maxwell W. Daughter of the late Charles and Sarah Rosenthal. Loving mother of Louise Rosenfeld and Steven Passerman. Dear mother-in-law of Gabriel Rosenfeld and Harriet Passerman. Adored grandmother of Eric Rosenfeld, Alison R. Desmarais, Dr. Leslie R. Wash, Toni Passerman, David Passerman, Shari P. Turner and Charles Passerman. Cherished great grandmother of Evan and Sarabeth Turner. Service Sunday, May 30, 1999 11:15AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th St., and Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the American Jewish Historical Society, 15 West 16th Street, New York, N.Y. 10011.

title: ART GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free.

title: Officer Is Cleared in Death Of a Suspected Drug Dealer
description: A Manhattan grand jury has declined to indict a police officer in the death of a suspected drug dealer who was hit in the head by a police radio thrown by the officer during a chase, the Manhattan District Attorney's office announced yesterday.

title: Ciprianis Seek Restaurant Bankruptcy in Battle With Union
description: In the latest skirmish in an increasingly bitter battle with the hotel and restaurant workers union, the Cipriani family filed for bankruptcy protection on Wednesday for its chic restaurant on Fifth Avenue: Harry Cipriani.

title: Bill to Regulate Fertility Procedures Gains in Italy
description: The Italian Parliament has approved a draft law on assisted fertility that sets prison terms for doctors who use donated sperm to perform artificial insemination.

title: IMPROVEMENT AT ING
description: Europe's seventh-largest financial company, ING Groep N.V., said yesterday that its first-quarter profit from operations jumped 32 percent as its ING Barings investment bank rebounded from losses. Profit from operations at the Dutch firm rose to 775 million euros ($807 million) from 588 million euros last year. Net income fell 12 percent from last year, when the figure was padded by 292 million euros in gains.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: The King of Imported Beers; Corona's Success: Choice Hops vs. Choice Marketing
description: At Key Food in Astoria, Queens, a six-pack of Corona Extra costs $6.99 plus tax. For the same beer, supermarkets here charge less than $2.50.

title: INSIDE ART
description: A David Portrait In Williamstown

title: With Later Hours, Later News Coverage
description: Yesterday's decision by the board that governs the Nasdaq stock market to add an evening trading session puts new pressure on newspapers, wire services and television networks already competing to get the latest market information to their readers and viewers.

title: Ashley Bickerton
description: Sonnabend

title: Commencements; Welcome Advice: 'Be Brief'
description: As far as commencement rituals go, it was a subdued ceremony yesterday for Pace University. No beach balls flew through the air. No one did ''the wave.'' Only a handful of stray bubbles floated through the air in the darkened, air-conditioned Theater at Madison Square Garden, where Pace held its 93d commencement exercises while Radio City Music Hall, its usual location, was undergoing renovation.

title: S.E.C. Files Suit Against Defunct Broker
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission filed suit yesterday against HGI Inc., a defunct brokerage firm formerly known as Harriman Group, contending it defrauded investors of millions of dollars.

title: Title Fight Site Not Yet Chosen
description: Although the six-fight deal between Don King Productions and Park Place Entertainment that was announced Wednesday virtually guarantees that the Evander Holyfield-Lennox Lewis rematch will take place in Las Vegas, Nev., the exact site has not been chosen.

title: Corrections
description: An article on May 14 about the funeral of Charles Lambert, a Waikiki beach boy and later convention manager in Honolulu, referred incorrectly to his ancestry. He was not a descendant of Queen Liliuokalani, the Hawaiian Islands' last monarch; she had no children.

title: The Selling Of a Legend Of Decor
description: Most of us missed the party of the century: Carlos de Beistegui's masked ball in Venice in 1951, the first truly flamboyant fete after the Second World War. Guests donned elaborate 18th-century Venetian costumes and masks and congregated via gondola at Beistegui's Palazzo Labia on the Grand Canal. Beistegui, a famous esthete, designed individual uniforms for all the staff, as well as his own outrageous costume as a ''procurer of the Republic of Venice,'' which he wore standing on stilts.

title: Dining Outside
description: Between the chill of early spring nights and the sweaty heat of summer, there are a brief few weeks for enjoying outdoor dining, and the Memorial Day weekend is prime time. (These summaries, written by Eric Asimov, are taken from Mr. Asimov's and others' dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times.)

title: The Charges: 'An Unknown Number of Kosovo Albanians Have Been Killed'
description: Following are key sections of the indictment issued yesterday by the International Criminal Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia:

title: ON STAGE AND OFF
description: The Records Are Falling

title: INSIDE
description: Reno Counters Critics

title: A Glare and a Scowl, and Clemens Tames Red Sox
description: Those Yankees bearing baseball-size lumps from Roger Clemens made peace with the Rocket in spring training, forgiving the beanballs he aimed at them in the past, assuming he would throw many more on their behalf. But for the first seven weeks of this season, Clemens hardly pitched inside, didn't hit anybody, didn't knock anybody down.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Wednesday about NATO's approval of a 50,000-member peacekeeping force for Kosovo and its approval of a plan to search ships that may be carrying fuel to Yugoslavia included an erroneous reference from NATO to Malta's intended role. Malta has indeed agreed to take part in the embargo and has instructed Maltese-registered ships to stay clear of the area.

title: FOREIGN MONEY POURS INTO JAPAN
description: Riding a wave of mergers and alliances, Japan drew a record amount of investment from foreign companies in the year ended March 31. The Finance Ministry said foreigners had poured nearly $11 billion into Japan, up 74 percent from the previous high two years ago.

title: Peter Halley
description: Grant Selwyn

title: I.B.M. Executive Describes Price Pressure by Microsoft
description: A senior I.B.M. executive testified today that the Microsoft Corporation had repeatedly raised the prices it charged the International Business Machines Corporation for its Windows operating system and had enforced other onerous licensing terms in retaliation for I.B.M.'s refusal to stop competing with Microsoft.

title: Chinese Press In Full Attack On Spy Report
description: China's official press today attacked the credibility of the Congressional report accusing China of extensive military espionage, asserting that ''the specter of McCarthyism looms large in the Cox report.''

title: Traveling in Cyberspace Can Get a Guy Cyberkilled
description: Some doors are best left unopened, and one of them leads to movies with the kind of denouement that resembles one of those boxes of salt with a picture of a woman holding a box of salt with a picture of a woman holding a box of salt with a picture of . . . The possibilities extend ad infinitum and, in the case of ''The 13th Floor,'' ad nauseam.

title: An Old Clone
description: Well, maybe it won't be so easy after all to gain immortality by cloning a replica of yourself, or to produce a whole basketball team of Michael Jordan clones, or even a herd of super-cows. The researchers who shocked the world by cloning a lamb known as Dolly from the cell of an adult sheep have now discovered that Dolly is a lot older by one measure than she ought to be.

title: Is a Kosovo Ground War Inevitable?; Serbian Responsibility
description: To the Editor:

title: Impressionism's Icy Beauties
description: Think of the Impressionists, and chances are you think green (or possibly pink, or lavender, or bluebird-blue in the case of Monet). They were painters of lawns, hedges and fertile fields, of a deciduous nature caught at full leaf.

title: TAKEOVER OFFER SWEETENED
description: A battle intensified for Hillsdown Holdings P.L.C., which makes products from food to furniture, after the Dallas investment firm Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst sweetened a cash offer by 11 percent, to $:515.5 million ($824.8 million). The increase is intended to thwart a rival, Candover Investments P.L.C., which said earlier it was considering a bid ''considerably in excess'' of the initial Hicks offer of $:464 million.

title: The Ayn Rand Cliffs Notes: Philosophy as Foreplay
description: Atlas shrugged.

title: George W. Bush's Secret of Success
description: George W. Bush recently revealed that though he believes his name and family may have afforded him opportunities, he thinks his successes in business are the result of ''results and performance.'' To me, it's a telling admission. For in this one instance, George Bush, the son, is telling us we should disbelieve the obvious.

title: Sports of The Times; The Streak Without A Record
description: AT Yankee Stadium last night, the primary plot was not merely Roger Clemens's first start as a Yankee against the Red Sox but also his success in extending his streak of consecutive victories to 19 over two seasons. But a strange streak also was extended. With two singles last night, Derek Jeter has now been on base in each of the Yankees' 45 games this season.

title: Stocks Resume Slide
description: Stock prices fell for the fifth time in six sessions as the Dow Jones industrials tumbled 235.23 points, or 2.2 percent, the Dow's biggest skid of the year in point terms and the third time it lost 100 points this week.

title: How to Lose Humanity
description: To the Editor:

title: Robert Birmelin -- 'Betrayals of Memory'
description: Luise Ross Gallery

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANTIN, ALBERT
description: MANTIN-Albert. Beloved husband of Gilda. Loving father of Stephen and Kito, and Lois. Cherished grandfather of Rik, Jahan, Jamal, and Janeen. Funeral services Sunday, 12:30PM, at I.J. Morris, 46 Greenwich St., Hempstead, NY.

title: GTE IS SELLING 187,000 PHONE LINES AND ALASKAN BUSINESS
description: The GTE Corporation, the No. 3 United States local phone company, agreed yesterday to sell 187,000 phone lines in Arizona, California and Minnesota to the Citizens Utilities Company for $664 million in cash, as part of a plan to shed slower growing units. GTE said it would also sell its Alaskan phone business, which includes about 20,600 phone lines, to the closely held Alaskan Telephone Exchange Acquisition Corporation for an undisclosed amount. Citizens, a company in Stamford, Conn., that provides phone, electric and gas services in 22 states, said the purchase was part of an effort to expand its business to three million phone lines. The deal was announced after GTE's shares fell $2.1875, to $62.4375, and Citizens fell 37.5 cents, to $8.9375.

title: Failing the Test
description: The dismal results of the new reading and writing test for New York State's fourth graders reveal how much needs to be done to improve schools everywhere. Less than a third of New York City students passed, and many city schools had failure rates above 90 percent. But the results are not reassuring for affluent suburban districts either.

title: PROFIT SURPRISE AT MITSUBISHI
description: Against a backdrop of weak corporate earnings throughout Japan, the Mitsubishi Motors Corporation reported a profit for the year ended March 31 despite a 6 percent decline in sales. The car maker, regarded as a potential takeover target, said earnings rose to 5.66 billion yen, or $46.4 million, from a loss of 101.8 billion yen a year earlier. Much of the unexpectedly robust earnings came from the sale of land related to a plant closing, though subsidiaries in the United States, Europe and Thailand all made money.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLAUNSTEIN, JEROME L., M.D.
description: BLAUNSTEIN-Jerome L., M.D. Passed away on May 24, 1999. He will be missed by many friends and relatives and especially by his companion of many years, Bruce C. Olsen.

title: Reorganization At Rizzuti Beckman
description: ''Dot.com'' fever is spreading along Madison Avenue as a direct response agency, Rizzuti Beckman & Lyman, reorganizes as Rizzuti.com.

title: Survey Shows Prices for Gas Are Up in City
description: Driving to the Hamptons or the Jersey Shore this holiday weekend? Taking the car to a friend's barbecue in the 'burbs? Be prepared to pay more for gas, a survey released yesterday by the city's Consumer Affairs Commissioner said.

title: On Military Bill, Senate Backing, House Chaos
description: The Senate tonight easily passed a $289 billion military authorization bill that tightens security at the nation's weapons laboratories. But the House, faced with a nearly identical bill, collapsed into chaos and abruptly recessed for the holiday weekend.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANDEL, ELEANOR
description: MANDEL-Eleanor. Our condolences to our dear Benjy, son-inlaw, husband, father, grandfather and brother-in-law, upon the loss of his beloved mother whom we shall always remember as a true Aishes Chayil. May Hashem comfort and strengthen him with the memories of a remarkable woman and Tzadekes. Pepa and Joseph Karasick Bernice Mandel Linda and Mark Karasick Denise and George Karasick Children and grand children

title: Lawyer Pleads Guilty to Securities Fraud
description: Hartley T. Bernstein, a well-known securities lawyer in New York, pleaded guilty yesterday to securities fraud conspiracy and perjury in Federal District Court in Manhattan and agreed to forfeit $850,000 in illegal proceeds made as an insider in five fraudulent public stock offerings, Federal prosecutors said.

title: Alice Adams, 72, Writer of Deft Novels
description: Alice Adams, widely admired for her deft, elegantly observed novels and short stories, died yesterday at her home in San Francisco. She was 72.

title: CARLYLE GROUP AGREES TO PAY $161 MILLION CASH FOR EMPI
description: Empi Inc., the No. 1 United States maker of devices that electrically manage pain, said yesterday that it had agreed to be bought by the Carlyle Group for about $161 million in cash. Carlyle, a Washington-based buyout company led by Frank C. Carlucci, a former Defense Secretary, is to pay $26.50 for each share of Empi. The company, with 1998 sales of $73.1 million, makes electrotherapy products that control pain and stimulate muscular function through low-voltage impulses. The shares of Empi, which is based in St. Paul, rose $3.6875, to $24.50. Empi has annual cash flow of about $15 million and holds about 22 percent of the $210 million electrotherapy products market.

title: Residential Real Estate; Rental Complex Is Bronxville's First in 30 Years
description: The first new rental complex in Bronxville, N.Y., in 30 years opened this week, with rents ranging from $2,100 to $8,000 a month. The 110-apartment complex has been built on a 1.7-acre site that had eluded development for nearly a decade, replacing a gas station and a small commercial building.

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Suspect in Slaying of Atheists Pleads Guilty to Weapons Charges
description: One day after Federal officials released an affidavit that accused him of participating in the abduction and killing of the atheist leader Madalyn Murray O'Hair, Mrs. O'Hair's former office manager pleaded guilty today to two weapons charges in Federal court.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in New York City this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Jackson Will Keep Knicks On Toes
description: There was chaos on the court for the Knicks about this time last year as a tipped ball was swung calmly from the Pacers' Chris Mullin to Mark Jackson to Reggie Miller in three swift motions.

title: Zhu Qizan -- 'Unafraid of the Autumn Wind'
description: China 2000 Fine Art

title: FOR CHILDREN
description: Theater

title: Poughkeepsie Official Admits Taking Bribes
description: The mushrooming Dutchess County political scandal claimed another government official yesterday when the longtime water commissioner of the Town of Poughkeepsie pleaded guilty to collecting thousands of dollars in bribes from contractors and dispatching town employees to work on the home of the county's Republican Party chairman.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZ, STANLEY
description: KATZ-Stanley. National Council of Jewish Women, Peninsula Section mourns the passing of Stanley Katz, husband of Barbara, devoted board member. We extend heartfelt sympathy to the entire family. Adrienne Lurie, President

title: Close Giuliani Aide Is Leaving And City Hall Explains Little
description: Cristyne F. Lategano, the close and ubiquitous adviser to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, is taking a leave of absence for personal reasons, administration officials said last night.

title: Kyoto Journal; The Nun's Best Seller: 1,000-Year-Old Love Story
description: As Japanese heroes go, he is an unusual one. He never wore a tie, never got a job, and after seducing his stepmother when he was a teen-ager he had a string of affairs with women who included his own adopted daughter.

title: The Topography of One Man's Life
description: ''Eternity and a Day'' won an overdue Palme d'Or at last year's Cannes International Film Festival for the Greek director Theo Angelopoulos, whose style of drifting metaphysical reverie is at its most accessible here. All things being relative, this is a dreamy, lulling film but also a more concise and straightforward one than the magnificently grandiose ''Ulysses's Gaze,'' the Angelopoulos opus that directly preceded it. ''Eternity and a Day'' is simpler, the haunting poetic valedictory of an artist whose memory leads him across the landscape of his life during his last day on earth.

title: Edith Lewin, 88, Mexican Art Collector
description: Edith Lewin, who with her husband, Bernard, amassed the largest privately owned collection of Mexican modernist art and then gave it away, died on Sunday at her home in Palm Springs, Calif. She was 88.

title: Editorial Observer; A Long Day of Venting About the City's Police
description: The issue of ''Police Practices and Civil Rights in New York City'' seemed too deep, too massive for one hearing by the United States Commission on Civil Rights in an undersized hotel meeting room in Manhattan. The torture of Abner Louima and the shooting of Amadou Diallo by police have made this historic issue altogether too current. And so the hearing on Wednesday brought out a large and unhappy crowd.

title: Once Again, Sampras Fails to Reach the Top
description: For the 10th straight year Pete Sampras concluded his annual business trip to the French Open, the only Grand Slam where his greatness has yet to leave its imprint. He fell from contention early, and he fell hard.

title: Movie Star and Other
description: In ''Notting Hill,'' Julia Roberts, below, with Hugh Grant, needn't stretch to play a movie star. Nor is it difficult for Mr. Grant to play the most photogenic tourist attraction on Portobello Road in London. If these two seem less like lovers than members of a support group for the desperately attractive, they still bond in a literate romantic comedy about fame.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, RICHARD M.
description: COHEN-Richard M. Died May 27 at 1:30 A.M., at the age of 62. Loving husband of Barbara, devoted father of Jimmy, Andy, Holly and the late Tina. He is survived by his mother Frances, his sister Marilyn and husband Richard, his brother Arthur and wife Karen, and his aunt Rose. This gentle and caring man will be deeply missed by all who knew him. His love and enjoyment of life was an inspiration. Funeral services will be held at Beth Jacob Congregation, 9030 West Olympic Boulevard, Los Angeles, CA on Friday, May 28, at 11:00 a.m. Phone (310) 278-1911. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be given in Richard Cohen's name to the Rape Foundation, Pediatric AIDS Foundation and the Jackie Robinson Foundation.

title: 'Unknown Talent' -- Women Abstractionists of the 30's, 40's and 50's
description: David Findlay Jr. Inc.

title: YAHOO IS BUYING SOFTWARE DEVELOPER FOR $130 MILLION
description: Yahoo Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Encompass Inc., a developer of consumer Internet software, for $130 million. With the acquisition, Yahoo, which is based in Santa Clara, Calif., can expand the services it offers its strategic partners through its Internet portal. Besides connecting consumers to the Internet, Encompass, based in Atlanta, provides product registration services that companies use to capture demographic information about customers.

title: The Pentagon Opposes One Bid by Litton, but Not Another
description: The Defense Department said last night that it was recommending against Litton Industries' unfriendly bid for Newport News Shipbuilding Inc. on the grounds that the proposed union would cause too much concentration in the military shipbuilding business.

title: Eric Fischl
description: Mary Boone

title: Court Rules Against LVMH in Battle Over Gucci
description: Gucci Group N.V. triumphed today in the latest round of a struggle to thwart a hostile bid by its bigger rival, LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton, when a Dutch court upheld Gucci's sale of shares to the French department store group Pinault-Printemps-Redoute S.A.

title: Does Giuliani Sue Too Much? Who Cares, He Wins
description: To the Editor:

title: Company Abandons Plan for Rival TV Ratings
description: The company that created a television rating system that network executives had identified as the best potential alternative ever devised to Nielsen Media Research announced that it was shutting the operation down yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HOWELL, HAMPTON P., JR.
description: HOWELL-Hampton P., Jr. There will be a memorial service on Saturday, May 29th at noon at St. Mark's Church, Westhampton Beach, LI for Mr. Howell who died in Providence, R.I. last February 11th. Donations may be sent to Westhampton Beach Historical Society Westhampton Beach, NY 11978 or Open Space Council, PO Box 275 Brookhaven, NY 11719

title: Despite Holes, Good Enough For a City Plan
description: LIFE is enriched by its little mysteries, like who first looked at a lobster and said, ''Mmm, I want to eat that,'' and what was the greatest thing before sliced bread.

title: My Fee-for-Service Coiffure
description: I went to my hairdresser the other day. I'm a doctor on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, and my hairdresser is my patient. He asked me whether I was in a certain managed-care network, and I said I was thinking of dropping out of all of them.

title: House Democrats Push Stricter Gun Rules
description: Democratic advocates of gun control urged the House today to adopt stricter restrictions on firearms than the Senate had, upping the ante for Republicans as the political gamesmanship over the issue intensified.

title: Drug Abuse Is An Insurer's Problem
description: To the Editor:

title: Waldo Semon Dies at 100; Chemist Who Made Vinyl
description: Waldo Semon, a chemist and inventor who brought about the age of vinyl, died Wednesday at a nursing home in Hudson, Ohio. He was 100.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Defending Humor Among Uniforms

title: Votary of Stanislavsky and Champion of Chekhov
description: STELLA ADLER ON IBSEN, STRINDBERG AND CHEKHOV

title: Lukas Goes to Belmont With Cat Thief in Met
description: Belmont Park begins the countdown to its third straight Triple Crown suspense thriller tomorrow with the 106th running of the Metropolitan Handicap, a one-mile race that has drawn Cat Thief, Lil's Lad, Affirmed Success and Sir Bear as the stars of a strong field of eight horses.

title: A Cancer Doctor Mindful of Body and Soul
description: WOMEN flock to his lectures, buy out benefits honoring him, contrive to throw him fund-raising parties. The well and the sick, the wealthy and the accomplished, they worship him. He has treated Linda Ellerbee and Linda McCartney. At one dinner to honor him this month, Carly Simon sat at his table and Bette Midler yanked him onstage for a jitterbug. As Evelyn H. Lauder, whose Breast Cancer Research Foundation was the beneficiary of that dinner, put it, ''The Larry Norton groupies were coming out of the walls!''

title: Ohio Justices Strike Down Voucher Plan In Cleveland
description: The Ohio Supreme Court has ruled that Cleveland can no longer offer vouchers that enable low-income children to attend private and parochial schools.

title: Shirley Katzander, 78, Publicist
description: Shirley Katzander, a public relations consultant who specialized in promoting cultural and political figures, died on Wednesday at her home in Manhattan. She was 78.

title: Flip Tabloid Apology Leaves Royals Cold
description: The Sun today published a full-page apology for having printed a picture of Prince Edward's fiancee, Sophie Rhys-Jones, with a breast bared, but Buckingham Palace declined to withdraw its official complaint against the tabloid.

title: Comparing the Fake and the Great
description: Western attitudes toward forgery have changed over the centuries. In the 16th century, Vasari admired Michelangelo for his ability to fake antiquities. The most famous forger in this century, Han Van Meegeren, went to jail for painting fake Vermeers. He chose Vermeer partly because the public had recently begun to admire him after centuries of neglect, and fakery thrives when people are beginning to prize an art, a situation akin to new love.

title: Police Say Doctor Tried To Have His Boss Killed
description: An orthopedic surgeon at St. Joseph's Hospital in Clifton, N.J., was arraigned yesterday on charges that he tried to hire a hit man to kill his supervisor. The doctor, John Pope, believed that his boss, Dr. David Rasa, was writing negative job evaluations of him and was trying to hold back his career because of bad blood over a woman they had both dated, Passaic County prosecutors said.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: As American As, Well, Sex

title: A Pocket Tour of the Century in 86 Small Works
description: Byron once said of something that it was ''Little, but to the purpose.'' This can be true of things either written or said, and it can also be true of works of art. It can certainly be applied to the 86 paintings, sculptures, drawings and photographs in the current exhibition at the Yoshii Gallery.

title: Lakers Reported Bypassing Jackson for Coaching Job
description: If Phil Jackson returns to coaching in the National Basketball Association next season, it appears that the Nets or the Knicks would have the best chance of securing him. The Los Angeles Lakers, the talented yet underachieving club that was believed to be Jackson's team of choice, are strongly considering rehiring the interim coach, Kurt Rambis, on a permanent basis, according to a published report.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Nasdaq Planning to Trade 100 Big Stocks in Evening

title: Isringhausen Receives Good News for a Change
description: As badly as things were going health-wise for the Mets' starting pitchers this week, there was good news involving two of the organization's young pitchers yesterday.

title: Empathy on the Bench
description: To the Editor:

title: PROSECUTION RESTS IN THE LOUIMA CASE
description: The prosecution wrapped up its case yesterday against the four police officers still on trial in the Abner Louima brutality case, but without presenting the kind of directly incriminating evidence that it amassed against Officer Justin A. Volpe, who pleaded guilty in mid-trial this week and threw himself on the mercy of the court.

title: Mohawk Casino Allowed To Begin Video Gambling
description: New York State and the St. Regis Mohawk tribe signed an agreement yesterday permitting the use of electronic gambling machines at the tribe's casino, a move that is expected to net the state at least $3 million a year and rescue the six-week-old casino from deep financial problems.

title: Dow Plummets 235.23 as Investors React to Rising Interest Rates
description: Stock prices resumed their losing ways yesterday as rising long-term interest rates prompted many investors to cash in profits on the approach of a long holiday weekend.

title: Plant Thieves Plague a Block In Brooklyn; Neighbors Irate but Baffled By Well-Dressed Suspects
description: Surrounded by the government buildings and parking lots of downtown Brooklyn is a verdant block where window boxes trail asparagus fern, and slender stalks of bamboo grow from barrels topped by a flowering bog rosemary. The block, a stretch of State Street between Bond and Hoyt Streets in Boerum Hill, is so strikingly lush, it was designated the borough's ''greenest'' last year by the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.

title: Indiana, Too, Has A Hurting Center
description: Rik Smits trudged off the Market Square Arena floor, grimacing enough for his teammates to notice. He is not in constant pain, but the 7-foot-4-inch center does have something in common with Patrick Ewing: he's hurting.

title: A Daydream Or a Chance, With Echoes Of Bunuel
description: Oh, for the chance to go back and relive the past and not make the same mistake twice. How sweetly tormenting such a fantasy can be when applied to love. If only, if only, if only.

title: TLC Beatrice to Sell Remaining Divisions
description: In a quiet finale to what has been a sometimes stormy saga, the remaining businesses of TLC Beatrice International Holdings Inc. -- potato chips and ice cream -- will be sold by the end of the summer and what was once one of the nation's largest black-owned companies will close its doors.

title: Valentine the Tinkerer Faces Multiple Choices
description: Manager Bobby Valentine of the Mets loves to tinker with his starting lineup. He will soon face a delicate challenge: finding playing time for five outfielders.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GERING, GLADYS
description: GERING-Gladys. On May 27, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Harold Spero and Marion Gering. Loving mother of Teri Spero. Dear aunt of Marianne and Helena Ross. Great aunt to Winnie, Jamie, Benjamin, Frans and Sammy. Graveside services Sunday 11am at Mount Ararat Cemetery.

title: Unlike Mandela, but Likeliest to Succeed Him
description: When Thabo Mbeki rose to speak in the half-empty community hall here recently, the applause was polite. Barely visible behind the tall lectern, the diminutive Mr. Mbeki began with what sounded like an attack on the press.

title: After Eluding Past Attempts, Show World Is Closed Down
description: Show World, a landmark strip club off Times Square that for years had eluded the twin buzz saws of Times Square redevelopment and the city's campaign against sex-oriented businesses, was closed yesterday by the Giuliani administration.

title: ON THE RECORD: Governor Bush and Education; Turnaround in Texas Schools Looks Good for Bush in 2000
description: On a rundown road in this sprawling border city, the Castaneda Elementary School, built in 1965 for the children of Mexican migrant workers, is still housed in its original portable buildings. All of its 360 pupils are Mexican-American; a majority arrive not knowing English and a quarter spend several months a year on the road with their working parents.

title: Drug Abuse Is An Insurer's Problem
description: To the Editor:

title: If Seeking Infinity, Try Outdoors
description: The cry of ''To infinity and beyond!'' heard in the film ''Toy Story'' is coming true for Infinity Broadcasting, at least in the booming realm of advertising seen and heard outside the home.

title: Delivering a Message, With a Little Chin Music
description: Roger Clemens had insisted that last night's start against the Red Sox did not have special meaning. Sure. Clemens had recited these words, but one wondered if he had also crossed his fingers and his toes as he spoke. No special meaning for Clemens? Sorry, Roger. That is impossible to fathom.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about a newly calculated rate of expansion of the universe referred incorrectly in some editions to the speed at which a galaxy appears to be flying away from Earth. It is 70 kilometers per second per megaparsec -- that is, 160,000 miles per hour faster for every 3.26 million light-years of distance from Earth, not for every 3.26 light-years.

title: The Story of Adam and Eve, Sort Of
description: In ''The Loss of Sexual Innocence,'' Mike Figgis's visually exquisite, intensely personal meditation on the story of Adam and Eve, the world's first couple are a black man (Femi Ogunbanjo) and a white woman (Hanne Klintoe), who emerge like angelic beings from the waters of a golden lake. Discovering each other, they explore their anatomical differences like playful children delightedly splashing around in the water.

title: Like Peter Pan, But Also Mortal
description: It must have been all those dreams of flying that did it: dreams where I could float and skim the ground, swooping and soaring, in endless flight. Only a strong and seemingly atavistic urge could have compelled me to volunteer for East Coast Paragliding's one-day introductory course.

title: 15 Minutes (Count 'Em) Of Infamy
description: The abysmal state of comedy glares with all the subtlety of a mandrill's rump off any screen unfortunate enough to display ''The Underground Comedy Movie.''

title: Corrections
description: The Restaurants column on May 5 about Amaranth, on the Upper East Side -- at a site that was formerly Arcadia -- misstated the number of stars the column had given Arcadia. It was three, not two.

title: Russian Silents That Say a Lot
description: In Aleksandr Dovzhenko's ''Arsenal'' (1929) a one-armed farmer, furious over his imminent starvation, beats his decrepit horse with a stick. Slowly the weary animal turns to him. ''You're hitting the wrong one, Ivan,'' it says.

title: Random House Cancels Book On Eisner
description: Broadway Books, a publishing division of Random House Inc., has canceled its contract with Kim Masters, a contributing editor of both Time and Vanity Fair magazines, to publish her book about Michael D. Eisner, the chairman of the Walt Disney Company, and his ascension to Hollywood power.

title: Fox Network and Affiliates in Financial Accord
description: The Fox network and members of its board of affiliates stations agreed yesterday on a plan that would reverse the financial agreement between networks and stations, in effect since the days of radio, by having the stations pay the network cash instead of the other way around.

title: BRAZIL AUTO DEAL
description: The Brazilian Government and car makers reached an agreement cutting taxes on automobiles as an effort to save jobs in an industry battered by high interest rates. The accord maintains a previous pact that lowered taxes on small- and medium-sized cars in exchange for pledges from car makers, including General Motors and Fiat, to delay layoffs. Taxes will remain reduced for 90 days; car makers will suspend job cuts for 120 days. The agreement coincided with news that unemployment in Sao Paulo, the heart of the country's auto industry, had risen to a record 20.3 percent in April, from 19.9 percent in March.

title: PRODIGY IN DEAL FOR CABLE AND WIRELESS SUBSCRIBERS
description: The Prodigy Communications Corporation said yesterday that it would acquire the United States dial-up Internet service of Cable and Wireless P.L.C. for between $50 million and $75 million. The final purchase price will be based on how many Cable and Wireless subscribers stay with Prodigy. The deal covers only individuals and businesses that connect to the Internet over standard modems and phone lines through the United States unit of Cable and Wireless. The subscribers that Prodigy will acquire were originally customers of MCI Worldcom Inc. Last year, Cable and Wireless, based in London, acquired certain Internet assets, including customers, from MCI Communications for $1.75 billion. Prodigy's shares rose $2 each, to $25.

title: APACHE DEAL IN CANADA
description: A 10-year contract was awarded to Derlan Industries Ltd. of Toronto by the Boeing Company to help develop a lightweight drive-train system for the AH-64 Apache attack helicopter. The deal, worth about $500 million to Derlan, contributed to a 38 percent surge in the stock of the diversified products company, which had 1998 sales of $193 million and has been seeking to concentrate on its military and pump businesses. Derlan shares closed at 2.70 Canadian dollars, or $1.84, on the Toronto Stock Exchange.

title: Metro Business; Trump Land Is for Sale
description: Nine acres of land on the West Side of Manhattan owned by Donald J. Trump and his partners from Hong Kong were offered for sale last week.

title: Novartis Is Ordered to Fix Doan's Ads
description: Novartis A.G., the pharmaceutical giant, was ordered today by the Federal Trade Commission to run advertisements correcting earlier statements that called its Doan's back-pain relievers superior to other medicines.

title: A Setback for United Farm Workers
description: For three years, the United Farm Workers of America has struggled to organize California's 20,000 strawberry pickers and packers -- who harvest more than 80 percent of the nation's strawberries under often backbreaking conditions -- in an effort to revitalize the crusading spirit of the union's founder, Cesar E. Chavez.

title: Safir Calls Shooting an Accident but Says Youth Was Out Too Late
description: Police Commissioner Howard Safir said yesterday that the shooting of an unarmed 16-year-old boy by a member of the Police Department's Street Crime Unit appeared to have been an accident, and he questioned what the youth had been doing out on the streets of the Bronx after midnight in the first place.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THURNAUER, MARIA
description: THURNAUER-Maria. Of Teaneck, NJ. Died quietly in her sleep on May 27, in her 88th year. Beloved wife of William. Loving mother of Joan and Andrew. Grandmother of Rebecca and Jesse, Caitlin and Michael.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A1-14

title: Is a Kosovo Ground War Inevitable?; Protectorate Is Needed
description: To the Editor:

title: Prosecutor's Statement: 'Sufficient Evidence'
description: Following are excerpts from the statement yesterday by Louise Arbour, chief prosecutor of the International Criminal Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia, charging President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia and four others with crimes against humanity, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Is a Kosovo Ground War Inevitable?
description: To the Editor:

title: Moscow, Seeing Obstacle, Sends Envoy to Belgrade
description: After an intense round of talks with his American and European counterparts, Russia's special Balkans envoy, Viktor S. Chernomyrdin, heads on Friday to Belgrade to meet President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEBOVITZ, SONIA. (NEE MILKMAN)
description: LEBOVITZ-Sonia. (nee Milkman). Beloved wife of the late Benjamin; devoted mother of Lucille and Linda; mother-in-law of Ian and Andrew; loving grandmother of Erikka, Carllee, Skyye, Toby, David, Joanna; loved by many nieces and nephews. Services Sunday. ''Wien & Wien'' 1-800-322-0533.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIRSCH, ANDREW
description: HIRSCH-Andrew. Beloved husband of Rita. Loving father of Joan, Ronald and Tracey. Adored grandfather of Lora, Steven, Blayne and Evan. Owner of Direct Machinery, distributor of laundry and dry cleaning equipment. Proud veteran of WW2. Services today, 1:45PM at ''Sinai Chapels,'' 162-05 Horace Harding Expwy., Fresh Meadows, New York.

title: Bette Midler Was Here: A Park Gets a Second Act
description: What I'm smelling on a May afternoon, as I stand on an overlook in Highbridge Park at 179th Street, is not the noxious fumes from compacted traffic on the Alexander Hamilton and Washington Bridges looming overhead. It's a heady floral scent, as intriguing as it is unlikely. Just above on the slope is a grove of locust trees in full white blossom. Even on their best day, they would never smell as good as this. Walking beyond the locusts, I come upon a field where the secret is revealed. Here, where less than two years ago carcasses of stolen cars were heaped, are dozens of low-lying lilac bushes in pale purple flower. Bette Midler had struck again.

title: Coaching Sanfords Enjoy Openers
description: The Sanford family of coaches did all right yesterday in the opening events of the Intercollegiate Rowing Association's national championship regatta on the Cooper River in Cherry Hill, N.J.

title: Rekindling a Love Affair With Tchaikovsky Ballets
description: After two weeks of works to scores by Stravinsky, the New York City Ballet is continuing its 50th-anniversary season by stepping a bit backward in musical history and devoting a week to another composer associated with dance: Tchaikovsky. The company opened its little Tchaikovsky Festival on Tuesday night at the New York State Theater with three fine ballets by George Balanchine.

title: Yugoslav Army Again Shells Villages in Northeast Albania
description: For the second day, Yugoslav forces shelled villages in northeast Albania today, heightening tensions along the main crossing point for refugees fleeing from Kosovo.

title: ALBANY INTERNATIONAL IS BUYING GESCHMAY BUSINESSES
description: The Albany International Corporation agreed yesterday to buy the paper machine clothing businesses of Geschmay Group of Germany for $232 million in cash. The Geschmay businesses that Albany is buying had 1998 sales of about $160 million. Albany International is the world's largest maker of paper machine clothing, which are custom-engineered fabrics that are used in the manufacture of paper. Shares of the company, which is based in Albany, dropped 62.5 cents, to $23, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: A Nomination Is Withdrawn, And a Deal Is Threatened
description: A prominent conservative Republican who was nominated by President Clinton to an important Federal appeals court as part of an extraordinary political deal is withdrawing her name, Congressional officials said tonight.

title: Resigning From Parliament, Netanyahu Hints at Return
description: In a defiant parting speech after his defeat in the Israeli election, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu announced his resignation from Parliament today but hinted at a political comeback.

title: Risk to Diplomacy
description: Privately, Clinton Administration officials say the war crimes indictments are likely to derail efforts to find a diplomatic solution in Kosovo.

title: Bertelsmann Is Reorganizing Random House
description: Less than a year after Bertelsmann A.G. bought Random House and blended it with existing holdings into the nation's largest publishing house, top executives moved yesterday to consolidate several long-established publishing units. Critics called the move a triumph of corporate organization over literary values.

title: Spacecraft's Data Yield First Detailed Map of Mars
description: The first global three-dimensional map of Mars, made with data from an orbiting American spacecraft, reveals a surface of extreme highs and lows sculptured by still mysterious processes, scientists said today.

title: 2 Indian Warplanes Lost Over Pakistan's Part of Kashmir
description: Two Indian fighter jets were lost in combat today on the Pakistani side of the cease-fire line in troubled Kashmir, worsening the confrontation between the subcontinent's two nuclear-armed rivals.

title: Suspected North Korean Atom Site Is Empty, U.S. Finds
description: American investigators in North Korea have discovered that an underground site that Washington suspects could be used to revive that nation's nuclear weapons program is a huge, empty tunnel, the Clinton Administration said today.

title: Kosovo Rebels, Once Weak, Start Taking a Toll on Serbs
description: Kosovo Liberation Army fighters, led by more experienced commanders and buoyed by NATO's escalating air campaign, are waging increasingly effective hit-and-run attacks against Yugoslav troops in Kosovo, Pentagon officials said today.

title: BIG STOCK MARKETS MOVING TO EXPAND TO EVENING HOURS
description: In a world so fast paced that few bankers keep bankers' hours anymore, there remains something quaint about the insulated world of stock traders.

title: Commerce Department Sees Corporate Profit Recovery
description: After more than a year of weak growth, corporate profits rebounded in the first quarter, the Commerce Department reported yesterday. The giant tobacco industry settlement distorted the figures, temporarily fattening the first-quarter number. But the rebound also suggested that the squeeze on profits evident last year may have lifted a bit.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Some will say that this indictment came too late. Others will say that it came too soon. I say it came perfectly appropriately.''

title: Cameos and Cameras: A Dancer's Dual Career
description: Rosalie O'Connor may look as if she had been born to stage royalty when she plays the role of Bathilde, a duke's daughter, tomorrow afternoon in American Ballet Theater's production of ''Giselle.'' But the big-eyed, willowy dancer, who bends graciously to the admiring young peasant Giselle, is even more at home behind the eye of a camera than she is in the rehearsal studio or on the stage.

title: Is a Kosovo Ground War Inevitable?; Hostage Mentality
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITE, JAMES JOSEPH
description: WHITE-James Joseph. Of Pleasantville, N.Y. and Spanish Point, Ireland. Died on Wednesday at University Hospital in Galway. He is survived by his wife, Josephine and his four children, James, Jr., Karen, John, and Maryann; his sisters, Ann Brown and Mary O'Connor; and his stepchildren, William and Kathleen. There will be a wake on Sunday from 2PM-4PM and 7PM-9PM at the William Graham Funeral Home in Rye, N.Y. and a funeral mass at 10:30AM on Monday at the Resurrection Church, also in Rye. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the American Heart Foundation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YALLOWITZ, LILLIAN
description: YALLOWITZ - Lillian. Beloved wife of our esteemed collegue, Paul. We extend heartfelt sympathies to her children, their spouses and her grandchildren. She was a woman of valor. Hoberman, Miller, Goldstein & Lesser

title: The Case Against Mr. Milosevic
description: Though it may complicate peace negotiations, the indictment of Slobodan Milosevic and four other Serbian leaders for crimes against humanity is just and consonant with the bedrock principles of a civilized international order. Serbia's systematic killing, deportation and persecution of Kosovo's ethnic Albanians are surely such crimes, and those responsible should be held accountable.

title: All Singing! All Dancing! All Gotham!
description: During rehearsals for ''I Married an Angel,'' a 1938 musical comedy about a Hungarian banker, the show's lyricist, Lorenz Hart, a quick-witted master of the last-minute fix, decided to add a new number called ''At the Roxy Music Hall.''
