When Joshua Logan, the director, asked anxiously how a number filled with allusions to contemporary New York personalities could possibly be made to fit into a comedy set in old Budapest, Hart answered airily: ''Well, just bring up the subject of New York. You can't sing about Budapest all night. We've got to give people a little fun.''

title: Drug Abuse Is An Insurer's Problem
description: To the Editor:

title: Shuttle Bound for Space Station, Supplies in Tow
description: The space shuttle Discovery is headed for a late-night Friday rendezvous with the international space station, where seven astronauts from the United States, Canada and Russia plan to spend six days setting up housekeeping for the first permanent crew.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHMID, FLORA T.
description: SCHMID-Flora T. Of the Village of Golf, Florida died on Thursday, May 27, 1999. Born on July 4th, 1912 in Chattanooga, Tennessee, she was predeceased by her late husband Carl J. Schmid. She is survived by her two daughters, Radiant Wolf and Elaine; her sister Arlene and by her three grandchildren, Christov, Carlene, and Laurel. A Visitation will be held today, Friday, May 28, 1999 from 11:00AM until 12:00 noon at Quattlebaum-Holleman-Burse Funeral Home, 1201 South Olive Avenue, West Palm Beach, FL 561-832-5171. No flowers, but donations please to either: Planned Parenthood, 26 Bleecker Street, New York, New York 10012; or to The Sanger Fund, Fishers Island, New York 06390.

title: Senate Panel Votes to Cut Transit Money
description: In a potentially serious blow to the New York metropolitan region's transit system, a Senate committee approved legislation today that would cut Federal mass transit aid to the state by nearly $200 million next year, enough to delay or jeopardize an array of programs intended to upgrade the region's buses, subways and commuter rail lines.

title: AS LOSSES MOUNT, CAPITAL RE AGREES TO SELL
description: The Capital Re Corporation, a bond reinsurer facing mounting losses on policies, agreed to sell itself to Ace Ltd. for $606 million in stock, less than its market value, based on Wednesday's closing price. Ace, based in Bermuda, will swap six-tenths of a share for each of Capital Re's. That equals $18.90 a share based on Ace's stock on Wednesday. Capital Re's shares fell 15 percent, dropping $2.9375 each, to $16.3125, while Ace dropped 87.5 cents, to $30.625. Capital Re also warned that it could lose $67 million because of reinsurance with the International Financial Services Life Insurance Company, which regulators are examining for missing funds. In February, Ace agreed to pay $75 million for an 11 percent stake in Capital Re.

title: Victim's Parents Sue Parents of Gunmen
description: The family of one of the 12 students killed in the Columbine High School shootings in nearby Littleton last month filed a state lawsuit here today against the parents of the two young gunmen.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COPPER PLUNGES. Copper fell after the Broken Hill Proprietary Company delayed a decision on closing mines that are adding to a global surplus. In New York, copper for July delivery fell 3.3 cents, to 63.15 cents a pound.

title: AUTOS ON FRIDAY /Collecting; Cars With Obscure Spots in the Record Books
description: OF the thousands of automobiles that have been built in the United States, which ones deserve a place in history? That's easy, to a point: The Model T Ford, the Chrysler Airflow, the original Corvette and Mustang qualify as milestones by any measure, as do various Packards, Duesenbergs and Cadillacs, among others.

title: Joke Brings Suspension and Reversal
description: Snezan Cebic, a Manhattan high school senior, downloaded the joke a month ago from an Internet chat room frequented by students at the University of Wisconsin.

title: 'Blue Wall of Silence' Stands Tall
description: To the Editor:

title: Revised Global Rules Advance For Air Crash Compensation
description: The world's airlines moved a giant step closer yesterday to providing better protection and compensation to victims of international air accidents with an agreement that would replace a system in place since 1929 -- two years after Lindbergh made the first solo nonstop trans-Atlantic flight.

title: Plan to Shift Poor to H.M.O.'s Raises Worries in Region's Hospitals
description: With little more than a month until New York begins forcing hundreds of thousands of poor people into managed care programs, hospitals and advocates for the poor say they are worried that the fledgling health care companies set up to accommodate them could crumble under the weight.

title: Unimed in Takeover Talks
description: Unimed Pharmaceuticals Inc. said today that it was in negotiations to sell all outstanding shares of the company to an unnamed third party. The sale will be handled by Hambrecht & Quist. Trading in the shares was halted before the announcement. Earlier, the stock rose to a 52-week high of $9.25, valuing the company at $84 million. Since the beginning of the year, Unimed's stock price has more than doubled. The company focuses on therapies for cancer and H.I.V. It markets three drugs, including the H.I.V. and cancer treatment Marinol, the only drug to contain THC, the active ingredient in marijuana. Unimed had revenue of $16 million in 1998.

title: CRISIS IN THE BALKANS: HORROR BY DESIGN -- The Ravaging of Kosovo, A special report.; How Serb Forces Purged One Million Albanians
description: On the night of March 24, as NATO bombs began falling over Yugoslavia, Hani Hoxha said he saw black-masked Serbs swaggering through Djakovica, shooting, cutting throats and burning houses.

title: Beliefs; In a wide-ranging talk, Al Gore reveals the evangelical and intellectual roots of his faith.
description: Forty-five minutes is really not much time to explore the religious convictions of a man who wants to be the leader of the world's most powerful nation -- and who is also as publicly reserved as Vice President Al Gore. But the seven religion reporters who met with Mr. Gore yesterday at the White House did their best.

title: National News Briefs; Shuttle Discovery Docks To International Station
description: Discovery and its crew pulled up and latched on to the international space station early today in the firs docking between a shuttle and the new orbiting outpost.

title: BRAZIL AIRCRAFT ORDERS
description: Latin America's largest aircraft maker, Embraer of Brazil, won a $420 million contract to provide Brymon Airways of Britain with up to 21 jets. The transaction includes seven firm orders and options to purchase an additional 14 Embraer ERJ-170's, each of which holds 70 passengers. Brymon Airways is a regional carrier for British Airways. Embraer also introduced a new aircraft, the EMB-145SA, above, a small radar-equipped jet. Brazil has bought five of the jets for a surveillance system to combat deforestation and drug smuggling in the Amazon River Basin. Simon Romero (NYT)

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-8

title: 'Lobbying' Doctors
description: To the Editor:

title: Vengeful After First Setbacks, Army Chose Unrepentant Force
description: The purge of Kosovo this spring was led by Yugoslav Army officers handpicked by President Slobodan Milosevic to replace the internal security forces who had tried and failed the previous summer to wipe out the Albanian rebels, NATO officials say.

title: A Dazzling Mind From Which the Language of Destruction Flowed
description: WALTER BENJAMIN

title: Truth With Consequences
description: The international tribunal's indictment of Slobodan Milosevic, whatever its intrinsic merit, reveals a serious flaw in the way we prosecute war crimes: no political body supervises the decision to bring criminal charges. This same flaw will exist in the proposed permanent International Criminal Court, whose treaty was approved last summer in Rome by 120 nations.

title: 2 Out-of-State Commuters Sue Over Albany's Repeal of Tax
description: Two men claiming that changes in New York City's commuter tax illegally discriminate against residents of other states filed a lawsuit yesterday to eliminate the tax.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE EURO FALLS. The euro declined to a new low against the dollar on concern about weak European economic growth and the budget deficit problems in Italy. The euro was at $1.0418, down from $1.042 on Thursday.

title: Hung Up by a Carom And a Call, Mets Fall
description: One unfortunate carom and one unfortunate call in the ninth inning left the Mets feeling exasperated after last night's 2-1 loss to the Arizona Diamondbacks at Shea Stadium.

title: Doctor Resigns Over Trilling's 'Diagnosis'
description: Last month The American Scholar published ''My Father and the Weak-Eyed Devils,'' an essay in which James Trilling, an independent art historian, asserted that both he and his father, Lionel, suffered from attention deficit disorder. Now the journal is feeling the fallout. Dr. Paul R. McHugh, the psychiatrist in chief at the Johns Hopkins Hospital, quit the journal's editorial board this month over the story.

title: 'Blue Wall of Silence' Stands Tall
description: To the Editor:

title: Children in Need
description: To the Editor:

title: A Bassist Brings the Mideast With Him
description: The bassist Avishai Cohen comes from a part-Yemeni family in Israel, and he brings some of his own geographical references into his music. When his sextet played at the Jazz Standard in an early set on Wednesday night, there were Arabic and Spanish scales in the melodies; in the music's scenes, Amos Hoffman doubled Mr. Cohen's bass lines on an oud.

title: Male Guard Wins His Sex Harassment Suit
description: A jury awarded a male state prison guard $3.75 million in damages today after he charged that prison supervisors had failed to protect him from sexual harassment by a female guard whose advances he rejected.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about efforts by the United Farm Workers of America to unionize strawberry workers in California misstated the value of the nation's annual strawberry crop. It is $600 million, not $600 billion.

title: YAHOO CUTS WORK FORCE AND TAKES EARNINGS CHARGE
description: Yahoo Inc., the No. 1 Internet search service, said yesterday that it had dismissed about 200 employees of Geocities Inc., or 63 percent of its work force, and would take a $68 million pretax charge against second-quarter earnings for its $3.7 billion acquisition. Yahoo's president, Jeff Mallett, said about 100 Geocities employees would be retained at Yahoo, where they will be integrated into the company's headquarters in Santa Clara, Calif., and throughout its regional United States sales offices. Yahoo will close the Geocities headquarters in Marina del Rey, Calif. Yahoo aquired Geocities, the top provider of personal Web pages, to broaden its audience and market other services.

title: EURO ANXIETY
description: Germany's top central banker expressed alarm at the depressed value of the euro against the dollar, hinting at a shift in the hands-off policy toward exchange rates. ''There should not be an attitude of neglect toward the exchange rate,'' Hans Tietmeyer, president of the Bundesbank, said in Paris. Despite his comments the euro ended lower.

title: Russian Finance Minister Resigns in Cabinet Power Struggle
description: Russia's Finance Minister, who was recently elevated to the post of First Deputy Prime Minister for financial matters, quit tonight after only three days in his new job, the apparent casualty of an extraordinary struggle between advisers seeking the blessing of President Boris N. Yeltsin.

title: An Airport Link With Potential
description: Although the trip from midtown Manhattan to Kennedy Airport by car or taxi is supposed to average 61 minutes, savvy travelers set aside as much as 90 minutes to compensate for congestion and other unforeseen difficulties. There is not much the New York City Council can do about road delays. But it can at least give harried travelers a fail-safe alternative by endorsing AirTrain, the Port Authority's proposed rail link to the airport.

title: ARM FINANCIAL SEEKING INVESTMENT BANK ADVICE
description: ARM Financial Services Group Inc., a provider of insurance-based retirement saving plans whose stock has languished, said it hired Morgan Stanley Dean Witter Inc. to ''evaluate strategic alternatives.'' Shares of the company, based in Louisville, Ky., fell 6.25 cents, to $15, the price of the company's initial public offering in June 1997 by Morgan Stanley. The company's stock is worth a total of about $357 million. ARM Financial did not say whether Morgan Stanley might try to find a buyer for all or part of the company. Martin H. Ruby, chairman and chief executive, said the company would focus on selling annuities, which are tax deferred retirement saving plans, to consumers through various methods including the Internet.

title: Hoop Dreams, Not War Games; From Montenegro to the N.B.A., Radojevic Has High Hopes
description: There is just one more month left in Aleksandar Radojevic's hurried odyssey to the National Basketball Association -- a month filled with tryouts in one city after another, with four-hour training sessions and with thousands of calories in protein shakes. And the pace of the final push is wearing on the gangly 22-year-old, who did not start playing basketball in his native Montenegro until he was 16, and who did not take the sport seriously until he sprouted to nearly 7 feet by 19.

title: Italian Banks Are Steered Clear of Mergers
description: While Italy's phone company fell prey last week to Europe's largest hostile takeover ever, the nation's banks are not afraid, for the moment at least, of unfriendly suitors.

title: To Some Midwesterners, Milosevic Indictment Gives War New Meaning
description: With no end to the bloodshed in Yugoslavia after two months of NATO bombing, Marcia DeClerk, a 54-year-old computer programmer who initially favored the air strikes, started to wonder if maybe the American troops should just come home.

title: Bill Seeks a Warning On Concert Tickets
description: The Michigan State Senate has passed a bill requiring music promoters to print warnings on tickets for concerts by performers whose music is considered inappropriate for minors. It is believed to be the first such bill to pass a legislative chamber.

title: 'Blue Wall of Silence' Stands Tall
description: To the Editor:

title: Showcasing City Ballet's Classical Side
description: The New York City Ballet's all-Tchaikovsky bill on Wednesday night led off with ''Aurora's Wedding,'' the final act from ''The Sleeping Beauty.'' Peter Martins's 1991 production of the full-evening 19th-century classic by Marius Petipa is one of the company's great successes, and this excerpt dazzled again in its choreographic verve.

title: Failed Business Zone
description: To the Editor:

title: Suspense? No, But the Duel Still Rivets
description: In its decades of incarnations on and off Broadway and on big and small screens, ''Inherit the Wind'' has attracted audiences both by its righteous theme and its dramatic punch. Once again tonight, the battle between benightedness and enlightenment offers viewers of a liberal persuasion the satisfaction of sharing in the play's assumptions and having their own advanced opinions confirmed. The drama comes most forcefully in the climactic confrontation between a spouter of the old-time religion and a secular advocate of free speech.

title: India Strikes at Muslim Guerrillas in Kashmir for a 3d Day
description: India today launched a third day of air strikes against hundreds of Muslim guerrillas who have dug into icy, barren mountainsides in the contested territory of Kashmir. India says the men are backed by its bitter adversary, Pakistan.

title: COMING ON SUNDAY: THE NEXT CLINTON
description: Hillary Clinton has waited 25 years for her own moment in the political sun. Yet even as she considers a run for the Senate, she can't stop talking about her husband. Is she willing to put herself on the line? A report by James Bennet, in The Times Magazine.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARCIA, ALAN A.
description: GARCIA-Alan A. Renowned singer and teacher, died on May 25. He is survived by a brother, two nieces and two cousins. Funeral will be Tuesday, June 1, 7:30 PM at Plymouth Church of The Pilgrims, 75 Hicks Street, Brooklyn Heights. Viewing will be at Frank R. Bell Funeral Home, 536 Sterling Place, Brooklyn, from 1 to 5:30 PM and at the church from 6:30 to 7:30 PM. Interment will be at Calverton National Cemetery, Riverhead, NY on Wednesday, June 2, 11 AM.

title: Mystery in Purity and Unity, From the Parts to the Whole
description: Steeledance may have been trying to create a sense of mystery at Dance Theater Workshop on Wednesday night when it presented works by its directors, Teri Lee Steele and Oliver Steele. But the results were muddled.

title: Father Arrives to Claim Train Victims' Bodies
description: A man whose family was struck and killed by an Amtrak train earlier this week arrived in New York from Ecuador last night and said that he intended to take the bodies of his wife and their four sons back home.

title: Japanese Chip Maker NEC Reports a Loss for the Year
description: It's been an especially rough year for the NEC Corporation, one of the world's largest makers of semiconductors and a symbol of corporate Japan.

title: California Crew Zips Right Along
description: California gave another display of speed and skill at the Intercollegiate Rowing Association regatta yesterday on the Cooper River at Cherry Hill, N.J.

title: Clean Cars Get Real; Makers of Hybrid Vehicles Add Fuel to Electric Mix
description: The annual showcase for electric cars, the Tour de Sol race, was so crowded this year that organizers were forced to turn some entrants away. But the crowded field was not so much a result of electric vehicles finally catching on as it was the new emphasis on another class of vehicles invited to join. These cars, known as hybrids, use batteries and electric motors, but also depend on gasoline or diesel engines as well.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COPPER FALLS. Copper declined on signs that a surplus will last longer than expected and on diminishing expectations of a rebound in Asian demand. Copper for July delivery fell 0.35 cent, to 62.8 cents a pound.

title: Rise in Chicago Manufacturing Index Slows
description: Manufacturing in the Chicago region expanded at a slower-than-expected pace in May, held down by smaller gains in new orders and production. Prices rose at a more subdued pace in May.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THURNAUER, MARIA
description: THURNAUER-Maria. The Board of Directors, staff and music school students of the Jewish Community Center on the Palisades deeply mourn the loss of Maria Thurnauer who dedicated her life to supporting music and the arts. Maria and her husband William endowed the JCC Thurnauer School of Music, and their continued dedication to the life and growth of this school has been immeasurable. All at the JCC are indeed blessed to have known Maria, whose memory will remain with us reflected in her beautiful photographs which grace the halls of the Center. We offer our deepest sympathy to William, son Andrew, daughter Joan and the entire Thurnauer family. May the Lord comfort them among all the mourners of Zion. Edward A. Grossmann, President Avi A. Lewinson, Exec. Director

title: Cohen and Other Ministers Size Up Possible Ground Force
description: Secretary of Defense William S. Cohen met with four NATO counterparts in Germany on Thursday in an unpublicized meeting and discussed what it would take to mount a ground invasion of Kosovo, American and European officials said today. Mr. Cohen and the Defense Ministers of Britain, France, Germany and Italy received a preliminary assessment by NATO's commander, Gen. Wesley K. Clark, that projected that a ground invasion would involve a force of as many as 150,000 NATO troops, one NATO official said.

title: RENEWED DIVISIONS LEAVE HOUSE G.O.P. IN A SERIOUS STALL
description: Speaker J. Dennis Hastert won the allegiance of his fellow Republicans with a pledge to restore order to the fractured House. But the Republican Congress collapsed in disarray this week, abruptly leaving hours early for a holiday recess without being able to act on military legislation and failing to pass several budget bills that Mr. Hastert had counted on finishing by Memorial Day.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the reaction of newspapers and television networks to the Nasdaq decision to add an evening trading session misspelled the name of the executive vice president of CNNfn. He is David Bohrman, not Borman.

title: Failed Business Zone
description: To the Editor:

title: George Perazich, 94; Led Relief Campaign
description: George Nikolas Perazich, a retired engineer and industrial economist who directed United Nations' relief efforts in Yugoslavia after World War II, died on Wednesday at the Hospice of Washington. He was 94 and lived in Washington.

title: The Yanks Reap the Benefits of Grimsley's Relief
description: Logic says Jason Grimsley is not really this good. His first 14 years in pro ball were undistinguished. He won fewer than half his 149 minor league decisions, and before this year, his earned run average in the majors was 5.39.

title: San Francisco Is Urged to Allow Secluded Sex in Bathhouses
description: AIDS closed the bathhouses here when the city tried and failed. It was 15 years ago, when the epidemic was raging and bathhouses, as bastions of anonymous, unsafe sex, were considered major contributors to the spread of the disease. The bathhouses successfully sued the city to remain open, but their reputation as a breeding ground for AIDS scared their customers off and put them out of business anyway.

title: MACNEAL-SCHWENDLER TO BUY MARC ANALYSIS RESEARCH
description: The MacNeal-Schwendler Corporation, which makes software used to design cars and spacecraft, said yesterday that it was buying the MARC Analysis Research Corporation for about $36 million to add software that tests complex designs and materials. The purchase gives MacNeal-Schwendler software that analyzes designs of products involving rubbers, plastics and other compressible materials. MacNeal-Schwendler's software has traditionally tested designs of metal products, its chief executive, Frank Perna, said. Closely held MARC, based in Palo Alto, Calif., had $19.4 million in sales last year, and has about 150 employees. The transaction consists of $20 million cash, and $16 million in notes and warrants.

title: BANKBOSTON SELLS STAKE IN CREDIT CARD VENTURE
description: The BankBoston Corporation sold its 19 percent share of the credit card venture Partners First to Bank of Montreal for $50 million as it sheds unwanted assets in preparation for its takeover by Fleet Financial Group Inc. BankBoston, the second-largest bank based in New England, formed the venture last year with Bank of Montreal, Canada's fourth-largest bank by assets, and First Annapolis, a consulting and investment banking firm. The banks combined their credit card businesses, which had $2.4 billion in receivables at the time. Bank of Montreal, through its Chicago-based unit Harris Bank, will have an 88 percent stake in the venture. First Annapolis will retain its 12 percent share.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLAUNSTEIN, JEROME L., M.D.
description: BLAUNSTEIN-Jerome L., M.D. Passed away on May 24, 1999. He will be missed by many friends and relatives and especially by his companion of many years, Bruce C. Olsen.

title: Friday Rally Can't Reverse Rough Week
description: After rising relentlessly for more than two months, the Dow Jones industrial average has given up a portion of its gains the last three weeks as investors begin to worry that cyclical stocks that seemed underpriced at the end of winter might be heading into the summer having risen too far or too fast.

title: HOLIDAY ON MONDAY
description: NEW YORK

title: Accounting Firm Is Named In Medicare Fraud Lawsuit
description: KPMG, the giant international accounting firm, was accused in a Federal whistle-blower lawsuit unsealed yesterday of aiding some hospitals in Florida in a plan to defraud Medicare through the use of bogus expense claims.

title: Should Government Team With Religion?
description: To the Editor:

title: Pacers Tune Up in a Knick-Free Zone
description: The standing ovation began as soon as Reggie Miller emerged from the tunnel, swaying his arms from side to side like wheat blowing in a Midwest field. It grew as the team members sprawled on the floor and stretched their ankles toward their opposite knees.

title: Throw? Catch? Lucas Awaits Answer
description: ''Look at these muscles,'' said Ray Lucas, glancing at his newly bulging biceps. ''With Vinny next to me, I've got to keep up.''

title: Woman Admits Using False Papers in Baby-Smuggling Case
description: A Mexican woman who worked with a lawyer accused of smuggling babies from Mexico has admitted that the infants were sent to the United States under false documents but insisted that the Mexican mothers gave them up for adoption voluntarily.

title: After Littleton, a Change in Principals' Worlds
description: Dick Kraemer, the principal at Fox Lane High School here, was on the phone in his office one day late last month when his worst nightmare suddenly flared to life: an assistant principal rushed in to report there was something ticking in a student's locker down the hall.

title: In Hong Kong, 'Star Wars: The Piracy Menace'
description: If you wanted to be the first on your block in New York to see the new ''Star Wars'' film, you had to line up three days in advance for tickets or buy them from scalpers for $100 apiece.

title: Refugees at Fort Dix to Give U.S. Evidence of War Crimes
description: Human rights investigators have begun interviewing ethnic Albanian refugees from Kosovo at Fort Dix, N.J., making the Army base-turned-refugee center into an important site in the efforts to document evidence of war crimes against President Slobodan Milosevic and other top Yugoslav officials.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAX, MICHAEL
description: LAX-Michael. Age 69, of NYC and Bridgehampton, NY, on May 25th, 1999. Beloved father of Jennifer and Rebecca. Cherished partner of Kirsten Childs. An exceptionally gifted and caring man. He will be greatly missed.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RECANATI, RAPHAEL
description: RECANATI-Raphael. It is with a profound sense of loss that the Board of Trustees, Medical Board and Administration of Beth Israel Medical Center join with the leadership of its parent company, Continuum Health Partners, Inc., in acknowledging the passing of our dear friend and devoted colleague, Raphael Recanati, Honorary Trustee of Beth Israel. Few have matched the extraordinary philanthropy of Mr. Recanati and his devoted wife, Dina, to Beth Israel. A consistent thread running through their history of support has been generous donations toward critically important needs of medical education and research, particularly in the areas of neurology, cardiology, nephrology, hepatology, pulmonary medicine, dermatology, orthopaedic surgery, pediatrics, pathology and infectious diseases. Mr. Recanati's creative philanthropic approach served as a crucial resource to our staff, allowing them to make important advances in patient care and expanded medical knowledge. He will forever be remembered for helping to create a clinical and educational environment that makes Beth Israel a vibrant place to study and practice medicine. Our heartfelt condolences are extended to Dina, his sons Oudi and Michael, the entire Recanati family and all whose lives have been touched by his extraordinary humanitarian spirit. Morton P. Hyman, Chairman, Boards of Trustees, Continuum and BIMC Robert G. Newman, MD, President and CEO, Continuum Matthew E. Fink, MD, President and CEO, BIMC Henry Singman, MD, President, BIMC Medical Board

title: Corrections
description: The Advertising column in Business Day on Thursday, about the distribution of Naya Inc.'s bottled water, referred incorrectly to the distribution system of another company, Triarc, which owns Snapple and RC Cola. Most Triarc beverages are delivered directly, not through brokers.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, RICHARD M.
description: COHEN-Richard M. We are deeply saddened by the passing of our long-standing dear friend and good partner, Richard. We will miss his insightful, analytical mind, his strength and his zest for living. Our sincere and deepest condolences to his wife Barbara, his children Andy, James and Holly, his sister Marilyn Davimos and his brother Arthur. Siema and Arnold Sollar Elaine and Edwin Eisen

title: Should Government Team With Religion?; Fighting Social Ills
description: To the Editor:

title: Officer Is Killed in Car Crash That Injures 4 in Nassau
description: An off-duty New York City police officer was killed and four people were seriously injured when the officer's speeding car struck another car on Jericho Turnpike in Nassau County early yesterday, the police said.

title: Masur Adds Some Curves To the Angles Of the Missa
description: It is the Missa Solemnis that Beethoven is holding, pen poised, as he poses for Joseph Karl Stieler's famous portrait of 1819. The iconography of mad genius is carefully arranged: the ruffled hair, beneath it the belligerent stare, and below both the delicate fingertips, just to make sure we understand that rebelliousness and sensitivity intersect.

title: APPLIED MATERIALS IN DEAL TO PURCHASE OBSIDIAN
description: Applied Materials Inc., the world's largest provider of equipment used to make computer chips, agreed to buy Obsidian Inc. for about $137.5 million in stock to add a new type of machine. Applied said it would issue about 2.5 million shares to pay for the transaction. Obsidian, a closely held company founded in 1997, is based in Fremont, Calif. Obsidian's technology will help Applied as chip makers move to more advanced manufacturing technology and seek better techniques for polishing the layers of metal on a computer chip. Shares of Applied, which is based in Santa Clara, Calif., fell 25 cents, to $55.

title: PRIMUS TELECOMMUNICATIONS BUYING TELEGROUP ASSETS
description: Primus Telecommunications Group Inc. agreed yesterday to buy some retail assets of Telegroup Inc., a struggling long-distance company, for about $72 million in cash and debt securities. The acquisition will increase Primus's revenue by about $150 million annually and add 350,000 retail customers, bringing its customer base to more than one million. Primus, based in McLean, Va., provides domestic and international long-distance voice, data, Internet and private-network services. Telegroup, based in Fairfield, Iowa, filed earlier this year for protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the United States Bankruptcy Code. Primus will purchase Telegroup's retail customer base in the United States, Japan and Hong Kong and the stock of its subsidiaries in Europe, where the operations are exclusively retail.

title: At Indianapolis Track, Racing and Progress Go On
description: A year from now, the Indianapolis Motor Speedway will have a completely different appearance. Construction of a road course, which will be host to a Formula One race in September 2000, has begun and major changes can already be seen around the Speedway.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITE, JAMES J.
description: WHITE-James J. The Society of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick in the City of New York records with profound sorrow the death of James J. White, A Life Member of the Society and extends sincere sympathy to his family. William J. Cronin, President Robert J. Reilly, Historia

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOKAR, IRVING
description: TOKAR-Irving. On May 27, 1999. Beloved husband to Rose for 59 years. Devoted father to Phyllis and Ed Birns and Dr. Stanley and Patricia Tokar. Cherished grandfather and great grandfather. You will be missed deeply for your kind and gentle soul and your love for your family and friends. Services Sunday 10AM at Gutterman's on Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury NY.

title: The Rabbi's Tapes
description: To the Editor:

title: Doctor Who Faced Questioning in Death Hangs Herself in Cell
description: A Jersey City podiatrist apparently hanged herself Thursday in her Pennsylvania jail cell minutes before she was to be returned to New Jersey to face questioning about her sister-in-law, whose decomposing body was found this month stuffed in a picnic cooler.

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: AFRICA

title: 2 in Baby-Selling Case Were Long Under Scrutiny
description: State regulators knew as early as a decade ago that two Long Island women were placing foreign-born children with adoptive parents in New York, even though they lacked the permits to do so. But the women appear to have hit upon an easy way of avoiding trouble, according to government officials and court filings: They simply went out of business, then reopened under a new name.

title: It's 3 Sets And Pout For Serena Williams
description: She had no control of her shots during her match and no control of herself after it ended. Serena Williams exited the center court at Roland Garros today to the tune of Gallic boos, not sympathy, after throwing a tiny temper tantrum in response to being upset by Mary Joe Fernandez, 6-3, 1-6, 6-0.

title: MetroStars Landed A Superman of Sorts
description: He has started more games and played more minutes than anyone else in the history of Major League Soccer. And in his career with the Kansas City Wizards and now with the MetroStars, he may have also played more positions than anyone. Diversification on the field -- and off -- is what Mark Chung is all about.

title: Union Will Vote On T.W.A. Offer
description: Trans World Airlines, the eighth-largest United States carrier, said today that it had submitted a final wage and benefit proposal to the machinists' union, which in turn agreed to send the terms to its members for a vote.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLICKSMAN, ABRAHAM M.
description: GLICKSMAN-Abraham M. On May 26, 1999. Beloved husband of Frances, loving father of Robert & Emilie, dear brother of Rosella Breinan, adored grandfather of Lisa & Michelle. He will be deeply missed. Service Sunday 9:30 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NORWALK, BERNICE L. (BUNNY)
description: NORWALK-Bernice L. (Bunny). Beloved and loving wife of Elliott for 60 years. Devoted mother of Jeffrey and Arthur. Proud grandmother of Lisa and great grandmother of Mary. Services ''Boulevard-Riverside,'' 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I., 1:30 PM, Sunday.

title: The Lucky Few: A Family Makes It Out
description: Twenty years ago, Ismail Bolukbasi opened a restaurant in Pristina, the capital of Kosovo, and it quickly attracted a clientele as diverse as Kosovo itself.

title: Plea Deal Approved for Kidnapper of 2 Daughters
description: Stephen Fagan, the Massachusetts father who absconded with his two daughters nearly 20 years ago and reared them in Palm Beach-style prosperity until he was caught last year, clinched a plea deal today that lets him off with no jail time.

title: Turkish Premier Assembles Ruling Coalition
description: Prime Minister Bulent Ecevit, who has headed a caretaker Government since elections last month, said today that he had assembled a three-party coalition to govern Turkey for the next five years.

title: Albany Notes; No Rush to Repeal Another City's Commuter Tax
description: When the Legislature abruptly voted to end the New York City commuter tax earlier this month, several lawmakers thundered that government had no business taxing people based on where they worked. But lost in the hullabaloo was an interesting footnote: New York is not the only place in the state with a commuter tax. Yonkers also has one. Shouldn't it be stamped out, too?

title: Douglas Elliman Real Estate Brokerage to Be Sold
description: Douglas Elliman, the largest residential real estate brokerage firm in New York City, is to be acquired by Insignia Financial Group, a largely commercial company that had no presence in the city before 1995.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENE, JEROME L.
description: GREENE-Jerome L. On May 27, 1999, at age 93. Beloved husband of Dawn Greene. Loving father of Patricia Humphrey and the late Cynthia Sue Greene & stepfather of Christina McInerney. Cherished grandfather of Daniel and Joel Humphrey. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 Street, Saturday, May 29, 7-9PM. Interment private. Memorial service at Temple EmanuEl, Fifth Ave. at 65 Street, Tues., June 15, at 4PM. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Montefiore Children's Hospital.

title: In 2d Year, Showalter Dreams of Post-Season
description: Buck Showalter sat in the empty third-base dugout at Shea Stadium yesterday and talked about the Arizona Diamondbacks the way a parent speaks about a child. He gushed about the quality players and quality people the Diamondbacks have assembled in their second season. Of course, because he is a major league manager, he lamented the unpredictability of his bullpen.

title: U.S. Hunts for Quid Pro Quo In Microsoft Witness's Actions
description: The Justice Department's chief trial lawyer in the Government's antitrust suit against the Microsoft Corporation closely questioned a Microsoft witness today about whether he had benefited as a result of his decision to defend the company and to testify in its behalf.

title: Can a Peaking Houston Halt a Streaking Miller?
description: Sometimes it's as if the slithering Reggie Miller is leading his pursuer through a car chase scene as he weaves through the traffic on the court.

title: Sports Of The Times; Chalk Talk By Parcells, Knicks Fan
description: THE theme of the chalk talk was versatility, and the speaker was Bill Parcells, the Jets' head coach. This was Day 2 of the Jets' minicamp at Hofstra University this week and Parcells, who led the Jets to the American Football Conference championship game last season, was discussing the theme of his coming 1999-2000 campaign: versatility.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Consumer Spending in April Adds 0.4% to March Rise

title: 2 Bad Schools To Reorganize In an Effort To Improve
description: Two South Bronx elementary schools will be shut down at the end of June in an effort to reverse years of academic failure that have made them among the worst in the state, the district superintendent said yesterday.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: AT HOME CORP., Redwood City, Calif., a provider of high-speed Internet access through cable TV lines, completed its $7.95 billion acquisition of the Web directory Excite Inc. and changed its name to Excite At Home.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PASSERMAN, MIRIAM R.
description: PASSERMAN-Miriam R. On May 26, 1999. In her 98th year, of Boca Raton, FL. Formerly of NYC and Chappaqua, NY. She was acknowledged to have been the oldest Alumna of the Columbia School of Journalism, Class of 1925. Beloved wife of the late Maxwell W. Daughter of the late Charles and Sarah Rosenthal. Loving mother of Louise Rosenfeld and Steven Passerman. Dear mother-in-law of Gabriel Rosenfeld and Harriet Passerman. Adored grandmother of Eric Rosenfeld, Alison R. Desmarais, Dr. Leslie R. Wash, Toni Passerman, David Passerman, Shari P. Turner and Charles Passerman. Cherished great grandmother of Evan and Sarabeth Turner. Service Sunday, May 30, 1999 11:15AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th St., and Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the American Jewish Historical Society, 15 West 16th Street, New York, N.Y. 10011.

title: Abroad at Home; Which Side Are We On?
description: The indictment of Slobodan Milosevic by the International War Crimes Tribunal told us nothing new about his character or his record. He has been carrying out crimes against humanity since 1991, when his forces leveled the Croatian city of Vukovar and executed 260 men in a Vukovar hospital.

title: The Unlikely Author Of a Lucky Life; Ex-Domestic Worker Finds Voice and a Book in the Ordinary
description: Shortly after her mother's death, when she was barely 17, Freddie Mae Baxter left her home in rural South Carolina. She settled in Harlem during the final months of the Depression and found work cleaning rich people's houses and taking care of their children. Black, female and uneducated, she was pretty much limited to low-paying, unskilled work. But she shared her food and lodgings with each of her seven brothers and sisters when they followed her north in search of jobs and apartments.

title: Belgrade Talks Go On, Clouded By Indictments
description: The day after President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia was indicted on war crimes charges, a search for a negotiated solution to the conflict in Kosovo proceeded today, clouded by uncertainty and recriminations.

title: Frank A. Gunther Dies at 91; Helped Create Radio Systems
description: Frank A. Gunther, a radio pioneer who helped create shortwave, two-way and FM systems, died on Monday at Bon Securos Hospital in Venice, Fla. He was 91 and lived in New York and Nokomis, Fla.

title: Robert F. Mozley, 82, Professor And an Expert on Arms Control
description: Robert Fred Mozley, professor emeritus of physics at Stanford University and an expert on nuclear arms control, died on Monday at Stanford Hospital. He was 82 and lived in Menlo Park, Calif., and Southport Island, Me.

title: SUGAR-COATED PRESSURE
description: Brazil's Government and its powerful sugar lobby have persuaded Ford and General Motors to make ethanol-powered automobiles for the domestic market. The agreement will benefit a sugar industry hurt by low prices and the dominance of gasoline-fueled cars. Brazil, the world's largest sugar producer, was once the leader in promoting ethanol, a cleaner-burning fuel that can be made from sugar or corn. The agreement came in conjunction with a wider accord cutting taxes on cars in exchange for pledges by auto makers to limit layoffs. It was unclear how many ethanol cars would be produced.

title: INSIDE
description: More Turmoil for Russia

title: Top Sweepstakes Promoter Settles Suits for $4 Million
description: American Family Publishers, one of the nation's two largest sweepstakes promotion companies, agreed today to extensive changes in its practices and to a $4 million settlement of civil charges by four states that the company deceived consumers.

title: Map Makers Explore The Contours Of Power; New Study Tries to Break the Eurocentric Mold
description: The history of maps once seemed a quaint preoccupation. The cartographer was a specialist in incomplete and antique vistas, surveying terrains, boundaries and trade routes that were decorously traced on tentatively shaped landmasses. Old maps -- with their compass roses, their illuminated borders and their vast blank spaces -- were sought by collectors and historians but were otherwise considered artful relics of ignorance, faltering steps on the way to modern geography.

title: KOSOVO UPDATE
description: DIPLOMACY

title: Woman Given 20 Years In Fatal Drunken Crash
description: A woman who crashed into a tree while driving drunk in 1997, killing six children and injuring two others, was sentenced yesterday to 20 years in prison.

title: Tenuous Trickle-Down
description: Certainly it is good news that the benefits of a vigorous economy have started to trickle down toward young black men in the inner cities. According to a recent study by the economists Richard Freeman and William Rodgers, even black males ages 16 to 24 are working more often, earning better wages and committing fewer crimes than was the case during the recession of the early 1990's.

title: A Merger Made In Hollywood?
description: Michael Ovitz, the Hollywood talent manager, has been asked to join a rival group seeking a National Football League expansion franchise two days after Commissioner Paul Tagliabue lauded Ovitz's plan to redevelop the Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum.

title: Corrections
description: A caption on Thursday about the Abner Louima brutality case, with a picture of Sgt. Michael Bellomo, a defendant, and his lawyer, John Patten, speaking to reporters outside the court, carried an incorrect credit in some copies. The photographer was Ruby Washington of The New York Times.

title: New Security Fears As Hackers Disrupt 2 Federal Web Sites
description: An enduring cat-and-mouse game between Federal agents and computer hackers took a novel twist this week as the hackers turned on their pursuers, disrupting the Web sites of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the United States Senate and forcing them to shut down.

title: BRITISH BREWING TALKS
description: The maker of Abbot Ale, Greene King P.L.C., said it was considering a takeover bid of $:140 million ($224 million) for a rival British brewer, Morland P.L.C. The price being discussed is 430 pence a share. Morland's shares gained 50 pence, to 422.5. Greene King is seeking to build its brewing business while it expands its retail business with an agreement to buy 165 pubs from Wolverhampton & Dudley Breweries P.L.C.

title: Children in Need
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWADRON, LAWRENCE (LARRY)
description: SCHWADRON-Lawrence (Larry). Son of Benjamin & Bertha (deceased). Much cherished partner of Jean. Beloved brother of Jack (deceased) & Thelma, Meyer (deceased) & Shirley Steinkohl and Ann & Lee Yarden. Much beloved uncle of Howard & Debbie, Lori & Glenn, Richard & Debbie, Linda & Chris, Joan & Rob, Randi and Paul. And beloved great uncle. Funeral on Sunday 11 A.M., at Riverside Memorial Chapel, New York.

title: Hess Excluded Family From Jets' Future
description: The will of the late Jets owner Leon Hess never explains why he did not wish his family to assume control of the team, but he outlined the exclusion of his beneficiaries from any roles under a new owner.

title: DRESDNER NET SOARS
description: Dresdner Bank A.G., based in Frankfurt, announced a 39.2 percent increase in first-quarter pretax profit to 465.2 million euros ($487.2 million) compared with 334.3 million a year before. The increase was mainly attributed to trading income that more than doubled to 460.5 million euros, from 185.8 million in the first quarter last year. Net interest income and net commission income also contributed to the rise in profits.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Kiss your wife and two children because this will be the last time you see them.''

title: An Eastern Alternative to Blockbusterwood
description: Call it Brooklyn's revenge for decades of indignities suffered at the hands of Hollywood. That is one thing that came to mind when Robert De Niro and Miramax Films announced a tentative agreement with New York City on a $150 million plan to develop the abandoned Brooklyn Navy Yard as a film-making complex.

title: Bronx Woman Is Charged In Suffocation of Niece
description: A Bronx woman who told authorities she woke up yesterday morning to find her 10-year-old niece dead was arrested last night and charged with killing the girl by gagging her in an attempt at discipline.

title: Feeling Strong, Torre to Wait for More Treatment
description: Joe Torre, the Yankees' manager, went through a series of routine tests for his prostate cancer in New York on Thursday and arrived here late this afternoon. Torre says he continues to feel strong, and he most likely will have more extensive treatments after the season -- a six-week radiation treatment is possible -- and be ready to come back in spring training.

title: HEWLETT-PACKARD IS PLANNING REDUCTION OF 350 JOBS
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company, the world's biggest maker of computer printers, said yesterday that it would cut as many as 350 jobs at its plant in Vancouver, Wash., as part of a plan to send more production to contractors. Hewlett-Packard will cut 100 manufacturing jobs in the next three months. It will decide how many more jobs to cut within nine months. The plant employs 2,000. Hewlett started cutting jobs at the inkjet printer plant in Vancouver in February of last year. The company plans to make only prototypes for new printers at the plant, sending commercial production to contractors. The company is based in Palo Alto, Calif.

title: HONG KONG G.D.P. DROPS
description: Confirming that it remains in the grip of a recession, Hong Kong said its gross domestic product had shrunk 3.5 percent in the first quarter. Weak consumer demand and a 5 percent decline in exports hobbled the economy. But officials pointed to a few rays of light, including a modest rebound in tourism and the residential property market. Hong Kong's government is sticking to an earlier forecast -- not shared by private economists -- that it will eke out growth of five-tenths of a percent for the year.

title: Ed Peterson, 78, Inventor of Warning Alarm for Trucks Backing Up
description: Ed Peterson, an automotive service and parts supplier who invented an alarm system that beeps a warning when trucks and other heavy machinery are backing up, died on Wednesday at his home in Boise, Idaho. He was 78.

title: Voting at Long Last, Nigeria Pinches Itself
description: At the U-Fine Barbers Shop in the slum of Nyanya here, Nigeria's final day under military rule registered with a mixture of great hope for the future and last-minute jitters about a return to civilian government -- long promised, yet often postponed.

title: City Hall Memo; 'Wrong' Vote And Spouse Is Too Noticed
description: There is a man who works for the City Housing Authority named Steven Cymbrowitz. For years he toiled in relative anonymity. People in power rarely had cause to utter the name ''Cymbrowitz.''

title: Children in Need
description: To the Editor:

title: The Rural Life; At the Hive's Entrance
description: On April 28, the postmaster called. A package for me had come from Claxton, Ga. -- four pounds of bees in a wooden crate. Late that afternoon, at home, I removed from the crate a small cage just large enough to hold the queen bee and a few attendants. I set the queen-cage in a wooden box called a deep super, the base of a new hive. Then I shook the rest of the bees into the hive and drove them down into the super with a few puffs of smoke. A wooden feeder went on top, filled with sugar-water, and then the cover.

title: Trying to Find Way Out, But the Key Is Missing
description: When Deputy Secretary of State Strobe Talbott, President Martti Ahtisaari of Finland and Viktor S. Chernomyrdin of Russia sat down to talk about Kosovo this week at Stalin's old dacha outside Moscow, they pulled up an empty chair. The fourth chair, according to an American official, was to remind them at all times that the key figure in their endeavor was not there.

title: Sweepstakes Agrees To Settle Lawsuits
description: American Family Publishers, one of the nation's two largest sweepstakes promotion companies, agreed to extensive changes in its practices and to a $4 million settlement of civil charges by four states that the company deceived consumers.

title: A Guide to the West
description: For the first time in three years, the Western Conference finals will not include the Utah Jazz. For the first time in seven years, it will include the Portland Trail Blazers. And whoever wins this series will have a realistic chance of winning the N.B.A. title, because Michael Jordan won't be waiting in the next round.

title: Chicago Regains Control of Housing Agency
description: The City of Chicago regained control of its Housing Authority this week, four years after widespread mismanagement in the agency caused the Federal Government to take it over.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOLLOWAY, JOSEPH BRUNING
description: HOLLOWAY - Joseph Bruning. Age 47. Of New York. Formerly of Wheeling, W.V. Died on Friday, May 27, 1999. Son of the late Walker Peterson Holloway. Surviving are his mother Barbara Bruning Holloway Locke of Wheeling, two brothers, Peter, Jr. and Dr. John Holloway, both of Wheeling. Also surviving are four nephews and Mark Nadler of New York.

title: Donald Sur, 64, Eclectic Composer
description: Donald Sur, a composer and musicologist, died on Monday at Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center in Boston. He was 64.

title: Schools Are Faulted on Access
description: When Ellen H. Delgado's son, David, was getting ready to enter ninth grade, the Board of Education gave her a directory of high schools in Manhattan that it said could accommodate his needs. David, now 17, has cerebral palsy and uses a wheelchair. But when Ms. Delgado went to look at 10 schools on the list, she said, she found most of them woefully inadequate.

title: Victory Through the Air
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Students Fall in Air Shaft
description: Two 11-year-old boys were seriously injured yesterday when they plunged four stories down an air shaft at their intermediate school in the Bronx, the police said.

title: MCI Will Pay $1.3 Billion To Buy Skytel
description: After denying earlier this week that it was in talks to acquire Skytel Communications Inc., MCI Worldcom announced an agreement late yesterday to buy Skytel, one of the nation's largest paging companies, for $1.3 billion in stock.

title: Toward Nursing Home Reform
description: In California, a struggle is playing out over nursing home reform. Embarrassed by hearings in Congress about needless deaths in California nursing homes, and spurred by Kevin Shelley, the new Democratic majority leader of the State Assembly, who started looking at nursing homes when his mother had a stroke, the legislature is now wrestling with the most comprehensive attempt to improve care in a decade and a half.

title: Sara Boutelle, Architectural Historian, 90
description: Sara Holmes Boutelle, an architectural historian who rediscovered Julia Morgan, one of the first female architects to achieve major success, died on Wednesday at the Dominican Hospital in Santa Cruz, Calif. She was 90.

title: Resettlement on the Yangtze
description: There are new signs that China's top leaders are facing up to the destructive reality of the Three Gorges Dam. This month Prime Minister Zhu Rongji made a highly publicized speech about the difficulty of resettling 1.3 million people whose towns and farmlands will be inundated by the dam's 400-mile-long reservoir. The project is plagued with engineering and cost problems, but resettlement issues have been the most difficult to ignore.

title: Brazilian's Golden Silence Conceals Hand's Strength
description: The final of the South American Championships in Lima, Peru, a week ago proved to be an epic battle between two great teams. Brazil, led by the veterans Gabriel Chagas and Marcelo Branco, had won the qualifying stage and had points carried over into the final. But their Argentinian opponents, who included some young talent, equalized matters, and the title was up for grabs in the last session.

title: Love Is the Topic, Secular and Sacred
description: When Al Green is onstage, there's no telling what he'll do next. He sings, he preaches, he dances, he tosses roses to the ladies; he jumps in and out of songs, cues sing-alongs and then tops them with oohs and ahs, walks out into the audience and keeps flashing his beaming smile. His concert at the Beacon Theater on Tuesday night, opening a two-night stand, was a jubilant combination of gospel testifying and a soul oldies show.

title: 'Blue Wall of Silence' Stands Tall
description: To the Editor:

title: What Murder Says About the Society It Exists In
description: At the heart of the analysis of the killings last month at Columbine High School in Colorado has been a deceptively simple question: Were the killers chillingly aberrant monsters or were they a part, however perverse, of something in the culture as a whole?

title: For Buchanan, the Third Time Around Is Crowded
description: This early in the quest, Patrick Buchanan seems to be sounding his patented campaign reveille as much for himself as for his political ''pitchfork brigades.''

title: New Political Dance for First Couple
description: Behind closed doors on Sunday, Bill and Hillary Clinton will be the featured speakers in one of their favorite forums, a talkathon on globalization, social investment and the ''third way'' of governing that they have long promoted.

title: RAWLINGS SPORTING EXPLORING FINANCIAL ALTERNATIVES
description: The Rawlings Sporting Goods Company, the sports equipment maker, said yesterday that it had hired the investment banking firm BancBoston Robertson Stephens to help it explore ''strategic financial alternatives'' amid a softness in its business. The St. Louis-based company said weakness in baseball equipment sales would cause its third-quarter and full-year earnings to fall below analysts' estimates. Rawlings said its earnings would also be hurt by its recent decision to recall 45,000 aluminum softball bats after reports that the tops of some bats sheared off during games. In Nasdaq trading, Rawlings shares gained 12.5 cents, to $10.0625.

title: Two Brothers Convicted In Slayings at Strip Club
description: Two brothers accused in the shooting deaths of a waiter and a bouncer three years ago during a brawl at Scores, a topless nightclub on the Upper East Side, were convicted by a jury in Manhattan on Thursday night, one on double murder charges and the other on a single count of manslaughter.

title: Shrugging Off the State Budget Delay
description: AT the County Office Building here last week, the bills were paid and the books balanced, despite the fact that the state budget was almost two months late and more than $300 million in aid that should have been on its way to Westchester remained tied up in Albany. In sharp contrast to previous years, there were only shrugs and expressions of annoyance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAMPBELL, PATRICIA A.
description: CAMPBELL-Patricia A. Beloved wife of Arlan J. Bird. Loving sister of Mary Campbell and James (Patricia). Dear aunt of James, Michael, Joseph, John and Brian. Burial was at All Saints Cemetery, Des Plaines, IL on May 27th. A memorial service will be held at Frank E. Campbell, 81 Street and Madison Avenue, New York City, Tuesday, June 1, 1999, 5 PM.

title: Once Rivals, Two Jazz Impresarios Agree to Disagree
description: GEORGE WEIN and Michael Dorf -- impresarios of this year's JVC Jazz Festival and the Bell Atlantic Jazz Festival respectively -- have been butting heads for 11 years. In 1954 Mr. Wein started the Newport Jazz Festival, which became the paradigm for outdoor music events. After moving through several different sponsors, it became the JVC festival in 1984. Mr. Dorf put on his first jazz festival (called ''What Is Jazz?'') at the Knitting Factory, his club in lower Manhattan, in 1988, scheduling it to compete with the JVC concerts uptown. A cordial relationship developed, but it broke down in 1997, when Mr. Dorf expanded, found a major sponsor (Texaco), and called his giant festival the New York Jazz Festival. This was the student rather stridently pulling rank on the teacher, and a period of bad blood followed.

title: Cricket Coverage
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Presidential Candidates Seem Indifferent to a Salary Rise
description: The people who want to be President seem almost indifferent to an issue of public policy that could affect one of them personally: How much should the next chief executive be paid?

title: Hungarian Orchestra in Greenwich
description: THE Hungarian Virtuosi Orchestra has been known in the United States almost entirely through its recordings, but the ensemble recently appointed an American, Stephen Rogers Radcliffe of Greenwich, as its principal conductor.

title: Tire Pressure Is Nothing To Andretti
description: Michael Andretti couldn't afford even the smallest miscue. He was leading the Motorola 300 but was riding on used-up tires, and there was a determined young driver, Helio Castro-Neves, gaining in his rearview mirror.

title: New Rulings On Tenants Of Sponsor
description: TWO subjects previously addressed in this column -- one that affects many rental tenants in New York City co-op and condominium buildings and another that will change the way buyers and sellers of real estate in Westchester County do business with one another and their brokers -- are now in need of updating.

title: Spree-ality
description: We may not all agree with the decisions Sprewell has made or the things he has done, but keep the criticisms to his basketball game and legitimate topics. Taking potshots at his family relationships -- and passing judgment on the man -- are out of line.

title: A Brutal Cure
description: Operating room No. 5 at University Hospital in Denver is chilled almost to the point of refrigeration, but already the team of surgeons is sweating. The noxious scent of burning flesh fills the air as a cauterizing instrument slices through the skin. Next comes the snapping sound of bone, first one rib removed, then another, until finally the target is in view. ''His lung looks awful,'' says Dr. Marvin Pomerantz, one of a small fraternity of surgeons in the world who would even attempt this operation. ''I always hope it will be better than expected, but it never is.''

title: A Plea to Yeltsin: Free Russia From 'Puppet Masters'
description: Yegor T. Gaidar, a former Prime Minister who began Russia's economic reforms in 1992, today appealed urgently to President Boris N. Yeltsin to stop the ''puppet masters'' who Mr. Gaidar and several political analysts say are manipulating the country's 10-day-old Government.

title: A Rage for Opera Houses (Oh, and Opera, Too)
description: REGIONALISM has been a powerful force in China from time immemorial. In the best of times, cities and provinces sniff disdainfully at one another and implement policies to guard their resources from their neighbors. In the worst of times, regions battle for land and power. Under the People's Republic, regionalism has been contained but not conquered.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DIAMOND, JUDGE TED
description: DIAMOND-Judge Ted, 1995. We will love, remember and miss you always. Your Loving Family

title: Olympians With Lessons To Impart
description: CALLIOPE, Euterpe and Erato looked out from the pages of the morning newspaper not long ago. Daughters of Zeus, goddesses of the arts, photographically rendered.

title: Through Bottles, Darkly, Glimpses of the Past
description: DAPPLED sunlight fell on freshly overturned soil in a quiet backyard on Perry Street in Greenwich Village. Dan Magee, standing waist deep in a pit, jabbed his pickax into something that clinked.

title: Among the Omitted
description: To the Editor:

title: GOING OUT
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We're trying to

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAITMAN, ROBERT
description: LAITMAN-Robert. Passed away on May 27, 1999, of Lauderhill, FL, formerly of Greenwich, CT. Beloved husband of Pegge, and adored father of Bonnie Eletz, Larry Laitman, Cathy Seligman. Grandfather of Michele EletzMetsch, Luva and Druvona Laitman, Abbe Eletz, Leigh and William Sorkin; and great-grandfather of Nicholas and Damien. Brother of Edwin and Sanford Laitman.

title: The Next Clinton
description: On the windy Friday in February that the Senate acquitted her husband of perjury and obstruction of justice, Hillary Rodham Clinton turned her attention to her life after his Presidency. From before the first vote that day until long after the last, she met with her friend Harold Ickes on the second floor of the White House, in the family quarters, to weigh whether for the first time to promote herself rather than Bill Clinton for public office. Hillary Clinton felt flattered that Democrats were begging her to run for the Senate from New York, an idea she had laughed off when Representative Charles Rangel, the mischievous Manhattan Democrat, first suggested it in a Chicago church last October. She was delighted with the shift under way in her public image, from passive victim to political heavyweight. After all her policy work and speechifying, it had galled her to watch her popularity spike upward in the past year as she turned her lapidary smile to the world and suffered through the revelations of her husband's affair with that woman.

title: Her Old Kentucky Home
description: Clear Springs A Memoir. By Bobbie Ann Mason. Illustrated. 298 pp. New York: Random House. $25.

title: New Asphalt, but Needed?
description: In theory, Park Slope residents ought to be grateful. Construction crews have been tearing up neighborhood streets this spring and laying down a smooth coating of black-as-night asphalt.

title: Bookend; Close to Home
description: SMALL towns rarely make the big-city papers, and are even less likely to turn up in books. I know of just two biographies that mention Sikeston, the Missouri town where I grew up. David Maraniss's ''First in His Class'' records that in 1946, Bill Clinton's father died in a car crash three miles outside town; nine years later, according to Peter Guralnick's ''Last Train to Memphis,'' Elvis Presley gave a concert there, back when he was young, scared and thin. Someday the New Madrid Fault will put my hometown on the front pages -- the last major earthquake to hit southeast Missouri was so strong that it changed the course of the Mississippi River -- but until now the only time Sikeston made news was after an event nobody likes to talk about: one Sunday morning in the winter of 1942, a man named Cleo Wright was dragged through the streets by an angry mob, doused with gasoline and burned to death.

title: A Civil (War) Action; A Weekend as a Re-enactor Means Heated Battles, Cold Nights and a Passion for Authenticity
description: CAPTAIN MORIARTY screamed ''Ready! Aim! Fire!'' and instantly a dozen guns erupted in the direction of the furtive figures taking shelter behind a tall hedge. None fell down; to do so would have risked contact with a fine young crop of poison ivy sprouting crimson from the ground. But the enemy did fall back.

title: A Bordeaux That Spells Bistro
description: Chalkboard menus, honest boeuf bourguignon and tarte Tatin fill the head as you sniff and slosh down a glass or two of '96 Chateau LaGrave Bechade. It's a sturdy, grandfatherly red, prematurely but charmingly showing age, that softens the afternoon's anxieties.

title: The Nation; When the Job Requires a Walk on the Ethical Line
description: A GOOD trial lawyer spins a story from threads of fact and possibility, and Marvyn M. Kornberg made his best effort. In defense of the police officer charged with brutalizing the Haitian immigrant Abner Louima, Mr. Kornberg promised the jury evidence that the injuries to Mr. Louima's rectum and bladder could have happened during consensual sex.

title: Lions Call Sanders, but the Phone Keeps Ringing
description: So, mum is the word in Detroit.

title: Time for Batman? Week of Wild Swings
description: It was like trading inside a comic strip. Bam! Pow! Kerplunk. Investors dodged and volleyed the best they could in a week marked by four consecutive swings of 100 points or more in the Dow Jones industrial average.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINER, ERNEST M.
description: WEINER-Ernest M., Dr. Beloved husband of Ethel, wonderful father to Robert and Diane, adoring grandfather to Daniel, David, Brian, Lauren and Steven, and dear brother of Bernard. Passed away on May 28, 1999, in West Palm Beach, FL. Ernie was an intelligent, warm, compassionate and tender person who gave freely to his family, friends, patients and colleagues. He was a pioneer and leader in his profession and his community. His many professional accomplishments include serving as President of both the New York State Podiatric Association and the American Podiatric Medical Association. After moving to Florida, he served as Chairman of the Council on Aging of the Jewish Federation of Palm Beach County and was a longtime member of the Board of Directors of the Joseph L. Morse Hebrew Home for the Aged. In whatever endeavor he pursued he set a standard of excellence, commitment and devotion. Services will be held at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave, at 9:30 AM, on May 31. Interment will be at Mount Hebron Cemetery.

title: Family Nights
description: What could have been called Honor Thy Parents Weekend in Atlantic City ends tonight as Lorna Luft and Frank Sinatra Jr. conclude engagements in which they sing about how unspeakably great their folks were.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: Desperate Characters

title: Macedonia Village Typifies: (a) Peaceful Coexistence (b) Dormant Hatred
description: The Macedonians and Albanians living in this village of 1,500 people till their soil side by side, experiencing birth, marriage and death within easy earshot of one another.

title: Best of the Best
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLETT, JOSEPHINE B.
description: MILLETT-Josephine B. Died at her home in Washington, CT. She was a graduate of the Chapin School. She served in the O.S.S. during World War II. She was the widow of Richard C. Millett of New York City. She is survived by her daughter Alexandra Daniele of Tucson, Arizona.

title: Some Lessons for Japan Learned by Merrill, in Japan
description: Addressing the Japan Society's annual dinner last week, David Komansky, chairman of Merrill Lynch, promised that he would not proffer yet another prescription for Japan's economic woes, on the ground that, had Japan listened to all the previously offered cures, ''the patient would be dead.''

title: Jane's Addiction
description: THE GIRLS' GUIDE TO HUNTING

title: IN MY... OFFICE: THOMAS O. HICKS
description: ON May 18, the day after his Dallas Stars of the National Hockey League went to overtime to win the Western Conference semifinals, Thomas O. Hicks, chairman of Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst, the Dallas buyout firm, headed for the baseball stadium in nearby Arlington to see the other team he owns, the Texas Rangers, play the Tampa Bay Devil Rays. But juggling several balls -- or pucks -- at once is not difficult for Mr. Hicks, whose leveraged acquisitions in the last decade top $33 billion. There have been acquisitions ranging from soft-drink companies (Dr Pepper/Seven-Up, since sold), to hotels (the Algonquin in Manhattan, among others) to radio stations (at last count, the firm controlled 465).

title: Virginia Marx, 93; Helped Improve Child Care
description: Virginia Wise Marx, an educator and psychologist who dedicated herself to the care of children and their families, died last Sunday at White Plains Hospital. She was 93 and lived in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: The Ethicist
description: Randy Cohen (May 9) says that men who prefer Asian women are racists. But men who prefer Asian women are no more ''racist'' then my friends from Asia who prefer California blondes.

title: Mets Fall 2 Runs and a Few Tricks Short
description: Dreadful was the word Tom Seaver, now a broadcaster, chose between innings to describe the Mets' 8-7 loss to the Arizona Diamondbacks yesterday. It was also dreadfully long.

title: Micol Rothman and Salim Haji
description: Dr. Micol Sara Rothman, the daughter of Dr. Sheila Rothman and Dr. David Rothman of New York, is to be married this afternoon to Salim Francois Haji, a son of Jeanne and Abdul Haji of Washington. Amy Zucker, the intern minister of the Champlain Valley Unitarian Universalist Society in Middlebury, Vt., will perform the nondenominational ceremony at the North Universalist Chapel of the Free Spirit in Woodstock, Vt.

title: Linzer Tortes To Go; Deli, Too
description: There's only one place in the South Bronx where you can order homemade chili and Linzer tortes and eat them under a rustic Swiss cowbell. But after 35 years on Burnside Avenue, Pop's Deli is for sale.

title: Report Card: How the County's Fourth Graders Are Reading
description: The State Educational Department released the first results of its new fourth-grade English Language Arts test last week, and the results were a disappointment to many parents and teachers across the state. The test, administered over three days in January, was designed to measure how many fourth graders meet new standards requiring them to read complicated passages and write intelligently about them.

title: Kenneth Siskind, Nicole Been
description: Nicole Elizabeth Been, a daughter of Natalie Been and Dr. Harold Been of Riverdale, the Bronx, is to be married today to Kenneth Marc Siskind, the son of Mary Ann Siskind and Arthur M. Siskind of Manhattan. Rabbi Jeffrey T. Segelman is to officiate at Wave Hill in Riverdale.

title: No Personal Advice To the Donor Intended
description: On Monday, Microsoft announced that Melinda French Gates, wife of Bill, had given birth to the couple's second child.

title: A Fleet Of Festivities
description: Celebrations for charities, the arts, design, gardens and the military.

title: Miller Enjoys the Role of Villain
description: In Salt Lake City last week, Cheryl Miller confronted a woman who kept directing profanities toward her during the Western Conference semifinals between the Utah Jazz and the Portland Trail Blazers.

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH: Hosi Simon; Touring Spin City
description: SURVEYING the crowd last Thursday night at Stylus, a weekly party held at a Lower East Side sushi lounge called Never, Hosi Simon nodded approvingly that few people were eating. ''If people were eating and ignoring the music, that would be a bad sign,'' said Mr. Simon, surrounded by hipsters in the latest Asian dragon tank tops. They sipped sake, eyes fixed on the deejay spinning his turntables from a perch in an aluminum-covered space. ''The night definitely has potential.''

title: The Western Front
description: It was disingenuous of William Kittredge (May 2) to cite the school shootings in Colorado as part of a Western code of violence. The fact is that the Littleton killers exhibited aberrant behavior many months before their spree, and parents didn't call them on it, school administrators didn't call them on it and law-enforcement officials didn't call them on it. Only the jocks did.

title: May 23-29; A Respite (Sort of) for Springer
description: Many fans of ''The Jerry Springer Show'' were angered when the episodes ''Guess What? I'm Bisexual'' and ''My Daughter Wants to Be an Adult Film Star'' were yanked, replaced by tamer, six-year-old reruns. Some station owners were peeved, too, because the show mesmerizes viewers at a Nielsen-rating level second only to ''Oprah'' and ''Judge Judy,'' earning scads of money.

title: Indonesia So Far Suffers Gladly the Chaos of Coming Vote
description: Former President Suharto used to call them ''festivals of democracy'' -- ritual one-candidate elections in which vocal opponents were jailed, voters were pressured and the results were manipulated at his whim.

title: War's Conduct Creates Tension Among Chiefs
description: The civilian at the top of the American military, Secretary of Defense William S. Cohen, rarely speaks directly to the commander running the war in the Balkans. Aides to the commander, Gen. Wesley K. Clark, derisively call him ''Senator Cohen'' since he spends more time advising and cajoling his former colleagues in the Senate.

title: For Ad Agency Giants, The Weather Is Just Right
description: BENEATH the patina of economic abundance, business competition is intensifying. Hard-pressed to fatten profits by cutting costs or raising prices, companies are pursuing a time-honored alternative -- trying to bolster sales by shoveling money into advertising.

title: Q&A/Eric E. Everett; A Musical Link to Ecology for Children
description: THE animals are having a party. The problem is that many of the invitations to the animals are coming back marked, ''Return to sender.'' This is the story line in a new musical compact disk by Eric E. Everett, a Rye resident and a teacher at Rye Country Day School. It is part of Mr. Everett's effort to bridge the musical gap between Raffi, a popular children's singe who appeals to the very young, and much of today's popular music, which is geared by theme to teen-agers and young adults. At the same time, Mr. Everett's self-produced CD (Zowie Music and Productions, named for his cat) is an effort to raise children's awareness of the environment and raise money for programs that protect it. Mr. Everett, whose nickname is Triple E, will donate all profits from the CD to causes supporting endangered species and environmental education.

title: Wallace Had a Look, but Spurs See a 1-0 Lead
description: There were seven seconds left in the opening game of the Western Conference final tonight, and the San Antonio Spurs were ahead by 2 points. But David Robinson, the Spurs' center, was afraid.

title: Will Right Turn on Red for Borough Get a Green Light?
description: Right turns at red lights are legal everywhere in the state except for New York City. But two Staten Island lawmakers say drivers should be allowed to turn right on red in the borough, where suburban development makes it practical and traffic congestion makes it necessary.

title: However You Train It, That Dog Won't Hunt
description: ''THE perfect investment strategy stops working the moment you start following it.'' So argues Harry Browne, a former investment newsletter editor who was the Libertarian Party's candidate for President in 1996. He's right: Many strategies that look good on paper have only been back-tested, and very few are as successful in the real world.

title: MUSIC; Holding Her Own Among All the Guys
description: IN 1964, the jazz critic Whitney Balliett theorized that women seldom made an impact as jazz instrumentalists because they lacked the physical strength necessary to blow on a horn or beat on the drums. But on a recent night at Tonic, a performance space on the Lower East Side of Manhattan, the drummer Susie Ibarra ferociously disproved Mr. Balliett's theory.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption last Sunday about large houses that are being built in the Hamptons misstated the surname of the owner of a compound in Water Mill. He is Larry Martin, not Miller.

title: Top-Seeded Players To Meet in the Final
description: Top-seeded James Blake of Harvard and second-seeded Jeff Morrison of Florida both advanced yesterday and will meet in the final of the National Collegiate Athletic Association men's tennis championships in Athens, Ga.

title: Can Intel Be as Nimble as It is Big?
description: INVESTORS who have chosen to leave the stock of Intel Corporation out of their portfolios have missed a lucrative ride.

title: Clean-Up Days
description: Westchester residents can dispose of household chemicals on two clean-up days: next Sunday and June 19. The first event will be held at the county's Material Recovery Facility in Yonkers and the second at Westchester Community College. Both events run from 9 A.M. to 3 P.M. and are free.

title: Judge Rules on Road
