description: Greenburgh plans to appeal a ruling by a State Supreme Court judge permitting a developer to rebuild an abandoned road on its border with Yonkers. The road, owned by the New York Thruway Authority, would connect a major retail complex under construction in Yonkers to a residential section of Greenburgh.

title: Law Lite
description: DID you see the six-foot-tall chicken on Court TV?

title: Where do I pack the basketball? And you're sitting on my baseball cap!
description: For the increasingly fussy tastes of urban athletes, Fubu, the line of hip clothing and accessories, is coming out with the street equivalent of a millinery box. Fubu's Hat Sak, a baseball-cap-shaped zip-up case, $21, is designed to preserve the integrity of one's favorite cap and clips onto knapsacks or belt loops. Other customized luggage includes the Bibo (ball in, ball out) backpack with a zippered mesh compartment to hold a standard National Basketball Association ball. Information: (800) 250-3723.

title: SOAPBOX; Saving Special Ed
description: IN my job I see too many children with their potential wasted by harmful placements in special education. Patrick M. is typical: he's an African-American boy who was doing well academically but needed counseling for behavioral problems. Instead Patrick's school recommended a special-education placement totally segregated from general-education students. Such a placement would be right for the most severely disturbed child, not Patrick.

title: As Agriculture Struggles, Iowa Psychologist Helps His Fellow Farmers Cope
description: After hauling oats to his cattle before sunrise on the Iowa prairie, Michael Rosmann drives to an office and sits down with farmer after farmer to listen to their troubles. A fourth-generation farmer as well as a clinical psychologist, he speaks the language of men and women on the verge of losing their place on the land.

title: Passing the Endurance Test; A 2-Acre Farm Belt At 194-15 73d Ave.
description: For most New Yorkers, springtime means warmer days and crisp nights, long walks in the park and the first crack of the bat. But for John Klein Jr., one of the last farmers in the city, spring means going back to the plow, sowing seeds and chasing raccoons.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LUBALIN, HERB F.
description: LUBALIN-Herb F. Imagine the visual and verbal delights Herb would have created in these 18 years. Remembering with love, Rhoda Sparber Lubalin

title: NIGERIA'S MILITARY TURNS OVER POWER TO ELECTED LEADER
description: In an exuberant ceremony of martial music and marches, Nigeria's military ruler turned over power to an elected leader today, opening an era of civilian government in the nation where one in six Africans live.

title: Young Swimmers Are Trying to Float Above Red Ink
description: Ashli Kyles was 9 years old when she started taking swimming lessons at Riverbank State Park and was recruited to the park's swim team, the Red Tails, the next year.

title: No Halt to Kashmir Strikes, Even for Talks, India Leader Says
description: Prime Minister Atal Behari Vajpayee said today that India would continue air strikes against what he described as Pakistani-backed infiltrators dug into Indian territory, and would only be willing to hold talks with Pakistan about the conflict if they were not conditional on a halt to the air raids.

title: Rafter Loses a Match, And His Bid to Be No. 1
description: Patrick Rafter, the carefree Australian who wore batik jams and a deep tan to the Grand Slam tournament where he hoped to defy the slow clay surface with his run-and-gun energy, came unglued today at the French Open.

title: No Rush To Upgrade Internet Stocks
description: It's been a black spring for Internet stocks, with the Bloomberg Internet Index falling 26.5 percent since its high on April 13. But are Wall Street analysts slapping ''buy'' signs on the reduced-price merchandise? Not especially, according to the First Call Corporation of Boston, which tracks analysts' recommendations.

title: Ideas & Trends; The Art of Finishing Unfinished Art
description: IMAGINE being Franz Xaver Sussmayr. Your teacher, Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart, is dying, just as he's writing one of his greatest works. On his deathbed he explains how he envisions completing it. The rest is up to you.

title: What's at Stake? A Trip to the N.B.A. Finals
description: The Knicks are in the Eastern Conference finals for the first time since 1994, when they beat Indiana on the way to the N.B.A. finals. Here are the keys to this year's matchup. By SELENA ROBERTS

title: Corrections
description: A picture credit was omitted last Sunday with an article about ways to keep cool. The photographer was Rebecca Cooney for The New York Times.

title: Few Assurances In Trip Insurance
description: BUILDERS warn that there is no standard-sized window. There is likewise no standard trip-cancellation insurance policy. Recent events have raised questions that expose widening differences among the popular policies sold to protect travelers against lost payments if they cannot take a trip, tour or cruise.

title: North Korea Unresponsive In U.S. Talks, Envoy Reports
description: Former Defense Secretary William S. Perry said today that during his just-completed trip to North Korea, he had ''clearly and firmly'' expressed concern about North Korean military programs, but that he did not get any definitive response.

title: PULSE; Is the Sun Block Still Working?
description: The latest in the sparkly makeup craze is Sungirl Sunscreen With Glitter, a gel introduced last winter by Natural Desires, a California-based company. Available for $7.99 at Nordstrom's and many local drugstores, Sungirl became a hot seller after it was featured in Sports Illustrated's swimsuit issue. Two of its four formulas contain Parsol 1789, an ingredient approved in 1997 by the Food and Drug Administration that provides some protection against ultraviolet A rays. But the main attraction is the glitter. It serves as a reminder: when the sparkles sputter, it is time to reapply. LINDA DiPROPERZIO

title: Passing the Endurance Test; Today Vinyl, Not Painting, Is the Sign of the Times
description: For Samuel Quinones, the writing is on the wall. One of 37 members of the union that represents outdoor-sign painters, Mr. Quinones still practices his craft on walls in the city. But as vinyl, neon and electronic signs replace painted ones all over New York, except for historic districts, jobs are few. Sign painters like Mr. Quinones are becoming obsolete.

title: 'Water Music' Given A New Meaning
description: AT exactly 9 A.M. on a recent Monday, a station wagon pulled up in front of the Manhattan School of Music on West 122d Street, and a tall, pencil-slim young man got out. Complimented on his punctuality, he replied: ''Hey, I'm a percussionist. If you're late, you're nowhere.''

title: Spinning Jinni
description: MOONLIGHT ON THE AVENUE OF FAITH

title: Where Have You Gone, Martin Dihigo?
description: THE PRIDE OF HAVANA

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on May 2 about an island off Sulawesi, in Indonesia, misidentified it. The island was Manado Tua, not neighboring Bunaken.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAYERS, ROBERT A.
description: MAYERS-Robert A., M.D. On May 27, 1999. Formerly of Rye, NY. Beloved husband of Annabelle. Loving father of Susan Tupper of Chicago, IL, Linda Olmstead of Troy, AL, Terri Byrne of Larchmont, NY, and Nancy Mayers of Stamford, CT. Devoted brother of Jack Mayers of Palm City, FL, Joan Mayers of Miami, FL. Dear uncle of William Mayers of New Milford, CT. Also survived by six grandchildren. Visiting on Sunday and Monday, 7-9 PM, at the William H. Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Rd, Rye, NY. Mass of Christian Burial on Tuesday, 10 AM, at Resurrection Church, Rye, NY. Interment to follow at Greenwood Union Cemetery, Rye, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations to the American Heart Association or Boy Scouts of America would be appreciated.

title: Greenport's First Black Fire Chief Lifts Hopes
description: WHEN they march down Front Street here, something in the faces of the volunteer firemen tells of resistance to change and deep attachment to tradition.

title: POLITICAL BRIEFING
description: A 'Bush' Web Site, Woven From Mischief

title: In Defense of Private Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: THE GUIDE
description: Sculpture Meant to Amuse

title: How America Views Its Uncle
description: UNCLE SAM wants you -- to attend the New-York Historical Society's exhibit ''Uncle Sam: The Face of a Nation,'' which is to run through Aug. 15.

title: Baseball Books in Brief
description: Owning A Piece of the Minors

title: NATO Allies Skeptical of Chernomyrdin's Latest Efforts to Sway Belgrade
description: The NATO allies today reacted with skepticism to the outcome of the visit by the Russian envoy, Viktor S. Chernomyrdin, to Belgrade where he aired ways to end the war in Kosovo with President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia.

title: Rivals in Argentina Rallying Around the Beleaguered Peso
description: As the race to replace President Carlos Saul Menem of Argentina heated up in recent weeks, the two major candidates thought they had found an ideal campaign theme: blame the incumbent's free market economic policies for rising unemployment and promise major changes if elected.

title: A Year After Lilco Takeover, Power Use Surges but Critics Hang In
description: Ever since New York State took over Long Island's electricity system a year ago today and cut rates by an average of 20 percent, customers have reacted like bargain hunters at a sale. They are using more electricity than ever.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TANGNEY, NICHOLAS J.
description: TANGNEY-Nicholas J. Of Ardsley on Hudson, May 28, 1999. Beloved husband of Constance (McHugh) Tangney. Loving father & fatherin-law of Robert and Wendy, William & Meg, Peter, Ann, Thomas and Evelyn. Devoted brother of Gerald, Cora, Sr. Therese, and Margaret. Fond grandfather of six. Mass of the Resurrection 10AM Wednesday, June 2, 1999 at the Church of the Immaculate Conception, Irvington, New York. Visiting Edwards-Dowdle Funeral Home, 64 Ashford Ave. (Sawmill Parkway Exit 17), Dobbs Ferry, from 2-4 P.M. and 7-9 P.M. on Tuesday. Memorials to Rosary Hill Home, Hawthorne, New York, would be appreciated.

title: Overseas Obstacles
description: To the Editor:

title: Stacey Lefont And Barry Biggar
description: Stacey Nichols Lefont and Barry Peter Biggar, lawyers in New York, are to be married this evening by Rabbi Fred M. Raskind at the Ritz-Carlton Buckhead in Atlanta.

title: For 2d Year, Ithaca Cracks Down on Cornell Students' Rowdy Block Parties
description: For years, the week before graduation at Cornell University has inspired late-night parties that flooded the narrow streets of Collegetown, a residential neighborhood bordering the campus.

title: Spree-ality
description: The fact is that Sprewell will always be an easy target because of his off-the-court behavior, which ranges from confusing to contemptible. But let's be honest: on the court, the guy can flat-out play.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLAUNSTEIN, JEROME L.
description: BLAUNSTEIN-Jerome L., M.D. Passed away on May 24, 1999. He will be missed by many friends and relatives and especially by his companion of many years, Bruce C. Olsen.

title: Corrections
description: An article on page 5 of the Arts & Leisure section today about obstacles encountered on Broadway by new plays includes an outdated reference to the Drama Dept. revival of ''The Author's Voice,'' by Richard Greenberg. The play closed yesterday, after the section had gone to press. The run had been scheduled to last through June 12.

title: Preparing Beaches, At a Cost
description: If the beach is soggy, trashy and smells like something other than brine, chances are it is in need of nourishment.

title: New Life at Vanderbilt Museum
description: ROSAMOND VANDERBILT'S negligee is on the bed. William K. Vanderbilt 2d's smoking jacket is thrown over a chair. There are fresh towels in the marble master bathroom, an ice bucket filled with fake cubes by the tub, and a safe hidden in the closet.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In /Bath Beach, Brooklyn; Once a Bayfront Resort, Now Residential
description: LIKE it's namesake, Bath, the spa town in England, Bath Beach is a tranquil place. But it is no longer the resort area it was a century ago. The beach itself was eradicated in a postwar building boom, and largely replaced by housing on a landfill. Now it is primarily residential with a walkway along the waterfront and a view of Coney Island across Gravesend Bay.

title: Baseball Books in Brief
description: How to Snag

title: The Numbers Game
description: To the Editor:

title: But Is It Kosher?
description: MEMORIES OF

title: Before the Train At Grand Central
description: BOBBY VAN'S STEAKHOUSE *

title: 'The Apple' and Other Movie Delights
description: The summer season of the New Jersey Film Festival, sponsored by the Rutgers Film Co-op and the New Jersey Media Arts Center, opens on Friday with the New Jersey premiere of ''The Apple.'' Directed by 18-year-old Samira Makhmalbaf, ''The Apple'' recounts the story of twin girls who were locked inside their house in Iran until the authorities found them when they were 12. Moshen Makhmalbaf, the director's father and an Iranian filmmaker, wrote and edited the film.

title: Oysters in the Name But Not on the Plate
description: YES, we have no oysters.'' That was the gist of our discussion with a waiter at the Blue Oyster Grill one recent evening. We had arrived with our mouths watering for oysters. Even though we saw no mention of them on the menu, our server assured us they were available and pointed out that the Blue Oyster salad included oysters. (The description in the menu includes lettuce, tomatoes, cucumbers, peppers and red onions but no oysters.) We ordered the salad but later were told it was not being offered.

title: Elena Marcuss, Tomas Ayala
description: Elena Daly Marcuss, the daughter of Rosemary and Stanley Marcuss of Washington, was married there yesterday to Dr. Tomas H. Ayala, a son of Isabel A. Vazquez of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and Julio E. Ayala of Caracas, Venezuela. The Rev. Elizabeth Orens, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Washington National Cathedral.

title: Lead Dust in the Wind Withers Mexican Children
description: The mothers who live in the cinder-block houses just downwind from a towering lead-smelting plant have begun describing their children by numbers.

title: Dinner at Spielberg's? With this hair?
description: In a trailer at the East 34th Street heliport, Anthony Susino of Oscar Blandi Salon has started giving preboarding or debarking trims and fluff-ups to the not-a-minute-to-waste chopper set. For $100 to $200 a cut, and $100 for a blow-dry, Mr. Susino offers hairdos in 15 minutes, though no one has enough hair spray to guarantee what will happen after a gusty walk under whirring copter blades. Information: (212) 593-7930.

title: The Nation: After All, Why Now?; The New Politics of Gun Control
description: IT did not happen after the bullets flew and the bodies fell at a high school in West Paducah, Ky., in December 1997, nor did it happen on the heels of the gunfire and bloodshed at schools in Jonesboro, Ark., or Springfield, Ore., last year.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about buying and picking strawberries misstated the Web address for information about pick-your-own farms. It is www.agmkt.state.ny.us.

title: Donna Lutz, Keith Shafritz
description: Donna Joanne Lutz, the daughter of Arlene Goldfus Lutz and Dr. Kenneth J. Lutz of Ocean Township, N.J., is to be married there this evening to Keith Michael Shafritz, a son of Sharon Shafritz and Dr. David A. Shafritz of Larchmont, N.Y. Rabbi Irving Koslowe will perform the ceremony at Temple Beth Torah.

title: Michael Ovitz Is On the Line
description: For someone who believes that ''perception is everything,'' Ovitz ought to have demanded photo approval. That cover shot looks like a publicity still from the sequel to ''Silence of the Lambs.'' Of course, maybe that's the point?

title: Schools Will Pay for Court Ruling; Rights and Preferences
description: To the Editor:

title: Spano Counts on Funds From Tobacco Lawsuit
description: COUNTY EXECUTIVE Andrew J. Spano contends that he has every right to count on the millions of dollars the county government expects from the settlement of the tobacco lawsuits as he seeks to fulfill his pledge to lower county taxes 15 percent during his four-year term.

title: The World; Hey, Allies, Follow Me. I've Got All the New Toys.
description: NATO's bombing campaign in Yugoslavia has exposed more than policy differences between the European and American alliance partners. As never before, it has revealed the vast technological gulf that separates American military capabilities from those of Britain, France and the others. And that, in turn, shows just how much the Europeans remain militarily dependent on the United States for their own defense -- dependent, and resentful.

title: Stages and Screens
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BLATAS, ARBIT
description: BLATAS-Arbit. Remembering Arbit Blatas Tuesday, June 1st 1999, 3:30 pm. The Kaye Playhouse, Hunter College, 68th St. between Park and Lexington Aves, NY.

title: Where Everybody Knew My Name
description: Elizabeth Stone's Lives column (May 9) on the on-line gathering of Elizabeths reflected perfectly the trend for small groups to coalesce on the Internet based on hobbies, interests or random commonalities like names. The Internet, vast as it is, seems to spark a small-town quilting-bee longing in many users.

title: Habitats / Kappock Street, Riverdale, the Bronx; 2 Apartments Into One, With a Room for Orchids
description: STEVEN EDBRIL and Richard Rodriguez like to say that their sprawling co-op apartment in Riverdale is like a ranch house. Maybe it is, but not like the ranch houses most people grew up with. It is spacious and light, and all on one floor. But there are also orchids everywhere, as fragile and colorful as life itself, and beautifully crafted display cabinets, cupboards and shelves that give the place a solid architectural feel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PREUSS, FERNA MAE
description: PREUSS-Ferna Mae of Rockville Centre on May 21. Beloved mother of Melvin and Jacob. Loving grandmother of Alexandra, Randi and Jessica, sister Elsie Burke and mother-in-law to Sherie and Linda. We will cherish you forever, swell. In lieu of flowers, send a contribution to your favorite charity.

title: Bill Would Let Towns Ban Nude Bathers on State Beaches
description: A bill rapidly moving through the Legislature would ban bathers from baring all this summer at Higbee Beach, one of the two nude beaches in the state.

title: May 23-29; Former Soviet, American-to-be
description: Nikita Khrushchev, his son Sergei said, once told Richard Nixon, ''Your grandsons will live in a Communist America.'' To which Mr. Nixon replied, ''No, your grandsons will live in a capitalist Russia.''

title: Nancy Sanborn, Richard Dahling
description: Nancy Lee Sanborn and Richard Priddie Dahling were married yesterday at St. James Episcopal Church in Farmington, Conn. Bishop Andrew F. Wissemann of the Episcopal Diocese of Western Massachusetts performed the ceremony.

title: Passing the Endurance Test; When Hardware Was Hardware And People Were Software
description: They were the clattering mainstay of every modern business office. They went to war and to America's college campuses. Generations of students learned to use them, fingers on the home keys. Until recently, most every American household had at least one of them, electric or manual.

title: Passing the Endurance Test; A Sole Umbrella Repair Shop Reigns When It Pours
description: Gilbert Center wasn't yet out of the crib when he got his first taste of the umbrella business. His father, who owned an umbrella shop on the Lower East Side, didn't care for restaurant food, so at lunchtime his mother delivered a home-cooked meal, wheeling young Gilbert into the Essex Street storefront in his carriage. As he grew, the workshop where his father repaired the spiny contraptions drew him like a magnet.

title: Ms. Greenbaum, Dr. Rubenfeld
description: Lynne Carol Greenbaum, a Spanish teacher, and Dr. Ira George Rubenfeld, an internist, are to be married this afternoon in Philadelphia. Rabbi Alan Fuchs will perform the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents, Julia Greenbaum and Dr. Charles H. Greenbaum.

title: Fitting Forbes For Oval Office Is Advertising Man's Assignment
description: William Eisner, who heads an advertising agency in Milwaukee, is best known for his commercials about Mrs. Paul's fish sticks, including one that features a sloppy little boy lassoing his head with spaghetti. ''Not impressed with pasta anymore?'' the announcer asks. ''Break the monotony with fish sticks.''

title: Fanciful Creatures Inhabit An Eccentric New Village
description: A village called Dynamo-ville is to open its doors on the Lower East Side Saturday, inhabited by fuzzy, plump creatures created by Alisa McRonald and Keith Knittel. Dynamo-ville, actually a gallery, is at 70 Orchard Street between Grand and Broome Streets.

title: Blue-Collar Sport in a White-Collar Town
description: NOW that Minnesota Gov. Jesse Ventura has thrust wrestling into the limelight, along with Representative Dennis Hastert, the Speaker of the House of Representatives who is a former wrestling coach, nobody is more enthusiastic than Richard Pluta.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIS, MINNA ROSE
description: DAVIS-Minna Rose (nee Heyman). Died Saturday at her residence in Clearbrook. Mrs. Davis was born and lived in Jersey City until 1981. She was 84. Her husband, Horace G. Davis, died in 1989. She is survived by her son Samuel H. Davis (Cheryl), a daughter, Mary Ann Reis Romer (Theodore), three grandchildren, Dr. Mark Davis, Dr. Jeffrey Davis and Lauren Davis. Funeral services will be conducted on Monday, 1 PM, from the Rezem Funeral Home, 457 Cranbury Rd, East Brunswick.

title: How Fourth Graders Are Reading, or Not
description: The New York State Education Department released the results of its new fourth-grade English Language Arts test last week, and the scores were a disappointment to many parents and teachers. The new test, administered over three days in January, was designed to measure how many fourth graders meet new standards requiring them to read complicated passages and write intelligently about them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIRSCHHORN, ANNE.
description: HIRSCHHORN - Anne. Beloved wife of the late Leo. Devoted mother of Dr. Ralph and Paul Hirschhorn. Loving grandmother and great-grandmother. Services today, 12 noon, at ''Gutterman's,'' 8000 Jericho Tpke, Woodbury, LI.

title: Designing for a World That's Already Filled
description: THEY say that anyone can nominate candidates for the Pritzker Architecture Prize. May I propose Gae Aulenti? The great Milanese architect has just broken ground for her first major project in the United States. She already has as distinguished a body of work to her credit as any Pritzker Prize winner. Not incidentally, she is also the most important female architect since the beginning of time. Think about it.

title: One Block -- and 13 Menus
description: It's a short stretch of Johnson Avenue, the block between 235th and 236th Streets. But it's become a mini-restaurant row, with Italian, Chinese and Japanese restaurants cheek by jowl with kosher delis and pizza parlors. All told, there are 12 places to eat on the block and 2 around the corner on 235th Street, with two more restaurants, one Mexican and one Indian, about to open.

title: BEST SELLERS: May 30, 1999
description: Weeks

title: Michelin Teams Mexico With Belize, Guatemala
description: Michelin has published its first combined tourist guide to Mexico, Guatemala and Belize. Mexico had a Green Guide of its own, last reissued in 1990, and the two smaller countries until now had none. The new volume, in the familiar paperback pocket-width format, devotes some 310 pages to Mexico, 26 to Guatemala and 18 to tiny English-speaking Belize.

title: Another Award, Other Memories Of McCarthyism
description: AROUND the time the first peals of outrage were heard in Los Angeles over the honorary Oscar for Elia Kazan, who had named names to the House Un-American Activities Committee during the McCarthy era, a small ceremony in New York was conducted with none of the dissonance that accompanied the Hollywood salute.

title: California Wins Title
description: The University of California crew stood off its only real challenge to an undefeated season yesterday while capturing the national championship on the Cooper River in Cherry Hill, N.J., at the Intercollegiate Rowing Association's 97th regatta. The Bears, acclaimed as one of the best men's heavyweight eights in the history of college rowing, shattered the course record by six seconds with a time of 5 minutes 23.6 seconds over the 2,000-meter course.

title: Disney North
description: Through June 30, or until 70 or so cases run out, visitors to Palmer Vineyards in Aquebogue will find a spiffy $17 white wine with an unfamiliar label: Fulton's Crab House and 1997 Proprietor's Reserve.

title: The Glass Half Empty
description: Caroline Knapp's (May 9) three-pronged approach to recovery from substance abuse (antiaddiction drugs, psychotherapy and group support like Alcoholics Anonymous) is all the more powerful coming from someone who has walked the walk. One hopes her message will be heard by those who categorically ascribe moral deficiency to people in the grip of addiction.

title: Schools Will Pay for Court Ruling; Taxpayers Will Suffer
description: To the Editor:

title: Headlights
description: Don't even think about parking on the grass at the Montclair Art Museum next weekend, even if it seems everyone else has. The 20 or so cars you'll see on the lawn have special permits.

title: Remembering Those Who Gave Their All
description: ALTHOUGH Long Island is liberally dotted with memorials to veterans of the country's wars, for the better part of the year they are little noticed. They may appear in news stories when desecrated by vandals, or are mentioned in driving directions, but most of the time they tend to be like the suit that's taken out of the closet only for weddings and funerals.

title: A Pilgrim's Rewards, Step by Step
description: I HAD climbed Mont Blanc, the highest mountain in Europe, to celebrate my 50th birthday, and wondered vaguely what I might do for an encore as my 60th approached. Nothing even remotely spiritual had so far disturbed my predictable pedestrian progress. However, I had read for years about the Camino de Santiago -- the Way of St. James, the ancient pilgrims' route to Santiago de Compostela in Spain, and contemplated attempting the journey. Finally, at the funeral service of one of my greatest friends, I made myself a promise that I would make the pilgrimage on foot to Santiago on his behalf, and that of my godson, who had died too young the previous year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BREIT, SADIE
description: BREIT-Sadie. On May 28, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Samuel. Loving mother of Martin, Muriel Orlan, and Erwin. Also survived by six grandchildren and twelve great-grandchildren. Service Sunday 1:15 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: The Dominican National Pastime
description: Away Games

title: Corrections
description: A review in the Book Review on May 9 about ''Germaine Greer: Untamed Shrew,'' by Christine Wallace, misstated Ms. Greer's academic affiliation in the late 1970's and early 80's. She was a professor at the University of Tulsa, not the University of Oklahoma.

title: Susan Knox, Ross Hunt 3d
description: Susan Elizabeth Knox and Ross Franklin Hunt 3d were married yesterday by the Rev. Dawson J. Ambosta at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Bronxville, N.Y.

title: In Defense of Private Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: Going Over the Edge to Death and Applause
description: When Owen Hart, a 34-year-old professional wrestler known as the Blue Blazer, plunged more than 50 feet from the rafters of a Kansas City arena to his death in the ring last week, fans thought it was part of the show, the kind of grand entrance they had come to expect. They cheered as his body was carried off. After all, the World Wrestling Federation had billed the nationally televised pay-for-view event as ''Over the Edge.''

title: Bringing Out the Gravitas In a Tough Housing Project
description: ON a cool spring Sunday in the Watts section of Los Angeles, the photographer Dana Lixenberg watched as Monique King Cade, a longtime resident of the Imperial Courts housing project, looked through a box of 50 postcard-size portraits. They were taken six years ago by Ms. Lixenberg during the second Rodney King trial.

title: French-Speaking Heroes Get Place in the Soleil
description: Tintin and his dog, Snowy (Milou in French), and Asterix and his portly pal, Obelix, are a few of the featured attractions at Karikter, a month-old downtown store that sells European cartoon character books and related items.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: Best Bet

title: Baseball Books in Brief; There Were Monarchs in Those Days
description: ''Catching could really wear you down, but I loved being behind the plate because you really had the whole game in front of you,'' Frazier (Slow) Robinson writes in his memoir, Catching Dreams: My Life in the Negro baseball Leagues (Syracuse University, $27.95). While Robinson may not have been the greatest ballplayer the Negro leagues produced -- think of him as a prewar Elston Howard -- he did have a prime view for some of baseball's most remarkable and all-but-forgotten moments during his career with the Kansas City Monarchs. He recalls the details of games played half a century ago as vividly as if they happened yesterday. Unclouded by sentiment, he recounts his ragged barnstorming tours against washed-up white Hall of Famers like Grover Cleveland Alexander and Hack Wilson (''Hack was happy to get the work, happy to get paid to keep playing'') and how he and the great Satchel Paige came to an uneasy truce on pitch selection: ''The truth was that he didn't have any kind of a curveball.'' Robinson analyzes the swing of the mighty Georgetown Grays slugger Josh Gibson as expertly as if he had a Telestrator and Super Slo Mo. ''The only way you could get him out was to watch the way he moved at the plate,'' Robinson recalls. ''If he leaned over too far, you could pitch high and tight on him. . . . And if he kind of stands straight up, you can break the ball down and away.'' Robinson's use of the language, at once poetic and unvarnished, is a joy, as when he recalls the most dreaded base stealer of the Negro leagues: ''I'm convinced that catcher's hell is papered with pictures of Cool Papa Bell.'' When Robinson talks about race, he does so with chilling immediacy. ''Back when I first went to Texas, I heard that one left-handed pitcher did get killed. I forgot his name now. Some guy shot him down. Happened right on the field they said. He'd struck out about 10 of their players.'' Robinson died in 1997 at the age of 87 after completing ''Catching Dreams'' with Paul Bauer, an Ohio rare-book dealer. But by using his last years to immortalize these stories, he contributed as much to the game with a tape recorder as he ever did with a bat or glove. Allen St. John

title: A Match Unmatched
description: To the Editor:

title: Luyendyk Hopes for a Fast Farewell at Indy
description: They know how to win, but just as important, most champions know when to quit. Michael Jordan knew when it was time. John Elway and Wayne Gretzky did. So now does Arie Luyendyk, who will race around the Brickyard for the final time on Sunday, two years after taking his second checkered flag at the Indianapolis 500.

title: A Getaway for Parents? Try Summer Camp
description: FOUR years ago, the Snowshoe Mountain ski area in West Virginia looked into ways to tap the rich markets of the Northeast and the mid-Atlantic states in the off season. Mike Valache, a manager, settled on a mountain-biking camp for 12- to 18-year-olds. He set up breathtaking downhill runs and scenic winding trails to appeal to the young and gonzo, and he made sure to have plenty of insurance and safety regulations to reassure their parents. But as it turned out, the parents were not anxious when they dropped off their progeny. They were envious.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VALLAS, DENNIS, CATHERINE
description: VALLAS-DENNIS-Catherine. On May 28, 1999. Devoted and loving mother, wife, sister, Yia-Yia and aunt. Daughter of the late Vovo and Nicholas Vallas and adored wife of the late Paul Dennis. Beloved mother of Dean and his wife Debra, and sister of Venus Dimou, Bess and her husband John Papandon and George and his wife Monica Vallas. Cherished Yia-Yia of Zoe and Sophie and caring aunt of Dean, John Jr., Bittie and John III, Stephen and Laura, Alexi and Jen, Liz, Greg and Eric and Nicholas. Distinguished and dedicated employee of Bloomingdale's for over 40 years. As a buyer, department manager and fashion coordinator she among others was responsible for the store's glory days. Following her success at Bloomingdale's she launched and managed the boutique at the Evelyn Lauder Breast Cancer Center at Memorial Sloan-Kettering. Enthusiastic and committed volunteer with The Metropolitan Opera, the Costume Institute of the Metropolitan Museum of Art and The Guggenheim Museum. Avid traveler, museum goer, dancer and participant in life's cultural joys. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 Street, Monday, May 31 from 2-5 and 7-9PM. Funeral service Tuesday, 11AM at The Cathedral of the Holy Trinity, 319 East 74 Street. In lieu of flowers, constributions may be made in her memory to The Evelyn Lauder Breast Cancer Center of Memorial Sloan-Kettering. She will be sorely missed.

title: Christopher Latta and Jennifer Bell
description: Jennifer Ellen Bell, a daughter of Ellen and William Bell of Huntington, N.Y., was married yesterday to Christopher Thomas Latta, the son of Shelley Latta and Thomas Latta, both of Henderson, Ky. The Rev. Nancy Hanna performed the ceremony at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in New York.

title: May 23-29; Charges Dropped
description: Kenneth W. Starr said he would not seek to retry Susan H. McDougal and Julie Hiatt Steele, whom he had accused of giving false or misleading testimony about President Clinton (Ms. McDougal about a Arkansas real estate ventures, Ms. Steele about sexual indiscretions). Both trials ended in deadlock. The independent counsel is still pursuing Webster L. Hubbell, an old Clinton friend and former Justice Department official. Mr. Starr's associates have said he may yet try to prosecute Bill Clinton himself.

title: Noisy Restaurant Makes Waves
description: Stephen Wallis, a photographer whose bedroom window faces the back of the Lobster Club, a restaurant on East 80th Street owned by the chef, Anne Rosenzweig, had a singular way of complaining to city officials about noise from the restaurant's fans.

title: War Stories; In Memoriam: Monuments Pay Tribute to New Jerseyans Who Gave Their Lives in Battle
description: BIRD song was the only sound. The black granite wall, reflecting the sharp sunlight, felt warm to the touch. And the students from Dover High School stood hushed in the center of an outdoor amphitheater surrounded by the names of 1,555 New Jerseyans killed in Vietnam.

title: Can the Police Learn to Be Color Blind?
description: TWO years ago, Malik Jones, 21, was shot and killed by an East Haven police officer after a high-speed chase from East Haven into New Haven.

title: Holiday Tomorrow
description: Memorial Day will be observed.

title: Q and A
description: In Hawaiian Waters

title: The Jersey Shore Sound Pays a Visit to the City
description: HERE'S how the Jersey Shore rock scene works: everybody knows everybody else and has, at one time or another, played together.

title: May 23-29; In Clash Over Kashmir, India Sends In Its First Jets
description: Two Indian jets were lost in airstrikes against a large force of guerrillas dug into the mountains of Kashmir. It was the first time New Delhi has used jet fighters and helicopters gunships in its decadelong dispute with Pakistan, sharply increasing tensions in the nuclear-armed subcontinent.

title: Laura Porio and Mark Silence
description: Laura Jean Porio, the daughter of Patricia and Salvatore V. Porio of Westport, Conn., is to be married today to Mark Steiner Silence, a son of Mary Anne and Steiner M. Silence of Ames, Iowa. The Rev. Richard J. Bourgeois will perform the ceremony at St. Patrick's Old Cathedral in New York.

title: Dreaded Words: Everybody Out of the Pool
description: IN a world in which everything requires a decision -- from your long-distance company to the fat content of your milk -- it's nice to have a few no-brainers. A place where you send your check without thinking. A choice that requires no calls or extensive Internet research.

title: Got a Cause? Get a Celebrity; Let Them Run
description: To the Editor:

title: For Class of '99, A Real-Life 'Rent'
description: WITH all the scarcity, hysteria, back-stabbing and astronomical prices in the real estate market, it would hardly seem possible for young people just out of college to find apartments.

title: Passing the Endurance Test; The Anatomy of Discretion, Or, How to Fit Brassieres
description: Deborah Sherman remembers what it was like. ''I used to go with my mother in the Bronx,'' she recalled the other day, with not much nostalgia. ''At the store, these huge old ladies would mrrff, rrrmm'' -- her hands smushed the air in front of her chest into imaginary A-cups. ''And you're just dying, but they don't care.''

title: From Brazil to Wall St. and Back
description: THE United States has had only two central bank chiefs in the last two decades, but boom-and-bust Brazil has had 20, an average of one a year.

title: The China Agenda
description: Washington's battered relations with Beijing suffered serious new damage last week from the Cox committee report on Chinese theft of American nuclear and missile secrets. Working ties will have to be rebuilt, but on more realistic foundations than before. While it still makes sense to encourage China to open its economy and play a constructive role in international affairs, Washington must give clear priority to protecting American security.

title: Bonnie Arffa, Timothy Perman
description: Bonnie Sue Arffa and Timothy James Perman are to be married this morning by Rabbi Charles C. Lippman at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx.

title: Soft Justice
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Breaking a Shrewd Blockade With Even Shrewder Tactics
description: One way to blockade a position is to sacrifice a rook for a knight to cripple the attacker's pawns and thus keep his firepower bottled up. Against this type of defensive strategy, especially sharp tactics are required to break out of confinement and win. An excellent example of the difficulties involved, with a complex, ingenious solution to them, is to be seen in the game between the grandmasters Gregory Kaidanov of Lexington, Ky., and Julian Hodgson of England in the National Open Tournament in March in Las Vegas, Nev.

title: JERSEY DIARY
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: OPINION; Steps Toward Affordable Housing
description: WITH all of Long Island's beaches, golf courses, parks and other positive qualities, young people and the elderly have serious questions about remaining here. The basic reason cited is the lack of affordable housing.

title: From the Hanoi Hilton To the Hilton Hanoi
description: The Hilton Hanoi Opera hotel has opened, a few blocks from Hoa Lo, the infamous ''Hanoi Hilton'' where American prisoners were held during the Vietnam War. (The few remaining cells of that prison have been preserved as a museum.) The seven-story classical facade of the new hotel resembles its more immediate neighbor, the newly restored 1911 French colonial Hanoi Opera House. The neighborhood is within walking distance of the city's central business district. Guest rooms, furnished with lacquered cabinets and Vietnamese art, have individually controlled air-conditioning, data ports and television with international channels.

title: Sonia Gandhi's Defenders; A Kashmiri Solution
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEINBERG, SYLVIA
description: STEINBERG-Sylvia. We are saddened at the news of her tragic passing caused by injuries sustained in a car accident, and send our expressions of sympathy and comfort to our colleague, her husband Harry, and to her daughters Mara and Lisa. Martin Bookspan, Henry Denker, Tovah Feldshuh, Bel Kaufman, Alan King, Cynthia Ozick, Estelle Parsons, Tony Randall, Paul Sorvino, Eli Wallach, Fritz Weaver, Elie Wiesel, Shelley Winters, Sidney Zion. Writers and Artists for Peace In the Middle East

title: Yes, Appropriate
description: To the Editor:

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: JOHN FARROW'S nimble direction brings WAKE ISLAND (1942) to a superb conclusion, as two doomed Marine officers (Albert Dekker and Brian Donlevy) almost impersonally swap alma maters while Japanese troops swarm over their Pacific island foxhole. The picture's granite realism is pervasive as American troops become aware of the final assault by the enemy in the weeks after Pearl Harbor. Macdonald Carey and Robert Preston are outstanding in key roles - Sunday at 10:30 P.M. and Sunday/Early Monday at 4:30 A.M. on AMC.

title: Michael Ovitz Is On the Line
description: In the complex, Machiavellian world of Michael Ovitz, it seems the last thing anyone is interested in is making movies (Lynn Hirschberg, May 9). No wonder a staggering number of recent films are dreadful, despite current production being at an all-time high.

title: Richard Kobler, 90, an Engineer and the Inventor of the First 'Talking Typewriter'
description: Richard Kobler, an Austrian-born electronics engineer who devised the first ''talking typewriter'' and scores of other contrivances after being resettled in New York 60 years ago by the actress Gloria Swanson, died on May 8 at the J.F.K. Medical Center in Lake Worth, Fla. He was 90 and lived in nearby Delray Beach.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAX, MICHAEL
description: LAX-Michael. Age 69, of NYC and Bridgehampton, NY, on May 25th, 1999. Beloved father of Jennifer and Rebecca. Cherished partner of Kirsten Childs. An exceptionally gifted and caring man. He will be greatly missed.

title: Representing America in a Language of Her Own
description: ANN HAMILTON, the installation artist who will represent the United States in the 48th Venice Biennale, is a slight woman who dresses in the art-world uniform, black pants and jacket, her salt-and-pepper hair closely cropped.

title: The Party's Over
description: Broadway Babies

title: Two Visions for Kosovo
description: To the Editor:

title: My Life on a Wing and a Prayer
description: SINCE the dawn of history, human beings have dreamed of being able to fly. And since the opening of the Long Island Expressway, Long Islanders have wanted to fly more than most. Imagine skimming along at 100 miles an hour above the permanent traffic jam at Exit 53, or flying eastward toward the Hamptons on a Friday evening in summer over endless lines of stalled BMW's and Lexuses.

title: The Demons of Gettysburg
description: It was Memorial Day weekend a year ago, and since I was deep in the writing of a novel about a black Civil War cavalryman, I decided to stop at Gettysburg on my way home from a college reunion. I had passed through the town several times before but had avoided the battlefield, put off not only by the commercial atmosphere of the town, but also by a feeling of emotional detachment from the battle, since no African-American soldiers had taken part in it.

title: Three Worlds in Three Nights at the McCarter
description: Princeton is internationally famous for its university, but the town beyond academe has other cultural sectors. On consecutive evenings this week, McCarter Theater points up the diversity in three very different concerts, in the process revealing plenty about fusion of forms and media.

title: Jennifer Fisk And Ian Novak
description: Jennifer Carol Fisk, a daughter of Pamela and Richard Fisk of Madison, Conn., was married there yesterday to Ian Mark Novak, a son of Major Dain Franks of Andrews Air Force Base, Md., and the late Stephen P. Novak. The Rev. David Parachini performed the ceremony at St. Andrew's Episcopal Church.

title: In America; A Cop Who Cared
description: Detective Investigator Juan Rodriguez, who died a little over a week ago, was the kind of cop you don't hear much about. He was 46 years old, skinny, wiry, tough, relentless and incorruptible. He was soft-spoken and a sucker for kids. He didn't strut, and he never engaged in macho games. But if you were a criminal or a corrupt cop and Juan Rodriguez knew about it, you had a problem.

title: Corrections
description: An answer in the Q & A column on May 16 about cruising to historic areas in the Southeast misstated the name of a cruise and a telephone number for the line. The Oct. 19 cruise on the Nantucket Clipper is ''America's Colonial Heritage Along the Intracoastal Waterway,'' not the Civil War site cruise. Clipper Lines' toll-free number is (800) 325-0010.

title: F.Y.I.
description: Big John's Legacy

title: Parolee Arrested in String of 19 Robberies
description: Police officers spotted a parolee wanted in a string of 19 robberies as they walked the Upper East Side of Manhattan Friday night and they arrested him, the police said.

title: Nationalist Group Fights for Identity in South Africa
description: The party whose slogan used to be ''one settler, one bullet'' is trying to stay in office by appealing to the nostalgia vote.

title: Lauren Steinfeld, Michael Knoll
description: Lauren Barnett Steinfeld, a lawyer, and Michael Steven Knoll, a law professor, are to be married this evening at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx. Rabbi Charles Kroloff is to officiate.

title: Passing the Endurance Test; Syrup in the Coke, Fizz in the Customers
description: Now this is a Coca-Cola classic. This Coke starts with three ounces of chestnut-brown syrup in a wide-mouth glass rich with ice. The glass is positioned under the nozzle of a soda fountain with a handle that looks like the throttle of a jet plane, and with a push of the handle seltzer fills the glass.

title: The View From/Wethersfield; Onion Fields to West Indies Trade, Museum Opens a New Exhibition
description: AS one of the earliest settlements in Connecticut, Wethersfield has always cherished its role in the state's history and understood the importance of preserving the landmarks of its past. To provide visitors with an overview of the town's heritage and direct them to its historic sites, the Wethersfield Historical Society developed a permanent exhibition entitled ''Legendary People, Ordinary Lives,'' which is at the Wethersfield Museum.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SALANT, JACK
description: SALANT-Jack. Died at age 91, on April 17, 1999. He was a devoted father and husband. He worked for over 40 years for the New York State Department of Insurance, and was President of the Association of New York State Insurance Department Examiners in 1953 and 1954. He served in the Air Force during World War II. He painted and wrote beautiful poetry. His intelligence, his extraordinary command of language, and his sense of humor were a source of delight to all who knew him.

title: Asia, Slowly Recovering, Still Offers Bargains
description: WITH the economies of most Asian nations appearing to be slowly on the mend, the region's airlines and hotels are no longer practically giving away their services, as they were less than a year ago. Nevertheless, there are still lots of travel bargains to Asia, and travelers whose plans can accommodate midweek departures, Saturday stays and other restrictions can save money, or at least enjoy an array of extras.

title: Script Doctoring
description: To the Editor:

title: May 23-29; Diplomacy and Betrayal
description: The balance of power between the United States and the United Nations is always tricky. And now former Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali, in his book ''Unvanquished: A U.S.-U.N. Saga,'' writes of his 1996 ouster, blaming it on caving in to Bob Dole's ''claim that American troops served under my 'command.' '' He feels especially betrayed by Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright, he says, accusing her of lecturing instead of doing ''the difficult diplomatic work of persuading.'' Ms. Albright's spokesman, James P. Rubin, said Mr. Boutros-Ghali had neglected his core duty: ''Smooth cooperation with the United States.''

title: U.S. May Try To Stop Loan Seen as Bad For Tibetans
description: The United States appears to be heading for another clash with China, this time over a divisive World Bank development loan that would help Chinese authorities resettle tens of thousands of Chinese in regions traditionally inhabited by Tibetans and Mongolians.

title: Onward, Christian Soldiers!
description: RED-HOT AND RIGHTEOUS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLAUS, IDA
description: KLAUS-Ida. The American Diabetes Association notes with sorrow the passing of its former secretary, Ida Klaus. Ms. Klaus was the secretary of the New York Diabetes Association and served on the executive committee during the late 1960's through the mid 1970's. She was a fundraiser par excellence and was instrumental in rekindling interest in membership, especially in the New York City area. Ms. Klaus was dedicated to the organization and will be missed by all who knew her.

title: Report Cards: How the Island's Fourth Graders Are Reading
description: The New York State Education Department released the first results of its new fourth-grade English Language Arts test last week, and the results were a disappointment to many parents and teachers across the state. The new test, administered over three days in January, was designed to measure how many fourth graders meet new standards requiring them to read complicated passages and write intelligently about them.

title: Mind Over Machine?
description: Sometimes it's the hardware. Sometimes it's the software. And sometimes it's just human error. Computer mistakes, malfunctions and glitches, beyond the obviously misdirected E-mail, continue to spread faster than a computer virus. What are your own most humorous or horrific stories? Send them to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: The Way We Live Now: 5-30-99; What They Were Thinking
description: Earl S. Cox

title: I'm Being Eaten Alive!
description: This season the battle against mosquitoes and other biting insects has become more sophisticated -- and stylish. Bugs B Wear of Minneapolis has a line of repellent-filled sterling silver jewelry. A frisky lemony-scented oil of lavender, citronella, lemongrass and spearmint is applied with a dropper in earrings, necklaces and, for the guys, stickpins, $27 each. Information: (877) 877-7879. ''You can take the jewelry off in the clubhouse for lunch, so you don't smell like insect repellent,'' Jill Johnson, the company's owner, said. Mosquito 'Cognito is a battery-powered citronella dispenser available from the Gardener's Supply Company catalogue for $29.95; (800) 863-1700. More militaristic additions to the arsenal include the Mosquito Killing Unit, $399.95; (877) 545-5667. It draws biting insects with heat, as does the Dragonfly, which uses carbon dioxide and a substance called octenol to lure biters. ''CO2 works like landing lights for biting insects,'' said Jim Nolen, president of Biosensory, which will sell the Dragonfly starting on Tuesday for $279, from www.biosensory.com or (860) 423-3009. Mosquito Magnet, $1,295, is a propane-fueled device that sucks bugs from the air. The American Biophysics Corporation, the machine's maker, says that in tests in the Florida Everglades, it caught 100,000 bugs a night. Available from (401) 884-3500 or www.mosquitomagnet.com. LINDA LEE

title: Director Joins Recital Of Chamber Music
description: FROM time to time, the pianist Joel Rosen, founder of Performers of Westchester who died last year, would appear at the private home recitals he started organizing 18 years ago. His successor as artistic director, the violinist and violist Alexander Simionescu, apparently plans to follow a similar path. Next weekend he will join the father-daughter team of the pianist Claude Frank and his daughter, the violinist and Avery Fisher Prize winner Pamela Frank, at the final concerts of the season: Friday at 8:30 P.M. in Harrison and next Sunday at 4 P.M. in Mamaroneck.

title: POSTINGS: $13.5 Million Project in Far West Village; 11-Story, 9-Unit Condo Being Built on West St.
description: Chances are that if a condominium looks like a warehouse or factory, it used to be a warehouse or factory.

title: In the Shadow Of the Boss
description: Q. I am a middle manager in a medium-sized company where nothing happens without the chief executive's approval. She is detail-oriented and strong-willed. Though some members of my staff get a charge from knowing that the chief is monitoring their projects, I wonder whether citing her wishes too often will undercut my own authority. This is of particular concern on those occasions when my staff and I are of one opinion, but the chief has other ideas. Should I present the boss's position as if I shared it, or make clear that I'm only carrying out her plans?

title: Schools Will Pay for Court Ruling; Protect Kids First
description: To the Editor:

title: Nourishing the Mungers
description: Like his friend Mr. Gates, Warren E. Buffett, the chairman of Berkshire Hathaway, plans to give away most of his wealth. Charles T. Munger, the vice chairman of Berkshire, has a different plan.

title: Take a Little Off the Top, Mulch and Feed
description: THE roar of the lawn mowers resounds everywhere. The annual ritual has begun. One fact that gardeners learn ever so slowly, though, is that the more the lawn is fed, the more the grass grows. Garden centers, nurseries and hardware stores have stacks of lawn fertilizer on sale each spring. Naturally they want to sell it. The homeowner responds by buying.

title: Lawrence Bershad, Linda Hartt
description: Linda Joan Hartt, a former social worker, and Prof. Lawrence Bershad, a law professor, were married last evening by Rabbi Paul Cohen at the Black Point Inn in Prout's Neck, Me.

title: May 23-29; An Unlawful Donor
description: Nearly three years after John Huang emerged as a central figure in the furor over how Democrats financed President Clinton's re-election, the Justice Department announced that Mr. Huang would plead guilty to a single felony charge of conspiring to make illegal contributions. Republicans dismissed the plea agreement as a sweetheart deal: Mr. Huang will receive no jail time in exchange for his continuing cooperation with authorities. Federal prosecutors will also clear him of charges contained in Congressional reports on the fund-raising issue that he may have had an espionage relationship with China. DAVID JOHNSTON

title: Too Much 'Ballyhoo'?
description: Too Much 'Ballyhoo?.'

title: Leslie Abbey, Stephen Dietz
description: Leslie Ann Abbey, the daughter of Diane and Arthur Abbey of Manhattan, is to be married this afternoon to Stephen Michael Dietz, a son of Carol and John H. Dietz of Portsmouth, R.I. The Rev. Richard D. Leonard is to perform the ceremony at the Unitarian Church of All Souls in Manhattan.

title: Front Desk? Send Up A Computer
description: WE may know how much to slip the bellhop for dragging the bags upstairs, but the modern hotel evokes a new question: How much do you tip him for tech support?

title: Monthly Rates to Rise For Cablevision Users
description: Cable television rates for more than half the 900,000 New Jersey customers of Cablevision, the state's largest cable provider, will increase by about 5.4 percent starting in July.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLICKSMAN, ABRAHAM M.
description: GLICKSMAN-Abraham M. On May 26, 1999. Beloved husband of Frances, loving father of Robert & Emilie, dear brother of Rosella Breinan, adored grandfather of Lisa & Michelle. He will be deeply missed. Service Sunday 9:30 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Cleaning and Repairing Screens
description: DURING the spring and summer months, homeowners keep their windows open to allow fresh air to circulate through the house. It is important to make sure the screens are clean before opening the windows; otherwise, dirt on the screens will blow into the house. Dirty screens can also obscure visibility and restrict air flow.

title: My New South African Identity
description: When I was young, in South Africa during the Second World War, I was far removed from the bombs, the nights in underground shelters, the rationed food, in Europe. I read reflections by those living through this experience, and these were not what I had in my mind as the way life must be, there; I had constructed their lives out of a projection of my own priorities in what makes life, my own fears of what would be most threatened in imagined circumstances.

title: Liberties; Here at The Ardsthorpe
description: Mr. Henry van der Luyden

title: May 23-29; Charitable Americans
description: Last year was good for charity: Americans donated a record $175 billion, 11 percent more than in 1997, according to Giving USA 1999, put out by the American Association of Fund-Raising Counsel's nonprofit arm. The only area that declined was the arts, culture and humanities (down about 1 percent). But donations jumped by 20 percent or more in environment and wildlife, health, human services and public benefit organizations (which includes civil rights groups, public affairs, consumer protection and scientific development).

title: Superstars Gravitate to a Super Scriptwriter
description: THE Shakespeare thing. Is it out of control? Like lemmings, Hollywood's bankable are rushing to throw themselves into the sea. Right now, Michelle Pfeiffer's Titania, queen of the fairies, is flitting through Michael Hoffman's ''Midsummer Night's Dream'' in starlit freefall. Soon to follow are Jessica Lange's Tamora, vicious Queen of the Goths, in Julie Taymor's ''Titus'' (a cinematic ''Titus Andronicus'') and Alicia Silverstone as the by no means clueless Princess of France in Kenneth Branagh's updated ''Love's Labour's Lost.'' The industry is smitten, cranking out Shakespeare as if there were no tomorrow. Tomorrow will come, though, right on schedule, and with it the reviews and grosses. At which point, the text for the day may well not be ''Once more unto the breach, dear friends, once more,'' but rather ''Our revels now are ended.''

title: In Defense of Private Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: As G.I. Joe Bulks Up, Concern For the 98-Pound Weakling
description: Just as Barbie dolls have taunted little girls with an impossible ideal of the female body, G.I. Joes have morphed over the last three decades into musclebound hunks that can harm the self esteem of boys, according to a new study.

title: Reading the Speedometer of G.M.'s Spinoff
description: ROUGHLY a million General Motors shareholders will get an unexpected present when they open their brokerage account statements for this month: about 70 shares of Delphi Automotive Systems for every 100 shares of G.M. they hold, the second part of G.M.'s divestiture of Delphi, its parts division. The question, of course, is whether to hold onto an untested auto parts company or to bail out by selling the shares and investing the money elsewhere.

title: Syracuse Advances To Title Match
description: Eighth-seeded Syracuse continued its surprising run in the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I tournament yesterday, advancing to the championship game for the 10th time by rallying to upset Georgetown, 13-9, in College Park, Md.

title: Software Bomb
description: In the first arrest of its kind in the county, the Westchester District Attorney's Office has charged a Katonah man with creating a software time bomb designed to destroy an employer's computer records.

title: Teen-Ager Is Shot by a Housing Officer
description: A plainclothes housing officer returned the gunfire of a teen-ager in Brooklyn on Friday night, wounding him, the police said. But the 16-year-old's family, including an aunt who said she had witnessed the shooting, denied yesterday that the youth had even had a gun.

title: Introduction
description: Responding to Lynn Hirschberg's article on Michael Ovitz, readers found new depths of meaning in Hollywood's definition of friendship. Mike Wise's profile of Latrell Sprewell prompted some fans to cry foul for looking too closely at the basketball star's behavior off the court.

title: Albright and Rwanda
description: To the Editor:

title: Celebrating a Somber Day With Flowers and Flags
description: ALTHOUGH Westchester is liberally dotted with memorials to veterans of the country's wars, for the better part of the year they are noticed only in passing.

title: Passing the Endurance Test; Job Projections Are Dim For the Movie Projectionists
description: Two projectors whirred away at 24 frames per second, casting the colored lights of ''Entrapment'' and ''Trippin' '' on the movie screens at the United Artists Criterion Theater in Times Square. Jim Anderson, 61, a film projectionist for 30 years, kept a wary eye on the machinery. A tall jovial man, Mr. Anderson took a drag on an unfiltered Pall Mall and delivered a glum assessment of his profession's future. ''It looks like there won't be any projectionists anymore,'' he said.

title: Lukas Makes Himself Seen And Heard Once Again
description: He calls them box-office horses, superstars that can put a stable on the racing map. D. Wayne Lukas found his first one 26 years ago in a gray mare named Native Empress whom he had claimed for $3,500. She was one of seven horses the coach-turned-trainer showed up with at Los Alamitos race track in California.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISS, KATHRYN ELIZABETH RYAN
description: WEISS-Kathryn Elizabeth Ryan, of Sewickley, PA, 84, died peacefully in her sleep at home after a short illness on May 27th, 1999. A native of NYC, Mrs. Weiss was the widow of Robert E. Weiss. She is survived by 4 children and 7 grandchildren. Interment in St. Joseph's Cemetery, Sommers, NY

title: Claudia Myers, Michael Pedroni
description: Claudia Emmanuelle Myers, a daughter of Myrna and Samuel Myers of Paris, was married yesterday at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden to Michael Nicholas Pedroni, a son of Monika and Peter N. Pedroni of Oxford, Ohio. Cantor Bernard Fitch officiated, with the Rev. Henry Fehrenbacher, a Roman Catholic priest, taking part.

title: BENEFITS
description: A Musical Farewell

title: A Notable Foundry Operates in Williamsburg
description: To the Editor:

title: Belgrade Sentences 3 From CARE As Spies
description: Two Australian aid workers and a Yugoslav colleague today received long prison sentences from a military court after being found guilty of charges of espionage.

title: Liberty's Broken Shackles, Like Toes, Are Hard to See
description: To the Editor:

title: Hello Son, Hello Daughter, Here I Am at Camp Myself
description: FOUR years ago, the Snowshoe Mountain ski area in West Virginia looked into ways to tap the rich markets of the Northeast and the mid-Atlantic states in the off season. Mike Valache, a manager, settled on a mountain-biking camp for 12- to 18-year-olds.

title: In Split Vote, Arts Council Approves Kosovar Program
description: The New Jersey Council on the Arts voted last week to set aside $10,000 to pay artists to work with the approximately 1,500 Kosovar refugee children at Fort Dix. The vote was 10 to 4; anything but unanimous votes by the council are rare.

title: Knee Surgery Uses Patient's Own Cells
description: DEBORAH MORAN caught her toe in a baby safety gate reaching for her 2 1/2-year-old son, Andrew, and landed full force on her knee. Her doctor recommended physical therapy and ultrasound. That did not work, and her pain was getting worse. ''I could barely walk,'' she said in a recent telephone conversation from her home in Mahopac.

title: You Gotta Have Ideas
description: You're MISSIN' A Great Game From Casey to Ozzie, the Magic of Baseball and How to Get It Back. By Whitey Herzog and Jonathan Pitts. Illustrated. 314 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $25.

title: Michael Ovitz Is On the Line
description: I couldn't care less whether Michael Ovitz's feelings have been hurt or that his former best friends felt betrayed and angry. Talk about a pathetic bunch of people -- spoiled, rich, out of touch, childish and, frankly, sad. The only thing they ever do that is worth a damn is make movies.

title: Michael Ovitz Is On the Line
description: David Geffen's definition of friendship -- If you scratch my back, I'll scratch yours'' -- is actually the definition of a commercial transaction. Referring to Ovitz and his inability to scratch anyone's back, Geffen goes on to say that someone like that cannot be a friend. He's right. But making deals and creating agencies and having financial rewards are business transactions, not friendships, no matter how much of your life you spend doing them.

title: Corrections
description: A caption last Sunday with an article about the safety and cleanliness of beaches in Westchester County misidentified a beach shown in two photographs. It was at Glen Island Park, not Davis Island Park.

title: Sports of The Times; A Popularity Contest And a Friendship
description: THEY have partied together, and lived together, and cried together. Mark Jackson confides in his best friend, Dave Snowden, and so he has logged on to his computer several times this past week and E-mailed his unexpurgated forecasts of how the Knicks-Indiana Pacers showdown will go.

title: JERSEYANA; Hitler's Scattered Remnants
description: Not much happens in Florence, unless the American Legion decides to hold a dance or the girls' softball team wins big. The steel mill in nearby Roebling, which once thrived here in the Delaware Valley, shut down 25 years ago and Florence's own pipe factory, in the shadows of the Pennsylvania Turnpike Bridge, is gradually downsizing.

title: D.H. Dims Yanks
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Pacers Have Many Reasons to Get Going
description: Each player has a different reason, but the Indiana Pacers are desperate to get the Eastern Conference finals under way. Seven straight playoff-game victories and seven straight days off have made them a little cranky.

title: Matthew Koff and Leah Rose
description: Leah Silberfarb Rose, the daughter of Anne and Dr. Peter Silberfarb of Norwich, Vt., is to be married this morning to Matthew Douglas Koff, the son of Barbara and Michael Koff of White Plains. Rabbi Michael Paley is to officiate at the Trapp Family Lodge in Stowe, Vt.

title: They Don't Want to Get Involved
description: One Case At A Time Judicial Minimalism on the Supreme Court. By Cass R. Sunstein. 290 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $29.95.

title: Spree-ality
description: While singling out Latrell Sprewell, Mike Wise (May 2) failed to acknowledge any number of other problems that have plagued the Knicks during this strike-shortened season, including poor point-guard play, an inability to pull down rebounds on either end of the court and an offensive scheme that revolves around an aging and highly immobile center. One thing is clear: when Sprewell is on the court, the Knicks are actually entertaining. Basketball is supposed to be about fun, right?

title: Legs with that freshly-plucked-chicken look.
description: Inspired by the successful reintroduction of sheer stockings like Donna Karan Nudes, Estee Lauder has come out with Bare Legs, a light waterproof liquid makeup that is meant to mask varicose veins, nicks and other imperfections. The product, which is $25 for a 1.7-ounce tube at Estee Lauder counters in department stores, cosmetics stores and some drug chains, is matched to your leg color. After an application, Bare Legs didn't streak like self-tanners, and while it did give the impression of stockings, it seemed better suited for evening use, unless you like the look of pantyhose with shorts.

title: The Way We Live Now: 5-30-99: The Ethicist; Father's Day
description: A year ago, I got pregnant. The guy in question acknowledged his financial responsibility but clearly wasn't ready to be a parent. I was, however, so I told him it was a choice I was making on my own, and I quite willingly relieved him of any obligation. Since then I've entered a committed relationship with another guy, who loves and cares for my baby daughter. But now her biological father has decided he made a bad mistake, and wants a part of her life, too. He's a decent guy, but I barely know him, and if it had been up to him she would have never been born. What do I owe him?

title: Composing 'Wozzeck'
description: To the Editor:

title: Editorial Observer; Where Will Hillary Clinton Love New York?
description: Bill and Hillary Clinton are said to be planning a vacation in New York this summer. The First Lady needs to learn more about the state she might like to represent in the Senate, but their problem is where exactly to go.

title: MetroStars End Their Scoring Drought, but Still Fall Short
description: Scoring goals is not the strength of the MetroStars and the New England Revolution, who had produced eight goals each in nine games this season.

title: What do you mean you don't have the directions?
description: From now on, listen to your car. This week, Mercedes-Benz will introduce the S500 sedan, with a gizmo-happy control panel that includes a hand-free voice-activated phone, a complex stereo player and a vocal satellite navigational system. Program in any address in the United States, and a friendly female voice gently guides you there. Make a wrong turn, and it automatically adjusts a new route, which is a good thing: With her talking to you, and you talking to the phone and scrolling through the stereo, it's no wonder you missed the exit. The car starts at $77,850.

title: Despite Grim Test Scores, a School Marks Its Small Triumphs
description: The day was winding down in a hectic week for Magalie Pierre's class of fourth graders at Public School 129 in Harlem, and so a party was in order.

title: The Nation; Right to Bear Arms: A Second Look
description: THE Second Amendment, the orphan of the Bill of Rights, has been written off as a legal backwater for decades. Judges and legal scholars have glossed over its guarantee of the right ''to keep and bear arms'' as if it were so much propaganda for the National Rifle Association.

title: The Next Job Perk: Elder Care for Parents
description: MARILEE CRISPINO said she had always dreamed of retiring at age 55. Now it's definite, but hardly as pleasurable a prospect as she had anticipated. She is ''hoping and praying,'' she said, that she can juggle office and home responsibilities until June 9, 2000, when she will quit being an administrative assistant at the New York State United Teachers in Hauppauge and devote her days to caring for her 81-year-old mother, who has Alzheimer's disease.

title: Spending Social Security
description: To the Editor:

title: Rebecca Flaste, David Karson
description: Rebecca Jo Flaste, the daughter of Dale J. Flaste of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and Richard A. Flaste of Manhattan, was married in Brooklyn on Thursday to David Harris Karson, a son of Barry M. Karson of Manhattan and the late Myra L. Karson. Justice Elliott Wilk of State Supreme Court in Manhattan, a cousin of the bridegroom, officiated at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.

title: Corrections
description: The Frugal Traveler article on May 16 about Bangkok referred incorrectly to the king who popularized jazz in Thailand. Bhumibol Adulyadej is the reigning King, not a former one.

title: Ms. Sutherland And Mr. Woodruff
description: Shelley Wagstaff Sutherland, a daughter of Beatrice Wagstaff Ingham of Locust Valley, N.Y., and Donald J. Sutherland of Glen Head, N.Y., was married yesterday to James Ray Woodruff Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Woodruff of Georgetown, Ky. The Rev. Ray Holdren, a Disciples of Christ minister, officiated at the home of Dr. and Mrs. Philip Corbett, friends of the couple, in Nicholasville, Ky.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHUSSLER, OLGA
description: SCHUSSLER-Olga (Matyas). On May 26, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Max Schussler, mother of Dr. George Schussler of NYC, grandmother of Abraham, Helen, Naomi, Edith, Miriam, Benjamin and Lilli Schussler and great-grandmother of Nina Schussler and Hannah Mermin. Burial today at the Jewish Community Cemetery, Berlin, Germany.

title: Passing the Endurance Test; The Bubbly That's Drunk Daily, Not Hoarded for the Millennium
description: With his bubbly effervescence and bottomless loquaciousness, you would swear that seltzer spritzes through Walter Backerman's veins. Indeed, seltzer has been the lifeblood of the Backerman family.

title: Votes in Congress
description: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York.

title: A New Version Of Adventure For the Kids
description: A playground seen as innovative when it was built in 1967 at Public School 166 on West 89th Street is to be demolished this week after years of concerns about its safety. A new $1 million playground, open to the public, will go up in its place.

title: OUT THERE: Los Angeles; If Billboards Make It Here, They'll Make It Anywhere
description: FOR 16 years, the brooding Marlboro Man made of plywood and paint was the colossus of the Sunset Strip. But now that most prominent billboard on the curving avenue of nightclubs and hotels is gone. In his place is a parody of Marlboro's icon of machismo: a cowboy puffing on a limp cigarette, with a vertical message proclaiming ''Impotent'' and underneath the warning, ''Smoking Causes Impotence.''

title: INSIDE
description: Indonesia's Giddy Chaos

title: Veronica Poon and Kevin Kogler
description: Veronica Jeanne Poon and Kevin Todd Kogler are to be married this afternoon in Sonoma, Calif. The Rev. Nancy Hargis, a minister of the Church of Religious Science, will perform a nondenominational ceremony at the Garden Pavilion, a private house.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Arts Headquarters Debut

title: A Peacenik Goes to War
description: Think of Abbie Hoffman or Jerry Rubin, yesteryear's counterculture icons, and imagine them as Secretary of State today. That will give you a first approximation of Joschka Fischer, 51, the onetime political prankster, street fighter and revolutionary who was sworn in as Germany's Foreign Minister last fall.

title: In the Region / New Jersey; Jersey City Seeing Riverfronts Activity
description: TWO speculative office buildings now rising on Jersey City's Hudson River waterfront have been or will soon be fully leased in less than a year, prompting their developers to start new office towers and other developers to start their own projects.

title: Susan Thomas And Tin Albano
description: Susan Gregory Thomas, the daughter of Susan D. Gries of Washington and W. Dugal Thomas of Durham, N.H., was married yesterday to Ireneo Martini Roldan Albano, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Ireneo Valdes Albano of Todt Hill, Staten Island. Judge Stephen F. Williams of the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit performed the ceremony at the Cosmos Club in Washington.

title: Lives; Commencement
description: Staring into the case of jewelry on the second floor of Tiffany, Elizabeth picks out her college graduation present: a necklace, a tiny silver bean linked to a thin silver chain. We go outside, on a cool and sunny spring day, and walk arm in arm west on 57th Street, the burnished necklace bright beneath her jet-black hair. I think about the ordinary miracle of rearing my only daughter to adulthood.

title: THEATER; Unlocking Broadway: Outsiders Seek the Key
description: LAURIE, a novelist and the main character in ''Hurrah at Last,'' a new play opening on Thursday at the Gramercy Theater, has reached the point in his career when he would like his work to be not only rarefied but read.

title: The Director's Voice
description: To the Editor:

title: The Way We Live Now: 5-30-99: Word & Image; The Pulitzer Paradox
description: I was planning this week merely to pick on the Pulitzer Prizes, but after jotting down a few complaints, I found myself propelled onto another plane: to contemplate the Pulitzer paradox.

title: Mara Kapelovitz and Adam Goldman
description: Mara Ilise Kapelovitz and Adam Micah Goldman are to be married today by Rabbi Fred Greenspahn at the Phipps Mansion in Denver.

title: Q. & A.
description: A Personal Residence Trust

title: The Great Ape Massacre
description: Perhaps it's better to have one swift bullet to the brain by a poacher than to be ripped from a family unit in a natural habitat, caged, sent to a research laboratory and ultimately killed in the name of AIDS research.

title: In Defense of Private Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: May 30, 1999
description: Weeks

title: Golf's Hypocrisy
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: White Lines
description: HEAT

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOELZ, SHIRLEY J.
description: GOELZ-Shirley J. On May 25, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Charles V. Goelz. Devoted mother of Adam and Joshua Galef and Peter and Thomas Goelz. Loving sister of Eleanor Stillman. Also survived by five grandchildren and two nieces. Funeral private. Contributions in her memory to the Project Reachout Division of the Goddard Riverside Comm. Center, 593 Columbus Ave., NY, New York 10024 would be appreciated. A memorial service will be scheduled at a later date.

title: Notes From a Huge Landmass
description: I'M A STRANGER

title: Rosalinda Rubio, James Williams
description: Rosalinda Rubio and James Robert Williams were married yesterday in New York. The Rev. William Bergen performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola.

title: Marianne Magid and Ian Jones
description: Marianne Eve Magid, a daughter of Caryn and James I. Magid of New York, is to be married this afternoon at her parents' house in Weston, Conn., to Ian Joachim Jones, the son of Teresita and Roy G. Jones of Westwood, N.J. Rabbi Ari Fridkis is to officiate with the Rev. Mary McNamara, a Presbyterian minister.

title: Three Friends, Stars in College, Are Now Role Players in the Semifinals
description: All three were taken in the first round of the 1991 draft, and all asked to wear No. 2 jerseys with their new teams. They also entered the National Basketball Association after a bitter Final Four experience.

title: The Fresh Air Fund; Children Spread Wings at a Camp
