description: Viewed from across the lake on a recent misty morning, the scene resembled a Norman Rockwell painting: a boy on a bridge with his baseball cap turned backward, shouting with joy as he caught his first fish of the day.

title: Raising the Stakes In a Purcell Opera
description: WHEN performers make new recording alliances, they often start by revisiting favorite works. Ideally, they do so for good reasons: their ideas have changed, or scholarship has yielded new perspective on a work. Just as likely, though, the motivation is more mundane. The earlier recording may have run its course in sales and been deleted or reduced to midprice, and the new contract may offer more favorable royalty provisions.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: CENTRAL PARK -- BUZZ; Flocking to Watch Warblers Warble
description: THE SETTING -- On a hill overlooking the lake in the Central Park Ramble, the Price Is Right Bird Club and the Early Birders converged at 9 A.M. on a recent Saturday, comparing binoculars and field notes in the best warbler season in years.

title: Portland
description: Of the three West Coast sisters, the Portland historian Terence O'Donnell once said, San Francisco grew up as the debutante, Seattle the tart and Portland the spinster. That characterization never bothered most people in Oregon's biggest city very much -- they were content with their demure hometown, and just as happy that the rest of the country didn't pay it undue attention.

title: Knicks Adjust For the Pacers
description: In their fourth straight day of practice, the Knicks worked for two hours today before departing for Indiana, where they will face the Pacers in Game 1 of the Eastern Conference finals on Sunday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PASSERMAN, MIRIAM R.
description: PASSERMAN-Miriam R. On May 26, 1999. In her 98th year, of Boca Raton, FL. Formerly of NYC and Chappaqua, NY. She was acknowledged to have been the oldest Alumna of the Columbia School of Journalism, Class of 1925. Beloved wife of the late Maxwell W. Daughter of the late Charles and Sarah Rosenthal. Loving mother of Louise Rosenfeld and Steven Passerman. Dear mother-in-law of Gabriel Rosenfeld and Harriet Passerman. Adored grandmother of Eric Rosenfeld, Alison R. Desmarais, Dr. Leslie R. Wash, Toni Passerman, David Passerman, Shari P. Turner and Charles Passerman. Cherished great grandmother of Evan and Sarabeth Turner. Service Sunday, May 30, 1999 11:15AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th St., and Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the American Jewish Historical Society, 15 West 16th Street, New York, N.Y. 10011.

title: Charting a Prodigy's Progress
description: 'FOR THE END OF TIME'

title: Colleges Still Try To Gut Title IX
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Sonia Gandhi's Defenders
description: To the Editor:

title: With the Ailing Ewing, The Spirit Is Willing
description: Patrick Ewing is as stubborn as a grass stain on white linen. As he marched defiantly down a set of stairs leading from the practice floor to a locker room last week, he shook his head ''no'' like a toddler to every question floating in his wake.

title: Lisa Liu, James Grady
description: Lisa Anne Liu, the daughter of Midori Liu and Dr. Donald Liu of Houston, was married yesterday to James Henry Grady, the son of Irene C. Grady of Ridgewood, N.J., and the late James H. Grady. The Rev. Tim Mills, a nondenominational minister, officiated at the Hans Fahden Vineyards in Calistoga, Calif.

title: AT A SIDEWALK CAFE WITH: Josh Patner and Bryan Bradley; Everything's Coming Up Froufrou
description: OVER lunch at a sidewalk table on Madison Avenue, Josh Patner and Bryan Bradley took one look at a young woman hurrying by in a navy blue pinstripe suit and shook their heads sadly.

title: INVESTING WITH: Charles Albers; Oppenheimer Main Street Growth and Income Fund
description: IN April 1998, Charles E. Albers moved his computer models from Park Avenue to Main Street. Or, to be more exact, from the Guardian Park Avenue fund, where he had been manager for 26 years, to Main Street Income and Growth, managed by the Oppenheimer Funds.

title: A Big Backyard In the Bronx; Gorillas' New Home Charms Young, as Elders Stay Back
description: A large gorilla sits on top of a tree, gazing toward infinity, while two young gorilla twins hug each other, then scamper playfully up a rock. Others concentrate purposefully on peeling tasty leaves off branches. A tall female stands as erect as a human and dances a jig. Youngsters pound their chests like little King Kongs.

title: The Way We Live Now: 5-30-99: On Language; We/Us
description: In her annual address to her subjects, Queen Elizabeth II updated the ''out of the mouths of babes'' idea with this observation: ''The young can sometimes be wiser than us.''

title: Sunken Treasure
description: It's not as hot as the Titanic, and Leonardo DiCaprio was never in a movie about it. But the Andrea Doria was also a luxurious cruise ship, and was filled with so many paintings, tapestries and sculptures that it was called a floating art gallery. And like the Titanic, the Italian liner made big news when it sank at sea, in 1956, after colliding with a Swedish ship off the coast of Sandy Hook. Many divers searched 250 feet below the surface to get at the riches. Among them was John Moyer of Vineland, who in 1993 was granted exclusive salvage rights by a Federal judge. The Ocean Life Center at Historic Gardner's Basin in Atlantic City is now displaying some of his finds, including the liner's bell, its steering helm and brass-framed windows as well as crystal and silver trays from first class. There are also deck plans, passenger diaries and newspaper and magazine articles on the sinking. The exhibition will continue through Labor Day; it is open 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. daily. Admission is $6; $5 for the elderly; $4 for children 4 to 12.

title: 37th Avenue as Memory Lane
description: MEMORIES collide along 37th Avenue, Jackson Heights's oldest commercial artery. The nostalgia of one people must coexist with the nostalgia of another, the hankering for a bygone era competes with the longing for a homeland left behind. Entire city blocks are reconfigured to suit these competing desires.

title: Upper East Side Story
description: When you're Robert A. M. Stern, dean of the Yale School of Architecture, and someone plans a condo tower blocking the view from your Upper East Side apartment, what do you do? First, you join Tony Randall and others to protest.

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: LOWER EAST SIDE

title: POSTINGS: $62 Million for 57th Street Structure and Lease on Land; Steinway Buys Its Building
description: Since 1925, Steinway & Sons has sold pianos and played host to great pianists in its elegant store at Steinway Hall, at 111 West 57th Street, between the Avenue of the Americas and Seventh Avenue.

title: Extravagant Fantasies a Collector Made Real
description: STORIES abound of millionaires with surly tempers, put-on airs and bad taste. Few stories, however, tell of anyone like Carlos de Beistegui, an international dandy whose character flaws were myriad but whose esthetic sense caused him to be widely admired as a rich man who deserved to be rich.

title: Setting the Universe's Clock
description: One of the rules of perspective, which nearly everyone understands intuitively, is that distant objects only appear to be smaller than nearby objects. But imagine a world in which distant objects appear younger than nearby objects, and younger not only on the narrow time scale of years or generations, but on an evolutionary time scale. In a world like that you would confront the paradox of looking at a horse on the distant horizon and seeing not a modern horse but its distant ancestor, running rapidly, as it happens, away from you. The same horse, if it chose in its solipsistic modernity to look your way, would see only the rapidly receding ancestral human in you. This would be a hard world in which to measure time or distance.

title: A Funky Roadhouse That Lures Families
description: A CANNONBALL shot down the center aisle of most Shelter Island restaurants on a recent Friday night would not have hit anybody. Even the early bird specials weren't drawing flies on this cool, crisp evening. The summer people hadn't arrived, and the locals seemed to still be hibernating.

title: 3 in Crime Spree Are Denied Parole
description: Three of five defendants in one of the most vicious crime sprees in the Island's history were refused parole last week.

title: 3 East End Hospitals Discussing Merger
description: Swept up in changes transforming health care on Long Island, three community hospitals on the East End of Suffolk County are discussing a merger that could be closely followed by a sponsorship agreement with North Shore-Long Island Jewish Health System, the Island's largest health network.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOORSCH, JOHN PETER
description: BOORSCH-John Peter. Age 54, of Princeton, NJ, on May 28, 1999. He leaves his wife Dorothea Dietrich, his father Jean Boorsch of North Haven, CT, his brother James of New Milford, CT, and his sisters Suzanne of New York City and Mary Louise Vogler of Redding, CT. He was a painter, graphic designer and educator, and a friend to many. A memorial service in Princeton will be announced for a later date.

title: Treating Dysfunction With Sugar
description: EVERY wacky family is wacky in its own way. But if you've seen enough plays about the genetically dysfunctional, they're all alike.

title: Feminism's Unlikely Heroine
description: AUDITIONING for a soap commercial, the aspiring actress Ann Marie, played by Marlo Thomas, is told by an executive that she has the look of ''every mother's child.'' That's enough to wipe the well-scrubbed, firmly fixed smile off the face of a young woman trying her hardest to be anything but.

title: In Defense of Private Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: Martinez Has Advice for Wright: Listen
description: At the age of 27, Pedro Martinez is not exactly the wise old veteran offering the benefit of his experience to the youth sitting at his knee. But 23-year-old Jaret Wright would probably do well to heed Martinez's advice because he knows whereof he speaks.

title: Ursula Hotchner, And Jay Gwynne
description: Ursula Lotte Hotchner and Jay Merle Gwynne were married last evening at the Central Presbyterian Church in New York. The Rev. Dr. Thomas A. Hughart, the senior pastor, officiated. The Rev. Richard Pokora, a Lutheran minister, took part in the ceremony.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the F.Y.I. column last Sunday about various Main Streets in New York City misstated a traffic regulation for the one on Roosevelt Island. Private cars are indeed permitted.

title: May 23-29; A School's Responsibility
description: As the Supreme Court interpreted Federal laws over the years to provide protection against sexual harassment, uncertainty remained over whether any law even applied to harassment of one student by another. Now, as a result of a bitterly fought 5-to-4 ruling, school districts are on notice that they can be sued for failing to stop severe and pervasive harassment in the classroom.

title: Pop! Goes the Bubble
description: HAS E-phoria ended? Highflying Internet stocks look mighty weak. Even on Friday, when other Nasdaq stocks were strong, many Internet shares couldn't muster their typical big moves up. As the week ended, shares of Internet concerns were well off their mid-April peaks. The Interactive Week index of 50 stocks is down 17 percent from its highs, while Thestreet.com index of 20 Net companies has fallen 26 percent since April 12.

title: Ms. Paxton And Mr. Johnson
description: Alexandra Marie Paxton, the daughter of Leslie and Glenn G. Paxton of Ojai, Calif., is to be married this afternoon to James Alexis Johnson, a son of Rufina and Harold E. Johnson Jr. of Fairfax, Va. The Rev. Shirley L. Paxton, a Presbyterian minister and an aunt of the bride, will perform the ceremony at the Church at Little Point Sable in Shelby, Mich.

title: Chelsea's New Palette
description: The weekend fashion look of the 1990's has met its understated match in the new art gallery district, right out of Edward Hopper, between 10th and 11th Avenues from 22d to 24th Streets. When many galleries quit the commercial frenzy of SoHo for this quiet section of Chelsea, the designer Rei Kawakubo followed, opening a gallerylike Comme des Garcons store at 520 West 22d Street. One woman was spotted wearing Ms. Kawakubo's lace-front dress (two views, below). The scene attracts plenty of other fashionable browsers, some of them artists who have already made a name for themselves (left, Brice Marden and his wife, Helen; below, second from right, Kiki Smith). One Saturday, a street artist, above, unrolled a carpet pad and spray-painted his message, then rode away on his bicycle.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about buying and picking strawberries misstated the Web address for information about pick-your-own farms. It is www.agmkt.state.ny.us.

title: Amid a Field of Stars, Sir Bear Takes the Metropolitan
description: Sir Bear, who was making the 44th start of his long career, showed that he was still a warrior at the age of 6 yesterday when he streaked through the homestretch at Belmont Park and won the Metropolitan Handicap against a field of stars.

title: Help Wanted: Low Salary, No Benefits, Little Respect
description: THE labor shortage created by the strong economy has done more than send Connecticut companies searching for skilled workers. It has also created a labor squeeze in classrooms, forcing schools around the state to scramble for substitute teachers, who can often make more money doing just about anything else.

title: Assessing the New, Tougher Tests
description: FOR many years, principals and administrators across Westchester could look forward to the state's elementary school reading test as a cause for celebration and self-affirmation: Almost all students tested met the state's minimum competency standards.

title: The Deep Slush at Bankers Trust
description: PORING over records at the Bankers Trust Corporation in early 1994, New York State auditors discovered something strange: Millions of dollars in unclaimed customer funds had disappeared.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALSH, PETER
description: WALSH-Peter. The entire family of St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center mourns the passing of the former Assistant to the President, Peter Walsh. An invaluable asset to the hospital center for over a quarter century, his cheerful spirit and dedication to our patients will never be forgotten. To his sister Rosemary and to his entire family, we offer our profound condolences. Sigurd H. Ackerman, MD President Carlton Boxhill, MD President of the Medical Board

title: Jerome L. Greene Dies at 93; Wide-Ranging Philanthropist
description: Jerome L. Greene, a lawyer, real estate investor and benefactor of Columbia Law School, Montefiore Medical Center and the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, died on Thursday at his residence in the Carlyle Hotel in Manhattan. He was 93.

title: The Glass Half Empty
description: It is significant that Knapp did not say medicine had found a cure for depression. An antidepressant user herself, she notes this solution to depression can be elusive and hard to maintain. Consider, for example, the massive use of antidepressants by young people. Rather than having found a cure for depression, we seem to be experiencing an epidemic of it.

title: May 23-29; Day and Night Trading
description: Citing demand from individuals who want to use the Internet to trade stocks outside of the normal market hours of 9:30 A.M. to 4 P.M., the Nasdaq Stock Market is planning an evening trading session, lasting as late as 10, to begin later this year. The New York Stock Exchange's board will consider a similar proposal when it meets on Thursday. Some Wall Street professionals expect that stock markets will soon be open around the clock -- just like casinos.

title: Times Sq. Dreamer or Visionary, He Hopes for a Better Deal
description: Real estate developers branded Charles B. Moss Jr. a hopeless romantic and worse last year after he walked away from a $92 million deal at his Broadway block front between 44th and 45th Streets.

title: The View From/Yorktown; Antique Apples Reveal Couple's Earthy Side
description: LIKE unofficial summer, the fruit at Orchard Hill here is just beginning. By Labor Day, apples will hang, crimson and russet and golden from the trees, but now, on Memorial Day weekend, they are little nubbins virtually the same green as the leaves surrounding them.

title: Using Fewer Shrimps but With Added Emphasis
description: SHRIMPS are crowd pleasers. Caterers will tell you that when shrimps are called for, they prepare extra because guests always eat more than expected.

title: Baseball Books in Brief
description: Born To Play

title: West Harrison Spot Offers Taste of the Sea
description: AS May begins to fade and thoughts of a beach vacation grow stronger, diners might appease their sea longings with a meal at Aquario. If visual aids can help, survey the sundry seascapes decking the walls of the ample dining room. If food can provide transport, Aquario will convey those who are sea starved instantly to the shore.

title: Commercial Property /Lexington and Third Avenues, 42d and 43d Streets; The Making of the Chrysler Center
description: WHEN Tishman Speyer Properties acquired the landmarked Chrysler Building, with its stainless steel peak, gargoyles and elaborate lobby, it also took possession of a far less glamorous structure at the other end of the block on 42d Street, an office building with the address of 666 Third Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEINMAN, HERBERT
description: KLEINMAN-Herbert. On May 18, 1999 at the age of 66. Beloved brother of Rosalind Shattan. Adoring uncle of Michael and Linda Shattan and Debbie Shattan. Services were held privately.

title: Keeping the Name Alive
description: Edsel B. Ford 2d, who ran the Ford Motor Company's car loan division from 1991 until he stepped down a year ago, is now working on museums and charities.

title: Just a Little Kid in a Man's Body
description: My legs can't move like others' can,

title: Word for Word/Spokane County, Wash.; Stop Whining, City-Slickers, Or, How the West Isn't Always Fun
description: IF you're anything like the pampered, reluctant farmer's wife played by Eva Gabor in ''Green Acres'' -- ''Dahling, I love you, but give me Park Avenue'' -- then you definitely want to think twice about moving to rural Washington state.

title: The Results Are in for Fourth-Grade Reading Tests. Now What?
description: WITH summer near, fourth graders throughout Long Island are far more interested in their vacation plans than in the English Language Arts test they took several months ago. That's not the case for their teachers and school administrators, who are trying to make sense of results of the exam released last week by the State Education Department.

title: May 23-29; Embryo Research
description: Should scientists be allowed to experiment on abandoned human embryos, the tiny spheres of cells often generated in excess by fertility clinics? The National Bioethics Advisory Commission signaled it would approve a specific use: the removal from embryos of the all-purpose stem cells, which generate all the tissues and organs of the body. Biologists hope these cells may directly replace damaged tissues, including brain cells lost in Parkinson's disease.

title: Sharpshooter
description: THE NIGHT INSPECTOR

title: Slamming the Closet Door
description: OUT FOR GOOD

title: Baseball Books in Brief
description: WHERE'S HARRY?

title: Conference Confronts the Difficulties of Being Muslim and Gay
description: Saying they came together out of loneliness and faith, a small group of men and women who are both gay and Muslim gathered yesterday in Manhattan to explore the tricky question of how to reconcile their sexual orientation with their religion.

title: Ms. Pearlstein and Dr. Chyba
description: Deborah Naomi Pearlstein, a law clerk, and Dr. Christopher F. Chyba, a planetary scientist, were married yesterday on Kent Island in Maryland. The Rev. Dr. Paul DeBeer, a Presbyterian minister, officiated at the Kent Manor Inn. Don Steiner, a member of Congregation Agudat Achim, a synagogue in Schenectady, N.Y., took part in the interfaith ceremony.

title: A Day to Nudge Us Out to the State's Memorials
description: ALTHOUGH Connecticut is dotted with memorials to veterans, for the better part of the year they are noticed only in passing. They may appear in news stories after they are vandalized or mentioned in driving directions, but most of the time they tend to be like the suit that's taken out of the closet only for weddings and funerals.

title: Whitman's Shift on Abortion Isn't Such a Surprise After All
description: It happened with such dazzling speed, that it would be easy to overlook the significance of Governor Whitman's decision to support a proposed new law that would force teen-agers to notify a parent before they could get an abortion.

title: From 'Turandot' to a Puppet 'Hamlet' in Bulgaria
description: The term ''European Cultural Month'' sells Plovdiv99 very short. The international arts festival that began Friday in this historic Bulgarian city will last for two months and promises to assemble more than 2,500 artists and performers from Eastern Europe and countries as far away as India, Japan and the United States.

title: Brook Meinhardt and Peter Moe
description: Brook Meinhardt and Peter Moe are to be married this evening in Clement Clarke Moore Park in New York. The Rev. Whiting Tennis, a minister of the Universal Life Church, will officiate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWADRON, LAWRENCE
description: SCHWADRON-Lawrence (Larry). Son of Benjamin & Bertha (deceased). Much cherished partner of Jean. Beloved brother of Jack (deceased) & Thelma, Meyer (deceased) & Shirley Steinkohl and Ann & Lee Yarden. Much beloved uncle of Howard & Debbie, Lori & Glenn, Richard & Debbie, Linda & Chris, Joan & Rob, Randi and Paul. And beloved great uncle. Funeral on Sunday 11 A.M., at Riverside Memorial Chapel, New York.

title: Jill Gulker and Todd Miller
description: Jill Karen Gulker, a daughter of Susan and Howard Gulker of Upper Saddle River, N.J., is to be married this evening to Dr. Todd Stuart Miller, the son of Susan Miller and Dr. Stephen I. Miller of Marlboro, N.J. Rabbi David Rosenzweig is to perform the ceremony at the Park Avenue Synagogue in Manhattan.

title: Female Yacht Manager Is an America's Cup First
description: When Dawn Riley, the skipper and founder of a San Francisco America's Cup syndicate, introduced the Mayor here at her yacht's christening last Wednesday, she referred to him as ''Millie.'' His name is Willie.

title: Bodegas Closed. Owners Cry Foul.
description: The Dume-Checo Grocery on the southeast corner of 162d Street and Fort Washington Avenue is boarded up and padlocked. The bodega had been operating on the ground floor of a residential building for 12 years before the city's Department of Buildings shut it down last month, said the president of the Dominican-Hispanic Chamber of Commerce, Jose D. Marte.

title: Henry James's View
description: To the Editor:

title: The World: Trading Places; Ground Wars Make Strange Bedfellows
description: IS Kosovo a liberal cause? A conservative one?

title: Writing, Loving, Fighting and Holding On
description: Dash and Lilly. Lilly and Dash. The two, Dashiell Hammett and Lillian Hellman, were married to others when they met in 1930. He was 36; she was 23. He was the acclaimed author of detective novels like ''The Maltese Falcon.'' She was an aspiring writer who saw the older man as a mentor, critic and lover. Their tortured and unconventional 31-year relationship -- in which they were constantly unfaithful to each other and frequently battled -- endured until 1961, when Hammett died of cancer. By then his literary output had long since dried up.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEBOVICS, CHARLOTTE
description: LEBOVICS-Charlotte, 89. On May 27 in Israel. Long-time resident of New York City. Beloved wife of the late Edward, proud mother of Menorah (Aubey) Rotenberg and Naomi (Rabbi Michael Graetz). Survived also by six grandchildren and two great-grandsons. Burial in Israel. Shiva at 42 Eshel Street, Omer, Israel. Telephone 011-972-7646-9027.

title: Style; The Painted Bird
description: This year when the fall runway models appeared (for the most part) with fresh glowing faces, their natural look seemed inevitable. Drop-dead glamour is an anachronism in the gender-free office. Plus, no one has the time to painstakingly paint a face: we want makeup we can apply in the back seat of a cab. In response, the beauty industry has come up with easy-to-use colors and forms. Foundations are so light they're almost moisturizers with sunscreen. (For the latest offerings, see Givenchy Teint Minimal or Neutrogena Healthy Skin Liquid Makeup.) Even Trish McEvoy, the makeup artist who specializes in providing a brush for every corner of the face, has come out with Face Shine, a transparent cream blush you rub on with a finger. At Estee Lauder you can still get lipstick in a case like a fluted gold column, but you can also pick up a double-ended chunky pencil with a deeper color and a complementing frost (Duo Lipstick).

title: Car Haulers Are Looking to Hoffa to Stay Firm on Concessions
description: With a Monday night strike deadline, James P. Hoffa is facing his first big test as teamsters president in seeking to secure higher wages and pensions and beat back concessions for 12,200 drivers who haul new cars to dealerships.

title: Bike Friendly Bridges
description: Those planning long jaunts by bike or foot in this city quickly realize that there is likely a bridge in their future. After all, New York, with the exception of the Bronx, is on an archipelago and has 76 bridges that span water.

title: Learning From Truman's Espionage Blunder
description: Reflecting on the Alger Hiss case a quarter century after it broke, George Kennan concluded that ''one must place much of the blame directly on the Truman Administration itself, and specifically for its failure to conduct a proper and exhaustive administrative investigation'' into the accusations that Hiss had been a Soviet spy.

title: State Efforts to Cut Smoking Leave New York Far Behind
description: New York, until recently considered a leader in combating smoking, is rapidly becoming a laggard, as other states leapfrog past it in the size and aggressiveness of their efforts.

title: An Irish I.P.O. Is Smiling As a Nation Lines Up for Shares
description: Ireland, it seems, is one nation that needs no lessons when it comes to working up an appetite for a hot new issue.

title: Minority Drive
description: In an effort to increase the number of minority groups and women in its work force, the county has intensified its recruitment efforts and is offering a study program for those who want to take Civil Service tests. ''We are working to recruit African-Americans, Hispanics and women in all jobs within the county, but to reach our goal we must encourage people to take civil service exams and help them by offering preparation courses that people can fit into their schedules,'' County Executive Andrew J. Spano said in announcing the drive earlier this month.

title: Schools Will Pay for Court Ruling; Money Isn't the Issue
description: To the Editor:

title: Picking Up the Pieces
description: COUNTRY OF MY SKULL

title: Sarah Jones, Jonathan Bergman
description: Sarah Elizabeth Jones, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John M. Jones of Irvington, N.Y., is to be married today to Jonathan Michael Bergman, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Abby Barry Bergman, also of Irvington. Judith Wank, the adjunct leader of the Ethical Culture Society of Westchester, will officiate at Tappan Hill in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: A Gift From the South of France
description: BISTRO seems to be 1999's name of choice for new restaurants. One of the latest is St. Tropez in Fairfield. Everything about this charming place is welcoming, from the friendly staff to the brilliant yellow of its walls, wooden chairs and draperies. While the elongated mural of the St. Tropez waterfront evokes the Riviera, the yellow itself has the intensity of Monet's dinnerware in Giverny.

title: The Nation; There's a Resurgence of Poets, and They Know It.
description: NOW that the fanfare around National Poetry Month in April has died down -- the readings, the slams, the tractor pulls -- there is time for a little serious contemplation about the future of the form.

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Chevrolet Silverado; The Cover Is Familiar But the Book Is All New
description: HOW important are General Motors' full-size pickups? Check out Wall Street's numbers or Main Street's traffic. These are the company's most popular products, with some 700,000 sold annually. They are lucrative, returning several thousand dollars in profit for each one sold. They also serve as the basis for a fleet of big sport utilities that account for another 400,000 even more profitable sales.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPERLING, PETER CARLIN
description: SPERLING-Peter Carlin. Of Manhattan and City Island, NY. Formerly of Southampton, PA. On May 27, 1999, at age 47. Friend and partner for 22 years of Stephen Roth. Son of Patricia Carlin Sperling and the late Sidney Sperling. Survived also by sisters Martha and Elizabeth and their families. Founder of Sperling Books and partner in City Island antique shop. Memorial services will follow.

title: In Defense of Private Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: A Day in the Life of Signora Maria
description: I WAS on a mission: to find the smallest mountain towns in Sicily. Tiny jewels, remote and isolated, tourists seldom see them. But they are the island's hidden treasure, and the secret spring of Sicilian endurance.

title: Laura Cohn, Peter Spiegel
description: Laura Sharon Cohn, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Burton H. Cohn of Camp Hill, Pa., is to be married today to Peter Howard Spiegel, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Richard M. Spiegel of Phoenix. Rabbi Jeffrey A. Wohlberg is to perform the ceremony at Adas Israel Congregation in Washington.

title: Domini's Proxy Votes Are an Open Book
description: Ever wonder how your fund manager voted on proxy issues that may or may not have a direct effect on a company's bottom line? Domini Social Investments, a New York money management firm and adviser to the $995 million Domini Social Equity fund, has begun providing such information over its Web site, www.domini.com.

title: Venturing (Widely) Forth With City Hall Capital
description: CITIES and states everywhere long to be the next Silicon Someplace. Many have used tax money to set up business incubators and promote their attractions to entrepreneurs; some even throw subsidies and tax relief at technology companies to lure them to set up shop, create jobs and join the local tax rolls.

title: The Master Planner's Big Picture
description: THE voters never elected Lee E. Koppelman to anything. If he had run for office, he probably would have been roundly defeated. Yet for nearly four decades he has endured as Long Island's master planner, spanning Republican and Democratic regimes and surviving demands for his ouster from both sides of the aisle.

title: Hello Muddah. Hello Fadduh. How's Camp?
description: FOUR years ago, the Snowshoe Mountain ski area in West Virginia looked into ways to tap the rich markets of the Northeast and the mid-Atlantic states in the off season. Mike Valache, a manager, settled on a mountain-biking camp for 12- to 18-year-olds.

title: THEATER; Bergman, as Stage Director, Never Stops Digging
description: THREE years ago, the great Swedish theater and film director Ingmar Bergman made news in the New York theater world by canceling at the last minute his eagerly awaited production of ''The Misanthrope.'' At the time, it was reported that Mr. Bergman had decided that the production of the Moliere play by the Royal Dramatic Theater of Sweden, known as Dramaten, was not in good enough artistic shape to travel to the Brooklyn Academy of Music, after it had been playing in Stockholm for a year.

title: BACKTALK; Their Life Was Wrestling, and One of Them Died for It
description: Almost any Canadian who grew up during the 1950's or 1960's remembers at least one otherwise dignified old gentleman -- a friend's grandfather, perhaps -- who spent Saturday afternoons feinting and jabbing at his television screen.

title: G.M. Removes Itself From Industrial Pedestal
description: Though often misquoted and taken out of context, a remark by Charles E. Wilson that ''for years I thought what was good for our country was good for General Motors, and vice versa,'' has long stood for the view that the business of America is very big business, so get out of the way.

title: A Festival Turns Newark Into a Party Town
description: IN October 1997, the $180 million New Jersey Performing Arts Center opened with the ambitious goal of revitalizing Newark's faded downtown by presenting top-notch cultural events within its elegant halls. Now -- to borrow a phrase from the Doobies -- they're taking it to the streets.

title: Same House, Different Lot: Princeton's Scrambled Buildings
description: A photograph of Princeton from 100 years ago or more might at first glance resemble the town of today with its concentration of 18th- and 19th-century houses. But look closer, and it may seem that the buildings have been scrambled. That's because they have been: over the past 130 years, nearly 200 buildings there have been moved from one place to another, some more than once.

title: Mixed Notices for Clock Sculpture
description: The sky was dark and threatening on May 19, when city officials, arts benefactors and top executives of Lincoln Center gathered for the unveiling of ''Time Sculpture,'' a clock tower designed by Philip Johnson, across the street from the arts center.

title: Food; Batter Up
description: Four decades and hundreds of miles separate him from the action, but the baseball legend Ted Williams can still feel spring training in the Florida air.

title: A Performer's Selves, at 39, Prepare Their Futures
description: ON a recent Sunday, Robert La Fosse of New York City Ballet prepared to put on the sleek black wig, orange gloves and cape of the evil sorcerer Von Rothbart for the final performance of Peter Martins's ''Swan Lake.'' Monday is the company's one day off, but his agenda was already full: he was helping to select cast members for a coming Asian tour of ''West Side Story.''

title: 'Anastasia' Lives On, Like an Open Question
description: NOT many story ballets are based on the lives of real people while they are still living. Yet the ballerina Lynn Seymour recalls that she wasn't surprised when the choreographer Kenneth MacMillan asked her to create the role of Anna Anderson, the woman who for years claimed to be the Grand Duchess Anastasia, a daughter of Czar Nicholas II of Russia, in a one-act ballet, ''Anastasia,'' that he choreographed in 1967 for Berlin's Deutsche Oper Ballet.

title: For Festival Prowlers at Cannes, Pouncing Is All
description: AFTER Heather Locklear, Kate Moss and a French actress with a tattooed buttock swanned up the red-carpeted steps to the Palais des Festivals for this year's closing night ceremonies, the top official accolades at the Cannes International Film Festival were awarded to two intense, painful French-language films dealing with hard lives in lonely surroundings. The Palme d'Or winner, the Belgian film ''Rosetta'' by the brothers Luc and Jean-Pierre Dardenne, offers a fierce portrait of a young woman trying to eke out a living against impossible odds. It is just the kind of small, profound, beautifully realized film that will be greatly helped by the prize.

title: Corrections
description: A picture with the art reviews on May 16, showing Rex Lau's painting ''My Hut at Night,'' was reproduced sideways. The doorway seen at the left should have been at the bottom.

title: Around Auckland, And Into the Bush
description: LAST summer, I boldly knocked on the door of a guesthouse room in a remote town in eastern Bali, and asked the woman who answered if I could have a look inside.

title: Embattled Child Center Had Great Achievements
description: To the Editor:

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from the most recent listing to contract.

title: Passing the Endurance Test; A Few Jobs Have Been Around Far Longer Than a New York Minute
description: IN a city that doesn't brake for pleasantries or red lights, Memorial Day seems oddly irrelevant. Tomorrow is, after all, the day to pause and remember, ponder the nature of change, and grasp for some sense of connection to what was and what will be. Great stuff, maybe, for Dubuque or Peoria. But the phrase ''in a New York minute'' wasn't coined for nothing.

title: Sports of The Times; The Monument Where Joe Louis Trained
description: WHEN Joe Louis was the heavyweight champion, he put this leafy little town on the map.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JAFFE, MARLENE MAE
description: JAFFE-Marlene Mae. March 29, 58 years old. Born in San Francisco. Daughter of the late Burton and Zella Jaffe. Very loving sister of Dr. Reuven Ralph and Ruth Jaffe. Beloved aunt to Naomi Devorah Jaffe and Adina and Rabbi Leslie Lipson and daughter Rebecca. A loving niece and cousin. Marlene had a wonderful sense of humor and much compassion. After her formal education, she worked for ABC-Paramount and for almost two decades was the ''heart'' of Time, Inc., where she also hosted many events for underprivileged children. Marlene was a cherished friend to many and supported Jewish causes, especially her synagogue. Memorial service on Sunday, June 6, at 12 PM, at Ansche Chesed, 251 West 100th St, NYC. Contributions may be made to Cancer Care, 1180 Aveune of the Americas, 2nd Floor, New York, NY 10036, or the cause of your choice.

title: Elizabeth Werley And Robert Plows
description: Elizabeth Lynn Werley and Robert Curtis Plows are to be married this afternoon by the Rev. Richard I. Preis, a Lutheran minister, at the Northampton Country Club in Easton, Pa.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAPERSTEIN, IRVING
description: SAPERSTEIN-Irving. Of Millerton, NY, died on Friday, May 28, 1999, at the age of 79. Loving husband of the late Shirley Gitlin Saperstein, he is survived by his children, Lewis of Pleasant Valley, NY, Judith Keller of Brooklyn, NY, and Susan Rabin of Syracuse, NY; five grandchildren; his brother Martin; a sister, Phyllis Cohen; and several nieces and nephews. A 53-year resident of Millerton, NY, Mr. Saperstein founded Saperstein's Department Store in 1946, upon his honorable discharge from the U.S. Army Air Force. Mr. Saperstein was a charter member and past President of the Millerton Lions Club, past President of Congregation Beth David, Amenia, NY, member of the American Legion and the Jewish War Veterans. Graveside services will be held Sunday at 2PM, Beth El Cemetery, Westwood, NJ. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Congregation Beth David, Amenia, NY; Sharon Hospital, Sharon, CT; or the Millerton Rescue Squad, Millerton, NY.

title: The Nation: Open Arms; Spying Isn't the Only Way to Learn About Nukes
description: NOW that a Congressional committee has released its three-volume, 872-page techno-thriller on the theft of atomic secrets by Chinese spies, much of Washington is agog. But the uproar overlooks an arresting fact. For more than a half decade, the Clinton Administration was shoveling atomic secrets out the door as fast as it could, literally by the ton. Millions of previously classified ideas and documents relating to nuclear arms were released to all comers, including China's bomb makers.

title: Reversing a Roth
description: If you rolled your retirement savings into a Roth IRA last year, and then realized that you were not eligible, you have until Oct. 15 to undo your mistake, the Internal Revenue Service says, acknowledging that it made a mistake when it told people the deadline to fix such errors was April 15.

title: A New Kind of Fed Watch: The Changing of the Guard
description: DURING a House Banking Committee hearing earlier this month, Representative Spencer Bachus, Republican of Alabama, warmly praised Robert E. Rubin, the outgoing Treasury Secretary. Then he turned to Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, who was sitting beside Mr. Rubin at the witness table.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLANKSTEIN, MORTIMER
description: BLANKSTEIN-Mortimer. Age 86, on May 29, 1999. Beloved husband of the late Rita. Survived by his children Steven & Ellen Blankstein, and Andrea & Gary Cooperberg; seven grandchildren; a sister Jeanette Aranoff; and his companion Wini Costigan. Graveside burial Sunday 10AM at Mt. Hebron Cemetery, Flushing, NY.

title: Massachusetts Home For Contemporary Art
description: Thirteen years in the making, MASS MoCA, a campus for contemporary art in North Adams, Mass., is set to open today.

title: Party Pooper?
description: THE replacement of a Marlboro Man billboard by a cowboy clone warning that ''smoking causes impotence'' isn't just turning motorists' heads on Sunset Boulevard.

title: Kathleen K. Meserve, 93, Bred Holly Hybrids
description: Kathleen Kellogg Meserve, an amateur horticulturist from Long Island who produced a series of hardy holly hybrids that have become standard in nurseries and gardens in the United States and Europe, died last Sunday at her home in Vero Beach, Fla. She was 93.

title: Baseball Books in Brief
description: PRAYING FOR BASE HITS

title: Our Towns; Ball Field Foe Says She Feels Out at Home
description: AS a story, it was too good to write without a snicker: all-American dad builds a full-size ball field in his backyard for his son and his son's friends, snooty neighbors take dad to court. When the story of Bill Ingraham's backyard ball park ran on the networks and in the papers across the country last summer, a lot of people got a good chuckle about the magic of the national pastime and shook their heads about the cluelessness of some people.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RECANATI, RAPHAEL
description: RECANATI-Raphael. It is with a profound sense of loss that the Board of Trustees, Medical Board and Administration of Beth Israel Medical Center join with the leadership of its parent company, Continuum Health Partners, Inc., in acknowledging the passing of our dear friend and devoted colleague, Raphael Recanati, Honorary Trustee of Beth Israel. Few have matched the extraordinary philanthropy of Mr. Recanati and his devoted wife, Dina, to Beth Israel. A consistent thread running through their history of support has been generous donations toward critically important needs of medical education and research, particularly in the areas of neurology, cardiology, nephrology, hepatology, pulmonary medicine, dermatology, orthopaedic surgery, pediatrics, pathology and infectious diseases. Mr. Recanati's creative philanthropic approach served as a crucial resource to our staff, allowing them to make important advances in patient care and expanded medical knowledge. He will forever be remembered for helping to create a clinical and educational environment that makes Beth Israel a vibrant place to study and practice medicine. Our heartfelt condolences are extended to Dina, his sons Oudi and Michael, the entire Recanati family and all whose lives have been touched by his extraordinary humanitarian spirit. Morton P. Hyman, Chairman, Boards of Trustees, Continuum and BIMC Robert G. Newman, MD, President and CEO, Continuum Matthew E. Fink, MD, President and CEO, BIMC Henry Singman, MD, President, BIMC Medical Board

title: Like Fathers, Like Sons; As the Generations Shift, The Loews Style Remains
description: JAMES TISCH'S Manhattan office is surprisingly cramped, abounding with family photos and the detritus that comes with a 23-year investment career. Two high shelves are crowded with acrylic-encased tombstone ads memorializing stock and bond offerings past. There's a bubble-gum machine, a shiny megaphone that Michael Milken's junk bond department once sent to clients, and a can of New Coke, which Mr. Tisch had thought might become a collectors' item.

title: Paterson Will Close Schools for 2 Muslim Holidays
description: At School No. 9 in South Paterson, almost 50 percent of students are absent from classes during a certain day in January because their families are observing the end of Ramadan, the monthlong fast in the Muslim faith.

title: The Color Black: On the Painter's Canvas and in the World
description: THE painter Norman Lewis (1909-1979) straddled two spheres. He was present at the creation of Abstract Expressionism as one of its important formulators, though he is not well known in this respect. He was also actively concerned with the role of art among African-Americans, belonging to and sometimes leading several community organizations in Harlem. Nowadays a multifaceted life is intriguing, but it wasn't always so. His politically-charged pursuits certainly contributed to the lack of attention paid him.

title: A Poetic Director Becomes a Cause To Champion
description: ALTHOUGH his 10 highly regarded films, stretching over two decades, are often compared with those of the Italian master filmmaker Michelangelo Antonioni, the Greek director Theo Angelopoulos is largely unknown in the United States.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRAHA, JACK
description: BRAHA-Jack. Died May 28, 1999 Loving husband of Ilene (Nemerow). Devoted father of Marc, Elliot, Joseph, Robert and their wives. Caring stepfather of David, Kevin, Jonathan and their wives. Grandfather of 17 beautiful grandchildren. A respected gentleman and a good friend. Shiva at his home in Deal, New Jersey.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NORWALK, BERNICE L.
description: NORWALK-Bernice L. (Bunny). Beloved and loving wife of Elliott for 60 years. Devoted mother of Jeffrey and Arthur. Proud grandmother of Lisa and great grandmother of Mary. Services ''Boulevard-Riverside,'' 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I., 1:30 PM, Sunday.

title: Secret Witness To Car Crashes In Black Boxes
description: Northwest 54th Street in Miami was crowded at 4:30 P.M. on Feb. 7, 1997, and many people saw the three-car collision that killed Detective Robert Vargas. But none of them could help the police determine why he died.

title: QUICK BITE/Garfield; Chef Boyardee Is Not Invited
description: After getting home from work, who hasn't wished for a dinner that not only tastes good but is nutritous as well as quick and easy to prepare? Even better if the rest of the family enjoys it too.

title: The Eloquent Stones of Wales
description: PEMBROKESHIRE, South Wales, is a land of stones. There are gray standing stones and headstones, way markers and Celtic crosses, fieldstones in walls and cut stones raised in church towers. Growing on them in almost miraculous profusion, as if fed on history itself, is a whole palette of lichens: daffodil yellow, marigold, mauve and ash.

title: Where to Play Across an Ocean
description: IT'S worth acknowledging from the start that few children travel willingly. It will be, everyone agrees, a fabulous experience for them; they will thank you when they are older. But that anticipated gratitude means little when parents are hauling them away from their cherished backyard, from the basketball camp they crave, from the friends with whom they go biking or hunting for frogs. At least until adolescence, one's own neighborhood seems plenty full of surprises and miracles.

title: Democracy, Unedited and as It Unfolds
description: FOR C-SPAN junkies in Connecticut, there is now a local version of democracy in action.

title: You Buy It, You Keep It, More Stores Are Saying
description: VIRGINIA SULLIVAN was walking up Park Avenue not long ago, her arms overflowing with purchases, looking every bit the battle-hardened New York shopper. But there's one thing that Ms. Sullivan, a professor at the Fashion Institute of Technology, no longer has the strength to endure: returning unsatisfactory merchandise.

title: Corrections
description: An article on May 16 about choices and costs for private schools misstated College Board scores for students at the Princeton Day School. The class of 1999 averaged 642 in the math portion and 625 in the verbal; the class of 1998 averaged 643 in math and 641 in the verbal part. The article also misstated the annual tuition for grades 7 through 12. It is $16,700.

title: Growing Beets: It's Not Easy Being Crimson
description: A GREAT many people do not like beets. The majority of them are either adolescents or adults who formed their opinion of beets as adolescents, probably as a result of being confronted at school lunch counters by canned Harvard beets -- crimson cubes coated with a sticky magenta-colored sauce.

title: Got a Cause? Get a Celebrity
description: To the Editor:

title: How a Seat Can Be More Than a Place to Sit
description: SOME chairs seem to jump out at viewers while others are, well, more utilitarian. Must a chair be designed primarily for seating, can it be a work of art, or indeed be both? This is the question posed in the exhibition ''Please Be Seated: Contemporary Studio Seating Furniture,'' on view at the Yale University Art Gallery through Aug. 8.

title: On the Banks of the Delaware, a Reason to Believe
description: We sloshed through the brook, in the cool darkness of the tunnel beneath the railroad tracks, and emerged in brilliant sunshine on the banks of the Delaware River. The ash and cherry trees on the mountainside opposite us were not yet leafed out. Their pale green buds appeared supercharged, nearly fluorescent, in striking contrast to the opaque black surface of the river at this place called Bouchoux Brook.

title: 'Star Wars' Studio Misses the Jackpot
description: To the Editor:

title: May 23-29; Cloned Sheep's Cells Aging
description: The genetic material in Dolly, the sheep that was the first animal to be successfully cloned from an adult, may be showing a sign of aging, in effect appearing older than the sheep itself, said the scientists in Scotland who created the animal. If confirmed, the finding would be the first sign of possible genetic abnormalities in cloned animals.

title: Baseball Books in Brief
description: BASEBALL'S PIVOTAL ERA,

title: Burning Down the House
description: MUSIC FOR TORCHING

title: What's taking the burgers so long?
description: It's green, egg-shaped and 189 pounds. Why is it in the backyard? The Big Green Egg, a grill based on the ancient Japanese kamado cooker, is made of a heat-holding ceramic designed to cut cooking time in half. It has been around for 27 years, but only recently has become a hot seller. Edward Fisher, Green Egg's owner, said that since 1997, sales have doubled to 20,000. The grill also serves as a smoker and is easy on the charcoal. The Green Egg is $99.95 for the mini version and up to $599.95. Green ham not included. Information: (800) 939-3447.

title: Ah, Luxury: A Closet, A Boom Box
description: ONE recent midnight, I found myself walking up to a White Castle drive-up window on the fringes of downtown Nashville. After a five-and-a-half-hour delay on a flight with no meal service, I was forced to beg a teen-ager to disregard the ''No Walk-Ups'' sign and sell me two double cheeseburgers, a small order of fries and a Diet Coke. My hotel, a historic train station converted into a hotel in 1986, didn't have 24-hour room service, so dinner ended up costing me $4.85 -- plus my last shred of dignity.

title: Plan for 631 Area Code To Be Filed
description: An industry plan for implementing the new 631 area code in Suffolk County is due to be filed this week with the state Public Service Commission, the next step in a service change that will consign the old 516 area code to Nassau alone.

title: Alyssa Ziegler And Gary Apple
description: Alyssa Jacqueline Ziegler, the director of public affairs at Lifetime Television, and Gary Elliott Apple, the weekend sports anchor at WCBS-TV, both in New York, are to be married tonight at the P.G.A. National Resort and Spa in Palm Beach Gardens, Fla. Rabbi Howard Shapiro will officiate.

title: The Nation: Ugly Rites of Passage; Rethinking America's Schools of Hard Knocks
description: JUSTICE ANTHONY M. KENNEDY was perplexed. Having grown up in a California suburb in the 1950's, the Supreme Court Justice objected to the way his colleagues were calling what schoolboys do to schoolgirls ''sexual harassment.''

title: Katrina Webster, Theodore Stamas
description: Katrina Ann Webster and Theodore Stephen Stamas were married yesterday at St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University in New York. The Rev. Jewelnel Davis, the Columbia chaplain, performed the nondenominational ceremony.

title: Sabres' Sudden Surge Leaves Leafs on the Brink
description: Pat Quinn, coach of the Toronto Maple Leafs, worried before the Eastern Conference finals about how his team would respond to its lofty status. After failing to make the playoffs for two consecutive seasons, the Leafs had reached the third round and felt good about themselves. But they had to face the Buffalo Sabres, who lost last year in this round and vowed that they had learned from their experience.

title: Mr. Mayor
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIRSCH, ANDREW
description: HIRSCH-Andrew. A very longtime true friend. Our sincere condolences to Rita, Joan and Ronald and families. We will surely miss him. Sylvia and Jerry Sternberg

title: A Fountain of Optimism on Age and Aging
description: When Jeanne Calment died in 1997 at the age of 122, she had lived longer than any other documented human being on earth. ''I see badly, I hear badly, I can't feel anything, but everything's fine,'' she told researchers a few years before celebrating her 120th birthday at the retirement home where she lived in Arles, France.

title: The Great Ape Massacre
description: Donald G. McNeil Jr.'s article (May 9) was shocking. I hope it will be a spur to action. However, the emphasis on the potential of chimpanzees to help scientists find a cure for AIDS was troubling. If it turns out that this endangered species cannot provide the key to a cure for human disease, will it then be acceptable to destroy these animals? The potential of other species to serve as the means to human ends cannot be their only value or our only reason for protecting them.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about where to see and buy art in the Hamptons misstated the hours for the Lizan Tops Gallery, 66 Newtown Lane, in East Hampton. It is open 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. daily, closed on Wednesdays.

title: Michael Sorrell and Lisa Winston
description: Lisa Marie Winston, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Michael R. Winston of Washington, is to be married today to Michael Joseph Sorrell, the son of Vera Williams Sorrell of Chicago and the late Wade J. Sorrell. Bishop William P. DeVeaux of the African Methodist Episcopal Church in Southern Africa will perform the ceremony at Dunbarton Chapel in Washington.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SCHENBAUM, DR. SOL
description: SCHENBAUM-Dr. Sol, 1986 SCHENBAUM-Gertrude, 1983 We will always love, remember and miss you. Your loving family

title: Slovaks' Choice: Reformer or Ex-Prime Minister
description: Slovaks faced a simple choice in the second round of their presidential election today: vote for further democratic progress and joining Europe, or slide back into international isolation.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HEYMAN, BELLE
description: HEYMAN-Belle. We miss you very much. Happy Birthday. With love Terry & Arty

title: A Tool to Supplement the Eye
description: 'Michael Gordon:

description: HOTEL

title: Nothing Matters, Only Style and Words
description: ALL the ages of classical and modern drama are ever ripe for re-invention. Transport Electra to post-Civil War New England, Richard III to Nazi Germany and Antigone to the battle of the homeless in contemporary New York. A theatrical distillation of ideas and feelings crosses time and cultural differences.

title: The Way We Live Now: 5-30-99; Eyes on The Fries
description: At the age of 16, I made one of my first important culinary finds. It was the J&M Luncheonette, a dingy eating spot near my school in Bethesda, Md., where the cook served up the full roster of soul-satisfying, life-threatening American classics. The fries were thick and oddly shaped. Some still had the potato skin on. The burgers were two-handers, dripping with juice and topped with a slab of cheddar cheese. This was the real thing.

title: Finance and Romance
description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: At a Crossroads Of an Oil Boom, Everyone Comes To Charlie's
description: NIGHT is falling over Baku, and Charlie Schroeder is upset that there aren't any nutshells on the floor of his bar.

title: Propagating Lilacs and Other Shrubs
description: To maintain vigor and appearance, remove spent flowers of lilacs and rhododendrons. Most other spring-flowering shrubs do not benefit from deadheading.

title: Yonkers Housing
description: For the first time in close to a decade, construction is about to begin in Yonkers on new affordable housing mandated under a Federal desegregation order.

title: Black Groups in Florida Split Over School Voucher Plan
description: Exposing the sharp debate over school vouchers among black people, two long-time allies from the civil rights struggle in Florida find themselves on opposite sides on whether the state should help pay for some children to attend private schools.

title: Lead Crisis Prompts A Change in Mexico
description: In one of the most severe environmental emergencies the country has ever faced, families living near a 98-year-old lead-smelting plant in central Mexico have discovered that their children have dangerously high blood levels of lead.

title: Kasson Stone, Luke Greenley
description: Kasson Carter Stone, a daughter of Sallie and Dudleigh Stone of Greenburgh, N.Y., was married yesterday to Luke Palmer Greenley, a son of Mary D. Greenley of Madison, Wis., and the late Dr. James R. Greenley. The Rev. Ralph E. Peterson performed the Episcopal ceremony at the Church of St. James the Less in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEIN, HELEN
description: STEIN-Helen (Kaven). Born in Canton, OH. Died peacefully on May 29, 1999, at age 81, after a long illness. Beloved wife of James Stein. Adoring mother of Elizabeth (Betsy) and mother-inlaw to Fredric Graber. Cherished grandmother of Anne and David Graber. Dear sister of Professor William Kaven. Memorial services at Temple Emanu-El, 5th Ave at 65th St, Tuesday, June 1st, 5 PM.

title: The Way We Live Now: 5-30-99: Questions for Sister Souljah; The Drama of the Ghetto Child
description: Q: You grew up in some rough housing projects, in the Bronx. And now you've written two fairly brutal books based on that world, full of drug dealers, hustlers, abusive parents. Do you ever worry about perpetuating negative stereotypes?

title: The Way We Live Now: 5-30-99: Salient Facts: Swat Team; Hometown Commandos
description: During the recent shootings in Littleton, Colo., fully equipped Special Weapons and Assault Teams were on the scene, carrying some pretty heavy accessories. Such units -- highly trained local and state police officers called in for dangerous situations that require special equipment or firepower -- have become standard crime-fighting tools in even the smallest and most placid cities. And they're likely to keep growing. Herewith, a review of the troops:

title: Testing Welfare Applicants for Drugs
description: In a controversial and unusual effort to move more welfare recipients into the work force, Michigan plans a pilot program that would require thousands of those applying for aid to take drug tests to qualify for benefits.

title: Missing Refugees Turn Up With Accounts of Abuse
description: What happened to the thousands of ethnic Albanian men -- from boys barely of fighting age to grandfathers -- who were separated from their families in recent weeks in Kosovo, shoved into trucks and who then disappeared?

title: Georgia Marsh and Ted Hedgpeth
description: FOR as long as she can remember, Megan Hedgpeth, 25, has been trying to find a girlfriend for her father, Ted Hedgpeth, 52. ''We'd be on a ski trip,'' she said, ''and I'd try to hook him up with a hot ski instructor girl. I was always on the lookout for him because he was a hot single dad guy.''

title: May 23-29; New Hampshire's New Holiday
description: As one civil rights advocate put it, New Hampshire won the race to be last. It effectively agreed to become the 50th state to adopt a holiday honoring the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. The state House of Representatives, which had resisted in the past, voted solidly to attach Dr. King's name to the existing Civil Rights Day, and no further hindrances remained to the new holiday. Most other states approved a Martin Luther King Day in the 1980's. So what took New Hampshire so long? Some holiday advocates said it was not racism that resisted the change but the tradition-bound, independent-minded nature of residents.

title: After a Computer-Age Windfall, Workers Reinvent Their Lives
description: WITHIN the modest headquarters and computer memory factory of the Kingston Technology Company is a living laboratory in how people react when blessed with a windfall.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-13

title: Commencement; West Point Graduates Include Ruler's Son
description: All 934 cadets who graduated today from the United States Military Academy received applause and encouragement, but only one was trailed by television crews who nearly interrupted the orderly procession.

title: Dr. John Adams, 85, An Early Authority On Brain Disorders
description: John Edwin Adams, a California neurosurgeon and pioneer in the use of radioisotopes to study brain functions and disorders, died on May 18 at the medical center of the University of California at San Francisco. He was 85.

title: Baseball Books in Brief; Big Mac, Sammy and the Yanks
description: Baseball is a densely woven tapestry of past, present and future, never more so than when records are falling. A few lucky people, writers mostly, get to turn it over and follow the strands to show us how the picture is created. This is what Mike Lupica does brilliantly in SUMMER OF '98: When Homers Flew, Records Fell, and Baseball Reclaimed America (Putnam, $23.95). Lupica is primarily interested in the two biggest stories of the 1998 baseball season -- the home-run hitting of Mark McGwire and Sammy Sosa and the near perfection of the Yankees -- but he finds fresh ways of telling us history we have already lived through, giving us Joe DiMaggio and Chuck Knoblauch side by side at the Yankee home opener, McGwire with the Maris family in St. Louis, McGwire with his manager, Tony La Russa, in Oakland, then reunited with the Cardinals. The book feels a little bit like a collection of Lupica's columns in The Daily News, held together by the strong thread of his relationship with his three sons and his father. For Lupica, baseball is still about (in Donald Hall's lovely phrase) ''fathers playing catch with sons.'' His sons, who range from 6 to 10 years of age, are discovering the joys of baseball much as their dad did, through a combination of radio, television and loving late-night notes from a parent-fan. The best moments in ''Summer of '98'' come when Lupica finds father-surrogate figures whose relationship to their ''offspring'' reveals a lot of character. For example, he shows us Sosa as a scrawny teen-ager, remembered by the scout who signed him, and Kerry Wood (the Cubs rookie who struck out 20 batters in his fifth start) through the eyes of his high school coach, who still speaks to his former charge almost every day. In contrast, THE PERFECT SEASON: Why 1998 Was Baseball's Greatest Year (Villard, $19.95), by Tim McCarver and Danny Peary, reads like a series of McCarver monologues snatched off the air from his television game analyses, replete with his dreadful puns. The book covers a wide range of the season's many outstanding achievements. There are moments of tremendous insight; McCarver is probably the best baseball analyst in broadcasting today, and it is hard to imagine hearing him over an extended period without learning something new about the game. He is nothing less than stunning in his insights into pitching, generously spread throughout the book. But over all ''The Perfect Season'' feels diffuse and unfocused. George Robinson

title: Priced Right Out Of the Mailbox?
description: Ever wondered how the banks that inundate Americans with credit card offers can afford all those come-on letters and tempting introductory rates? Perhaps some of them can't. The mailbox of the future may still groan under the weight of credit card solicitations, but they will come from a smaller number of banks, Moody's Investors Service says.

title: From Bucks County, by Way of France
description: AROUND the end of the 19th century, Bucks County began its long association with the fine arts. Groups like the New Hope School of Impressionists and the New Hope Modernists were inspired, largely, by the success of the French Impressionists.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YOUNGS, JOHN H.
description: YOUNGS-John H. Of Old Brookville, Long Island on May 28, 1999, aged 78. Beloved husband of Vivian B. Father of Jo-Hana Gooth (William) and Paula Weir (Richard III). Grandfather of Richard Weir IV, Beagan Gooth, Abby Weir, Remsen Weir and Liam Gooth. Friends may call at the Funeral Home of Dodge-Thomas, Glen Cove, Sunday 7-9 PM, Monday 3-5 and 7-9 PM. Service Monday, 8 PM. Interment Brookville Cemetery, departing 9:30 AM. Donations may be made to Brookville Reformed Church.

title: Science Fiction
description: Christopher Priest's new novel, THE EXTREMES (St. Martin's, $24.95), is about violence. Its protagonist, Teresa Simons, is an F.B.I. agent who, along with her husband, works for a special unit that seeks to get into the minds of mass murderers with an eye toward predicting and preventing the next bloodbath. Using an advanced form of virtual-reality technology, Teresa is thrust over and over into scenarios of actual killing sprees from the recent past; sometimes she is a victim, sometimes a bystander, occasionally she must act out the lethal rage of the perpetrator himself.

title: Bronx Woman Is Charged With Murder Of Niece, 10
description: A Bronx woman tied her 10-year-old niece to a bed with garbage bags and beat her repeatedly until she lost consciousness and died, the authorities said yesterday.

title: Baseball Books in Brief
description: Where They Ain't

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

description: SCHLEIFER-NACHIMSONMargaret. Your 38th birthday. Maggie, we miss you so. Your Loving Family and Friend

title: 'False Dawn'
description: To the Editor:

title: Good Times, as Usual, Up and Down the Shore
description: SUNBATHERS in swimsuits and flip-flops will line the bar at Martell's in Point Pleasant Beach this weekend, listening to the music of the day just as other beachgoers have done every summer since 1940.

title: Kristin Boger, David Gershfield
description: Dr. Kristin Marie Boger, a daughter of Donna Boger and Dr. Leo Boger of Los Gatos, Calif., is to be married today to Dr. David Neil Gershfield, a son of Hedy and Bruce Gershfield of New York. Rabbi Yeshaia Familant is to officiate at Villa Montalvo, a historic house in Saratoga, Calif.

title: Jennifer Blum, Michael Schiff
description: Jennifer Lyn Blum, a daughter of Bonnie and Leonard Blum of Fairfield, Conn., was married yesterday to Michael Eric Schiff, a son of Anne and Ronald Schiff of New York. Rabbi Steven Carr Reuben officiated at the Riviera Country Club in Pacific Palisades, Calif.

title: Streetscapes /The 30th Street Station House; The Fortress That Was at the Heart of the Tenderloin
description: WHEN it was built in 1908 it was the heart of the Tenderloin, where the police were reputed to make small fortunes off New York's heaviest concentration of gambling and prostitution. Now home to New York City's Traffic Control Division, the old 23d Precinct station house at 138 West 30th Street is a spectacular midblock surprise. Designated a landmark last year, the turreted fortress is almost completely intact inside and out, although desperately neglected.

title: Randolph and Jefferson Win Titles
description: A.P. Randolph High School, which won the girls' indoor team title last winter, added the Public Schools Athletic League outdoor championship yesterday. The Manhattan school edged Tottenville of Staten Island, 76 points to 71, at St. John's University.

title: The Way We Live Now: 5-30-99: Shop Talk; Prom '99: Versace Dress, Stretch Humvee, Condom
description: How has senior prom, that singular distillation of the American high-school experience, changed in recent years? We asked Argamany and Gilbert - experienced party planners from opposite coasts - to discuss the latest trends from students' status symbols to administrators' attempts at inclusiveness.

title: Q & A/Marge Hiller; Group Uses Grants To Inspire Teachers
description: THE Bridgeport Public Education Fund makes education mountains out of cash molehills. The fund awards modest grants to Bridgeport teachers for classroom projects and provides seed money for other innovative school projects. The founding executive director is an energetic former librarian, Marge Hiller. ''There isn't a community in the country that couldn't use an education fund,'' she said, ''a partnership between people who care about education and educators.'' ''The principle of bringing people together around education issues is very sound, very valuable. It makes the system stronger.''

title: Strapped Islanders Trade Linden To Montreal for a Draft Pick
description: The Islanders continued to slash their payroll yesterday by trading their captain, Trevor Linden, to Montreal for a first-round choice, the 10th over all, in the June draft.

title: Sports Medicine From the Doctor's Viewpoint
description: I THOUGHT I would make tennis my livelihood,'' Dr. Kevin Plancher said. ''As a young kid, I lived in Forest Hills. My mother started me playing when I was 6. Later on, Alex Mayer became my coach, and even though John McEnroe beat me in a high school championship match, it didn't change my plans. But after I broke my ankle while teaching my dad how to improve his net game, I got a wake-up call.''

title: FIVE QUESTIONS: for LINDA GARGIULO; Putting Children First In a Toy Settlement
description: LAST week, Toys ''R'' Us and two major toy makers agreed to pay $50 million in cash and merchandise to settle one of the largest antitrust cases the toy industry has ever faced. Attorneys general in 44 states had accused Toys ''R'' Us of using its clout with manufacturers to keep popular items like Barbie's Dream House and Fisher Price Nursery Monitors out of warehouse and discount stores.

title: David Altman, Caroline Gaspar
description: Caroline Eva Gaspar, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew Gaspar of Roslyn, N.Y., is to be married today to David H. Widett Altman, a son of Barbara Widett of Newton, Mass., and Edward Altman of Cambridge, Mass. Rabbi Alan B. Lucas is to officiate at the Plaza in New York.
