description: To the Editor:

title: Halyce Richard, Seth Krasilovsky
description: Halyce Beth Richard, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Warren Richard of Calabasas, Calif., is to be married today to Seth William Krasilovsky, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Krasilovsky of Forest Hills, Queens, at the Four Seasons Hotel in Los Angeles. Rabbi Joel Rembaum is to officiate.

title: Yankees Pass Pop Quiz, but Their Big Test Comes This Week
description: David Cone whipped a fastball past the slugger Carlos Delgado to end the first inning today, and as he walked off the field, Cone pulled his left shoulder to his forehead, presumably to wipe his brow of sweat.

title: Corrections
description: An article on May 16 about a lawsuit over a father's effort to have his 3-year-old son circumcised misstated the faculty position and campus location for Sally Goldfarb, a specialist in family law who commented. She is an associate professor at Rutgers in Camden, not a full professor at the Newark campus.

title: In Boston Neighborhood, a Reach for Office Space
description: THANKS to a strong downtown office market, thousands of new white-collar jobs will be created in the outlying Fenway neighborhood, four miles west of the central business district.

title: Tradition, Not Sizzle
description: A VISIT to Fiesta Hut will convince you why you should eat at authentic Mexican (instead of ''Mexican'') restaurants. There may not be any showy sizzling fajita plates, or banjo players urging guests to sing along to ''La Bamba,'' nor are there waitresses offering to pour shots of tequila down your throat.

title: Allied Air Strikes Kill 9 On Busy Bridge in Serbia
description: Four NATO warplanes bombed a major bridge in southern Serbia today, as the alliance seized on clear skies to intensify daytime bombing across Yugoslavia, allied officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAY, HAROLD
description: KAY-Harold. On May 29, 1999. Beloved husband of Anita. Loving brother of Ruth Clark and George. Beloved uncle and friend to the whole world. Services Tuesday, 10 AM at ''Schwartz Bros.-Jeffer Memorial Chapels,'' 114-03 Queens Blvd. at 76th Road, Forest Hills.

title: Standish F. Medina Jr., 58, Lawyer Who Often Avoided Trial
description: Standish Forde Medina Jr., a leading trial lawyer who made a name for himself by resolving disputes so that clients could avoid trial, died on Saturday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering hospital in Manhattan. Mr. Medina, who had residences in Manhattan, Westhampton, N.Y., and Washington, Conn., was 58.

title: E-Commerce Report; Discounts might be a good way to build a retail clientele -- but not until on-line shoppers become more price conscious.
description: IN a business environment in which E-commerce sites often sell goods at a loss in order to attract customers and build brand names, it is no surprise that consumers expect the Web to be an around-the-clock fire sale, with the next bargain just a click away.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALTUS, CYNTHIA
description: ALTUS-Cynthia. At rest May 28, 1999. Wife of the late Harold R. Altus. Mother of Dr. Philip Altus of Tampa, FL; Charlotte Fainblatt of New York City; and Susan Rudnick of Sudbury, MA. Six grandchildren and six great-grandchildren also survive. Service at Levine Memorial Chapel, Albany, New York, on Monday at 2 PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARFIELD, MARION BUSSANG
description: HARFIELD-Marion Bussang. In her 90th year on May 29, 1999. Beloved wife of Henry Harfield for 58 years. Mother of Susan Harfield Leness Peck and the late Ellen Harfield Piel; grandmother of Amanda, Susie and Tony Leness, and Sarah and Katherine Piel. Daughter of the late Mabel and R. William Bussang. Graduate of Emma Willard School '28, Smith College '32, and Columbia School of Journalism '35. Funeral service will be held at Westhampton Presbyterian Church, 83 Meetinghouse Rd., Westhampton Beach, NY 11978 at 4 PM on Monday, May 31. In lieu of flowers, memorial gifts may be made to the church.

title: Gun Owners Fear Connecticut Bill on Gun Seizures
description: Cathy Smittner has spent the last eight months coaching her 3-year-old grandson, Lenny Smittner, on the fine points of firing a pellet rifle at silhouettes and clay pigeons in the backyard, starting with the rule that he does not put his finger on the trigger unless he is ready to squeeze it.

title: It's Adelphi Again
description: For the second year in a row, Adelphi defeated its Long Island rival C.W. Post by 11-8 for the Division II title.

title: Jostling for Share Of E-Mortgages
description: The on-line mortgage business is heating up.

title: Sharing a Lawyer Raises Question of Ethics
description: In Hollywood, anybody who is anybody knows everybody. But does that mean that any journalist can write about anybody?

title: An automotive device that can make a tell-tale breath stop the car and even alert the police.
description: ONE way to cut down on drunk driving is to keep a car from starting if its driver has been drinking.

title: FIREARMS LIMITS GAINING SUPPORT IN LEGISLATURES
description: Just as the school shooting in Colorado last month spurred Congress to the verge of approving measures like background checks for gun buyers and safety devices for firearms, many state legislatures have been passing gun-control laws, in some cases taking up measures that had long been considered unlikely to pass.

title: Protesters Seek More Money for Veterans' Health Care
description: More than 200 people gathered yesterday in front of the Department of Veterans Affairs Medical Center on East 23d Street in Manhattan to protest what they called the steady erosion of health care services for veterans.

title: INSIDE
description: 'Just Say No' to Drinks?

title: Correction
description: Because of a typographical error, a letter on Friday misstated the date that New York State's Managed Care Bill of Rights was enacted. It was 1996.

title: Picture of a Fiery Puerto Rican Poet
description: ''Anger belongs in art'' the young Puerto Rican poet Julia de Burgos tells Pablo Neruda in Carmen Rivera's celebration of her life and work, ''Julia de Burgos: Child of the Water.'' And in this woman there was anger enough to fill countless poems. She was born in Puerto Rico in 1918 and died on a sidewalk in East Harlem in 1953, leaving behind two shipwrecked marriages, the debris of several disastrous affairs, a blank decade of incurable alcoholism and three volumes of verse that testify to a fierce struggle to achieve a magnificent purity and honesty of spirit, emotion and expression.

title: Commencements; Cornell Graduates Credited With a Degree of 'Character'
description: Under a blazing sun and a clear blue sky, more than 6,000 students received degrees at Cornell University's 131st commencement today.

title: An Extraordinary May In Its Ordinary Weather
description: Has it been your sense that this has been an extraordinary month of May, an uncommon string of lovely days and delightful nights capping a spring of phenomenal pleasantness?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FAY, FRANCIS R., JR.
description: FAY-Francis R., Jr. On May 29, 1999, of Rye, NY, and Londonderry, VT. Beloved husband of Carole Corbett Fay. Devoted father of Susan, Catherine McCarthy and Francis III. Loving grandfather of Fallon and Thomas Francis McCarthy. Brother of Martin. B.S., Fordham University. M.B.A., New York University. Served in U.S. Navy during the Korean War. Former Vice-President of both A.G. Becker, Inc., and Prudential Securities. Reposing at Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Road, Rye, NY, Wednesday, June 2, from 2-4 PM and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass, Church of the Resurrection, 910 Boston Post Road, Rye, NY, Thursday, June 3, 10 AM. Donations to Children's Hospital at Dartmouth (CHAD), 1 Medical Center Dr., Lebanon, NH 03756.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EIGEN, JOAN, MARTIN, AND MOLLIE
description: EIGEN-Joan, Martin, and Mollie. The Eigen family deeply mourns the deaths of Joan Eigen, daughter of Arthur and Paula Hirsch; sister of Linda and Harold. Martin Eigen, son of Mollie and Benjamin Eigen, brother of Albert, beloved parents of Barry, Amy and Jonathan, grandparents of Melyssa and Justin. Mollie Eigen, sister of David, Dorothy, Ruthie and Lillian, mother of Martin and Albert, beloved grandmother of six and great-grandmother of three. Funeral services to be held at Gutterman's in Rockville Centre, LI, on Tuesday, June 1, 1999. Contributions in their memories can be made to either the American Diabetes Association or the American Cancer Society.

title: A Battle in Kosovo: Justice vs. Peace; Little Negotiation
description: To the Editor:

title: Amor (Those Hips!), Pasion (Those Lips!)
description: To many of his new fans it seems that Ricky Martin, the Puerto Rican pop sensation, came out of nowhere. He didn't. He is simply the English-speaking point man for a Latin pop-star system that has long been manufacturing hits and stealing hearts across the Spanish-speaking world. Chayanne, one of Mr. Martin's rivals, brought his own stage spectacle to the Theater at Madison Square Garden on Friday night. Tall, dark and square-jawed with a boyish smile, Chayanne sang and danced through a decade's worth of hits, with excerpts from his video clips projected overhead.

title: Above the Salt: Daredevil Racers Against Life-Threatening Oceans
description: CLOSE TO THE WIND

title: Disabled Spouses Are Increasingly Forced to Go It Alone
description: As modern medicine extends the lives of people with chronic diseases from diabetes to cystic fibrosis, the rate of divorce among them is increasing, leaving a growing number without income, health insurance or support at home, health analysts say.

title: As the Pressure Shifts, Wary Indiana Notices
description: No Reggie time. Not today. No 3-point rainbow to bury the Knicks. This time, instead of Reggie Miller putting both hands in that choke hold to taunt the Knicks, he was the one who appeared to be choking. The scenario was familiar, 12.4 seconds and the Indiana Pacers were down by 2.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVINGER, JOSEPH N.
description: DAVINGER-Joseph N. On May 30, 1999, at age 92. Beloved husband of Blanche. Loving father of Bruce and Barry. Adoring grandfather of Tara Glicksman; Nicholas, Christopher and Jennifer Brandaleone, and Steven and Bethany Davinger. Great-grandfather of Alexandra Glicksman. Dear brother of Pauline Spiegel. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Monday, 7-9 PM, with service Tuesday, 1:30 PM. Interment private.

title: Rivals Are Failing to Reduce Mandela Party's Huge Lead
description: A political cartoon in South Africa this week shows the front-running presidential candidate, Thabo Mbeki, dressed as Snow White looming with an unconcerned smile over seven miserable dwarfs who represent the opposition parties -- labeled Grumpy, Shorty, Whiny, Crazy, Bully, Murky and Choppy.

title: In Brooklyn, a Stunning Design That's All Wrong
description: To the Editor:

title: Market Place; Newspaper companies are setting up Web units despite a cooler market for Internet stocks.
description: THE tables were turned at the newspaper publishers' annual meeting last month: Instead of being grilled by Wall Street analysts seeking to poke holes in glowing corporate presentations, the publishers questioned three leading analysts.

title: Washington Talk; Stars, Stripes, Flames And Free Speech Redux
description: One of these days not on Flag Day, June 14, and not even by the Fourth of July, but probably sometime this year -- Republicans in the Senate will bring up a proposed constitutional amendment that would permit laws banning flag-burning.

title: Plane Crashes Kill 2 People And Injure 7
description: Two people were killed and seven injured yesterday in two separate small-plane crashes in New York and New Jersey. On Saturday, a small passenger plane went down in New Jersey, killing two people.

title: A Village Girl Who Suffers A Universal Heartbreak
description: Not everyone was at the beach over the weekend. The hot ticket at American Ballet Theater, which drew packed houses at the Metropolitan Opera House, was ''Giselle'' in its first three performances of the season.

title: Plan to Include Alcohol In Antidrug Ads Is Resisted
description: Evidence abounds that beer is more popular with adolescents than marijuana. But although the Government is spending $195 million this year on its national media campaign to dissuade adolescents from using illicit drugs, not a penny of the appropriated tax dollars is going to warn about the dangers of drinking.

title: THIS WEEK
description: EVENTS

title: Travel Tips: Overtime, TV and Air-Conditioning
description: You can watch some sporting events on television while doing other things -- reading newspapers, making phone calls, preparing meals or cleaning up the house. But other telecasts force you to push everything aside and pull up a chair to shout and stare at the screen for three or four hours.

title: Let's Not Forget Milosevic's Partner in Crime
description: What about Tudjman?

title: Can Money Alone Save the Schools?
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; Shot Misses, and Knicks' Plot Thickens
description: IF Knick fans remember their history, then they could have been excused if they had covered their eyes when Reggie Miller took a pass from Mark Jackson and got set to seal their doom again. ''Reggie has killed us so many times with the big 3's,'' Patrick Ewing said after the game, recalling this moment.

title: Degrees That Glitter, And How They Grow
description: Honorary doctorates, in categories from letters to law to fine arts, have little function other than being an honor. But the many colleges and universities that line up actors, authors, politicians, executives -- and even scholars -- find them useful as a way of recognizing achievements of people respected within the institution, and of adding glitter to their commencement ceremonies.

title: In Brooklyn, a Stunning Design That's All Wrong
description: To the Editor:

title: Who Knew What, When At Morgan?
description: The general counsel of Morgan Stanley Dean Witter learned of an in-house lawyer's decision to pay $10,000 to an informant involved in the arrest of a former employee shortly before the payment was made, according to a person close to the firm.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an article on May 23 about an annual survey of crime on college campuses misstated the reported decline for robberies and burglaries. Robberies fell by 9 percent and burglaries by 8 percent in 1997 from the year before. In 1996, robberies fell by 6 percent and burglaries by 5 percent compared to 1995.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAYE, LEONARD F.
description: KAYE-Leonard F. On May 29, 1999. He will be missed by many, but especially by his wife Joan, his son Sam, his daughter Liza, and granddaughter Pammy.

title: A Battle in Kosovo: Justice vs. Peace; Guilty of Weakness
description: To the Editor:

title: The Big City; The Tourists Are Replaced By Refugees
description: AFTER two months of NATO bombing, the National Tourism Organization of Serbia remains unbowed. It still maintains a Web site offering cheery exhortations like, ''Come! In Serbia something's always at the height of the season.'' The English is not always perfect -- ''Roam through Serbia! You won't loose your way'' -- but the enthusiasm is unmistakable.

title: Teaching Hospitals in Trouble
description: The nation's teaching hospitals are facing deep financial trouble, brought on by the growth of managed care and cost-cutting measures in government health programs. Congress can help by restoring some cuts made to Medicare funding in 1997 that squeezed these institutions severely. But their long-term financial health will depend on new ways of financing their special missions, along with requirements that they live by reasonable cost controls.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TANGNEY, NICHOLAS J.
description: TANGNEY-Nicholas J. Of Ardsley on Hudson, May 28, 1999. Beloved husband of Constance (McHugh) Tangney. Loving father & fatherin-law of Robert and Wendy, William & Meg, Peter, Ann, Thomas and Evelyn. Devoted brother of Gerald, Cora, Sr. Therese, and Margaret. Fond grandfather of six. Mass of the Resurrection 10AM Wednesday, June 2, 1999 at the Church of the Immaculate Conception, Irvington, New York. Visiting Edwards-Dowdle Funeral Home, 64 Ashford Ave. (Sawmill Parkway Exit 17), Dobbs Ferry, from 2-4 P.M. and 7-9 P.M. on Tuesday. Memorials to Rosary Hill Home, Hawthorne, New York, would be appreciated.

title: In Los Angeles, Endorsement From Dead Mayor Is Attacked
description: The battle over the legacy of former Mayor Tom Bradley, who died last year, is looming large in a tight Los Angeles City Council race, centering on a disputed campaign letter asserting that just before his death, Mr. Bradley endorsed the incumbent councilman.

title: Kurd's Trial Draws Attention to Turkish Court
description: In a legal and political confrontation likely to attract worldwide attention, the Kurdish rebel leader Abdullah Ocalan is to be tried for treason in a Turkish court beginning on Monday.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I feel completely and utterly entitled to whatever success comes our way. Not everybody's good, not everybody has the winning idea, not every idea deserves to be funded or to be public. I'm sorry, but there are sheep and there are shepherds, and I fancy myself to be the latter.''

title: It's Getting Ugly: Mets Stoop Before Johnson
description: Facing Randy Johnson is punishment enough. But having to face the 6-foot-10-inch left-hander when your team is struggling is cruel.

title: Salisbury Takes Championship
description: Salisbury State defeated Middlebury, 13-6, in 90-degree heat to win the Division III men's national championship yesterday at Byrd Stadium in College Park, Md.

title: Score Another One for the Behavior Police
description: Sometimes even Supreme Court Justices resort to spin control.

title: A Push to Redefine Eurocorps Role
description: TOULOUSE, France  Responding to what they said is Europe's incapacity to take independent military action on matters like Kosovo, France and Germany have announced their plan to remodel their Eurocorps unit into a rapid-reaction force within a new European Union defense role.

title: Looking Through a Keen Eye, Sometimes With a Wink, Too
description: To rock or not to rock? That was the question raised by Fountains of Wayne on Tuesday night at the Bowery Ballroom. This New York group answered positively in songs that merrily ransacked the memory of a generation raised on scruffy guys playing guitars. But it did so with a wink, since shrewd bands like this one know that rock heroics are as gloriously dumb as they are seductive.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SILBERMAN, CORINNE
description: SILBERMAN-Corinne. It's been 10 years since we lost a kind, sincere friend. You are deeply loved and missed. Fran and Marty

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Media Web Units Positioned To Ride the Internet Wave

title: 2 Senators Seek Limits on F.C.C.
description: Firing their latest shot at the Federal Communications Commission, Senate leaders have introduced legislation that would eliminate the agency's authority to review most mergers in the industries it regulates.

title: Concluding an 'Opulent Music' Series
description: It fell to the Lark Quartet, on Wednesday evening, to close the Miller Theater's Opulent Music series and, more, the entire first season under the adventuresome new direction of George Steel of the theater at Columbia University.

title: Reporter's Notebook; An Insinuation Revisited During the Louima Trial
description: When the trial in the Abner Louima case opened a month ago, the lawyer for Police Officer Justin A. Volpe suggested that Mr. Louima had suffered severe internal injuries not because of torture by his client but in a consensual sex act with another man.

title: Can Money Alone Save the Schools?
description: To the Editor:

title: Stocks Drive a Rush to Riches In Manhattan's Silicon Alley
description: There was something about the wave of unrepentant jubilance sweeping through iVillage's downtown Manhattan offices the day the three-and-a-half-year-old Internet company went public that made Susan Weaver uneasy.

title: Euro Proves Its Worth as Catalyst for Bond Market
description: LONDON  To judge by the euro's dwindling value on the foreign-exchange market, where it has been sliding closer to parity with the dollar, Europe's single currency is a flop.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KLEIN, BARRY
description: KLEIN-Barry. On your birthday & every day, you are missed & loved more than words can ever say. Love & kisses, Sherry

title: D. Robert Yarnall Jr., 74, Former Manufacturer
description: D. Robert Yarnall Jr., who helped build a local Pennsylvania manufacturing company into a multinational corporation, died on Thursday at the Unitarian Universalist House nursing home in the Germantown section of Philadelphia. He was 74 and had lived most of his life in the city.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KOPLIK, KENNETH E.
description: KOPLIK-Kenneth E. May 31, 1996. Three years without you, yet the legacy of your love continues to be an ever-present inspiration. You were the laughter in our hearts and the substance in our souls. How blessed we were to have shared your life. Diane, David and Family

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SMITH, PETER K.
description: SMITH-Peter K. Not a day goes by that you're not in our thoughts. We love you and miss you. Love, Patty, Maureen and Mik

title: Critics Say ABC Opened Its Checkbook for a News Source
description: ABC News paid a friend of one of the teen-age gunmen in the Columbine High School shootings $16,000 for the exclusive broadcast rights to home videos and other materials containing details about the killers. Then last Monday, the network presented what it called an exclusive interview with the 18-year-old, Nathan Dykeman, on its news program, ''Good Morning America.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEIN, HELEN (KAVEN)
description: STEIN-Helen (Kaven). Born in Canton, OH. Died peacefully on May 29, 1999, at age 81, after a long illness. Beloved wife of James Stein. Adoring mother of Elizabeth (Betsy) and mother-inlaw to Fredric Graber. Cherished grandmother of Anne and David Graber. Dear sister of Professor William Kaven. Memorial services at Temple Emanu-El, 5th Ave at 65th St, Tuesday, June 1st, 5 PM. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Hematology and Oncology Department at the New York-Presbyterian Hospital, Cornell Campus, York Avenue at 68th street, New York, N.Y. 10021.

title: Ends and Embryos
description: To the Editor:

title: When the F in Flamenco Means Fun
description: It isn't often that one leaves a dance performance feeling sore from laughing. But that was the case with Paco Alonso's ''Espanolisimass'' on Saturday night at Theater East, a hilarious yet loving tribute to flamenco singers, dancers and styles from the 1920's on.

title: The Lost Sub Is Found, And Israelis Can Grieve
description: For three decades, a missing submarine has haunted Israel. Accustomed to bloody battle and gruesome terrorism, the country was lastingly unsettled by the quiet tragedy of an unsolved mystery.

title: Godless Schools? Not Around Here
description: Gary Norris lives his faith every day. Not just at Salina's First Church of the Nazarene, where he is the congregation's lay worship leader and back-up choir director, but in his job.

title: Citations Given With Honor, And, at Times, A Little Levity
description: Colleges and universities herald their honorary degree recipients with a citation -- a brief resume, at times lighthearted, at times poignant, of an accomplished life. These excerpts are from citations provided by the institutions. Honoris causa . . .

title: KOSOVO UPDATE
description: COMBAT

title: In Brooklyn, a Stunning Design That's All Wrong
description: To the Editor:

title: New Company Getting Capital For Web Video
description: The Dell Computer Corporation and the Microsoft Corporation have invested in Digital Entertainment Network, a start-up company developing youth-oriented television programming for delivery over the Internet.

title: Editorial Observer; A War Hero Appeals to the Noncombatants
description: Here is a theory for a Presidential campaign: Take a prominent Republican senator and war hero, who once underwent enormous suffering for his country, and voters weary of moral relativism will leap at the chance to have a chief executive they can really look up to. Senator John McCain of Arizona is trying out the scenario this year, undeterred by the fact that it failed completely for Bob Dole.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VALLAS, DENNIS, CATHERINE
description: VALLAS-DENNIS-Catherine. On May 28, 1999. Devoted and loving mother, wife, sister, Yia-Yia and aunt. Daughter of the late Vovo and Nicholas Vallas and adored wife of the late Paul Dennis. Beloved mother of Dean and his wife Debra, and sister of Venus Dimou, Bess and her husband John Papandon and George and his wife Monica Vallas. Cherished Yia-Yia of Zoe and Sophie and caring aunt of Dean, John Jr., Bittie and John III, Stephen and Laura, Alexi and Jen, Liz, Greg and Eric and Nicholas. Distinguished and dedicated employee of Bloomingdale's for over 40 years. As a buyer, department manager and fashion coordinator she among others was responsible for the store's glory days. Following her success at Bloomingdale's she launched and managed the boutique at the Evelyn Lauder Breast Cancer Center at Memorial Sloan-Kettering. Enthusiastic and committed volunteer with The Metropolitan Opera, the Costume Institute of the Metropolitan Museum of Art and The Guggenheim Museum. Avid traveler, museum goer, dancer and participant in life's cultural joys. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 Street, Monday, May 31 from 2-5 and 7-9PM. Funeral service Tuesday, 11AM at The Cathedral of the Holy Trinity, 319 East 74 Street. In lieu of flowers, constributions may be made in her memory to The Evelyn Lauder Breast Cancer Center of Memorial Sloan-Kettering. She will be sorely missed.

title: Presidential Substance
description: To the Editor:

title: At-Bat by At-Bat, Jeter's Star Is Ascendant
description: As he waits his turn to bat from the on-deck circle, Derek Jeter glances curiously at the fans sitting in box seats nearby, like a playful seal checking for youngsters outside his pen at the zoo. If somebody engages him, Jeter will answer with a grin. Sometimes he sees a child and asks, ''Think I should swing at the first pitch?''

title: A Battle in Kosovo: Justice vs. Peace
description: To the Editor:

title: Robinson Takes Control of the Ship
description: In Game 1 of the Western Conference finals on Saturday, it looked as if David Robinson were still the principal player in the San Antonio Spurs' offense. Attempting jumpers, driving to the basket and receiving passes on the low block, the swift 7-foot-1-inch center took more shots than any of his teammates, including his esteemed partner in the post, Tim Duncan.

title: A Small Bookstore, Not Bound by Its Walls
description: What was Sebastian Junger, best-selling author of ''The Perfect Storm,'' doing in a high school gymnasium in Greenwich, Conn., filled with 500 children?

title: The American Way of Class, a Game of Self-Delusion
description: It was pointed out to me recently that the old existential profundity ''Hell is other people,'' which we used to intone with such dark fervor, really does better when seen as the basic principle of comedy or, let's say, comedy at its most aggressive. Rephrase Jean-Paul Sartre, and you get Dorothy Parker greeting new visitors with the words ''What fresh hell is this?'' and dubbing herself and her peers a ladies' auxiliary of the damned.

title: On Summer's Porch
description: The dry resonance at night -- the ticking of insects -- is not as authoritative as it will be in another month. The city has just begun to seep with heat, and has not yet melted at the crosswalks. Memorial Day is the porch before the house of summer, and spring is still latent here, still discernible in what blooms and has not bloomed, in the constellations that have not yet risen to midsummer's height. If summer is the flat light on a dead-calm sea, the haze that enshrouds the horizon after a week without rain, then this is a time when wind and water are still freshening, still disturbed by echoes from a more vehement season.

title: This Time, Ewing Buries Miller and the Pacers
description: For years, Patrick Ewing has seen the waif-like Reggie Miller jackknife around screens, pop free for devastating shots and then go dancing on the Knicks' misery, boldly spinning and twirling on the court.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCLAUGHLIN, ANNE P.
description: McLAUGHLIN-Anne P. On May 30, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Walter T. Loving mother of Edward, Patricia, and the late Gene. Devoted grandmother of Eileen, Cathy, Nancy, Michael and Eddie, Jr. Great-grandmother of Thomas and Julia. In repose at the Fairchild Sons Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Boulevard, Manhasset, Tuesday, 3-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass Wednesday, 10:45 AM, Saint Mary's R.C. Church, Manhasset. Interment Saint Charles Cemetery, Farmingdale, New York.

title: Critic of CUNY, Badillo, Chosen To Head Board
description: Gov. George E. Pataki has named Herman Badillo, a sharp critic of the City University of New York and a primary force behind efforts to change it, as its next chairman.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-7

title: Day for Church and Sales Shattered by a Day of War
description: Sunday afternoon began peacefully today in this small Serbian town. Two boys were down by the water's edge fishing. Sanja Milenkovic, 17, a top mathematics pupil at a Belgrade high school, was walking home across the bridge. The local Orthodox priest, The Rev. Milivoje Ciric, was celebrating Trinity Sunday inside his small white church perched above the river.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CASTLEMAN, LEONARD, M.D.
description: CASTLEMAN-Leonard, M.D. Dedicated physician for almost fifty years. At home on May 29th. His body was donated at his request to the Anatomical Gift Program at Downstate Medical Center. His survivors include his wife, Anita; his grandchildren, Ben and Rachel; his daughters, Janet and Nancy, along with her partner, Marc.

title: Brack's Victory Does Indeed Compute
description: The white flag waved, signaling there was only one lap remaining in the Indianapolis 500 today, and the only thing Kenny Brack could do was hope that his calculations were right. Race cars can run only 30 laps around the Brickyard on a tank of fuel, right?

title: A New Team That Relies On Veterans
description: Market Square Arena is a musty antique left over from Indiana's American Basketball Association days. Built in 1974, its bowl shape, peeling paint and blue-and-gold bunting take you back to a time before laser-lighted technology and luxury suites, to the original Pacer Roger Brown, to Kareem, Pistol Pete and McAdoo.

title: Stepping Carefully in a Newspaper War
description: In the frenzied first hours of the Columbine High School shootings last month, an editor of The Denver Rocky Mountain News slipped away from the fray and telephoned newspapers in towns that had endured similar events: Paducah, Ky.; Jonesboro, Ark., and Springfield, Ore.

title: India Still Weighing Pakistan's Offer of Kashmir Talks
description: Two days after Pakistan offered to hold peace talks with India about the current crisis along the cease-fire line in Kashmir, the Indians said today that they were still unsure whether they wanted to take part in any such negotiations.

title: The First Lady of Serbia Often Has the Last Word
description: The Yugoslav President, Slobodan Milosevic, and four of his top associates have now been indicted for war crimes in Kosovo. But by all accounts here, the person with the most influence over him is his dreamy and complicated wife, Mirjana Markovic, whose lifelong sense of persecution will intensify with this new threat to her husband and family.

title: Journalists Coming Home From the War
description: The misery of the Kosovar refugees has tugged on heart strings across America. But it tugs a little less frequently now, with the crisis two months old and American television networks showing fewer pictures of the camps.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAMPBELL, PATRICIA A.
description: CAMPBELL-Patricia A. Beloved wife of Arlan J. Bird. Loving sister of Mary Campbell and James (Patricia). Dear aunt of James, Michael, Joseph, John and Brian. Burial was at All Saints Cemetery, Des Plaines, IL on May 27th. A memorial service will be held at Frank E. Campbell, 81 Street and Madison Avenue, New York City, Tuesday, June 1, 1999, 5 PM.

title: Treating Drug Abuse
description: To the Editor:

title: Hip Joins Hip With Little Ado
description: Think different. Dress casual. Whatever.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWADRON, LAWRENCE (LARRY)
description: SCHWADRON-Lawrence (Larry). Son of Benjamin & Bertha (deceased). Much cherished partner of Jean. Beloved brother of Jack (deceased) & Thelma, Meyer (deceased) & Shirley Steinkohl and Ann & Lee Yarden. Much beloved uncle of Howard & Debbie, Lori & Glenn, Richard & Debbie, Linda & Chris, Joan & Rob, Randi and Paul. And beloved great uncle. Funeral on Sunday 11 A.M., at Riverside Memorial Chapel, New York.

title: To Protect and Serve On Another Front; In an Increasing Job Migration, Police Officers Make the Switch From Crime Fighter to Firefighter
description: It takes courage to stare down a suspect with a gun. Does it take a different but equally impressive burst of bravery to storm into a tenement awash in flames?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SINGH, KRISHNA G.
description: SINGH-Krishna G. On May 29, 1999. Beloved husband of Encarnacion. Loving father of Anil Singh and Fabiola Guerlan. Services Tuesday, 10:30 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St and Amsterdam Ave. Visiting hours Monday, 3-8 PM.

title: A Republican With a Weighty Toe on the House Seesaw
description: EVERY session of the House of Representatives has its own personality, its own emblematic types, from the comfortable Democratic incumbents of the late 1980's to the Republican revolutionaries of 1994.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENE, JEROME
description: GREENE-Jerome. The Juilliard School deeply mourns the death of Jerome L. Greene. A Trustee of the School since 1985, he brought extraordinary leadership to the institution through his exceptional intellect, unique vision, and caring sensitivity to the needs of all members of the Juilliard Community. With a quick wit and a devotion to the performing and visual arts, he enriched us all through his presence and commitment to the School. The Jerome L. Greene Fellowships stand as the first scholarship fund in the history of Juilliard to be created for all three of the performing arts taught at the School. His wise counsel and generosity also made Juilliard's residence hall a reality. We send our heartfelt condolences to his beloved wife, Dawn, and all of his family. He will be profoundly missed by us all. Mary Rodgers Guettel, Chairman Joseph W. Polisi, President

title: Finally in Hardcover, the Hughes Hoax
description: It has taken 27 years, but one man's fabled literary hoax is finally a hardcover book -- bound, printed, packaged and sold exclusively over the Internet as an ''imaginative biography'' of Howard R. Hughes.

title: Recognizing Achievement, Adding Glitz
description: Thomas Jefferson had strong opinions about what a university ought and ought not to do. One was that it should not grant honorary degrees. Founder of the University of Virginia, Jefferson feared that its board might get carried away by political or religious enthusiasms rather than choose a recipient based on scholarly considerations. To this day, the University of Virginia gives no honorary degrees.

title: That 50's Cocktail of Hellman, Hammett and the Red Scare
description: There is a delicious escapist quality to mythic romances in which the characters' rough edges are smoothed away and every quarrel reflects the lovers' incendiary charm. The decadeslong affair of Lillian Hellman and Dashiell Hammett certainly lends itself to that treatment, and if ''Dash and Lilly'' had merely given their legend a romantic gloss, the film might have been enjoyable pap. But this trite movie does worse things than clean up Hellman and Hammett's messy affair. It wastes a perfectly cast Sam Shepard and a fiercely energetic Judy Davis on an unspeakable script, directed by the actress Kathy Bates with an unfailing adherence to cliches.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  EDELMAN, HILDA W.
description: EDELMAN-Hilda W. 5 stones in memory. Mort, Diana, Robert, Nancy and Alex

title: Essay; 'We Never Sleep'
description: When Allan Pinkerton, Lincoln's bumbling Secret Service chief, set up a private detective agency after the Civil War, he adopted as his logo an open eye and the slogan ''We Never Sleep.'' That spawned the phrase ''private eye.''

title: Women Accused of Baby-Selling Used a Friendly Approach
description: They could have been selling Amway, or Avon. Wearing light makeup and casual clothes, Arlene Lieberman and Arlene Reingold sought clients at the mall, served coffee and doughnuts at meet-and-greet sessions, and invited prospects to their split-level homes, which are three doors apart on a shady street here on Long Island.

title: Advertisers Spend Eagerly For TV Time in Fall Season
description: The advance sale of commercial time by the broadcast television networks for the fall season, known as the up-front market, is ending on an even stronger note this year than the optimistic forecasts in recent weeks had anticipated.

title: Spreading the Small-Town News; A New Sort of Company Invests in Community Papers
description: Before sound bites, before the press was called the media, before the talk of broadband communications, narrowcasting or dot-com Web portals, there was The Cullman Times.

title: They Were Human Shields When 80 Died, Kosovars Say
description: They had no choice but to spend the night outside a warehouse off the highway in Korisa, Haxhere Palushi said today. There were 700 Albanian refugees like herself, and Serbian soldiers herded them all inside the building's iron outer gates, promising that they would be allowed to leave Kosovo the next day.

title: Shift by Older Voters to G.O.P. Is Democrats' Challenge in 2000
description: Older Americans were once among the most loyal of Democratic voters in Congressional elections, reliably returning the party of Roosevelt and Truman to power on Capitol Hill.

title: Slovaks Choose Pro-Europe Democrat as President
description: Rudolf Schuster, the candidate of the governing four-party coalition and the popular Mayor of the eastern town of Kosice, defeated former Prime Minister Vladimir Meciar to become the first elected President of Slovakia, according to results announced today.

title: In an Antitrust Suit, a Tiny Ex-Partner Is Taking Aim at Microsoft
description: As the trial in the Government's antitrust case against the Microsoft Corporation resumes on Tuesday in Washington, evidence in a separate trial set to open this week in Connecticut seems to offer tantalizing support for an assertion that the company's rivals have made for years -- that Microsoft wields its industry-standard Windows operating system as a club to control the software business.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOCHTENBERG, HARRY
description: DOCHTENBERG-Harry. Devoted father of Phyllis and Andrew Fier, and Donna and Leonard Berg. Dear brother of Max. Loving grandfather of Amy Gitlin of Israel, Lisa Fier, Adam and Jacqueline Berg. Adoring great-grandfather of David, Elkanah and Chava Gitlin. Funeral Tuesday, 11:30 AM, Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91st Street and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Rupert P. Lonsdale, 93, British Navy War Hero, Dies
description: Comdr. Rupert P. Lonsdale, who became the only British captain to surrender a warship on the high seas during World War II when he gave up his crippled submarine to save the lives of its 59 crewmen, died on April 25 in Bournemouth, England. He was 93.

title: Alomar Adds Skills, Thrills And Victories
description: Forget the first Seven Wonders of the World. The Cleveland Indians have the Eighth, and they are taking him to New York this week.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GEFFNER, JEANNINE VERGNES
description: GEFFNER-Jeannine Vergnes. Thank you for all the wonderful years and memories. Happy Birthday. Love and kisses, David

title: Can Money Alone Save the Schools?
description: To the Editor:

title: Just Deserts: A Big Budget, A Big Benefit
description: Buck Showalter wouldn't say it. ''We're going to find out how good we are,'' said the manager whose team had just completed a three-game sweep of the Mets.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SCHWARTZ, HARRY
description: SCHWARTZ-Harry. You've left us a joyous legacy. Always missed. Love, Nancy

title: A Nearly Endless Competition Is Approaching Its Resolution
description: Virtually all bridge events, and indeed virtually all sporting contests, have a predictable schedule within narrow limits. An exception is the Greater New York Bridge Association's Von Zedtwitz Double Knockout Teams, which should be completed in 9 months, with a match being played each month, but frequently takes 14.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEGAL, BERNARD
description: SEGAL-Bernard. Beloved husband of Sylvia. Devoted father of David Segal, Donald and Mindy Segal. Adored grandfather of Jayme Segal. Dear brother of Henrietta Segal and David Segal. Graveside services 11:30 AM today at Wellwood Cemetery, Pinelawn, New York.

title: Joao Carlos de Oliveira, at 45; Held Triple Jump World Record
description: Joao Carlos de Oliveira, a Brazilian sports hero who held the world triple jump record for a decade, died Saturday at Beneficencia Portuguesa Hospital in Sao Paulo, Brazil. He was 45.

title: Under Cloud of 4th Graders' Scores, 8th Graders Brace for New Tests
description: With students, educators, parents and elected officials still smarting from the abysmal results on New York State's new fourth-grade English test, scores of children across the state will begin a new round of similar testing this week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, RICHARD M.
description: COHEN-Richard M. My family and I extend our sincere condolences to his wife Barbara, his mother Frances, and Arthur and Marilyn and family. Richie was my childhood friend, college friend and longtime partner. We had good times together and I have fond memories. Michael Lipstein

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RECANATI, RAPHAEL
description: RECANATI-Raphael. It is with a profound sense of loss that the Board of Trustees, Medical Board and Administration of Beth Israel Medical Center join with the leadership of its parent company, Continuum Health Partners, Inc., in acknowledging the passing of our dear friend and devoted colleague, Raphael Recanati, Honorary Trustee of Beth Israel. Few have matched the extraordinary philanthropy of Mr. Recanati and his devoted wife, Dina, to Beth Israel. A consistent thread running through their history of support has been generous donations toward critically important needs of medical education and research, particularly in the areas of neurology, cardiology, nephrology, hepatology, pulmonary medicine, dermatology, orthopaedic surgery, pediatrics, pathology and infectious diseases. Mr. Recanati's creative philanthropic approach served as a crucial resource to our staff, allowing them to make important advances in patient care and expanded medical knowledge. He will forever be remembered for helping to create a clinical and educational environment that makes Beth Israel a vibrant place to study and practice medicine. Our heartfelt condolences are extended to Dina, his sons Oudi and Michael, the entire Recanati family and all whose lives have been touched by his extraordinary humanitarian spirit. Morton P. Hyman, Chairman, Boards of Trustees, Continuum and BIMC Robert G. Newman, MD, President and CEO, Continuum Matthew E. Fink, MD, President and CEO, BIMC Henry Singman, MD, President, BIMC Medical Board

title: Elderly Queens Couple Found Dead in Home
description: An elderly couple in Queens were found dead by their grandson last night in what the police said appeared to be a murder-suicide.

title: Jerkens the Giant-Killer Is Focusing on the Belmont
description: He is a tall, husky, 70-year-old man who frequently wears a broad-brimmed white hat and a serious look, and he always rates a respectful salute when he drives through the stable gate at Belmont Park before dawn. But for a horse trainer who saddled his first winner nearly 50 years ago and who is known in New York as ''the Chief'' because of his intensity and success, Allen Jerkens has a remarkably thin record in Triple Crown racing.

title: Has the First Lady Decided to Run? The President Smiles, but Isn't Saying
description: President Clinton was coy tonight when asked whether his wife, Hillary Rodham Clinton, had made up her mind to run for the Senate seat from New York, refusing to answer directly but shrugging and smiling.

title: Surfing to Soothe a Savage Breast
description: The Comcast Corporation, a cable giant with diverse holdings that include stakes in the television and on-line versions of the QVC shopping channel and E Entertainment Television, has added a more highbrow investment to its portfolio: Culturefinder.com.

title: Williams Is Stunned, Agassi Stunning
description: A pair of dispa rate underdogs one an obscure Austrian with a penchant for literature and power tennis, the other the most charismatic showman to enliven the men's game -- divested the French Open today of Venus Williams, a favorite to claim the women's title, and Carlos Moya of Spain, the defending champion.

title: Expansion of Settlements Angers Palestinians
description: Alarmed by 11th-hour moves by the departing Israeli Government to expand Jewish settlements, Palestinian officials warned Prime Minister-elect Ehud Barak today that they would not resume peace negotiations without a halt to settlement activity.

title: Can Money Alone Save the Schools?
description: To the Editor:

title: What's No Longer on Museum Walls
description: When ''Museum as Muse: Artists Reflect'' closes at the Museum of Modern Art tomorrow, nearly all the 188 works in the show will be crated and shipped to the exhibition's next stops, in San Diego and then Madrid. But one will stay behind, in the homes of various visitors to the exhibition and also in the museum's bookstore: a slim 15-page publication with a bright red cover titled ''Painting and Sculpture From the Museum of Modern Art: Catalogue of Deaccessions, 1929 Through 1998.'' It is the work of Michael Asher, a 55-year-old Conceptual artist from California.
